https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/world.print_headline: Coup in Thailand Follows Old Pattern
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/world.body_text: **********The apparently bloodless seizure of power by the armed forces in Thailand yesterday is the culmination of a long period of animosity between the military, whose traditional strength had been eroding in a period of democracy, and the first elected Prime Minister since 1976, Chatichai Choonhavan, who took office in August 1988. **********The coup represents a return to an old pattern in Thailand, which has now experienced 17 coup attempts since the end of the absolute monarchy in 1932. **********It is a pattern that Thai modernizers thought was no longer likely, if only, they joked, because senior military officers had too much money invested in the booming Thai stock market and economy, and did not want to jeopardize their investments. **********A coup, it was argued, would shake the confidence of overseas investors, businesses and tourists, more than five million of whom visited Thailand last year. **********But the Persian Gulf crisis and the recession in the West hit Thailand and its markets fairly hard, and Mr. Chatichai's decision to appoint a rival of current military leaders as Deputy Defense Minister was apparently the last straw for the military, which likes its politicians tame. King Could Intervene **********The revered King of Thailand, King Bhumipol Adulyadej, is also thought to be opposed to coups, and has been instrumental in the past in persuading the military to abandon its efforts. It is possible King Bhumipol, one of the world's longest-serving monarchs, will try to intervene again, despite the dissolution of both houses of Parliament and the military's revocation of the Constitution. **********Mr. Chatichai is reported to have been arrested at the airport as he was about to fly to Thailand's northeast to meet with the King, reportedly to get his constitutional assent to the promotion of a former army Chief of Staff, Arthit Kamlang-ek, to Deputy Defense Minister. Mr. Chatichai himself served as Defense Minister. **********Mr. Arthit is disliked by Supreme Commander Gen. Sunthorn Kongsompong, who announced the coup, and the more powerful army Chief of Staff, Gen. Suchinda Kraprayoon. General Sunthorn has been perceived as more prickly in defending the military against perceived slights, while General Suchinda has publicly played a more calming role, while warning that the army has "limits to its patience." Criticism Has Grown **********In the last year or so, there has been increasing military criticism of Mr. Chatichai and his "no problem" attitude to charges of corruption, lack of direction and incompetence in his administration. He has ignored such criticism from his political opposition, but it has been heard, with increasing sharpness of tone, from the country's powerful military commanders. **********The role of Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, the former army Chief of Staff and supreme commander, is currently unclear. General Chavalit was widely expected to be Thailand's next Prime Minister, and Mr. Chatichai tried to establish General Chavalit as his successor in the Chart Thai Party. General Chavalit joined the Chatichai Cabinet as Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister in the spring of 1990, but resigned only 10 weeks later. **********He had attacked alleged corruption in the Government and among Thai politicians, but another Cabinet minister described General Chavalit's wife as "a moving jewelry box," implying that he, too, was corrupt. The army has been threatening coups ever since, managing to get the offending minister dismissed and political shufflings engineered more to their liking. **********It seemed the military was angling for new elections, and General Chavalit decided to form a new party so he could get elected to Parliament. **********Mr. Chatichai, himself a former general, was the first Prime Minister to have been an elected member of Parliament since 1976, the date of the last successful coup, and a parliamentary seat seemed a prerequisite to becoming Prime Minister in a modern Thailand. All Eyes on Elections **********It may be that the coup is an effort to arrange these elections, but under a new Constitution that could provide more checks and balances on the power of elected politicians, a favorite issue among military commanders. **********Mr. Arthit's appointment as Deputy Defense Secretary was believed to have been made without the approval of Generals Sunthorn and Suchinda. It also seems to have signaled the 71-year-old Mr. Chatichai's efforts to arrange for Mr. Arthit to succeed him, since General Chavalit has chosen his own path. **********The military has also been upset by the sudden re-emergence of rumors about a 1982 assassination plot allegedly aimed at the King, the then-Prime Minister, Prem Tinsulanonda, and Mr. Arthit, army Chief of Staff at the time. **********In April 1981, Mr. Arthit put down a coup attempt, then survived numerous attempts on his life. Plans to kill the leaders were apparently laid for October 1982, but twice came to nothing, and the plot was covered up. **********In the last few weeks, leaflets have been distributed in Thailand trying to implicate Mr. Chatichai's son, Kraisak Choonhavan, a former left-wing academic, who has been a confidant to his father, and another key Chatichai aide. The leaflets started after Mr. Chatichai removed two senior police officers who had worked on the assassination plot investigation. **********These efforts at destabilization simply display how isolated Mr. Chatichai has become. When he refused to defer to the military, they did what they continually promised not to do -- interfere with the political life of the nation -- in an effort, they no doubt will suggest, to purify and improve it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Hasbro Extends Tonka Bid Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/busin.body_text: **********Hasbro Inc., which is trying to complete its planned $470 million acquisition of the Tonka Corporation, has again extended its deadline for Tonka's bondholders to tender their securities, from 7 P.M. today until 7 P.M. on Monday. The toy manufacturers said in a joint announcement that they were negotiating with each other and with Tonka's bondholders to restructure the buyout to make it more attractive to the investors, who have balked at Hasbro's offer. **********Hasbro has proposed reducing the price per share to be paid to holders of Tonka's common stock and increasing the amount to be paid to bondholders, the companies said. Hasbro has offered Tonka stockholders $7 a share. It has offered $800 per $1,000 in face value and $750 per $1,000 in face value on two types of Tonka bonds. Stockholders have approved the deal, but bondholders have refused to accept it. Hasbro is the nation's largest toy manufacturer. Tonka is the third largest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/21/busin.body_text: **********In one of the few recent bits of upbeat figures on the economy, builders broke ground for new homes last month at the fastest pace in nearly a year and 7.3 percent above that of September, the Government reported today. **********Permits for future construction, moreover, posted their second straight solid advance, suggesting that starts will continue what until now has been a slow but persistent rise and reinvigorate a feeble recovery. **********"The October housing starts statistics indicate that the industry is starting to pick up as a result of the lower interest rate environment," declared Marilyn Schaja, an economic for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. She noted that last month's increase included both houses and multifamily dwellings and all regions of the country. Data Often Erratic **********While analysts shied away from downright optimism since these figures are notoriously erratic and were rebounding from severely depressed levels, most said they were heartened. **********"They're better than we expected," said Michael Carliner, an economist for the National Association of Home Builders, noting particularly the broad nature of the gains. "It's a positive sign." Yet he added that sales of new homes continued to be depressed and that builders' surveys did not yet show any real pickup in customer traffic despite the lowest mortgage rates in about 15 years. **********Conventional mortgages averaged just under 8 7/8 percent in mid-October and have fallen since to just under 8 3/4 percent. Most in 11 Months **********"The housing market is clearly off the bottom and is moving up" because of lower rates, said Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist at ASB Capital Management in Washington. Modest gains in starts have now been recorded in six of the last seven months, the report showed. **********Housing starts in October ran at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1,096,000, the most since 1,130,000 for November 1990 and 6.8 percent higher than in the month a year earlier. **********Without adjustment for seasonal variation -- starts in midsummer typically double those of midwinter -- the October pace was 1,031,000 compared with 865,000 in September and 942,000 in October 1990. **********Even with last month's jump, however, starts are running at barely half the 1986 yearly peak of just over two million dwellings. This indicates that further increases will need to be substantial if they are to provide a significant thrust for economic recovery. Analysts watch housing closely since starts imply demand not only for construction materials and labor but also appliances, carpeting and other goods. **********Single-family homes rose 3.9 percent last month to a rate of 898,000, the fastest since April 1990. Apartments and other multifamily dwellings rose to a 198,000 rate, a 26.1 percent jump from the September pace. **********The South had the biggest overall increase, 9.7 percent, followed by 9.3 percent for the Northeast, 7.4 percent for the Midwest and 2.4 percent for the West. **********Although the Northeast's percentage gain was comparable to that of the other regions, the level of starts was far below any of the others, both with and without seasonal adjustment. **********John P. LaWare, a governor of the Federal Reserve, said he was heartened by today's figures, which were also greeted warmly by Marlin Fitzwater, the chief White House spokesman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.body_text: **********The Unisys Corporation, the nation's third-largest computer maker, said it was asking employees to volunteer to take severance packages and leave the company to reduce its worldwide work force by at least 2,000. Unisys, whose debt totals $3.43 billion, has posted meeting notices or met with employees, asking them to take the severance packages. Employees have until Friday to take advantage of the program. **********Shares of Unisys fell 37.5 cents on the Big Board today, to $4.625.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/30/world.main_headline: Despite Euphoria on Arms Control, Deterrence Remains a Potent Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/30/world.print_headline: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW; Despite Euphoria on Arms Control, Deterrence Remains a Potent Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/30/world.body_text: **********Despite the United States-Soviet agreement that will cut the long-range nuclear weapons of both countries for the first time, Washington and Moscow will still have vast arsenals of roughly the same size as when the talks began in 1982. **********Moreover, the pact to be signed Wednesday allows and encourages the superpowers to continue improving the power and accuracy of their nuclear weapons. **********The hope that a new era in arms control will begin with the signing of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty at the Moscow summit this week may be misguided, officials and arms control experts acknowledged. They said that the principle of deterrence by threat of massive retaliation remained the bedrock of nuclear policy. For 40 years, the United States and Soviet Union have held each other's nuclear arms hostage with the threat that a first strike would unleash a devastating nuclear counterpunch.  Deterrence's Defense **********To those who maintain that this policy should be changed to reflect thawing cold war tensions, its adherents say deterrence has worked for the last four decades and ask why it should be abandoned so quickly now. **********President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev pledged at last year's summit meeting in Washington to push for deeper reductions after the strategic arms treaty, but negotiators, weary from their nine-year labor, seem to have neither the energy nor the inclination to pursue more radical cuts anytime soon. **********"We have to see how this works out," said Jay P. Kosminsky, deputy director of defense policy studies at the Heritage Foundation. **********In all likelihood, say Administration officials and arms control specialists, there will be a pause in the arms talks to gauge not only the treaty's results but also the future course of the Soviet Union. **********"Certainly in their present situation the Soviets are not going to be thinking of attacking the United States, but we have to think about 5, 10, even 15 years from now," Harold Brown, a former Defense Secretary, said in a telephone interview. **********Amid this wariness, however, there are some signs of accord between the two armed forces. Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said on the ABC News program "Nightline" last week that joint military exercises between American and Soviet forces are possible in the future. **********"The relationship is growing so that we may well see that happening at some point in the future," said General Powell, who was in the Soviet Union for a weeklong tour of military installations. **********Seven years after it takes effect, the strategic-arms treaty will bring the number of Soviet long-range nuclear weapons down from nearly 11,000 to between 7,000 and 8,000, and the United States warheads from 12,000 to 10,500. **********The number of Soviet ballistic missile warheads -- which the United States considers most dangerous -- would be reduced by about 50 percent. The United States would reduce its ballistic missile warheads by about 35 percent. **********While the total number of strategic weapons will be about the same as it was nine years ago, Edward L. Warner of the Rand Corporation said the number of ballistic missile warheads would decline by about 30 percent from 1982 levels. **********The treaty covers only strategic weapons, those with ranges of more than 3,000 miles. The Natural Resources Defense Council, a private, nonprofit group supporting limits on weapons, said that shorter-range nuclear missile warheads in Europe, as well as other warheads not covered by the treaty like those dropped by planes or fired from ships and submarines, the United States has a total of about 27,300 nuclear warheads and the Soviet Union about 30,000. Most Soviet Missiles Withdrawn **********The Soviet Union has withdrawn most of its tactical nuclear missiles from the former Warsaw Pact countries in Eastern Europe. The United States has said any decision to remove its 3,000 to 3,500 short-range nuclear warheads in Europe would be made in consultation with its allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********The aim of arms control is to prevent nuclear war. The current deterrence philosophy evolved after the deployment of American nuclear weapons in postwar Europe to deter the threat of attack from the much larger Soviet conventional forces. **********The signing of the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, which codifies reductions in troops and equipment and reverses the advantage in NATO's favor, has largely eliminated that threat. **********At issue now is how many nuclear weapons Washington needs to deter a Soviet attack against the United States. **********A weapon's ability to withstand a first strike increases its retaliatory value and, by definition, enhances its deterrent capability. The goal of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty has been to slim and shuffle the superpower nuclear menu into a more predictable and therefore more stable mix. This encourages the development of quieter submarines, gravity bombs dropped from planes and mobile ballistic missiles, and discourages land-based missiles with multiple warheads.  Missile Rules Differ **********"The irony is if an enemy's forces are survivable, that's good," said the Rand Corporation's Mr. Warner. **********The treaty, for example, cuts the number of SS-18's, the Soviets' most accurate weapon against hardened targets like American missile silos. Under the pact, the Soviets would cut SS-18's to 154 from 308. Each missile carries 10 warheads. **********At the same time, the treaty is more permissive in its counting rules for warheads carried by heavy bombers or cruise missiles, because these weapons are less capable of launching a first strike and less vulnerable to attack. **********"Start is designed to encourage the restructuring of nuclear forces in ways that will make them more stable and less threatening," a senior Administration official involved in the talks told reporters last week. "Cuts for the sake of cuts isn't just missing the point, it's bad arms control." **********But many arms control specialists and former Administration officials contend that both sides could come down to as low as 3,000 weapons without eroding the ability to deter a nuclear attack.  Biden Poses Question **********"Must we continue to accept a world in which the capability to detonate tens of thousands of Hiroshimas is deemed a necessary and normal fact of international life?" asked Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Europe, two weeks ago at an arms-control hearing. **********Dunbar Lockwood, a senior analyst at the Arms Control Association, a nonprofit advocate of arms reduction, said lowering the levels would also reduce the need for costly nuclear fuel production; improve the ability of the superpowers to prevent an accidental launch -- a growing concern given the domestic unrest in the Soviet Union -- and put more pressure on the superpowers to discourage nations with budding nuclear programs. **********Moreover, arms control advocates say, Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty negotiators have settled the difficult task: niggling but important details like rules about counting, weapon definitions and verification procedures. With an enduring framework in place, these officials said, making the actual cuts is easy. **********Driving the number of warheads is the number of targets in the Soviet Union that American planners assign as they consider contingencies. Administration officials said that the United States has slashed about 3,000 potential targets from a group of 10,000 in its most recent list. **********Many of those targets were fixed structures in Eastern Europe or military equipment that the Soviets have withdrawn under the conventional forces agreement. Several nuclear arms specialists said the Admistration could shrink its targeting list even further. **********"You don't have to hit every P.T.A. building in Siberia to deter the Soviet Union," said a Senate staff member who follows arms control.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/29/busin.main_headline: ARCO Posts Loss; Unocal Net Off Sharply
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/29/busin.print_headline: ARCO Posts Loss; Unocal Net Off Sharply
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/29/busin.body_text: **********ARCO Inc. said today that it took a $340 million charge against earnings to pare 2,100 workers from its payroll and other actions, and that as a result it reported a net loss of $156 million in the third quarter. **********The Unocal Corporation said its net income fell by 92.5 percent in the quarter. Unocal, like ARCO, has faced gasoline price wars in California through much of this year, as well as sharply lower natural gas prices in the United States. **********ARCO also said its oil and gas operation would auction 1,100 producing sites in several states that together contribute 2 percent of its total oil-and-gas output. **********The move mirrors actions by other large oil companies in the last 18 months to sell comparatively isolated properties in the continental United States that have become too costly to operate. **********The quarterly loss for ARCO, in the period ended Sept. 30, was its first since the second quarter of 1985, when the company posted a $1.1 billion loss related to job cutbacks, sales of most of its operations in the Eastern half of the country and other actions. **********Following are details of the companies' reports:  ARCO **********Without the special charge in the quarter, ARCO, which is based in Los Angeles, said it would have earned $184 million, or $1.14 a share. The company earned $462 million, or $2.79 a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. Its sales fell by 9.1 percent, to $4.37 billion, from $4.81 billion. **********The charges included approximately $190 million for previously announced job cutbacks and for streamlining operations in the continental United States. An additional $135 million was placed in reserve to cover anticipated losses on the oil-and-gas properties around the country and on a mining operation in Australia. **********The company said the number of job cuts was increased to 2,100, from 1,500, when the policy to pare operations was announced last month. ARCO also said it spent $85.9 million to buy back 734,500 common shares. **********Oil prices fell, to an average of $13.15 a barrel, in the quarter, from $16.89 a barrel in the same period a year ago. Most of ARCO's crude output is from its operations in Prudhoe Bay in Alaska. Natural gas prices fell to an average of $1.35 per 1,000 cubic feet, from $1.44 in the 1990 period. **********ARCO's shares rose by $2.125 each today, to $121.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.  Unocal **********Unocal's net income fell to $9 million, or 4 cents a share, from $121 million, or 52 cents a share. Its revenues declined by 12.7 percent, to $2.68 billion, from $3.07 billion. **********Lower sales of gasoline and other refined products, the California gas pricing wars and lower prices for crude and natural gas all contributed to the earnings decline. The sales of Unocal's petroleum products, including gasoline, fell by 8.7 percent, to 425,400 barrels a day. **********The shares of Unocal, also based in Los Angeles, rose 50 cents each, to $27, on the Big Board.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/world.main_headline: An Ocean Away, Pundits and Former Players Offer Views of Madrid Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/world.print_headline: THE MIDDLE EAST TALKS; An Ocean Away, Pundits and Former Players Offer Views of Madrid Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/world.body_text: **********William B. Quandt  Political Analyst Brookings Institution **********I think the Palestinian-Israeli talks will almost certainly begin and there will be some substance in those quickly. The Palestinians have the most to gain, and the best chance to score a public relations coup by looking reasonable and moderate during these talks. They might even surprise everyone with specific proposals early on. They want this process to succeed more than anyone else. **********The Syrian-Israeli talks, obviously, are a bigger question. I imagine there will be a meeting, but I don't know where -- or how optimistic the parties will be to continue. The real process of the Israeli-Syrian accommodation will not be seen in official negotiation committees. Those responsible will probably be their intelligence services meeting in Czechoslovakia or somewhere and seeing what they can agree on. I wouldn't be at all surprised to see the conference established elsewhere than in the formal negotiating forum. **********It's also possible to see Lebanon-Israel negotiations turn serious, but with a strong Syrian hand reflected in the discussion. I can almost imagine Israel and the Lebanese talking about Syrian issues and the Syrians plugging into that. **********The United States has to recognize its ongoing role as a mediator. The United States has to have substantial ideas to inject into the negotiating process. President Bush cannot go to the conference and then say, "O.K., now we've done our job, we can go home and leave you to it." We should present certain ideas on specific issues with the objective of trying to define what the big trade-off will be. We need to go to the parties and say, "If you could get so and so, would you consider such and such?" **********Judith Kipper  Political Analyst Brookings Institution **********The fact that the parties to the conflict are meeting in one room changes the agenda in the Middle East. It means de facto recognition of one another and acknowledging that they must find some form of coexistance. **********I think bilateral talks will take place because none of the parties can refuse to go. That party would be blamed for the talks' failure. None of them can afford this, with the end of the Cold War and each of them looking towards the United States for assistance. **********But there will be ups and downs, walkouts, consultations, assurances, clarifications, Arab summits, elections in Israel -- every Middle East postponement tactic they can use. The parties to the conflict enjoy the role of victim too much and are too fearful of taking the risks necessary without mediation from the United States and the Soviet Union. It will require powers of persuasion, new ideas, incentive, threats, the whole basket of instruments available -- not a specific plan, but for the United States to suggest ideas when the parties reach a deadlock. **********Everyone will take familiar positions and we will hear some vitriolic speeches and accusations of all kinds of things. But the bilateral talks will start for a couple of days, then stop, and everyone will go back for consultations with their governments and leaders. So clearly, the United States and the Soviet Union will have to have teams for handholding. These negotiations mirror what has happened in the world, the transformation from the cold war to a new world order. **********Joseph Sisco Assistant Secretary of State, 1969-74 **********I don't accept the gloom and doom scenarios that this will break up. There will be stops and starts, surprises and crises. It is significant that the Israelis and Arabs are in the room together. It is not a guarantee the conference is not going to fall apart. But something happens when people get into the room together. **********The Arabs and Israelis will begin bilateral relations. The most hopeful dimension is in Baker's framework within which Israel, Jordan and the Palestinian residents in the West Bank will focus on bilateral dialogue over some form of autonomy as reflected in Camp David. The general understanding is that they'll leave the tough issues of sovereignty, borders, Jerusalem and the like for the later stages. **********My concern is really the Syrian position. I think Syria is pivotal. Historically, they have been the spoiler. Syria made it very clear they want to play a role in three dimensions -- the question of the Golan Heights, the question of Lebanon, where Syria as well as Israel is present, and the position that they don't believe in separate agreements. That means they are seeking to exercise a veto over Israeli-Palestinian negotiations relative to the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. **********Each of the parties will play to its own home audience during the talks. At the outset each side will adopt totally impossible positions. But even so, that will not prevent bilateral dialogue. The reason is the pressures that brought them to the conference table are the same pressures that will keep them there. Neither side wants to affront the United States, which is at the zenith of its power in the area. And everyone knows that the route to Jerusalem is through Washington. **********Zbigniew Brzezinski   National Security Adviser, 1977-81 **********There will be enduring difficulties, occasional disruptions, some dramatic abortions, but in the end I think there will be a peace treaty. It will involve both the Syrians and Palestinians. It could conceivably happen within a year. **********What no one has fully seized is that there are three important changes here: First, this is the first time in the modern age that only one power is dominant in the Middle East, the United States.  The Arabs have nowhere to go. Israel has to take American views extremely seriously, especially since the President has demonstrated over the housing loan guanrantees that he will not be jerked around. Second, every peace conference in the past has included only Egypt, not any of the other Arab states. Third, this time we know exactly what the outcome will be, though we are not sure how to get there. **********There will probably be some arrangement on the Golan Heights that is similar to the arrangement in Sinai. And some sort of arrangement in the West Bank that is similar to Camp David. **********Above all, the United States has to keep the pressure on, and make it clear that there are definite penalties for any party that disrupts the process. **********Samuel Lewis   U.S. Ambassador to Israel, 1977-85 **********I think the end result, by the end of the decade, will be a large measure of peace. I think we'll have a settlement in five to six years, maybe a decade, that reaches some accommodation of the Israeli-Palestinian-Jordanian part of the problem. My guess is it won't be total independence but a confederation structure with different borders than 1967. **********I'm not sure about Syria. Maybe there will be recognition of Syrian sovereignty in the Golan Heights with some Israeli and international forces present. But it will be less clear-cut than an Israeli withdrawal. Hafez al-Assad deciding to enter negotiations was the key element that broke the logjam, but it doesn't mean he's ready to go to full peace. **********There will be a lot of turbulence between the opening conference and the bilateral talks. But there's too much invested to walk away. The Arabs and Israelis are in a bazaar, where there are a lot of negotiations. Once they begin the less public horse-trading, the mediators can begin to operate outside the public glare. The Israelis are not going to make concessions on territory in the West Bank and Gaza Strip in the near future. The present bilateral negotiations are over autonomy, and that does not involve territory. **********I certainly hope the United States will not come up with a peace plan. That would be the end of the story. When the United States put forward peace plans in the past, everyone turned from dealing with each other and began shooting at the plan. We should assist with the deadlocks. But it will take an enormous committment and will divert attention from the rest of the world and domestic issues. **********Richard Murphy **********Assistant Secretary of State, 1983-89 **********We should try to play down the content of the conference. It's the symbolism that is important. Israelis and Arabs listened to each others' speeches, and that is something they don't even do at the United Nations. The substance is not in what goes on in the three days at Madrid, but the stated intent to continue into bilateral talks. There we will see how serious each one is in their profession to want peace. **********They wouldn't be at the conference without having the stage set by what happened in Europe to end the cold war and what happened in Iraq. I hope they find that the geopolitical situation has changed on a global scale, and the Middle East is not immune to that change. But what happens in Madrid is really more of a television show. It's more visuals than oral. **********Bush pledges his support for a continuing effort to bring about a comprehensive peace. But it is important that at the beginning there not be an American plan. Why put forth something that we know in the initial stages will be shot down? The United States has to determine early in the bilateral talks, when the parties realize that their real positions are those stated in public, to say, "All right, here's a standoff, two fixed positions clearly expressed, but what do you think about this or that possibility?" **********People said the only reason they parties are there is because they don't want to say no to the United States. I don't think that is the full reason. Both sides -- and there is no one Arab position -- are aware that times have changed. It is the end of their ability to depend on the grace and favor of a superpower in the sense of the 1970's and 80's. I think they're aware times have changed. **********Robert Oakley National Security Council Special Assistant, 1987-88 **********The real catalyst here is the feeling of the people of the region. They believe the time has come to do something different and end this conflict. Arabs and Israelis prefer the benefits of peace. It requires responsible, courageous political leadership because a lot of people are working against any compromise. All the players invested a lot of political capital in going to the conference, and they didn't do that because of war or because of United States pressure. That explanation has been exaggerated. Rather, they believe the world has changed and they realize they'd better change with it. **********But the process is going to take a long time. There was a similar conference in Geneva in December 1973. Syria did not attend, and it took six more years to get to the Camp David talks. Still, the conference ran directly into the beginning of the movement towards a peace between Israel and Egypt. **********I don't think anything more could be done than has not been done already. It almost looks as if the United States is more interested in peace in the Middle East than the Middle Easterners. Middle East leaders have to understand that this is what the people there want. That will be the catalyst. **********We have to help them learn how to talk to each other. The President has done just right. He saved himself for the big issues, as a court of last resort. He has not adopted the Carter approach of getting in there. But he has full confidence in Secretary of State Baker and everyone knows that.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/18/world.main_headline: Moscow to Ask Help From West On Reform Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/18/world.print_headline: Moscow to Ask Help From West On Reform Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/18/world.body_text: **********The Kremlin has begun an initiative to get major Western countries to join directly in drafting and financing a far-reaching plan for economic and political reform, including creation of a market economy, political decentralization and privatization. **********The initiative, details of which were made public in the weekly Moscow News, has not been formally endorsed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev or by the Group of Seven industrialized powers. **********But extensive private contacts have produced an appeal to the West signed by Yevgeny M. Primakov, a senior adviser to Mr. Gorbachev, and Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a widely respected economist.  Young Aide's Second Initiative **********Mr. Yavlinsky, the 39-year-old economist who was the primary architect of the "500 day plan" of radical economic reform rejected by Mr. Gorbachev last summer, was said to be the major mover behind the new initiative. **********His aides say he and Mr. Primakov are to fly to Boston on Sunday to discuss refinements for the plan with economists at Harvard University. The idea began taking shape last month when Mr. Yavlinsky was invited to a meeting of experts on the Soviet economy from the Group of Seven. **********The initiative that emerged is still taking shape, and Mr. Gorbachev is said to be awaiting the reception in the West before he publicly endorses the plan. The Kremlin reportedly hopes to reach sufficient agreement for Mr. Gorbachev to be invited to the summit meeting of the Seven -- the United States, Canada, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Japan -- in London in July. **********In Moscow, the initiative is thought to come at a propitious time. On the Soviet side, Mr. Gorbachev has struck a promising truce with Boris N. Yeltsin, the head of the Russian republic and the primary champion of radical economic reform, in which the President finally recognized the sovereignty of the republics and their right to secede.  Growing Sense on Need for Aid **********There is also a growing sense in the Soviet Union that the "crisis program" produced by the government of Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov can only be a stopgap measure without extensive Western assistance. Mr. Pavlov himself in a recent interview appealed to the West not to be bystanders to the Soviet crisis. **********On the Western side, President Bush has lately demonstrated a renewed interest in assisting Mr. Gorbachev, prompting a flurry of new contacts, including a telephone conversation between the leaders on May 11. **********In addition, many Western experts have come to say that the West cannot sit on the sidelines if it is interested in genuine reforms in the Soviet Union. One of these, Graham Allison, former dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, helped Mr. Yavlinsky shape the proposals. **********Mr. Yavlinsky is considered by many Western experts to be the most competent of Soviet economists. He has remained active as an adviser to Mr. Yeltsin and other republican leaders. Mr. Gorbachev's willingness to listen to him again was in itself viewed as further evidence that the President is retreating from the alliance with hard-line forces that he formed last fall.  Basic Principles Outlined **********The basic principles of the new initiative are included in an "Appeal to the Group of Seven" signed by Mr. Yavlinsky and Mr. Primakov. It calls on the Soviet Union to draft a comprehensive reform plan and asks the Group of Seven to prepare a parallel plan of economic cooperation. **********The letter outlines these basic objectives: ***********"A concrete distribution of powers between the center and the republics, especially in economic matters." ***********Strict financial and monetary policies and liberalized prices. ***********A "broad program of privatization and demonopolization." ***********"The creation of conditions for the formation of an open economic system in the Soviet Union and its integration into the world economy." ***********The development of legislative bases for a market economy. **********These elements have been cited in most previous reform plans. The difference is that this is the first to propose an active role for the West. The financial package, the Soviets say, could include new terms for repaying Moscow's foreign debt, the lifting of trade restrictions, Soviet membership in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, long-term credits and diverse technical assistance.  No Cost Mentioned **********Drafters of the letter did not include a cost for the proposal. But Aleksei Mikhailov, a member of Mr. Yavlinsky's economic think-tank, "Epicenter," pointed to a recent article by Prof. Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard University -- currently an economic advisor to the Polish government -- in which he said Western assistance to Moscow should be on the order of $30 billion per year for five years. **********Mr. Mikhailov said the proposal resolved the needs of both the Soviet Union and the West. The West would help Moscow achieve the political and economic stability without which it cannot introduce reforms, and the Soviet Union in turn would launch the reforms that the West demands as necessary for any assistance. **********In an interview with Moscow News, Mr. Yavlinsky said he was prodded to seek new solutions after Mr. Gorbachev ordered troops into the Moscow streets in March in an unsuccessful attempt to block a pro-Yeltsin rally. The stalemate, he said, proved "that nobody can win," and that the only path was through compromise and negotiation. **********Then last month he was invited to attend a meeting of experts preparing the Group of Seven summit talks. Before going he consulted with Mr. Primakov and other Government officials. Mr. Yavlinsky's departure coincided with Mr. Gorbachev's meeting with the presidents of nine Soviet republics, at which they called off their destructive feuding and agreed to cooperate. **********Mr. Yavlinsky said he argued his case for cooperation in Washington. The experts wanted a sign that the Kremlin shared his interest, and from this arose the idea of a joint appeal from him and Mr. Primakov.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/02/busin.main_headline: Reader's Digest Aims at an Affluent Target
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/02/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Reader's Digest Aims at an Affluent Target
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/02/busin.body_text: **********Seeking to remind advertising agencies that The Reader's Digest does indeed reach beyond Middle America, the magazine is starting an edition for its most affluent readers. **********The Reader's Digest Power Plus edition will be sent to the monthly's readers in those neighborhoods, identified by Federal census data, offering high concentrations of households with incomes of $50,000 and up. The new edition, being presented to agencies this week, will make its debut in March and then appear again in June, September and December. **********Like many other magazines' demographic editions, Power Plus will carry the same articles as the regular edition; the sole difference will be in the advertising.  'Much More Focused' Sales **********Power Plus is part of a program to "make our sales efforts much more focused," John Donoghue, publisher of The Reader's Digest, said in an interview last week. **********For Power Plus, the circulation rate base, or total circulation guaranteed to advertisers, will be 4.1 million, compared with 16.25 million for the flagship magazine. A four-color ad page will cost $95,000, compared with $131,000 in the flagship edition. **********Like the flagship edition of The Reader's Digest, the nation's largest magazine in total paid circulation, Power Plus will be the largest demographic edition of a magazine. It will be more than twice the size of an edition of Time magazine called Time Business, which at 1.635 million circulation is currently the largest. **********Some agency executives will be "surprised that we can come up with an edition that size," Mr. Donoghue said, adding that The Reader's Digest has always seen itself as a magazine "that carries the type of editorial that attracts all kinds of people, including affluent people." **********Power Plus has the same goal as any higher-income demographic edition, Mr. Donoghue said: to attract new advertisers in categories like travel, financial services, home electronics and imported cars. **********Roberta Garfinkle, vice president and director of print media at McCann-Erickson New York, sees another purpose. Mass-circulation magazines like The Reader's Digest "get so big, and therefore, so costly, that a lot of advertisers can't afford them," she said. "This is giving them a lower cost." **********Demographic editions have long been a mainstay for the nation's larger publishers. The Time Inc. Magazine Company, for example, offers 10 such editions of Fortune, Sports Illustrated and Time. **********"I think with Time magazine, you can buy the left side of 86th Street," Ms. Garfinkle said.  'Is It Going to Light Fires?' **********An edition like Power Plus makes sense for The Reader's Digest, she said, "and potentially it could bring some business in." **********"Is it going to light fires?" Ms. Garfinkle asked. "I don't think so. But it's interesting." **********Power Plus is not the magazine's first higher-income edition; one, with a circulation of a million, was introduced in 1970 and discontinued a year later. This time, "we're in this for the long term," Mr. Donoghue said. **********Some industry executives criticize The Reader's Digest for maintaining its role as a mass-circulation magazine in an era of smaller, special-interest titles that reach a targeted group of consumers. But Power Plus "was not created because we think a magazine the size of The Digest does not have a future," Mr. Donoghue said. "The Digest itself will remain the most efficient buy for anyone selling a mass-marketed product."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/30/world.main_headline: China Still Detains Dissidents Without Trials
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/30/world.print_headline: China Still Detains Dissidents Without Trials
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/30/world.body_text: **********More than a month after the Chinese Government announced that trials of democracy advocates were "basically completed," dozens of dissidents are still being detained without trial -- people like Han Dongfang, 27 years old, a railway worker who tried to organize an independent labor union during the 1989 Tiananmen protests. **********Mr. Han, who is believed to be severely ill and is confined in Qincheng Prison on the outskirts of Beijing, is one of many whom the authorities seem unwilling to prosecute or release. Another person who has been detained in Qincheng since the summer of 1989, but has never been tried, is Wu Jiaxiang, a 35-year-old poet and political theorist who destroyed a brilliant career in the Communist Party by denouncing martial law. **********Li Minqi, an undergraduate democracy advocate at Beijing University, is also in the twilight zone of indefinite detention, although there are reports that he may be tried soon. **********Since March, Chinese leaders have been reassuring the West that the trials of Tiananmen figures are "basically over." But as China tries to move on toward normalization of relations with Western countries, Mr. Han, Mr. Wu, Mr. Li and others remain in prison. **********"It gives a lie to the whole promise," said a Western diplomat who estimated that there may be 250 Tiananmen figures whose fates remain unresolved. "They're just dangling there." **********From the Government's point of view, this has certain benefits and little cost. Indefinite detention preserves flexibility and avoids angering the West with announcements of long sentences. In addition, the system exercises maximum pressure on the inmates, partly because they are frequently prohibited from seeing their families until after sentencing. **********"My greatest fear was that they would just keep me inside indefinitely for years, without even handing me over to the courts," said a dissident who was recently released after many months in prison. "It's that constant uncertainty that gets to you." **********Thousands of young people, mostly workers, appear to have been sentenced to prison or to "labor re-education" camps because of their involvement in the Tiananmen movement, and a small number were executed. **********Robin Munro, a researcher in Hong Kong for Asia Watch, the American human rights organization, said the Government may try the remaining cases secretly, to avoid attracting attention in the West. He cited the case of two students from Beijing who were secretly sentenced last month to prison terms exceeding 10 years. **********According to information gathered by Asia Watch, the two students are Zhang Yafei, 24, sentenced to 11 years, and Chen Yanbin, 23, sentenced to 15 years. They were convicted of counterrevolutionary propaganda and incitement, for forming a pro-democracy group in 1990 and for distributing 400 copies of a pro-democracy newsletter. **********The sentences, which are longer than many others have been, may signify an effort to be particularly severe to those who pursued democracy after the Tiananmen movement died down. **********The Government has also transferred Liu Gang, a physics graduate student who is believed to have been tortured in prison, to the northeast Chinese city of Changchun to serve out his six-year sentence. Mr. Liu, who is 30, particularly angered the authorities with his "bad attitude" and the hunger strike he staged in Qincheng Prison. **********After the hunger strike, which Mr. Liu organized by tapping messages through the prison water pipes to other cells, the guards put him in heavy leg irons and handcuffed him with one arm bent backward over his head and the other bent behind his back for a full week, said a Chinese with reliable information about the case. **********In Changchun, Mr. Liu faces tougher prison conditions than in Beijing and presumably shares a cell with common criminals or else endures solitary confinement. Moreover, once he is released, he might not be allowed to return to Beijing to live. **********In China, citizens are allowed to live only in the city where they have a residence permit, and few punishments are feared more than the cancellation of the right to live in a major city.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/world.main_headline: IRAN'S VIEW OF U.S. SEEMS TO SOFTEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/world.print_headline: IRAN'S VIEW OF U.S. SEEMS TO SOFTEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/world.body_text: **********Looking back on momentous times, Moussavi Khoeniha could not disguise a twinkle of pride. **********As the spiritual leader of the militants who seized the United States Embassy here in 1979, taking 52 Americans hostage for 444 days, he encouraged the takeover, he said, and thus helped mold Iran's revolution. "Today," he said, "there is no Shah and the United States has no base in Iran." **********But these days the cleric is caught in a more complex debate about the United States. And, while the discussion is still defined by the anti-American orthodoxy of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died in 1989, some Iranians seem to be reaching slowly and cautiously for different ideas. **********"Personally, I am strongly against the resumption of relations with the United States," Mr. Khoeniha said. "I do not think Iran currently has the readiness, as far as public opinion is concerned." **********Mr. Khoeniha belongs to what outsiders term the radicals in Teheran's political hierarchy, meaning that he stands opposed to the so-called pragmatic policies of President Hashemi Rafsanjani. He recently started a newspaper called Salam to promote what many here see as the fading, but still significant, cause of Ayatollah Khomeini's fundamentalism. 'A Convergence of Interests' **********Mohamad Javad Larijani, by contrast, is a senior presidential adviser and one of the pragmatists who are seeking a more liberal theocracy still rooted in strict observance of Islam. **********"I believe personally that, in the security of the Persian Gulf, there is a convergence of interests with the United States," Mr. Larijani, a former Deputy Foreign Minister and a current member of Iran's National Security Council, said in an interview, suggesting a "marriage of convenience" between the two without formal ties. **********Yet, he added, even those Iranians sympathetic to a resumption of relations with Washington "are suspicious." **********"They think that the United States wants to fool Iran, dominate Iran, interfere in Iran," he said. **********The inference from both conversations, conducted separately, was that, whatever other issues block a resumption of ties between Teheran and Washington, Iran's convoluted inner politics preclude much progress in overcoming what Mr. Larijani termed a lack of confidence. **********"We don't have any confidence in the United States and they don't have any confidence in our intentions," he said. **********The debate over the relationship with the United States seems symptomatic of the far wider struggle for Iran's soul that consumes the political energies of both factions. "The radicals are on the wane," a European envoy said, "but they can still sting and obstruct." Radicals Control Parliament **********The so-called radicals control Parliament and exert influence through other institutions, like Government ministries where their followers predominate, village mosques and Islamic associations on university campuses and other institutions. They may seize an issue -- like accusations that Western relief for Kurdish refugees is deficient -- to prod the authorities to reassert their own, revolutionary credentials. **********But after the strictures of the revolution under Ayatollah Khomeini and over a decade of war and decline, the radical message has lost some appeal. **********Asked if radical influence was declining, Mr. Khoeniha said: "Your question is correct. Islamic fundamentalists are in a different situation now than when Ayatollah Khomeini was alive." **********The political considerations have a central bearing on the continued detention of Western hostages by Iranian-backed groups in Lebanon. The hostages represent one of the principal obstacles to a resumption of ties with Washington. **********The hostages, Mr. Larijani said, are "for Iran a pure liability," although he denied that Teheran exercised decisive influence over their captors. **********Within Iranian politics, however, a Western diplomat said, any release of the Western captives that seemed submission to the West could be used by the radicals to belabor the authorities. **********President Rafsanjani, the diplomat said, "does not wish to jeopardize his position for parliamentary elections" next year, when the expectation among foreign analysts and some Iranians is that the radicals will lose their parliamentary footing.  Issue of Regional Security **********Even if that happens, Iran seems unlikely to abandon a perception of Washington, bred over 12 years, as the ogre that once bent Iran to its will. "The hostility toward the United States is not right now a problem that differentiates the two groups," Mr. Larijani said. **********But, the official said, both Washington and Teheran share an interest in a peaceful and stable Persian Gulf region, and in reliable oil markets. **********So there could be, even without diplomatic relations, what he termed a "marriage of convenience" whereby the United States helped rid the region of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq by promoting a coup and sponsored a "regional security arrangement," or a "United Nations monitoring group with U.S. participation." **********Washington seems unlikely to show much enthusiasm. But the notion of an Iranian official publicly acknowledging an American interest in the Persian Gulf and envisaging the prospect of a United States role, however indirect, in regional security seemed a marked divergence from what it called the line of Ayatollah Khomeini. **********But it is not, so far, the public line.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; IRAQIS SEVER TIES WITH SIX NATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; IRAQIS SEVER TIES WITH SIX NATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/world.body_text: **********The Baghdad radio reported today that Iraq was severing diplomatic relations with six allied countries, and Iraq reported that about 150 people, including 35 children, were killed by allied bombing in a southern city. **********The report of the deaths in the southern city of Nasiriya overnight is by the far the highest casualty toll reported by Iraq in a single attack since the Persian Gulf war began on Jan. 17. **********Iraq said it would break off ties with the United States, Britain, France, Italy, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. Those countries, except Egypt, have taken part in air attacks on Iraq. Egypt has the largest Arab force in the coalition. **********The official Iraqi News Agency said it learned from diplomatics that Iraqi artillery bombardments killed 40 allied soldiers and wounded 38 near Hafr al Baten in northeastern Saudi Arabia. Many Homes Struck, Iraq Says **********Iraqi officials said many homes were hit during the raid on Nasiriya. Travelers arriving from the city said it came under intensive bombardment on Tuesday night. They said military and industrial targets were hit, and huge columns of smoke rose over the city. **********Iraqi officials said allied bombs and missiles rained down on Baghdad overnight, smashing a bridge, a hospital, a communications center and homes. "The enemy carried out 263 raids and missile attacks on Iraq," an Iraqi military spokesman said this morning. **********Iraq said two allied warplanes were shot down overnight. **********The Government daily Al Thawra reported today that 349 people have been killed in the southern port city of Basra since the allied raids began. Iraq had announced earlier that 428 civilians had died in allied air attacks. **********Baghdad radio, in a commentary this afternoon, said the allies "want to expel Iraq from the 20th century." **********Baghdad radio also warned of an escalation of terrorist attacks against Western targets. The radio said the holy war, "mounted by good Muslims against the imperialist interests," would escalate every day. **********Two surface-to-surface rockets hit the al-Jomhouriwa Bridge over the Tigris River in downtown Baghdad. It was the second strike against the 33-year-old bridge this week and it destroyed the span. Two other surface-to-surface rockets landed near a bus station, officials said, destroying two movie theaters and about 200 shops. **********Reporters were shown a communications center that has been a frequent target of allied attacks. The center, equipped by the French company Thomson-CSF, was destroyed. Diplomatic Move Unusual **********AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 6 (Special to The New York Times) -- Western diplomats said today that it was unusual for diplomatic realtions to be broken by a radio broadcast. For example, officials in London said no formal notice of the Iraq's announcement had been given to the Government. **********Technically, the announcement on Baghdad Radio means that Iraq will have to withdraw its diplomatic personnel from some of the Western and Arab capitals where it maintains embassies and hand responsibility for intergovernmental communication to diplomats from other countries. **********The United States and its allies withdrew diplomatic personnel from Baghdad before the start of the war. But Iraq maintained reduced missions in Washington and other allied capitals. **********Some diplomats here said the continuation of diplomatic ties after the start of hostilities was an anomaly since there was no communication between Iraq and its adversaries anyway. **********According to those parts of the broadcast that were heard by radio monitors, there was no apparent mention of either Syria or Turkey. Both are neighbors of Iraq and members of the Western-led coalition, but they have largely Muslim populations that have shown significant opposition to the Western assault on Iraq. **********In particular, Iraq has excluded Syria -- led by a rival wing of the Arab Baath Socialist Party -- from its comments, and has urged Damascus to join it in the fight against the West.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/13/busin.main_headline: A Hard Line From China On Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/13/busin.print_headline: A Hard Line From China On Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/13/busin.body_text: **********China faces a difficult battle in Congress this summer to retain its preferential access to the United States market, but you would hardly know it from the unconciliatory remarks being made by Chinese officials. **********Ambassador Zhu Qizhen, in a speech last week outlining his Government's position in the coming debate, took a hard and at times menacing line. China has not violated any human rights, he said; it does not have a problem trade surplus with the United States, and it keeps adequate controls over its exports of arms and nuclear technology. Retaliation Is Likely **********China will also use high tariffs to drive American companies out of its markets if the United States does not renew the current trade privileges, Mr. Zhu added. Billions of dollars in contracts and thousands of jobs in industries from aircraft manufacturing to agricultural chemical production would be at risk, he said. **********Mr. Zhu's remarks were only a little more strident than other policy statements by Chinese officials. For China has pursued a pugnacious four-pronged lobbying strategy here that has dismayed its friends and gladdened its foes. **********Mr. Zhu's comments were not what members of Congress had hoped to hear. The massacre at Tiananmen Square in 1989, along with reports in the last month by a human rights group and a Congessman that political prisoners are being forced to produce goods for export, have so stained the reputation of China's leadership that diplomats' assurances carry little credibility. **********A growing number of American lawmakers say they want China's "most favored nation" trade status revoked outright. "The Ambassador's threats will strengthen their case," said Representative Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat who opposes renewal unless it is linked to human rights improvements. Bush Decision Due by June 3 **********President Bush must notify Congress by June 3 if he wishes to renew for one year China's most-favored status, which is due to expire on July 3. A motion of disapproval, which seems likely to be introduced, would have to pass both houses of Congress within 90 days, and it probably would provoke a Presidential veto. **********When President Bush renewed China's trade status last year, the House voted to disapprove the renewal. The Senate considered similar action but did not take a vote before the 90-day time limit expired, so the renewal stood. **********Several lobbyists who favor renewal expect that this year President Bush will recommend a renewal of the special status, that both houses of Congress will disapprove it, and that the President will veto the disapproval. It is possible, though unlikely, that Congress will then override the veto. **********Another possibility is that Congress will pair its disapproval of the status for China with approval of a renewal for the Soviet Union, said one lobbyist who favors a renewal for China. In that case, the President would face a particularly difficult dilemma, because the Soviet Union is in desperate need of certain trade subsidies and other credits that indirectly depend on a renewal of its status. Tariff Would Rise to 47.48% **********The U.S.-China Business Council, a Washington-based group of American companies with investments in China, has estimated that the average tariff for the 25 biggest categories of American imports from China will rise to 47.48 percent, from 8.35 percent, if most-favored status is not renewed. With this status, Chinese products enter the United States at the lowest rate available to any American trading partner for each category of goods. **********The test of China's strategy will come soon. Congress appeared increasingly likely last week to authorize the Administration to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico and another round of reductions in global trade barriers. At the same time, China's trade status was moving quickly toward the top of the agendas of Washington's economic policy makers. **********An eclectic alliance of trade protectionists, anti-Communist conservatives and liberal human rights advocates opposes an unconditional extension. **********The strongest of China's four lobbying themes has been that Congress and the Administration should value the United States' strategic relationship with China too highly to risk endangering it for the sake of human rights or trade surpluses. President Bush, a former chief of the American liaison office in Beijing, is widely seen as particularly influenced by this argument. Overestimation by Chinese **********But the Chinese consistently overestimate how much weight is given to such long-term considerations on Capitol Hill, said Warren W. Williams, the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong. Mr. Williams has led a delegation to lobby Washington in support of the Chinese. **********"Their fundamental lack of understanding of how things work in Washington, D.C., is a continuing surprise," he said. **********Another Chinese lobbying tactic is to insist that China guarantees different human rights, including rights to food and shelter, than the the United States does. American officials, by this argument, should not judge a foreign country by their own standards. **********Chinese officials also criticize American trade statistics showing that China shipped $15.1 billion worth of goods to the United States last year while importing products worth only $4.8 billion. Excluding Chinese exports that pass through Hong Kong, the trade is nearly in balance, Mr. Zhu contended. But this argument has not been persuasive in Washington, Mr. Williams said.  Attempt to Intimidate U.S. **********The last of China's four approaches to lobbying in Washington has been intimidation. "I have a fondness for the American people," Mr. Zhu said after his speech on Tuesday. "I really don't want to see West German or Japanese people there, taking over." **********Business conditions for Americans in China are said to be deteriorating already. For three weeks, Chinese negotiators have been stalling in contract talks with American companies, said an American businessman with extensive contacts there, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. He said the Chinese negotiators were acting on Government instructions. **********But in a possible change of tack, the New China News Agency said Saturday that China would send a buying mission to the United States, Reuters reported. **********Some people in Washington question the credibility of Chinese threats to exclude American businesses and products. "They may not love capitalism; they may not love human rights, but they love money," Representative Pelosi said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/16/world.print_headline: Security Seen as a Dividend of Soviet Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/16/world.body_text: **********As a debate simmers in Washington over what sort of economic aid the United States should extend to the Soviet Union if it adopts democratic, free-market reforms, the question inevitably arises: what is in it for the United States? **********The answer from many of those who favor aid, including economists, members of Congress and Administration officials, is that the payoff for the United States -- if there is one -- will be primarily in political-security terms and not economic ones. **********"For the United States, the case for Soviet aid is really a political call, not an economic one," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International and former Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. Buying a Tranquilizer **********"If you really want to get some economic bang for the 30 billion in bucks people are talking about, there would be a lot better way to spend it," Mr. Hormats said. "If the aid works, what you are buying is an economic tranquilizer designed to stabilize a potentially chaotic situation in the Soviet Union, in order to permit a transition to a free market and more democratic confederation of some sort." **********To be sure, whether the Administration chooses to develop a Soviet economic rescue package will depend primarily on the seriousness of the Soviet Union's own rescue plans, or as President Bush said Friday: "The reforms have got to be detailed a bit more before blank checks are written, and even then it would be difficult. We're not rolling in cash." **********But Mr. Hormats said the size of any aid program would also depend on "how desperate" the Administration believed the political situation in the Soviet Union to be, whether it was in the national security interests of the United States to try to stabilize it and whether that would be possible with any amount of money. Hopes for immediate benefits to the American economy will be secondary. **********Indeed, Administration officials acknowledge that the key factor prompting President Bush this week to grant Mr. Gorbachev's request for $1.5 billion in additional credits to buy American food was a fear that food shortages in the Soviet Union, coupled with political turmoil, might lead the country to implode before any reform program could be instituted. Possible Global Consequences **********Since the Soviet Union occupies one-sixth of the world's landmass, has 12,000 nuclear missiles, countless conventional weapons and some 50 nuclear reactors, a few billion dollars in credits is deemed a small price to pay for helping to prevent political and economic turmoil there, the consequences of which could be global, officials say. **********"Spending American tax dollars to aid the Soviet economic transformation is the easiest proposition in the world to mock," said Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard University economist who has been working with Soviet economists on a five-year, $100 billion reform plan. "But those who want to stand by and see the Soviet Union collapse have an incredible lack of historical memory." **********Americans are taking for granted the cooperation exhibited by the Soviet Union in recent years on a broad front including Eastern Europe and the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Sachs said. **********"Do we really want to wait for a right-wing backlash in the Soviet Union, produced by a sense of failure, paranoia and anger about losing the cold war?" he added. "We will very much regret that. That is exactly the sort of sentiment that produced a man like Hitler after the First World War." **********Not everyone, though, accepts this aid-to-prevent-nuclear-chaos argument. **********"I think that it's somewhere between a new form of nuclear blackmail and gross exaggeration," Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, said in an interview on the Public Broadcasting System foreign affairs television series "American Interests." "The fact is that the Soviet military is in control of the nuclear weapons, they're primarily controlled by Russians in Russia and I don't think that it's a serious, very serious problem." Some See Political Benefits **********Nevertheless, the potential benefits in American national security terms go beyond preventing nuclear chaos. Virtually all of the leading economists and lawmakers now advocating some American aid package do so on the condition that it not be paid out unless the Soviets take concrete steps to transform their economy from central control to a free market and their polity from a Communist system to a democratic one. **********If such a transformation can be promoted, said Stanley Fischer, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist working with the Soviet Union, "you will end up with both a democratic and capitalist Soviet Union, and the fact is you find very few wars between democracies." **********When Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on international operations, is asked by constituents why their tax dollars should go to help transform the Soviet economy, this political point is where he takes off from. **********"We now have the opportunity to participate in the most fundamental change in a major society in the 20th century and to help shape that society in a way that will give us an opportunity to minimize our defense expenditures," Mr. Obey said. "We now spend $120 billion a year on military expenditures, which principally involve the defense of Western Europe from the Soviet Union. **********"If we can promote democratic changes in the Soviet Union that will allow us to reduce that by only 10 percent a year, you could still save a lot more than the few billion that anyone up here is talking about for programs to promote Soviet reform. It makes sense financially, it makes sense economically and it makes sense in security terms. The most expensive thing would be to do nothing." Effect on Eastern Europe **********Mr. Sachs argued that to think that an internal explosion in the Soviet Union would not have a spillover effect in Eastern Europe or the Muslim nations to the south would be "extremely naive." The Soviet Army remains in Germany and Poland, and its withdrawal from Eastern Europe could easily be derailed by internal turmoil. **********Eastern European economies have already been badly hurt by the fact that the Soviet authorities have halted virtually all of the barter arrangements they had and are now insisting on being paid hard currency for Soviet oil exports. Because the Eastern Europeans are short of hard currency, they are having to look to the West for help in buying oil and have lost about 50 percent of their exports by no longer having access to many Soviet markets. **********"So here we are pumping money into Eastern Europe to support reforms there, and it is being offset by the economic downturn in the Soviet Union," Mr. Sachs said. "And ask yourself: How many Western businessmen are going to want to invest in Eastern Europe if the Soviet Union is exploding next door? Imagine the refugee problems for Eastern Europe that would cause. You can't bottle up turmoil." **********Finally, an orderly transition to democracy in the Soviet Government would, almost by definition, have to be accompanied by granting republics the right of self-determination, and that means the Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia would be much more likely to find a nonviolent path to independence, which has been a basic objective of American foreign policy. **********On the purely economic side, the Soviet Union with its 290 million people and vast natural resources represents an enormously attractive potential market if its resources could be fully tapped through a free-market system. But there would be little direct benefit to the American economy, except for certain sectors like consumer product and food producers, oil and gas equipment manufacturers and machine tool makers. The most immediate beneficiaries would be the Europeans in general and the East Europeans in particular, given their historical trade links with the Soviet Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/31/busin.body_text: **********A.T.& T. said Tuesday that it had reorganized senior management for the largest part of its business, long-distance service. **********The reorganization of the long-distance business, whose revenue could exceed $21 billion this year, is in part a result of the fast growth of multinational American companies, especially in Europe, as well as A.T.& T.'s own innovations with residential customers. **********The reorganization creates two units, Consumer Services and Business Services. The consumer group will include executives for residential long- distance service, wireless communications including cellular telephones, telemarketing and the Universal credit card. The business group includes executives for organizing special networks for corporations and related services like electronic mail and facsimile machines. **********The American Telephone & Telegraph Company also said it planned to offer credits to customers who are paying for unused subscriptions to its "Reach Out" group of long-distance discount plans. **********The company said some consumers were possibly continuing to receive A.T.& T. bills for unused subscriptions even though they have switched to other carriers.
