https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/busin.main_headline: Tax-Exempt Yields Are Up; Taxables Continue to Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER RATES; Tax-Exempt Yields Are Up; Taxables Continue to Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/busin.body_text: **********Yields on tax-exempt money market funds showed a significant rise over the last week, according to IBC/ Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and issues The Money Fund Report. At the same time the taxable funds continued their steady downward progress, dropping quite sharply. **********Referring to the tax-exempts, Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/ Donoghue's, said that yields had probably risen "because of the large supply of municipal securities that has come to market before the year end." **********But he said total assets of the tax- exempts were $91.5 billion, down $1.2 billion for the week. The decline probably indicated that a substantial number of investors had withdrawn money to seek better yields elsewhere.  Shorter Maturity **********The average days to maturity of the holdings of the tax-free funds dropped by one day, to 58 from 59 days. **********The seven-day compound average yield for the tax-exempts was 4.01 percent, up 22 basis point from last week, which he called a sharp rise. The seven-day simple yield for the tax-exempt funds also showed an increase, rising by 20 basis points, to 3.93 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. **********The 30-day compound yield was 3.83, up 6 basis points from the previous week, and the 30-day simple yield was 3.76 percent, also up 6 basis points. **********Among tax-exempt funds investing in individual state securities, the top New York fund was once again Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, which reported a seven-day compound yield of 4.52 percent versus 4.48 percent a week earlier. Top New York Fund **********In Connecticut the top-yielding fund this week again was Dreyfus Connecticut Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.35 percent, compared with a yield of 4.14 percent. **********New Jersey's leading fund for yields was again Calvert Tax Free Reserve New Jersey with a seven-day compound yield of 4.42 percent, compared with 4.30 percent a week earlier. **********Nationwide, among those funds with $100 million or more in assets, the highest-yield performance for the week was once again turned in by Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.97 percent, compared with 4.80 percent a week earlier.  Outflow of Assets **********With regard to the taxable funds, Martha Wittbrodt, editor of the IBC/ Donoghue Money Fund Report, said that their total assets showed a sizable drop, declining $6.4 billion to a total of $468.8 billion. She said, "Most of the asset outflow can be attributed to seasonal factors, which would include window dressing by institutional holders who like to show more cash on their books at year-end and withdrawals for holiday spending by individuals." **********She said that "taxable money fund yields will continue to decline, especially in view of the Federal Reserve's aggressive move to cut the discount rate by a full percentage point about a week ago." **********The average days to maturity of the portfolio holdings held steady at 61 days, indicating that money managers were trying to lock in rates ahead of the further expected declines in yields, according to Miss Wittbrodt.  Taxable Yields Drop **********The seven-day compound yield on the taxable funds was 4.64 percent, compared with 4.70 last week, and the seven-day simple yield for the taxable funds was was 4.53 percent, compared with 4.59 percent. In each instance the decline was 6 basis points. **********Meanwhile, the average compound 30-day yield dropped to 4.72 percent, down 5 basis points from 4.77 percent, and the 30-day simple yield was 4.61 percent, also down 5 basis points from 4.66 percent. **********Among the taxables the top-yielding fund for the week was Riverside Capital Money Market Fund of Columbus, Ohio, with a yield of 16.87 percent, which includes capital gains. **********By comparison, bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, yielded 4.34 percent and certificates of deposit yielded an average of 4.37 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's weekly national index issued on Tuesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/30/world.body_text: **********President Bush met today with President Arnold Ruutel of Estonia and said good-faith negotiations were the only way to resolve the standoff between Moscow and the independence-minded Baltic republics. **********Mr. Bush reiterated his unequivocal support for Estonia's right to self-determination and expressed outrage over Moscow's use of force in Vilnius and Riga in January, a White House statement said. **********The meeting in the Oval Office was the fifth time that Mr. Bush has held talks with a Baltic leader since last May.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/world.main_headline: India in an Uproar Over Refueling of U.S. Aircraft
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/world.print_headline: India in an Uproar Over Refueling of U.S. Aircraft
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/world.body_text: **********A decision to allow United States military aircraft to refuel at Bombay's international airport en route from the Pacific to the Persian Gulf has set off a political outcry that could bring down the Government of Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar. **********Beginning on Jan. 9, American C-141 transport planes stopped at Safar Airport in Bombay at the rate of about two a day, according to The Times of India, which first reported the refuelings on Monday. **********The newspaper said the planes werecoming from the Philippines. A spokesman for the United States Embassy here, refusing to comment on the report, said today that diplomatic missions do not normally confirm or deny military movements. **********Mr. Shekhar, who has since the beginning of the gulf war taken a stand more critical of Iraq than that adopted by nearly every other political party, is being accused of pandering to "American imperialism." **********Among his sharpest critics are the leftists and the Congress Party of Rajiv Gandhi, whose support is needed to keep the Shekhar Government in power. Another former Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, has also opposed any policy that appears to favor the United States, saying that violates India's traditional posture of nonalignment. **********A strategic analyst here, Bharat Wariavwalla, said in an interview today that it appeared that the Shekhar Government, in a significant departure, "was trying to distance itself from a kind of third-world romanticism about Saddam Hussein." **********The decision to refuel American planes, which the Indian Government said were carrying no weapons or other war supplies, comes at a time when the domestic airline, Indian Airlines, has had to cut back its servicesby nearly one-third to conserve aviation fuel. **********From the start of the gulf crisis in August, India has only half-heartedly backed United Nations condemnations of Iraq. Baghdad and New Delhi had close ties, diplomatically and economically. Indian expertise and labor had been used in Iraqi industrial and strategic development. **********Last year, Iraq stood nearly alone among Islamic nations in refusing to join in condemnation of India's heavy suppression of an independence movement in Kashmir. **********Soon after taking office in November, Mr. Shekhar, a pragmatic man with no experience in foreign policy, rejected attempts to link the annexation of Kuwait with Israeli occupation of areas claimed by Palestinians. On several occasions, he has said Mr. Hussein couldhave been more forthcoming in responding to efforts to avoid a war. **********Mr. Shekhar's political enemies and Congress Party supporters, unable to deflect him from taking bold domestic steps like meeting leaders of militant Sikh organizations to discuss the crisis in Punjab or refusing to dismiss controversial ministers, have now found a potent weapon in foreign policy. **********Mr. Shekhar's Foreign Minister, V. C. Shukla, was disqualified from Parliament with seven others in early January for having broken a law against switching parties without resigning a seat. The Law and Justice Minister, Subramaniam Swamy, was forced to apologize publicy to the Speaker of the House for having threatened to arrest him if he did not do the Government's bidding in postponing the disqualification decision.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of Israel said on Tuesday that it would permit foreign companies to issue stocks and bonds on the Tel Aviv stock exchange. But the amount of money a foreign concern could take out of the country would be limited to 20 percent of any new issue. Previously the central bank had turned down applications by foreign firms to issue shares on the stock market. The change of policy "will make the Israeli stock market more international," said Gideon Schurr, speaking for the Bank of Israel."Now we need local investments, not Israeli investments abroad."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/world.body_text: **********Islamic fundamentalists appear to have achieved a clear edge today in Algeria's first free parliamentary elections, taking a commanding lead in the first round of voting for 430 seats in the National Assembly. **********Run-off elections will be held Jan. 16 between the two leading candidates for those seats in which no candidate received a majority in the first round. **********Early returns today suggested that the primary fundamentalist party, the Islamic Salvation Front, was ahead in most provinces. Coalitions in 2d Round **********It was not clear tonight how many candidates for Parliament had already won a seat by getting a majority in the first round. But it was clear that other parties will have to form coalitions to face the Islamic Salvation Front in most districts where there are run-offs. **********Speaking at a delayed news conference tonight, Algeria's Interior Minister, Larby Belkhair, said more than 60 percent of the eligible 13.3 million voters participated in the elections, which he said took place in a "calm and serene atmosphere." **********Without giving any final results, Mr. Belkhair said the Government had respected its pledge to remain "totally neutral" and had conducted "a free election in total transparency." He described the vote as "a new phase in Algeria's history." **********Algerian officials said final returns in this round would be announced by early Friday. Severe Defeat for Secularists **********Still, a number of Government officials speaking privately conceded tonight that secularists may have been badly defeated by the Islamic fundamentalists from the Salvation front and other Muslim parties. **********Some leaders of secularist political parties said that with the exception of the Government party, the National Liberation Front, which came in second to the fundamentalist group, all other secularist parties had been eliminated. **********Rabeh Ben Sherif, the president of the National Party for Solidarity and Development, who has vehemently opposed the fundamentalists and called for a united front among their opponents, said: "We expected these results and we have told all pro-democratic parties in this contest that we must present a united front, but unfortunately most of those parties were not up to the level of political game. As a result, today, we are facing the clear conclusion in what are undeniably a clean and honest elections, that democratic secularist parties have been blown away." **********The new Parliament must agree on the President's selection of a Prime Minster and on the Cabinet as well as on the Government's programs. President Chadli Benjedid's term ends in January 1994. **********In a pre-election talk on Wednesday, President Benjedid seemed to strongly favor a vote against the fundamentalists, whom he indirectly accused of violence and anti-democratic practices. However, he said he would abide by the will of the people. 5,712 Candidates Ran **********While stressing that preliminary nature of their reports, radio stations, which are closely following the vote all over the country, reported that the Salvation Front had scored the highest number of votes in most provinces, followed by the National Liberation Front, known from its French initials as the F.L.N. Forty-nine parties ran a total of 5,712 candidates for the 430 seats. **********The F.L.N. has ruled Algeria ever since it achieved independence in 1962. **********Observers from all participating parties could be seen at many polling stations in Algiers and were reported to be present throughout the country too. There were no reports of interference by the authorities or significant distrubances. **********Over the last two years, the Salvation Front, known by its French initials F.I.S., has clearly emerged as by far and away the most powerful opposition party to the Government, having won 55 percent of the posts in gubernatorial and local elections held in May 1990. **********Veiled women were present at many voting stations in the capital, driven there or accompanied by male relatives. A previous law allowing men to cast proxy votes for their wives was changed by the Government. **********In Constantine, one of Algeria's largest cities, it was reported late tonight that mosques turned on their loudspeakers to broadcast Koranic verses in an apparent salute to what seemed to be a triumph for Islamic-oriented forces. **********Of the smaller parties contesting the elections, Hamas, a more moderate Islamic fundamentalist party than the Islamic Salvation Front, also appeared to have run well. **********Sheikh Mahfouz Nehnah, the leader of Hamas, told the Algerian radio tonight "Algeria seems finally to be getting out from under the one-party-rule system which is good news for Muslims and all Arabs". **********Sheikh Nehnah, who has opposed some of the violent practices of supporters of the Islamic Salvation Front, went on to call for a democratic Government in Algeria so that "our country can make the crossing to freedom through open dialogue. **********Among secularist parties, the Front for Socialist Forces, led by Hossein Ait-Ahmad, seems to have carried most of the votes in the Kabylia region, where Berber culture predominates. **********Mr. Ait-Ahmad, a historic figure in the war of liberation against France from 1954 to 1962, is of Berber stock and has strongly opposed Islamic fundamentalism as well as the F.L.N., of which he used to be a member. **********The president of the Algerian women's association said in a radio interview tonight that the results she has seen so far "give me fear in the stomach." **********The future for us does not seem to be rosy." **********Commentators say that if secularists hope to recoup from what appears to be a strong showing by the fundamentalists, parties like those of Mr. Ait-Ahmed may have to ally themselves in the second round to the F.L.N., despite their professed hostility to the ruling party throughout the campaign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/11/busin.main_headline: 2 Europe Tire Makers Set New Merger Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; 2 Europe Tire Makers Set New Merger Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/11/busin.body_text: **********Continental A.G. and Pirelli S.p.A, two of Europe's largest tire makers, said today that they would resume merger talks. The move followed the resignation on Thursday of Continental's chairman, Horst Urban, who had opposed the merger. **********Pirelli, an Italian company that is the world's fifth-largest tire maker, began a $3.5 billion takeover attempt last year for Continental, Europe's fourth-largest tire company and owner of General Tire Inc. in the United States. Together, the companies would control 16 percent of the world market. **********Pirelli has proposed transferring its tire operations to Continental and then taking control of the company. Pirelli holds more than 6 percent of Continental's stock and says it heads a group that holds over 50 percent of the voting shares. But Mr. Urban, who is 54 years old, had doggedly fought the combination and talks between the two companies broke off in September. **********The two sides described the new talks as friendly and unconditional. "The war is over," said a source close to the negotiations. "Now diplomacy begins." **********A merged Continental-Pirelli group would have annual sales of $9.24 billion and challenge the European leader, Michelin of France. It would still be ranked fourth in the world tire market. **********Michelin, Bridgestone of Japan and Goodyear of the United States dominate the global market with shares of 22 percent, 20 percent and 17 percent, respectively.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/world.main_headline: Twisted Hulk of Warehouse Tells a Grim Story of Death
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: THE SCUD ATTACK; Twisted Hulk of Warehouse Tells a Grim Story of Death
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/world.body_text: **********Miniature American flags tucked into duffel bags and placed on the street stood guard today in front of the twisted metal girders and shards of metal -- the ghostly remains of a military barracks destroyed in a single flash on Monday by an Iraqi Scud missile. **********The United States Command said today that the missile, which hit a transformed warehouse housing American soldiers at 8:23 P.M. on Monday, killed 28 soldiers and wounded at least 100. The warehouse stands near a supermarket in Al Khobar, a town considered to be part of Dhahran. **********The attack on Monday night killed more people than the 70 previous Scud attacks on Israel, Saudi Arabia and smaller gulf nations combined. And it inflicted more casualties on American troops than the Iraqi military had in the first two days of ground combat, based on casualty figures from the American military command.  Missile Broke Up **********The Scud apparently fragmented above the atmosphere, then tumbled downward. Its warhead blasted an eight-foot-wide crater into the center of the building, which is three miles from a major United States air base, Brig. Gen. Richard I. Neal of the United States Command, said. The Scud could not be tracked by the Patriot missile radar system, he said, because it had fragmented when it entered the atmosphere. **********"The system we utilize to defeat this system has a known trajectory," General Neal said. "Our investigation looks like this missile broke apart in flight. On this particular missile it wasn't in the parameters of where it could be attacked." **********General Neal said the warehouse stood in a "major civilian area." He also insisted that the United States military uses a dependable missile defense system. **********Baghdad radio hailed the attack against "the coward traitors who mortgage the sacred places of the nation and turn Arab youths into shields of flesh."  Attacks on Gulf Emirates **********Most of the Scuds fired by Iraq, including one fired on Monday at the island nation Bahrain, about 20 miles east of Dhahran, have been intercepted by American Patriot defense missiles. Iraq earlier today also fired its first missile against Qatar, an Arab member of the multinational coalition. It crashed in a deserted area and no damage was reported. Just after dusk this evening, air raid sirens went off again but no missile was reported to have hit in Saudi Arabia. Scud attacks have usually occurred when there is heavy cloud cover and the weather in Dhahran has been overcast during the last several nights. **********A sign at the entrance of the barracks marked it as the home of the 475th Quartermaster Group, an Army Reserve water and petroleum distribution unit based in Farrell, Pa. Although the wounded and the dead had still not been identified this evening, it appeared that the casualties had been from a number of units. Military officials said the wounded had been taken to the 85th Evacuation Hospital located at an air base here in Dhahran as well as to an air transportable clinic. Officials also said there were women among the soldiers who were killed. **********In Farrell, a town of 6,000 people close to the Ohio state line, Ella Ward, whose husband Roy is a staff sergeant in the 475th Group, said that her husband called her Monday night and said that most people in the unit were all right. But Hugh Farnen, of Columbia, Mo., the father of one of the reservists, said today that his 22-year-old son had been killed in the blast. Iraqi Withdrawal Announcement **********The missile hit only hours after Iraq announced it was withdrawing from Kuwait. Less than a minute after the air raid sirens sounded throughout Dhahran, the missile appeared as a burning streak of light crosding the night sky and then blasted into the building, setting it afire. **********Many of the soldiers were eating dinner or relaxing. Others were sleeping. No one had the time to don gas masks, as is the military procedure when the sirens sound. In the chaos that ensued, soldiers digging through the rubble attempted to give first aid to their comrades. Foil sheets were used to wrap those who had been badly burned and any mode of transport to hospitals was commandeered. Bus windows were smashed so that stretchers could fit inside and convoys of dozens of ambulances raced to hospitals. The worst cases were stretchered to waiting helicopters. **********As the dead were brought out and the casualties ferried to the hospitals, soldiers cried and embraced each other. Four pairs of boots lay in the rubble. The charred floors were littered with sleeping bags, cots and military uniform belts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/busin.main_headline: New Bankruptcy-Fee Rules Harsh on Investment Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/busin.print_headline: New Bankruptcy-Fee Rules Harsh on Investment Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/busin.body_text: **********Investment bankers working on bankruptcy cases will have to disclose hourly billing rates and account for their time down to every six minutes under strict new guidelines that became effective yesterday in the Southern District of New York. **********The guidelines reflect a growing effort to rein in advisory fees run up during bankruptcy cases. **********The guidelines, issued by the district's seven bankruptcy judges on June 20 and disclosed yesterday in Corporate Financing Week, apply to all professionals who advise in bankruptcies, including accountants, lawyers and real estate advisers. **********But they are expected to have the harshest impact on investment bankers, who do not bill by the hour but charge basic monthly retainers for bankruptcies plus fees based on their performance. Lawyers and accountants have long followed rules similar to those now being required by the court. **********"It puts the investment bankers down to the status of mere mortals with the rest of us, because they have to comply with the time-record-keeping requirements that everybody else has had to comply with all along," said Robert Miller, a bankruptcy lawyer at Berlack, Israels & Liberman. He does not expect the guidelines to require a drastic change in the way his firm does business. **********The issue has become significant because of a growing consensus that bankruptcy fees "have simply run amok," as Mr. Miller put it yesterday. Stories of abuse have become legion, like that of a law firm involved in the Drexel Burnham Lambert bankruptcy that billed thousands of dollars to cover the time it spent preparing its bill. **********By law, big companies involved in bankruptcies must pay not only for their own legal and financial advice, but for that of creditors and shareholders. That requirement might cost $5 million a month in fees, about 20 percent of which might go to investment bankers. That money ultimately comes out of the pockets of creditors and shareholders. **********Investment bankers interviewed yesterday acknowledged that fees were getting out of control, but said their firms were not geared to bill by the hour. **********"We do not have an hourly billing rate, nor do we have any intention of setting a billing rate," said Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the head of corporate finance at Rothschild Inc. "In our industry, the month is a standard unit of time, and I don't know why it's any easier to figure out what's an hour's worth of work than a month's worth of work." Partly to Blame **********Although Mr. Ross said he thought a middle ground could be found, he also acknowledged that the investment banking business was partly to blame for the court's current stance. **********"What they're really grappling with is how do you measure an investment banker's productivity?" he said. "I think it's a fair question. The real problem is the courts don't see investment bankers much, because much of what an investment banker does is in the conference room, not in the courtroom. " **********How would he cut bankruptcy fees? "The ultimate thing is to cut the duration of the cases," Mr. Ross said. **********Another investment banker warned that the new rules might force some firms to decline cases. "If these rules were to be literally enforced as is, it would be difficult for the biggest securities firms to participate in bankruptcy court cases," said Norman Brown, a managing director for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. He said his firm was "still trying to figure out whether it could comply." **********The guidelines' impact could reach beyond the Southern District if the reaction of A. Jay Cristol, a bankruptcy judge in Miami, is any guide. "If they have done something to require investment bankers to account for their time, I look upon that with great favor," he said. **********Though the administrative order is labeled "guidelines," nearly all of the rules it outlines will be mandatory in the Southern District, the document states. Departures from the norm, in the few categories where they are permitted, will have to include a detailed explanation of why the adviser thinks them justified. **********Advisers will be expected to keep records to support their fees, the document says. Records of expenses for things like photocopies and faxes will also have to be submitted to the courts before reimbursements can be approved. And charges have been limited: Photocopies can not exceed 20 cents a page, outgoing faxes can be reimbursed at no more than $1.25 a page domestically and $2.50 abroad, and incoming faxes are not reimbursable. **********The document discourages unnecessary overnight mail service and forbids the use of radio cars or taxis to deliver documents. Dinners eaten before 8 P.M. can be reimbursed only if professionals return to their offices for at least an hour and a half. **********The document states that "local taxi and limousine charges should be minimized and justified. Because of the proximity of mass transit to the court, mass transit should be used whenever practicable."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/04/busin.main_headline: Vehicle Sales Dip, but Selling Rate Picks Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/04/busin.print_headline: Vehicle Sales Dip, but Selling Rate Picks Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/04/busin.body_text: **********Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 10.1 percent in late June compared with an unusually strong period a year earlier. On a seasonally adjusted basis, however, the results provided new evidence that the sluggish American automotive market is gaining strength. **********The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 7.4 million for the June 21-30 period, the highest rate since late December. The late June rate compared with an 8.1 million rate a year earlier and a 6.5 million rate in mid-June. **********The Big Three and the seven Japanese companies that build vehicles in North America sold 212,491 cars in late June, down 11.1 percent from 268,953 a year earlier. Light-truck sales were 120,385, down 8.3 percent from 147,634. There were eight selling days in the period this year, compared with nine last year. **********The General Motors Corporation's sales of North American-made vehicles dropped 18.1 percent in late June. The Ford Motor Company's sales fell 19.1 percent, while the Chrysler Corporation's sales rose 1.4 percent. **********For the entire month, sales of cars and light trucks, both domestic and imported, fell 6.5 percent from June 1990. The annual selling rate for the month was 6.6 million. There were 25 selling days in June, compared with 26 in June 1990. **********Japanese auto makers continued to shift production to North American factories. (Cars and trucks produced in the United States, Canada and Mexico are all considered domestically made.) In late June, the Honda Motor Company's sales of domestic vehicles rose 12.5 percent, the Toyota Motor Corporation's sales rose 13.6 percent and the Nissan Motor Company's sales rose 5.4 percent. **********Auto-industry and Wall Street analysts noted that results in the last six 10-day sales periods had markedly improved from the bleak results of winter and early spring. **********"The market wasn't as dreadful as in the first quarter," said Robert L. Rewey, a Ford vice president for sales. "Now the bad news: apparently the sales recovery is going to be more gradual than we'd like." **********Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, said, "The fact the industry has put together two months of solid numbers lends credence to the idea that the market is on the way back up." **********Because auto makers have been building relatively few vehicles and maintaining fairly slim inventories, the recent sales strength has immediately resulted in more bullish production schedules for the coming months. Earlier this week, Ward's Automotive Reports said North American auto makers would produce 57,000 additional cars and light trucks in the third quarter. **********Among the Big Three, it was a relatively strong month for G.M. and Chrysler, each of which gained market share, and a weak one for Ford, which lost share. **********Industry analysts said G.M.'s Chevrolet division sold aggressively to rental fleets during the month, while Ford passed up fleet sales, which typically provide little profit. Chrysler's market share was bolstered by strong light-truck sales, particularly of the company's mini-vans, the Dodge Dakota pickup and the Jeep Wrangler and Cherokee models. **********Despite declining sales of import models, Japanese auto makers continued to offer large sales incentives.  Three's Car Share Dips **********The Big Three's share of the car market, imported and domestic, dropped to 62.3 percent in June from 63.1 percent a year ago. At the same time, the Japanese producers increased their share to 29.2 percent, from 27.2 percent last year. Non-Japanese importers, hurt by big declines for European luxury cars, dropped to 8.5 percent of the car market, from 9.7 percent last year. **********In light trucks, which include mini-vans, utility vehicles and pickup trucks, the Big Three makers were able to gain some market share, to 86.7 percent in June from 85.8 percent last year. Japanese producers, meanwhile, dropped to 12.6 percent of the market, from 13.4 percent a year earlier. Non-Japanese importers fell to six-tenths of a percent, from eight-tenths of a percent a year ago. **********Over all, the Big Three's share of the total vehicle market fell slightly, to 70.3 percent, from 70.5 percent last year, while the share of Japanese producers rose to 23.8 percent from 22.7. The share of non-Japanese importers dropped to 5.9 percent from 6.8. A share point equals the sale of about 130,000 vehicles annually.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/18/world.main_headline: YELTSIN'S DECREES SEEK FULL CHARGE OF RUSSIAN ASSETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/18/world.print_headline: YELTSIN'S DECREES SEEK FULL CHARGE OF RUSSIAN ASSETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/18/world.body_text: **********With a burst of new decrees issued over the weekend, Boris N. Yeltsin has moved to assert the Russian republic's dominance over the foundering Soviet economy, proclaiming control over Russia's dwindling reserves of oil, gold and other precious metals and opening its doors to foreign trade. **********The package of new measures, officially announced early today, would lift most controls over imports, exports and foreign-currency transactions on Russian territory and allow the value of the ruble -- now fixed by the Soviet central bank though widely traded on the black market -- to float according to market rates, starting Jan. 1. **********The floating of the ruble would sharply reduce its value, but would greatly improve the climate for foreign investment by allowing investors to take their profits in cash instead of having to resort to cumbersome barter arrangements. Undercutting Union Accord **********With his latest flurry of decrees, Mr. Yeltsin appears to be undercutting a union economic agreement signed early this month by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the leaders of 9 of the 12 remaining Soviet republics. **********The agreement recognized individual republics' sovereignty over their own economic output, but it provided for a single currency administered by a Soviet central bank. **********Efforts to coordinate policy continue to be hampered by unilateral decisions, as each of the republics stakes out turf and takes measures to assure its own survival. Since the failed coup attempt against Mr. Gorbachev in August, Mr. Yeltsin has steadily sought to expand the power of his giant republic, filling the vacuum created by the disintegration of Soviet state authority and the erosion of Mr. Gorbachev's influence. **********With his decrees -- issued in the name of the Russian republic's government, which under his current special powers is effectively under his personal control -- Mr. Yeltsin again showed his determination to drive the pace of economic reform not only in Russia but also beyond its borders. **********But the Russian leader's ability to dictate change has come under question in recent weeks, as his decrees, like those of Mr. Gorbachev, are swallowed up in the growing economic and political confusion. **********Last week, for instance, his Parliament overruled his effort to impose emergency rule in a troubled Muslim region, Chechen-Ingushetia, forcing him back to the negotiating table with Chechen separatists. **********The new package of decrees and government resolutions made no mention of Mr. Yeltsin's proposal last month to lift controls on consumer prices. This sharply increased the cost of most goods, from food to computers, as Russians rushed to protect themselves from expected hyperinflation. **********The Russian President, however, seemed to anticipate the social strains of his economic policy. Among other steps, he raised minimum salaries to 200 rubles a month -- the average salary is 350 rubles a month -- and pay for certain state employees 90 percent. Oil and Convertible Currency **********Russia's announcement that it would liberalize the rules governing foreign trade came just after Ivan S. Silayev, head of the interim Soviet economic council, moved to lift a number of restrictions on foreign trade across the Soviet Union. **********But Mr. Yeltsin's measures, which would allow all registered Russian companies to engage in foreign trade and Russian citizens to hold hard-currency bank accounts, go further. **********Russia controls 90 percent of Soviet oil production. Odfficials of the republic, worried about meeting the needs of their people as winter approaches, are now calling for a review of all existing oil-export licenses, and have frozen the granting of any new ones until Dec. 1. **********The measure would impose quotas on all exports beyond Russian borders. The production of oil, one of the links that still binds the economies of the republics, has been steadily falling. The resolution calls for strict controls over illegal bartering of oil for other products, arrangements that have become commonplace as oil-producing regions in Russia search for contracts to supply their people with desperately needed goods. **********According to the newspaper Kommersant, Russian authorities are also concerned about mounting prices paid for Russian oil on the Moscow Oil Exchange. This is seen as an attempt by other republics, in particular the former Baltic republics and the Ukraine, to unload unwanted rubles before issuing their own currencies. **********Mr. Yeltsin this weekend also carried out a long-threatened move to wrest control over gold, diamonds and other precious metals mined in Russia from the Soviet authorities. He declared that the production, processing, sale and storage of these metals would fall under Russian jurisdiction, with local producers to be paid 25 percent of their value in hard currency. **********The status of Soviet gold -- of which 67 percent comes from Russia -- has become a hot political topic in recent days, after reports that the country's supplies have been steadily depleted by Soviet officials in their anxious search for foreign currency reserves. Grigory A. Yavlinsky, an economic adviser to Mr. Gorbachev, recently announced that Soviet gold reserves had shrunk to 240 tons, from 2,050 tons in 1953. **********In a newspaper interview Friday, Aleksandr Orlov, who heads an audit commission of the Soviet Parliament, asserted that there were no gold reserves left in the Soviet central bank. Tales of Vanishing Gold **********"Our specialists have analyzed the gold situation," Mr. Orlov said, "and come to the conclusion that the Soviet state bank is bankrupt." **********The newspaper Izvestia, following the trail of Soviet gold, last week presented documentary evidence that five tons of "hard-currency freight" -- gold and platinum -- had been taken out of the country in the last six weeks. **********There was no clear answer available on the gold question, with various officials contradicting each other and Soviet credibility facing increasing doubt in world markets. A loss of gold reserves would reinforce doubts about Moscow's ability to service its $68 billion foreign debt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/world.main_headline: POLES VOTE TODAY IN ANXIOUS MOOD
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/world.print_headline: POLES VOTE TODAY IN ANXIOUS MOOD
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/world.body_text: **********More than two years after the Solidarity movement triumphantly toppled the Communist Government, Poland holds its first fully free parliamentary elections on Sunday against a backdrop of social unrest and disillusionment. **********The exhilaration of June 1989, when Poland became the first Eastern European nation to push out Communism, has been supplanted by rising anger and anxiety over the rigors of the nation's pioneering economic reforms. **********More than 100 parties are contesting seats in a political free-for-all that began with President Lech Walesa's decision last year to cleave the Solidarity movement into several parties. Public opinion polls predict that Poland's new proportional election rules will produce a fragmented Parliament elected with a turnout expected to fall below 50 percent. **********While comparable with elections in Western European nations, the expected turnout worries political leaders.  European Standard Unmet **********"We are having democratic and free and fair elections, with a European level of participation, but we cannot cope with such a European standard," said Bronislaw Geremek, a leader of the Democratic Union who was one of Solidarity's top strategists in the 1980's. **********"For our reforms, we need social involvement," he said. "That was our capital at the beginning of this process. Since we couldn't obtain what the East Germans obtained, that means money, our capital was human. **********"The question, now that we are in the second stage of this economic transformation, is whether we can count on this capital. Will there be a minimum of confidence, a minimum of hope?" **********Political leaders agree that election results will set the course for this country's transition to a free-market economy and democratic politics. **********Among the first tasks facing the new government will be whether to continue the "shock therapy" reforms that have brought Poland a booming private sector but sharp rises in unemployment. Many of the 7,600 candidates for 560 seats have called for significant loosening of the existing tight monetary policies. Some also called for delays or revisions in the privatization of major state-run enterprises scheduled to begin shortly. Looking for Coalition **********On Friday, Mr. Geremek met with other leaders of the Democratic Union trying to figure out how a governing coalition could be assembled from the jigsaw puzzle of parties. **********The Union, the center-left party to emerge from Solidarity, includes many of the intellectuals from the anti-Communist movement and is led by Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the former Prime Minister who finished third in the presidential election last December that was won by Mr. Walesa. Recent nationwide polls suggest that Union will finish first, with anywhere from 15 to 25 percent of the vote. **********But as Mr. Geremek acknowledged, the process of building a majority is likely to be complicated by a wide spectrum of parties representing competing interests, from the farmers to the new urban middle class to the Solidarity trade union. **********The current Prime Minister, Jan Krzysztof Bielecki, heads the Liberal Congress, which preaches doctrinaire devotion to free-market principles. Mr. Bielecki has expressed willingness to join the Democratic Union and continue the existing economic policies. The Parties' Positions **********On the other hand, the more rightward leaning party of former Solidarity figures, the Center Alliance, has unequivocally ruled out cooperation with the Democratic Union, and favors an extensive easing of Poland's tight monetary policies. Parties hoping to appeal to the 30 percent of Poles who work as farmers have said they would join any party willing to accept their budget-busting plans for guaranteed farm prices. The Solidarity union, which favors major modifications in the economic plan, is also running a slate of candidates and is expected to fare well in major industrial areas. **********With all of the confusion and dissatisfaction, there have been fears among some analysts that the former Communists might fare well, as they did in the recent Bulgarian elections. **********Aleksander Kwasniewski, a leader of the Social Democratic Party, predicted in an interview that his party would score between 7 and 10 percent and said his party stood ready to join virtually any coalition. In fact, every major party has already ruled out cooperation with the Social Democrats, which would probably leave Mr. Kwasniewski in the position of what he terms "responsible opposition." **********If the next government continues the free-market reforms along current lines, the resulting bankruptcies and layoffs could make the Social Democrats' election calls for more social spending, more job creation and more production at state-enterprises even more popular. **********Campaigning in these elections was mostly done retail, with candidates trudging from town to town meeting small numbers of voters in movie theaters and local schools. Every night at 10 P.M., an hour was set aside on national television for campaign commercials. The time was divided equally among all parties, and national surveys showed that most people responded to the parade of politicians by switching off their set or changing the channel. **********A week ago, the Roman Catholic Church injected an unpredictable element into the races. A letter from the nation's bishops endorsing candidates who espouse Christian principles and oppose abortion was read out at every Mass. Polls taken before the bishops' letter showed the five self-proclaimed Catholic parties running well behind. But there was speculation that such new groups as the Committee for Catholic Action might benefit from the last-minute endorsement. **********Poland, the first nation in Eastern Europe to oust Communism, is paradoxically the last to dismantle the remnants of the old system. In 1989, after months of talks between Solidarity and the regime, the Communists agreed to hold parliamentary elections in which all of the 100 seats in the Senate and 35 percent of the places in the Sejm, or lower house, would be freely elected. The remaining 65 percent of the seats, and control of the presidency, military and the police, were to be reserved for the Communists and their allies. **********In the ensuing election in June of 1989, Solidarity swept nearly every contested seat and cobbled together a coalition that brought Mr. Mazowiecki to power. Although seen at the time as a stunning success, the Polish victory was soon eclipsed by the fall of Berlin wall and collapse of Communism through the Eastern bloc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/world.main_headline: Mood in Beirut's Southern Suburbs Is Still Defiant
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/world.print_headline: Mood in Beirut's Southern Suburbs Is Still Defiant
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/08/world.body_text: **********Even though the Syrian-backed Government has moved forcefully in recent months to disarm Lebanon's militia fighters, the mood remains defiant here in Beirut's southern suburbs, the belt of poverty surrounding the southern and eastern fringes of the capital. **********This overpopulated area, home to thousands of refugees driven north by Israeli air strikes and incursions, is the main stronghold of the Iranian-backed Shiite Muslim fundamentalist group calling itself the Party of God. Somewhere deep inside the maze of endless alleys and intertwining roads, Shiite kidnappers affiliated with the Party of God are believed to hold some or all of the 10 Western hostages, whose freedom diplomats believe may be near as a result of stepped-up diplomacy. **********Although the Syrian Army ordered the disarming of this quarter of the capital earlier this year, guns can still be seen carelessly hidden under the dark green combat fatigues worn by most males over the age of 12. **********"The West considers us terrorists, while at home we are viewed as reactionaries," said a Party of God official here who asked to be identified only by his nom de guerre, Haj Abed. "We are simple people trying to push oppression imposed on us from every corner of the world. Our only weapon is a strong belief in Islam." **********"When one feels he is going to be squashed anyway, he might as well take his enemies with him," he said. **********The defiant tone is reflected by a huge graffiti drawing on a building here showing a hand crushing American and Israeli flags and reaching out for Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem, one of Islam's holiest shrines. **********On both sides of the main Beir el Abed street, there are layers upon layers of rubble from long years of sectarian fighting in Lebanon's civil war. **********Shacks and fallen houses jam the four-square-mile stretch, where more than 800,000 people live. Narrow dusty roads snake through garbage piles, sandbags and rows of small shops. **********Since 1973, families of more than 10 have been living here in single-bedroom apartments without running water, electricity or plumbing. They have provided cheap labor during peacetime, but have fueled the country's civil strife with thousands of war-hardened militiamen. **********Dozens of Party of God security men in civilian clothes keep a tight watch on everyone who enters the suburbs. **********"We are the only Lebanese group that is constantly tailed by almost all of the world's secret services," Haj Abed said. "But thank God, so far no one was able to pierce our security or infiltrate our ranks." **********The Government's plan to end lawlessness and militia rule was jeopardized by recent Party of God attacks against Israeli patrols in southern Lebanon, and by the brief kidnapping in Beirut of a French medical worker after the first of two Western hostages were released last month. **********Angered by the organization's defiance, Lebanese officials were quoted as saying Lebanese Army troops were being prepared to thrust into the slums and regain control. **********But Sheik Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah, the overall leader of the Lebanese Muslim fundamentalists, dismissed the remarks at a recent prayer meeting, saying: "We are Lebanese citizens, and our right to exercise freedom of expression is protected by law. We are a political necessity, not only to Lebanon, Syria and Iran, but to the United States itself."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/world.main_headline: Prices Already Soaring in Soviet Shops
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/world.print_headline: Prices Already Soaring in Soviet Shops
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/world.body_text: **********Even before the enactment of a new plan for sharp price rises, the cost of food and other necessities are booming upward along with the anxiety level in this battered capital city. **********Chronic shortages of the most basic foods -- sugar and eggs, and in some neighborhoods even bread -- are proving extremely worrisome as Russian consumers attempt to adjust to the announcement by Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian federated republic, who said this week that there is no alternative to a painful plunge into free marketry in which most state subsidies must be ended. **********"As we say, Russians are made for suffering," Lyudmila Belosova said unhappily, summarizing the mood in a crowded Moscow store where, after days of empty shelves, an unexpected delivery of sausage stirred a brief consumer frenzy this afternoon.  'Talk About Food' **********"I long ago stopped smiling," said Miss Belosova, a 34-year-old photo shop clerk. "I would like to go to a movie or the theater some time with friends, but instead we meet at night and all we can do is talk about food. I'm shamed by what is happening. I don't live -- I exist." **********There has been no shortage of debate, confusion and anxiety since Mr. Yeltsin called Monday for people to face up to a hard year of price rises and shrunken purchasing power that he estimated would allow the government to get a foothold on the free-market next fall. **********He followed that up today by discussing one of the difficult tasks required by his strategy, the possible creation of a separate central bank for the Russian federated republic. If it proves necessary, he said it would be done by appropriating resources from Gosbank, the national bank of the Soviet Union, which represents the central economic monopoly Mr. Yeltsin is committed to undoing.  Gold and Hard Currency **********"This includes everything -- the gold reserves, the hard currency, and so on," Mr. Yeltsin was quoted by the Interfax news agency as telling a group of city officials. **********In his speech Monday, Mr. Yeltsin emphasized that a new centralized banking reserve system based on a single currency controlled by the republics was preferable for the world market. Should separate republics establish their own currencies and banking practices, he said, the alternative would be for Russia to create its own bank and currency. **********"We can not be a party to the community and at the same time give the control of" cash and credit to "to somebody else," he was reported elaborating today. Mr. Yeltsin's aides stressed that he was raising the problem with the hope of reaching an orderly understanding with Gosbank officials.  Support of Central Ministries **********In his Monday speech, the Russian leader also said the Russian republic would end its majority-share financial support of unneeded central ministries.  The effect in the capital has bordered on bureacratic panic. Estimates are that this will mean that tens of thousands of Muscovites will lose their jobs by the end of the year. The newspaper Izvestia reported that 50,000 could be out of work in redundant bureacracies. **********Moscow shoppers say their struggle is worsening in such areas as de facto rationing of a large number of goods ranging gasoline, for which drivers lately face unexplained limits of 40 liters per purchase after waiting in line for an hour, to butter, for which the store counter limit is 300 grams per shopper. **********There were scenes of increased pushing and shoving in the city today as skimpy supplies of milk showed up in some neighborhoods. Shoppers said the lines were never longer and tempers never so short in a populace noted for forbearance. **********For officially rationed items such as sugar, shoppers with the necessary ration coupons have been waiting days for a minimum purchase, forming elaborate waiting lines in which each individual has his place in the order written into the palm of her or his hand, to be verified the following dawn when the line reforms.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/20/world.main_headline: SOME KURDS IN IRAN RETURNING TO IRAQ
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/20/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; SOME KURDS IN IRAN RETURNING TO IRAQ
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/20/world.body_text: **********Riddled with dysentery and typhoid after days of foul and fruitless waiting to enter Iran, some Kurdish refugees at this checkpoint on the Iran-Iraq border today abandoned their flight from Saddam Hussein's army and began heading back into Iraq. **********They said they would walk 11 miles to Halabja, a Kurdish stronghold twice destroyed by Mr. Hussein's army and the scene of an infamous 1988 massacre in which 5,000 or more civilians died from mustard gas and cyanide. **********Kurds at the border today said that about 1,000 refugee families had already gathered in the 100 buildings still standing in Halabja, but that could not be independently verified. 20-Mile-Long Exodus **********That any Kurds would consider returning to Iraq underscores the increasing desperation along this high, twisting mountain road, where scores of thousands are pressing the Iranian border in a line of cars and pedestrians that extends nearly 20 miles. **********But many refugees are concluding that the risks of remaining here outweigh the risks of incurring Iraq's wrath. And despite an all-out effort by the Red Crescent and Iran's military, disease and hunger were beginning today to gain the upper hand in some areas nearby. **********The Kurds said the rubble-strewn town of Halabja lacks sanitation and harbors disease, but seems safe for the moment from Iraqi troops. An Iranian Government official in Shushami today said that Iraqi troops were 20 air miles away and still posed a threat. **********"We will go to Halabja. There is no Saddam there," said a Kurdish exile who calls himself Ismail said as he stood only 100 yards from the border. **********"They have no place here -- no food, no medicine," a doctor at a frontier station said of the refugees. "So they are going back to Halabja and Sirwan," a tiny village three miles from the Iranian border. **********Iran controls not only its own territory, but also effectively occupies a nearly four-mile stretch of Iraqi territory that serves as a no man's land between the two countries. Iranian helicopters and trucks have been distributing food and medicine in that area and allowing the sick to cross the border to visit the medical station. Menace of Impure Water **********Nevertheless, dysentery and other diarrhea-related illnesses have been epidemic because of a lack of sanitation and a shortage of clean water. Mountain breezes that were clear during a visit to this camp on Monday are now foul with the stench of human waste after three days of heavy rain. **********The one doctor at the border medical station, himself a Kurdish refugee named Azar, said the installation had run out of anti-diarrhea tablets and antibiotics and was almost out of baby formula and sugar-saline solution for infants dehydrated by diarrhea. **********The doctor added that typhoid had begun to break out among refugees still in Iraq, but that he had no drugs with which to treat it.  German Assistance Begins **********As he spoke, a team of German military doctors arrived to assess the area's needs and to plan a mobile hospital -- the first sign of international help, the doctor indicated, since he began work at the station a week ago. **********German officials said tonight that no help could be sent to the region until Monday at the earliest. **********Asked how many people had died at the medical station at Shushami, the doctor replied: "They don't reach here. They die in the mountains." He later said he had learned of or seen 500 to 1,000 deaths since coming to the station a week ago. **********Refugees, whose claims are often exaggerated, said the number of deaths among Kurds deep in Iraq is far higher and that 200 are dead in Halabja alone. **********In recent weeks, the Kurdish refugees have been allowed to cross freely over this mountain road into Iran. Lately, however, the flow of Kurds has been reduced to a trickle, and there are rumors that the border will close entirely. **********The reasons are not clear. An Iranian Government official here said today that the military was deliberately curbing the entry of more Kurds into the province. "The question is not about room, it is about security," the official said. "We don't know if these people are Iraqi intelligence agents or mujahedeen," members of an Iranian opposition army based in Iraq. **********But the region is also overflowing with refugees, and resources are strained. Today, Iranian earthmovers were frantically scraping bare the mountain valley around Shushami, seeking to level areas for new tent cities. The Government says that more than 500,000 Kurds have already been admitted to this area, and food is said to be running short. A Plea to 'Mr. Bush' **********Today, thousands of Kurds huddled with their few possessions along stretches of mountain roads. Many, especially children, were visibly ill. Others approached foreign visitors with what quickly became a daylong refrain: "In markets, in stores, we hang pictures of Mr. Bush," a middle-aged Kurd said. "We all love Mr. Bush. Why doesn't Mr. Bush help us?" **********At a vast refugee encampment at Do Ab, eight miles from Iraq, sanitation and health conditions were deteriorating, refugees and doctors said. **********A doctor at one of the encampment's four medical stations said pneumonia, dysentery and infant diarrhea had become serious problems, as had kidney ailments. Two of the three doctors at the station were themselves ill, and one had been flown back to Teheran for treatment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/09/world.body_text: **********Shahpur Bakhtiar, an ex-Prime Minister who has lived in exile since 1979, was found slain outside Paris. Some experts blamed terrorists who oppose Iran's efforts to mend ties with the West. Page A6.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/busin.main_headline: Careers; Demand Up In Medical Technology
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/busin.print_headline: Careers; Demand Up In Medical Technology
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/busin.body_text: **********HOSPITAL industry executives say there are thousands of job openings across the country for technologists in medical imaging and radiation therapy. "We are desperately in need of people," said Howard W. Schwartz, senior administrative director of radiology at the University of Minnesota Hospital and Clinic in Minneapolis. **********The supply of trained people has not kept up with the explosion in the use of medical technology, notably images generated by computerized X-ray scanners, magnetic resonance imaging and ultrasound devices, as well as radiation treatment for cancer patients. **********The Labor Department forecasts continued strong demand: At least 70,000 more jobs for radiolologic technologists and technicians will be created by the end of the 1990's. **********Despite the recession and cutbacks in New York health-care budgets, there are an estimated 1,000 unfilled jobs for radiologic technicians in the state, said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, operator of the New York Health Careers Center, which provides information about wages, job opportunities, educational requirements and scholarships in imaging, as well as other hospital job openings. **********Mr. Raske said that in New York City radiologic technologists earn $26,000 to $28,000 a year. Diagnostic medical sonographers, who work with ultrasound, make $31,500, and radiation-therapy technologists, who work mainly with cancer patients, $36,000. **********He said most hospitals were raising wages in these specialties by 10 percent annually to compete with higher offers from a rapidly growing number of independent imaging centers. James N. Heuerman, a partner at Korn/Ferry International, a health- care management recruiter, said technologists at some imaging centers earned $50,000 to $60,000 a year. **********Nationally, the average pay scales are several thousand dollars lower than in New York, where living costs are high. Mr. Schwartz said that a Minneapolis ultrasound technician, for example, might earn $24,000 to $25,000, plus benefits. The American Medical Association publishes wage and school information in an annual Allied Health Education Directory. **********Applicants for imaging jobs must have certificates or associate degrees from a one- or two-year training program. Some earn four-year college degrees. To be admitted to the training, students must have a high school diploma, or its equivalent, with classes in mathematics and science. **********"It is a tremendous opportunity," said Barbara Bloom Kreml, director of the human resources department at the American Hospital Association. "They have the potential of studying for two years and coming out and making a good salary." **********There were 672 radiography training programs in community colleges and hospitals last year, and most could have admitted more students. "Student spaces are going begging," Ms. Kreml said. **********Mr. Schwartz said hospitals and radiologists became alarmed when the Labor Department predicted that the number of imaging jobs would increase by 66 percent between 1988 and 2000. "We had to do something," he added, because the supply of candidates was growing much more slowly. Indeed, the number of high school graduates was shrinking, and under budget constraints many schools curtailed career-counseling programs. **********Physicians' professional groups, administrators and licensing boards in radiology, nuclear medicine, ultrasound and radiation therapy organized a consortium, the Summit on Manpower, to drum up interest in the school programs and job opportunities. The group sponsored public service radio and television announcements and is working on videotapes and high school science workbooks to describe the field. **********The consortium also hopes to improve the status of imaging technicians in hospitals, which provide 90 percent of the jobs. "We used to call these jobs X-ray technicians," Ms. Kreml said. "Now they want to call them radiologic scientists." Mr. Schwartz said that another problem was to answer concerns about exposure to AIDS and other diseases in hospital work. **********Some hospitals are broadening the possibilities for advancement, for example, by raising the pay of employees who learn to operate both X-ray and magnetic resonance imaging scanners. But Mr. Heuerman, the management recruiter, said the technicians, unless they also studied business administration, only rarely moved up into supervisory jobs. **********Students and job counselors can call hospital personnel departments or contact the New York Health Careers Center, 555 West 57th Street, 15th floor, New York, N.Y. 10019, telephone (800) 365-1633, and the Summit on Manpower, 1825 K Street NW, Suite 210, Washington, D.C. 20006, telephone (800) 432-3247. The Allied Health Education Directory may be ordered from the American Medical Association, P.O. Box 2964, Milwaukee, Wis, 53201-2964.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/22/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; Saudis Try to Cope With Too Few Masks and Too Little Information
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/22/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; Saudis Try to Cope With Too Few Masks and Too Little Information
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/22/world.body_text: **********Handguns have become one of the hottest items on the black market. **********Saudis are not officially permitted to own them. But a Kalashnikov rifle now goes for 11,000 Saudi riyals, or about $2,900, and one Saudi recently paid $1,200 for a tiny revolver, which he called a "precaution" against possible panic and rioting by foreigners from poor countries working here. **********While most people are reaching for gas masks rather than guns, the boom in small arms reflects the anxiety so many people feel about the pyrotechnical display of exploding Scud and Patriot missiles that kept residents of the capital awake throughout the night. **********Most Saudis, however, are handling the crisis with aplomb. Unlike many foreigners, who huddled in shelters in the luxury hotels, hundreds of Saudis could not resist watching the action from their balconies and gardens. **********"It was sensational," said Abdullah Dabbagh, Secretary General of the Saudi Chamber of Commerce. "I saw one missile after another whooshing over my head. You don't see that everyday." 'Our First Major Crisis' **********The relative Saudi sang-froid is even more remarkable considering that the kingdom has not known strife of this magnitude since its unification in 1932. **********"This is really our first major crisis," Mr. Dabbagh said. "We're learning how to manage it. And we're not doing a bad job." **********But diplomats and even Saudis cite two distinct failures in crisis management -- the Government's approach to news, particularly bad news, and a lack of gas masks. **********There is in the kingdom, as the warden in the film "Cool Hand Luke" put it, a certain "failure to communicate" -- both before and after air raids. On Sunday night, for example, Saudi television did not interrupt its programming to announce the first air raid until after the all-clear siren had sounded. And there was no prompt Saudi announcement on television of what had hit the city or of casualties and damage after the Scud attack. A City of Rumors **********As a result, Riyadh was a city of rumors today, with diplomats and Saudis exchanging anecdotes about what they saw and what politically connected friends told them. **********By the day's end, a consensus on this informal grapevine had developed: despite official pronouncements, prominent people in this city were saying that one of the four incoming Scuds had been damaged, but had struck the ground and exploded, along with pieces of a Patriot that had failed to self-destruct. Some 17 people were said to have been wounded. Twenty-four hours after the attack, the Ministry of Interior finally announced that 12 people had been wounded by unspecified "debris" that left a crater 15 to 20 feet wide in the ground and shattered windows in a nearby building. **********The lack of reliable information has troubled Saudis and foreigners alike. "This is the major cause of panic," Rajib Nair, an Indian store manager in downtown Riaydh said. Gas Masks Not Delivered **********As for the gas masks, the Saudi Defense Ministry recently ordered 700,000 of them, but because Saudi airspace has been under military restrictions, many have not arrived. The Government did not start issuing masks to residents of Riyadh until last Wednesday. Saudis and foreigners had to get in long lines at banks to pay $37.50 for a receipt entitling them to a mask. But distribution centers quickly ran out, leaving hundreds of angry customers. **********Word spread quickly on Sunday night that one center had gotten a new shipment. "It was worse than Bloomingdale's on a sale day," a Westernized Saudi said. **********Officials at the Defense Ministry have masks, but several complained that their families do not. Others in need include nurses and health workers at Riyadh Central Hospital's Maternity and Children's Hospital. Most are Indian or Philippine. **********Mr. Nair, whose wife works at the hospital, said that during the air raid, doctors ordered nurses into a safe room and told them they would look after the wards. The doctors, at least, had masks. Fatigue and Skepticism **********Fatigue is perhaps the most difficult effect of the missile war, far more debilitating than excitement or fear. Hardly anyone has gotten much sleep. As a result, the normally chaotic driving patterns here are even more so. And the Saudi post-lunch siesta has been extended. **********Many Saudis have sent their families north and west to family villages for safety, but until recently few had thought they would have to leave. The United States had assured the Saudis that Scud missiles could not reach Riyadh. Saudis are now more skeptical of American assurances. **********And they take issue with the way the Western press often portrays them. "Sometimes we really can't win," Abdulaziz Fahad, a lawyer, said. "If we act calmly, we're fatalistic. If we panic, we're excitable Arabs."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Torture; Freed Kuwaitis Tell of Iraqi Abuse Including Some Cases of Torture
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Torture; Freed Kuwaitis Tell of Iraqi Abuse Including Some Cases of Torture
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/world.body_text: **********On the third floor of a gutted mansion, a Kuwaiti Army major slowly pushed open a door with his foot to what was once a laundry room. It had been converted by the Iraqis, he said, into a torture chamber. **********In one corner were metal box springs, raised off the floor by chairs. Next to the springs was a crude brown box with bare electrical wires protruding from black cords. **********"They put the prisoners on the springs, poured water over them and then applied the current," said the Kuwaiti Army officer, Maj. Jamal al-Hassan, who was a leader in the underground during the occupation. "If they were not happy with the answers, they turned up the voltage."  Accounts of Torture **********Kuwaitis who were picked up by the Iraqi secret police had their own stories to tell. **********"They beat me, did not let me sleep and made me sit naked on a bottle of hot sauce," said 21-year-old Faisal al-Anizi. "This went on for three days in what used to be the reform school." **********Others tell of being rubbed down with sandpaper, having their heads thrust into cold water and being hung by their hands from a hook. **********When an American correspondent arrived in Kuwait City on Tuesday, ahead of entering allied troops, he found Kuwaitis who were eager to tell the world that Saddam Hussein brought more to Kuwait than Iraqi license plates and innumerable self-portraits. Mr. Hussein had also brought the techniques of control that have kept his authoritarian Government in power. **********Members of the Kuwaiti underground, acting on information provided by people who said they were taken and tortured by the Iraqi secret police, have identified various places where Kuwaitis were questioned, beaten and tortured. **********A visitor is overwhelmed by reports that hundreds, perhaps thousands of young men were taken by the Iraqis, many in the final hours before the Iraqi forces left the city on Monday. Their parents and friends fear that they may not reappear. **********"A lot of people have disappeared in Iraq and never been seen since," said Raid al-Moussa. "My son is missing, and I worry he may never come back." **********Several of the places that people here suspected of being torture centers, such as those believed to have been set up in the Meridien Hotel and the central police station, were burned by departing Iraqi troops. **********In that police station, one room had been set ablaze. **********Today, the remains of the furniture, charred among blackened metal box springs, were still smoking. Destroying the Evidence **********"This was one of the central rooms," said Ahmed Othman, a Kuwaiti underground fighter, who appeared after the Iraqis left. Standing in front of the blackened walls with a .38-caliber pistol tucked into the waist of his gray sweatsuit, he said: "They tried to destroy as much evidence as possible before they left." **********The Kuwaitis said they also believe that women were held prisoner and tortured in the Meridien Hotel, which was shelled by a tank and burned before Iraqi troops made a hasty retreat from the city. **********Kuwaitis who fought against the Iraqis, wearing red armbands as they patrol roadblocks and ferret out Iraqi soldiers who remain hidden in the city, are also going through houses confiscated by Iraqi troops. **********"They used these private homes to carry out their worst interrogations and torture," Mr. Othman said. Disappearance of Young Men **********One of the subjects frequently raised with the American correspondent, was the disappearances of Kuwaitis, mostly young men, after being picked up by the Iraqi police. **********In a few cases, families with money were told that their loved ones would be returned for ransoms. **********"The Iraqis came and told me they had my brother," said Abdul Hamid, a retired civil aviation official. **********"They said we could have him back for 5,000 Iraqi dinar and a car. We paid them and he came back." **********But others said they had spent fruitless hours going to and from police stations to seek information. Finally, the Grim News **********A few said the Iraqis finally, after much pleading, informed them that their relatives were dead. **********"After three months of going nearly every week to the Iraqi police, they told us that my cousin had died in Iraq," a woman said. She asked that her name not be used since family members abroad did not know of her cousin's death. **********"We do not know how he died and we never received his body," she said. **********Some Kuwaitis said that Palestinians, foreign workers in Kuwait, had aided the Iraqi police after the invasion in August. **********"The Iraqis gave arms to some Palestinians," Major Hassan said. "These Palestinians, many of whom had lived here for a long time, were very useful to the Iraqis. They knew where people lived and who was influential. We have not found any of these Palestinians. They may have left with the soldiers." Hospital Atrocity Stories Wrong **********Some of the atrocities that had been reported, such as the killing of infants in the main hospitals shortly after the invasion, are untrue or have been exaggerated, Kuwaitis said. **********Hospital officials, for instance, said that stories circulated about the killing of 300 children were incorrect. **********Rumors circulated around Kuwait City in the immediate hours after the Iraqi withdrawal about young girls being hung with wire until they were dead and children being shot, but none of these stories could be substantiated today. **********There is increasing evidence, however, that those Kuwaitis considered opponents of the Iraqi occupation were selected for very rough treatment. Late-Night Visits **********Families suspected of aiding the opposition movement or having members in the underground say they were frequently visited during the night by Iraqi policemen. **********"The Iraqis burst into my house late at night," said Taiba al-Ayar. "They flipped over our beds and dragged my son-in-law away in his pajamas. He has not returned." **********"Just after the invasion, the members in my resistance section had five satellite phones," Mr. Othman said. "After a few weeks, those members who had the phones were all taken by the Iraqis. I began to sleep in a different place every night and carried a gun in case they came for me."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/09/world.main_headline: Soviet Georgia Chief, In Quest of Freedom, Sees Only Enemies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/09/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; Soviet Georgia Chief, In Quest of Freedom, Sees Only Enemies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/09/world.body_text: **********For the beleaguered and increasingly insecure leader of Soviet Georgia, who has struggled for decades to get the Soviet Union and the world to recognize the independence of his fiercely proud republic in the Caucasus Mountains, the victory in Moscow of the forces of democracy after last month's failed coup was nothing to cheer about. **********President Zviad K. Gamsakhurdia says he wants nothing to do with the Soviet Union any more, whether it is a democracy or a dictatorship. All he wants is real autonomy for Georgia, which he rules like a freely elected despot, preoccupied with plots, real and imagined, to do him in and keep his land under Moscow's domination. **********Since Georgia declared independence on April 9, only Romania has recognized it, and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has ignored it. **********Mr. Gamsakhurdia, as if paralyzed, has let the Georgian economy go to ruin until the republic is free, and last week his government forbade the export of meat, milk, vegetables, building material and most other goods, all in acute shortage. **********His government's price controls and tax laws discourage private enterprise, seemingly a natural tendency for a land known over the centuries for its traders. Mr. Gamsakhurdia blames a Soviet "embargo" for the shortages, and said on Saturday that Georgia could not even begin to make economic progress until Moscow let it go its own way. **********The difficulties of this republic of five and a half million people seem to show that autonomy is hardly the end of trouble for the long-unwilling partners of the Soviet Union; independence for the Soviet republics also raises new problems. **********Mr. Gamsakhurdia's behavior has puzzled many former friends, even those who know that Georgia is the land of Medea and the birthplace of Stalin -- an old, querulous mountain country where intrigues are as gnarled and thick on the ground as the grapevines in people's backyards. **********On Saturday, speaking of plots against his leadership by Georgia's enemies in Moscow, Tbilisi and even in the United States, he said that his recently dismissed Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, the head of the national guard, and the leader of the opposition in the republic's Parliament had all betrayed him. **********He recently suspended publication of the most critical Georgian-language opposition newspapers, setting off nightly demonstrations in the streets of the capital calling for his resignation. And a small-scale civil war continues in the South Ossetian Autonomous Region north of Tbilisi, where separatists want to secede from Georgia and join a similar region just north of the Caucasus, in Russia.  All a Plot **********To Mr. Gamsakhurdia, all this is part of a conspiracy to thwart Georgian independence. **********"Moscow wants to create civil war here," he said Saturday, and he held little hope that things would change.
