"I believe Gorbachev continues this usual line against Georgia," he added. He said that Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian federated republic, had promised to consider recognition, but so far had done nothing. **********Anti-Georgian provocateurs in the United States are keeping Washington from extending diplomatic recognition, he said, and Moscow and its agents are waging a whispering campaign in the West: "Here is a fascist dictator, and the people are against him. You must not recognize Georgia." **********These hardly sound like the words of a man who was elected with 87 percent of the popular vote in May. Now, in early September, his power seems to be waning prematurely. **********Last Monday, a violent clash between demonstrators and special police units in Rustaveli Square, near the center of Tbilisi, raised fears that there might be a macabre replay of the events of April 9, 1989, when Soviet troops used entrenching tools, and allegedly poison gas, against demonstrators, killing 20 of them. **********This time it was Georgian versus Georgian as gunshots were fired, by policemen and perhaps also by demonstrators. Twenty people were wounded, four seriously. **********Protesters have been out in the streets every night since. But the police, instead of charging them with shields and nightsticks, have sealed off part of the area with buses drawn up in front of the pink stone neo-Classical government headquarters. Down a winding boulevard, demonstrators and onlookers ambled under trees, listening to recorded speeches demanding Mr. Gamsakhurdia's resignation and new elections. The Coup  Treading Carefully, And Getting Burned **********The 52-year-old President, dignified in a dark suit and a thin mustache, sounded irritated, chopping the air with impatient gestures. **********Surrounded by bodyguards and journeying back and forth from his home in the hills above Tbilisi in a cavalcade of armored black Mercedes limousines, Mr. Gamsakhurdia seems increasingly distant from his dissident past. **********The son of the pre-eminent writer of modern Georgia, Konstantin Gamsakhurdia, he was first jailed for nationalist activities in 1956, at the age of 17. He finished his last prison term in 1980, after three years behind bars for "anti-Soviet activity." **********His latest troubles have intensified since the failure of the coup in Moscow. **********By his own account and those of others, President Gamsakhurdia trod a tightrope during the revolt, agreeing to cause no trouble in Georgia and appealing to his people to remain calm, while calling on the world to show its support for the forces of democracy -- in Georgia and elsewhere. **********Defying an order by the coup leaders, he said, he also refused to dissolve his 15,000-member national guard, a group created in November from the ranks of Georgians who objected to service in the Soviet Army. **********Gen. Valery A. Patrikeyev, the Soviet troop commander of the Caucasus Military District, appeared on Georgian television during the coup and said his relationship with Mr. Gamsakhurdia was "excellent." Mr. Gamsakhurdia later carefully distanced himself from the putsch attempt, saying it had not been clear to him that it might not have been a charade. **********But his opponents seized upon the events and charged that he had been ambivalent. Last Monday's rally was called by Georgi Chanturia, the head of the National Democratic Party, one of a coalition of groups that boycotted Parliament elections last year and the presidential voting in May. **********"We wanted to expose his links with the coup leaders," Mr. Chanturia said in an interview, saying he had proof of the President's complicity. The proof turned out to be an assertion, made by the dismissed Prime Minister, Tengiz Sigua, that a Deputy Prime Minister "must have" discussed plans with the coup makers during a one-day trip to Moscow on Aug. 18, the Sunday the coup began. **********Before last Monday's rally began, Mr. Chanturia said, the President's commandos charged the crowd with batons, firing pistols into the air. A videotape of the incident was broadcast on Soviet television the next evening. Mr. Gamsakhurdia's officials say the police were attacked first, but the President said they should not have used their weapons in any case. **********On Wednesday, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet Foreign Minister and a Georgian, commented on the violence. He said on television that it was a direct result of Mr. Gamsakhurdia's refusal to talk with the opposition. **********People here remember Mr. Shevardnadze as their Interior Minister and Communist Party leader, the job he held in Tbilisi when Mr. Gamsakhurdia was being prosecuted for nationalist activities. Now, in the President's eyes, Mr. Shevardnadze is in league with those who want to bring him down. **********The violence also split the Georgian national guard, whose commanding officer, Tengiz Kitovani, broke with Mr. Gamsakhurdia and said the force would "resist any activity directed against the people." **********Mr. Gamsakhurdia said Saturday that he no longer recognized Mr. Kitovani as being in charge. Now he groups him among his enemies -- along with Mr. Sigua; his former Foreign Minister, Georgi Khoshtaria, dismissed in August for "wanting to make his own foreign policy," and Nodar Notadze, another longtime former comrade of the President's, who is now the leader of the opposition in Parliament. **********"He is very close with the armed opposition now," Mr. Gamsakhurdia said of his onetime colleague in the dissident movenment, "and he protects them in Parliament -- also now these criminals."  Home and Abroad  Little Recognition; Rebellion Aplenty **********At the empty and echoing Foreign Ministry, a former Communist Party school and agricultural institute up one of Tbilisi's steep hills, Deputy Foreign Minister Nodar Gabashvili complained about how difficult it was to get foreign nations to recognize Georgian independence. **********"The extra-parliamentary opposition wants the world to see Georgia as a Soviet colony, and not to recognize us until the Soviet Army is forced out and new general elections are called," he said. "Under our former Foreign Minister, our ministry didn't make much effort at counter-propaganda." **********Mr. Gabashvili said he hoped that the new minister, Murman Omanidze, would have better luck. Mr. Gamsakhurdia said the new Prime Minister, Vissarion Gugushvili, would meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Moscow on Monday to plead Georgia's case for recognition by the United States. **********"We have more democracy than in your countries," Mr. Gamsakhurdia told a group of Western correspondents. "Nobody can stop traffic in the streets in your country and make rallies, can they?" But, he added, "When you are in war, you cannot think of democracy. Now we are in war." **********The struggle in the South Ossetian Autonomous Region, which has been formally abolished by Mr. Gamsakhurdia, has taken perhaps a hundred lives so far this year, and sent 50,000 Ossetians fleeing north across the mountains. **********On Thursday, the government says, four Georgian partisans there were killed and a herd of sheep was stolen by the Ossetian rebels, who have vowed to continue the struggle for their own independence. The Soviet press agency Tass reported that more Ossetians and Georgians were killed in shootings on Saturday. **********Mr. Gamsakhurdia refuses to give independence to the Ossetians because, he said, the separatist leaders are agents of Moscow, which hopes to divide and continue to rule Georgia. He has declared a state of emergency in what he calls "the former southern Ossetia" and issued orders to arrest its leaders. They have gone underground. **********"The leaders of South Ossetia officially supported the coup in Moscow," he said, reading from statements published in their Russian-language newspaper, Sovetskaya Ossetiya, on Aug. 20. "This territory belongs to Georgia. National minorities have only cultural rights in every country, not political autonomy." **********Mr. Chanturia, once Mr. Gamsakhurdia's friend, said of him, "He is a pathological coward, and a coward who holds power is very dangerous." **********The Georgian leader is a complex character, a man who told the court at his sentencing in 1978, "I sincerely regret what I have done and condemn the crime I have committed." The statement, taped and edited, was broadcast over Soviet television at the time, and made many people wonder what had come over Mr. Gamsakhurdia. **********In an interview with this correspondent in January, he explained that he had bargained with the K.G.B. and expressed regret for distributing "anti-Soviet propaganda," books and materials on the United States that had been provided by an American diplomat and several journalists. "I never renounced my Georgian nationalistic activities," he said, but added he feared that if he did not compromise, he would lose his citizenship and be expelled. **********He said he had also agreed to testify as a prosecution witness against this reporter and Harold Piper, then a correspondent for the Baltimore Sun, in a July 1978 case charging the American reporters with slander. The Soviet State Committee for Television and Radio brought charges against the reporters for writing articles reporting friends' and relatives' doubts about the genuineness of his televised confession and apology. The correspondents did not take part in the trial in Moscow, where Mr. Gamsakhurdia testified that the broadcast confession had been accurate. **********His three-year sentence was later reduced to two years, since he had been held in solitary confinement for a year before his arrest. And instead of being exiled to Siberia, he was released after serving the two years in jail and allowed to work in Georgia. **********Despite all his troubles, Mr. Gamsakhurdia remains popular among many Georgians. Crowds of supporters who gather in front of his headquarters every day do not want him to go. **********"Those people just want disorder so the West won't recognize us," said Gabunia Daredzhali, 40 years old, a Tbilisi office worker. "They want the world to think we're killing each other. Our President is not a dictator; he's a good Christian believer." **********Mr. Gamsakhurdia addressed a rally of several thousand in front of the government buildings on Saturday afternoon, to cheers. But the police had barricaded the square with buses yet again, giving the event an almost claustrophobic air.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/18/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Housing Administration suffered another multibillion-dollar loss in 1989 and its books are in such poor shape that the loss may be greater than indicated, Government auditors said today. **********"As we projected last year, F.H.A.'s financial condition has significantly worsened," the General Accounting Office said in a letter to the House and Senate banking committees. **********The F.H.A.'s mortgage insurance program lost $3.9 billion in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1989, the latest period for which financial information is available, said the G.A.O., the investigative agency of Congress. The F.H.A. lost $4.2 billion in 1988. **********"There are indications that losses have continued in 1990 and will continue in 1991," G.A.O.'s assistant comptroller general, Donald H. Chapin, wrote.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/world.main_headline: U.N. Discusses South Iraq Refugee Havens
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; U.N. Discusses South Iraq Refugee Havens
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/world.body_text: **********Diplomats and United Nations officials have been discussing the possibility that thousands of refugees now in southern Iraq may be admitted into Kuwait, Iran and Saudi Arabia, United Nations officials said here today. **********There are some 30,000 refugees in the south of Iraq, many of whom backed an unsuccessful Shiite Muslim uprising there. The refugees have been under the protection of the coalition that drove Iraqi forces from Kuwait, but the coalition's troops are being pulled out of the area. **********One official said he assumed the movement of refugees would be completed before Iraq re-established control over the zone. **********The United Nations officials said here today that discussions about moving the refugees have been held in recent days here and in the capitals of the countries involved. **********Officials estimated that roughly 4,000 of the 30,000 were Iranian Shiite Muslims or Shiite Iraqi nationals of Iranian descent with relatives in Iran. They said the number of Iraqi Sunni Muslims among the 30,000 was something less than 4,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/world.body_text: **********Joel Diamond came home smiling from more than 27 hard years of foreign exile, steering a luggage-laden cart through the airport terminal with his left hand while he thrust his right fist skyward in the salute of the African National Congress. **********"It is very good to be back," Mr. Diamond announced. "The struggle continues." **********Mr. Diamond, a former guerrilla who had not spoken to his family since leaving Port Elizabeth in 1963, referred to the congress's continuing campaign against white minority rule in South Africa. But the struggle that he mentioned might have included the adjustment problems confronting his group of 94 exiles and dependents who arrived here last week. **********As many as 40,000 South Africans who left because of apartheid are thought to be abroad. Half of these say they are loyal to the African National Congress. 'Very Old and the Very Young' **********"We're talking about 20,000 exiles, including the very old and the very young," Thabo Mbeki, foreign affairs spokesman for the congress, said in a recent interview. **********Home Affairs Minister Eugene Louw said that as of last Tuesday, his department had received and processed 5,967 applications from exiles seeking to return, including about 2,600 dependents, but he had no idea how many more would apply. **********While some South African exiles have previously come home as individuals, last week's flight was a harbinger of a flood of returnees to a society that is ill-equipped to accommodate them. The African National Congress has scheduled four more weekly flights from Lusaka, Zambia, its headquarters in exile. **********"In many cases, too much will have changed," The Sowetan said in a recent editorial about the exiles. "Loved ones will have died, and in some cases cherished memories and dreams will turn out to be false. It is going to be a difficult time for them." Rivalry and Resentment **********Thousands of the exiles have no marketable skills beyond those they learned for guerrilla warfare and personal survival. Children who studied in another language will face difficulty catching up in school. In the competition for meager resources in the black townships, where unemployment sometimes exceeds 50 percent, those returning have already encountered resentment from those who stayed behind and do not want to yield priority for scarce housing and jobs. **********"It would be a tragedy if we turned on each other now, claiming, perhaps, that we have suffered more than they and regarding the returning exiles as a threat to our own positions," said The Sowetan, which urged its readers who help the newcomers. "We have endured too much for that." **********An African National Congress official said returning exiles would each get the equivalent of $120 and fare back to their old hometowns, where they must look for work and housing. **********Other exiles will fare worse, including those who belong to the rival Pan-Africanist Congress or the Azanian People's Organization, which have not joined the repatriation program, or those who are unaffiliated. **********Cecil Hoyi, a former member of the Pan-Africanist Congress who fled abroad a decade ago, quit his organization in 1984 and returned to South Africa last year. He said the South African Council of Churches provided train tickets home to Port Elizabeth. But Mr. Hoyi, who is 41, said he gets no other assistance and cannot find work to support his Kenyan-born wife and two children. **********In a recent interview, Vusi Khanyile, finance chief of the African National Congress, estimated that the cost of bringing back and resettling the congress's 20,000 exiles could exceed $100 million, more than $5,000 per person, which he said the group did not have. **********The South African Government has refused to contribute to the repatriation, contending that the exiles left of their own will. Mr. Louw said last week that as South African citizens, those returning were entitled to "normal state assistance" under existing social welfare programs. **********Overseas aid for South African exiles is limited. Sweden agreed to finance the five flights of congress supporters from Lusaka. And Britain offered $40,000 to renovate and furnish a hostel near Cape Town that will provide some exiles with short-term accommodations and counseling. So far, the United States has not moved to help. **********If the United Nations High Commission for Refugees became involved, this might well encourage more foreign aid. But the Government has balked at letting it operate in South Africa. Mr. Louw said the refusal would be reviewed this month.  Opportunity and Difficulty **********The return home prompted mixed emotions among the exiles who flew in last week. **********"I am very happy to be back in my country again after so many years," said Ben Koppie Baartman, 67, a union organizer who left the Cape Town area 30 years ago. "But I'm not happy because the system which had made me leave is still there, still exists in this country. There is still a difference between a white man and a black man." **********But for all the obstacles ahead, the exiles seemed confident. Thobila Zondani, 30, who fled in 1979, had suffered the loss of his left foot, which was blown off two years ago by a bomb planted at the African National Congress office where he worked in Lusaka. Mr. Zondani said he did not regret having left because he hated apartheid. He remarked that other exiles had suffered worse injuries from bombings by South African agents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/world.main_headline: Ex-P.O.W.'s Offer Accounts Of Terror and Torture in Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: P.O.W.'S; Ex-P.O.W.'s Offer Accounts Of Terror and Torture in Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/world.body_text: **********In their first extensive public comments since being released two weeks ago, Americans taken prisoner in the Persian Gulf war today recounted tales of terror, torture and, occasionally, compassion at the hands of their Iraqi military captors. **********Almost all the former prisoners who spoke today recalled feeling confident that the United States would extract them from prison, either by force or by a quick victory in the war, if they could merely survive their ordeals. And they expressed delight at the patriotic greeting they received on their release. **********Although several said they endured beatings severe enough to dislodge teeth, and one told of being shocked with electric wires wrapped around his face, none of the former prisoners said the mistreatment was life-threatening. But some said the prospect of dying, either by execution or by strikes from allied warplanes, was ever-present. Brief News Conferences **********More than a dozen of the 21 American prisoners freed from Iraq held brief news conferences today to describe their experiences. All those who spoke were men. **********"About 90 percent of the time you felt you were in danger of losing your life," said Lieut. Jeffrey N. Zaun of the Navy, from Cherry Hill, N.J., whose swollen and wounded face, displayed in an antiwar videotape in which he was forced to take part, brought national outrage over Iraqi treatment of American P.O.W.'s. **********Lieutenant Zaun said that 90 percent of his facial injuries occurred when he ejected from his damaged A-6 Intruder attack jet over Iraq 36 hours after the air war began in January, and most of the rest came from "getting slapped around." Seven Cite Reasonable Treatment **********He said he also "banged my nose" in a failed effort to appear so badly beaten that his captors would decide not to place him on television. **********Outwardly, the former prisoners looked none the worse for their abuse. Seven Air Force pilots who appeared at Andrews Air Force Base near Washington looked fit in crisp flight suits, bore no marks of beatings, and displayed broad smiles. **********At their news conference, the seven Air Force pilots generally maintained that that they had been reasonably treated by Iraqi officials, with the exception of physical beatings during interrogations. But they refused to recount their lives in captivity in any detail, apparently because some worried that their remarks could affect the fates of Americans still in Iraq. Evaded Capture for 2 Days **********Iraq has insisted that it has freed all allied prisoners of war, and the highest-ranking Air Force P.O.W., Col. David W. Eberly, said that he and his fellow pilots believed "that everyone is either present or accounted for." **********"Beyond that, we know there are still people missing," he said, "and our prayers still go out to the families of those people to say that we hope there is a chance that maybe others who are still listed as missing may turn up." **********Colonel Eberly and a fellow Air Force pilot, Maj. Thomas E. Griffith Jr., evaded capture for two days after a surface-to-air missile downed their jet in western Iraq the night of Jan. 19, Major Griffith said today. They were later moved to a central holding pen in Baghdad for interrogation. **********He gave a typical account of conditions endured by the seven Air Force pilots, who stayed for all but a few hours in individual solitary-confinement cells near other prisoners from Kuwait and Britain. Pilot Tells of Hospital Care **********"We were captured near the Iraq-Syrian border by an army border patrol, basically," he said. "The initial treatment under the hands of the army was pretty fair. They treated us basically as soldiers doing our duty and in accordance with the Geneva Convention. **********"Later on, during the longest stay we had in one particular prison, the conditions were pretty harsh. We had, obviously -- I guess this is standard in their prisons -- we had no beds. They gave us a couple of blankets so we had to sleep on the floor. And we got very little food, which is the reason most of us were able to lose a little bit of weight. But again, nothing as severe or harsh as what you read about during the Vietnam War." **********A third Air Force pilot, Capt. William F. Andrews of Mechanicsburg, Pa., said he broke his leg in two places while parachuting from his damaged plane Feb. 27. He described his treatment on the ground and in a military hospital in Basra as "pretty good." **********"The soldiers that captured me did a pretty good job, showed a lot of -- it seemed like compassion," he said. "They gave me their food and helped take care of my leg. **********"In Basra, a military doctor took an X-ray, saw it had some broken bones, and put half a cast on it and wrapped it up. And that pretty much held my leg in place until I was able to come back to freedom." **********Others said they were treated far less charitably. The most terrifying account came from Maj. Jeffrey S. Tice of the Air Force, from Sellersburg, Pa., who was hit near Baghdad and glided his jet south for 150 miles before bailing out. He said he was captured by Bedouins who turned him over to Iraqi soldiers for the trip to Baghdad. Thought to Be an Arab **********Major Tice, who has dark hair and a mustache, said his captors might have punished him more severely because they suspected him of being an Arab and a traitor, not an American. **********"I was subjected to a form of electrical shock therapy that I called the 'talk man,' " he said, "and basically had some wires wrapped around my ears and under my chin and was shocked periodically during early captivity, when they were trying to coerce me into making a videotape. **********Major Tice said he "lost a few pieces of teeth and other things like that" during this interrogation, but never feared for his life. 'Numb After the First Shocks' **********"You got kind of numb after the first few shocks. You know, it wasn't that terrible," he said. "It sounds bad but, it wasn't that terrible. It was more physically tiring than it was physically damaging." **********Some servicemen who appeared in Iraqi propaganda broadcasts said they had been coerced into making the videotapes. Lieutenant Zaun, whose appearance included a monotone statement that the allied coalition had "wrongly attacked the peaceful people of Iraq," said he had deliberately tried to "screw up" the tape to indicate that he had spoken under duress. **********"They took me to a TV studio and sat me next to the big guy and then told me what questions they were going to ask and they told me what my answers were going to be," he said. "I had enough faith in Americans to know that anybody who saw this was going to say, 'This is ridiculous.' " **********For Colonel Eberly of the Air Force, the low point came days after his capture when he realized that his family did not know he was alive. **********"I suddenly realized that somebody had to notify my family," he said. "And that realization, that for a period of time my family had to go through somebody telling them that I might be dead, that was the toughest night of all of it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/busin.main_headline: President of Primerica Surprised by Promotion
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; President of Primerica Surprised by Promotion
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/busin.body_text: **********When he graduated from Harvard Business School in 1982, James Dimon faced the same question as many of his classmates: Where should he work as an investment banker? **********Mr. Dimon asked the question of an old family friend, Sanford I. Weill, who had just merged the firm now known as Shearson Lehman Brothers with the American Express Company. **********Mr. Weill came up with a different possibility: Forgo the heavy compensation of investment banking and instead work as his personal assistant. Mr. Dimon jumped at the chance. **********That decision nine years ago has paid off in spades. Yesterday Mr. Dimon was named president of the Primerica Corporation, the financial service conglomerate where Mr. Weill now serves as chairman and chief executive. **********The title of president has been held by Mr. Weill, while Mr. Dimon has been executive vice president and chief financial officer, and is expected to keep the second title. **********The promotion is an astonishing move, making Mr. Dimon, at 35, perhaps the youngest president of a major financial services firm and one of the most powerful members of his generation on Wall Street. **********"I am very surprised," Mr. Dimon said yesterday in an interview. "When Sandy told me, I almost fell off my chair." **********The move was standard for Mr. Weill, who has often given the executives working for him a great deal of power, with the result that they end up in high-level posts. **********Mr. Weill said yesterday that Mr. Dimon had won the post because of his prodigious work. "It seemed appropriate to promote Jamie, who has done a fantastic job in understanding and relating to every part of our business, and give him the oppportunity to grow and do a lot more," Mr. Weill said. "I think it is applauded by everybody in the company." **********The promotion came as part of a broader management restructuring. Also yesterday, Primerica named to the new positions of vice chairmen Robert I. Lipp, the chairman of the company's consumer service division, and Frank G. Zarb, the chairman and chief executive of Primerica's Smith Barney Inc. **********While working with Mr. Weill at American Express, Mr. Dimon held the titles of vice president and assistant to the president. **********When Mr. Weill left American Express, Mr. Dimon joined him, moving to the Commercial Credit Corporation in 1986 when Mr. Weill took it over. **********The purchase of Primerica by Commercial Credit resulted in Mr. Dimon becoming chief financial officer, where he became the central force behind the financial restructuring of the company, which has resulted in several upgradings of its debt ratings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/world.main_headline: ALLIES TO STEP UP ATTACKS ON IRAQIS IN COMING WEEKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: THE OVERVIEW; ALLIES TO STEP UP ATTACKS ON IRAQIS IN COMING WEEKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/world.body_text: **********Declaring that a ground war with Iraq is now inevitable, the British commander in the Persian Gulf said Thursday that the allies planned to greatly intensify their fierce air assault on President Saddam Hussein's forces in the coming weeks. **********In Paris, President Francois Mitterrand told television journalists that an allied ground offensive "promises to take place in the coming days, a little more perhaps, in any case, sometime this month." **********Although a defector described life in Iraq this week as "bombs, bombs, not a moment without bombs," the Briton, Lieut. Gen. Sir Peter de la Billiere, said the coalition's aerial bombardment to date was "minor, compared to what they've got coming."  Concentrating on Iraqi Troops **********An American official agreed that the number of missions, now about 2,500 a day, could soon increase, with a growing number of bombing runs concentrated on Iraqi troop positions. **********As debate continued here and in allied capitals over whether Mr. Hussein's crack Republican Guards had been hurt badly enough to permit an early ground attack, the British commander said he would not commit British land forces until "we've thrown everything we have" at the enemy. An aide said it could take a week, or two or three, to accomplish that. **********The timing of an offensive will be a crucial issue when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, arrive in Saudi Arabia today to meet with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the American commander here, and Saudi leaders. **********Interviewed while en route to Saudi Arabia today, Mr. Cheney declined to comment on the British commander's assessment. But he discussed a potential ground offensive with an air of inevitability, saying, "There will be a point out there when we'll want to kick in the next stages of the campaign." **********Mr. Cheney suggested that an American ground offensive could draw Iraqi troops into the open, so they could be more easily targeted by allied combat planes. **********Preparation for ground fighting continued on Thursday, with a second American battleship, the Wisconsin, pounding the coastline where a Marine amphibious force might land. American pilots began firing a large number of Maverick antitank missiles over the potential battlefield in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. **********American pilots reported that the Iraqis, who are said to have shifted some of their command and communications installations into schools to protect them from attack, were moving antiaircraft artillery onto rooftops in residential areas, probably to give them similar protection. **********Early this morning, Iraq fired a long-range Scud missile at Riyadh, the Saudi capital, but it was destroyed by Patriot defense missiles. No casualties were reported. , **********Air activity was intense on Thursday. The American command announced that a Navy F/A-18 fighter bomber was lost as it returned to its carrier base, disappearing suddenly over the gulf, apparently without having been hit by hostile fire. A Huey medical evacuation helicopter went down over Saudi Arabia, also for unknown reasons, killing one person and injuring four. **********Brig. Gen. Richard I. Neal, an American military spokesman, said at the central command briefing on Thursday in Riyadh that American fliers had shot down three enemy helicopters in two days. He also disclosed that Air Force F-15C Eagle interceptors had bagged two Soviet-built Iraqi SU-22 fighters that were trying to reach haven in Iran and probably also downed a third that was with them. Type Used by Senior Officers **********One of the helicopters was an Alouette, manufactured in France, of a type usually used for transporting senior officers in the Iraqi Army. **********Revising figures he had issued a day earlier, General Neal said American pilots shot down four planes headed for Iran on Wednesday, not two. The pilots had reported the kills but official confirmation was withheld overnight. And he increased the United States estimate of Iraqi planes in Iran to 134 -- 109 warplanes and 25 transports -- including 11 that arrived there on Wednesday. **********An Iranian television broadcast reported that five Iraqi aircraft headed for Iran crashed and one landed safely during the previous 24 hours. Teheran television said that the pilot of one Iraqi plane ejected over western Hamedan province in Iran, and four more aircraft crashed while trying to land on roads in Lorestan, Bakhataran and Kurdistan provinces. **********The Iranian President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, said he would continue his efforts to find a formula for ending the war, despite an evident lack of enthusiasm in Washington and Baghdad. The Teheran Times, which usually reflects his views, commented in an editorial that "Iran, the Soviet Union and France share many identical views, which could find a basis for diplomatic efforts to end the war." **********In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d proposed the creation of a Middle East Bank for Reconstruction and Development as part of the plans for a postwar Middle East that the Administration started to make public this week. Mr. Baker said Iraq itself could benefit from such an institution, but that aid would be more forthcoming if Mr. Hussein were no longer in power. **********"There is no suggestion on our part that the rebuilding of Iraq could proceed, if the current leadership of Iraq remained in power, to the same extent and degree that it could otherwise," Mr. Baker said. **********On the ground in the Middle East, action was again desultory, with only three brief, inconclusive border skirmishes between American forces and Iraqi units. The Wisconsin on Duty **********At sea, the Wisconsin replaced her sister ship, the Missouri, on duty off the Kuwaiti coast and fired 11 rounds from her 16-inch guns at an artillery emplacement. Commissioned in April 1944, the Wisconsin, which carries a crew of 1,500, last saw combat off Korea, as did the Missouri. **********Marines on board the amphibious helicopter vessel Okinawa, part of a big task force steaming north in the gulf, interpreted the use of the heavy guns on the two battleships as part of the preparation for a landing. They told reporters that they expected their job to be the taking of Kuwait City. **********"The cities are more dangerous," said Lance Cpl. Thomas Fix. "You never know where anyone is at in there. You've got to go and find them." **********Not far from the marines' ships, the oil slick in the gulf resumed its southerly movement after a week when winds kept it in much the same place. It is now approaching islands rich in marine bird life and the big desalting plants that supply much of the drinking water for Saudi Arabia's cities. **********Both General Neal and General de la Billiere again insisted, in the face of reports of substantial civilian casualties in Iraq, that only military targets were being hit deliberately. But they were a bit more forthcoming than in the past in acknowledging that some of their bombs have gone astray. **********The allies conceded they were bombing bridges in Baghdad and other cities that were heavily used by civilians. But these are military targets and have long been considered so, top commanders said.               --------------------          Allies Bomb Baghdad **********BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The allies pounded Baghdad with bombs and missiles for 12 hours during the night, and Iraqi officials said today that 22 civilians were killed and many others wounded. The allies also struck near Iraq's border with Iran, where the official Iranian press agency, monitored in Cyprus, reported "massive explosions." **********Ramsey Clark, a former United States Attorney General and an opponent of the gulf war who visited the southern city of Basra on Tuesday and Wednesday, told reporters in Baghdad that what he saw was "a human and civilian tragedy" exceeding the mandate given by the United Nations. **********Mr. Clark said the relentless allied bombardment of Basra had destroyed residential areas, hospitals, nightclubs, coffee shops, clinics and law offices. He told reporters that a doctor in Baghdad told him several thousand people were killed or wounded by the bombing. **********Officials at a hospital in Baghdad's Al-Adhamiya district said six people died shortly after they were brought there after a midnight raid. Iraqi officials said 16 other people, including nine women and a child, were killed in strikes on the Sheik Omar district.               --------------------          Cheney Discusses Ground Attack **********SHANNON, Ireland, Friday, Feb. 8 -- Defense Secretary Cheney said today that a ground assault was an central element of the American war plan, but sought to counter concern that it would lead to heavy American casualties. **********In an interview while en route to Saudi Arabia, Mr. Cheney and General Powell emphasized that any final decision to launch a ground attack would rest with Mr. Bush. They declined to discuss the timing of such an offensive, but Mr. Cheney challenged arguments by some lawmakers that a ground assault should be delayed for months while air bombardments of Iraqi targets continue. **********Mr. Cheney is to brief the President on Monday on the recommendations he receives from military leaders during his three-day trip. **********The Defense Secretary said that air power would be more effective if used in tandem with ground power, allowing the allied coalition to win the war more quickly. "We're thinking in terms of the situation, which clearly would continue the air campaign, and add to that other capabilities: the amphibious capability, your ground forces as well. **********"And it's the use of all these assets, all those capabilities, that's likely ultimately to produce the result, our objective, and that is to expel Saddam Hussein from Kuwait," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/28/busin.body_text: **********The directors of the C&S/Sovran Financial Corporation are discovering that two years and one false step make all the difference in the turbulent banking industry. **********In 1989, Bennett A. Brown, then the chairman of the Citizens and Southern Corporation, would not even meet with Hugh L. McColl Jr., the aggressive chairman of the NCNB Corporation, who had started a hostile takeover bid for Citizens and Southern. Instead, Mr. Brown, a courtly Georgia banker, not too politely told Mr. McColl to mind his own bank. **********Months later, Mr. Brown agreed to merge Citizens and Southern with the Sovran Financial Corporation. A New Merger Proposal **********Now, the C&S/Sovran board is "looking seriously" at an informal proposal to merge with NCNB, said Mr. Brown, now the chairman of C&S/Sovran, following a special meeting in Atlanta yesterday where the regional banking company has one of its headquarters. **********The NCNB bid, if successful, would amount to a nearly $4 billion exchange of stock, making it the costliest merger in American banking history and making NCNB the nation's second-largest bank, after Citicorp. **********Although Mr. Brown's statement today plainly raised the prospect that C&S/Sovran might accept a merger, Mr. Brown also expressed caution. He said the board had not decided "to depart from its strategy of proceeding as an independent institution." **********Mr. Brown added: "We are trying to determine from information obtained from NCNB and further discussions whether a combinaton of the two companies is in the best interests of the C&S/Sovran stockholders. The due-diligence issues are important, and we will consider them very carefully."  NCNB's Statement **********Yesterday, Ginny Mackin, a spokeswoman for NCNB, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., said, "We are looking forward to continuing the discussions" with C&S/Sovran. The talks between the two began last week when Mr. McColl met with Mr. Brown at his Atlanta condominium. **********Since the C&S/Sovran merger, the company's once-optimistic prospects of rising income have been derailed by a surge of troubled real estate loans on Sovran's books that had gone unnoticed, or were underestimated, by Mr. Brown. Nonperforming assets at the company soared to $1.1 billion at the end of March, from $703.2 million at the end of December, and company executives have not promised that the loan troubles will end soon. **********Sandra J. Flannigan, a banking analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., a brokerage in Baltimore, estimated that as much as $300 million in additional bad loans would be reported this quarter. And the company's yearly dividend of $1.56 a share may soon be cut, said Richard Stillinger, who follows Southern banks for Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a bank research firm in New York. **********The setbacks for C&S/Sovran have forced Mr. Brown, who is 62 years old, to postpone his planned retirement, which was scheduled for the end of the year when the merger with Sovran was announced. They have also contributed to his change of heart toward Mr. McColl, his longtime competitor. Though NCNB has only modest operations in Georgia and Virginia, where C&S/Sovran has large operations, the two banking companies compete in several surrounding states. **********According to a person close to Mr. McColl, the NCNB chairman would not have agreed to the meeting in Mr. Brown's Atlanta condominium without strong indications that C&S/Sovran would actively consider a merger bid from NCNB.  Terms of the Informal Offer **********Mr. Brown outlined to C&S/Sovran's directors yesterday the informal offer that Mr. McColl presented to acquire C&S/Sovran. It would involve an exchange of one share of C&S/Sovran for three-fourths of a share of NCNB stock. **********NCNB's stock closed yesterday at $37, down $1.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price, the proposed deal would be worth $27.75 a share to C&S/Sovran stockholders, or $3.7 billion. Such a price would represent a 17.5 percent premium over C&S/Sovran's stock price yesterday. C&S/Sovran's stock closed at $23.625, up 87.5 cents, after trading around $24, after the company announced the board's position yesterday afternoon. **********Mrs. Flannigan, of Alex. Brown & Sons, said directors of C&S/Sovran would probably reject Mr. McColl's initial offer as inadequate. But, she added, "When you start getting into an offer of $30 to $35 a share, then there has to be greater pressure on the board" to approve a merger. **********Indeed, Bloomberg Business News reported that two shareholders of C&S/Sovran had filed a lawsuit in Delaware Chancery Court against Mr. Brown and 28 other officers and directors of the company yesterday to pressure them into broadening the talks with NCNB into a full-scale auction of C&S/Sovran to a high bidder. **********The lawsuit said NCNB was maneuvering to exploit the downturn in C&S/Sovran's stock value and real estate loans to acquire C&S/Sovran for a bargain-basement price, Bloomberg reported. **********C&S/Sovran said it did not know the details of the lawsuit and could not comment. **********The 1989 offer that Mr. Brown had emphatically rejected from NCNB would have been worth $39 a share then to Citizens and Southern's stockholders, and about $40 a share today. Instead, the shares of Citizens and Southern and, subsequently, C&S/ Sovran made a steady decline, falling below $15 late last year, before rising moderatly to $19 before reports of NCNB's overture emerged early this week.  New Signs of Trouble **********The final straw for C&S/Sovran directors could be new signs that real estate problems will worsen in the District of Columbia suburbs, and elsewhere in C&S/Sovran's seven-state territory in the South. **********Dennis C. Bottorff, the 46-year-old president and chief operating officer at C&S/Sovran, told stockholders in Atlanta at the annual meeting in April that he could not say when the mounting real estate problems near Washington would peak. **********"The market continues to deteriorate, and we expect further increases in nonperforming assets," he said. Bad real estate loans in the Washington area contributed $342 million of the $403 million rise in C&S/Sovran's problem loans in the first quarter.  Unhealthy Level of Bad Assets **********The percentage of total nonperforming assets rose to an unhealthy level of 3.25 percent of total assets in the quarter, a figure that analysts said was certain to rise this quarter. **********Thus far, Mr. Brown has kept C&S/ Sovran's loss reserve at a conservative ratio of 91 percent of the nonperforming total. The loss reserves of many Southern banks amount to less than 70 percent of their nonperforming loans. **********Mr. Stillinger of Keefe, Bruyette said this meant that Mr. Brown was not so desperate that he would be forced to seek a merger partner, even if the NCNB bid was rejected. **********At March 31, the company's common equity capital, the clearest measure of the bank's capital cushion, totaled $2.94 billion, or a healthy 5.9 percent of $50 billion in total assets. **********Mr. Stillinger added that bank regulators probably would not protest if Mr. Brown let his loss-reserve ratio drift down a bit this quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/01/world.main_headline: Judge Backs Gulf Use Of Unapproved Drugs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/01/world.print_headline: Judge Backs Gulf Use Of Unapproved Drugs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/01/world.body_text: **********The military may require troops serving in the Persian Gulf to take unapproved drugs to protect against biological and germ warfare, a Federal judge ruled today. **********Judge Stanley S. Harris of United States District Court dismissed a lawsuit that contended the troops should be warned about the risk of side effects, allowed to refuse the treatment and required to give their consent. **********The action by the Defense Department, allowed by the Food and Drug Administration, to give unapproved drugs to troops involved "strategic military decisions," not research on involuntary human subjects, the judge ruled. Both agencies have said the Pentagon has no intention of using drugs still in the experimental stage, but rather drugs that have not won F.D.A. approval. **********Susan Hansen, a Pentagon spokeswoman, confirmed the military is administering anti-germ warfare vaccines to troops. **********The advocacy group Public Citizen, which filed the lawsuit on behalf of an unidentified Army soldier, said it would appeal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/18/world.main_headline: 17 Hours Across Rural Cuba: A Living Revolution
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/18/world.print_headline: 17 Hours Across Rural Cuba: A Living Revolution
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/18/world.body_text: **********Over the last two decades, Cuba's largest cities, Havana on the western shoulder of the island and Santiago de Cuba near its eastern end, have become grand skeletons -- places of crumbling roads and buildings, dwindling supplies and people increasingly uneasy with the Communist Government of Fidel Castro. **********But away from the cities, along winding mountain roads cutting through endless fields of sugar cane, live many who remember the grinding poverty of the countryside during the 1940's and 50's under the rightist dictator, Fulgencio Batista.  Unsupervised Tour **********A 17-hour drive last week from Havana to Santiago, free of the Government escorts whose job it used to be to assure that foreign journalists received only positive images of Cuba and its Government, produces a sense that support for Mr. Castro and his revolution 32 years ago remains strong in the Cuban countryside. **********No amount of travel could determine whether progress might have been quicker under a non-Communist government. Outsiders who have seen the countryside in other large Caribbean islands say development here compares favorably with that in Haiti, is roughly on a par with the Dominican Republic and Jamaica, and lags behind Puerto Rico. But it is clear that in more than three decades under Mr. Castro, the lot of the Cuban campesino -- the peasant-class farmer -- has improved. **********"This place was not a town, just scattered houses," said Froilan Perez Machado, a farmer and teacher. Mr. Perez, 42 years old, his wife and her 69-year-old mother live in a modest six-room wooden house on the main road into Jibacoa, about three hours' drive from Havana. **********"After the victory of the revolution, a new community was built here," Mr. Perez said. "Before, there was no road, no medicine, no electricity, only people riding horses and a few scattered farm houses." **********"The closest doctor lived in Manicaragua," he continued, referring to a town about 30 miles away. "You had to get there to see a doctor by horse. Now, when someone is sick in the family, you have medicine. There was nothing before. Now we have everything. Everything has changed since the revolution." **********They live across from an elementary school, the newest of two schools built in Jibacoa since the revolution. Before, Mr. Perez said, there were none. **********"Here it's healthier," Mr. Perez said. "You can breathe pure air in the mountains. The air is pure and we have fruit. Living conditions in the mountains have improved." Automotive Ghosts Tax Mechanic's Ingenuity **********Government officials point with pride to the network of roads that traverse the plains and mountains of Cuba's lush countryside. The most lavish is a six-lane highway that begins in a tobacco-growing province, Pinar del Rio, runs east through Havana and ends 435 miles later in Cabaiguan. **********But even on the main highway, a drive down the spine of Cuba is like taking a journey back in time. **********The roads are dotted with rolling ghosts made by General Motors, Chrysler and Ford, cars that haven't been sold here new since the revolution. **********There are 1958 Chrysler New Yorkers, '55 Buicks, '55 Chevrolets cruising among the small East European and Soviet makes, seeming like whales among sardines. Most are painted over three times, riding on mismatched tires and held together mostly by ingenuity. **********Maurino Camilo is the manager of a filling station in Aguandad de Pasajeros, 120 miles east of Havana on the main road. It is the equivalent of the American or European oasis where motorists refresh in one section and refuel in another. **********Before becoming the manager, Mr. Camilo, who operates the station with his wife, spent four years in Halle, East Germany, at a mechanics' training school. The training has not been in vain. After filling the tank, Mr. Camilo motions to follow him into the station and back into his work area. There sits his masterpiece: a fully restored 1957 Chevy Belair, which he bought in 1990. **********Everyone who drives must have a touch of Camilo. All along the road, hoods are raised as self-taught mechanics coax and kick their old Chevrolets, De Sotos and Fords into running order. A Thoroughfare For Cars and Cows **********Just outside Santa Clara, three goats prance across the highway. A few miles later, a cow ambles across. They do not seem frightened and walk as though the road is theirs as much as the machines'. **********In Cuba, the road is a river, carrying most of the country's traffic. The shoulder of the road is not for emergency stopping; it is the lane for bicycles, horses and ox-drawn wagons. **********Even for the minority of families who own cars, few can drive the 841 miles from Havana to Santiago. **********The trip requires two months' ration under a system in which car owners are allotted 13 to 16 gallons of fuel a month -- a rationing system imposed after the Soviet Union sharply reduced oil allocations as part of an overall aid reduction. Cuts in Soviet aid have produced Cuba's "special time in a time of peace," a slogan announced by Mr. Castro last year and repeated every time some new restriction is announced. **********For the traveler, there are mass-transit options, but the rail system cannot serve every village. Now, even the bus system, which most Cubans rely on for long-distance travel, is erratic. **********The standard scene along the highway is of people standing on the soft shoulders of roads, waiting. The reduction of fuel deliveries by the Soviet Union is the overriding cause; the other is the Pan American Games, which have been taking place since Aug. 2 in Havana and Santiago de Cuba. To accommodate the thousands of visitors, buses that normally serve the provinces have been diverted, along with fuel, to the major cities. **********The consequence of this diversion is sitting, often in 100-degree heat and blinding sun. People thumb rides and climb into flatbed trucks or any other form of mass transportation. Each car is "the bus," trucks are the bus, anything that stops can be the bus. Capitalism Rears Its Athletic Head **********Havana and Santiago are engaged in a dollar-driven competition wrought by the Pan American Games. **********Although this country's Communist leaders denounce capitalism, they are allowing large-scale commercial advertising for the first time. Big signs advertising everything from McDonald's to Puma line sports stadiums. **********These advertisements are intended for the overseas fans watching the games on television, not for the domestic market. There are no McDonald's in this country. **********Away from the camera's eye, it becomes quickly apparent that the sights ahead will include no commercial billboards selling french fries or motels. Communism, however, is energetically marketed. **********The first cluster of billboards is on the main highway. It is a painted poster of Fidel and Ernesto (Che) Guevara, Cuban Communism's No. 1 martyr. **********Every village and hamlet has a billboard welcoming travelers and offering a slogan with the picture of a hero of the revolution. **********"For peace, life and against imperialist aggression," one says. Invariably there is the bust of Jose Marti, the 19th-century writer and nationalist leader. **********For variety, there are public service messages, announcing that "alcohol is an ally of death" and that "speed is the ally of death."  Cratered Road Leads To City With Charm **********As the two-lane road from Santa Clara to Trinidad climbs toward the Sierra del Escambray, the second-highest mountain range in Cuba, there are stretches of fresh paving that suddenly give way to cavernous, bone-jarring craters. The road is winding and treacherous, with the potholes and two-way traffic that includes large flatbed trucks, buses, cows, mules, bikes and pedestrians. **********After two hours, the tension is broken. With the beginning of the descent from the Escambray, there is a breathtaking, panoramic view of the Caribbean and on its shore about a mile inland, Villa de la Santisima Trinidad. Founded in 1514, it is one the first settlements in Cuba. **********Compared to Havana, with its crumbling roadways, buildings and other main facilities, the cobblestone streets and Moorish architectural motifs of Trinidad seem like an oasis. It has been turned into a museum piece, and its buildings are carefully restored to lure the Europeans and Canadians who come here for sun and relaxation. **********But for all of its charm, Trinidad is the major city in Sancti Spiritus province, with the attendant problems of a city. **********The tourists draw beggars, small children follow foreigners, wait outside the shops, and then beg for candy, soft drinks and chips. Gradually, their pleas escalate to watches, caps and bags. "A dollar, senor. For my baby," asks a young woman holding a child. **********A red police car passes by and angrily shoos the children away. **********One child doubles back. "One dollar. One dollar," he says. Along the Roadside, 2 A.M. Camouflage **********If alcohol and speed are allies of death, night driving is normally the ally of fatigue. Yet on a two-lane highway from Las Tunas to Bayamo, the road is alive and bustling. **********The moon and headlights are the only guides to a road that cannot make up its mind whether to be bad or fair or horrible. The spare tire has already been used, thanks to a crater-induced flat tire outside Jatibonico. Now it is 2 A.M. between two major towns, with cane fields in between. **********Even at 2 A.M., there are more bikes, pedestrians and horse-drawn wagons than cars. Because most do not have taillights or any other form of illumination, it is necessary to guess at forms in the night to avoid running them down from behind, or meeting them head-on when attempting to change lanes to pass a slow-moving vehicle. **********There are cane fields on each side of the road. One can travel for 15 minutes; then suddenly a man with white clothing and a white hat steps out from between the stalks. **********It goes on like this for the next hour and a half. Darkness, cane field, soldiers standing in the middle of nowhere watching the car as it speeds by. Darkness, cane field, an old man walking down the road, hands clasped behind his back, walking, head bowed, contemplating. Darkness, small town. A man standing on the side of the road holding a machete, with a pool of blood and something freshly killed at his feet. Havana's Strain To Santiago's Ease **********At 1 A.M., on a descent from the Sierra Maestra mountain range, Santiago de Cuba appears as a cluster of lights nestled on a sweeping bay that flows into the Caribbean. Santiago is Cuba's most Caribbean region, laid-back and tranquil compared to the bustle and hustles of Havana. The narrow streets are cleaner, the intensity of work, poverty and decay markedly reduced. **********But the strain of revolution that begins in Havana and flourishes in the countryside is ever-present in Santiago. This is the home of Antonio Maceo, the son of a black merchant in Santiago who is one of the two great leaders of Cuba's war for independence. This is also the city where Mr. Castro accepted the surrender of General Batista's army in January 1959. **********Thirty-two years later, the revolution is no longer an event but an institution, from one tip of the island to the other. A trip along much of its length in this "special time in a time of peace" suggests a country undergoing difficult times. Where it is going is anyone's guess.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/12/world.main_headline: Young Rioters in Britain Challenge the Police
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/12/world.print_headline: Young Rioters in Britain Challenge the Police
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/12/world.body_text: **********When mobs of youths set fire to shops and clashed with the police on Monday night in North Shields, a suburb of Newcastle-upon-Tyne in northeastern England, the rioters said they were taking revenge for the deaths of two young men, killed over the weekend in a high-speed chase after they stole a car. **********By police accounts, the young men were "hotting," a current craze among restless, urban youths in Britain who set out to taunt the police and impress their peers by using city streets to perform high-speed stunts in stolen cars.Police campaigns to crack down on the growing incidence of car theft and hotting in Britain were one of the factors that contributed to outbursts of rioting and street violence among crowds of young people in at least two British cities over the last 10 days. **********The police and sociologists say the craze has gained popularity over the last two years as a brazen show of defiance among bored youths in working-class neighborhoods and public-housing complexes of provincial British cities, where jobs are scarce and unemployment levels high. **********Typically, the drivers of the stolen cars use the streets around publichousing areas to perform dangerous, high-speed driving exhibitions in front of admiring peers, and sometimes defy passing police patrols to give chase. **********In some instances, the police say, they conclude their spree by ramming the car through a shop window, to steal the goods inside. **********James Gow, a sociologist who has studied the phenomenon, say the craze is more than just thrill-seeking. "It is an anti-authoritarian gesture, aimed at showing up the police and showing off to their peers," Mr. Gow said. In a survey of young joyriders, he said 70 percent of those sampled said they would race off or encourage a chase if approached by the police. **********In the street violence in North Shields, young rioters spread the word on Monday night that the two young men killed in the weekend crash had been killed by their police pursuers, whom they accused of ramming the stolen car into a lamppost. The police denied this, saying the young men lost control of their car while traveling at 125 miles an hour. 400 Rioters on Monday **********In a five-hour rampage Monday night, more than 400 rioters firebombed buildings, looted shops and cut telephone wires. The area was calm Tuesday night. **********Last week, in Oxford, two nights of street disturbances similarly grew out of police efforts to crack down on hotting exhibitions by young people. As a measure of how audacious some of the young car thieves have become, one youth wearing a scarf across his face to conceal his identity raced a car back and forth in front of riot police who had answered a call to stop the disturbance. **********The rioting in North Shield on Monday was the worst episode of street troubles at the end of summer in several cities across Britain, including Cardiff and Birmingham. **********In addition to the antics of the car thieves, the police said warm late-summer weather also contributed to the problem, by drawing large numbers of young people into the streets. On Tuesday, Prime Minister John Major condemned the violence, which he attributed to a "copycat effect." **********But Labor Party politicians said the incidents had less to do with hotting and warm weather than the problems of poverty and unemployment. **********Unlike the disturbances that swept London in the early 1980's, which broke out in predominantly black neighborhoods and were racial in origin, the troubles over the last two weeks have involved mostly white youths who live in public housing, where there is a high percentage of unemployed people and single-parent families. **********According to Mr. Gow, car theft among juveniles have grown sharply over the last two years. In South Wales, for example, 16 percent of all juvenile crimes committed in 1990 involved car theft, compared with less than 9 percent the year before. **********Largely as a result of the hotting craze, the police say Britain now has the highest rate of car theft in Europe. According to one estimate, a car is stolen every minute in Britain.
