https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/16/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Syria; 'Absolute Truths' Collide in Arabs' War of Words
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/16/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Syria; 'Absolute Truths' Collide in Arabs' War of Words
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/16/world.body_text: **********The foreign newspapers on sale here have a flimsy lightness to them these days because government censors have torn out news of the Persian Gulf war. A recent copy of The International Herald Tribune, thus, went from page 2 to page 7, with nothing in between. **********The censorship reflects an official urge in Syria and most other parts of the Middle East to control the flow of information about the war. The phenomenon that has shriveled press freedoms throughout the region, which is caught nervously between old calculations and a precarious, uncharted future. **********For alongside the military campaign in the gulf, another campaign is being waged by Arab leaders, who using images and hints, smoke and mirrors, seek to position themselves for a post-war era where their wartime stands and statements will help or hurt them. **********In a region bitterly divided by the conflict, the question is: who, really, pursued the long-term Arab interest -- those who sided with Saddam Hussein in the name of Arab pride, or those who opposed him in the name of other principles?  Stakes Are Survival **********The answers, which are now being shaped, are framed in terms of survival -- not only political survival of key figures but also their very physical survival. A reporter criss-crossing the Arab divide gains the impression that the stakes are so high that no one can admit to being less than absolutely right. **********"Politically, Saddam Hussein is dead," said an official in Syria, which supports the United States-led coalition against Iraq. "He won't last a week after the war is over." **********"I have the feeling that when all this is over, Assad and Mubarak won't be around for too long," said a senior politician in Jordan, which has swung toward Iraq. The politician was referring to the leaders of Egypt and Syria, which oppose Baghdad. In both cases, the assessments reflected an unusual acknowledgment that in tempestuous times, the feelings of ordinary people will count. **********The result of such sentiments is a propaganda war that pits Baghdad Radio's appeals to pro-Iraqi Arab emotions in many parts of this region against the attempts of anti-Iraqi regimes to contain explosive passions among their own people. **********"The problem in this region," said an exiled Iraqi politician with long experience in Arab politics, "is the lack of democracy. Most people don't like their regimes. They don't like the United States. They don't like Israel. When they see someone who stands up to all these things, they ignore the other factors and applaud." Exploiting Frustrations **********"Saddam Hussein is very successfully exploiting the frustrations of a region that is replete with frustration and denial," said a senior Western diplomat. "He is appealing to Islamic sentiment, Palestinian sentiment, rich-poor sentiment to try to build opposition to the regimes that oppose him, to destabilize them." **********Many Western diplomats suspect that the Iraqi Embassy in Amman, Jordan, is the source of much manipulation, planting stories on a Jordanian press that is at once among the most free in the Arab world and also among the most eager to stoke the fires of anti-American and pro-Iraqi sentiment. **********"The Iraqi Embassy in Amman is the source of a variety of untrue rumors of coups and lethal violence against demonstrators here," a Western envoy said. "There is a thin line between propaganda and the attempt to destabilize." **********Such is the Syrian sensitivity that Jordanian television broadcasts, which are regarded as pro-Iraqi, have been jammed here for months. Syrian reporters working for foreign news organizations say they have been told to avoid all reference in their dispatches to pro-Iraqi sentiment on the streets. It is a sentiment that Western diplomats call widespread in a land that reversed decades of anti-American hostility to align itself with the United States-led coalition against Baghdad. **********"When I speak against Saddam, I know that 75 percent of my staff are against me for saying so," said a pro-Government Syrian entrepreneur, who declined to be identified by name. "They do not say it with their voices. They say it with their eyes." **********Such are the concerns about the impact of hard news on volatile sentiment that when Syrian and Iraqi soldiers clashed in Saudi Arabia -- a grievous offense to the pan-Arabist ideology embraced here -- official public acknowledgment was delayed for 48 hours. **********The day after this week's American bombing of a building in Baghdad where many civilians died, an event that inflamed Arab passions, the official Syria Times did not refer to the catastrophe at all. The reticence was reflected in officially controlled newspapers in other parts of the Arab world that are aligned with the United States. In those places, commitment to the Western-led coalition faces a potential challenge from pro-Iraqi sentiment on the streets. Possible Move to Split Allies **********Some saw today's highly conditional Iraqi offer on Kuwait as a further attempt to weaken Arab commitment to the Western alliance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.main_headline: Your Taxes; Charity Tax Effort Is Set to Backfire
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.print_headline: Your Taxes; Charity Tax Effort Is Set to Backfire
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.body_text: **********Those who counsel that it's better to live with unfavorable elements of the tax code than to risk changes now have fresh ammunition. **********Take the issue of deductions for charitable contributions, which the Internal Revenue Service is to address next Thursday when it conducts a hearing on a regulation it proposed in March. If adopted, the proposal could affect tens of millions of dollars in contributions and possibly impose substantial new recordkeeping burdens. **********Inspired in part by the Bush Administration's "thousand points of light" mandate, various corporate contributors decided the Government might want to smile particularly brightly on donations to American charities. Corporations thus sought to get full deductions for contributions to charities in the United States, instead of being required -- as under current law -- to allocate such deductions against income earned in this country, but not income earned abroad. **********But what emerged from the I.R.S. was an addition to Sec.1.861(e) of the Federal Tax Code that would allow a company that contributes to an American charity to deduct from domestic income only that part of the contribution actually used by the charity in the United States. Money used abroad would have to be deducted from money earned abroad. **********More than 100 American charities say the proposal would cut donations to organizations working overseas and would discriminate between types of nonprofit groups, create more paperwork and diminish the ability of the private sector to support worldwide efforts to, as one document put it, "feed children, distribute medicines, save rain forests or even arrange educational exchange programs." **********One of those charities, the Fund for Private Assistance in International Development, contends that the I.R.S. took a "bookkeeper's view" when devising the proposal and failed to realize the negative effect on contributions, especially from multinational companies with foreign tax credits greater than can be applied against liabilities in the United States. **********With the support of more than two dozen senators and various members of relevant House committees, officials of the charity say they are increasingly confident the proposal will be withdrawn. The I.R.S., however, has yet to acknowledge any change of heart, with a spokesman insisting that it will use the public hearing at its Constitution Avenue headquarters on Thursday to make sure that the agency fully understands the issue, not to debate or defend its proposal.  Democrats' Theme: Fairness **********Democrats in the House are pressing the leadership to keep alive an issue of potential impact in next year's Presidential campaign: tax fairness.This week, the Democratic Study Group, sent a letter with 156 signatures to Speaker Thomas S. Foley urging that a "concrete" outline for a tax bill be developed so it can be considered early in 1992. **********"The central component of this package should be a significant reduction in the tax burden on middle-class and working families," the letter stated. "If such tax relief must be offset by revenue from other sources, we believe that the tax rates paid by the very wealthiest individuals should be raised." **********Bills embodying tax cuts for Americans of ordinary means have already been introduced, however, and the Democrats are at odds over how best to replace the lost revenue as required under last autumn's budget agreement. **********Republicans, meanwhile, are busy disputing the Democrats' premise, denying that changes in the tax code over the past decade favored the well-to-do at the expense of those with low and middle incomes. Footnotes **********The I.R.S. figures that the proposed simplification of rules covering maids and other household employees would reduce by 80 percent the paperwork burden of filing, reporting and paying tax obligations. Among other things, the threshhold for being subject to Social Security taxes would be raised to $300 of wages a year from $50 a quarter. **********By increasing its cigarette tax to 5 cents from 2 cents, North Carolina no longer has the country's lowest tax. Virginia's is 2.5 cents and Kentucky's is 3 cents. The three highest are 46 cents in Hawaii, 43 cents in Minnesota and 41 cents in Texas. **********Proof copies of the major tax forms for 1991 (Publication 1407) are available by writing the Internal Revenue Service at P.O. Box 25866, Richmond, Va., 23289. Suggestions for improvements will be considered until Sept. 6.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/world.main_headline: Polish Cardinal Served A Summons in Albany
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/world.print_headline: Polish Cardinal Served A Summons in Albany
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/world.body_text: **********A summons opening a lawsuit for defamation was served on Jozef Cardinal Glemp, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Warsaw and Primate of Poland, yesterday outside the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Albany. According to Aline Frisch, a process server from New York City, the Cardinal said, "No, no, no," as she tucked the legal papers under his arm. **********The suit will be filed in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan by Rabbi Avraham Weiss of the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale, the Bronx, who led demonstrators onto the grounds and porch of a convent located adjacent to the Auschwitz death camp in July 1989. Rabbi Weiss says he was slandered and defamed when Cardinal Glemp expressed relief in a homily that the demonstrators had been stopped before they could kill the nuns or destroy the convent. **********Last Friday, In a meeting with a dozen Jewish religious and community leaders, the Cardinal, who is visiting Polish-American communties in the United States, expressed regret that this statement and others made during and since that 1989 homily "caused pain to the Jewish community and were seen as fostering stereotypes of Jews and Judaism." **********Cardinal Glemp or his legal representative will have 20 days to challenge the suit in New York or move for its dismissal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.main_headline: Wall Street; The Seed Money Flow Slows in Computers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.print_headline: Wall Street; The Seed Money Flow Slows in Computers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.body_text: **********The high-technology darlings of tomorrow's stock market are incubating in the venture-capital nurseries today. That's the good news. The bad news is that the nanny may be about to give notice. **********For the computer industry, in fact, 1990 may become "the year the Great American Venture Capital Machine began to slow down," said Richard A. Shaffer, savvy editor of the Technologic Partners' Computer Letter. Mr. Shaffer estimates that at least 10 of the 300 firms he surveys left the field last year. And at a recent conference, a session titled "How to Wind Down a Venture Capital Firm" drew a capacity crowd, he said. **********Where will the pain be felt? In California, mostly. At least half of each year's venture activity since 1986 has occurred there. Meanwhile, Mr. Shaffer looks for a rebound in deal activity in Massachusetts, where the weak economy "has made it far easier to find qualified people and inexpensive space to put them in." One startup in the Boston area is operating rent-free for three years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/world.main_headline: Can Washington End Hussein's Rule Yet Keep His Country in One Piece?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: STIRRING THE IRAQI POT; Can Washington End Hussein's Rule Yet Keep His Country in One Piece?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/world.body_text: **********The American downing of an Iraqi warplane today demonstrates the Bush Administration's willingness to use additional military force to humble Iraq as long as President Saddam Hussein remains in power and presages an active postwar pressure campaign to oust the Iraqi leader, Administration officials say. **********But at the same time, the episode raises the question of whether the Administration has developed a policy to prevent the breakup, or "Lebanization," of Iraq and to influence the succession that may lie ahead in Baghdad. So far, the Administration has not explained its approach beyond predicting that Mr. Hussein will probably not be in power by year's end. **********Mr. Bush and his advisers also face a critical decision on whether the United States should abandon the Iraqi insurrection that it has nurtured by protecting it from the Iraqi fighters, bombers and helicopter gunships grounded for now by American air patrols. **********By forcefully telling Iraq that any airplane that flies -- even 1,000 miles north of the cease-fire line to attack Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq -- is a threat to the United States, Mr. Bush has for the moment attached the fate of the rebellion to the allied cause. **********Senior Administration officials continue to say the overall American objective is to bring United States troops home as quickly as possible. But they also continue to call on the Iraqi people to overthrow their vanquished leader. **********"There clearly is a bit of ambiguity in our position," an Administration official said today. "We've talked a lot about getting Saddam out, but the clear priority is to get the troops home. It seems to be a contradiction and if you look at our public statements, the Administration has not been very effective in explaining its position." **********There is still another Iraqi alternative Washington may face, no happier than the others. It is that the Iranian-backed Shiite Muslim rebels may take control of the country and impose a fundamentalist system similar to the one in Teheran. **********At the heart of the United States' problem is the fact that as long as 100,000 troops are bivouacked in southern Iraq and American planes patrol the skies, President Bush has the ability to influence events in Iraq and could be forced by events to do so. **********Last week in Martinique for his meeting with President Francois Mitterrand of France, Mr. Bush was asked whether it would be safer for Persian Gulf security to allow Mr. Hussein to reassert his authority by crushing the rebellion or run the risk that fundamentalist Shiite Muslims, who make up 55 percent of Iraq's 18 million people, would take control and establish an Islamic republic similar to Iran's. 'A Little Too Negative' **********"I'm not going to answer your question," Mr. Bush replied. "But you spell out two hypotheses. It's a little too negative. Perhaps there's something that's a little more positive than either of those alternatives. Let's hope so." **********Mr. Bush's remarks reflect the still dominant assessment among American intelligence officials that neither the southern Shiites nor the northern Kurdish minority can defeat Mr. Hussein's authority and the tradition of Sunni Muslim control it represents. **********The most likely Iraqi institution that would act to save Iraq from centrifugal disintegration and then challenge Mr. Hussein's claim to rule after his disastrous adventure in Kuwait is the military, which is imbued with Iraqi nationalism and which has suffered mightily under Mr. Hussein. **********But a critical policy question that has arisen in the three weeks since the end of hostilities is whether the Iraqi military is more likely to act while it is engaged in putting down rebellion, or after it crushes the rebellion and in doing so eliminates the threat to the territorial integrity of the country. **********"It is important to stabilize the situation in Iraq," said Christine Moss Helms, an Iraq scholar who has advised the White House and Pentagon during the Persian Gulf crisis. "Until the situation is stabilized nobody is going to be able to focus on getting rid of Saddam Hussein," she added.  An Iraqi 'Pandora's Box' **********That may mean that on completion of a formal cease-fire, the United States will have to cede control of the Iraqi skies to Iraq, where the military will certainly launch a punishing air campaign against rebel strongholds. **********Ms. Helms argued that the Bush Administration, having devastated the Iraqi military and thereby "opened the Pandora's Box" of religious, ethnic and irredentist forces in Iraq, may not fully appreciate the consequences of encouraging the drift toward civil war. But there are contrary views. **********Some United States officials and allies, notably Saudi Arabia, are pressing Mr. Bush to maintain a strong military presence in southern Iraq for as long as possible to prevent Iran from taking further advantage of the situation. **********Iran, already said to be aiding the rebels in both north and south, is well positioned to influence the outcome of any civil war. **********"We are creating a situation where the United States wins the war and the Iranians win the peace," said Laurie Mylroie, an Iraq scholar on leave from Harvard University as a visiting fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. **********In an interview, Ms. Mylroie said that the United States was dealing itself out of any role in a future government in Baghdad by refusing to talk to the coalition of opposition groups that held its first postwar convention in Beirut last week. "We are now in a situation where you have an armed revolt of 75 percent of the population," Ms. Mylroie said. Why, she asks, should the Administration look to the other 25 percent, the largely Sunni leadership class, to control the future? **********The answer may lie in the belief among senior analysts in the Administration that the Sunni elite of Iraq, the nationalist core of the country from which leaders have sprung and provided the hard control to hold together Iraq's disparate population, has the best credentials to ultimately remove Mr. Hussein and appoint a successor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.main_headline: Recession? Can't Get Enough of It!
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Recession? Can't Get Enough of It!
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.body_text: **********There is clearly no recession in advertisements with recession-related themes. Anyone unaware that the economy has been in a slump since July need only watch television or leaf through a newspaper to learn all about it -- not from the news, but from the ads. **********These ads began appearing in the fall, increased in frequency during the winter and now, as the recession nears its first anniversary, are in full flower. Especially unusual is that the ads use words and images at odds with the advertising's traditionally perfect universe, a world of endless horizons, blue skies and cheerfulness that might tire even Pollyanna. Here, the horizons are limited; the skies are cloudy, even stormy, and terms like "gloomy," "bad" and "recession" appear. Cajoling and Advice **********"Where is the good news in all the bad news?" asks the headline of a print ad created by Grey Advertising, Los Angeles, for the Coldwell Banker Residential Group real estate brokerage. Another ad in the same campaign advises would-be home buyers on "how to step up in a down market." **********"Look, I know you have less to spend these days," R. David Thomas, founder of the fast-food chain Wendy's International, says earnestly in a television spot created by Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York, "but that doesn't mean you have to eat less." **********In a newspaper ad for Konica Business Machines USA's copiers and facsimile machines, a mock supermarket tabloid carries the headline "Expert tells how to beat recession: Try nothing." The ad, by Keiler Advertising, Farmington, Conn., pitches a program selling office equipment with no finance charge. **********"The economic recovery may be months away," reads the text of a newspaper ad, created by Chiat/Day/ Mojo, New York, for the brokerage firm Shearson Lehman Brothers, "but that doesn't mean you have to wait around to start benefiting from it." The ad offers readers a research report on 14 stocks "that could start recovering before the recovery," so that "you could start your own economic recovery now." **********The trend is not limited to large national advertisers. A series of small newspaper ads for the Adrienne restaurant in New York's Peninsula Hotel asks questions like "Hard times, hard rolls?" **********Recession-related advertising is based on a time-honored tradition of playing off the news of the day. **********"You're trying to create empathy with the consumer, and this is what's on people's minds," said Donny Deutsch, executive vice president and creative director of Deutsch Inc., New York. For one client, the furniture retail chain Ikea, Mr. Deutsch is producing print ads showing fashionably furnished rooms above headlines like "What recession?" **********"Anytime you can bring anything relevant into an ad, the difference of being topical makes it fun," Mr. Deutsch said. **********"It's a sensible strategy," said Judith Langer, head of Langer Associates, New York, a market research and trend-spotting consultancy. In the firm's focus-group interviews, there has emerged "a strong sense among consumers that even if they haven't been affected yet personally," she continued, they are fully aware of the depth and breadth of the country's economic problems. **********Leo J. Shapiro, chairman of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a market survey and consumer research company in Chicago, said: "During a period like this, it irritates people if you tempt them to buy things they don't think they can afford. So there has to be a shift in the way you advertise." **********What makes recession-related campaigns stand out is that advertisers are talking to consumers about an economic climate in which they are spending less money to get them to spend more money. **********"You have to give them permission to spend," Mr. Deutsch said, "because everything out there tells you, psychologically, 'Don't spend; don't spend.' " That is why, he said, his agency's Ikea campaign stresses the chain's philosophy, as described in the advertising, of offering high-quality furniture for lower prices than other furniture retailers. **********One vital ingredient, Mr. Deutsch said, is humor, which leavens the otherwise serious thoughts that might be stirred by frequent invocations of hard times. For that reason many of his agency's Ikea ads also include puns. Other advertisers, including the Stouffer Foods Corporation, temper the somberness of their messages by emphasizing how their products are priced to offer "value," and playing down the economic conditions causing consumers to be concerned about saving money. **********Look for recession-related campaigns to remain popular, Mr. Shapiro said, until they become so popular that "all the competitors" in various consumer-product categories are running them. Then they will be replaced by a new generation of advertising, he said, in which marketers will "talk about their products being better or different."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/24/busin.main_headline: 4 Big Agencies Will Share Work for Northwest Airlines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/24/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 4 Big Agencies Will Share Work for Northwest Airlines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/24/busin.body_text: **********NORTHWEST AIRLINES joined the ranks of giant marketers using more than one large advertising agency when it announced yesterday that it would create a four-way "communications partnership" for worldwide advertising, marketing and promotional campaigns. **********Northwest is hiring this shop quartet: the J. Walter Thompson Company, New York; Ogilvy & Mather, New York; FCB/Leber Katz Partners, New York, and McElligott Wright Morrison White, Minneapolis. **********Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest airline, would not discuss billings, but it is estimated that they could reach $90 million in the next year. Northwest's spending has fluctuated between $20 million and $60 million in the last three years, varying with the economy's ups and downs and the Persian Gulf war. **********"It became obvious to us we needed to present a face, and communicate, on a global basis," Christopher E. Clouser, senior vice president of communications and advertising, said in a telephone interview from Northwest's offices in Minneapolis. The joint task of the four agencies, he added, will be "to produce the operating and communication strategy for a global brand." **********While specific assignments for each agency are still to be determined, Mr. Clouser described this general lineup: domestic and international advertising aimed at consumers, to Thompson; the Trump Shuttle, assuming Northwest's deal to manage it goes through, and a second, undisclosed project, to Ogilvy; direct-marketing campaigns aimed at business travelers and frequent flyers, to FCB/Leber Katz, and corporate identity, to McElligott Wright. **********Hiring two or more agencies to work on huge accounts has become popular in the last couple of years. Among those doing so are McDonald's, which splits its account between the Leo Burnett Company and DDB Needham Worldwide; I.B.M., which employs Wells Rich Greene BDDP and Lintas New York, and Burger King, which has on its roster Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. **********"This is a pretty bold experiment," said Tony Wright, president of McElligott Wright, "to choose four agencies to work together to come up with big global ideas." Mr. Wright, who worked on the British Airways campaigns in Britain, said he would welcome the partnership because it was "tough to do great advertising that crosses borders." **********At Ogilvy, Bill Hamilton, executive vice president and creative head, said, "We're going into this with the idea we're going to work together to leverage the entire Northwest brand." It can work, he added, "if you have your head screwed on right and don't play N.I.H. games" -- meaning accepting the others' ideas instead of resisting them as "not invented here." **********To help make the partnership work, top executives of the agencies will meet quarterly with Northwest officials. All will become members of a new communications board the airline will create. Mr. Clouser hopes new ads can appear in the next 90 days. **********Northwest's decision ends a seven-year relationship with Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, which handled Northwest's consumer account. "We're very proud of what we did," said Ed Wax, president and chief executive of Saatchi. "But this is a business where change is inevitable." The ad community had been speculating about an agency change since April, when Mr. Clouser and Peter Hoult, senior vice president of marketing and sales, joined the airline. Indeed, the company acknowledged in May that it was reviewing the status of its account. **********Once Northwest decided to rethink its marketing communications in worldwide terms, Mr. Clouser said, that presented a conflict for Saatchi. Its British parent, Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., represents British Airways internationally. **********For Ogilvy, the assignment means "we're back in the airline business," Mr. Hamilton said. Its relationship with Eastern Airlines ended when Eastern went out of business this year. The Trump Shuttle account, which billed as much as $7 million to $9 million under Donald J. Trump, had been handled by Scali, McCabe, Sloves, New York. **********Northwest's decision also puts Thompson back in the airline business for the first time since it handled USAir's account from 1978 to 1986. "It's exactly what we've been looking for," said Donald Sullivan, executive vice president of Thompson. The agency is known for its Pan Am campaigns from 1942 to 1978, including "Pan Am makes the going great."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.print_headline: FORUM; The War's Inevitable Fifth Horseman
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.body_text: **********As the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse rampage east of the Suez, yet another scenario for a short, bargain-priced war is vanishing in the sands. The ghastly implications of this"creeping Vietnamization" are clear. But human sacrifices will not be the only costs. **********In modern wars, a Fifth Horseman always trails behind the more familiar quartet to claim the toll on mountains of debt run up by the armies as they fire the cash equivalent of Mercedes-Benzes back and forth at each other. In 1991, this horseman's long, black shadow already stretches far across America. **********Back in November 1990, when Desert Storm was still Desert Shield, the Center for Defense Information, a private research organization in Washington, estimated that the operation added about $74 million a day -- or $27 billion a year -- to the military budget. **********This sum, however, did not take account of subsequent deployments, later revelations that the Pentagon was paying premium prices for equipment acquired on short notice or the gigantic costs of canceled debts and foreign-aid payments funneled to third world economies devastated by the crisis. For example, the United States has already forgiven about $7 billion in loans to Egypt alone. As of last December, at least half a dozen more countries had also received money from the allied coalition. **********Once the air war started -- at about $500 million a day -- the sky became the limit in many senses. A recent Congressional Budget Office report suggests that a short, one-month war could cost about $28 billion while a longer one of six-months would cost $86 billion. But these widely repeated figures also neglect the costs of foreign aid and debt forgiveness. **********The Administration, however, argues against any tax increase, claiming that the war amounts to an extraordinary one-time expense, which should simply be rolled into the deficit. **********The Bush team also suggested that the allies and the gulf states will bail out the United States by agreeing to pick up much of the tab, a claim the President advanced himself in the State of the Union address. **********These assertions essentially represent a very curious new "voodoo economics" of war. **********While Administration economists sit in one room of the White House explaining that the war is a one-time expense, their colleagues down the hall at the National Security Council and across town at the State Department are leaking sweeping plans to restructure the whole Middle East once the shooting dies away. **********Now it is perfectly obvious that the web of bilateral treaties and special security agreements American policy makers envision for the region will be spun from threads of the purest gold. Foreign aid "loans" -- better read as grants -- and, particularly, foreign military assistance, are destined to skyrocket. And while the Chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, argues that costs can be contained by not replenishing depreciated equipment, the postwar scenarios envision a massive pre-positioned buildup in the desert for possible future use. **********The golden cloud does come with a silver lining: Saddam Hussein is an authentic monster whose departure will be extensively unlamented. **********But there is a tunnel at the end of the light. Apparently unaware of how its "new world order" looks to the vast mass of poor Arabs, Washington now appears determined to throw its full weight behind a set of quasi-feudal regimes on the verge of a head-on collision with democracy and the 20th century. This we have all seen before and as we know, implies further visits by all Five Horsemen. **********As for the allied promises to pay, the paltry amounts actually anted up thus far suggest that for purposes of realistic fiscal planning, these must be regarded as the equivalent of sovereign "junk bonds": worth something, but much less than face value. **********Nor is it reasonable, once the war ends, to expect either the gulf states or the allies to finance a Middle Eastern Pax Americana at anything remotely resembling concessionary rates. Obtaining foreign financing for two major wars cost Britain its empire; in the long run, Americans cannot expect to pay any less if they go that route. Citizens and especially the Congress, accordingly, should recall that the policy makers who now assure them that foreigners will open their wallets are the same ones who said the allies would open their markets. **********The Fifth Horseman, however, is implacable. He must still be paid. How? **********Probably not in steeply inflated dollars. For this to occur, the political and economic establishment would have to be prepared to cede the international role of the dollar. This is about as likely as oil flowing uphill. **********In the end, it is all too clear who will pay. American overseas assistance to less strategic areas will be cut even more, but most of the costs will come out of the domestic civilian sector. **********Spending on virtually everything besides the military will be even more desperately squeezed. Financial pressures on states and cities will intensify. However, many of the foregone expenditures are precisely those that are most vital to the revival of American productivity. **********But the Fifth Horseman will claim still more. In the short run, extra military spending will help pull the economy out of recession. But as the economy revives, the tumescent deficit will keep fueling total demand. To limit inflation, the Federal Reserve will have to tighten the money supply, bringing the economy right back to the devastating combination of tight money and expansive fiscal policy that defined real-life Reaganomics. **********In the short run, as we learned in the 1980's, such policies can produce political business cycles substantial enough to guarantee the re-election of almost any regime. But as we also learned in the 80's, the cost in terms of long-term industrial competitiveness is steep: fixed investment by business -- outside of the military sectors -- is desperately squeezed, while import-competing and interest-sensitive industries like automobiles are hammered. **********The Fifth Horseman's ultimate victims will thus be the middle- and working-class Americans whose real earnings will continue falling while racial and economic inequality increase.
