Making a Difference;
On the Block: Yogi & Co.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/busin.body_text: **********Hanna-Barbera Productions created Yogi Bear and Fred Flintstone. But at least one of the Hollywood cartoon studio's most valuable properties is human. He is David Kirschner, the 36-year-old president and chief executive. **********Earlier this month, the studio's owner, the Great American Communications Company, said it might sell Hanna-Barbera for cash to meet heavy debt payments. One interested suitor is MCA Inc. **********What role Mr. Kirschner might have under new ownership is not known. But the question is important because the executive, a talented illustrator and idea man, has played a major part in the studio's rejuvenation. Indeed, when Mr. Kirschner, a film producer who created the characters for the animated movie "An American Tail," joined Hanna-Barbera in 1989, the studio was moribund. It had not had a big hit since "The Smurfs" in the early 1980's. **********Now it is rolling again. Mr. Kirschner has coaxed several new Saturday morning shows out of Hanna-Barbera, including one portraying Yogi Bear in his teen years. And two series, "Fish Police" and "Capitol Critters," produced with Steven Bochco, are set for prime time next winter. Cartoons, it seems, are in. **********"Baby boomers who grew up on classic Disney, Warner Brothers and Hanna-Barbera are now writers and producers and heads of studios," Mr. Kirschner said. "They want to do the same things with their families they did as kids. On Friday nights, the Kirschner family used to sit down together to watch the Flintstones. Today, I do it with my kids to watch the Simpsons."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/07/world.main_headline: Japan's Chief Regrets Scrapping of Bush Trip
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/07/world.print_headline: Japan's Chief Regrets Scrapping of Bush Trip
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/07/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa expressed regret today over the cancellation of President Bush's visit to Japan, while his aides struggled to come up with a new plan to overcome recent strains in the relationship with the United States. **********Officials had hoped that Mr. Bush's trip, which had been scheduled for this month, would arrest the rising mutual criticism between Japan and the United States, especially focused on the approaching 50th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. **********There had been plans for Mr. Bush and Mr. Miyazawa to renew Japanese- American ties by issuing a "Tokyo Declaration" to provide impetus for solving immediate trade frictions and mobilizing resources in other parts of the world. **********Now such plans will be postponed or discussed piecemeal with other Cabinet members scheduled to visit Japan in the coming days and weeks. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney are among those expected to visit Tokyo within the next month. **********Some irritation was expressed among those who had been planning Mr. Bush's trip, especially because the President had canceled an earlier trip to Japan in February because of the war against Iraq. But Mr. Miyazawa said at a news conference that he understood the reasons. **********"I feel sorry that he cannot come," he said. "But it also seems unavoidable. I hope he can come as soon as possible." **********Other officials said they were taken aback that Mr. Bush's political problems at home were so serious that they forced him to pay attention. **********"The more we hear about the recent defeat in Pennsylvania, and rising voices demanding the President to pay more attention to domestic matters, the more we understand that this is one of those things he has to do," a senior official said. **********He was referring to the defeat of Mr. Bush's friend, former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, by Harris Wofford, a little-known Democrat with an anti-Bush message, for the United States Senate from Pennsylvania. Concern Over Pearl Harbor **********There was speculation in Japan over whether Mr. Miyazawa would now travel to the United States. Mr. Miyazawa said at his news conference that it was too early to discuss the possibility of a trip. **********One focus of Japanese attention was whether Mr. Bush would follow through on plans to attend the memorial service for the Pearl Harbor attack on Dec. 7. Japan had been hoping to use Mr. Bush's trip for a reaffirmation of the Japan-United States friendship before his appearance in Hawaii. **********Japanese officials acknowledged that Mr. Bush's trip to Japan would not be accompanied by any breakthrough on the many issues dividing Washington and Tokyo. **********Japan is not yet prepared to accept Washington's demand that it open its markets to imported rice. Nor has there been progress on other trade issues. **********Mr. Bush was to have visited Japan, South Korea, Singapore and Australia. But American officials have said the main intent was to reassure Tokyo and Seoul that even as Washington withdraws troops from Asia, it still regards this region as critically important.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.body_text: **********The United States today asked Japan to begin talks on a new semiconductor agreement to replace a controversial accord that expires in July, Japanese officials said. **********United States trade officials said American chip and computer industry groups had reached a consensus on the need for a continued arrangement to improve United States access to the Japanese semiconductor market and monitor prices to protect against dumping, an official at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said. **********The discussions are likely to focus on whether the agreement should contain a specific target for foreign market share in Japan. In a controversial "side letter" to the current agreement, the Japanese Government said it would work to achieve a foreign market share of 20 percent by the expiration of the accord. United States officials say the figure was a commitment, while Japan maintains it was only a goal. **********After rising steadily for a year and a half, the foreign chip share slipped three-tenths of a point, to 13.1 percent, in the third quarter of 1990. **********The agreement also called for an end to "dumping," or the selling of chips at less than fair market price, in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/19/world.main_headline: Those Who Have Taken Leadership in the Kremlin
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/19/world.print_headline: THE SOVIET CRISIS; Those Who Have Taken Leadership in the Kremlin
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/19/world.body_text: **********Gennadi Ivanovic Yanayev Vice President **********Appointed Vice President a year and a half ago by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. . . . Liberals and reformers in the Party said he was a committed member of the right wing. . , . But Mr. Yanayev calls himself "a Communist to the depths of my soul." . . . Born in Gorky region of Russia in 1937. . . . Graduated from the Gorky Agricultual Institute and the All-Union Law Institute. . . . Holds an advanced degree in history. . . . Rose through Soviet youth groups locally and nationally until he earned a place on the Politboro in 1990. . . . His rise to vice president disappointed reformers who had hoped for a more aggressive supporter. . . . Many saw him and Mr. Gorbachev as kindred spirits. . . . Initially an active proponent of perestroika, which caused some to say Mr. Gorbachev had found a yes man. . . . But he told the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies, "I'm a normal guy, I assure you," and Mr. Gorbachev pleaded, "I want someone alongside me I can trust." Vladimir A. Kryuchkov Chairman, K.G.B. **********Accompanied Mikhail S. Gorbachev to Washington in December 1988 for a summit meeting with President Reagan, and thus startled both American experts and some in the Communist Party itself since it was one of the few times that a senior Soviet intelligence officer had accompanied a Soviet leader to the United States, and Mr. Kryuchkov leaped over several others in the party to achieve such a prominent and visible role. . . .Worried the Bush Administration last year by assailing Mr. Gorbachev's reforms as "blind radicalism," giving a firm indication that Mr. Gorbachev's position in power was anything but secure. . . .A hardliner, Mr. Kryuchkov joined the party in 1944. . . .As a young diplomat, was chosen as an assistant to Ambassador Yuri V. Andropov, who played an important role in the invasion of Hungary in 1956. When Mr. Andropov became director of the K.G.B. in 1967, Mr. Kryuchkov moved with him as a senior aide. . . .According to many American officials, he next served at the United Nations as the Soviet Union's senior spy, or "rezidant." Valentin S. Pavlov Prime Minister **********Appointed prime minister in January, follwing a term as Finance Minister. . . . In February he said Mr. Gorbachev's plan to order large ruble notes out of circulation was intended to foil a Western bankers' plot to topple the Government by cornering billions in rubles and destablizing the economy. . . . Had led the push in October 1969 to raise prices of beer, cigarettes and delicacies. . . . Defended the decision as necessary to pay for social benefits, including payments to rail workers, police officers and school teachers. . . . Not a popular move in a country of heavy smokers and drinkers. Dmitri T. Yazov Minister of Defense **********Appointed Defense Minister in May 1987, plucked by Mr. Gorbachev from his command of the Soviet army's Far Eastern strategic forces. . . . Typical of most Soviet appointments, he was not well known to Western analysts. . . . At 67, Mr. Yazov has already headed two of the Soviet Union's 16 military districts -- the Far East and Central Asia -- and has commanded Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia.  . . . Mr. Gorbachev seemed to rely on his breadth of experience. . . . Most important, he had spent the years from 1977 to 1987 out of the country, which many analyists believed made him free of political entanglements at home. Boris Karlovich Pugo Minister of Internal Affairs **********Among the recent movers in the Soviet Politboro. . . . Born in Kalinin, Latvia, 55 years ago. . . . Graudated in 1960 from Riga Polytechnical Institute. . . . Served as chairman of the Central Committee's party control committee. . , , Appointed chairman of the party watchdog agency in September 1988. . . . Member of the Central Committee since 1986. . . . Rose to power as a party leader in Latvia for four years, beginning in 1984. . . . Joined the KGB in 1976, rising to head the Statet Security Committee of Latvia. . . . Occupied various party and Komsomol Communist Youth posts since 1961, including party boss of Riga, Latvia's capital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/world.main_headline: Dourados Journal; For Brazil's Indians, a Final Way Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/world.print_headline: Dourados Journal; For Brazil's Indians, a Final Way Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/world.body_text: **********There is an underside to the prosperity in this area of Brazil's agricultural frontier, a landscape of grain silos, sleek white cattle and a sea of soybeans extending west to the horizon. **********In despair over the collective loss of Brazil's west, this municipality's original inhabitants are quietly killing themselves. Last year, in a reservation of 7,200 Indians, there were 29 suicides, and 8 more were reported by mid-May of this year. **********"Nineteen-ninety was the year it exploded," said Maria Aparecida da Costa Pereira, a psychologist sent here by the National Indian Foundation, a Government agency known to everyone here as Funai. "They are sending out an appeal. The suicides speak of a lack of prospects, of a lack of a future." **********The Americas are littered with unsuccessful attempts at reconciling Indian and European cultures, but the Dourados reservation is an especially stark example as the hemisphere prepares for observations next year of the 500th anniversary of the arrival of Christopher Columbus.  Reserve Dates to 1920's **********In an attempt to speed the Kaiowa Indians' assimilation of European ways, the Dourados reserve was established here in the 1920's alongside one of the few white outposts in a wilderness territory called Mato Grosso, or Big Forest. **********"When I came here, Dourados had six inhabitants," recalled Irenio Isnard, a wizened Kaiowa man of 91 years who sat on a stool, protected from the shade by a crumpled hat. **********Today, Dourados is an agro-business center of 150,000 people. But over the years, the adjacent 8,819-acre reservation has become a dumping ground for ranchers who wanted to rid their lands of migratory bands of Kaiowa, a subgroup of the Guarani, an ethnic group once found across southern Brazil and Paraguay. **********Today, the Dourados reserve holds almost one Indian per acre -- not enough land for traditional subsistence farming. To survive, Indian men work as migrant laborers, leaving the reservation for months to cut sugar cane for alcohol distilleries situated several hours by truck from here. Indian women walk to town to sell Indian trinkets, to beg or to engage in prostitution. Until it was closed recently, a town dump was on the edge of the reserve, providing limited material for scavengers. **********"I once saw 30 to 40 Indians fighting over clothes and toys in the dump," Joel Vitorino da Silva, a former Indian protection agent, said as he drove a car down the red dirt roads of the reserve.  Churches Move In **********Neighboring white farmers started to rent Indian land, and traders brought in alcohol from the adjacent town. The last traditional shaman died a decade ago, and evangelical churches aggressively moved into the reserve, preaching against the Indians' ancestral beliefs. An Adventist mission had been on the reserve since the 1940's, maintaining the Kaiowas only hospital. But five new churches have opened recently, limiting their social action to collecting monthly tithes. **********"Historically, in situations of pressure, the Guarani withdraw," said Ms. Pereira, the psychologist. "Under pressure, the Guarani resort to migration, prayer or death." **********With the big forest now a big farm, there is nowhere to go. **********In Mato Grosso do Sul state, the Kaiowa and other Guarani subgroups have been concentrated in 11 reserves, totaling 52,000 acres. The Missionary Indigenous Council, a Roman Catholic group, seeks legalization of 10 more reserves, which would almost double recognized Indian land. **********But previous attempts at protecting the Indians have been slapped down by hostile local judges or by violence from ranchers.  Encounter With the Pope **********In one appeal that caught the eyes of the world, a Kaiowa leader from Dourados, Marcal de Souza, addressed Pope John Paul II during the Pope's visit to Brazil in 1980. **********"When Brazil was discovered, we were a great nation," Mr. de Souza said of Brazil's Indian population, which has dwindled from an estimated six million 500 years ago to 230,000 today. "Today, we inhabit the margins of this country with no way to live. Even our survival is in danger as we are being murdered on this land." **********Turning to the stocky Indian leader, the Pope replied: "With all my heart, I hope that you, as the first inhabitants of this land, will obtain the right to live in peace and tranquillity. May you not suffer the true nightmare of being removed for the benefit of others." **********Three years later, Mr. de Souza was slain. Although evidence appeared to point to a local rancher, Libero Monteiro de Lima, the case has never gone to trial. Moving faster, however, a state judge recently upheld Mr. de Lima's claim to 5,700 acres of land now occupied by 200 Indians. Funai, the Indian protection service, is appealing the decision. **********Feeling corralled on all fronts, the Kaiowa here started to turn to suicide. **********"For the Guarani, death is not the end," said Olivio Mangolim, regional coordinator of the Missionary Council. "It is a way to get to a better situation without suffering."  Remedial Plan Drawn Up **********Alarmed by the rising suicide rate, especially high among adolescents, Funai drew up a remedial plan in late April. **********To reduce the need for men to migrate for work, the Indian agency plans to build fish ponds and to supply seeds, tools and fertilizers to improve farm yields. To strengthen the role of traditional leaders and of traditional rituals, a prayer house is to be built and a shaman is to be brought in from Paraguay. **********"If necessary, we will remove the new churches," Edivio Battistelli, the superintendent of Funai, said in an interview in Brasilia. "There are also plans to increase the reserve areas. There are Guarani in the state who are completely landless." **********From his perch by his family's mud and wattle house here, Mr. Isnard, like most Indians interviewed, skirted direct talk about the suicides. **********"When I gave orders around here, this didn't happen," said the old man, who handed his chieftancy to his son-in-law in 1986. Mr. Isnard did not mention that his son-in-law attempted suicide himself last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/busin.main_headline: A REVIVAL IS SEEN FOR 'JUNK BONDS' AS MARKET GAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/busin.print_headline: A REVIVAL IS SEEN FOR 'JUNK BONDS' AS MARKET GAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/busin.body_text: **********The Wall Street market for high-risk corporate bonds, which fueled the corporate takeovers of the 1980's only to collapse after a series of defaults and bankruptcies, is showing signs of life. **********More than a year after the bankruptcy of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which pioneered and promoted the market, prices for high-risk, low-grade "junk bonds" have improved sharply, the market seems calmer and major buyers, sellers and underwriters are starting to describe the recovery as viable and real. **********If a new junk bond market takes hold, the effects will be felt from Wall Street to Washington. Companies in need of credit would be less dependent on scarce bank loans. The owners of junk bonds, including a host of savings and loan institutions and insurance companies, would be able to value their assets more accurately and sell them more easily and at better prices. Rescue Cost Could Be Cut **********That, in turn, could pare the bill for rescuing insolvent savings and loans and ease the strain on the nation's insurance industry. **********Junk bonds are corporate bonds whose creditworthiness is at the low end of the grading scale used by Wall Street rating agencies. They came to prominence during the 1980's when they were used by many corporate raiders to stage hostile takeovers that reshaped some of America's largest corporations, and that were blamed for plant closings, job losses and community upheavals. **********The collapse of many junk bond deals also caused bruising losses for many individual investors who were initially attracted to their eye-catching yields. With the bankruptcy of Drexel and the criminal prosecution of Michael R. Milken, the head of the firm's junk bond operation, the market shriveled and seemed on the verge of vanishing. **********But the market seems to have confounded its critics. It has weathered both the Persian Gulf war and an economic recession, two developments that were widely thought to be deadly for junk bond investors. The market is coping surprisingly well with the junk bond sales conducted as part of the Federal bailout of insolvent savings and loans that were major junk bond holders. **********Market research is broader, as firms like Merrill Lynch, Salomon Brothers and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette have stepped in to fill the knowledge gap left by Drexel's demise. And new ways of obtaining current, realistic prices are springing up to guide the traders who are tiptoeing back to the game. **********The clearest sign of recovery is the market's ability to absorb new issues. Since January, three major corporations, RJR Nabisco, Chiquita Brands and Johnston Coca-Cola Bottling Group, have been able to find buyers for a total of $1.85 billion worth of newly issued junk bonds. At least three more new issues totaling $675 million have been announced. Last year, by contrast, only $385.8 million worth of new junk bonds were issued publicly, most of it by only two corporations.  'Fundamental Reason to Exist' **********"The market has a fundamental reason to exist," said Garrett Moran, managing director of the high-yield bond department at Donaldson, Lufkin. "Companies need to raise money to grow their company or make sensible acquisitions. The market is a lot smaller, the deals will be smaller, and the buyer universe will be smaller. But if the deals make sense you'll be surprised how many buyers there are." **********Donaldson, Lufkin did almost $1 billion worth of private junk bond financings last year because "there was so much dislocation in the public market," Mr. Moran added. "If I had those deals to do today, I'd do them as public deals -- there's absolutely no question about it." **********Philip Sanford, senior vice president and treasurer of Johnston Coca-Cola in Chattanooga, Tenn., said he would have been leery of trying to raise money in the junk bond market a year ago. " Clearly there were questions created about the marketplace," he added. "Any issuer would have felt less comfortable than now. But our recent issue was very successful. Our underwriters tell us it was oversubscribed, with new buyers as well as repeat buyers." **********Those who buy bonds also see a sharp improvement. "The market machinery is much stronger that it was," said Morris W. Offit, chief executive of Offitbank, a New York money manager specializing in bonds. "You have securities firms committing more resources to the area, in terms of trading, research and sales distribution. And institutional portfolios are taking a close look at the issues. There is still enough of a yield differential to give you an incentive to buy, as long as you do your homework." Reminder to Investors **********For now, no one is predicting that this reborn junk market will grow into the behemoth it became in the 1980's, when junk bonds fueled a binge of poorly structured deals that made Wall Street rich and left many American corporations laden with expensive debt. Indeed, the failure of many of those companies to pay their bond obligations today is a constant reminder to investors that junk bonds remain a risky venture. But even major defaults do not rattle the market as they once did, as investors have become better at assessing the debt renegotiation process. **********"It's not a completely healthy market yet," said Kingman Penniman, senior vice president in the MCM Investment Research unit at Duff & Phelps, a credit rating agency in Chicago. "But it's certainly been wheeled out of critical care and into the recovery room." **********The prognosis was far less encouraging in the months immediately after Drexel limped from the scene. Firm price quotations were difficult to come by, the available quotes were at fire-sale levels, few dealers were willing to make trades, and analysts were leaving the market in droves. Then came last summer, with the threat of war, an economic recession and an uncertain regulatory climate. Surprises on Regulatory Front **********It has helped, of course, that the gulf war ended so quickly, and that the recession's end is almost, if not certainly, in sight. But market analysts say the real surprises have been on the regulatory front, most notably, the skill with which the Resolution Trust Corporation has handled the $9.1 billion portfolio of junk bonds it accumulated in the course of the savings and loan bailout. **********Fears that a clumsy liquidation of that portfolio would swamp the unsteady junk market have proved groundless. "I give them all the credit in the world," said Martin S. Fridson, managing director of Merrill Lynch's high-yield research unit. "They have felt their way along to see how much they can sell, and how quickly. They've handled it extremely well, and that has reassured the market." **********Market participants have also started to solve some of the information problems that plagued them last year. Duff & Phelps, for example, is offering a new electronic service to provide daily price quotations, based on actual transactions, for 100 junk bonds, and weekly price quotes for more than 200 additional issues. **********And a six-month rally has helped push junk bond prices up to levels that are attracting the attention of professional investors. The investment return on junk bonds this year, as measured by Merrill Lynch's high-yield bond index, is up nearly 20 percent, after a 4.35 percent decline last year. The flow of funds into junk bond mutual funds is improving, and some pension funds have been shopping in the higher-grade end of the junk market, portfolio managers report. **********Although the economic forecast and the gyrations of the stock market still have a powerful effect on junk bond prices, the tone of the market is so much improved that the chief junk bond analyst at Salomon Brothers reversed his earlier pessimism and endorsed junk bonds early last week as a good long-term investment. **********"I had not been bullish for two years," said Joseph C. Bencivenga, the director of high-yield research at Salomon. "But I am definitely optimistic now. When things are fairly priced, it is hard for people to argue with the product." **********Mr. Fridson, of Merrill Lynch, is similarly encouraged. "The market adjusted very quickly to all its problems, and now we're in a position where you can do a reasonable level of business," he said. "We're not going to get back to the Drexel days, with $30 billion in new issuance a year. But there's a reasonable flow of business, and people are feeling much better about the conditions in the market." Nervousness on Insurers **********The market is still nervously waiting to see how state insurance regulators handle the insolvencies of the First Executive Corporation and the First Capital Corporation, two insurance holding companies that had invested heavily in junk bonds. "That's the next 800-pound gorilla this market has to deal with," said Mr. Bencivenga. "Together, they have about $14 billion to $15 billion worth of junk bonds and nobody is eager to see that hit the market." But the regulators have indicated that they will not liquidate the portfolio in a hasty fashion, he added, so he is not unduly alarmed. **********Not everyone in the market is as confident. Some analysts point out that defaults are expected in about $20 billion worth of junk bonds this year, not counting bond issues that are renegotiated before an official default. That is almost 10 percent of the total market, and five times the default level the market had expected back in the early 1980's. Warning by Magazine **********Investment Dealer's Digest, a magazine serving the brokerage community, recently ran a cautionary cover story warning that the mutual funds that are now investing in junk bonds could flee the market just as quickly at the first sign of trouble, increasing volatility and demolishing prices. The magazine warned traders against becoming overly optimistic. **********But for Mr. Bencivenga, this cover story itself was evidence of the market's changed mood; it is unthinkable, he said, that any publication would have felt it necessary or newsworthy to emphasize the junk bond market's weaknesses just a few months ago. **********"This is the way markets work," he said. "They overreact in both directions. We're coming off a huge bottom, where investors overreacted in pounding prices down. We've weeded out the players who don't want to be here. What's left are the people who do want to be here. All told, I think we're poised for continued double-digit annual returns, despite the defaults."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Stanley Expecting Drop in 1990 Net
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.body_text: **********The Stanley Works, the hardware and tools supplier, predicted its earnings for 1990 would be down 5 percent to 8 percent. "Stanley fourth-quarter sales and earnings have been affected by the spreading economic weakness in the United States," said Richard H. Ayers, chairman and chief executive. The company has not yet released earnings for the fourth quarter or the year. **********To offset lower consumer demand, the company is cutting staff through layoffs and attrition, a spokeswoman, Patricia R. McLean, said. The number of cutbacks was not specified. Stanley also moved to save money through worker furloughs over the holidays. In 1989, Stanley earned $117.7 million, or $2.71 a share, on sales of about $2 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/busin.main_headline: Fears on Cut In U.S. Arms; Shrinking of Industry Is Called Dangerous
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/busin.print_headline: Fears on Cut In U.S. Arms; Shrinking of Industry Is Called Dangerous
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/busin.body_text: **********As Pentagon budgets decline sharply, every big weapons contract takes on added importance for military contractors. But few contracts define the stakes so starkly as the selection the Navy will make soon of a company to build its next attack submarine. **********Industry executives and Government officials say that what is at stake is the survival of one of the two remaining submarine-building shipyards -- the General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn. **********Electric Boat has said that unless it receives the next Seawolf contract, which could be awarded as soon as this week, it will probably not have enough business to stay open beyond the middle of the decade. A closing of Electric Boat would mean the loss of 22,000 jobs at the company and thousands more at its suppliers and subcontractors. **********That would leave the Navy totally dependent for its submarines on a single source, Tenneco Inc.'s Newport News shipyard in Virginia. **********While the Seawolf program would be "a matter of relative prosperity for Newport News, it now appears to be a matter of survival for Electric Boat and much of the submarine industrial supplier base in New England," James E. Turner Jr., Electric Boat's general manager, told a Congressional hearing last month. **********The situation at Electric Boat is just one example of how declining military budgets and the resulting shrinkage of the contracting business are raising fears within the Government and the industry of a permanent erosion in the nation's ability to design and manufacture weapons. **********The Air Force's selection last week of a team headed by the Lockheed Corporation to build a new generation of fighter planes gave Lockheed and its partners, General Dynamics and the Boeing Company, a solid base of military aircraft orders for the next two decades. And it left the losing team, the Northrop Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, seemingly dropped from the front ranks of the combat aircraft business, and in the long run, perhaps even being forced out of the field. **********The Army is down to one tank manufacturer, General Dynamics, which is struggling to win enough domestic and foreign tank orders to keep its production line open after 1995. And the Army's selection earlier this month of Boeing and the United Technologies Corporation's Sikorsky division to build a new light attack helicopter seems to doom McDonnell Douglas's helicopter operations to a long period of retrenchment. **********The Grumman Corporation, formerly the premier builder of Navy aircraft, is lobbying furiously in Congress to overturn a decision by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to end the F-14 fighter program. Mr. Cheney's decision would essentially force Grumman out of the aircraft-building business. Only Moderately Concerned **********So far Pentagon officials say they are only moderately concerned about the industry's diminishing size and strength and its ability to provide military superiority to the nation's forces. **********In announcing the selection of the Lockheed team last week, Air Force Secretary Donald B. Rice said concerns about the military contracting industry played no role in his decision. He added that the Air Force "will simply have to leave to market forces" the question of whether some companies leave the airplane business. **********Some people argue that the shrinking of the industry is overdue, since it has been plagued for years with overcapacity, particularly in aircraft manufacturing. Many Government officials say it would be a mistake to start awarding weapons contracts on any basis other than merit and cost. **********But as more companies approach the day when they must mothball their assembly lines, dismiss engineering and scientific staffs and cut back on research, there are growing warnings -- some, predictably, motivated by self-interest and pork-barrel politics -- that the Pentagon should slow the dismantling of the industrial base on which it has relied. **********In a speech last month, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said, "Our declining defense industrial base and the long-term consequences of decisions made today about the procurement of weapons systems" amount to a "serious problem that threatens to endanger the security of the United States." He urged the Navy to give the Seawolf contract to Electric Boat. **********Many industry executives and analysts and Government officials stop short of calling for the Pentagon to take an active role in managing the shrinkage of the industry. But they say the military should do more to define what it needs to insure that the appropriate industrial abilities are retained. **********"We still face the question of what is the minimum capability we require and what are the necessary inefficiencies we need to put up with in order to maintain it," said Gordon Adams, the director of the Defense Budget Project, a nonpartisan research group based in Washington. "Even if they are making the decisions without industrial base considerations, the decisions have industrial base implications." **********The implications are clear on the Seawolf program. Electric Boat won a competition with Newport News several years ago to build the first Seawolf under a $726 million contract. The Navy originally planned to buy three or four Seawolfs a year and to split the business between Electric Boat and Newport News. The Navy thought the competition between the shipyards would bring down the program's costs. **********But with the cold war apparently over and Pentagon budgets being slashed, the Navy now plans on buying no more than one Seawolf a year. **********"We need to honestly face the fact that long-term procurement of one submarine per year will not sustain both submarine construction yards," H. Lawrence Garrett 3d, the Secretary of the Navy, told a Congressional committee several weeks ago. **********The military aircraft business is also being forced to shrink. The Northrop-McDonnell Douglas team's loss on the new fighter program last week leaves Northrop's future almost totally dependent on the B-2 Stealth bomber program, which accounts for more than half the company's revenues. If the B-2 were to be canceled after the 15 planes the Air Force has already ordered -- a step many in Congress think is likely this year -- Northrop would be left as a producer of missiles and electronics systems and as a subcontractor on a few aircraft programs. **********McDonnell Douglas has a large backlog of commercial and transport aircraft orders. But over the next several years, most of its biggest combat aircraft programs will end, including the F-15 and AV-8B fighters and the Apache helicopter. Earlier this year, the Navy canceled the company's other big hope for the future, the A-12 attack plane.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/world.main_headline: Soviets Assure Safety at A-Plant Damaged by Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/world.print_headline: Soviets Assure Safety at A-Plant Damaged by Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/world.body_text: **********Officials said today that no radioactivity escaped during a fire that occurred on Friday night at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, site of the infamous nuclear eruption five years ago. **********About 300 firefighters and 60 fire trucks were rushed to fight the blaze from as far away as Zhitomir, 100 miles away, and Kiev, 60 miles away, and brought it under control by 11:30 P.M., three and a half hours after it began, officials said. **********The fire destroyed the roof over a generator attached to the No. 2 reactor, one of three still functioning since the April 1986 disaster destroyed the No. 4 reactor. **********The blaze was evidently limited to the area of the turbines, which are in a building adjoining a separate building housing the reactors, and did not affect the nuclear reactors. Officials said workers immediately shut the No. 2 reactor down, but that the first and the third continued to operate. Each reactor feeds two turbines. **********Officials later said only one of the turbines of the third reactor was still operating, because the second one, located near the second reactor, was idled. **********Spokesmen for the Soviet Ministry of Nuclear Power Industry and for the Soviet Hydrometeorology Committee, which monitors radiation, said no radioactivity was released during the fire, and radiation levels were unchanged at the plant and in surrouding regions. Fire Laid to Faulty Switch **********According to a statement issued by the spokesman of the Ministry of Nuclear Power Industry, Yevgeny Ignatenko, the fire broke out shortly after 8 P.M. when a faulty switch suddenly sent current to a turbine and generator, starting fires in the wiring. **********The spokesman said workers shut down the No. 2 reactor within a minute, drained oil from the turbine and replaced flammable hydrogen in the generator with nonburning nitrogen. The hydrogen is apparently used to cool the generator. **********But the fire in the bus ducts, which carry the high-tension wires, led to the escape of hydrogen into the turbine hall, "which apparently created the conditions for fire to start in the roof and for one of the trusses supporting the roof to collapse," an official said A Month for Repairs **********The press agency Tass reported that according to Nikolai Skreka, the deputy director of the plant, it would take about a month to repair the damage from the fire. **********Mr. Ignatenko said that the automatic systems and firefighters worked succesfully, and that the fire was fully put out by 11:30 P.M. He said a commission had started work today to investigate the fire. **********Tass reported that Vladimr Yavorivsky, head of the Ukrainian parliamentary commission charged with overseeing the consequences of the 1986 Chernobyl disaster, demanded that the entire power station be immediately shut down. The same demand was made by French Green environmentalists in the European Parliament now meeting in Strasbourg. **********In contrast to the 1986 eruption, when the Soviet Government was slow and evasive in reporting on the disaster, the Soviet media this time gave quick and detailed reports.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/01/busin.main_headline: Ultimately, Customers Will Bear the Cost
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/01/busin.print_headline: Ultimately, Customers Will Bear the Cost
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/01/busin.body_text: **********Bankers said yesterday that the higher deposit insurance premiums they must pay the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will be spread without great pain among their customers and shareholders. But they complained that all banks, including the strong, were being required to pay for the problems of the weak. **********"Everybody is going to try to pass along the cost to their customers with higher fees, lower interest rates on deposits and higher rates on loans," said Raymond V. O'Brien, chairman of the Emigrant Savings Bank, New York. "We can afford it, but it definitely is going to put a dent in our bottom line." **********Bank deposit insurance premiums will rise on July 1 to 23 cents per $100 of deposits, nearly double the 12 cents charged a year ago and up from the 19.5 cents that went into effect Jan. 1. The 23-cent premium will raise about $870 million a year for the F.D.I.C.'s Bank Insurance Fund. Banking industry profits last year were estimated at more than $17 billion. **********Under the current system, where insurance premiums are charged only on deposits in domestic offices, the impact is greatest on those banks that rely heavily on domestic deposits and whose earnings are already at a low level. **********John W. Spiegel, executive vice president at SunTrust Banks Inc., in Atlanta, said the need for banks to keep profits high enough to attract capital will require that the higher insurance costs be eventually passed on to customers. "Most of the banks in our system were planning for a 19.5 cent premium this year, though some had anticipated it could be higher," he said. **********"It is reasonable to expect the banking system to pay for its deposit insurance system" Mr. Spiegel said, "though I think higher-quality banks should pay lower premiums than weaker banks, just like non-smokers pay lower life insurance premiums than smokers." **********James W. Kienker, executive vice president at Boatmen's Bancshares, St. Louis, said that collecting the higher deposit insurance premiums from bank customers and shareholders was ultimately not much different from collecting the cost from taxpayers. "Indirectly, all taxpayers are customers of ours or some other deposit-taking institution," he said. **********Orin Kramer, a New York consultant to financial companies, said that questions about the health of the banking system were more important than the debate over how to refinance the F.D.I.C. **********"The more important question still facing the F.D.I.C.," he said, "is which banks are going to fail and how fast will they be closed." **********Because insurance premiums are charged only on deposits in domestic offices, a recent analysis by Keefe, Bruyette & Woods concluded that the higher rates will hurt many banking companies in the economically troubled Northeast and Middle Atlantic States. These banks, the study said, are already financially weak and rely heavily on domestic deposits for their capital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds; The No-Load, Closed-End Munis
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds; The No-Load, Closed-End Munis
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/busin.body_text: **********The closed-end municipal bond fund industry is a sedate business -- a haven for investors seeking high tax-free yields. But a spark of creativity has energized the $19.5 billion industry. One fund group has eliminated the upfront sales charges, and some people think this approach is likely to spread. **********The investing public is snapping up Van Kampen Merritt's no-load series of six closed-end municipal bond funds. The offerings have raised more than $980 million since the initial subscription started in August. "It was a tremendous success, far beyond our expectations," said Stephen J. Hodgdon, marketing director for Van Kampen Merritt, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill. **********Unlike mutual funds, which continuously issue shares as more investors buy in, closed-end funds sell a fixed number of shares that trade on stock exchanges. Because share prices are set by supply and demand, fund shares can trade at a premium or discount to the value of the securities in their portfolios. **********Until now, new offerings of closed-end funds came to market with hefty underwriting costs built into their share prices. These costs create an immediate premium. So investors might pay $10 for a share of a closed-end fund with a net asset value of $9.30 a share -- for a premium of 7.5 percent. **********After the initial public offering, the share prices often drop, sometimes to the point where the fund is trading at a discount to its underlying holdings. Therefore, many investment advisers steer investors away from initial offerings. Wait until the shares begin to trade, they say; then buy shares for less than the fund's net asset value. **********But the closed-end municipal bond funds have so far proved an exception, sustaining premiums almost continuously for several years. This is good for stockholders, but many advisers believe the premiums will disappear once the huge demand for tax-free funds is filled. In any event, the higher the purchase price for a fund, the lower the effective yield. **********That is why Thomas J. Herzfeld, an investment adviser in Miami who specializes in closed-end fund investment and analysis, calls the Van Kampen Merritt move "one of the most significant developments in the industry." If other issuers follow its lead, "you'll see price competition in underwriting for the first time in the closed-end municipal market," he said. **********W. Douglas Dent, editor of Cappiello's Closed-End Fund Digest, a newsletter based in Santa Barbara, Calif., calls the Van Kampen innovation "the beginning of a new way of marketing closed-end funds." **********Other fund groups are quietly taking notes. A spokesman for John Nuveen & Company, one of the biggest players in the municipal market, said that while the company had no current plans to issue no-load closed-end municipal bond funds, "we're watching what they are doing." **********If the new marketing structure catches on, it may help convert the entire closed-end industry to no-load form. That is because investors will dump shares that they hold in existing funds that sell for premiums, pocket the profit, and then reinvest in no-load funds with the same yield. The selling in turn may drive down the premiums on existing funds. **********Even now, premiums have been sliding on two other Van Kampen funds: the premium on the Investment Grade Municipal Bond Fund peaked at 8 percent in September and slipped to 6 percent last week; the premium on its Municipal Income Trust dropped from 9 percent in early October to 3 percent. **********Here is how the Van Kampen Merritt deal works: Instead of tacking on the normal underwriting fee of 6 or 7 percent, Van Kampen is acting as its own distributor and using its own money to pay 3 percent commissions to the sales force. To recoup the upfront sales costs, Van Kampen charges higher management and administrative fees than comparable funds. Its fees total about 1.2 percent; by contrast, the Nuveen Investment Quality Municipal Fund has expenses of 74-hundredths of 1 percent. **********Which is the better deal for investors -- a lower upfront sales charge or lower expenses? Because both reduce the fund's yield, the answer depends on the size of the expenses and the premium on the fund. **********For example, on Oct. 23 the Nuveen fund yielded 6.76 percent after expenses. A comparable Van Kampen fund would yield 6.30 percent. But because the Nuveen fund sells for a 7 percent premium, its real yield is only 6.29 percent, roughly the same as the level of a Van Kampen fund. **********Even with their higher annual costs, the Van Kampen funds confer an extra benefit: the new no-load funds are less vulnerable to market risks than funds that sell at premiums. Premiums can erode for many reasons, and it is simpler for fund sponsors to erase a discount than re-create a premium. **********For these reasons, both advisers recommend the new no-load funds, which Mr. Dent calls an "attractive, innovative deal" -- the flaw, if any, is the high administrative expense. **********Van Kampen Merritt is still offering shares in the California, Florida, New York and Ohio funds. The Pennsylvania and national funds are closed, although trading has not yet begun.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.main_headline: Managing; Americans Aim To Speak in Many Other Tongues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.print_headline: Managing; Americans Aim To Speak in Many Other Tongues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.body_text: **********Market research told the Ryko Manufacturing Company that selling its car wash equipment in France would be a breeze. But when it tried, potential buyers resisted mightily -- and for a good reason. Ryko's instruction manuals were in English, a language that few car wash operators could read. **********So Ryko translated its manual into French, and 1991 sales took off. "Operating in local languages has become a necessary part of competing overseas," said Barbara Wilson, international administrative assistant for the Grimes, Iowa, company. **********No one has hard numbers to prove it, but language experts insist that more American companies are reaching that conclusion. "The demand may not be a gusher yet, but it is a lot steadier than a trickle or a drip," said Bernard Bierman, editor of Translation News, an industry newsletter. **********All of this is wonderful news for the 4,500 members of the American Translators Association, as well as linguistically talented students who may want to join the profession. **********"Our graduates no longer have to go to Europe to find good jobs," said Margarita B. Bowen, head of the division of interpretation and translation at Georgetown University's School of Languages and Linguistics. **********Peter Priest, who heads a Russian translation program for engineering students at the Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology in Terre Haute, Ind., has noticed that "Corporate recruiters who used to only care about our students' engineering skills increasingly ask about their translation abilities." **********There are many reasons for the upsurge: *********** More strategic alliances with foreign companies. "American companies do not want a foreign partner's translation of a contract to be the operating document," said Marilyn Miller, president of Language Services International, a Des Moines translation agency whose volume of corporate assignments has doubled annually for three years. *********** The opening up of Eastern Europe to foreign commerce. "Eastern Europeans have no point of reference for phrases like 'stock exchange' or 'leveraged buyout,' so the translations have to be done here," said Ronald J. Patten, dean of DePaul University's College of Commerce. *********** More innovation, particularly in pharmaceuticals. "Intensified competition has yielded more research, more patents, and more multinational lawsuits -- all of which means more translations," said Peter C. Richardson, general patent counsel of Pfizer Inc. Anne Saxon, a New York interpreter of Italian, adds that pharmaceutical companies are holding more international teleconferences, requiring oral interpretations of speakers. *********** The increased flow of immigrants and tourists to the United States. Spanish-language translators report more assignments to translate textbooks, bill inserts, advertising and other material from English into Spanish, for the benefit of the rapidly growing Hispanic population. American hotels, travel agents and restaurants are translating brochures, menus and such from English into Japanese, German and other languages spoken in thriving economies. *********** Increased clamor from overseas distributors of American products for materials in their own languages. Amana Refrigeration Inc., for one, just translated user manuals for its major appliances into Greek and Hebrew, at the request of distributors in Greece and Israel. It is now doing one in Portugese, for its distributor in Portugal. "They say they can sell our product more readily if we stop assuming that everyone speaks English," said Brian K. Parrott, who supervises the production of Amana's customer literature. **********Fisher Controls, the instrumentation subsidiary of the Monsanto Company, even wants to match dialects. For its European customers, it has customer training guides in French, Spanish and Portugese. Now it is tailoring those guides to match the way Spanish and Portugese are spoken, respectively, in Columbia and Brazil. "We want to accommodate any culture that uses our equipment," said Joseph M. Morris, a marketing manager in Fisher's education department. **********Of course, not all translations are done in the United States. Fisher, and other companies looking for local nuances, generally turn to translators in the country they have targeted. Companies listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange generally have their annual reports translated into Japanese in Tokyo. And companies often let their own overseas offices translate brochures. **********"The products we sell overseas, we make overseas, so doing the translations here doesn't make sense," said John Cox, a senior vice president at Avon Products Inc. **********Maybe not -- but foreign translators can massacre idioms. One American company just asked Louis Korda, a Hungarian translator in New York, to retranslate several documents. "They got nervous when the Hungarians translated 'blue chip company' as 'maker of blue chips,' " Mr. Korda said. TRANSLATORS AND ANTITRUST **********Four years ago, the American Translators Association, rankled that its members often got paid just a few hundred dollars for translating complicated documents, began publishing annual guidelines for what translators should charge. **********The Federal Trade Commission was not amused. It is investigating whether the practice constitutes price-fixing. **********Frank Patton Jr., a New York lawyer representing the association, says that in January his client provided the F.T.C. with the documents it requested and has heard nothing further. But the group is taking no chances on an unfavorable ruling. It has adopted a "specific and defined and tough policy to comply with antitrust requirements," Mr. Patton said. Thus, the 1990 fee recommendations -- $95 per 1,000 words for nontechnical translation, $105 for technical translations -- will be the last. **********The F.T.C. would not discuss the case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/16/world.main_headline: Radio Linked to C.I.A. Urges Iraqis to Overthrow Hussein
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/16/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Radio Linked to C.I.A. Urges Iraqis to Overthrow Hussein
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/16/world.body_text: **********For more than three months, the Voice of Free Iraq, a clandestine radio station that Iraqi exiles have linked to the Central Intelligence Agency, has passionately urged the Iraqi people to rise up against President Saddam Hussein, appealed to the Iraqi Army to embrace the popular revolt and even extolled the prospect of martyrdom for the cause. **********The existence of the station became widely known this month when NBC News reported that it was operating with the help of the C.I.A., which has declined to confirm or deny such reports. **********The station continued to broadcast emotional calls for revolution from its base on the outskirts of the Saudi port city of Jidda even after the White House declared publicly on March 26 that it would not interfere in the Iraqi civil war. **********Whether the broadcasts helped to incite the people or the armed forces of Iraq to rebel is impossible to determine. The broadcasts are beamed into Iraq on four frequencies and, according to some Iraqi exiles, use transmitters in Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates. Coupled with President Bush's call to the Iraqi people and army to force President Hussein to "step aside," they may have encouraged the rebellion. **********But it is not known what percentage of the Iraqi population can receive radio broadcasts. Allied bombings knocked out much of the country's electricity, and because of the global embargo against Iraq, batteries have been scarce and expensive. In addition, the Voice of Free Iraq is only one of at least four opposition radio stations. **********The station announced its existence in a broadcast on Jan. 2, two weeks before the beginning of the war. **********"It will be an information backup for the Iraqi people's struggle, whose nationalist forces are gathering today to exercise their role in deciding the fate of Iraq and liberating it from the dictatorial regime," the broadcast proclaimed. **********Iraqi exiles who have taken part in the broadcasts say the station operates under the authority of the Saudi intelligence services and is run by two Iraqi exiles who were once senior members of the governing Baath Party and close associates of Mr. Hussein.  Army Is the Primary Target **********One of the chief managers, Ibrahim al-Zubaidi, is the former director of the state-run Baghdad Radio. He lived in the United States for a number of years. Another manager, Salah Omar Ali al-Tikriti, was involved in the seizure of power in Iraq by the Baath Party in 1968 and played an important role in the public hangings of Jews and other Iraqis as spies in 1969. He served as Minister of Information and Culture and in the early 1980's was Iraq's chief delegate to the United Nations. **********A review of the broadcasts as recorded by the BBC indicates that the primary target is the army. **********In its first broadcast, for example, the radio praised Mr. Hussein's Minister of Defense, Gen. Saadi Tuma Abbas, as a "successful military man, intelligent and educated, who appreciates the current military situation in the region." The broadcast called on General Tuma Abbas to curb "the mad bull and take things in hand." Two weeks ago, Mr. Hussein named his son-in-law, Hussein Kamel al-Majid as Defense Minister, appointing General Tuma Abbbas as a military adviser. **********Only a few of the broadcasts speak about democracy, and none criticize the United States or the vast destruction caused by allied bombing. Rather, they call on Iraq's military to end the civil war by joining with the people to topple the Government. **********"Sons of our Iraqi people, sons of our valiant army, officers and men wherever you may be in all sectors, champion your people's uprising," said a program on the day after the White House statement on noninterference. "Back the will of the people to overthrow the Saddam regime. Slain Iraq will not come back to life except through the force of the army and the people." The broadcast continued, "Stop the bloodshed of your people by staging an army uprising and toppling Saddam." **********On April 6, the radio said that the people looked to the army as the only structure that could unify them and lead them to victory. But some broadcasts directly called the Iraqi people to arms. In an effort to broaden the revolt beyond the Shiite Muslim areas of the south and the Kurdish north, for example, a commentary on April 6 called on "brother Iraqis" to liberate Baghdad.  C.I.A. Role Debated **********A commentary by Mr. Zubaidi on March 20 appeared to revel in the revolt, saying, "The Iraqis have never felt such enthusiasm, joy and a desire to take part in the revolution or to be martyrs." **********The question of C.I.A. involvement has been debated by Iraqi opposition leaders. "This is a C.I.A.-British-Saudi operation," said Talib al-Shibib, an opposition leader who was Foreign Minister of Iraq during the Baath Party Government that was briefly in power in 1963. "I have met a lot of people who know about this, including C.I.A. people. They're my friends, and I have nothing against them." **********On the other hand, Saad al-Jabr, a London-based Iraqi exile leader, denied that the C.I.A. was involved. "As far as I know, it is run 100 percent by the Iraqis," he said. "It's paid for by the Saudis and other Arab states. To bring in the C.I.A. into everthing is unfair." **********The C.I.A. and the British Government have neither confirmed nor denied involvement, although both have experience in setting up clandestine radio stations around the world.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/11/world.main_headline: For Kuwaitis, First War and Now Wheeze
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/11/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; For Kuwaitis, First War and Now Wheeze
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/11/world.body_text: **********The weather forecast, as carried today by the Armed Forces Desert Network: smoky with a chance of thundershowers. **********This time the forecast was right, although predicting the smoke part was not much of a challenge. It travels on the breeze, and with 500 burning oil wells sending off tall columns of smoke across the flat horizon, you don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows. **********The smoke really is the weather here, turning this city the color of a Cape Cod fog in November, or, if the wind is right, back into the dazzling clearness of a desert spring. **********With each turn comes a change in the feeling in a million throats, and 2 million eyes. **********For a few people, the smoke is life-threatening. Doctors are advising patients with asthma to leave the country, because the smoke is setting off their attacks, and increasing the likelihood that a trip to a hospital emergency room will mean a stay. Wondering About Risks **********But that is no escape, because the air in the hospital is really no better, said Dr. Shafika al-Awadi of the Amiri Hospital. It simply means "we put them in a place where they can't run around, going inside and outside," she said. **********It is hard to judge how many people face an acute risk. There are fewer people living here than there were before the war, and thus fewer asthmatics as well. **********At the Chest Disease Hospital, Kuwait's only specialized hospital for respiratory diseases, the 300 beds in use before the war have been reduced to 80, and on Monday only 12 were in use for respiratory problems. Of those, 6 had cancer and 6 had problems unrelated to the smoke, according to the physician in charge. But on bad days, 4 or 5 people come in. **********And everyone, from doctors to soldiers to oilfield workers, wonders about the longer-term risks. **********There are more pressing risks. Some hospitals have running water only part of the day, and the Chest Disease Hospital got electrical power back only last week. Most hospitals relied heavily on nurses from Egypt, the Philippines and other distant places, and many have returned home. So have many doctors.  'It Can't Be Good for You' **********But despite those problems, the smoke is on everyone's mind -- not to mention everyone's car, clothes and hair. It is also in everyone's nose. **********"It can't be good for you," said Billy Ray Patterson, a drilling superintendent with the Kuwait Oil Company. He left his wife and 12-year-old son in his native New Mexico, which they were visiting on the day the Iraqis invaded, and now he sees no point in exposing them. He is suffering from a sore throat, as is virtually the entire country, and waiting for his shift of 40 working days to end. **********"We've all got raw throats," said Barry Collins, an American supervisor of Dowell Schlumberger, a French company helping to plug wells. "We've warned the company not to be bringing in anybody with respiratory problems -- we could be facing litigation." **********Soldiers from an Army Signal Corps unit stationed near the Iraqi border said that sometimes the smoke was so bad that they quit their volleyball games and sealed themselves in their tents or in air-conditioned shelters. **********"We talk about it, but there's nothing we can do," said Staff Sgt. Jesus Pardo, who is from Sacramento, Calif. **********Sgt. Jonny Campbell of San Francisco said, "Maybe in 10 or 20 years they'll give us compensation pay, like the Agent Orange people." **********Warrant Officer John H. Smith of the 301st Support Group, a retired New York City detective, said that he had never seen air pollution like this, and that his unit moved north from its camp near the port of Shuwaiba to get away from the smoke. **********The smoke had a psychological effect, he said. After his unit crossed the Saudi border at Khafji, his group did not see daylight for two days, and now at night, he said, when a soldier leaves his tent "you walk into a cloud of smoke." **********Ordinary Kuwaitis also describe a psychological effect. Ahmed al-Yaquob, a producer with the state radio network, said that each time he smelled the oil he was reminded of his country's wealth being burned. **********Officially, the Army has no warning or advice for its personnel in the smoke; the spokesman at Camp Freedom, a post south of Kuwait City and near the Ahmadi field, said the issue had not been mentioned in the daily high-level meetings of officers. **********Civilian doctors do not have much advice, either, other than to leave, and they are worried. **********"It's really unhealthy," said Dr. Yousef Mustafa of the Chest Disease Hospital. "Even healthy people are suffering when the smoke blows to our side." **********The clinical definition of chronic bronchitis, he said, includes symptoms like a sore throat and coughing for three months a year for two or three years. The air could be bad that long, and so by definition, most of the country would have chronic bronchitis, he said. **********Wearing a mask might help a little, he said, but "you'd have to wear it 24 hours a day for 2 years."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/busin.body_text: **********The Seagram Company yesterday agreed to sell a group of well-known liquors to American Brands Inc., a diversified company and the maker of Jim Beam bourbon, for $372.5 million. **********Analysts said the deal signaled a move by Seagram to build a war chest for an acquisition. But Seagram said it was simply selling brands with lower profit margins and less growth potential than its costlier offerings, like Chivas Regal. **********The sale of the seven brands including Ronrico rum, Calvert gin, Wolfschmidt vodka and Leroux cordials, requires Federal antitrust clearance and is expected to close before the end of the year. **********"While the divested brands represent approximately one-quarter of the House of Seagram's sales in the United States, they constitute a significantly lower percentage of operating income," said Edgar Bronfman Jr., president of Seagram.  Focus on Premium Brands **********The company has shifted its strategy to focus on premium brands with higher profit margins and greater growth potential. It has run advertising for Chivas that asks, "Drinking Less? Then Drink Better." **********Stephen E. Banner, senior vice president of Seagram, said the company was not actively shopping for acquisitions. But he added: "We are going to be opportunistic. We are certainly going to look at acquisitions, but it really depends on what is out there." **********The sale will reduce Seagram's presence in the market in the United States, where drinking is declining because of health and social factors. **********The drop in consumption has been sharper for cheaper liquors, analysts said. "It's very hard to be optimistic in terms of growth trends in the United States for the lower-end brands," Mr. Banner said. **********William J. Alley, chairman and chief executive of American Brands, said buying the Seagram brands would strengthen the company in the market for vodka, whisky and rum. With the acquisition, American Brands' Jim Beam Brand Company will displace Seagram to become the third-largest spirits company in the United States. **********Mr. Banner, formerly a lawyer with Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, joined Seagram in August. He was described yesterday as a "deal guy" by Roy D. Burry, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company. Mr. Burry said he expected Seagram to make an acquisition within 18 months. **********David A. Goldman, an analyst at the Nomura Research Institute, agreed that the sale was a prelude to an acquisition. Seagram acquired Martell cognac and Tropicana Products Inc. in 1988 for a combined $2.2 billion. "It's fairly clear to me that one shoe has not fallen," Mr. Goldman said. **********Mr. Banner said acquisition candidates would not be limited to the beverage industry. "Clearly, we are going to look for things in our base business," he said, "but if it is not in our base business we would like to see something that is complimentary." **********Seagram, a beverage company with $5 billion in annual sales, also owns 24.5 percent of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. **********American Brands makes the cigarette brands Carlton, Pall Mall and Benson & Hedges. Among other businesses it owns the Franklin Life Insurance Company and the Acco World Corporation, a maker of office supplies. It recently ended an attempt to acquire Invergordon, a spirits company in Europe. **********American Brands shares closed yesterday at $42, unchanged, in New York Stock Exchange trading. Seagram stock gained 50 cents, to $113.50, in Big Board trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/14/busin.main_headline: First American Gets New Chief Executive
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; First American Gets New Chief Executive
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/14/busin.body_text: **********First American Bankshares Inc., the embattled Washington, D.C., bank-holding company that Federal prosecutors say was secretly controlled by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, has announced that George L. Davis, a founder of a New York financial consulting firm with more than 30 years' experience in bank management, has been elected the company's new president and chief executive and a member of the board. **********He will succeed Jack W. Beddow, who retires at the end of the month. **********Mr. Davis, 57 years old, comes to First American after working for Citibank and the First National Bank of Chicago in a number of positions. In late 1990, he founded Scarborough Partners Inc., a financial consulting firm. **********He takes the helm of First American amid an avalanche of negative publicity and in the wake of a significant drop in deposits. **********"My job, historically, has been with things that are at less than a steady state," Mr. Davis said in an interview. "I enjoy it and I think I'm good at it. I enjoy this type of exercise, and I'm pleased with what I've seen. This is not going to be easy, but most American banks have problems today. First American is not alone." **********B.C.C.I.'s operations were shut down this summer after reports linked the bank to numerous abuses, including money laundering and fraud, leaving more than a million depositors, many of them in the developing world, fearing for their money. **********Mr. Davis said he would not be excessively burdened by the B.C.C.I. scandal. "I'm looking right through B.C.C.I.," he said. "Other people wiser and smarter than I are taking care of that." **********Frightened by the negative publicity, however, First American Bankshares depositors withdrew more than $1 billion in the three months up until the end of September. But Mr. Davis said he felt the situation might have stabilized, with deposits rising in November and so far in December. **********"The first thing I've got to do is make sure the ship is stable," said Mr. Davis, who stressed that he would also "do everything possible to collect on the bad loans" and "to get new business -- in a more conservative way than we've done in the past." **********Mr. Davis was chosen because of his leadership abilities and his strong background in a variety of banking positions, said Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, chairman of First American Bankshares, in a release announcing the appointment on Thursday. **********Mr. Davis "has had oversight responsibility for commercial, investment and merchant banking, operations and finance," Mr. Katzenbach said. Mr. Davis said he had contacted Mr. Katzenbach, who succeeded Clark M. Clifford as chairman, offering his services and expertise with troubled banks. **********Mr. Katzenbach, a former Attorney General, general counsel of the International Business Machines Corporation and a friend of Mr. Clifford's, became chairman in August. The Government and the directors of First American agreed to the succession but said Mr. Clifford could not stay on the board. **********Mr. Beddow became president and chief executive in July 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/15/busin.body_text: **********Dillard Department Stores Inc. yesterday denied published reports that it was bidding for Carter Hawley Hales Stores Inc. **********"That's an erroneous story," said William Dillard Sr., the founder of the department store chain based in Little Rock, Ark. "The creditors came out and solicited us to make a bid, but they didn't have any figures to give us." **********Mr. Dillard said that although some of the stores in the Carter Hawley Hale empire might fit into Dillard's expansion strategy, his company was not actively considering a bid for any piece of it. Dillard has almost 200 stores throughout the Midwest and across the Southern United States. **********Acquiring Carter Hawley Hale, which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, would not mesh with Dillard's current strategy to build the chain's business in Florida, said Walter F. Loeb, president of Loeb Associates Inc., a retail consulting firm. Carter Hawley Hale operates the Broadway and other stores in the Southwest and along the West Coast. **********Dillard recently spent $76 million for eight stores in Florida that were part of the Maison Blanche department store chain, a family-owned company based in Baton Rouge, La., giving it a total of 22 properties in Florida. "We are anticipating we'll have a few more there," Mr. Dillard said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/01/world.main_headline: Now, Allies and Others Begin Offering Competing Bids for Postwar Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/01/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: WORLD REACTION; Now, Allies and Others Begin Offering Competing Bids for Postwar Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/01/world.body_text: **********Having stood firmly alongside the United States during the climactic days of the Persian Gulf war, Western European governments are quietly preparing to compete with Washington for political influence in the Middle East now that the fighting is over. **********The allied victory was hailed across Europe today, with Britain and France particularly cheered by the low loss of life among their combat troops. But already the focus of attention seemed to be shifting to the political and diplomatic challenges ahead. **********"If we cannot win the peace, our military victory could turn out to be a Pyrrhic victory," the Italian Foreign Minister, Gianni De Michelis, said today. "Winning the peace will be much more difficult than winning the military conflict." **********In London today, there were no victory parades or pealing church bells, but British political leaders in the House of Commons paid tribute to President Bush and their own and allied forces for their swift success. **********"The victories of peace will take longer than the battles of war," Prime Minister John Major said in the House of Commons. Regional security, he said, "must also deal with the other problems of the region, above all, that of the Palestinians." **********Britain and France feel confident that their participation in the war has already earned them places at future negotiating tables. But Germany, Italy, Spain and other European Community nations are also claiming a role in promoting security, stability and development in the postwar Arab world. France Takes 'No Orders' **********Signaling France's intention to play an active role after the war, President Francois Mitterrand said last weekend, "We will spell out the objectives that we consider just, and no one will give us orders." France will demonstrate, he added, that "it has not gone to war against Islam or Arabs." **********Today, the European Community promised "a global approach" to the problems of the Middle East, a phrase that Community foreign ministers defined last week as dealing with the Arab-Israeli conflict, the Palestinian question and the Lebanese crisis as well as the aftermath of the gulf war. **********Driving the diplomacy is acute awareness that Europe's historical, cultural and geographical links to the Arab world make its interests different from those of the United States. It therefore hopes to insure that Washington is not alone in determining the future of the region. **********It also wants to protect European companies that have long done good business in the Middle East. The only recent sign of disharmony between London and Washington came last week when Britain complained that most contracts for the reconstruction of Kuwait were going to American companies. **********In the months leading up to the war, though, the 12 showed anything but unity. Unable to agree on a joint response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Britain strongly backed the United States, France offered its own peace plans and other nations refused to send ground troops to Saudi Arabia. Regional Bloc Frays **********Yet now that the fighting is over, the cohesion of the anti-Iraq coalition may again be tested by differences within Europe as well as by competition between Europe and the United States. Indeed, in recent weeks European governments have acted more individually than as a regional bloc. **********Britain, for instance, has strong historical and economic ties to Kuwait and the gulf emirates and seems most interested in helping to build a security system in the region, albeit without direct participation of British ground troops. In this, its position is almost identical to Washington's. **********For Bonn, the war has been a diplomatic disaster, as Germany was criticized for its reluctance to help the allies and embarrassed by revelations that German companies developed Iraq's chemical weapons capacity. Earlier this month, it sent Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher to Israel and then to Jordan, Egypt and Syria in the hope of patching up ties. **********France, Spain and Italy, which have large populations of North African immigrants, are most alarmed by the deterioration of their relations with Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia, where pro-Iraqi sentiments were running strong. "We must avoid hurting Arab public opinion that felt solidarity with Iraq," a French politician said today. **********Paris, Madrid and Rome also believe that the bitter legacy of Iraq's defeat can be buried in these and other Arab countries only if the Palestinian problem is addressed. But they recognize that only Washington can persuade Israel to take part in an international conference that tackles this question. **********European governments do at least agree that the Palestine Liberation Organization has destroyed its credibility by supporting Iraq in the war. "The question of the P.L.O. will have to be looked at differently in the light of many of its reactions in recent weeks," Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said today.
