https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/world.main_headline: Honecker's Move to Moscow Causes an Uproar in Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/world.print_headline: Honecker's Move to Moscow Causes an Uproar in Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union said today that it had given advance notice to Germany before flying Erich Honecker, the former East German Communist leader, here for medical care necessary for "humanitarian considerations." **********The transfer of Mr. Honecker has caused an uproar in Germany, where justice officials are demanding his return because of pending charges relating to the deaths of East Germans who were shot by his govenment's police in the days of a divided Germany. **********Charges of Soviet meddling and German collusion are being made in the German press, because Mr. Honecker's flight occurred not long after German courts had declared that Soviet diplomatic immunity did not extend to the Soviet military hospital in Beelitz where Mr. Honecker was treated. **********The Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, denied today that the move was in any way improper, saying "we had talks with the Germans before the fact, as it occurred."  'Not Possible' to Block It **********The Soviet Foreign Ministry later said that Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany had been told several hours in advance of the flight on Wednesday of the 78-year-old Mr. Honecker. A Kohl spokesman said in Bonn that the German Government had been told of the transfer about 90 minutes before it happened, and that by then it was "not possible" to block it. **********Mr. Honecker was said by Soviet officials to be suffering severe cardiac problems that required his shift from the hospital in Germany to a better equipped hospital in the Soviet Union. **********Since the fall of the Berlin wall and the end of the East German Government, Soviet officials had rejected requests from German officials that Mr. Honecker be turned out of the Soviet hospital in Germany to face charges in the deaths of some of the 200 people who had been shot trying to escape to West Germany from 1983 to 1989. **********Mr. Honecker, who had manslaughter charges pending through an extensive period of illness in Germany, has no intention of ever leaving here, according to Friederich Wolff, the lawyer for Mr. Honecker who was quoted in the German press. **********According to the Cologne-Bonn Express, Mr. Wolff said: "He will probably spend the autumn of his life in the Soviet Union."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Mobil Reduces Spending Budget
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/07/busin.body_text: **********The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company, behind the Exxon Corporation, said it had cut back this year's spending budget by $500 million, or 10 percent, from what it had originally planned because of the recession. The company, based in Fairfax, Va., also said it had deferred some investments until business conditions improved. **********"These are difficult times for the oil industry as the pace of economic recovery is slower than expected," said the company's chairman, Allen Murray. He said that the recession in the United States and in key markets abroad was having a significant impact on demand for Mobil's petroleum and chemical products. A Mobil official declined to disclose the actual level of the 1991 capital budget, saying the data are strictly for internal use.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/07/world.main_headline: Russian Republic Backs 28 Percent Tax on Goods
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/07/world.print_headline: Russian Republic Backs 28 Percent Tax on Goods
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/07/world.body_text: **********The Russian republic held fast to its plan for sweeping price rises today as the Parliament approved a 28 percent value-added tax and as other Soviet republics were reported to be reluctantly following the giant republic's lead toward a free-market economy. **********President Boris N. Yeltsin, the republic's leader, under pressure from neighboring republics to hold off on his reform plans, said after a Kremlin meeting that there would be no delay in the timetable to begin freeing prices on most foods and consumer goods in 10 days. **********"Liberalization of prices will start on Dec. 16," Mr. Yeltsin told the Soviet press agency Tass. **********A value-added tax is levied at various stages in the production and sale of a product, putting the burden on businesses to report their full dealings more honestly in order to realize Government rebates. Maintaining Finances **********The tax was chosen as the best way to maintain essential Government finances as prices rise rapidly under the reform program. An income tax would miss the considerable business activities of the black market, and would also be largely irrelevant in the republic's low-wage environment, said finance officials who added that a sales tax, in turn, would be too easily avoidable through off-the-books dealings. **********Tass said six other republics had reacted to Russia's decision by agreeing on plans to begin setting higher limits on certain controlled prices by Jan. 1. Their agreement, Tass said, was made in the hope of absorbing some of the effects of the Russian changes and as a preliminary move in ultimately freeing their own prices. **********Tass identified the six as Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Armenia, Tadzhikistan, Kirghizia and Georgia. But no independent confirmation of this was immediately available, particularly from Ukraine, the republic second in size and economic power to Russia. **********Ukraine sealed its own fervid independence path in a referendum last Sunday and has thus far made a point of avoiding most joint economic operations with other republics. Ukraine finance officials, however, have been most concerned with the aftershocks of Russia's ambitious reform plan and have talked lately of trying to tailor Ukraine's accordingly.  Yeltsin's Forecast **********"In December, Russia faces historic events, the transition to a market economy with all the consequences -- privatization, issuing of shares, changes in taxation and the financial system, liberalization of foreign economic activity and of prices," Tass quoted Mr. Yeltsin as saying. **********Prices have already been shooting upward and consumer goods have become scarcer in anticipation of the Russian reform program. The flow of food supplies into this hard-pressed capital has been severely worsening in the last three weeks and heightening panic buying, say city officials who varied considerably in their estimates of how severe a winter Moscow faces. **********The office of Mayor Gavriil K. Popov insists that while supply lines are increasingly destabilized with the collapse of the Soviet Union's interrepublic structure, the city is certain of enough basics to avoid hunger and manage another bad winter. **********However, Deputy Mayor Yuri Luzhkov, the executive charged with overseeing food supplies, has lately begun issuing more alarming warnings, saying the consumer market was "on the verge of catastrophe." It was Mr. Luzhkov's direct appeal to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that caused the Soviet leader to issue his own sudden appeal Thursday to the rest of the country to help with a "critical situation." Mr. Gorbachev followed up with a message today to Ukraine, Byelorussia, Kazakhstan and Moldavia, all important agricultural areas, saying current reserves of meat, butter and sugar might last only a few more days in the capital. Supplies at State Stores **********His estimates, based on what city officials told him, referred to the situation at state stores, where most people shop. Prices are theoretically low there, but such basic consumer goods have been in rare supply in state shops for months. They have been available, however, in the parallel open-priced markets at costs that have begun rising rapidly in the last several weeks in anticipation of Government price reforms that will end most state price subsidies. **********Mr. Luzhkov estimated that the supply crisis could come to a head in 10 to 15 days if emergency relief was not obtained. But Mayor Popov's office said the city's previous precautions were bearing enough results to protect the city's population of nine million. **********In the most basic measure of the situation, bread, panic buying was occurring at some neighborhood bakeries, even though the city already has enough flour in its storehouses to produce the usual supply through the winter and up to next year's wheat harvest, said Sergei K. Stupar, a spokesman for Mayor Popov. **********But in a whole range of other foods, including meat and dairy products, the city's supplies have waned steadily all year with each new worsening of the union's political and economic crisis, Mr. Stupar said. The city normally consumes 2,000 tons of meat a day, for example, and already is cumulatively short by a total of 60 days' need, which Moscow shoppers have felt and been adjusting to for months. **********"Our normal suppliers are holding on to their produce for themselves or are waiting for prices to rise," Mr. Stupar said. "And that situation is growing worse, in turn, because people are panicking."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/05/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF; War Summary
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/05/world.body_text: **********"BIG MO" GOES TO WAR, AGAIN  For the first time since the Korean War, the battleship Missouri fired its 16-inch guns in combat. Shells weighing a ton each hurtled toward what American commanders described as Iraqi command bunkers near the Kuwaiti coast. The command also reported thatsince the war started aerial bombing sorties averaged one a minute. A report from Baghdad said the capital and environs suffered five hours of predawn raids yesterday. Among other targets were tank formations and the lifelines of Iraqi frontline forces.  THE VIEW FROM THE TOP Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of the American forces, said Saddam Hussein's will to keep fighting is not likely to be broken since he takes a "very rudimentary tactical approach to warfare." The Iraqi military is another story, in his view. It probably is beginning to crack, the general said, and is not "holding up very well." In Washington, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney cautioned that uncertainties still abounded and that no quick victory was in sight. WAR LOSSES ALLIED FORCES Troops: The U.S. Central Command gave no new figures at yesterday's briefing and said the reported deaths of four marines in the a helicopter crash in Saudi Arabia remained unconfirmed. One of three airmen listed as missing after the crash of a B-52 over the weekend was found dead. This brought the number of American losses recorded to date to 15 killed in action, 25 airmen missing and 8 more confirmed as prisoners. Aircraft: A Marine Huey UH-1N helicopter with four men aboard crashed in Saudi Arabia in the 24 hours preceding today's briefing, the second helicopter loss in 24 hours. Termed "non-battle damage," the crash did not add to the previous count of 22 aircraft shot down, 15 of them American. Iraq claimed its forces downed nine more aircraft.  IRAQI FORCES Troops: Iraq issued no report, and aside from some anecdotal evidence, no meaningful figures on military or civilian casualties were otherwise available. Aircraft: The American command added 10 more to its count of Iraqi aircraft impounded in Iran, bringing the total to 99.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/world.main_headline: Crime Bill Would Establish Alien Deportation Tribunal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/world.print_headline: Crime Bill Would Establish Alien Deportation Tribunal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/world.body_text: **********The anticrime bill that President Bush has sent to Congress would permit the Government to hold special tribunals in which foreigners accused of terrorism would not be allowed to rebut or even see some or all of the evidence against them. **********Justice Department officials say the tribunals, which would require the approval of a Federal judge, would give the Government a needed mechanism to deport alien terrorists without being forced to disclose evidence that would reveal the identity of confidential sources, make public the nature of investigative methods or damage relationships with foreign countries. **********The department says the tribunals would not be needed in most terrorism cases, only in those in which the evidence was particularly sensitive.  Principles of Law **********But some civil liberties experts say the proposal would violate fundamental principles of American law: that the Government's evidence against a person must be public, and that the accused has a right to be informed of that evidence and rebut it. **********The provision has been largely overlooked until now in the public debate over the anticrime bill but is drawing increasing fire from civil libertarians as the larger measure nears Senate consideration in June. **********A similar proposal was offered several years ago by Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. It was subsequently incorporated into anticrime legislation put forth by the Reagan Administration, but that bill was never passed. The greatest support for the idea now appears to be coming from within the Justice Department. **********No Congressional hearings have yet been held on the proposal. But aides on Capitol Hill said it was likely to encounter strong opposition on civil liberties grounds, although they acknowledged that heightened anxiety over terrorism in the wake of the Persian Gulf crisis might lend it added support.  'No Secret Courts' **********Representative Don Edwards, a California Democrat who heads a House civil rights subcommittee, predicted that most Democrats on the panel would oppose the provision. "We need no secret courts in America," he said. "There are other ways of handling problems like they seem to fear. There's a Kafkaesque tinge to all of this." **********The Supreme Court has long held that aliens living in the United States who face deportation are entitled to constitutional protections, including a public hearing in which the Government is not entitled to keep evidence against them a secret. **********Existing immigration law does permit the Government to prevent a foreigner from entering the United States on the basis of evidence that can be withheld from that person. The Administration's proposal now seeks to apply similar procedures to foreigners already living in the United States. **********"We're faced with the dilemma of either declassifying information we have about an alien, and compromising our intelligence-gathering methods and endangering human sources, or we have to allow an alien who we know is providing material support to a terrorist group to remain in this country," said Steven R. Valentine, a deputy assistant attorney general who oversees the Justice Department's immigration litigation office. **********The special proceedings could be initiated by the Justice Department against any alien who had "engaged in terrorist activities," as defined by the Immigration Act of 1990. Under that law, terrorism includes support activities like fund-raising and recruiting members for a terrorist group. **********As a result, the Government could seek the deportation of a person who raised money for the African National Congress, for example, or anti-Government forces in El Salvador, said David Cole, a Georgetown University law professor who works for the Center for Constitutional Rights and who opposes the proposal.  Groups Under Scrutiny **********"The Government will obviously be very political about who would be considered a terrorist," said Mr. Cole. "Groups that will be targeted will be those that the Administration doesn't approve of politically." **********But Mr. Valentine said that the procedure "would not be invoked lightly" and suggested that it would be applied in relatively few cases. At present the Government, using ordinary deportation procedures, is seeking the removal of two aliens for associating with a terrorist group, he said.  Both are Palestinians living in Calfornia. **********Here is how the proposal would work, according to both civil liberties lawyers and Justice Department officials: **********The proceeding would begin with the Government's request for a secret hearing before one of five Federal judges who would be designated by the Chief Justice of the United States. With the filing of such a request, which would itself be secret, the Government could arrest and jail an alien under scrutiny. **********If the judge determined that there was probable cause to believe that the alien had engaged in terrorist activities, and that disclosure of the evidence would jeopardize national security, the judge could order the special trial, called a "special removal hearing." **********The judge would be required to decide what, if any, information about the charges could be disclosed. The accused would be given a written summary outlining the general nature of the Government's evidence or a statement that no summary could be made public. **********The removal hearing would be held in public. But the evidence on which the Government's charges were based could be withheld from the accused, and prosecutors could present their evidence to the judge in private, without the accused or defense lawyers present. **********Upon determining that an alien had engaged in terrorist activity, the judge would have to write an opinion to that effect. But those parts of the opinion that related to secret evidence could be withheld from public disclosure. The alien could appeal the decision of the judge, but would still have no access to any evidence presented in secret. **********A person who is ordered deported as a result of such a hearing could be held in jail for as long as it takes the Government to find a country willing to accept him.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/24/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; End of an Era at Kimberly
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/24/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; End of an Era at Kimberly
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/24/busin.body_text: **********When Darwin E. Smith said earlier this month that he would step down Dec. 19 after 20 years as chief executive of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, he also declared that the company soon would pay its 20th consecutive annual dividend increase and split its recently high-flying shares two-for-one. **********Analysts said it was a fitting coda for one of the more dazzling corporate reigns of the last two decades. Mr. Smith, who will be succeeded by Wayne R. Sanders, the company's president, transformed Kimberly from a staid forest products concern when he took charge in 1971 into what is now a handsomely profitable maker of mainly consumer products. **********The one-time Chicago lawyer, who joined the company in 1958 and is now 65, accomplished this by expanding into fast-growing consumer markets, building on brands like Kleenex tissues and Kotex feminine napkins and adding diapers. He used cash raised from auctioning paper mills and forest lands, narrowing the Dallas-based company's reliance on commodity products. **********Initially with the Kimbies brand and, since 1978, with Huggies, Mr. Smith gradually wrestled the lead in diaper sales from the giant of consumer marketing, the Procter & Gamble Company. Huggies, with 32 percent of the United States diaper market last year compared with 11 percent in 1980, contributed nearly one-fourth of Kimberly-Clark's 1990 sales of $6.4 billion. A product introduced in 1987, training pants for toddlers called Huggies Pull-Ups, will post sales of $300 million this year and so far has no competitors. **********Mr. Smith succeeded against Procter & Gamble by spending heavily on new technology, while keeping his eye on long-term financial performance, said Sherman Chao, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. **********The company's return on shareholders' equity was 19.9 percent last year, compared with 5.6 percent in 1971. And the common share price has risen at a yearly average of 14 percent in the last 20 years. **********Yet Mr. Smith, who has long had a reputation for being a demanding boss, has made his share of mistakes, too. A few new products bombed during his tenure, for example, including an enhanced Kleenex called Avert, which was designed to prevent the spread of colds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/29/world.main_headline: U.N. Union Plans International Protest Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/29/world.print_headline: U.N. Union Plans International Protest Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/29/world.body_text: **********They work behind the scenes in offices from New York to Addis Ababa to Tokyo, forming the backbone of a sprawling international organization whose diplomats are receiving growing recognition. **********But many civil servants at the United Nations -- the administrators, researchers, technicians, clerks and others who attend to the details at its agencies and committees -- say they are neither respected nor adequately paid. Their unions assert that work conditions have worsened, and they criticize the United Nations for refusing to negotiate with them. **********In an effort to press its demands, the largest union, the Federation of International Civil Servants' Associations, has planned a protest outside United Nations headquarters on Dec. 6. It says more than 3,000 will attend, including hundreds from United Nations offices around the world. **********The scheduling of the demonstration underscores an increased militancy on the part of the unions, whose calls for pay increases have collided with moves by the world organization to cut costs. The unions have conducted protests in recent years, but not actions of this size. **********Edward J. Freeman, the president of the federation, which represents 32,000 workers at 29 United Nations agencies. said: **********"After 15 years of arguing patiently and submitting tons of documents to show that salaries are not competitive, these arguments have fallen on deaf ears. Now we are going to start on a series of industrial-action campaigns. Now we are going to offer political answers to the problems." **********The unions are not allowed to negotiate directly with the General Assembly, which sets salaries. Instead, they present their case twice a year to the International Civil Service Commission. **********The salaries of most United Nations employees are pegged about 15 percent higher than those of the American Civil Service. There is also a stipend to make up for the higher cost of living in cities like New York or Geneva. A clerical-staff employee is paid the going rate in the city where he or she works, the United Nations says. **********A middle-ranking professional at New York headquarters receives about $43,000 a year after a United Nations income tax and pension payments are taken out, said Prakash Ranadive, the executive secretary of the civil service commission. A secretary gets about $20,000 after similar deductions. **********Between 1984 and 1988, professional salaries were frozen by the General Assembly, a move that angered many workers, Mr. Ranadive said. **********Mr. Freeman said that because of those wage freezes and what he called insufficient cost-of-living increases, salaries and pensions of some union members are 30 percent less than they were in 1975, after adjustments are made for inflation. He added that some United Nations agencies were having trouble recruiting staff members because salaries were not competitive. **********Imelda J. M. Henkin, who works for the director of the United Nations Population Fund, said: "It is a bit difficult these days to recruit competent people at the salaries being offered, especially people in Europe. The salaries there are much more than we can offer." **********Still, some diplomats said they were becoming increasingly frustrated with workers' demands. They asserted that the federation was slanting its data when it said that salaries had declined in real terms. **********"Generally, we think they're paid enough as is," said a Western diplomat who specializes in staffing issues. "They have enough benefits, and we do not think they need any more." **********Diplomats said the unions were getting a sympathetic hearing from France and the Nordic countries. In contrast, the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union, which have lobbied hardest to trim the United Nations bureaucracy, have criticized the unions for seeking money that they say the world organization does not have. **********Many nonaligned nations are less committed to a position, although some maintain that if the United Nations spends more money on staff salaries, financing for development projects might suffer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/28/busin.main_headline: Bills Seek More Competition in Electricity Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/28/busin.print_headline: Bills Seek More Competition in Electricity Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/28/busin.body_text: **********Access to the power transmission grid, a key element of the utilities' monopoly control of the nation's electric system, is up for grabs for the first time in the history of the industry. **********As part of the National Energy Strategy package moving through the Congress, a House subcommittee has approved provisions that will require utilities to carry electricity from independent buyers across the utilities' territory to independent sellers, even if the utilities lose electric sales as a result. The version of the bill that the Senate is planning to take up this week does not have the same provision. **********But the Senate version would repeal a law concerning who may own power plants, the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, and many other participants in the electric market are demanding access to transmission in exchange for the repeal. **********Taken together, these legislative proposals would vastly extend the deregulation of the utilities that Congress started in 1978, opening the transmission system and freeing participants to build power plants. **********"A key to whether there is any real competition at all is transmission," said Larry Hobart, the executive director of the American Public Power Association, many of whose members are small utilities that serve commercial and residential customers with power they buy from larger utilities. "If you have an independent power producer, that's like a dot inside a circle that is the service territory of an investor-owned utility. We're another dot, outside the circle. Unless you can tie them together with a transmission line, it's of no use to us." **********The producers also seek more competition, arguing that they must be freed from "monopsony," a variation of monopoly in which there are many sellers but only one buyer. Under the Public Utilities Regulatory Policy Act of 1978, independent producers now sell to the utility in whose territory they are situated at "avoided cost" -- the price that the utility would have to have paid to make the power for itself. Many independent producers think they could do better if they could offer their product more widely. 'Just Like the Phone System' **********The utilities argue that their control of the transmission system is essential to the stability of electric supply. At the Edison Electric Institute, the trade association of investor-owned utilities, Mary Kenkel, a spokeswoman, said the demand to open the transmission system came from "a bunch of people wanting to take something without paying for it." **********Many investor-owned utilities see no advantage to a proliferation of independent producers, because no one can build power plants more cheaply than they can. But some utilities would like to see more such plants, because they themselves would like to build them, either inside their territories or far afield. That group of utilities is also seeking repeal of the holding company act, which puts onerous regulation on utilities doing business in more than one state. **********Experts say that opening the transmission system would remove a large part of the monopoly power of utilities, turning transmission lines, now private property, into something akin to common carriers. If the market were thrown open to competitors, the amount of power traded that way might be small, but it would go far toward determining electric prices for everyone. When President Bush proposed the National Energy Strategy earlier this year he called for such open access, and there is substantial support in Congress. **********"It's got to be opened up, just like the phone system," said Senator Timothy E. Wirth, a Colorado Democrat. Giving small producers and small utilities more access to transmission would mean big improvements in competition and efficiency, he said. **********In a possible model for opening the transmission system, in two recent cases courts or regulators have required open access as a condition of utility mergers. **********Lurking behind both the holding company act, which the Senate bill would repeal, and the transmission access issue is the question of whether the utilities' three traditional roles -- as generators, transmitters and distributors of power -- should be split up. **********Independent producers say access will create competition that lowers price for everyone. Traditional utilities say that with access, independent producers can go "cherry picking," stealing away the best customers, like major industrial plants, and leaving the utilities with generating stations with no one to serve, creating "stranded investments." **********The cost of those plants will have to be spread among small consumers, they say, who will be captive and heavily saddled. "You've built to satisfy all customers equally, and now these customers can go elsewhere, so who pays for all that investment?" said Dick Disbrow, the chairman of American Electric Power, a Midwest holding company. If the cost of idle plants is spread among the remaining customers, he said, the price that the traditional utility must charge will rise further, creating an even bigger cost differential. The Issue of Priority **********On the other hand, the Public Service Company of Indiana favors transmission access and has proposed opening its system in exchange for the right to sell its surplus power elsewhere at whatever price it can get. **********"Injecting competition into regulated industries is good public policy," said James E. Rogers Jr., the company's chief executive, in a speech in Chicago earlier this year. **********In between is the position taken by a coalition of 17 large public power agencies, led by Richard M. Flynn, the chairman of the New York Power Authority. In this hybrid, small producers would negotiate for access, and impasses would be resolved by binding arbitration. **********"The maximum savings from competitive bidding won't flow to consumers unless all potential power suppliers have a fair shot at the transmission system," Mr. Flynn said. **********Among the thorny issues is who should have priority on the system. Should it be the third-party buyer and seller, who want round-the-clock access, or the existing utility customers, who use the system far less but save money doing it? 'Economy Transfers' **********Utilities currently use their lines for unscheduled "economy transfers," so that if one company has a plant that can produce power for 2 cents a kilowatt-hour but is idle and a neighboring utility is running a plant at a cost of 4 cents a kilowatt-hour, the second utility will shut its plant and buy from the first at a cost of 3 cents a kilowatt-hour. The volume of such transfers increased nearly 20-fold between 1960 and 1985, when a huge difference existed between the fuel costs of oil and coal. **********Costs have narrowed somewhat since then, but transfers still save consumers $18 billion a year, the investor-owned utilities stress. **********The system was paid for by those customers through their monthly bills, the investor-owned utilities point out. At the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners in Washington, Michael Foley, an electricity specialist, said, "Given the fact that they paid for that hardware, shouldn't they get first dibs on any of the power?" **********The Edison Electric Institute casts it in a somewhat grimmer light. "If access to the system is mandated for a few special interests, the benefits now accruing to the majority of a utility's customers may be compromised," it said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/07/world.body_text: **********Plotters who tried to overthrow President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in August acted partly because they feared that he was making the Soviet Union dependent on the United States, according to the confession of one plotter published in the German news magazine Spiegel. **********"Gorbachev often traveled abroad in recent years, and frequently we had no idea what important issues he discussed there," former Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov reportedly told interrogators. **********"Take Gorbachev's report to the G-7 meeting in London -- none of us knew what he said there," Mr. Yazov said, referring to the Soviet President's meeting with leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized countries in London in July. "We were naturally not ready to increase our political, economic and even military dependence on the United States."  Excerpts From Videotapes **********In its issue to be distributed on Monday, Der Spiegel published what it said were excerpts from videotaped interrogations of Mr. Yazov and two other organizers of the coup, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, former K.G.B. chief, and Valentin S. Pavlov, former Prime Minister. Advance copies of the article were made available today. **********Der Spiegel did not say how it had obtained the material, but in the past it has paid for exclusive information. **********According to the article, Mr. Yazov cited the Soviet Union's economic decline and internal unrest as other factors that motivated the coup plotters. **********The accounts reportedly given by the three imprisoned plotters suggest that their coup was haphazardly planned. Mr. Pavlov, for example, said the plotters simply hoped that the Supreme Soviet would approve their action and that afterward "things would be worked out." **********Mr. Yazov said that at a key meeting on Aug. 18 at which the coup was planned, he, Mr. Kryuchkov and a third plotter, Boris K. Pugo, former Interior Minister, who later committed suicide, were all drunk. **********Mr. Pavlov told his interrogators that he also consumed "quite a decent amount of alcohol" at that meeting. **********Of the three plotters, Mr. Yazov, formerly a senior military officer, was the most contrite. All three men face trial and possible death sentences for their roles in the coup.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.main_headline: Credibility, Too, Is a Victim Of the Repression in Vilnius
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.print_headline: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: MUSCOVITES; Credibility, Too, Is a Victim Of the Repression in Vilnius
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.body_text: **********Yelena Trifanova turned on her television Sunday evening to hear the latest news about events in Lithuania and, she said, she felt as if she had stepped back in time, to the years before Mikhail S. Gorbachev became the Soviet leader and began encouraging honest and truthful reporting. **********The announcer described the army's killing of pro-independence demonstrators in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, as a defensive action, and the story he told was completely different from what she had heard earlier in radio reports by the B.B.C., Radio Liberty and the Voice of America. **********"There was another victim this weekend, aside from the poor people who were killed in Lithuania," said Miss Trifanova, a Moscow teacher. "After listening to the official news reports, it is clear that glasnost and objectivity were also killed. Last night I heard the announcer begin to read, and I thought, 'This man is simply an actor and this is like a script from 10 years ago.' " **********In the years of Mr. Gorbachev's much-touted glasnost, Soviet press reports have generally improved in objectivity. But such truthfulness often seems to dissipate in times of stress and controversy, as in the overall, official reporting of the events in Vilnius.  'The Big Lie' **********In its coverage of the army attack in Lithuania early Sunday morning, "the official Soviet media has once again resorted to the Big Lie," said one senior Western diplomat, who has been closely monitoring events in the Baltics. "If you say it loud enough and often enough, you can convince people that your lie is the truth. This is a great tool from the old Soviet media handbook and it's clearly being put to use here." **********The most prominent and egregious flouting of the truth came in the Sunday night evening news broadcast of Vremya that Miss Trifanova and millions of other Soviet citizens watched. **********While there are a few independent print journals willing to contradict the Government's version of events, most Soviet citizens get their news of breaking events from Vremya, where the Government exercises powerful propaganda prerogatives. **********The Vremya anchorman, Dmitri Biryukov, told viewers that the Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, accused President Gorbachev of reneging on his promises not to use force. **********"But unfortunately, the chairman of the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet failed to make clear that fire was opened outside the television and radio building not by troops but by Sajudis guards," Mr. Biryukov said, referring to the main Lithuanian pro-independence movement.  Demonstrators Crushed **********Mr. Biryukov's version of the events completely contradicted reports by Western journalists in Vilnius, who saw Soviet troops shoot at unarmed crowds and tanks crush peaceful demonstrators, who had surrounded the local television transmitter in an effort to prevent its takeover by the military. **********"It is a shame what's going on on television," said Sergei B. Stankevich, Deputy Mayor of Moscow and a member of the national congress. "There is no doubt that the state TV is being run with an iron hand with no eye toward the truth. The situation is very dissappointing." **********The chairman of Gosteleradio, the state broadcasting administration, said he did not view the airwaves as a proper place for making political statements and denied his programs had done anything but report the "objective facts" of what had happened in the Lithuanian capital. **********"Television should not be radicalized, either to the right or to the left," said the Gosteleradio chief, Leonid P. Kravchenko. "It should report straightforward and honestly, without taking sides." **********And who gets to determine what is radical and what is middle-of-the-road objectivity? he was asked. **********"I do," he said.  Objectivity Abandoned **********The official press agency Tass also abandoned any claim to objectivity, including in its news dispatches from Lithuania, as opposed to its analyses or commentaries, such assertions as: "There is no doubt that all these casualties are fully on the conscience of the present leadership of Lithuania and Sajudis." **********While the Tass service is not freely available for people here to read, its reports are used by many newspapers around the country; the way it covers the news sets a clear tone that most official news outlets copy. **********Tass, as well as other major Soviet press organizations, like Pravda, the Communist Party's daily newspaper, and the state-run radio and television news programs have displayed no effort to determine who is behind the National Salvation Committee, the shadowy group that declared that it had seized power in Lithuania from the Parliament; in the committee's name, Soviet troops carried out their attack on Sunday, but its members refuse to identify themselves.  Western Reporters Rebuffed **********Western journalists have been rebuffed in their attempts to uncover the group's members and have been allowed to interview only the appointed committee spokesman. It seems clear the group is comprised of leaders of the hard-line Communist Party opposed to Lithuanian independence; many people assume its actions are directed by the party leadership. **********But though Soviet press organizations contend the group is as anonymous to them as it is to Western reporters, they presume the committee's right to power in all of its reports. The committee's actions and motivations are neither questioned nor criticized. **********Pravda today reported all the charges of the committee against Lithuania's elected government, but barely mentioned the killings Sunday morning.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Federated and Allied Shifted 3 Executives
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/busin.body_text: **********Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation set in motion yesterday a three-way shift in top-level posts in their Bloomingdale's and Rich's/Goldsmith's chains and their New York buying office. **********Carl Tooker, president and chief operating officer of Rich's, the 24-store subsidiary in Atlanta, was named its chairman and chief executive. Russell Stravitz, executive vice president and general merchandise manager of Bloomingdale's, was named president of Rich's. **********In the move that opened up the other two changes, Roger N. Farah, the 38-year-old chairman and chief executive of Rich's, was named chairman and chief executive of the New York-based Federated/Allied Merchandising Services. All three moves take effect July 1. **********Under Mr. Farah and Mr. Tooker, 43, Rich's became the most profitable of the nine store divisions operated by Federated/Allied, so that Mr. Farah's move was seen by executive recruiters yesterday as a promotion. All the companies' 246 stores are given merchandising assistance by the New York buying office, particularly through the new team-buying approach. **********Since both Mr. Farah's and Mr. Tooker's appointments were expected, the promotion of Mr. Stravitz to Rich's presidency was perhaps the most striking change announced yesterday by Allen I. Questrom and James M. Zimmerman, Federated/ Allied's chairman and president, respectively. **********An executive at Bloomingdale's since 1969, the Mr. Stravitz, 43, was introduced yesterday to the staff of Rich's. Will he carry with him to Rich's some thing of the trendiness of Bloomie's, Mr. Stravitz was asked. "No," he replied in a telephone interview from Atlanta. "Not a bit. My main role here will be to learn what makes Rich's/Goldsmith's such a success in its markets." **********Asked if he thought that regional department-store chains like Rich's had a future because of the constant market encroachment of the Wal-Marts, K Marts, Limiteds and Gaps, he said: "Those are certainly all competitors. But our role at Rich's, and the other store subsidiaries is that we have to constantly work to understand who our customers are and what they want. Rich's is over 100 years old and has shown its worth many years in all its cities and towns. But, still, with the competition, that's just a starting point. Personally, I feel that in 100,000-to-300,000-square-feet stores such as we have, we can offer a much greater host of attractions than any specialty store can."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/16/busin.main_headline: Russian Republic Imposes Ban on Some Oil Exports
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/16/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; Russian Republic Imposes Ban on Some Oil Exports
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/16/busin.body_text: **********The Russian republic sent a shudder through the oil market yesterday, announcing that it was suspending permission to export some cargoes of oil. But outside experts were not certain whether this was a symptom of the continuing decline in production in the Soviet Union, which is the world's largest producer, or part of an internal power struggle or the restructuring of the Soviet economy. **********The announcement, the kind of news that the market has been more or less anticipating for two years, pushed crude prices up 60 cents a barrel early in the day on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but prices declined later, with oil for December delivery closing at $22.79, up 27 cents on the day. **********"Clearly it is a major source of concern going into the winter," said Nauman Barakat, an oil expert at Merrill Lynch. But he said that while exports might fall, "they won't entirely suspend them, because of their desperate need for foreign exchange." **********While the price move yesterday was not large, it was a reverse in direction, pointed out Vahan Zanoyan of the Petroleum Finance Corporation, a consulting firm in Washington. Oil prices are down $1.50 from recent highs, and the price would have gone down yesterday but for the Soviet announcement, he said. "The market is terribly oversupplied," he said. "There's far too much crude; we're swimming in it." **********Several analysts said that while the announcement could be a symptom of declining production, it might also reflect a general loss of control in the Soviet economy. Thane Gustafson of Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Cambridge, Mass., said Soviet refineries were making private deals with foreign companies, and so were some production units, so that crude oil and refined products were flowing out of the country in an unaccustomed way. **********In addition, he pointed out, control over export licenses is now being transferred from the central Government to the republics. The Russian republic may have decided to block some exports until it can figure out what is going on, he said. **********Mr. Zanoyan said that oil was trading within the Soviet Union at about 70 rubles a ton, but that with rubles selling on the street for 110 to the dollar, the world price is about 9,000 rubles a ton, creating great inducement for producers and refiners to export. **********George Friesen of Deutsche Bank Group in New York said it would take a severe drop in Soviet production to create problems on world markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Brand Officer Quits Burger King
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/busin.body_text: **********Gary L. Langstaff, the Burger King executive who oversaw the development of the slogan "Sometimes you've gotta break the rules," resigned yesterday, as the company and its advertising agencies weighed whether to replace the slogan. **********Though the company said it had made no decision on the fate of the theme line, which has been criticized by franchisees as ineffective, it has asked its two advertising agencies, Saatchi & Saatchi and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, to develop new creative ideas, said Cori Zywotow, a Burger King spokeswoman. **********Mr. Langstaff, who had been executive vice president-brand strategy at the Burger King Corporation since 1989, would not comment yesterday on his resignation, although Ms. Zywotow said he had left "to pursue other interests." **********Ms. Zywotow said Burger King had no immediate plans to put its account under review. She refused to confirm reports in trade publications this week that the company would soon adopt a new theme line: "Your way. Right away." **********Such a slogan would be a variation on the one the company used in the 1970's: "Have it your way."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.main_headline: Founder of Brokerage To Shift His Focus
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Founder of Brokerage To Shift His Focus
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.body_text: **********Randall D. Smith Jr., one of the best-known traders of securities of troubled companies, is reorganizing the brokerage firm he founded so that he can focus on his own investments, the firm announced yesterday. **********Mr. Smith did not return a phone call yesterday to his home in Short Hills, N.J., and calls to his downtown New York office were referred to his brother Jeffrey A. Smith, who also did not return them. **********Several associates and customers of Mr. Smith's firm, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that firm officials had told them that Mr. Smith was seeking to sell the broker-dealer that he started in 1985 to an employee group to minimize charges of conflicts of interest between trading for himself and for customers. **********Regulators at the Securities and Exchange Commission are known to have made recent inquiries into some of R. D. Smith's practices, as well as those of other distressed investors, and some of the firm's customers have complained that the firm puts Mr. Smith's interests ahead of their own. Many have taken their business elsewhere, and as a result, R. D. Smith and its affiliates have been laying off many of their analysts and salespeople. **********By separating the broker-dealer from Mr. Smith's other affiliates, the trader appears to be putting some distance between himself and the part of his empire that is watched most closely by regulators. **********Still, some customers and competitors noted that a Smith family member would continue to own a minority interest in the brokerage, and that John Adams, Mr. Smith's former tax lawyer and one of his closest confidants, would be the co-head of the brokerage firm with Carl W. Vaicek Jr., the firm's sales manager. **********"It could be that he'll be back in two years when the dust settles," one customer said of Mr. Smith. **********Others, however, said that it might be an example of exquisite market timing by Mr. Smith, a move that allows him to keep his reputation intact and to ease out of the business just when it is about to become more regulated and less profitable. **********"Randy has been in this for a long time," said Gary Hines, chairman of the Delaware Bay Company in New York, a fast-growing competitor. "The climate has changed. He may have decided that given the current regulatory climate, he has decided he doesn't need the hassle." **********Besides Mr. Adams and Mr. Vaicek, the employees most likely to receive some interest in the slimmed-down brokerage operation are understood to be Michael C. Singer, the president and former research director; Craig Davies, the current research director; and Kevin McCabe, the analyst who is overseeing the firm's investment in the Penrod Drilling Corporation. **********The brokerage firm earned $414,000 on revenues of $14.1 million for the 12 months ended Aug. 31, according to S.E.C. filings, and had a book value of $2.1 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; Mr. Bossidy's Action Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; Mr. Bossidy's Action Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.body_text: **********Wall Street was delighted when Allied-Signal Inc. managed to lure Lawrence A. Bossidy from the General Electric Company to take over as its chief executive this past July. Long troubled by poor profit margins and expenses that outstripped its cash flow, Allied-Signal seemed to be sorely in need of the kind of skills the 56-year-old Mr. Bossidy had demonstrated in his 34-year climb through the ranks of G.E. to the job of vice chairman. **********So far, Mr. Bossidy is living up to the high hopes that sent Allied-Signal's shares up more than 10 percent on July 1, the day of his appointment. In fact, when he unveiled his plan for Allied-Signal last Wednesday, the shares jumped even more dramatically, even though the plan included a sharp cut in dividends, to 25 cents a quarter from 45 cents. **********The plan involved some extremely painful steps for the company: a 14 percent reduction in managerial staff, a 24 percent cut in proposed capital spending, the sale of numerous smaller businesses, a smattering of plant closings and consolidations, and warnings that some high-profile product lines like anti-lock brake systems might be dropped unless profits picked up in a year. But what really impressed analysts was how detailed a program Mr. Bossidy had been able to present in just 90 days. **********Mr. Bossidy said that he was confident the plan was realistic because it had been developed and accepted by the company's top management, in Morris Township, N.J., rather than imposed by him. **********Immediately after presenting the plan to analysts in New York, Mr. Bossidy flew to Los Angeles as part of a taxing schedule of discussions with groups of employees. "I've got a lot of preaching to do," he said before leaving. "Not everyone in the company thinks this is great."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/29/busin.body_text: **********In his gloomiest assessment since last winter, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the national economy had taken a turn for the worse. **********The economy is still growing slightly, Mr. Greenspan told a group of business executives in Providence, R.I., but "in recent weeks, it's turned demonstrably sluggish." **********Early news service reports characterized Mr. Greenspan's speech as even more pessimistic than it was, and traders in the stock and bond markets took the remarks to mean the Fed would act soon to lower interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 40.70, to 3,045.62, and prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose.  [ Pages D10 and D22. ] No Indication on Rates **********Mr. Greenspan, however, gave no indication even indirectly of what his intentions might be on interest rates. He has recently been under increasing pressure from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and others in the Administration to drive rates lower. The Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the Fed, meets next on Nov. 5. **********In July, when he gave Congress his official midyear review of the state of the economy, Mr. Greenspan proclaimed the recession over, reported signs that inflation was slowing, predicted progress on the Federal budget deficit and was otherwise remarkably optimistic. **********Today's speech, which he delivered from notes, had a much different tone. The "signs of spark" that could be observed in the economy in the spring and early summer, Mr. Greenspan said, were no longer apparent. 'Credit Crunch' Cited **********In addition to not tipping his hand on interest rates, Mr. Greenspan did not say whether other steps should be taken to lift the economy. Many lawmakers of both parties have offered tax-cut proposals in recent days, saying that a cut was necessary to generate a surge in the economy. **********Mr. Greenspan referred often today to what he called a "credit crunch" and suggested that it was now the main factor dragging the economy down. "The economy is moving forward, but in the face of a 50-mile-an-hour head wind," he declared. **********When bank lending is tight, the growth in the nation's money supply is inhibited, and that inhibition acts as a drain on the economy. **********The Federal Reserve has been pushing interest rates down steadily, so that they are now at their lowest point since the 1970's. But since that decline has not led to more bank lending, it has not caused the economy to grow as much as Mr. Greenspan and other officials hoped. **********Some Bush Administration officials have been arguing that the main cause of the credit restrictions is overly zealous restrictions placed by bank examiners. **********But Mr. Greenspan suggested that more important reasons were the reluctance of banks to lend freely when they have many bad loans already on their books and the disinclination of businesses to borrow money in the face of a weak economy. Focus on Credit **********Most of Mr. Greenspan's speech today was devoted to the credit situation, a problem that is especially severe in New England. Mr. Greenspan implied, although he did not say so directly, that he was not sure whether the inability of creditworthy customers to find loans was a short-term or a long-term phenomenon. **********The problem had its roots, he said, in the tax law of 1981, which allowed generous new tax breaks for real estate construction. Many parts of the country experienced a significiant overbuilding of commercial real estate, and banks found that their loans for these buildings were not repaid. **********"We just overbuilt to a point that is quite incredible," he said. **********Eventually, Mr. Greenspan said, credit will once again become more available. He said that availability would begin when banks see that they have fewer nonperforming loans in their portfolios. Banks will then realize that unless they lend more aggressively, they will lose their share of the market to competitors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/world.main_headline: Alberta and California at Odds on Natural Gas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/world.print_headline: Alberta and California at Odds on Natural Gas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/world.body_text: **********A natural-gas war has broken out between Alberta and California, which could undermine some of the energy trade gains made by Canada and the United States under their epochal free-trade agreement. **********A United States official said energy officials of the two Governments had held "frank and open" discussions about the conflict in Ottawa last Thursday and Friday under a special free-trade consultative mechanism. **********[ The matter -- considered one of the most divisive on the trade front since the pact went into effect on Jan. 1, 1989 -- stepped up to a higher level on Dec. 10, when Canada's Energy Minister, Jake Epp, took up the issue in a meeting with the United States Ambassador, Edward Ney. ] **********The hostilities arose from a decision in November by the California Public Utilities Commission to break a 30-year-old supply arrangement between Alberta's gas producers and their principal customer in California, the San Francisco-based Pacific Gas and Electric Company. The utility, in turn, resells the gas to seven million users in Northern California. **********A Pacific Gas and Electric subsidiary in Calgary pools the gas from 190 Alberta producers, including such international companies as Amoco and Shell Oil, that have entered into long-term contracts covering supplies beyond the year 2000. The gas is then shipped to California over a pipeline owned by P.G.& E. **********The commission says the long-term supply contracts -- especially in the current period, when both Canada and the United States have excess supplies of gas -- keep prices too high and penalize users, including hospitals, nursing homes and schools. **********The California commission ordered that the pipeline be open by November 1992 to any group that wants to buy gas directly from any Canadian producer. With buyers able to shop Alberta for the best buy, the lower imported gas prices could put price pressure on American producers as well. **********"We've been trying to open up and unbundle the gas market for years," the Public Utilities Commission's president, Patricia M. Eckert, said in a telephone interview from San Francisco. "We want our end users to be able to cut the best deal. We want the least expensive gas for California." **********Californians are now paying up to 33 percent more for their gas than consumers in Alberta. A consumer agency in the California commission has charged that P.G.& E. owes consumers $390 million because it sold them Alberta gas at above spot-market prices in the last three years. **********But the Alberta producers counter that the contracts were freely entered into as a way of providing secure supplies at times of shortage as well as excess, and that it is unthinkable for a state regulatory body to ask that they be revoked. **********"If you have the potential for unilateral regulatory intervention in gas pricing, how safe do you feel investing a few million dollars in a pipeline?" said Ian Smyth, president of the Canadian Petroleum Association. "We have to send the message that we are deadly serious, and that's what we're doing." **********To the cheers of the industry, Canada's provincial and federal authorities have now challenged the Calfornia order. They said they would refuse to give gas removal permits for any sales to California that would displace any of the fuel being shipped under the long-term contracts. **********It was considered a modulated response that permits the Canadians to press for enforcement of the contracts without raising the possibility of re-regulating the industry, which won market freedom on both sides of the border with the free-trade agreement. **********But the owner of one gas company, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said in an interview: "Contract sanctity is the basis for all civilized business dealings. Do away with that, and you're back to the jungle." **********Ever since oil and gas were discovered here after World War II, much of the energy has been sold to the United States. California, the second-largest market for Alberta gas after Ontario, takes about 40 percent, representing $650 million of revenues over the first nine months of this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/world.main_headline: ISRAELIS AND U.N. HOPE FOR ACCORD ON HOSTAGES SOON
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/world.print_headline: ISRAELIS AND U.N. HOPE FOR ACCORD ON HOSTAGES SOON
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/world.body_text: **********Optimism grew today among United Nations and Israeli officials that a deal could be struck soon for a sweeping exchange of Middle East prisoners that would include freedom for the 10 remaining Western hostages in Lebanon. **********There were fresh reports from several capitals in the region giving the outlines of possible settlements. One carried by Iran's official press agency said that later this week, Israel might free a Shiite Muslim cleric who has been a pivotal captive for the last two years. **********Officials here refused to talk publicly about the possible solutions that could end the hostage ordeal, and a senior Foreign Ministry official closely involved in the discussions, Yohanan Bein, said the Iranian report "doesn't make very much sense."  Two-Phase Process Described **********While Israeli officials declined to discuss the specifics of a possible deal, newspapers and Israel radio today outlined a two-stage plan that is supposedly being considered. **********Under it, Israel would first commit itself formally to releasing prisoners in return for word on seven Israeli servicemen missing in Lebanon. The second stage would involve a full exchange of captives -- Arab prisoners under Israeli control, surviving Israeli soldiers and the Western hostages, five of them Americans. **********The fact that Israeli officials were tight-lipped suggested that negotiations had reached a critical stage. Several officials acknowledged that they were reluctant to say much in public out of fear that a single slip could blow apart delicate arrangements. White House officials said they, too, were trying to avoid stirring the waters at this point.  Solution Serves Many Interests **********Mr. Bein said the situation "looks quite hopeful" and he added that the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, "believes a solution is at hand, most probably because the countries that are responsible for a solution want it." **********The Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, said that the willingness expressed by the hostage takers to talk and the Secretary General's personal involvement "allow an opening for hope." **********For his part, Mr. Perez de Cuellar, who has become the middleman in the hostaging bargaining, said in Geneva that he now sees a basis for a broad exchange of captives. The various sides were "not that far apart," he said, adding: "It is not an ocean. I would say a river." **********Israeli negotiators, led by a veteran diplomat and trouble-shooter, Uri Lubrani, prepared to leave for Geneva on Wednesday to meet a second time this week with the Secretary General, who has also had talks there with a senior Iranian diplomat. **********It seemed clear that broad arrangements for any bargain would have Israel release about 375 Arab prisoners under its control while Islamic groups give back the Western hostages and the Israeli servicemen missing in Lebanon for many years. Some of the Israeli soldiers are assumed to be dead, and Israel wants their remains returned. **********An important question is whether this sort of plan would satisfy the kidnappers. One group holding several hostages, Islamic Holy War, sent a letter to Mr. Perez de Cuellar demanding the release of "fighters" held by Israel and by European countries. These include convicted killers and hijackers, and some of the European Governments are hardly eager to free them. **********To its discomfort, even resentment, Israel has found itself thrust into a central role in the crisis.  A Central Figure **********It has been asked by British leaders and other Westerners to offer a good-will gesture to the hostage-holders in Lebanon by letting some of its Arab prisoners go. **********High on most lists is the Shiite cleric, Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid, at the time of his abduction believed to be the Party of God's representative in southern Lebanon, who Israelis admit was taken by its soldiers from his home in Lebanon to serve as a bargaining chip in a situation like this. **********Nonetheless, Israel feels that the spotlight is focused on it unfairly -- obscuring, in its view, the fact that Syria and Iran are the Lebanese kidnappers' patrons and have shown through the release of three hostages in the last few days that they control events when they want to. **********Reflecting this attitude, Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee urged today that no Israeli good-will gesture be offered unless the the missing servicemen were made part of the bargain. 'Great Importance' **********That underlined the degree to which the fate of those men was the key to a settlement. **********"If I could solve this problem, almost everything would be solved," Mr. Perez de Cuellar said, "so I attach great, great importance to the whereabouts of the seven Israelis." **********News reports from Beirut today quoted officials of the Party of God, a pro-Iranian group of Muslim fundamentalists, as saying that they are holding two unnamed Israeli soldiers who have been missing in Lebanon since 1982. They would include those men in a comprehensive prisoner exchange, the officials reportedly said. **********A Palestinian faction, the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, said in Damascus that it was willing to turn over the body of an Israeli Druse soldier captured near Sidon, Lebanon, in 1983. The group asserted that the soldier, Sgt. Samir Assad, had been captured alive but was killed in an Israeli air attack. **********According to still another report here, the Party of God has said that it would let the International Committee of the Red Cross visit the Israeli soldiers in its custody if Israel would do the same for Sheik Obeid. Mixed Feelings in Israel **********Israeli officials say they have had "no credible knowledge" about what happened to their missing soldiers. Only one man, an air force navigator named Ron Arad, is believed with a high degree of probability to be alive. **********Israel's deep involvement in the crisis is laced with intricacies. Officials acknowledge that they worry about being accused of having torpedoed the hostage-release process should it break down. Such a development could have unwelcome repercussions for the regional peace conference that the United States is promoting. **********But pragmatic politics aside, the hostage crisis has given Israel a welcome chance to get back its missing soldiers or their remains, always a matter of abiding concern and emotion here. **********"This country is mentally vulnerable to situations of missing soldiers, dead soldiers," an official said. "When they get us on that, they get us where it hurts."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Two more portions of the Kroger Company's advertising account have been assigned to regional agencies, as the supermarket chain continues to divide its $20 million national advertising account into 10 regional accounts. **********The account for Kroger's Columbus, Ohio, marketing area, which stretches from Toledo to Wheeling, W. Va., was awarded to Hameroff/ Milenthal/Spence Inc., Columbus. Other finalists in the review were Campbell-Mithun-Esty, Chicago, the incumbent on the national account; Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco; J. Walter Thompson, Detroit, and Young & Rubicam, Detroit. Billings are estimated at between $5 million and $8 million. **********Kroger's Atlanta marketing area was assigned to a group of Atlanta agencies. Creative Consultants was awarded the creative work for all broadcast advertising; Metier Marketing will coordinate strategic planning, communications-development and research, and Masotti's Media Services Inc. will handle media planning and execution. Phelan & Lowry Ltd. will continue to manage promotions, community and employee relations and other activities. **********A Kroger spokeswoman in Atlanta said that there were five other finalists in that review. The account's broadcast billings are between $6 million and $7 million, the spokeswoman said, adding that the total budget would not be disclosed. **********Three Kroger marketing areas have chosen to keep their accounts with Campbell-Mithun-Esty. The southern Texas and Louisiana area awarded its account, valued at $4.5 million, to Taylor-Smith, Houston.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/08/busin.main_headline: Easier Rules For Banks Are Issued
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/08/busin.print_headline: Easier Rules For Banks Are Issued
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/08/busin.body_text: **********As part of a drive by the Administration to stimulate the economy, the four Federal bank regulatory agencies announced new guidelines yesterday to make bank examinations less tough and encourage banks to make more loans. **********The measures would permit examiners greater latitude in reviewing commercial real estate loans to try to "insure that regulatory policies and actions do not inadvertently curtail the availability of credit to sound borrowers," the agencies said in a joint statement. **********Their action was intended to draw attention to an effort begun by the Adminstration in March to relax tight credit by making it easier for banks to make loans so that business could expand and grow. But some bankers and analysts said the guidelines would do little to help an economy hobbled more by a lack of loan demand than by an unwillingess of banks to lend. And others feared that yesterday's action could cause banks to make the kind of poor loans they did in the 1980's, which are causing problems today. More Scrutiny of Regulators **********This also comes as greater attention is being paid to the actions of regulators. On Wednesday, a Senate committee rejected Mr. Bush's attempt to reappoint Robert L. Clarke as Comptroller of the Currency, the regulator of some 4,000 nationally chartered banks, in part because Mr. Clarke was considered too lenient in the 1980's and was seen as having failed to head off a wave of bank failures. And it comes as Congress is considering a complex bill to overhaul the banking industry and mandate earlier regulatory intervention at troubled banks. **********"All this stuff is pretty marginal as far as I'm concerned," said Robert E. Litan, a banking industry analyst at the Brookings Institution. "I don't think the new regulations will do much to change things and the key thing is what message gets to the troops. In reality, examiners are probably totally perplexed. They've just seen their leader whipsawed in Congress and they know the climate on the Hill is to be tough rather than lenient. I think examiners are going to be very nervous about getting too liberal all of a sudden." **********The measure, however, was praised by representatives of the banking and real estate industry, but raised concerns among others who feared any relaxation in regulatory standards. The document, which will be distributed to bank presidents and examiners, was drafted by the Comptroller's office, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Federal Reserve Board and the Office of Thrift Supervision. Last March, these agencies issued general guidelines and the document released yesterday provides specifics to guide examiners. **********"A lot of this is common sense stuff," said Wendy B. Samuel, general counsel of the National Coucnil of Community Bankers. "But I can't picture a lot of bankers immediately changing their lending practices. Bankers would love to make loans and are finding that the sort of loans they want to make are just not there." 'Constructive Approach' **********Steven A. Wechsler, president of the National Realty Committee, said the guidlines were a "constructive approach to restoring regulatory balance to the system," while Robert H. Dugger, chief economist at the American Bankers Association, said the new guidelines "will definitely help." **********But Herbert M. Sandler, chief executive of World Savings and Loan Association, one of the nation's largest, said "I'm concerned that a message not be given to go back to the old practicies of the 1980's when people received credit for loans which should never have been made. Now we're saying, gee, we're wrong, let's go back and give these people credit." **********Among the specifics of the guidelines are details about when real estate loans should be classifed as in danger of default and how much should be set aside as reserves against them. One important move welcomed by the American Bankers Association was a shift in emphasis from evaluating existing loans on a worst case scenario based on current market conditions to judging real estate loans based on future market conditions. **********The agencies also said they will convene a national meeting of senior bank examiners in December to review this policy statement. They will also undertake a random audit program to check up on how examiners are following the guidelines and plan to allow bank holding companies to use a greater amount of preferred stock to meet regulatory capital guidelines. **********The argument against greater use of preferred stock is that it is a security considered to be similar to debt. But the change is intended to help Citibank and several other large money center banks meet their regualatory capital standards.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; 7-Year Debentures From Fannie Mae
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/busin.body_text: **********The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $600 million in seven-year debentures due March 10, 1998, through various securities dealers. **********The debentures, which have an 8.20 percent coupon, are priced at 100 to yield about 25 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. **********Fannie Mae said the proceeds will be used to redeem $150 million of 12 percent debentures that will be maturing March 11, 1991, and for general corporate purposes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/20/busin.body_text: **********The former president of Cubic Defense Systems Inc. was sentenced today to 18 months in prison for theft of Government property and conspiring to bribe an Air Force official. **********Colvin C. (Sam) Wellborn pleaded guilty on Jan. 15 to conspiring to bribe Victor D. Cohen, a former Deputy Assistant Air Force Secretary, to influence the award of three contracts. He also admitted he had obtained confidential Pentagon data about bids submitted for the contracts by competing military concerns. **********Mr. Wellborn was sentenced to 18 months on each count by Federal District Judge Claude M. Hilton, who said the sentences would run concurrently. He must also pay a $15,000 fine on the conspiracy count and serve two years of supervised release. **********The judge had calculated the range of Mr. Wellborn's sentence at 33 to 41 months, but the Government asked that it be reduced to 18 months, citing his cooperation in the investigation. **********Cubic Defense, a San Diego-based unit of the Cubic Corporation, pleaded guilty in January to conspiracy, theft of Government property and filing false statements. It agreed to pay $4.65 million in penalties. **********Prosecutors said Mr. Wellborn agreed to pay a military consultant, William M. Galvin, $1 million with the understanding some of it would be paid to Mr. Cohen if Cubic Defense won a lucrative contract to build a tactical air reconnaissance system. **********Mr. Wellborn paid Mr. Galvin $328,580 over five years for help in getting military contracts. Some money was used to purchase meals, gifts and trips for Mr. Cohen and his friends, prosecutors said. **********Court papers said Mr. Cohen persuaded the Pentagon to give Cubic Defense a contract to build an Air Force pilot-training center in the Philippines when other officials wanted competitive bidding. The Pentagon later canceled the $1 million contract, court papers said. **********Mr. Galvin pleaded guilty to a separate charge and was sentenced in September to 32 months in prison. Mr. Cohen has denied any wrongdoing and has not been charged.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/26/busin.body_text: **********THE ECONOMY **********Retailers would probably like to forget Christmas 1991. While most merchants had been prepared for a sluggish season, many said sales turned out to be even worse than expected. Results through Monday indicate that retail spending will be flat or only up slightly in December. A month ago, many retailers hoped to exceed last year's sales by 5 percent.
