https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/02/world.main_headline: Army Strikes Back; Aristide Tried to Put Haitian Military Under Control at Last, So It Rebelled
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/02/world.print_headline: Army Strikes Back; Aristide Tried to Put Haitian Military Under Control at Last, So It Rebelled
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/02/world.body_text: **********In his inaugural address in February, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti made it clear that as the country's first democratically elected leader and an outspoken critic of army abuses, he believed that his most urgent task was to bring the military to heel. **********But after the fall of six Haitian governments in the last five years, and nearly two centuries of national history strewn with dozens of coups, many wondered whether President Aristide could ever establish control over the country's unruly armed forces. **********For nearly eight months in office, the priest-turned-President visibly grew in self-confidence as he gained international support for his country and began a domestic reorganization. But the 38-year-old leader has fallen victim to Haiti's oldest game, a power play by soldiers fearing they were being cut out of the picture. Senior Officers Retired **********In his inaugural speech, Father Aristide stunned his audience with an alternately playful and poker-faced delivery as he announced the "marriage" of the armed forces with the people and proposed the immediate retirement of a cast of senior military officers he felt he could not trust. **********It appeared that President Aristide had scored a major victory when the soldiers dutifully retired. **********With his grassroots support still strong and pledges of good will and assistance pouring in from abroad, a resentful army, mindful of the violent routing of a band of coup plotters only a month before by hordes of Aristide supporters, could do little but swallow hard and play along. **********But in the succeeding months, diplomats and Haitian experts say, tensions grew. A number of unorthodox moves by the new President further riled many in the army. For example, at public appearances around the country, Father Aristide has spontaneously promoted enlisted soldiers to the officer corps, bypassing the military promotion system. Special Militia Worried Soldiers **********Wary of conspiracies, diplomats said, Father Aristide recently began constituting a 300-man militia thought to be detached from the ordinary chain of command. **********Soon, soldiers began bitterly referring to the force's members as attaches, a name previously used to refer to members of the Tontons Macoute, the murderous private militia formed by the dictator Francois Duvalier. **********For the Haitian military, the parallel is a frightening one. Mr. Duvalier used his militia to murder and exile ambitious soldiers, soon reducing the army to a marginal force in national life. **********Father Aristide earned high marks from diplomats for naming Brig. Gen. Raoul Cedras as provisional commander in chief in June. General Cedras replaced Herard Abraham, who had overseen the country's bumpy transition last year to democratic rule. **********General Cedras, 43 years old, reportedly gained the President's confidence as a moderate professional through his smooth handling of security arrangements for the elections last December, which Father Aristide won in a peaceful landslide. Cedras's Role in Coup **********Until shortly before the announcement late Monday, nearly a day after the coup began, that General Cedras was claiming to head a three-man junta, Western diplomats and observers insisted that the Haitian command was uninvolved in the coup. **********Today, diplomats said that while the situation remained clouded, it appeared that General Cedras had been a reluctant participant at first, moved in part by the detention of his wife by rebelling enlisted men. **********"We had the impression he wasn't free to talk, that he was physically surrounded by rebels," said one envoy who had spoken repeatedly with the new military leader as the coup unfolded on Monday. **********Observers said an added motive for General Cedras to cast his lot with the rebelling soldiers was the suspicion generated by Father Aristide's failure to submit the general's name to the legislature for its formal approval as commander in chief. **********The delay was one of the grievances cited by soldiers in Haitian radio broadcasts today. **********Unlike the plotters of the coup attempt in January, led by Roger Lafontant, a former official of the Duvalier Government, the organizers of Haiti's latest coup took no chances at allowing popular support to rally around the President, sending soldiers to shut down radio stations and break up crowds as they began to form. **********Sure to be scorned locally for their overthrow of a popular leader and the deaths of dozens of people who fell in the coup, and frozen out by the international community, it is unclear how Haiti's new rulers will hold on to power. The United States and France, the largest sources of Haiti's desperately needed foreign aid, immediately condemned the takeover and cut off aid. **********"We consider this a wholly illegitimate event," the United States Ambassador to Haiti, Alvin P. Adams Jr., said in a telephone interview from Port-au-Prince.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.body_text: **********In a declaration that could complicate efforts to free the Western hostages in Lebanon, the German Embassy in Beirut today rejected any link between the release of the two German hostages and two Shiite Muslim Lebanese jailed in Germany on terrorism charges. **********The declaration appeared to rebut reports by fundamentalists here of an agreement between Teheran and Bonn according to which the Lebanese prisoners, Mohammed Ali Hamadei and his brother Abbas, would be freed from prison in Germany several months after their associates here free the German captives, Thomas Kemptner and Heinrich Strubig, as part of a general exchange of prisoners in the Middle East. **********The release of the Hamadeis is the sole demand of the captors of the German hostages. Mohammad Ali Hamadei, 27, is serving life sentence for air piracy, murder and illegal possession of explosives and false travel documents. Abbas, 32, is serving a 13-year-prison term for conspiring to kidnap Germans in Beirut. **********Fundamentalist contacts here said that the German hostages would be excluded from a general swap of captives if Germany insisted on keeping the Hamadei brothers in prison.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.main_headline: Nicaragua Sinks Further as Chamorro's Magic Fails
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.print_headline: Nicaragua Sinks Further as Chamorro's Magic Fails
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.body_text: **********Despite expectations of a quick economic turnaround after the inauguration of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro last April, the Nicaraguan economy has not recovered and is now deteriorating amid large deficits and continued high military spending, economists and diplomats say. **********The flood of new private investment that Mrs. Chamorro's election was predicted to release has been reduced to a trickle by investors' fears of new civil unrest. Foreign aid has been held up by concerns about Government disarray and free spending that has forced Mrs. Chamorro to draw down the country's scarce reserves by roughly $50 million in the last two months alone. **********In Managua, traffic has become sprinkled with the shiny vehicles of visiting exiles weighing whether to return. But there has been little new long-term investment to help reverse a decade of economic decline. **********On the rutted streets of the capital, beggars have begun to go door to door in search of handouts, and currency changers wave thick stacks of local bills that lose up to half their value each month due to five-digit inflation. **********"A worker, a carpenter, a tailor can't even afford a pound of meat a week for his family," said Alfredo Vega Mendoza, a 50-year-old clothing salesman, carrying a small bag of rice and other purchases from a Managua market. "There hasn't been any kind of change -- that's all a lie."  High Cost of Concessions **********Mrs. Chamorro's aides staked the economy's future on her ability to win commitments of aid from the international community, and credits from international institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which American sanctions effectively made unavailable to Nicaragua under the Sandinistas. **********But the arrival of a mission from the I.M.F., World Bank and Inter-American Development Bank this month is also certain to focus hard international scrutiny on the admitted disarray of the Chamorro Government's economic policies. And it is expected to highlight the high economic cost that the Government has paid for its policy of cushioning its transition to power with salary concessions and slow reductions in Nicaragua's armed forces. **********"The concern is that the policies will not measure up, and instead of opening the door to new credit, the visit will only make things harder by confirming the worst impression that donor countries have about this Government," said a European diplomat whose country has been approached for aid. **********The Government's economic problems have weakened the effect of the outside aid that is already coming in, including $300 million in emergency American aid approved last year, and they have effectively delayed other major foreign commitments. **********Part of the American aid is the key to benchmarks of economic progress the Government has been unable to meet. Other important donors, like Japan, which has tentatively committed large amounts of aid, have dragged their feet, waiting for signs that the Government can make effective use of the money.  Production Shrinks **********Once expected to hold steady or even increase by the end of 1990, the economy's overall production shrank by as much as 5 percent -- even more than the relative loss suffered in the final year of Sandinista rule -- and is continuing to fall, Government analysts say. **********The deteriorating production has been accompanied by a resurgence of the hyperinflation that stripped the value of local currency for several years in a row. The Nicaraguan cordoba, which was reissued in February 1988 by the Sandinista Government at an exchange rate of 10 to the American dollar, now trades at roughly 3.2 million to the dollar. The Government's plan to introduce a new dollar equivalent currency, the gold cordoba, has been frozen by a lack of reserves to back it. **********Diplomats and independent economists here attribute much of the economy's trouble to the Government's inability to control social and military spending. **********Under a plan developed by Francisco Mayorga Balladares, a Yale-educated economist and key member of Mrs. Chamorro's campaign circle, the Government's monthly deficit fell from more than $30 million in the month after the President's inauguration to roughly $8 million in September. Mr. Mayorga also succeeded in obtaining large foreign aid commitments at a June conference of potential aid donors in Rome. Tight Restraint Abandoned **********But after worsening clashes with Mrs. Chamorro's family advisers, Mr. Mayorga was forced to resign in October. And the tight budgetary restraint he imposed was gradually abandoned, first in generous settlements of nationwide Sandinista strikes in May and July, and later in broader employment and salary concessions that formed part of a national pact signed with unions and business leaders on Oct. 26. **********As part of its policy of avoiding confrontation with the Sandinista-dominated military, the Government has also made a series of secret payments to the army that have amounted to as much as several million dollars a month above its formal budget, said diplomats and Government officials who have witnessed the payments. **********Signs of economic crisis have grown more urgent. The Government's monthly deficit has risen to at least $35 million, and inflation has surged again to roughly 50 percent a month. **********Early in December, Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law and chief strategist, Antonio Lacayo Oyanguren, led the Nicaraguan delegation to another donor's conference in Paris. But the delegation came away empty-handed after presenting a report that aid officials said made little attempt to justify the Government's deepening deficit. **********"The Rome document found acceptance among almost everyone; the Paris document found acceptance among almost no one," said another independent foreign expert. "The difference between was politics."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Bid Extended For Square D
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/busin.body_text: **********Groupe Schneider S.A., the French electric equipment concern, said that Square D shareholders had tendered 67.5 percent of their shares in support of its $78-a-share cash offer for Square D. **********Schneider said that when those shares were combined with the 318,000 it already owned, 68.9 percent of Square D shareholders favored the acquisition. **********Schneider said it had extended its tender offer to April 12 from March 29. **********"In light of the clear message being sent by Square D shareholders, I would like to renew our invitation for Square D to meet us," Didier Pineau- Valencienne, chief executive of Schneider, said. "We are prepared to discuss all aspects of our proposal." **********Square D, an electrical equipment maker in Palatine, Ill., called the Schneider offer inadequate and urged shareholders to reject it. "There is nothing to gain by tendering now," Jerre L. Stead, chairman of Square D, said in a statement. "And to those holders who may have tendered, we recommend strongly that they withdraw their shares now." **********Schneider is expected to begin a proxy fight to gain control of Square D's board at the company's May 24 annual meeting. **********Square D stock closed down 37.5 cents yesterday, to $76.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Securities a Bit Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher yesterday in unusually active pre-holiday trading. Dealers and traders said there was also a fair amount of domestic and foreign retail buying, considering that most market participants had closed their books for the quarter and in Japan for their fiscal year as well. **********Because today is Good Friday, there will be no markets in corporate or tax-exempt debt issues. The Chicago Treasury bond futures market will also be closed. Although the Treasury, Federal Reserve and many banks will be open, the New York Government securities dealer community will not operate. **********"Any business in Treasury paper on Friday will be like watching paint dry," said Mark A. McCluskey, chief Treasury securities trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich. "Most markets in Europe will also be closed for the Easter Monday holiday as well." **********One reason for the positive mood in the Treasury market was the good reception accorded the auctions of $20 billion of two- and five-year notes this week. Another reason was the usual "window dressing" of portfolios with Treasury bills and notes that many investment managers undertake at the end of a quarter. Amount of Business Surprising **********The amount of business was somewhat surprising because many bond traders are reluctant to assume sizable positions unless they can hedge, or lay off, part or all of their exposure in the futures market. **********"But it's also true that the front end of the Treasury market looks very cheap to many," Mr. McCluskey said. "That's one reason why this week's auctions of the two- and five-year notes went so well." **********The new 7 1/8 percent notes of 1993 were offered late in the day at 100 5/ 32, up 1/32, for a yield of 7.04 percent. At Tuesday's auction, the average yield on the two-year notes was 7.15 percent. The new 7.75 percent notes rose 2/32, to 100 2/32, for a yield of 7.73 percent. This compared with an average yield of 7.81 percent produced at Wednesday's auction of the five-year notes. Both Treasury maturities are now auctioned each month.  Claims for Unemployment **********Although the Government reported that the initial claims for unemployment insurance in the week ended March 16 was 510,000, it was somewhat below market expectations and had no effect on the fixed-income market, Mr. McCluskey said. Nor did the increases in personal income and consumption for February reported yesterday. **********Among the shortest maturities, discount rates on Treasury bills were little changed on the day. The 90-day bills slipped two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.76 perent; six-month bills dipped a basis point, at 5.79 percent, and the one-year bills lost three basis points, at 5.89 percent. **********The Treasury sold $13.5 billion of 15-day cash management bills at an average discount rate of 6.05 percent, and also announced that it would hold its regular auction of one-year bills on Thursday. The size of the auction is $10.75 billion. **********Among the longer maturities, the Treasury's 7.75 percent notes of 2001 were unchanged in price and yield at 97 31/32 and 8.05 percent, respectively. The benchmark long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue due February 2021, rose 3/32, to 95 31/32, as its yield slipped to 8.23 percent, from 8.24 percent the day before. **********For its part, the Federal Reserve added $1.5 billion of reserves to the banking system to accommodate the usual holiday demand for cash. The funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans was at 6 1/8 percent when the Fed intervened. The funds then traded down to close at 6 percent, the Fed's perceived target level for this bedrock cost of credit. **********Following are the details of the Treasury's auction of 15-day cash management bills: (000 omitted in dollar figures) Average Price . . . 99.748 Discounted Rate . . . 6.05% Coupon Yield . . . 6.16% High Price . . . 99.750 Discounted Rate . . . 5.99% Coupon Yield . . . 6.12% Low Price . . . 99.747 Discounted Rate . . . 6.07% Coupon Yield . . . 6.19% Accepted at low price . . . 42% Total applied for . . . $40,545,000 Accepted . . . $13,505,000 N.Y. applied for . . . $37,847,000 N.Y. accepted . . . $13,035,000

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/06/busin.main_headline: Services: A Boom Area Goes Bust
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/06/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH; Services: A Boom Area Goes Bust
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/06/busin.body_text: **********It WAS the boom area of the economy in the 1980's, and the bust area in the current recession. Now the economic statistics show that the service sector is once again starting to hire workers. **********But the catch may be that hiring is still at a low level in the precise area that this economy depends on to provide a push. "This really undermines the growth in purchasing power that consumers need to sustain recovery," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley. **********For those who focus on economic statistics, discerning the transitory from the permanent, the cylical from the secular, is a major challenge. Mr. Roach's bet is that the weakness in services will endure, as industries that became "complacent and bloated" are forced to restructure because of increased competition, some of it from overseas, just as manufacturing industries were forced to retrench in the last decade. **********Not counting health care -- an industry that grows merrily along, since no one seems able to get a grip on the upward spiral in costs -- this recession was roughly four times as severe as the one in 1981-82 in terms of private service jobs lost. And while 50,000 such jobs were gained last month, that is only a third of the average monthly gain from 1983 through 1990. **********Services is an amorphous grouping. It includes the folks flipping burgers at McDonald's, but it was not those jobs that provided the 80's boom. It was work in banks, law firms, health care, airlines, entertainment and retail sales that set the tone. Unfortunately, argues Mr. Roach, all that hiring, and billions spent on computers, produced rising incomes but not improved productivity. Now there are layoffs at lots of service firms, ranging from American Express to Skadden Arps. **********"This will be a recovery that is driven by productivity, or efficiency improvement, rather than one that is driven by excess hiring," Mr. Roach said on Friday, adding that more effective use of computers will be a big help. "That is good news for cost control, for inflation and, hopefully, for interest rates. It is bad news for those who have to pay the price for cost control by losing their jobs." **********Among Wall Street economists, Mr. Roach has not been a paid-up member of the alarmist camp. He has been calling for a recovery, and still is, but sees a greater downside risk than he had. "My single greatest concern is seeing this take a tremendous toll on white-collar job creation," he said. **********If Mr. Roach is right, then pressures to stimulate the economy are likely to increase, perhaps as stock traders grow more nervous. In the near term, that is likely to mean lower interest rates as the Fed eases monetary policy. **********But that could change. Just now, nobody in Washington wants to be known as a "budget buster," and there are government layoffs from coast to coast. But as the election nears, fiscal stimulus may regain respect and government spending may take off, scaring bond traders and pushing up rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds; As the I.R.A. Season Draws Near
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds; As the I.R.A. Season Draws Near
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/busin.body_text: **********Like crocuses, mutual fund advertisements -- coaxing investors to open individual retirement accounts before April 15 -- are harbingers of spring. So far, they have succeeded: Mutual funds had captured almost a quarter of the $465.4 billion I.R.A. market at the end of 1989, the most recent totals from the Investment Company Institute, a trade group. That's a bigger chunk than the I.R.A. money invested through banks, savings institutions, life insurance companies, credit unions or brokerage firms, which also offer the tax-deferring I.R.A.'s. **********So far during this tax season, mutual fund companies say, new accounts are down, probably because of the Mideast conflict. But they believe that sales will pick up before April 15 as tax time draws nearer and a market rally, driven by apparent war success, takes hold. **********Given that, how should people invest their I.R.A. funds? Most investment advisers recommend putting a big chunk of retirement savings into stock funds, which outperform fixed-rate investments over time. But it makes sense to move into stocks slowly to limit losses in case the market slips. Put cash into a money fund and then buy shares in stock funds at regular intervals. **********The following are questions investors are asking Oppenheimer, one of the big fund groups, and answers from Sam Freedman, president of Oppenheimer Shareholder Services; Robert M. Fields, an attorney with the New York law firm of Spengler Carlson Gubar Brodsky & Frischling, and Lewis J. Altfest, a New York investment adviser. **********Question: How much can I contribute to an I.R.A.? **********Mr. Freedman: Anyone younger than 70 1/2 can contribute up to $2,000 of earned income each year -- or $2,250, if your spouse doesn't work. But you lose part of the tax deduction for the contribution if you participate in your employer's 401 (k) or another retirement plan (or if your spouse does, if you file jointly) and your adjusted gross income rises from $40,000 to $50,000 for married couples filing joint tax returns (for singles, the equivalent is $25,000 to $35,000). When you earn more than that, you lose the deduction entirely. **********Q. Is it worthwhile to contribute to an I.R.A. if I can't deduct the contribution? **********Mr. Altfest: I urge clients to set aside the maximum amounts in pension and 401 (k) plans but I'm less enthusiastic about I.R.A.'s. **********They make sense for people who lack the discipline to save. They are also good bets for active traders, because the I.R.A. shields trading profits from the capital gains tax. **********But for everyone else, the sole advantage is that earnings in the account build up tax-free until the money is withdrawn. But you can get that elsewhere. Let's say you put $2,000 into an I.R.A. every year for 20 years and the account earns 10 percent annually. You end up with $126,005, or $86,943 after Federal tax is paid at the 31 percent rate. But if you invest the same amount of money in municipal bond funds earning 7 percent, you would have slightly more, $87,730. **********The longer you leave the money in the I.R.A., the more valuable the tax deferral.  You can also come out ahead with the I.R.A. if you pay tax at a lower rate at retirement. **********One warning: When you withdraw money, you will need records to show which contributions were deductible and which were not. Keep copies of Form 8606, filed with your tax return. To make record-keeping easier, Oppenheimer, for one, will segregate nondeductible contributions in a separate I.R.A. **********Q. How can I move my existing I.R.A. account into a mutual fund? **********Mr. Freedman: The easiest way is called a "trustee-to-trustee" transfer. You complete an I.R.A. application and a "Change of Trustee" form, which authorizes the mutual fund group to take the money from your old I.R.A.  Unlike an I.R.A. rollover, this transfer does not have to be reported to the Internal Revenue Service by the fund or by the investor. **********Q. When must I begin withdrawing money from the I.R.A.? **********Mr. Fields: You can start withdrawing the money without penalty when you turn 59 1/2. If you don't, you must begin taking out a minimum amount based on I.R.S. tables by April 1 of the year following the year that you turn 70 1/2. You have to take another minimum distribution by Dec. 31 of that year; after that, one annual withdrawal is required. **********Some fund groups will calculate the minimum required amount and then mail you checks on a monthly, quarterly or annual basis. **********Q. How much will it cost to set up an I.R.A.? **********Mr. Fields: Some funds charge a small fee, around $10. After that, you should expect to pay a yearly fee of about $10 or $15. The fees come under the heading of "miscellaneous expenses," which when toted up can be deducted to the extent that the total exceeds 2 percent of adjusted gross income. To claim the deduction, you must write separate checks for the I.R.A. contribution and expenses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/busin.body_text: **********A Santa Monica, Calif., trade-magazine publisher has purchased S.F. and Angeles, glossy home-design and fashion monthlies that appeared doomed when their parent company went under last month. **********Steve Goldstein said in a telephone interview that he had purchased all of the assets "and none of the liabilities" of the two publications. A sister magazine, California, was not included in the deal. **********"S.F. and Angeles were pretty much where they were supposed to be, and climbing," he said. "Their problem was high overhead since they shared staff with California, which had offices in New York, and San Diego, L.A., San Francisco." **********The three magazines were owned by the Australian Consolidated Press. The publications were closed last month because of declining ad revenue and the recession.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Cats are known for their unpredictable hours, and the owner of a headstrong feline might find it desirable to install a separate pet entrance. The problem, however, is that a pet door also opens a home to other furry guests, from inquisitive racoons to passing strays. **********The solution? Give kitty a key. **********Reilor Ltd., a privately held British company, has developed an electronic door that lets the cat of the house come and go freely, but denies entry to any other creature. **********Once the door, marketed under the brand name Staywell, is plugged in, a small transmitter emits a high-frequency radio signal at one-second intervals, then waits for an echoing signal. When the authorized cat approaches, a small "key" worn on its collar intercepts the signal, and generates the answering frequency.  When the door "hears" the response, it relaxes the latch with a loud click. This signals the cat to push against the door to gain entry, and also lets the owners know where the cat is. Cats will have to be taught push the door; a short lesson should suffice. **********The door also has a manual lock, which allows the owner to override the electronics and keep things closed, or to set the mechanism so the door will open one way but not the other. For example, it might allow the cat to come in but not go back out. **********There are three different frequency codes available, limiting the possibility that two cats on the same block will have the same key code. **********If overlap does occur, the company will tune the door to a different frequency without charge. The door also comes with two spare keys. More are available from the company for $7.50 apiece. **********Reilor, which operates in this country through a Pennsylvania-based subsidiary, has been selling these doors for about two years, alongside its line of nonelectronic cat and dog doors. The company estimates that it has sold about $85,000 worth of the electronic variety so far in this country, mostly through catalogues. Richard Charney, the American unit's general manager, said the electronic door made up about 1 percent of total United States sales. **********"Sales haven't been astronomical," Mr. Charney said. "This is a select item, with a limited appeal." One reason, Mr. Charney pointed out, is the electronic door's price, which averages about $125 retail. Traditional magnetic doors sell for about $20.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/busin.body_text: **********The Consumer Price Index climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in January, and twice as much if gyrating food and energy costs were excluded. But economists said inflation at the retail level was not as bad as it seemed. **********Separately, new housing activity skidded to its lowest levels since the early 1980's, with builders starting just 850,000 new homes and apartments at an annual rate, 12.8 percent below the depressed December level. Permits for future construction fell 4.7 percent. **********Taken together, the reports provided a mixed reading of economic performance last month, with the price figures tending to support the notion that downward momentum was being contained and the housing figures reflecting an industry mired in deepening recession.  War and the Credit Crunch **********Even housing, however, was said by various specialists to have shown signs of rebound in early February. **********"Hopefully, we are near the bottom of this recession," said Mark Tipton, president of the National Association of Home Builders. He attributed the January drop in housing starts to a sharp decline in consumer confidence before the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf and "a severe credit crunch," or a reluctance of banks to make loans. **********Patrick C. Jackman, the Labor Department official who supervises the data-gathering for the price index, said most of the unexpected jolts in today's report could be explained away and that inflation seemed likely to remain in check. **********"If I were Mr. Greenspan, I certainly would not change my policy based upon these numbers," Mr. Jackman said, referring to Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.  Greenspan's Forecast **********Indeed, the Fed chief projected at a Congressional hearing today that consumer prices would rise by 3.25 to 4 percent this year, down from 6.1 percent in 1990. The Fed chairman also said that he expected a recovery "reasonably soon," but saw risks to the economy from the war, the health of the banking system and availability of credit.  [ Page D19. ] **********The consumer price figures, which were worse than expected, pushed up interest rates in early trading in the credit markets, but upon closer examination traders and investors appeared to have decided that there was little danger of a sustained rise in inflation. **********Much of the increase reflected the imposition of luxury and other taxes on Jan. 1 and presumably temporary advances for new cars, resort lodging and fresh fruits and vegetables. **********"The rate of inflation is likely to be lower" in coming months, said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. He contended, for example, that a 1.3 percent January jump in the price of new cars, the biggest increase since May 1981, was unlikely to be repeated anytime soon.  1991 Models Costlier **********The Labor Department said the January rise reflected the continued introduction of higher-priced 1991 models as well an end to rebates on some models. The introduction of new models, starting in the fall, has been slower than usual this year. **********The four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the January Consumer Price Index covering all urban consumers followed two months of three-tenths of 1 percent increases. It was marked, among other things, by a 2.4 percent drop in the price of energy, and was partly offset by a nine-tenths of 1 percent jump in the price of food and beverages. **********Exceptionally cold weather in late December, especially in California, sent some food prices soaring, with oranges up 37.2 percent and lettuce up 24.5 percent. The price of alcoholic beverages advanced a record 4.9 percent, partly reflecting a Jan. 1 rise in Federal excise taxes but also reflecting industry increases put through at the same time. **********Cereal and bakery products jumped 1.3 percent, but dairy products fell for the third straight month and beef, pork and seafood also fell.  Housing Component Up **********The housing component also rose much faster than in December, increasing eight-tenths of 1 percent. That was the largest increase since mid-1982. A big factor, however, was a 6.8 percent jump in out-of-town lodging costs, reflecting greater-than-usual increases in vacation areas. Mr. Jackman speculated that advertised hotel and motel discounts applied mostly to weekend and other brief trips and not to longer stays. **********But household fuels also rose 1.5 percent as increases for electricity and natural gas -- up 2.8 percent and 1 percent, respectively -- more than offset a 5.6 percent drop for fuel oil. Local phone service rose 4 percent. **********The transportation component dropped 1.2 percent as gasoline fell 6.9 percent and used cars, tires and automobile body work also cost less. Besides new cars, the cost of auto financing rose and there was another sharp increase in airline fares that brought the advance to 13.4 percent over the latest five months. **********Apparel jumped 1 percent, reflecting smaller-than-usual price reductions for fall and winter clothing, as well as an earlier-than-usual introduction of higher-priced spring and summer clothing, the department said. The subindex for watches and jewelry climbed 4.3 percent, partly reflecting the new Federal luxury tax. Medical Costs Rise **********Medical care rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month, somewhat less than the eight-tenths of 1 percent average in the second half of 1990, while the "other" goods and services category rose seven-tenths of 1 percent for the third straight month. The latter category includes tobacco, on which taxes were also raised last month, and school tuitions. **********The eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in the so-called core inflation rate that excludes food and energy compared with a four-tenths of 1 percent average monthly rise in 1990. **********Before rounding, the consumer price index covering all urban consumers rose 0.4470939, a rate that if maintained and compounded over 12 months would produce annual inflation of 5.5 percent. **********Prices in the New York City area rose 1 percent last month, today's report also showed, with one of the main factors being the jump in out-of-town lodging. Mr. Jackman said that if many New Yorkers wintered in, say, Miami the cost of Miami lodging would be incorporated in the New York inflation rate. **********The index now stands at 134.6, which means that a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in 1982-1984 now costs $13.46. **********The C.P.I.-W covering urban wage earners and clerical workers also advanced four-tenths of 1 percent last month following two months of minimally smaller increases. **********Housing Starts **********The housing figures, which are compiled by the Commerce Department, showed that starts of new homes ran at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 850,000 last month, down from 975,000 in December and barely half the 1,543,000 started in January 1990, which was exceptionally warm. Last month's was also the lowest since January 1982, which had an annual rate of 843,000 units. **********Single-family dwellings accounted for most of the decline, falling 15.6 percent to a rate of 632,000, the lowest since June 1982, when 613,000 houses were started at an annual rate. Buildings with five or more units accounted for 189,000 at an annual rate, with smaller multiple-dwellings accounting for 29,000. **********By region, the drop in the Northeast was just under 30 percent, to a rate of 77,000 a year. The Midwest and South had 15 percent declines, to 198,000 and 340,000, respectively, while the West posted a tiny advance to 235,000. **********Amid the gloomy figures, however, the home builders' group and other analysts said they see some signs of revival. Mr. Tipton, of the home builders association, said he expected construction to begin rising after another two months or so because of lower interest rates, a restoration of confidence and evidence from a survey in the first half of February showing 42 percent of builders experiencing "high to average" traffic in their subdivisions, up from 24 percent who ranked traffic that high a month earlier. **********Mr. Rippe of Dean Witter also found "some positive signs" emerging in housing, including a faster rate of sale of existing homes and increasing affordability of housing over the past six months. **********Permits for future construction fell 4.7 percent last month to a rate of 804,000, 5 percent below the revised December rate of 844,000 and far below the 1,739,000 rate of January 1990 when there was a rush to beat new Federal requirements for accessibility by the handicapped to multi-family dwellings. **********Permits for single-family units were 6 percent lower, at an annual rate of 606,000, with the rate about unchanged at 99,000 in the Northeast, modestly higher at 187,000 in the Midwest and lower in the South and West with 301,000 and 217,000, respectively. **********The Commerce Department's report also showed that shipments of mobile homes for December ran at a rate of 167,000, 8 percent less than in November.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/22/busin.main_headline: Court Papers Provide a Look at Sears Defenses
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/22/busin.print_headline: Court Papers Provide a Look at Sears Defenses
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/22/busin.body_text: **********Sears, Roebuck & Company released a trove of documents today, part of a shareholder lawsuit against Sears that had been sealed. While incomplete, the documents support the shareholders' view that one reason for Sears's large-scale restructuring announced in October 1988 was to thwart hostile bidders. **********Directors of a public company can legitimately defend it against a hostile bidder, but the defense becomes illegal if the company cannot offer shareholders a better alternative than the bidder and if the directors' primary purpose is to entrench themselves. The shareholders' suit contends that Sears's management acted to entrench itself, rather than to benefit shareholders. Sears disputes that contention. **********The documents released are mostly shareholder accusations and Sears's responses. Sears released only snippets of depositions by its executives and of internal Sears memorandums that have been offered into evidence.  Secret Meeting **********In one memorandum, James M. Denny, Sears's chief financial officer, wrote to other Sears executives in advance of a secret meeting they held at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Chicago on Aug. 30, 1988, to discuss the planned restructuring. **********"The purpose of the analysis is to assist in the formulation of a strategy to deal with a hostile approach to the company," Mr. Denny wrote. In another memo released today, Mr. Denny discussed the plan for a huge repurchase of Sears stock as part of the restructuring, saying, "It is important to act before too large a percentage of stock falls into the hands of arbritragers." **********The documents also referred to a memo written in March 1988 by John Sayre, a Sears financial analyst, to Stanley Wright, head of Sears's corporate financial analytical group. Mr. Sayre wrote that the restructuring would be an "essential weapon against unfriendly investors." **********In another memo, an unidentified Sears executive encouraged Sears to play down the anti-takeover effects of an employee stock ownership plan, which Sears formed in 1989, and to develop instead a "legitimate" public reason for establishing the plan. **********The documents released today were seen by only a handful of reporters, but as they are more widely circulated, they are expected to be grist for discussions on corporate governance. **********But even if a court finds that Sears's restructuring was an effort to protect management, the top executives may still not be in jeopardy. "For a corporation not to have some sort of defense against an abusive takeover would itself be irresponsible," said Robert Hessen, a corporate governance specialist at Stanford University. "The beauty of a public corporation such as Sears is that you have the ability to bail out, that is to sell your shares. Anybody who believes that management was simply stalling and did not have a plan to strengthen the company could get out." **********The documents also show that Goldman, Sachs & Company, Sears's longtime Wall Street adviser, concluded in November 1987 that a raider might be able to restructure Sears and achieve a 37 percent to 68 percent premium for investors, compared with the 23 percent to 38 percent premium that Sears could achieve if it restructured itself. The documents say Goldman, Sachs then recommended a series of anti-takeover measures that Sears subsequently adopted. **********A Goldman, Sachs spokesman declined comment, referring reporters to Sears. **********Sears has said all along -- and it repeated today -- that the overriding purpose of the restructuring is to benefit investors. The sweeping corporporate overhaul included a $1.7 billion stock buyback; plans to sell the Sears Tower; divesting the commercial division of Sears's Coldwell Banker real estate unit; refocusing Sears's Dean Witter Reynolds and Allstate Insurance groups and overhauling the troubled Sears Merchandise Group by cutting prices and introducing more brand names. **********Despite the breadth of the restructuring, the court documents indicated that Sears's directors had taken only two hours and 20 minutes to approve the plan. In a deposition made public, Mr. Denny acknowledged that key elements of the restructuring -- for example, the decision to move Dean Witter away from the institutional brokerage business in favor of small investors -- had not been discussed by the board before the restructuring meeting. **********The plaintiffs are trying to show that the Sears board acted hastily, rubber-stamping a restructuring plan favored by top executives who wanted to keep management intact. Sears disputes that accusation. **********"The Sears board was well informed with the information it needed on these issues both before the meeting and at the meeting," a spokesman said. **********David Shute, Sears's top in-house legal counsel, acknowledged that the restructuring was accelerated because of takeover rumors then swirling about Sears, but he insisted that its purpose was to generate more earnings for Sears shareholders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/world.main_headline: Athens Journal; At the Foot of the Acropolis, a Big Dream Unfolds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/world.print_headline: Athens Journal; At the Foot of the Acropolis, a Big Dream Unfolds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/world.body_text: **********In this city of breathtaking ruins and some of the nastier urban tangles of these times, an ambitious planner has taken office, impatient to mobilize barriers and bulldozers and start changing the face of the capital. **********He is the new Mayor of Athens, Antonis Tritsis, an architect, engineer and town planner, trained in Chicago and the first man to come to this job with a far-reaching new master plan for the town center in more than 150 years. **********"It's a matter of survival," said the Mayor, who has gained a reputation for creating controversy. He said that unless Athens changes "it will be a jungle in 10 years." **********If Mr. Tritsis gets his way, main avenues may become passable again and quiet electric streetcars will end the era of the belching and roaring bus. The remains of the ancient city will cease to be ringed by asphalt and noise but united in a large archeological park linking the main sites and monuments.  City's Monotonous Look **********Which other city in Europe has a soul more than 3,000 years old? the Mayor said, making that sweep across the centuries that comes easily to Greeks. "We must reveal and recapture this historic soul," he said. **********As an epicenter of Western thought, Athens may be among the oldest and most evocative of places. Yet ever since the Turks left and the first king called on Bavarian architects in the 1830's to draw up a street plan, the town at the foot of the Acropolis has been straining at its leash. **********The city doubled in size in the last three decades. Greater Athens today is home to almost 4 million of the nation's 10 million people. **********The view from the Mayor's office offered the monotonous concrete look that gives Athens more in common with the sprawl of Amman or Mexico City than with the brick and stone of old European cities. The horizon was blurred by the "nefos," the nefarious brown smog that lingers whenever the wind is weak. All around sat a thicket of billboards and television aerials.  Plan to Ban Buses **********"Look at those," Mr. Tritsis said, frowning and declaring that the crass signs and the thousands of antennas would have to be replaced. Then Mr. Tritsis, now 54 years old, sat down to explain his plans. **********One calls for banning a portion of the one million buses and private cars from perennially jammed downtown streets. Instead he wants to bring in streetcars. **********"My pet project is a light tramway system," he said. "It's electric so it's clean, it can carry many people and it can combine with pedestrian ways." **********Besides, he said, unlike a new subway, streetcars stay safely above ground -- no small advantage in a city where digging invariably draws archeologists who may find important reasons to suspend the work.  Cleaning Up the Capital **********A former Environment Minister, Mr. Tritsis has been prodding the Government to deliver cleaner fuel and is asking Athenians to make room for trees to improve their air and relieve the stark cityscape. With only 2.8 percent green space, Athens has less than any European capital. **********In office since Jan. 1, the Mayor said he was still sorting out the books and dealing with his bureaucracy. He has been talking to garbage workers and gardeners and, not least, bankers and business executives to raise money. **********He is of course not the first Mayor pledging to clean up the capital. Others have promised but tripped over hurdles that say as much about Greece as about the job. **********In the land of the ancient city-state, today's metropolis has virtually no power and no income. An administrator said Athens does not even get to keep its parking fines. The Culture Ministry jumps in if plans are made in the vicinity of one of the dozens of ancient monuments. The Health Ministry has a say in basics like where to dump garbage. Almost all the funds depend on the Finance Minister.  Breathing Space and Visitors **********Some residents here suggest that getting anything done is a feat for any Mayor in Greece's antagonistic political climate, where rivals readily thwart each other's projects. **********"I have a double-edged problem," said Mr. Tritsis, who has taken office at a moment in which Greece is almost broke. "I need extra financing from the Government, and at the same time I need to fight for more power." **********Yet he said he believed that by rehabilitating the past he can enhance the present. An archeological park in the center will provide a breathing space, he believes, and bring in visitors who avoid this bad-tempered city and treat it merely as an airport on the way to the islands. **********He said he wanted to link all the sites from Classic to Roman to Byzantine Greece. That means an area embracing the temple of Zeus, the towering Acropolis, reaching through the Roman market, Monasteraki, the Agora as far as the Academy of Plato. It means closing roads and building new plazas and pedestrian ways.  Rundown Zone Restored **********Associates describe the tenacious planner as the main engine behind the transformation of Plaka, the old and rundown zone below the Acropolis. It is now cleaned up, restored and brimming with restaurants. **********When Mr. Tritsis was Minister of Environment and Planning, one friend recalled, people told him that taming Plaka would be impossible. But enlisting the police, he saw to it that in one night 93 places were shut, including seedy nightclubs and fronts for drug-dealing that had ignored official deadlines to close. **********He referred in jest to 1984, when he was dismised as Environment Minister, apparently because he fought with the real-estate lobby and refused to compromise. **********"The difference is," he said, "I can't be fired now for four years."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/29/busin.main_headline: Making a Differnce; A Mutual Attraction
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/29/busin.print_headline: Making a Differnce; A Mutual Attraction
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/29/busin.body_text: **********JOHN GUMMERE, chairman and chief executive of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company, expresses nothing but contempt when he surveys the large number of mutual life insurers that have converted to stock ownership to raise capital. **********Mutual companies -- those owned by their policyholders -- are formed "to enable the policyholders to obtain insurance at lower prices than they could get from a stock company," Mr. Gummere said. "De-mutualization is an admission of management failure. If we are doing our jobs right, we are producing insurance at a lower price than the stock companies, and we are doing it profitably." **********Such thinking, said Mr. Gummere (pronounced GUM-er-y), led him to announce recently that he had agreed to merge the Hartford-based Phoenix Mutual with another big mutual insurer, the Home Life Insurance Company of New York. **********The goal is to remain owned by policyholders and thus avoid the need to take on the expense of paying dividends to shareholders. **********To keep its mutual status, the new company, to be called Phoenix Home Life, hopes to trim expenses by $70 million a year by cutting jobs, paring computer systems and closing some offices. That in turn would increase profits, the companies say, as well as the capital base that has become so crucial in this period of growing life insurer insolvencies. Indeed, the merger comes in the wake of a very bad year for the industry. Regulators seized several insurers that had been hobbled by portfolios filled with junk bonds and bad real estate. **********Executives of both Phoenix and Home Life say that their merger -- the first involving two big mutual insurers -- was not prompted by financial troubles although both have large real estate portfolios. **********Mr. Gummere, who is 63 and says he has no plans to retire, will remain the boss, overseeing an organization with $600 million in capital, more than 2,000 employees and $11 billion in assets. Based on the last figure, Phoenix Home Life will be the nation's 13th-largest mutual insurer. **********"I'm not sure what the optimum size is," Mr. Gummere said, "but bigger is definitely better in our market segment."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/02/world.main_headline: In Palestinians' Strategy for Talks, Self-Rule Is Seen as Attainable
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/02/world.print_headline: In Palestinians' Strategy for Talks, Self-Rule Is Seen as Attainable
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/02/world.body_text: **********Palestinian strategy in the Middle East peace talks scheduled to resume Wednesday in Washington rests on the conviction that self-rule in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip is an attainable goal that serves larger American interests in the region and can be tolerated by Israel as well. **********Palestinians plotting the course of their direct talks with Israel say their primary goal will be to compress the time it will take to attain self-rule and hold local elections. Their aim is to build up, in a period short of three years, a core of Palestinian leaders in the Israeli-occupied territories at the nuts-and-bolts level of governing. **********Israel had said it prefers a five-year time span for local autonomy. **********The Palestinians will also strive to widen the concept of self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza to include all municipal, administrative and educational matters, Arab diplomats and Palestinian officials said. 'Squeezing Expectations' **********Palestine Liberation Organization officials in Tunis who are drawing Palestinian strategy in the new round of talks say they think that within those broad limits, Palestinian, Israeli and American visions for peace are not too far apart. Arriving at an agreement, they say, is a matter of "squeezing expectations." **********These officials and those among the group of advisers to the Palestinian negotiating delegation say they sense no resistance from any of the Arab countries to their approach, which a negotiator summed up in three points: ***********Avoiding any conflicts with the co-sponsor of the talks, the United States. ***********Presenting positive suggestions in response to any problems raised by the Israeli negotiators to gain further ground in Israeli, and perhaps American, public opinion. ***********Aiming for achievable goals at the early stage of this new round of talks. Courted by Syrians **********"Syria has been on a charm offensive with the Palestinians lately, probably because they need us more than we need them," said the negotiator on the advisory board to the Palestinian delegation. **********"They have reopened the P.L.O. office in Syria, and they are releasing Palestinian prisoners jailed for years," said the adviser, who asked not to be identified. "Egypt is totally behind anything we do, and we have had no conflicts with Jordan so far." **********Palestinians think that the United States is eager to achieve progress at this round of direct talks because it expects the third stage, negotiations on regional issues between Arab countries and Israel, to be far more complicated. **********"The Americans have to be tough on Israel now in the bilateral talks because they plan to be very tough on the Arabs in the multilateral talks," a senior P.L.O. policy planner at Tunis headquarters said in a telephone interview. Israeli Signals Seen **********Palestinians say they see signals supporting their analysis in some recent Israeli and American actions. **********"The Americans are telling us to go directly into the substance of self-rule, and we will," said another P.L.O. official at the Tunis headquarters. **********In Israel, some Palestinian analysts say they see subtle indications of a slowdown in construction of new Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza resulting largely from a lack of funds in the Israeli treasury. This, they speculate, may be an excuse to freeze settlements without saying so. **********Tactically, the Palestinians see an opportunity to put their case directly to the American people from the American capital. "We will be the first to sit down at the table on Dec. 4," said a Palestinian academic, who like other negotiators insisted on anonymity. **********Palestinians want to pursue their objectives under the international umbrella of a peacekeeping force, preferably one from the United States. **********They also want to label the entire process a "transitional period," as opposed to "self-rule," thereby affirming that it is not an end in itself. **********Palestinian officials say they know that the Israeli Government led by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir will fiercely resist any idea of an independent Palestinian state. But they believe that before discussions reach that stage, there may be a change of government in Israel. **********They are betting on the eventual replacement of Mr. Shamir's Likud Government with a coalition of the Labor and Likud parties "that can take things further from the self-rule stage," said the senior planner. **********They acknowledge that while these initial steps may be attainable, talks with Israel will bog down in great difficulty on the emotional issues of the status of refugees from the Arab-Israeli wars and the Jewish settlements in the territories. **********Syrian talks with Israel appear far more difficult to start than those with the Palestinians, Egyptian and Palestinian officials interviewed over the last few days said. **********But they are convinced that if the Syrians and Israelis can overcome a psychological barrier -- mutual hatred and contempt -- their major territorial issue, a final status for the Golan Heights, can be resolved. Israel captured the strategically important area from Syria in the 1967 war and annexed most of it. **********The area could be demilitarized and returned to Syrian sovereignty without altering Israel's security there, experts interviewed said. Similarly, they said, an agreement with Syria would entail an accord with the Lebanese Government, which demands the withdrawal of Israeli troops from the southern part of Lebanon. **********An Arab envoy here expressed optimism. Speaking of the Syrian President, he said, "Hafez al-Assad can sell any Syrian concessions on the Golan Heights to his people as a triumph of Syrian will over the Israelis the same way he told them he has entered Lebanon to free it from Israeli occupation, and protect the Christian Lebanese, and then the Palestinians."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/16/world.main_headline: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: The Foreign Minister Man in the News: Aleksandr Aleksandrovich Bessmertnykh; Soviet Master of Washington's Ways
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/16/world.print_headline: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: The Foreign Minister Man in the News: Aleksandr Aleksandrovich Bessmertnykh; Soviet Master of Washington's Ways
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/16/world.body_text: **********In 1988, after assuring members of the Soviet Parliament that the treaty limiting medium-range nuclear missiles was good for Moscow, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, then a Deputy Foreign Minister, paused in the Kremlin to chat in English about the agreement with an American journalist. **********The Soviet official was at ease as he talked about the political dimension of Soviet-American relations and the importance of the treaty. Such informality, common with American officials, was unusual for a top Soviet official. **********But it was typical for Mr. Bessmertnykh, now 57 years old, who has spent most of his professional life working in or studying the United States. He became Soviet Ambassador to the United States in May 1990, arriving here to take up his diplomatic duties the same week President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived for summit meetings with President Bush. **********So when Mr. Bessmertnykh was named Foreign Minister today, Bush Administration officials welcomed the appointment as a reassuring indication that Soviet-American relations would remain on track. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said: "We've all worked with him in a number of capacities. He's been very instrumental in shaping Soviet-U.S. relations, particularly through this gulf crisis." In U.S. Many Years **********American officials and Soviet scholars say nobody in the Soviet Foreign Ministry knows the United States better, and few Soviet officials have more experience dealing with Washington. Mr. Bessmertnykh -- the name is pronounced byeh-SMEHRT-nikh and means immortal -- worked at the United Nations Secretariat in the 1960's, served at the Soviet Embassy here from 1970 to 1983 and was later head of the Foreign Ministry department responsible for the United States and Canada. **********Paul H. Nitze, the former arms control negotiator for the United States, said: "Mr. Bessmertnykh is very intelligent and friendly. His sympathies are basically with the United States. He knows the U.S., and I think he is fond of Americans." But Mr. Nitze said, "I don't think he will be as influential" as the last Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, whom Mr. Nitze described as "one of the two or three great men" of the Soviet Union today. **********"Bessmertnykh is an attractive man, but not a great man," Mr. Nitze said, adding, "I'm very fond of him." **********Aleksandr Aleksandrovich Bessmertnykh, the son of a civil servant, was born Nov. 10, 1933, in Biysk, in south-central Siberia. He graduated in 1957 from the Moscow State Institute of International Relations and has a degree in international law and political science. He gives the impression of being precisely what he is: a well-trained bureaucrat.  Worked Hard on Treaty **********Acquaintances say that Mr. Bessmertnykh, as a diplomat here in the late 1970's, worked hard on a treaty to limit strategic arms, hoping it would contribute to a lasting improvement in Soviet-American relations. They recall that he was downcast after the treaty was shelved after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in late 1979. **********Dimitri K. Simes, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said Mr. Bessmertnykh was "probably the best expert on the United States in the Soviet Foreign Service." **********"If you wanted to find somebody who would be a good partner for Secretary of State Baker and has a longstanding relationship with the State Department, someone who understands how the U.S. political system functions -- the role of Congress and the news media, and constraints on the President -- I don't know anyone who would perform better than Mr. Bessmertnykh," Mr. Simes said. **********Mr. Simes described Mr. Bessmertnykh as "an honorable man who displayed a great propensity for lying on behalf of his country when appropriate."  Defended Afghanistan Role **********For example, he said, Mr. Bessmertnykh publicly defended the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan as a response to an invitation from Afghan officials, and Mr. Simes asserted that Mr. Bessmertnykh "would have no particular difficulty justifying to the world what the Soviets do in the Baltic republics, if Moscow decides to proceed with a crackdown." **********Mr. Bessmertnykh took diplomatic lessons from a master, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the urbane former Ambassador to the United States. The two served together in the embassy here from 1970 to 1983. Mr. Bessmertnykh said Mr. Gorbachev chose him to be the Ambassador here last year because Soviet-American relations required "the professional touch." **********As one of three First Deputy Foreign Ministers from 1988 to early 1990, Mr. Bessmertnykh was responsible for North America and the Middle East. In those years, he visited Iran, Iraq, Syria and Turkey, among other countries. **********Diplomats at the Soviet Embassy say Mr. Bessmertnykh is a connoisseur of art and classical music. "He took advantage of every spare moment to go to art galleries and art exhibitions" in Washington, said a Soviet diplomat. While working in Moscow, Mr. Bessmertnykh discovered some paintings in the Foreign Ministry archives and put them on display. **********From his first marriage, Mr. Bessmertnykh has a daughter, Marina, who was born in 1961. His first wife died in April 1989. A year later he married Marina Vladimirovna, now 35 years old. They have a son, Arseni Aleksandrovich, born at a hospital here two and a half weeks ago.
