https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/busin.main_headline: Under Audit, Stanford Will Repay U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/busin.print_headline: Under Audit, Stanford Will Repay U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/busin.body_text: **********Stanford University said today that it would refund about half a million dollars of Government research money used for the upkeep of university-owned homes for the university's president, Donald Kennedy, and two other administrators. **********Mr. Kennedy made the announcement as the university was feeling increasing pressure from Federal agencies that are investigating whether Stanford overcharged the Government by tens of millions of dollars for research done there in the last decade. **********The investigations are being conducted by the Defense Department, which is the agency responsible for auditing Stanford's charges, the General Accounting Office and the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Questionable Links to Research **********Although the investigations are not complete, they have already turned up evidence that Stanford charged the Government for part of the costs of work that do not seem related to research, like a cedar closet and the refurbishing of a grand piano in the university-owned home where Mr. Kennedy, who has been president for 10 years, lives. **********At issue is the amount Stanford charges the Federal Government for the indirect, or overhead, costs of conducting research for all Government departments on its campus. The Defense Department was named from among the departments with research done at the university as the agency responsible for the costs there. **********The way the Government finances research grants consist of two components: direct costs, which can easily be attributed to a specific project, like laboratory equipment and professors' salaries, and indirect costs for the overhead charges, including administrative services, operating university buildings and maintenance of roads. **********It is difficult to quantify the expenses of running the library or the provost's office, for example, that should be allocated to research, and each university reaches its own agreement on such figures with the Federal Government.  Denial of Wrongdoing **********Mr. Kennedy has repeatedly denied that the university did anything wrong, saying that Stanford merely fought aggressively for every dollar to which it was entitled under Federal rules. **********Larry Horton, Stanford's associate vice president for public affairs, said the charges for Mr. Kennedy's home were allowed under Federal regulations because the residence was used for receptions and other official functions, some of them related to research. But because of the controversy, Stanford would voluntarily refund the $500,000 in costs claimed since 1981 for the operation of the homes of Mr. Kennedy and two other university administrators, he said. **********Mr. Horton emphasized that Mr. Kennedy himself did not make decisions to charge items like antiques and the closet to the Federal Government. Rather, he said, all the expenses of running the house were put into a pool and the total costs of the pool were allocated to different sources of money like indirect research costs and tuition. **********While repeating that nothing wrong had been done, Mr. Kennedy in a statement today acknowledged that Stanford's accounting system had "some shortcomings, real as well as perceived" and that there were legitimate questions about Stanford's procedures. Committee Is Being Formed **********In addition to refunding the money, Mr. Kennedy also said today that Stanford has hired the accounting firm Arthur Andersen and Company to do an independent evaluation of the university's accounting practices. **********He also said an advisory committee of five people was being formed to review these practices and recommend changes. Retired Admiral Bobby Ray Inman, the former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, Father Timothy Healy, president of the New York Public Library and the former president of Georgetown University, and Joseph Connor, chairman of Price Waterhouse World Firm Ltd., another accounting company, have been named to the committee so far. **********Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is the chairman of the subcommittee investigating Stanford, today called the university's moves "a good beginning." He added, "We're delighted they realize they have a problem and are taking some steps to solve it." But he said the investigation would continue. **********It is also expected that the investigations will look at other universities. **********Refunding the money for administators' houses may not be the only concession that Stanford will eventually have to make.  Charges Among the Highest **********The amount Stanford charges for indirect costs is among the highest assessed by any university. Until recently it has been 74 percent of the amount gained in grants. For each $100,000 a professor receives in direct research grants, Stanford receives an extra $74,000 to cover overhead costs. The university, under pressure from Defense Department auditors, recently dropped that to 72 percent, a reduction that will cost it more than $2 million a year. **********Such charges for indirect costs, for which the Government paid about $80 million in the 1989 fiscal year, account for almost one-third of Stanford's operating budget and are its second biggest source of unrestricted funds after tuition. **********Since the Federal investigations began late last year, a series of embarrassing discoveries have been made. As part of its indirect research costs, for instance, Stanford charged taxpayers $184,000 to cover depreciation on a luxury yacht that had been donated to it. Stanford said the charge was a mistake and has refunded the money. **********Then it was discovered that the costs at least partly billed to the Federal Government included $2,500 for refurbishing a grand piano, $3,000 for a cedar-lined closet and up to $2,000 a month for flowers at the university president's house. An investigator with the House subcommittee said today that other charges at Mr. Kennedy's house included $9,000 for antique furniture in 1988 and $7,000 for linen in 1987. **********While charges for the cedar closet and the yacht receive attention, the money at stake is determined by far more complex matters, like the accounting procedures used to determine what percentage of the costs of running the libary should be allocated to research, which can then be recovered from the Government as indirect costs. **********A Defense Department representative stationed at Stanford, for instance, has said Stanford used a cost allocation formula that allowed it to receive about $5 million more each year from the Federal Government than it would under a formula used by many other universities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.main_headline: The Executive Life; Dirty Shirts at the 6:18, Clean Collars Tonight
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.print_headline: The Executive Life; Dirty Shirts at the 6:18, Clean Collars Tonight
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.body_text: **********It's 6:18 on a Tuesday morning, and the Greenwich, Conn., train station is bustling. Cars drop off sleepy-eyed commuters, who dash to the newsstand, coins and monogrammed briefcases in hand, before heading to the Manhattan-bound platform. **********Some commuters, however, carry something more. James Carrier, a salesman with Reuters Information Services, races in with an armful of crumpled shirts. "No starch," he blurts to an attendant at the blue-and-white booth just inside the station's entrance.  "See you tonight." **********When Mr. Carrier returns 12 hours later, his fresh-pressed shirts will be waiting, done by Commuter Cleaners, a four-year-old service that has grown to seven outlets -- at railroad stations and in small shops -- in suburban Westchester County and Connecticut. "It used to be that I could never get to my cleaners except on weekends," Mr. Carrier said. "This is much more convenient." **********Commuter Cleaners is the brainchild of Paul McDonald, a 31-year-old former accountant who got fed up with working long hours and commuting -- and never having a clean shirt as a result. His early efforts involved standing outside the Greenwich station with a laundry basket, offering to ferry commuters' clothes back and forth from local cleaning shops. Today he runs a $1 million business with 20 employees, a fleet of vans and his own production plant. It is, to the best of his knowledge, the only such service in the country, and he also offers tailoring and shoe repair. **********"Our concept is to attract the time-sensitive customer," Mr. McDonald explained.  "These people spend 40 hours a month on the train. Anything they can do to save a little leisure time is a big help." **********Operating a cleaner along one of the nation's chief power corridors means Mr. McDonald sees some unusual dirty laundry.  Take the morning Tom Sexton, manager of the fixed-income department at First Boston, left a pair of golf slacks at the Greenwich station. During the cleaning, a money clip turned up -- with more than $1,000 in cash.  "He gave our driver a pretty big tip when he found it waiting," said Mr. McDonald. **********Another time, a prominent executive -- whom Mr. McDonald won't identify -- arrived with his wife. When he dumped his clothes on the counter, a peep show token rolled out of a pocket. "He told his wife he found it on the street, that it was a coin from another country," recalled Mr. McDonald. **********Until 1987, Mr. McDonald had had little experience with either commuting or cleaning. The Oklahoma-bred entrepreneur earned an M.B.A. from Tulane University in New Orleans, then took a job with Arthur Andersen there. When the regional economy headed south, he headed north to Creditanstalt Bankverein, an Austrian bank with offices in midtown Manhattan. He settled in Westchester, and for 18 months commuted to his job as an account supervisor. **********"There's a lot of time on the train to sit and ponder your future," he said. **********Armed with demographic statistics from Metro-North, Mr. McDonald did a market analysis of commuters using the New Haven and the Harlem-Hudson lines. He started his service in Greenwich because it had the right station configuration. "You need to get customers between their cars and the train," he says. "It helps if they all come through the same entrance." **********He negotiated for a lease on the Greenwich (there are also Old Greenwich and Cos Cob stops) station, from a private real estate company; later, in Stamford and Chappaqua, two other station sites, he had to win approval from the municipalities. **********To insure success with customers, he undercut local services, charging $1.50 a shirt instead of $2. Because his business required only low overhead -- a few feet of space in the station and a truck to transport the clothes, which were processed at a low bulk rate by local cleaning plants in their downtime -- he turned a profit in his first month.  (Recently, he raised shirt prices to $1.75, to cover the cost of his production plant.) **********Metro-North's research suggests that more than 60 percent of the area's commuters are men, but Mr. McDonald is trying to woo women, too; their clothes are more expensive to clean, generating higher profit margins, and they are highly appreciative of his service. "With two-career couples, convenience becomes a major issue," says Molly Ingram, director of consumer promotion programs for Cahners Publishing, who commutes from Greenwich. "This has made things much easier for us." **********But some of Mr. McDonald's best customers aren't commuters at all. Two years ago, he added home delivery, and makes pickups and deliveries twice a week. He now also has four small shops in Westchester to soak up his cleaning plant's additional capacity. His storefront customers include the likes of Carl Icahn, who has been seen dashing from his car with dirty shirts in hand. But Mr. McDonald would not air customers' dirty laundry -- or at least the names of the owners of said dirty laundry -- for publication. **********There are still a few kinks to smooth out, such as how to deal with executives who want to drop off shirts in Chappaqua and pick them up in Stamford. But plans are underway to expand this fall into three more stations and Mr. McDonald is considering other sites. "Imagine Long Island," he said, eyes gleaming. "The Huntington station alone has 5,000 commuters a day. Think of all those shirts."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********"Running Aid in Tandem With Reform" (Forum, Oct. 20) rightly emphasizes the need for reforms involving market incentives and development of "market-friendly" institutions supported by foreign finance. **********But Vinod Thomas, the author, also admits that "when aid programs are poorly designed, they allow recipients to postpone -- or totally avoid -- difficult policy changes." Yet the reasons for what might be called the past preponderance of non-success -- and the relatively few success cases -- are never dealt with. I suppose the reader is to conclude that if the symbiosis between reforms and financing doesn't work out, it must be due to the failure of the recipient country to treat the program "as its own, rather than as a foreign imposition." **********Surely there is more to it. One possible cause of failure extends to the behavior of the donor/creditor agencies, including Mr. Thomas's own World Bank. At least part of the problem resides with such agencies' felt need to keep lending even when recipients' actions don't warrant it. Bluntly put, as long as meeting some sort of informal lending levels overcomes the insistence on high quality, donors may undermine their own objectives by permitting recipients to pursue inappropriate policies. **********The World Bank is all too often unwilling to act like a bank at the outset -- to wait until the recipient proposes a serious, long-term program of reform. It is also not often prepared to cease lending if mutual understandings are violated. This is, of course, not lost on would-be recipients and is a major reason why structural adjustment packages have often deteriorated into ritual dances while the money kept flowing. **********While donors are asking for policy reforms in the third world and Eastern Europe, little attention is paid to the sociology and operating behavior of their own institutions. **********Achieving success in linking policy change with foreign financing may require institutional and policy reforms from donors as well as recipients. GUSTAV RANIS  New Haven, Oct. 23    The author is the Frank Altschul Professor of International Economics at Yale University. He has served as assistant administrator for program and policy in the Agency for International Development.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/15/world.main_headline: Satellite Group Plans a Pocket-Phone System
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/15/world.print_headline: Satellite Group Plans a Pocket-Phone System
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/15/world.body_text: **********Inmarsat, a London-based international satellite consortium, has announced plans to set up a system to relay calls from pocket-sized wireless telephones anywhere on earth. **********Industry experts say the Inmarsat plan, announced Friday, makes it likely that when an international conference is held next year, world governments will assign to satellite telephones the radio frequencies they need to operate. **********Officials of Inmarsat, which already provides marine and aircraft communications, emphasized that they had not yet decided what kinds of satellites to use. The sateliites would relay signals to telephone systems on the ground from light-weight portable telephones at a cost of about $1 a minute. Inmarsat officials say that no more than 30 to 40 satellites will be involved and that they are waiting until next year's conference is over before deciding what kind of satellites to launch. **********Inmarsat's plans for what it calls Project 21 are similar to those announced last year by Motorola Inc., which wants to launch a fleet of 77 small satellites that would provide mobile telephone service. **********One of the biggest obstacles to such plans is that virtually all the radio frequencies assigned for mobile satellite communications are already being used. The same frequencies sought for satellite telephones are also being sought for other technologies, from locally provided wireless telephones to digital radio broadcasts that would have sound quality comparable to that of compact disks. **********But Inmarsat, which is itself owned by 64 Governments around the world, including that of the United States, will bring special influence to the global talks scheduled for February, known as the World Administrative Radio Conference. Indeed, some analysts worry that Inmarsat could cramp the development of other communications systems by obtaining exclusive use of choice frequencies for satellite telephone service. **********"By the nature of what they're designing, Inmarsat is saying that they need to have spectrum specifically allocated to mobile satellite services," said John Pemberton, an analyst at the Gartner Group in Stamford, Conn. A better approach, he argued, would be to allocate a large band of frequencies more flexibly, for a wide variety of services. **********The United States, which is Inmarsat's largest shareholder, generally supports new technologies like satellite phones, but officials have tended to advocate assigning frequencies for a range of possible uses. **********The London-based consortium already provides mobile telephone services. During the Persian Gulf war, for example, journalists used suitcase-sized satellite transmitters to communicate over Inmarsat satellites with their home offices and Inmarsat is now preparing to offer services for telephones small enough to fit inside briefcases. **********"The next step is to make it even smaller," said Olof Lundberg, director general of Inmarsat, in a telephone interview from London. "It is technically feasible; it can be done today. But it can't be a marketable product because the satellite systems being used today are not well suited to these very, very small terminals." **********Inmarsat plans to provide the satellite network and set the technical standards for the new servces, but other companies would provide the actual telephones and sell service to individual customers. Market Is Still Tiny **********Despite the futuristic allure of pocket-sized satellite telephones, Mr. Lundberg noted that the market for them is tiny in comparison to that for cellular telephones in Europe, Japan and the United States. The phones are expected to be of use primarily to people who travel heavily in remote regions where conventional telephones are unavailable. They might also be in demand in countries with territories that are largely unpopulated. **********Organization officials said they expect the new system to cost between $500 million and $1 billion to put in place.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/26/world.main_headline: Germans May Now Try To Extradite Honecker
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/26/world.print_headline: Germans May Now Try To Extradite Honecker
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/26/world.body_text: **********The collapse of Communism in the Soviet Union has raised new hopes here that the former East German Communist leader, Erich Honecker, might now be subject to extradition and trial. **********Mr. Honecker fled to the Soviet Union in March as prosecutors were preparing to charge him in connection with shoot-to-kill orders issued to guards along the Berlin Wall. **********A German newspaper, Bild am Sonntag, today quoted a former Kremlin adviser as predicting that Mr. Honecker would soon be sent home to face his accusers. Since Mr. Honecker's flight, Germany has done little to seek his return. Politicians and commentators have suggested that if he is brought to trial, the results could be politically embarrassing for many parties. Mr. Honecker turned 79 today. A newspaper said he is living in a luxurious house at Batumi in the Caucusus. **********The former East German intelligence chief, Markus Wolf, is also believed to be living in the Soviet Union. With the power of his K.G.B. protectors now shattered, his extradition to face espionage charges is also considered possible.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/03/busin.main_headline: New System for Trading in Treasury Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/03/busin.print_headline: New System for Trading in Treasury Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Seeking to reduce the cost of trading Treasury securities, EJV Partners, a newcomer with blue-chip backing, plans to introduce a new computerized system where trading firms will arrange their purchases and sales electroncially. **********The new system is expected to start within the next month or two, and if successful, could eliminate hundreds of jobs for brokers who talk with dealers by telephone and collect price information that is then displayed on video screens.  Using Available Technology **********The backers of the new venture are six of the most active trading firms in the Treasury market -- Goldman, Sachs & Company, the First Boston Corporation, Salomon Brothers, Morgan Stanley, Citicorp and Shearson Lehman Brothers. Those firms, in combination with 34 more firms that are also primary dealers in the Treasury market, trade about $100 billion of securities daily, and pay annual brokerage fees estimated at more than $500 million. In 1988, before Wall Street consolidations, there were 46 primary dealers. **********None of the firms would comment on EJV, whose initials stand for Electronic Joint Venture, but all six are known to be keenly interested in reducing costs in the highly competitive Treasury securities market. **********"What we are doing is using the available technology in a way that over the long term will keep our costs well below our competitors," said Richard K. MacWilliams, president of EJV Brokerage. **********The competitors are a half-dozen brokering firms that match securities firms' orders to buy Treasury issues with orders to sell; they do no business with the general public. Securities dealers trade through brokers rather than directly with each other to conceal their identity and trading strategies. **********"You have to question whether there is a need in this market for 40 primary dealers and five or six brokers," said Peter Carney, president of Fundamental Brokers Inc., one of the brokering firms, when asked about EJV. "With so many people serving vanilla ice cream, you see people putting sprinkles on top to make themselves different." **********Harry Needleman, senior vice president at the Cantor Fitzgerald Securities Corporation, one of the largest brokers of Treasury securities, said the idea of matching buyers and sellers electroncially "is something we have seriously considered," but he declined to discuss the firm's current plans. **********The prices and yields of Treasury securities are closely watched and serve as benchmarks for other interest rates ranging from home mortgages to short-term corporate i.o.u.'s. **********Most of the advantage of EJV comes, Mr. MacWilliams said, from its system of allowing buyers and sellers to enter the amounts and prices of securities they wish to trade directly into a computer, which then displays the information on a screen. **********Trades on the EJV system would also be handled by the computer, following instructions received directly from the securities dealer. The system would use a voice recognition system where each trader's voice pattern is identified by the computer so that trade instructions can be taken verbally rather than by entering numbers and letters on a keypad. At present, a securities dealer delivers instructions to a human broker. **********EJV has not yet set a price for its service, "but we expect to have the lowest price in the market," Mr. MacWilliams said. He said the firm would begin brokering only Treasury bills and notes due in less than three years, but would expand to longer term issues by the end of the year. **********"When you have a commodity-type product, such as Treasury securities, electronics can play a role in breaking down the cost structure, and that is what EJV is doing," said one of the largest dealers in government securities, who asked not to be identified.  Treasury Bill Fees Fall **********Securities dealers noted that anticipation of EJV's arrival had already caused brokerage fees on Treasury bills to fall by about a third to around $12 to $15 per $1 million of securities traded from about $20. **********In the long-term bond market, where EJV does not pose any immediate threat, brokering commissions are much higher -- about $39.06, or 1/256th of a point, for each $1 million of bonds. Brokers fees for long-term bonds were about twice as high in the early 1980's, before securities dealers joined forces to create Liberty Brokerage Inc., which cut prices to levels that became the industry standard. **********When EJV stops testing its system and begins live trading, Mr. MacWilliams expects that the firm will need only six to eight people to provide the training and instruction dealers need to use the new system for short-term issues, plus the Digital Equipment Corporation computer that organizes and displays the information that securities dealers provide. At a traditional brokering firm, more than a dozen brokers would be needed just to handle trading in very short-term Treasury issues, and a few hundred are needed to handle the full range of Treasury securities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Magazines Urged to Be Aggressive
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/08/busin.body_text: **********In a speech he billed as a "call to arms," the chairman of the Magazine Publishers of America today asked for an industrywide effort to halt the shift of magazine advertising dollars to non-traditional advertising like telemarketing and supermarket rebates. **********"Promotion alone is where 45 cents out of every advertising dollar goes today," the chairman, Reginald K. Brack Jr., told hundreds of magazine executives gathered here for the American Magazine Conference. "Promotion is a pot of gold at the end of the rainbow and we should all be chasing that rainbow." **********He urged the executives to stop fighting one another for declining advertising dollars and to join in the effort to show advertisers that magazines are the most effective medium in which to distinguish their brands from those of their competitors. **********"There are 1,300 magazines represented in this room this morning," he said. "If each of you creates just one ad showing how a specific advertiser has been helped by an ad placed in each magazine you publish, can you imagine the effect? In a matter of months I believe we could drastically alter the way the business community looks at magazines as an advertising vehicle." **********With a registration of 630 people at the magazine conference, attendance is up over the last two years as magazine executives struggling with the steepest advertising decline in two decades turn to one another for answers. The philosophical ones point out that it is the 250th anniversary of magazines (Andrew Bradford, a printer, beat out his old boss, Benjamin Franklin, by three days and published the country's first magazine, American Magazine, in January 1741) and that grim times are nothing new. Doing Away With Gimmicks **********Calling for "nothing short of a revolution in the magazine business," Mr. Brack told publishers that they had to change the way they did business with their customers. He called for a halt to building up circulation with gimmicks and premiums just to attract advertisers. He also chided publishers for making pricing and editorial compromises. **********The speech was striking because of its assertions that the magazine industry was responsible for some of its own troubles. The industry has traditionally been in a self-congratulatory mood when it gathers for its annual meetings and has tended to deny that trouble existed. **********In an interview Mr. Brack said that too much attention had been placed on the business practices of magazines, like cross-media advertising, with too little focus on the effectiveness of the editorial side of magazines. As an example of editorial influence, he pointed to a recent article in Money magazine naming Seattle as the No. 1 city in the country, which resulted in such a mass of visitors coming to see for themselves that the highways around the city were clogged. **********"Every good editor should know -- and every good publisher should acknowledge -- that the only important measure of a magazine comes from asking one question over and over: What are we doing for our readers?" Mr. Brack said. **********"No successful magazine was ever created just for the sake of an advertiser," he said. "Readers are the masters we serve."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/17/busin.main_headline: Merck Posts 18% Higher Profit for Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/17/busin.print_headline: Merck Posts 18% Higher Profit for Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/17/busin.body_text: **********In the latest in a string of strong quarterly results in the pharmaceutical industry, Merck & Company, the world's largest drug maker, said yesterday that profits rose 18.8 percent. **********Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, Merck's chairman, said the third-quarter earnings growth came from strong gains in unit sales of high-profit drugs, continued cost controls, productivity improvements and a lower tax rate. The company recorded sizable gains, for instance, in unit sales of its cholesterol-lowering drug Mevacor and of Vasotec, a treatment for high blood pressure and congestive heart failure. **********Earnings totaled $552.4 million in the three months ended Sept. 30, up from $465 million a year earlier. Earnings per share were $1.43, compared with $1.19 in the 1990 period. Sales rose 11 percent, to $2.12 billion. **********Security analysts said Merck's results usually had a spillover effect, encouraging investor interest in other drug stocks. "If big brother is doing well, it creates an updraft that takes the others with it," said David F. Saks at Wedbush Morgan Securities. **********Analysts recalled that Dr. Vagelos had warned early last year that Merck should not be expected to maintain the 25 percent earnings growth it had achieved in earlier years. "They tried to warn people that growth might not be terrific, but they are still delivering," Mr. Saks said. **********Added Mariola Haggar, at Kemper Securities, "They still have tremendous momentum." **********Ronald Nordmann at Paine Webber Securities said Merck's profits had been up by at least 18 percent in every quarter since the last three months of 1989. In the latest quarter, he added, pretax profit margins increased to 38.2 percent from 36.1 percent in last year's period. The tax rate was 31.8 percent, down from 32.7 percent. Impact of Strong Dollar **********Dr. Vagelos said that 45 percent of sales were outside the United States. The relative strength of the dollar in foreign exchange reduced sales by a percentage point. The negative effect of currency exchange on sales "will worsen if the dollar remains where it is right now," Mr. Nordmann said. **********Sales of Merck's leading products continued to grow. Mr. Nordmann said that Mevacor was up 35 percent in the quarter and was projected to reach sales of $1.1 billion this year. Vasotec was up 12 percent and "should be $1.8 billion" in 1991, he added. **********Other products showing strong gains included the anti-ulcer drug Pepcid, up 16 percent; the antibiotic Primaxin, up 25 percent, and Zocor, also a cholesterol-lowering drug, up 21 percent. **********Analysts said that each of these products would have sales this year between $400 million and $625 million. They said ivermectin, Merck's best-selling anti-parasite drug for animals, would reach $590 million. **********Zocor was approved for registration this month in Japan. It was recommended for approval by the Federal Food and Drug Administration by an F.D.A. advisory committee earlier this year. **********Merck shares were unchanged yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $130.75 each.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Press and U.S. Officials at Odds on News Curbs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Press; Press and U.S. Officials at Odds on News Curbs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/20/world.body_text: **********Three days into the fighting, the United States Government continues to exercise tight control over news of the war, withholding information about the extent of the bombing and the destruction in Iraq and restricting interviews with troops and returning pilots. **********At the same time, journalists, particularly on television, have periodically failed to distinguish fact from rumor, and the public has received false and misleading reports. **********As a consequence, editors and news executives on one hand and military and political officials on the other are uneasy about the war coverage so far. **********The journalists feel they and by extension their readers and viewers do not have the information they need to assess how the war is going, information that reporters and editors believe could be provided without compromising security. **********The officials believe that the unreliable information that has occasionally been broadcast is evidence journalists cannot be trusted. "I spend more time putting out fires than dealing with real information," said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. Vietnam Deception Recalled **********Both sides of this controversy concede that they are fighting the last war, the one in Vietnam. **********Journalists now mistrust the Government and especially the military in large part because of their experience of having been deceived in Vietnam, where officials consistently painted a much rosier picture of the war than turned out to be justified. "Given the record of significant deception, reporters and the American people are entitled to skepticism," said Marvin Kalb, a veteran television correspondent who is now director of the Shorenstein Barone Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University. **********Similarly, the view prevails within the military that the free rein journalists had in Vietnam led to reporting that seriously damaged morale and turned the country against its own troops. **********There is general agreement on two other points growing out of the Vietnam experience. **********The first is that if the press had more access to unfavorable information -- evidence, say, that equipment was malfunctioning or that a particular tactic had gone awry -- the journalists would focus on it. It is in the nature of journalism that bad news tends to be overemphasized and good news underplayed. **********The second point growing out of Vietnam is that if the public knew how gruesome the fighting was, more people would turn against the war. There is even a suspicion among journalists here that the Government wants to keep news of the damage and casualties in Iraq to a minimum to keep Arab allies from turning against the United States out of horror. On the Military's Side **********If members of Congress reflect public opinion on the question whether the Government is controlling the news too tightly, then the public, at least at the outset of the war, is clearly on the side of the military. **********At a briefing for lawmakers on Thursday evening, Representative Mary Rose Oakar, an Ohio Democrat, complained to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney about the degree of control. Her question was greeted with a chorus of groans from colleagues of both parties, and Mr. Cheney brushed off the question by saying he saw no problem. **********"Not everybody was against me, but most of them certainly were," Ms. Oakar said later. **********The main complaint from editors is that by selectively releasing information, the Government has prevented reporting of the scale of the military operation in Iraq and Kuwait. **********"We are not getting any information that really fully and properly describes the magnitude," said Max Frankel, executive editor of The New York Times. "We don't know how many are participating, how much ordnance is being dropped. It's hard to remember this is a nonstop, massive operation, the likes of which we may not have seen before." **********Other editors agreed and said they could not understand why, after the fact, the Government could not describe the extent of destruction or provide some word about casualties from a night of bombing in Baghdad or of carpet bombing by B-52's in Kuwait. **********"I can appreciate the national security concerns," said David Gergen, editor at large of U.S. News & World Report, who was director of the White House office of communications in the Ford and Reagan Administrations. "But it appears to me," Mr. Gergen added, "that there is too strong a tendency to lean toward less coverage the better." **********The Government's view, shared by many military experts, is that journalists do not understand the extent to which certain details could be helpful to the enemy and even endanger the lives of American pilots. At a Pentagon briefing for reporters Friday afternoon, Lieut. Gen. Thomas Kelly declined, for instance, to say what percentage of Iraqi planes had been knocked out of action. "If I were in Iraq, I would want to know the answer to that question," he said. Reports Prove Wrong **********The main concern of Government officials is the misinformation that has found its way regularly onto the air. **********Then, on Thursday night, most if not all of the networks reported that Israel had launched a counterattack on Iraq. And after the second attack on Israel this morning, CBS News reported unequivocally that four missiles had struck Tel Aviv and 11 had hit Jerusalem. All those reports turned out to be wrong. **********"There has been a lot of speculative reporting, and it complicates things a little bit," Maj. Gen. Robert Johnston of the Marines told reporters at a briefing in Saudia Arabia today. **********Television editors say that the unavoidable problem with live coverage is that viewers get to observe the gathering, checking and processing of news rather than the final product they are used to seeing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.body_text: **********An influential German trade group has predicted that the nation's trade surplus, one of the main engines of the economic growth of the 1980's, would be cut in half in 1991. **********The German Federation of Chambers of Commerce also said this week that Germany's current-account balance of payments would be roughly in balance after swinging into a deficit at the start of the year. **********The group's managing director, Franz Schoser, said exports would rise by 2 to 3 percent this year. Imports, bolstered by good economic growth in western Germany and strong consumer demand in the east, would jump by 10 percent, he added. **********Germany's trade account moved into a deficit for the first time in 10 years in April. **********The trade surplus in the first four months of 1991 fell to 5.4 billion marks, or $3 billion, from 44.5 billion marks, or $24.6 billion, for West Germany in the similar period last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/busin.body_text: **********The Data General Corporation yesterday reported a profit of $18.4 million, or 50 cents a share, for its fourth fiscal quarter, ended Sept. 30, against a loss of $89.3 million in the 1990 quarter. **********The computer maker, based in Westboro, Mass., continued to buck the industry trend by turning in its fourth consecutive profitable quarter and its first full year of profit since 1985. **********Revenues for the company's fourth quarter were $295.6 million, down from $308.5 million a year ago. The loss in the 1990 quarter included a restructuring charge of $71.7 million. **********For the year, net income was $85.6 million, or $2.45 a share, compared with a loss of $139.8 million last year. Income this year included a one-time gain of $13 million from a previously announced sale of Nippon Data General, its Japanese subsidiary. **********Ronald L. Skates, president and chief executive, attributed the company's turnaround to the ability to get costs under control and the success of its Aviion work station line. Mr. Skates said that the Aviion computers, which store and distribute data to networks of personal computers, have grown into a $200 million business for Data General in just two years. **********Barry Bosak, an analyst with Smith Barney, said Data General's performance was impressive in light of the current economy. He said weakness because of competition from companies like the Digital Equipment Corporation in Europe hurt Data General in the fourth quarter but he predicted similar results for the first fiscal quarter of 1992.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/busin.body_text: **********BEFORE looking at policy illustrations, it makes sense to compile a list of companies you might want to do business with. Good financial planners are beginning to shop from a short list of insurers that meet specific criteria. **********For example, Andrew Wray, a planner in Memphis, looks for an insurer that has been rated A+ for the past 10 years by A. M. Best & Company in Oldwick, N.J., the only agency that has been rating insurers at least that long. The insurer also must be rated at least AA by one of the other three leading ratings agencies: Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Services in New York and Duff & Phelps in Chicago. Mr. Wray rules out any insurer that has a rating below a "contingent A" by Best, an AA- by S.& P. or Duff & Phelps or an Aa3 by Moody's. Ratings from these companies are available by calling the company and asking for the ratings desk. **********It is also important to know how the insurer has treated existing policyholders. Some apply the same interest rate across the board, adjusting older policies to reflect the company's more recent experience. **********But others sort policyholders into groups, marketing new products with competitive rates but leaving existing policyholders with lower rates. "You want to know how fairly they treated old policyholders in the past," said Harold Evensky, a Miami planner.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/world.body_text: **********This isolated mountain village was asleep the other day when about 80 rearmed veterans of the contra rebellion attacked the local police station in a six-hour battle that grew out of growing tension between the former rebels and their old foes, the Sandinistas. **********A day later, the village's muddy streets were filled with more than 200 reinforcements from the police and army, which are still controlled by the Sandinista Front despite the party's ouster from power in national elections last year. As the reinforcements searched houses for suspected collaborators, people began to feel the enormity of the most significant action since some of the contras, who laid down their arms after the new center-right President, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, came to power, began rearming early this year. **********"I don't know what Dona Violeta is going to do with two armies," said Donaldo Moreno Ceas. Surrounded by a group of friends gathered in a general store, he said that he was not home when the police came looking for him the night before and that the "only crime of those being arrested is that we are not Sandinistas." **********Sitting in the bullet-scarred city hall, next door to the police station, Mayor Carlos Altamirano did not try to conceal his sympathies with the leader of the attackers, a man known as Comandante Indomable. **********"Indomable had demanded a dialogue with the Government," said the Mayor, a skinny 29-year-old man in jeans and cowboy boots. "I tried to mediate, but the Government didn't respond. Every day we kept hearing of an imminent attack. Then it came." **********At least two men died -- one on each side, according to the Mayor -- and several were wounded before the attackers withdrew. Other accounts put the number of dead as high as four. Mr. Altamirano said Comandante Indomable, whose real name is Jose Angel Moran Flores, was in hiding about 12 miles outside Quilali. **********Like other rearmed contras here in the department of Nueva Segovia and elsewhere across northwestern Nicaragua, Comandante Indomable demanded that Mrs. Chamorro dismiss Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, the Sandinista who was allowed to continue as army chief despite the front's election defeat. **********He also demanded the breakup of the army, a general purging of former members of the state security force from police ranks, and a new police chief here. Further, he demanded that Mrs. Chamorro dismiss her chief minister, Antonio Lacayo, who is also her son-in-law. **********Keeping General Ortega, as well as the entire Sandinista command structure of the army and the police, was the trade-off Mrs. Chamorro made to be certain the Sandinista Front would peacefully turn over power. **********Shortly after she took office, more than 20,000 contras turned in or hid their weapons, ending a decade of war between them and the Sandinista Government. The Chamorro Government promised the contras personal security and help in returning to farming on their own or new land. **********But there are mounting claims from former contras and their families of abuses at the hands of the police. Dozens of killings have been confirmed -- some people who follow the situation closely say more than 200 have died -- and former rebels regularly complain of threats from the police or armed civilian supporters of the Sandinistas. **********Killings of Sandinistas by former contras appear to be far less numerous. **********General Ortega says more than 1,000 former rebels have taken up arms again. Most Nicaraguans call them "re-contras."  Explosive Situation Seen **********Santiago Murray, an official of the Organization of American States, who directs the demobilization and assistance program for former contras, estimated the number of rearmed men at closer to 500. **********Supporters of the "re-contras" say the decisions by individual men to take up arms again have often come after relatives or former comrades in arms were killed or assaulted. **********People in Quilali said Comandante Indomable's return to arms about six weeks ago came after an attack on his farm in which his wife was fatally wounded. Later, just before the attack on the police station, a former contra was shot and wounded by the police at a party in Quilali, and another was killed as he rode on a bus near here.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The General; Briefing by Powell: A Data-Filled Showcase
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The General; Briefing by Powell: A Data-Filled Showcase
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/world.body_text: **********In a nationally broadcast report on the Persian Gulf war today at the Pentagon, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, showcased himself in a new role, that of an articulate and persuasive spokesman for Bush Administration policy. **********"The comments I heard are that he had the press eating out of his hand," said a Government official who is regularly briefed by General Powell. "Whether that's good or bad, I don't know." **********General Powell's forum was a news conference prompted in part by complaints that the Pentagon has cloaked its strategy and basic facts of the conflict in needless secrecy. **********His answer was to take the offensive, using his command of the facts and forceful language seldom heard in the acronym-dependent military bureaucracy. 'Deaden the Nerve Endings' **********Summarizing elaborate plans to soften the Iraqi Army for a later attack by bombing its logistics and communications lines, General Powell said simply: "Our strategy to go after this army is very, very simple. First, we're going to cut it off, and then we're going to kill it." **********He then described plans to hit the army's "brains" -- its command-and-control centers -- and to "deaden the nerve endings" leading to commanders inside Kuwait. **********Later, he imposed a dramatic end on a debate, set off by conflicting statements by officials in Saudi Arabia and Washington, over whether allied forces truly rule the skies. **********"We can debate whether it's air superiority as defined by an American doctrine or air supremacy, as some of my British colleagues have alluded, or local air superiority, as some of my friends in Riyadh say," he said. "I used to teach the subject. I own the J.C.S. publication that has the definition in it, which I helped write when I was a captain. And I can assure you that this qualifies for the definition of air superiority." **********He similarly rejected Iraq's assertions, bolstered by a television report, that American jets had bombed a baby-formula factory in Baghdad. **********"It is not an infant-formula factory, no more than the Rabta chemical plant in Libya made aspirin," he said. "It was a biological weapons facility. Of that we are sure, and we have taken it out."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/busin.body_text: **********A Federal appellate court said today that the Food and Drug Administration was taking too long to act on applications to sell new generic drugs. The court, however, refused to order the agency to work faster. **********"Congress sought to get generic drugs into the hands of patients at reasonable prices -- fast," the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit said in ruling on a suit by Barr Laboratories. "The record before us reflects a defeat of those hopes." **********Barr, based in Pomona, N.Y., contended the F.D.A. was taking an average 336 days to process past generic drug applications and asked the court to direct the agency to give 23 of its pending application a high priority. The F.D.A. acknowledged that it was taking an average 262 days, with some cases taking as long as 669 days, the court said. **********Federal law allows generic drug producers to use an expedited process to get approval. The law sets a 180-day deadline for the F.D.A. to act on the applications. **********While the court rejected the F.D.A.'s argument that the deadline was only a guideline, the judges refused to order the agency to act faster on Barr's applications, saying that would simply move "all others back one space and produces no net gain."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.body_text: **********State business leaders and bank analysts believe this week's takeover by Federal regulators of Connecticut Bank and Trust, a subsidiary of the insolvent Bank of New England Corporation, could help Connecticut's economy if the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits, manages to sell the bank to a strong institution within a few weeks. **********A new owner might loosen commercial credit, helping to slow the state's downward economic spiral. Connecticut Bank and Trust, one of the state's largest lenders, had curtailed lending over the last year. **********"The action of the F.D.I.C. has helped clean up the situation to the extent that there will be a buyer, and that it will provide a little bit more lending capability," said Edward J. Deak, an economics professor at Fairfield University in Fairfield, Conn., and the Connecticut analyst for the New England Economic Project, a nonprofit forecasting group. Calling In Loans **********But Peter M. Gioia, director of research for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, a trade organization based in Hartford, said that if the 135-branch New Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, as the bank was renamed by the F.D.I.C. on Sunday, remained unsold, the bank might have to call in loans to cover nonperforming assets, particularly real estate. "You now have a major New England bank that is not making any more loans," he said. **********The bank lends to many of the companies based in the state, many of which say they will keep their accounts with the bank. As of Sept. 30, Connecticut Bank and Trust's loan portfolio was 28 percent commercial and industrial, 7 percent consumer, and 59 percent real estate and construction. The remaining 6 percent was made up of lending to the state and local municipalities and miscellaneous loans. **********Since 1989, four other Connecticut banks and savings institutions have been taken over by other financial institutions in the state after becoming insolvent. They were National Industrial Bank of Meriden, Columbia Federal Savings Bank of Westport, Brooklyn Savings Bank of Brooklyn, Conn., and Community Federal Savings and Loan of Bridgeport. **********Two other institutions -- the Charter Federal Savings and Loan of Stamford and Financial Federal Savings Bank of Hartford -- have been taken over by the Federal Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency in charge of the Government savings and loan bailout.  'A New England Problem' **********"It is statewide; it is probably a New England problem," said Mr. Gioia, also citing the closing of 45 banks and credit unions in Rhode Island last week. "It is happening in New Hampshire; it is happening in New Haven." **********Although small and minority-owned businesses have apparently been especially hard hit by the credit squeeze, Diane Goodman, chairman of the business council of the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce, said the takeover of Connecticut Bank and Trust probably would not have a dramatic effect on most small businesses. "Small businesses go to small banks," she said. **********The bank's larger commercial customers -- Connecticut-based companies like United Technologies, Ames Department Stores, Heublein Inc., Dairy Mart Convenience Stores and Cigna -- appear content to keep their funds at the bank, while the Government searches for a new owner. **********"We are definitely optimistic," said Frank Colaccino, president of Dairy Mart, a chain of 1,200 stores based in Enfield, Conn., which plans to keep its commercial accounts with Connecticut Bank and Trust despite the Government takeover. **********He said he was pleased with the F.D.I.C. guarantee of deposits of more than $100,000 and by the decision to leave the management of the 4,200-employee subsidiary in place. "From what I understand, C.B.T. was one of the stronger parts of the Bank of New England." he said.  Local Officials Optimistic **********Many municipal officials were also optimistic about the takeover. On Monday, the City of Hartford postponed a decision made on Friday to transfer $2 million to another bank. **********And Tuesday, the State Commissioner of Banking, Howard B. Brown, rescinded a Jan. 4 order that gave the city 30 days to remove its transaction accounts from the bank. **********The order had been issued because the bank fell below the requirement in a state law that says it must keep at least 3 percent of its assets in cash. A spokesman for the State Department of Banking, Dave Tedeschi, said today that the infusion of F.D.I.C. funds over the weekend gave New Connecticut Bank and Trust an equity-capital ratio that exceeded that level.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Hunt Transport At a Crossroads
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Hunt Transport At a Crossroads
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.body_text: **********FOR most of the last 10 years, J. B. Hunt Transport Services Inc. has thrived under the freedoms brought by the deregulation of the trucking industry in 1980. **********A nonunion carrier, it benefited from lower costs, an absence of union work rules, and an aggressive management that knew how to exploit the opportunities created when hundreds of older unionized companies failed. Hunt, based in Lowell, Ark., saw its revenues grow to $579 million in 1990 from less than $100 million in the early 1980's. Hunt is the second-largest full-truck-load long-haul carrier, behind Schneider National Inc. of Green Bay, Wis. **********The company became a favorite of investors and analysts, whose reports helped push the price of the stock up to $33 a share in 1987, from an average in the low teens in 1985. It closed at $19.75 yesterday in over-the-counter trading. **********In recent years, Hunt has sustained growth of about 15 percent a year, but it expects to find it more difficult now to meet that target. **********When it faced a severe shortage of drivers, the company parked many trucks and then raised its pay rate to 33 cents a mile last year, from 25 cents a mile in 1987. The raises brought a flood of applicants, from which Hunt was able to pick the best, but its cost advantage over union carriers and other nonunion carriers has lessened. **********At the same time, its customers, like Ford Motor and Reynolds Metals, have become tougher. They are resisting rate increases and demanding better on-time service, particularly customers that are running their plants on just-in-time inventory deliveries. The recession has also caused many customers to take a sharper look at their haulers. **********"They just had open-ended growth opportunities," said Paul R. Schlesinger, the trucking analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. "As they could add equipment, they could fill it at decent rates." **********But competitors were also adding equipment, which put pressure on prices, making it difficult for truckers to make price increases stick, despite rising labor and fuel costs. **********Hunt's operating costs soared from 77 percent of total revenue in 1986 to 90.2 percent in 1990. At the same time, freight rates were steady until last year, when the industry was able to push through a 3 percent rise. "They're at the crossroads," Mr. Schlesinger said. "They've discovered that the growth that they had been counting on will not do the job." **********As a result, the management has entered new areas of trucking where Hunt has not shown the expertise it demonstrated in the long-haul, full-truckload market. **********Last year the carrier made its first acquisition of a company since 1978. It bought Bulldog Trucking, a short-haul trucking company in the Southeast, based in Carnesville, Ga., to spearhead its drive into the short-haul market. **********From 50 to 70 percent of freight is considered short-haul, thus providing a huge market for growth. Hunt is betting that its large size and reputation will enable it to gain market share quickly in a segment that is dominated by small trucking companies. **********Hunt also plans to build up its flatbed business, through which it hauls mostly building materials, another highly decentralized business dominated by owner-operators or small companies. **********Also, instead of competing in major corridors with railroads, which have made big improvements in the cost of hauling truck containers, Hunt has formed a partnership with the Santa Fe Railway for some of its long-haul business. **********Kirk Thompson, president and chief executive of Hunt, said that about one-third of Hunt's business was for hauls of less than 500 miles. "This is not anything particularly new to us," he added. **********He said Hunt had been able to persuade some of its Fortune 500 customers, who use it for long hauls, to turn over their short-haul freight to the company, because many prefer limiting the number of vendors they use. **********He contended that with its investments in trucks and terminals and with a reputation on which it could now cash in, the company would not have trouble growing in the 90's. **********"We took the risk and availed ourselves of the opportunities in the 1980's," he said, "and now we have new opportunity in the 1990's." He added that the industry was resistant to economic slowdowns, commenting, "You can live without frozen yogurt, but you can't live without transportation." **********Some analysts suggest that Hunt may even benefit from the recession, because it could lead to the failure of more carriers, giving the stronger companies an opportunity to pick up more customers. **********Mr. Thompson also argues that the larger companies have built up such an advantage over smaller truckers that it would be hard to catch up with the efficiencies that a large carrier has.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/20/world.main_headline: CAMBODIAN TREATY TO BE SIGNED SOON
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/20/world.print_headline: CAMBODIAN TREATY TO BE SIGNED SOON
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/20/world.body_text: **********After tortuous negotiations, Cambodia's four warring factions have at last agreed to sign a peace accord here on Wednesday to end their 13-year conflict and prepare the devastated nation for free elections. **********The agreement will require the United Nations to play perhaps its biggest peacekeeping role ever, with thousands of foreign soldiers and civilians due to assume responsibility for monitoring a cease-fire, disarming combatants, organizing elections and insuring that they are fair. **********Indeed, more than in any other country where the United Nations has tried to settle a bitter internal conflict with foreign ramifications, the organization will effectively co-govern Cambodia, sharing power with a coalition of the four factions until a new government is elected.  A Result of Cold War's End **********The accord is seen as a another fruit of closer cooperation between Washington and Moscow and other changes in the international climate that have already resulted in solutions, or progress towards settlement, of disputes in Namibia, Angola, Afghanistan and El Salvador. **********In this case, the United States, the Soviet Union and China all played a pivotal role by supervising negotiations and nudging their respective political clients in Cambodia to accept the risks of democracy over continuation of a war that none seemed likely to win. **********But the deep distrust dividing the Phnom Penh Government and its three guerrilla enemies was still evident even as delegates from 19 countries gathered here for a conference on Cambodia that is to begin on Monday and culminate with the expected signature of the peace accord on Wednesday. **********At a meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Bangkok this week, members of a combined Cambodian delegation exchanged insults. Khmer Rouge guerrillas were also accused of trying to push more than 40,000 refugees from camps in Thailand into areas under their control. **********Recalling that the last major peace conference on Cambodia in Paris broke up in disarray two years ago, Western officials involved in the new negotiations have cautioned against excessive optimism. Crucial Role of the U.N. **********And it is for this reason, they said, that the role of the United Nations is crucial, even though it may cost the organization as much as $2 billion during the estimated 18 to 21 months before elections are held, a new constitution is written and a legitimate government is appointed. **********Yet if peace finally comes to Cambodia, it will bring its eight million people their first respite since the nation was drawn into the Vietnam War in 1970, when American and South Vietnamese troops invaded its territory to combat Vietcong and Khmer Rouge rebels. **********In April 1975, the Khmer Rouge, led by Pol Pot, seized Phnom Penh, beginning a reign of terror that left more than one million people dead before it was driven from power in late 1978 by Vietnam, which installed a new Government, led by Heng Samrin, in January 1979. **********Since then, backed and armed by China, the Khmer Rouge has continued to control territory in western Cambodia and has maintained its warfare against the Phnom Penh Government. **********Two other rebel groups appeared, one headed by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who was ousted as head of state in 1970, and the other, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, led by a former Prime Minister, Son Sann, who was backed by the United States.  A Divided Coalition **********Although the three opposition forces formed a loose coalition, it was always deeply divided, with followers of Prince Sihanouk and Mr. Son Sann almost as eager to prevent the Khmer Rouge from returning to power as they were to oust the Government in Phnom Penh. **********On Thursday, in preparation for the future elections, Mr. Heng Samrin's party dropped its commitment to Communism, accepted political pluralism and free-market economics and changed its name. **********Under the peace agreement, which is to go into effect as soon as it is signed on Wednesday, the 12-member Supreme National Council, formed from the four factions and led by Prince Sihanouk, will assume the powers of government. But it will also surrender enormous power to what will be known as the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia, or Untac. **********This week, the Security Council approved the dispatch of the first peacekeeping unit to Cambodia, comprising 268 military officers and civilians under the command of a French officer, Brig. Gen. Jean-Michel Loridon. It will be in charge of monitoring the initial cease-fire and recommending the size of the main United Nations contingent. **********Some estimates have put the eventual United Nations presence as high as 20,000 soldiers and civilian administrators. **********Before the United Nations can begin preparing for elections by organizing voter registration and drawing up an electoral code, it faces the intimidating task of securing a cease-fire, insuring the withdrawal of the remaining Vietnamese troops, gathering the warring armies in designated areas and taking charge of their weapons. **********The United Nations will also assume responsibility for assisting the return to Cambodia of some 350,000 refugees living in camps across the border in Thailand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/08/world.main_headline: AFTER THE WAR: The Overview; Red Cross Says Iraqis Will Release Journalists
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/08/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: The Overview; Red Cross Says Iraqis Will Release Journalists
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/08/world.body_text: **********Officials of the Red Cross said Thursday that most of the roughly three dozen journalists who disappeared earlier this week while traveling toward Basra in southeastern Iraq to cover civil unrest there would be released by the Iraqis in the next few days. **********The officials said the journalists would be turned over with Kuwaiti civilians who had been abducted by the Iraqis at the beginning or the end of the Persian Gulf war. But there was no sign of them in the 17 vehicles laden with exuberant Kuwaiti detainees that passed shortly before midnight through the border town of Safwan, where peace talks were held last weekend. **********There was no confirmation of the planned release from Baghdad, from Western governments or from Red Cross headquarters in Geneva.  American Troops Jubilant **********Earlier, American soldiers were as jubilant as the Kuwaitis as they waited in the desert for their flights home, many still carrying their rifles. They flashed the inevitable V-for-victory signs and talked of wives, husbands, children, parents, pizza, soda pop, beer, showers and soft beds -- the things they lacked for seven months while training, waiting and fighting. **********Among the first to go were troops belonging to the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, who headed for Fort Stewart, Ga., after a stop in Germany. Also included in the initial homeward-bound contingent were members of the 82d Airborne Division from Fayetteville, N.C., and First Tactical Fighter Wing from Langley Air Force Base, Va., and Marine Corps and Navy personnel. **********United States and Iraqi officials held two important meetings Thursday, one scheduled, one impromptu.  Prisoners and Missing Discussed **********At an air base near Riyadh, the Saudi capital, the International Committee of the Red Cross presided over a six-hour discussion of unfinished business in the aftermath of the seven-week war, including the repatriation of the 63,000 Iraqi prisoners the allies say they hold, accounting for missing American servicemen and women, and the return of civilian detainees. **********In a statement issued here early today, the United States military command said the chief Iraqi spokesman at the meeting contended that the missing journalists had "entered Iraq illegally," The Associated Press reported. But the spokesman, Dr. Akram al-Witry, also said the Iraqi Government was "now engaged in a search for the missing journalists to insure they are safe," the statement quoted by the news agency said. **********The six participating nations -- the United States, Britain, France, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Iraq -- signed a "memorandum of understanding," the Red Cross said, agreeing to expedite the repatriation of prisoners of war held by the allies and civilian internees held by the Iraqis. It made no specific reference to the number of Kuwaitis held or to the journalists. **********The American command's statement early today said the mass repatriation of Iraqis would begin on Monday, with "several hundred" prisoners returning from holding camps in Saudi Arabia each day. **********Iraq says it has already released all of the allied prisoners it held. The Pentagon said Thursday that 24 Americans were now listed as missing in action, including the 14 crewmen of an AC-130 gunship that went down over the Bay of Kuwait. Navy divers are trying to recover their bodies. **********Earlier Thursday, two Iraqi lieutenant colonels and four soldiers arrived at First Infantry Division headquarters near Safwan and asked to talk to the Red Cross about the organization's representatives coming to Basra to pick up the Kuwaiti detainees and foreign journalists.  Offer to Free Journalists **********Thomas Pizer, a Red Cross official, said at Safwan that the Iraqis were prepared to hand over 21 journalists, whose names and nationalities were not given. Gian Battista Beccheta, another Red Cross official, who spoke with reporters in Kuwait City, put the number to be released at 29. **********Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, said the best count available to American authorities was 38 journalists missing behind Iraqi lines. They represent news organizations in the United States, France, Britain, Norway, Italy and Brazil. **********Ten Americans, including Chris Hedges of The New York Times, are on that list. Two other journalists who had been on the list, Chris Everson and Tim Dickey of CBS News, turned up at the 24th Division, in good shape after spending several days in the custody of Iraqi troops, Mr. Williams said. **********According to an Iraqi opposition leader, the journalists were detained to prevent them photographing or writing about civil unrest in Basra.  U.S. Holds Iraq Responsible **********In Washington, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said that the United States would hold Iraq responible for the journalists' safety. But he added, despite the Red Cross officials' statements, "Unfortunately, it may not be that Iraq has them."
