https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/29/world.main_headline: Human Tides: The Influx in Europe - A special report.; Europeans Look for Ways To Bar Door to Immigrants
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/29/world.print_headline: Human Tides: The Influx in Europe - A special report.; Europeans Look for Ways To Bar Door to Immigrants
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/29/world.body_text: **********The "fortress Europe" that Americans, Japanese and other outsiders fear when the European Community finally becomes a tariff-free, continent-wide market at the end of next year is already being built. But its walls are intended to keep out people, not commodities. **********A flood of people fleeing poverty and political unrest in parts of Eastern Europe, in Africa and in South Asia has combined with years of high unemployment in Europe to inflame social and political tensions not only in European Community countries but in Austria and Switzerland as well. **********A total of 500,000 people applied for asylum in Western Europe as a whole last year, according to the British Home Secretary, Kenneth Baker. And as unemployment levels have risen in every major European economy this year, popular resentment at the influx has nurtured right-wing political movements in Belgium, Switzerland, France and Germany, among others. Heaviest Influx in Germany **********Time-consuming asylum procedures, including an obligation to house and feed applicants while their cases are being decided, are also imposing a drain on governments already hard pressed to meet welfare demands, and raising questions about how European countries that have never thought of themselves as ethnic melting pots can preserve their national identities. **********The influx has been heaviest in Germany, which because of its past is the European country most inhibited from just sending the refugees packing. As the richest European nation and with a population just over 79 million, it already has its hands full coping with the estimated 2.5 million ethnic Germans from Eastern Europe who have taken up citizenship over the last three years, a right the 1949 Constitution automatically guaranteed to Germans everywhere. **********While 500,000 applications for asylum does not seem a lot in a continent of more than 300 million people, there are hundreds of thousands more illegal immigrants in most of the principal countries. Until 1985, the number of applications for asylum in Europe and North America combined had never exceeded 250,000. **********Not since the collapse of colonialism after World War II have the countries of Europe faced influxes of people on such a scale. Then, the immigration of hundreds of thousands of Indians and Pakistanis helped change the face of Britain, as the flow of North and Central Africans changed the faces of France and Belgium. **********Now the process is repeating itself in countries that had no overseas empires, challenging Germans, for instance, to re-examine their long-held aversion to immigration by other ethnic groups. While the Europeans are only groping for answers, they seem more intent this time on keeping as many of these people out as they can, if only they can find a way. **********Last summer, Italy sent entire boatloads of would-be asylum-seekers from Albania back across the Adriatic Sea, much as the United States has been barring Haitians from coming across the Caribbean. Spian  Public Attitudes Largely Tolerant **********European approaches to the problem vary greatly from country to country. In Spain, which has tolerated large-scale illegal immigration from Morocco for years, public attitudes so far are relatively tolerant. **********Abdalia Aziz Dukuly, a 27-year-old refugee from the civil war in Liberia, discovered that life in Spain would not be easy after he arrived in the Canary Islands on a freighter from Mauretania on Oct. 29. "I lost my family, so I had nothing to lose," he said one recent morning at the Spanish Red Cross headquarters in Madrid, waiting in a corridor with a score of other refugees, most of them new arrivals from Africa. **********"My mother was killed in the fighting," he said, "and I made up my mind to come and hide in Europe. They told me in Las Palmas that Spain couldn't accept me unless I went to the capital, so here I am." **********It is not easy to establish grounds to stay in any European country as a refugee. Under the terms of the 1951 United Nations Convention that all European Community countries, as well as the United States, are pledged to observe, asylum can be granted only to someone who can prove a "well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion." **********Only seven percent of applications for refugee or asylum status in Spain are approved, a figure roughly typical for the whole of the European Community, and for a basic reason: Most "refugees" coming to Europe actually want to build a better life for themselves, either here or, eventually, back home, and perhaps therefore are better described as immigrants. **********Since few European countries permit much immigration at all, the only way to get a foot in the door is to sneak into countries like Spain, which until recently did not even require visas of people coming over from Morocco, or to fly into an airport and ask for asylum, then taking advantage of the time it takes to determine qualification to settle down and take root anyway. **********But gradually, the new arrivals are beginning to change the face of the country in unexpected ways, even in Spain, where the numbers -- about 5,000 a year -- are relatively small in a total population of more than 39 million. A surprising number of Spaniards had never laid eyes on a black person before Africans began arriving, for instance. **********"King Balthazar was the only black most people here had ever been familiar with," said Felix Barrena, director of the Spanish Red Cross Center for Assistance to Foreigners, referring to one of the Three Magi. **********Referring to the difficulties asylum-seekers have in being integrated in Spanish society, he said: "It's a social problem, not a racial problem, in my experience. People see refugees sleeping in the parks, and last summer some of them were caught selling drugs on the Plaza de Espana, and they make stereotypical judgments." **********So far Spain has been spared the kind of organized campaigns against foreigners that have seen gangs of skinheads demonstrate against and attack Vietnamese and other refugees in some of the hardest-hit industrial towns in eastern Germany, where unemployment after the collapse of the Communist economy has soared to around 50 percent of the work force. Germany  Both Acceptance And Resistance **********The integration of foreigners, whether they are immigrants or refugees, has come a long way in Germany, which has had substantial populations of Yugoslavs, Turks and Italians since the 1960's, when they were invited in as "guest workers." **********In Berlin, for example, 312,374 foreigners now make up 11 percent of the population, and 136,302 of them are Turks. In 1960, there were only 22,065 non-German people in the city. **********The civil war in Yugoslavia has sent more Yugoslavs fleeing into Germany in recent months, and they have displaced Romanians as the largest single group seeking asylum there. **********Many Germans have been as shocked as the rest of the world by the beatings and firebomb attacks on refugee centers. As Barbara John, the Berlin city official in charge of helping foreigners, sees it, the public image of Germany as a country where neo-Nazi thugs terrorize anybody who does not look German distorts the true picture. **********"That has happened mainly in the East, and it's a sign of the collapse of the old system and of the order that held it up," she said. **********Racism in a mostly homogeneous, white society like Germany can hide better than it does in a country like Britain or Belgium that had to accept a large number of immigrants from former colonies. **********And Mrs. John was optimistic. "We know many Germans don't object to foreigners being here," she said. Hundreds of thousands of them took to the streets in November to protest the harassment of foreigners and to demand that the authorities do more to stop it. **********The reason Germany attracts almost two-thirds of the total number of asylum-seekers in the European Community, according to many officials, is that the German Constitution gives them a better chance of getting one foot in the door. It allows anyone a chance to make a claim and obliges the state to look after them while officials painstakingly examine it. **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl tried this year to get the Constitution changed to allow a speedup in the examination procedure, which might discourage some "refugees" from coming, but he was blocked by the opposition Social Democrats. **********Failing that, he tried at the meeting of European leaders in Maastricht, the Netherlands, to get the others to agree to a common asylum and immigration policy to be decided by majority vote. Instead, they agreed to coordinate them as closely as possible by the end of 1993, in effect putting off an attempt to find a solution. **********"Politicians show a helplessness that confuses and disturbs voters," Mrs. John said. One way out, she suggested, might be for countries like Germany to give up the pretense that they do not allow immigration -- since most of the asylum seekers who stay on are not expelled even if they are rejected -- and instead to set limits on numbers of immigrants. **********With civil war in Yugoslavia and economic chaos in the territory of the old Soviet Union, German newspapers and magazines often speak of the threat of millions of refugees flooding in unless something is done to bar the door. But so far, the main group that has come are the descendants of ethnic Germans imported into Russia in the 18th century by Catherine the Great.  And according to the weekly news magazine Der Spiegel, only 50,000 non-Germans have been granted German citizenship in the last 10 years. France  New Citizens And Illegal Aliens **********In France, by contrast, the census of 1990 showed that 1.77 million people who had acquired their French citizenship were living in the country at the end of the year, representing 3.13 percent of the total population of more than 56 million. **********Estimates of the number of foreigners living illegally in France range to the hundreds of thousands. Many of them work in the construction industry in big cities like Paris, Lyon or Marseille, according to Michel Devacht, a caseworker with the French Democratic Confederation of Labor. **********"Any economist will tell you these people are necessary for the economy," Mr. Devacht said, because they do dirty or disagreeable work that French workers no longer want to do.  "But there are three million unemployed, so they are a scapegoat." **********Last month, the ultra-right National Front party of Jean-Marie Le Pen proposed an anti-immigration platform that would ship out unwanted aliens by boat, and put those awaiting expulsion into guarded camps. **********It is not competition for jobs, but skin color that often defines the true nature of the antagonism, according to many experts. **********"What worries the French is not the number of people who are legally foreigners, but the number of non-European immigrants and their children," Robert Sole wrote last month in the daily Le Monde. **********Mr. Devacht said, "Eastern Europeans are invisible." Black Africans and people from the formerly French territories of North Africa stood out and were resented, even though statistics show that the North Africans are 80 percent more likely to lose their jobs in hard times than "native" French workers are, according to Mr. Sole. Britain New Rules Due On Asylum-Seekers **********Nowhere is the racist aspect of the new European anxiety about immigrants more open than in Britain, where there were fewer than 20,000 nonwhite residents before the collapse of the empire. **********Today the nonwhite population is about 2.6 million, 4.7 percent of the population of about 56 million and more than half of them of Indian, Pakistani or Bangladeshi origin, according to official statistics, and about one-fifth of West Indian origin. Yet it is still possible for a well-dressed black man to walk into a barbershop, as one did near Victoria Station the other day, and cause all three Italian barbers to stop snipping. Asked what he wanted, the man answered, "A haircut." Apologetically but firmly, the chief barber answered, "We don't know how to cut your kind of hair." **********British immigration from former colonies has been largely stopped, and only about 50,000 people a year are accepted here for settlement every year, many of them from Canada or Australia. The thought that more are seeking entry, most of them from Asia or Africa, raises fears among some Britons that their country might soon become ethnically unrecognizable. **********Applications for asylum in Britain have risen from 5,000 in 1988 to an estimated 50,000 this year, according to Home Secretary Baker. **********The British are enacting new legislation so the authorities can determine whether asylum-seekers qualify within 90 days, instead of years as before.  Refugees would have only two days to appeal refusals, in writing, to immigration officials who could decide, without a hearing, within five days whether an "arguable" case exists. **********"I do not think the problem is a question of numbers, though numbers make it worse," wrote Charles Moore in The Spectator Magazine, known for its conservatism, earlier this fall. **********"It is a question of race," he went on. "You can be British without speaking English or being Christian or being white, but nevertheless Britain is basically English-speaking, Christian and white, and if one starts to think that it might become basically Urdu-speaking and Muslim and brown, one gets frightened and angry." **********So the reaction has led, as it has in other European countries, to pressure to crack down and keep more such people out. At the beginning of November, Britain doubled the fine on foreign airlines that fly in foreigners without proper entry documents, from $:1,000 to $:2,000, or $3,600, per person. **********The problem, as Amnesty International and other organizations that look after the rights of asylum-seekers and refugees have pointed out, is that most people who do qualify for asylum are likely as not to arrive without passports or visas because asking for them in the countries from which they fled could have been dangerous. **********Increasingly, the London-based human rights organization said in a report at the end of November, all governments in Europe, not just Britain's, are taking a restrictive approach toward asylum-seekers. And increasingly, they are playing with people's lives. **********Last March, in an example Amnesty International cited in its report, 17 Tamils from Sri Lanka, which has been torn by civil strife for the last several years, arrived at Schwechat Airport in Vienna and claimed asylum. The Austrian authorities turned them back to Rome, through which they had passed in transit on their way to Vienna, saying that because they had first arrived on Italian soil, Italy should consider their claim first. **********"In Vienna, they were held in the transit lounge and denied access to a U.N. representative," Amnesty International reported. Upon their return to Italy, they were sent back to Sri Lanka as "deportees in transit" from Austria. **********United Nations officials said later that at least some of the Tamils had presented "clear grounds for asylum" to the Austrian airport authorities, according to Amnesty. The Outlook Restrictions Seem Most Likely **********Small wonder, perhaps, that at Maastricht, the European Community countries agreed to leave asylum policies in the hands of national governments, for the most part, instead of agreeing to common policies. **********"That would have lost us our ability to control our own borders," said a British official close to Prime Minister John Major. "The long-term solution is to strengthen everybody's external frontiers." **********The outlook, as Eastern Europe and the lands of the former Soviet Union continue to be wracked by upheavals, is for a restrictive policy that, in most countries, favors whites from Eastern Europe who can speak the language of the country they seek to settle in and have, in the eyes of the authorities, a reasonable chance of economic success. **********"Either we continue with a very restrictive immigration policy," Mr. Moore wrote in The Spectator, "or we develop a more liberal one which is more 'racist.' " **********With nationalist parties feeding off the discontent with the present trend in Belgium, Germany, Austria, and France, many outsiders fear that he may be right.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/02/busin.print_headline: Rates Increase for Long-Term Debt Issues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/02/busin.body_text: **********Long-term interest rates climbed yesterday as more investors moved into issues with shorter maturities. Dealers attributed the trend to a growing belief that the end of the Persian Gulf war will hasten the end of the recession, stimulate demand for credit and lift inflationary pressures. **********Any positive economic development is considered negative news to investors in fixed-income debt issues, who fear that inflation will erode the value of their holdings. **********Consequently, prices of fixed-income securities were also depressed by a surge in the closely watched Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 basic food items and industrial materials. The index, which uses a 1967 base of 100, jumped by 2.39, to 217.94. A week ago the index had been hovering above a four-year low.   Long Bond Yield at 8.27% **********The Treasury's benchmark long-term bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, were offered late in the day at 95 19/32, down 24/32, or $7.50 for each $1,000 of face value. The long bond's yield rose to 8.27 percent, from 8.20 percent the day before and 8.06 percent a week ago. **********"The sudden surge in the C.R.B. index frightened many, because it had been cited for many months as a sign that inflation was no longer a problem," said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc. **********Mr. Ricchiuto said that despite the shift toward shorter maturities and the steepening of the yield curve between the long and short maturities, many market participants still considered the shorter Treasury issues underpriced. Indeed, he noted that Treasury bill rates were only a bit above the key Federal funds rate, which is the bedrock cost of credit. **********Despite the $2 billion of reserves that the Federal Reserve added to the banking system, there was enough demand for the funds to force the rate up to 6 3/8 percent at the close. This is 1/8 percent above the Fed's perceived target level for the funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans.   Discount Rates Rise **********Meanwhile, the discount rates on Treasury bills, which are most sensitive to changes in the funds rate, continued to rise. The 90-day bill rate rose 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.10 percent. Six-month bills also rose 5 basis points, to 6.12 percent, and one-year bills gained 6 basis points, to 6.14 percent. **********The Treasury said it planned to auction $10.75 billion of new one-year bills on Thursday. **********Among other representative Treasury issues, the 6.75 percent notes of 1993 fell 5/32, to 99 8/32, to yield 7.16 percent, and the 7.5 percent notes of 1996 dropped 10/32, to 98 29/32, and now yield 7.76 percent. **********The long notes, the 7.75 percent issue due in February 2001, tumbled 17/32, to 97 20/32, as the yield rose to 8.10 percent, from 7.89 percent a week ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/world.main_headline: Seoul Student Killed in a Clash With Police
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/world.print_headline: Seoul Student Killed in a Clash With Police
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/world.body_text: **********A student was killed today in a street battle here between the police and protesters as anti-Government violence erupted across South Korea. **********The woman, Kim Kwi Jong, a 25-year-old third-year student at Sungkyunkwan Confucian University in Seoul, was killed as police officers tear-gassed a group of protesters near the city center. **********The cause of her death was not immediately clear. Witnesses quoted in the press here said she may have been trampled as crowds fled a police charge. **********Clashes also took place in Pusan, the country's second-largest city and major port, Taegu, Ulsan and other areas as thousands of students and dissidents denounced President Roh Tae Woo. **********In the southwestern city of Kwangju, more than 50,000 mourners, chanting anti-Government slogans to the sound of traditional gongs and drums, took part in mass funeral rites for a student protest suicide.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/world.main_headline: Moscow Official Denies Soviets Need Huge Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/world.print_headline: Moscow Official Denies Soviets Need Huge Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's top economic adviser said today that the Soviet leader would not ask for hundreds of billions of dollars worth of aid when he meets in London next month with participants in the seven-nation summit conference of industrial democracies. **********The adviser, Yevgeny M. Primakov, told the newspaper Izvestia that what the Government's reform plan needed was coordinated support from the West to help make the ruble fully convertible and keep inflation down when prices are fully decontrolled. Other Soviet officials say controls are to be lifted by the end of next year. **********With a United States-Soviet summit meeting in Moscow tentatively planned to start at the end of June or early July, according to Western diplomats here, Mr. Primakov said he thought the Soviet delegation he led to Washington last week had convinced President Bush that the latest Soviet Government economic reform plan was a serious attempt to move as fast as possible to a market economy. **********In its latest form, he repeated, it laid out a schedule of privatization "by certain deadlines." 'Trickled Into the Sands' **********"Bush knows that much of what we got in the past trickled into the sands," Mr. Primakov acknowledged of Western credits in the past. "But now he has seen that the new approach is not connected with that but with coordination and synchronization of our actions." **********As a first step, Mr. Primakov said, the ruble should be made convertible with other currencies on the Soviet internal market, but to prevent its sudden collapse would require international help, in the form of a stabilization fund. A dollar on the black market here now costs 32 rubles, while some retired people receive a pension of only 79 rubles a month. **********He denied Western reports that he and other officials in Washington last week had told the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank that the Soviet economy would need $250 billion in Western aid. **********"I am convinced that these figures will not crop up from our side during the London summit," Mr. Primakov said. 'Economy of Complete Scarcity' **********Maintaining that the latest Soviet Government plan was intended to lead to the complete lifting of all price controls, Mr. Primakov said: "When price controls are lifted, they begin to rise at first. It's one thing when the market is saturated with goods, and quite another when it's an economy of complete scarcity. So here we will need support and aid from outside." **********What the Soviets will be asking for, according to Mr. Primakov and other officials, is Western commodity aid -- not just credits to buy food and other scarce consumer goods -- during the transition period, to keep prices from spiraling out of control. **********"The Soviet Union is the only large, unexploited, capacious market in the world where somehow there is already a serious industrial base," he said. "Already many are trying, even in not very good conditions, to enter this market just to be in position later." **********Legal and financial conditions that would finally encourage large-scale private investment from the West still lie in the distant future. Last week, Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov presented a draft bill on foreign investment to the standing Soviet legislature. If approved, it would allow foreign companies to buy up to 100 percent of some Soviet enterprises, but not in the military industry, and take out profits in hard currency. Talks on Arms Treaty **********The Bush-Gorbachev summit meeting is now reportedly only a few weeks away, depending on the outcome of a meeting of the American and Soviet foreign ministers in Geneva Friday on eliminating the remaining obstacles to a new treaty to reduce nuclear arms. Soviet officials say that the Moscow summit meeting will be crucial to determining the future of the American-Soviet relationship after the end of the cold war. **********"The United States should not try to humiliate us," a Communist Party adviser to Mr. Gorbachev said. "If we can't get the United States to cooperate with us on bringing us into the world economy, we'll bank on the Germans." **********German officials seem to be among the biggest supporters of grasping Mr. Gorbachev's hand firmly when he comes to London, but not necessarily with huge sums of money. **********Mr. Gorbachev came away from Japan empty-handed last month, but Mr. Primakov said he now had the feeling that only Japan among the Group of Seven at the London meeting next month had remained fundamentally skeptical about the seriousness of the Soviet reform plans. **********The Administration in Washington just hadn't understood, until last week, Mr. Primakov said. "They thought that we intended to go to a market economy by administrative methods," he told Izvestia, "but we have the kind of social psychology that means there won't be any initiatives without an order to take initiatives locally."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.main_headline: Regulators Investigate Peat On Its Auditing of S.& L.'s Regulators
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.print_headline: Regulators Investigate Peat On Its Auditing of S.& L.'s Regulators
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.body_text: **********The Office of Thrift Supervision issued subpoenas earlier this month to the accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick seeking information on all its audits of savings institutions for 1989 and 1990, the firm acknowledged yesterday. **********John Higgins, Peat's spokesman, said the firm believed that the investigation was a response to the firm's refusal to settle a case concerning the San Francisco Federal Savings and Loan Association, a subsidiary of the SFFed Corporation. In the case, regulators had challenged the propriety of roughly $900,000 in loans that Peter Meeks, the Peat partner in charge of the San Francisco Federal Savings audit, had borrowed from the institution over seven years to build a home in Portola Valley, Calif. **********Though the accounting profession has long tolerated auditors taking out certain loans, like mortgages, from institutions whose books they check, the issue has become a hot one lately because of the number of financial institutions that have failed without any warning from the independent auditors. **********In the case of San Francisco Federal, The Office of Thrift Supervision, the primary Washington regulator for savings and loan associations, contended that the loans to Mr. Meeks involved special considerations. It rejected Peat's 1990 report on the institution's financial statements on the ground the audit was tainted. **********Last month, without admitting any fault, the bank and its chief executive, Roger L. Gordon, consented to a cease-and-desist order that prevents them from making new loans to most outside professionals they hire and agreed to pay $80,000 in fines. **********Peat, in contrast, has defended the loans as complying with all applicable rules and has refused to settle. **********Still, the far-reaching investigation, which was first reported by The American Banker yesterday, took the accounting firm by surprise. Though Peat has always had one of the largest practices in the savings field, it has not been hurt nearly as much as other accounting firms in the collapse of hundreds of savings institutions. **********One of the most prominent cases involving questionable loans to auditors is being pursued by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Ernst & Young, the successor to Arthur Young. **********The investigation reportedly concerns commercial real estate loans that dozens of Arthur Young partners had with Republicbank, an audit client. Though Arthur Young gave the bank clean opinions in all the years it worked for the bank, the bank failed shortly after it merged with the Interfirst Corporation and became the Republicbank Corporation. **********The Government's inquiry into Peat, said Joseph Mauriello, national director of Peat's savings practice, is "just totally out of proportion to the narrow issue and concern they have, which is with San Francisco Fed." He called the investigation a fishing expedition. Agency Has No Comment **********Paul Lockwood, a spokesman for the Office of Thrift Supervision, said it was the agency's policy "not to comment about investigations that may or may not be under way." **********The challenge by regulators to the propriety of loans to audit partners has prompted several firms, including Peat, to re-examine their codes of conduct. **********"Clearly, that's where it's headed," said Mr. Higgins, the Peat spokesman. He added that Peat had also offered to work with savings regulators in tightening up the profession's rules. **********"They had asked us to settle," he said, "and we said: 'No, thank you. If you want to rewrite the rules, let's do it together and do it going forward.' But we don't think it's fair or appropriate for the O.T.S. to rewrite the rules retrospectively."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Apple Computer In Soviet Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/30/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer Inc. is selling its Macintosh machine with Russian-language software in the Soviet Union. Greg Borovsky, Apple's director in the Soviet Union, said the company signed a one-year contract this month to set up dealerships with Intermicro, a Soviet-Austrian venture based in Moscow. **********The first Macintosh computers using Apple's operating system will go on sale in October, Mr. Borovsky said. He declined to reveal the value of the contract. Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., said the base price for the standard Macintosh Classic would be $951, plus $92 for a Russian-language keyboard. A similar English-language computer costs $999 in the United States. The Macintosh SE will cost about $3,700.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/23/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev credited foreign radio stations such as BBC, Voice of America and Radio Liberty yesterday with keeping him informed on what was happening during the three days that he and his family were held incommunicado at his Crimean villa. **********At his news conference yesterday, he said that after all the phones in the house went dead, members of his personal staff found some radio receivers in the servants' quarters and hooked up antennas. **********"We were able to catch some broadcasts and find out what was happening," he said. "We got BBC best of all. They were the clearest signal, Radio Liberty, then Voice of America."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/30/world.main_headline: A Contrite Schwarzkopf Says He Agreed '100%'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/30/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; A Contrite Schwarzkopf Says He Agreed '100%'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/30/world.body_text: **********Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf said today that contrary to his comments in a television interview, he agreed "100 percent" with President Bush's decision to halt the Persian Gulf war. **********The general, commander of the allied forces in the gulf, apologized for his "poor choice of words" in questioning the President's judgment about calling a cease-fire. **********Mr. Bush told reporters there was "no need for any apology" as he left the White House for the weekend. "He's got my full support," the President said before boarding a helicopter for Camp David, Md. **********General Schwarzkopf told David Frost in a television interview broadcast on Wednesday night that history would second-guess Mr. Bush's decision to call a cease-fire on Feb. 27. He said the truce, which took effect the next day, had opened an escape route for retreating Iraqi forces. Healing Political Wounds **********"Why did we stop when we did when we had them completely routed?" he said in the interview. "Frankly, my recommendation had been continue the march" to "reap great destruction" on Iraq's army, he told Mr. Frost. But he added that Mr. Bush's decision to end the war had been "very humane" and "courageous." **********The general today blamed media "mudslingers" for trying to create a controversy. A popular figure whose national standing soared with the success of the allied war effort, he moved quickly to make amends and heal any political wounds. **********General Schwarzkopf has been reported to be in line for a fifth star or the job of Army Chief of Staff. He has also been mentioned as a potential political candidate. **********Concerning President Bush's calling of the cease-fire, the general told reporters in a brief meeting arranged by his public-affairs officers: "I agreed 100 percent with the decision. I thought it was a correct decision then and I think it's correct decision now." **********He said the President had telephoned him on Thursday when Mr. Bush had found out that "I felt very bad about it." **********"As far as he was concerned," General Schwarzkopf said, "he knew exactly how the decisions were made. He had great confidence in me, and he knew that I in no way intended to cast any dishonor or to even criticize him in any way, and that made me feel great." **********He said he had apologized to Mr. Bush. **********"I said, 'I am extremely sorry for the poor choice of words on my part that in any way would result in dishonor cast upon you.' " **********"He's my Commander in Chief, and he said: 'I'm telling you, just forget it. It's not important.' Since he's my boss and he told me to forget it, I'm going to forget it." **********On Thursday, Mr. Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney disputed General Schwarzkopf's comment in the television interview and said all three men had been in total agreement. **********"I have such high regard for General Schwarzkopf that I'll let him explain what he said," Mr. Bush said. **********Today, the general did just that, saying: "If I could do the whole thing all over again, I know I would change the word 'recommend' to say 'we initially planned.' Because that's what it was. We initially planned to do one thing." **********But he said he had later been asked about calling the cease-fire on Feb. 27 and had agreed to that date. **********But at the time he and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were discussing the strategy, he said, they both agreed they had accomplished military objectives "and that the appropriate time was coming in the very near future to stop the battle." **********During a subsequent call, General Schwarzkopf said, General Powell asked him, "Well, what do you think about this time?" General Schwarzkopf said he had replied, "Hey, that's great. I agree." **********"And so that then became the decision," he said. **********The suggestion that Mr. Bush had halted the offensive prematurely came at a time when his Administration was under pressure to give aid to Iraqi rebels fighting President Saddam Hussein's forces. The pressure continues, and some critics say the United States military should have toppled President Hussein while it had the momentum. **********General Schwarzkopf said today that any decision on assisting the rebels would have to be made by the Bush Administration. **********"Generals aren't in the business of commenting on the correctness or incorrectness of the President's decisions," he said. "Anybody who thinks he should be able to do that ought to be fired on the spot."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/world.main_headline: Haitian Legislators Name a Judge To Be President Until a New Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/world.print_headline: Haitian Legislators Name a Judge To Be President Until a New Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/world.body_text: **********The Haitian National Assembly swore in a Supreme Court Justice as provisional president today to replace the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country's first democratically elected leader, who fled the country after being overthrown in a military coup eight days ago. **********The appointment of Joseph Nerette, a Justice described as political centrist in his late 60's, came after the parliament overwhelmingly ratified a motion declaring the office of the president vacant. **********The action officially vacating the office was first taken by parliament on Monday and repeated today. The initial vote Monday came as soldiers surrounded the National Assembly building and fired their automatic weapons into the air. The soldiers also briefly took over the airport Monday while a delegation of diplomats from the Organization of American States was meeting there.  Motion Declared Illegal **********Because of the actions by the soldiers and the absence of many members of Parliament, including its president, the motion to vacate the President's office was declared illegal on Monday by O.A.S. representatives and Western diplomats. **********[ In Washington, the Organization of American States drew up plans to toughen economic sanctions against the new Government of Haiti, and also considered an offer to send a civilian O.A.S. observer force to Port-au-Prince. Page A3. ] **********Asked if the soldiers had coerced the legislature to declare Father Aristide's office vacant, Haitian politicians said the soldiers may have forced the issue, but the outcome was inevitable. "We are repeating our vote today because there appear to be doubts about what occurred yesterday," said Senator Thomas Dupiton, referring to the ratification vote today. **********While opposition by enlisted men in the Haitian military to Father Aristide's return is genuine, several politicians described Monday's action by the soliders outside the Parliament as intended to send a strong signal to the O.A.S. that Father Aristide's departure was irreversible. **********"The thing was cooked up to present a fait-accompli before the international community," said the leader of one political party who acknowledged that in recent days there had been repeated contacts between soldiers and civilians opposed to Father Aristide's return to Haiti. **********After being sworn in by Senator Dejean Belizaire, the president of the National Assembly, Mr. Nerette, a gaunt and diminuitive legal scholar, delivered an inaugural speech in which he made several references to complaints made frequently against Father Aristide during his presidency, including officially-sanctioned violence, class tensions and disregard for constitutional checks and balances.  Duvalier Aide May Be Named **********"The realization of this country's potential requires the reconciliation of all its sons," Mr. Nerette said. Haiti, he added, "does not belong to one man, or a small group of men. This country belongs to all its sons, whether rich or poor." **********Uncertainty over how the provisional government would be received internationally was underscored by the absence of any diplomatic presence at the swearing-in ceremony. **********The new President was expected to name Jean-Jacques Honorat as his Prime Minister. Mr. Honorat is a former director of tourism under the government of Jean-Claude Duvalier. **********The naming of Mr. Nerette, who is charged with leading Haiti to new elections within 90 days, came after several days of of a power vacuum in which soldiers prowled the streets intimidating and sporadically attacking citizens. **********Since Father Aristide was forced out of the country by a military rebellion on Sept. 30, diplomats estimate that as many as 300 people may have died. **********In stark contrast to the swearing-in of Father Aristide in January, after the populist priest-turned-politician was elected in a landslide, the streets of the capital were nearly deserted this afternoon, and except for those invited to the inaugural ceremony, there appeared to be little celebration.  Aristide's Rights Record Cited **********In recent days, a high-level mission of the O.A.S. had repeatedly warned that Haiti would remain isolated and subject to an economic blockade unless Father Aristide were promptly returned to office. **********Haitian politicians today reproached the O.A.S. team for coming to Haiti with what they called a predetermined and inflexible mission -- the return of Father Aristide -- without bothering to gather information on both the deposed president's record of alleged human rights violations and the exceptionally strong sentiment against him. **********"I think they were uncouth to come here and tell us what to do," said Louis Dejoie, the leader of the Parti Agricole Industriel National, who applauded the naming of an interim government. "To blockade our ports and leave us without anything to eat would be genocide. It's an insult." **********Asked how the international community would regard the provisional government, the Canadian ambassador to Haiti, Bernard Dussault, said: "The O.A.S. does not intend to break dialogue."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.main_headline: Open Positions on Short Sales Decrease by 5% on Nasdaq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.print_headline: Open Positions on Short Sales Decrease by 5% on Nasdaq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.body_text: **********The association also said that 30.4 million shares were in a short position as of mid-January in 1,122 less-active over-the-counter securities that are traded in its automated quotation system, but not in the national market system. That report represented a decrease of 16.3 percent from the 36.3 million shares held short in the December period, when 1,181 securities were involved. Investors Who Expect Declines **********In a short sale, an investor, believing that a stock's price will decline, sells borrowed stock in anticipation of buying back an equal number of shares later at a lower price and thus making a profit. The number of shares in which a short position is still held by investors is totaled by each exchange at the end of each monthlong reporting period and represents the "short interest" for that period. **********Some traders and analysts consider a large short position to be bearish because it presumably represents a strong cumulative belief that the market will turn down. Under this reasoning, a large jump in the short position would also be bearish. But many other analysts contend that a large short position is a bullish sign for the stock market because short-sellers must eventually buy back the stock they have sold. **********The value of short interest as a predictive indicator of market bullishness or bearishness has been questioned in recent years. The reason is that stock is sold short by arbitragers involved in many special situations, including proposed or pending takeovers, conversions of securities of a company, rights offerings, stock splits or distributions and tenders. Other Anomalies in the Situation **********Other anomalies exist in the short-interest situation. For example, a decline in the less actively traded Nasdaq issues may be explained as a result of various strategies employed by certain brokerages that make markets in such stocks. **********Then, too, seasonal distortions may occur. In December, for example, short-interest figures may be skewed by tax-deferral strategies that use short sales. **********Still, many analysts who track market sentiment study short interest and have devised ways to screen out the arbitrage and other "noise" that distorts the figures. **********For the recent period, the following N.A.S.D. stocks showed shifts in short interest of 10,000 shares or more:

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/world.main_headline: Syria's Foreign Minister Sees Real Hope for Mideast Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Syria's Foreign Minister Sees Real Hope for Mideast Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/world.body_text: **********As United States Mideast diplomacy gathers momentum, a senior Syrian official has asserted that Arab nations have never been so flexible and Washington has never been so serious in the quest for peace. But he said that any peace had to be based on the return of the territory that Israel captured from the Arabs in the 1967 war. **********The assessment, by Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa, was the first by a senior Syrian official since Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d toured the region last week, discussing moves toward peace with officials from Egypt, Israel, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Syria. Mr. Baker returns this week for another round of talks. **********"In our view, I think Secretary Baker, after the deep discussions that he had with President Assad, went back to the United States with a feeling of a breakthrough, a genuine breakthrough, because what we are saying is very convincing for any honest broker," Mr. Sharaa said in an interview Sunday, referring to President Hafez al-Assad. **********Mr. Sharaa's talk of a breakthrough seemed intended to signal both the United States and Israel that his Government saw a chance for a settlement and that Syria should not be blamed for a breakdown, analysts said. **********When Mr. Baker met with Mr. Assad for six hours last Thursday, Mr. Sharaa said, the Syrian leader renewed pledges to the United States that he is ready to give Israel international-backed guarantees of peace in return for withdrawal from the lands Israel occupied in 1967. Territory Won in Battle **********As a result of the 1967 war, Israel took control of the Sinai peninsula and the Gaza Strip from Egypt, the Golan Heights from Syria, and the West Bank of the Jordan River, including East Jerusalem, from Jordan. And as the result of the 1979 peace treaty with Egypt, Israel returned the Sinai but has retained control over the other areas. **********Asked what assurances the Syrian leader had given Mr. Baker, Mr. Sharaa said that if Israel "had no plans for a greater Israel or maintaining some of the occupied territories, what President Assad told Secretary Baker is very assuring." **********"There would be a termination of the state of war, guarantees -- international guarantees -- at the conclusion of the peace process after Israel's withdrawal from the occupied Arab lands." **********Questioned as to whether those guarantees covered chemical weapons, the Syrian offical said that details had not been discussed, but added: "We would be ready to make the Middle East a zone free of all mass destruction weapons. This means nuclear, chemical and biological." **********In the hourlong interview, Mr. Sharaa also said that Syria and other Arab countries were convinced that President Bush was serious in his pledge to seek a Mideast settlement based on United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338.  Foundation U.N. Resolutions **********Resolution 242, drawn up in November 1967, calls on Israel to return territory occupied in 1967 in return for secure and recognized borders. Resolution 338, drawn up in October 1973, after the war that month, calls for negotiations to put Resolution 242 into effect. **********Mr. Sharaa also said Syria insisted on conditions for peace talks between Arabs and Israelis, including the Israeli application of Resolutions 242 and 338 and a significant United Nations role at a peace conference -- terms that Israel has thus far rejected. **********"They are prerequisites for peace," he said. "Without these you cannot have peace. If the land is not returned, there'll be no peace. If there's no mechanism, which is the international peace conference, there'll be no peace." **********On the Palestinians, Mr. Sharaa said: "I think the Palestinian people should be free to send their own representation to the peace conference, because after all, these people have been suffering for a long time under Israeli occupation and must decide for themselves who would represent them. **********"So many things happened recently which discredited the P.L.O. in the Arab world, especially during the gulf crisis. But again, it's up to the Palestinian people. If they want the P.L.O., we would respect that for sure." **********Asked how Syria saw a peace conference being structured, he said: **********"We cannot accept any conference that is not given a U.N. role. What we feel now is that the U.S. is serious and this is what made us serious and this is what made us flexible to the maximum. Flexibility does not mean we give up part of our land. No one can expect us to do that. We want all the occupied territories back."
