https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/world.print_headline: Bush Backs China Trade Status, Reopening Conflict Over Rights
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/world.body_text: **********In a move that immediately reopened a conflict with Congress over relations with China, and surprised even his staff, President Bush said today that he wanted to extend China's favorable trading status for another year despite misgivings about its human rights record. **********Within an hour, as members of Congress began attacking the President's remarks, the White House tried to back away from Mr. Bush's comments. Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the President had not yet made a formal decision to extend China's trading privileges, known as most-favored-nation status, for another year. **********Mr. Bush's statement today highlighted not only the basic conflict between the White House and Congress over how to handle relations with China but also the highly secretive and personal way in which the President operates when it comes to relations with the authorities in Beijing. Calls It a 'Big Pitch' **********Mr. Bush considers himself an expert on China after serving as envoy to Beijing in 1975 and generally makes all decisions on Chinese-American relations with one or two advisers in the Oval Office. He disclosed his intentions about China's trading status today without waiting for the normal option papers from Government agencies. His comments took his own staff and other departments by surprise. **********Despite Mr. Fitzwater's efforts to mitigate the political impact of Mr. Bush's statement, the President's intentions seemed clear when he told reporters on the White House South Lawn that he had made a "big pitch" for renewing China's trade status during a Capitol Hill lunch with Republican lawmakers. Under Federal law, the President has until June 3 to recommend the extension formally; the trading privileges expire on July 3. **********Mr. Bush acknowledged that "there are major problems in China" on human rights, arms exports and other issues, but added, "I want to see M.F.N. for China continue." **********Most-favored-nation status fixes tariffs on imports at the lowest prevailing rates and is not normally granted to Communist countries, including the Soviet Union.  Reward for Support on Gulf **********The President said he did not want to isolate Beijing and indicated that he was trying in part to reward China for not blocking American actions at the United Nations during the Persian Gulf crisis. Mr. Bush said today that he was considering asking the Security Council, where China has veto power, for a new resolution that would send a United Nations police force to northern Iraq. **********"I look at the big picture," he said. "I look at the support we got from China back in Desert Storm, the importance of China as a country. And I don't want to see us isolate them. I do want to see them come forward more on some of the things that we've been asking." **********He argues that diplomatic pressure will be more effective with Chinese officials than economic pressure. But many lawmakers, who want to squeeze China financially, say the diplomatic efforts have failed so far. **********"We've had far too many high-level contacts and not much result," said Representative Don J. Pease, Democrat of Ohio, who tried to tie China trade to human rights issues last year. **********Other lawmakers zeroed in on the quid pro quo suggested by Mr. Bush in his comments today. "It's unfortunate that the President sees China in such a different light from any other country," said Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California. "He makes the argument about China's cooperation in the Persian Gulf war and yet we don't have most-favored nation with the Soviet Union, which was even more cooperative." **********Ms. Pelosi is sponsoring a bill that would extend China's trading status for this year but make the 1992 extension contingent on human rights improvements and other conditions. Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, the majority leader, plans to introduce a similar bill on Thursday. Limited Requirements Now **********Under current law, Mr. Bush need not consider human rights and other issues in deciding on trade with China. Under a provision of law known as the Jackson-Vanick Amendment, the granting of favored trade status is tied only to emigration. **********China, which sold $15.2 billion in goods to American companies last year, is the eighth-largest exporter to the United States. But its purchases of $4.8 billion made it only the 18th-largest importer of American products. **********Administration officials said the options papers on extending Chinese trade privileges had not even been completed, much less sent to the White House, when Mr. Bush spoke today. The President had received only a strategy memo from Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that did not discuss the pros and cons of extending the trading privileges but merely outlined ways to sell the idea to Congress, one official said. **********It was not entirely clear why the President chose to reveal his position on China trade so precipitously in an unscheduled question-and-answer session on the White House South Lawn. **********But some officials said the President felt the pressure of time because of two coming events that would make such an announcement particularly inappropriate. On May 23, China plans to unveil a monument to its absorption of Tibet, which is not recognized by the United States, and June 4, a day after the deadline for the trade decision, is the second anniversary of the violence on Tiananmen Square. **********Congress has been pushing Mr. Bush to punish Beijing for that crackdown on political dissent, while the President has always sought to balance those pressures with economic pressures from American companies that do business with China and his strong personal penchant for maintaining relations with Beijing. **********"I go back to the days when I was in China as the equivalent of Ambassador and though there are major problems in China, things we don't like about their system, things are an awful lot better than they were back in 1975," Mr. Bush said. Envoy Dispatched **********Last month, Mr. Bush blocked the sale of satellite parts to China because of concern about its sale of missiles and other weapons to Pakistan and other nations. Earlier this month, Robert M. Kimmitt, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, was sent to Beijing for what American officials called a candid discussion about human rights, trade and weapons sales. **********But since the Tiananmen Square violence in 1989, Mr. Bush came under steady fire from Capitol Hill for not speaking out more strongly against Beijing or taking tough action, like cutting off China's favorable trade status. **********The pressure dramatically increased when it was disclosed in December 1989 that Mr. Bush had sent his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and the Deputy Secretary of State, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, on a secret mission to Beijing that the President later admitted was a failure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.main_headline: Son of Co-Founder Named President of Sturm Ruger
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Son of Co-Founder Named President of Sturm Ruger
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.body_text: **********William B. Ruger Jr., whose father co-founded Sturm Ruger & Company in 1949, yesterday was named president of the company. **********His father, a renowned gun designer, remains chairman and chief executive of the company, which is based in Southport, Conn., and makes small arms -- pistols, revolvers, assault rifles and the like. **********The war in the Persian Gulf has not brought any increased business to Sturm Ruger, the new president said. To the consternation of American arms makers, Baretta, an Italian company, has the contract to supply pistols to the United States armed forces. **********Mr. Ruger, 51, succeeds Gary W. French, who left as president of the firearms division of Colt Industries to join Sturm Ruger less than a year ago. Mr. French resigned on Jan. 11. **********The elder Mr. Ruger will oversee engineering and development, while his son will be in charge of operations. Another son, J. Thompson Ruger, 46, is vice president for marketing. **********The company, with annual sales of more than $121.5 million, has been constantly, although not spectacularly, profitable in an industry in which several other companies are struggling to survive. **********Sturm Ruger has been helped by its specialty in investment casting, a precision process for casting gun parts, and by work for aerospace and other industries. About 10 percent of its revenue is derived from the casting process, Mr. Ruger said. **********The company's co-founder, Alexander Sturm, died af few years after the company was founded. His daughter, Joanna Sturm, is a major stockholder, and the two families together hold about 46 percent of the stock, Mr. Ruger said. The shares are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, where they closed yesterday at $24.50, down 25 cents. **********William B. Ruger Jr., after graduating from Harvard in 1961, joined the company in 1964 and most recently was senior vice president. In his spare time, he said, he likes to hunt, and he and his father collect 1930's Cadillacs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********"Too Many Stations, Too Few Buyers and Depressed Prices," (June 30) was informative, but several points need to be clarified. The characterization of radio revenue as being "virtually unchanged" from 1989 to 1990 is less than accurate. Radio revenue grew 4.8 percent in 1990, faster than the overall advertising growth rate of 3.8 percent for the year and a respectable showing when compared with the decrease in newspaper revenue. **********The number of stations on the air increased by 93 between October 1989 and October 1990. When viewed in the context of the media industry as a whole, the number of stations "going dark" is less disconcerting than it might appear. With the exception of USA Today, a profitable daily newspaper has not been launched since 1940, and since then more than 250 newspapers have ceased publication. In that time, 8,614 new radio stations have gone on the air. Radio advertising revenues continue to grow. And Americans still spend almost three hours a day listening to the radio -- a figure unchanged since this country's "Radio Days" began more than 60 years ago. WARREN POTASH  New York, July 1    The author is president of the Radio Advertising Bureau.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; Now, Implants Instead of Dentures
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/busin.body_text: **********After a long period of slow development, false-teeth implants are rapidly gaining popularity with dentists and consumers as an alternative to ordinary dentures. The implants can cost more than twice as much as dentures but they are more secure, easier to maintain and less likely to irritate gums or harm adjacent natural teeth. **********"This field is as hot as can be," said Dr. Dennis Tarnow, chairman of New York University's recently formed Department of Implant Dentistry. Consumer spending on dental implants could top a half-billion dollars in the United States this year. **********"Back in 1988, experts were saying we would have them in 100,000 people by 1992," Dr. Tarnow said. "But it's been growing twice as fast as most people expected."  Centuries of Experimentation **********Physicians have been experimenting with dental implants since the days of the Pharaohs. Over the centuries, wood and a variety of metals have been tried. But until researchers began working with titanium in the 1960's, even the best implants were not anchored firmly enough to last more than a few years and the tissue around them was prone to infection. **********Titanium's advantage is that bone tissue actually fuses to it. Today, some implants are coated with a form of synthetic bone to speed the bonding process, which is known as osseointegration. **********"For reasons we don't understand yet, titanium seems to bond with successive generations of bone cells while other materials lose their bonding power over time," said Leif Ek, chief executive of Nobelpharma A.B., the Swedish company that is the worldwide leader in implants. **********Industry sources estimate that implant suppliers in the United States will generate between $90 million and $100 million in revenues this year from oral surgeons, periodontists and dentists who specialize in constructing false teeth. **********Those figures will be dwarfed if, as experts expect, implants eventually take over a large part of the denture market. In the United States alone, there are 40 million denture wearers. Another 60 million Americans are missing one or more teeth and make do without dentures. **********"We are just at the beginning of what this can do," said Gerald A. Niznick, a dentist who founded the Core-Vent Corporation, the leading domestic implant company, in 1982. "We estimate that only about 11 percent of dentists are working with implants now. As the older people retire and new dentists who have learned how to do implants in school get started, that will change." **********For a dental patient, a single tooth implant can cost from $800 to $2,500, depending on the difficulty of the case and on the region of the country where the surgery is performed. Whole arches, which use multiple implants to anchor a complete set of false teeth for the upper or lower jaw, might cost as much as $15,000, barring unusual complications. Implants are most cost competitive with dentures in cases where a single tooth is to be replaced; the implant can be done without grinding down and capping the neighboring teeth, as is required with a single denture. But to date, dental insurance plans rarely cover implants. A Fortunate Discovery **********Nobelpharma owes its industry leadership to a lucky accident in 1952. Per-Ingvar Branemark, a Swedish university professor investigating how living bone recovers from wounds, found that the tiny titanium microscope he had inserted into bone tissue had become stuck. He began a long string of careful experiments on the phenomenon and by 1965 had developed the tools and techniques for implanting titanium roots to anchor false teeth. The artificial teeth attached to those first roots are still functioning, Nobelpharma says. **********Dr. Branemark methodically developed carefully controlled studies of the performance of his implants, and even today he works at refining techniques at the Institute for Applied Biotechnology in Goteborg, Sweden. His emphasis on the need for clinical studies, which many rival companies today credit with "professionalizing" the industry, led to a slow international product rollout by Nobelpharma. By 1984, when the company set up a unit in the United States to market its product, Core-Vent was already marketing its own titanium implants at prices as much as 40 percent lower, by some estimates. **********Nobelpharma is a subsidiary of Nobel Industrier A.B., a troubled conglomerate currently controlled by Nordenbanken, a bank owned by the Government of Sweden. Last year was the first that Nobelpharma had a positive cash flow, Mr. Ek said. **********Nobelpharma's efforts to begin reaping the benefits of its decades of investment are being hindered by competition from German and Swiss implant designs as well as those of Core-Vent and smaller American companies. Dr. Tarnow estimates that 40 implant systems are currently on the American market. Many Competitors **********Industry executives estimate that Nobelpharma now controls about a third of the American market as measured by sales revenue, followed closely by Core-Vent, which is based in Encino, Calif. Core-Vent recently sold all rights to market its products to Dentsply Holdings Inc. of York, Pa., the world's largest dental supplies company. Core-Vent offers the broadest product range and asserts that it actually leads Nobelpharma in unit sales, once its lower prices are taken into account. Other domestic vendors include Calcitek Inc. of San Diego, a subsidiary of Swiss-owned Intermedics Inc.; the Denar Corporation of Anaheim, and Implant Innovations Inc. of West Palm Beach, Fla. **********Dr. Niznick gives Dr. Branemark credit for convincing dentists that osseointegration works. But Core-Vent and Nobelpharma have been almost continually locked in litigation in recent years and conflicting patent claims have entangled other companies. Core-Vent is now pursuing antitrust, false advertising and libel claims against Nobelpharma in Federal District Court in Los Angeles. No trial date has been set. **********The differences between the various implant systems reflect minute design features whose long-term impact remains to be seen. The leading German approach, known as the IMZ system, marketed in the United States by Interpore International of Cambridge, Mass., incorporates a small plastic shock absorber. **********The most popular Swiss technique, called the ITI method, marketed in this country by the Straumen Company in Cambridge, challenges the prevailing notion that the implant root must be buried under a flap of the gum during the months it takes for bonding to occur. The ITI system eliminates the need for a second surgical operation to penetrate the gum when the supporting abutment and false tooth are added to the root. **********Despite the competition, everyone concedes that the biggest factors for success are choosing the right dentist and the appropriate implant design for a particular case. **********In general, the chances for success are considerably higher in the lower jaw -- about 95 percent -- because it is a thicker bone. But dentists say achieving such high rates requires rejecting a large number of potential patients whose jaws are not healthy enough to make success likely.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/28/busin.body_text: **********The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States rose slightly last week, with 28 new rigs working, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The company, which makes oilfield equipment, said 846 rigs were operating nationally, 155 fewer than a year ago at this time. Last week's count was 818. Baker Hughes officials have said heavy spring rains kept the count low, and improved weather would bring on a seasonal increase. Of the rigs working, 361 were handling gas, 451 oil and 34 others were listed as miscellaneous. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for petroleum and natural gas, not those producing oil and gas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.body_text: **********A $110 million tax-exempt issue of Dade County, Fla., aviation revenue bonds was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. **********The maximum yield was 7.1 percent for a bond due in 2006 with a 6.75 percent coupon and a price of about 96.765. For shorter maturities, the yield ranges from 5.3 percent in 1993 to 6.15 percent in 1996, 6.75 percent in 2001 and 6.95 percent in 2003. **********Underwriters said that for some investors, the bonds might be subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax. The issue was rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/busin.main_headline: I.B.M. Faces a Harsher World in 90's
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/busin.print_headline: I.B.M. Faces a Harsher World in 90's
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/busin.body_text: **********From a technology standpoint I.B.M.'s house is largely in order, most analysts agree. But the company is clearly worried that it is moving too slowly to transform itself into a pared-down company that can compete in the new world of the 1990's, those analysts say. **********The International Business Machines Corporation announced on Tuesday that it expected sharply lower revenues for the year than most analysts had anticipated. And that sent its stock tumbling, down $12.75 on Tuesday and another $1 yesterday, to $114.125. **********Historically, I.B.M. has always sold itself as a company that could handle any customer's computing needs. But as it has begun to reduce its staff by tens of thousands of workers, through attrition and incentive programs, I.B.M. has found itself stretched thin at some points on the broad front it is trying to cover. **********Not long ago a new chief executive at a major I.B.M. customer had to wait two months after he took office before an I.B.M. salesman made an introductory courtesy call. **********"How long do you think it should have taken?" asked the executive, who insisted on anonymity. I.B.M. is still too cumbersome, he said. I.B.M. said on Tuesday that it would continue to reduce its staff, an acknowledgement that it has a distance to go to become the leaner, more competitive powerhouse it hopes to be. **********For decades, I.B.M. has been a powerful battleship, formidable but slow to turn and maneuver. And now it finds itself surrounded by hundreds of smaller, quicker rivals. Unable to stand up to I.B.M.'s firepower, these companies seek to change the rules of engagement to a new way of computing known as open systems. **********In an open system, customers can mix equipment from different manufacturers, as they choose, and find software that will run on the resulting setup. This is attractive to customers because they can shop around for the best prices and modify their systems to reflect innovations. **********The shift to open systems challenges the heart of I.B.M.'s business: the ultra-powerful $10 million to $20 million water-cooled mainframes running I.B.M. software and cared for by I.B.M. technicians. It is on such systems that giant corporations have based their businesses. **********So I.B.M. is trying a balancing act: modifying its computers to incorporate open systems while persuading its largest customers to shift from one generation of its mainframe computers to its next one.  'Troubling Problem' **********I.B.M. has added features to the new mainframes to enable them to plug in and play with other companies' equipment in open systems. But with the commitment to open systems comes another problem: I.B.M. is exposed to competition. **********"In the long run this is a very troubling problem for I.B.M.," said Gary Curtis, a partner in the Boston Consulting Group. "The company will have to learn how to maintain high margins in an open systems world." **********And compounding the other problems is the global economy, which has many spots of weakness. **********"It has to be their nightmare," said Daniel Mandresh, a computer industry analyst at Merrill Lynch who has followed I.B.M. for many years. "It's a company that gets 61 percent of its revenue from overseas and suddenly finds that local results are weakening while facing a rapid acceleration in the strength of the dollar." **********The weak dollar was a significant factor in the unexpected strength that I.B.M. showed in its final quarter last year. But that may come back to haunt it in the second half of this year, when many analysts were expecting the company to shine. **********Another factor appears to be that I.B.M. may have shifted revenue forward to strengthen the final quarter of last year, and may be paying the price now. "It's a fairly arbitrary decision of where you book the revenues," said Robert Djurdjevic, president of Annex Research, a Phoenix market research company. "I.B.M. may have borrowed revenues from 1991 to beef up last year." **********I.B.M. disputes that, saying it is unlikely that companies making multimillion-dollar purchasing decisions could shift them casually.  Analysts Surprised **********Many analysts who follow the company said yesterday that they were stunned that I.B.M. seemed to be giving up on 1991 so early in the year. **********"It's really unbelievable for I.B.M. to be in a situation where they essentially concede the year in March," said Michael Chuba, an analyst at the Gartner Group, a market research group in Stamford, Conn. **********The true test for 1991 will come in the second half of the year, Mr. Chuba said. Until now most people in the industry felt that I.B.M. was virtually assured of selling at least 400 to 500 of its new top-of-the-line System 390 mainframes -- which have the highest profit margins of any I.B.M. hardware. The arrival of those machines will complete the transition to the mainframe family that the company began in September. **********I.B.M. now appears to be saying that it will not be able to use the strength of the mainframes to offset the overall slowness of the first half of 1991. And the biggest ticket items will be the largest question marks if the economy continues to slip. **********"Customers have never been asked to pay $22 million for a mainframe," Mr. Chuba said. **********And Allan Z. Loren, the president of Covia Inc., an airline reservations company with a data processing center in Denver, drove that point home when he said: "In mainframes we're driven by price-performance. But unless it's a survival issue I'm probably going to fit the new technology in when I can afford it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/busin.body_text: **********Two leading insurance companies agreed on Thursday to pay $750,000 each and testify in an antitrust lawsuit against some of the nation's largest insurers. **********Under the settlement signed by State District Judge Peter Lowry, the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company of San Francisco and the USF&G Corporation of Baltimore will pay a total of $1.5 million. They will be prohibited from engaging in any anti-competitive activities. **********Neither company admitted wrongdoing. The companies' lawyers said that fighting the largest antitrust lawsuit in Texas history would have cost the companies more than the settlement. **********The suit was filed in March 1988 by Jim Mattox, who was the Attorney General at the time. He accused eight leading insurance companies and other insurance groups of illegally conspiring to boycott, coerce and intimidate consumers to drive up rates and cut back coverage of commercial liability insurance. **********In October 1989, two other insurance companies -- the Travelers Insurance Company and the St. Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company -- settled with the state for $500,000 each. **********Also named in the suit is the Insurance Services Office, an industry rating organization. The suit contends that the office provided information that insurance carriers used to fix prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/world.main_headline: PRESIDENT ASSERTS HE IS PUTTING OFF LAND-WAR DECISION
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: THE WHITE HOUSE; PRESIDENT ASSERTS HE IS PUTTING OFF LAND-WAR DECISION
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/world.body_text: **********After meeting with his top two military advisers, President Bush said today that he would continue the bombing of Iraqi positions and put off making the politically difficult decision about whether to order American ground troops into combat. **********"The air campaign has been very, very effective and will continue for a while," Mr. Bush said at a brief appearance in the White House Rose Garden. Repeating his vow that he, not President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, would dictate the pace of the war, he said, "We are going to take whatever time is necessary to sort out when a next stage might begin." Overlap Is Possible **********Mr. Bush, who refused to answer questions from reporters, did not say how long the bombardment by planes, cruise missiles, naval guns and land-based artillery might last without an accompanying ground offensive. There probably will not be a sharp line between the air campaign and the ground action, since bombing and artillery attacks are likely to continue throughout a ground offensive. **********But after his meeting with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the President said he had not made the decision to proceed to the next phase of the war by committing ground troops to offensive action. Mr. Cheney and General Powell spent the weekend in Saudi Arabia consulting with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the American commander, and with other allied officers.  Advice From Saudis **********"We are not talking about dates for adding to the air campaign," Mr. Bush said. He indicated that Mr. Cheney and General Powell, who officials said were advised by military leaders in Saudi Arabia over the weekend to continue bombing alone as long as three more weeks, had not offered a recommendation to start ground operations. **********"I will rely heavily on the advice of our Secretary of Defense, our Chairman, of our generals out there, General Schwarzkopf and others," Mr. Bush said. "And then if they come to me and say there needs to be another phase, then I will then make that decision, because that is a decision for the President of the United States." **********As Mr. Bush put off what could be a politically explosive decision to start a ground offensive that is likely to produce a higher number of American casualties, he and his aides tried to deal with another political problem: the growing debate over the extent of civilian casualties in Iraq and Kuwait from 26 days of nonstop allied bombing. **********During his Rose Garden appearance, Mr. Bush made a special point of addressing that issue. "I would be remiss," he said, "if I didn't assure the American people that this war is being fought with high technology. There is no targeting of civilians." **********The White House has been increasingly vexed by the issue of civilian casualties, as well as by a recent spate of peace feelers toward Iraq by Iran, Pakistan and most recently the Soviet Union, and by questions about whether Washington is exceeding the United Nations mandate in the war. A senior Administration official said those issues not only put political pressure on the alliance against Iraq, but also increase the pressure to begin a ground offensive in hopes of ending the war as quickly as possible. **********At his daily news briefing today, Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, addressed those issues with a rare display of temper, suggesting that journalists -- and even President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union -- had been duped by Iraqi propaganda. **********Mr. Fitzwater asserted that the White House and the Pentagon had no reliable civilian casualty estimates to offer, but insisted that the casualties were lower than Iraq's estimates. He suggested that President Saddam Hussein was using the issue to score political points and thereby diffuse the alliance that is trying to force Iraq to comply with the United Nations demand that it leave Kuwait. Hussein's 'P. R. Points' **********"The propaganda and P. R. battle is where Saddam is scoring his points," Mr. Fitzwater said. **********Answering a question about Mr. Gorbachev -- who said over the weekend that the scope of the allied attack on Iraq, including the bombing of power stations and water supplies, might be exceeding the United Nations resolutions about Kuwait -- Mr. Fitzwater said: **********"We are going to such great lengths to target military facilities and military installations and to not try to do any damage to civilian targets. And it does strike me that Saddam Hussein must be having some impact in terms of trying to convince the world otherwise. And that is disturbing to us, because clearly one of his major objectives is to show that the United States is attacking civilians and not the military, and that is not the case." **********Top American field commanders consulted in the gulf, who generally favored continuing the bombing for at least three weeks, indicated the time could vary, depending on the weather, the effectiveness of bombing raids and Iraq's response, officials said. **********At the Pentagon today, officials generally echoed that sentiment, without being specific about the advice to the President. **********Pete Williams, Mr. Cheney's spokesman, said that "more progress can be made by continuing the air phase of the campaign," although he added that military leaders "are, of course, preparing for the next phase." **********The bombing began on Jan. 17 against strategic targets in Iraq and was aimed first at destroying Mr. Hussein's supply lines, his ability to shoot down allied aircraft and launch his own planes, his chemical, biological and nuclear weapons programs, and his ability to command his forces in the field. **********Pentagon officials have said this effort was largely successful. General Schwarzkopf has estimated that 90 percent of Iraq's communications and supply lines have been cut. New Focus on Troops **********More recently, allied bombers have focused on destroying Iraqi troops and weapons in Kuwait and southern Iraq, especially the Republican Guard, the vanguard of the Iraqi army. **********Lieut. Gen. Thomas Kelly, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said at a Pentagon briefing today: "We have not passed, I think, what's been referred to as a point of diminishing returns in the air campaign. I think the last report that was publicized was 750 tanks were destroyed, 600 armored vehicles were destroyed, and about 650 artillery pieces. That certainly isn't the lion's share of what they have there." **********According to estimates by the United States and its allies, Iraq had more than 4,000 tanks, 2,300 artillery pieces and 2,500 armored vehicles among the 545,000 troops in the war zone. **********General Kelly said he believed that the damage figures had increased in recent days, but he said so much of the Iraqi armor had been protected with sand walls or dug into the sand itself that it sometimes took "one bomb per vehicle" to destroy them. **********"The more that that kind of force can be attrited by air before we send in foot soldiers and tanks and artillery men, the fewer casualties we're going to take," General Kelly said. **********Mr. Bush said he was pleased with the report by Mr. Cheney and General Powell on their visit to the gulf and was "very satisfied, having heard their briefing, with the progress in the war." **********But he said he would not discuss the timing of his decision about starting a ground offensive "for a lot of reasons, including the safety of our own troops." He added, "Their safety is paramount in my mind." **********He said the war "has gone far better, in terms of casualties, than I'd hoped, though we mourn the loss of every single one of our armed forces and the coalition forces." He added, "My heart still goes out to the families." **********Mr. Bush also said Mr. Cheney and General Powell were "very reassuring in terms of the morale of our people over there." He continued: "They know why they're there. They are gung-ho about it. They know its importance, they know that it's right and just, and so I have great confidence in them, and altogether I feel much better after this briefing."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/world.body_text: **********Nine Americans and Europeans engaged in the daredevil sport of helicopter skiing were killed by an avalanche in the remote Purcell Mountain range of Canada, the ski tour operator said today. **********A Canadian Mountain Holidays spokesman, Walter Bruns, said the nine had been skiing in the Bugaboo Mountains. Their names were withheld pending notification of next of kin. **********Heli-skiing is popular among wealthy thrill-seekers who enjoy carving turns in virgin snow. After three deaths in 1981, the tour company was successfully sued for negligence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Motorola Inc. said today that its first-quarter profits fell 8.7 percent, but Wall Street welcomed the modest decline. Motorola stock shot up $6.75 a share, to $62.875, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Motorola, the nation's largest manufacturer of semiconducter computer chips, said earnings fell to $116 million, or 88 cents a share, from $127 million, or 98 cents, in last year's first quarter. Sales at the Schaumburg, Ill., company rose 8.3 percent, to $2.74 billion from $2.53 billion. **********Michael Gumport of Shearson Lehman said, "The company prepared for a slow environment, did well in the semiconductor sector and seemed to get its communications group together."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/busin.main_headline: Washington Presses Japan to Open Construction Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/busin.print_headline: Washington Presses Japan to Open Construction Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/busin.body_text: **********After several years of diplomatic fencing, Japan and the United States traded harsher jabs today over American access to the Japanese construction market. **********The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, began a legal process that could result in Japanese companies being barred from many Federal and federally funded construction projects in the United States, beginning on June 1. **********A Japanese negotiator who insisted on anonymity said that if the sanctions go into effect, Japan will retaliate by suspending its current program of giving preferential treatment to foreign companies on 17 big public works projects. But he said considerable progress had been made recently in negotiations and insisted that the American sanctions would probably never go into effect. 3 Nations Cited **********An American official who also insisted on anonymity agreed that some issues were being resolved. The Japanese Government offered today to expand the preferential treatment program to certain other projects, he said, while adding that the sanctions would go into effect if remaining differences were not addressed. **********Mrs. Hills today also officially cited China, India and Thailand for tolerating violations of patents, trademarks and copyrights. This could result in duties or other restrictions on imports from all three countries. **********She said President Bush approved of the decision to name China. The President, a former chief of the American liaison office in China, resisted sanctions after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989. **********Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, who led a push in Congress for citing the three countries, said he was "very pleased" with their designation. A Hardening Stance **********Mrs. Hills's moves reflect a hardening of the Administration's stance on trade and a new willingness to take unilateral action against countries perceived as treating American businesses unfairly. **********The collapse of negotiations last winter in Brussels for a new global round of tariff reductions has cleared the way diplomatically and legally for the more aggressive stance. The American trade laws pertaining to economic sanctions permit less action to be taken when foreign countries are proceeding in good faith with bilateral or multilateral negotiations. **********The move against Japanese construction companies comes five years of increasingly acrimonious disputes over the tiny share of Japanese public works contracts that are awarded to American companies. **********The Japanese Government has maintained that the limited success of American firms reflects their lack of experience in the Japanese market. American trade negotiators have maintained that American firms are excluded deliberately. **********Today's move was partly symbolic, because Japanese companies do little work on Federal and federally funded projects in the United States. In 1989, Japanese companies won contracts worth $2.8 billion in an American market worth $435 billion, said Elizabeth Dugan, a spokeswoman for the Commerce Department. **********But Federal projects accounted for only $14 billion of the market, and Japanese companies won only $100 million worth of contracts for these projects, she said. **********By comparison, the Japanese construction market is variously estimated at $300 billion to $550 billion, with American companies claiming only $300 million a year. **********The proposed regulation would bar Japanese companies from public works projects that receive money from the Energy, Transportation and Defense departments and from the Bureau of Reclamation in the Interior Department. Appropriations for these projects amount to at least $21 billion this fiscal year, Mrs. Hills said.  Problems in Europe **********The procurement practices of the European Community and three of its members -- Germany, France and Italy -- are also causing concern and are now the subject of negotiations, Mrs. Hills said. **********John R. Tucker, president of AEG Westinghouse Transportation Systems Inc., a Pittsburgh-based maker of mass transit equipment, said Japan had raised a series of obstacles to American construction companies. Japanese criticisms of American safety and tidiness practices, he said, are only the latest in a series of smokescreens thrown up to obscure a refusal to do business with American companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/16/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Allies and Adversaries; Anti-Iraq Nations Firmly Reject Offer, Calling It 'Insincere' and an 'Obstacle'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/16/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Allies and Adversaries; Anti-Iraq Nations Firmly Reject Offer, Calling It 'Insincere' and an 'Obstacle'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/16/world.body_text: **********Iraq's conditional offer on Kuwait was firmly rejected today by Saudi Arabia and other Arab gulf countries, as well as by Egypt and Syria, which are at war with Iraq. **********While Arab nations supporting Iraq welcomed the offer, the bitterness in the anti-Iraqi nations' response was evident in the tone and content of the statement today by the Foreign Minister of Egypt, Esmat Abdel-Meguid. He spoke in the name of the eight Arab foreign ministers in the anti-Iraq coalition who are meeting here, rejecting categorically the Iraqi offer. **********"The ministers view this proposal as an insincere offer which contains conditions that were previously considered unacceptable as well as new conditions," Mr. Abdel-Meguid said, reading from a statement at a news conference. **********"This proposal by Iraq is an obstacle to the United Nations resolutions and is, therefore, rejected in total and in all its details. We call upon the Iraqi regime to pull its troops immediately out of Kuwait." **********The Iraqi offer appeared to dominate the attention of the ministers at the meeting, representing Egypt, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. They had come to Cairo to discuss their vision of the post-war period. **********The meeting, which continues on Saturday, will also examine a $15 billion fund to help poorer countries in the region and security arrangements for the future to contain Iraq and any other powers that may attempt to threaten the Arab oil-producers' security. **********In an impromptu news conference Thursday night, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt blamed the death of civilians in the bombing Wednesday of a Baghdad building on President Saddam Hussein. **********Mr. Mubarak's attitude underlined a fact pointed out by many Arab officials here, who say the gulf crisis has become the subject of deep and lasting personal enmity among many Arab leaders, which will have an effect on inter-Arab relations for many years to come.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/12/busin.body_text: **********The London Futures and Options Exchange said today that an investigation had found that the exchange had given brokers almost $375,000 in payments and fee rebates to encourage trading in new products. **********Some of the practices may be illegal or at least improper, the exchange officials and regulators said. The schemes appear to have been intended to make it look as if new products were more successful than they really were. The London exchange is relatively small, but it has been struggling to expand. **********The investigations began examining the trading in property futures, which were introduced in May. But in today's letter to members, Phillip A. Thorpe, the exchange's new chief executive, said the inquiry had found that the questionable practices went beyond property futures trading. **********Rebates, fee holidays or fee discounts were used to promote trading in rubber and arabica coffee contracts and a contract tied to a base-metals index. **********Brokers were relieved that the contracts in the questionable trading were not the exchange's main ones: cocoa, sugar and robusta coffee. But they warned that it might take a while to restore confidence in the exchange. **********The exchange said the Securities and Investments Board would decide whether any of the practices were illegal. The Securities and Futures Authority said its investigation, which was focusing on the brokers themselves, was continuing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/world.main_headline: The Dream of Land Dies Hard in Mexico
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/world.print_headline: The Dream of Land Dies Hard in Mexico
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/world.body_text: **********For 74 years, the Mexican Constitution has promised land to any citizen who would work it. But there were a few catches: the land could not be rented, mortgaged or sold. **********So when a Government functionary began telling local farmers here the other day how President Carlos Salinas de Gortari was going to change all that, the men might have been expected to applaud. They did not. **********"What?" an older man bellowed over the din that rose in the ruins of a once-vast estate here, not far from where the peasant revolutionary Emiliano Zapata was killed in 1919. "Was the revolution worth nothing? What did all of those people die for? There is nobody, not even the President of the republic, who can take away our land!" **********There were a few shouts of "Viva Zapata!" as the official tried to point out that the proposed law would merely allow peasants to rent or sell their plots or join with outside investors; it would not compel them to do so. But the confusion and mistrust was by no means unusual. Officials in Mexico City said they expected such explaining to continue around the country for months. **********The tumult underscored how Mr. Salinas's plan to transform Mexican agriculture has quickly become the stiffest challenge of his quest to modernize the economy. **********"This is touching the very heart of Mexican history of the last 70 years," said Luis Tellez, the Under Secretary of Agriculture who was a principal architect of the proposed laws. "It is the point of no return." **********The "agrarian reform" that most Mexicans knew had been a seemingly endless process, the basic tool by which the Government redistributed wealth in the countryside and asserted political control over it. But early in November, with 2.5 million peasants still waiting for their plots, Mr. Salinas told the country what its leaders had realized for years: that there was no more land to hand out. A Role for Foreigners **********In addition to legalizing the sale of redistributed land, he also moved to permit large-scale agribusiness ventures, with foreigners free to participate. **********While there is little doubt that the Congress, dominated by Mr. Salinas's Institutional Revolutionary Party, will approve his plan, the debate reinvigorated the country's floundering political left to the point that the President took the unusual step of inviting opposition parties to propose amendments to the new laws. **********"The only thing that will happen is that those who can buy will reconstitute the big estates," said Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the leftist leader whose father, President Lazaro Cardenas, gave land to nearly a million peasants in the late 1930's. "Now, instead of the haciendas, it is going to be the great transnational corporations." **********Mexican officials say the capitalization and modernization of agriculture are essential if Mexico is to compete successfully with the United States and Canada under the free trade agreement now being negotiated. But they do not doubt that the adjustment will be a wrenching one. Meager Farm Investments **********While farmers and their families now make up nearly a third of the country's 82 million people, they produce less than one-tenth of the gross national product and have collected less than 1 percent of the billions of dollars in foreign investment flowing into Mexico. The great majority of the 17 million Mexicans who, by World Bank standards, live in extreme poverty live in the countryside. And within a decade or two, Mr. Tellez said in an interview, about half of the rural population will most likely be forced to move. **********Many of the migrants, officials say, will settle in towns in the interior. Others will swell the already overcrowded and underserviced cities. But despite the new jobs that a booming economy should create, critics wonder whether a third destination is not most likely. **********"Where is the support system for those people?" asked Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, a political scientist. "It is on the northern border and in the United States." **********Even the most passionate of advocates for the Mexican family farmer does not dispute the need for change in the country's system of community farms. **********The ejidos, as both the communities and their lands are called, hark back to the land tenure of the Maya. Reconceived under the revolutionary Constitution of 1917, they have been carved from expropriated holdings until, under Mr. Salinas, they came to cover about half of the country's arable land. They may be worked communally or, far more often, as individual parcels, but can be transferred only from one generation to the next. **********Divided among heirs, farms that were mandated to be at least 25 acres have typically shrunk to half that. Most lack irrigation, and with outside investment barred by law, their mechanization is usually a day's tractor rental at best. Under the weight of Mexico's huge foreign debt, credits to the ejidos nearly evaporated during the 1980's, while many private landowners stopped investing out of fear that land-starved peasants might invade their parcels in order to force the Government's hand. **********Almost as a rule, ejido farmers must take on additional work to sustain their families. Some sell knickknacks or cut wood from outlying forests, and some pick vegetables in California or pack fish in Alaska. Thousands return to harvest their crops; others simply sell or rent their land illegally. **********The system would have collapsed of its own inefficency long ago, economists say, had the Government not heavily subsidized farm loans and grain prices. And despite paying about double world market prices for its peasants' corn, for example, only in the last two years has Mexico not had to import corn and beans. Higher Subsidies Asked **********In selling the new plan, the Government has essentially argued that "land and liberty" -- the slogan of Zapata's revolt and the chorus of Government oratory for half a century -- do not necessarily go together anymore. **********By granting farmers the power to vote themselves titles to their land, officials contend, the Government will end its paternalistic control over the ejidos, undercut the power of the corrupt bosses who dominate many farms and free the farmers from the demands of Government banks that often condition loans on the planting of certain crops. **********But critics of the plan are demanding that the Government raise rather than cut its subsidies. "The Government is backing away from its responsibility," said Ramon Danzos Palomino, the 79-year-old former Communist leader who is a sort of grand old man of the peasant left. **********Far as such arguments might diverge from the mainstream of contemporary economic logic, some officials acknowledged that they might still be persuasive to millions of poor Mexicans. **********"The worry," said a senior official who spoke on condition he not be identified, "is that you could have political unrest in the countryside at this stage, when we are negotiating a free-trade agreement with the United States." **********After an initial flurry of leftist opposition to his bill, Mr. Salinas promised to soften the repayment terms on outstanding ejido loans and spend about $3 billion next year on new credits, technology and infrastructure to strengthen the farm system. Different Reactions **********Like Mexican agriculture itself, the longer-term reception given the new law will almost certainly vary by region. In the north, where landholdings are larger and production agriculture is more established, farmers are expected to turn more quickly to the many potential investors whom Government officials say have shown interest. In the south, where plots are smaller, poorer and still disputed by thousands of peasants, the evolution will likely be much slower. **********In visits to ejidos in the state of Morelos, just south of the capital, it was difficult to find a farmer even thinking about cashing in under the proposed laws. "As long as I have faith in God, I think I would not sell my land," said Clemente Torres, 40, who stood on one of the rutted dirt streets of San Jose de Pala. "It has always given me something to eat." **********But the appearance of new crops in the fields belie the outward resistance to change. **********On the ejido of Miacatlan, Valente Mastache, 61 years old, was still smarting from the loss of $670 he suffered when a Canadian company backed out of the pilot project under which he had abandoned his corn to grow Chinese vegetables. But keeping to his diversification, Mr. Mastache had sown peanuts and watermelons this year. And he did not rule out the possibility of another effort to grow oriental squash. **********"We just have to make the contract a little bit better next time," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.main_headline: All About/Denim; The Appeal of Blue -- Now Red or Green -- Jeans
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.print_headline: All About/Denim; The Appeal of Blue -- Now Red or Green -- Jeans
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.body_text: **********High-fashion denim, these days, means much more than designer jeans. Franco Moschino covers a denim jacket with transparent sequins. Donna Karan shapes a strapless denim minidress. As sales of blue jeans flag, designers are devising new uses for a familiar fabric. **********These novelties tickle the fashion-conscious, but to most people denim still means jeans. More than 650 million square yards of denim are produced in this country every year, mainly by automated factories in the South. At least 90 percent of the denim goes into the basics: blue jeans, jackets, overalls and skirts. The domestic denim market has matured as a vast business. At $6 billion in 1989 retail sales for jeans and $8.25 billion for all denim clothing, it represents one of the largest categories of apparel. **********Jeans and denim manufacturers remain optimistic despite fluctuations in their markets. Domestic demand has suffered from turmoil in the retail industry, a recession and the graying of the jeans generation, but foreign demand is on the rise. Manufacturers continue to expand the variety of jeans with new fabric finishes, colors and styling. "The key to the growth of the jeans business is innovation," said Arnold Elder, a vice president of Swift Textiles Inc., a major denim manufacturer. "In order to get a person to buy another pair of jeans, the eye must be attracted to something different."  Made in the U.S.A. The Big Mills Are In the South **********The United States produces more denim than any other country, primarily for domestic use but increasingly for the world market. The largest denim mills bear little resemblance to the crowded plants of the past. Towering machines suck cotton from bales and spin it into yarn, dyeing the fibers, then weaving them into fabric that flows onto wide 600-pound rolls. The plants are spacious, but eerie for the scarcity of employees, whose duties are mainly to adjust the computer controls and tweak the machines. **********Swift Textiles Inc., a United States subsidiary of Dominion Textiles Inc. of Montreal, is generally regarded as the world's largest supplier. For the year ended last June, Swift Textiles sold more than $300 million of denim, supplying major jeans makers like Levi Strauss, Lee, Wrangler, Sassoon and Liz Claiborne. **********Next comes the Cone Mills Corporation of Greensboro, N.C., privately held but willing to confirm an annual output of more than 165 million square yards. The company says Levi Strauss is its largest account, since almost all the denim for Levi's best-selling five-pocket 501 jeans comes from Cone Mills. It also supplies Oshkosh B'gosh, Calvin Klein and Polo/Ralph Lauren. Industry executives say the next-largest producers are Greenwood Mills Inc. of Greenwood, S.C., and then Burlington Industries Inc. of Greensboro, N.C. **********The mills have learned to produce much more than the traditional, 14 1/2-ounce-per-yard denim used in 501's. The fabric can be as light as 4 1/2 ounces, known as chambray, or as heavy as 15 1/2. About 90 percent of the denim is pure cotton, with 10 percent containing some polyester and a very small percentage incorporating stretchy spandex. Four of every five yards are indigo blue. **********More American-made denim is going to South America, the Far East and especially Western Europe, which imports 40 million to 50 million yards annually. This amount is more than all the other markets combined, said Nessim Levy, president of the Level Export Sales Corporation, which sends Cone Mills products to Europe. Fashion-conscious Italians buy the most from the United States.  American denim and jeans makers hope to find large new markets in Eastern Europe. **********But denim production is by no means limited to the United States. Europe weaves an estimated 275 million square yards annually, while Japan fills much of its own demand and imports some from Hong Kong. **********Arnold Elder, a vice president of Swift Textiles, said exports can more than make up for stagnant domestic consumption. "Denim is being worn today for everything from casual sportswear to shirts to dresses," he said. "It's acceptable around the world."  Levi, the Leader Foreigners Want The American Look **********Levi Strauss & Company, a privately held corporation with headquarters in San Francisco, remains by far the largest jeans company in the world. Since Levi's founding in 1850, when a Bavarian immigrant used French cotton serge to sew sturdy trousers for California miners, the company has stitched up two and a half billion pairs. Sales reached $3.6 billion in 1989, with more than $4 billion estimated for 1990. The figures include Levi's Dockers, a line of cotton twill pants introduced in 1986, with sales of $600 million last year. Dan Chew, Levi's marketing manager, attributes the company's steady growth to the success of Dockers and the increased global demand for American jeans. **********Europe is Levi's biggest foreign market, but Asians also like the American look. "Even though we manufacture in Japan for the Asian market," Mr. Chew said, "Asians go to great lengths to obtain Levi's 501's made in the United States, so we do export some American-made jeans to Asia." **********Mr. Chew said Levi Strauss sells twice as many jeans as its closest competitor, Lee Jeans. Both Lee and Wrangler are subsidiaries of the V.F. Corporation of Reading, Pa., the country's largest publicly held apparel company. Lee estimates that it has sold one billion pairs during its one-century lifespan. **********Jeans makers are still trying to develop computers and machines that can stitch up pants as well as they can weave fabric. Most jeans factories have rows of women tending sewing machines, with computers reserved for cutting patterns, tracking orders and managing inventory and distribution.  The Designer Craze Paying for a Name On the Pocket **********Farmers, ranchers and laborers have always worn denim work clothes, but as a fashion for those with whiter collars, blue jeans have been cyclical. They represented social rebellion in the 1960's and entered the realm of high fashion in the late 70's and early 80's. When Brooke Shields promoted one designer by cooing about her Calvins, other designers rode the trend. Jeans sales reached an all-time high of 502 million pairs, 77 percent of them denim, in 1981. **********Much of the appeal of designer jeans still lies on their back pockets, where labels like Calvin Klein, Gloria Vanderbilt or Ralph Lauren merit prices of $70 to more than $100. Basic jeans can be found for less than $20. **********Designers who insist the extra money buys sassier styling do not discount the value of cachet. "Designer jeans historically cost more, but you buy a name and a fit," said Denise Seegal, president of DKNY, Donna Karan's less expensive line of sportswear. **********DKNY spawned DKNY Jeans last year as a separate division, and Ms. Seegal projects sales of $40 million in 1991. But the basic DKNY jeans that sold for $85 in 1989 can now be had for $70. "I took a haircut to lower the price to position myself to compete," Ms. Seegal said. But Donna Karan is no kin of Levi Strauss. "When a store asks me why we can't sell jeans for $20," Ms. Seegal said, "I tell them that if you produce a million pairs, it costs less than producing a thousand pairs or a hundred thousand." **********A designer's name may sell the first pair of jeans, but it will not necessarily produce repeat sales, some jeans makers have found. The customer must be tempted by something new, something he or she does not already own. **********Now there are black jeans and white jeans, jeans in several colors absent even from the rainbow. All manner of finishes -- bleaching, over-dyeing, acid-washing, stone-washing, sand-blasting and even shotgun-blasting -- give denim a new, or old, look. **********Until five or six years ago, 70 percent to 80 percent of the Levi's sold were rigid or slightly prewashed, said Mr. Chew. Now, 80 percent have further finishes. About 35 percent are acid-washed ("But that's on the way out," he said) and 30 percent stone-washed. All these washes and finishes make jeans softer and more comfortable. What's more, the styles make the wearer look like the survivor of a month on the ranch, a landslide, a shootout or at least a good dunking in a Clorox vat.   THE LITTLE BLACK DENIM DRESS **********Donna Karan calls denim the new gabardine. She uses it for much more than jeans. She has had a denim blazer in her DKNY line for two years and included denim in her latest high-fashion collection for spring. She uses a silk-and-cotton denim for dresses, jackets and skirts that bear as little resemblance to jeans as a cocktail party does to a hoedown. Her prices befit her clientele of movie stars and top executives: $640 for a short, strapless denim dress, $1,000 for a satin-lined denim coat. **********Such are the inspirations that have allowed Ms. Karan to become one of the hottest designers in the country, building sales of more than $150 million in six years. "Denim is wonderful to style," she said. "It comes in different weights and it tailors beautifully. Everything can be made in it. Denim for me is a classic. It's a seven-days-a-week, day-to-night fabric." **********Young American designers like Rebecca Moses and Zang Toi also used denim in unconventional ways for spring. Ms. Moses made a bustier and pants covered with transparent sequins. Mr. Toi used bright pink and red denim for short trench coats, strapless dresses and boleros with jeweled fringes. **********American designers are not the only ones pursuing denim panache. Franco Moschino, the enfant terrible of Italian fashion, has a jeans line that racked up worldwide sales of $80 million last year. The line includes sundresses, sequin-covered jackets, skirts trimmed with beaded fringes and denim pants with pleated legs of see-through rayon. **********The basic slacks account for only 10 percent of Moschino Jeans sales. To keep the price of these pants down to $32 wholesale, they are made in this country. The rest of the line is sewn in Italy of American-made denim from Cone Mills and Burlington. "In Italy, people wear Moschino jeans the way we wear Levi's," said Anne Marino, executive vice president of Simint U.S.A. **********Simint, an Italian holding company, manufactures and markets Italian designer jeans and leisurewear, including Moschino's. The largest leisure apparel company in Italy, it also makes and distributes Armani Jeans in Europe and supplies the jeans to Emporio Armani boutiques in the United States. **********Armani Jeans, a $100 million business, was one of the first to offer jeans in a wide range of colors and finishes, including ones it calls smoky wash, ice-blue wash and tea wash. **********Like other designers looking to the 1960's for inspiration, Mr. Armani has turned to the past in his jeans line, reviving tie-dying. And Norma Kamali has reintroduced another 60's fashion that may portend the next direction for jeans: bell-bottom hip huggers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Newspaper Ads, for Newspapers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/busin.body_text: **********The newspaper industry ended its annual convention here today by announcing a national multimedia advertising campaign to promote a product that has rarely been effectively advertised: newspapers themselves. **********"Go on the offensive and holler!" Donald F. Riesett, vice chairman of W. B. Doner & Company, the Baltimore ad agency that created the campaign, exhorted the American Newspaper Publishers Association. The association's 1,400 members include most of the daily newspapers in the United States and Canada. **********Mr. Riesett said the campaign was intended to reverse the image of newspapers as old-fashioned, and tout the advantages of advertising in newspapers. He pointed to campaigns by television, radio and magazines that try to portray newspapers as out-of-date. **********Like true believers at a revival, the publishers cheered such ads as one that read: "Some car dealers love to see themselves on TV. Others love to see a lot of buyers in their showroom," followed by the campaign's tagline: "Newspaper. The best way to close a sale." **********The campaign, which will begin this month, includes a $500,000 budget for placing ads in advertising and marketing trade publications and a commitment by 15 major metropolitan papers to bear the cost of repeatedly publishing the ads in their own pages. **********In addition, the ads will be distributed by direct mail, and camera-ready newspaper ads, radio spots and videotapes will be provided to all newspapers at a modest cost so they can localize the campaign in their own markets. **********The advertising agency had recommended a $5 million campaign that would have included national television and billboards, but that approach was deemed too expensive for an industry looking for every opportunity to trim costs. **********The promotion effort comes as newspapers are suffering through what many here say is the worst advertising recession in memory. **********The association reported that newspapers accounted for 24.9 percent of the $129 billion spent on advertising in 1990, which meant newspapers retained their longstanding place as the largest advertising medium, followed by television with 22.2 percent. **********But the newspaper share of the total advertising pie was down from 26.1 percent in 1989, and the decline has only intensified the anxiety among publishers. **********Indeed, this year's convention has been unusually serious. Its theme was "reinventing" the traditional local daily to prosper in a dauntingly competitive world. **********"There has been very much less sizzle and much more on operations," said Richard T. Schlosberg 3d, group vice president for newspapers for the Times Mirror Company. **********But the nation's 1,611 daily papers, each with its own quirks and procedures, have a history of talking about change without following through. **********For instance, retailers like K Mart, which advertise in many markets and are newspapers' most important customers, have long complained that the industry should standardize certain procedures and forms to facilitate buying space. **********In 1986, for instance, the association adopted a standard advertising invoice format and loudly predicted its universal use by 1988. But a majority of papers still do not use the format, or use it incorrectly.  Symbol in an Invoice **********The failure to adopt the standardized invoice "has become a symbol of newspaper inertia to our best customers," said Ann C. Hunt, a vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, an industry support organization. **********There are signs that this time, the industry will rouse itself, if only because it has no choice. **********"We're not alarmist to say that the retail-newspaper partnership may be up for grabs," Ms. Hunt warned. **********After years of discussing the need for a mechanism that would allow advertising agencies to buy advertising at many newspapers through a single centralized computer system, such a system now seems a near reality. **********A rapt audience of publishers watched wall monitors today as the new system was put through its paces and, in minutes, was used to plan a hypothetical $75,000 advertising campaign in four cities. Under the system, which is still being refined, the entire campaign could be ordered with the push of a button. **********But, once again, the success of such a system will depend on whether most of the nation's newspapers will provide data and follow procedures in the standardized fashion that such a computerized system requires. **********Jerry Tilis, vice president for marketing at Knight-Ridder Inc., who has headed the project, said that without broad industry support, "we will end up with a technological success and a marketing failure."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/17/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Issues Little Changed
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/17/busin.body_text: **********The semiannual report by Alan Greenspan to Congress on the economy and monetary policy, normally an event of some note in the credit markets, was greeted with a yawn yesterday, and prices of Treasury securities were little changed in very slow trading. **********In his remarks to a subcommittee of the House Banking Committee, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board painted a portrait of an economy climbing out of recession while inflationary pressures continued to moderate. **********"He basically recapped what is a fairly broadly held consensus on the economy and inflation trends," said Joseph Liro, senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "The fact that he didn't break any new ground meant that his comments were not a catalyst of any significant change in the bond market." **********In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed in conducting monetary policy "has adapted a posture of watchful waiting" as economic data have increasingly suggested the economy is recovering.  Short-Term Interest Rates **********Traders interpreted those comments to mean that the Fed was highly unlikely to lower -- or raise -- short-term interest rates in coming months, and perhaps not for the balance of the year. **********"He said that it's starting to look like a recovery, but that's what we want, and we won't try to abort it," said Robert Barbera, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers. **********With Mr. Greenspan's testimony containing few surprises, traders said the market's focus shifted to the release today of consumer price data for June, as well as coping with huge amounts of new Treasury securities. **********"In the next six weeks we either have an announcement of a new debt sale, or an auction," one government securities trader said. "That adds up to a lot of supply. And coping with that supply will be the issue confronting the market." **********Today the Treasury is expected to announce the size of two-year and five-year note auctions to be held the week of July 22. **********Between now and the end of the month the Treasury will sell another issue of new one-year notes, and will tell market participants how many securities it intends to sell at its quarterly refunding auctions in early August. All told, over the next six weeks the total could add up to more than $72 billion in new bills, notes and bonds. **********"It's a big, big number," the trader said. **********But the looming supply had little noticeable impact yesterday on price movements in the secondary market for Treasury securities. **********By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 15/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.44 percent, the same level as late Monday. **********Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 9/32 in late trading, up 1/32, to yield 8.25 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/4, up 1/32, to yield 6.85 percent. **********Short-term Treasury bill rates moved modestly higher. **********In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.57 percent, up three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a like amount, to a late rate of 5.71 percent. **********In other developments, the Resolution Trust Corporation priced its second offering of mortgage-backed securities through an underwriting group led by the First Boston Corporation. **********The $579 million issue consists of adjustable rate mortgages from three California-based institutions in RTC conservatorship, the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, County Bank FSB and the Santa Barbara Savings and Loan Association. **********The securities were sold in two parts, and for the first time were priced off the one-month London interbank offered rate, a feature that underwriters said allowed the securities to be offered to a broader investor base, including overseas buyers. **********The first $437 million worth of the securities, which carry an average life of 2.1 years, were priced at 55 basis points above the prevailing one-month Libor rate at the time of pricing. **********The remaining $142 million of securities, which have an average life of just over five years, were priced at 68 basis points above the prevailing yield on one-month Libor. **********Rates on the securities will be reset monthly. The issue is rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.  Investment-Grade Bonds **********In the investment-grade corporate bond market, South Carolina Electric and Gas offered $145 million worth of 15-year first mortgage bonds through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers. **********The 9 percent bonds were priced at $99.55, to yield 9.055 percent, 80 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricig. **********The securities, which mature July 15, 2006, are noncallable for life. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's. **********In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said an unexpectedly large increase of $1.029 billion in Citicorp's loan-loss reserves had a negative impact on prices of the banking company's outstanding debt obligations. Prices of some Citicorp securities fell by as much as 1 3/4 points after the company released its second quarter earnings report. **********In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up about 1/8 point.
