https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/world.main_headline: Furor in Japan Over U.S. Funding Program
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/world.print_headline: Furor in Japan Over U.S. Funding Program
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/world.body_text: **********At the height of frictions with the United States last year, Japan created an ambitious new $375 million Government-financed endowment to support scholarly, political and cultural exchanges between the two countries. **********But now as the new venture is about to begin, an unusual controversy has arisen, with warnings by American foundation executives and scholars that the fund might backfire by being seen as a costly attempt to improve Japan's public relations reputation in the United States. To Japanese and Americans alike, the controversy reflects the tense state of relations these days, aggravated by endless trade disputes and American resentments over Japanese investments and what many officials see as Tokyo's half-hearted response to the war against Iraq. **********"Apparently the Japanese Government has become a kind of leper, with everything it approaches being seen as smeared," said an irritated former Japanese diplomat involved in the creation of the new fund. "Why can't the Government of Japan be seen as sincerely wanting to do good deeds?" **********Japanese officials praise the fund as a brilliant idea that won high-level political backing when it was proposed by Shintaro Abe, an influential former Foreign Minister who is now ailing. **********The fund endowment is to generate about $30 million annually for a variety of exchanges between Japanese and American scholars, particularly "grass roots" officials, journalists and other specialists who would explore common problems in the two countries. Among the subjects to be examined are the environment, economic tensions, politics and social problems. **********In a recent symposium to discuss the establishment of the fund, American scholars and foundation representatives expressed enthusiasm, saying it could supplement much of the support for scholarly research on Japan and United States-Japan relations. **********But they also warned Foreign Ministry officials that because of the current climate in the United States, such studies would be seen as tainted if they were sponsored by a unit dominated by the Government. These Americans urged that the new Global Partnership Center be freed of all Government ties. **********One of the strongest warnings came from a vice president of the Ford Foundation, Susan V. Berresford, who said in a speech at the symposium that "many knowledgeable people" were concerned that the fund would "set U.S.-Japanese relations back rather than advance them." **********"I will be very candid," she went on. "They fear that it will be set up and run with the express purpose of polishing the Japanese image rather than being a legitimate philanthropy in the U.S. tradition." **********The suggestion, echoed by several others, has in turn irked Japanese officials, who argue that because the new fund is backed by taxpayers' money, it would be accountable to some degree. **********"The fund will be very independent," said Kazuo Ogura, director general of cultural affairs at the Foreign Ministry. "We want it to do new things, and to be imaginative, creative and perhaps even controversial." **********But he added that an overly independent fund might "strike out a certain independent, individualistic, unorthodox or controversial policy" unacceptable to the Government. "The fund will have to strike a balance," he said. **********Others involved with the fund said that a "tug of war" was under way in the Foreign Ministry, with various consuls general of Japan in the United States seeking authority to give grants to groups in their communities to improve Japanese relations. **********"Much of Japanese corporate money and Government money is, bluntly speaking, P.R. oriented," said Tadashi Yamamoto, president of the Japan Center for International Exchange. "There's very little money on the Japanese side for substantive policy-oriented intellectual joint studies." **********Another Japanese official promised that the fund would have an "advisory council" to insure that "we can have American ideas and American suggestions for our activities." But he said that the power of the advisory council had not yet been determined.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/06/world.main_headline: U.S. Expects Lithuania Not to Erase War Crimes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/06/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; U.S. Expects Lithuania Not to Erase War Crimes
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/06/world.body_text: **********The Bush Administration said today that it expected the newly independent Government of Lithuania to comply with its own law by excluding war criminals from its program of judicial exoneration for citizens condemned earlier as Nazi collaborators by Soviet authorities. **********"I'm sure we'll be following this up with them to find out more about the actions that are being taken now," Richard A. Boucher, the spokesman, said at the State Department's regular press briefing. A department official said Mr. Boucher's remarks were authorized by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. **********The disclosure of Lithuania's blanket exoneration of convicted Nazi collaborators came as something of shock here in a week that began with President Bush's announcment that the United States would resume full diplomatic relations with the three Baltic republics, including Lithuania, whose independence he warmly hailed. **********Mr. Bush followed that by immediately dispatching Curtis W. Kamman, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for European affairs, to the Baltics to carry out the announcement and he is expected to arrive in Lithuania later this week. Secretary of State Baker is expected to visit Lithuania and the other Baltic republics next week. 'Terrible Credibility Problem' **********A senior Administration official who insisted on not being identified said that unless Lithuania moved swiftly to clear up the exoneration issue and retract certificates issued to people clearly convicted of war crimes, its government would face "a terrible credibility problem." **********The Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations is pursuing the cases of several Lithuanians suspected of war crimes and it is seeking the assistance of the State Department in pressing the new Lithuanian Government to cooperate. **********Of the Lithuanian Government, Mr. Boucher said, "We would expect that they would be acting in accordance" with an exoneration law passed by the Lithuanian Parliament in May 1990, which excludes people guilty of genocide or murdering civilians. **********Jewish organizations assert that several convicted mass murderers were recently issued certificates of exoneration in Lithuania. **********In an interview on Tuesday, the Lithuanian chief prosecutor, Artusas Paulauskas, said his Government had been issuing certificates proclaiming the innocence of Lithuanians convicted by Soviet authorities without new investigation of the cases. **********Mr. Boucher said: "It is our understanding that the Lithuanian law of last year that annulled illegitimate convictions by Soviet authorities also specifically excluded genoicde and the murder of civilians. Obviously our concerns about the crimes that were committed in World War II have been amply expressed by our actions over the past 50 years." **********The Administration wanted more information from the Lithuanians since it was "something that we do feel strongly about," the spokesman said. **********Asta Banionis, director of government affairs of the Lithuanian-American Community, said her organization, based in Arlington, Va., had sent an inquiry today to the Government in Vilnius asking for a clarification on the exoneration program. Letter From Wiesel **********"We as Americans read with great dismay and in fact outrage the story in The New York Times today," Ms. Banionis said. "If the facts are correct, the Prosecutor General of Lithuania in our opinion has not been implementing the laws of the democratically elected Parliament of Lithuania." **********Elie Wiesel, the survivor of Nazi death camps who was awarded the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize, said in a letter addressed today to Vytautas Landsbergis, President of Lithuania, that the disclosure of "your Government's decision to rehabilitate war criminals" had left him with "a sense of disappointment and deception and outrage." **********From his office at Boston University, where he is a professor of humanities, Mr. Wiesel wrote of those Lithuanians who have apparently been exonerated: "Many of them have committed murder, assassinating men, women and children only because they were Jewish. To rehabilitate them today means to forgive them. That this would be among the first steps of an independent Lithuania is something no decent person can understand or accept."                    --------------------       2 Exonerations Reviewed **********VILNIUS, Lithuania, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Following an outcry from Jewish groups that Lithuania was exonerating Nazi war criminals, the Government agreed today to review two of the thousands of exonerations. **********A Lithuanian prosecutor, Vidmantas Vaicekauskas, denied that his newly independent republic had deliberately cleared Nazi war criminals, but acknowledged that some may have been inadvertently cleared. **********"It was possible that some would slip through," said Mr. Vaicekauskas, who is in charge of the exonerations. But he insisted that the overwhelming majority of the certificates granted so far were valid. **********The Los Angeles-based Simon Wiesenthal Center has submitted a list of 13 people it says were cleared even though they took part in the killing of Jews between 1941 and 1944, when Lithuania was occupied by invading forces from Nazi Germany. **********"As far as the survivors of the Holocaust all over the world, they'd be absolutely horrified by this news," said Rabbi Marvin Hier of the Weisenthal Center. **********Mr. Vaicekauskas said he agreed to re-examine two cases, even though Lithuanian investigators had determined the Soviet charges against them were false. He said he could find no information in his files on the other 11 names provided by the American group. **********Mr. Vaicekauskas displayed a July 17 letter from Ephraim Zuroff, head of the Israeli branch of the Weisenthal Center, naming the 13 **********Rabbi Hier said at least half of the group is alive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.main_headline: Child World Receives Offer Competing With Earlier Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.print_headline: Child World Receives Offer Competing With Earlier Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.body_text: **********A second investor group announced a bid for Child World Inc. yesterday, in competition with an earlier agreement with WC Acquisition, a group led by two former Toys "R" Us executives. But Child World's largest shareholder reacted coolly to the second bid and said he continued to favor the earlier deal. **********The new offer, by Baytree Investors Inc., is just as mysterious as that of WC Acquisition in that neither bid carries a total price tag, or at least one that has been made public. **********But Baytree said it was offering a deal that is "significantly better than what has been announced" by WC Acquisition. "These other bidders are just dreaming about getting trade credit, but we can provide it," said Christopher A. Jansen, president of Baytree. With such credit, toy makers would be willing to supply Child World with toys; without it, the troubled toy retailer might seem like a poor risk to suppliers. **********Mr. Jansen said M. L. Rothschild & Company, a provider of commercial credit to trade suppliers, would open a $50 million to $100 million line of credit for Child World as part of the Baytree bid. Dennis J. Permut, a Baytree managing director, is the son of Clarence Permut, president of M. L. Rothschild. **********Jeffrey A. Cole, whose company, the CNC Holding Corporation, owns 82 percent of Child World, expressed skepticism about the Baytree proposal. He said yesterday that he still favored the deal with WC Acquisition, which has signed a letter of intent with CNC Holding. **********Mr. Cole said Baytree was not among the final three bidders for Child World, as Baytree contended. But he said: "I can't say I'm rejecting the deal because I haven't spent any time studying it. But I believe it's completely unworkable." **********Mr. Cole also expressed irritation that Baytree had apparently broken its pledge to keep secret all aspects of the bidding by alerting the press with a faxed letter to Mr. Cole and others that had been marked "confidential."   Top Shareholder's Concern **********Central to Child World's future, Mr. Cole said, is the trust of trade creditors and bankers, who favor a Child World management familiar with toy retailing. WC Acquisition is headed by W. John Devine, former executive vice president of Toys "R" Us, and Ronald E. Tuchman, its former director of purchasing. **********Baytree, a merchant banking firm in Rosemont, Ill., said that if it was successful, it would install as Child World's chairman George (Phil) Kelly, a former chairman of Marshall Field & Company, the department-store chain. Mr. Kelly, who now heads a Chicago store chain called Mallard's, could not be reached for comment. **********Earlier this week, WC said it planned to buy the Child World stake owned by CNC Holding in a "non-cash transaction." Part of that deal would involve the First Executive Corporation, the Los Angeles insurance holding company and owner of $190 million in CNC "junk bonds," removing part of that debt from CNC's books. **********WC would then buy the remaining public stake at $2 a share. If CNC's stake were valued at the same price, the total value of the deal would be $22.8 million. But Mr. Cole said that the CNC stake was worth substantially less than $2 a share and that it would be difficult to place an exact value on the CNC part of the deal. Difficulty Computing Value **********"The value could be anywhere from nothing to something," he said. **********Baytree said its offer for both the CNC stake and the remaining public shares was worth more than that of WC Acquisition, but it was not more specific. **********Mr. Cole said that Baytree share prices that had been reported elsewhere -- $1 a share for the CNC stake and $5 a share for the public -- did not "sound right" and were a further indication that "this deal isn't workable." **********Child World's share price rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $2, in over-the-counter trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/02/busin.main_headline: White House Loses a Vote On Bank Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/02/busin.print_headline: White House Loses a Vote On Bank Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Democrats in the House of Representatives handily repelled a White House attempt today to kill comprehensive banking legislation, setting the stage for a final vote on the package as early as Monday. **********In a vote that was virtually straight down party lines, a first since the package was introduced Wednesday, the House defeated a motion 243 to 158 that would have killed the measure, with two Democrats, Representative Doug Barnard of Georgia and Representative Thomas R. Carper of Delaware, voting with the Republicans, the only two to cross party lines. **********Although a final vote on the legislation is expected to be less partisan and much closer, today's action revived some lawmakers' hopes that Congress would go beyond merely refinancing the insurance fund that protects bank deposits and adopt a broader package of legislation. **********In the Senate, members were told today that the broad bank-overhaul measure narrowly approved by the Senate Banking Committee in August could reach the floor as early as Wednesday. **********The Federal Deposit Insurance Corpporation's bank insurance fund, which is worth less than $3 billion and is at its lowest level since its founding in the Great Depression, could be out of money early next year. That prospect has been the driving force behind Congressional action. Even if a broad package fails, Congress would be likely to adopt a much narrower measure aimed at shoring up the insurance fund. **********A key provision in the legislation would increase the fund's borrowing authority with the Treasury to $30 billion, from $5 billion, and provide billions more in working capital to assist failed banks. Administration officials say the taxpayer loans would be repaid by increased insurance premiums paid by banks and that the working-capital loans would be repaid through the sale of assets from seized institutions. **********The legislation in the House imposes significantly more restrictions on banks' expanding into the insurance and securities businesses than President Bush has sought, and as a result, the White House has threatened to veto it unless it is greatly changed. **********Like the House bill, the Senate measure rejects the Administration's call to permit industrial companies to own banks. The House and Senate measures impose significantly more restrictions on the ability of banks to expand into the insurance business than the President's plan. **********On the issue of affiliations between commercial banks and investment banks, all the proposals repeal the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which restricted such affiliations, but in significantly different ways. **********Both measures, as well as the Administration's proposal, would eliminate many of the decades-old barriers that have restricted the ability of banks to expand into other states. **********Big banks say that although the House measure permits commercial banking companies and investment banking companies to merge, the walls between them would still be high enough to make it impossible for the banks to compete on securities services. **********The architects of the proposal, Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, and Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, chairman of the Banking Committee, say the legislation would grant banks sufficient new powers while keeping enough safeguards to protect depositors and taxpayers. **********In other votes taken today, the following actions were taken by the House: ***********An amendment by Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, to impose higher capital standards for banking companies that wish to open new banks or acquire banks in different states was approved by voice vote. *********** A proposal by Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, to repeal a cap that prevents limited-service banks from growing more than 7 percent annually was defeated 290 to 104. ***********A measure by Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, to restrict banks from expanding if they have failed to provide loans to low-income and minority customers was defeated 241 to 152. **********The White House's unsuccessful effort today to kill the legislation was led by the Republican minority leader, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois. It came a day after the White House and the nation's largest banks suffered a serious setback by failing to strike the compromise provision of the bill devised by Mr. Dingell and Mr. Gonzalez. **********The victory was viewed largely as an expression of sentiment by the Democrats not to surrender control of the debate as well as a rallying cry around House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington, who had been attacked by the Republicans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/01/busin.body_text: **********KPMG Peat Marwick told its 1,876 partners in a memorandum yesterday that the accounting firm had come up with a list of 265 partners who would be terminated. **********The affected partners, who should be notified by Monday, are part of a program that the firm's new chairman, Jon C. Madonna, announced about three weeks ago to streamline the partnership. Mr. Madonna has maintained that the program is urgently needed to insure that Peat's best partners remain well paid and that the firm has the right mix of talent for the years ahead. **********Initially, he had said the firm might cut as many as 300 partners, roughly one out of six, but the final list is actually closer to one of seven. Unlike a purge at Peat some years ago that pinpointed partners near retirement, this one appears to have selected as targets more of the firm's younger partners. **********According to the memorandum, the 265 partners own 270,000 partnership units and are entitled to a severance payment of $52 million, equal to one year's pay. Those figures suggest members of the group have an average income of $196,000 a year, about what the typical Peat partner makes. **********The program should eventually result in higher pay for those remaining but will mean heavy costs this fiscal year and next, the memorandum said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/busin.main_headline: Big Berlin Site Is Sold to Sony
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Big Berlin Site Is Sold to Sony
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/busin.body_text: **********The Sony Corporation of Japan today bought a 7.5-acre site on Potsdamerplatz, the historic square that will be transformed from a cold war wasteland into Berlin's bustling center. **********Officially, the price was a secret. But political-opposition leaders said it was $56 million, which they said was too low. **********Sony plans to build its European headquarters on the square and will also build shops, restaurants and a hotel in a venture with Daimler-Benz A.G., Germany's largest conglomerate, and other companies. **********Parliament voted last week to move the Government seat from Bonn to Berlin and the vote has sent Berliners into a planning frenzy, working out details for the Government move and for the city's candidacy for the Olympics nine years from now. Foreign countries are also busily seeking sites for their embassies. **********Potsdamer was the busiest square in Europe in the 1930's, but now is a nearly barren tract where the Berlin wall once stood. The wall was opened on Nov. 9, 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/26/world.main_headline: The Uphill Task Confronting Yeltsin: Achieve Change and Stave Off Chaos
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/26/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; The Uphill Task Confronting Yeltsin: Achieve Change and Stave Off Chaos
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/26/world.body_text: **********For months now, Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, has been arguing that his plans for a radical overhaul of his republic's economy would have already gone into effect were it not for the "center" -- a word that encompasses the Kremlin, the lumbering bureaucracy of the Soviet Union's huge ministries and the long hand of the Communist Party. **********In the last 48 hours, in a blizzard of decrees, Mr. Yeltsin removed the center from his path. He seized control of the party's Moscow-based media apparatus, took over communications networks, and kicked the struts out from under Gosplan and Gosnab, the two state agencies that once controlled planning and distribution for the entire Soviet Union, by banning their activity on the vast territory of the Russian republic. **********Today, after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's order to the party to cease its meddling in government and economic affairs, Mr. Yeltsin would seem to be free to work his will inside Russia and, to some extent, beyond, in what will be left of the Soviet Union. But with events moving more rapidly than even Mr. Yeltsin can issue decrees, the question is whether even he, with his enormous popularity and bull-dog ways, can bring about change in a land that could be on the brink of chaos, and hold the remnants of the union together. **********In an interview televised tonight, Mr. Yeltsin called on his battered nation to get back to work, after the week's tumultuous events. "The situation is very hard, but I think that people are now very eager to do business," he said. "We must not interfere and just give them freedom of the free market."  An Appeal for Calm **********"The people should be calmed down and we all must part with euphoria, including the euphoria of victory," he said. "And no euphoria of revenge, or else we will lose our self-respect as democrats." **********From the White House, as the Russian government building is called these days, Mr. Yeltsin's team, fresh from its triumph over the coup and the outpouring of public support, speaks with the self-assurance of a civics text book as its worka to fill the vacuum opening up at the top and the bottom of the Soviet power structure. **********"The first task is to create an executive system in the localities, that will be able to function locally," said Pavel Voshanov, a top aide to Mr. Yeltsin, in an interview today. **********"The goal is take economic reform to the end, to realize the reforms," Mr. Voshanov said. "The strategy is the old one, to move quickly to a market economy, privatization, private property and to start on land reform, which is already late in getting started."  The Same Old Problems **********But as they look out across a land that stretches across 10 time zones, encompasses 31 autonomous regions and is home to scores of non-Russian nationalities, the Yeltsinites find themselves inheriting problems much like those that bedeviled Mr. Gorbachev when he first embarked on his program of change. **********There are problems of personnel, of expectations and of a clash of national identities that has already begun to emerge. With the party in tatters, a new system of administration will have to be put in place, drawing on the small pool of people who are both uncompromised and qualified. Although he is now riding high in popularity, Mr. Yeltsin will now soon have to answer for an economic crisis that is sure to get worse for the average Russian citizen, as unemployment rises and shortages linger. **********This week Mr. Yeltsin moved quickly to eradicate the obvious pockets of resistance -- those places where in the early hours of the Monday coup, local party and government leaders set up local "state of emergency" committees, and issued orders reflecting the junta's harsh directives. Speaking at the funeral services on Sunday for the three young men killed in the coup, Mr. Yeltsin said again that those who supported the coup would be removed from their posts and investigated by the prosecutor's office. **********As Mr. Gorbachev's power goes into eclipse, Mr. Yeltsin has emerged as the caretaker of the Soviet Government, adding its complex problems to the ones he faces in the Russian republic.  Chief Champion of Unity **********He has also become the chief champion of the union treaty, a document he negotiated with Mr. Gorbachev and eight other republic leaders that redistributes power from the center to the republics. The treaty was to have been signed by most major repbulics on Aug. 20, but was suspended by the government takeover last Monday. **********In his interview tonight, Mr. Yeltsin said he would now wait until Sept. 15 for the signing, to see which way the Ukraine goes, now that it has broken ranks -- together with the Baltic republics, Georgia, Moldavia and Armenia -- and declared its independence. **********The prospect of a defection by the Ukraine, the second largest republic in population with historic links to Russia, from even the loose bonds of the proposed union treaty poses problems for Russia, which could find itself alone in a union dominated by the Muslim republics of Central Asia. **********Mr. Yeltsin today also proposed in the television interview to cut short the session of the Supreme Soviet that opens on Monday, and to move quickly to convene a Congress of People's Deputies "to solve all the problems at once -- both on the participation of the cabinet of ministers, on its replacements, on its structure, on new cadres etc."  Yeltsin Aides in Key Posts **********Of the four people named on Saturday to the interim committee that will be running the national economy, three were drawn from the Yeltsin camp -- including the chairman, Ivan Silayev, who is now the Russian Prime Minister, and Grigory Yavlinsky, the young economist who has drafted the most radical plan to date for the rescue of the Soviet economy. **********Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev have also agreed that the next Prime Minister will be nominated by the Russian republic, as well as the new Vice President, replacing former Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov and Vice president Gennadi Yanyev, who were both members of the eight-man junta. **********No Prime Minister has yet been named because, according to Mr. Voshanov, the first task is to redraw the composition of the Cabinet of Ministers itself, a group that includes more than 50 ministries and state committees representative of the old older. Mr. Voshanov predicted that this number would be cut drastically. **********"We have to change the whole structure because in one week, some of these ministries will be gone," he said. "The committee has to work out a new model, and then after the model, will come the appointments."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.body_text: **********The Tennessee Valley Authority announced plans yesterday for the sale of $500 million of 10-year bonds through competitive bidding. It expects to receive bids on Wednesday for the issue, which will refinance an equal amount of 9.195 percent bonds held by the Federal Financing Bank. **********The prospective issue is expected to save several million annually in interest costs. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/15/busin.body_text: **********Two of Spain's biggest private banks, Banco Central and Banco Hispano Americano, plan to merge to create the nation's largest commercial bank, Economy Minister Carlos Solchaga said today. **********Banco Central has $40 billion in assets and is Spain's third- largest private bank, while sixth-ranked Banco Hispano Americano has assets of $36.7 billion. Until now, the Banco Bilbao Vizcaya was the largest commercial bank, with assets of $71 billion. **********The new institution is to be known as the Banco Central Hispano Americano S.A., sources close to the merger told state-run Spanish Television, or TVE. **********TVE said Banco Central would absorb Banco Hispano Americano in the deal, swapping five of its shares for every six of Hispano Americano. **********The merger details must be approved by the Government and by shareholders of each bank, TVE reported.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/world.main_headline: Russian Assembly Demands That Cabinet Speed Reform
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/world.print_headline: Russian Assembly Demands That Cabinet Speed Reform
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/world.body_text: **********The Russian republic's Parliament vented its frustration over the failing economy today by adopting a motion to recognize the obvious: that reform measures have been unsatisfactory and inefficient, and new approaches and ministers had better be tried fast. **********The nonbinding motion was not particularly important, except as a measure of the elected politicians' edginess over being held increasingly responsible for the economy now that centralized Communism has been effectively banned as a Government instrument. **********In the four weeks since an aborted coup brought about the collapse of the union Government and the party's hegemony, the public's worries have been shifting from the Kremlin to the pocketbook. A new opinion poll suggests that the top concern of nearly 70 percent of the public is rising prices, while only 8 percent care much about the "disintegration of the Soviet Union." **********Deputies in the Russian Parliament criticized the year-old cabinet of the republic's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, as the cabinet ministers emphasized the enormous task of digging out from under seven decades of Communism.  Conceding the Difficulties **********The lawmakers seemed to concede as much, stepping back from the more forceful move of taking a no-confidence vote in the Yeltsin government and instead voting, 134-19, to express how "unsatisfactory" the planning for economic recovery has been. **********Rather than directing their ire at Mr. Yeltsin, who was confirmed by voters three months ago and proved to be the hero of the coup resistance, they sought to criticize the Russian Prime Minister, Ivan S. Silayev, who has lately held a second job as chairman of the economic management committee of the union transition Government. The committee's charge is to undo economic Communism and speed the advent of a free market. **********The day's parliamentary session, in which lawmakers were again miffed by the absence of Mr. Yeltsin, who has called in sick for three days running, was an apt summary of the mood of crankiness that has replaced the capital's euphoria since the defeat of the coup. **********As the collapse of the central Soviet Government continues, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has conceded that the Kremlin now controls little more than the military and research institutes, and that it is increasingly difficult to find enough revenue to keep paying them on time. **********He offered no details on the problem, which he mentioned in a two-day-old interview with Soviet news editors released today. The question of revenue -- how much, if any, support the remaining republics are contributing to the fallen center -- is one of many unknowns in the current phase of the Soviet political crisis. **********Mr. Gorbachev said the republics were already running most parts of the economy and that the main question is whether they will join again in some new, more effective union arrangement or pursue separate republic "centers" that threaten the nation's identity. **********Looking ahead to the prosecution of the coup conspirators, Mr. Gorbachev said he did not rule out the possibility that some of the plotters might try to make it more of a political trial than a criminal one and seek to "compromise" the Soviet leader, presumably by contending he was the plot's chief agent and not its victim. **********He speculated that the principal strategist of the coup was Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, the former chief of the K.G.B. Mr. Gorbachev also said that Anatoly I. Lukyanov, the former Parliament chairman and long-time Gorbachev confidant, had "probably" been a behind-the-scenes participant whose mission was to see to Parliamentary approval of the coup. Mr. Lukyanov denies this.  Grim Fuel Statistics **********More pessimistic winter statistics were released today as Soviet officials pressed their case for foreign governments to extend a greater amount of food credits and aid in the coming year. Specialists of the transition Government said that oil extraction was down 10 percent this year and that coal output shrank 18 percent, signaling that the nation will have to cut its energy consumption by up to 15 percent this winter. **********Mr. Yeltsin was reported to be rebounding from his illness this evening and departing on a weekend peace mission to Nagorno-Karabakh, the embattled ethnic enclave within the republic of Azerbaijan that has brought Armenians and Azerbaijanis to fierce communal conflict over the last three years. He is traveling with the President of the republic of Kazakhstan, Nursultan Nazarbayev.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.main_headline: Sears's Plan To Offer Visa Is Set Back
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.print_headline: Sears's Plan To Offer Visa Is Set Back
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.body_text: **********Visa U.S.A. Inc. said today that the Federal appeals court in Denver had effectively blocked a plan by Sears, Roebuck & Company to offer Visa credit cards through a Utah savings and loan owned by Sears. **********The appellate court's ruling overturns a preliminary injunction that was issued against Visa in February by a Federal district court in Salt Lake City, Visa said. The injunction had blocked Visa's attempt to keep Sears from offering the cards. The matter will now to proceed to trial; no date has been set. **********Visa, an association of banks and savings units, has sought to keep nonbank companies like Sears from issuing Visa cards because the companies can offer no-fee cards, discounts on merchandise and other incentives that the banks cannot match. **********A.T.& T.'s Universal Visa card, for example, offers discounts on long-distance calls. Sears currently offers Discover, a no-fee card not affiliated with Visa or Visa's rival, Mastercard. **********"We believe allowing Sears to issue Visa cards would not be in the best interests of the consumer, primarily because it would reduce competition between two brands, Visa and Discover," said David Brancoli, a spokesman for Visa, which is based in San Mateo, Calif. "It would be like selling Big Macs at a Burger King." **********Mr. Brancoli said Visa learned of Sears's intentions when a card manufacturer informed the association that MountainWest Financial, a small Utah savings and loan, had placed an order for 1.5 million cards. MountainWest was a failed savings unit that Sears had purchased from the Resolution Trust Corporation, but Sears's ownership was not disclosed when MountainWest reapplied for membership in Visa, Mr. Brancoli said. **********After Visa subsequently blocked the issuance of those cards, Sears filed suit in Salt Lake City. The district court granted a preliminary injunction forcing Visa to approve the manufacture and delivery of the cards that MountainWest ordered. The appeals court's reversal of that ruling today means that Sears will not be able to issue Visa cards unless it prevails at trial. **********Sears had intended to offer the cards with the Prime Option logo, a registered trademark of Sears's Dean Witter subsidiary. Sears said today that it was disappointed that the court's decision would delay introduction of the Prime Option cards. **********"Consumers want a no-fee Visa card with real value, like Prime Option," Philip J. Purcell, chairman and chief executive of the Dean Witter Financial Services Group, said in a statement.  Discover's Future Unclear **********Like the Sears Discover card, Prime Option would not carry a fee. But in contrast to the Discover, the Prime Option would carry the cachet and wide merchant acceptance of the Visa name. **********Sears said that it did not believe its Visa card would erode the market for Discover, which contributed about $117 million to Sears's profits last year. But analysts disagree. **********"My thinking is they wanted to join Visa and phase out Discover," said H. Spencer Nilson, publisher of the Nilson Report, an industry newsletter for credit card issuers. **********When the Sears suit against Visa comes to trial, several issues will probably be raised. One is whether the Resolution Trust Corporation has the right to sell Visa membership as part of the assets of a thrift. Another is whether Visa has the right to create a bylaw, as it did in 1989, that excludes Sears and the American Express Company from issuing Visa cards. The trial is also likely to take up antitrust considerations, such as Visa's contention that Sears should not be able to issue competing cards. **********Following the success of the A.T.& T. card, Visa tightened the rules on operators of "affinity programs," in which banks issue credit cards on behalf of organizations as diverse as the Sierra Club and American Airlines. The new rule banned any bank that issues affinity cards from giving more than 25 percent of its credit-card business to nonbank groups. **********A.T.& T. cards are issued by the Universal Bank in Columbus, Ga., which was specially created for that purpose by the Synovus Financial Corporation, a Columbus banking company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/10/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell below the 3,000 level yesterday for the second time this week, closing at 2,996.20, down 17.66 points. **********Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was relatively low at 144.07 million shares, down from 163.9 million on Thursday. Declining issues outpaced advancing ones by 868 to 695. **********For the week, the Dow dropped by 10.06 points. **********The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell yesterday by 2.20, to 387.12, while the American Stock Exchange's composite index fell 0.61, to 365.98. In over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq composite index was off 1.08 at 508.31.  Gains Soon Eradicated **********A better-than-expected report on the inflation front yesterday morning on a drop of two-tenths of a percent in the Producer Price Index for July lifted stocks but the gains were soon eradicated. **********Birinyi Associates, which follows program trades, said all five made yesterday were sell programs, with a combined time of 41 minutes, during which the Dow fell by a cumulative 35.35 points. **********Paul J. Kronlokken, a technical analyst for Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis, said the stock market went full circle, with the full breadth down most of the day. "Initial reaction to the producer price figures was good for stocks, behind a bond market rally," he added. During the day the market attempted a couple of rallies, but fell short each time. **********Early gains were erased as investors began fretting over this week's quarterly refunding, particularly the sale of the long 30-year bond, which did not do as well as the three-year and 10-year note auctions. **********"On an intra-day basis the market found support with the Dow at 3,010," Mr. Kronlokken said, "but 3,000 is a psychological level, and you always find some resistance above or below." **********Technology and health-care stocks made early gains, but gave them all back toward the close, he noted. **********In reporting the drop of two-tenths of a percent in producer price figures, the Labor Department attributed a good portion of the decline to a steep fall in gasoline and food. Without those often volatile components, the core rate rose by two-tenths. **********Wall Street economists had expected the index to be unchanged with the core rate up by two-tenths of a percent. **********Among the most active stocks yesterday, with 2.96 million shares traded, was Westinghouse Electric, which fell 1 1/2, to 22 3/4. Westinghouse had announced that the chief financial officer of its troubled Westinghouse Credit unit had resigned. **********Deere fell 7/8, to 50 7/8, as Shearson Lehman Brothers lowered its 1991 earnings estimate for the company, to $1.35, from $1.70. Deere's fiscal year ends Oct. 31.  Outlook Depresses G.M. Stock **********General Motors fell 1 3/8, to 38 1/8. Jacob T. Battenberg 3d, a G.M. vice president, in a talk to security analysts, said the auto maker did not expect North American operations to return to profitability in the next two to three years. He added that the company would lose money in North America until auto sales returned to 15 million units a year. **********USX-Marathon rose 1/8, to 28 3/8. Paul Ting, an Oppenheimer analyst, said he had been briefed on the potential size of an oilfield Marathon discovered in Tunisia. "It's very bullish for the company," he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/27/busin.body_text: **********Iran will raise its oil output to 5 million barrels a day by 1993, from 3.5 million, its oil minister says. **********In an interview published Saturday in the Middle East Economic Survey, Gholam Reza Aqhazadeh said plans were under way to modernize oil terminals and offshore platforms damaged in the 1980-88 war with Iraq. **********"Before the war our production capacity was more than 5 million barrels a day," he said. "Considerable damage was inflicted on our oil production and export facilities. Also during the war we were not able to carry out the necessary drilling in the fields." **********He said he had the Iranian Parliament's approval to seek foreign money and expertise to restore crude output to what it was before the war. Large-scale drilling and gas injection projects are needed to raise capacity. **********"The Iranian Parliament has already approved these plans and allocated the necessary funds, both in terms of foreign exchange and local expenditure," Mr. Aqazadeh said. "So, there is no problem about that." **********He said Iran had put into operation 18 new drilling rigs in the southern fields, bringing the number of active rigs to 30. The country was leasing some rigs from Canada, "but we are doing the rest of the drilling ourselves," he said. **********Mr. Aqazadeh said Iran was talking to American oil companies about the direct sale of crude to the United States after a recent decision by Washington to lift a ban on such imports from Iran.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/05/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; Egyptians Now Replace Other Arabs in Saudi Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/05/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; Egyptians Now Replace Other Arabs in Saudi Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/05/world.body_text: **********Egyptians have become the fastest-growing foreign population in the Saudi kingdom, with more than a million now living and working here. Many of them have replaced Yemenis, Jordanians and Palestinians who were in effect forced to leave after their political leaders criticized Saudi Arabia's role in the coalition opposing Iraq. **********Sayed Kassem el-Masry, Egypt's Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, said in an interview that visas issued to Egyptian citizens since the Persian Gulf crisis began six months ago had roughly tripled, and that half of all new visas being issued to foreigners by the Saudi Government were to Egyptians. Egyptian and Saudi officials say about 684,000 Egyptians have been given visas to work here, and Riyadh is prepared to welcome many more for political and economic reasons. **********"We're entering a new phase in which relations between our two countries have moved from normal and brotherly to even far closer," Mr. Masry said. "Egypt and Saudi Arabia are becoming the pillars of the new Arab order." **********Egypt was among the first countries to support King Fahd's call for help in defending Saudi Arabia and freeing Kuwait from Iraqi occupation. Egypt sent some 45,000 soldiers and support staff here to fight under the Saudi command, a gesture deeply appreciated by the ruling Saud family. **********In return, Egypt has been well rewarded. Saudi Arabia has provided some $4.2 billion in direct and indirect aid to debt-ridden Egypt, one of the poorest Arab nations, with the Arab world's largest population. Remittances, or income from workers abroad, are one of Egypt's largest sources of hard currency. The departure of more than 1 million Egyptians from Iraq and Kuwait led to a decline of more than $1 billion in such crucial revenues last year. The migration of workers to Saudi Arabia is expected to offset the loss. **********In contrast to the welcome accorded the Egyptians, Arab workers from countries sympathetic to Iraq are being forced to leave as the Saudi Government has declined to renew their work permits. For instance, special residency and trade privileges extended to people from neighboring Yemen were revoked last fall, after the Yemeni Government harshly criticized Riyadh's decision to invite non-Islamic forces into the kingdom. **********Egyptians are now widely noticeable here, and are more often seen in the sensitive jobs once held by the other recently departed Arabs. For example, Saudia, the national airline, recently hired several new Egyptian pilots. A Tally of Egyptians **********According to Egyptian Government statistics, there are about 180,000 Egyptian farmers in the kingdom, 22,000 doctors and pharmacists, 16,000 engineers and 18,000 lawyers and related professionals. About 21,000 Egyptians hold administrative and clerical jobs; 150,000 are unskilled and 150,000 are skilled workers like plumbers and electricians. **********Saudi Arabia, like many countries in the gulf, is heavily dependent on Egyptians in teaching. About 44,000 Egyptians work in the schools, 13,000 of whom are women, who, unlike Saudi women, teach mainly in the villages. **********Mr. Masry said Egyptians were popular workers in Saudi Arabia because they are apolitical and deeply attached to their country. Unlike other Arabs who come to Arabia, he said, most do not want to stay here or become Saudi citizens. **********"They don't care about politics or secularism," he asserted. "For millennia, they have been tied to their soil. Their main goal is to improve their social and economic status and return home. And that makes the Saudis feel very comfortable about them." **********Despite the new-found enthusiasm in Saudi-Egyptian relations, historical and political tensions abound. Egypt crushed the first Saudi state in 1818, and as late as 1965, Egyptian planes bombed southern Saudi Arabia from bases in Yemen, when Egypt intervened in Yemen's civil war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Testifying before Parliament on the recent string of stock market scandals, the former top executives of Nomura Securities and Nikko Securities admitted today having had much closer and longer-term ties to a widely known organized crime boss than they had previously acknowledged. **********In addition, the executives said for the first time that top officials at the two brokerage houses had condoned the improper practice of compensating some customers for stock market losses, an admission that is likely to increase demands for reform of the scandal-plagued securities industry and damage the reputations of the firms and their managements. **********Setusya Tabuchi, the former chairman of Nomura, said a notorious gangster, Susumu Ishii, had originally been introduced to Nomura in 1986 by a known sokaiya, another type of gangster who specializes in corporate extortion. In spite of this questionable introduction, Mr. Ishii was quickly taken to meet the head of Nomura's sales department, Takehiko Matsuda, who personally handled his account.  A Memory Lapse **********Asked the name of the sokaiya, Mr. Tabuchi stirred a round of chuckles when he replied, "I'm embarrassed, but up until yesterday I remembered his name, while today it does not seem to come to mind." **********No bombshells were dropped at today's testimony. But the disclosures added weight to suspicions that the scandals involved longstanding patterns of behavior in the Japanese stock market and not one-time ethical lapses. **********There was an air of drama because the hearings were the first at which sworn testimony had been taken since former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone testified during the Recruit influence-peddling scandal on May 25, 1989. In that episode, a number of top politicians were implicated, and Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita was forced to resign, underscoring how devastating the current series of scandals has been for the credibility of Japan's stock market and financial industry.  Following the Money Trail **********It was disclosed earlier that Nomura, the world's largest brokerage house, and Nikko, the third-largest, had each provided through affiliates more than $100 million in financing to Mr. Ishii. Part of the financing was provided by purchasing what they knew to be worthless memberships in a country club controlled by Mr. Ishii, who reportedly used the money in a share manipulation scheme involving the Tokyu Corporation, a large railroad and real estate concern. **********The Justice Ministry has said there is a criminal investigation under way on whether Nomura conspired with Mr. Ishii to manipulate Tokyu's share price. **********Mr. Tabuchi added that Nomura had acquired the worthless golf club memberships from Mr. Ishii's country club without even looking at the place, seemingly confirming suspicions that the transaction was intended to conceal an improper payment to the mob.  An Accusation Denied **********Mr. Tabuchi flatly denied manipulation had taken place, even though the price of Tokyu shares soared after Nomura issued a buy recommendation on the stock through its brokerage network last October. Before the recommendation was issued Nomura had helped Mr. Ishii acquire several million shares. **********The Finance Ministry has ruled that no securities firm can account for more than 30 percent of the trading in any individual stock. Mr. Tabuchi admitted in his testimony that Nomura had exceeded the limit in Tokyu for a few days last October, but said the firm had not broken the letter of the law, which prohibits exceeding 30 percent averaged over a month.  Visit to a Gangster's Home **********Takuya Iwasaki, who was forced to resign as Nikko's president as a result of the scandal, said Nikko had had dealings with Mr. Ishii since 1986. Nikko also gave him high-level service, handling his account out of its head office, Mr. Iwasaki said. He added that Nikko had no idea Mr. Ishii was a yakuza member -- that is, a member of an organized crime group -- until the summer of 1987, when a Nikko official visited him at his home, outside of Tokyo. **********"Either in July or August an official in charge of Mr. Ishii called on his house in Yokosuka and reported that the atmosphere was very unusual," Mr. Iwasaki testified, drawing laughter from the chamber. **********Both executives said that the top executives of their firms had explicitly approved paying the improper compensation to cover market losses for a select group of clients. Both insisted that the compensation had been paid at the instigation of the brokerage houses, not the customers. The heads of the second- and fourth-largest securities firms in the world, Daiwa Securities and Yamaichi Securities, are scheduled to testify before the panel later. Both firms have admitted to paying similar compensations to clients.

The companies' business overlaps in many cities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/24/busin.body_text: **********The Pennzoil Company said yesterday that it had completed an agreement with a Russian enterprise to develop an oilfield in western Siberia with an estimated 40 million to 45 million barrels of recoverable reserves, plus 30 billion to 35 billion cubic feet of natural gas and gas liquids. **********Work will begin early next year in the West Mogotlorsk field, according to the company, and will involve the drilling of about 50 wells. The project will use Russian drilling rigs and American technology, according to Robert Harper, a spokesman for Pennzoil, which is in Houston. **********Mr. Harper would not say how much Pennzoil would invest or what the likely rate of production would be. **********The field is within a mile of the Trans-Siberian oil pipeline, and production will be exported for hard currency from Baltic or Black Sea ports, according to Pennzoil, which will keep 50 percent of the proceeds. **********The Russian partner is the Agansk Geological Enterprise, based in Novoagansk. **********Pennzoil announced earlier this month that it would seek more oil and gas exploration outside the United States. **********The price of Pennzoil shares rose 12.5 cents each, to $52.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/08/busin.body_text: **********Consumer credit fell at a 4 percent annual rate in January, the Government reported today. It was the steepest plunge in four years as recession and war curbed personal spending. **********The Federal Reserve said consumer installment debt dropped a seasonally adjusted $2.44 billion, the biggest percentage decline since it fell 5 percent in February 1987. **********It followed a revised six-tenths of 1 percent slip in December for the first back-to-back decline since a three-month string of losses that began in December 1986. **********The $342 million drop in December was the first decline since a two-tenths of 1 percent dip in February 1989. December debt was reported earlier to have decreased at a 2.3 percent rate, to $1.45 billion. Finances Consumer Spending **********Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages and home-equity debt. It is tracked closely since it helps finance much of the spending by consumers, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. **********In recent months, the Persian Gulf war has eroded consumer confidence and the recession has reduced jobs and income. As a result, consumer spending fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January, its biggest drop since a 1.3 percent decline in January 1987, the Commerce Department reported. Retail sales were down nine-tenths of 1 percent, including the second consecutive 4.4 percent monthly drop in automobile sales. **********Major retailers reported yesterday that buyers continued to avoid their stores in February, making that typically slow month even slower. **********But although the recession persists, some economists have reported signs of improvement in some areas of the economy since consumer confidence plunged to a 10-year low in January as the Persian Gulf war broke out. **********Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress on Wednesday that after the end of the war, traffic picked up in real estate offices and auto showrooms, raising "the possibility that stronger consumer demand may be emerging." **********But in January, consumers had backed off. Auto loans, which had fallen for six months until picking up at a three-tenths of 1 percent rate in November and 3.6 percent in December, dropped again -- down a sharp 8.2 percent, or a seasonally adjusted $1.95 billion. **********Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate plummeted 14.7 percent, or $2.63 billion, following a 5.8 percent gain a month earlier. **********Consumers reached again for their credit cards, however, increasing revolving credit by a 7 percent rate, or $1.27 billion. Revolving credit had fallen by 8.3 percent in December. **********Borrowing for mobile homes erased a 37.4 percent rate of decline in December by jumping 47.8 percent in January, or $868 million.
