https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/world.main_headline: Reporter's Notebook; Couch Gives Peace Talks A Distinction
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/world.print_headline: Reporter's Notebook; Couch Gives Peace Talks A Distinction
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/world.body_text: **********Elyakim Rubinstein, who described himself the other day as the last refugee of the 1978 Camp David peace process, was back in Washington this week leading an Israeli team negotiating with Palestinians and Jordanians. He says Camp David taught him patience. It didn't prepare him to be a couch diplomat. **********Mr. Rubinstein, a man with a wry sense of humor, says that what will be recalled most about the inconclusive round of Middle East peace talks that ended Wednesday night in Washington will be a sofa. **********"Though it was not photographed, I think it will be the couch that will be remembered," he told reporters before returning to Jerusalem. "You know we have had all kinds of diplomacy -- walk-in-the-woods diplomacy, Ping-Pong diplomacy, proximity talks. Now you'll have sofa diplomacy, or couch diplomacy." **********The bright blue sofa in a State Department corridor was where Mr. Rubinstein and his Jordanian and Palestinian counterparts spent 30 hours of procedural wrangling, unable to agree whether the Jordanians and Palestinians were one delegation or two, the hurdle that blocked the door to the conference room. Progress and Publicity **********Today President Bush, talking to foreign reporters, said he was disappointed with the results of the talks between Israel and Syria and Lebanon as well as Palestinians. The talks are tentatively scheduled to resume during the week of Jan. 7, but the location is still undecided. A full conference of all parties is planned for Moscow at the end of January. **********"I felt that a lot of time was spent talking of modalities and locations, and obviously we would have liked to see more progress," the President said of this round. **********Israeli and Arab officials noted that they were no match for the William Kennedy Smith trial in getting television coverage. **********"We were third tonight," a diplomat was heard muttering, "Behind the rape and the Russians." Spotlight on the Urbane **********Although Israeli-Syrian and Israeli-Lebanese delegations were able to sit down around conference tables in the hope of starting work on full-fledged peace treaties, they soon became stalled, allowing the full glare of the spotlight to fall on the Palestinians in the corridor. Within a few days, the Palestinian spokeswoman, Hanan Ashrawi, a professor of English literature, was setting the daily press agenda at her brisk news conferences at the Grand Hotel. The hotel staff, getting into the spirit of reconciliation, had decorated the Christmas trees in the conference room with white doves of peace. **********"We are the Palestinians and we are at the core of the conflict," Mrs. Asrawi said of Israeli efforts to subsume them in a Jordanian or pan-Arab identity. "If you ignore us, we will not go away." **********At their briefings an hour later each day, the Israelis were forced to react to Palestinian accounts of events and daily reports of crippling curfews and evictions in the West Bank and the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Silwan. Benjamin Netanyahu, the official Israeli spokesman, complained of negotiating in sound bites in "a media town." **********Since the peace process began, Mrs. Ashrawi and the delegation leader, Haidar Abdel-Shafi, a doctor, have given the Palestinians a new international image of elegant urbanity. The Israelis, while welcoming the change, offered reporters daily reminders of the radical side of the movement that was nowhere to be seen or heard in Washington. Precision English **********In banter as well as negotiations, the language of the Middle East peace process has been and continues to be English, although many members of the various delegations were qualified to communicate in French or Arabic or Hebrew. A leading Arab diplomat said English was chosen at the outset as a neutral language understood by all. **********"It is also an excellent language for diplomacy," he said. "There is very much scope for precise expression." **********Ghosts hovered over the Washington talks. Israelis saw "Syrians in the air" above the Lebanese delegation, a reference to Damascus's military presence in Lebanon. The Palestinians conjured up pictures of the curfew-bound people of the West Bank and the homeless of Silwan, calling them "hostages in a gigantic prison." A Quirk in History **********If one topic was aired more than any other in a week of talks about talks, it was where the next round of negotiations should go. Israel has persistently demanded that future rounds of bilateral talks with neighbors be held in the Middle East. **********There have been some creative explanations for that. Communications are better close to home, the Israelis say. The telephones and offices are wonderful here, counter the Arabs. Well, it is the ability to discuss nuances with Government leaders that's missing, retort the Israelis. **********An Arab delegate who has watched the debate over the location of talks from the sidelines said he was struck by history turned on its head. **********"The Arabs prefer to meet here for many reasons," he said. "But my God, can you imagine the Israelis not wanting to come to Washington!"

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/busin.body_text: **********India's Commerce Minister announced today that his Government had approved two joint ventures between American multinationals and local companies, and preliminary plans for two others. **********The minister, Palaniappan Chidambaram, said India had given final approval for a joint venture by I.B.M. and the Indian conglomerate Tata Industries to produce I.B.M. Personal System 2 computers and computer programs, and by the Indian auto maker Maruti Ltd. and the Ford Motor Company to produce aluminum radiators for cars. **********The International Business Machines Corporation is returning to the Indian market after the company left in 1977 in response to a law limiting foreign ownership to 40 percent. The bitter dispute was a landmark in efforts by third world countries to limit the influence of multinational corporations. Change in the Law **********A new law that took effect on July 24 provides for the automatic approval of foreign stakes up to 51 percent, and an accelerated approval process for foreign companies seeking higher stakes, Mr. Chidambaram said. The Indian Government has eased restrictions on foreign investment as part of a broader strategy of reducing the Government's role in the economy and reducing India's reliance on bank loans to finance economic growth, the minister said. **********India is struggling with a large trade deficit, continuing trade disputes with the United States and a $69 billion foreign debt. On Friday a group of international lenders led by the World Bank endorsed the Government's economic stabilization plan, which calls for a 23 percent devaluation of the rupee and smaller budget deficits, and increased assistance to India. **********But Ajay S. Kapur, an economist at the WEFA Group, an economic consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said that India still faced formidable problems in attracting foreign investment. India's reputation for low manufacturing wages is an illusion because of low productivity, steadily rising government salaries and powerful unions with close ties to political parties, he said. **********"One shouldn't think of India as a land of multitudinous landless laborers waiting to be hired to make transistors," he said, while adding that engineers, software programmers and other professionals were often paid far less in India than in the West.  Few Investments Come In **********India attracted only $70 million worth of foreign investment last year, compared with $480 million even in the Philippines, Mr. Kapur said. **********Mr. Chidambaram is on a five-day visit to the United States to woo American businesses and discuss trade issues with the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills. But the Indian Commerce Minister said he had not discussed the United States' investigation of charges that India allows the piracy of American patents, copyrights and trademarks. The four-month-old investigation could lead to trade sanctions on Nov. 26. **********The Indian Government has also approved preliminary plans by the General Motors Corporation and Hindustan Motors Ltd. to build cars and automobile parts, and for the Kellogg Company to set up a breakfast cereal factory and sell stock to local investors, the minister said. **********Richard E. Lovell, a spokesman for Kellogg, which is based in Battle Creek, Mich., said India's growing middle class and strong domestic transportation and distribution network had attracted the company. "We see India as a good-potential, long-term-growth market," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/world.main_headline: White House Moves to End Feud at Information Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/world.print_headline: White House Moves to End Feud at Information Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/world.body_text: **********The White House has asked the director of the United States Information Agency, Bruce Gelb, to step down and accept the post of Ambassador to Belgium, Administration officials said today. **********The move, the officials said, is intended to defuse a bureaucratic feud between Mr. Gelb and the director of the Voice of America, Richard W. Carlson. **********An Administration official said Mr. Gelb, a former Bristol-Myers executive, had accepted the offer from President Bush on Jan. 14. Other Administration officials said Mr. Gelb had agreed only on condition that Mr. Carlson, whom he perceived as a rival, was removed too. **********The information agency, with about 8,800 employees, conducts information and education exchanges with foreign countries. The Voice of America, whose charter gives it editorial independence, has been semi-autonomous in recent years. It has 2,800 employees, making it the largest component of the information agency. Both Presidential Appointees **********The current question, as one official put it, is "whether there should be a double decapitation." Mr. Gelb, who is 64 years old, has told friends that White House aides have told him that Mr. Carlson, 49, would leave the broadcasting service soon. **********The Gelb-Carlson feud started 11 months ago when the agency chief tried unsuccessfully to fire the Voice of America director. He also failed last summer to persuade the White House to oust Mr. Carlson, who like him is a presidential appointee. **********"I think there is bad blood on both sides," said an official who described herself as a friend of Mr. Gelb. **********Their disputes escalated in December, when Mr. Gelb announced a vast reorganization plan, transferring budget and personnel authority from the Voice of America to his agency and, in effect, shrinking the broadcasting service's independence. Although he firmly asserted that he had "adequately consulted" Mr. Carlson on the changes, he later admitted that he had not consulted him. **********That action riled the White House and members of Congressional oversight committees, who were not consulted either, and both subsequently signaled the agency director that he should freeze the plan. **********The action also caused rebellion at the Voice of America, where Mr. Carlson enjoys considerable support. That support was reflected in an unsual forum convened on Jan. 7 by Mr. Gelb against the advice of the White House and Mr. Carlson.  Meeting With Employees **********The agency director, facing about 500 Voice of America employees in their main auditorium, explained his reorganization plan as means of dealing with a tight budget. There were scattered boos, hissing and derisive laughter. He then acknowledged differences with Mr. Carlson, describing him as a "strong manager," and adding, "I am not a pantywaist myself." Employees there are now wearing "I am not a pantywaist" buttons, mocking Mr. Gelb. **********Senior Administration officials said that the White House found this and other incidents involving Mr. Gelb that had become public to be embarrassing and that this had contributed to the decision to remove him. **********One widely publicized incident concerned his request last year that the Federal Bureau of Investigation examine a sofa in his office because he suspected two employees of having used it for a tryst. No evidence was found. **********A second incident occurred on Jan. 17, when Mr. Gelb requested that the F.B.I. sweep his office for electronic listening devices. None were found. An aide said the F.B.I. action had been part of a Government-wide sweep. The F.B.I. subsequently said the sweep had been conducted only in Mr. Gelb's office and had been done in response to a single request. **********Neither Mr. Gelb's office nor Mr. Carlson's office had public comment on the White House plans for their future postings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.main_headline: American Pilots Anticipate Tough but Brief Battle
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: THE FIGHTER AIRCRAFT; American Pilots Anticipate Tough but Brief Battle
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.body_text: **********Despite their powerful advantage in numbers and equipment, American fighter pilots expect a difficult fight in the now seemingly inevitable war with Iraq. **********With the possible onset of hostilities only hours away, the air forces of the United States and its allies were making last-minute preparations today for an assault intended to smooth the way for ground forces. **********In the opening phase of the war, allied commanders are banking on the success of their air forces in destroying many key military objectives, including missile launchers, command centers and air bases. Commanders expect that this process might be completed in several days, but say nothing is certain. **********A key to the performance of the strike aircraft that will attack ground targets is the ability of allied fighter planes to keep Iraqi Air Force fighter planes at bay.  Allied Advantage in Aircraft **********A senior United States Air Force commander said that the allied fighter pilots and their planes will quickly achieve control of the skies. The allied fighter force outnumbers its Iraqi counterpart by at least two to one, and the disparity becomes even greater if older-model Iraqi planes are discounted. **********Pilots regard Iraq's French-built Mirage F-1 fighters, which are flown by Baghdad's best pilots, as the main threat. According to the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies, Iraq has about 30 Mirages, as well as about 30 Soviet-built MIG-29's, among the best fighters in the world. **********The United States Air Force has several hundred fighter aircraft in Saudi Arabia, many of them F-15's, which experts consider a match for any opponent. Depending on tactical decisions made by American commanders, hundreds of attack and fighter aircraft are available from the Marine Corps and the Navy, which has stationed three large aircraft carriers in the Persian Gulf or the Arabian Sea, including the Midway, Saratoga and John F. Kennedy, and has three other carrier groups on the way or already on station. The Saudi, British and French fighter contingents contribute additional fighter planes. American Pilots Expect Losses **********Despite this overwhelming armada of combat aircraft, few American fighter pilots expect the allies to escape unscathed. **********"In general, the advantages are all on our side," one said. "But if a couple of our fighters suddenly found themselves up against 20 or 30 enemy fighters, even old MIG-21's, we certainly wouldn't get all 30 of them, and some of them would probably score hits on us." **********American pilots will try to attack their Iraqi foes with long-range radar-guided missiles without getting close enough to have to use short-range heat-seeking missiles or their 20-millimeter Gatling guns. **********"We never want to be close enough that we can actually see our adversary," a pilot said. "If we can see him, we're in his range."  Iraqi Planes Have Missiles **********But the Iraqi Air Force also has French- and Soviet-built radar-guided missiles, so Iraqi pilots do not necessarily need to come within sight of allied planes to be a threat. **********Despite the international composition of the air forces arrayed against Iraq, both attack aircraft and fighters are now well practiced in coordinating their actions, an officer said. **********For each mission, representatives of the air forces of all participating nations meet in committee to work out details of an "air tasking order," he said, deciding on the combat roles of each unit, its targets, weapons and courses, the radio frequencies and recognition signals that will be used, and many other details. The Air Force jargon for this process is "deconflicting." **********When American and allied forces began arriving here after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, one of the major military concerns was about the possibility of a chaotic breakdown in command and coordination between the various forces. Despite many initial difficulties, practice has smoothed out most potential problems, an officer said.  Coordination Problems for Iraq **********The officer said the Iraqis may have major coordination problems, with a strong likelihood that their missile crews could shoot down their own planes. **********"They certainly did that during the war they fought with Iran," the officer said, "and it's likely they would have the same problems here." **********Allied commanders here expect Iraq to fire their big ground-to-ground missiles at air bases and other targets, but key bases are well-protected by Patriot anti-missile missiles, an officer said. "A few of the Iraqi Scud-B missiles might get through, but the Patriots should get most of them," a commander said. **********American officers note with satisfaction that Iraq faces the special problem of having to prepare for a war on three fronts, against Turkey, Israel and the joint forces in Saudi Arabia. "His air force as well as his army will be spread pretty thin," the officer said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/world.main_headline: Official and 18 Others Die in Sri Lanka Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/world.print_headline: Official and 18 Others Die in Sri Lanka Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/03/world.body_text: **********A car bomb exploded today on a busy street and killed the head of the Government campaign against Tamil separatists along with at least 18 other people, officials and witnesses said. About 73 people were wounded. **********The bomb went off in a parked car about 8:30 A.M., in the morning rush hour, killing Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne as he rode by, the witnesses and officials said. The others killed included police bodyguards and bystanders. **********Officials had said earlier that at least 30 people had died."I saw human hands and legs strewn all over and a number of vehicles ablaze," said Nimal Piyasiri, the owner of a nearby hotel. "It was awful." No Claim of Responsibility **********No one immediately claimed responsibility, but the police said they suspected insurgents of the Tamil ethnic minority. Mr. Wijeratne had overseen the drive against the Tamils, who are fighting for an independent homeland in the country's north and east. But other members of the police told Reuters that besides the Tamil rebels, possible suspects included insurgents among the majority Sinhalese ethnic group and even casino owners, whose alleged illegal activities Mr. Wijeratne had been investigating. **********A spokesman for the Tamil insurgents, based in London, said he did not know if his group was responsible. **********"If it was done by our cadres, we will say we were responsible," the spokesman, Sathasivan Krishnakumar, said in a telephone interview. "Right now, I don't know anything about it." **********The rebel group, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, has claimed responsibility in the past for two bomb attacks in Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital. A car bomb set off by the group in 1987 killed 125 people, and another blast two months later left 50 people dead. **********Mr. Wijeratne, who was 60 years old, had a reputation as a tough and often abrasive administrator. He acted as the Government's minister for plantations and industry in addition to his other duties. Vowed to Crush Insurrection **********Last month, he announced the start of the army offensive to capture the Tamil rebel headquarters in the northern Jaffna Peninsula. The offensive has bogged down in the dense jungles south of Jaffna, but Mr. Wijeratne had vowed to crush the insurrection. **********The minister was also responsible for putting down an anti-Government campaign launched by ultranationalist Sinhalese in 1987.Tamil militants have been fighting since 1983 for a homeland in Sri Lanka, an island off the southern tip of India. They assert that their predominantly Hindu community, which makes up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, is discriminated against by the mostly Buddhist Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of the population and control the Government and the military. Mr. Wijeratne was Sinhalese. **********The war between the Government and the militants has been fierce since June, when the Tamil separatists broke a 13-month cease-fire. **********At least 14,000 people have been killed since the rebels began their campaign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/09/busin.body_text: **********Japan will limit its car exports to the United States to 2.3 million again in the fiscal year beginning on April 1, the Kyodo News Service reported today. **********It would be the 10th straight year of voluntary curbs since Japan agreed to them in 1981 under strong pressure from the United States Government and American car makers, then seeking to retrench and restructure. **********But an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry's automobile department, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Government was still studying whether to extend the export restraints. **********"We will make an announcement after it is finally decided," said the official, who noted that the announcement on the current fiscal year's curbs was made in mid-January of last year. **********In 1981, Japan agreed to limit its annual exports to the United States to 1.68 million vehicles through 1983. **********When President Ronald Reagan decided not to ask for continued restraints in 1985, Japan set the ceiling at 2.3 million a year and has maintained it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/10/busin.main_headline: Patents; A Desk That Ends Computer-Age Clutter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/10/busin.print_headline: Patents; A Desk That Ends Computer-Age Clutter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Sadeg M. Faris is waging war against what he calls "office environment pollution," the tangled cltter of telephones, computers and straggling cords that occupy much of the desktop space in today's offices. **********"There is desktop everything," complained the inventor, a Libyan-born computer scientist and entrepreneur who lives in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. "You have a desktop fax, a desktop printer, desktop computer, desktop phone." **********Mr. Faris recently patented a sleek desk with a full array of built-in electronics. The equipment pops out easily when needed and can be moved out of sight when a a clean working surface is needed. **********The desk also does away with the familiar nest of wires behind many desks, featuring an internal "mother board" that distributes power to each piece of equipment. As a result, the desk features only two external cords, one for power and one for telephone lines. **********Mr. Faris acknowledged that the built-in electronics made it difficult for customers to change equipment once they had bought their desk, but he said many people would feel morethan compensated by the relief from confusion. **********He received patent 5,033,804.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/world.body_text: **********Hoping to put an end to an ugly political debate charged by allegations of racism, British Conservatives in western England have agreed to unite behind a black barrister as their candidate for the House of Commons. **********At a conference in Cheltenham, a fashionable spa city of 81,000 in the Cotswolds, members of the local Conservative Party on Sunday overwhelmingly rejected an attempt by party dissidents to overthrow the candidacy of John Taylor, a 38-year-old adviser to the Home Office on racial issues. **********If he wins in the next election, Mr. Taylor would become the first nonwhite Conservative member of Parliament, according to a Conservative Party spokeswoman. The national elections are to be held sometime before the middle of 1992. **********In backing Mr. Taylor by a vote of 406 to 104, the Cheltenham Conservatives resolved what could have been a serious embarrassment for Prime Minister John Major. He was elected leader of the Conservative Party in November, espousing a vision of a "classless society" with equal opportunity for all. **********After Mr. Taylor was first named as the choice of the Cheltenham Conservative Association in December, a small but highly visibile group objected vehemently. One man, who was later expelled from the party, was widely described in the press here as calling Mr. Taylor "a bloody nigger." Not From Cheltenham **********The group passed a petition forcing the party to reopen the selection process. They argued that Mr. Taylor was not from Cheltenham, an almost wholly white community, but from Solihull, a racially mixed district in the industrial Midlands. They contended that they were not opposed to Mr. Taylor on the basis of his race. **********Members of the House of Commons often are not residents of the constituency they represent. **********"This is the right decision, overwhelmingly reached," Mr. Major said of the local party endorsement. Mr. Taylor was chosen to run for the seat held by Sir Charles Irving, a Conservative, who will retire. **********After the ballot, Bob Williams, a Cheltenham businessman who had opposed the choice of Mr. Taylor, said he would now work on his behalf. **********Of the 650 members of the House of Common, 4 are non-white, all members of the Labor Party. About 4.5 percent of Britain's population is nonwhite.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/22/busin.body_text: **********Airline travel remained light in April despite the end of the Persian Gulf war, the International Air Transport Association said today. **********Scheduled international passenger traffic of the association's 200 members was 11 percent lower in April than a year earlier -- only a slight improvement on the 14 percent drop in the first three months of the year. **********Travel had declined by 15 percent in March, 26 percent in February and 6 percent in January. For the first four months of the year, international passenger traffic was down 13 percent. **********Initial indications are that passenger traffic may have recovered somewhat in May, an association official said. **********Freight traffic dropped by 4 percent in April from a year earlier. It had been down 2 percent in January, 1 percent in February and 3 percent in March.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; KURDISH LEADERS INSPECT IRAQI CITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/world.body_text: **********American and Iraqi officers took two Kurdish guerrilla leaders to inspect the city of Dohuk today in a sign of a possible deal that could coax hundreds of thousands of reluctant refugees down from the Turkish mountains. **********Dohuk, a provincial capital just south of the zone occupied by American, British, French and other allied troops, has emerged as an important issue in recent days. While many refugees are pouring back into the allied-controlled area, the bulk of the Kurds who had fled to the eastern mountains are from Dohuk and its surroundings, and they fear to return to the city while any Iraqi security forces remain there. **********American field commanders, whose mission in Iraq is to coax the refugees out of Turkish territory and back to their homes, have recommended expanding the allied zone to include Dohuk. But officials in Washington are said to be reluctant to undertake such a move over Iraqi objections, fearing that it would increase the chances that American forces will be stuck in the area for months or years. **********The idea for some form of compromise was raised on Thursday by Maj. Gen. Abu Firas Saber of the Iraqi Army in a meeting requested by the Iraqis to find a way to avoid an allied takeover of Dohuk. **********Col. Richard Naab, one of the American negotiators, said the Iraqi general reported that giving up the city, the gateway to the Tigris River valley and a major highway running all the way to Baghdad, would be "really embarrassing." **********"It would be a bit more of an insult to their soverignty," Colonel Naab said. "They were concerned about our tearing down the existing institutions of government. It's a provincial capital. This could send the wrong signal to their own population." **********He said General Saber had "proposed a couple of ideas we're kind of attracted to." **********The colonel did not spell out the Iraqi proposals, but he hinted that one possibility might be that a smaller European nation, such as Spain, might take some responsibility for Dohuk, adding, "I wouldn't rule out necessarily all elements of the coalition." **********Another possibility, he suggested, might be leaving what he described as "a viable Iraqi police force" in the city with "someone supervising them."  Refugee Flow Accelerates **********"The idea here is an Iraqi solution, and then we'd be ahead of the game," he said. "The key issue is what is going to be satisfying for the Kurds." **********The unannounced visit of the Kurdish guerrilla leaders to Iraqi-controlled Dohuk came as the flow of tens of thousands of Kurdish refugees out of the squalid Turkish mountain camps accelerated, overflowing the tent city the Americans have set up here. **********By dusk, Isikveren, a refugee center in Turkey that at its peak held perhaps 100,000 people, was down to only about 3,000 inhabitants, Special Forces officers bringing the refugees down said. **********But at Cukurca to the east, where most of the 100,000 refugees are from Dohuk and the surrounding villages, almost no one had left for Iraq. It is the refugees at Cukurca and the nearby camp of Uzumlu who are now the main concern of American military planners. **********The key to whether the Kurds choose to return home, American military and aid officials agree, is, as several put it, "their perception of security." **********Two Kurdish guerrillas planned to fly by helicopter to Cukurca this evening after they toured Dohuk, an American military spokesman said. The evident intention was for the guerrillas to vouch for the safety of Dohuk and urge the refugees to return. The spokesman said the trip had been organized under United Nations auspices.                    --------------------       Rebel Meets Hussein **********BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 11 (Reuters) -- President Saddam Hussein met today with Mr. Barzani for the second time since Baghdad began talks with the heads of Kurdish organizations. **********A state-run Kurdish newspaper said talks between the Government and the Kurds on a new autonomy pact could end in agreement within two days. **********The official Iraqi press agency said President Hussein met with Mr. Barzani, the main guerrilla commander of the Kurdish Democratic Party.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.main_headline: SRI LANKA BATTERS LAST REBEL GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.print_headline: SRI LANKA BATTERS LAST REBEL GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.body_text: **********Using ground troops and planes, the Sri Lankan Army appears to be battering a thinly stretched Tamil guerrilla army all across the northern tier of this island nation. **********The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the best equipped, the most disciplined and the last of insurgent groups fighting Colombo, is responding with suicidal frontal attacks, some involving children, Sri Lanka's Defense Secretary says. **********Casualties on both sides are high. The Defense Secretary, Cyril Ranatunge, says more than 950 guerrillas and about 180 troops have died since mid-March. **********The Tigers, who inexplicably resumed their war with Colombo in June 1990 after 14 months of peace and negotiations with President Ranasinghe Premadasa that left them in virtual control of large areas of the north, significantly eroded their support among the Tamils of the Jaffna Peninsula, the militants' base, when they resumed fighting. Tigers Called Fascists **********A recent report by the increasingly bold University Teachers for Human Rights at Jaffna University say the militants "calculatedly left the Tamils at the mercy of enraged Sri Lankan forces." The teachers are the only group of Tamil intellectuals willing to attack the Tigers in strong language, calling them "fascists" for their heavy-handed treatment of people in their areas of control. **********The group says the Tigers want bodies for propaganda purposes abroad. The university teachers are asking that Tamils overseas stop contributing to the Tiger cause. They also ask international human rights organizations to discredit the claims of "degenerate" liberation groups. **********Taking advantage of Indian preoccupation with a national election and a relatively powerless caretaker Government in New Delhi, the Sri Lankan Army can hit the Tamil Tigers almost as hard as it wants without incurring Indian intervention. In 1987, a similar campaign against the Tamils led to Indian airdrops of supplies over Jaffna in violation of Sri Lankan airspace, and ultimately the introduction of an Indian peacekeeping force. **********India has more than 55 million Tamils in the state of Tamil Nadu, and political parties often make the plight of Sri Lankan Tamils into state or national issues. Indian troops were in the end humiliated by the Tigers and disliked by the Jaffna Tamils. Indians Left in 1990 **********They found that a guerrilla war could not be fought with conventional tactics. Prime Minister V. P. Singh brought the last troops home in early 1990. **********"There is no question of a military solution," General Ranatunge, the Defense Secretary, said in an interview, discounting the idea that a final offensive against the Tigers was now under way. "This is a political problem, and we want a political solution." **********"What this ministry is trying to do is to bring law and order to all parts of the country," he said, adding that areas of the east coast, where fighting was intense last year, were now relatively calm and that the army was concentrating on the north. **********In eastern Sri Lanka, the population is a mixture of Tamils, Sinhalese from the ethnic and linguistic majority and Muslims, who consider themselves a separate entity. The Tamil Tigers terrorized Muslims last year, forcing many to flee from the east and north. They form part of a displaced population of nearly 700,000. Up to 100,000 people more have fled abroad since fighting resumed last June. **********While the army presses its attacks on Tiger areas in the north, President Premadasa has reiterated his call for new talks, but has made it clear that this time he wants the elusive Tiger leader, Vellupillai Prabakaran, at the table. Talks in 1989 and 1990 were conducted through intermediaries. Military Stand Toughens **********The military is in no mood to give any ground this time. **********"We dismantled a lot of camps at the request of the L.T.T.E. at the conference table," General Ranatunge said. Within weeks, the Tigers simply took over bases, often forcing out residual companies of police officers left in charge when the army withdrew. **********To the Tamils of the Jaffna Peninsula, the renewed resolve of the Sri Lankan military means bombs, curfews and restrictions on every item of consumer goods that could possibly be used to manufacture weapons of any kind. The list is endless. **********"Both sides had ceased to battle for the hearts and minds of the people," the Jaffna University rights group wrote. "It was rather over their lives."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/busin.main_headline: One More Calamity in a Painful Decade for the Newspaper
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/busin.print_headline: One More Calamity in a Painful Decade for the Newspaper
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/06/busin.body_text: **********For people who have lived through the last painful decade at The Daily News, the sight of the editor, James P. Willse, trudging toward the center of the newsroom yesterday morning could only signal bad news. **********"These meetings aren't called frequently." said Andrew Kirtzman, a reporter at The News, "So you often go with a sense of dread." **********Robert Maxwell, Mr. Willse announced, the man who only months before had bought the 72-year-old tabloid and saved it from an almost certain demise, was reported missing from his yacht off the Canary Islands. Hours later, Mr. Maxwell's body was found in the Atlantic Ocean. **********For the newspaper's journalists and executives, Mr. Maxwell and his purchase of the paper earlier this year after a wrenching strike against the former owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago, was virtually the only bright spot in an otherwise miserable recent history. **********Years of financial losses had sapped the paper's strength. During the five-month strike, many of The News's workers were jobless and the future of the paper was in limbo. Then, 10 days ago, John Cotter, a new managing editor at The News, died of a heart attack the morning he was start. **********"I think we are all worried about what is going to happen to this paper," said Dean Chang, a reporter who covers transportation. "It's just been one calamity after another." **********Kevin Maxwell, one of Robert Maxwell's sons, was named publisher yesterday. **********Officially, optimism reigned. "We've been through so much in the last two weeks that we are kind of shell-shocked," said Matthew B. Storin, executive editor of The News. "And yet, because we are doing what we are always doing and getting reassurances from the family, we are confident that we are going to keep forging ahead." **********But as employees came and left the Art Deco-style Daily News building on East 42d Street between Second and Third Avenues, they said they had been dumbfounded by the reports about Robert Maxwell. Not only had they lost a savior of sorts, but they once again faced the uncertainty that has shadowed the tabloid. **********"We are all upset," said Pat Quintiliano, an accountant for the paper who stood in the building's lobby with three of his colleagues. "It's just shocking news. We don't know what to think." **********After Mr. Willse's morning announcement, reporters and other employees said, workers had continued their normal daily routines. But many people checked news service reports every few minutes and watching televised reports on CNN for updates about Robert Maxwell, a man who had won their appreciation if not their affection. **********"He came on the scene as a savior," said Don Singleton, a reporter who had served as a negotiator during the strike. "I can only hope his sons have the same kind of commitment to the paper that he had."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/03/world.main_headline: Pope Tries to Patch Schism of Poles and Ukrainians
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/03/world.print_headline: Pope Tries to Patch Schism of Poles and Ukrainians
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/03/world.body_text: **********When Pope John Paul II finished his sermon in this town near the Polish-Soviet border, he plunged into a crowd of Ukrainians who had waited for hours to glimpse the leader of a church they had kept alive clandestinely for a generation. **********Tears streamed down the faces of men and women, some of whom had only a rudimentary knowledge of the Roman Catholic religion. **********"I can now die -- I have seen the plenipotentiary of Christ and have kissed his hand," said Marita Iwanicka of Sambor, a Soviet town about one hour from here. "How happy I am that I came here today." **********Tens of thousands of Ukrainians were allowed to enter Poland without visas for the Pope's visit. The women wore kerchiefs, and the men carried the traditional black and gold icons of their church. Some of the 500,000 Ukrainians still living in Poland also returned today from the northern towns to which they had been deported.  Seeking to Calm a Dispute **********The Pope traveled to Przemysl, one of many cities in Eastern Europe where the demise of Communism has unleashed centuries-old antagonisms, to calm an increasingingly bitter dispute in Poland between Poles and Ukrainians. **********He was also clearly testing the waters for a first papal visit to the Soviet Union. The Pope today delivered some of his sermon in the Ukrainian language and promised more when "it will be given to me one day to come to Lvov," the capital of the western Ukraine. **********Church officials say there are more than five million Catholics living in the Ukraine. The followers of the church call themselves Greek-Catholics and pray with the same liturgy as the Eastern Orthodox. But their allegiance is to the Pope, which distinguishes them from the Russian Orthodox religion. **********A Soviet ban on the Catholic Church was lifted in December 1989 by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and since then the Western Ukraine has witnessed a powerful religious revival that has accompanied demands for national independence. **********Poles and Ukrainians in Przemysl share a Pope, but little else. Their heritage of hatred dates back centuries, and brutalities against Poles in World War II were followed by the forcible deportation of Ukrainians at the end of the war.  Dispute Over a Cathedral **********Most recently Przemysl has been torn by a sharp conflict over whether to donate one of the local cathedrals to the Ukrainians, who have no fixed place of worship. Poland's Catholic bishops approved a temporary transfer of the building for five years while a new church was constructed, but local Carmelite monks occupied the building, which served as a Ukraine church here from the 19th century until 1945. **********The Pope's scheduled stop at this church was canceled. But he delighted the Ukrainians by announcing that they would receive immediate title to a second church that sits just a few hundred yards from the disputed basilica. **********"Both our nations have passed through so much bitterness and torment during the last few decades," the Pope said in a homily that appeared to have broader resonance in a region increasingly torn by inter-ethnic violence. "May this experience also serve as absolution, soothing the memory of past conflicts, offenses and mutual distrust." **********"Any attempt to revive the historical nationalisms and aversions would be against Christian identity and a glaring anachronism, unworthy of two great nations," he continued. "Oh how fervently I wish that Catholics of both rites would love each other." **********Many of the Soviet pilgrims expressed hope that the Pope would soon play the same role in their drive for national independence as he had in his native Poland.  5,000 Travel From Lvov **********Jaroslaw Swatko, was among the 5,000 Ukrainians who traveled from Lvov to line the streets of Przemysl, which is only nine miles from the Soviet border. Mr. Swatko, a member of the Lvov city council, said he was thrilled at the chance to glimpse the leader of his church. **********"Of course I'm happy," he said. "For every citizen of the Soviet Union, it can be only one day in his life to see the Pope." **********"It will help our independence," Mr. Swatko continued. "But the visit of the Pope to Lvov would give us even more." **********Many of the Ukraianians from the Soviet Union and Poland grumbled about their treatment at the hands of the Poles, and complained about intolerance. Local Poles said there had been fights among Ukrainian and Polish schoolboys and other incidents. **********"There was no hostility on our side," said Mieczyslaw Mirowski, a member of the committee that organized the occupation of the church that was to be turned over to the Ukrainians. Mr. Mirowski said the protest had been suspended in honor of the Pope's visit, but said he was uncertain whether it would resume next week. **********Before the Pope reached Przemysl, he celebrated Mass in nearby Rzeszow and addressed soldiers in Koszalin, near the Baltic coast.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.main_headline: Sony and Philips End Rift Over Recording Formats
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.print_headline: Sony and Philips End Rift Over Recording Formats
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/10/busin.body_text: **********The Sony Corporation and Philips Consumer Electronics International said today that they were ending their bitter dispute over what technology should be used in the next generation of audio equipment and agreed to jointly license each other's two newest products. **********The agreement, announced in Tokyo today, appeared to be an effort to end the dispute over whether Sony's new mini-disk system or Philip's new digital compact cassette -- or DCC -- tape should prevail as an industry standard. The mini-disk, or MD, is a new size and format for compact disks. It would play on a Walkman-like personal stereo. Despite being half the size, MD has the same playing time of a conventional CD. But unlike conventional disks, MD can be "rewritten" -- meaning that it can record music, much as a tape does. **********DCC is a digital tape technology, with sound quality only slightly below that of compact disks. But ordinary tapes can also be played on a DCC player. **********Although Sony and Philips developed the compact disk together in the early 1980's, they have been unable to agree on the merits of MD versus DCC tape. Each company accused the other of confusing consumers with an array of new, incompatible technologies with only marginal audio improvement. But today the companies said that they would jointly license the MD technology as Philips is already licensing DCC to other manufacturers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/world.main_headline: U.S. to Open an M.I.A. Office in Hanoi
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/world.print_headline: U.S. to Open an M.I.A. Office in Hanoi
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/world.body_text: **********The United States has agreed to establish its first official presence in Vietnam, President Bush's special envoy for humanitarian affairs said here today. **********The official, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., in a statement issued with the Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, said Washington would establish a temporary office in Hanoi to resolve cases of American soldiers who were listed as missing in action or taken prisoner during the Vietnam War. But differences over Cambodia continue to stand in the way of opening normal relations, American officials say. **********"In keeping with the discussions we had in Washington, we agreed that the United States would establish a P.O.W.-M.I.A. field office in Hanoi on a temporary basis," General Vessey said. **********Reading the statement after two days of talks with Mr. Thach, he said both Governments wanted to normalize relations and would continue talks on the subject. **********"Minister Thach and General Vessey both reaffirmed their Governments' desire to normalize relations and agreed on the importance of continuing discussions to resolve differences between them," the statement said. "They agreed that it would be useful for them to meet again, at a date to be determined." **********But Mr. Thach gave a noncommittal answer when asked by reporters whether he had agreed to a plan presented by the United States, under which Washington would normalize relations with Hanoi in exchange for Vietnam's cooperation in insuring that a United Nations peace plan succeeded in Cambodia. **********"I have not accepted and I have not rejected," he said. **********General Vessey and Mr. Thach were officially meeting about the war prisoners and those missing in action, an issue that the Bush Administration also sees as an obstacle to normalization. **********It wants Hanoi to help account for 2,278 American soldiers who are listed as missing, were taken prisoner, or are known to have been killed in Indochina, including 1,661 in Vietnam. **********The joint statement said General Vessey had expressed American appreciation for Vietnam's cooperation in improving efforts to resolve the issue. **********"At the same time, General Vessey expressed the hope that even further progress and greater results can be obtained in the future," the statement said. **********Washington says the biggest stumbling block to normalization is the Cambodian dispute. It wants Hanoi to make its ally in Phnom Penh back the United Nations peace plan, which provides for disarmament of Cambodia's army and of guerrilla groups before elections. **********Western diplomats said the American delegation expected a response from Mr. Thach to a four-phase plan presented in Washington last week to Vietnam's United Nations delegate. **********Under the American "road map" to normalization, Vietnam would virtually have to insure peace in Cambodia before the United States would normalize relations. **********The United Nations plan would have to be carried out, Cambodia's warring factions disarmed, elections held and a national assembly formed before full relations were established with Vietnam. **********Western diplomats in Hanoi said that Washington was demanding too much of Vietnam and that Hanoi officials were discouraged over short-term prospects for normalizing ties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/world.main_headline: Union of Soviet Writers Is Also Breaking Apart
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/world.print_headline: THE SOVIET TRANSITION; Union of Soviet Writers Is Also Breaking Apart
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/world.body_text: **********The failed hard-line coup and its aftermath have thrown the Soviet literary world into turmoil, with those who earn their living by the pen spending most of their time crossing swords instead. **********As during so much of Russian history since Peter the Great, the intelligentsia is split between Russophile conservatives who favor strong law-and-order measures to keep their country from being overwhelmed by Western influence, and pro-Western reformers who want to jerk their country into the present no matter what the price to traditional values. **********Today the split among writers became formal, with the pro-conservative Russian Federation Writers' Union declaring independence from the Soviet Writers' Union, an umbrella group originally set up by Stalin to keep scribblers in line and reward those who obeyed with state-provided dachas and other benefits. **********Until now, the Russian federation writers' group has been a part of the nationwide union, which after the coup elected a new leadership controlled by what the Russian federation writers call left, liberal or progressive writers who view their Russian federation colleagues as chauvinistic reactionaries.  Writers Who Seldom Wrote **********Some "writers" under the old system seldom wrote anything, and none had to worry much about how many books they sold. The future of subsidies for literary bureaucrats when Soviet publishing goes fully commercial, a day rapidly approaching, is another underlying issue. **********"Things are approaching the point where every writer is going to have to answer the categorical question, 'Are you with us or them, for the reds or the whites?' " Irina Strelkova said today in the weekly Literaturnaya Rossiya. **********The politics are increasingly vicious and personal. The conservatives, who include such well-known writers as Yuri Bondarev and Valentin Rasputin, accuse their foes of an illegal takeover of the Soviet writers' organization last month after the coup, and they have named the poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko as the main organizer. **********Mr. Yevtushenko and his allies, in turn, accuse the other writers of taking public positions that had the effect of encouraging the coup plotters, who tried to use tanks and troops to overthrow President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********At the end of last month, Mr. Yevtushenko was elected vice president of the Soviet Writers' Union by members disgusted with the previous executives' failure to issue a statement condemning the coup while it was under way Aug. 19-21. **********He then pointed an accusing finger at the conservatives in the Russian union. "We must not leave such people morally unpunished," he said, urging the police to seal the Russian Federation Writers' Union's neoclassical headquarters building on Komsomolsky Prospekt and seize the property for the forces of democracy. **********After a sit-in by the angry conservative writers prevented the militia from seizing the building, a Moscow City Hall official came by, apologized and called off the siege. In More Conciliatory Mood **********Now, in a somewhat more conciliatory mood, Mr. Yevtushenko and other liberal leaders of the Soviet Writers' Union have announced plans for an alternative Russian writers' organization, to be called the Union of Russian Writers, for those who do not want to be associated with the conservatives. **********"Civil war in literature, like all civil wars, is unjust on both sides," said the announcement, published Wednesday in the daily newspaper Izvestia and signed by Mr. Yevtushenko and more than a score of other writers, including Fazil Iskander, Anatoly N. Rybakov and Robert Rozhdestvensky. **********"It's the old struggle of Slavophiles versus modernizers," said Feliks F. Kuznetsov, who was thrown out of the leadership of the Soviet Writers' Union by the liberals last spring. **********But it is also a struggle for material advantage. "The dachas we live in, the hospitals where we are treated and many other things are all provided to us by the Soviet Writers' Union Literary Fund," Mr. Rybakov said the other day in his summer cottage, a tranquil, winterized log cabin in the pine woods of the writers' colony of Peredelkino, at the western city limits of Moscow. **********Mr. Rybakov -- author of the novel "Children of the Arbat," which was published here in 1987 at the beginning of an outpouring of Soviet literary depictions of the horrors of Stalinism -- did not let worries about his dacha keep him from issuing a condemnation of the coup on behalf of the Soviet Pen Center, of which he is honorary head, on the morning of Aug. 19. **********But now, what happens to the Soviet Writers' Union "Litfond," the endowment that takes care of dachas and other writers' benefits, is one of the hottest political issues among writers. Those who do not have dachas think they should be privatized and rented to the highest bidder, or sold off. **********The authors of the proposal for a new Union of Russian Writers -- many of them, including Mr. Yevtushenko, comfortably occupying dachas in Peredelkino -- were careful to include a sentence saying, "Membership in the Litfond and all benefits and services associated with it will be preserved." **********Standing in a brief interlude of sun between rain squalls outside the Gorizont movie theater during a break in the two-day Russian Federation Writers' Union congress, Mr. Kuznetsov said the days of the Soviet Writers' Union were clearly numbered. **********"It's a general staff without any soldiers," he said, after proposing a "Conference of Writers' Unions" to try to bring some order to the chaos that would result if other Soviet republics form unions independent of the Soviet Writers' Union, as they have already started to do. **********Mr. Kuznetsov, as secretary of the Moscow organization of the Soviet Writers' Union in the 1970's, was in charge when it drove out such well-known "Westernizers" of the time as Vasily P. Aksyonov and Viktor Yerofeyev, for trying to break censorship under the old Soviet regime. **********Because of charges that conservatives at the Russian Federation writers' organization had created the intellectual atmosphere necessary for the coup, the events of August were something of a sore subject during the group's conference here. **********Some of its best known writers had written an "appeal to the nation" published in what was then the ultra-conservative daily Sovetskaya Rossiya on July 23. Nikolai S. Portugalov, a Communist Party Central Committee functionary, said the appeal was generally recognized in those quarters as a call for a coup d'etat. 'Plunging Into Darkness' **********"Our motherland, this country, the great state which history, nature and our predecessors called upon us to preserve, is dying, breaking apart and plunging into darkness and void," it said, calling on the nation to avert civil war and economic collapse, sounding in some ways like the coup plotters' appeal on Aug. 19. **********The earlier "appeal to the nation" was signed by 12 authors, including Mr. Bondarev and Mr. Rasputin. **********Mr. Rasputin said Thursday that he did not regret his signature. **********Today, the Russian union's conferees voted at one point to approve issuing the appeal again, since the country and the structures that held the Soviet Union have been falling apart faster than ever since the pro-democracy forces defeated the coup last month. **********But Vladimir M. Sangi, a lone voice of regret at the conference, said that as a member of the Russian group's secretariat in June, he had spoken against issuing a similar appeal on the eve of the popular vote that elected Boris N. Yeltsin as President. **********"I was against it because it, too, was a call for a coup," he said. **********"Shame on you!" one member of the audience shouted. **********Mr. Sangi is a member of a tiny Asiatic ethnic minority, the 4,000-member Nivkh people, which inhabits the Pacific island of Sakhalin. Like members of other such groups whose interests up to now were seen to by the Russian and Soviet writers' unions, he was worried about what organization would look after them now. **********"Nobody needs us," he said, sadly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Homestake Gains In Galactic Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/30/busin.body_text: **********The Homestake Mining Company, a gold exploration concern, has been cleared by the Federal Trade Commission to acquire an interest in Galactic Resources Ltd., the Canadian natural resources developer. Under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act, companies planning to acquire assets of $15 million or more, or a minimum of 15 percent in another company, must notify the commission. **********Homestake, based in San Francisco, also announced a second-quarter loss of $69 million, compared with a loss of $37.3 million in the 1990 period. Homestake's stock was unchanged today at $17 on the New York Stock Exchange, while Galactic rose 12.5 cents, to 81.25 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/14/busin.main_headline: The Word on Strategies From A.T.& T.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/14/busin.print_headline: The Word on Strategies From A.T.& T.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/14/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Senator Everett Dirksen had a favorite rhetorical device for speeches back home in Illinois. He'd pull a newspaper clipping from his pocket and begin to read a spirited editorial denunciation of some political miscreant. After a few sentences, he'd stop, look around in mock astonishment and say: "Why, do you know who they're talking about? They're talking about    me   ." **********It's tempting to say I had a similar reaction when I read A. Michael Noll's "The Failures of A.T.& T. Strategies" (Forum, March 31). As he attacked the wisdom of our trying to acquire the NCR Corporation and accused us of lacking direction, he mischaracterized A.T.& T. as it is today and as it is developing for the future. **********A.T.& T.'s mission is broad and deep: to be the world leader in information technology -- a technology that inescapably involves the best of both computer and communications technology. **********A.T.& T. has a well-defined strategy for establishing leadership in this field: **********1) Maintaining leadership in its core businesses like network services (which Mr. Noll extols) and the manufacturing and sale of network telecommunications equipment (which he ignores). **********2) Establishing world leadership in networked computing, which is the technology driving the growth of electronic transactions. We expect such transactions, now running about 50 billion a year, to reach 200 billion annually by 1995. The critical enabler for satisfying this demand is the marriage of convenient user terminals like NCR's automatic teller machine computer systems and error-free communications networks. **********3) To firmly establish A.T.& T. as a truly global company. **********The merger with NCR would combine NCR's leadership in the hardware and software of electronic transactions with A.T.& T.'s expertise in the global networking of information. **********NCR's technology would benefit from the support of A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories, the world's leading research and development organization. A.T.& T.'s globalization drive would benefit from NCR's vast international presence and customer base. **********Mr. Noll apparently would have A.T.& T. stick to its telecommunications knitting, ignoring the fact that telecommunications and computing have been linked irrevocably for years. **********More disturbing, he seems to endorse the idea that economic growth is dependent almost exclusively on services, and that manufacturing should be left to others. This approach doesn't add up for America or for A.T.& T. In the new age of information technology, products and services are increasingly hard to separate. Consider: Is a cash machine, or supermarket point-of-sale terminal, a product or a service? **********Mr. Noll's implication that A.T.&T.'s "premier network" is not producing new information services is at odds with the facts. A.T.& T. has kept the United States network infrastructure the envy of the world. A.T.& T. has been putting more and more intelligence into its public switched network, available to large and small users at whatever level they wish and without the need for huge capital investments in private networks. **********To borrow a phrase, the company has done well by doing good. A.T.& T. had record earnings in 1989, and held them last year, despite a sliding economy, with the help of a 40 percent increase in international equipment sales. **********As Everett Dirksen also used to say: "I'll sketch it for you in brief form." We have computers and communications; we have products as well as services. And, yes, we do have strategy and direction. RICHARD BODMAN  New York, April 8  The author is senior vice president for corporate strategy and development at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/world.main_headline: Senate Prepares for a Gulf Debate Soon After Baker Meets With Aziz
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Senate Prepares for a Gulf Debate Soon After Baker Meets With Aziz
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/world.body_text: **********The Senate today put itself in position to debate legislation concerning war in the Persian Gulf as early as Thursday, the day after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is scheduled to meet with Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister. **********But Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, indicated that it was more likely that the issue would come up on Monday Jan. 14, the day before the United Nations deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait expires and the authorization for military force takes effect. **********Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, urged a serious debate. He said that while he disagreed with Democrats who challenged the President, he sympathized with their frustration over Congressional inaction. **********"For months we have been standing on the sidelines, making all kinds of speeches but not casting a single vote," he said. "Congress has been AWOL." A Lack of Consensus **********But Mr. Dole said he hoped that when the Senate debated, it would unite behind President Bush and the threat of force. **********"What a message that would be to Saddam Hussein," he said, arguing that unity in Congress might finally persuade Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait if Mr. Baker's efforts and all else had failed. **********He conceded that he did not know how Congress would vote, and whether a majority would back Mr. Bush. But however it acted, he said, Congress had a duty to vote. **********There does not appear to be a consensus in either House. Congress, and especially its Democratic leaders, seem committed to voting on how the nation should proceed in the gulf, though it is clear that many individual members are reluctant to take a stand.  Time Left, But Not Much **********Absent any direct, insistent appeal from Mr. Bush, there seems to be little Congressional inclination to urge or even acknowledge a course toward war and much sentiment in favor of keeping economic sanctions in place longer. But many on Capitol Hill say they do not expect him to make such a request in earnest for fear that defeat, or a even narrow victory, would undermine his efforts. **********Congressional leaders seem to feel that they have time left, that Mr. Bush will not seek to pre-empt their debate by attacking on Jan. 16. But they appear to feel they do not have much time. **********Leaders in the House, which was not in session today, did not offer comparable scheduling plans. But the House is expected to be in full session beginning Jan. 14, and for the rest of that week, so that it, too, could debate the situation in the gulf. **********The House Foreign Affairs Committee is expected to meet informally next week to discuss the gulf crisis and possible resolutions concerning it. The committee also scheduled a closed-door meeting for Wednesday with ambassadors from the countries allied against Iraq. Daily Cost of a War **********In the only gulf-related event on the House side of the Capitol today, its Budget Committee heard the head of he General Accounting Office say it would cost the United States nearly $1 billion a day once fighting started. The official, Charles A. Bowsher, said that even without war, the gulf operation would cost about $30 billion in the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1. **********Today's Senate session began with a series of Democratic speeches contending that the Constitution required President Bush to obtain Congressional approval before any attack on Iraq and urging more time for economic sanctions to work. **********"Congress alone has the power to declare war," said Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa. **********"Sanctions are running Iraq's economy into the ground," said Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. Request for a Resolution **********Republicans counterattcked. Senator Steven D. Symms of Idaho complained about "handwringers," and said Mr. Bush had displayed "great restraint." **********Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York said "the issue is not the Constitution." Instead, he said, "the issue is bottom-line American interest." He said the Senate should vote today to support Mr. Bush. **********In contrast to Thursday's sharp half-hour exchange before nearly all members of the Senate, today's speeches were given in a generally deserted Senate chamber and punctuated by repeated quorum calls awaiting the arrival of the next speechmaker. **********One Republican, Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, sided with the Democrats on the constitutional issue and with his fellow Republican senators on policy. He said "the President should formally request the Congress to pass a resolution" giving him the authority to use force.
