https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/world.main_headline: Pope Begins Hungary Visit With Tribute to Mindszenty
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/world.print_headline: Pope Begins Hungary Visit With Tribute to Mindszenty
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II today began a five-day visit to Hungary by praying at the crypt of the militantly anti-Communist Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty. **********The Pope said Cardinal Mindszenty, who died in 1975, "left behind a shining testimony of devotion to Christ and the church, as well as of patriotism." **********"We will always remember his name with a blessing," he told thousands of worshipers gathered before the cathedral where the Cardinal's remains are interred. **********Cardinal Mindszenty's conflict with the Hungarian authorities was one of the most dramatic episodes in postwar European history. **********He was named Primate of Hungary in 1945, and vigorously denounced Communist decrees seizing church-owned lands and restricting Roman Catholic education. In 1948, he was arrested, and a "people's tribunal" sentenced him to life imprisonment. Freed in 1956 Uprising **********The Cardinal was freed during the anti-Communist uprising in 1956, but after the uprising was crushed, he sought refuge in the American Embassy, where he remained for 15 years until he was allowed to move to Rome. **********After his death, Cardinal Mindszenty was buried in Austria. His body was returned to Hungary this year and interred at the cathedral in Esztergom, which has been a center of Hungarian Catholicism for 10 centuries. **********The Pope chose Esztergom to deliver his first homily in Hungary. His visit to Hungary is the first ever by a Pope. **********In his homily, John Paul praised the courage of Hungarian priests and nuns who remained active during Communist rule. **********"I know the difficulties which you have had to face in the course of these 40 years," he said. "I know that some wounds still remain. It is now time for charity to conquer the leftover tensions, reservations and suspicions." **********Nearly two-thirds of Hungary's 10.7 million people profess Catholicism, although many are not observant. Under Communist rule, religious observance was discouraged, and Hungary became, at least superficially, a strongly secular country. **********In recent years, however, church attendance has risen substantially. Church officials say that more than 2,000 young Hungarians have begun studying for religious vocations each year since 1988. **********After his appearance in Esztergom, the Pope traveled to Budapest for a meeting with Government officials. Upon arriving, he welcomed Hungary's "new climate of freedom." **********President Arpad Goncz described the papal visit as "a historic moment for us." He said he hoped the visit would spark a "moral renaissance" in Hungary. **********"I do believe and profess that the Christian spirit is love itself, which is the source of easing and even resolving social problems," Mr. Goncz said in his official greeting. **********The Pope replied that he hoped Hungary's new democracy would have a "religious orientation." **********During his stay, the Pope will travel to cities in all parts of Hungary. Most of his stops will be in Catholic regions, but he will also take part in a Byzantine Mass, visit a Calvinist church, and meet with leaders of Hungarian Jews. **********"He is reaching out beyond a strictly religious agenda," said a diplomat with long experience here. "His message is that he wants to work with Protestants, Jews and secular people to make the Hungarian experiment work."  POPE TO VISIT GUINEA **********CONAKRY, Guinea, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Pope will visit Guinea in February, the authorities here say, on a trip that will also take him to Senegal. Both West African nations are predominantly Muslim.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.body_text: **********The Uniroyal-Goodrich Tire Company will close up to three plants in Canada. The company, owned by Groupe Michelin of France, said it would close its tire-cord manufacturing plant in Lindsay, Ontario, on Aug. 30, and would close one or both of its tire factories in Kitchener, Ontario. The Lindsay plant, with 74 employees, is the least efficient of its tire-cord operations, the company said. As for the Kitchener plants, Uniroyal-Goodrich cited overcapacity as its reason for the cutback. The three plants have already had layoffs and work-sharing programs. In January, the company said it would cut 1,350 jobs at operations in Eau Claire, Wis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/29/world.main_headline: Soviet Trade Bloc Is Out of Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/29/world.print_headline: Soviet Trade Bloc Is Out of Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/29/world.body_text: **********The nine member nations of Comecon, the Soviet-led trading bloc, signed an agreement today to put the organization out of business. **********The ceremony in Budapest today was a formality because the members had previously agreed to disband Comecon, which had become an anachronism with the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe. Trade within the bloc had already largely collapsed. **********As soon as Eastern European countries began ousting their Communist governments in 1989, they started campaigning to dismantle Comecon, which was one of the pillars of Soviet domination of its allies. **********Moscow pushed to establish the organization in 1949 to bind Eastern Europe economically and politically to the Soviet Union, but Eastern European officials long complained that it held back their economic progress.  A 50% Drop in Trade **********Trade between Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union has plummeted by about 50 percent since Jan. 1, when Comecon nations started trading on a hard-currency basis rather than in Soviet currency. This drop in trade has pushed the region deeper into recession and aggravated the problems of moving toward a market economy. **********Comecon, whose formal name is Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, consists of the Soviet Union, Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania and Vietnam. **********The Soviet Union used Comecon as a tool to promote economic coordination, but many Eastern European economists and officials said Moscow's efforts to export its centrally planned concepts bogged down their economies. **********The agreement today designates a committee to determine over the next 90 days how to liquidate assets owned jointly by the member nations. In addition, the committee is expected to determine how member nations should be compensated for their investments in Soviet gas and oil pipelines. **********Another pillar of the Soviet bloc, the Warsaw Pact, is to be dissolved Monday in a ceremony in Prague. **********The three countries that pushed hardest for shutting down Comecon -- Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland -- are struggling to figure out how to rebuild their trade with each other, the Soviet Union and the West.  Alternatives Considered **********Some officials have proposed a free-trade zone within Eastern Europe to stimulate trade, like a rudimentary European Community. But some Eastern European leaders, eager to join the European Community, balk at forming a league of poor European nations. **********"Closer economic ties between Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, perhaps as a free trade area, certainly make sense," said Jan Stankowski, a Comecon expert at the Institute for Comparative Economic Studies in Vienna. "But they certainly won't choose any organization that contains remnants of Comecon." **********Vietnam, Cuba and Mongolia favored a successor organization, to be tentatively called the Organization for Economic Cooperation, but Eastern European nations rejected such an idea, instead proposing an organization, comprising just the European members, that would examine how to end the region's trade collapse and how to move toward a market economy. **********"Creation of another Comecon is out of the question," Poland's Foreign Minister, Krzysztof Skubiszewski, said. "We propose something else which would be a temporary form of multilateral information and consultation between the European states of the former Comecon."  Looking West for Growth **********The ministers did not make a decision about a successor organization. **********For future growth in trade, Eastern European officials are generally looking toward the rich Western markets, rather than toward the Soviet Union or other Eastern European nations. **********"There is a crisis in trade with the Soviet Union," said Anita Tiraspolsky, an Eastern European specialist at the French Institute for International Relations. "As for the Eastern European nations, there has always been very little trade between them. They traded principally with the Soviet Union and East Germany." **********Many Eastern European nations hope to rebuild trade with the Soviet Union. Because of their nation's dearth of hard currency, many Soviet officials are pressing for two-way agreements, based largely on barter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/30/busin.main_headline: 3 Companies Said to Invest In Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/30/busin.print_headline: 3 Companies Said to Invest In Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/30/busin.body_text: **********Sony and Motorola have joined Apple Computer in investing in a closely watched Silicon Valley start-up company that is developing a new type of portable computing device, industry executives said today. **********The start-up, General Magic Inc., was formed last year by three former Apple Computer Inc. employees with a minority investment from Apple. It is developing what it calls a personal intelligent communicator, which is believed to be a pocket-sized device that will help people organize personal notes and appointments and will receive and transmit faxes and computer data by radio waves. **********Jane Anderson, a spokeswoman for General Magic, declined to comment on reports of the investments. "We're hard at work trying to make it happen," she said, referring to the product development efforts. "We'll let you know when there's something to talk about."  Almost an Open Secret **********But other industry executives said the investment had become almost an open secret. "I know that for a fact," said Jean-Louis Gassee, the former head of product development for Apple who now heads his own company, Be Labs, in San Jose. Mr. Gassee said executives from Motorola Inc. and the Sony Corporation had told him of their involvement in General Magic without making a great secret of it. In Japan an executive close to Sony confirmed that the company had taken a small stake in General Magic. **********Motorola's investment was first reported by a Japanese newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, on Thursday, while Sony's investment was reported by Fortune magazine several weeks ago. Sony U.S.A. and Motorola were closed today and spokesmen could not immediately be reached for comment. **********It is not known how much the companies have invested in General Magic, but industry executives and news reports indicate that it is several million dollars apiece, giving each company a stake of about 5 to 10 percent. Apple is believed to have a somewhat larger investment. **********Apple, Sony and Motorola have worked together in the past and a partnership would be logical. Sony brings expertise in miniaturization. It already makes a notebook computer for Apple, and executives of the two companies have said they plan to cooperate in other areas as well. Motorola, a supplier of chips to Apple, is also a leader in radio communications.  Product a Year Away **********General Magic, based in Mountain View, Calif., is said to be more than a year away from having a product ready. Some industry executives expect that General Magic itself will not sell hand-held communicators but will license its technology to other companies, like Apple, that will. Executives say it is also talking to several other companies, particularly Japanese consumer electronics companies. **********General Magic's three founders are Andy Hertzfeld, who developed key software for the original Apple Macintosh, Bill Atkinson, who was the lead developer of Apple's Hypercard information management software, and Marc Porat, a former manager of business development in Apple's advanced technology group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/busin.main_headline: Sales of Existing Houses Rose 6 Percent Last Month
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/busin.print_headline: Sales of Existing Houses Rose 6 Percent Last Month
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/busin.body_text: **********Lower mortgage rates continued to lure home buyers in May, lifting sales of existing single-family houses by 6 percent, to their highest level in 18 months, a real estate trade group said today. **********"Low mortgage rates and increased consumer confidence are fueling momentum in the housing market and allowing entry-level buyers to finally get up the courage to dive into the market," said Harley E. Rouda, president of the National Association of Realtors. **********The group said sales of previously owned single-family houses were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.51 million in May, the highest since the 3.56 million rate in December 1989. Low Point in January **********Sales of existing homes plunged to a 2.9 million rate in January, but have increased each month since then, including gains of 9 percent in February and 1.9 percent in March. New-home sales and housing starts as well as applications for building permits have also increased since January. **********John A. Tuccillo, the trade organization's chief economist, said that as the recovery takes hold, sales of existing homes "should be healthy for the remainder of 1991 and robust in 1992." **********According to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the interest rate for 30-year conventional fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.47 percent in May, down nearly one percentage point from the same month in 1990. **********The median price of an existing home was $99,700, up 4.7 percent from the May 1990 price, but six-tenths of a percent below that of April. The median price means half of the homes cost more and half cost less. **********Sales in the Northeast, which rose 2.8 percent in April, slipped 1.9 percent in May to an annual rate of 530,000 units. The median price in the region was $143,600, 1.9 percent above that of May 1990. Sales rose in the Midwest, West and South.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.main_headline: Bank Losses Worst in 50 Years, But No Danger to System Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.print_headline: Bank Losses Worst in 50 Years, But No Danger to System Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/busin.body_text: **********As Congress begins debate on one of the most extensive series of changes ever proposed for the nation's banking system, there are clear signs of serious illness at many banks -- large as well as small. But experts say the system itself does not appear in danger of collapse. **********The banks are suffering more from losses on bad loans than at any time in the last 50 years -- the amount sharply accelerating in the first nine months of last year. Federal regulators expect 180 banks to fail this year -- banks whose average size is much larger than those that failed in recent years. Nevertheless, the problems do not approach those of the early years of the Depression, when the collapse of 7,000 banks before the national bank holiday was declared in March 1933 helped shatter the economy. **********By contrast to the savings and loan industry, which is essentially broke, the banking industry earned a profit of $14.7 billion in the first nine months of 1990, despite the increase in loan losses. And to absorb future losses, the banks have a record $218.2 billion of capital and $52.3 billion of other reserves. Capital, in this sense, means stockholders' equity or, more simply, the difference between what a bank owns and what it owes.  A Large Bank's Fall **********The state of the banking system is now a matter of heightened public interest following the collapse in early January of the Bank of New England and several reports of losses and dividend cuts at other banks. The problems are typified by the troubled history of a little bank in White River Junction, Vt., for example, where the 1980's temptation to seek ever higher profits from real estate helped bring the institution to its knees -- or by a similar story in New Hampshire at a bank that had been in business since 1830. **********Attention is also being drawn to the system by the Administration's attempt to broaden it, by giving banks the powers to do business nationwide and to make it easier for them to enter the insurance and securities businesses. The proposals would not help solve a bank's immediate problems with bad loans, but they could eventually help make the banking industry more profitable, specialists say. **********"We certainly don't have a banking crisis in the sense that the country as a whole has a problem," said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. "But in certain areas of the country there is real stress," he continued, adding that bank problems will worsen if the recession is more severe than he expects or if it lasts beyond midyear. **********The troubles among larger banks are clearly shown on the F.D.I.C.'s most recent list of banks that it sees as vulnerable to failure or requiring close supervision. At the end of 1990, that list, which is not publicly available, included 1,046 banks with $408.8 billion of assets, or 12.1 percent of the industry total. A year earlier, at the end of 1989, there were 1,109 banks on the problem list, but their assets were only 7.1 percent of the national total, or $235.5 billion. The list changes every quarter as the condition of some banks improves while other banks deteriorate or fail.   Stocks Down Sharply **********Among the nation's 10 largest banking companies, all continue to be rated as "inherently sound" with ratings of a middle grade or higher, according to Thomson Bankwatch, a bank rating firm based in New York City. But sharp declines in the stocks of those companies -- many are down more than 50 percent in the last 15 months -- are a reminder that investors and analysts see problems that the banking companies may not yet have acknowledged in their financial reports. **********Indeed, for 8 of the 10 largest banking companies, industry analysts estimate that losses on loans -- particularly risky loans for commercial real estate and leveraged buyouts -- are well in excess of the reserves set aside by the banks to cover those losses. **********Bankers dislike the private estimates of loan losses, because the losses for similar kinds of loans may vary widely from bank to bank. **********"We make sure our reserves are consistent with the risk characteristics of our portfolio," said John F. Kooken, vice chairman at the Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest banking company, based in Los Angeles. "There are a lot of checks and balances in the mechanism for setting reserves," he added, noting that the bank's loans are studied by outside auditors as well as banking regulators. Loan Troubles  Large Banks Cut Dividends **********Even if banks deny that loan losses are as severe as analysts estimate, they acknowledge that problems exist. Citicorp, Chase Manhattan, Chemical Banking and Manufacturers Hanover have all cut their dividends in recent months, and others have reported large increases in their delinquent loans. **********Thomas Hanley, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said recent increases in loan problems among larger banks "are especially alarming because they are showing up at the earliest stage of the recession but are already much greater than at the end of the 1981-82 recession." **********Financial statements filed with the F.D.I.C. by the banks on Sept. 30, the most recent available, show that through the first nine months of 1990, commercial banks in the United States charged off as a loss 1.36 percent of their outstanding loans, compared with only 56-hundredths of 1 percent in 1982, the last year of the most severe recession since World War II. **********Loans that were seriously delinquent equaled 2.65 percent of all bank assets on Sept. 30, up from 1.85 percent in 1982. In loans in this category, no payment has been made for 90 days or more or full payment is no longer expected. In a recession, when more borrowers default, the banking industry normally doubles its write-offs of bad loans; so analysts now expect losses to remain high for many months.  Problems Shift to the Northeast **********A New York Times analysis of the Sept. 30 data shows a geographic shifting of banking industry problems away from oil-producing states like Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana to the Northeastern region, where the troubles are rooted in declining real estate values. **********More than one in five Northeastern banks reported a loss, according to the September data, for the first nine months of 1990, compared with one in nine for the rest of the country. Many of the worst problems in that region have occurred at savings banks, including Goldome in Buffalo and several in New Hampshire and Massachusetts, that ventured outside their traditional business of collecting consumer deposits and making low-risk home loans and investments and into commercial real estate. **********The Times study of the financial reports filed by the nation's 12,926 banks identified 252 that were in weakened condition, either because of a low level of capital or unusually large amounts of seriously delinquent loans. Inclusion on these lists does not mean that all 252 banks are going to fail, but it is regarded as matter of serious concern.  Oil Collapse Jolted Southeast **********Most of the weakly capitalized banks are in Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana, where many banks are still suffering from losses in the late 80's, following the collapse of oil prices in 1986. Troubled banks in Massachusetts and Connecticut dominate the list of banks with large holdings of seriously delinquent loans. **********The F.D.I.C., whose list of "problem" banks has many more names on it than 252, has complete access to bank records and can examine the quality of individual loans. It does not publicly identify problem banks, though depositors may request an annual financial statement from their bank or may write to the F.D.I.C. to obtain a copy of quarterly reports filed by any bank with federally insured deposits. **********Measuring the health of banks depends mostly on the value of the loans they have made and how that value is figured. Since there is no stock exchange to determine the value of bank loans, their worth is always open to debate. **********If it is assumed that the loans would be sold immediately, their price would be sharply lower than their face amount and banks would realize large losses. An alternative, preferred by bankers, is to assume that the loans will not be sold, and that losses would be recognized only when a default occurred or became likely.  Realty Woes Banks Are Forced To Take Losses **********The steep decline in real estate markets in the last two years has led bank examiners to conclude that many bank loans backing those projects have also declined in value. They have forced banks to write off many loans as a loss and build their reserves to cover future losses. **********But in the last few weeks, in response to complaints that strict accounting practices were closing off the supply of new loans to the economy, regulators have shown signs of adopting easier accounting rules. These rules could reduce the losses and reserves required of banks. **********"We don't want the environment bankers face to be more difficult than it has to be," said Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency. **********To measure whether a bank can withstand a siege of bad loans, analysts and regulators pay close attention to the bank's capital to absorb the losses. For many banks, the capital cushion is now thin. But the industry as a whole has more than $6.50 of capital for each $100 of assets, or more than double the minimum standard for financial safety set by regulators.  Two Key Ratios Studied **********Two important warning signs that analysts look for are the ratio of a bank's capital to assets and the ratio of bad loans to assets. Experience suggests that an average of at least 30 percent of banks with capital of less than 3 percent of assets will fail within two years, and that 60 percent with less than 1.5 percent will fail in that time. Warnings sound, too, when a bank has more than 8 percent of its assets in nonperforming loans. **********Texas still has more insolvent and weakly capitalized banks than any other state, but problems are abating there, with fewer banks reporting losses and delinquent loans declining. In the Northeast, despite its problems, relatively few banks have accumulated enough losses to push their capital below 3 percent. But the number of banks reporting losses is growing and their holdings of delinquent loans are rising faster than in any other region of the country.  Customer Losses Leading Concerns Look Elsewhere **********The temptation to plunge into commercial real estate lending was especially strong for many of the country's largest banks. They had been hurt when top-rated corporations, beginning in the 1960's, started to bypass American banks to get funds from foreign banks or the securities markets, where interest rates were lower. **********"Twenty years ago we would have had major credit commitments and outstanding loans to companies like Du Pont and TRW," said Edward Brandon, chief executive at the National City Corporation, a Cleveland-based banking company that has been hurt in commercial real estate but remains profitable and well capitalized. Without those top-flight borrowers "banks have been forced to seek other borrowers, which inevitably means making riskier loans." **********Still, bankers and analysts alike repeat that for all the unfavorable trends, the great majority of the nation's banks are faring well. A Stress on Growth **********A leading cause of bank problems, said James McCormick, president of the First Manhattan Consulting group, is "a reliance on growth to cover up other failings, whether it is a high level of expenses, a recent acquisition that cost too much, or unprofitable operations." **********Because real estate loans carried higher interest rates than other business loans, they seemed attractive. Many banks increased their commitment to these loans by 20 percent or more from 1986 through 1989. **********"The most seductive trap in banking is growth," said John G. Medlin Jr., chairman of the First Wachovia Corporation in Winston-Salem, N.C. "It looks so good while it is happening, but the real costs do not become apparent until later." **********Mr. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, said many leading bank executives ignored warnings issued by his office as long ago as 1985 that standards for real estate loans were slipping. **********"There are just too many bankers who forgot or ignored some fundamental precepts of the business," he said. "They put too many of their eggs into the basket of commercial real estate, and now they are paying the price."  Insolvencies  Most Are in Texas And the Northeast **********The compilation of the Sept. 30 bank data shows the following: **********Twenty-five banks, with assets totaling nearly $13.5 billion, had the weakest capitalization in the country. Their losses had eaten away at capital to the point where they were insolvent and owed more to depositors and other creditors than the value of their "hard" assets, like loans and investments. Fourteen of the 25 have since closed. **********Texas accounted for 13 of the insolvent banks, reflecting in large part the economic problems that hit the state and the region after the 1986 fall in oil prices. Five banks in the Northeast are in that category, including three F.D.I.C.-insured savings banks that are the only ones on the list with more than $500 million of assets -- Goldome, with headquarters in Buffalo; the Maine Savings Bank of Portland, and the New Hampshire Savings Bank of Concord. **********The largest insolvent bank is Goldome, which has nearly $10.3 billion of assets. Under close scrutiny of regulators it has been steadily shrinking its business. It has sold 24 branches with $2.8 billion of deposits in the New York City area to the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. **********Thomas A. Cooper, chairman of Goldome, said the negative capital position was not necessarily a death knell. "Capital is extremely important, and regulators are right to demand that banks keep their financial condition strong," he said. But he noted that accounting practices show Goldome's weakness but "do not reflect our strength, which is the value of our consumer business." **********By allowing Goldome to stay in business despite a lack of capital, Mr. Cooper said, regulators gave the bank time to cut expenses by 40 percent. He noted that the company returned to profitability in the last half of 1990. Insufficient Capital **********Another 166 banks, with assets totaling $55.8 billion, had capital equal to less than 3 percent of their assets, the minimum set by regulators. For 61 banks, capital was less than 1.5 percent of assets. **********While Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana account for 92 of the banks with capital below 3 percent, they are relatively small institutions, with only one having assets above $500 million. Nine of the 10 largest banks in Texas have either failed or been acquired in the last few years, leaving only the smaller banks with lingering problems. **********In the Northeast, which to the F.D.I.C. includes the District of Columbia, Maryland and the 10 states to the north, there are fewer undercapitalized banks, but they are much larger than those in Texas. The weakly capitalized banks from the region included 11 with more than $1 billion of assets, including the $13.2 billion Bank of New England, which was taken over last month by the F.D.I.C., and the $5.9 billion American Security Bank, a unit of MNC Financial, a Baltimore company that owns the Maryland National Bank. To raise cash and strengthen its bank units, MNC recently sold its credit card business. **********The largest savings banks reporting weak capital were also in the Northeast, and included the Meritor Savings Bank of Philadelphia, now known as the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society, with $5.6 billion of assets, and the Dollar Dry Dock Bank of New York, with $4.6 billion. Both Meritor and Dollar Dry Dock have been selling branches and taking other measures to reduce expenses.  Bad Loans **********There were 118 banks, with total assets of $68.8 billion, that had more than 8 percent of their assets in nonperforming loans. The industry average for such loans on Sept. 30 was only 2.65 percent. But earnings reports for the fourth quarter of 1990, not yet compiled by Federal regulators, showed continued rapid increases in nonperforming assets in the Northeast and some evidence that California was beginning to experience the same problem as real estate prices there turned down. **********Eight percent is a red flag to regulators and analysts, warning that additional loan losses are likely. **********Northeastern states account for 68 of the banks with nonperforming loans above 8 percent. Two of the largest are the $9.3 billion Midlantic Bank in Newark and the $5.2 billion European American Bank in New York. Midlantic has been trying to improve its condition by reducing its size and selling assets, while European American has relied on a fresh capital investment by its European owners, led by ABN AMRO Holding of the Netherlands.  A Bank's Fall  Poor Management And Realty Losses **********The brief but troubled history of the Valley Bank in White River Junction, Vt., is an example of how the temptation of high profits from real estate lending and poor management can bring a bank to its knees. **********When Valley Bank was established in early 1987, there was still enough spark in the New England real estate market for the founders to expect to match the high profits and rapid growth of many other New England banks. **********"There was great pressure to generate earnings, and in that process the principles of lending got put on a back burner," said Joseph J. Greco, who was named Valley Bank's president a month ago. "The supply of credit for real estate deals from banks and savings banks far outstripped the demand. If you were the new bank on the block, like Valley was, you did not get the more sound, reputable businesses. You had to take the second tier." **********By Sept. 30, the costs of those policies were clear: heavy loan losses had reduced Valley's capital to only $508,000, or 1.23 percent of assets. With the real estate market still falling, Valley is stuck with 49 percent of its assets consisting of loans backed by commercial real estate projects.  Looking for Capital **********As recently as a decade ago, commercial real estate loans accounted for only 5.8 perent of bank assets, and many bankers refused to consider such loans at all. Or they would require personal guarantees from developers as well as a solid business plan, with tenants lined up before construction began. But such lending grew rapidly in the 80's and reached 11.9 percent of assets by last Sept. 30. At 2,836 banks, commercial real estate lending accounted for more than 15 percent of all assets. And at 123 banks, the figure reached 40 percent. **********"In retropect, it was probably not the best time for this particular venture to have been started," Mr. Greco said. But now that the mistakes have been made, he added, the bank is trying to recover what it can from the bad loans "and look everywhere for more capital." **********The rush to participate in the 80's real estate boom claimed victims far older and better established than Valley National. The New Hampshire Savings Bank in Concord, for example, was founded in 1830 as a mutual-type bank owned by its depositors. But in 1982 it converted to a shareholder-owned company and soon became an aggressive lender on real estate. Losses on bad loans wiped out the $58.6 million of capital the bank had at the end of 1988 and left it insolvent, owing $38.8 million more to depositors and creditors than the estimated value of its assets. **********Whatever else is done, most experts agree that the banks must return to sound lending practices, even if growth is sacrificed. In the best of times, the difference between healthy and weak banks is small. Operating on average with only about $6.50 of capital for every $100 of loans and investments, banks are extremely vulnerable to relatively small losses on loans, which can be enough to wipe out much of their capital. **********"This is a business where you can be right 95 percent of the time, and still be in serious trouble," said Mr. Seidman of the F.D.I.C. **********Next: The bank run WHAT THE CHARTS AND LISTS SHOW **********The charts are based on balance sheets and income reports from 12,926 banks as of Sept. 30, 1990, the last period for which such data are available. All the banks are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. **********A computer-assisted search of those records identified banks that were insolvent, or had a small amount of capital relative to their size, or had a high amount of nonperforming loans. Banking experts regard low capital and large holdings of nonperforming loans as two key indicators of a troubled bank. **********Banks on the insolvent list were those with negative capital-to-asset ratios, meaning that the amounts they owed depositors and other creditors were greater than the value of their "hard" assets, like loans and investments. Eighteen of the 25 banks on this list have since closed. **********The Low Percentage of Capital to Assets list includes banks whose equity capital had shrunk to less than 3 percent of assets. Equity capital represents the amount that a bank's assets exceeds what it owes to depositors and other creditors.  Nonperforming Loans **********And the banks on the Nonperforming Loans list were those with more than 8 percent of their assets tied up in loans that are delinquent by 90 days or more, or so troubled that the bank does not expect repayment in full. **********The appearance of a bank on these lists does not mean it will fail. But bank regulators regard it as a clear sign of serious trouble when a bank's capital-to-assets ratio falls below 3 percent or when bad loans climb to more than 8 percent of assets. **********The chart covering the nation's 10 largest banking companies compares the amount of capital and reserves they reported on Sept. 30 with outside analysts' assessments of the losses banks are likely to suffer on their loans. Bankers count on the reserve for loan losses as a way of setting aside money to cover bad loans, but many analysts say those reserves are not enough to cover the losses that banks will actually face. **********For 8 of the 10 largest banking companies, the losses based on assumptions used by analysts exceeded the banks' reserves and left the institutions with less capital than their financial statements showed on Sept. 30. Two companies, J. P. Morgan & Company and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, appeared to have reserves greater than losses assumed for their loan portfolios. Of course, the actual loss on those loans will vary widely from bank to bank, and could disappear for many loans if the economy and real estate markets improve.  Estimates of Losses **********Based on past experience, analysts assume the losses average 10 percent for loans to highly indebted companies; 20 percent for all kinds of commercial real estate; 50 percent for delinquent loans to less-developed countries; 25 percent for all other kinds of loans so delinquent that bankers call them nonperforming, and 1.5 percent for all other kinds of loans. Those losses are then subtracted from the company's loan-loss reserves and existing capital. **********The bankers counter by saying that the analysts' estimates are exaggerated. Even if all those losses materialized, they would probably occur over a period of time, during which banks could build up reserves from profits, the bankers say. Citibank officials add that the analysts' estimates are wrong because they do not recognize the full extent to which the bank company has already written off troubled loans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/04/busin.body_text: **********Brooks Brothers is putting many of its sales clerks on a new commission system that the men's wear retailer hopes will give them an incentive to increase sales and service. **********With sales slumping and consumers complaining that service has deteriorated in many stores, other big American retailers have added commissions, among them, Bloomingdale's and Macy's. **********Brooks Brothers' change could be especially important to that chain, where sales have suffered from the effects of the recession on the men's wear industry. **********Like the sales clerks at many other long-established specialty stores, Brooks personnel are considered to be better informed about merchandise and closer to customers than their department store counterparts. Many have relationships with loyal consumers that go back many years. A Double-Edged Effect **********The new system raises the commission percentage paid to sales clerks who exceed certain goals, more directly linking higher salaries to the amount of merchandise they sell. But those who do not surpass the goal are effectively penalized with a lower salary. Another important part of the plan allows sales clerks for the first time to sell items in departments outside their own. **********"What we've done is in effect lower the commission but create incentives which didn't exist before," said Edward Murphy, Brooks Brothers' executive vice president and chief operating officer. With a new base and a guaranteed wage, the sales clerks "now can take more time to sell in other departments so that they can write up multiple sales," he added. **********The men's wear chain previously used a system common in retailing, in which sales clerks receive a flat commission based on a percentage of the price of the goods they sell. In Brooks Brothers' case it averaged 9 percent, regardless of how much an individual's sales increased. 500 Sales Clerks Affected **********The new policy affects 500 of the company's 1,500 sales clerks. They are paid a base hourly wage averaging about 75 percent of what they earned in 1989. **********Those who sell 75 percent or less of what they sold in 1989 will receive just the hourly rate. But if they exceed it, they will get an added commission for the sales above that base. And the percentage paid as commission rises along with the sales volume. **********For example, those who sell 85 percent of what they sold in 1989 will get a 5 percent commission on that increase. Above the 85 percent level, the commission will be 10 percent. **********The salary changes affect only sales clerks in stores that are not unionized among the total of 50 that Brooks Brothers operates in this country. The New York stores are unionized. Brooks Brothers has been owned by Marks & Spencer, the British retailer, since 1986. **********Brooks Brothers has been grappling with declining earnings and sales, as is the case with much of the men's wear retailing industry.  Some Consider It a Wage Cut **********Some sales clerks say they do not like the new system, fearing that they will earn less. Some consider the 75 percent base a 25 percent wage cut. **********But at least one compensation expert said it was a good way for Brooks Brothers "to lock in its top sales producers." **********"This plan has a built-in guarantee, and it indicates a strong commitment to current salespeople," said the expert, Steven E. Hall, managing director of the New York firm Pearl Meyer & Partners, consultants on executive compensation. **********Two salesmen in the Brooks Brothers store in Northbrook, Ill., seemed to typify the employee reactions. **********"The new compensation just started, and it's too soon for me to react," Sam Blum said in a telephone interview. "I just don't know how I feel about it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/29/world.main_headline: Uncertain Future for a Russian Enclave
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/29/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; Uncertain Future for a Russian Enclave
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/29/world.body_text: **********As Konigsberg, it was the easternmost outpost of German power for 402 years, ending in 1945. As Kaliningrad, it has been the westernmost outpost of the Soviet Union for the last 46 years. **********Now, with the politics and geography of the Soviet Union in question, the future of the small enclave on the southeastern coast of the Baltic Sea is murky. Soviet authorities apparently intend to retain the city and surrounding district as part of the Russian republic. But it will be isolated from Soviet territory when the Baltic republics achieve full independence. **********Konigsberg was founded by the Knights of the Teutonic Order in 1308 after their conquest of a now-vanished tribe called Prusi, or Prussians. In the 16th and 17th centuries the city was ruled by Polish monarchs, but in 1701 it came under German control again, as the capital of the province of East Prussia. With its university, Konigsberg was a seat of learning made famous in the 18th century by its philosopher son, Immanuel Kant. **********Before World War II, Konigsberg was a city of 372,000 and the second-largest German naval base after Kiel. During the war, it was virtually leveled by British bombing and Russian shelling. **********At the Potsdam conference in 1945, Stalin demanded, and received, the city and a surrounding 6,000-square-mile portion of East Prussia as booty. In 1946, the city and district were renamed to honor Mikhail I. Kalinin, who for many years had been the President of the Soviet Union under Stalin and who had died that year. **********The port of Kaliningrad, prized because it is ice free, was turned into the Soviet Union's main naval base on the Baltic. Until early this year, most foreigners were barred from the region, which has a population of about 900,000 -- almost all ethnic Russians. Virtually the entire German population fled west at the end of the war. **********A plan to transform Kaliningrad into a free-trade zone awaits action by the Russian Parliament. There are also proposals to change the name back to Konigsberg. A visitor last April found many residents calling themselves "Konigsberger" and cultivating an interest in their city's German past.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.body_text: **********The decline in yields on certificates of deposit and bank money-market accounts steadily gained momentum in the last week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, the publication in North Palm Beach, Fla., that specializes in covering interest rates. **********"The speed and the size of the current decline is intensifying," Robert K. Heady, the publisher of The Monitor, said yesterday. He said banks had been racing to bring down their cost of funds before the Federal Reserve reduced its discount rate again; however, a high-ranking Fed official suggested yesterday that the Fed's policy makers were unlikely to take urgent action on rates when they meet next week. Mr. Heady said he thought the unusually low current yields would move even lower by mid-February, possibly by another 25 or 30 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Sees 4.5% on 6-Month C.D.'s **********He said that the nationwide average yield on six-month certificates of deposit probably would be less than 4.50 percent. New York banks have cut yields by about 14 basis points, to 4.16 percent, he said. **********In the case of money-market accounts, the largest cuts were made by Astoria Federal Savings Bank and Bank of Tokyo Trust, which both cut yields by 26 basis points. **********The Bank of Tokyo Trust was also the leader in cutting its three-month certificates of deposit by 45 basis points and its six-month certificates by 35 basis points. **********For the New York commercial banks, the average yield on money market accounts was 4.18 percent, down 6 basis points. The average yields on those banks' three-month and six-month certificates were, respectively, 4.16 percent, down 14 basis points, and 4.26 percent, down 11 basis points. Cuts by Savings Institutions **********At savings institutions in the New York area, yields were cut to 4.83 percent, down 9 basis points, for money market accounts; to 4.83 percent, down 10 basis points, for three-month certificates, and to 5.00 percent, also down 10 basis points, for six-month certificates. **********The Monitor said the average yields at 20 major banks outside the New York area had been cut by 8 basis points, to 4.47 percent, on money-market accounts, and by 14 points, to 4.55 percent, for six-month certificates. **********By comparison, at the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction on Monday, the three-month bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 4.21 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********The author probably wasn't responsible for the headline on the article "Pursuing Zero Defects Under the Six Sygma  [ sic ]  Banner," (Jan. 13), but this particular error represents an effect of the current corporate "quality" posturing and flinging about of buzz words. The sad fact is that most engineers and scientists, let alone makers of industrial policy, have never had a course in statistics because it is still an arcane (and very dull) elective in this country. Reducing defects is all well and good, but it must be combined with knowing something about their significance and impact on product or process. The chart with the article, previously published by the International Business Machines Corporation, compares incommensurate errors and final results of errors and leads to the conclusion that tighter controls and measurements enhance quality, when, in many cases, they act to hinder development, innovation and design improvement which can have larger impact. Better products do not only come from fine tuning manufacturing yields so that you lose one good part in every million; they come from designs which are less sensitive and a process which has wider latitude. We've imported and accentuated only one component of the Japanese quality technology, and this is the biggest defect of them all. RICHARD J. STEIN  West Redding, Conn., Jan 14

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/14/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer; Borland Is Making the Most of Old Technology
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/14/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer; Borland Is Making the Most of Old Technology
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/14/busin.body_text: **********For users not yet ready or willing to switch to the Windows operating system from the Microsoft Corporation, Borland International's new Quattro Pro spreadsheet, version 3.0, offers almost the same "what you see is what you get" graphics and commands. Perhaps more than any other recent program, Quattro Pro proves that there is still plenty of life left in the DOS operating system. **********The Quattro Pro graphical interface is the most noticeable improvement in what many people already regarded as the best spreadsheet for personal computers made by the International Business Machines Corporation and compatible models. The true value of a spreadsheet is its ability to manipulate and consolidate numbers, and Quattro Pro does that as well as program. **********Certainly, Microsoft's Windows is a productive advance, replacing the character-based face of DOS with a mouse-driven system of pull-down menus, symbols and windows. Microsoft, which is based in Redmond, Wash., has sold more than two million copies of Windows, and its Excel 3.0 spreadsheet has become the standard that everyone, including Borland and the Lotus Development Corporation, is scrambling to meet. **********"Let's face it, there are tens of millions of computers out there, and 90-plus percent of them are Intel-based PC's running DOS," said Frank J. Michnoff, director of desktop computer strategies for the Meta Group, a market research and consulting firm in Westport, Conn. He was referring to the many personal computers powered by microprocessors made by the Intel Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif. "Everyone is so focused on Windows and OS/2, they're forgetting that the old technology continues to progress as well," he said. "I see more happening in the DOS market than ever before." **********Unlike Windows in general and Excel in particular, which requires a personal computer using a fast 80286 chip and several megabytes of memory, Quattro Pro will work on a personal computer with the less powerful 8088 chip and only 512 kilobytes of memory (the configuration of the old I.B.M. PC XT). Of course, Quattro Pro, like most spreadsheets, will work better with more processor power and memory. And an EGA or VGA monitor is required to take advantage of Quattro Pro's "what you see is what you get" graphics mode. That feature is popularly known as wysiwyg (pronounced wiz-ZEE-wig). **********Borland, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., is not alone in courting the millions of spreadsheet users in the DOS world. Lotus, whose 1-2-3 spreadsheet, popularized that form of software, is reported to be nearly ready to release an upgraded version of its low-end spreadsheet, to be called Lotus 1-2-3 Release 2.3. (To confuse matters, Lotus is developing a raft of 1-2-3's, including a Windows version and a Macintosh version, and another DOS version called Release 3.1 Plus. It also makes a version for the OS/2 operating system.) Lotus 1-2-3 Release 2.3 is said to have some impressive features of its own, including a built-in viewer function that lets the user actually look into spreadsheet files on a hard disk before loading them into memory, a trick first used in Lotus's Magellan program. **********On the surface, Quattro Pro could pass for a Windows program. Command buttons, which are operated by clicking a mouse, have a sculpted, three-dimensional look just like the ones on Excel. They even depress when they are clicked. **********Quattro Pro 3.0 allows users to see typefaces, sizes, colors and styles the way they will appear when the worksheet is printed -- a great benefit for people who use spreadsheets to create presentations and reports. **********A "zoom" command even lets an executive swoop in to look more closely at a particular table or area of a worksheet, or zoom back out to see the bigger picture. **********Under the hood, however, Quattro Pro lacks such advantages of Windows as advanced memory management or the ability to stay active on screen while the user works in another application. Nor does it have Excel's impressive object-linking and embedding technology, which ties together, for example, a chart within a spreadsheet to its original data source. But for looks, both on screen and on paper, Quattro Pro yields little ground to the fancier Windows programs. **********Other improvements include better printing performance on laser printers and a "print to fit" feature that can condense a spreadsheet to fit onto a single page. For those whose worksheets are too big to fit legibly on one page, Quattro Pro has a banner-printing feature as well, for printing sideways on continuous-form printers. **********Some executives forgo paper and use their spreadsheets for computer-based presentations. For them, Borland has added a number of jazzy features, including sound effects and slide-show transitions, which employ television tricks like fades, wipes, dissolves and spirals. The effects can be quite impressive, although some users may find it gauche to start a presentation with trumpet fanfare and conclude it with the sound of digitized cheering and applause. **********Borland also includes a "Proview Power Pack" that offers guidance on how to use these special effects to best advantage. The Power Pack comes with a selection of clip art that can be used to add emphasis to reports or 35-millimeter slides, a collection of digitized sound effects, special shortcuts called macros and templates that automate the production of many styles of graphs and charts and two Bitstream headline fonts to supplement the 18 fonts included with the spreadsheet itself. **********All these new features augment what was already a superior spreadsheet, and it is somewhat surprising that Borland released version 3.0 so soon after the last major upgrade, version 2.0, which was introduced last fall. **********"It is very, very impressive that they were able to turn this around so quickly," said Louis Giglio, vice president and director of computer software and services research for Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. "Version 2.0 shipped in October, and here it is tax time and they've already shipped a new version with impressive new features." **********Quattro Pro has a list price of $495. Owners of earlier versions of Quattro Pro can upgrade for $49.95 to $99.95, depending on which version they have. And Borland will sell the new version for $129.95 to anyone willing to switch from competing high-end spreadsheets, a tactic that has made significant inroads against Lotus's 1-2-3. The Proview Power Pack is included with the main software; it costs an additional $49.95 for those who are upgrading or switching from a rival. **********"Some of Lotus's problems can be laid directly on Borland's doorstep," said Mr. Giglio. He said he expected the competition to heat up when Lotus, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., brings out its Windows version of 1-2-3 later this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.main_headline: Argentine Prosecutor Sees Trials of Generals Winding Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.print_headline: Argentine Prosecutor Sees Trials of Generals Winding Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.body_text: **********For the last seven years, Luis Moreno Ocampo has confronted the elite of Argentina's military, accusing them of crimes against the state, torture and murder, and trying to persuade judges to lock them up for years. **********His targets as the country's chief prosecutor have included members of the junta that ruled the country in the late 1970's and early 1980's, top police officials and commanders of the war against Britain in the Falklands. Others have been middle-ranking officers who staged four rebellions in as many years. **********While he has won convictions in almost every case, his problem has been insuring that the generals stay in prison. Since coming to office in mid-1989, President Carlos Saul Menem, arguing the need for national reconciliation, has granted pardons to almost all convicted military officials. **********But for now at least, Mr. Moreno Ocampo says, he sees the era of generals on trial winding down, and with it a diminishing in the threat of a military takeover that has cast a shadow over Argentina since its return to democracy in 1983. **********"We prosecuted the generals who ordered the disappearances," he said in a recent interview in his cluttered office in the Government's Palace of Justice. "We put them on trial for human rights abuses and made them face their accusers. We convicted the generals who started the war with Britain. But that era is over. The only thing left may be for the families to try to find some of the bodies of the disappeared."  Convictions Upheld **********On Monday, the 39-year-old prosecutor had a symbolic ending to his career as a thorn in the side of the military. Argentina's Federal Appeals Court upheld the convictions of 15 leaders of the rogue military unit called the Carapintadas, or Painted Faces, which staged a rebellion in December, two days before a visit by President Bush. **********It was the fourth uprising since 1987 by the Carapintadas, who get their name from the war paint they smear on their faces. In a day of violence, in which 600 soldiers commandeered tanks and took over government offices in downtown Buenos Aires, 21 people were killed and more than 200 wounded, raising once again the uneasy question whether after eight years of nonmilitary rule democracy was still only an experiment. **********But the response of both the military establishment and the civilian Government was surprisingly strong, with the army overpowering the rebels. **********Some officers called for the death penalty for the rebellion's leaders, and a military court promptly sentenced several to life in prison. The commanders appealed to the civilian courts, and Mr. Moreno Ocampo was called upon to insure that the sentences stuck. **********There are other signs that military experts use to argue that in the current political environment Argentina's history of military coups may be fading. The armed forces, through budget cuts, have been significantly reduced and are now poorly equipped. President Menem forced the air force to shut down its secret ballistic missile project in a display of executive authority. And public opinion polls show very little desire for a return to military rule. **********"The symptoms of lack of discipline and disintegration are many," said Rosendo Fraga, a military analyst. "And this has produced a noticeable wearing away of the pre-eminence of the Ministry of Defense and the four heads of the armed forces." **********Most important to Mr. Moreno was that the courts upheld the life sentence against the leader of the Carapintadas and mastermind of the last two uprisings, Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin. Despite the failure of the coup attempt, Colonel Seineldin has become a kind of folk hero among militant nationalist sectors of Argentine society, with graffiti appearing on many walls and kiosks around town saying, "Seineldin is the people." **********A commander in the Falklands war, Colonel Seineldin has said his idols are Franco and Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, the former military leader of Paraguay. Though a Muslim by birth, he converted to Roman Catholicism. He and others among the rebellion's leaders hold daily Mass in their prison cells. **********The basic Carapintada philosophy is that the Argentine civilian Government has compromised its traditions by aligning itself with the United States, which it considers has supported Communism in the Soviet Union. Colonel Seineldin has asserted that the State Department is "filled with Communists." **********Mr. Moreno Ocampo has argued that contrary to assertions by the Carapintadas that they were protesting poor pay and neglect, the December rebellion was a full-fledged coup attempt. **********But the Appeals Court did not agree. While it upheld the life sentence on Colonel Seineldin and stripped all the officers of their military rank, it reduced some of the sentences of the other officers. Mr. Moreno Ocampo cannot feel entirely at ease, given President Menem's record of pardoning previously convicted officers, even though he has promised that he will not pardon any of the convicted Carapintadas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/30/busin.body_text: **********THE expansion needs of the Capital Holding Corporation, a big insurer, are driving two major construction projects in downtown Louisville; one will be the tallest building in Kentucky. **********The insurer has formed a partnership with Gerald Hines Interests of Houston and Kawasaki Steel America, a unit of the Kawasaki Corporation of Japan, to build a $110 million corporate headquarters with offices to rent out as well. **********Separately, the Louisville division of the Dallas-based Paragon Group is under contract to build a $35 million office complex that Capital Holding will lease for subsidiary operations. **********Jack McCabe, managing director of real estate investments at Capital Holding, said the space commitments were made because "we are really busting at the seams." Capital is one of the top five publicly owned life insurers, with $16.7 billion in assets. **********The company's present 300,000-square-foot headquarters building, considered obsolete, is to be demolished when the new developments are completed early in 1993. The company's 1,700 Louisville employees are scattered through that building and in leased space in three others. **********Capital Holding is a minority partner, with an investment of $2.5 million, in the 700,000-square-foot tower to be known as Capital Holding Center. The filigree domed building, designed by John Burgee Architects of New York, will reach 550 feet and will dominate the city's skyline. **********The project is the first in Louisville for Hines and the three foreign lenders, which are putting $75 million in construction loans into the project. They are the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Banque Nationale de Paris (Paribas) and the Sumitomo Bank of Japan. **********Kevin Shannahan, Hines's vice president, said the decision to be involved in the most expensive multitenant office project begun in the Southeast this year was based on "positive events unfolding in the region," especially the steady increase in service-related jobs. **********The city is home to Humana Inc., one of the nation's largest health-care companies; United Parcel Services' international package-sorting hub; and the Ford Motor Company's most productive truck plant, where the Explorer sport-utility vehicle is produced. It is also home to Churchill Downs, site of the Kentucky Derby and of the 1991 Breeders Cup thoroughbred racing championships, which will be held on Saturday. It also has a fiber-optic telecommunications network that has attracted several national computer centers in recent years. **********Economic development officials have tracked a 25 percent growth in employment in health care, insurance, communications and transportation in the last five years. **********The city has not totally escaped the downturn in the national economy, but the real estate industry here is considered one of the healthiest in the country. New-home construction is up more than 5 percent for the year and the downtown office vacancy rate is 7.3 percent, according to a Cushman & Wakefield study. **********Capital Holding is to lease 185,000 square feet in the Capital Holding Center for its headquarters. Among the major tenants that have agreed to relocate to the building are Brown, Todd & Heyburn, the largest law firm in the state, and Vencor Inc., a hospital company. The building is 75 percent preleased. **********The land for the development, which is at Market Street and the Fourth Avenue Mall, was assembled by the city through its urban renewal powers. The city is building a parking garage there. It will be reimbursed for the property and receive a percentage of the parking revenues. **********Capital Holding will move 875 employees of affiliate operations to the 290,000-square-foot One Commonwealth Place, named after its primary subsidiary, Commonwealth Insurance. The complex will have a six-story office structure, a two-story data-processing center and a single-level training site and employee cafeteria. **********A company-subsidized day-care center and gym have opened in the ground floor of the complex's parking garages, which have been completed. **********The Capital Holding projects are not the only major developments in the city's central business district. Waterside Complex, which is being developed by Al Schneider, has been under construction since the early 1980's and will have one million square feet when it is finished. One of the three buildings in the complex is partly completed, and tenants have begun moving into the 300,000-square-foot structure. **********Waterside, by adding new space, may raise the overall vacancy rate, but the Cushman & Wakefield report indicated that the owners of older properties would bear the impact because of Mr. Schneider's leasing strategy. **********Space in Waterside is being offered at $12 to $20 a square foot, while space in the Capital Holding Center is being advertised at up to $23 a square foot.
