https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/15/busin.body_text: **********Alcoa says its earnings declined by half in the second quarter, while a competitor, Alcan Aluminium Ltd., said it lost $5 million in the period, primarily because of lower aluminum prices. **********Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum maker, said on Friday that its net income totaled $81.2 million, or 95 cents a share, compared with $161.9 million, or $1.86 a share in the second quarter of last year. Its revenues fell to $2.6 billion, from $2.74 billion. **********Alcoa, which is based in Pittsburgh, said prices for alumina, a fine, white powder used to make aluminum, were down 25 percent. That lowered earnings for its Alcoa of Australia unit, the world's largest alumina producer. **********Alcan, based in Montreal, said its $5 million loss contrasted with a profit of $84 million a year earlier. The loss included a $17 million charge related to staff cuts at Alcan's troubled Brazilian, British and Australian operations. **********Alcan's revenues fell to $2.02 billion, from $2.15 billion. **********The share prices of both companies rose on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, with Alcoa's gaining $1, to $70.375, and Alcan's rising 50 cents, to $20.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/19/busin.body_text: **********A California candy entrepreneur has patented a way to make customized chocolate bars that can be engraved with whatever logo, picture or message a customer wants. The system was invented by Jeffrey Robinson, founder of Totally Chocolate Inc. of Valencia, Calif., for companies that want to send gifts with messages. Mr. Robinson's company is using the system and selling close to $1 million worth of chocolate. **********He received patent 4,979,720.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Vatican; War Stirs New Demands in Italy For Vatican Recognition of Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Vatican; War Stirs New Demands in Italy For Vatican Recognition of Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/world.body_text: **********The Persian Gulf war and Iraq's missile attacks on Israel have prompted new demands for the Vatican to establish full diplomatic relations with Israel. **********Since Iraqi missiles first struck Israeli cities, Jewish groups in Italy have issued statements and organized a demonstration with unexpected backing from Italian newspapers and politicians who had not before been openly pro-Israel. **********About 50 members of Parliament formally asked the Government to press the Vatican into changing its stance on Israel. The missile attacks on Israeli civilians appear to have shocked many Socialists and Communists who have long been strongly pro-Palestinian. **********The Vatican has long argued that it cannot formally recognize Israel until its borders are accepted by its Arab neighbors. Although Pope John Paul II has often condemned anti-Semitism and supported Israel's rights to secure borders, he has equally defended Palestinian rights.  Dormant Issue Revives **********The issue of diplomatic relations, which is as old as the state of Israel itself, had been dormant for several years, and, a Jewish organizer in Rome said, "even the Government of Israel had stopped asking." **********But the issue arose again after the first Iraqi missiles hit Israel, as Italian Jewish groups and politicians complained that the Pope had condemned the bombing of civilians but failed to mention Israel by name. **********In his next sermon, John Paul called the bombing of Israel "disgraceful." But complaints from Jews and non-Jews about the lack of diplomatic links with the Vatican continued, some of them displayed on the front pages of leading newspapers. **********The Vatican has responded with a long statement, saying that it recognizes the state of Israel and that Popes and Israeli leaders have had personal contacts for more than 20 years. **********But the Vatican arguments on why diplomatic ties will have to wait has led to new controversy. In its statement, the Holy See reiterated that "difficulties" prevented diplomatic links, difficulties such as Israel's continued presence in the occupied territories, its treatment of the Palestinians and its annexation of East Jerusalem. Vatican Sincerity Questioned **********For the first time, though, it pointed to difficulties experienced by the Catholic Church in Israel and some of the occupied territories. A Vatican spokesman repeatedly cited this point when explaining the document. **********Israeli diplomats in Rome, including the Ambassador, retorted by questioning the Vatican's sincerity and saying that while other nations also have some of the cited differences with Israel, they had not blocked diplomatic links. **********Priests familiar with Vatican thinking said a more important, though unmentioned, reason for postponing diplomatic ties was the Vatican's worry that such links would make life even more difficult for the Christian minorities in the Arab world. **********The Rev. Peter Gheddo, an official of the Vatican's Missionary Office, said in a recent interview that Christians throughout the Middle East were suffering strong pressures from Islamic governments and were often ostracized politically and economically for being Christians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/01/world.main_headline: San Andres Journal; On English-Speaking Isle, Tidal Wave of Spanish
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/01/world.print_headline: San Andres Journal; On English-Speaking Isle, Tidal Wave of Spanish
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/01/world.body_text: **********Coursing over this island's coral cays and through its coconut groves runs an invisible cultural fault line that separates Caribbean reggae from Latin American salsa. **********On one side are the natives -- English-speaking, Protestant and black. **********On the other side are "the mainlanders" -- Spanish-speaking, Roman Catholic and Latin. **********In a reversal of roles for a cultural clash common to the Americas, it is the English speakers on San Andres who charge that the Spanish speakers are trying to wipe out their culture and their language. **********"The Spaniards get very cross -- they say they don't want to hear any English around here," said Fernando Broughton, a young taxi driver, telling of friends who were arrested this year for speaking in English to policemen who understood only the Spanish of mainland Colombia. **********English has been the language of inhabitants of this island and nearby Providence since English Puritans arrived in the early 1600's to establish cotton and coconut plantations. After a brief era as a lair for pirates like Henry Morgan, the archipelago in 1822 became part of Colombia, a newly independent nation 500 miles to the southeast.  Declared a Free Port **********But for decades the island was stamped by the Afro-English culture that still survives in pockets on Central America's Caribbean coast -- the nation of Belize and the port towns of Bluefields, Nicaragua; Limon, Costa Rica; and Bocas de Toro, Panama. **********Nervous that an island separatist movement might deprive Colombia of extensive fishing and mineral rights in the western Caribbean, a military dictator declared San Andres a free port in 1953, built a huge airfield here and started a heavy-handed colonization campaign. **********English-language Bibles were collected and burned. Baptist and Adventist schools were temporarily closed and then allowed to reopen only on the condition that teaching be in Spanish. Government jobs and scholarships were restricted to converts to Catholicism. Immigrants were lured here from the mainland with incentives like free passage and subsidized housing and electricity. **********"When Colombia decided to Colombianize us, they cut all our connections with our English-speaking neighbors," charged Bill Francis, a charter member of a native rights group that has emerged here, S.O.S., or Sons of the Soil.  A Dispiriting Island Tour **********Today, Colombians admit they are embarrassed by the effect of the colonization campaign. In 1954, the island had only 7,000 people, largely fishermen and farmers. Today, this 10-square-mile island is crowded with 70,000 people, giving it one of the highest island population densities in the world. **********On a recent afternoon, members of the now English-speaking minority served as guides for what became a dispiriting island tour. **********"This used to be one of our cemeteries," said Enrique Pusey, a Sons of the Soil leader, pointing to a lot now occupied by a tourist hotel and McPollo, a fried chicken joint. **********The coastal road passed other marks of Colombia's domination: a coconut processing cooperative that had been expropriated for a naval base; a mangrove swamp that was bulldozed to build vacation retreats for members of the Cali cocaine cartel, and the rocky skeleton of a two-mile beach in the native section of the island that had been dug up and trucked away for building materials. **********From the steeple of the First Baptist Church, a white clapboard structure built in the 19th century from imported Alabama pine, a visitor could see shantytowns filled with poor immigrants lured from Colombia's coastal cities. **********Although police harassment has subsided, the Sons of the Soil group still spreads its files among members' houses. **********At a recent closed-door meeting, a surprising amount of resentment toward "the Spaniards" flowed out on a river of Caribbean-accented English. **********One complained that English-language books, Bibles and magazines are routinely held up in customs, even though San Andres is a free port. American pastors never seem to get visas to preach for more than a few days. "The Spaniards" are changing place names -- Orange Hill is now Loma Naranja, Bean Hill is now Loma Frijol and Jones Point is Punta San Juan. **********"The Colombian Government wants to destroy our language, our culture and our race," Mr. Pusey said. **********But in Bogota, Colombia's confidence in cultural colonialism seems to be faltering. In the constitutional assembly, a proposal to respect the islanders' linguistic and cultural rights has won support from delegates who represent constituencies that are being heard for the first time in Colombia -- Indians, Protestants and former guerrillas. **********In mid-June, President Gaviria signed a measure declaring 15 mainland towns to be free ports with relaxed import duties -- a first step to move free-port tourism off this crowded island. **********During a break between lobbying the constitutional convention, Kent Francis James, the island's Governor, listed his demands: complete bilingual education, English-language television, restriction on land sales to mainlanders and free passage for immigrants back to "continental Colombia." **********Using a coinage increasingly popular among islanders, the Governor said, "We don't want to end up as the Palestinians of the Caribbean -- a people without a home."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Jack Goeken wants to make the flight from New York to San Francisco more "productive" ("Latest Quest by the Idea Man of Communications," April 28) with an executive office in the sky -- where one can "from the seat of an aircraft anywhere in the world . . . send and receive faxes, transmit data from a laptop computer and book hotel rooms." More productive? God forbid. What about reading, writing letters, listening to music, doing "nothing" or simply -- perish the thought -- wasting time by thinking? A. M. CLARFIELD Montreal, April 30

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/28/busin.body_text: **********General Mills Inc. said today that strong performances by its consumer foods and restaurant divisions helped earnings rise 21 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter. **********The company said it earned $90.9 million, or 55 cents a share, up from $75.3 million, or 46 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose 7 percent, to $1.83 billion from $1.71 billion. **********For its fiscal year ended May 26, the company reported profits of $473 million, or $2.87 a share, compared with $381 million, or $2.32 a share, the previous year. **********The news helped the company's stock gain $2 a share on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $57. **********The earnings figures included an extraordinary net gain of $26.5 million from the sale of the O-Cel-O sponge and Lancia-Bravo pasta operations. **********The company said operating profits for consumer foods rose 20 percent before the unusual gain and that restaurant profits rose 12 percent. Big G cereals, Betty Crocker Products and the Olive Garden restaurant chain made the largest contributions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/10/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Desperate Iraqis Rush to Surrender
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/10/world.body_text: **********At Checkpoint Charlie about 30 miles northwest of here, a steady stream of young Iraqis are trying to be taken prisoner. **********One after another, the young men approach the checkpoint, pull rumpled documents out of their pockets, and proclaim themselves to be members of Saddam Hussein's military. **********It is not easy to sell. In the topsy-turvy world of southern Iraq, the United States Army is a discriminating captor. **********American troops, who are preparing to leave Iraq soon, carefully screen Iraqis at the checkpoint to make sure that would-be prisoners of war are not simply desperate refugees trying to get out of Iraq. **********"They have to have proof for us to take them," explained Sgt. Maqsood Shah, a 28-year-old American soldier who was born in Afghanistan and is fluent in Arabic.  Intricate Escape Schemes **********American soldiers say some refugees are so desperate to get out of Iraq that they buy military passes to Basra on the black market and steal Iraqi military uniforms so they can pose as soldiers. **********Soldier or poseur, each day young Iraqi men walk away from the checkpoints here in allied-occupied Iraq, disappointed that they have not been led away by American military policemen for transport to prisoner-of-war camps in Saudi Arabia. Some return the following day with new documents, trying again to persuade the Americans to take them into custody. **********Iraq's acceptance over the weekend of United Nations peace terms, and the official truce put into place today, have heartened the American soldiers here. **********But it has unnerved many in southern Iraq who fear that the Saudi border will slam shut, with them inside and at the mercy of Saddam Hussein's army. **********The number of prisoners of war has shot up dramatically in recent days. Over the weekend, the Third Armored Division took in 988 Iraqi prisoners of war in one day, three times the average in the days before the cease-fire terms took effect. American soldiers have continued to accept Iraqis who have turned themselves in as war prisoners despite the cease-fire and the emerging peace settlment.  Possible Saudi Asylum **********If an Iraqi soldier becomes a prisoner of war and is taken to Saudi Arabia, he is given an opportunity to seek asylum there under international law. American soldiers at the checkpoints here say some Iraqi soldiers are repeaters, who turn themselves in after being returned to Iraq from camps in Saudi Arabia. **********Unless an Iraqi becomes a war prisoner, his best chance to get out is probably to join the throngs of refugees at the camps in Safwan. But right now the refugee camps are "something of a dead end," said Capt. Roland F. de Marcellus, 28 years old, of the Army's 404th Civil Affairs Company, a reserve unit from Trenton, N.J. **********The peace settlement to be administered by the United Nations has given the refugees in Safwan a measure of protection in the short run. Under terms of the settlement, Safwan is in the zone that is to be monitored by United Nations observers and troops. **********The area is tense despite the peace arrangements. Some of the refugees have threatened the Mayor and other local officials because they support the Government of Saddam Hussein. **********Many refugees say Mr. Hussein has planted spies in the camp and are afraid of what will happen when the Americans leave. The south of Iraq is the region dominated by Shiite Muslims, many of whom took part in the recent ill-fated revolt against Mr. Hussein's rule. Some have already died, and many others assume further reprisals are coming.  Indictment of U.S. Role **********The long-term future for the refugees is uncertain, and the United States has done little to reassure the refugees on this count. **********An Iraqi professor complained that the United States has not set up an effective system for processing requests for asylum. Requests are taken by officers and funneled up the chain of command. But it is not clear what, if anything, is done with them. And no State Department officials have come here to help deal with the refugee problem, Captain de Marcellus said. **********The captain said the refugees were told that it is "highly unlikely that they will get asylum of any sort while we are here." **********"Our goal is to give them an honest appraisal and let them make the decision," he added. "They know what the risks are."  Outside the Future U.N. Zone **********A further problem is that many of the would-be refugees are outside the six-mile strip inside Iraqi territory to be occupied by United Nations forces. **********As a matter of policy, the Army is not arranging transportation for the refugees to Safwan, though exceptions are quietly made for high-ranking civilian officials who want to leave Iraq as well as Iraqis bearing important information about their country's military. **********The American concern is that the raising of such hopes would make Safwan a magnet for a huge number of Iraqis who would flee here. But even without American help, Iraqis continue to stream here in dilapidated buses and trucks, some hitchhiking along the highway to Safwan. **********"It is not our policy" to transport them, Captain de Marcellus said. "That would reinforce the delusion that we could help them more than we can. We don't want them to think we can get them out of the country."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/busin.main_headline: Technology; Push 'M' for Mayo, Sales Pitch Included
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/busin.print_headline: Technology; Push 'M' for Mayo, Sales Pitch Included
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/busin.body_text: **********When they enter the Pathmark supermarket here, shoppers can pick up computerized grocery carts that display advertisements and other information while they push the carts along. **********Infrared triggers on the ceiling above the entrance to each aisle, working like television remote controls, tell the small computers on the carts to display programs about products as the shopping carts near them. **********At the end of the day, Pathmark managers, as well as product manufacturers, can study where customers took the carts, how long they lingered near certain displays and whether the advertisements displayed on the computer screens resulted in purchases. **********The system, developed by Videocart Inc. of Chicago, is being tested at nearly 50 supermarkets, including such chains as Von's in Los Angeles, Dominick's in Chicago and Winn Dixie in the South. It reflects the growing interest in "point-of-purchase advertising," in which products are promoted as customers approach them or examine them. **********"This is a tremendous boon to retailers because it enables them to better understand the flow through the store and better merchandise products," said Robert L. McCann, executive vice president of Videocart. As the argues the case, the Videocart service "is revealing very important marketing data." **********Asked about the new system one recent evening in the Pathmark here, Hank Rodriquez, 68, said, "If your're looking for sales, the carts are great. Everybody thinks they're cool." **********Well, not everybody. **********"They're fun for the kids and everything, but when I use them, I tend to ignore the screen," said Cecilia Pacheco, 24. "I know what I'm going to buy when I come here. It's just a toy, but it's not a help to shop." **********Videocart began working on the system in 1986 when it was a unit of Information Resources Inc. of Chicago, a company that tracks retail sales. Videocart was spun off as a publicly traded company last October; its first annual report, issued this spring, showed a loss of $6.7 million for the fiscal year ended in March on revenues of $4.9 million. Its executives have not predicted when they expect the company to turn a profit. **********Videocart's technologies remain largely hidden from shoppers because infrared and FM radio signals control the system. The carts themselves look just like standard shopping carts, except for a 6-inch by 9-inch liquid crystal screen and computer perched on the right side of the handle. **********The unit appears similar to a laptop computer screen. Underneath is the computer itself, which has 1 megabyte of memory, about 800 kilobytes of which are programmable so advertisements and other information can easily be changed. The system has no audio capability, so customers receive information only by looking at the screen. A rechargeable battery under the cart supplies power. **********A satellite dish on the supermarket roof receives new advertisements and other data from Videocart headquarters in Chicago each week. The information is loaded into the cart computers each week. Immediate changes can be made through the FM radio channel that a central computer in the store uses to communicate with the carts. **********The system works like this: As a customer enters an aisle, the cart passes through infrared waves transmitted by the trigger that tell the cart where it is located. The computer begins to display a list of specials for products in the aisle. **********For example, as the shopper approaches the condiments section, a picture of Kraft salad dressing is shown, along with a pitch for the brand. At soft drinks, the screen displays an advertisement for Pepsi. **********The screen also displays messages inviting shoppers to press buttons on the computer in order to locate products and see a sample of recipes that use the brands they are examining. And the computer can display a map pinpointing the customer's location in the store. **********Videocart recently unveiled yet another feature: electronic coupons. When customers examine a particular brand, the computer tells them that they can save money on the product by pressing a button. If the customer agrees, the computer sends a message to the checkout counter so that if the product is scanned at the cash register, the coupon value is deducted from the bill. The computer keeps track and the discount is granted only to that particular customer if the product is bought. **********All this technology, of course, is not cheap. A system for a single store, including 150 to 200 shopping carts, is about $100,000, Mr. McCann said. Ordinary carts, purchased in bulk, cost about $100 each. **********The company's revenue stream is based on charging manufacturers $3 per thousand shoppers a week for each advertisement at each store. Mr. McCann said the company determines how much to charge each chain by weighing the size of the supermarket and how much visibility a particular supermarket can provide for the carts. The supermarket can also promote items on its own that the manufacturers are not paying a fee to advertise. **********Most supermarkets allow customers to choose between Videocarts and standard shopping carts. Giant Food of Washington, which is testing the carts at its store in Frederick, Md., has found that 55 to 60 percent of shoppers take the Videocarts, said Joanne Anderson, the chain's manager of data processing field support. **********At the Pathmark store here, which has been testing the system since March, customers also prefer the Videocarts and have reported few problems using them, said Frank Pagano, an assistant manager at the store. **********Mrs. Anderson of Giant Food said she had had a number of questions about the Videocarts before the chain began testing them in May. "We were concerned about how to get the batteries recharged, how labor-intensive the system is, are the batteries safe, and whether the radio frequency would interfere with any other frequencies used in the store." **********But she said Giant has encountered few problems. **********"Reaction from customers has been very positive," she said. "I think they see it the way we want them to see it -- as an additional service from Giant." **********Still, Videocart will have to overcome resistance from shoppers who don't see grocery shopping as a pleasant experience. **********"I'm very familiar with the layout for the store, so the carts are not very useful," said John K. Ryan, a 52-year-old lawyer. "Given the choice, I avoid using them. From my vantage point, they contribute nothing that adds efficiency to the shopping experience."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/busin.body_text: **********A former official of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International has agreed to break all connections with B.C.C.I. and cooperate in the investigation of the scandal-ridden bank, the Federal Reserve announced today. **********In exchange for agreeing to the cease-and-desist order, the Fed said it was dismissing administrative charges against Khusro K. Elley, the former head of B.C.C.I.'s New York office and a senior executive of the First American Bank of New York. **********The agreement does not imply any admission of guilt, according to the order, which was effective on Friday. **********B.C.C.I., based in Luxembourg, is enmeshed in a global scandal involving drug-money laundering, arms trafficking and fraud. **********It pleaded guilty on Friday to racketeering charges and forfeited an estimated $550 million in United States assets. Prosecutors are now focusing their attention on B.C.C.I. officials that they have accused of wrongdoing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/busin.body_text: **********With many countries struggling against slowdowns or recessions, economists are hanging on every development in the Persian Gulf for signs of how much economic damage the war is likely to cause. But few economies appear poised to benefit as much as Japan's in the event of a brief war, or have the staying power to endure a long war with as little strain, a range of experts say. **********Japan has been criticized for contributing money but not personnel to help in the allied effort to force Iraq out of Kuwait, even though it is more dependent on Middle East oil than any other industrial country. Now some economists say that in the war's aftermath, Japan may enjoy the greatest economic boost, particularly if the risk of soaring oil prices is reduced.  A Difficult Transition **********This is not to say that Japan's economic forecast is entirely rosy. Even before the crisis began, Japan was in the midst of a difficult economic transition. Growth is slowing from its blistering pace of the last several years, a problem in a country that considers expansion of less than 3 percent a recession. The stock market plunged 40 percent last year as interest rates soared, corporate profits are falling, and many are predicting property prices will decline after big increases in the 1980's. The recession in the United States is also threatening to cut into Japanese exports. **********Most menacing, economists say, are the glaring weaknesses in Japan's financial sector: many fear that a sharp slide in Japan's real estate prices is posing a threat to banks, which have made hundreds of billions of dollars of loans with land as collateral. **********The mounting difficulties Japan faces sound similar, in fact, to those in the United States. But there is one huge difference: while America's policy makers are rapidly cutting interest rates and fighting to save banks, protect jobs and stave off an economic contraction, the Japanese Government has deliberately slowed the boom here by tightening its monetary policy and keeping interest rates high. **********"The biggest possible cause of a recession in Japan is too tight a monetary policy by the Bank of Japan," said Takao Akabane, formerly the vice minister at the Economic Planning Agency. **********Overly easy monetary policies during the latter half of the 1980's, then a severe tightening in the last year, are responsible for the current precarious balance in the markets, economists say. **********It is a risky policy, to be sure, because the markets have already shown a tendency to spiral out of control when investors panic in the face of big price declines. But many analysts are confident that Japanese economic managers are skillful enough to succeed, barring a huge external shock. **********"Our real fear is outside disturbances like the Persian Gulf, not internal forces," said Yoshihisa Kitai, chief economist at the Long Term Credit Bank. "As for the internal factors, the Bank of Japan has chosen this tight monetary policy so it can avert a collapse if it wants to" by trimming interest rates should the economy slow too much, he said. **********Moreover, because of its long-standing budgetary conservatism, Tokyo has the leeway to increase growth with higher Government spending, if that becomes necessary. Japan has already agreed with the United States to increase public investment and could accelerate this program. Revamping the Banking System **********Underlying the tight money is a broader policy goal that could affect Japan's financial system for years: the restructuring of the banking sector. The Finance Ministry wants to encourage smaller banks to merge with stronger institutions, forcing the long-protected institutions to be more competitive. **********It was reported Friday in the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading economic daily, that the Finance Ministry had even created a special group within the deposit insurance system to handle mergers between small- and medium-sized banks. Ministry officials denied that such a mergers unit had been created, but the report was consistent with comments made publicly and privately by officials for months. **********Many worry that this approach may succeed in improving the profitability and innovativeness of a few Japanese banks, while weakening many others and perhaps causing a rash of bank failures because of tight money and a crash in the property market. Any failures or crashes -- which have never occurred in Japan -- could strain the Government's ability to engineer a controlled strengthening of the industry.  Unprepared for a Shock **********Susumu Saito, director of the Trilateral Institute, a research and advisory body, warned that few banks were really prepared for another shock to either the stock market, on which they are dependent for capital, or the property market, on which so many of their loans are based. "Many of the banks are assuming that the worst is past," he said. **********But Mr. Akabane, the former Government economic planner, said: "A severe economic situation would be an inviting time to restructure. The bureaucrats don't say this explicitly, but I think this is in their minds." **********The overall goal is to produce a financial sector that would match in strength the vibrant health of the industrial economy, which was strengthened considerably by Government policies of the last five years. Big corporations used the booming markets of the late 1980's to remove debt from their balance sheets and go on an unprecedented capital spending binge, sharply improving their efficiency. **********"There is going to be a shakeout among the regional banks and tremendous pressure on the city banks," said Kenneth Courtis, chief economist here for Deutsche Bank. "The Ministry of Finance clearly believes and says it will use this environment to restructure the sector. The trick is to accomplish this without causing a crash." **********What Japan calls a slowdown, of course, would be a solid year in the United States. The economy grew 5.4 percent in 1990, with unemployment slightly higher than 2 percent and inflation close to 3 percent. **********Officially, the Government is forecasting a 3.8 percent growth rate this year, as high interest rates begin to bite. The official discount rate for Government loans to banks has been jacked up to 6 percent, from 2.5 percent just 18 months ago. **********There have been a rash of real estate-induced bankruptices as a result, not to mention the collapse of stock prices last year. In December alone, the number of business failures rose 45 percent.  Few See Doom **********Some economists see growth of closer to 3 percent in 1991, but few accept the predictions of doom that have made headlines in recent weeks. **********"The world has seriously mistaken what has happened in Japan," said Richard Koo, a senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute. "The Bank of Japan is trying to slow the economy with every tool they have. This is a policy-led slowdown because it's the only way they can clear out all the excesses of the past few years, when monetary policy was too easy." **********Added Susumu Kato, chief economist for Goldman, Sachs (Japan): "There are problems, but they're manageable. We don't see those kind of crash scenarios taking place." **********Indeed, hardly a day passes when Yasushi Mieno, the governor of the central bank, does not deliver another insistent sermon on the need to keep interest rates high to bring sky-high property prices down and cool the economy. He has said publicly that he would not mind a decline in land prices of 20 percent, a figure that he also said would not cause unmanageable losses for banks. **********"The extreme case is several hundred billion yen in losses from real estate loans for each major bank," said Mr. Kitai. "But I still see the chances of this extreme case as relatively low."  Lower Debt Ratings **********Even some of the tougher critics of Japanese banks take this view. For instance, Moody's Investors Service, the credit-rating agency, stunned many here by lowering the ratings of Japan's big banks over the past year, warning of real estate-related difficulties. **********But Roger Arner, head of the Tokyo office of Moody's, said his concerns were for the profitability of the banks in a tough environment, not their ability to survive, as is the case with many large American banks. **********"You have to remember that their ratings are still very high, on balance," Mr. Arner said. "This is not New York."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/01/world.main_headline: Serbia Says It Is Accepting European Peace Proposal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/01/world.print_headline: Serbia Says It Is Accepting European Peace Proposal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/01/world.body_text: **********Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, announced today that it was accepting a European Community plan to send foreign observers to oversee a cease-fire in Croatia and set up an arbitration commission to resolve the overall Yugoslav crisis. **********"The basic elements of this document, which are the result of France's plan and support, are acceptable for Serbia," said Serbia's Foreign Minister, Vladislav Jovanovic, on Belgrade television tonight. "We consider that it is reasonable, balanced, and does not favor any one side." **********Mr. Jovanovic rejected the European Community's charge that Serbia was fueling the conflict in separatist Croatia, which has pitted Croatian militias against ethnic Serbs there who oppose secession. The Foreign Minister said European Community officials were not recognizing the "culpability" of Croatia's armed forces. **********Serbia for over a month has blocked attempts by the community and Croatia's government to send foreign observers to monitor several failed cease-fires in Croatia. A serious rise in the fighting throughout the separatist republic in the last week has brought sharp criticism from the 12 community nations and the United States.  Army Said to Side With Serbs **********This week a community envoy confirmed charges that the Yugoslav Army, which is led by a largely Serbian officer corps, was intervening on the side of the rebel Serbs in Croatia. The army insists it is acting only as a buffer between the Serbs and Croats. **********Mr. Jovanovic said tonight that Serbia would accept foreign cease-fire observers so long as they are civilians. **********In his attacks on the community's initiatives, Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, has always referred to foreign observers as "foreign troops" and said Serbia would never accept them on Yugoslav soil. **********The Yugoslav Army is now the only key player in the Yugoslav crisis not to have announced a decision on the community proposal. Both Croatia and the Yugoslav federal Government approved the plan days ago. **********The community gave all sides until Sunday to agree to a cease-fire, allow foreign observers to monitor compliance, and arrange peace talks. They threatened unspecified sanctions against any party that did not agree to the plan. **********Before the Serbian announcement tonight, fighting flared again today in Croatia. **********In the Danube River town of Osijek, in the ethnically mixed farmlands of eastern Croatia, skirmishes with automatic weapons were reported through much of the day. The long siege of the river city of Vukovar also continued, with pounding from Yugoslav Army artillery, from gunboats on the Danube River and from Serbian rebel units. **********In the Serbian stronghold of Knin, on the tip of Croatian land touching the Adriatic, the Serbian-controlled radio reported that rebel Serbs had repelled a Croatian police force controlling the mountainous national park at Plitvice. But the report could not be independently confirmed. Clash at Zagreb Airport **********Zagreb, Croatia's capital, was unusually tense. Croatian officials closed the airport to civilian traffic after army troops fired on Croatian policemen who approached two civilian aircraft that had earlier been forced to land by Yugoslav fighters. **********The press agency Tanyug later reported that one of the aircraft -- a civilian Air Uganda jet forced down while en route to another separatist republic, Slovenia -- was found to have 19 tons of rifles, ammunition and anti-tank guns on board. The second plane was allowed to depart after a search. **********[ A senior Croatian government official quoted by The Associated Press said it appeared that some Croatian police officers died or were hurt when their vehicle was hit by a tank or artillery during the airport clash. ] **********In Zagreb's old town, the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, met through the day with his government's officials. In a televised interview this evening, Mr. Tudjman gave no indication that Croatia intended to widen hostilities, which he said had already claimed more than 308 lives on the Croatian side. **********"I think that a peaceful end to all of this is possible," he said, "and that those who started this aggression against Croatia will be forced to have talks to end the aggression."  Return to Barracks Demanded **********Mr. Tudjman warned earlier this month that Croatia would in effect declare war on Yugoslavia if the national army units in his republic were not ordered back to their barracks and if the rebel Serbs who have brought large areas of Croatia under their control were not brought to heel by tonight. **********Analysts in Yugoslavia doubt that Mr. Tudjman can risk taking on the larger and better-armed national army. **********In the two months since Slovenia, Yugoslavia's wealthiest republic, declared independence, and Croatia, the second most wealthy, said it would initiate steps toward "disassociation" from this multi-ethnic country, more than 300 people have been killed, 140,000 people have fled their homes, federal authority has collapsed and the economy is in a shambles. **********Croatia's leaders argue they are fighting simply to maintain control over their territory. Serbia insists it is not seeking to annex Croatian land, but defending what it says are the endangered 600,000 ethnic Serbs residing in Croatia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/09/world.body_text: **********Helmut Kohl Chancellor of Germany **********Helmut Kohl has been enthusiastically preaching the benefits of European unity. He would like to see European nations surrender much of their national sovereignty and accept a powerful European Parliament, an independent central bank and a single currency, and in this he has the support of virtually all German politicians. **********On several occasions, Mr. Kohl has publicly referred to his own experiences during World War II. He was too young to be drafted into the German Army, but for several years he was a local civil defense worker. One of his jobs was to help pull bodies out of bombed buildings, and he says that experience instilled in him an intense desire to prevent war. Union, he believes, is the best insurance. **********Mr. Kohl, who is 61 years old, joined the center-right Christian Democratic Union after the war and rose steadily through its ranks. He was elected Chancellor in 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.main_headline: Kremlin Transfers Coal Mines To Control of Russian Republic
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.print_headline: Kremlin Transfers Coal Mines To Control of Russian Republic
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Government transferred control of the Siberian coal industry to the Russian republic today, marking a milestone in Boris N. Yeltsin's campaign to wrest economic and political authority from the Kremlin. **********After months of conflicting claims by the central Government and the republics, with resulting confusion over ownership and control of natural resources and industries, the agreement on the mines represented the first sizable transfer of an important industry from the national Government to that of a republic. **********Before today's accord, Mr. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic's Parliament and principal political rival of the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had complained that Russia effectively controlled only 16 percent of its wealth.  Satisfying a Demand **********The transfer of control was a principal demand of strikers who have sharply reduced output at vital mines in Siberia. **********The Russian radio said the agreement covered more than half the coal mines in the Soviet Union, including primarily the Kuznetsk Basin in central Siberia, but also the Sakhalin Basin in the Far East and the Rostov mines near the Ukraine. The Soviet Union is the world's largest coal producer, and coal ranks as one of its primary sources of energy. **********Details of the transfer were not immediately known, except that regulation of the mines would pass from the Soviet Coal Industry Ministry to the Russian Fuel and Energy Ministry. **********Mr. Yeltsin pledged to give the mines considerable economic autonomy, suggesting that instead of quotas and deliveries set by the central authorities, the mines would eventually negotiate direct agreements with customers. **********Coming immediately after a truce declared 10 days ago at a meeting between Mr. Gorbachev and the leaders of nine republics, including Mr. Yeltsin, the transfer seemed to foreshadow a new pattern of power sharing between Moscow and the 15 increasingly assertive republics that make up the union. **********Mr. Yeltsin told the Russian Parliament today that Deputy Prime Ministers Yuri Skokov of Russia and Vitaly Doguzhiyev of the Soviet Union had signed agreements on the transfer, which is to take effect Sunday. **********Mr. Yeltsin also announced today that he had reached agreement with Vladimir Kryuchkov, the chief of the K.G.B., to form a Russian version of the security and intelligence agency. Details of the division of responsibilities were not immediately known, but the agreement marked another step in the decentralization of power. **********The Russian Parliament also opened debate on the creation of an executive presidency, with elections scheduled June 12. Mr. Yeltsin is expected to win handily, though a lively race is shaping up with the declaration of candidacy by Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, the former Soviet Prime Minister.  Other Yeltsin Initiatives **********The Parliament session is also to consider a package of other measures that Mr. Yeltsin is seeking to enact, including creation of a constitutional court, perhaps the first step toward an independent judiciary in the Russian republic. **********The impending transfer of the coal mines was disclosed last week when Mr. Yeltsin traveled to the Kuznetsk Basin. The miners there, who have been striking since March 4, welcomed the idea but remained suspicious and decided to continue striking until the deal was concluded. **********They remained skeptical today. Aleksandr V. Smirnov, a member of the Novo-Kuznetsk City Strike Committee, said workers in the majority of mines pledged to continue striking "until they see the first signs of implementation of the signed accords." It was expected, though, that the miners would quickly resume work once the signing is confirmed. **********There was no immediate comment from the Kremlin, and Mr. Yeltsin avoided any gloating in his speech to the Russian Parliament, saying only that he was satisfied that the coal mines had remained in proper working condition through the two-month strike. His approach apparently reflected reluctance to antagonize Mr. Gorbachev or to further excite the touchy miners.  Gorbachev Resignation Demand **********Besides seeking higher pay and improved working conditions, the miners have political demands, including the resignation of Mr. Gorbachev and the delegation of more power to the republics, as well as the transfer of mines to Russian jurisdiction. **********The strike-plagued Kuznetsk Basin in Siberia is the second-largest producer of coal in the Soviet Union after the Donetsk Basin, which is situated mainly in the Ukraine; half the estimated 130 million tons produced in the Kuznetsk region is high-quality coking coal that feeds a huge metallurgical complex in Siberia. **********In assuming control of the Siberian coal industry, Mr. Yeltsin also assumed some enormous problems of that region, including antiquated mines and rundown cities. **********Today, Mr. Yeltsin told the Russian Parliament that if Mr. Gorbachev's intentions were "truly serious, if this is not another attempt at political intrigue, this is the first important step on the way out of the crisis." **********After so many earlier false starts, many Soviet citizens have been reluctant to pin large hopes on the latest truce.  Indications of Seriousness **********But the Kremlin's agreement to transfer the mines to Russian control, and the low-key handling of the transfer by both sides, seemed to mark a serious effort to resolve the power struggle between Moscow and republic authorities. **********In a way, the Siberian miners thus became both the catalyst and the first beneficiary of the truce. **********Their strike was the first major workers' action to make political demands. The action began with a series of spontaneous walkouts, and ended with a majority of miners walking out and demanding Mr. Gorbachev's resignation. **********Mr. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov tried at first to ignore the strike, then to dramatize its effects, and finally to offer the miners a generous economic package, all to no effect. **********The strike thus became the symbol of distrust and displeasure with Mr. Gorbachev at a time he was seeking to introduce a crisis program.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge upheld his $64.1 million award to a New Jersey concern that says Iraq breached a contract to buy industrial furnaces by maintaining they were meant for civilian rather than military use. **********Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin's order, issued Thursday, also allows the Consarc Corporation of Rancocas, N.J., to try to collect some of the money by asking that some Iraqi assets in this country be unfrozen. **********Judge Sporkin rejected the Bush Administration's argument that the award conflicts with United States economic sanctions imposed on Iraq. The Administration said it was working toward an "orderly resolution" of all claims against Iraq. **********Judge Sporkin ruled on April 5 that Consarc was entitled to $9.1 million in costs and $55 million in damages from Iraq for four industrial furnaces it custom-built for the Baghdad Government. **********Iraq had told the company it would use the furnaces to produce artificial limbs for victims from its war with Iran. But American officials determined the furnaces would be used to produce nuclear weapons and lightweight titanium parts for extending the range of Iraqi missiles. **********Consarc, the nation's largest producer of specialty furnaces for the automobile, aerospace and aircraft industries, contended that Iraq had used fraud and deceit to skirt restrictions on exporting weapons components.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/world.body_text: **********Tens of thousands of anti-Government protesters rallied in major cities across South Korea today, demanding the resignation of President Roh Tae Woo. **********Estimates of the total number of demonstrators ranged from 100,000 and 400,000, and the rallies were probably the largest since the student and worker uprising in 1987 that helped lead to democracy here. One million people were said to have walked off the job or to have boycotted classes. **********Clashes between protesters and the riot police were reported natiowide. Seoul's city center was brought to a standstill by fighting between students armed with firebombs and stones, and riot police officers who retaliated with volleys of tear gas. A police spokesman said 28 police officers were wounded nationwide. There were no reports on injuries to protesters, and no arrest figures were provided. **********The demonstrations are the latest in a series provoked by the killing of a student protester on April 26. The protester, Kang Kyong Dae, died after being beaten by the riot police. The killing has aroused such passions that in the last two weeks three people, including two students, have committed suicide in protest by setting themselves on fire. Demonstrators' Demands **********Today's demonstrations made good on a threat by leftist leaders, who had set a Wednesday deadline for the Government to meet a number of demands. **********Those include the resignation of the Cabinet, the disbanding of riot police squads of the kind responsible for the death of Mr. Kang, and the prosecution of the entire chain of command -- from the Interior Minister down -- behind the squad that killed Mr. Kang. **********The Government made some concessions. The Interior Minister at the time of the killing, Ahn Eung Mo, was dismissed. The riot police squads were ordered not to deploy at demonstrations, and the law on public gatherings is to be reformed. But the deadline passed without further reaction from the Government, and this morning, Prime Minister Ro Jai Bong rejected the call for the resignation of his Cabinet and said the Government would deal resolutely with any disturbances. **********"Our choice is no other than the democratic order," the Prime Minister was quoted as telling a Cabinet meeting. "We cannot but stand firmly against all illegal, violent protests and actions on the grounds that we must protect the people."  An Echo of 1987 **********The authorities are aware that it was the death under police torture of a student militant that provoked the student uprising in 1987, which toppled the military regime of President Chun Doo Hwan. The authorities are also aware that the 1987 uprising was successful only because workers and the growing middle class began to take to the streets in support of the students. **********This year the students are largely on their own, though the numbers are high. The number of protesters in Seoul today was put at 35,000 to 100,000. State television reported 50,000 demonstrators in Pusan, the country's second-largest city, 30,000 in Kwangju, a traditional center of anti-Government activity, and large numbers in Taegu, Masan, Taejon, Inchon and Chongju. **********"There is no sign whatsoever of the middle class coming out in support," said a Western diplomat who asked not to be identified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/busin.body_text: **********The Government said today that it was putting tighter lending standards into place for mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration. One lending group charged that the move would reduce home sales by as much as 200,000 annually. **********The new rules will require people financing their purchases with F.H.A.-backed mortgages to pay higher closing costs and for the first time they will have to make annual payments for mortgage insurance. **********"These new regulations could not have come at a worse time," said Warren Lasko, executive vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association. "These changes will lock out thousands of families who will no longer be able to afford a home."  'Hits Right at Middle America' **********He added that his group, which represents 2,300 mortgage lenders, would lobby Congress to overturn the new regulations. "This requirement hits right at middle America -- young, moderate-income families trying to insure some measure of economic stability for themselves by buying a home," he said. **********The F.H.A. said the requirements, which take effect July 1, were required to shore up a mortgage program that is losing $200 million a year. It estimated that the more stringent requirements would prevent 20,000 potential buyers from purchasing homes. **********However, housing groups contended that the new rules, which come as the housing industry is struggling to emerge from a two-year slump, go much further than intended by Congress. Mortgage bankers estimated that the new rules could reduce annual home sales by 100,000 to 200,000 annually, enough to abort a housing recovery and to make it more difficult for the overall economy to emerge from the recession. **********Jack Kemp, Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, said when the Administration first proposed the requirements last year that they were necessary to "protect the taxpayer from bearing the costs of poor management" of the program. **********A recent audit by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, estimated that the F.H.A.'s cumulative losses were approaching $7 billion, partly because the agency did not require sufficiently large down payments. With less of their own cash at risk, homeowners were more likely to default on their mortgages. **********One of the new requirements taking effect July 1 will limit closing costs that can be financed in the mortgage to 57 percent. At present up to 100 percent of closing costs can be financed. **********That would mean a home buyer taking out a $100,000 F.H.A. loan and facing closing costs of $2,500 would have to pay $1,000 of the closing costs out of pocket, rather than financing the full amount as part of the mortgage. New Insurance Premium **********In addition, F.H.A. home buyers now will have to pay a new annual mortgage insurance premium of five-tenths of 1 percent. Previously, they had been required to pay only an up-front premium of 3.8 percent. On a $100,000 loan, the new premium would add $80 to the monthly payment. **********The new rules also require that homeowners refinancing existing F.H.A. loans pay the new insurance premiums. **********The mortgage program was set up by Congress in 1934 and provides for 800,000 new loans each year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; Using Bacteria to Control Pollution
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/busin.body_text: **********Bacteria may be better than chemicals or absorbent materials at controlling emissions of volatile solvents that contribute to low-level smog and at eliminating the odors of sewage treatment plants and composting operations, experts in the field say. **********Although the use of bacteria to clean up pollution on land and in water is still in the experimental stage, at least two dozen biological filters are in use in this country, scrubbing out odors and breaking foul organic compounds into more benign carbon dioxide and water. **********Biofilters or soil bioreactors, as they are called, take advantage of bacteria's ability to adapt themselves to feed on whatever material is available, from tree leaves to propane. **********The filters are decidedly low tech and appear from the outside to be little more than a mound of dirt. But they can control air emission problems without consuming the chemicals used in scrubber systems or without the regeneration systems needed with activated carbon treatment. **********S. C. Johnson & Son Inc. uses a biofilter to treat emissions of pentane and butane that escape from its aerosol can filling operations in Racine, Wis. "We lose from 30 to 100 tons from the aerosol filling line a year," said Timothy Lafond, the environmental manager at Johnson's Waxdale manufacturing plant. "On average we get 90 percent-plus control efficiency" from the biofilter, he said. The bacteria present in the soil break the relatively simple hydrocarbons into carbon dioxide and water, which are vented into the atmosphere. **********Since volatile organic compounds like pentane and butane contribute to low-altitude smog, emissions are being progressively restricted by Federal and state regulations. The Johnson filter has been in continuous operation since December 1988 with little maintenance other than watering in dry periods.  Key Ingredient Is Dirt **********Like most biofilters, the principal ingredient is dirt. Air from around the aerosol filling is collected and blown into a grid of perforated pipes laid in a bed of gravel. The gravel diffuses the air-solvent mix, which rises into the three-foot-deep dirt filter. **********In it, the hydrocarbon molecules are adsorbed on droplets of water and then broken down by microbes that obtain energy and elements necessary for their survival and growth in the process. The oxygen-rich atmosphere insures that the offensive compounds will be converted chemically to oxides before leaving the filter. **********The Johnson filter occupies an acre between two factory buildings. It is covered with grass and looks like an open field. The performance of the filter fluctuates with the seasons because it is based on living organisms. Mr. Lafond says that 99 percent of the hydrocarbons are destroyed in warm weather, but that the breakdown rate drops to 65 percent in severe cold as the bacteria become less active. **********Mr. Lafond said it was not necessary to develop special strains of bacteria to make a soil filter work. "The bugs are already there," he added. But he said there was a "learning curve" when it was first used, as the bacteria adapted to feed on the hydrocarbons. "We started at 30 to 40 percent efficiency and gradually took that up to over 90 percent," Mr. Lafond said, as the solvent-eating bacteria increased in number.  Looking for Green Grass **********Since moisture in an important part of the treatment process, the water content of the filter is monitored. "If the grass is green, then we assume the water is O.K.," Mr. Lafond said. "If it starts to turn brown, then we get concerned." Lawn sprinklers are used until the grass is green and lush again. **********Since the bacteria feed on the wastes they are treating, the filters can be operated for years with little attention. Maintenance is sometimes limited to cutting the grass. The one exception is in cases where the chemical products of the breakdown process tend to acidify. Many of the bacteria that best remove odor-causing compounds are sensitive to acidity of the soil. Once again, though, the solution is simple. **********For example, in Gainesville, Fla., a soil filter is used to remove hydrogen sulfide -- a toxic gas with a rotten-egg smell -- from a sewage treatment plant. Although the filter removes more than 99 percent of the offensive gas, according to Eric R. Allen, a professor of environmental engineering at the University of Florida, the sulfur oxides produced by the breakup of hydrogen sulfide tend to combine with the moisture in the earth to form sulfuric acid. **********"We have to add lime to offset the acidity," Professor Allen said.  'Very, Very Cheap' **********He said the low-tech nature of biofilters had made it difficult to convince engineers accustomed to chemical treatment systems of their value. But he said economics might increase their attractiveness. "They are very, very cheap to operate," he said. **********A report produced by Geoffrey A. Kuter of International Process Systems, which uses biofilters to control odors from composting operations, indicated that the annual operating cost would be 44 percent less than a chemical scrubbing system and 75 percent less than activated carbon -- which is highly adsorbent because of its large surface area. **********One drawback is the amount of land required for a biofilter. Not every industrial site has an acre or more to set aside to treat emissions. "If you have a lot of area, then you can use a biofilter," said Sam Cha, a chemist with TRC Environmental Engineering in East Hartford, Conn. "But if you do not, they you would probably want a carbon system, because they are very compact." **********There are a variety of formulas for the composition of biofilters, depending on the compounds to be treated. Ordinary soil, compost and peat provide the microorganisms, and other materials, like volcanic ash, sand and bark, are used to make the pile porous. Mr. Kuter said the ideal filter had 40 to 60 percent empty space to allow air to circulate. **********He said biofilters were merely an engineered version of a technique practiced for centuries: covering foul-smelling materials with soil to control odor. Some examples are the soil covers typically found over septic systems and garbage landfills. **********But he said the effectiveness of this approach had been limited by the amount of oxygen present in the soil. By controlling the amount of air being mixed with the substance to be treated, biofilter operators can insure an abundant supply of oxygen. **********Biofilters have been widely used in Europe and Japan, and are gradually attracting more interest in this country. "We did our project before it became popular," Mr. Lafond said. "Now a lot of people are very interested in biological systems."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Reporter's Notebook; Desert Fires Announce A Victory to the G.I.'s
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Reporter's Notebook; Desert Fires Announce A Victory to the G.I.'s
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/world.body_text: **********The war against Iraq finally became visible today for hundreds of American soldiers camped out along the tense but still largely quiet border between Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. **********From their positions, they could see the flames rising this morning from 24 burning Iraqi tanks, armored personnel vehicles and supply trucks, a result of what was described as the most successful, confirmed allied attack on Iraqi armor since the war began. **********"They were sloppy and they were caught," Col. Ron Richard said of the Iraqi military convoy that was destroyed by American warplanes as it moved across the open desert Monday night. "It was the first hard kill we've gotten on a big target." **********Colonel Richards, of the Marine Second Division, told a small pool of American reporters organized by the Defense Department that the Iraqi convoy had apparently been on routine maneuvers near the border when it was detected by a squadron of Marine Harriers and other allied warplanes. **********The armored vehicles were still on fire at daybreak, and the flames could be seen for miles across the barren desert flats that have become the front lines of this war. **********American military officials released details today of another skirmish near the Kuwaiti border -- this one well inside Saudi territory. **********According to the American account, an Iraqi officer was killed in a botched ambush of Saudi border guards on Sunday night. Three Saudi guards were wounded slightly in the attack. **********The ambush was reported to have occurred several miles inside the Saudi border -- under military reporting rules, the exact location cannot be identified -- when 12 Iraqis opened fire on the three Saudis, who were in a pickup truck. **********A senior American military official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said the Iraqi officer was shot in the chest, apparently the victim of Iraqi crossfire. The other Iraqis were taken into custody by American soldiers.  Pocket Money for British **********Sightseeing costs money, and British troops have begun packing $5 million in small bills into unused ammunition boxes, ready for Britain's frontline troops when, and if, they march into Kuwait. **********Lieut. Col. Tom O'Donnell told a pool of British reporters today that every soldier joining in the ground war against Iraq would be given at least $60 -- more for senior officers -- to buy food, drinks, cigarettes and souvenirs during their stay in Kuwait. **********"We felt we would not be able to use Iraqi money and there is doubt over the viability of the Kuwait dinar," Colonel O'Donnell said. The American dollar has long been the preferred foreign currency in the Middle East.  Men Behind the Trons **********Lieut. Steve Schwing says he lives to put "trons on target" -- the electrons, that is, that the lieutenant and his fellow Navy aviators direct against Iraqi air-defense stations to jam their radar. **********Lieutenant Schwing is an electronic countermeasures officer aboard one of the Navy's EA-6B Prowler jets, chubby carrier-based planes that have the job of zapping enemy radar. **********The work of the jamming teams is little understood, but it is crucial to the success of the American air war against Iraq. **********"It is so important that you would not run a strike without us," said Lieutenant Schwing, a 29-year-old Austin, Tex., native who joined the Navy because "it was the best way I could think of to fly." **********The Prowlers have been buzzing Iraqi air-defense stations since the war began, overwhelming the Iraqi radar systems with electron bursts that make it impossible for the Iraqis to monitor American aircraft. **********Instead of seeing American bombers on their screens, the radar operators who control Iraq's surface-to-air missiles see an image of bicycle spokes, or pie-shaped cutouts, or a blizzard of electronic snow. **********Worse for the Iraqi technicians, the jamming puts their lives at risk. Unless they turn off their radar screens, they suddenly become a target for the Prowlers' high-speed antiradiation missiles, or HARM's, which follow the path set by enemy radar beams. **********The Prowlers' jamming campaign has helped neutralize Iraq's surface-to-air missiles. **********"About all the SAM's they have fired that we have seen so far are unguided," said Comdr. Mark Lawrence, 38, the intelligence officer on the aircraft carrier Roosevelt. "Because they are afraid of our HARM missiles," he said, the Iraqi radar system operators blink their radar screens "on and off -- or they just leave them off." **********The exact abilities of the Prowlers' radar-jamming equipment is classified. But Lieutenant Schwing said Navy aviators still talk about the plane that accidently left its jamming equipment on a few years ago and knocked out electronic communications in much of the city of San Diego.  A Wedding Is Planned **********There is romance in the desert sands. **********During a sandstorm at a Saudi air base several weeks ago, Dee Ann Heiderscheit, a 27-year-old Air Force staff sergeant from Dubuque, Iowa, stopped at a bus station to ask directions. **********The stranger who gave her directions, Staff Sgt. Steve Poole, 27, of Copperas Cove, Tex., is now her fiance. They are planning a spring 1992 wedding in Dubuque.
