https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/busin.print_headline: Piano-Making at Steinway: Brute Force and a Fine Hand
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/busin.body_text: **********In Steinway's turn-of-the century factory in Astoria, Queens, tour guides proudly tell visitors that the craftsmen and managers are bound to the company for generations. "We believe in nepotism, supremely," said Horace Comstock, the guide on a recent tour, describing a traditional, inbred world. **********Today, however, the company is less inbred. Its new general manager has been at the company less than three months. And the waves of Italians and Greeks and other European immigrants who built pianos here for generations have been replaced with newer immigrants, many of whom do not stay as long. **********On the shop floor, young men, some with pony tails and tattoos, assemble black concert grand pianos while piano music wafts in from a radio in the corner. It is Bruce Springsteen's "Blinded by the Light." **********If the workers are very much today, much of what they do would seem ripe for modernization. The company gives the impression of not having fully absorbed the concept of interchangeable parts, popularized by Eli Whitney in 1798. No  Standard Sizes **********For example, a computer-controlled woodworking tool is deliberately set to make parts slightly too big, so that a craftsman can later strip away unneeded wood. If the tool cut the wood to a standard size, said Sanford G. Woodard, the general manager, it would fit with others but not perfectly; the only way to do that is by hand. **********Rim-making, a procedure that is at the heart of Steinway technology, seems comically primitive. To make the U-shaped rim, six workers stack 18 wooden boards and carry them, like a long ladder, around the twisting confines of the factory. The boards are run through rollers like a washing-machine's mangle, to coat the sides with glue. A worker with a pot and a paintbrush applies more on spots the roller missed. **********Then the men wrestle the boards around a mold in the shape of a piano. They attach the straight side first. Then the men line up on the free end and push hard, forcing the boards around the curve. Later, they attach a block and tackle, to force the boards around the frame. The only deviation from muscle power is a power-driven torque wrench, used to tighten the bolts that hold the wood to the right tension. **********Production of rims could be automated, but the company builds them only three mornings a week, turning out only about 2,500 last year, a number that hardly justifies a major investment. Yamaha, known for its degree of automation, produces 200,000 pianos in some years. **********Other manufacturers' rims tend to de-laminate over time, the company says, which means the end of the piano. But Steinway rims, demonstrably, endure for more than a century. This is part of what allows them to be rebuilt so successfully. **********Once the frames are bent on the mold, they are left to age, said David A. Grossi, the national service manager, leading a tour recently. "Sometimes the frame relaxes a quarter inch or an eighth of an inch, and assumes the shape it's going to have for its lifetime," Mr. Grossi said. "We let it do that; it's part of a Steinway."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; New Restrictions in Maxwell Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.body_text: **********An American suspected of having played a central role in helping Robert Maxwell siphon off hundreds of millions of dollars from employee pension funds has been barred from leaving Britain, it was disclosed today. **********Larry Trachtenberg, who became a director of Bishopsgate Investment Management Ltd. in September and resigned last week, was ordered by a judge not to leave the country. Mr. Trachtenberg was also an executive at London and Bishopsgate International Investment Management P.L.C., which is under investigation for its role in transferring pension funds. **********The disclosure came at a news conference held by Neil Cooper, a corporate-recovery expert whom an English judge appointed on Sunday night to take control of an investment-management firm owned by the Maxwell family, and by Margaret Cole, a lawyer assisting him. They have already begun to try to trace and secure the missing pension fund assets. **********The Bishopsgate firm is believed to be at the heart of the system masterminded by Mr. Maxwell to move $:763 million ($1.38 billion) from pension funds and two public companies controlled by the Maxwell family. **********"He was obviously central," Mr. Cooper said of Mr. Trachtenberg. **********Investigators say they believe that Mr. Maxwell used the money in a desperate and ill-fated attempt to prop up his private companies. Last week, a month after his death, his two main private companies filed for the British equivalent of bankruptcy protection. Now, most of the Maxwell empire is expected to be sold off. **********The six Maxwell pension funds that had assets controlled by Bishopsgate should have assets worth about $:727 million ($1.31 billion), Mr. Cooper said. Mr. Maxwell is now believed to have taken about $:426 million ($769.6 million) from the funds. **********Mr. Cooper said about $:327 million was missing from the funds. **********Miss Cole said that success in tracing the assets was no guarantee that they would be retrieved because the financial institutions that now have them may be able to assert legal rights to them. **********Conflicts over ownership could arise, she said, because a Maxwell firm, possibly Bishopsgate, might have had title to the pension fund shares and sold them to others when Mr. Maxwell was said to have ordered the firm to raise cash. Now title to those shares may be legitimately held by other institutions. Giving Up a Passport **********The judge's order to Mr. Trachtenberg required him to surrender his passport until he had provided any information he might have on Bi shopsgate. **********The judge took the same action earlier this week against Mr. Maxwell's two sons, Kevin and Ian, and also froze up to $:450 million ($812.9 million) of Kevin Maxwell's personal assets. Kevin Maxwell is considered to have been more involved in efforts to transfer pension fund assets than his older brother. But early today, the judge decided to allow Kevin Maxwell to go to New York to work on the reorganization of The Daily News, which filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States last week. **********Kevin Maxwell had argued that his presence was urgently needed in New York to save The Daily News; the judge told him to return by Friday evening. Selling a House **********When he gets back, his four-story house in London's Chelsea section could be for sale. Mr. Maxwell and his wife, Pandora, have said they are putting it up for sale; estimates are that it could bring $1.6 million to $3.1 million. **********"We have a mortgage like everyone else," Mrs. Maxwell said. "Ob viously I am worried about the future. My husband doesn't have a job, so we are going to have to sell the house." **********The Maxwell family also decided that a New York memorial service for Mr. Maxwell that had been scheduled for Wednesday would be postponed. More than 600 people had been invited to the service scheduled for noon at the Park East Synagogue in Manhattan, according to John G. Campi, vice president of promotions and public relations at The Daily News. Notices of the postponement were sent out this week. **********One of the two big public companies controlled by the Maxwell family, Mirror Group Newspapers P.L.C., has already needed to raise money after Robert Maxwell took at least $:97 million ($175.2 million) from the company. A group of banks announced today that it had agreed in principle to give Mirror a short-term loan. **********As for Mr. Trachtenberg, the court ordered him to provide information on the investment firms. He has already been reported to have said that he was involved in transferring assets. But it is not clear that what he did was illegal: he may not have known that the assets were not going to be returned. **********A special team from Coopers & Lybrand Deloitte, the accounting firm, examined the Maxwell empire at the request of banks after Mr. Maxwell died, and Mr. Trachtenberg told them that he transferred shares from one of the Maxwell investment firms to Robert Maxwell's personal safe.  Role Is Questioned **********One person at a large pension fund in the Maxwell empire said Mr. Trachtenberg had dictated investment instructions to the pension funds before he had any role at the Bishopsgate firm. This official noted that as an executive of London and Bishopsgate, a separate firm that merely invested pension-fund money that Bishopsgate assigned to it, Mr. Trachtenberg should not have had that power. **********For this reason, pension fund officials had made Mr. Trachtenberg a Bishopsgate director in September.  "Trachtenberg started to attempt to issue instructions in the name of Bi shopsgate, claiming to be so instructed by Robert Maxwell," the official said. "It was agreed in those circumstances that he should be appointed a director so he had the responsibility and the liability." **********Although it is unclear whether Mr.  Trachtenberg did anything illegal, the transfer of the pension assets is under investigation by the Serious Fraud Office and by regulators. **********Mr. Trachtenberg, who had once been a lecturer at the London School of Economics, was co-managing director at London and Bishopsgate . **********Attempts to reach Mr. Trachtenberg were unsuccessful.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/busin.body_text: **********A furious political battle broke out in California today over the future of the state's huge public-employee pension fund, with the fund's leaders charging that Gov. Pete Wilson was trying to pack its board and squash its highly visible shareholder-rights campaign. **********The fight broke out after Governor Wilson, a Republican, proposed legislation over the weekend that would enable him to tap the fund for $1.6 billion to help close the state's $14.3 billion budget deficit. **********The legislation would also permit Mr. Wilson to abolish the current 13-member board of the California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, as it is known, and replace it with a new nine-member board, five of whose members would be appointed by the Governor. The other four would be appointed by the Legislature. The Governor effectively appoints four members to the present board, or less than a third.  Wilson's Motives Questioned **********Calpers executives and representatives of workers and retirees charged today in response that the proposals were unconstitutional. They said the proposals were motivated largely by what they said was Governor Wilson's desire to win favor in the business community by silencing the pension fund's efforts to force large corporations to be more responsive to shareholders. **********"You could clearly characterize this as an attempt at a hostile takeover," said Dale M. Hanson, chief executive of Calpers. **********An aide to Mr. Wilson called the fund's view of the situation "garbage." Other state officials said the intent of the proposals was not nearly so nefarious as Mr. Hanson and his supporters had made it out to be. They said Governor Wilson was just seeking maximum flexibility to deal with the worst budget crisis in the state's history.  Vote Could Come This Week **********David J. Tirapelle, the state's director of personnel administration, said the Governor had developed the board proposal along with legislative leaders "essentially to provide greater accountability to the taxpayer." The proposals are contained in two bills that could be voted on by the State Senate and Assembly this week. **********The state pays about $1 billion annually into the public pension fund, which has assets of $65 billion and is the largest in the country. **********Mr. Hanson has been at the forefront of a shareholder movement among large public pension plans, challenging corporations to explain poor performance, to hold down executive compensation and to appoint more board members with no ties to management. **********This year alone, Calpers has taken on the ITT Corporation, Sears, Roebuck & Company and the General Motors Corporation over various issues, generally winning at least compromise agreements that call for the companies to consult more closely with their shareholders. Mr. Hanson's efforts have consistently been backed by the fund's board, although some members have expressed reservations about pushing the issue too hard.  'Promise to Business' **********Mr. Hanson said in a telephone interview today that he believed at first that Mr. Wilson wanted to change the board out of concern that the current board would resist any efforts to tap its funds to close the budget deficit. **********"We learned this weekend as we met with legislators," Mr. Hanson said, "that that is not the purpose, that the Governor has made a promise to business that he will put a more compliant board in there so we will not be so active in corporate governance." **********The proposals also drew sharp criticism from Kathleen Brown, the State Treasurer, whose seat on the board would be eliminated. Ms. Brown, a Democrat, called the proposals "a very inappropriate kind of power play" by Mr. Wilson. **********"Calpers has been in the leadership nationally, whether in trying to rein in executive compensation or in bringing more independent directors onto boards," Ms. Brown said. "To introduce this takeover into the context of our state budget deliberations does a disservice to the budget process." **********It was unclear how much support Governor Wilson's proposals might have in the Legislature. Mr. Hanson said an initial tally showed that 27 of the 40 state senators supported the proposals, but he said that opposition from workers and retirees, among others, might change the situation. **********Ms. Brown said talks were under way in the Legislature that could bring some compromise at least on the issue of whether the state could tap pension fund money to close the deficit. She added that the situation was so fluid that it was difficult to say what the outcome might be. **********Mr. Hanson said pension officials had tried to make offers to state officials to help the state resolve the budget problem in a way that would not create problems of fiduciary responsibility for Calpers. But, he said, state officials, including Thomas Hayes, the director of the State Finance Department, had not responded to the offers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/02/busin.main_headline: BANK REGULATORS SEEKING TO RELAX ACCOUNTING RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/02/busin.print_headline: BANK REGULATORS SEEKING TO RELAX ACCOUNTING RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/02/busin.body_text: **********With banks in many regions of the country shying away from making new loans, Federal banking and savings regulators moved to ease that logjam today by recommending a relaxation of the standards used by banks to put a value on their loans. **********Specifically, the regulators called for changes in the way banks evaluate commercial and real estate loans that are in trouble. The new accounting standards would enable banks to report greater profits on such loans, providing them with an incentive to extend credit to more borrowers. **********Many banks and savings and loans are in trouble, mainly because of loans that went sour in a troubled economy. As these troubles mounted, banks and customers started complaining that bank examiners, with the savings and loan fiasco fresh in their minds, were becoming too aggressive in scrutinizing loans. This in turn was said to compound the tightening of credit, particularly in New England, where the economy has quickly eroded. The Goal: Easier Credit **********Officials said the long-awaited measures were intended to counter these complaints and to make it easier for people and businesses to get loans. **********"There is an atmosphere of fear in financial institutions out there that they are going to get whacked in the back of the head if they make any loan," said John E. Robson, Deputy Treasury Secretary and the senior Administration official coordinating the regulatory changes. "That is clearly not the atmosphere you want to have." **********But critics said today's measures would eventually come back to haunt the industry and the Government because the changes dilute standards at a time when increasing numbers of large banks are failing or reporting lower earnings. They likened the proposal to the decisions in the 1980's to relax standards for savings institutions and to refrain from closing weak institutions. **********"It's not as egregious a forbearance standard as the savings and loans, but it mirrors the excesses," said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa and a member of the House Banking Committee. "It conveys the notion that toying with the books is legitimate, and therefore obviates the need for commercial banks either to raise more capital or shrink." **********Mr. Leach said the new standards would increase the likelihood of a taxpayer bailout of the Federal program that insures deposits at banks and would also have the effect of deferring "the necessary consolidation of the industry." **********The guidelines clarify the way banks put a value on real estate loans and on their financing of transactions made with a large amount of debt. They also call for greater disclosure about loans on which the borrower has stopped paying interest. The changes have been urged by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. **********The guidelines were issued jointly today by the Federal Reserve, the Comptroller of the Currency, the Office of Thrift Supervision and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. **********None of the proposals require legislative action, but the most significant one, involving the treatment of non-performing loans, is subject to final approval by the bank regulators and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which oversees accounting standards. That is expected to occur after the 45-day period set aside for comments from accountants and industry representatives.  Allowing Some Leeway **********The proposal would allow so-called loan-splitting, in which a troubled loan still paying some interest would be divided into good and bad parts instead of being entirely written off. Existing guidelines require banks to label the entire amount of such loans as "nonperforming," which is the category for loans that are 90 days past due or are so troubled that the bank does not expect full repayment. **********As an example of a loan that should not be written off entirely, regulators today cited a homeowner who is delinquent on mortgage payments, but who promises to start making payments after 90 days and then does so. Currently, the bank would have to write off the entire loan but under the changes the bank would be able to recognize the interest payments. **********These are some of the other changes and guidelines: ***********Banks and savings associations would not have to put a value on real estate in a troubled market, reflecting the depressed price the property would bring if it was sold immediately. Rather, the value put on a house, apartment building or commercial property should reflect its market value over a longer period, which would give the bank the chance to benefit from an upturn in the market. ***********The definition of "highly leveraged transactions," which include company buyouts or other broad changes that rely on a large amount of debt, would be loosened so that it would no longer include certain kinds of debt. Bankers and regulators keep track of such transactions to help judge an institution's soundness. ***********Weak banks would be encouraged to make loans to "sound borrowers" even though such loans would further dilute the bank's capital level, a formula that is generally viewed as an indicator of a bank's health. ***********Financial institutions would be encouraged to provide greater disclosure of the details of their entire loan portfolio. **********"We hope that the actions taken today will encourage lenders to make prudent loans and assure that examiners perform their review in a balanced, sensible way," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said, describing the measures as a "sensible approach to the credit crunch." **********The pressure on regulators to act swiftly has been apparent for weeks. Senators and representatives from New England have threatened to oppose the Bush Adminstration's proposal to provide more financing for the savings and loan bailout until the Administration addressed the tightening of credit.  Quick Action Urged **********In a House Banking subcommittee hearing on Thursday, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d pursued an aggressive line of questioning and urged senior regulators to move quickly, even if it meant circumventing the normal process for changing the rules. Mr. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, suggested that the banks be permitted to ease accounting standards immediately, before the Securities and Exchange Commission formally acted, and then return to the old standards if the agency later objected. **********But that idea was quickly rejected by Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the S.E.C., who said he could not "throw the rules out the window," adding that 'the worst mistake made in the thrift disaster was the move to weaken accounting rules." **********On Wednesday, Mr. Breeden said that "there is nothing inherently wrong" with the idea of loan-splitting, but that he wanted the commission to be able to study the concept fully before aprroving it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.main_headline: 16 Are Charged in Computer Parts Scheme
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.print_headline: 16 Are Charged in Computer Parts Scheme
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.body_text: **********Federal authorities said that they had broken up a $6 million racketeering scheme that took discarded computer parts and illegally sold them. **********The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced indictments on Tuesday against 16 people in the scheme. Last month, the Digital Equipment Corporation, made similar accusations in a suit that named many of the defendants. **********The investigation centered on Windham Recovery Systems Inc., a Boston company that contracted with Digital to reclaim precious metals from discarded computer parts. **********The authorities said that instead of being destroyed, the parts were shipped to California and resold. They said some parts were also sold after being stolen from Digital warehouses. The indictment said the scheme netted $6.4 million from early 1989 to September 1990, and the money was laundered to conceal the profits. **********Named in the indictment was Philip M. Carnovale, 38 years old, of Boxford, Mass., who is an officer of Windham Recovery Systems. **********Mr. Carnovale and the company were named in the suit Digital filed on June 12 in Federal District Court. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., said in its suit that the scheme lasted from 1984 to 1990. **********According to the indictment, Windham employees bribed a Digital warehouse worker and stole parts from the site even before the company entered into the contract with Digital. **********Also charged was Louis Buckman, 29, of Plymouth, Mass., who was accused of getting a job as a security guard at Digital's warehouse in Athol, Mass., to allow others there to steal parts. **********The products were shipped to the Moore Group of Torrance, Calif., a company that buys and sells used computer products, the indictment said. The parts were also marketed by Fred Kleinerman, 40, of Boca Raton, Fla., through a venture called KBG Inc. **********Mr. Kleinerman was among those indicted, as were two others described as officers of Moore: Ruslan Moore, 51, of Houston, and Darrell S. Pierro, 32, of England. Neither the Moore Group nor KBG was charged. **********The defendants face various charges, including racketeering, interstate transportation of stolen property and money laundering.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/04/busin.main_headline: SOVIET VENTURES ARE LOSING APPEAL FOR U.S. BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/04/busin.print_headline: SOVIET VENTURES ARE LOSING APPEAL FOR U.S. BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/04/busin.body_text: **********One casualty of the political and economic chaos in the Soviet Union has been American enthusiasm for investment there. **********The explosive tensions between Moscow and the Baltic republics, as well as the bureaurats' dogged hold on power, make the Soviet Union a far less welcome place for investors than Eastern Europe. Most former Soviet satellites have eased visa restrictions, are closer to the Western European market and, unlike Moscow, usually do whatever it takes to attract Western ventures. **********As a result, the small but steady flow of American investment into the Soviet Union, which began in 1987, has greatly slowed down. Many companies that were leaning toward investing here are thinking again. The dollar amount lost might be relatively small, but the Soviet Government remains hungry for Western technology and management expertise as well as money. Three Forms of Caution **********"The Western financial and investment community is more cautious now," James H. Giffen, president of the American Trade Consortium, a group of major American companies that is negotiating to invest in the Soviet Union, said in an interview at his Moscow office. "This caution is taking the form of either withholding investment entirely, slowing investment or downsizing investment." **********The experience of Dresser Industries, a Dallas-based producer of oil-drilling equipment, reflects the difficulties facing Western investors. When President Mikhail S. Gorbachev began courting Western investors four years ago, Dresser jumped at the chance and set out to build two factories in the world's largest oil-producing nation. **********Today, despite climbing hurdle after hurdle, Dresser's plans, remain just that -- plans. The ministry Dresser was working with was almost abolished. It found it had to negotiate with both Moscow and the republics, which are locked in a tense tug-of-war. And Dresser's state-owned joint-venture partner said it did not have the money to help build the factories.  'Situation Getting Prohibitive' **********"Things have changed," said Raymond Cossette, coordinator of Soviet activities for Dresser, which says it has not given up. "The situation in this country looks as if it's getting prohibitive." **********Other American companies have similar woes, and many corporate executives are considerably less enthusiastic than they were when plans for Soviet investment were formulated. After two years of negotiations, RJR Nabisco Inc. is still waiting to sign papers to produce cigarettes in Leningrad and crackers outside Moscow. The Colgate-Palmolive Company is mired in negotiations with the Ministry of Health to open a toothpaste plant this year in Kiev. **********"The Soviet Union is a large market with a massive population of 280 million people, and obviously that represents a lot of teeth for us," said Edgar J. Field, group vice president for international business development at Colgate-Palmolive. Still Seeing Opportunities **********Many American companies are loath to drop their plans. They still see colossal opportunities, and America's corporate giants want to make sure they are not the last to arrive as one of the world's largest countries and consumer markets opens its economy to the outside world. **********Among the other American companies that continue to negotiate in the Soviet Union are Texaco, Chevron and Eastman Kodak. They hope to join companies that have already invested here, Pepsico, McDonald's, Johnson Wax and Combustion Engineering among them. **********Some American executives even privately support a drift to dictatorship, saying someone needs to take firm control of the chaotic situation. Still, they worry that the increasing power of old-guard Communists will slow, and perhaps threaten, the transition to a market economy. **********"The fact that there may be some reactionary influences at work I don't think scares investors all that much," said Karl von der Heyden, chief financial officer for RJR Nabisco. "The basic thrust is toward a more open society." Abundance of Horror Stories **********Every American in Moscow has a horror story or two about the difficulty and unpleasantness of living and working in the Soviet Union. Even though the McDonald's restaurant in Moscow had a contract to buy chopped meat for one ruble a pound, it is being forced to pay seven times that. Some American executives who come to explore prospects go away complaining about unappetizing meals that cost $75 and shabby $200-a-night rooms in hotels where 25-watt bulbs and prostitutes are part of the decor. **********Making investment less inviting are the K.G.B. officials who rail against Western executives for gathering what the K.G.B. contends is sensitive information about the Soviet Union. American companies are also often unsure whether they should negotiate with the national Government or individual republics. **********"There's a lot of uncertainty about what can and cannot be done," Michael Adams, chief executive of the Young & Rubicam advertising agency office, said in an interview in his Moscow office. "You have the Russian Federation saying, 'Come on down; let's make a deal,' and then you have the all-union government making fundamentally different policy. You don't know whether to scratch or wind your watch." **********For months, Mr. Adams has been searching for a respectable house or apartment. A Communist Party official who got wind of his quest invited him to look at a modest house at a riverside retreat for party functionaries. Mr. Adams inquired about the rent and was stunned: $12,500 a month. **********American investment in the Soviet Union is as varied as American industry. Chevron plans to drill for oil; McDonald's has opened the world's busiest restaurant, on Gorky Square; Price Waterhouse has a small accounting office; Tambrands makes sanitary napkins in the Ukraine; Combustion Engineering's joint venture makes process controls for oil refineries. **********Mark S. Vecchio, a Moscow-based lawyer with the firm of Coudert Brothers, said many American companies were attracted by the nation's immense natural resources and large proportion of highly skilled low-wage workers. But some companies invest without doing their homework, he said. 'Lots of Wishful Thinking' **********"There is lots of wishful thinking about what is possible," he said. "Some companies think, 'If there is such an immense consumer market, then all I have to do is come in and the Soviets will buy my product.' But they forget that the Soviet ruble is not convertible, which makes it hard for them to take out their profits." **********More than 2,000 joint ventures have been registered so far in the Soviet Union, but because of the bureaucratic thicket they must hack through, only about 500 are up and running. Of these, about 100 are losing money. **********Several of America's best-known companies have set up the American Trade Consortium, in which one member, Chevron, will in theory provide the hard currency for the others through its revenues from exploring and developing Soviet oilfields. All told, consortium members hope to invest more than $10 billion over the next dozen years. **********"We wouldn't be here if we didn't think we could make a profit," said Mr. Giffen, president of the consortium and chairman of the Mercator Corporation, which is serving as its merchant bank. "The trick is to have a profit level commensurate with the downside risk." Soviet Entrepreneur's View **********Andrei Stroyev, widely considered the Soviet Union's foremost entrepreneur, criticizes Americans for being far more hesitant than Europeans to invest here. **********"American business thinks that the best solution is just to be careful and that waiting is better," Mr. Stroyev, a real estate developer, said. "But I can't close my door because there are so many Germans, Swiss, Swedes, Austrians, Italians knocking." **********He is co-chairman of one of the few successful Soviet-American joint ventures. It is named Perestroika, and it specializes in real estate development. Its American partner is the Worsham Group, an Atlanta-based developer. **********The two-year-old venture renovates buildings and then rents offices to blue-chip companies, including Hoechst, Mitsubishi and Fiat. They pay their rents in hard currency, making the Worsham Group one of the few companies that can easily repatriate its profits. Service-Oriented Concerns Gain **********Many service-oriented companies have also been successful. Ernst & Young, Price Waterhouse and other large accounting firms rushed to open offices here, which help Western companies prospect for partners and analyze Soviet businesses and balance sheets. **********Advertising agencies do market research and public relations for Western companies. The law firms here, including Coudert Brothers and Baker & McKenzie, help draw up contracts and negotiate with Kafkaesque ministries. Manufacturers have a far tougher time. **********An aluminum company wanted to start a joint venture in Armenia, for example, but backed off when it learned that neighboring Azerbaijan had cut the rail lines.  McDonald's Talks Took 14 Years **********McDonald's had to weather 14 years of negotiations before opening one restaurant in Moscow. **********Although the rubles-only restaurant has generated little hard currency earnings, George Cohon, chairman of McDonald's Canada and vice chairman of McDonald's in Moscow, said the outlet was a huge success, with 50,000 customers a day and 1,200 workers. The company plans to open several more restaurants soon, including one that would sell hamburgers for hard currency. **********Looking out at the 90-minute-long line of shivering people, he said: "Sure, it's a risk to be here now. But it might be a bigger risk to wait. I don't care what system there is in this country: people are going to continue flooding into this place."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/15/busin.main_headline: Loss Could Force Businessland Into Bankruptcy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/15/busin.print_headline: Loss Could Force Businessland Into Bankruptcy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/15/busin.body_text: **********Businessland Inc., once considered the nation's premier retailer of personal computers, said today that it had been cut off by one of its key lenders and might have to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. **********The announcement came as the San Jose, Calif., retailer reported a net loss of $43 million for the third quarter, ended on March 31. The loss, its sixth consecutive quarterly deficit, put the company in violation of agreements with various creditors. **********Businessland said the ITT Financial Corporation had ceased to provide any more financing for Businessland's purchase of personal computers from Apple Computer Inc. and the Compaq Computer Corporation. Unless it can reach an accommodation with ITT Financial or figure out a new way to finance its inventory, Businessland "will be unable to continue to conduct its current level of operations," the company said in a statement. **********The company said it is exploring alternatives, including a sale of the company or a restructuring, as well as a bankruptcy filing. It said it was in discussions with a possible buyer, but declined to identify it.  A Long Slide **********The announcement culminates a long slide for Businessland, which became the largest company-owned chain of computer stores but was unable to adjust to the intense price competition that has characterized computer retailing in recent years. **********"Businessland is no longer viable as a continuing separate entity," said Seymour Merrin, a personal computer retailing consultant in Palo Alto, Calif., who has long been critical of the company. **********It is also likely to be the final blow to the credibility of the company's founder and chief executive, David A. Norman. As recently as last Friday, Businessland officials had vehemently denied that a Chapter 11 filing was being contemplated. They also denied that ITT Financial, a unit of the ITT Corporation of New York, had cut off the company's inventory financing. **********Industry executives say Businessland is hoping its computer suppliers will extend it credit, rather than see a major distributor of their machines go under. **********Businessland said it was in violation of its agreement with the I.B.M. Credit Corporation, which finances its inventory of personal computers from the International Business Machines Corporation, but that I.B.M. was continuing to make financing available. Businessland has long been considered a supporter of the I.B.M. personal computer. **********Industry executives say one company looking at buying Businessland is JWP Inc. of Purchase, N.Y. JWP had $2.8 billion in revenues in 1990. **********Other companies might also look. Mr. Merrin, the consultant, said Businessland would probably go into Chapter 11 before being bought, so the buyer would have some protection from the chain's existing creditors. **********Businessland's third-quarter loss was higher than expected on operations and included a restructuring charge of $17.7 million for closure of stores and work force reductions, and a $6 million reserve for settlement of a shareholders' lawsuit against the company. **********Revenues for the third quarter were $269.7 million, down 17 percent from $323.4 million a year earlier. In the previous third quarter the company had a loss of $3.6 million. **********Businessland's stock, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed at 7.03 cents, down 92.97 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.main_headline: A.T.& T. And NCR Hold Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; A.T.& T. And NCR Hold Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.body_text: **********The chairmen of A.T.& T. and NCR met for several hours yesterday in New York in an effort to negotiate a friendly end to an often bitter takeover battle, but no agreement was announced afterward. No accord was reached on price and no further meeting scheduled, people close to the talks said. **********In anticipation of a possible deal worth more than $100 a share, the NCR Corporation's share price climbed $1.375 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $99.625. The computer maker, based in Dayton, Ohio, said on Sunday that it was willing to share confidential business information with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to try to persuade the telecommunications giant to raise its $100-a-share bid, worth a total of $6.77 billion. **********A.T.& T.'s share price rose 12.5 cents yesterday on the Big Board, to $33. A.T.&T. Cancels Strategy Meeting **********A two-day meeting of 50 top A.T.& T. managers to discuss the company's long-term strategy, scheduled to begin yesterday, was canceled as the executives considered NCR's first encouraging response to nearly four months of overtures. The negotiations yesterday involved both A.T.& T.'s chairman, Robert E. Allen, and NCR's chairman, Charles E. Exley Jr. **********Jack B. Grubman, a telephone industry analyst at Paine Webber, said that NCR's willingness to start negotiating with A.T.& T. made a deal likely. "It's sort of like a freight train," he said. "It's hard to get going, but once it is, it's hard to stop." **********A.T.& T.'s big advantage lay in the possibility that it might win more than 80 percent of the vote at a special meeting of NCR shareholders on Thursday, which would enable it to replace NCR's board. A simple majority of the shares would enable A.T.& T. to replace a third of NCR's board.  Bid May Be Reduced **********A.T.& T. has said its $100-a-share bid will be reduced to the original level of $90 a share, or $6.09 billion, if it wins the vote on Thursday. **********NCR's main strength is its ability to make the deal quick and friendly if A.T.& T. is willing to raise its bid slightly. **********A merger would considerably expand A.T.& T.'s equipment businesses, which rival the company's long-distance services in annual sales though not in public recognition or profitability. A.T.& T. computer operations, which the company was allowed to start following the 1982 settlement of an antitrust case, accounted for less than 10 percent of the company's $37.29 billion in sales last year.  Outlet for Bell Labs Products **********The acquisition of NCR would give A.T.& T. a much better established marketing network in the computer industry through which to sell the high-technology products developed by Bell Laboratories, the research arm of A.T.& T., Mr. Grubman said. **********A.T.& T. has separately scheduled a news conference this morning to announce its first joint project in telephone network management with the International Business Machines Corporation. **********But it remains unclear whether combining telecommunications products and services will work. "If you go with the premise that they should be in the computer business, then they definitely should be with NCR," Mr. Grubman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/busin.main_headline: Fed Fines Ex-Chairman of a B.C.C.I. Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/busin.print_headline: Fed Fines Ex-Chairman of a B.C.C.I. Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/26/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve Board announced a $20 million civil fine today against the former chairman of a Southern California bank that the Fed says was illegally and secretly acquired by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. **********At the same time, the Justice Department, at the request of the Fed, obtained a temporary freeze in United States District Court in Los Angeles on the assets of the former bank official, Kemal Shoaib. **********Earlier this month, the Fed assessed a civil fine of $37 million against the Saudi businessman Ghaith R. Pharaon for his role in fronting for B.C.C.I.'s purchase of the bank, the Independence Bank in Encino. **********Regulators were originally told that Mr. Pharaon purchased Independence Bank in 1985 for $23 million. The Fed now says B.C.C.I., the Luxembourg bank that was taken over by regulators in several countries in July amid charges of widespread fraud, actually owned 85 percent of the bank, with Mr. Pharaon owning the rest. **********The Fed has already fined B.C.C.I. $200 million and began actions to ban both Mr. Shoaib and Mr. Pharaon from the American banking business. **********Mr. Shoaib, according to the Fed, had been a key official with B.C.C.I.'s offices in London before becoming chairman of Independence. Mr. Shoaib, the regulators say, was "instrumental in the acquisition of Independence," and "continued to act on behalf of B.C.C.I." while chairman of the California bank. **********Specifically, Mr. Shoaib, while heading Independence, communicated with B.C.C.I. officials on a number of occasions to discuss personnel, budgetary and planning issues, according to the Fed. **********Mr. Shoaib could not be located for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/world.main_headline: Czechoslovakia Auctions Stores to Private Buyers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/world.print_headline: Czechoslovakia Auctions Stores to Private Buyers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/world.body_text: **********The auction gavel came down today in Prague city hall, and Ladislav Krombholc became one of Czechoslovakia's first private owners of a fruit and vegetable store. **********The 34-year-old writer and translator said he was already employing eight sales people to sell produce at outdoor market stalls. Now, by being the last bidder to stay in the contest as the selling price hit $17,000, he became owner of his own store. **********Mr. Krombholc's new shop, like many others, was sold without its real estate. The new owners will be guaranteed occupancy in the state-owned buildings, usually at extremely low rents, for two years. **********After that, they will have to negotiate terms with the new owners of the land and buildings, since most of those too will be sold. After two years, the new real-estate owners will be free to rent the shops at whatever price the market will bear.  State-Owned Stores Auctioned **********"Of course it's a risk" said Mr. Krombholc, now elevated to the previously officially despised "bourgeois class.' "But I'm absolutely sure I'll earn back my investment in a year." **********Forty-two years after Czechoslovakia was taken over by one of Eastern Europe's most severely anti-capitalist governments, the country's new anti-Communist leaders have started an ambitious attempt at dismantling the present economy. **********All of Czechoslovakia's several hundred thousand state-owned stores are being auctioned, a process that officials say should be more than half completed by the summer. **********"This is the most important event in our economic reform," said Tomas Jezek, Minister of Privatization of the Czech Republic, one of the two constituent parts of the Czechoslovak Federation.  Liquidation of Capitalists **********Unlike its neighbors, Hungary, Poland, and even the former East Germany, Czechoslovakia under Communist rule allowed almost no private shops or businesses. **********During the worst Stalinist period of "liquidation of the capitalist class" during the 1950's, butchers, bakers and other small shopkeepers were sometimes sentenced to forced labor in uranium mines. Often, their sole offense was belonging to the "enemy class." **********For decades stores were nothing more than the state-run retail distribution points of a stodgy command economy. Today most are old-fashioned, and badly in need of renovation. **********Moreover, although Czechoslovakia had one of the highest living standards in the Eastern bloc, the choice of retail goods is even now much more limited and less modern than in the West.  The Need? 'Prosperous Shops' **********At a first round of bidding for each store, only Czechoslovaks are allowed to take part, including anyone who was a citizen as far back as 1948. To reduce the chance of foreign investors using Czechoslovaks as fronts for buying prime shop space, new owners cannot sell to foreigners for two years. **********Any stores not sold are sent to a second auction, in which foreigners can bid. Officials say they are unworried by the prospects of an economic takeover by their far richer neighbors, the Germans and Austrians. **********"Let them -- why not?" said Mr. Jezek. "What we need is prosperous shops. The customer doesn't care who the owner is." **********But Czechoslovaks appear to resent more the fact that under the Communist system, those who were able to accumulate the most money were black-market money changers, swindlers and higher-ranking Communist Party members who could exploit various connections.  Tense Bidding Wars **********But officials said that was an injustice the country had to live with. **********"It's sure, there is dirty money here" said Mr. Jezek. "But the best method for cleaning the money is to let them invest it." **********After today's auctioning, officials said they were pleased with the enthusiastic degree of participation. Some of the seven fruit and vegitable stores and food markets were sold at more than 50 times the starting price. **********Several hundred spectators, who paid almost $2 for tickets to attend the proceedings at city hall, applauded the bidders as they pushed the prices up in tense bidding wars. **********Restitution Claims **********Officials say the biggest problem in auctioning off hundreds of thousands of stores is claims for restitution of the property from former owners. A first restitution law passed in the fall covers former owners whose small properties were confiscated by the Communists since 1955, in the "final phase of the liquidation of the capitalist class." **********Those people have until the end of April to claim their property. A new law is expected soon, returning the larger properties taken in the first years after the Communists took power in 1948. **********Shops cannot be auctioned off "when there is any doubt as to the ownership" said Mr. Jezek. **********The new shop owners have no obligation to retain current shop employees. If they lose their jobs, the state organization that currently employs them must continue paying their wages for five months. Czechoslovakia has also instituted unemployment payments to give some protection to the growing number of jobless, as inefficient businesses begin closing.  'I'd Be Sorry to Lose My Job' **********"I'm afraid," said Jaroslava Juzova, a saleswoman in a small mercery shop in the center of Prague. "I'd be sorry to lose my job," Like all other stores, it too will be sold off soon. **********"I think we'd be able to serve the customers better in a private shop" she said. "There'd be more variety of goods to offer." **********Larger businesses and factories will be sold after Parliament passes a special law on "large privatization," expected shortly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/busin.body_text: **********United States vehicle sales closed the year on a downbeat amid widespread expectations that the automotive industry's slump will probably continue well into 1991. Total sales in 1990 were the lowest since 1983. **********Retail sales of American-made cars and trucks fell 1.4 percent in the Dec. 21-30 period, capping a year in which sales were off 5.1 percent from 1989. The overall drop in the final 10 days was caused by a 15.5 percent decline in light-truck sales; car sales for the period were up 8.1 percent, for a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.3 million, compared with 7.5 million last year.  Monthly Sales Also Down **********Car and truck sales were off 2.1 percent for all of December, to 962,767, from 983,330 last year. Car sales were up 1.8 percent, to 657,164, but light-truck sales dropped 9.5 percent, to 305,603. The monthly figures include all retail sales, of both American-made and imported vehicles. **********Sales of light trucks have been particularly weak in recent months. Light trucks are less fuel-efficient than cars, and many commercial buyers have scaled back truck purchases because of the weak economy. **********For the year, sales of imported and domestic vehicles reached 13,790,280 -- 9,338,911 cars and 4,451,369 trucks -- compared with a 1989 total of 14,489,530 -- 9,831,122 cars and 4,658,408 trucks. **********Beyond the decline of the last year, the question on the minds of many auto executives and analysts was how much longer the slump would continue. With consumer confidence low, personal debt high and fear of war pervasive, many think only a resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis will bring a rebound for the industry.  January 'Debacle' Expected **********"January will be a debacle," predicted Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. "I think within a couple of months of the situation in the Middle East's being resolved, we will begin to report year-over-year increases." **********Robert L. Rewey, vice president for sales for the Ford Motor Company's North American operations, said: "Industry sales in 1990 were disappointing, with a weak economy and concerns about international uncertainties pulling auto sales down, especially in the final months of the year. Based on present economic forecasts, we expect industry sales weakness to continue in early 1991, with improvement as the year progresses." **********Ford's car and truck sales in 1990 were 3.63 million, a drop of 7.8 percent from 1989. **********But analysts said there was substantial pent-up demand for vehicles based on the age of the existing fleet. David Healy, automotive analyst for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Inc., noted that sales had begun to pick up in the summer after a nine-month slump. **********The General Motors Corporation, the industry leader, posted a gain of eight-tenths of a percent in vehicle sales in late December. G.M.'s United States sales dropped 3.3 percent in 1990, to 4.97 million cars and trucks. But G.M. was able to increase its market share slightly from 1989, the only Big Three auto maker to do so. **********George C. Eads, the company's vice president of product planning and economics, said G.M. "is well equipped to meet increasingly aggressive challengers in the U.S. automotive marketplace." **********The Chrysler Corporation's car and truck sales fell 4.1 percent in late December, compared with a year earlier. Car sales were up 17.1 percent, but truck sales were down 18.2 percent, reflecting the recent trends.   Honda Nudges Chrysler **********For the year, Chrysler's vehicle sales dropped 15.5 percent, to 1.69 million from 2 million in 1989. Chrysler barely nosed out the Honda Motor Company as the nation's No. 3 car maker, with 860,834 sales to Honda's 854,879. Chrysler's top-selling vehicle was its mini-van, sold under the Chrysler, Dodge and Plymouth nameplates. **********The proportion of cars sold that were built in the United States increased in 1990, but more of those vehicles were built by foreign companies at "transplant" factories in the United States. Domestic cars accounted for 73.6 percent of cars sold, compared with 71.9 percent in 1989. But cars built at transplant factories accounted for 11.4 percent of sales, compared with 7.9 percent in 1989. **********The Big Three's share of the total American vehicle market declined to 69.9 percent in 1990, from 71.1 percent in 1989. The share of Japanese auto makers, including those with American operations, increased to 23.5 percent from 21.6 percent. Other imports declined to 6.6 percent of the market from 7.3 percent last year. **********While most car companies posted sales declines for the year, the top two Japanese auto makers -- the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company -- were able to increase American sales as they relied more on vehicles built in the United States, which cost them less to build than those imported from Japan, primarily because of the yen's strength relative to the dollar. But the Nissan Motor Company posted a substantial decline for the year. **********"Despite the apparent downward turn of the economy last year, sales of Toyota vehicles have never been better," said Pat Moran, president of Toyota's distribution company for the Southeastern United States. Mr. Moran said he expected "sustained growth" in 1991. **********Particularly hard hit in 1990 were several European auto makers, including Volvo, Saab and BMW. Sales of Audis dropped to 21,106 for the year from 21,283 in 1989, and "quite frankly we don't see 1991 being any better," said Richard L. Mugg, the American executive in charge of Audi. Mr. Mugg said Audi's December results reflected some sales that were "unquestionably pulled ahead from January to beat the impending luxury tax" on vehicles costing more than $30,000.   PLANT CLOSINGS CONTINUE **********DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Big Three auto makers will continue reduced car and truck production next week by shutting down all or part of 29 assembly plants and putting more than 62,000 auto workers on temporary layoff. **********The shutdowns stretch out closings that began at some plants the week before Christmas. **********The Ford Motor Company plans the most extensive shutdowns and layoffs next week, with all but five assembly plants closed because of low orders, the company said today. Ford will lay off about 20,360 North American workers next week. **********The General Motors Corporation will close 13 plants, resulting in 33,280 layoffs, and the Chrysler Corporation will shut three assembly plants, laying off about 8,400 workers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/busin.body_text: **********The White House said today that it would nominate Ira H. Raphaelson, a Federal prosecutor in Chicago, to head the Justice Department's savings and loan fraud unit. **********Mr. Raphaelson is the one of the department's top white-collar crime specialists. He recently led the prosecution of a racketeering case in which eight of nine commodity futures traders were convicted of fraud-related charges. He has also prosecuted political and judicial corruption cases. **********If confirmed by the Senate as special counsel for the financial institutions fraud unit, Mr. Raphaelson would be responsible for coordinating all the department's savings and loan prosecutions and marshaling the department's manpower on the highest-priority cases. **********He would succeed James G. Richmond, who held the job on leave from his position as the United States Attorney in Northern Indiana. Mr. Richmond is resigning to enter private law practice in Chicago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/22/busin.body_text: **********The Dunlop Tire Corporation said that because of substantial losses, it would lay off workers at plants in Tonawanda, N.Y., and Huntsville, Ala. Randall L. Clark, the chairman, said that it had not been determined how many jobs would be cut but that it was likely that at least some passenger tire lines would be eliminated at the Tonawanda plant. Dunlop, which began sharp cost-cutting measures this year, employs about 3,000 at the two plants. The company is a unit of Sumitomo Rubber Industries of Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Gillette Getting Vote of Confidence
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Gillette Getting Vote of Confidence
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.body_text: **********ALFRED M. ZEIEN, who took over as the chairman of the Gillette Company two months ago after Colman Mockler Jr. died of a heart attack at age 61, says his style may be different than Mr. Mockler's but his agenda is the same -- notably, to start turning a profit on Gillette's hot-selling Sensor shaving system. **********So far the market is giving him a vote of confidence. Gillette's stock rose $2.50 yesterday, to $74.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts and colleagues credit Mr. Mockler, who had planned to retire at the end of 1991 and had put a succession plan in place just months before his death, with setting Gillette on a solid course. **********But they note that Mr. Zeien, 60, who had been vice chairman of Gillette the last 10 years, had been running Gillette's main day-to-day activities. **********Mr. Zeien has made it clear that he plans to keep Gillette "steady as she goes," which makes perfect sense to the financial community. Gillette is riding high in the consumer products industry with record revenues and profit increases in 1990 and continued strong growth expected, but Mr. Zeien does want to shore up the toiletries and cosmetics division, whose sales sagged in 1990. **********"I expect a steady 18 percent growth in earnings over the next three years," said Jay Freedman, a senior vice president at Kidder, Peabody. "The stock should be very strong this year." **********Andrew Shore, an analyst with Prudential Securities, predicted Gillette stock would be "an upper $80-per-share stock in nine months." Gillette recently approved a 2-for-1 stock split, its third since 1986, and a 15 percent dividend increase to take effect on May 1. A company spokesman said that Gillette management wanted the stock to trade at $30 to $50 a share because it was more attractive to the small investor. **********"Al Zeien won't change the strategy because it's working so well," Mr. Shore said. Indeed, Gillette's sales rose 14 percent in 1990, to $4.3 billion, and profits gained 29 percent, to $368 million, compared with $285 million in 1989. Although Gillette's new Sensor shaving system took the market by storm -- generating $200 million in sales and grabbing 9.2 percent of the domestic blades and razors market in its first year -- the company did not earn a penny from Sensor in 1990, Mr. Zeien said. **********The reason is that Gillette underestimated demand for Sensor, he said, and is still putting resources into increasing manufacturing capacity for the product, which could delay profitability. In addition, Gillette's Braun division underestimated the popularity in Europe and Japan of the new Flex Control pivoting head electric razor, delaying the introduction of the product in the United States. **********Analysts are not worried about the Sensor's lag in profitability, predicting that the shaving system will earn huge profits for Gillette for many years. They point to Gillette's Atra shaver, which has been profitible for more than a decade. "Sensor will generate profits for several years," said Deepak Raj, an analyst with Merrill Lynch. "People may be surprised at the extent of margin improvement in the blades and razors division." **********Gillette increased its market share in blades and razors to 36 percent in 1990 from 32 percent in 1989, Mr. Freedman said, far ahead of Schick, the No. 2 brand. Schick, which is owned by the Warner-Lambert Company, has 14 percent of the market. **********Mr. Zeien said he expected strong competition from Schick and would be shocked if Schick did not start producing a twin-blade cartridge to fit the Sensor handle. Gillette licensed its Sensor technology to Schick, but the agreement prevents Schick from selling such a blade until January 1992. **********Schick has promoted its own new Tracer shaver, but Mr. Shore pointed out, "Schick lost 1.9 points of market share last year." He added, "They need Tracer to be a successful product, but it shouldn't present much of a problem to Sensor." **********With the promise of long-term profits from Sensor and aggressive new marketing plans under way, including a big advertising campaign this year, Gillette is getting no criticism from analysts. Mr. Zeien's biggest challenge may be to decide where to spend the enormous cash flow Gillette is generating. He indicated that he intended to lower the company's $1 billion in long-term debt but will also continue capital expenditures aimed at increased manufacturing capacity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/10/busin.main_headline: Patents; Efforts to Promote Sight Through Artificial Eye
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/10/busin.print_headline: Patents; Efforts to Promote Sight Through Artificial Eye
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Researchers at the National Institutes of Health obtained a patent this week on a method for simulating nerve impulses to the brain that might someday allow people to see through an artificial eye or feel through an artificial limb. **********"I have to say, right up front, that we don't know whether this works or not," said Barry J. Richmond, a neurologist at the National Institute of Mental Health and one of the inventors. But the patent is based on new insights about the coding patterns employed by cells in the nervous system, called neurons, that fire electrical pulses to the brain in response to light, sound and other stimuli. **********Dr. Richmond said most researchers had previously believed that sensory perception was based on the rate at which neurons fired and the parts of the brain that received the pulses. In reality, he said, the neurons fire in particular sequences that constitute a code providing different kinds of information. For photoreceptors in the eye, for example, the patterns emitted by a single neuron allow it to convey information about brightness, shape and texture. **********The patent outlines a basic approach to analyzing these patterns, so they can be simulated in prosthetic devices. **********Dr. Richmond and Lance M. Optican, a biomedical engineer at the National Eye Institute, received patent 5,037,376.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/03/busin.main_headline: Uneven Economic Recovery Shakes Faith in Fed's Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/03/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Uneven Economic Recovery Shakes Faith in Fed's Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/03/busin.body_text: **********The economy's uneven response to the Federal Reserve Board's deliberate reduction in short-term interest rates over the last year has led to a debate among credit market analysts about whether the Fed is capable of engineering a sustainable recovery. **********"The Fed seems to have less ability to stimulate the economy today than it had in the past," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America. "It will be hard to get the kind of recovery we have had in the past with just monetary policy." **********The Fed's job was clearly easier in the past, when the interest-sensitive industrial sector accounted for a larger share of overall production. **********Moreover, the central bank has usually not had to act as the sole pump primer. This time, huge budget deficits at the Federal, state and local levels have effectively removed government fiscal policy as an ally.  New Capital Requirements **********Currently, the Fed's job is further hampered by the new capital requirements that it placed on commercial banks. Meeting those new standards is a reason that banks have been unwilling to step up lending over the last 12 months or so. **********Even if new credit were readily available, it is questionable whether loan demand would be strong, given the exceptional increase in debt taken on by consumers and businesses during the 1980's, analysts said. **********Because of the new capital adequacy requirements, "continually lowering rates and putting reserves into the banking system is not having the impact it formerly did and normally would," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. **********And Jay N. Woodworth, senior domestic economist at the Bankers Trust Company, said, "The slow death of the savings and loan industry and changes in the banking system make it more difficult for the Fed's usual policy levers to bring about changes in the growth rate of money, credit and of the economy."  Lower Federal Funds Rate **********Since August 1990, the Fed has reduced the overnight Federal funds rate, which it closely controls, by 2.5 percentage points, to 5.5 percent. And in recent weeks, the economy has been showing some sputtering signs of life, particularly in manufacturing industries. **********Since April, a month in which many analysts think the recession bottomed, industrial production has risen by 7.5 percent at an annual rate. **********But with personal income growth remaining weak, analysts question whether the rise in industrial activity during the last three months is sustainable. Car sales, they note, remain mired at close to recession lows. A failure by Detroit to move its new models in September and early October could lead to production cutbacks later in the fall. **********The view is not universal that the Fed's powers have been diminished by time and special circumstances. Indeed, some analysts say the sputtering recovery may be just what the Fed wants.  The Fed's Intention **********"I still think the Fed has plenty of ability to affect the economy," said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. Seeking to curb a resurgence in inflation, "the Fed has intentionally tried to promote a gradual recovery," Mr. Johnson said, adding, "That intention is apparent in the relatively modest cuts in the funds rate that we have seen." **********Compared with the way the Fed has responded during previous recessions, the reduction of 2.5 percentage points in the Federal funds rate thus far is mild, Mr. Johnson said. **********"Typically, the Fed has pushed very hard and driven the funds rate through the rate of inflation," Mr. Johnson said. **********Based on recent inflation readings, the Federal funds rate would need to drop by roughly 1.5 percentage points from its current level if the Fed were to revert to previous pattern. **********Few analysts are willing to say the Federal funds rate will actually decline by that much before a sustained recovery is in place. But most economists acknowledge that lower rates are needed.  Value of a Quarter-Point **********"Four percent funds is a long ways from where we are now," Mr. Wood at Bank of America said. "I would be surprised that the Fed would have to move that far to get the economy going again. But I don't think the next quarter-point cut in the funds rate, when it comes, will accomplish very much. The last quarter-point cut didn't get us anything." **********Debate about when the Fed will move to reduce rates again will probably come to a boil this week, because employment statistics, the key monthly reading on the economy, are scheduled to be released on Friday. **********In advance of the August figures, most analysts are forecasting that nonfarm payroll employment rose by about 50,000 last month, but that the unemployment rate inched higher from its 6.8 percent reading in July. **********"The market is setting itself up for how the Fed is going to respond," said Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers. **********In Mr. Slifer's view, a report that showed payroll growth close to the consensus forecast would provide the Fed with enough incentive to ease monetary policy further. **********"Everybody will be on pins and needles on Sept. 6," Mr. Fine said. "That bothers me, but it also makes a lot of sense."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/13/busin.body_text: **********President Bush announced today that he had appointed John A. Shaw, 52 years old, to become the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Export Enforcement. Mr. Shaw, an expert on the Middle East and an associate deputy secretary at the department, replaces Quincy Mellon Krosby. **********Mr. Shaw's appointment is the latest of several personnel moves at the Commerce Department. Eric Garfinkel, the Assistant Secretary for Import Administration, has been nominated to replace Dennis Kloske as the Under Secretary for Export Administration. Shortly before he left the department last spring, Mr. Kloske accused the State Department and the White House of authorizing exports of high-technology products to Iraq over his objections. **********Mr. Shaw would report to Mr. Garfinkel if both are confirmed by the Senate. **********Bruce A. Soll, 34, counsel to the Commerce Secretary, Robert A. Mosbacher, left the department last week to work in the office of the chairman of The Limited, a retailer. No replacement for Mr. Soll has been nominated. **********Mr. Mosbacher is expected to leave the Commerce Department soon to run President Bush's re-election campaign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.main_headline: Banks Say Stiff Credit Is Easing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.print_headline: Banks Say Stiff Credit Is Easing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.body_text: **********The credit drought that some worry will cause the recession to drag on may not be over but there are signs that it is easing. "The risk that credit problems would prevent a recovery appear to have declined," William Brown, chief economist at J. P. Morgan & Company, said. **********The number of banks tightening credit is declining, the Federal Reserve's latest survey of senior bank loan officers shows. The survey of 58 American and 18 foreign-owned banks, taken in mid-March, was issued yesterday. **********Just over a fifth of the banks surveyed said that they had imposed stiffer terms on business loans in the last six weeks, compared with a third in January and half last November.  Caution on Results **********Stiffer terms might be anything from lower credit limits and wider margins to higher collateral requirements. "If there was a credit crunch, it looks like it has flattened out," said Anatole Balbach, director of research at the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. **********The Federal Reserve's March survey was taken just six weeks after the previous survey, half the usual interval. "That makes the results harder to interpret," cautioned Thomas F. Brady, who directed the poll. **********But there are other straws in the wind. After stagnating for months, the nation's money supply -- an indicator, if an imperfect one, of banks' ability to lend -- has been climbing rapidly again. Nearly every source of bank funds -- from large time deposits to money market deposits -- has been expanding this year. Indeed, the money supply has been growing at a 9.5 percent annual rate since early February, putting it in the Federal Reserve's upper target range.  Slide in Loans Slows **********"That's presumably because the Federal Reserve lowered the Federal funds rate starting late last fall," Mr. Brown of J.P. Morgan said. "If M-2 had continued to languish, one would have been increasingly concerned that credit problems were having a broad effect on the economy." M-2 consists of cash, savings and checking accounts, and small certificates of deposit. **********The slide in actual business lending has slowed. Commercial and industrial loans, which fell sharply in January, merely edged down in February. "That typically signals the end of a recession," said Herbert L. Baer, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. **********T. Waite Rawls, vice chairman at the Continental Bank, said, "Not a whole lot has changed, but if we get signs in the next couple of months that the recession ended with the war, things will loosen up some." **********Indeed, in the first quarter, many corporations took advantage of lower interest rates to refinance debt. They retired short-term bank debt and issued long-term bonds. Some economists interpreted the surge as a sign that plenty of money was available for business. **********Banks are not clamping down so much on consumers, either. According to the Federal Reserve's loan officer survey, half as many banks as in January reported that they were imposing stricter conditions on residential mortgages, and two reported that they were easing up. **********Separately, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America reported that applications for mortgages had tripled since December and that more than a third of all mortgage applications were from homeowners who were refinancing existing mortgages. With mortgage rates lower than last year, many borrowers with adjustable-rate mortgages are trying to switch to fixed-rate mortgages. **********Consider the recent experience of Banc One, the large regional bank with headquarters in Columbus, Ohio. Business lending is still off, as it has been since last year. But consumer loans have jumped 15 percent since the start of the year. "The consumer is coming back," said John B. McCoy, the bank's chairman. "That's a precursor of industry coming back. We can't do anything for G.M. unless somebody wants to buy cars."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; P.& G. Assigns Ads For New Cosmetics
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.body_text: **********The Procter & Gamble Company, Cincinnati, announced yesterday that the advertising for several newly acquired cosmetics and fragrance brands had been assigned to four agencies with experience on other P.& G. beauty-product accounts: Lotas Minard Patton McIver, New York; the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago; Grey Advertising, New York, and Dentsu Inc., Tokyo. **********Advertising in the United States for Max Factor was assigned to Lotas Minard, while the brand's advertising overseas was awarded to Burnett. Burnett and Grey will share overseas advertising for Betrix products. And Dentsu has been assigned at least one Max Factor brand in Japan, SK-II. **********The assignments come less than a week after the consumer-products giant completed the $1.1 billion purchase of the beauty lines from Revlon. While billings were not disclosed, Leading National Advertisers reports that Max Factor spent $19.4 million last year for advertising in the United States. **********Tarlow Advertising, New York, which Revlon owns, had previously handled Max Factor in this country. Several other agencies previously handled Max Factor overseas as well as Betrix, which sells its cosmetics and fragrance products primarily in Europe.
