https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/13/world.main_headline: U.N. Using U.S. Spy Planes to Monitor Iraqi Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/13/world.print_headline: U.N. Using U.S. Spy Planes to Monitor Iraqi Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/13/world.body_text: **********Surprised by disclosures that Iraq conducted clandestine nuclear and biological research despite international monitoring, the United Nations said today that it had started using United States-owned high-altitude spy planes to survey Iraq for nuclear, chemical and biological weapons sites. **********A United Nations spokesman said that U-2 flights over Iraq began last weekend under the guidance of the United Nations special commission charged with identifying and eliminating Iraq's weapons of mass destruction. The commission was set up after Iraq's defeat in the Persian Gulf war. **********Baghdad agreed to the monitoring, but only after its Foreign Ministry wrote Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar protesting the flights and the decision to use American aircraft. **********"American aircraft have for months been overflying Iraq for purposes of reconnaissance and have photographed virtually every inch of Iraqi territory," said the letter, dated Aug. 6 and signed by Iraq's chief United Nations delegate, Abdul Amir al-Anbari. **********The special commission did not say how many U-2 flights it requested. It said Security Council Resolution 687, the cease-fire resolution that ended the gulf war, allowed it to make the aerial surveys to insure that Iraq was complying with the terms of the resolution. **********"The special commission will be provided with the photographs on all the sites, locations, facilities and objects which have been surveyed at its request," said a United Nations spokesman, Frederic Eckhard. "This will permit the special commission to arrange for its own independent evaluation." **********Mr. Anbari said that Iraq would "not place any obstacle in the way of the proposed reconnaissance flights" by the American planes, but that it would have preferred another nation, specifying the Soviet Union, France or India. **********A Pentagon official said the first U-2 flight took place on Sunday. He said the flights were distinct from the reconnaissance missions by American and French jets over northern Iraq since the end of the war to monitor Iraqi military activity in Kurdistan. **********The official said the spy plane would provide better coverage of Iraq because spy satellite coverage has been interrupted by cloud cover or haze. The Pentagon said the missions would originate from a base in Saudi Arabia.                    --------------------       Kuwaiti Shift on Detainees **********KUWAIT CITY, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- Trying to improve an image tarnished by harsh martial-law trials after the Persian Gulf war, Kuwait announced today that it had outlawed the indefinite detention of political prisoners. **********Under amendments to security laws, prisoners can now be held without trial for a maximum of six months. **********The amendments are aimed at limiting "state security detentions," said Deputy Justice Minister Abdul Aziz al-Dakhil. "The new law obliges the Attorney General to send detainees to court for trial once six months has elapsed from the date of arrest," he said. **********In the months after the war, some political prisoners were tried in their cells or held indefinitely without charges. The amendments will provide better legal safeguards for defendants previously denied the right to appeal decisions of martial-law courts. **********The changes will benefit 400 people sentenced or awaiting trial on charges arising from the Iraqi occupation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/world.main_headline: Taipei Journal; Kidnapper of Chiang Kai-shek Ends Long Silence
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/world.print_headline: Taipei Journal; Kidnapper of Chiang Kai-shek Ends Long Silence
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/world.body_text: **********At almost 90 years of age, the Young Marshal seems to have everything a man could want -- public esteem, a splendid house, a family extending for four generations. But he still has one other, more poignant desire: to discard his reputation as one of the greatest heroes in modern Chinese history **********"Even this name, Zhang Xueliang -- I don't want it!" he said earnestly, leaning forward in his chair. "I don't want to be Zhang Xueliang! I just want to be an ordinary person, free to do as I wish. I can't take everybody's compliments." **********Then one of China's most-powerful warlords, Mr. Zhang intervened to amend Chinese history in 1936, by kidnapping Chiang Kai-shek, the paramount national leader. Before releasing Chiang, Mr. Zhang made him promise to work with the Communists, instead of killing them, so that China could stand united to battle the Japanese troops that were steadily encroaching on eastern China as a prelude to World War II. **********The kidnapping, which took place in the city of Xian and is known as the Xian incident, transfixed the world at the time, and led to a period of uneasy cooperation between the Nationalist Government and the Communist rebels until the end of World War II. This long reprieve from attack helped the Communists recover their strength and positioned them to overrun all of China in 1949.  Under House Arrest **********If Mr. Zhang had fled with the Communists, he might have become a national leader after the revolution. Instead, he disavowed any personal ambition and on Dec. 25, 1936, he released Chiang and flew back with him to the capital, Nanjing. He was put under house arrest, and vanished for half a century. **********"It was a rebellion and I had to take responsibility for it," said Mr. Zhang in explaining his decision to accept punishment. **********Last year, on his 90th birthday -- he is 89 by Western count, but traditional Chinese reckoning starts with a year at birth -- Mr. Zhang emerged in public for the first time since 1936, celebrating his birthday with admirers at a hotel. These days there no longer appear to be any restrictions on his movements, and he spoke freely in a 100-minute interview, the first ever in his home. **********Only one other time since the Xian incident has Mr. Zhang given an interview, to a Japanese television reporter at a hotel last year, and he emphasized his distaste for publicity. **********"I'm frightened of all those reporters," he said with a laugh. But he remains a larger-than-life figure throughout the Chinese-speaking world. 'A Symbol of Chivalry **********"To people of my generation, he's a semi-god," a Chinese university lecturer in his 30's said. "He's a symbol of chivalry and righteousness, an example of someone who looked after the weak and fought for justice." **********The key to Mr. Zhang's popularity seems to be that his intervention was aimed purely at confronting a foreign enemy. Even those who deplore the Communist revolution admire his patriotic fervor against the Japanese. Mr. Zhang's willingness to accept half a century of isolation has only added to the legend. **********"He doesn't support any party or any faction; he just loves this country and his countrymen," said his wife, Zhao Yidi, who is 70. Explaining his decision to kidnap Chiang, she added: "It's simple: he was against the civil war. He didn't want to see his people killed." **********A gnarled man who speaks with a faint northeastern China accent, reflecting his boyhood home, Mr. Zhang abounds with energy and constantly bustles around his living room, searching for a newspaper article or book to make his point. His eyes gleam, he occasionally tells a joke, and his mind seems as clear as ever. **********Mr. Zhang is also known as the Young Marshal because his father, Zhang Zuolin, was called the Old Marshal. After the Old Marshal was assassinated by the Japanese in 1928, Mr. Zhang inherited an army of 200,000 soldiers. But it was only after he kicked his playboy image and a drug habit, and replaced them with a nationalist passion, that his reputation began to soar. A Friend of Chiang **********In all those years of house arrest, first on the mainland and then on Taiwan, Mr. Zhang maintained a remarkable mutual respect and friendship with the Chiang family. Chiang seems to have kept Mr. Zhang under house arrest only partly as punishment; a major reason also was the knowledge that Mr. Zhang could become a dangerous rival if he emerged in public. **********Mr. Zhang, a Baptist who became increasingly religious over the years, saw the Chiangs each Sunday when he worshiped with them at their family chapel. Chiang's son, Chiang Ching-kuo, personally selected the beautiful Government-owned house in which Mr. Zhang lives. **********The house is decorated with paintings and calligraphy honoring the Chiang family, all gifts from Chiang. Mr. Zhang remembers the couplet he wrote after Chiang died in 1975, and it underscores their peculiar relationship: **********With mutual affection and esteem, we are blood brothers; **********Yet political disputes made us almost enemies. **********Mr. Zhang's house arrest seems to have been lifted gradually over the last five years or so, as it became clear that he would not challenge the Government and had no interest in becoming a celebrity. **********He said that he would like to visit the United States before long, to travel around and revel in the anonymity. Asked if he would also like to visit the Chinese mainland, Mr. Zhang seemed overcome with yearning. **********"I badly want to visit the mainland, for it is my home," he said in a voice rich with the tug of emotion. **********"But it's impossible," he added, apparently fearful that a visit would take on a political significance that he does not seek. "The mainland would welcome me, of course, but with such a welcome it would be even more difficult to go."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/world.main_headline: New Warning by the Army Imperils Yugoslav Standoff
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/world.print_headline: New Warning by the Army Imperils Yugoslav Standoff
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/world.body_text: **********Yugoslavia's fragile cease-fire appeared increasingly shaky tonight after the army high command warned Slovenia, the secessionist republic at the center of the nation's crisis, to stop harassing army units. **********The tensions arose a day after the nation's Prime Minister said the Yugoslav Army had been ordered back to its barracks to ease the confrontation. **********The army's new warning, released in a statement here in Belgrade, the capital, accused Slovenia of refusing to allow food and water to military units and said army officers and their families were being seized and mistreated. **********Fierce fighting flared last week between the Yugoslav Army and Slovenian militia units after Slovenia and Croatia, the two northernmost republics in Yugoslavia and the richest regions in this multi-ethnic nation, issued declarations of independence. Although the nation's central Government called both declarations illegal, the authorities in Belgrade have so far taken no action against Croatia. **********The move to send the army back to its barracks, some of which are in Slovenia, and the rest of the cease-fire accord were negotiated with the help of the European Community. Those governments intervened on Friday, helping to broker a truce out of fear that Yugoslavia would be consumed by violence among its six feuding republics and two autonomous provinces.  Fighting Began Last Week **********The fighting began last Wednesday after Serbia, the largest of the nation's republics and the dominant force in the Yugoslav military, made clear that it would use force to hold the federation together and prevent Slovenia from setting up border checkpoints and taking other steps toward autonomy. **********Serbia is dominated by a reconstituted version of the Communist Party, which governed until the collapse of Communism in Eastern Euorpe. **********Much of the military high command is drawn from longtime Communist cadres. The Slovenian and Croatian leaderships that emerged after post-cold-war elections are more Western-leaning and intensely nationalistic. **********Croatia's succession effort has caused other tensions. Although the army has yet to act in the republic, Croatia's large Serbian minority has made it clear that it will fight the Croats to remain part of Yugoslavia. **********It is unclear to what extent the military remains under civilian control. On Sunday, the nation's Prime Minister, Ante Markovic, said the army's move to prevent Slovenia from seceding from Yugoslavia was undertaken without his knowledge or consent.  Warning From the Army **********In its statement today, the army high command said its units were in full combat readiness and that further harassment of its units by the Slovene militia would be met by military force. "Any kind of threat will be responded to with a massive and vigorous strike," the statement said. "Any fraud and treachery will be short-lived. This will be proved soon." **********In Ljubljana, the Slovenian capital, Slovenian leaders accused the army of planning another attack and said they were demanding that national army units in Slovenia surrender their weapons before they lifted blockades preventing the army's return to barracks. **********Tense standoffs between Slovenian and Yugoslav forces continued today around some barracks, and armored national army units, which rolled into the republic last week, destroying Slovenian barricades, were reported trapped in some parts of the republic. But in the last two days, there have been reports of only sporadic shooting. **********The army statement, released through the official news agency Tanyug, was all the more striking because it came after a meeting of the country's collective presidency, which along with the military is officially under the command of a Croatian, Stipe Mesic. It was after Mr. Mesic was officially granted his seat that the army was ordered back to its barracks. **********Rubbing salt in the army wounds, Mr. Mesic, warned today that army generals could be expected to be called to account for their actions in the fighting, which included bombing and strafing of civilian targets. **********Singling out the army chief of staff, Gen. Blagoje Adzic, a fiercely pro-Serbian officer, the President said, "A number of generals will have to reassess their position on recent events, and particularly regarding the so-called war in Slovenia." **********Slovenia's President, Milan Kucan, said at a news conference in Ljubljana, Slovenia's capital, that the Yugoslav Army had called up 200,000 reserves from Serbia and the republics of Bosnia-Herzegovina. He cited Belgrade television as the source of this report. **********Evidence of the army's resolve to act appeared tonight when the state television in Belgrade announced that the army commander in chief in the Slovene region, Gen. Konrad Kolsek, a Slovene, had been replaced by a Serb, Gen. Zivota Avramovic. **********The cease-fire was one element of an agreement sealed late Sunday under the mediation of three European Community foreign ministers, after the Friday truce appeared to unravel.  Three-Month Moratorium **********In exchange for the troop withdrawal, Slovenia and Croatia agreed to a three-month moratorium on their independence declarations. For its part, Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest and most populous republic, agreed to drop resisting the election of Mr. Mesic as President, an election mandated by the Constitution, which requires that the presidency be rotated among the leaders of the six republics. **********Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, arrived in Belgrade today for a two-day visit to Yugoslavia to explore ways of helping the country out of its crisis by sending an observer mission under the auspices of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. But Mr. Genscher made it clear that this was intended to be a civilian mission. **********Mr. Genscher is scheduled to travel to Ljubljana on Tuesday for talks with Slovenian leaders before going to a meeting of the conference in Prague. **********But the army's action, which came after Mr. Genscher's meeting with Mr. Mesic and Prime Minister Markovic, cast doubt on the ability of the 35-nation process to help mediate here. At a news conference this evening, Mr. Genscher said Mr. Markovic asserted that he neither condoned nor knew of the preparations to use force last week to keep Slovenia in Yugoslavia. **********"I was impressed by the declaration of the Prime Minister," Mr. Genscher said, "that he bore no responsibility for this and had no knowledge of it." **********Western diplomats said the army appeared wounded and angry after its poor performance against Slovenia, in which its forces were severely defeated by the poorly equipped but highly motivated Slovenes. At least 69 people died and many more were wounded in the fighting. **********The Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, said today that European Community mediators had told him that at the conclusion of the three-month cooling-off period, his republic of 4.5 million would gain independence. **********"If you abide by the agreements," Mr. Tudjman cited the European foreign ministers who mediated the accord as telling Croatians, "you will be free in three months, in all respects. No interpretation of that is needed." Soviets Speak of Hypocrisy **********MOSCOW, July 1 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Communist Party daily Pravda said today that Western double standards over the Baltic republics had helped set off the Yugoslav crisis. **********The daily said the declarations of independence by Slovenia and Croatia were part of a separatist virus that threatened to set off of civil war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/11/busin.main_headline: Campeau Is Sued By Its Founder
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Campeau Is Sued By Its Founder
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/11/busin.body_text: **********Robert Campeau, who brought the Campeau Corporation to the brink of bankruptcy and was then forced out, is suing the company for wrongful dismissal and seeking $88 million in compensation. Mr. Campeau's suit seeks damages for the way he was removed as president, chairman and chief executive. Campeau, founded in Toronto by Mr. Campeau 37 years ago, owns major United States retail chains including Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Burdines, which are operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. **********In response to the suit, the company said that Mr. Campeau had not told the whole story. "There are people who would say someone who brings a corporation to the brink of bankruptcy hasn't been improperly dismissed," a spokesman, Dick Wertheimer, said. Mr. Campeau was dismissed last August, and in May the company sued him for $12.8 million in overdue loans. He was also asked to return paintings, cars and more than $5,300 in telephone equipment installed in his Toronto home.

The newspaper quoted unidentified people familiar with the situation as saying that Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, asked Ford's former chairman, Donald E. Petersen to act as an intermediary in talks between the auto makers. Mr. Iacocca, a former Ford executive, approached Mr. Petersen after Chrysler's talks with the Italian auto maker Fiat S.p.A. fell through, The Journal reported. But the newspaper said it was not clear whether Ford and Chrysler officials held any direct meetings. Officials at Ford and Chrysler, along with Mr. Petersen, declined to comment on the matter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.main_headline: BUSH IS PLEASED BY FREEING OF 10
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: THE WHITE HOUSE; BUSH IS PLEASED BY FREEING OF 10
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.body_text: **********President Bush welcomed the release of 10 allied prisoners by Iraq today, but vowed to win the freedom of "every single" captured soldier and Kuwaiti citizen. The nation's senior military officer said the war would not be formally ended until Iraq accounted for all its prisoners. **********One day after Iraqi officers met with allied military commanders in southern Iraq, the Pentagon said the suspension of hostilities was holding and the White House called Iraq's initial compliance with the United Nations' conditions for a permanent cease-fire encouraging. **********The Bush Administration said that in addition to releasing the 10 prisoners, who included 6 Americans, Baghdad had also supplied the location of land and sea mines in Kuwait and the Persian Gulf to coalition forces, as demanded by the alliance as a condition for a formal cease-fire. **********"We're making progress in our journey from war to peace," Mr. Bush told a veterans' group in the White House in a speech that mingled a sense of triumph with quotations from Abraham Lincoln and assurances from the President that he was "not gloating." 'It's Not a Time to Brag' **********Mr. Bush's comments were part of a concerted effort by the Administration today to convey the impression that the United States was not seeking to punish Iraq after the coalition's military victory, but to play what Mr. Bush has called the "role of the healer." It came at the start of a week in which Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is to begin a diplomatic mission to the Middle East. Mr. Bush plans to meet next week with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, President Francois Mitterrand of France and Prime Minister John Major of Britain to discuss the future of the Middle East. **********"It's not a time to brag," Mr. Bush said, quoting Lincoln's post-Civil War formulation of "malice toward none." **********Although Mr. Bush has vowed not to spend "a single dime" of taxpayers' money to rebuild Iraq, he added: "We are a generous nation. And we've got a lot to do now. We've got a lot to do to heal the wounds. Our argument has never been with the people of Iraq, with those hapless soldiers that were sent to a fate that they didn't even know what was in store for them." Iraqi Compliance Demanded **********In his remarks, Mr. Bush repeated that Iraq must comply with all the United Nations resolutions on Kuwait, including ones that require Baghdad to renounce its annexation of the emirate and accept "in principle" that it must pay war reparations, before the allies move beyond the current suspension of hostilities to a "more permanent and stable cease-fire." **********But Mr. Bush said he could not "relax at all until every single one of those prisoners is home and every single missing is accounted for to the best of the ability of the Iraqi forces." Mr. Bush said Iraq must also free the thousands of Kuwaitis seized by its retreating forces in the final days of the war. **********He added, "And clearly, on a sad subject, that requires the returning of the remains of all our fallen heroes." **********Speaking to another veterans' gathering in Washington, a meeting of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, also demanded that all prisoners be released. "In this war, it won't be over until we get a full and immediate accounting for all of our P.O.W.'s and M.I.A.'s," he said. Iraqi Cooperation Noted **********Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the United States still treated Iraqi assurances and commitments with "a high degree of skepticism." But he said that with the release of the prisoners today, "they were being cooperative in a way that was very helpful and we're optimistic about that." **********Mr. Fitzwater reiterated that until the allies sign a permanent cease-fire with Iraq the coalition will keep its forces in the southern part of that country. But Mr. Fitzwater and Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, declined to estimate how long that might take. **********Mr. Fitzwater said the United States did not intend to initiate any attempt to prosecute President Saddam Hussein of Iraq on war crimes charges, but "would be part" of such an effort if one was started by an Arab country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/01/world.main_headline: Europeans Try to Ease Croatia Crisis
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/01/world.print_headline: Europeans Try to Ease Croatia Crisis
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/01/world.body_text: **********Having helped negotiate a cease-fire in Slovenia this month, the European Community now hopes to bring an end to the fighting in Croatia without having to assume the risks of sending a peacekeeping mission into Yugoslavia. **********While recognizing that a peace force might eventually become necessary, European officials said much depends on how the Yugoslav parties respond to the community's latest offer to expand its truce-monitoring role beyond Slovenia once a cease-fire has been agreed on in Croatia. **********Senior European officials flew to Belgrade today to prepare a weekend visit by the foreign ministers of the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Portugal, who will seek approval of the community plan by Yugoslavia's national Government as well as by the Serbian and Croatian leaderships.  Promote Negotiations **********But with Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, boycotting new crisis talks in Belgrade today, confidence about an early breakthrough was hard to find in European capitals. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France expressed his fear that Yugoslavia was "digging in for a civil war." **********The community's idea is not only to increase its unarmed observer force from 50 to 200 civilians, but also to use any hiatus in the fighting to promote negotiations with a view either to creating a new federal structure or to allowing a peaceful secession from Yugoslavia by Slovenia and Croatia. **********Shortly before Slovenia and Croatia declared their independence on June 25, the 12-nation community went on record as opposing the dismemberment of Yugoslavia, a position that opened it up to later criticism that it had encouraged the Yugoslav Army to move against the rebel republics. **********Since the new surge of fighting in Croatia, most community governments now appear to believe that stability in the Balkans will be more threatened by a full-scale civil war in Yugoslavia than by the negotiated breakup of the existing state. **********"At first, there was a lot of concern about the situation in the Balkans as a whole," a British official said. "But Slovenia is now quiet and the focus is very much on Croatia. The key thing is to get an effective cease-fire and insure the safety of the monitors." **********Even France, which until recently insisted on preserving Yugoslavia's political unity, has adopted a more flexible position. "Whether territorial integrity or self-determination eventually prevails, the important thing is that it should not be through violence," a French official said.  Monitors Seem to Help **********Germany, which at one point seemed to favor recognizing Slovenia and Croatia, is now fully backing the community plan. "We have reports that the mere presence of the monitors in Slovenia is contributing to peace there," a German official said. **********Austria and Italy, which could be swamped by refugees across their borders with Yugoslavia if the conflict worsens, have scaled down their expressions of alarm since the cease-fire went into effect in Slovenia and are now counting on the community's achieving the same results in Croatia. **********The immediate question for the community is whether what is still largely an economic bloc has the political weight to impose and sustain a cease-fire between Serbs and Croats, whose historical enmity has been deepened by the fighting and casualties of the last two weeks. **********Officials from France, Britain and Luxembourg privately acknowledge that tension in Yugoslavia is so high that it may become necessary to beef up the observer team with military personnel. This week, France already suggested that the observers carry sidearms for their own protection. **********But the community is clearly reluctant to propose the dispatch of a peacekeeping force, not only for fear of being drawn into the quagmire of Yugoslavia's ethnic quarrels, but also because it lacks a mandate from either Yugoslavia or the international community to do so.  Concern Over Precedent **********Its current observer mission was endorsed early this month by the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. But since the security conference works through consensus, the mission became possible only because it was approved by Yugoslavia. **********Many European officials believe that even if Yugoslavia sought an international peacekeeping force, the Soviet Union might block such a move for fear of setting a precedent of foreign involvement at a time that it is wrestling with its own rebel republics from the Baltic to the Ukraine. **********Further, the European Community is itself not equipped to organize a peacekeeping mission, although it could theoretically turn for assistance to the Western European Union, a regional defense group embracing nine community members. **********"We prefer to take this step by step," said a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman in the Netherlands, which holds the rotating presidency of the community. "We'll have to see what happens with the ministerial mission this weekend before there is serious consideration of a peace force." **********A German official said that with no experience in dealing with a conflict "in its own backyard," the community was still feeling its way. "Some people say the community has not done enough," he said. "But you could ask what would have happened if the community had done nothing."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.body_text: **********Builders broke ground for new houses and apartments at an annual rate of 1,040,000 in June, the third straight increase and the first million-plus month since November, the Census Bureau reported today. **********The 5.2 percent advance included a sharp rebound in the Northeast, albeit from very depressed levels, with the West being the only region to show a decline. **********At the same time, permits for future construction rose 4 percent, to a annual pace of 1,002,000, the fastest since last August. 'A Mild Recovery' **********But while the rise in activity was somewhat stronger than expected, analysts continued to view housing as a relatively subdued contributor to an economic rebound that itself is likely to be lackluster. **********"The housing market continues to improve, but it's improving slowly, and it's improving by less in this recovery than in previous recoveries," said David W. Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. He said housing would "lead" the economy in coming months but, with starts at about two-thirds the pace of the mid-1980's, would not be strong enough to "pull" it. **********"This fits with our preception of a mild recovery," added Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. **********Today's housing figures were published as the Labor Department reported that consumer prices last month rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent over all, but a mildly unnerving four-tenths of 1 percent excluding food and energy.  [ Page D10. ] **********This was seen as consistent with modest economic reovery and not as grounds for the Federal Reserve to either relax or tighten monetary conditions. **********June's 1,040,000 pace of housing starts consisted of 868,000 single-family homes and 172,000 multifamily units, according to the bureau. The total compared with 989,000 in May, a pace revised upward from the 982,000 that was initially reported. No Trend Established **********The Northeast posted a sharp increase to an annual rate of 148,000, a pace 29.8 percent faster than May's 114,000 rate. Government and private analysts cautioned, however, that monthly starts figures were highly erratic and that it may take three months or more to establish even a national trend. **********At their June pace, starts in the Northeast returned to the levels of last October and November. **********Starts climbed 17.5 percent, to a 255,000 rate, in the Midwest and by 6 percent, to 389,000, in the South. In the West, the decline was 14.8 percent, to 248,000, offsetting a May surge. **********During the first half of the year, there were 487,700 starts, 25 percent less than for the same period of 1990. **********Without seasonal adjustment, nationwide starts were 104,100 last month, about twice the January low of 52,500. Permits Up in All Regions **********All four regions posted gains in permits at a seasonally adjusted annual rate -- to 115,000 from 105,000 in the Northeast; to 231,000 from 221,000 in the Midwest; to 392,000 from 379,000 in the South, and to 264,000 from 261,000 in the West. **********For the first six months of 1991, 470,200 permits were issued, 26 percent under the comparable period last year. **********Today's report also showed that manufacturers shipped mobile homes at a 174,000 annual rate during May, 1,000 fewer than in April and 16,000 fewer than in May 1990. **********Early this month, the Government reported that sales of new single-family houses fell to an annual rate of 474,000 in May. This is little more than half the level of single-family starts this year, the apparent discrepancy is explained by the fact that sales figures do not include custom-built homes for which sales contracts are signed in advance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/world.main_headline: Another U.N. Report Says Iraq May Conceal Uranium
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/world.print_headline: Another U.N. Report Says Iraq May Conceal Uranium
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/world.body_text: **********United Nations inspectors have unearthed new evidence suggesting that Iraq may be concealing a quantity of highly enriched uranium suitable for use as a nuclear explosive and probably acquired from an unknown foreign supplier. **********The evidence was discovered last month by experts from the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency, during their seventh inspection tour investigating Saddam Hussein's secret nuclear programs. It takes the form of traces of uranium enriched up to 93 percent -- "weapons-grade" levels -- which were found at four places inside the Thwaitha nuclear installation, 40 miles southwest of Baghdad. **********In a report issued today, the inspectors ruled out the possibility that these uranium traces could have come from reactor fuel that France sold Iraq in 1980 because they contain "significant amounts" of the isotope uranium 236. **********The French fuel -- most of which is still buried under the rubble of an Osirak reactor at Tuwaitha, bombed by Israel in 1981 -- contained no uranium 236. **********Iraq's only other known supplier of highly enriched uranium was the Soviet Union. But its reactor fuel was only enriched to about 80 percent and, like the French-supplied fuel, was under safeguards of the international agency, making diversion for military ends difficult. **********The inspectors also say it is unlikely that Iraq could have enriched uranium to such high levels itself, although it was experimenting with three enrichment techniques. **********"The traces seem to imply Iraq had a foreign supplier of highly enriched uranium and that it may still have undeclared stocks," Rolf Ekeus, director of the commission established by the Security Council to oversee the destruction of Iraq's nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, said today. **********"The source of this material remains an important open issue requiring further investigation," the inspectors added. **********Experts say the contamination by uranium 236 shows it had been used first as reactor fuel, reprocessed to separate the plutonium, and then re-enriched to weapons-grade levels. **********Iraq is unlikely to have done this itself because its preferred enrichment method, called electromagnetic separation, would also remove the uranium 236. And the United Nations inspectors found no evidence that the centrifugal enrichment machines Baghdad was building were operational. Absolving the French **********France appears unlikely to have been the source, experts say, since traditionally it does not re-enrich spent reactor fuel. This is because the process tends to contaminate the plant with fission products, creating special hazards for those working there. **********"The Soviet Union or China seem the most likely suspects," according to Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, a Washington-based group seeking to stem the spread of nuclear weapons to developing countries. "But by careful analysis of the traces, the United Nations should be able to work out where they came from."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/world.main_headline: U.S. Holds Up Visa for Iranian Ex-President
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/world.print_headline: U.S. Holds Up Visa for Iranian Ex-President
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/world.body_text: **********The State Department has held up a decision on whether to grant a visa to Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, who was President of Iran during part of the hostage crisis, forcing him to delay or cancel a United States tour to promote a new book. **********Mr. Bani-Sadr was scheduled to leave for the United States from Paris today, said Franklin D. Margiotta, president of Brassey's, a Virginia-based publisher that has published "My Turn to Speak: Iran, the Revolution & Secret Deals with the U.S." **********Mr. Bani-Sadr was planning to appear on television and to give interviews next week about his book, which includes his opinion that the 1980 Reagan campaign team negotiated with Iranian officials to delay the release of the American hostages as part of its effort to defeat President Jimmy Carter. **********Mr. Bani-Sadr's book does not provide evidence for that thesis but offers speculation based on the way some people behaved in Iran. Former Reagan officials deny any such deal. **********A State Department spokesman said Mr. Bani-Sadr's visa request was under review, adding, "Obviously an application from anyone associated with the Iranian Government at the time of their holding U.S. hostages in Teheran has to be looked at carefully."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.main_headline: So Far From Mideast: Mongolia's Oil Intrigues Bush
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.print_headline: So Far From Mideast: Mongolia's Oil Intrigues Bush
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.body_text: **********It has a vast desert and a large oil potential, President Bush was told, and this piqued his interest in Mongolia, a country about three times the size of Texas and thousands of miles from the Middle East. **********The topic of oil came up when the President, a former Texas oilman, conferred with Punsalmaagiyn Ochirbat, President of Mongolia, the Asian leader said today. **********Asked about reports that American oil companies are interested in developing production in basins in the Gobi desert, Mr. Ochirbat said that at his White House meeting with Mr. Bush on Wednesday "we told him about it and maybe expanded his knowledge." **********President Bush was extremely cordial to Mr. Ochirbat, the first Mongolian head of state to visit Washington, and after announcing that the United States would extend trade benefits to his Government said he was looking forward to increased American commerce with Mongolia. Oil Production to Begin **********In a meeting with reporters, President Ochirbat said that within two years Mongol Gazryn Tos, the Mongolian petroleum company, would begin extracting oil from deposits discovered decades ago by Soviet geologists at Zuunbayan, 280 miles southeast of the capital, Ulan Bator, and that "shortly we will begin exploration for new deposits." **********Mr. Ochirbat said the Mongolian Parliament had recently approved laws permitting foreign investment and joint ventures. **********Mongol Gazryn Tos was set up a year ago, replacing a Government ministry, as part of program removing Communist political and economic structures that had existed since the 1920's. **********Last month, Exploration Associates International of Houston, a consulting concern, published a report on previous petroleum exploration in Mongolia that showed good prospects in Gobi desert sedimentary basins. **********Mike Buck, vice president of the company, said the report was based on 150 exploratory studies conducted by Soviet, Hungarian, Romanian, East German and Polish geologists and geophysicists between 1939 and 1989 and covering about 60 percent of Mongolia. **********Mr. Buck said he became interested in exploring Mongolian oil deposits two years ago when he learned while in China that some of the oil-rich sedimentary basins of North China extended across the frontier into southern Mongolia. The North China basins are estimated to contain about 10 billion barrels, he said. 200 Wells Are Drilled **********"The more we dug into the geological reports, the more we found," Mr. Buck said of oil prospects in Mongolia, "We are very enthusiastic." About 200 exploratory wells have been drilled in Mongolia. **********In a telephone interview, Mr. Buck said the report covered Mongolia's 13 major sedimentary basins, most of which lie to the south of Ulan Bator. **********The report, at $45,000 a copy, has become something of a best seller in the oil industry, and the company has become the technical adviser of Mongol Gazryn Tos in a new joint venture.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Levi and Spike Lee Return In 'Button Your Fly' Part 2
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Levi and Spike Lee Return In 'Button Your Fly' Part 2
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.body_text: **********NOT every advertising campaign is successful enough to inspire T-shirts. Fewer still inspire imitative T-shirts. Having inspired both, Spike Lee's "501 Button-Fly Report" for Levi Strauss & Company 501 jeans is returning for a second year. **********Since the campaign first appeared last summer, "we have definitely seen percentage increases in sales in a market that has been pretty flat," Daniel M. Chew, Levi's marketing manager, said in a telephone interview on Friday from the company's San Francisco headquarters. **********The official T-shirts, which Mr. Chew said have sold in the tens of thousands, bear the campaign's slogan, "Button your fly." The unauthorized versions, which are sold on city streets, carry the message, "Unbutton my fly." **********"In a way, it's flattering because it indicates the popularity of the real ones," Mr. Chew said of the imitative T-shirts. "But at the same time, we prefer that people put on our jeans and button them up." **********To that end, Levi Strauss will spend $15 million on commercial time for the 1991 edition of the campaign, which makes its debut next Monday. **********The spots are again produced by Foote, Cone & Belding San Francisco and directed by Mr. Lee, the film maker, who is also a writer and actor. Once more, viewers of the ads will see jeans-clad youths across the country engaged in unusual pursuits; previously, there were youngsters chasing home-run balls outside Wrigley Field in Chicago and talking backwards about "Sivel 105" in Brooklyn. **********For '91, the campaign takes viewers to sites like Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., where Joe Hamm, a lighting technician, defies heights to prepare for a Grateful Dead concert; New Braunfels, Tex., where spelunkers explore mysterious caves, and Las Vegas, Nev., where the camera observes arrangements being made for a Mike Tyson fight. **********This year, the spots are "a little more aspirationa," Mr. Chew said, using a marketing buzzword for ads intended to make consumers aspire to emulate the people endorsing the products. Mr. Chew said the Levi spots are intended to make the target audience, the 14-to-24 age group, ask, " 'Gee, if these guys are doing all this, what could I be doing?' " **********The "aspirational" aspect is also what attracted Levi Strauss to Mr. Lee, Mr. Chew explained. "We want to build on the popularity and respect we've found he has in this target market," he said, "in that he's seen as someone who has accomplished a great deal at a relatively young age." **********Mr. Chew also praised Mr. Lee's rapport with the on-camera talent, which in the 501 campaign is people who are not professional actors. That rapport is important, he said, because the spots are unscripted. **********One new feature in this year's series is an on-camera appearance by Mr. Lee. He can be glimpsed in the 30- and 60-second spots at Giants Stadium, wearing, as usual, a baseball cap (and jeans, of course). Once more, Mr. Lee provides the off-camera voice-over narration. **********Levi Strauss is the second large marketer for which Mr. Lee has made commercials. He continues to work with Wieden & Kennedy, of Portland, Ore., on the "Mars Blackmon" ad series in which he appears with the basketball star Michael Jordan for Nike Inc.'s line of Air Jordan athletic footwear, **********The 501 campaign comes amid an unprecedented advertising blitz by Foote, Cone for the nation's leading jeans maker. Levi's Jeans for Women are being promoted in a $12 million print and outdoor campaign that began earlier this month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/busin.main_headline: All About/Blood Banks; A Multibillion-Dollar Business in a Nonprofit World
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/busin.print_headline: All About/Blood Banks; A Multibillion-Dollar Business in a Nonprofit World
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/07/busin.body_text: **********Blood banking is a paradoxical business, a multibillion-dollar industry whose product is largely donated and then sold by nonprofit organizations. **********"Blood is a bit like water," said Donald Doddridge, president of the American Association of Blood Banks, which represents about 2,370 independent centers in the United States. Though the raw material is, for the most part, free, "someone has to get it and purify it, which costs money," he explained. "Basically we're supplying a product and selling it." **********The purpose of collecting and distributing blood is to use it and its constituent components to save lives. But the industry has increasingly come under attack, accused of violating Federal guidelines, thus adding to the spread of AIDS and hepatitis. In Congressional hearings last month, Federal officials charged that slipping safety standards, improper training of personnel, deteriorating equipment and the drive for revenues had imperiled the industry. **********The American Red Cross, the nation's largest blood supplier, was singled out for criticism. In the past year, the Red Cross has also been cited by the Food and Drug Administration, which regulates the blood industry, for hundreds of violations of procedures. In contrast, only 10 percent of the independent blood centers were found to have similar violations. **********"No single license-holder for blood has had the problems of the Red Cross," said Dr. Gerald V. Quinnan Jr., acting dean of the Center for Biological Evaluation and Research at the F.D.A. **********Responding to the criticism, Elizabeth Dole, the former Transportation Secretary who has been president of the Red Cross since February, argued that "the blood supply is safer than ever." But she added that the Red Cross will be making major changes in the way it conducts its blood-banking and processing business.  The Players Giant Red Cross Has Image Problems **********Though most blood bank officials do not like to compare their product to other commodities -- potatoes, say, or oil -- there are some similarities. In contracting to supply domestic hospitals, blood banks operate in a very competitive market. Then too, like oil, blood can be refined into a variety of higher-priced products with market values fluctuating widely depending on world supply and demand. **********Since the 1960's, the banks have been separating blood into its components -- red cells, platelets and plasma -- in addition to selling it whole. This conserves and specializes the blood supply, as well as bringing in greater revenues. But industry officials acknowledge that breaking blood down into a variety of components increases the possibility of infection, since a single patient may get components from a variety of donors. **********Three nonprofit organizations dominate the $2 billion American market for whole blood. The industry leader is the Red Cross, which was founded by Clara Barton after the Civil War. Its 53 regional blood centers collect more than half of the nation's blood supply, or 6.5 million units a year. The Red Cross's blood services division last year had $741 million in revenues and $14 million in tax-exempt "profits," meaning excesses of revenues over expenses. Total revenues raised for its relief services were about $945 million last year. **********The Red Cross's main rival is the American Association of Blood Banks, which includes members of the Council of Community Blood Centers as well as hospital blood centers. The association, founded in 1947 primarily to counteract the dominance of the Red Cross, acts sets uniform operational guidelines for its independent members. **********Community blood banks, which are not-for-profit organizations, operate like small businesses with a board of directors and president. Mr. Doddridge, head of a community center in St. Petersberg, Fla., as well as current president of the association, estimates that most independently licensed centers have revenues of $50,000 to $500,000 and retain 5 percent to 10 percent of revenues in not-for-profit excesses. **********"You can't operate a blood bank in the red," Mr. Doddridge said. "Whatever profit margin you have is put back into the business. That's why we stress that we are a service, collecting blood for the nation." **********In contrast to independent centers, which each have their own license from the F.D.A, the Red Cross has only one license. **********The Red Cross's venerable image, as well as its single license, was seriously threatened in 1988, when the agency closed its Washington blood center after it was discovered that 235 people who had received blood there tested positive for the AIDS virus. **********Mrs. Dole announced last month that under the new restructuring plan, all of its blood centers will be closed on a rotating basis over the next two years to insure that computer inventories and screening systems are uniform nationwide and that Federal regulations are being met. The restructuring effort is expected to cost $125 million. **********"When a large organization like the Red Cross has problems, you have to look at the operating philosophy," said Robert W. Reilly, president of the American Blood Resources Association, a trade group representing about 50 companies that own and operate more than 400 blood plasma collection centers nationwide. "Every product must be treated and handled in the same way."  The Components A Global Market For Blood Plasma **********A pint of whole blood fetches about $100, but broken into various components, might bring in $190, depending on the region in which it is sold. **********Plasma, valued for its relatively long shelf life, is what remains when the platelets and oxygen-carrying red cells are removed from blood. One can extract about $55 worth of it from a pint of whole blood. And it can be separated further -- into albumin, which is used to keep blood-vessel walls from collapsing after an injury; Factor VIII, a blood-clotting agent used by hemophiliacs, and immune globulins, which can be used to strengthen the human immune system against certain diseases. **********Collecting and further processing plasma is no easy matter. Commercial companies typically pay donors, because separating the plasma from the whole blood, which is done at the bedside, can take as long as three hours. That and further processing require a sizable investment in technology and training. As a result, only the largest nonprofit organizations -- often in collaboration with profit-making companies -- have entered the market for plasma products. **********Plasma is the fastest-growing segment of the blood-products industry. It is a global market which last year had revenues of about $2 billion, according to Jack M. Reasor, president of the Marketing Research Bureau of Laguna Beach, Calif., which studies plasma collection in 30 countries. Five international companies dominate the market. But the United States is the major producer of plasma, collecting more than 60 percent of the world's annual yield of 15 million liters. **********The industry leader for plasma products, with about 30 percent of the market, is the Armour Pharmaceutical Company of Bluebell, Penn., a subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, the big French Government-owned pharmaceutical company. **********Next is Hyland Therapeutics of Glendale, Calif., a subsidiary of Baxter International Inc., which has 25 percent. Cutter Laboratories, a subsidiary of Miles, which is in turn a division of Germany's Bayer A.G., has 15 percent of the market, followed by Alpha Therapeutic, a subsidiary of Japan's Green Cross Corporation, with 10 percent. **********The Red Cross took a bold step in 1978 by contracting to use the manufacturing facilities of Hyland, thus entering the commercial plasma market with its donated plasma supplies. That business, which now accounts for about half Hyland's output, brought the Red Cross roughly $100 million of tax-exempt revenues last year.  New Complexities The Technology In the Age of AIDS **********In the last decade, blood collection has become increasingly complex. Blood centers have added five tests since 1985 to screen for hepatitis and AIDS, and two more AIDS tests will be added by the Red Cross this fall. **********There is no single repository for blood donor data, but both commercial companies and nonprofit blood centers have purchased computer systems to track donors. And the American Blood Resources Association is setting up a nationwide donor referral registry, in which any center will be able to call an 800 number to find out, among other things, if a donor has tested positive for the AIDS virus. **********Perhaps the biggest challenge facing the blood industry is the tremendous capital that will be required in the next 10 years to build or upgrade facilities, conduct research, purchase new equipment and hire more staff to further safeguard the blood supply. **********Commercial companies have invested about $50 million in research for new blood products, and the Red Cross, $7 million. About a quarter of the independent blood centers have plans to expand or build new facilities at an average cost of $1 million per center, said Mr. Doddridge.  THE STORE-YOUR-OWN CONCEPT **********Until recent years, the medical establishment gave barely a thought to the idea of individuals stockpiling their own blood for future operations or emergencies. Then came the AIDS epidemic, and with it, increasingly urgent questions about the safety of the nation's blood supply. **********Not surprisingly, given the special storage requirements, the first autologous, or self-donating, American blood bank was started by a sperm bank. The Daxor Corporation, based in New York, which began freezing sperm at superlow temperatures for artificial insemination in 1971, has through a subsidiary, Idant, been freezing blood since 1985. **********"I realized that we could do the same thing with blood that we were doing with sperm," said Dr. Joseph Feldschuh, who founded Daxor and is author of a book, "Safe Blood," which, despite its title, argues that America's blood supply is unsafe. **********Conventional blood banks consider self-storage controversial. They worry that it could destroy the voluntary system of donating blood and that the costs are too high, said Donald Doddridge of the American Association of Blood Banks. **********Idant charges an initial testing and processing fee of $100. The blood is run through 30 tests, including ones for cholesterol and for glucose, to detect diabetes. It can be safely stored for 10 years or more, according to Dr. Felschuh. Storage charges vary, from $12 a month for a pint of fragile red cells to $8 for more resilient plasma. **********So far, Idant has attracted about 2,000 customers. But the company is not a moneymaker. "It's not been a good investment," said Dr. Feldschuh. "We have lost money since it was initiated and acceptance is slow." Twenty-five other autologous blood banks have already gone out of business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: BAGHDAD; Iraq Closes Window to Outside World
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/world.body_text: **********Iraq's decision yesterday to expel Western correspondents from Baghdad closes one of the few remaining windows on life in the battered Iraqi capital. **********Iraqi officials there and in Amman, Jordan, where many foreign journalists obtained their Iraqi visas, said no more visas would be issued. And, they said, journalists still in Iraq would have to be out by 4 A.M. tomorrow, Baghdad time (8 P.M. today, Eastern time). **********About three dozen journalists, including some Americans, remained missing in southern Iraq yesterday after they crossed into Iraq from Saudi Arabia Sunday and Monday to cover a reported rebellion against President Saddam Hussein in the city of Basra.  Arnett Given Extra Time **********Among the correspondents being expelled from Baghdad was CNN's Peter Arnett, who remained in the city throughout the war. **********In what CNN said could be his last broadcast from Baghdad, Mr. Arnett said that most of the correspondents in the city had been asked to leave within hours but that he and his crew had been given an extra day. "We have so much equipment," he said, "We've been told that we'll have tomorrow to pack up." **********Mr. Arnett, who has been in Baghdad for almost eight weeks, since just before the allied air campaign started in January, said the correspondents had been given no official reason for their expulsion. **********He said the correspondents had been told that Information Ministry officials were tired, that "they want to regroup, they want to rethink press policy, and that if we all go to Amman, Jordan, and wait there, in 10 days they will come and start the whole procedure all over again." **********He recalled that news coverage, always severely restricted in Iraq, had expanded enormously in the last three months. **********The press corps had "blossomed to hundreds of journalists," he said. "Journalists from all over the world talking freely; if not freely here, certainly they talk freely when they get to neighboring Amman, Jordan, about what they see. 'Explosion of Coverage' **********"So there's been an explosion of coverage," he said, "and at this point in time it's clear the Iraqi Government wants to get some kind of control over the information that's going out of here." **********Asked to speculate on why the reporters were being ousted, Mr. Arnett said, "That will be a matter of speculation throughout this evening as our colleagues pack. We have had the advantage of being here for nearly eight months. Some of our colleagues arrived last night. They've been trying to get visas for two, three months. They are very unhappy at the prospect of having to leave tomorrow or the next day. **********"The climate in the past week here has been very limiting for reporters. Reports of unrest have been widespread, broadcast considerably on international radio broadcasts that come in here. We have known of incidents nearby and elsewhere in the country that we haven't been permitted to talk about under punishment of banishment, under the rules of the game, which had changed as the days went on. We were told to talk less and less about the public attitudes here." **********The CNN correspondent said he regretted that he would not have time for another interview with President Saddam Hussein. **********Noting that, in his last interview with Mr. Hussein, the Iraqi leader told him to "ask whatever you want," he said: **********"I'd love to meet him again in the next few days and ask him anything I want about what's happened in the two months since I first saw him."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Japan; Japan Pledges $9 Billion to War Amid Opposition
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Japan; Japan Pledges $9 Billion to War Amid Opposition
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/world.body_text: **********The Japanese Government said today it would contribute $9 billion to the allied force fighting Iraq and supply military aircraft for evacuating refugees from the war zone. But both proposals are encountering stiff opposition among the Japanese people. **********The money would be in addition to the $4 billion in aid already promised by Japan, although less than half of that pledge has actually been disbursed. Half of the earlier sum was earmarked for the war effort and half for economic assistance to Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. **********To pay for its contribution, the Government must obatin legislative approval. The opposition has focused on reports this week that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will soon propose a special tax and possibly a bond issue to raise the cash as quickly as possible. **********Officials expressed confidence that they would win Parliament's approval of the tax and the airlift measures. But the Government has had problems mustering a consensus even within its own leadership and that of the governing Liberal Democratic Party.  Kaifu Canceled Announcement **********On Wednesday evening, Mr. Kaifu suffered embarrassment when he was forced to cancel a news conference at which he was planning to unveil the aid proposal and outline his views on Japan's role in the war. **********Officials said the cancellation was the result of squabbling among Government officials and senior members of the ruling party and of criticism from opposition parties controlling the upper house of Parliament. **********There has been disagreement about how many strings are to be attached to the new money. Up to now, Japan's aid to the gulf military effort has been restricted to nonlethal support. Even the cash has come with a requirement that it not be spent on arms or ammunition. **********The United States has asked that these restrictions be removed, but the announcement today left them in effect for the time being.  Opposition to War **********The announcement also comes amid growing dissatisfaction with the American-led offensive against Iraq. Some officials in the Government are worried that news accounts and television commentary has focused over the last week on the American decision to wage war rather than on the Iraq's initial invasion of Kuwait. **********Opposition in Japan has focused on the price tag of the aid proposal, estimated earlier as ranging from $5 billion to $10 billion. The possibility of a tax is increasingly denounced by business and consumer groups. **********The Japanese press has described the proposed aid as equivalent to Japan's annual welfare payments, and the tax as equivalent to $75 for every man, woman and child in Japan. Many seem shocked at the amount of money Japan is being asked to pay.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/20/busin.body_text: **********Despite higher pretax earnings, the quarterly profit of the Lockheed Corporation fell 13.6 percent, as its tax rate increased sharply, the military contractor said. **********Lockheed, which built the Stealth fighter and recently led a team that won the contract for the next-generation advanced tactical fighter, said this week that its second-quarter earnings fell to $70 million, or $1.11 a share, from $81 million, or $1.28 a share, in the comparable period in 1990. Sales rose fractionally, to $2.43 billion from $2.42 billion. **********Lockheed's corporate tax rate rose strikingly, to 35 percent in 1991 from 21 percent in 1990, because of changes in required accounting procedures. **********Before-tax program profits rose to $134 million in the second quarter from $128 million a year earlier. The gain mainly reflects the absence of costs for developing and testing advanced tactical fighter prototypes, which have been completed. **********The company's share price rose 50 cents today, to $47.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/22/world.main_headline: Rootless but Ruling for Unity, the Dynasty That Was Modern India Is Gone
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/22/world.print_headline: ASSASSINATION IN INDIA; Rootless but Ruling for Unity, the Dynasty That Was Modern India Is Gone
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/22/world.body_text: **********Their styles and their agendas were each different, ranging from the visionary nation-building of Nehru to the more narrowly opportunistic political maneuvering practiced by Indira and Rajiv. But they all shared a kind of cosmopolitan rootlessness, very rare among Indian politicians, that reinforced an ideological commitment to secularism and strong central government. **********The family had originated in Kashmir, India's northernmost territory, but had lived for generations in the Hindu heartland of Uttar Pradesh, with the result that it had no real regional power base. As one Indian scholar noted, "In U.P., they were Kashmiris. In Kashmir, they were from U.P. And what they all wanted desperately was to be Indians."  Crossed Ethnic Boundaries **********Indira Gandhi, a Hindu, had married a Parsi. Her youngest son, Sanjay, who until his death in an airplane crash in 1980 was being groomed to follow her, had married a Sikh. Rajiv's own wife is Italian-born. **********In turn, the three generations had all sought mandates to rule over an India in which local and regional powers would be subordinated to the transcendent authority of their Congress Party, which as time went by became more dominated by themselves and their closest retainers. **********Of the three, it was Nehru who came closest to achieving that broad mandate. Under the tutelage and sponsorship of Mohandas K. Gandhi, Nehru led the Congress Party through its nonviolent struggles to liberty. As the country's first Prime Minister, he established and imposed a national vision of a secular state committed to democracy at home and nonalignment in its foreign policies. India, at least in some regions, became a modern, technological and even scientifically advanced country. **********In the process he was able to forge the Congress Party into a powerful national political machine that accumulated votes and transmitted patronage in virtually every part of the huge country, from the Muslims of Kashmir to the Bengalis in the southeast. **********When Nehru died in May 1964 after 17 years in office, he was followed as Prime Minister by Lal Bahadur Shastri, a loyal Nehru follower. When Mr. Shastri died a year and a half later, the leaders of the Congress Party chose Indira Gandhi. Collectively these locally powerful political bosses were known as "the Syndicate." Their choice of Mrs. Gandhi, then a soft-spoken and seemingly shy woman who was not related to Mohandas K. Gandhi, was based on the assumption by many that they would be able to dominate her while she held the party together with her name. **********They and the rest of India soon learned how they had miscalculated. Systematically, she removed the Syndicate members one by one, leading some of them to form and join rival offshoots of the old Congress. The splits led to bitter political clashes in the 1971 parliamentary election, but Mrs. Gandhi's party won. **********Four years later, when the courts found Mrs. Gandhi guilty of electoral malpractice in those 1971 elections and barred her from holding electoral office, she declared a state of emergency. Her critics and rivals were arrested, political activity was suspended and the press was muzzled. **********At the time her younger son, Sanjay, was her chief lieutenant and apparent heir. Though unelected to any office, Sanjay led national campaigns including an aggressive and controversial drive for birth control in which some people were forcibly sterilized. Rajiv Gandhi, the older brother, avoided the limelight. Increasingly Under Attack **********Though the Supreme Court cleared Mrs. Gandhi of the charges in 1975, she was increasingly under attack at home and abroad for having abandoned a commitment to democracy. **********In the 1977 election, she was defeated and her family's political and personal fortunes plummeted. She and Sanjay were repeatedly charged with crimes growing out of the emergency, and accused of having grown rich through bribes. This span, lasting three and a half years, was the longest in which India was not led by a member of the family. **********It ended when Mrs. Gandhi's rivals, then in power, began tearing at each other. Their patchwork coalition dissolved and in January, 1980, Mrs. Gandhi was returned as Prime Minister. "I won on my name," she said on the morning after her comeback. **********This time, her Government relied heavily on Sanjay Gandhi and the group of mostly young, mostly urban and well-to-do people he had assembled. That changed six months later when on June 23, Sanjay Gandhi was killed in the crash of his aerobatic biplane. **********Within weeks, Rajiv Gandhi, who had always shunned public life, was projected into active politics. He was summoned by his mother to prepare for what she viewed as his rightful place. In June 1981 he was elected to take over his brother's parliamentary district. Eight months later he was named General Secretary of the Congress Party. **********He found his closest advisers among the newly emerging middle class whose views of industrial and urban growth he endorsed. **********As his political education continued, the pressures that his grandfather warned could someday fragment India were growing more intense. In the south, local parties were gaining. In Kashmir, India's most Muslim state, there was a resurgence of separatism. And Sikhs' resentments grew sharply when in June 1984 Government troops invaded the Golden Temple in Amritsar, the Sikhs' holiest shrine, to dislodge an extremist sect. **********That October Indira Gandhi was assasinated by Sikh members of her personal guard. Rajiv Gandhi, who had never served in any Cabinet post, was sworn in as Prime Minister. **********In December 1984, Rajiv Gandhi, aided by a sympathy vote, led his party to the most sweeping victory in India's history. From that point, however, his popularity declined, as regional conflicts grew and local politicians sought greater shares of federal authority. **********In November 1989, Rajiv Gandhi and his party were defeated by a coalition led by V. P. Singh, one of the politicians who had left Mrs. Gandhi and her party. **********Now without Gandhis, that party seems leaderless. But given its role in the history of the nation and the great likelihood that it may gain from a large sympathy vote, many may rush to seek to claim leadership, among them people who felt estranged and left the party in recent years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/busin.main_headline: Fear of Political Moves Keeps Bond Rates Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Fear of Political Moves Keeps Bond Rates Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/busin.body_text: **********A weak economy and a marked slowdown in inflation usually occasion falling long-term interest rates. **********Some credit market analysts say those factors could indeed be potent enough to induce bond yields to fall toward 7.75 percent within weeks. **********But improvement beyond that level seems unlikely, the analysts said, even if the Federal Reserve Board continues to push short-term interest rates lower. The reason: persistent fears about what Washington might do to insure a recovery. **********There is little argument that long-term rates have room to come down. Even though yields fell a bit last week, the spread between 30-year Treasury bonds and 2-year Treasury notes was more than 2.2 percentage points, an extraordinarily wide margin.  Several Worries **********Concern that the Fed is reinflating the economy through its measured reduction in short-term interest rates is one reason that the yield curve is so steep. **********But at the moment the greater worry seems to be that Congress and the Administration will come up with a fiscal-rescue package that will mainly succeed in expanding a Federal budget deficit that some economists now project will reach $400 billion in the current fiscal year. **********"One of the things we have learned over the years is that you can't trust Congress on fiscal policy for more than a year at a time," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America. "Whenever things start to get tough, they bail out, and the deficit goes up." **********Mr. Wood, who recently spent a week talking to people in Washington, said the atmosphere was reminiscent of 1981, when Congress gave Ronald Reagan all the tax relief he asked for, and then some. "That is one reason," he said, "why I am pessimistic about the chances of bond yields falling much further." Regulatory Concerns **********Compounding the challenge of coping with mountainous Federal financing needs -- a fact of life in the credit markets for the last decade -- is the cloudier relationship the market now has with its regulators. **********Various investigations undertaken since the Salomon Brothers bidding violations were disclosed in August have made market participants highly cautious and have led to greater inefficiencies in the pricing of securities, traders contend. **********Those inefficiencies were reflected at last week's refunding auctions, when demand for the new 3-year and 10-year notes was far below expectations. **********A letter sent to dealers last week by Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance, is not likely to ease tensions or improve the market's efficiency. **********Mr. Markey sent dealers a list of requests for information on why the three-year notes were so poorly received.  Types of Information **********Information as to whether dealers had stayed away from the auction as a form of protest against new Treasury bidding regulations was deemed to be of particular interest. So, too, was information about contacts between primary dealers concerning the auction. **********The letter, which asked that the information be supplied by Friday, did not sit well with some primary dealers. **********"A lot of people who don't understand the securities business are doing what they think is right to insure the integrity of the market," said the chief executive of one primary dealer, who insisted on not being identified. "But in so doing they are risking complicating the lives of market participants to such a degree that results shown at the first two stages of the refunding may become commonplace." **********The request for information about who is talking to whom, and about what, "won't make communication more frequent," the executive said, adding that such communication is highly important if a market is to function efficiently. **********"A market which functioned extremely well is being tampered with," the Wall Street executive said.  Awaiting Statistics **********The bond markets will be closed today in observance of Veterans Day, and the focus for the rest of the week is expected to be on economic and inflation reports scheduled for later this week. Analysts expect the reports to confirm that the economy is extremely soft and that inflation is coming down. **********"There can be little doubt that inflation is improving steadily," said Steven Slifer, executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers. "Industrial prices, which have been falling since the recession began in August 1990, hit a new low last week. And wage pressures continue to abate." **********Further confirmation will arrive in the form of very favorable figures on producer prices and consumer prices, Mr. Slifer said. **********According to his forecast, the Producer Price Index, due out on Wednesday, probably rose by just one-tenth of a percent in October. And consumer prices, which are expected to be released on Thursday, increased by only two-tenths of a percent, he said. **********Weak retail sales figures and a report on industrial production showing that factory output did not rebound sharply in October are also expected, bolstering the case that the economy remains weak. **********"I am getting very fearful for the Christmas season," said Mr. Wood of Bank of America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/busin.body_text: **********Continuing its recent strategy of moving to increase market share by cutting profit margins, Apple Computer Inc. announced significant price reductions today on its mid-range and high-end Macintosh personal computers. **********The price cuts on the SE/30, IIci and IIfx modes range from 10 percent to 31 percent and are effective immediately. The SE/ 30 is now $3,369 to $3,869, depending on hard disk drive and memory; the IIci is now $5,269 to $5,969, and the IIfx is now $7,369 to $8,669. **********"Apple's market share strategy means providing better computers at aggressive price points in all parts of the product line," Randy Battat, Apple's vice president for worldwide product marketing, said in a statement. **********Apple shares fell $1.50 today, to $63.50, in over-the-counter trading. **********Analysts had long expected a price cut on Apple's mid- and high-range machines. Sales of such machines had slowed since the company introduced three new powerful low-range models last year. Apple also increased the amount of main memory provided with its high- end computers and announced a new version of A/UX, its rendition of the Unix operating system software.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/busin.main_headline: A System to Speed Computer Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; A System to Speed Computer Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/23/busin.body_text: **********From a computer-filled trailer next to the Tampa stadium where the Super Bowl will be played on Sunday, photographs taken on the field will be relayed over telephone lines to newspapers in two minutes. That is about 10 times faster than has been possible in the past. **********The system that rapidly sends photographs is only one of many new products emerging now that technical experts have agreed on a standard method for condensing computer images for faster transmission and more economical storage. The method, which blends sophisticated software with powerful specialized chips, squeezes the series of zeroes and ones that represent computerized images into far fewer bits of information so that the data take much less time to send.
