The method permits the condensed data to be reconstructed after arriving at their destination with no visible loss in quality. **********Just as an internationally accepted standard for compressing facsimile images spawned mass production that drove down the price of facsimile machines, the internationally accepted standard for compressing the more complex images stored in computers is expected to encourage the introduction of a variety of inexpensive consumer products. They will feature high-resolution color images that can be stored, retrieved and manipulated. Such products include not only improved newsphoto transmission systems but also video telephones, facsimile machines, copiers and printers that will be able to send and edit images as simply as text, and television-computer hybrids that allow the viewer to edit images much as today's word processors edit text. **********"The big shift is from today's analog television to digital images," said Andrew Lippman, associate director of the Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass. "Television is learning the language of the computer." **********A simple compression method is already used in high-speed facsimile transmission systems. Without compression it would take nearly an hour to transmit a simple 8 1/2-by-11-inch sheet of paper. But the internationally accepted Group III facsimile standard replaces blank lines with a short code that indicates that the line is empty. Other lines can be compressed by being encoded as lengths of black and white spaces. **********The new standard for compressing digital images is already in commercial use and will be formally released in March. It was developed by an international standards group known as the Joint Photographic Expert Group, or JPEG. Later this year a second standard for full-motion digital video will be defined by a parallel group, the Motion Picture Expert Group, or MPEG. The MPEG standard is expected to offer image compression in ratios exceeding 100 to 1, making it possible to store and retrieve more than an hour of video images on a single compact disk. How It Works **********The internationally accepted JPEG compression system works this way: A color image is converted into rows of dots, called pixels. each with a numerical value that represents brightness and color. The picture is then broken down into blocks, each 16 pixels by 16 pixels, and then reduced to 8 pixels by 8 by subtracting every other pixel. The software uses a formula that computes an average value for each block, permitting it to be represented with less data. Further steps subtract even more information from the image. To retrieve the data, the process is simply reversed to decompress the image. **********A specialized chip compresses and decompresses the images hundreds of times faster than is possible on a standard desktop computer. **********MPEG offers even greater compression by taking advantage of the fact that full-motion video is made up of a sequence of still images. Because many successive frames consist of large areas that are not changed -- like a blue sky background -- it is possible to reach far higher levels of compression. **********But the current MPEG standard will lack some of the flexibility of the JPEG standard, which treats each image separately and therefore makes editing easier. Some companies, like Supermac Technology in Sunnyvale, Calif., see JPEG as an ideal standard for creating full-motion digital editing systems that permit computers to capture television video and store and edit the images on large Winchester or erasable optical disks. Current video-editing systems permit users to capture only single images. 'A Huge Bottleneck' **********Sophisticated compression standards are necessary if the promise of high-resolution digital video is to be realized, industry executives say. **********"There is a huge bottleneck to working with images as opposed to working with text," said Robert R. Tillman, president of Storm Technology, a Palo Alto, Calif., company making products that use JPEG. **********Consider the staggering storage requirements of a single color picture. A standard full-color digital image displayed on an I.B.M.-compatible computer requires about a million characters of computer text, or one megabyte, of storage capacity on the computer's disk. By contrast, the novel "Moby Dick" requires only 1.3 million characters. **********The problem is exponentially compounded for engineers hoping to display full-motion video on a computer screen. To display 30 frames each second -- the rate needed to achieve smooth motion -- two billion bytes of storage are needed for a single minute of video. **********The storage problem is even worse for color printing applications. Printing an 8 1/2-by-11-inch color picture at a resolution of 300 dots an inch, which is typical for an office laser printer, would require more than 25 million bytes of disk storage space. **********Today's standard office personal computers generally come equipped with hard disk drives that store 20 to 40 megabytes. That is adequate for most text-only computer applications, but too little for the new class of graphics and color-image programs. Licensing Agreement **********Last month the JPEG standard took a significant step toward broad acceptance for both specialized graphics and standard office applications when Adobe Systems Inc., publisher of the Postscript printer language, announced that it was licensing the JPEG compression software technology from Storm Technology. **********Postscript is a standard computer printer language widely used in the desktop and higher-quality publishing industries. After Adobe adds the JPEG software to a future version of its Postscript, it will greatly ease the burden of sending large computer files in the Postscript format to computer printers. **********Moreover, some computer companies like Next Inc. have begun to add to their machines chips built expressly to run the JPEG software. Next is using a custom JPEG processor made by C-Cube Inc. of San Jose, Calif. **********The JPEG standard permits the user to select the degree of compression, and therefore how close to the original the decompressed image will appear. **********At Sunday's Super Bowl, five newspapers, including The New York Times, will cooperate in using a system to digitize photos taken during the game. The pictures will then be run through the JPEG compression process and transmitted by modem to the newspaper offices. The new process will save two hours for newspapers on the East Coast, which will be closer to their production deadlines when the game is played, said Steven P. Schaffran, president of the Color Group, an Albany, Calif., company that is coordinating the process.  Making Digital Images Easier to Store and Send Digitized images take up an enormous amount of computer memory. A 4-by-5-inch photograph being prepared for newspaper publication takes up hundreds of thousands of bytes of information, making transmission slow and difficult. JPEG, a new standard for compressing digitized images, reduces the information in such photographs and keeps the loss of visual quality at a minimum. Photographs are composed of many tiny dots, called pixels. In a digitized color photograph, each pixel contains shade and brightness information, represented numerically. JPEG works by dividing the image into blocks of pixels, then assigning each block several numbers that describe its characteristics. This eliminates the need to process the image pixel by pixel. Some pixels are removed from a block to reduce the information it contains. The amount of data removed depends on the amount of compression desired. To further compress the image, each block is given a base value, shown here in the upper left hand corner by the letter B. All other pixels in the block are then assigned numbers that describe their shade and brightness in relations to the base value. In later steps, these values are simplified mathematically, but remain proportional. The loss of detail is minimal, because enough information about shade and brightness variations within the block is maintained.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/11/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said last week that it would give interested parties two more weeks to submit bids for the three banking units of the failed Bank of New England Corporation. **********The F.D.I.C. said on Friday that it had extended the deadline to March 29 because of the large number of requests from prospective buyers. The extension would also give the agency time to provide financial data to potential bidders. **********The BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco, the nation's second-largest banking company, and the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, have said they are interested in the Boston-based bank. **********Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York-based takeover firm, and Fleet/Norstar Financial Group of Providence, R.I., are joining to make a bid for the bank, according to someone close to the situation. **********The trade newspaper, American Banker, has said other possible bidders are the Bank of Boston Corporation, the Shawmut National Corporation in Hartford and the UST Corporation in Boston. **********For sale are the New Bank of New England, with branches in Massachusetts; the New Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, and the New Maine National Bank.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.main_headline: Black Factions' Truce Threatened in South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.print_headline: Black Factions' Truce Threatened in South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.body_text: **********The fragile peace between South Africa's two largest black political groups threatened to unravel today as the leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party denounced the African National Congress for demanding concessions from the Government that he said could lead to civil war. **********"What the A.N.C. is actually doing is making the kind of demands which would precipitate what would be nothing less than a civil war in South Africa," said Inkatha's president, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi. **********Chief Buthelezi was addressing the legislative assembly in the Zulu homeland of KwaZulu, which he heads. He referred to an open letter on Friday in which the African National Congress said it would suspend discussions with the Government unless the violence that has ravaged black communities was brought to an end by May 9. Officials' Ouster Demanded **********The Congress also demanded the dismissals of Defense Minister Magnus Malan and Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok, whose security forces it accused of contributing to the violence. **********Chief Buthelezi said the Government of President F. W. de Klerk could not survive if it accepted such demands, which he attributed to a bid for power by hard-liners in the African National Congress. **********His tough words aligned Inkatha with the Government against the Congress and dispelled already uncertain hopes of a united front of black organizations to hasten the end of apartheid. **********The South African Institute of Race Relations, an independent organization that monitors the effects of apartheid, said today that political violence had killed 550 to 600 people in the first three months of 1991, adding to a total of more than 9,700 people since September 1984. Most factional clashes have involved followers of Inkatha and the Congress or its allies. **********In its open letter, the African National Congress implicitly blamed Inkatha and its supporters for fueling a cycle of violence, which, it said, was meant "to inflate the image of the Inkatha Freedom Party from that of a minor to the rank of the third major player in the political arena." **********The African National Congress had stopped assailing Inkatha since its deputy president, Nelson Mandela, concluded an accord with Chief Buthelezi on Jan. 29. The two leaders met again on March 23 to discuss how to end the unrelenting violence. **********Today, the Inkatha leader painted a gloomy picture of the negotiations that President de Klerk has proposed on a new constitution that would give the black majority political rights. He said the process was being jeopardized by what he characterized as the Congress's "lust for power." 'No Longer on Track' **********"Let me say rather bluntly that for me the negotiating process which includes the Government, the I.F.P. and the A.N.C. is no longer on track," Chief Buthelezi said, referring to Inkatha and the African National Congress. **********"We face the crisis from which the prospects of the proposed negotiations may not recover from one totally destructive, ill-conceived, power-grabbing attempt by the A.N.C. and its Communist Party ally to thwart the whole process," the Inkatha leader said. **********Chief Buthelezi has frequently needled the Congress over its alliance with the South African Communist Party.The Congress's latest demands include the outlawing of weapons, "traditional or otherwise," at public rallies and marches. This refers to spears, clubs and shields that Inkatha supporters are allowed to carry on grounds that they express Zulu tribal tradition. The police have also turned a blind eye to more modern axes, metal rods, machetes, knives and sometimes pistols also displayed by Inkatha supporters. Such weapons have caused the majority of deaths in factional hostilities. **********Chief Buthelezi did not address the issue today, according to excerpts from his speech released by his office. But two subordinates told Inkatha supporters at rallies in Katlehong and Soweto on Sunday not to give up their weapons. At least seven people were killed after the Sunday rallies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/14/world.main_headline: Bush Walks Tightrope: Soviet Aid, Risks at Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/14/world.print_headline: Bush Walks Tightrope: Soviet Aid, Risks at Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/14/world.body_text: **********The Bush Administration created its plan to aid the Soviet economy in about five days. The plan for American economic recovery will have taken about five months by the time the President offers his promised growth proposals late in January. **********This contrast in timing defines the problem Mr. Bush faces as he tries to fulfill the international obligations that are central to his duties as President, while at the same time preparing for an election that could turn on domestic problems. **********By outlining a policy for dealing with the upheaval in the former Soviet Union, Mr. Bush could satisfy the first set of expectations and solidify his credentials as the leader of the much-proclaimed new world order, even if the plan seems unlikely to make much of a dent in the problems facing the Soviets. **********But in dealing with the Soviet crisis, Mr. Bush risks walking into the trap that has been so eagerly laid by the Democrats vying for their party's nomination and by challengers from his own party's right wing. **********For months, these critics have complained that Mr. Bush devotes too much attention to other countries' problems and not enough to America's. Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative who entered the Republican nomination race on Tuesday, has been lampooning the new world order as a betrayal of what he calls "America First" principles that ought to prevail when American workers are losing jobs to foreign competition. **********Republicans and Democrats, including Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, have suggested that even if the President is effective overseas, he has done a poor job of explaining himself at home. This image was only reinforced when the new Soviet policy was presented by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in a speech at Princeton University on Thursday, rather than by Mr. Bush himself in a nationally televised address. Trying to Blunt Criticism **********Administration officials said Mr. Bush's initiative on the Soviet Union had been inspired solely by that country's political and economic crisis, one far deeper and more immediate than American economic problems. But Mr. Baker seemed to be trying to inoculate Mr. Bush against campaign-year criticism as he outlined the new policy. **********By following the Administration's blueprint, he said, "We can prevail over the fearful isolationism that threatens to return us to the failures of the 1920's and 1930's. We can prevail over political paralysis to forge a bipartisan consensus about what has to be done and then, united at home, we can join with our allies to form a new coalition." **********This fall, Mr. Bush has come under intense criticism, first for his unwillingness to consider economic growth measures and then for the deliberateness -- some say sluggishness -- with which he is developing such proposals. **********Now, he has moved with startling speed on yet another foreign policy challenge. His aides are confident this will reinforce his image of a President who can be trusted with the nation's security. They argue that Mr. Bush has freedom to act in foreign affairs that is denied him in negotiating on domestic issues with a Democratic-controlled Congress and that whatever the political climate at home, his diplomatic portfolio is simply too important to be slighted. Democrats' Bind **********Indeed, it has not been that long since Democrats were complaining that Mr. Bush was a passive spectator on the world stage, and the Administration's policy pronouncement left them in a double bind. It was unveiled as one of the Democratic Presidential contenders, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, was delivering a speech saying that Mr. Bush had not taken the lead on the Soviet crisis and suggesting actions that did not greatly diverge from Mr. Bush's plan. **********But other opponents on the right and the left quickly moved to further their assault on what they view as Mr. Bush's weakest electoral flank. **********"The fact of the matter is that he has come up with an economic plan for the Soviet Union more than a month before we can even expect an economic plan for the United States," said Lorraine Voles, spokeswoman for Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who is running for the Democratic nomination. "It's once again a sign of the President just ignoring the domestic dilemmas that this country is facing." **********Even those Democrats who have been pressing Mr. Bush to do more, not less, to aid the Soviet Union tried to chip away at Mr. Bush's grip on the foreign policy debate and to reinforce what even White House aides concede has been the President's difficulty in explaining himself to voters. Letter From Gephardt **********Mr. Gephardt said in a letter to Mr. Bush on Thursday that his "modest measures are steps in the right direction but, given the enormity of the crisis, more explanations are needed and more actions may be necessary." **********Mr. Gephardt urged Mr. Bush to address the nation about his Soviet policy, and his office pointed out to reporters that some key elements of Mr. Bush's plan, including the idea of assembling industrialized nations to coordinate aid, were proposed by Mr. Gephardt nearly two years ago. **********Bush aides argued that it is in the direct economic interest of the United States to insure stability in the old Soviet Union. Bush Campaign's View **********Charles Black, Mr. Bush's campaign chairman, said: "Throughout the campaign, we're going to have to repeat a message consistently that there is a threshold requirement for any President to manage national security and foreign relations. From an economic standpoint, there are more markets in a peaceful world than in a dangerous one and as the one superpower still standing, we have the clout to go out and expand markets." **********Mr. Black acknowledged that these arguments are difficult to win in an election year, especially with rightists like Mr. Buchanan and liberals like Senator Harkin making emotional appeals to American self-interest. **********But Mr. Bush may have no choice but to stick to foreign policy. His aides have yet to agree on any fix for the nation's economic problems, and it will take months to get any results. Beyond that, the Administration fundamentally believes the Government can and should be much more active in foreign affairs than on economic and social issues. **********There are also tactical considerations. **********"If you don't have any good economic news, you can't just sit there and do nothing," said Lance Torrance, a Republican political strategist. "You've got to show motion and that motion at the current time has to be on foreign affairs. You can be really hurt in politics, potentially fatally, not as the Democrats are saying by being imbalanced on the domestic versus foreign policy side, but by doing nothing."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/busin.main_headline: Debating the Pros and Cons Of Research vs. Creativity
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Debating the Pros and Cons Of Research vs. Creativity
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/busin.body_text: **********ONE of the longest-running debates in advertising, apart from whether Certs is a breath mint or a candy mint, is whether research can help, rather than stifle, creativity. According to the participants in a lively seminar on the subject yesterday, the answer is a qualified yes. **********The seminar, held at the New York Helmsley Hotel in midtown Manhattan, pitted advocates of focus groups, surveys and advertising tests against disciples of the pure creative process. **********The more than 100 people who attended the event, sponsored by the New York council of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, heard panelists defend their opinions by invoking examples of campaigns that succeeded because -- or in spite -- of research. **********Joel Hochberg, president of domestic marketing for the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation and a former executive at agencies like DDB Needham Worldwide, warned against "treating research as a distant relative: The only time you call is when you're in trouble." Rather, the self-described "convert" to research said, it can be useful "as a guidance system." **********Mr. Hochberg showed the audience how the trailers, or coming attractions, for Fox's comedy hit "Home Alone" evolved through research. Though "research isn't the reason why 'Home Alone' has become the third-largest grossing movie of all time," he said, it led to the creation of a trailer that would "encourage kids to come back even more" by humorously suggesting they see the film "a million times." **********A colleague of Mr. Hochberg's, Andy Fessel, senior vice president of research and marketing for the Fox Broadcasting Company, discussed how audience research had enabled Fox to identify "market opportunities" -- the young adult viewers who had been turning off the Big Three television networks' fare -- and to target them with series like "21 Jump Street" and "Beverly Hills 90210." **********Research has also been invaluable to Levi Strauss & Company, said Steve Goldstein, the director of consumer marketing for its menswear division, in "giving men a new way to think about their clothing." That has been accomplished, he added, by the company's Dockers line of casual wear, which since its introduction five years ago has grown to have annual retail sales of an estimated $1.5 billion. **********Showing a series of television commercials for Dockers that Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, has been producing since 1987, Mr. Goldstein outlined how research contributed to the creation of "Dockers World, the mythical place where our Dockers consumer feels comfortable." **********The spots, in which Dockers-clad men engage in offhand chats about life, have been changed in response to data gathered from consumers, Mr. Goldstein said. Moments have been emphasized during which the actors in the spots display traits like being "good friends, non-judgmental, non-competitive, successful, outgoing, easy to like," he added. **********Most outspoken at the seminar was Ed McCabe, chairman of McCabe & Company, who has created attention-getting campaigns for clients like Perdue Farms and Volvo. He made a sharp distinction between research -- "Without great research, you can't make great advertising" -- and testing, which he attacked as "the idiocy that keeps greatness from happening." **********Referring to the process by which advertising is scrutinized by agencies before being released, he added, "Testing is a crutch the one-eyed use to beat up the blind." **********Mr. McCabe showed a reel of his work, including a spot for Hebrew National hot dogs in which an actor portraying Uncle Sam is brought up short by the company's insistence on exceeding Federal regulations because its products are kosher and must "answer to a higher authority." **********The spot "tested not very well," Mr. McCabe said. "I had to wrestle the client to the ground to ignore the testing and run the commercial anyway." **********Nineteen years later, he added, it is still running.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/world.main_headline: REFUGEES IN SOUTH BEG ARMY TO STAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; REFUGEES IN SOUTH BEG ARMY TO STAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/world.body_text: **********More than 100 Iraqis held a peaceful demonstration at the main refugee camp here today, appealing to American forces to stay in southern Iraq. **********The heavily armed American troops in southern Iraq, who numbered about 90,000 last week, will be replaced with a United Nations observer force. The refugees, who fled after President Saddam Hussein's forces put down the rebellion in southern Iraq, waved signs urging the Americans to stay. **********"The leaving of the Americans is a very big problem for us," said a 23-year-old medical student from Basra University, who said his name was Ali. "The U.N.'s force is not like the American Army. Saddam is afraid of the Americans. At night when we hear tank noises, people run to the window, worried that the American Army will withdraw." **********The Army initially expected United Nations officials to arrive today, but they were delayed. The 1,440-member force includes 300 observers, about 650 lightly armed soldiers to protect them, and a smaller number of combat engineers to blow up mines. **********The United Nations force will patrol an area that runs about 6 miles into Iraq and about three miles into Kuwait. **********But Iraq will be responsible for police functions in Iraqi border territory, which troubles the refugees. They say that Iraqi secret police have already tried to infiltrate the camp and they fear Government reprisals, such as terrorist bombings.  'We Will Run With Their Tanks' **********"When the Americans leave, we will run with their tanks," said a 34-year-old Iraqi mechanical engineer from Basra who gave his name as Kareem. **********Another Iraqi refugee, who declined to give a name, said refugees would throw themselves in front of the American tanks to keep them from leaving. **********"We would never do that with the Iraqi army, but we know the Americans would never hurt us," he added. **********But many of the 11,000 refugees here are reconciled to the Americans' departure and are desperately looking for political asylum or, failing that, refugee status outside of Iraq. But the Army says the Iraqis are not techincially refugees because they have not crossed international borders. **********"Why don't they put us in a camp in Kuwait?" Ali said. "We are afraid to stay inside Iraq."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.body_text: **********The Amoco Corporation beat several Western rivals for the right to develop the large Azeri oilfield in the Caspian Sea, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported today. **********Officials from the Soviet Oil and Gas Ministry, and the republic of Azerbaijan chose Amoco over proposals from the Unocal Corporation, British Petroleum and Statoil of Norway. **********B.P. has estimated that the field, in water 400 to 425 feet deep, could contain up to one billion barrels of oil. **********Tass said Amoco would develop the Azeri field with Soviet partners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/world.main_headline: Soviet Economy In Bleak Shape, Aides Tell West
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/world.print_headline: Soviet Economy In Bleak Shape, Aides Tell West
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/world.body_text: **********Soviet officials offered a startlingly bleak assessment of their economy to Western financial leaders here this week, saying that the failed coup in August had caused a crippling withdrawal of international lines of credit to Soviet banks, setting off a debt crisis and accelerating the economy's precipitous fall. **********A top Soviet economic planner, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, explained the painful slide during a wide-ranging, two-hour interview today. Mr. Yavlinsky had offered the assessment earlier in a confidential report to Western financial leaders in the hope of winning their support for his program of radical economic reform. **********Those leaders in the Group of Seven industrial nations agreed on Sunday to unprecedented support to help rebuild the Soviet economy on a free-market basis, but have not yet committed themselves firmly to monetary support. Shrinking Soviet Economy **********A copy of the report on the Soviet economy was obtained from Western officials, and it paints a devastating picture. **********A section of the report labeled "Situation" said the Soviet economy is expected to shrink by 13 percent this year, industrial production by 9 percent and farm production by about 11 percent, suggesting that the onetime Communist superpower is suffering a severe recession. **********But fiscal and monetary conditions appear even worse. Retail price inflation has reached a 96 percent annual rate and is accelerating, the report says. The central Government is expected to post a budget deficit this year of more than 120 billion rubles, and to suffer a deficit of at least 80 billion rubles more on expenditures that do not show up on the budget. Together, the Soviet republics are expected to have budget deficits that total 120 billion rubles. **********There is no longer any understandable way to translate ruble deficit into dollars or other Western currencies because stable exchange markets can no longer be sustained by Soviet authorities. But some sense of the magnitude of the deficits can be gained in the fact that few Soviet workers are paid more than 500 rubles a month. Scarce Hard Currency **********To finance the growing deficit, the Government is printing money. The report says the amount of cash in circulation increased by more than 15 billion rubles a month in the June-to-August period. **********Imports plummeted by 45 percent in the first eight months of the year from the corresponding period in 1990, in part because less earnings from hard currency have been available for purchases. Exports fell by 27 percent during that time, "basically as a result of an overall decline in the production of energy," the report said. **********The Soviets have estimated their hard-currency debt at $70 billion, which is not considered an overly burdensome sum given the country's size and natural resources. But the decline in exports and the withdrawal of credit lines during the coup have left Moscow unable to pay as much as $5 billion in foreign debts coming due in the next three months. **********Mr. Yavlinsky explained that the sudden withdrawal of foreign deposits and credit lines to international banks after the coup was responsible in large part for slashing his country's access to the hard currency it needs for the payments. **********"The real structural problem was the fall in our exports, but we could have gone on some time this way," he said. "But you didn't hear us talking about this liquidity situation in May or June. It was the problem of the coup and the banks." 'Shopping for Money' **********Western countries are worried that a default on debt payments could disrupt trade and make it impossible for the Soviets to obtain the credits on which they are critically dependent. **********Mr. Yavlinsky said that although he had not come to Bangkok "shopping for money," some kind of debt relief or short-term loans would probably be required to get the country through the winter. **********The Group of Seven -- consisting of the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Italy and Canada -- said over the weekend that their deputy finance ministers would soon go to Moscow to consult with the Soviets on their economic problems and intended reforms. Mr. Yavlinsky said today that one of their principal tasks will be to determine the nature of any financial assistance needed to alleviate the immediate crisis and restore confidence in Soviet banks. **********"The fundamental decision will be made in Moscow," he said. "Sooner is better than later -- and maybe cheaper." Partnership With West **********Mr. Yavlinsky, 39 years old, an energetic man, insisted that he had sought something much more important in Bangkok than financial support. **********He said that Soviet leaders are seeking a partnership with the West to stabilize their economy, develop workable reform plans and, perhaps most important, persuade recalcitrant elements in the country that they need not fear the risks associated with change. **********Mr. Yavlinsky admitted that there was tremendous resistance in the Soviet Union to his plan. The pace of disintegration is rising at a time when he is trying to preserve certain central powers. **********But he said that the meetings in Bangkok had added momentum to the process that began with the meeting of the Group of Seven heads of state in London in June. The main difficulty, he said, was keeping ahead of the collapse of the Soviet economy. **********"Time is not going into a refrigerator, you know," he said. "Inflation is growing, production is falling. You can't stop this process." **********In the eyes of most Soviet citizens, the Western economic systems work, while the Soviet system does not. Thus, Mr. Yavlinsky said, they would have more confidence in something that Western leaders had endorsed. He received a strong endorsement from the Group of Seven on Sunday to take part in the reform process. **********But Mr. Yavlinsky expressed disappointment on one point. He said he had wanted to return to Moscow able to announce the date on which the Soviet Union would move from its current status as a special associate member of the International Monetary Fund, which is meeting here this week, and become a full member. **********The Western countries and Japan have only said that the Soviet Union is expected to join the lending institution soon. Membership would provide the country with a great deal of technical assistance as well as access to billions of dollars a year in loans. **********Some republics want to become independent and then simply abandon the debt. But Mr. Yavlinsky said the leaders of the industrial nations reaffirmed that it would be very difficult if not impossible for the republics to obtain new credit if they walked away from a bankrupted union. **********"It was made clear that all the republics must pay the debt together," he said. "There will be no new credits without paying the old ones, even to individual republics. I can now tell these people, 'I've spoken with the Western finance ministers and they told me how they will do these things. I know.' " **********Mr. Yavlinsky emphasized that the Soviets had to resolve a range of problems on their own, particularly the treaty defining economic relations among the republics. **********"I want to stress that this is not the traditional style of support, where you just say, 'I'm in a crisis, give me money,' " he continued. "This has a different character. That is what we are trying to explain. It is a deeper, long-term process that will create mutual understanding. If there is no understanding, there is no support."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/busin.body_text: **********The Treuhandanstalt privatization agency, which has the assignment of selling off former state-owned enterprises in eastern Germany, has sold 1,000 of the 8,000 businesses, a board member was quoted today as saying. **********Birgit Breuel told the newspaper Suddeutsche Zeitung that the agency's work had so far been successful, with 500 more businesses expected to be sold soon, but she added that the pace of privatizations might slow. **********"Not all companies that can survive can be sold," she was quoted as saying.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/world.main_headline: Syrian Leader's New Gamble: Pursuing Power as Arab Champion
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Syrian Leader's New Gamble: Pursuing Power as Arab Champion
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/world.body_text: **********Through a long and crisis-prone rule that has often resembled a poker marathon, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has rarely blinked, always believing that the chips at game's end would vindicate the way he played the hands. **********The strategy has been the same from his move into Lebanon in 1976 to his backing for Iran in its war with Iraq to his support for the American-led coalition in the Persian Gulf war. All damaged his reputation as an Arab radical and were unpopular with his people, but ultimately succeeded in enriching the trove Mr. Assad most cherishes: regional power. **********In Damascus on Sunday, after unproductive negotiations with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, the Syrian leader seemed to be pursuing a strategy that gambled the outcome of Middle East peace efforts and his newly strengthened ties with the United States against the longer-term calculation that power and survival itself depend on advancing himself as an Arab champion untainted by compromise. **********Throughout the latest Middle East peace effort, Syrian officials had emphasized that they would not compromise on the basic demand: the return of all Arab lands occupied by Israel in 1967. To do so, in the Syrian view, would be to forfeit the political basis of the Government. And the Syrian leader apparently believes others will blink first.  On the Side of the Winners **********His seemingly unshakable belief that his policies will stand hindsight's scrutiny emerged in a speech he gave to Muslim clerics last month. **********"Our stand seemed weird to some people for a certain period of time," he said, referring to the hostility with which many of his people greeted his decision last August to reverse decades of anti-Americanism and side with Washington in the war against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. **********But with the defeat of President Hussein by allied forces, Syria emerged on the side of the winners. "The course of events," he told the clerics, "has proved repeatedly that our stand was the correct and healthy one, exactly like our stand on Lebanon and the Iran-Iraq war. We did what we could according to our national interests." **********The stalemate with Washington possibly reflects a sense that this time the stakes are higher than ever, for, in this region's politics, any hint of softness toward Israel carries severe political and physical risk, as President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt discovered 10 years ago when he was assassinated after making peace with Israel. **********President Assad "has not given away anything that would enable anyone to point a finger at him later," a regional diplomat said. Weeks ago, Syria's officially controlled newspapers began to harp on a familiar theme: if peace efforts break down, Israel is to blame because Arabs have proved flexible while Israel has been intransigent. **********Moreover, Syria has reportedly spent more than half of the $2 billion it got in aid from the gulf nations after the gulf crisis on new weapons, notably enhanced Scud-B long-range missiles capable of hitting Israel. "The Syrians feel that Israel never gave anything to weaklings," an Arab diplomat said.  Several Games at Once **********The Syrian leader is also playing several games at the same time, all of them ultimately centering on the purported source of his political legitimacy: steadfastness in the Arab-Israeli dispute. **********In Lebanon, he is seeking to promote an Arab pact called the Taif accord, which, with United States support, acknowledges Syria's primacy there. Under the accord, Syria is committed to disbanding all Lebanese and non-Lebanese militias in the country. But a Syrian official said Damascus did not wish to move against Palestinian and Iranian-backed militias while Israel still controlled its so-called security zone in southern Lebanon. **********In the maneuverings over an Arab-Israeli peace conference dispute, the Syrian leader has emerged as the most important Arab player by far. His decision to support Iran in its war with Iraq and then to back the Arab moderates against Baghdad in the gulf war has placed him in a position to bridge Iranian and Arab interests. **********None of Syria's maneuvers are uncomplicated. But a senior Western diplomat said that in virtually all of them "he needs the United States" because the demise of Soviet power has led him to a fundamental reappraisal of Syria's position. No longer can Syria play the role of a confrontational Soviet proxy in the Middle East. **********On all fronts, however, the Syrian leader is calculating that the United States needs him, for he alone controls something that determines whether there is peace or not: his cooperation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/25/world.main_headline: News from Gulf Is Good, and Cheney's Press Curbs Are Loosened
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/25/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: THE PRESS; News from Gulf Is Good, and Cheney's Press Curbs Are Loosened
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/25/world.body_text: **********The Pentagon's highly restrictive news policy announced by the Secretary of Defense last night was loosened today when allied field commanders came forward with glowing reports of early success in the war zone. **********But many American news executives contended that the curbs were the latest, and possibly most troubling, example of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's efforts to control the flow of information from Washington. **********More than two hours after the ground assault began, Mr. Cheney summoned reporters to the Pentagon on Saturday night to announce that to protect the troops, regular briefings in Washington and in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, would be suspended until further notice. **********"Even the most innocent-sounding information," he declared, "could be used directly against the men and women whose lives are on the line carrying out these operations." **********The policy changed this morning when Pentagon officials said the Secretary gave permission for the American commander in the gulf, General H. Norman Schwarzkopf, to deliver what was an upbeat briefing to reporters in Riyadh. **********"Good news defeats a blackout," said Jonathan P. Wolman, Washington bureau chief of The Associated Press. "The military apparently has a good story to tell, and they are abandoning their blackout to let it be told." **********Howell Raines, Washington editor of The New York Times, said the Pentagon, motivated by political concerns, was preventing the press from providing a more complete picture of the war. **********"The Administration wants to use the legitimate theme of security, in some cases, to install a kind of blanket news management that we've never had in this century," he said. "No one argues with legitimate security needs. There's a kernel of truth in Secretary Cheney's argument." But he said that Mr. Cheney had gone too far, noting that it was not until late tonight that the first photograph of a wounded American soldier was released. **********When the restrictions on coverage began, groups of reporters escorted to the war zone by military officers found that transmission of their dispatches, already subject to review by the officers, was being delayed. **********General Schwarzkopf's briefing, though it lacked detail, seemed to have had the effect of signaling to other officers in Riyadh and Washington that they could at least speak anonymously to reporters. As the day wore on, news organizations began to receive dispatches from pool reporters in the field, and the networks began to get war footage. **********Still, many editors and news executives expressed frustration with what they regarded as heavy-handed restrictions on reporting the ground assault in the name of troop security. General Schwarzkopf, for example, refused in his briefing to disclose an estimate of allied casualties, as is standard practice, saying only that they were "remarkably light." **********Fred S. Hoffman, a Pentagon spokesman for five years in the Reagan Administration and who, before that, covered the military for 24 years for The Associated Press, said Mr. Cheney's restrictions were misguided. Even during Vietnam, he said, there were never such limitations on coverage. **********"I think it was handled clumsily," he said. "It would have been more logical if they had simply said, 'The information is early and raw, and we have to sort it out, and we'll have it for you when we have it.' " **********Peter Schmeisser, a journalist and historian who is writing a book about Government control of the news during wartime, argued that Pentagon officials believe they can get away with restricting information because the public supports the Administration. **********"I think Cheney is trying to condition the American people and the American press," he said. "He is trying to get the electorate used to there not being information during combat. That is unprecedented." Mr. Schmeisser added that he has found that "when people cite security concerns, historically, 80 or 90 percent of the time, those concerns are used to keep embarrassing things from coming out." **********Paul K. McMasters, chairman of a committee of the Society of Professional Journalists that monitors freedom-of-information issues, said even the loosening of restrictions today will not mend the rift that has developed between the Pentagon and the press. **********"Sometimes the restrictions have more to do with political insecurity than with military security," said Mr. McMasters, who is deputy editorial director of USA Today. "So far in this war, the American public has been inundated with information, but the vast majority of the information has been Government-issue."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/12/busin.main_headline: PAN AM CREDITORS BACK $1.7 BILLION OFFER FROM DELTA
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/12/busin.print_headline: PAN AM CREDITORS BACK $1.7 BILLION OFFER FROM DELTA
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/12/busin.body_text: **********The creditors of Pan American World Airways agreed early this morning to a new offer from Delta Air Lines for Pan Am's most prized assets. **********The creditors' about-face came after Delta agreed to raise its bid sharply and to help finance a reorganization of the struggling Pan Am, which would survive as much smaller carrier primarily serving Latin America from the United States. **********Delta's new bid of $1.7 billion won out over a $1.3 billion joint offer from three other suitors that had banded together in a last-ditch attempt to buy Pan Am. That offer had come from United Airlines, American Airlines and Trans World Airlines. **********The creditors' approval greatly improves the chances that Delta will end up with Pan Am's valuable routes to Europe and its Northeast Shuttle, which serves Boston, New York and Washington. The Pan Am assets would make Delta a much stronger competitor among international airlines.  Deal Long Sought **********Pan Am's management has long supported a deal with Delta, but its creditors had strongly opposed the Delta bid as recently as Friday. Pan Am is operating under protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, **********As a result of the truce, signed at 12:04 A.M. to the negotiators' robust applause, the creditors said they would join Pan Am's management in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan today in an effort to sell the new deal to Judge Cornelius Blackshear, whose approval is required. The Federal Transportation Department must also approve any transfer of Pan Am's routes to another airline. The Justice Department, which can oppose acquisitions on antitrust grounds, had blessed a Pan Am deal with Delta on Friday. **********"We got a deal," an exuberant and tired Leon Marcus, the attorney for the creditors' committee, said late last night, moments before signing the agreement. "We got a good deal." **********Besides providing $1.7 billion, the tentative deal promises to save the jobs of 13,500 Pan Am employees, out of a total of 17,300 workers. **********The agreement caps what had been a "grueling weekend," as one adviser to the creditors put it, during which Pan Am's many suitors presented their deals to the creditors in a round-robin of one-upsmanship. **********With so many competing offers to choose from, the creditors were not shy about playing one suitor off of another to raise the bidding. For instance, after Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, agreed to absorb Pan Am's operating losses above $140 million between now and the time he would close a deal, Delta reluctantly agreed to do the same. While the creditors had found Delta's earlier proposals attractive in terms of a future stake in a reorganized Pan Am, the creditors had worried that the airline might run out of cash before it would even get to close the deal. The guarantee provided some reassurance. **********"One of the principle reasons that Delta's revised proposal was acceptable is that it contained a stop-loss provision over $140 million, same as Carl's, and consequently it helped relieve any fears the creditors had that the transition would not take place," said Henry Miller, an investment banker at Prudential Securities who was advising the creditors. **********"That cinched it," Mr. Marcus agreed.  Team of Bidders **********T.W.A. and American Airlines had teamed up in an effort to wrest Pan Am away from Delta, and Delta's ambitions were in the greatest danger of being disappointed yesterday when United Airlines scrapped its own bid and joined forces with T.W.A. and American. **********Bankers and lawyers who were at the meeting said United would have forsaken its longstanding desire to acquire all of Pan Am's Latin American routes and would have satisfied itself with about 20 landing slots at John F. Kennedy Airport in New York and three of Pan Am's four flights to Mexico City. American would have walked off with the shuttle, and T.W.A. would have taken what was left, primarily some of the Latin American routes and a lot of spare parts. **********The creditors committee immediately disclosed the three-way bid to Delta, which came back about five hours later with a far-richer offer that many bankers and lawyers said was designed to be "pre-emptive" and put an end to the bidding. **********"Delta came back and gave in on every major point," Mr. Miller said.  Unlikely Suitor **********Mr. Icahn, who had been an unlikely suitor from the beginning because of T.W.A.'s own financial woes, conceded defeat gracefully, people at the meeting said, and even joked at his own expense. **********Neither Mr. Icahn nor officials of United could be reached late last night for comment. **********Under the revised deal, Delta has agreed to pay Pan Am's creditors roughly $621 million in cash and assume liabilities of $720 million. In addition, the creditors would receive 55 percent of the equity in a reorganized Pan Am, which they were valuing last night at about $456 million. **********In particular, Delta would pay $416 milion for the North Atlantic routes and the Northeast shuttle plus some additional spare parts, and would absorb 6,600 of Pan Am's existing employees to staff those businesses. That contrasts to its earlier $310 million bid for the same package of assets minus the spare parts. **********Asked whether the spare parts singlehandedly made up the price differential, a lawyer for Delta declined comment. Investment Is Planned **********Delta has also agreed to invest $305 million into Pan Am's Latin American division and its Miami maintenance base in the form of $50 million of equity, $155 million of senior notes paying 10 percent annually, and $100 million in capital, which would be kept in the company for working capital purposes. It was hoped that the investment would enable Pan Am to emerge from bankruptcy as a smaller but potentially prosperous carrier, employing 6,900 of Pan Am's existing employees in addition to the 6,600 that Delta agreed to absorb. **********To help Pan Am get to that point, Delta will also provide $80 million of temporary financing, pending closing of the asset purchase. **********The deal's architects said the transaction should provide Pan Am's creditors with a total of $621 million in cash, in addition to 55 percent of the equity in the reorgnized Pan Am.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Steering the Federation Toward Activism
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.body_text: **********THE American Advertising Federation has promoted from within in naming its first new president in 23 years. It has chosen an executive with extensive experience in governmental relations who seeks to steer the organization in a more activist direction. **********Wallace S. Snyder, 48 years old, was elected president yesterday by the board at the organization's annual conference in Nashville. Mr. Snyder, who has been the executive vice president of government relations since last June, succeeds Howard H. Bell, who has served as president of the Washington-based trade association since 1968. **********Mr. Bell, 64, was the first president of the association after it was founded in 1967 in the merger of the Advertising Federation of America and the Advertising Association of the West. **********The change in command will take effect after Mr. Bell retires in December. The organization has 52,000 affiliated members nationwide representing all disciplines of the advertising industry. **********The president leads the group's efforts to influence public issues, like government regulation and taxation, in ways acceptable to the advertising industry. **********While government relations will remain the most important priority for the association, Mr. Snyder said in a telephone interview from Nashville: "We have to be even more pro-active than before. It's time we go on the offensive, instead of being always on the defensive." **********For instance, Mr. Snyder said he saw a "need to develop, with the entire advertising industry, an effective educational program that will demonstrate to the American people the value they get from advertising." He added, "We have a long way to go in that area." **********Such a program could counter skepticism about advertising among consumers, Mr. Snyder said, by describing the "entertainment benefits and product information" that advertising can provide. **********In the often-contentious relationship of advertising and government, Mr. Snyder is calling for "a middle-road standard of regulation." The reassertion of authority on the Federal level, as typified by recent challenges to food-product labeling by the Food and Drug Administration, is "very positive, over all," Mr. Snyder said, because "the industry cannot afford to have 50 different standards" imposed by 50 states. **********"We have to have one national standard," Mr. Snyder said, "and we can help develop that national policy by cooperating with the F.D.A." and the Federal Trade Commission. "This is also an area where the industry needs to be pro-active," he added. **********Mr. Snyder joined the association in 1985 as senior vice president of government relations after a 16-year career at the F.T.C. He has also served as the association's general counsel and has been involved in management tasks like hiring and budgeting. **********The association also made other executive changes yesterday: John McMennamin, vice chairman, who is vice president of marketing services at Nestle USA, becomes chairman, effective today. He succeeds David Bell, president of Bozell Inc. Succeeding Mr. McMennamin is Carlo Vittorini, chairman, publisher and chief executive of Parade Publications Inc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/08/world.main_headline: U.S. Is Holding 200 Haitians on 2 Ships
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/08/world.print_headline: U.S. Is Holding 200 Haitians on 2 Ships
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/08/world.body_text: **********Nearly two hundred Haitians seized as they sought to flee their homeland in small boats are being kept aboard two Coast Guard cutters while the United States considers what to do with them. Washington is reluctant to send them back to a country whose elected leader was forcibly overthrown or to admit them and risk encouraging a new surge of Haitian boat people to head north. **********Before last month's coup, the Coast Guard routinely returned Haitians they intercepted sailing for the United States. But officials here said that since the coup this practice has been suspended and that recently apprehended boatloads of Haitians have been housed aboard the two ships -- some for as long as 10 days -- while Washington asks other Caribbean countries to offer them temporary sanctuary. **********United States officials say that although most of the boat people are economic, not political refugees, they are leery of repatriating Haitians because of the widespread political violence in that country since the Sept. 30 army coup that overthrew President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Three hundred people are estimated to have died so far in coup-related violence. **********Officials say they are also concerned, however, that if Washington opens the doors to many of the 185 Haitians the Coast Guard says it has in its custody aboard the two 210-foot ships, thousands more Haitians might be encouraged to attempt the perilous ocean journey to the United States. Thousands Sent Back **********Since the treaty allowing the United States to repatriate Haitian boat people was signed 10 years ago , immigration officials said, more than 23,000 Haitians have been picked up at sea by the Coast Guard. Only 28 of them were able to convince their interrogators that they had grounds to claim political asylum and were thus allowed to enter the United States. **********"Right now we are examining the situation to determine whether it would be advisable to return these people to Haiti," said a State Department official, who declined to comment on whether a third country was being sought to receive the Haitians already aboard United States ships. **********An official at another United States agency involved in the issue, however, confirmed that other Caribbean countries were being approached to serve as temporary hosts for Haitians until they can be returned home. **********"The numbers are building up, the ships involved are building up, and this thing is coming to a boil," said the official, who asked not to be identified. "They are looking for other countries. The U.S. knows it will have to bear the burden of the cost. The question is whether we have enough weight with some of these Caribbean islands to get them to take some of these people." 2 Nations Want No More **********The Dominican Republic and the Bahamas, the two countries closest to Haiti, already have large numbers of immigrants from that country, and officials said they would be unlikely to accept more. **********Asked how long the Coast Guard could maintain its holding pattern with the refugees it has picked up, a spokesman, Chief Petty Officer Luis Diaz, said: "We don't know. We have never run into a situation like this of having so many Haitians or any other aliens aboard our cutters for so long." **********Officials said Haitians seeking to reach the United States might have received some encouragement from the news that 52 Haitians who reached southern Florida by boat shortly after the coup had not been quickly returned home as is usually the case. **********After Washington announced a stringent economic embargo against Haiti last week, the country's provisional Prime Minister, Jean-Jacques Honorat, warned in an interview that the United States should "get ready to receive" a wave of refugees. **********Advocates for Haitian immigration rights condemned the search for other countries that could receive boat people from Haiti and said they should be admitted temporarily into the United States. "Nobody should be forcibly returned to Haiti under the current circumstances," said Jocelyn McCalla, director of the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees in New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/07/busin.main_headline: Japan's Sleight of Hand in Trade . . . And Its Duty to U.S. Auto Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/07/busin.print_headline: FORUM; Japan's Sleight of Hand in Trade . . . And Its Duty to U.S. Auto Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/07/busin.body_text: **********The number of people working in automobile manufacturing in this country has shrunk more than 20 percent since 1978, and that includes employees at Japan's newly established operations here. Obviously, an even steeper decline has taken place at Detroit's Big Three. **********That means Detroit will have fewer employees to fund its retiree benefits obligations. That is especially troubling because American companies are now paying for health-care benefits of retired men and women who contributed to Detroit's prosperity years ago. This is a burden that Japanese transplant companies don't have to shoulder because almost none of their employees are old enough to be eligible for retirement. **********Skyrocketing health-care costs have made Detroit's burden a heavy one. In 1988 and 1989, the General Motors Corporation paid more than $1 billion in health-care costs for its retired employees. And the health-care retirement burden is almost certain to get worse as Detroit cuts middle management and strives to catch up with the Japanese in terms of automation. **********So where is the money for these retiree benefits obligations to come from? Taxpayers could end up bearing some of the burden. Remember the Chrysler Corporation bailout in 1979. If Chrysler had gone out of business, taxpayers would have had to absorb more than $1 billion in Federally insured pension benefits to the company's retired workers. **********In terms of health care, there is a way out: Congress could take a page from the Railroad Retirement Act of 1935. By that year, the increased use of cars and the effects of the Great Depression had slashed the number of railroad employees by more than 40 percent from the 1920's levels. Congress responded with an act implementing a system of retirement benefits for all railroad employees. The railroads and their employees were to be "taxed" uniformly to pay for those benefits. This act solved an important social problem -- rising unemployment coupled with the number of retired people with little income -- and helped to create a more level playing field for surviving railroads. **********In these treacherous times, the best way to finance a similar system for auto industry health-care benefits would be to levy a uniform sales tax on all motor vehicles and parts sold in this country, including imports. **********Taxing imported vehicles would prevent them from having an unfair cost advantage over Detroit's products and taxing parts would help to compensate for the fact that Japanese transplant companies -- by putting artificially high values on imported parts -- are able to largely avoid paying any corporate profit taxes to Washington. **********Detroit's Big Three, which are now badgering Washington for special protection, might add this to their agenda. And labor might think about supporting them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/05/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; Sumitomo Does the Unusual: It Brings In an American
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/05/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; Sumitomo Does the Unusual: It Brings In an American
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/05/busin.body_text: **********When Sumitomo Bank Ltd. decided to get into equipment leasing in the United States -- a business that has thrived here, but not in Japan -- it took a practical, but for the company novel, approach: It hired an American. **********Thomas F. Herlihy, formerly the head of aircraft and railway equipment finance and leasing at Citicorp, was wooed away to head the venture last month. **********The leasing business caught on in the 1980's as a way for industrial companies to free up cash. Railroad companies, for example, could reduce their high capital investment needs by selling their locomotives to financial institutions and then leasing them back. **********Now, Sumitomo has decided to flex its financial muscle just as many American banks, hobbled by a dwindling capital base, are retreating. **********Mr. Herlihy, 45 years old, said in an interview last week that Sumitomo chose an American to head the new unit because it was the only way to build a strong presence. **********The New York-based unit, Sumitomo Bank Leasing and Finance Inc., is one of three nonbanking subsidiaries that the company is opening here. The heads of the other two -- securities trading and the investment advisory business -- are expected to be named soon. And they are also expected to be non-Japanese.

The move could raise as much as $3 billon. **********Sony would neither confirm nor deny the reports yesterday. But two Wall Street executives who said they had talked with Sony management said the company had been considering such moves for several months. Both spoke on condition that they not be identified. **********One Wall Street analyst who follows Sony added that a Japanese newspaper report several weeks ago said Sony would apply in Japan to sell shares in in Music Entertainment Japan, a part of Sony Music that makes and sells compact disks, music tapes, videocassettes and laser disks. **********Yesterday, The Wall Street Journal reported that Sony was considering an equity sale in Japan, as well as the sale of stock in the United States in its American entertainment operations. The operations in the United States primarily include Columbia Pictures Entertainment, recently renamed Sony Pictures Entertainment, and CBS Records, which was renamed Sony Music after it was acquired in 1989 for $2 billion. Columbia was acquired last year for $3.5 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds; The Rehabilitation of 'Junk Bonds'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds; The Rehabilitation of 'Junk Bonds'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.body_text: **********MutuaL funds that invest in "junk bonds" took investors on a dizzying downhill ride after the junk market collapsed more than a year ago. But in the first quarter of 1991, the funds roared back, recouping last year's losses and then some. **********The 86 junk-bond funds rose an average of 14.1 percent, and the leader, the Dean Witter High Yield Fund, rose 30.6 percent, while the corporate A-rated bond funds rose only 2.9 percent in the same period, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds. **********Investor interest in junk funds surged as their performance soared. Sales shot up in February, as more money moved into junk funds than moved out for the first time since August. March was even better; junk fund sales at T. Rowe Price, for one, doubled from February. In those two months, investors poured more cash into the junk fund than in any of the group's other 15 bond funds, said Steve Norwitz, a T. Rowe Price spokesman. **********What happened? The junk market began the year at rock bottom. At the end of 1989, most investors believed the banking industry was on the verge of collapse, and "we couldn't give some of these bonds away," said Mark Vaselkiv, co-manager of the $673 million T. Rowe Price High Yield Fund. **********The doom-and-gloom attitude was reversed in the first quarter as many junk issuers strengthened their balance sheets. RJR Nabisco, a bellwether for the junk market, set the tone with a successful sale of common stock and debt to buy back high-interest bonds. **********Some analysts believe that the market has righted itself and that long-term investors can reap handsome yields from junk. Before 1989, "the risks of junk were underrated," said Ken Gregory, a partner in Litman/Gregory, San Francisco-based investment advisers. "Now, the risks are overrated." **********Looking ahead, some managers say the junk market will move away from its involvement in leveraged buyouts to its earlier purpose of financing growth companies and "fallen angels" -- companies struggling through hard times -- and refinancing going concerns that prefer to raise money through borrowing instead of selling stock. **********The market will return to "what it was 5 or 10 years ago, when the high-yield market financed Turner Broadcasting and MCI," said Richard T. Shotte, who manages the $200 million American High-Yield Fund, sponsored by the Capital Research Group in Los Angeles. **********Moreover, many managers say the junk market is fairly valued now. While Treasury issues yield about 8 percent, the top-tier junk issues yield about 12 percent, a wide enough margin to compensate for defaults or bankruptcy losses in a diversified portfolio. **********The yields on the higher-quality junk funds will not be as spectacular as the yields of the more aggressive junk funds, of course. Most high-quality funds yield about 13 or 14 percent while aggressive funds can yield more than 20 percent. But the very high yields for the most aggressive funds reflect their exceptional riskiness and such funds could have sharp drops in price. **********Aggressive junk funds are very volatile. For example, the Dean Witter fund that was top-ranked in the first quarter of 1991 was the bottom-ranked fund of the 86 junk bond funds in 1990, when it lost 15.5 percent, compared with an average drop of 5.7 percent. **********Since there is no rating in a fund's prospectus, how can investors identify high-quality junk funds? Be wary of funds that buy many of the most speculative types of junk bonds, like zero-coupon bonds and pay-in-kind bonds, neither of which make regular interest payments. **********Look for funds that are well diversified -- say, 40 to 50 issues. But it is possible for a portfolio to be too diffuse. Mr. Gregory says funds holding hundreds of issues are diluting the quality of their managers' research. **********Next, look at the tenure of the fund manager. Many of today's junk managers, called in to fix their predecessors' mistakes, are relatively new. But there are some managers who have run funds for five years or more, demonstrating their ability to maneuver through the junk market. Mr. Gregory's favorite: William Veronda, who manages the Financial Bond Share High Yield Fund. **********Lori Lucas, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., Chicago-based mutual fund consultants, likes two relatively new funds. They are the Plymouth High-Yield Fund, sponsored by Fidelity Investments in Boston, and the American High-Yield Fund. **********Ms. Lucas also recommends Merrill Lynch High Income Fund and the Vanguard High-Yield Fund, which she says have always focused on total return as a matter of policy, even in the 1980's, when other funds sought high yield at the expense of principal. **********One final note: Funds' current-yields calculations are based on a yield-to-maturity formula required by the Securities and Exchange Commission. This assumes all bonds will be paid off in full when they mature. For most portfolios, this assumption is probably incorrect. As a result, investors should discount the yields quoted by junk-bond funds. For instance, Mr. Veronda, the Financial Bond manager, estimates his fund's true yield is about 13 percent, not the 15 percent based on S.E.C. yield calculations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/busin.main_headline: Bonn Sets Big Tax Rise For Unity and Gulf Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/busin.print_headline: Bonn Sets Big Tax Rise For Unity and Gulf Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/27/busin.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government agreed today to an unexpectedly large package of tax increases to help pay for German unity, as well as Bonn's contribution to the allied forces in the Persian Gulf and aid to Eastern Europe's fledgling democracies. **********The move could raise as much as $18 billion annually through a surcharge on income taxes and higher taxes on motor fuels and insurance premiums. The accord comes a week after the Government acknowledged that it had misjudged the cost and difficulty of uniting eastern and western Germany, a process Mr. Kohl repeatedly assured Germans would not be paid for through higher taxes. 'Relatively Undamaging' **********Finance Minister Theodor Waigel said the tax increases were "economically relatively undamaging" and should impose no lasting burden on the economy. But economists said they would probably shave half a percent to 1 percent from Germany's economic growth this year. Last week, Mr. Waigel said he expected Germany's gross national product to grow by 3.2 percent this year, after growing by 4.6 percent in 1990. **********Most of the revenue generated by the tax increases will probably be used to cope with the economic decline in eastern Germany, where unemployment is rising as unprofitable companies shut down and surviving businesses slash their work forces. The eastern Germans themselves will be hit hard by the increases, since their average annual earnings are only about 40 percent of what western Germans make. **********Mr. Waigel said the three parties forming Mr. Kohl's coalition Government agreed at a meeting this morning to impose a 7.5 percent surcharge on personal income and corporate tax payments for one year, beginning July 1. The income-tax surcharge alone should raise $7.5 billion annually. Germans now pay taxes on a progressive scale tied to the size of their income, and the surcharge will be applied equally to each tax level.  Gasoline Taxes **********Motor-fuel taxes will also be raised, with the tax on leaded gas rising by 16.7 cents a liter; on unleaded gas, by 14.6 cents, and on diesel fuel, by 6.7 cents a liter. A tax on insurance premiums will also be increased. **********The agreement ends weeks of public bickering among Government and party officials over which taxes to raise and by how much. The proposals must first be approved by Mr. Kohl's Cabinet and then voted into law by Parliament, where the coalition has a large majority that makes approval almost certain. **********Economists said raising German taxes might benefit other nations by reducing the amount of money Bonn would need to borrow on the world's financial markets to pay for rebuilding eastern Germany. Lower German borrowing could take some of the upward pressure off the nation's currently high interest rates, thus helping the dollar and other currencies, which have been persistently weak against the mark in recent months. **********Opposition leaders and taxpayer groups quickly denounced the increases, saying they proved Mr. Kohl's promises were empty. **********Hans-Jochen Vogel, the chairman of the Social Democratic Party, said the tax increases were "the greatest and most brazen deceptive maneuver since the beginning of the Federal Republic," in 1949. **********Armin Feit, president of the German Taxpayers Association, called the increases "economically nonsensical, budgetarily unnecessary and politically impossible." He contended that Federal and state governments were overlooking possible budget cuts totaling $16 billion. **********The Kohl Government has earmarked more than $70 billion this year to pay for the reconstruction of eastern Germany's economy. The bulk of the funds have come from heavy borrowing on the capital markets, borrowing that is expected to raise the public-sector budget deficit to more than $100 billion this year from $73.3 billion last year. **********But the war and the difficulties that eastern European nations like Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland are experiencing in converting their economies to free-market principles have put additional and unexpected financial burdens on Germany. **********Bonn has pledged $10.6 billion to the allied effort in the Persian Gulf. And Government officials said about $3 billion in aid would go to Eastern Europe this year.
