https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.main_headline: USAir to Lay Off 3,585 and Cut 268 Flights
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.print_headline: USAir to Lay Off 3,585 and Cut 268 Flights
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.body_text: **********USAir Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 3,585 employees, including 660 pilots, as part of major new reduction in flights to try to survive through the current period of slumping traffic and high fuel costs. **********The cut, which is about 6 percent of USAir's 50,000 workers, is one of the largest furloughs by a major carrier that has not sought bankruptcy protection. **********British Airways P.L.C., the largest European airline, also announced yesterday that it planned to eliminate 4,600 jobs, or 8.8 percent of its work force, in a drive to cut costs. **********Last week, Pan American World Airways, which is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, said it was reducing its work force by 4,000 people or about 15 percent. **********USAir said it would reduce its daily flights by 268, to 2,626. The carrier, which is owned by the USAir Group, has its headquarters in Arlington, Va., and major hubs at Pittsburgh and at Baltimore-Washington Airport. **********The layoffs will mostly affect the East Coast, where USAir has most of its routes. **********The airline, which is the sixth largest in the United States, said it would close flight crew bases in Greensboro, N.C.; Miami; San Diego, and Syracuse, as well as a maintenance shop at Utica, N.Y., and a reservations office in Reston, Va. **********The USAir cuts were announced by Seth E. Schofield, the president and chief operating officer, in a series of meetings with employees. **********"Today's airline environment is marked by slumping traffic and sharply higher operating costs, particularly as a result of the price of jet fuel," he said. "USAir is being restructured to survive this difficult period and to rebuild for the future." **********The carrier also recently announced a major cut in flights on the West Coast. **********Paul Karos, the airline analyst for First Boston, said continued cuts would put USAir further behind in the race to build a strong nationwide route system.  Other Airlines May Expand **********He said that United Airlines and Delta still planned to expand their capacity by 10 percent this year and that American Airlines, after reaching a tentative labor settlement with its pilots, might grow by the same amount. **********Over all, he added, the cuts will help all carriers. "The more capacity that keeps coming down," he said, "the quicker will be the return to profitability for the industry." **********In addition to Pan Am, the other domestic carriers that have announced major layoffs recently have been Trans World Airlines, which furloughed 2,500 people, and American, which is cutting about 1,000 jobs. **********The pressure for cutbacks hit USAir despite its cautiousness about expanding too quickly. Company managers were worried about the trend of declining traffic even before the beginning of the gulf war last August. **********The carrier ran into problems trying to meld Piedmont Airlines into its system and for a while was plagued by service problems, most of which have been solved now. **********The layoffs will include 660 pilots, 540 flight attendants, 505 maintenance and utility employees, 1,300 customer service agents, 305 reservation agents and 275 managers and staff. Fall in Traffic Called Severe **********Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst with Solomon Brothers, said the fall in traffic was unusually severe, with some carriers reporting 15 percent to 40 percent drops in their international business. **********He recalled that in 1986, when traffic fell because of terrorist attacks, the overall reduction by the end of that year totaled only 1.7 percent. **********He said lower fares like that announced Sunday by British Airways could help but might not bring many fliers back. **********"I don't know whether cutting prices will get people to travel more," he said. **********Many travelers have said they are afraid to fly during the gulf war, because of the news that Iraq has urged those sympathetic to its cause to begin terrorist attacks against the coalition of nations attacking Iraq. No major incidents have been reported. **********One of USAir's planes, a Boeing 737, collided with a commuter plane on Feb. 1 at Los Angeles Airport. The accident killed 34 people. Job Cuts at British Air **********LONDON, Feb. 11 (Special to The New York Times) -- Reflecting the severity of the downturn in the European airline business following the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war, British Airways P.L.C., the largest European airline and one of the most competitive, announced today that it would cut 8.8 percent of its work force and lay off an additional 3.8 percent of its workers at half pay. **********The company said it planned to eliminate 4,600 jobs -- 2,500 by the end of next month and 2,100 others as soon as possible after that. It said it hoped many of the jobs would be eliminated as people took voluntary early retirement and accepted voluntary severance packages. **********British Airways said it was laying off 2,000 other employees at half pay until its passenger traffic recovered. Traffic, as measured by the number of miles its passengers had flown, fell by 5.5 percent in January from a year ago, the company said. **********A company spokesman said the airline's planes were now flying about half full -- even though the carrier had cut its capacity, measured by the available number of passenger seats on planes flying, by 13 percent since the start of the gulf war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/busin.main_headline: Europeans in Accord to Create Vastly Expanded Trading Bloc
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/busin.print_headline: Europeans in Accord to Create Vastly Expanded Trading Bloc
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/busin.body_text: **********Europeans took a decisive step today toward building a unified Europe, agreeing to create the world's largest trading bloc. It will embrace 380 million Western European consumers from the Arctic Circle to the shores of the Mediterranean. **********The 12-nation European Community, now the world's largest trading bloc, and the 7-member European Free Trade Association concluded two years of tough negotiations at a make-or-break overnight session in Luxembourg early today. After compromising on nettlesome details like fishing and trucking rights, they agreed to form a new common market, to be known as the European Economic Area. **********That paved the way for several new countries to seek full membership in the European Community, which is rapidly moving toward social and political, as well as economic, integration.  'Important Trial Run' **********"Now we are heading full speed toward the community," Sweden's Prime Minister, Carl Bildt, said today. Of the seven members of the Free Trade Association, Sweden and Austria have already applied to join, and Finland is expected to do so soon, while Switzerland, Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein are still undecided. **********Jacques Delors, president of the community's executive commission, said today that the accord would serve as "an important trial run" for countries hoping to join the community and at the same time aiding the community's "spiderlike strategy to organize the architecture of a Greater Europe." The community members are France, Britain, Ireland, Germany, Greece, Portugal, Spain, the Netherlands, Belgium, Denmark, Luxembourg and Italy. **********The agreement would allow for the free flow of most goods, service, capital and people among its 19 member nations and should go into effect just as a single regional market is formed by the European Community on Jan. 1, 1993. **********At the same time, it could mean tougher global competition for the United States and Japan, particularly in areas of trade that depend on negotiations between regional blocs, such as in agriculture, textiles and automobiles. **********The agreement is now subject to approval by each of the 19 national parliaments, some of which are still expected to hold lengthy debates about the merits of the accord. Switzerland is also required by its constitution to approve the accord by referendum. But the private sectors in many of the nations of the free trade association are particularly eager for greater access to the community's markets. **********European officials said that today's accord should also encourage community members to agree on the next economic and political stages of their own integration process when a year of difficult negotiations culminates in a summit meeting in Maastricht, the Netherlands, on Dec. 9 and 10. **********"It increases the chances that the heads of government of the community members will agree on substantial progress in deepening cooperation within the European Community," Germany's Chancellery Minister, Rudolf Seiters, said today. **********Community members are hoping to work out a timetable to create a single regional currency and central bank, as well as to agree on mechanisms for reaching a common foreign and security policy to give the community a stronger political voice in world affairs. **********If the Maastricht meeting achieves these goals, even after today's agreement goes into effect, the community's higher level of economic and political unity will continue to give it a separate identity within the European Economic Area. In essence, the Luxembourg agreement involves acceptance by the seven members of the Free Trade Association of community trading, financial and labor rules. It will also require them to adopt community laws on consumer protection, company law, environmental protection, competition and social policy. **********In exchange, goods, workers, services and capital from the seven nations, which have a combined population of 40 million, will be given broad access to the community. Even now, with $220 billion in annual trade, the seven do 60 percent of their trade with community countries; 25 percent of community imports and exports are with the Free Trade Association. **********The talks were deadlocked for several months over demands for special arrangements by members of both blocs. Finally, early today, compromises were found in the three key areas of dispute -- fishing rights, trucking rights and special payments for poorer community members. **********The fishing dispute, which stemmed from the refusal of Iceland to open its fishing grounds to community members, was finally resolved when Norway allowed Spanish fishermen a larger quota of fish from Norwegian waters in exchange for gaining greater access for its own fishing products in the larger market. **********Poor community members had been demanding a larger contribution from Free Trade Association countries to a special regional development fund. The seven finally agreed to provide $1.8 billion in low-interest credits and $600 million in grants. **********The final dispute involved Austria's and Switzerland's environmental opposition to heavy truck traffic from community members. Under the compromise, Greece was offered a special quota, and the community agreed to reduce truck emissions by 60 percent over 12 years in Austria and to make greater use of railroads in Switzerland.  Farm Issues Postponed **********The two sides also decided to postpone integration in the highly sensitive area of farm products, principally because community members are still trying to revise their own Common Agricultural Policy so that the current round of world trade liberalization talks can resume. **********But the agreement also includes features that suggest the parties intend to go beyond formation of a common market. They will establish a court modeled after the community's European Court of Justice to settle disputes and, in an important step toward political cooperation, they will form a joint council of ministers. **********The move toward greater integration will be strengthened by Austria's and Sweden's negotiations to join the community. These talks are expected to start next year, with a view to completion by 1995. Negotiations with other applicants may take place at the same time. **********"We hope today's agreement will make it easier for Norway and Finland to approach a decision on the question," Denmark's Foreign Minister, Uffe Ellemann-Jensen, said. Norway's main parties disagree over community membership, but Finland's Prime Minister, Esko Aho, has signaled that Helsinki will apply next spring. **********Several of Eastern Europe's new democracies, notably Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, have also expressed hopes of eventual membership in the community, but they have been told this will only be possible when their economies are strong enough to compete with more developed nations. **********But Frans Andriessen, the community's commissioner in charge of external affairs, said today that the European Economic Area should nonetheless help Eastern Europe because "we will be able to function even better and take our responsibility in the reforms taking place there."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; Oil Retreats, Losing Gains Posted Earlier in the Week
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/busin.body_text: **********After gaining 45 cents in the first two days of this week, crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange dropped 47 cents yesterday, to $18.50 a barrel, in thin trading. **********February crude is now below last Friday's previous 10-month low at $18.52. Crude prices have not been this cheap since Feb. 22, when the April 1991 contract settled at $17.91. **********With yesterday's decline, crude oil seems to be resuming its recent trend downward. The February crude contract has plunged 20.5 percent from Nov. 5 to last Friday's close. **********Trading volume was light, however, on the day after Christmas. **********"It was a pretty boring day," said Mike Cardelfi, a partner with the brokerage Arboil. "We just drifted lower in lackluster volume." Crude prices weakened as the buying from locals, or independent floor traders, began to evaporate, traders said. **********On Tuesday, the floor traders started buying after a statement from Algeria's oil minister, who called for a 10 percent cut in the OPEC crude output of about 24 million barrels a day. **********Volume has been light all week as a result of the Christmas holiday. Volume yesterday was 50,129 contracts. Monday's volume was 65,805 contracts and Tuesday's was 36,795 lots. A full-session volume of 100,000 lots is generally considered heavy trading. **********In the oil products today, January heating oil fell 1.47 cents, to 50.32 cents a gallon, and January unleaded gasoline dropped 0.94 cent, to 52.99 cents a gallon. **********Heating oil weakened despite continued cold weather in the Northeast, the nation's largest market for heating oil. Full stocks of distillate, primarily heating oil and diesel, helped push prices lower, Mr. Cardelfi said. Stocks are currently 9.7 million barrels above levels a year earlier. **********London's International Petroleum Exchange was closed yesterday for the Boxing Day holiday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.main_headline: Metropolitan Life Settles Its Bond Dispute With RJR
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.print_headline: Metropolitan Life Settles Its Bond Dispute With RJR
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.body_text: **********Metropolitan Life and the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation announced a settlement yesterday that in effect restores much of the value of RJR bonds that was lost when RJR was taken private in 1989. **********The preliminary settlement gives the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company an attractive deal, through a series of securities exchanges, that other bondholders are not likely to get on their own. However, Metropolitan Life said that it would offer to buy the bonds of other investors who are not covered by the settlement. **********Four bond issues are included in the settlement. Under the settlement, Metropolitan Life and its co-plaintiff, the Jefferson-Pilot Life Insurance Company, will get exclusive rights to exchange all RJR bonds bought before the $25 billion leveraged buyout for more attractive securities. **********Other investors in one of the four issues are not covered by the settlement. But Harry P. Kamen, an executive vice president of Metropolitan Life, said the insurance company would offer to buy at par or near par the bonds of those investors. **********RJR also announced that it had reached an understanding to settle a class action suit on behalf of former shareholders and merger securities holders relating to the auction that preceded the buyout and to the company's recent recapitalization. **********The preliminary settlement with Metropolitan Life includes several different kinds of exchange agreements that the insurance company's executives said would largely restore the value of the securities they purchased before the buyout. Jefferson-Pilot, which holds about $9 million of the pre-buyout bonds, will participate in the settlement. **********It's a fair settlement," Mr. Kamen said. "Our claim was to be paid in full right away, and we're not getting that but we're very satisfied." **********Metropolitan Life, which holds about $225 million of these bonds, sued RJR in 1988, soon after the tobacco and food company announced that its management at that time would seek to take the company private. Soon after the announcement, the bonds held by Metropolitan Life and other RJR bondholders lost nearly $1 billion in market value. **********Metropolitan Life originally asserted that the buyout violated implicit agreements between RJR and its bondholders because it destroyed much of the value of the securities. That claim was thrown out by a Federal district court judge, but other claims, including charges of fraud and fraudulent conveyance, were still being deliberated in court prior to the settlement. **********In a leveraged buyout, a company takes on additional debt to purchase its stock. Frequently the value and ratings of already outstanding debt securities fall because the ability of a company to meet all its obligations is reduced.  Record Price for Company **********RJR's management at the time eventually lost its bid for the company to the New York buyout firm of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, which paid the record price of $24.88 billion to take it private. **********As part of the settlement, Metropolitan Life will exchange $30 million of the pre-buyout bonds it holds for common stock of RJR of comparable value. Metropolitan Life will also take a participating interest in a $200 million to $250 million note to be issued by an RJR employee stock ownership plan. Metropolitan Life will not contribute any cash to the exchange but will give $125 million of its RJR bonds to the stock plan in exchange for a $125 million interest in the note. The stock plan's note will be backed by RJR preferred stock contributed by RJR Holdings. **********The remainding $70 million of the bonds held by Metropolitan Life, long-term securities that mature in 2016 and 2017, will be exchanged at par in December 2002 for a combination of 90 percent in cash and 10 percent in common stock, or, if RJR so chooses, all cash. RJR Nabisco Holdings, the holding company for the food and cigarette maker that is controlled by Kohlberg, Kravis, has agreed to retire not only Metropolitan Life's long-term bonds retiring in 2016 and 2017, but the entire issues, which include those held by other bondholders. The two issues have a total face value of nearly $1 billion. **********RJR will cover the legal costs and other expenses incurred in the case by Metropolitan Life and Jefferson-Pilot. These expenses are estimated to be near $15 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/09/world.main_headline: Leader Says Austria Must Face Its Nazi Past
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/09/world.print_headline: Leader Says Austria Must Face Its Nazi Past
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/09/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Franz Vranitzky today made one of the most explicit acknowledgments of Austrian complicity in the crimes of the Nazis, telling his people that they could not ignore moral responsibility for their past. **********"We acknowledge all the facts of our history and the deeds of all sections of our people, the good as well as the evil," the Chancellor told Parliament. "And just as we take credit for the good, we must also apologize for the evil to survivors and relatives of the dead." **********Mr. Vranitzky, a Socialist, said that while individual Austrian politicians had often acknowledged guilt for the country's past, he wished to do so explicitly in the name of the Government, "as our contribution to the new political culture in Europe." **********His speech was prompted by a scandal over remarks by a prominent right-wing politician praising Hitler's employment policies. Jorg Haider, leader of the Freedom Party, was voted out of office as Governor of Carinthia last month after telling a Socialist rival in Parliament, "They had a sound employment policy in the Third Reich, which is more than your Government in Vienna has managed." **********Huge crowds cheered Hitler's annexation of his native Austria in 1938. Part of the Third Reich until 1945, the country had a higher percentage of Nazi Party members than Germany and produced a disproportionate number of war criminals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/world.print_headline: Price Rises Rule Postwar Cairo's Scuttlebutt
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/28/world.body_text: **********Across this city as summer builds, the talk has turned from war's high drama to far more humdrum scripts -- the cost of gas and taxicabs and most other things afflicted by a scourge of suddenly rising prices. **********During the Persian Gulf war, President Hosni Mubarak staked a claim as leader of the so-called moderate Arabs, America's most resolute Arab ally in turbulence that seemed to offer gains to offset the risks. The economic crisis befalling his land, by contrast, is far less easy to either confront or wish away and has now re-emerged to haunt him. **********In some ways, the crisis -- so deep rooted and long running that it is part of society's fabric -- reflects a familiar phenomenon in this region. **********In Egypt, the discussion turns on a peculiar legacy: For decades -- some would say centuries or even millennia -- this society has endured on a crude but effective social contract that is now threatened by economic reforms instilled at the behest of the International Monetary Fund. **********"The pharaoh has always been responsible for supplying the minimum, and the Egyptian expects it," said Galal Amin, an economist at the American University of Cairo. "It is so much part of Egypt, this expectation that the Government is morally obliged to have the children accepted at school, to put bread in the bakery, to provide the basics." **********Since the fall of the monarchy in 1952, that relationship has been cemented in place by subsidies that kept prices of staple goods low, by jobs in the bureaucracy for college graduates and by guaranteed free education for the rising population of over 55 million. **********But Western economists say those subsidies and bloated Government expenditures have also contributed to a skewed and indebted economy that has lost all claim to self-sufficiency. **********That, in turn, has produced its own paradox. Diplomatically, Egypt has by tradition been the centerweight of Arab diplomacy; it is Washington's main regional ally and the most populous nation in the Middle East. But, economically its underpinnings are frail. **********The International Monetary Fund, in negotiations with the Government over the last three years, has offered help in debt rescheduling and financial aid in return for changes that strip away subsidies and send prices skyward. **********"Over the next year or 18 months, the old social compact here is going to be under a lot of strain," a Western diplomat said. "It's going to be difficult to keep on providing what people expect." **********That shows through in many conversations across Egypt's social strata. **********"I'm planning to get married," said a 24-year-old middle-class office worker. "But suddenly, I find the fridge I wanted has gone up by one-third because there's a new sales tax. So I can't afford it." **********Talk to any cabby and he'll say gas prices went up by a third in May. Kerosene for cooking stoves increased by 50 percent while the cost of utilities -- telephones and electric power -- has increased by 30 to 50 percent. Significantly, though, the price of bread, which was allowed to creep up last year, and sugar, of which Egypt is a major consumer in sweet tea and pastries, have not gone up again this year. **********"There has been a considerable period of crunch," said a Western economist, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "And there are more price rises to come in only a few months' time."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/world.main_headline: Delay of Hearing Angers State Department
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/world.print_headline: Delay of Hearing Angers State Department
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/world.body_text: **********The State Department expressed anger today over a move by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to delay a hearing at which April C. Glaspie, the former Ambassador to Iraq, was prepared to defend herself against accusations that she misled Congress. **********The department's deputy spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said that the committee's decision to postpone the hearing was "censorship, pure and simple." The hearing was originally set for Friday. **********At issue is whether Ms. Glaspie was tough enough with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq when she met him last on July 25, 1990. Eight days later, the Iraqi Army invaded Kuwait. **********In testimony last March, Ms. Glaspie insisted that she had warned Mr. Hussein not to take military action against Kuwait. But two senators on the Foreign Relations Committee said last week that she had been conciliatory toward the Iraqi leader. **********They based their comments on secret cables that Ms. Glaspie sent to Washington about her meeting and that were made available to the committee last week. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger offered to accompany Ms. Glaspie to testify before the committee. **********The Washington Post reported in today's editions that the hearing would be postponed because the State Department had rejected a Senate request to declassify Ms. Glaspie's secret cables. **********The committee released a statement saying the newspaper story was incorrect. It said the hearing was delayed to accommodate committee members who wanted more time to review Ms. Glaspie's past testimony. **********Beyond that, Mr. Boucher said an unidentified committee member informed Mr. Eagleburger that he would not be permitted to appear with Ms. Glaspie at the hearing. **********Mr. Boucher accused the committee of engaging in delaying tactics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/27/busin.body_text: **********For years, Tony Bove has been collecting bootleg music videos and songs by the Beatles and other groups. Now, by using programs based on a new Apple Computer software standard called Quicktime, which allows video and sound to be incorporated in Macintosh computers, he is developing his own presentations for friends to play back on their Macs. **********These creations are like music videos, but they are also "interactive," allowing the computer user to cut among songs, movie scenes, animated graphics and excerpts from documentaries in response to whatever is on the screen at any moment. **********Easily prepared "multimedia" presentations like Mr. Bove's have long been a sacred goal for the personal computer industry, which is counting on this technology to re ignite its once-explosive growth. **********Quicktime will be a standard component in color Macintosh computers beginning early next year. Announced in June by Apple Computer Inc., it is a software extension to the Macintosh operating system that will appear in a range of new programs that add full-motion video, sound and computer animation to existing computer applications. **********This capability results from technological breakthroughs that have allowed video images to be digitally encoded, just as audio data are captured on compact disks, and then to be stored and manipulated electronically using techniques that "compress" the digital data. **********For example, by adding a standard "movie" file format for digitized video, Quicktime will permit users to place movie animations in word processing or database documents, accomplish simple video teleconferencing over standard dial-up phone lines and edit video images to play back later. **********"It's a grass-roots tool," said Mr. Bove, who edits a computer newsletter from his home in Gualala, Calif., north of San Francisco. "There has never been a technology that has been scaled down like this to the level of the individual." **********At the Comdex computer exhibition here last week, a number of consumer products companies, including Sony and Eastman Kodak, demonstrated new equipment designed to bridge the gap between videocassette cameras and recorders and personal computers. Sony displayed a new video-computer interface known as the V/Box that permits a Macintosh or an I.B.M. PC to control a number of different Sony video systems simultaneously. **********Apple is hoping Quicktime will lead to a burst of applications in this new video market, just as two of the Macintosh's original features -- the graphics-oriented screen display and the laser printer -- led to a trove of new programs, like Adobe Illustrator to create complex graphics and Aldus Pagemaker for professional-quality desktop publishing. **********But while the Cupertino-based computer maker had an advantage of several years in desktop publishing, it will not stake out such a large lead in the multimedia business. **********Microsoft has already developed a series of similiar extensions for Windows, its program that offers Macintosh-like graphics and mouse control for I.B.M. PC-compatible computers. At the Comdex show, Microsoft said it would make the extensions a standard part of the next version of its Windows program, due to be shipped early next year. **********In addition, the Tandy Corporation and other PC makers have announced specialized personal computers that are designed to support the new multimedia standards. **********According to Doug Camplejohn, Apple's product manager for Quicktime, the company's advantage is that there are several million Macintoshes that can now run Quicktime applications off the shelf. To run multimedia applications in the I.B.M. PC-compatible world, it is necessary either to purchase a specialized multimedia personal computer or to obtain an upgrade kit to run applications stored on CD-ROM. **********"It's not clear yet who will win," said Rob Lippincott, director of product development for the Lotus Development Corporation's multimedia products group. "But Apple appears to have the better design. It's a complete system rather than a set of extensions." **********It appears that International Business Machines is acknowledging the power of Apple's approach. Quicktime was apparently a key ingredient in the formation of one of the two joint ventures between I.B.M. and Apple that were announced last month. Apple has licensed Quicktime to the Kaleida venture to develop consumer-based multimedia applications. **********Quicktime consists of a series of components: a movie "toolbox" that provides users with ready-made software functions for creating, editing and playing back digitized movies on a computer screen; an image-compression manager to create a standard way of connecting movies and other kinds of data, and a "component manager" that offers a standard way of connecting peripheral devices like digitizer cards and cameras. **********Like other important projects at Apple, Quicktime began as an experiment, said Roger Heinen, Apple's vice president for system software. "We were experimenting with digital signal processors, and a couple of engineers decided that they could do much of what we were trying to do in software," he said. **********As a result, Quicktime offers graphics capability even for the least powerful color Macintosh. Because of its modular design, it permits the addition of a variety of hardware-based image compression technologies, including industry standards developed by the Joint Photographic Experts Group and the Motion Picture Experts Group. **********The flexibility of the Quicktime standard was demonstrated last week when the New Video Corporation, based in Venice, Calif., introduced an add-in compression board for the Macintosh based on DVI, a compression technology that was originally developed for I.B.M.-compatible computers. **********A Macintosh without a compression hardware accelerator will generally be capable of playing movies only at 12 frames a second in a small window measuring 160 by 120 pixels, which are dot-sized "picture elements." New Video's DVI card, however, will play movies with full stereo sound running at 30 frames a second on full screens up to 16 inches. **********But other breakthrough video applications do not need special compression technology. Farallon Inc., a telecommunications company in Emeryville, Calif., is developing a data-teleconferencing program based on Quicktime. **********Currently, Farallon publishes a Macintosh program called Timbuktu, which permits one PC to control and view programs running on a remote system via either an office network or over telephone lines. A future version of the program will include a video teleconferencing feature. Inexpensive cameras can be used to display a small image on the remote computer screen. **********The most widespread use of Quicktime is likely to be in digital video products that will permit editing of video and sound information as simply as text and other data are edited on personal computers. **********For example, Adobe Inc. is preparing to introduce Premier, a digital video system originally developed by Supermac Technology Inc. It includes a video capture, playback and compression system as well as a digital-video editor designed to work with Quicktime. Applied to video images, it enables a minute of digital video data to be reduced from about 1,700 megabytes of storage space to less than 85 megabytes. **********Systems like Adobe's will dramatically change the way video is used. Cutting, pasting and manipulating images in motion will become standard personal computer operations. **********For example, to demonstrate the power of Quicktime, Mr. Heinen had a video of himself riding a bicycle edited into the final sprint of the Tour de France. In the resulting video, Mr. Heinen won. **********"What will happen when all of our video archives begin to go digital?" asked Mr. Camplejohn. **********The challenge will be to explore the new medium and gain a better understanding of its potential, a process that has been repeated with other new media in the past. "When television was invented, people were reading radio scripts in front of TV's," Mr. Camplejohn said. "It will be interesting to see how people will take advantage of Quicktime."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/world.main_headline: All Eyes on Cuba at Ibero-American Summit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/world.print_headline: All Eyes on Cuba at Ibero-American Summit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/world.body_text: **********Setting aside his domestic troubles for two days in the diplomatic limelight, President Fidel Castro of Cuba is to make a rare foreign appearance at an international summit conference here this week, seeking to shore up regional support for his Government. **********The first Ibero-American Summit Conference, which will bring together leaders from 21 Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries on Thursday and Friday, has been billed as an important new vehicle for regional cooperation and economic integration. The list of confirmed participants includes President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua, King Juan Carlos of Spain and President Alberto Fujimori of Peru.  Castro the Focus of Attention **********But ever since Mr. Castro announced his intention to attend, preparations have been dominated by speculation about how the Cuban leader will be received by regional leaders whose friendship now looms as a vital lifeline for the weakened Cuban economy. **********"This is a crucial opportunity for him to reach out, practically and symbolically, to the rest of Latin America," a foreign diplomat in Mexico City said. "It is the only important base he's got left." As Cuba's network of Communist allies and trading partners around the world has collapsed, forcing Havana to impose strict rationing of basic goods, regional trends toward greater democracy and more conservative economic policies have left Mr. Castro increasingly estranged from the new generation of Latin American leaders. **********Cuba's isolation has been encouraged by the Bush Administration, which has missed few opportunities to impress its Latin American allies with its demands that the Castro Government accept broad democratic changes and free elections before it receives help in its current crisis. **********But for heads of state like President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, who has made his reputation on tight fiscal discipline and closer ties to the United States, Mr. Castro's presence is a useful demonstration of diplomatic neutrality and regional independence. **********Mexican officials, who see a politically and economically valuable role for their country as Cuba's link to the outside world, have repeatedly rejected any suggestion that the summit meeting be used as a tool for forcing Mr. Castro to change. **********Emphasizing their commitment to what they describe as diplomatic diversity, Mexican officials have responded to criticism of their ties with Mr. Castro by noting that the summit talks will also include President Guillermo Endara of Panama. Mr. Endara's Government has been kept at arm's length by Mexico, which withdrew its Ambassador from Panama after the United States invasion in December 1989. **********Strapped by enormous debt burdens and regionwide economic difficulties, Latin American nations are not in a position to offer direct aid to Cuba. Regional diplomats say points for possible discussion will include closer trade ties, support for Cuba's crash efforts to encourage tourism, and demonstrations of warmer diplomatic relations. **********The meeting is envisioned as the first in a series of annual events. Spain is to play host to next year's conference as part of its celebration of the 500th anniversary of the arrival of Spanish explorers in the New World. The 1993 conference is to be held in Brazil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/22/world.body_text: **********The jawbone of an animal that could prove to be a "missing link" between apes and humans has been found in southern Africa, one of its discoverers said today. **********"It really is quite unexpected and quite startling," said Glenn Conroy, leader of a four-member team that found the fossil in the northern Otavi hills in Namibia on June 4. **********Dr. Conroy, professor of anatomy at Washington University in St. Louis, said preliminary evidence from surrounding rock showed the fossil was 10 million to 15 million years old. He said little had been found in the fossil record to shed light on the development of higher primates 5 million to 15 million years ago. **********This is the first discovery of a hominoid, a member of the zoological family comprising apes and humans, in southern Africa, he said, and "if the dating holds up, it may represent the sort of animal that may have been ancestral to living humans and apes." **********The yellowed lower jaw, with gray teeth and gum cavity of a tusk-like fang, had intriguing features of both humans and apes and belonged to an adult animal smaller than a human. He said he did not know whether the animal walked on two legs or four. **********Martin Pickford, a British paleontologist attached to the College de France in Paris, found the fossil in the first 15 minutes on the first day of exploration, Dr. Conroy said. **********"We were all sort of pinching ourselves and not really believing this could be quite true," said Dr. Conroy, whose team also included Brigitte Senut of the French National Museum of Natural History and John Van Couvering of the American Museum of Natural History in New York. **********The Namibian Government has given Dr. Conroy permission to take the fossil to the United States for three years of study. Its date will be determined by analyzing the characteristics of small mammals, including rodents, found in the same rock formation. **********Dr. Conroy said the team, sponsored partly by the National Geographic Society, had been very lucky. "You could go there for the next 20 years and never find another thing," he said in an interview.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/08/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Blue-Chip Phase For Hostile Deals
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/08/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Blue-Chip Phase For Hostile Deals
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/08/busin.body_text: **********THE merger deal finally reached on Monday between A.T.& T. and NCR illustrates the sea change that has occurred in takeovers in the last year, and may signal the beginning of a new stage in the business. **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company joins the ranks of the few well-capitalized and respected companies that have climbed onto the hostile-takeover stage in the last year, as the financiers and other corporate purchasers from the 1980's have stepped aside after the collapse of the "junk bond" market. **********Indeed, in the last year, the big hostile deals have come from large corporations, not corporate raiders or leveraged buyout firms. The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, the forest-products giant, waged a successful $5 billion battle for the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation in 1990. And Groupe Schneider S.A. of France is still pursuing its hostile $78-a-share bid for the Square D Company. **********"The fly-by-night operators who got into takeovers because the market bubbled have disappeared," said Joseph Flom, a partner with the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate Meagher & Flom. "Now the companies that are well heeled are in the act. With A.T.&T. successful, a lot of other companies will say that it is respectable to do strategic hostile deals." **********Unlike the fast-paced 1980's, when a takeover offer was often merely the opening volley of a war among multiple bidders, no competitor to A.T.&T. ever emerged in the NCR fight. And the NCR Corporation was left without many of the defensive refinancing techniques common in recent years. **********The reason: the collapse in the junk bond market, which fed many huge takeovers in the 1980's. That, combined with the increasing capital problems of the nation's banks, has meant that only the best of the blue chips have access to the capital needed for a large buyout. **********Some loan routes "have been closed off," said Samuel Hayes 3d, a professor of investment banking at Harvard. "The opportunities for effecting the classic leveraged buyout restructuring is very unfavorable, with the well-capitalized companies now coming to the fore." **********In the NCR deal, those financial difficulties had significant meaning, even though no junk bond financing was involved. Potential competitors could not hope to have the access to capital that the telephone giant had. At the same time, NCR could not use the junk market to raise money to pay shareholders a large dividend as a counter to A.T.& T.'s offer. And those limitations give any corporate bidder much more certainty about how an offer might progress. **********"In the 1990's, one of the things that we have seen is a lack of competition for the deals," said Arthur Fleischer, a partner with the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. And with the large defenses put in place by companies in the 1980's to limit their attractiveness, any takeover battle now is likely to resemble the five months of talks between A.T.& T. and NCR: drawn-out and frustrating. **********"You will have the takeover serenade, which because of the 'poison pill' defenses will go on for months," Mr. Fleischer said. "So the music will tend to get tedious." **********This is not the first time that the collapse of a market has brought the large strategic buyers out of the woodwork. Indeed, many lawyers, investment bankers and academics say that the small stream of strategic takeovers is a rerun of the early 1970's. **********In the years before then, from 1966 to 1969, the so-called conglomerateurs snapped up corporate properties in the largest takeover wave before the 1980's. In many deals, warrants and convertible securities -- derided at the time as "funny money" -- were used to get the money to pay the ever-increasing prices the companies were fetching. **********But a severe downturn of the stock market in 1970 and a rationing of credit by banks cut the conglomerateurs off from the financing for deals, putting takeovers on the back burner. After the shakeout, in 1973, well-capitalized companies, including International Nickel, International Paper, and others, came into the hostile-deal market, using their strong position to try strategic purchases. **********"What you had in 1973 was the development of strategic acquisitions," said Mr. Flom, the lawyer. "And that is exactly what we are seeing today. But now, the respectability quotient of making a hostile deal is higher than it was then, and with a company like A.T.& T. in a hostile deal, that respect is going to grow even more."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.body_text: **********The Travelers Corporation will eliminate 93 jobs and create 39 new ones over the next few months in a realignment of field offices, the company said. The reorganization affects commercial-lines operations, which sell property-casualty insurance and services to businesses. None of the job cuts will be in Connecticut, and some of the people whose jobs are eliminated will be given the new field positions, Travelers said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Shearson Rejects Plan by MCorp
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/07/busin.body_text: **********MCorp, the Dallas-based banking company, said a group of preferred shareholders dominated by Shearson Lehman Brothers had rejected its Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization plan. As a result, creditors other than stockholders may be the only ones who receive bankruptcy court distributions, MCorp said. Shearson Lehman owns almost all the shares in this preferred class. **********The rejection triggered a clause in the bankruptcy plan that disallows any distributions to equity shareholders if the preferred class turns down the proposal. An MCorp spokesman said it was unclear why Shearson had voted to deny itself any available funds. Shearson officials in New York did not issue an official comment.
