https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.main_headline: In Search of a Good Borrower
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.print_headline: In Search of a Good Borrower
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/busin.body_text: **********Get rid of the money. That is usually what bankers do. Theodore H. Silbert, at 86 perhaps the country's oldest active banker, knows that. Bankers are supposed to loan money. But Ted Silbert is rattled easily. Which is why for quite a few years the bank he runs has clung furiously to so many of its dollars. **********Mr. Silbert is the chairman of Sterling Bancorp, which has as its principal business the Sterling National Bank & Trust Company of New York, one of the city's tiniest and more mysterious banks. In these parlous days for the banking business, it also appears to be one of the steadiest. It likes to call attention to its "fortress" balance sheet, constructed on being wary of giving anybody money. Featured in the window of its main office on 55th Street and Madison Avenue is a large poster bragging about how the bank has no leveraged buyout loans, how all but $312,000 of its real estate loans are current, and how the bad loans amount to a preposterously low one-seventh of 1 percent of all loans. **********"We are an example of a place willing to sacrifice earnings for several years in order to build up a secure bank," Mr. Silbert said. **********A conservative strategy for a bank may seem just right -- especially when one thinks about how those banks that indulged in huge-risk lending in the 1980's have suffered. But depending on how the bank invests its money, it can also be damaging. During the 80's, Sterling planted a lot of money in short-term government securities, because it thought other banks were dangling loans at very low rates to risky customers. Interest rates shot up and, though the bank itself remained profitable, Sterling Bancorp wound up saddled with its first loss ever -- a $7.9 million deficit in 1989 -- partly a result of settling a long-running tax dispute. Had it lent the money instead, analysts figure the opposite might have happened. **********But a one-time loss beats a portfolio of delinquent mortgages. And now, with credit tight, Sterling is eager to make loans (though make sure your credit rating is impeccable). At a time when large and small banks are reeling from flawed loans and a sagging economy, the quirky Sterling finds itself in an unusual situation. In days of tight credit, it wants to lend money. And since a long-time core business of the bank has been funding bankrupt companies, it finds its expertise in that area could not be more timely. **********"We would like to lend more money than we're lending," Mr. Silbert said. "But we don't want to make bad loans. There are many applicants where the money would go down a sinkhole. We are in the very envious position of having money to lend and not having enough people to lend to." **********Finding good borrowers who want money, though, is not a cinch in this economy, and Sterling's growth strategy may not work as well as it anticipates. In the first quarter of this year, Sterling's earnings dropped more than 40 percent, largely, it says, because it couldn't find enough of the right borrowers. What's more, John Millman, the president of Sterling Bank, cautions that more of the bank's real estate loans may sour as the year proceeds. "There is clearly more deterioration in the real estate industry," he said. Still, the bank remains sanguine that its fresh personnel will round up more business during the balance of the year. **********Jerome Fischer, an analyst at Value Line, expects the company's profits to roughly equal the $1.9 million it earned last year, despite a tough environment. Last year was a notable improvement over 1989 (since there weren't the sizable investment losses), but well shy of the $5.2 million profit in 1988. **********"They should service the middle-market customers turned away from other banks," Mr. Fischer said. "Sterling has a tremendous capital base that's not being fully utilized." **********Sterling is the very picture of an old-fashioned bank. It opened in the inauspicious year of 1929, when the events foreshadowing the Depression were proving especially bothersome to banking. The bank has just five branches, two in Queens and three in Manhattan. Capital totals about $86 million, a tiny fraction of the banking behemoths of Manhattan (though more than most of America's banks). **********In its earlier days, Sterling had many conventional individual depositors and lent heavily to the garment industry. But about 10 years ago, the bank became largely a "wholesale" institution. It caters to midsized businesses, but doesn't pursue individual depositors seeking auto loans and checking accounts. Nonetheless, Sterling does accept people with substantial net worths. If you want to bank at Sterling, it would be good to deposit at least $100,000. Your net worth ought to be in the neighborhood of $1 million to $5 million. **********Everything about Sterling and its relentlessly conservative strategy is an outgrowth of Theodore Silbert. He is a study in patience. "Banking is like war," he said. "You have to expect to get hit by shrapnel. But you don't want any fatal wounds." **********Despite his advanced age, Mr. Silbert can't restrain himself from presiding over the bank's major decisions. His years of experience, he points out, have instilled in him four precepts of management: "You must organize, deputize, supervise -- and then you wind up doing it yourself." **********Capable of avuncular charm, Mr. Silbert has thin white hair, flinty eyes and a craggy face. His voice is like a rolling timpani. His age has not stolen his lucidity, and though he is still kinetic, he's slightly wobbly on his feet. He is also extremely well paid, earning $456,00 in cash and deferred compensation last year. **********On a soporific day, Mr. Silbert sat in a stiff-backed chair at the head of a long table to preside over the daily executive meeting. Each executive briefly addressed activities in his area, and Mr. Silbert had comments for everyone. There is no muffled reserve about him. The head of personnel reported on some recent hirings. "Interesting," Mr. Silbert said. "Five or six years ago, we did our planning about downsizing  [ as Sterling became more of a wholesale bank ] , and now we're hiring when everyone else is downsizing. I hope we know what we're doing." **********Another executive spoke about an involvement with a community organization. "You better make sure they're not building a little bureaucracy with our and other banks' money," Mr. Silbert said. "Check them out very carefully. There's a great opportunity for racketeers to start bleeding banks. Check them out." **********Midway through the meeting, the phone trilled; it was Mr. Silbert's wife. **********"I can't talk to her now," Mr. Silbert said. "I want to get through this meeting." **********The executive conveyed the message: "She said she's at the airport." **********"I know," Mr. Silbert said. "I can't talk to her now. Later. Later." **********In essence, Mr. Silbert has structured his entire life to carefully husband money. He was born in 1904 in Boston. His parents were professional entertainers who worked in vaudeville and on radio. He never acquired a college degree, and in his early working days held a number of cashier and other odd jobs in and around the theater. **********But he didn't like the way his parents and other theater people frittered away money. Money would come in, and after the most temporary of residences, out it would go. "I reacted violently against that," he says. "What was more important to my parents was a round of applause than a good savings account." **********Banking struck him as the ideal profession to enter. His first real job was as a lending officer at the Broadway Bank in New York. In 1934, he founded his own factoring firm, the Standard Financial and Standard Factors Corporation (which would eventually become Sterling Bancorp) with $1,000. He paid himself $50 a week. In 1968, he bought Sterling National Bank, which then had $25.5 million in capital, and soon after changed the name of the parent company to Sterling Bancorp. **********The younger employees at Sterling don't like to talk too much about age, but age counts at Sterling. Mr. Silbert prefers to be counseled by people with experience. For instance, Ezra Denerstein, the vice chairman, is 72 years old. For some years, Mr. Silbert has liked to keep a coterie of consulting bankers and influential individuals, known as the Senior Citizens Advisory Committee, whose cumulative number of years in banking at any given time might be 300 or 400 years, enough to know what's what. Their main function is to offer advice and tutor younger bank employees who may be a mere 55 or 60 years old. **********To staff this senior citizens committee, Mr. Silbert has a standing offer to all retired bankers, and other older and wiser individuals, to sign up. At some junctures, the committee had six or seven members, but the very nature of its entrance requirement has an unfortunate thinning effect: participants keep passing away. At the moment, the committee consists only of Abraham Beame, the former New York mayor. **********Solid experience is a characteristic of Sterling's board of directors, too. Of the dozen members, only John Millman is embarrassingly young -- 48. The next youngest director is 60. Five of them are in their 80's. **********Recently, Mr. Silbert has given more thought to succession. Three youthful executives were recently hired: Leonard Rudolph, 42, from Bank Hapoalim, John Aloisio, 48, from Citibank and Gerald Levine, 39, from Manufacturers Hanover. Mr. Rudolph and Mr. Aloisio are middle-market specialists, while Mr. Levine is focusing on high net-worth individuals. "These guys came from the banks that got Sterling into trouble by giving low rates," Mr. Millman says. "Now they're helping us. The enemy is now ours." **********The trio is viewed as Sterling's future leaders. As Mr. Denerstein put it, "Sooner or later Mr. Silbert and I will have to put an end to this. You've got to give the younger people a chance." STERLING STICKS ITS NECK OUT **********One of Sterling National Bank's core businesses is funding companies in bankruptcy. Theodore Silbert, Sterling's chairman, has been one of the pioneers of financing for companies operating under protection of the bankruptcy laws, an area known as debtor-in-possession financing. **********Last year, Sterling said its financing of hobbled companies rose 15 percent, accounting for about 10 percent of its business, and it anticipates similar growth this year. **********Such financing is not as risky as it sounds, if the loans are made to companies given a good chance of recovery, since the bank has the first call on assets after professionals like lawyers and accountants. "It's as safe as Treasury securities," Mr. Silbert said. **********And it pays better. "The fees are higher than normal because there are fewer players," says Louis Cappelli, who oversees this area for Sterling. **********So far, Sterling has helped companies like the Interstate Stores Corporation, Botany 500 Menswear, Seatrain Lines, Penn-Dixie Industries and the Lionel Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/world.main_headline: Gulf Security Talks Stall Over Plan for Saudi Army
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/world.print_headline: Gulf Security Talks Stall Over Plan for Saudi Army
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/world.body_text: **********WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- **********Seven months after the end of the war in the Persian Gulf, the United States negotiations with Saudi Arabia over a new security alliance for the vital oil-producing area are deadlocked by a dispute over the future size and strength of the Saudi armed forces, United States and allied officials say. **********For the first time, the Saudis want to supplement their sophisticated air defense system with an offensive army capable of large-scale, mobile warfare like that demonstrated by allied forces against Iraq earlier this year, those officials say. **********But such a transformation would require a huge infusion of American weaponry and training, a step that would alter the military balance in the Middle East and would lead to a bruising fight with Israel and its supporters in Congress, who already are reeling from a confrontation with the White House over loan guarantees. **********The officials say that while the Bush Administration is committed to insuring the Saudis' long-term security, it is not ready to invest the enormous political capital that would be needed to transform the Saudi armed forces. **********But the issue is being handled with delicacy because the Bush Administration is counting on the Saudis to play a visible role in promoting a Middle East peace conference and taking part in the multilateral talks with Israel after the opening of the conference. **********Since the end of the war, the United States has been trying to substantially increase its military presence in the Persian Gulf. Plan Was Scaled Back **********In April, the Pentagon sought support within the Bush Administration for a new security plan that included positioning, mostly in Saudi Arabia, a huge stockpile of American armor, enough to equip 150,000 soldiers fighting as a corps-level force of three divisions and a large logistical organization to move them, the same way NATO forces are structured in Europe. **********But that plan was scaled back dramatically in interagency meetings after the State Department argued that such an ambitious military undertaking would effectively turn Saudi Arabia into an American military base, an action that the conservative Muslim monarchy would oppose because it would undermine the country's own military ambitions and because it would incite a reaction of Arab nationalists and Islamic fundamentalists. **********Also, such a major step, other Administration officials argued, would draw significant opposition in Congress, where there have been increasingly loud calls for restraint in arms sales and support for the Middle East peace process. **********The Bush Administration and Saudi officials have sought to play down the dispute, and experts in United States-Saudi relations insist that the close wartime relations between Riyadh and Washington remain strong, with both sides committed to protecting Saudi Arabia's oil reserves and limiting the regional power of Iran and Iraq. **********But the officials say the postwar demands on both sides have put a significant strain on the countries' relationship and all but frozen the plan to provide credible deterrent forces on the Arabian peninsula. **********A reconstruction of American-Saudi security negotiations since the war, based on interviews with American and allied officials, indicates that: ***********Saudi Arabia has refused since June to accept Pentagon plans to place an American Army division worth of tanks and heavy weapons in Saudi Arabian depots without a commitment from Washington to produce a detailed survey of Saudi military needs that, in the Saudi view, should then pave the way for the transformation of the Saudi Army. ***********Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to Washington, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, has declined to meet with the State Department's chief negotiator on the issue, Richard A. Clarke, the Assistant Secretary of State for Politico-Military Affairs. Saudi officials now perceive Mr. Clarke's negotiating strategy as one that would lock in a weapons-positioning agreement without making a specific commitment to upgrade Saudi ground forces. Mr. Clarke's efforts to meet with Saudi officials have been repeatedly rebuffed since June, and during a tour of Persian Gulf capitals later this month, he is planning to bypass Saudi Arabia. ***********Pentagon officials have been forced to defer their plan, announced in April, to put a "forward headquarters element" of the Central Command on shore in the gulf after Saudi officials expressed their concern that such a high-profile step would inflame sensitivities over a United States ground presence in the region. ***********Saudi officials have refused to enshrine any new defense cooperation agreement with Washington with a "memorandum of understanding" like the one Kuwait signed last month. Though the Saudis have said privately that they would undertake new military cooperation under certain conditions, their unwillingness to publicly acknowledge coordination with Washington after the war has added to the tone of ambivalence in the relationship. U.S. Focal Point: Weapons Stockpile **********Another element of confusion arose last month, when King Fahd removed the well-known Saudi war commander, Khalid bin Sultan, who was deeply involved in postwar planning for his Government. American and allied officials said Prince Khalid was retired by royal decree after he demanded a promotion to chief of staff of Saudi armed forces in a direct communication to the King, outside the chain of command that goes through Prince Khalid's father, the Minister of Defense. **********Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, returning from a tour of Arab capitals in the Persian Gulf in May, said he had reached general understandings with Saudi Arabia and other Arab governments about storing American military equipment in those countries, along with agreements to hold joint exercises. **********Mr. Cheney's initial postwar soundings paved the way for detailed negotiations by Mr. Clarke's State Department team. In four months of talks, the negotiations have produced some progress with the smaller Arab countries, including a formal defense cooperation accord signed with Kuwait. **********Even Saudi Arabia quickly agreed to provide more port access for the American Navy and more ground support for the American Air Force. But the centerpiece of the security plan first envisioned by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the allied commander during the war, was the deployment of a United States Army stockpile. **********On this critical issue, the negotiations have broken down. **********But an aide to Mr. Cheney confirmed this week that "the Saudis have never given an answer" to repeated American requests to create the strategic stockpile in three areas of guarded depot storage in Saudi Arabia. In a specific change in tone from Mr. Cheney's assessment in May, the spokesman said, "I don't know that our expectations were ever very high over pre-positioning" in Saudi Arabia. Riyadh's Goal: High-Tech Army **********A key indication of the emerging attitude was Saudi insistence that the Pentagon undertake a "security review" of Saudi ground forces that was promised by senior Bush Administration officials, including Mr. Cheney, shortly after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. During the summer, the Pentagon sent a team headed by Maj. Gen. Dennis Malcor of the Army to Saudi Arabia and General Malcor's report was completed in draft form in August. **********The Pentagon's production of that study was said to have caught State Department officials by surprise and was regarded by Mr. Clarke as an attempt by the Pentagon and Saudi officials to possibly delay or forestall his negotiations. In one meeting described by two different officials, Mr. Clarke angrily demand a copy of the Pentagon study, but General Malcor refused to supply it until Mr. Cheney has approved the document, officials said. **********Mr. Clarke declined a request for an interview on the negotiations. **********Subsequently, the State Department drafted a formal diplomatic note to the Saudis requesting action on the weapons-placement negotiations, but the Pentagon has blocked the sending of the letter, officials said. **********Senior Bush Administration officials understand that the commitment sought by the Saudis to transform their military would require new and large-scale American arms sales to the monarchy, including M1-A2 Abrams tanks, Bradley armored fighting vehicles, tank-killing Apache helicopters and a score of battlefield weapons, communications and intelligence systems. **********It would also require beefing up the United States military training mission in Saudi Arabia to a full time staff of more than 1,000 people, one allied official said. **********For King Fahd and the Saudi royal family, the risks of delaying new security arrangements appear to be acceptable since the Saudis see no immediate threat from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, at least no threat that the formidable American and Saudi air and naval forces still in the area cannot deal with. **********In an interview, the Saudi Ambassador to Washington, Prince Bandar, said he had "never seen the relationship healthier" between Washington and Riyadh. **********But at the same time, Prince Bandar said the two countries would continue to pursue their interests, and he indicated that when those are in conflict, Saudi Arabia for now prefers a course of delay rather than confrontation. U.S.-Saudi Ties: Uncertain Future **********Paul D. Wolfowitz, the Pentagon's Undersecretary for Policy, declined to directly comment on the problems in the American-Saudi negotiations. **********"We'd all like things to move faster," he said. "But the most important thing is that they keep moving, and moving in the right direction and I think that's happening." **********The unresolved questions about the future of Saudi-American military cooperation erupted during September and threatened to abort or delay allied efforts to challenge Iraqi behavior. **********For months, the United States had pledged that before any new military action against Iraq launched from Saudi soil, the United States would re-deploy Patriot anti-missile batteries in the kingdom to protect Saudi cities from possible Scud missile retaliation. **********But in its haste to draw down American forces in Saudi Arabia, the United States military had disassembled and crated all of the Patriot batteries sent to Saudi Arabia during the war. **********Many of the crates had been loaded onto United States transport ships and could not be retrieved without weeks of searching. That forced Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to cut into the last reserve of Patriot forces in Europe and also forced American officials to haggle with the Saudis over whether one Patriot battalion could do the job (General Powell's position) or three battalions (the Saudi position). The compromise was two battalions. **********When Iraq objected to unfettered United Nations helicopter flights over its territory, President Bush authorized the deployment of attack helicopters and warplanes to Saudi Arabia to escort airborne U.N. teams hunting for secret weapons sites in Iraq. **********But officials insisted that the operation be spread out so as not to appear to be an exclusively Saudi-American military venture. They suggested setting up a support base in Kuwait or inside Iraq. **********Then President Bush shifted course. When General Powell suggested a course of punitive bombing raids against Iraq. Pentagon planning began to deploy 3,000 U.S. troops and up to 100 additional allied war planes to Saudi Arabia, but Saudi officials questioned the plan. **********During meetings last week involving Prince Bandar, Mr. Cheney, General Powell and National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, Saudi and American officials were said to have agreed to continue refining contingency plans to mount punitive raids against Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/29/busin.main_headline: Fiat Owners Seek Diversity In Bid for French Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/29/busin.print_headline: Fiat Owners Seek Diversity In Bid for French Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/29/busin.body_text: **********In one of its biggest diversification moves outside of Italy, the Agnelli family, which controls the Fiat automobile group, began a takeover bid today for Exor S.A. That French holding company owns big stakes in Perrier, the bottled water company, and Chateau Margaux, the elite Bordeaux wine maker. **********In a communique today, officials of the Paris Bourse announced that an Agnelli holding company was offering $326 million for 1.36 million shares of Exor, which would raise the Agnellis' holdings to two-thirds of the Paris-based company. **********Earlier this year, Ifi International, the Agnellis' Luxembourg-based holding company that is making the bid, acquired a 21.8 percent stake in Exor. When the Mentzelopoulos family, which controls Exor, agreed this week to sell the Agnellis enough additional shares to raise their stake to more than 33 percent, the Agnellis were required by French stock exchange rules to make a tender offfer for a two-thirds stake. **********A senior Exor official said his company considered the Agnellis' offer a friendly one. **********Exor has a market capitalization of close to $1 billion. Its holdings include more than a dozen prime office buildings in Paris and a 3 percent stake in Banque Indosuez, the French investment banking empire. **********Exor controls 35 percent of the shares of Source Perrier S.A. and 40 percent of its voting rights. The chairman of Exor, Jacques Vincent, is also chairman of Perrier. **********With the bid, Giovanni Agnelli, the chairman of Fiat S.p.A., Italy's largest industrial group, gave his strongest signal yet that his family was expanding outside Italy and the auto industry. Revenue From Italy **********Paul Dionne, an analyst with Pasfin, a Milan-based stock brokerage, said the diversification made sense because some 60 percent of the Agnellis' automobile revenues come from Italy. **********Analysts said the Agnellis' moves were not surprising considering that Italy, which is plagued by deficits, faces rough economic times. Furthermore, it will soon eliminate its severely restrictive quotas on Japanese car imports. **********The announcement today was the second major development this week involving Italy's most powerful and most closely watched family. On Sunday, Mr. Agnelli, who is 70 years old, confirmed what had long been believed when he said his younger brother, Umberto, who is Fiat's vice chairman, would succeed him. The elder Agnelli did not specify a date for the change. **********According to the Paris Bourse, Ifint is offering 1,320 francs, or $240 a share, for Exor. That represents a premium of 23 percent over the price of 1,070 francs at which Exor was trading when it was suspended on Wednesday. In trading in Paris today, Exor shares closed at 1,302 francs. **********Several analysts said that the Agnellis' offer might face some antitrust scrutiny. Another Agnelli holding company, Ifil, owns a 5.8 percent stake in BSN, which is France's largest food company. BSN, the arch-rival of Perrier, markets Badoit and Evian mineral waters and has a larger share of France's bottled water market than Perrier. **********In addition, the Agnellis and BSN have formed a joint venture that has become the largest food company in Italy. That venture owns Ferrarelle, Italy's largest bottled water company, as well as extensive interests in cheese, pasta and beer. **********Pierre Martinet, an assistant to Exor's chairman, said that despite such links, BSN would have no say in how Perrier was run. **********Sylvain Massot, a food industry analyst for Morgan Stanley in London, saw no conflicts. "My feeling is that as long as Perrier and BSN are run separately and remain competitors, there should be no antitrust problem," he said. **********Mr. Massot said the Agnelli offer seemed attractive because it offered a substantial premium over Exor's recent stock price. But he noted that the offer of 1,320 francs was well below the 2,000 francs Exor shares reached in 1990. **********Exor's stock has been hit hard by the depresssed Paris real estate market and the slump in Perrier stock, which resulted from the dive in Perrier sales after the discovery last year of benzene in its bottles. **********Some analysts suggested that the Agnellis' timing was shrewd, saying it was only a matter of time before Paris real estate prices and Perrier profits picked up. **********As for the Mentzelopoulos family, analysts said they reduced their 30 percent stake in Exor because they wanted to further diversify their holdings. **********Many analysts said the price of Exor's pieces far exceeded the $820 million capitalization it had before the Agnelli offer and the $992 million capitalization at today's closing stock price. **********One analyst said Exor's Perrier holdings were worth $730 million, its real estate holdings were worth $635 million, its Chateau Margaux holdings, $180 million, and its Indosuez shares, $164 million. **********As part of their diversification efforts, Agnelli-controlled companies have acquired a 6.4 percent stake in Saint Louis, a leading French food processing company, and a 6 percent stake in Alcatel-Alsthom, the giant French telecommunications and electric equipment company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/21/world.main_headline: U.S. Planning $1.5 Billion in Food Aid To Soviet Peoples Through Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/21/world.print_headline: U.S. Planning $1.5 Billion in Food Aid To Soviet Peoples Through Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/21/world.body_text: **********Amid rising concern about possible hunger and civil unrest in the Soviet Union this winter, the Bush Administration announced today that it would send about $1.5 billion worth of food aid, most of which would be channeled through the central Government in Moscow. **********The announcement, which followed weeks of delay, included the first large-scale American shipments of free food to the Soviet Union in seven decades. **********The action is part of a broadening Western effort to help the Soviet Union. The United States has already given $2.5 billion worth of food credits in the last 11 months, almost all of which has been delivered. Japan, the European Community and individual Western European countries have made separate pledges of aid in recent months, but so far have delivered very little. **********All of these aid efforts are driven by concerns of food shortages and the possible collapse of new democratic institutions in the Soviet Union this winter. But these efforts are complicated by weakening economies and growing government budget deficits across much of the industrialized world, particularly in the United States. Farm States Back Aid **********The aid package announced today is distinct from discussions in Congress over whether to use $1 billion from the military budget to help the Soviet Union. The announcement today is linked only indirectly to negotiations in Moscow concerning ways to help the Soviet Union with its foreign debt, variously estimated at $60 billion to $100 billion. **********Congressional reaction today was divided on regional rather than party lines, with legislators from farm states favoring more aid and other legislators tending to worry that existing aid may already be excessive. **********Representative David R. Nagle, an Iowa Democrat on the Agriculture Committee, said in a telephone interview that the Administration's aid plan today was "too little, too late" and added, "We haven't given them enough to get through a couple weeks." **********But Representative Charles E. Bennett, the Florida Democrat who is vice chairman of the Armed Services Committee, criticized the deal for not requiring the Soviet Union to barter or sell oil or other natural resources in exchange for food. "The U.S. taxpayer shouldn't have to give a charitable gift if the Russians have the wherewithal," to buy the grain, Mr. Bennett said in a telephone interview. Rationing in St. Petersburg **********In another indication of Soviet food shortages, Anatoly Sobchak, the Mayor of St. Petersburg, announced today that all types of food would be rationed beginning on Dec. 15 because the city has been receiving only half the food it needs, Reuters reported from Moscow, citing local journalists. Some American officials have worried for weeks that urban areas will suffer first from hunger this winter because farmers are refusing to sell their crops for rapidly devaluing rubles. **********Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan told reporters at the White House today that the United States would guarantee $1.25 billion worth of commercial bank loans for the purchase of American grain, and would provide $165 million worth of free food, mainly through private voluntary organizations. **********The Agriculture Department is negotiating with the United Way, CARE, World Vision Relief and the Seventh-day Adventists to distribute the food, said a department official who insisted on anonymity. **********In addition, a much smaller but still undetermined amount of money will be used to build a model farm in the St. Petersburg area, construct model wholesale food markets near Moscow and Kiev, send American agricultural extension workers and provide credit guarantees for loans to private Soviet-American ventures in Soviet food processing and distribution, Mr. Madigan said. Helping U.S. Farmers **********The program will help American farmers and "is aimed at alleviating food shortages and other dire humanitarian consequences in the Soviet Union this winter," Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said. Only the food grants and technical aid projects will result in direct outlays by the Federal Government, he pointed out. **********All of the credit guarantees will go to Vneshekonombank, the Soviet central bank for foreign trade. But each of the 12 remaining Soviet republics has also accepted responsibility for the debt's repayment if the central Government or the other republics are unable to do so, Mr. Madigan said. **********A detailed plan has been worked out for the amounts of food each republic will actually receive, Mr. Madigan added. The plan was intended to reassure conservatives who have warned that the central Government is not credit worthy and will use the threat of withholding food as a lever to compel the obedience from republics. **********These arrangements did not initially satisfy some conservative critics. **********"This appears to be a thinly disguised scheme to continue U.S. taxpayer loan guarantees to a discredited Moscow center that is totally uncredit-worthy," said Roger W. Robinson Jr., who was the National Security Council's senior director for international economic affairs from 1982 to 1985. Issue of Credit Worthiness **********Federal law bars agricultural loan guarantees to countries that are not credit worthy. Mr. Madigan said that this rule was met by the agreement by the Soviet central Government, Vneshekonombank and the 12 republics to take responsibility for repayment. **********Some of the credit guarantees will only be available if the Soviet Union makes payments falling due soon on previous loans already guaranteed, Mr. Madigan said. **********The program announced today by Mr. Madigan calls for $500 million in credit guarantees to be made available immediately, followed by $250 million aid packages in February, March and April. **********A confidential Agriculture Department study has found that while the Soviet transportation system may be clogged with deliveries of European food in January and February, very little grain has been committed for delivery in December. Grain Shipment Scheduled **********The last grain from the most recent American assistance program, $1.5 billion in credit guarantees granted in June, is scheduled for shipment at the beginning of next month. If a new aid package had not been approved this week, some of this transportation capacity might have been wasted. **********Franklyn D. Holzman, professor emeritus of economics at Tufts University, said the Soviet Union had paid a small percentage of the cost of the food it received from the United States during World War II. The announcement today represents the first time that the United States Government has given free food to the Soviet Union since Herbert Hoover oversaw a $20 million program right after World War I, Mr. Holzman said. **********The bread lines and panic buying of food in the Soviet Union are the result of both production and distribution problems there, American officials say. Grain Production Drops **********The Agriculture Secretary said for the first time in Congressional testimony on Oct. 30 that while food distribution in the Soviet Union is a serious problem, a decline in grain production this year has also become a crucial factor in a substantial Soviet need for food imports this winter. **********Nearly two weeks later, on Nov. 12, the Agriculture Department reduced its estimate of this year's Soviet grain harvest to just 175 million metric tons. Last month the department estimated a crop of 185 million metric tons, and in August and September the prediction was 190 million metric tons. **********Soviet crops in recent years have been close to 200 million metric tons, while last year's near-record crop totaled 235 million metric tons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Israelis Say Their Patience With Scud Attacks Is Thin
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel; Israelis Say Their Patience With Scud Attacks Is Thin
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/world.body_text: **********After several days of growing frustration over the slow pace of allied efforts to eliminate Iraq's Scud missile launchers, Israeli officials warned today that Israel may not wait much longer before it attacks. **********For the last 10 days, Israeli officials, heeding American calls for restraint, have said they would refrain from responding to the Iraqi missile attacks -- for the time being. But if the public statements of several senior officials over the last few days can be taken at face value, the Government's patience has about run out. **********An Israeli television interviewer offered a sentiment common among Israelis when he told Defense Minister Moshe Arens this eveniing: "The Americans keep bombing launchers but haven't been terribly effective. Meanwhile, Americans are watching the Super Bowl, and Israelis are sitting in shelters and sealed rooms." **********Mr. Arens responded: "The situation you described isn't going to continue -- not two months, and not a month. I simply estimate that a situation in which we'll be neutral or not active, and their ability to launch missiles against us isn't eliminated, it won't continue for a long time." Much of Nation Traumatized **********And in a meeting with a visiting French politician today, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is reported to have said that Israel wants to play an active role in the battle against Iraq but is constrained by limits imposed by the United States. Mr. Shamir said he hoped the limits would be lifted soon. **********Iraq has fired 26 missiles at Haifa or Tel Aviv on seven occasions over the last 12 days, killing four people and wounding nearly 200. More than 2,000 apartments have been seriously damaged or destroyed. Elementary schools remain closed because there are too few teachers to help children put on gas masks quickly when the missile alert sounds. **********Productivity in business and industry is off. Much of the nation is traumatized. For the first time, Israel is under attack and unable to respond. **********Some Israelis are beginning to blame the United States, and not just Iraq, because they believe Washington is preventing the Israeli Air Force from solving the missile problem. Confidence in Israeli Army **********As often happens here, Israelis seem to be of two minds about the United States. Most are grateful that the American military is aggressively attacking Israel's enemy, Saddam Hussein. But at the same time, Israelis have little respect for the American military while they maintain broad, and sometimes overblown, confidence in their army. **********A senior Government official said air force commanders had repeatedly told the Government's leaders during Cabinet meetings that they have the ability to seriously reduce or neutralize the Scud missile threat, if only they could be given the chance. **********Mr. Arens, in a meeting with American Jews visiting here this week, said Israel had precise information about where the Scud launchers are. But American and other allied leaders have repeatedly warned that Israel could seriously damage the anti-Iraq coalition if it decided to enter the war. **********In an American television interview on Sunday, Mr. Arens said, "We think we could make a contribution to neutralizing that threat." But first, he said, "we would have to arrive at a level of understanding and coordination with the U.S. and particularly with the U.S. Air Force operating in the area." Sharon Defies Shamir Order **********Asked if that meant Israel intended to act soon, Mr. Arens said that depended on whether the United States would agree. **********Trying to force the Government to speak in one voice, last week Mr. Shamir ordered all the ministers except Mr. Arens and Foreign Minister David Levy to keep their thoughts on the issue to themselves. **********That became too much for Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, who blurted out to reporters this morning that "Israel is capable of stopping the attacks and can do it now." **********This evening, the former army chief of staff Mordechai Gur, now a senior Labor Party politician, said during a news conference that he thought Israel should carry out air strikes against the Iraqi missile launchers right away.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Consensus management is a process for working through diversity towards a common objective. ("Scrap Consensus, Try Diversity," (Forum, April 7) By all means, let's value and encourage diversity, have fast and flexible teams tackling problems and issues, focus on outcomes and reward innovation and risk. Consensus assures what Mr. Cox is searching for: a stimulating environment in which the individual is valued and the achievement of goals is the common objective. Let's not ruin what may be a management renaissance in America by making consensus the villain. DADIE PERLOV  New York, April 9  The author is president of the Consensus Management Group

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Marks & Spencer To Cut 850 Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Marks & Spencer P.L.C., the British retailer whose holdings include the Brooks Brothers clothing stores in the United States, plans to reduce its British work force by 1.4 percent. The company said it would cut 550 jobs at its London headquarters and 300 trainee and junior manager jobs at its stores. Six hundred of the cuts will be achieved through layoffs, and the remainder through attrition, the company said. **********British retailing has suffered a serious slump since last year. Marks & Spencer said restructuring costs associated with the job cuts would reduce its current fiscal-year earnings by $27 million. The company employs 62,000 people in Britain, where it operates 291 stores. It also employs 13,000 people at 389 stores abroad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/busin.main_headline: Paris Delays Barring NEC Stake in Bull
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/busin.print_headline: Paris Delays Barring NEC Stake in Bull
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/busin.body_text: **********The French Government appeared poised today to block the NEC Corporation from buying a stake in Groupe Bull, France's largest computer maker. But the decision, which would almost certainly worsen relations with Japan, was apparently put on hold later in the day after it was reported in the French press. **********The press accounts were based on statements made by Government officials on Thursday. But today, the Government of the new Prime Minister, Edith Cresson, who has long been a vocal critic of Japan, issued a statement saying it had not decided whether to bar the deal. It added that Mrs. Cresson's administration was studying the matter and would make a decision soon. **********The Government's apparent about-face from Thursday to Friday aroused speculation that Bull's chairman, Francis Lorentz, had threatened to resign unless the Government reconsidered its plan to bar the NEC deal, contending that such an action might violate longstanding accords between NEC and Bull. Change From Previous Stance **********The Prime Minister's move would reverse a decision by the former Industry Minister, Roger Fauroux, that would have allowed NEC to obtain a stake of up to 5 percent in Bull, a state-owned company that lost $1.2 billion last year. **********Le Monde, the Paris-based daily, and Les Echoes, a business journal, also reported that Mrs. Cresson wanted NEC to sell off its 15 percent stake in Bull HN, the corporate entity that owns Bull's international operations. NEC acquired that stake in 1987. **********As part of a corporate restructuring, Bull is planning to fold much of its international operations into the parent company. As part of that plan, NEC was going to swap its 15 percent stake in the international operations for a smaller stake in the parent company. Loss of Independence Feared **********Les Echoes wrote that Mrs. Cresson feared that NEC would nibble away at Bull's independence, slowly gaining a larger and larger share until it dominated the French enterprise. Mrs. Cresson and Bull executives have strongly criticized Britain's leading computer manufacturer, International Computers Ltd., for allowing itself to become dependent on Fujitsu, Japan's largest computer company. After obtaining technology from Fujitsu, International Computers last summer allowed Fujitsu to buy an 80 percent stake. **********Industry analysts said that if NEC was forced to divest itself of its stake in Bull's international operations, it would likely ask Bull to compensate it. But Bull is in severe financial difficulty after staggering losses last year. Indeed, the French Government is pumping $1 billion into Bull to help insure its survival and finance its research and development. **********The day after taking office, Mrs Cresson said: "Europe has no response to the Japanese. I would love to see a response emerge." She added, "It is inadmissible for Europe's defense and its industries to be totally dependent on the Japanese" for electronics. Need for Technology Seen **********Some industry analysts say Bull needs sophisticated Japanese technology to remain competitive, but French officials say that could prove to be a trap in which Bull grows increasingly dependent on NEC and sees its in-house abilities atrophy. **********Computer experts said NEC would no doubt regard Mrs. Cresson's decision as a violation of previous agreements with the company. Complicating matters is the fact that NEC already makes Bull's largest mainframe computer. **********Seeking to become a more formidable competitor, Bull has in recent years acquired the computer businesses of Honeywell and of Zenith Electronics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/04/busin.main_headline: I.B.M. of Britain Plans to Cut Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; I.B.M. of Britain Plans to Cut Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/04/busin.body_text: **********The British unit of the International Business Machines Corporation plans to cut its work force by about 5 percent over the next two years as part of a strategic shift in its operations. The cuts would shrink the number of employees at I.B.M. of Britain to 17,000 from 18,000. **********The Times of London reported that the British unit would shift its focus to specialty computer markets with strong profit margins. rather than markets for general supplies. It will also concentrate on areas it has previously left to third-party suppliers, the paper said, and increase emphasis on software, and industrial consulting. The Times said I.B.M. expects to see little or no growth in its British business during 1991. An I.B.M. spokesman at the company's headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., was unavailable for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.main_headline: Four A's Tries Promotions Using Top Corporate Chiefs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Four A's Tries Promotions Using Top Corporate Chiefs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.body_text: **********TO convince marketers to keep up their advertising spending despite the gloomy economic outlook, the American Association of Advertising Agencies is signing celebrity endorsers -- not sports stars or singers, but top corporate executives. **********In an effort scheduled to begin running next week, the executives, including John Sculley, chairman and chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., and Michael R. Quinlan, chairman and chief executive of the McDonald's Corporation, will appear in print advertisements from the association, the trade organization for the nation's ad industry. The ads are meant to stimulate ad spending amid continuing doubts among industry executives that marketers' budgets will soon recover to the robust levels of the 1980's. **********"Unlike most celebrities, these guys have credibility," Allen Kay, chairman of Korey, Kay & Partners and the executive behind the ads, said in an interview at the association's office in midtown Manhattan. **********The ads, which feature photographs of the executives alongside enthusiastic remarks about the benefits of advertising, replace a series of statistics-filled pitches that ran for two years. **********The change follows a difference of opinion behind the scenes between Mr. Kay and other members of the association's Committee on the Value of Advertising, which has supervised the effort since its inception in 1989. Mr. Kay said that while he had advocated the use of clients as endorsers of advertising, others preferred the data approach. **********"Allen was saying what we should do is to look at it from the point of view of the advertiser," said John E. O'Toole, the association's president and chief executive, who joined Mr. Kay for the interview. The goal, he added, was "to dispel all the doubts like 'I know half of my advertising is wasted, but I don't know which half.' " That was a reference to an oft-quoted remark frequently attributed to the merchant John Wanamaker. **********"I felt the message was perfect, but that the Four A's shouldn't be the one to deliver it," Mr. Kay said of the previous ads. "A group of advertising agencies telling companies to advertise is no great shock." **********So far, the Four A's has signed four executives for the ads: Mr. Sculley; Mr. Quinlan; Ira C. Herbert, president of the Coca-Cola Company's North America unit, and Richard Branson, chairman of Virgin Atlantic Airways. Each ad carries a catchy headline; Mr. Herbert's, for instance, reads, "The surest, swiftest way to achieve corporate anonymity is to stop advertising." **********The ads were created by the agencies that represent the executives' companies: Apple, BBDO Los Angeles; Coke, McCann-Erickson in New York; McDonald's, the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, and Virgin, Korey, Kay in New York. **********Only one executive turned down the Four A's, Mr. Kay and Mr. O'Toole said: Hamish Maxwell, who at the time was about to retire from the Philip Morris Companies; his successor as chairman and chief executive, Michael A. Miles, has been asked to participate. Other executives being sought for subsequent ads include Joseph D. Williams, chairman and chief executive of the Warner-Lambert Company, and Robert McCurry, executive vice president of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/26/busin.body_text: **********One in every six commercial banks responding to a survey expects to be bought out within a few years, if Congress passes legislation removing 64-year- old barriers to interstate banking. **********If the banks' expectations prove accurate, the number of commercial banks in the nation -- which topped 14,000 five years ago -- could shrink through mergers and failures from 12,250 now to less than 10,000. That would be the fewest since the 1890's. **********According to the June survey, released today by Grant Thornton, an accounting and management-consulting firm, 17 percent of the responding banks did not expect to survive as an independent institution through 1996. **********Twenty-six percent of the 632 banks responding, which ranged in asset size from $50 million to $3 billion, said they expected to be on the purchasing end of mergers in the next five years. Fifty-eight percent said they would not take part in merger activity. **********Many analysts say fewer and bigger banks are needed if the industry is to survive increasing competition from huge foreign banks and other providers of financial services, like brokerage firms and insurance companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/world.main_headline: Bush Looks Ahead to Accelerated Soviet Reforms and Greater Stature for Yeltsin
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/world.print_headline: AFTER THE COUP; Bush Looks Ahead to Accelerated Soviet Reforms and Greater Stature for Yeltsin
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/world.body_text: **********Declaring today a "very fine day" for democracy, President Bush began looking ahead to a changed Soviet Union in which he expects democratic reform to leap forward and President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic to enjoy an "enormous" new stature in his own country and around the world. **********Recounting his 12-minute conversation with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, which he said had begun at 12:19 P.M. Eastern time, Mr. Bush said, "In his view the constitutional authorities are back in power and democracy and freedom have prevailed." **********The President, who looked tired after monitoring the unsuccessful coup in the Soviet Union, which had interrupted his vacation, added: "He stated his sincere appreciation to the people of the United States and others around the world for their support for democracy and freedom. He sounded in good physical condition. Indeed, his voice was buoyant." Delighted at the Outcome **********Mr. Bush, who has always been careful to observe diplomatic protocol with the other members of the club of world leaders he has assembled while in office, emphasized that his official dealings would continue to be with Mr. Gorbachev. He said the Soviet President "has certainly not been diminished by this at all." **********"He will still be a force to be reckoned with," Mr. Bush told a group of reporters whom he called to his Walkers Point vacation home for his second news conference in less than two and a half hours. It capped a tumultuous day that began with restrained optimism after a phone call to Mr. Yeltsin and later included expressions of the President's "delight." **********Before heading off for an afternoon round of golf in a chill drizzle, Mr. Bush reminded reporters of his "respect for Gorbachev." **********Looking ahead, Mr. Bush said the vanquishing of the coup should change attitudes in the Soviet Union and abroad about the longevity of the reforms Mr. Gorbachev has undertaken. "What will be filtered out will be the fear of a right-wing military takeover, because the people will see that the power of the people to stand up against this illegality is pretty good, pretty strong," Mr. Bush said. **********He also signaled that he might be more inclined to consider greater financial aid to Moscow in light of the events of the last few days. And his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said he believed that the vanquishing of the coup might also bolster public support for economic assistance to the Soviet Union and make American companies more willing to invest in that country.  Yeltsin's Gain in Stature **********But as Mr. Gorbachev prepared to return to the Kremlin, Mr. Bush said that Mr. Yeltsin "will have a well-earned stature around the world that he might not have had -- that he was on his way to having but might not have fully achieved before all this happened." **********With Soviet power back in the hands of a constitutional authority and the risks that Mr. Bush took in backing Mr. Yeltsin seeming to be paying off, the President and his aides were free to begin pondering what one senior official said would be "inevitable changes" in the relations between Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin and between Moscow and Washington in general. **********Mr. Bush seemed to be addressing this in his conversations today with the two Soviet officials. Mr. Bush said he had told Mr. Gorbachev, "as I've told Yeltsin, that we're ready to talk to the leaders of the republics and certainly we'll be ready to talk and deal with the President of the Soviet Union itself." **********While American officials said it was too early to draw sweeping conclusions, they suggested that the end of the coup could accelerate progress toward free-market policies, cement the Soviet Union's democratic reforms and radically alter the equation in the negotiations between Moscow and its constituent republics. **********An Administration official said the United States would have to walk a delicate line while Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev sort out their own relationship. 'A Very Courageous Individual' **********But Mr. Bush's admiration of Mr. Yeltsin was vividly apparent today. He referred to "President Yeltsin" repeatedly, and White House aides said Mr. Bush had been deeply affected by the televised scenes of Mr. Yeltsin's mounting a tank in Moscow to hurl his defiance at the Kremlin junta that seized power for three days. **********"It leaves the world looking at him as a very courageous individual, duly elected by the people, standing firmly and courageously for democracy and freedom with enormous stature as a result of that," he said. **********Even Mr. Bush's response to a reporter who asked -- before Mr. Bush was able to speak to Mr. Gorbachev -- what message he would send to the Soviet President offered a subtle indication of the way the image of Mr. Yeltsin has changed in Mr. Bush's mind. **********Mr. Bush said: "I would say: 'Stay with your principles. Stay with your reforms. Stay with your commitment to democratic process and constitutional law. Stand shoulder to shoulder with Yeltsin, as you have been, in seeing the evolution of democracy and perestroika and glasnost in the Soviet Union.' " **********Mr. Bush said he was confident that there would not be a "Gorbachev-versus-Yeltsin battle" for power in the aftermath of the failed coup. "I think he is properly and with feeling expressing himself in total support of Mr. Gorbachev," Mr. Bush said. **********A senior Administration official said Mr. Bush's attitude toward Mr. Yeltsin had undergone "a fairly steady evolution ever since his first, ill-fated visit" to the United States in 1989, when Mr. Bush refused to receive Mr. Yeltsin formally. White House aides recounted with some disdain the way Mr. Yeltsin simply turned up at the White House, refused to enter at first unless he saw Mr. Bush and then had to be cajoled into meeting with Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser. **********At the time, Mr. Yeltsin was an unelected politician and a prime irritant to Mr. Gorbachev, with whom Mr. Bush was doing important business. On Mr. Yeltsin's second visit, as President of the Russian republic, he was received in the Oval Office. **********"His election impressed people here," the official said. **********He went on: "Yeltsin was the first popularly elected leader of Russia in history and got an enormous mandate. People who are engaged in electoral politics themselves take that kind of thing very seriously. His modus vivendi with Gorbachev and his turning into a partner, however fractious, in trying to reach a negotiated outcome to the country's problems impressed people that he had taken a very realistic turn. **********"Then his last visit here was important. People saw a different kind of guy, somebody who was much more sophisticated, much more aware of himself and just a much more savvy player on the domestic and international scene. The President quoting him and the phone calls over the past few days were all the logical outcome of this process."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/busin.main_headline: Offerings Set a Record, but Fees Slip
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/busin.print_headline: TROUBLED TIMES ON WALL STREET; Offerings Set a Record, but Fees Slip
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/busin.body_text: **********American corporations sought a record amount of cash from the public markets in 1990, but the volume of business did little to improve the financial condition of Wall Street. The collapse of the high-yield "junk bond" market and problems throughout the capital markets steepened a decline in fees paid to investment banks to their lowest levels since 1984. **********For the year, corporations issued a record $315.9 billion in domestic securities, up 2.2 percent from the previous year's record of $309.1 billion, according to IDD Information Services, a New York research firm. **********The biggest underwriter for the third straight year was Merrill Lynch & Company. In 1988, Merrill moved past Salomon Brothers Inc., then the perennial leader in underwriting, and has been building a steady lead in the business ever since.  Merrill's Share at 17.6% **********Last year, Merrill underwrote $55.75 billion, taking 17.6 percent of the market, according to IDD. Goldman, Sachs & Company was second, underwriting $40.74 billion, for a 12.9 percent share through maintaining a strong focus on industrial issuers. Next came the First Boston Corporation and Salomon Brothers. The three firms that followed Merrill all lost market share last year. **********Despite the record number of issues, much of the capital was raised from debt securities. With the Dow Jones industrial average turning in one of its worst annual performances since 1981 and the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait raising concerns among investors, new equity offerings fell. **********Indeed, 1990 was even worse for equity offerings than 1989, when the markets were unsettled by a 190-point plunge in the Dow. Common stock offerings fell last year to $19.2 billion, below the anemic amount of $23.2 billion in 1989, IDD said. Other equity securities, like convertible preferred securities, also experienced a drop in the amount issued.  Fewer First Offerings **********At the same time, the already poor market for initial public offerings became even worse. In 1990, only 209 such offerings took place, raising $10.1 billion, compared with 247 issues, raising $13.8 billion in the previous year. **********With less investor interest in the equity securities, virtually all types of debt securities increased sharply in their use to raise capital. One of the only exceptions was junk bonds, where the market collapsed early in the year. **********Moreover, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the market's biggest underwriter of junk bonds, sought bankruptcy protection last year. According to IDD, only $1.3 billion in junk bonds were issued in 1990, down by about 95 percent from the $24.8 billion raised the previous year. **********With the possibility of junk bond-financed takeovers more a memory than a threat, the appetite for investment-grade debt climbed. The issuance of such debt increased 15.5 percent last year, with corporations raising $286.2 billion, up from $247.6 billion in the previous year.  Asset-Backed Debt Up **********Among the biggest gainers in the debt market were asset-backed and mortgage-backed bonds. The asset-backed debt climbed to $40.4 billion in 1990, up 72 percent over the $23.4 billion raised in 1989. Debt backed by mortgages increased 20.7 percent, to $138.3 billion, up from the previous year's total of $114.6 billion. **********"While 1990 was difficult, it was a good year for the new-issue debt business," said Edson Mitchell, managing director of Merrill's debt markets division. He added that at current rate levels he expected January to be "a very active month for corporate issuance." **********One important factor that could stand in the way of corporations taking advantage of lower rates would be a flare-up of the tensions in the Middle East, the underwriters said. **********Fears of the events in the Persian Gulf led to a steep decline in the underwriting business in the fourth quarter of last year. The total amount of American corporate securities fell 14.7 percent in the fourth quarter, to $78.6 billion, compared with $92.1 billion in the 1989 period.  Fees Down 38.7% **********Despite the record amount of issuance, the fees garnered by Wall Street virtually collapsed in 1990. According to IDD, Wall Street firms disclosed fees of $1.9 billion, down 38.7 percent from the $3.1 billion in fees the previous year. The fee collapse largely resulted from the troubles in the junk bond market, where underwriting such securities had long been enormously profitable, as well as the troubles in the equity markets. The average fee earned on a transaction was $750,000, compared with $1 million in 1989, according to the Securities Data Company, a research firm. **********The leading firm in fees was Merrill Lynch, which disclosed $339.4 million last year, compared with $450.4 million in 1989. **********One surprise for the year was the performance of Kidder, Peabody & Company, which underwrote $21.43 billion in securities to place sixth and gain 6.8 percent of the market. That was up from $8.8 billion the firm issued in 1989, putting Kidder in 10th place, with 2.8 percent of the market. **********But despite the increase, Kidder disclosed only $40 million in fees, according to IDD, down from those the previous year of $48.2 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/16/busin.main_headline: Notes and Bonds Decline in Price
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/16/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Notes and Bonds Decline in Price
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/16/busin.body_text: **********The looming reality of war enveloped the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped after a report this afternoon that France had abandoned all hope that a peaceful resolution to the Persian Gulf crisis could be reached before midnight. **********A new French peace initiative had been mentioned on Monday and again yesterday morning. However, at around 2:30 yesterday afternoon news service reports informed market participants that those efforts had been abandoned. That caused bond prices to dip by about 3/8 point. **********The move into Treasury bills, meanwhile, continued yesterday, as interest rates on the short-term securities fell further. **********Trading remained extremely light, as the United Nation's midnight deadline approached for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. **********"You can't do anything in a situation like this," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S.G. Warburg & Company. "You aren't talking about dealing with risk here; you are talking about absolute uncertainty." Retail Sales Report **********Traders basically ignored a report showing that retail sales fell four-tenths of a percentage point in December, another number that confirmed the economy was very weak in the fourth quarter. **********Reports expected today on industrial production and consumer prices will probably be summarily dismissed, traders and analysts said. **********"As an economist, I will be interested to see the industrial production figures," said Nancy Kimelman, chief economist at Technical Data in Boston. "But this is such a politically driven market that not many other people will pay much attention." **********A government bond trader said that "all we are doing is waiting," adding, "We are held hostage to the political situation, and there is nothing you can do about it." **********Yesterday morning President Bush met for 30 minutes with his top economic advisers, including Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to discuss what might happen in the economy in the event of war. **********"They could have been discussing what would be least disruptive for the financial markets," the bond trader said. **********Mr. Liro and others said the markets would be up to the challenge of an outbreak in hostilities. **********"We are looking for a lot less reaction to the beginning of war than what happened in October of 1987," Mr. Liro said. "They were fast markets back then, but that is what you are here for. I would think the bond market is up to the task of maintaining an orderly situation."  30-Year Bond Offering **********By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 103 7/8, down 11/32, to yield 8.39 percent, compared to 8.35 percent late Monday. **********Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102, down 6/32, to yield 8.19 percent. And the 7 1/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 7.12 percent. **********Demand continued strong in the short-term market, however. **********In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.05 percent, down six basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by five basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.14 percent. **********In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the City of Los Angeles Department of Water and Power offered $150 million worth of securities at competitive bid. **********A bid from an investor group led by Merrill Lynch & Company won the issue, which consists of serial bonds maturing from 1997 to 2011 and a term bond that matures in 2031. **********The serial bonds were reoffered at yields from 6 percent in 1997 to 7 percent in 2011. The term bond was reoffered at a price to yield 7.23 percent. **********The securities are rated AA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********In the secondary market for municipal bonds, traders said prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point. **********Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged in very light trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.main_headline: Your Money; New Calculations For Keogh Plans
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.print_headline: Your Money; New Calculations For Keogh Plans
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/busin.body_text: **********Although income tax rules for 1990 returns are little changed from last year, self-employed people face some tricky new calculations that must be done correctly to determine how much may be contributed to a Keogh tax-deferred retirement plan. **********Keogh plans must have been set up by Dec. 31, but participants have until the date their returns are due -- with extensions, as late as October -- to put money in them. **********Sidney Kess, a New York lawyer and certified public accountant, explained that people commonly wait to make their contributions, because the size allowed depends on their net income from self-employment; most people do not have the precise figure until income-tax calculations have been made. Net earnings means self-employment income after the Keogh contribution. **********What makes the calculations particularly complicated for 1990 is a change in the self-employment taxes paid for Social Security and Medicare. In 1989, self-employed people paid at a 13.02 percent rate, giving them a break of two percentage points over the combined rate for employees and employers. For 1990, however, they must pay 15.3 percent, which matches the employee and employer contributions. Then they can deduct half of their self-employment tax, just as employers can deduct what they pay on behalf of employees. **********"Some people may overlook the new self-employment tax deduction," Mr. Kess said, because it is on the front of the 1040, rather than on the Schedule C form for self-employment income, Schedule E for partnership income, or Schedule SE, which is used to calculate the self-employment tax. For 1990, the maximum deduction is $3,924.45 (half of 15.3 percent of the top wage base of $51,300).The important point is that the self-employment-tax deduction lowers the figure on which the Keogh contribution is based, so it too must be considered when calculating how much to contribute. **********"People who fail to reduce self-employment income by the deduction for one-half of self-emplyment tax may overfund their Keoghs and be subject to penalty on excess contributions," Mr. Kess said. "Then, too, if they attempt to correct the error by withdrawing the excess, they can incur a premature distribution penalty unless they are over age 59 1/2." **********Mr. Kess offered the following six-step worksheet for determining the allowable contribution for any type of Keogh plan, for those who do not also have salary income: **********1. Enter net profit from Schedule C, or in the case of partners, net self-employment earnings from Schedule K-1. **********2. If this figure equals or exceeds $55,550, subtract $3,924.45 from the amount in step 1. If it is less than $55,550, multiply the amount by 0.92935. **********3. Enter the nominal contribution percentage as a decimal (for instance, enter 0.25 for 25 percent). **********4. Multiply the amount in step 2 by the percentage in step 3. **********5. Add 1 to the percentage in step 3 (for instance, 0.25 plus 1, equaling 1.25). **********6. Divide the amount in step 4 by the amount in step 5. The result is the limit for a 1990 contribution. The rules will change for 1991 because of higher taxes. **********Joel S. Isaacson, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company, an accounting firm in New York, said people whose Keoghs were set up for the maximum allowed contribution could figure their 1990 amount in just one or two steps, depending on the type of Keogh plan they had. **********Contributions to a profit-sharing plan, which offers the flexibility to limit contributions in lean years, cannot exceed 15 percent of net self-employment income. For a money-purchase plan, to which contributions are required at a set percentage each year, the maximum is 25 percent. That is also the limit for a paired plan, which combines features of the two. **********Mr. Isaacson said those who earned less than $55,550 and had profit-sharing plans should multiply net income by 12.12191 percent. Above that amount, they should multiply earnings by 13.043 percent and subtract $512. For money-purchase plans, the percentage below $55,550 is 18.58704. Above, it is 20 percent of earnings less $785. **********In any case, the maximum allowed contribution is $30,000. **********Milton Pickman, a senior tax partner with Anchin, Block & Anchin, a New York accounting firm, says people who are employed but also have self-employment income often fail to realize that they are eligible for a Keogh plan, and thus do not set one up by Dec. 31. **********There is a way to recover, he noted. A simplified employee pension plan would allow these people to save for retirement on a tax-deferred basis. Such a plan is essentially a large I.R.A. account, but it can be established, and contributions can be made, until the due date of the tax return. The contribution limit is 15 percent, or a maximum of $30,000.
