https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/22/busin.body_text: **********A House committee voted unanimously today to turn over a large segment of the radio spectrum, previously reserved for the Government, to commercial uses. **********The approval of the House Energy and Commerce Committee marked an important step toward finding room on the increasingly crowded airwaves for new communications technologies like pocket-sized radiotelephones, digital radio and computers that transmit data over the air. **********The new legislation does not endorse particular technologies, nor does it settle the sticky issue of how the new frequencies will be allocated. But it takes the crucial first step of requiring the Commerce Department to identify the large array of underutilized Government frequencies that can be reassigned for commercial purposes. Support Grows **********Support for the measure, which passed the House last year but died in the Senate, appears to have increased significantly in recent months. The Senate Commerce Committee recently passed a similar measure, and House Democrats have succeeded in overcoming objections by Republicans. **********The Bush Administration, which opposed the measure last year out of concern over the national security implications of reassigning such a wide range of frequencies, now supports the general proposition. But it still contends that any legislation should require that new channels be allocated through an auction process to the highest bidder. House Democrats favor the use of comparative hearings, in which potential users would have to establish their relative merits over those of their rivals. **********But senior Republicans on the committee supported today's measure after Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the telecommunications subcommittee and a principal sponsor of the bill, committed himself to considering the entire process by which new frequencies should be allocated.  Move Called Crucial **********The new legislation would give the Secretary of Commerce two years to identify Government frequencies totaling 200 megahertz -- about four times the band width used by cellular telephone systems -- that can be allocated for new commercial uses. The Federal Communications Commission would then have 15 years to define the particular uses for each new frequency. **********To speed the development of technologies now ready for commercialization, the measure would also allow the Commerce Department to shift a much smaller group of frequencies within a year. **********Advocates of reassigning Government frequencies to commercial use contend that the move is crucial to the development of advanced communications technologies. "This is a truth that to most people is self-evident," Mr. Markey said. If the legislation is not adopted, he said, American companies will lose the lead to those in Europe and Japan that have been quicker to set aside frequencies for these new technologies. "Instead of blaming others, we'll be left pointing our fingers back at ourselves," he said. **********Assuming that the legislation can survive objections from the Administration, however, the process of reassigning frequencies will remain difficult and divisive. **********The Pentagon, the Department of Energy and the intelligence agencies, which are all significant communications users, have resisted giving up any of the frequencies they now control. Those objections are certain to make specific decisions by the Commerce Department difficult. **********The assignment of the new frequencies is likely to be slow and full of disputes as well. In the past, the F.C.C. has allocated frequencies through either comparative hearings, which often lead to long regulatory and legal battles, or, in the case of cellular telephone franchises, by lotteries. Although lotteries are quicker than comparative hearings, many critics have complained that lotteries merely lead to applications from speculators who resell the licenses that they win. **********Supporters of auctions contend that they are inherently more rational, in part because bidders will place a price on frequencies that comes closer than any other method to reflecting the commercial importance for different uses. In addition, auctions would produce a lucrative windfall for the Federal Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/21/busin.body_text: **********Brazil, the world's largest delinquent debtor country, agreed yesterday to make a cash down payment of $900 million toward the $8 billion in late interest it owes foreign banks, according to William R. Rhodes, a senior executive at Citibank. **********The $900 million payment, due on July 1, would be followed by monthly installments totaling another $1.1 billion by December, for a total of $2 billion in cash payments. The Brazilian Senate approved the plan for paying the past-due interest late on Wednesday. **********Banks around the world have agreed to accept in the form of 10-year bonds the remaining $6 billion in past-due interest owed as of the end of last year. Brazil will continue to pay 30 percent of interest as it comes due, banking officials said. **********The bonds would carry fixed or floating interest rates and would be eligible for use as payment in Brazil's program to sell state-owned businesses. The bonds would not be issued until Brazil and the foreign banks agreed to terms on the country's $50 billion in medium and long-term loans. **********Citibank, the largest American bank lender to Brazil, with medium- and long-term loans totaling $2.7 billion at the end of last year, is expected to receive about $56 million of the $900 million. **********Brazil's chief debt negotiator, Pedro Malan, will start talks in early July about the $50 billion owed banks. About a third of the $50 billion is owed to American banks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/busin.main_headline: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS LOAN COSTS TO SPUR ECONOMY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/busin.print_headline: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS LOAN COSTS TO SPUR ECONOMY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/busin.body_text: **********Faced with a raft of new evidence that the economy is still weak, the Federal Reserve today drove down the interest rates it controls to their lowest points since the 1970's. **********Across the country, large banks responded immediately by reducing their prime rate, the benchmark for many mortgages and other consumer and commercial loans. **********The Federal Reserve cut the discount rate, the rate it charges banks for loans, to 5 percent from 5 1/2 percent, and acted to lower the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for loans, to 5 1/4 percent from 5 1/2 percent.  Push for Consumption **********Economic policy makers hope that lower rates will lead consumers to borrow and spend more and give the economy the jolt it needs to move cleanly out of recession. New data released today showed a sharp drop in retail sales and only a modest rise in prices in August.  [ Page 35. ] **********The Federal Reserve's actions had been so widely anticipated in the financial markets in light of recent economic data that stock prices fell, apparently reflecting the adage that traders buy on rumor and sell on fact. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,985.69, down 22.14 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent. Bond prices were off slightly.  [ Page 38. ] Action May Not Be Enough **********Many economists said the steps taken today might prove insufficient to stimulate an economy that is having trouble getting past the recession that began in mid-1990. In general, the recession was not nearly so deep as the one in the early 1980's. But the economy barely grew in the year before this latest recession began, and even if, as most economists now believe, the recession is over, the economy is virtually at a standstill. **********"I sense a growing anxiety about the strength of this economic recovery," said Norman Robertson, chief economist of Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "In many ways, the recovery is indistinguishable from the recession." **********Someone familiar with the thinking on the Federal Reserve Board said the central bank acted today in large part because of figures that came out on Thursday showing that the nation's money supply by the most common measurement fell last week. Growth in money this year is now below the Federal Reserve's target range. **********In addition, the data on retail sales reinforced the economic weakness recorded in other recent statistics like those on employment, automobile production and housing construction. **********And the policy makers apparently felt that the modest rise in consumer prices indicated that inflation was under control. The main argument against reducing rates is that doing so might lead to worse inflation. Timing the Fed's Action **********Another reason the Fed may have moved today is that the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is going to Moscow next week to discuss economic reform with Soviet leaders, and the discount rate would not have been reduced in his absence. **********The Bush Administration, which has been pressing for lower rates to make the economy stronger as the Presidential election year approaches, expressed pleasure. "It's good news," said Marlin Fitzwater, President Bush's spokesman. "I don't think there's any doubt we're coming out of the recession." **********Most Democrats were less upbeat. Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, chairman of the Banking Committee, said that the Federal Reserve's decision was long overdue and that "its strategy of small, slow steps has not worked." **********The Federal Reserve Board met early this morning and announced shortly after 9 A.M. that it had voted, 4 to 0, to cut the discount rate to 5 percent, the lowest rate since February 1973. One Federal Reserve governor, Edward W. Kelley Jr., did not vote because he was out of the country, and two seats on the seven-seat board are vacant. Large Purchases of Securities **********Later in the morning, the Federal Reserve bought large quantities of Government securities to indicate that it wanted to reduce the Federal funds rate to 5 1/4 percent, the lowest since 1977. **********No sooner had the discount rate cut been announced than the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York, the nation's fourth-largest bank, announced that it was reducing its prime rate to 8 percent from 8 1/2 percent. Other banks quickly followed suit. This means that interest rates may fall soon on mortgages, auto loans and other consumer borrowing, even though they have been slow to do so up to now. **********The spread between the rates the Federal Reserve controls and the prime rate is unusually large, as it has been for a few years. This shows that banks are reluctant to lend money and are wary about taking risks in light of the many bad loans made in the 1980's. Spread Between the Rates **********In the spring of 1987, the last time the prime rate was as low as 8 percent, the Federal funds rate was 6 1/4 percent and the discount rate 5 1/2 percent. In 1973, when the discount rate was last at 5 percent, the prime rate was 6 percent. **********This was the third time this year the discount rate has been cut and the sixth time the Federal funds rate has been reduced. The Federal Reserve has been steadily driving rates down since 1989, when the Federal funds rate was nearly 10 percent and the discount rate 7 percent. The prime rate reached 11 1/2 percent in early 1989. **********The Federal Reserve Board issued this official statement this morning: "Action was taken in light of weakness in the money and credit aggregates, the improving inflation environment and concerns about the ongoing strength of the economic expansion. The reduction, in part, realigns the discount rate with market interest rates." Concern About Money Supply **********Mr. Greenspan has told Congress that he is extremely concerned about the slow growth in money supply. The only way the money supply will rise is if banks lend more money. **********The Federal Reserve's target for growth in M-2, which is primarily cash, checking, savings and money market accounts and small certificates of deposit and is the most common gauge of the money supply, is 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent for the year. Growth is running below that range now. Last week, M-2 fell by $9.7 billion. **********Michael J. Boskin, chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, said he was especially pleased by the Federal Reserve's action today because it indicated a desire to move the money supply into the middle of the target range. **********Some economists believe the Federal Reserve is placing too much emphasis on M-2. For example, Albert M. Wojnilower, a senior economist at First Boston Corporation in New York, said that it was an unreliable figure and that he was disappointed the central bank cited it in its official statement about the rate cut. Embarrassing to the Fed **********But other economists said the inability of Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues to keep the money supply within such a large range was embarrassing. **********What worries some experts is that the Federal Reserve may not be able to reinvigorate the economy singlehanded, and there are no other arrows in the quiver. **********An expected budget deficit of well over $300 billion next year means that Federal taxes are not likely to be cut or spending increased, normal steps when the economy is weak. State and local governments, which must operate on balanced budgets, are doing exactly the opposite, raising taxes and cutting spending, a drag on the recovery. **********"The open question is whether what happened today is too little, too late," said Robert H. Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank in New York. "We just don't know the answer yet."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.main_headline: Business Technology; Putting Pollen to Good Use: The Delivery of Drugs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.print_headline: Business Technology; Putting Pollen to Good Use: The Delivery of Drugs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.body_text: **********At this time of year, few allergy sufferers need any reminder of pollen's ability to enter the body. Pollen inhaled, touched or eaten can cause eyes to itch and sinuses to clog. Now a Southern California company is working on a technology to deliver drugs by substituting them for the natural allergens in pollen grains. **********Amer Particle Technologies Inc., based in Montecito, Calif., said its method could be an alternative to injection of protein-based drugs, like those created by the biotechnology companies. Because they are large molecules, proteins defy delivery through the nose or skin; because they are digested, they are not effective taken through the mouth. Amer believes its method would allow patients to take the drugs in skin creams, pills or nose sprays. Pollens could also be used for the controlled release of conventional drugs. **********Pollen grains have impermeable outer membranes with equally spaced pores, so they are, in theory, suitable for the controlled release of any substance they can be made to contain. Different pollens have different structures, lending themselves to a wide range of release times and therapies. Pollen is also available in large quantities at reasonable prices. **********Amer has conducted both test tube and animal studies, which it says show the practicality of delivering drugs with pollens. Suitable drugs might include growth hormones, birth control substances, blood-pressure medicines, sedatives and clot-dissolving substances. Amer has four patent applications pending covering drug delivery with pollens and synthetic replicas of pollens. But the company has not yet begun clinical trials, and marketable products are years away.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/world.main_headline: AFTER THE WAR: Iran; For U.S. and Iran, a Chance for Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: Iran; For U.S. and Iran, a Chance for Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/world.body_text: **********Iraq's military defeat and the prospect of creating new security arrangements for the Persian Gulf provide an opportunity for the United States and Iran to repair their long-tattered relationship -- if the two sides choose to do so. **********The two countries have emerged from the gulf war with three common goals: the military containment of Iraq, preservation of Iraq's territorial integrity and the creation of a postwar security structure in which Teheran plays an important political role. **********But the convergence of interests does not mean that the United States and Iran are now poised to bury their differences. Rather, it reflects a practical realization by both sides that since they are destined to be involved in the region they may as well try to cooperate. **********"At this stage, both sides are peering through the window," said Gary S. Sick, who has written and lectured extensively on United States-Iranian relations. "They haven't climbed through." Harsh Oratory Avoided **********Throughout the crisis, both President Bush and Iran's President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, and their officials went out of their way to avoid the harsh oratory that has characterized their relationship since the Iranian revolution in 1979. Both sides regularly passed messages to each other through intermediaries in exchanges that at times approached a dialogue. **********The subjects discussed ranged from assurances that American planes would not bomb Shiite Muslim shrines in Iraq to Iranian queries on flights over its territory, Administration officials say. **********In an interview with Arab journalists on Friday, President Bush said the United States harbors no animosity toward Iran and indeed seeks better relations. He added that he did not think that the Iranians should "be treated forever as enemies" by the six rich Arab countries that make up the Gulf Cooperation Council. **********Administration officials read with interest remarks by Mr. Rafsanjani on Friday urging President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to submit to the will of his people and step down. But they noted that he did not call for creation of an Islamic government like his own. Domestic Audience in Mind **********The American officials said they thought the remarks were intended for a domestic audience, designed to deflect criticism from militants who have urged direct involvement in the overthrow of Mr. Hussein. **********During the gulf conflict, Administration officials consistently portrayed Iran as a responsible country that would not take Iraq's side. They repeatedly stated that they believed Iran's assurances that it would not violate the embargo against Iraq, that it would not return more than 120 Iraqi planes sent to Iran during the war and that it would not get directly involved in Shiite revolts in southern Iraq. **********The status of the planes is still unclear. Hassan Habibi, Iran's First Vice President, said in Ankara today that Iran would not use the Iraqi planes as part of his country's $900 billion reparations claim against Iraq for the Iran-Iraq war. But he did not say whether or when the planes would be returned. **********In a Congressional hearing on Feb. 6, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d praised Iran for its conduct during the crisis and called it "a major power in the gulf" that could play an important role in "building a reinforced network of new and strengthened security ties" in the region.  Significant Bid for Talks **********Mr. Rafsanjani's attempt last month to mediate between the United States and Iraq at the height of hostilities was more than a vague peace proposal. It was also an offer to open direct political talks with Washington, for the first time without a list of conditions. **********For the moment, Washington and Teheran have very different visions of what postwar regional security means. Iran has always demanded an American pledge not to interfere in the region's affairs. Its leaders, across the political spectrum, have demanded that the allies pull their forces from the gulf as soon as possible. **********In recent weeks American officials have stressed the need to incorporate Iran into any political structure for the region, but they envision no military role for Iran in a postwar security structure. "We do not want to see Iranian troops stationed in Kuwait," a senior Administration official said. **********The Americans also want Iran to use its influence over terrorist groups it supports in Lebanon that are still holding American hostages. However, these groups have taken a harsh line against American military intervention in the region and say they will not release the hostages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/world.main_headline: Israel Refuses to Match Syrian Position on Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/world.print_headline: Israel Refuses to Match Syrian Position on Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/world.body_text: **********The Israeli Government announced today that it would not offer any concessions to match those made by Syria on the issue of a regional peace conference when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visits here next week. **********The Government greeted Syria's positive reply to the American compromise plan for the talks with heavy skepticism and deep concern. **********In the only official statement issued today in response to the Syrian letter of acceptance, the office of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said, "Understandably, Israel will stand on all the positions expressed in the Prime Minister's letter to President Bush." **********Mr. Shamir's letter rejected the compromises Mr. Bush proposed.  Trickery Masked by Rhetoric? **********In fact, senior officials said they were worried that President Hafez al-Assad's letter was not a concession at all, but a trick intended to insure that Israel would take the blame if the American initiative failed. **********The general tone of the official remarks this afternoon suggested that the Government's intent was to debunk the view that the Syrian response was positive or important. **********Officials said they had not seen the text. But Defense Minister Moshe Arens, the senior minister closest to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, suggested that any Syrian concessions would have no effect on Israel's point of view. **********"The Syrians can put on the table whatever they want, and we will put on the table whatever we consider the proper thing to do," he said.  Moment of Truth **********An Israeli newspaper said in an editorial today that "this is the moment of truth for Shamir's Government" because "it will be called upon to make compromises after it has already drawn its red lines." **********Shimon Peres, leader of the Labor Party, also took that approach. **********"The Israeli Government always said it wanted the Syrians in," he said. "And now they will have to deal with this or appear as the only rejectionist on the scene." **********President Bush sent letters to the Israeli and Syrian Governments last month asking both to accept compromises on the format for a regional peace conference. Specifically, Mr. Bush asked both Governments to allow the conference to reconvene periodically, if all parties agreed to that. And he asked Israel and Syria to allow a United Nations observer to sit in on the conference with no power to interfere. **********Almost immediately Israel rejected both requests. In the weeks since then, Israeli officials have berated Syria for taking so long to respond. **********Now that it seems as if Syria has accepted Mr. Bush's proposed compromises, Israeli officials are arguing that any response that does not accept unreserved, direct negotiations with Israel is no concession at all. Based on that assumption, the Government can argue that it need not respond with any concessions of its own. **********"I don't understand why the Syrian answer is being described as positive," the Economics and Planning Minister, David Magen, said. "In a long letter he tried to create the impression of a positive answer. But in my opinion he said no to the American initiative and to the Israeli appeal to hold direct negotiations." **********Mr. Arens offered a similar view. "I haven't seen the letter," he said. "But if the Syrians have indeed expressed a willingness to sit down and negotiate directly on a peace treaty with Israel, then this is a very positive development."  'The Initiative Was Ours' **********Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was even more direct, saying a Syrian response to questions from the United States was essentially irrelevant. **********"We have proposed a peace initiative," he said. "President Bush asked some questions about it, and we answered them as well. But the initiative was ours, not the Americans'. Syria has given answers to Bush's letter, not to the Israeli initiative." **********Foreign Minister David Levy criticized the others in the Government who responded skeptically to the letter before they had seen it. He said they were speaking only for themselves. But in fact Mr. Levy is the most isolated minister in this far-right Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/28/world.main_headline: Baker Says Iraq Arms Issue Warrants Serious Response
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/28/world.print_headline: Baker Says Iraq Arms Issue Warrants Serious Response
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/28/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d accused Iraq today of an "extraordinarily serious" attempt to hide some of its remaining nuclear-weapons materials from international control and told reporters to "stay tuned" to see what the United States does about it. **********Administration and military officials say there have been discussions in recent days of possible military options for dealing with Iraqi bomb-making components that survived the Persian Gulf war and that Iraq appears to be trying to save from destruction. **********Pentagon officials say that the United States capacity to hit a wide variety of targets in Iraq with ground-based and carrier-based aircraft is virtually as great today as it was when the gulf war ended. **********At this stage, though, officials seemed to indicate that no specific military options had been chosen, but rather that the Administration had decided to intensify its threat to use force in hopes that this will get Iraq to comply peacefully with United Nations Resolution 687, which requires Iraq to surrender or destroy all dangerous nuclear materials and chemical and biological weapons. 'Clear Messages to the Iraqis' **********Asked to interpret Mr. Baker's remarks, an Administration policy maker said: "Don't read that we are going to war tomorrow, but do read that we are not going to tolerate them trying to hide their nuclear capabilities. We now have a very good idea of what they still have. We got most of it in the war, but not all of it. What you are hearing now are some very clear messages to the Iraqis that we will not tolerate their keeping this stuff, and we have established a pretty good track record with them of doing what we say." **********After a meeting at the State Department, Mr. Baker went out of his way to make sure that reporters got the ominous message, so that it would be quickly relayed to Baghdad. "Stay tuned," he said. **********Speaking of Iraq's refusal to permit a United Nations team into a military base suspected of being the storage point for enriched uranium, an essential ingredient for any nuclear weapon, Mr. Baker added with uncharacteristic emotion: "This is a very serious matter. We're talking about possible nuclear weapons. This is extraordinarily serious, and we take it as such." **********The Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said of the Iraqi President, "Saddam Hussein is still trying to protect what remains of his nuclear weapons program." Meeting With Iraqi Envoy **********The Administration gave the Security Council classified reconnaissance photographs on Wednesday to back the American assertion that Iraq is trying to preserve uranium-enrichment machinery used for making nuclear bombs. The photographs showed equipment being moved around on trucks and buried. **********The United Nations commission responsible for locating and destroying Iraq's weapons of mass destruction reported that its inspectors were denied access to a site north of Baghdad on Sunday and again on Tuesday. **********The State Department today summoned the senior Iraqi diplomat in Washington to a meeting with David Mack, the Deputy Assistant Secretary for Near Eastern Affairs. Mr. Mack underscored the importance of Iraqi compliance with the United Nations resolution, said the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler. **********The Security Council president, Jean-Jacques Bechio of the Ivory Coast, also informed the Iraqi ambassador to the United Nations, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, that inspectors want access to nuclear material or equipment reportedly removed from the site, although at this stage it is going to be very difficult to track down. **********Ambassador Anbari was quoted as telling reporters at the United Nations: "I believe the burden of proof is on those who make allegations," adding that if equipment was removed from the site, "it could be anything, like office furniture."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.main_headline: The Executive Life; Dress Down Days For Corporate Summer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.print_headline: The Executive Life; Dress Down Days For Corporate Summer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.body_text: **********Earlier this summer, the American Express Travel Related Services division sent a memo to 50,000 employees, inviting them to hang up their suits every Friday. "People can wear anything they feel comfortable in," said Larry Kurlander, an American Express spokesman. **********Well, sort of. "I suppose bikinis would be verboten," he added. But wherever the line is drawn, between Memorial Day and Labor Day, Friday is viewed by many companies as a quasi-holiday -- at least when it comes to dress codes. **********"On summer Fridays, people who normally look neat and corporate show up for work in shorts, sundresses and sandals," said Elizabeth Beier, a senior editor with the Putnam Berkley Group, a New York book publisher.  "It's like everybody wants to start the weekend a little bit sooner." **********While the phenomenon is most common in "creative" fields like publishing, advertising and retailing, other industries are increasingly permitting casual clothes -- and behavior -- on Friday. "Companies are finding that when people dress down, it breaks down status hierarchies," said Douglass Lind, president of the Trisource Group, a New York executive consulting firm. **********But not everywhere. Many top executives do not indulge in the same privilege they extend to employees. Although several divisions of the International Business Machines Corporation are permitted casual clothes on Fridays, John Akers, the company's chief executive, seldom deviates from his standard uniform. At American Express's Travel Related Services, colleagues can't recall seeing Edwin Cooperman, who runs the unit, attired informally. And Ms. Beier said of her boss, Phyllis Grann, the chief executive of Putnam Berkley: "I don't think our president ever relaxes her dress standards. She has to retain her dignity." **********Still, signs of the looser dress code abound, even though some skeptics raise eyebrows about the whole idea. "It's an attempt to create a notion of equality among people at different levels in an organization," said Abraham Zaleznik, a professor at the Harvard Business School. "It's an episodic ritual of power reduction which can be insidious." **********If anything, Dr. Zaleznik thinks, casual clothes are a distraction. "When people come to work in shorts, their concentration is reduced," he said. "They're more likely to hang out and schmooze." **********Other management experts suggest that dressing down represents a ritual of relaxation -- rather than actual relaxation. "It's a purely symbolic gesture," said Allan Cox, an executive consultant in Chicago. "It makes people think the boss has a little heart, that he's willing to humanize the workplace. But it doesn't make employees less efficient or productive." **********While many people readily relinquish neckties or heels, not all do. "I wear loafers on Friday instead of wingtips," admitted Robert Parker, chief financial officer for the New York advertising agency Della Femina McNamee. "That's about as far as I go." **********In Mr. Parker's view, "casual" means a blazer and slacks, not a T-shirt and jeans.  "Friday looks different from Thursday here, but it shouldn't look like Saturday," he said. **********There are a few industries where casual clothes would raise eyebrows -- even for an hour or two. One investment banker at Morgan Stanley recalls working with a female partner on a Friday who was leaving at 10:30 A.M. on Friday for a weekend sojourn. "She was only going to be in the office for half the morning, but she wore a suit anyway," the investment banker said. **********There's a reason for this, according to Mr.  Lind. "In an industry like investment banking, clothes send important signals. If power dressing is key, and you don't have your suspenders on, what have you got?" **********At smaller investment banking boutiques, however, informal attire is often allowed -- even encouraged. Liz Kelly, an associate with the New York-based firm of Scully Brothers Foss & Wight, favors brighter colors in the summer, and occasionally sports slacks on Friday. However, she noted, "I keep a black dress in the office in case a client comes by." **********The abbrieviated summer hours traditionally associated with advertising have migrated to other businesses. At some corporations, it's hard to figure out who's around on Friday. **********Take Time Warner, the communications and entertainment giant. Employees with the Book of the Month Club, Home Box Office and the magazines can take Friday afternoons off -- but employees with the movies and records units and the corporate office can't. Those with summer hours aren't necessarily in sync. Some are dismissed at 1:00 P.M., others at 3:00 P.M. **********"The rules relate to the nature of the different divisions," said Edward I. Adler, a Time Warner spokesman. **********Even when summer hours are offered, they aren't always observed. At Unilever, the New York-based arm of the Dutch consumer products company, employees may take a half-day off anytime during the week -- providing they work an additional 45 minutes the remaining days. Yet only about 50 percent of Unilever employees leave early.  "Some departments frown on it," said Mary Hernandez, a company spokeswoman. "It might be O.K. in marketing, but not in manufacturing." **********Due to the recession, some companies have lengthened -- or abandoned -- their summer hours. At Della Femina McNamee, employees may take five Fridays off, down from 10 a few years ago. And they must take whole days, not half days. **********"We think this is the best way," said Mr. Parker. "It means everybody doesn't mentally wind down at 11 o'clock and check out for the weekend."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; North American Currency Links?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; North American Currency Links?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/busin.body_text: **********SHOULD the United States, Mexico and Canada, follow Europe's lead and move toward a North American currency area as well as a freer regional trade zone? **********The question is not on any official agendas. But the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas and the Mexican central bank are quietly studying coordination to dampen swings in the peso-dollar rate. Some hard-pressed Canadian exporters are urging the Canadians to peg the Canadian dollar to the United States dollar. And the former Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, recently predicted that "in five years, you will find a fixed exchange rate among the peso, the U.S. dollar and the Canadian dollar." **********Harvey Rosenblum, research director of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said: "You don't have to go all the way to a single currency to get some of the advantages. A tacit agreement to keep rates within a narrow band, absolutely fixed rates, or a single currency are all degrees of the same thing." **********Since its economy is by far the biggest of the three, the United States would probably feel fewer effects of currency linkage than Mexico or Canada. **********With steadier exchange rates, importers and exporters would face fewer problems, less uncertainty and lower business costs. Mr. Rosenblum compares bumpy exchange rates to pothole-strewn highways: "You can haul the goods, but it's a lot tougher." **********Predictable exchange rates could also increase investor confidence, helping to broaden financial markets and bring in more investment -- particularly in Mexico where the perennial worry remains the risk of a sudden flight from the peso. "Economists always say that you can hedge," said Richard Cooper, an economist at the Kennedy School. "But you can't hedge an investment with a 10-year life." **********Stable exchange rates could also help defuse a potential backlash against freer trade from business and unions by minimizing large swings in currencies. **********Finally, linking currencies "puts pressure on high-inflation countries to mend their ways," said Robert Gay, an economist at Morgan Stanley. In Mexico, inflation has been running at 20 percent, multiples of the 3.5 percent in the United States. **********The peso was, in fact, linked to the United States dollar during the 1950's and 60's -- "a remarkable period of growth and stability and open capital markets in Mexico," as Mr. Volcker put it. **********Few economists would deny that these benefits may accrue. But many believe that the economic case for giving up floating rates and edging toward a North American currency area is much weaker than in Europe -- quite apart from the fact that the merest whisper of economic integration raises hackles in Canada and Mexico. The biggest drawback to monetary unions is the loss of sovereignty. **********"Currency alignment means giving up your economic policy," said Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University. Defending a fixed exchange rate can mean adopting exactly the opposite monetary policy than the one that domestic conditions call for. **********"The one market of Western Europe and that of North America are very different entities," said David Laidler, an economist at the C.D. Howe Institute, a Canadian think tank. "To put it simply, the one European market is part of a broader political union and the one North American market shows no signs of developing in such a direction." **********And it's far too soon to predict how free-trade agreements will evolve. The free-trade area in the agreement between the United States and Canada will not be completed until 1999 and the agreement with Mexico is not a sure thing. Further, said Miguel Mancera, president of the Banco de Mexico, "Currency areas are not essential to free-trade zones' good performance nor are the benefits of such unions self-evident." **********The potential cost saving from going, say, to a single currency are probably much smaller here than in Europe. There are only three currencies in North America, not 12; the United States and Mexico depend less on foreign trade, and, in any case, business can always be conducted in United States dollars. The existing system of floating rates has also worked much better in North America than in Europe. Flexible currencies have helped the region adjust relatively quickly to shocks -- a big surge or plunge in world oil prices. **********In any case, there is no compelling evidence that trade liberalization requires fixed exchange rates. "Central bankers always want to fix things," said Sir Alan Walters, vice chairman of the AIG Trading Corporation and a former economic adviser to Margaret Thatcher. "It makes them feel more important." The lack of a currency union has not prevented Canada and the United States from trading more than any other two nations. **********At an international economics meeting in August, several Mexican and Canadian economists made elaborate arguments against a North American monetary union. **********"It may be politically suicidal, and economically premature to say anything else," Mr. Volcker commented at the meeting. "But I also have the feel that they doth protest too much."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; New Head Of Meredith Magazines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/busin.body_text: **********William T. Kerr, president of The New York Times Company Magazine Group, yesterday was named president of the Meredith Corporation Magazine Group. Meredith publishes The Ladies' Home Journal, Better Homes & Gardens and other magazines. **********Mr. Kerr will replace James A. Autry, who joined Meredith in 1960 and has headed the magazine group since 1986. Mr. Autry had previously announced that he would retire in December, setting off an intense competition among magazine executives for the job. **********"It might be one of the best jobs that a top corporate executive in magazine publishing could have," said Martin Walker, president of Periodical Studies Service, a magazine consultant. "It is a strong corporate department within a well-financed company. Both Ladies' Home Journal and Better Homes are doing well. Meredith has solid mass magazines and special-interest titles, and they seem to have a pulse on middle America." A Move to Des Moines **********Contenders for the job included a number of top magazine executives, people familiar with the seven-month search said. The principal obstacle, however, seemed to be that Meredith is based in Des Moines, and executives used to the world of New York magazine publishing were said to be reluctant to move there. **********Mr. Kerr said he and his family would establish a home in Des Moines, although he would still spend much of his time in New York. Meredith has an office and about 300 employees in New York. **********Mr. Kerr, who is 50 years old, will also become executive vice president at Meredith with responsibilities for overall corporate development. He joined the Times Company in 1979 as vice president for corporate development and became magazine group president in 1984, overseeing the expansion of the group from 6 to 17 magazines. **********"We were able to grow the group and build one of the top teams of people," Mr. Kerr said yesterday. "Five or six years ago industry observers may have felt that The Times was ambivalent about being in the magazine business whereas today it is one of the major players." **********Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive of The New York Times Company, issued a statement crediting much of the success of the magazine group to Mr. Kerr's leadership. **********"It is with real regret that we see him depart," Mr. Sulzberger said. "We are fortunate, however, to have a strong management team in place, and we will continue our momentum in the magazine industry." **********The Times magazines include Family Circle, McCall's, Child, Golf Digest and Tennis.  A Former Consultant **********Before joining the Times Company, Mr. Kerr was a management consultant with McKinsey & Company. He holds degrees from the University of Washington, Harvard and Oxford, where he was a Rhodes Scholar. **********Jack D. Rehm, Meredith's president and chief executive, said Mr. Kerr's appointment did not signal any new directions for the company, which he described as "acquisition-minded and start-up-minded." **********Meredith's magazines also include Country Home, Metropolitan Home and Country America. It is a diversified media company involved in magazine and book publishing, television broadcasting, cable television and residential real estate. **********Mr. Autry, 58, a published writer and poet, is taking early retirement to spend more time with his family and devote himself to other pursuits. "Love & Profit: The Art of Caring Leadership," a book of his poetry and essays, was published this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/busin.main_headline: TV Just for Women . . . and Men
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; TV Just for Women . . . and Men
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/busin.body_text: **********NBC never promoted "L.A. Law" the way Lifetime does. **********"Lifetime gives you five good reasons to watch 'L.A. Law,' " says the wry voice-over in a commercial for the series. Then, along with their pictures, a list of five male lawyers who star in the series: "Becker. Kuzak. Sifuentes. Rollins. Brackman." **********Another tongue-in-cheek commercial for the "L.A. Law" reruns refers to the lawyers as "hunky guys in dark suits." (The same ad also touts the "hunky guys in dark suits" on "China Beach" reruns.)  Pursuit of an Image **********Lifetime calls itself the women's network, and its aggressive pursuit of that image has been a big part of its success. While audience growth has leveled off for several other cable networks, Lifetime's prime-time viewership has continued to increase. **********Lifetime says its prime-time Nielsen ratings have jumped 20 percent, averaging 1.2 points in the first nine months of 1991, compared with a one-point rating a year earlier. In Lifetime's case, a rating point represents 535,000 homes with cable television. **********The network claims to have an audience attractive to advertisers. It says its typical viewer is a woman 18 to 49 years old, with a household income of about $38,000. **********"They have positioned themselves as the female network," said Peter Spengler, vice president for marketing services at the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, which advertises on Lifetime. "And it worked."  Shows for Women -- and Men **********Indeed, Lifetime, which is owned by Hearst/ABC-Viacom Entertainment Services, has grown steadily in its seven years as a women's network. **********Still, even though Lifetime's promotions of "L.A. Law" reruns are intended to appeal to women, the network chose to run that series in prime time precisely because both women and men like the show. **********"You can't have a show on at that time that's male-unfriendly," said Pat Fili, head of programming for Lifetime. **********In fact, some industry experts suggest that Lifetime can only be a women's network part of the time in order to remain successful. **********"They have picked up some programming that makes sense to women," said John Mandel, director of national broadcasting for Grey Advertising. "But some of their programming choices seem to be more broad. In order for them to do better, they have to be broader, which is why they say they don't want to alienate men. But how can you say you don't want to alienate men -- and yet you're the women's network?"  No Wrestling or Football **********So what does make Lifetime a women's network? **********Lifetime executives like to say that their network can perhaps be best defined by what it does not have. The list includes beer commercials, wrestling, football ("Here's something to cheer about -- New Year's Day with no football," a Lifetime ad said last year), women as victims, slasher movies, soap operas and situation comedies like "Coach," about -- what else -- a male football coach. **********"If you want to watch male beer guzzlers, you can tune in to ESPN," said Thomas F. Burchill, the president of Lifetime. **********Lifetime is also the network that resurrected the canceled NBC series "The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd," about a single woman trying to make a life for herself in New York City. It commissioned 39 original episodes; Molly Dodd became pregnant, and had a baby, on Lifetime. **********In the morning, Lifetime presents two programs for parents, "What Every Baby Knows: The First Three Years" and "Growing Up Together." **********In the afternoons, the network has reruns of "Moonlighting" and "The Tracey Ullman Show," as well as two game shows that revolve around shopping and "Attitudes," a talk show that has recently dealt with issues as varied as parental consent for abortions and how to sew your own designer outfits. **********In the evenings, Lifetime presents original programming, including movies -- in one, "Stop At Nothing," Veronica Hamel played a woman who rescues abused children. It also offers documentaries about such issues as rape on college campuses, and also reruns of network series.  Tapping Into Emotions **********"If it taps into emotions, whether it's fear or happiness or sadness, it appeals to women," Ms. Fili said. **********Mr. Burchill said Lifetime was growing along with other cable networks that aim at particular viewers. "There is a higher level of audience satisfaction for these networks, whether it's kids tuning in to Nickelodeon, or classic movie fans to TNT or women to Lifetime," he said. **********Still, Erica Gruen, associate director for television information at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, said Lifetime faced a problem familiar to other niche cable networks. **********"If you're too small, you can't produce programming anyone will want to watch," she said. "There are a number of sincere people at Lifetime trying to figure out how to be a women's network in the face of the paradox that if you target yourself too narrowly, you drive yourself out of business."  Developing New Programs **********As such, Lifetime is developing several new programs that should appeal to women -- without necessarily excluding men. **********The actress Diane Keaton is directing "Wildflower," a television movie for Lifetime, in which a hearing-impaired teen-age girl re-enters the world after years of abuse by her stepfather. The movie is scheduled to appear next month. **********In the wake of Anita F. Hill's sexual-harassment accusations against Clarence Thomas, a nominee for Supreme Court Justice, the network is also working on a documentary on sexual harassment for next year. **********And the network is planning a movie for 1992 in which a female war veteran gets elected President. Ms. Fili said she had the writer, a man, rethink his original treatment. **********"In the first one, the woman won by default," Ms. Fili said. "She was Vice President, and the President died. We said, 'No, no, no. That's not the movie we want. She wins on her own.' "

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/world.main_headline: Israel, Rebuffing U.S. Plea, Says It Will Answer Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Israel, Rebuffing U.S. Plea, Says It Will Answer Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/world.body_text: **********Defense Minister Moshe Arens made clear today that Israel would not meet an American request to stay out of a Persian Gulf war if it is attacked. **********After two hours of talks with a high-ranking American delegation, Mr. Arens drove to an air base in the northern Galilee region and said: "If we are attacked, we will respond. If attacked we will respond. I believe what I've said is quite sufficient." **********Mr. Arens made the statement in front of an American-made F-16 fighter-bomber, one of dozens in the country that are now fueled and armed with pilots strapped into the cockpits 24 hours a day. **********Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger and several other senior State and Defense Department officials are now in their second day of meetings here with political and military officials, trying to coordinate American and Israeli actions in the event of war. **********The Bush Administration's hope is that Israel not respond if attacked, the President's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said in Washington today. **********American and Israeli officials said Mr. Eagleburger asked the Israelis "to lay low" and let the Americans handle any response. If Israel retaliated, the United States delegation said, that might lead to a fracturing of the American-led coalition in the Persian Gulf, one of Saddam Hussein's goals in attacking Israel. **********For the United States, Israel remains a sort of wild card, one that can endanger the grand but delicate international alliance carefully assembled and maintained over the last five months. **********While some Arab countries, notably Egypt, have said that Israel has the right to retaliate if attacked, others have taken a different view. On Saturday, the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, indicated that Syria would reassess its role in the anti-Iraq alliance if Israel got involved, even to retaliate after an Iraqi attack.  Syria as a Political Asset **********"In this case," Mr. Sharaa said, "it is meant to reshuffle the cards, and therefore Israel should not intervene. Syria cannot accept an Israeli intervention in this crisis." **********If Syria withdrew from the coalition, that would have little effect on the military situation, since it is far from certain that the Syrians would participate in an offensive in any case. But the presence of this normally anti-American Arab nation in the alliance has been an important political chip for Washington. And some American officials fear that if one Arab state withdraws, that would put pressure on others to follow suit. **********Israelis of varied political perspectives took umbrage when word of the American request reached Jerusalem over the weekend. **********At this morning's weekly Cabinet meeting, several ministers asked Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who spent Saturday night in talks with Mr. Eagleburger, how Israel stood on the question. It is up to Israel to decide how to respond if attacked, the Prime Minister answered. **********"That is the way it has been, and that is the way it will be," Mr. Shamir said.  Israelis 'Will Respond' **********After the Cabinet meeting, a senior aide to Mr. Shamir, Health Minister Ehud Olmert, added: "When, how, in what form, how fast, where -- all those are questions we will answer at the proper time. But on the issue of whether we will respond, we will, and I don't think it could be otherwise." **********Israel has promised the United States that it will not carry out any pre-emptive attacks against Iraq, a favored Israeli tactic when threatened in the past. And Israelis could hardly feel more threatened than they do now. **********The nation is in near-war fever. Civil defense instructions now fill the airwaves, and almost everyone is preparing a shelter in his home, protected as best it can be against chemical attack. Thousands of Israelis and new immigrants who have not yet picked up their gas masks stood in long lines at distribution centers today. **********While the Americans worry that Israel might endanger the coalition, Israelis continue to complain that, until now, the United States has made no effort to coordinate Israeli and American military efforts. **********"There is a possibility, as many Israeli spokesmen already have admitted, that there might be some clashes between American forces, especially American airplanes, and Israeli airplanes, attacking the same target," said Gabi Sheffer, a political scientist at Hebrew University who specializes in American-Israeli relations. **********A senior Government official who has direct knowledge of the talks with Mr. Eagleburger and the others said that as soon as the Americans realized that Israel would refuse their request not to retaliate, the discussions moved to coordinating military responses, should Israel and the United States end up in the battle at the same time. **********"It will be a very, very crowded battlefield up there," the official said. **********At Washington's request, Israel has kept a low profile since the gulf crisis began. At the air base this afternoon, Mr. Arens said his Government would be happy to keep it that way. **********"We are not interested in getting involved," he said. "We hope we won't get involved. But if we are shot at, we will respond."  4 Guerrillas Killed in Clash **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 13 (Special to The New York Times) -- Four members of a militant Palestinian group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, have been killed in a clash with Israeli troops in southern Lebanon. **********The faction said in a statement that the guerrillas died early Saturday in a fight with an Israeli patrol inside the southern Lebanese buffer zone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/world.main_headline: Treaty Dispute With Soviets Causes Delay in Troop Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/world.print_headline: Treaty Dispute With Soviets Causes Delay in Troop Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/22/world.body_text: **********Negotiators at arms talks here agreed today to postpone further formal meetings toward a new round of talks until March 21 as a consequence of a dispute over a Soviet interpretation of the conventional arms treaty signed last November. **********The delay was suggested by NATO countries and unanimously approved in a plenary session of the 22 countries involved in the arms talks. The decision in effect halts the negotiations here, which were called for in the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe that was signed in Paris in November. The talks, which opened last week, are intended to reduce the number of troops in Europe and establish an aerial inspection system. **********NATO countries and most Eastern European countries have said the Soviet Union is misinterpreting the conventionalarmed forces treaty by trying to exempt some forces from the cuts by relabeling them as coastal defense or naval forces. Soviet officials have said that the conventional forces treaty did not cover coastal naval forces, while Western officials have argued that all land forces are subject to the treaty. **********Despite the decision today, Western negotiators said they would maintain informal contacts with the Soviet Union and would agree to meet again formally in a full session as soon as the Soviet Union changed its position. They also said that the Joint Consultative Group, a forum set up by the conventional forces treaty that handles the dispute over the Soviet interpretation, would continue to meet regularly. **********"Since the Soviets weren't really making it possible for us to do much substantive work we decided that the schedule of meetings should reflect that," one Western diplomat said. **********Concerning the dispute over the interpretation, a Western diplomat said: "We've now had two plenaries in which not only countries like the United States but also three Eastern European countries have made it clear that there is no support for the Soviet interpretation with respect to naval forces. Having done that, there was the question of how one can convey in procedural terms our dissatisfaction." **********The negotiators have usually held full sessions every week. Some negotiators stressed that the lack of formal meetings between now and March 21 would not seriously slow the talks because no proposals have yet been presented. But they said NATO negotiators in Brussels are nearing completion on a proposal for troop reductions and possibly on aerial inspections. **********The next meeting is now scheduled for March 21, the day before the end of the second round of these talks. The third round is scheduled to start in April.
