https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/busin.body_text: **********America's giant insurance companies are abandoning their cherished tradition of paternalism, cutting jobs on a scale almost unthinkable a few years ago. **********The cutbacks come after insurers have failed to improve results through more tentative means like dropping poorly performing insurance lines and brokers who yield the companies no profits. **********Several major companies have begun cutting back. The USF&G Corporation of Baltimore, with major losses in its real estate and "junk bond" portfolios, said earlier this month that it would reduce its work force by 2,800 people, or 25 percent, in 1991. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said it would offer early retirement to 4,000 of its 9,000 New York employees, and that 1,000 were expected to accept.  Other Recent Layoffs **********Others announced staff reductions in the previous months: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company is cutting 2,600 employees, or roughly 5.5 percent of its domestic work force; the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, 757 employees, or 11.7 percent of its total, and the Travelers Corporation, 1,000 employees, or 3 percent percent of its total. The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company has reportedly had heavy layoffs too, but declines to comment. **********Except for USF&G, the percentages of workers involved are not huge; together, the cutbacks amount to less than 1 percent of the 2.1 million people who, according to the Labor Department, worked in insurance as of Dec. 31. Many of the cuts came as companies left unprofitable insurance lines, like Aetna's decision to stop writing individual health policies. To the extent that these policies will be issued by others, the jobs eliminated by Aetna will be made up elsewhere. **********Nonetheless, the latest layoffs are the most severe that many in the industry remember. While they have cut their staffs before, the biggest insurers have long been known as benevolent parents, where most held onto their jobs in good times or bad. Insurers could get away with consistent staffing regardless of business volume because many were mutuals, owned by policyholders, not by investors. One insurer, Metropolitan Life, still gives employees a free hot lunch every day. **********Lately, returns in many insurance lines have worsened so much that even the most protective of insurers have begun to wield the ax. **********"For years, insurers viewed themselves as having a wider, statesmanlike position in America," said Sean Mooney, chief economist at the Insurance Information Institute, a New York trade group. "They would wage expensive campaigns against drunk driving and auto theft even if they hurt profits. Now that is changing. More and more, people running insurance companies are saying, 'This is a business, and it has got to be run for the bottom line.' " **********Behind the work-force reductions lies the toughest business environment insurers have faced in years. **********For life insurers, fierce competition from investment firms has made it much harder to win money-management business from pension funds. Lower prices for real estate and junk bonds have cut deeply into life insurers' investment returns. **********Property-and-casualty insurers, meanwhile, have been grappling with a fourth year of depressed premium levels for commercial liability policies. They face a continually expanding legal definition of liability. Many business liability insurers say they never dreamed of having to pay for pollution cleanup, an area of coverage that courts are often forcing them to provide. **********Auto insurance lines have their own problems, among them rate rollbacks by the states and soaring jury awards and medical costs. **********All this has taken a toll. According to the A.M. Best Company, a research firm based in Oldwick, N.J., property-and-casualty insurers reported an average return on shareholders' investment of 6.7 percent in 1990 -- up from 6.1 percent in 1989 but still well below what investment professionals say the insurers should be earning given their risks. **********Life insurers' returns were much better -- about 13 percent in 1989, by A.M. Best's most recent figure -- but still below the 17 percent to 20 percent that top-performing companies in other sectors generate. Industry experts say that life insurance returns fell sharply last year under the weight of junk bond defaults and continued weakness in real estate. **********All sides agree that the job reductions are needed to lift insurer returns, but not about whether the companies are cutting fat or muscle. Most consumer groups and some analysts have long said that many of the country's biggest insurers could stand a diet. **********"Most of these companies have not been very efficient," said Gloria Vogel, who follows the industry for Bear, Stearns & Company. "Among property-and-casualty companies, 30 percent of every premium dollar goes to expense." **********George G. C. Parker, who teaches about financial institutions at the Stanford Business School, says that many insurers became complacent. With the large amount of capital and the knowledge of regulations required to enter the industry, Professor Parker said, "insurers could afford to be a little sloppy in productivity and still earn a decent return." **********But Mr. Mooney of the Insurance Information Institute said that insurers' expense-to-revenue ratio was no worse than that of other industries. Banks spend about 30 percent of their interest income on overhead, department stores 35 percent and specialty stores 38.6 percent. More Layoffs Loom **********Alan Levin, the senior insurance specialist at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said that despite some seemingly high costs -- like agent's commissions equal to 15 percent of a policy's first-year premium -- the insurers are actually efficient. "There just are not that many excess people," he said. **********Most industry experts say that more layoff announcements loom, if only because the reductions announced so far will not allow the insurers to produce a more respectable 15 percent return on shareholders' money. Any savings will benefit insurance shareholders in the form of higher profits. Higher profits, in turn, will benefit policyholders in terms of the companies' ability to pay claims. **********But not all analysts believe that cutting jobs is the most sensible approach to improving returns. Most insurers continue to lose money on the insurance side of their business, profiting only by earnings on investments. **********"I find it amusing that in hard times the insurers focus on reducing overhead," said Michael Smith, the insurance analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. "They accept the fact that the expense that represents 75 percent of their outlays -- namely, claims payments -- cannot be controlled."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/world.main_headline: Kurds Frozen in Place at Iran's Frontier
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Kurds Frozen in Place at Iran's Frontier
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/13/world.body_text: **********Down a vast treeless bowl, high in northern Iran's mountains, an endless river of Kurdish exiles now seems almost frozen in place, by icy weather that has killed scores, by gas shortages that have immobilized hundreds of cars and vans, by stiff military security that has made passage to warmth and food on the plateau below a slow and agonizing process. **********The Iranian officials said 8,000 vehicles and 150,000 refugees fleeing Iraq and Saddam Hussein's army have traveled the mountain pass to Iran in the last eight days. Today, Iran's army was mounting a dogged effort to feed and shelter the hungry, half-clothed horde still making the trek. **********Convoys of Government trucks carried apples, cakes, biscuits and water to refugees trapped in the pass. A rusting orange shipping container doubled as pharmacy and transfer point for ambulances ferrying the sick to doctors in the town of Pyranshahr below.  Hobbling Throngs **********But the officials said hundreds of thousands were waiting to enter. For at least five miles, until the two-lane mountain road wound along the pass into Iraq's snowy peaks, the tarmac was clotted with vehicles and hobbling throngs of people. Refugees said it stretched for 40 more miles, past the Iraqi town of Diana, but there was no way to verify the assertion. **********During a Government-sponsored visit of several hours for reporters today, only a trickle of cars, vans and walking refugees made it through the five-mile no man's land separating Iraq's border and the Iranian checkpoint in the hills of Pyranshahr, **********It is uncertain why the parade, which officials say averaged 20,000 daily, had slowed. Pyranshahr's Mayor, Ahman Ziai, said the influx of refugees itself had disrupted relief efforts. "Some people are in such a hurry to enter they block the road," he said.  Search for Weapons **********But some refugees said the pace has been slowed by the Iranian military's insistence that each vehicle obtain a pass before entering Iran. Military guards subjected each Kurdish man to a hand search for weapons. The columns were halted by the convoys of relief trucks, which blocked off the road a few yards from the Iraqi border as they maneuvered to unload supplies. **********"Tell them the Government has to let us cross by car," said a Kurdish refugee from Erbil, a doctor who gave his name as Ibrahim. If cars are not given free passage, he said, the exodus could be blocked for two months more. **********The refugees have few days to spare. Mr. Ziai said they were being pelted nightly by snow and rain. Ten to 20 die daily along the road, he said, and 300 to 400 more have perished in his town. **********Kurds in the pass told stories of babies and old men dying of disease and exposure, and of fresh graves dug along the highway by grieving parents. Dr. Ibrahim said he had seen 10 dead babies and had treated his own 18-month-old daughter for gastroenteritis. **********Almost all the refugees said they had fled homes in Erbil, Kirkuk, Diana and Sulaimaniya in the last two weeks as the Iraqi Army snuffed out a rebellion by Kurds seeking autonomy in Iraq. **********Infants and toddlers make up much of the tide of refugees. In near-freezing weather braced by teeth-chattering winds, some of the youngsters and their mothers walked in mud without shoes or gloves. Many wore threadbare jackets. Those children who were not crying appeared numbed by the cold. **********To cope, the Kurds have converted their slow-moving column into a sort of long, narrow city. Trucks and cars alike carry bundles of brush, and huge scorched areas testify to bonfires lit nightly for the many who are not lucky enough to sleep in a vehicle. **********Today, walkers bathed muddy feet in streams of snowmelt that ran from the 1,800-foot mountains guarding each side of the mile-high pass. Iranian soldiers shooed youngsters from the hills, off the highway, which some refugees said were planted with land mines in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. **********Vehicle owners left their families to walk to Pyranshahr, where they bought jerrycans and gasoline and then retraced the several-mile path up the mountains to their stalled cars. Aid Called Too Little **********Several agreed today that they could walk to Iran with their families far more quickly than if they stayed with their cars, awaiting a military pass. But they said the vehicles offered shelter, heaters, and an investment with which to stake a new life in Iran. **********Iranian military officials said most of the refugees were being moved outside the traditionally Kurdish area of Iran and into two cities, Khoi and Maragheh, each 140 miles from the mountain pass. They said Pyranshahr lacked housing and food for them. **********Mr. Ziai, echoing leaders in Teheran, chided the outside world for its lack of assistance. Only a single planeload of seven tons of supplies from France had landed in his region. "The foreign aid is not going to help," the 31-year-old Mayor said. "It's a small amount." **********The Kurds in turn expressed gratitude for the stacks of yellow Iranian apples and boxes of sweet cakes that soldiers tossed from trucks, and which refugees carried to the far reaches of their column. Few of the exiles expected to return to Iraq any time soon. **********"They won't go back to their country until Saddam Hussein goes down," an Government interpreter quoted several as saying. "They say there isn't such a system as his anywhere."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/world.main_headline: Salvadoran Far-Right Leader Ill With Cancer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/world.print_headline: Salvadoran Far-Right Leader Ill With Cancer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/world.body_text: **********Roberto d'Aubuisson, the far-right leader accused of death-squad involvement in the early 1980's, who went on to build the dominant political party in El Salvador, is fighting what associates say is terminal cancer. **********The passing of Mr. d'Aubuisson, a hard-smoking, hard-drinking man with the style and image of a tough guy, would be likely to throw Salvadoran politics into disarray and could create confusion in the peace negotiations under way between the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani and leftist insurgents. **********The illness of the 48-year-old Mr. d'Aubuisson has been known since early this year, but until recent days neither he nor associates would confirm the seriousness of it. **********"It is a malignant tumor," Armando Calderon Sol, president of Mr. d'Aubuisson's party, said at a news conference today, Reuters reported. Mr. Calderon described the illness as "mortal." **********A foreign diplomat said recently, "Everybody in his party now speaks of him in the past tense." Two Growths Removed **********Politicians and diplomats in touch with Mr. d'Aubuisson's circle say that two malignant growths have been removed from his tongue since early this year and that cancerous growths have since spread to his throat and shoulder. **********He has been making frequent trips to Houston for radiation therapy. **********Mr. d'Aubuisson, a former Salvadoran Army intelligence officer once known for rough treatment of captured leftists, was thrown out of the army after reformist officers took power from a traditional military Government in October 1979, when the current civil war was threatening to explode. **********But after the new governing junta's agrarian reform and bank nationalizations angered the richest families in the country, Mr. d'Aubuisson began organizing an alliance of those families and dissident army officers who thought the junta was sympathetic to the growing guerrilla movement. **********The d'Aubuisson alliance was nearly as antagonistic to the Christian Democratic Party of Jose Napoleon Duarte, who eventually joined the junta, as it was to the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. **********In the wave of political killings that erupted in 1980 -- by most estimates, 10,000 people died that year in political violence -- Mr. d'Aubuisson and those around him were alleged to be responsible for several of the best-known cases.  Archbishop Assassinated **********One was the assassination of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero as he said Mass in a hospital chapel in 1980. There is strong circumstantial evidence linking people close to Mr. d'Aubuisson to the killing, but no charges were ever filed. He always vehemently denied the public accusations that Mr. Duarte made against him in the years before his own death from cancer in 1990. **********In 1982, Mr. d'Aubuisson organized a political party, the Nationalist Republican Alliance, known as Arena, and surprised his critics and opponents by finding strong popular support, even among the rural poor whom the guerrillas often claim to speak for. **********One of his campaign slogans was to equate the Christian Democrats, who were then dominant, to a watermelon: green on the outside and red on the inside. **********Since then, Mr. d'Aubuisson has been a leading figure in the Legislative Assembly, and in 1989 he saw his handpicked candidate, Mr. Cristiani, elected President. **********In recent years Mr. d'Aubuisson has come to be viewed as an astute politician in a country with few of those. He has developed a willingness to compromise, say members of other parties. **********One of his recent notable actions was to support the nomination and election of Ruben Zamora, formerly a member of the guerrillas' political organization, to be a vice president of the Assembly.  Concern About Power Struggle **********There is concern among other political leaders that Mr. d'Aubuisson's death would set off a power struggle among younger members of his party eager to earn their machismo ratings. **********"What worries some of us is the new generation of young men who haven't matured," said a diplomat, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "They might want to revert to his early '80's mantle." **********The same diplomat said Mr. d'Aubuisson had supported the peace talks under way with guerrilla leaders, and even from his sickbed in Houston had intervened several times in recent months to persuade the most hard-line members of his party to go along with various parts of the proposed accords. **********"His death would throw a new ingredient into a process where trust is important," the diplomat said. **********"Besides the uncertainty it will create for this Government," he added, "the guerrillas as well will feel the loss of Roberto d'Aubuisson. They need him to keep stability on the right during the peace talks, but also because with him gone they will no longer have the devil figure that they need to justify their own recalcitrance."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/25/busin.body_text: **********New orders for American-made machine tools plunged 32.4 percent in January from an unusually high level in December, according to a report to be released today by the industry's trade association. **********Industry analysts said that in addition to being skewed by the year-end surge in orders, the sharp decline stemmed from the weak demand that is typical in the winter months. **********The level of orders for new machine tools fell to $199.9 million in January, from the December level of $295.8 million, according to the Association for Manufacturing Technology. The December figure was the highest monthly level of 1990. **********The level of orders in January was virtually unchanged from that of January 1990. 'Orders Remained Firm' **********"At first glance, January orders look low when compared to the robust December figure," said Albert W. Moore, president of the association, which is based in McLean, Va. "But take a look at January a year ago, and you see a nearly identical first-of-the-year total. In spite of the uncertainty created by the current economy and the war in the Persian Gulf, machine tool orders remained firm." **********Machine tools are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in products ranging from appliances and cars to aircraft and construction materials. The strength of tool orders generally reflects the strength of industrial production, and economists consider patterns of machine tool sales to be important indicators of capital spending by manufacturers. **********Machine tool orders had risen 43.7 percent in December. Analysts attributed that big jump to increased demand from auto makers as they began to produce redesigned engines and other auto parts.  A Very Strong December **********"The January decline does not mean too much because December was inordinately strong as a result of new designs being released in Detroit," said William G. Copeland, president of Copeland Economic Group, an economic consulting firm in Stamford, Conn. "Also, there was so much uncertainty in the marketplace due to expectations about the war in the Persian Gulf, which caused people to hold off on their purchase of new machine tools. People wanted to wait to see how the economy would shape up." **********Orders from foreign customers were particularly strong last year, as the depressed value of the United States dollar made the prices of American machine tools very attractive in overseas markets. **********In recent months, machine tool industry executives have said that demand has increased from an array of industries. And they have predicted that American companies will spend more this year to improve their manufacturing operations. Orders for Metal-Cutting Tools **********Orders for metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, dropped 27 percent in January from the December level. Compared with January of last year, new orders for metal-cutting tools were down 7.9 percent. That segment of the industry typically accounts for three-fourths of new orders. **********Orders for metal-forming tools plunged 40.6 percent in January from the December level. Compared with January of last year, metal-forming orders were up 12.2 percent. **********The backlog of orders for machine tools stood at $1.48 billion in January, up from $1.46 billion in December. The backlog in January 1990 was $1.77 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Battery System For Electric Cars
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.body_text: **********The Nissan Motor Company and the Japan Storage Battery Company said they had jointly developed new batteries and a recharging system for electric vehicles that could reduce recharging time by 80 percent. The system can recharge the newly developed nickel-cadmium batteries to 40 percent capacity in 6 minutes and newly developed lead-acid batteries to full capacity in 12 minutes, Nissan said. **********The auto maker said it was developing a prototype electric car that would use this system. Lengthy battery recharging time has restricted the practical use of electric cars because it limits driving range. Executives of the Big Three auto makers in the United States told Congress last week that Americans would not choose electric vehicles over gasoline-powered cars and trucks until problems of cost, range and battery-recharging time were resolved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/12/busin.body_text: **********The assets of the nation's 551 money market mutual funds increased by $5.1 billion, to $457.6 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The 202 institutional funds' assets rose by $2.69 billion, to $129.99 billion. The assets of the 259 general-purpose funds were up by $401.2 million, to $177.85 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds' assets increased by $2.01 billion, to $149.76 billion, the institute said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/busin.main_headline: Washington at Work; A Crusader Driven by Outrage
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/busin.print_headline: Washington at Work; A Crusader Driven by Outrage
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/busin.body_text: **********Jack A. Blum, for 25 years a Washington lawyer, Senate investigator and doggedly liberal Democratic muckraker, uncovered early signs of wrongdoing by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International in 1988. He was serving a two-year stint as chief investigator for Senator John F. Kerry's Foreign Relations subcommittee. **********Back at the subcommittee early this month, this time as a witness at televised hearings on fraud and corruption at B.C.C.I., Mr. Blum unleashed an accusation that propelled him and the Massachusetts Democrat onto the evening news: the Bush Administration had soft-pedaled its criminal inquiry into B.C.C.I. despite abundant evidence of misdeeds by the bank. More Recent Charges **********Only recently, Mr. Blum made virtually identical charges against Senator Kerry's chief patron, Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. **********The Los Angeles Times reported in March that Mr. Blum "believes that lobbying and financial contributions" to Senators Pell and Kerry by Clark M. Clifford, the Democratic Party insider now enmeshed in the B.C.C.I. scandal, "may have cost him his job" as chief investigator for the Kerry subcommittee. Days later, a Boston Herald article quoted Mr. Blum as calling Senator Pell a "clunker" who was "utterly hostile" to the B.C.C.I. inquiry. **********In a long interview last week, Mr. Blum denied making the accusation, said that The Los Angeles Times had misstated his suspicions, and asserted that The Boston Herald had misquoted him. ("I didn't call him a clunker.") Besides, he said, he does not believe Senator Pell can be swayed by political money. **********But in the next breath, Mr. Blum added: Senator Pell has "forgotten the role of the Foreign Relations Committee" as a watchdog over the White House, and that the panel could use more "crockery breakers" like Mr. Blum himself. **********The episode speaks volumes. Friends call the 50-year-old Mr. Blum the original gumshoe -- a tenacious, moralistic crusader who produces charges of high-level corruption like a grinding wheel throws off sparks. Critics -- and a few friends -- say his accusations sometimes land with about the same accuracy and too often burn innocent bystanders. **********Mr. Blum does have an acute sense of drama. In his testimony this month, he hinted that his inquiries had led B.C.C.I. to wage a smear campaign against him, to tail him with a private detective and to tap his telephone. **********Ultimately, he said, he was warned by law-enforcement friends that his life was in danger. "I thought under the circumstances the risk was worth it," Mr. Blum testified, deadpan. **********What is unique about Mr. Blum is that he was not joking. **********"Jack had, and he clearly retains, what is an increasingly rare commodity in Washington these days: moral outrage," said one admirer, Karin Lissakers, a lecturer in political science at Columbia University who worked with Mr. Blum in the Senate in the 1970's. "He was a    very    good investigator." **********Mr. Blum was a Roman candle of allegations at the witness table when he testified: the Central Intelligence Agency's covert war in Afghanistan had been corrupted by B.C.C.I.-related arms thievery; B.C.C.I. had been the "original banker" to Oliver North's secret arms enterprise; the Federal Reserve had a secret list of American officials whom B.C.C.I. had paid off; the World Bank and Latin American leaders were enmeshed in the bank's web of deceit. **********Senate aides say that proof of some of those and other charges is in hand and only awaits the proper moment to be revealed. But the Federal Reserve has since denied that it has a list, and Iran-contra records show that a Geneva concern, not B.C.C.I., had set up and ran the finances of Mr. North's arms network. **********And the Senate Intelligence Committee aide who monitored the C.I.A.'s Afghan program in the 1980's, David Holliday, said he had investigated Mr. Blum's charges of corruption and found them baseless. **********"It's very easy to make those kinds of broad, sweeping accusatory statements and then let them bounce around with nothing to back it up or support it," he said. "It's another matter when people who make those kinds of statements are pinned down to come up with hard evidence." **********Said Mr. Blum: "I heard this from ex-B.C.C.I. employees. God bless him if he's found otherwise. But that's not what I'm being told."  Aflame Over Injustice **********Now a lawyer in private practice, Mr. Blum has been out of the Congressional investigative detective business for years. But he says he has been besieged by calls from clients and old colleagues about his B.C.C.I. detective work and he still comes across in person as a man aflame over the world's injustice and more than a little impatient with those who fail to do something about it. **********He rails against the White House ("I'd like to meet the guy there who made the calculated decision that this number of people should die from crack and heroin so we could have a victory in Central America."), the Justice Department ("They used every tool at their disposal to slow us down.") and the Senate under George Bush's thumb. ("Here are subpoena rights that Congress has, a central part of the constitutional process, that have been allowed to atrophy.") **********Mr. Blum's colleagues on the Foreign Relations Committee have virtually nothing to say publicly about his work from 1987 to 1989 for Senator Kerry's Subcommitte on Terrorism, Narcotics and International Operations. "On the record, Jack Blum was on the mark about B.C.C.I. as an investigator," one former supervisor, Jonathan M. Winer, said in a brief interview. Starting Off in Journalism **********Mr. Blum got his start as an investigator by founding a crusading newspaper near Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He sold it after he concluded that local journalism was financially too demanding, too objective and too toothless. He went to law school and landed at the Federal Communications Commission. **********Within months, Mr. Blum said, he had roiled the agency. When the newspaper columnist Jack Anderson heard of his complaints about waste and rubber-stamp renewal of broadcasting licenses and printed them -- and his name -- Mr. Blum says he began to feel unwelcome. **********He went to the Senate, where he spent seven years on a Judiciary subcommittee in an unsuccessful legislative crusade to break up the major oil companies and other locuses of corporate power before moving on to a Foriegn Relations panel and an investigation into the influence of multinational corporations on American foreign policy. **********There, he hit his stride, staging some of the splashiest hearings of the 1970's: on the ITT Corporation's efforts to rig national elections in Chile, the Lockheed Corporation's bribery of Japanese and Middle Eastern officials, big oil companies' attempts to shape American policy in the Middle East, and Arab nations' "recycling" of oil profits through international banks. **********"It was a somewhat innocent time, when the bounders and crooks were just beginning to take root," he said. Private Law Practice **********He tired of the growing rigidity and pomposity of the Senate, he said, and entered private law practice in 1976, helping small gasoline marketers in battles with big oil companies. On the side, he advised a liberal research organization, the International Center for Development Policy, on third world issues. **********By the mid-1980's, he was helping the center investigate Mr. North's secret role in the contras' war in Nicaragua. Senator Kerry, also pursuing Mr. North, hired Mr. Blum in 1987 to head a broad inquiry into whether the White House had winked at drug-dealing by anti-Communist allies in Central America like Manuel Noriega. **********The reliability of some of that inquiry's less reputable witnesses became an object of nagging doubt, then hot dispute, said several Senate aides who spoke on condition of anonymity. But on the other fruits of the investigation -- the B.C.C.I. scandal -- no one disputes Mr. Blum's investigative nose.  A Convincing Interview **********An interview with a retired B.C.C.I. official left Mr. Blum convinced that the bank was involved in criminal activities and that it secretly controlled American financial instututions, including the biggest banking company in Washington, where Mr. Clifford, the Washington lawyer, was chairman. **********Mr. Blum relayed those suspicions to the Justice Department, which won a delay in Mr. Blum's subpoenas, arguing that they threatened the department's own investigations of B.C.C.I., of General Noriega and of drug-money laundering. **********Eventually, the material was produced, but it fell far short of Mr. Blum's expectations. **********"My unhappiness became acute when we got to the end and it was clear there was a rush to get the investigation off the premises," said Mr. Blum, whose contract with the Senate panel expired in April 1989. But he insisted that it was not his impatience with Senators Pell and Kerry, but with the Justice Department, that then led him to go directly to Robert Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, and lay out his case against B.C.C.I. **********"He said that for various reasons the Senate was not going to be able to go forward and do an investigation," Mike Cherkasky, head of Mr. Morgenthau's investigative division, said in a telephone interview. Indictments Won in July **********Mr. Blum had left Senator Kerry a memo detailing the allegations against B.C.C.I.. The subcommittee pursued the case until Mr. Morgenthau won indictments in July. **********When Senator Kerry held his own televised hearings on the scandal this month, his first act was to thank Senator Pell "for the consistent support that he has provided me." **********Then he summoned Mr. Blum to testify about his investigation of the bank. **********"When they can produce more than I've produced," Mr. Blum said last week of his critics, "then let 'em talk." A large part of his job, he says, is to draw attention to wrongdoing, and he does not pretend that each jot or tittle of his complaints is entirely accurate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/world.main_headline: Fight Over Water Rights in India Threatens Government Coalition
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/world.print_headline: Fight Over Water Rights in India Threatens Government Coalition
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/world.body_text: **********A dispute over river water-sharing between two southern Indian states erupted into a bitter confrontation today, shaking the minority Government of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao as the states held rival Government-organized strikes and lawmakers revolted. **********The confrontation between a defiant Congress Party Government in Karnataka state and a regional party backed by Congress in the neighboring state of Tamil Nadu gave Mr. Rao's Government its sharpest political test since it took office last month. **********The turmoil embarrassed the ruling party by dividing it between supporters and opponents of more water for Tamil Nadu from the Cauvery River, an issue that has troubled relations between the two states for much of this century. The water is needed to irrigate dry farmland in the delta of the Cauvery, which flows from its headwaters in Karnataka to the Bay of Bengal. More than 60,000 farming families are affected, one lawmaker said. Lawmakers Threaten to Quit **********P. N. Narayanan, a leader of the Tamil party that governs Tamil Nadu, said, "The rights of the Tamils are more important than anything else, including this Government." **********Last month, the party, the All-India Anna Dravidra Muthera Kaghazam, allied with Congress to win a major victory in the Tamil Nadu elections. Today, 11 lawmakers from the regional group threatened to quit their seats, a move that would reduce pro-Congress strength to less than 230 in the 511-member ruling house of Parliament. Congress lawmakers from the state met Prime Minister Rao to demand tough action against Chief Minister S. Bangarappa. **********Congress and regional party legislators stormed out of the upper house of Parliament demanding the central Government's immediate intervention. Mr. Rao scheduled a visit to Tamil Nadu on Saturday to tackle the problem. **********Karnataka has denounced a judicial panel's recent interim award on water sharing and passed a law on Thursday night to protect the state's interests. **********The waters of the Cauvery, one of India's major rivers, have been troubled by disputes for decades although a 50-year agreement between the two neighboring states was concluded during British rule in 1924. That accord ended in 1974 and since then the two sides have resisted each other's demands for more water in tortuous legal and political battles. **********A tribunal, set up by New Delhi and agreed to by both disputing governments, was empowered to settle the dispute. Last month, the tribunal announced its interim ruling. Karnataka described the award as discriminatory and organized a statewide strike that disrupted airline services and transportation and closed markets, Government offices and educational institutions. **********A similar protest, demanding the water for farmers in the delta of the Cauvery, shut most of Tamil Nadu state today, reports said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/busin.main_headline: F.C.C. TAKES STEPS TO COMBAT ABUSES ON '900' NUMBERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/busin.print_headline: F.C.C. TAKES STEPS TO COMBAT ABUSES ON '900' NUMBERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/15/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission proposed rules today aimed at preventing fraud and deceit by companies that provide information and services through "900" telephone lines. **********There are "900" numbers that provide everything from stock quotations and sports scores to titillating sexual messages. They are among the fastest-growing segments of the telephone industry and are expected to generate revenues of more than $1 billion this year. But they have also garnered thousands of complaints from consumers who say they were misled about what they received and what they had to pay. **********Typically, advertisements are run to encourage people to obtain information by calling a number beginning with "900." The calls cost anywhere from less than a dollar to more than $50, and charges are incurred as soon as a customer dials the number. Hang-Up Option Sought **********Under the new proposal, providers of "900" services would be required to introduce each call with an explanation of the prices and the services. The customer would then have a brief period to hang up without being charged for the call. **********The commission will accept comments from the public over the next several months and is expected to issue a final order before the end of the year. **********Representives of "900" services quickly protested the plan, saying the preamble would prompt many people to hang up without good reason, would annoy customers and would unnecessarily hamper the business. "If you've got criminals and crooks breaking the law, throw the bums in jail, but don't throw the baby out with the bath water," said Bruce J. Fogel, chairman of Phone Programs Inc., of New York City, which provides sports and a variety of information on "900" lines throughout the country.  Proposal Called Reasonable **********But George Vinall, director of regulatory and external affairs for Telesphere Communications Inc., a long-distance carrier that relays the calls for many "900" companies, said, "Based on what was in the commission's press announcement, I thought what they are proposing was eminently reasonable." **********The proposal would also require local telephone companies to allow customers to block all access to "900" numbers in their homes. The provision is a response to complaints by parents who say that their children rack up huge bills by calling such numbers without understanding the costs involved. The measure is not opposed by the industry, which does not consider it to be as onerous as the preamble proposal, **********The F.C.C. proposal would also require companies providing "900" service to instruct children in the preamble to hang up if they have not received parental permission to make the call. **********Finally, local telephone companies would not be allowed to cut off telephone service to customers who refuse to pay their "900" bills. The charges for such calls are automatically listed on a customer's local telephone bill, and the amounts collected are then distributed to the information providers. **********The F.C.C. has jurisdiction over interstate calls, like those usually made on "900" lines. Local pay-per-call services, mostly on lines with "976" and "540" prefixes which provide similar information as that offered on the national "900" numbers, are not under the commission's jurisdiction but are regulated by state utilities. **********The commission also asked for comment today on similar rules for "700" party lines, which allow many people to participate in group conversations and often involve interstate calls. And it also sought comment on the possibility of restricting computerized marketing systems that dial numbers automatically and play long sales pitches.  Many Legitimate Services **********To be sure, most of the new "900" services are entirely legitimate, and recognizing that, the commissioners emphasized that they did not want to put the industry out of business with overly burdensome rules. Yet the F.C.C.'s action reflects a growing concern among Government officials and in Congress about abuses by pay-per-call services. **********The Federal Trade Commission, which has authority over deceptive and fraudulent marketing practices, has sued to stop operations at four companies since last July, accusing them of deceptive practices in connection with using pay-per-call services to tout job listings and gold credit cards. Officials say more investigations are under way. Congress, meanwhile, is weighing legislation that would impose restraints similar to those proposed by the F.C.C., as well as some additional ones. **********In one of the F.T.C. cases, the agency charged that Transworld Courier Service Inc. of Roswell, Ga., ran newspaper ads offering construction jobs and listing a toll-free number for applicants. The civil suit contended that callers were then instructed to call "900" numbers without being told they would be charged $18 a call. In one case, F.T.C. officials said, a person made repeated calls, running up a bill of $180. The F.T.C. won a temporary court order freezing the company's assets and ordering it to stop such practices, but the litigation is still in progress. No one answered calls to Transworld. **********In another case, the F.T.C. said that two Baltimore companies, First Capital Financial Inc. and Midas Financial, had advertised on television and in newspapers that people who called a special number would get gold credit cards similar to those offered by American Express or Mastercard. The call itself cost $49.95, and callers received a card that could be used to buy goods only from catalogues distributed by the two companies. The F.T.C. also won court orders to freeze the firms' assets and stop those activities. Phone listings could not be found today for either company. **********Members of Congress are weighing legislation that would include the F.C.C. proposals and several other provisions. A bill sponsored by Representative Bart Gordon, Democrat of Tennessee, would require the long-distance companies that relay calls for "900" services to review the advertising content of messages being relayed. Another provision would place a price cap on "900" services directed at children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds; The Allure of 'Dull' Little Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds; The Allure of 'Dull' Little Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Their cluttered offices are just a few steps from Central Park, in the heart of Manhattan, but their true address could be Main Street, U.S.A. Listen to how money managers Chuck Royce and Tom Ebright describe their favorite stocks. Mr. Ebright: "Not sexy, not exciting, real Middle America." Mr. Royce: "We don't own anything that ends with 'tech.' " **********Funds that specialize in small companies usually buy stocks that are, well, sexy and exciting and often end with "tech." But at the $125 million Royce Value Trust, the $150 million Royce Fund and the managers' flagship $500 million Pennsylvania Mutual Fund, small "dull" companies are the gist of things. **********The two managers depart from another small-company tradition, too. They keep a tight lid on risk -- and that makes them a good bet for risk-averse investors who nevertheless want to tap into the long-awaited small-company rally that began last month. **********"They're not gunslingers; they buy cheap, high-quality companies, which explains why they do well in the long term," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., a Chicago-based mutual fund consulting firm. **********How has this contrarian approach worked? Very badly in 1990, when Pennsylvania Mutual dropped 11.5 percent, compared with a 10.8 percent drop in all small-company funds, according to Morningstar. But superbly over time: The fund has a one-and-a-half percentage-point edge over its peers for the five years ended Dec. 31, 1990. Over 10 years, it had an average annual return of 13.6 percent, compared with 7.1 percent for all small-company funds and 10.7 percent for all stock funds. **********Part of the dismal 1990 performance was a result of the fund's huge portfolio, several hundred stocks divided among various industries and companies, a division meant to lower risk. The fund's biggest holding equals less than 1 percent of its assets, a philosophy at odds with most small-company funds, which tend to make big bets, hoping for big returns, by owning fewer stocks. **********Another part comes from Pennsylvania Mutual's lack of high-flying stocks, especially in last year's winning biotech sector, combined with the general slump in small-company stocks. **********"Tech" stocks are favorites of most small-company funds, which usually are run by managers who -- unlike the Royce-Ebright duo -- fall into the growth or emerging growth camps. Small companies that develop new products or services can experience explosive growth because they start from such a small base. On the other hand, these investments are very volatile and can fall as hard as they rise. **********Mr. Royce, who is 51 years old, and Mr. Ebright, 46, are value managers who look for discrepancies between a company's worth and its market price. "When we do our analysis, we focus on how much we can lose, not on how much money we can make," Mr. Royce said. Their dream holding, he said, is "a small company in a basic industry, growing 10 percent annually, that looks dowdy because it's very financially conservative." **********As Mr. Ebright put it, "We buy companies with low leverage and excess cash flow. And to lower risk, we stick with lesser-known companies and avoid the high-traffic stocks, which have large institutional ownership and are very volatile." **********Clearly, they have a long-term view. Their average holding period is four or five years, among the longest in the industry, and they have owned one stock, the Block Drug Company, of Jersey City, N.J., for 15 years. Block, whose main products are Poli-Grip and Dentu-Grip, over-the-counter dental products, is a low-cost producer with high margins and low expenses. **********Another favorite: Farmer Brothers, a Torrance, Calif.-based distributor of coffee and spices with the dominant market share of institutional coffee sales on the West Coast.  The two managers also like the Pittsburgh-based Mine Safety Appliances Company, which started out manufacturing safety goggles, then expanded to hard hats and air-quality monitoring devices. As workplace safety became more of an issue, the company's market grew, Mr. Ebright says. **********International Aluminum, of Monterey, Calif., which makes aluminum-extruded products like window frames and storefronts, is another pick. The business is perceived as cyclical because it is associated with housing starts and business cycles. But the company is well managed and earnings have risen over the last 10 years, Mr. Ebright said. **********Lately, Mr. Royce and Mr. Ebright have been buying into the Boston-based State Street Bank. It gets about two-thirds of revenues from securities processing and record keeping fees from mutual funds and pension funds -- and thus, unlike most banks, is not dependent on interest income, less vulnerable to local and industry problems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/busin.main_headline: Wall Street; Maintaining a Healthy Skepticism on HMO America
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/busin.print_headline: Wall Street; Maintaining a Healthy Skepticism on HMO America
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/03/busin.body_text: **********Despite lackluster performance by most health maintenance organizations -- H.M.O.'s, for short -- some brokerage houses are optimistic about the robust profits at HMO America, expected to announce quarterly results this week. **********But skeptics say the Chicago-based company's earnings growth has coincided with a drop in its reserves to cover future claims. Indeed, reserves for claims "incurred but not reported," has barely budged since 1989, despite sharp growth in revenue and membership. David Citron, a company vice president, said the lower reserves are justified because the company is paying reported claims faster, reducing the uncertainty it faces. **********The Illinois Insurance Department, which is currently auditing the company, has raised questions about reserve practices before, Mr. Citron said, "but we have answered them, we think, to their satisfaction." But James Hanson, assistant deputy insurance director, said he has been corresponding with HMO America since summer about issues that "have not yet been resolved."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world.body_text: **********If Arabs and Israelis decide to make deals, not war, how much does the Israeli economy stand to gain? **********Nobody has a remotely reliable estimate, said Michael Bruno, governor of Israel's central bank. Nobody is suggesting, said Dan Halperin, an Israeli consultant in Tel Aviv, that "lifting the boycott today will have a major impact tomorrow." **********And while an Israeli business group said this week that the boycott has cost Israel more than $36 billion since 1948, some Government officials, like Amnon Neubach, the Israeli economic counselor in Washington, say they are not sure that the Arab ban has hurt Israel measurably. **********Egypt and Saudi Arabia had proposed ending the 43-year-old economic boycott of Israel if Israel freezes further settlements in the West Bank. Israel has rejected that proposal, but if the talk about peace produces any agreements with Syria and Jordan, the boycott could start to come down. **********The Arab ban covers all direct trade with Israel, dealings with most companies that do business with Israel, as well as with firms that buy or sell to, or invest in, companies that do business with Israel.  Boom Not Expected **********Economists, investment experts and executives, including Mr. Bruno and Mr. Halperin, argue that, in time, ending the boycott could lift confidence among foreign investors, stimulate more service ventures, and improve the prospects for Palestinian exporters in the West Bank and in Gaza. **********To be sure, economists are not predicting an Israeli export boom in the region. Most Israeli exports -- diamonds, electronics, pharmaceuticals -- are geared to upscale markets in Europe and the United States, not to neighbors like Jordan or Syria whose living standards are roughly one-tenth of Israel's. **********Trade between Israel and Egypt, except for oil, remains negligable more than a decade after Egypt broke ranks with other Arab nations and dropped out of the boycott. Besides, the most eager buyers and sellers on either side of the Israeli-Arab divide are already finding ways to make hundreds of millions of dollars worth of transactions regardless. **********The biggest benefit for the Israeli economy, said Walter P. Stern, a New York investment adviser, is likely to be an intangible one, greater investor confidence. The end of the boycott would be "a long term signal of Israel's re-entry into the world as a legitimate place to trade and invest." 'Psychological Barriers' **********Jean Abi Nader of the United States Arab Chamber of Commerce said, "It would lift psychological barriers to companies that want to do business in both markets." **********Multinationals that have refrained from making investments in Israel -- especially Japanese, Korean and French firms -- may take a second look, Israeli economists say. With a few exceptions like I.B.M. and Motorola, foreign direct investment is small. **********"You would see the involvement in Israel of more multinational companies, especially in industries where you don't see them at all," said Dan Halperin an Israeli consultant in Tel Aviv. "It will also become easier for Israeli firms to buy knowhow from international companies." **********What is more, Israel's credit rating could get a welcome boost, Mr. Bruno said. Lenders, he said, would likely be less reluctant to risk their funds. Israel is struggling to create jobs for hundreds of thousands of new Soviet immigrants and is looking to the rest of the world to supply some of the needed investment.  High-Skilled Labor Advantage **********Consumers in Saudi Arabia or Syria may not be about to start stocking up on Israeli brands for which there are easy substitutes, economists say. But, Israeli services, from computer programming and insurance to medical services and tourism and agricultural may find a more ready reception. **********"Israel has a comparative advantage in services because of its high skilled labor," said Leonardo Liederman, an economist at Tel Aviv University. With the influx of Soviet doctors, engineers and scientists, such services are apt to become even more affordable and abundant. **********The total volume of imports and exports could swell by $1 billion if the boycott ends, said Haim Ben-Shahar, professor of economist at Tel Aviv University. Total trade last year was about $37 billion. **********Surprisingly, some of the biggest winners of a cease-fire in the Arab economic war against Israel could be Palestinians in the Gaza and West Bank. Small businesses there produce things that Arab neighbors can afford to buy -- fruit, vegetables, olive oil, cut stone, clothing and shoes. **********"These are natural traders," said Howard Rosen, an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "The boycott hurt Palestinian trade much more than Israel's." **********Palestininas now find their exports to Arab countries blocked for a variety of reasons related to the boycott, like relying on Israeli ports, using inputs made in Israel or being required by the Israeli Government to sell produce through Israeli cooperatives. **********"I could imagine an export boom," said Peter Gubser, president of Near East Refugee Aid. "You'd see a lot of products with some Israeli inputs going out under a West Bank label." **********A spurt in export-related production on the West Bank and in Gaza would be blessing because, due to the Palestinian uprising as well as the Soviet immigrant wave, unemployment among Palestinians is rising.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Blue Cross of California said it was negotiating to offer health insurance to 25,000 policyholders of the Great Republic Insurance Company, the troubled insurer that was seized by state regulators this week. The California Insurance Commissioner, John Garamendi, said he was trying to place Great Republic's 6,800 life insurance policies with those of another insurer. **********The health insurance policyholders of Great Republic, whose assets exceeded its liabilities by $454,000 when it was seized this week, will continue to receive full benefits and payments. Life insurance policies will continue to pay full death benefits. **********For the time being, investors cannot cash out or borrow against policies issued by the Great Republic, which is based in Santa Barbara.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/25/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; A New President at Putnam
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/25/busin.body_text: **********David Shanks has been named president of the Putnam Berkley Group Inc. **********The promotion is to be announced today by Phyllis Grann, the chief executive, who is taking on the additional title of chairman of the book publishing company. **********Mr. Shanks, 44 years old, joined the company in 1979 and became president of the Berkley Publishing Group in 1985. Ms. Grann said Berkley Publishing increased its revenues more than fivefold under the direction of Mr. Shanks. **********Ms. Grann, 54, became president of Putnam Berkley in 1986 and chief executive in 1987. Mr. Shanks will take over Ms. Grann's title as president. **********The Putnam Berkley Group is owned by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Corporation, which acquired it as part of its purchase of MCA Inc. last year. **********The group consists of G. P. Putnam Sons, a publisher of hardback general-interest books; Perigee Books, a publisher of general-interest paperbacks; Putnam & Grossett, a publisher of children's books, and the Berkley Publishing Group, which includes Berkley Books, Jove, Diamond, Ace Science Fiction and Fantasy paperbacks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/18/busin.main_headline: Your Money; Raising Returns With Less Risk
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/18/busin.print_headline: Your Money; Raising Returns With Less Risk
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/18/busin.body_text: **********A low-risk, high-return portfolio sounds like an investor's impossible dream, but proponents of "asset allocation" theory contend that a properly diversified portfolio can indeed bring solid returns while minimizing risk. **********Bertram J. Schaeffer, a director of Ernst & Young who addressed the New York Chapter of the International Association for Financial Planning, examined the performance of different assets from 1971 through 1990. **********In that 20 years inflation ran at an annual rate of 6.26 percent, he said, while the compound annual return of Treasury bills was 7.66 percent, long-term Government bonds 8.71 percent, stocks as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index 11.15 percent and gold 12.44 percent. The gold figures, of course, were skewed in the 1970's when the dollar was no longer tied to the gold standard, and gold subsequently surged; in the 1980's it lost 3.98 percent in value. **********"A client seeing this may just decide, 'I should put all my money in the stock market,' " he said. But that could be the wrong decision because of the market's volatility. The market could well be down just when the investor needed the money. **********The way to iron out that volatility is to diversify, putting money in assets that hold their own during economic cycles when stocks are being pummeled. Using charts and numbers from Ibbotson Associates, Mr. Schaeffer said a portfolio that was split into 20 percent Treasury bills, 28 percent long-term Government bonds, 47 percent stocks and 5 percent gold would have yielded 10.39 percent over the 20 years. At the same time, its volatility, as measured by standard deviation, would have been 9.26 percent, compared with 16.13 percent for the stock portfolio. **********Every $1,000 invested in the diversified portfolio would have grown to $7,221, while every $1,000 in a pure stock portfolio would have grown to $8,283. By reducing my return 14 percent, I've reduced volatility 43 percent," he said. **********That particular asset mix is not a formula for everyone. Mr. Schaeffer advised investment professionals to allocate assets for individuals after assessing their risk tolerance, investment objectives and profiling such personal characteristics as age and stage in career, liquidity requirements, size of portfolio, annual cash flow and tax bracket. **********Many people, fearful of the risk of losing money in the stock market, retreat to the perceived safety of Treasury bills or money-market funds, he noted, overlooking the risk of inflation. After taxes, "history suggests that Treasury bills will not outperform inflation," he said. **********The way to prevent the real value of holdings from being eroded by inflation, he said, is to accept other risks -- market, business, interest-rate, credit and liquidity risks -- and to balance one against the other by careful asset allocation, using technologies available today. **********After Mr. Schaeffer's talk, four investment professionals discussed asset allocation. **********Martin Jaffe, senior vice president and chief operating officer of Wood, Struthers & Winthrop, the investment management subsidiary of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said, "Today it is cheaper to have an individual manager than a mutual fund." **********An individually managed portfolio can be sensitive to the investor's corporate holdings and tax situation, he said, and importantly for fixed-income investments, a direct holding provides the protection of maturity not present in funds. **********Dick Rubenstein, representing the Oppenheimer Asset Allocation Fund, described the sophisticated strategies a large fund is able to use. These include interest rate futures and derivative securities to control risk and investments in international markets for diversification and the potential of higher returns, like those now enjoyed by Canadian bonds. **********"You have to discipline yourself to buy when it's bad and lighten up when it's good," he said, "because the mrket is a discount mechanism -- not looking at what's going on but where it's going." **********Lewis J. Altfest, president of L. J. Altfest & Company, financial and investment advisers, replied to a question about commodities in a diversified portfolio. "In theory they really belong, but there are obscene transaction costs," he said. "You can get wiped out in commodities very easily." **********Michael D. Hirsch, president of M. D. Hirsch Investment Management Inc., allocates clients' assets through mutual funds, combining 10, 20 or 30 in a portfolio. Some people ask if that is not overdiversification, he said. "Probably, if the goal is to maximize return," he continued. "Our goal is to minimize loss. In 16 years our balanced portfolios have never had a single loss."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Phone-Service Theft Surges at Companies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/28/busin.body_text: **********A growing epidemic of telephone fraud is leaving companies and other organizations with bills for hundreds of thousands of dollars of calls they did not make, and is forcing the users of sophisticated phone equipment to scramble for better ways to lock out high-technology phone thieves. **********The industry has long been plagued by sophisticated users who found ways to tap into phone company lines or people who used stolen credit card numbers to make calls without paying for them. **********This latest wave is being carried out by people who break into the computerized systems that organizations use to route calls and manage their telephone lines. **********The thieves often obtain the necessary codes for entering the systems from employees inside a company, rummaging through its trash or by experimenting with various combinations of numbers. **********The new form of electronic theft has surged in recent years, in part because the long-distance telephone companies have tightened security over their own networks. That has made it harder to use stolen credit cards and other devices to tap into phone company lines directly without authorization. **********In search of easier targets, intruders have shifted their focus to office systems known as PBX's, which stands for private branch exchanges. **********"It is by far the largest segment of communications fraud," said Rami Abuhamdeh, an independent consultant and until recently executive director of the Communications Fraud Control Association in McLean, Va. "You have all this equipment just waiting to answer your calls, and it is being run by people who are not in the business of securing telecommunications." **********While there are no precise measures of how widespread the new problem is, scores of corporations and other organizations have fallen victim to such crime in the last several years. The Mitsubishi International Corporation reported losing $430,000 last summer, mostly from calls to Egypt and Pakistan. The Procter & Gamble Company lost $300,000 in l988. The New York City Human Resources Administration lost $529,000 in l987. And the Secret Service, which investigates such telephone crime, says it is now receiving three to four formal complaints every week, and is adding more telephone specialists. Carrier Backed by F.C.C. **********Some victims have tried to make the phone companies or the equipment makers shoulder the costs, but they have had little success. In its only ruling on the issue thus far, the Federal Communications Commission decided in May that the long-distance carrier was entitled to collect the bill for illegal calls from the company that was victimized. **********In the closely watched Mitsubishi case filed in June, the company sued the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for $10 million in the Federal District Court in Manhattan, arguing that not only had it made the equipment through which outsiders entered Mitsubishi's phone system, but that A.T.& T., the maker of the switching equipment, had also been paid to maintain the equipment.  Financially Overwhelming **********For smaller companies, with fewer resources than Mitsubishi, the problems can be financially overwhelming. For example, the WRL Group, a small software development company in Arlington, Va., found itself charged for 5,470 calls it did not make this spring after it installed a toll-free "800" telephone number and a voice mail recording system machine to receive incoming calls. Within three weeks, the intruders had run up a bill of $106,776. to U S Sprint, a United Telecommunications unit. **********WRL's customers had barely begun to use the new numbers before the phones took on a life of their own. Hundreds of calls suddenly started pouring in, mostly from the New York metropolitan area. Instead of trying to reach the company, however, callers essentially hijacked the phone line and made outbound long-distance calls to Mexico, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador and Colombia. Even more surprising to experts, they had managed to log 129,315 minutes of talking time over one line -- a seemingly impossible feat, because it equaled an average of roughly three calls going out simultaneously every minute of the day. **********"My average bill is around $500," William Rogers, WRL's president, said in bewilderment. "If this is real, very simply, my company will have to declare bankruptcy."  Used by Pirate Companies **********Phone service theft was once used mostly by computer hackers to make long-distance calls without paying for them. But such techniques are increasingly being used to operate pirate telephone companies. The pirate operations charge customers $5, $10 or $20 apiece to make calls anywhere in the world. **********These "call-sell" operations, as Government officials refer to them, are run from public telephone booths and from individual apartments. The greatest concentration is in the New York metropolitan area. In many cases, authorities say, the telephone bandits market their stolen long-distance service to low-income immigrants who want to call home cheaply. Drug dealers, interested in concealing their international calls, are also believed to be big customers. **********In the past, long-distance carriers bore most of the cost, since the thefts were attributed to weaknesses in their networks. But now, the phone companies are arguing that the customers should be liable for the cost of the calls, because they failed to take proper security precautions on their equipment. **********The basic principles of breaking into PBX switches and voice mail systems are well-known to experts. Often, the intruders begin by searching for toll-free "800" numbers that are connected to a company's automated call-routing system. In many cases, they use high-speed dialing devices that can test hundreds of numbers automatically.  Access Codes Figured Out **********Once the intruders locate a PBX or voice mail system, they proceed to figure out the access codes that will allow them to obtain outbound long-distance lines. In many systems, the principal target for hackers is the feature that is intended to allow employees to obtain a long-distance line from outside the office. The appeal of this feature is that calling a company's own PBX is cheaper than using telephone credit cards. **********Voice mail systems, which act like sophisticated answering machines for an entire office, have other weaknesses. Experts say even those that are not intended to provide remote access can be manipulated to offer outside lines. In some cases, the machines give the caller a momentary dial tone as it forwards calls to an outside number. Experienced hackers can seize the line in that moment and hold onto it to make endless numbers of calls. **********Experts in communications security say it is hard to track down the principal culprits once theft occurs, but that it is usually preventable. "A lot of times, companies go out and buy systems without understanding them," said Paul DeMatteis, a former security consultant who is now director of Telecommunications Security/Special Projects for the New York City Human Resource Administration. "Any large corporation, I think you can say, has problems. They don't all admit to it, but they've got problems."  Tighter Security Urged **********To combat unauthorized access, the long-distance carriers and equipment manufacturers have been urging corporate customers to tighten their security in a number of ways. They can increase the number of digits in access codes, program their computers to block calls to places where the company has no business and shut down the remote-access feature at nights or on weekends. In addition, the companies can monitor their daily traffic to spot unusual surges of activity. **********Some consultants urge companies to install devices that will verify outsiders' locations by calling them back before giving them outgoing lines. **********"We don't have control over the customer's PBX," said Robert Fox, assistant vice president of corporate security at U S Sprint. "We can't listen in on a customer's calls. We have to carry all that traffic." **********Nevertheless, the last several years have produced a thriving market in "hot" "800" numbers, access codes and how-to tips on the weaknesses of different systems.  Weaknesses Described **********Consumertronics, a mail order company in Alamogordo, N.M., sells brochures for $29 that describe the general principles of voice mail hacking and the particular weaknesses of different models. Included in the brochure is a list of "800" numbers along with the kind of voice mail systems to which they are connected. **********"It's for educational purposes," said the company's owner, John Williams, adding that he accepts Mastercard and Visa. Similar insights can be obtained from 2600 Magazine, a quarterly publication devoted to telephone hacking that is published in Middle Island, L.I. **********But the Mitsubishi case against A.T.& T. suggests that even sophisticated users can be victims. Because Mitsubishi had a maintenance contract with A.T.& T., it says, A.T.& T. kept a representative on its site at all times. Mitsubishi contends that unauthorized intruders began blocking legitimate access to the remote-access feature in early July, but A.T.& T. executives thought the problems stemmed from other sources. The suspicion of unauthorized intruders did not appear until later that month, Mitsubishi said, when the New York Telephone Company, a Nynex Corporation unit, warned Mitsubishi officials about the possibility.  '99 Percent Preventable' **********A.T.& T. officials have not responded in detail to the suit, though the company continues to insist that the customer is responsible for setting up proper security procedures. "We believe that PBX fraud is 99 percent preventable with proper system administration," said Jim McGann, an A.T.& T. spokesman. **********Meanwhile, the incident involving Mr. Rogers' small company, the WRL Group, in Virginia, raises the question of whether all of the problem is inside corporate computer systems, or whether phone thieves may also be manipulating computers operated by the local telephone company. In theory, the company's single line should not have been able to carry what amounted to three calls at the same time. But the company was also using Centrex, a call-routing service offered by all the Bell telephone companies, which works much like an office PBX. **********Stephen Clark, a communications consultant hired by Mr. Rogers, argues that the unauthorized callers may have been able to manipulate the Centrex computer to free the office line once the telephone company had established a connection to the long-distance carrier. "What I'm saying is that in this particular case, someone had to access their computers," Mr. Clark said. "It's the only logical explanation." **********Executives at the Bell Atlantic Corporation said they did not believe their system was to blame. A more likely situation, they said, was that the victims employed several lines that might have been linked in ways they did not fully understand. **********"There simply cannot be a single outgoing line that routes multiple calls at once," said Kenneth Pitt, a Bell Atlantic spokesman. "What they think they have, what they're supposed to have and what they do have may not be the same thing."
