https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/busin.print_headline: BANKERS EXPECTED TO STAY HESITANT TO LEND FOR YEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/busin.body_text: **********Just as the bank failures in the Depression years bred a generation of conservative bankers, the new banking crisis is creating a cautiousness among lenders that bankers themselves say may slow the flow of loans long after the recession ends. **********Many factors affect a bank's willingness to lend, from the health of the bank to the size of its underlying capital base. But none are as important as the mindset of the bankers themselves. And there is widespread evidence that that mindset has changed in a way that may transform banking for months or years to come. **********There has been a trauma, and that trauma will make bankers cautious for a period of time," said Robert Hawkins, president of the Southern Commercial Bank of St. Louis. Wary of Loose Lending **********The caution in banking circles represents a shift away from the free-lending approach of the heady 1980's and a return to more traditional banking standards. **********What had loosened banking standards was partly deregulation, and partly the increased tendency of the most creditworthy corporations to borrow directly from the credit markets, bypassing the banks. Pressed for business, the banks looked elsewhere for customers, competing to make higher-risk loans, including many in real estate -- a strategy that cost the banks dearly in loan defaults. **********The new caution among lenders showed up repeatedly in 25 interviews with bankers, corporate finance officers and Government officials. It is a caution that goes far beyond the credit tightening of the last year that the banks have often attributed to Government regulators. Even Big Banks Change **********Even large, healthy banks say they are changing their ways. "In all types of lending, the price -- the interest rate -- is not only higher, but the terms of the transactions are becoming tougher and will remain so," said Lewis Coleman, vice chairman of the Bank of America in San Francisco. **********For consumers, the new caution shows itself in such things as slightly higher rates on bank credit cards -- they have already risen by nearly a percentage point in the last year, to an average of 19.6 percent -- smaller lines of credit and a growing reluctance to issue new credit cards to people who already hold one or two others. **********"They are target marketing to those with higher incomes and good credit records," said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America. "In terms of ZIP codes, instead of mailing down 80 percent of the income ladder, as they used to do, they mail down 50 percent or 40 percent." **********Lenders are also requiring higher incomes from home buyers seeking mortgages, and often larger down payments. They are declaring that any borrower, consumer or corporate, will have to show higher levels of income in the 1990's to qualify for loans than in the 1980's. And bankers increasingly are putting limits on how much they will lend to even the most creditworthy corporations. **********"If someone wants $50 million from us, they have a tough sell on their hands," said Jerry Jordan, chief economist at the First Interstate Bank Corporation in California, where lending officers once could make such loans without higher management's approval. "We are trying to limit how much exposure we have to any borrower." Outgrowing Fear **********How long might this caution last? The estimates run from two or three years to the end of the decade. "Once there are enough new faces in banking who did not experience the current crisis, lending will ease up again," said Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow and banking specialist at the Brookings Institution. **********Many experts argue that not only the nation's banks, but also two other major sources of loans, insurance companies and private finance companies, are simply returning to the lending standards that prevailed before the 1980's -- forced into doing so by the numerous loan defaults that threaten the survival of many banks. As Mr. Coleman put it, "I am making loans today with a feeling of deja vu." Low Inflation a Factor **********The earlier cutback in lending had largely been a result of Government rules that in effect limited lending at banks with insufficient capital or labeled as risky many loans that in the 1980's went unchallenged by bank regulators. **********These obstacles still exist. But other forces are also kicking in to prolong the lending cutback, chief among them the defensive reaction to the trauma of bad loans and bank failures. The failures have occurred in a more concentrated fashion than at any time since the Great Depression. **********Low inflation, expected to endure well into the decade, is also playing a major role, especially in real estate lending. Property is not appreciating the way it did in the late 70's and early 80's. High inflation made real estate loans low risks and masked any mistakes a lender might have made in granting the loans. Now weaker prices have often made homes and machinery worth less than the loans floated a year or two ago to purchase them. **********The greater care in lending probably will dampen the economic recovery, once it materializes, because of less credit for corporate operations and consumer spending. For the longer term, the result is likely to be weaker economic growth in the early 1990's than in the 1980's. Growth of Debt Reduced **********The credit shortage has already helped to reduce the growth of all outstanding debt in the United States, except that owed by the Federal Government and the lenders themselves, to an annual rate of less than 4 percent, according to Federal Reserve data. That is less than half the growth rate for debt in the late 1980's. **********The slowdown is partly a result of the scramble by many banks to raise cash to reimburse depositors whose money has been lent out and lost in unrepaid loans. Citibank is engaged in this scramble, and the experience is changing its long-term lending standards, said Michael Callen, a senior executive in corporate lending. "The mistake the banks made in the 1980's was to move downscale and lend to less creditworthy companies," he said. "The banks were not recognizing the level of risks and appropriately pricing for it." **********To recognize the risks, Citibank has increased interest rates for many commercial loans, with some companies whose credit ratings are of less than top quality paying two to four percentage points more than the bank once offered, Mr. Callen said. **********Such caution is similarly in vogue for healthy lenders. Many institutions, for example, are trying to keep down the levels of unpaid debt on bank credit cards, in part by trying to issue the cards to higher-income people likely to pay their bills every month, said Diane Casey, executive director of the Independent Bankers Association, which represents 10,000 midsized banks. "You try to issue cards to people who don't really need them," she said. **********Similarly, General Electric Capital, a healthy lending company whose activities include financing charge-card operations for retailers like Montgomery Ward, is monitoring income levels of card holders and limiting credit to low-income households, said James A. Park, G.E. Capital's senior vice president of finance. **********Many banks are no longer lending out as big a proportion of their deposits as they did in the 1980's, a cutback that allows them to be more selective. Deposits instead are often invested in Government securities. First Interstate is in this category, and so is Southern Commercial in St. Louis. Southern Commercial once lent 90 percent of its deposits, which total $180 million today. Now the proportion is 80 percent. **********"We don't have the loan demand today and even if we did, I would be nervous about getting back up to that level," said Mr. Hawkins, who is also president-elect of the Independent Bankers Association. The 'Club Loan' **********The multibillion-dollar bank loan, once common for corporate takeovers and huge commercial real estate projects, is also more difficult to obtain, although big sums can still be raised by creditworthy companies through new bond issues.  In the 1980's, a major bank would underwrite a multibillion-dollar loan and then quickly syndicate it, selling off shares to other institutions. Now the syndicated loan has become what Mr. Coleman of Bank of America describes as the "club loan." **********"The banks all sit down with the borrower and decide how much each will take, before the loan is made," Mr. Coleman said. And the amounts involved are much smaller. In the late 80's, there were syndicated loans put together in excess of $5 billion, and now the top is about $2 billion, he said. **********Even the nation's most creditworthy companies, among them the Colgate-Palmolive Corporation, are feeling the pinch. They often raise money on their own, by selling i.o.u.'s known as commercial paper, which currently total more than $550 billion. **********Colgate-Palmolive's i.o.u.'s are in such demand that the consumer products giant is paying less than 6 percent interest annually on $100 million in borrowings, said Brian Heidtke, the company's treasurer. By comparison, the banking industry's prime rate for loans to good corporate customers is 8.5 percent and many companies say they now have to pay above that level. **********But any corporation, no matter how creditworthy, traditionally lines up a bank guarantee to assure holders of commercial paper that they will be repaid should disaster strike the company. Lately the banks are making these guarantees more expensive and publicly warning that they will not pay off under certain conditions. Mr. Heidtke, for example, says that when Colgate-Palmolive renews its current $460 million standby credit, the nearly $600,000 annual fee will probably double.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/13/world.main_headline: Strauss Will Give Up $4 Million In Salary to Take Post in Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/13/world.print_headline: Strauss Will Give Up $4 Million In Salary to Take Post in Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/13/world.body_text: **********Robert S. Strauss will take a pay cut of more than $4 million and step down from seven corporate boards on his confirmation as the next United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, according to a financial statement that he recently filed with the Government. **********Mr. Strauss's financial disclosure statement, which was made public this week and reported today in The Washington Post, details what is already widely known: the 72-year-old lawyer is a power broker of abundant wealth and envious political and corporate connections. It shows that as advertised the Soviets will be receiving a consummate capitalist, and one that as anticipated has some potentially awkward connections. **********Emerging from the disclosure statement is a portrait of a lawyer whose clients include the solid citizens and the high flyers of Wall Street (Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., Goldman, Sachs and Company, Forstmann Little & Company, Morgan Stanley Group Inc.), the glitziest of Hollywood (MCA Inc., the Motion Picture Association of America), the biggest of corporate America (Northrop, Westinghouse Electric Corporation and Pepsico) and several Japanese powerhouses (Fujitsu, Matsushita Electric Industrial Company). **********"It is impossible to determine with any precision all of the clients for which I have personally rendered more than $5,000 in services during the reported period," Mr. Strauss said in an attachment to the disclosure statement, because unlike all the other lawyers in his firm, he does not bill by the hour. In consultation with his partners, Mr. Strauss listed 30 companies -- from American Airlines to the Xerox Corporation -- that they could identify "to the best of our recollection." Oil and Gas Investments **********His investments range from a wide array of oil and gas interests, stock in many of the nation's largest corporations, and a stable of racehorses in which he is a partner with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. **********The disclosure statement also makes clear that Mr. Strauss could be in an awkward position when he goes to Moscow because of his close connections to corporations and business executives with long ties to the Soviet Union. Among the companies in which Mr. Strauss has substantial stock holdings and companies on whose board he has served are Pepsico and the Archer-Daniels-Midland Corporation, the large agricultural exporter. Both are among the largest American companies with business ties to Moscow. **********In a letter attached to his disclosure statement, Mr. Strauss said that he would sell his Pepsico and Archer Daniels stock, which he values at more than $1.5 million, and that he is "sensitive to the need to avoid even the appearance of impropriety." **********Dwayne O. Andreas, chairman of Archer-Daniels, and Mr. Strauss are old friends. With the help of Mr. Andreas, Mr. Strauss obtained a cooperative apartment at the Seaview Hotel in Bal Harbour, Fla. Mr. Andreas, one of the founders and officers of the cooperative, also helped obtain apartments for Senator Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader; Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the former Speaker, and Howard H. Baker Jr., former Senate Republican leader.  At Least $13 Million in Holdings **********But left unsaid is how hospitable Mr. Strauss will be toward executives and old friends, like Donald M. Kendall of Pepsico and Mr. Andreas when they visit Moscow. In the past, they have received the royal treatment from the American Embassy. **********Mr. Strauss's letter, which was sent to the State Department, also said that his oil and gas investments would preclude him from "any official matter that has or could have a direct and predictable effect on the price of domestic oil or gas." **********Mr. Strauss said in a brief interview this afternoon that "it would be inappropriate" to discuss how he will handle visits to the Soviet Union from the companies that he has represented or served. **********The disclosure statement lists assets and income in general categories of value, making it impossible to precisely calculate Mr. Strauss's worth. At a minimum, Mr. Strauss holds investments and assets that he values at more than $13 million and earned more than $2.5 million in the last 18 months in income outside his law practice. **********Mr. Strauss also said that as senior partner at Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, he received $4.5 million in the last 18 months. When he leaves the firm to go to Moscow, he will receive a severance package of $1.4 million. **********The Ambassador's salary is $115,300. **********Mr. Strauss said in his disclosure statement that he would put many of his assets in a blind trust and that he would remove himself from any Government business having to do with his investments until the trust was set up. He listed more than 40 companies in which he has investments that would be put in the trust, including RJR Nabisco, Xerox and Reader's Digest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; A Prize Winner in Research
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; A Prize Winner in Research
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.body_text: **********The honors keep rolling in for Leo Esaki, a Nobel physicist who has led in developing new types of ultra-fast computer chips. Earlier this month, in a ceremony here, Dr. Esaki received the Medal of Honor, the highest award of the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers. **********Dr. Esaki, 66, is a researcher for the International Business Machines Corporation and has spent a lifetime applying the arcane principles of quantum physics to the design of electronic circuits. Such quantum devices represent perhaps the most exciting frontier in semiconductor research today, promising smaller and faster electronic circuitry. **********Instead of being made of silicon, such circuits are made of two or more materials, like gallium arsenide and gallium aluminum arsenide, in a precise configuration to control the energy levels of electrons. **********"I don't think silicon will be replaced by this kind of thing," Dr. Esaki said, explaining that silicon keeps improving and is inexpensive. But, he said, quantum devices will be used for communications and electronic instruments. Some quantum structures, known as quantum wells and superlattices, are being applied in lasers and high-speed communications circuits. **********A native of Osaka, Japan, Dr. Esaki was working for Sony in 1957 when he invented the tunnel diode, the first quantum device. For that he received both his doctorate and, in 1973, the Nobel Prize in Physics. **********In 1960, Dr. Esaki moved to I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., for what was to be one year. He has been there ever since. In Japan, Dr. Esaki said, the best graduates go into manufacturing, the next best into product development and the rest into research. Here, it is the other way around. "That's why I came to this country," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/01/busin.body_text: **********Citing a weakening economic environment, Moody's Investors Service Inc. yesterday downgraded about $2 billion in debt issued by Allied-Signal Inc., a diversified company that manufacturers products for the aerospace and automotive industries. **********Moody's said the outlook for future profits at the company was dimmer because of the effect of the weakening economy on some of its core businesses and uncertainties related to Allied-Signal's ability to significantly reduce its debt with future cash flows. The ratings agency lowered Allied-Signal's senior debt to A-3, from A-2, and the company's subordinated debt to Baa-1, from A-3. The commercial paper rating was also downgraded, to Prime-2 from Prime-1. **********Moody's placed the company under review on Dec. 19, and now thinks that its pressures on profits, capital spending and dividend payments in the near term will make it difficult for Allied-Signal to cut its high debt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.main_headline: U.S. Seeks to Prevent Saudis From Being Sued
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; U.S. Seeks to Prevent Saudis From Being Sued
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.body_text: **********At the request of the Saudi Embassy, the Bush Administration has asked a Federal appeals court to reverse a ruling that allows the Saudi Government to be sued in the United States for the reported torture of an American businessman. **********In taking the unusual step, the Administration contends that an important national interest exists in reversing the ruling -- to prevent foreign governments from retaliating by allowing American officials to be sued in their courts. **********If the ruling in the precedent-setting case in the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta stands, American courts could hear several such allegations of mistreatment, which have long been an irritant in American-Saudi relations. **********A three-judge panel ruled unanimously on Feb. 21 that under a 1976 law, Scott J. Nelson of Raleigh, N.C., could bring suit against the Saudi Government for what he says was a severe beating during his 1984 imprisonment.  Letter to Baker From Saudi **********Two weeks after the ruling and just after the end of the Persian Gulf war, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Ambassador in Washington, wrote a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d seeking his help in the case. The department and lawyers for the Saudi Government have acknowledged the existence of the letter but declined to release it, saying it is a confidential diplomatic communication. The embassy followed up with other letters and telephone calls, department officials said. **********Last week, the Bush Administration formally entered the case of Scott Nelson v. Saudi Arabia, asking the three-judge panel to reconsider its February decision or, alternatively, to have the case heard before the entire 11-member court. **********Mr. Nelson, who is 37 years old, said that Saudi officials beat him on the knees with a rod until his bones cracked and tortured him further by beating the soles of his feet. In papers filed with the 11th Circuit, the Saudi Government replied that no such beating took place. **********Several Americans have testified before Congress that they have been mistreated and have not been sufficiently helped by American diplomats. **********Mr. Nelson's lawyer, Prof. Anthony D'Amato of Northwestern University Law School, asserted that the State Department was "saying there's a foreign policy component here just to cozy up to the Saudi Government because of the need to maintain good relations." **********The case may be emblematic of a pattern of extreme sensitivity at the State Department to Saudi sensitivities. Even before the gulf war, American diplomats had been especially cautious in dealing with the Riyadh Government's concerns. **********In 1988, for example, the State Department recalled the Ambassador, Hume A. Horan, because some Saudi leaders were not comfortable with him. "It's not easy to get along with kings," a State Department official explained at the time. **********Professor D'Amato said Mr. Nelson was "tortured for doing his job." Mr. Nelson was hired in the United States to monitor safety systems at the King Faisal Specialist Hospital in Riyadh and contends that he was arrested and tortured because he embarrassed hospital officials by reporting faulty seals on oxygen valves. Saudi Denial **********Saudi Embassy officials deny that Mr. Nelson was ever mistreated during his 39-day confinement. Moreover, they dismiss his contention that he was arrested and deported for reporting safety violations. **********He was charged with submitting a forged diploma from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to get his job, said Mudassir Siddiqui, the embassy's legal adviser. **********Mr. Nelson acknowledged that he offered a forged M.I.T. diploma to his employers in Saudi Arabia but said that was not the reason he was arrested and mistreated. In an interview, he said he told a royal commission checking the hospital about the faulty oxygen-valve seals, and his whistle-blowing infuriated hospital administrators who then used the issue of the false diploma to take revenge on him. Details Recounted **********"I was picked up at the hospital and driven to a secluded villa," he said and then handcuffed and shackled. "A bar was put behind my knees and I was struck with a bamboo rod on the knees until I heard a sound like a dry twig breaking. That basically was the separation of my knee joints." **********David Denny, a State Department spokesman, said because the case was in litigation there would be no comment beyond the brief filed jointly by the State and Justice Departments. **********In 1987, the State Department informed Congress that Mr. Nelson was visited by a consular officer shortly after his arrest, who reported that his allegations of mistreatment were not credible. **********The three-judge panel in Atlanta said that the Foreign Sovereign Immunity Act, passed by Congress in 1976 to prevent governments from being sued, included an explicit exception if the foreign government's activities were connected to commercial acts that occurred in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/16/world.main_headline: PHILIPPINE SENATE VOTES TO REJECT U.S. BASE RENEWAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/16/world.print_headline: PHILIPPINE SENATE VOTES TO REJECT U.S. BASE RENEWAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/16/world.body_text: **********The Philippine Senate voted today to reject a new treaty for the Subic Bay Naval Station and to end an American military presence in the country that has lasted nearly a century. But President Corazon C. Aquino effectively extended the American lease by calling for a national referendum on the base's future. **********In a vote of 12 to 11, the Senate adopted a motion to spurn the new treaty, which would allow thousands of American troops to remain at the base for another 10 years. The current treaty on Subic Bay, the largest American military installation in the Philippines, expires today. **********"The treaty is defeated," the Senate President, Jovito R. Salonga, announced in a solemn tone after the vote was taken this morning in a show of hands. The decision was greeted with applause and tears in the chamber.  Anger Over Compensation **********The 11 senators who voted in favor of the new treaty were 5 short of the two-thirds majority needed for ratification. **********The vote reflected a view among many senators that the compensation package offered by the United States was too small and, more broadly, that it was time to end an American military presence that began when the United States acquired the Philippines by winning the Spanish-American war. **********In voting to spurn the new treaty, Senator Agapito Aquino, brother-in-law of the President and younger brother of her slain husband, Benigno S. Aquino, described the decision as "the dawn of our nation's birth."  Ending an 'Adolescence' **********"It is a vote for a truly sovereign and independent Philippine nation," he told colleagues in a speech on the Senate floor. "It is a vote to end a political adolescence tied to the purse strings of America -- a crippling dependence." **********But Mrs. Aquino's call for a referendum under the terms of the Philippine Constitution has the effect of extending the deadline for an American departure by at least several months, and quite possibly for several years. **********Invoking the rallying cry of "people power" that she used with such success in ousting President Ferdinand E. Marcos in 1986, Mrs. Aquino proposed in a televised address Sunday night that "we take the issue directly to the people." **********"Once again people power is being called upon," Mrs. Aquino said. "As in 1986, we seek the direct expression of the sovereign will of the Filipino people. Now, as in the past, every one of us must participate in an exercise that gives added substance to the democracy we have established." **********The referendum could not be held until late this year or in 1992. Mrs. Aquino's move is expected to set off a series of time-consuming court challenges by lawmakers and others who assert that the Constitution permits voters to overrule a vote by the Senate on a regular law, but not on a treaty.  U.S. Stand Called Flexible **********While the Bush Administration indicated last week that it would start an immediate and irrevocable withdrawal from Subic if the Philippine Senate vetoed the 10-year treaty, Western diplomats said in recent days that the American position was actually far more flexible, and that American troops would probably remain at the base until after a referendum. Interim arrangements for compensation to the Philippines were unclear. **********The base, home to more than 7,000 Americans -- servicemen and women and civilian workers -- is a major refueling and repair station for the United States Seventh Fleet. **********While its strategic value has declined with the end of the cold war, Bush Administration officials say that replicating the functions of Subic Bay at installations elsewhere in the Pacific would cost several billion dollars. **********Clark Air Base, a sister American installation on the central Philippine island of Luzon, was abandoned this year after it was smothered by volcanic ash released by nearby Mount Pinatubo.  Possible Election Issue **********Beyond its implications for Philippine-American relations, Mrs. Aquino's call for a referendum on the future of Subic Bay will doubtless have a broad effect on domestic politics. **********She may well have created the principal issue in next May's general election, including the vote to pick her successor: whether the United States should be allowed to continue to place troops and weapons, including nuclear weapons, on the soil of a former colony that in many ways has yet to emerge from the American shadow. President Aquino has insisted that she will not seek re-election when her six-year term expires next year. **********The new 10-year base agreement rejected today had been hammered out this summer between the Bush Administration and the Manila Government. **********. Washington offered $203 million a year in compensation, far less than was originally sought by Manila. Some of the Philippine lawmakers had demanded that the treaty be renegotiated. **********Mrs. Aquino, aware of opinion polls showing that an overwhelming majority of Filipinos support the treaty, is refusing to acquiesce in the Senate's rejection of it. The Philippine military also strongly favors the treaty. **********At stake are the jobs of tens of thousands of Filipinos who work at the base or in related jobs, as well as hundreds of millions of dollars that the Subic Bay installation injects into the strapped Philippine economy each year. **********Acknowledging on Sunday night that Senate rejection of the base agreement was "likely," Mrs. Aquino said that she would invoke a section of the Constitution that gives voters the right to overturn legislative decisions in a national referendum. **********Under the Constitution, the signatures of 10 percent of the nation's voters, or about three million Filipinos, are needed on petitions authorizing a referendum. **********Many senators disagree with Mrs. Aquino on the question of whether a treaty vote in the Senate, as opposed to the Senate's vote on a regular law, can be overturned by referendum. **********The constitutional differences will probably have to be sorted out in the Philippine Supreme Court, a process that could take several months. It could even delay a referendum until after the general election in May, when new senators, including some who may be more receptive to a base treaty with the United States, will be selected.                    --------------------       U.S. Supports a Referendum **********WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (Special to The New York Times) -- American officials welcomed the effort by President Aquino today to win approval of the base treaty through a referendum. **********Richard H. Solomon, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said in an interview, "We support her efforts." **********Exactly when the current agreement ends is, from the American perspective, a complicated question. The Philippines has said it expires on Monday. The United States disagrees, saying the earliest possible date is Sept. 16, 1992. **********The Military Bases Agreement was signed in 1947, eight months after the Philippines became independent of the United States. An amendment adopted by both nations in 1966 says it "shall remain in force for a period of 25 years from September 16, 1966, after which, unless extended for a longer period by mutual agreement, it shall become subject to termination upon one year's notice by either government." **********The Philippines gave such notice several months ago. State Department officials contend that the notice could not properly be given until Monday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/21/world.main_headline: Lamu Journal; Kenyans Alter Little. Will Tourists?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/21/world.print_headline: Lamu Journal; Kenyans Alter Little. Will Tourists?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/21/world.body_text: **********In many ways, this island in the Indian Ocean still resembles the city-state that prospered in the 18th and 19th centuries from sea trade with Arabia and established a flourishing example of the Swahili culture. **********The people here, known as Swahili from the melding of Arab intruders and indigenous Africans, have done much to preserve the traditional way of life. Dhows still ply the waters, and three dozen mosques, one dating to 1370, are well attended. The muezzin's cry echoes at dawn through stone alleys wide enough for donkeys but too narrow for cars. The only vehicle on this island of 20,000 people belongs to the District Commissioner. **********A few impositions from the West have blended in. Inexpensive boarding houses attract budget travelers, but not too many of them. The beach boys who man the dhows grow plaits and peroxide their tips in memory of Bob Marley. But the reggae music is kept discreetly low. **********But now, some longtime residents say that the character of Lamu, a slower-paced version of Zanzibar, the Tanzanian island to the south, is threatened. Suddenly, two new hotels have appeared on the waterfront. By most standards they are modest buildings of three stories and reflect Swahili architecture with traditional styled arches and whitewashed exteriors. **********But what rankles the local residents is an apparent flouting of zoning procedures and the effect of beach tourists on the integrity of their Islamic traditions that demand no alcohol and modesty in dress. Lamu women are clad in head-to-toe black Islamic dress, known here as buibui. **********"Building such a hotel in front of this Islamic village where beer and other vices will be peddled is an insult to the local people," said Philip Katana, conservator of the Lamu Museum and one of the chief critics of the Sheik Ya Shella Hotel. **********"There is a real conflict between the different values of the locals and the visitors," he said. "The young people get tempted, that's what people are complaining about." **********As Mr. Katana talked near the shore of Shella beach, where the new hotel juts out onto the sand, a fisherman gently advised a young European sunbather to drape something around her nearly nude body. **********Beyond the brash culture that the new Sheik Ya Shella Hotel, with its bargain-priced beer, represents, its construction across a broad swath of beachfront interferes with daily commerce by obstructing the landing area of local boatmen. Wary of Strangers **********Ali Omar, a fisherman, said he used to bring his catch to the sands where the hotel now stands and other boatmen brought coral stones used for construction. **********"We have nothing against foreigners," Mr. Omar said. "For years we have welcomed them. But now we are becoming wary of strangers who come here pretending to be innocent only to realize they are looking for ways to grab a plot of land." **********A second hotel -- named, to the annoyance of the local residents, Paradise Hotel -- has just been completed on the waterfront in the center of the town. Mr. Katana said the building was too big and out of proportion for the size of the land. **********For historic reasons, Mr. Katana said, it is important to preserve Lamu in as natural state as possible. It is the most authentic of three extant Swahili towns designated as national monuments by the Kenyan Government, he said. The other two are the old stone town of Kenya's chief port city, Mombasa, and Pate, a small collection of dwellings on Pate Island, to the north of Lamu. Ancient Mud Mosques **********Indeed, Mr. Katana said he believed that Lamu is one of the best examples of the Swahili culture along the entire Swahili coast that stretches from war-ravaged Mogadishu, the capital of Somalia, in the north, to Mozambique, in the south. **********"There's no other culture in Kenya that we know of that goes back as far as the Swahili culture," Mr. Katana said. "And this is one of the superior cultures -- the fact they came up with towns, shows that." **********On nearby Pate Island, at a place called Shanga, archaeologists have found evidence of mud mosques dating back to the eighth century, Mr. Katana said. Lamu is thought to have existed by 1300, with the remnants of a settlement now buried under sand dunes at the south end of Lamu town. **********In the early 1800's, the Sultan of Oman conquered Lamu, had an imposing fort built that still stands in the center of the town and used the island as a foothold from which to take Zanzibar. The Omani Sultans stayed in power until the British declared Kenya a protectorate in 1895. But the British ignored Lamu, left a puppet Sultan in place until the 1920's and unlike practically every other corner of Kenya, there is barely a remnant of British colonialism. Technicians' Approval **********As in many unsullied places across the world where possible profits suddenly loom, the construction of the Sheik Ya Shella Hotel was approved by the "politicians instead of the technicians," Mr. Katana said. **********To curb the temptations offered to elected politicians by potential developers, the Kenyan Government has agreed to set up a new planning commission of technical civil servants through which all such proposals must pass, the curator said. **********"In any case, there is a lot of free beach land along the coast and on nearby Manda Island which is ideal for hotels and which would not hurt anyone," Mr. Katana said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/world.main_headline: Angola and Rebels Sign Pact Ending 16-Year War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/world.print_headline: Angola and Rebels Sign Pact Ending 16-Year War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/world.body_text: **********The Government of Angola and the rebel faction that it has battled for 16 years signed a long-awaited peace agreement today aimed at ending civil war and preparing the ravaged southern African nation for free elections and democracy. **********An official cease-fire went into effect after the accord was signed here tonight by Angola's President, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, and Jonas Savimbi, the longtime leader of the rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita. An informal truce declared by the two sides on May 15 appears largely to be holding. **********Mr. dos Santos's Government until recent years espoused Marxism and received support from the Soviet Union, while the Unita rebels took their aid and their cue from Washington and South Africa. **********The signing today fits in with continuing Soviet-American efforts to resolve regional rivalries -- United States and Soviet officials were on hand today -- and it comes as the civil war in Ethiopia, at times a focus of East-West dispute, has reached a pivotal moment. **********Under the Angolan accord, which was initialed by negotiators here on May 1, the two sides agreed to build a unified armed force, to strive for political pluralism and a market economy, and to work together until free elections are held in the second half of 1992. **********The signing ceremony, at the Portuguese Foreign Ministry, was the climax of a year of negotiations in which the United States and the Soviet Union pressed the two sides to end a war that has taken an estimated 300,000 lives. Portugal, which ruled colonial Angola until 1975, acted as a mediator in the talks. **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who witnessed the signing along with Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh of the Soviet Union, described it as another product of the new cooperation between Washington and Moscow. **********But the cease-fire also became possible because the warring factions apparently reached the conclusion that neither side could win on the battlefield. While the Government controls the capital, Luanda, as well as the coast and the oil-producing areas, the rebels occupy much of the arid south and east of Angola. **********Sitting between the once bitterly hostile leaders of the two Angolan forces, Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva of Portugal said, "Today there are no losers and only one winner: the Angolan people." If the accord is respected, he added, Angolans can at last look forward to economic development and better living conditions.  Peace and Democracy **********Congratulating the two sides for ending the fighting, Mr. Baker said: "Once adversaries in war, you now stand together as partners in peace. You have the opportunity to show the world that a multiparty democracy can be built where before there was only destruction and distrust." **********For many of Angola's nearly nine million people, the accord may in fact mean the first peace they have known. Before the civil war erupted on the eve of independence in November 1975, the country had experienced years of guerrilla warfare led by nationalists demanding freedom from Portugal. **********"After 30 years of pain, deprivation and struggle, the Angolan people are now able to face the future with confidence and optimism," President dos Santos said today, declaring that peace in Angola could also help end the civil war in Mozambique and apartheid in South Africa. **********Under the agreement, a small United Nations observer force will monitor the cease-fire during preparations for international-supervised elections, to be held between Sept. 1 and Nov. 30, 1992. The force is expected to number 440 military and police officers and 175 civilians.  A Single Army **********The Luanda Government and Unita have further agreed to create a single 50,000-member armed force. Portugal, Britain and France are to help build the new army, while Washington and Moscow have pledged to stop sending in weapons. **********Under an earlier agreement, Cuban troops completed their withdrawal from Angola last week, five weeks ahead of schedule, after playing a major role in sustaining the Luanda Government since 1975. At one point, as many as 50,000 Cuban soldiers and advisers were involved in the war against the rebels. **********Under that same agreement, signed in December 1988, South Africa ended its support for Unita in 1989, and in 1990 it granted independence to Namibia, from which its forces had mounted frequent attacks into Angola dating back to 1975. **********In Angola, the governing party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, set the stage for the move to democracy when it dropped its commitment to Marxism in March. Since then, the formation of new political parties has been permitted.  Rivalry Will Move to Ballot **********The main contest for the presidency next year seems likely to pit Mr. dos Santos against Mr. Savimbi. Announcing plans to return to Luanda early in July to start preparing his campaign, the 56-year-old Unita leader said he would recognize Mr. dos Santos as President of Angola until the elections. **********While the peace accord thrashed out during seven negotiating sessions is detailed, much remains to be worked out by a commission in which the United States, the Soviet Union and Portugal will take part as observers. **********Some constitutional reforms toward a market economy have already been adopted. But more may be needed, particularly if Angola is to attract the foreign investment and credits it will need to rebuild its war-wrecked economy and develop its resources of oil, diamonds, gold and farm products. **********An electoral law to establish both the date and rules for next year's voting, including the length of presidential terms, will require negotiation among all political groups. Unita is pressing for the elections to be held in September 1992, before the rainy season starts.  Provision of Troops **********The two sides have agreed that each will provide half the new 40,000-member army, but because Unita has only ground troops, the Government will supply all 6,000 members of the air force and 4,000 members of the navy. Guarantees of the armed forces' political neutrality must still be worked out. **********Perhaps the biggest threat to the peace accord is the deep distrust that continues to divide the governing party and Unita. They are not only separated by ideology, but by tribal allegiance. Nonetheless, President dos Santos and Mr. Savimbi pledged to carry out today's accord to the letter. **********Mr. Baker said that while the agreement would not be easy to carry out, the United States would help by providing relief aid to all Angolans and by lending expertise to the electoral process. **********Turning to the Foreign Minister Bessmertnykh, Mr. Baker expressed thanks for Moscow's cooperation "in resolving yet another issue that once deeply divided our countries but that now unites us in common purpose."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.main_headline: Live Entertainment Seeks Merger With Carolco Pictures
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Live Entertainment Seeks Merger With Carolco Pictures
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.body_text: **********Live Entertainment Inc., a home video distributor, said today that it wanted to negotiate a merger with Carolco Pictures Inc., which already owns 54 percent of the company. **********Live Entertainment said it had formed a committee of outside directors not affiliated with Carolco to negotiate a transaction, but it did not propose a price or any other details. Theodore B. Bean, Live's chief financial officer, said that one possibility would be for Carolco to buy out Live's shareholders or begin a stock merger in which shareholders of both companies would emerge with a stake. **********Carolco said in a statement that it would appoint a committee of outside directors to negotiate with Live and said it would respond as quickly as possible to any proposal. **********Live's shares rose $1.875 today, to $12, on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price, the Live shares not already owned by Carolco would be worth about $70 million. Carolco's shares rose 25 cents a share, to $7.75. **********Live, which in addition to distributing home videos to retailers, owns the Strawberries and Waxie Maxie chains of music retailers on the East Coast, is the primary distributor of Carolco's films in the home video market. Carolco, best known for its big-budget action films like the "Rambo" series and the coming "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, has 4 of the 12 seats on Live Entertainment's board. Peter M. Hoffman, Carolco's chief executive, served for some time as acting chief executive of Live several years ago after the murder of Jose E. Menendez, Live's chairman at the time. **********Wayne H. Patterson, Live's chairman, said in a statement that the two companies were so "mutually interdependent" that a combination would give shareholders of both companies "substantially greater returns" than if they remained separate. **********Mr. Patterson said a deal would "create significant operating efficiencies and would allow a greater portion of the combined company's cash flow to be dedicated to production of an increased number of films, thus taking advantage of the distribution strength of the new company."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/19/busin.main_headline: McDonnell Joins Dynamics In Posting Good Results
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/19/busin.print_headline: McDonnell Joins Dynamics In Posting Good Results
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/19/busin.body_text: **********The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the nation's largest military contractor and the second-largest builder of commercial aircraft, said yesterday that its operating earnings rose sharply in the third quarter, bolstering the aerospace company's contention that it has put its financial woes behind it. **********On a net basis, earnings at McDonnell actually fell 69 percent, but that was attributable to a one-time gain in the quarter last year. When that gain is excluded, operating earnings were five and a half times greater than in the 1990 quarter. **********The General Dynamics Corporation, the second-largest Pentagon contractor, also reported improved results in the latest quarter, with a 4.4 percent gain in earnings over last year. **********Following are details of the two companies' results: McDonnell Douglas **********McDonnell reported that its net income fell compared with last year's third quarter, when it recorded a large one-time gain related to its pension fund obligations. The company said its net earnings were $77 million, or $2.02 a share, compared with $248 million, or $6.46 a share, in last year's third quarter. **********Excluding the the one-time after-tax gain of $234 million, or $6.11 a share, however, McDonnell's operating earnings in the period last year were $14 million, or 35 cents a share. **********For St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas, the operating results were the continuation of a rebound that began early this year. Pentagon officials were concerned earlier this year that the company might have to file for bankruptcy because of its high debt level and problems afflicting both its weapons and commercial aircraft businesses. **********But the company has now posted three consecutive quarters of healthy earnings, enabling it to pare debt in its aerospace operations by 19 percent since the end of the first quarter, to $2.68 billion. **********Much of the earnings improvement has come from the commercial aircraft business. The company began delivering its MD-11 wide-body jetliner to airlines late last year and has increased production rates and profitability on its MD-80 midrange jetliner. **********McDonnell Douglas said it was continuing to negotiate with other companies, including foreign aerospace concerns, about becoming partners on the development of a new widebody jetliner, the MD-12X. The company also repeated that among the options it was considering was selling a "substantial but minority" stake in its entire commercial aircraft business to potential partners. The company has been discussing partnership arrangements with a variety of Asian, European and domestic companies for months. **********While the company took a $14 million charge in the third quarter to cover problems with a new missile it is developing, earnings in its military businesses have remained relatively strong. The company has also been slashing employment to reduce costs and selling many of its non-aerospace units. **********"The financial discipline needed for them to improve their performance is finally taking hold," said Howard A. Rubel, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence Inc. **********McDonnell Douglas shares rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $71.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.  General Dynamics **********General Dynamics said it earned $71 million, or $1.70 a share, in the third quarter, compared with earnings of $68 million, or $1.63 a share, in last year's third quarter. Revenues fell 8.3 percent, to $2.09 billion from $2.28 billion. **********General Dynamics said it continued to win new military contracts and to improve its profitability and cash flow despite the downturn forecast for Pentagon spending. The company, which is also based in St. Louis, signaled its long-term commitment to being in the military contracting business on Thursday, when it said it planned to sell its Cessna small-aircraft division, the largest of its nonmilitary businesses. **********The company's stock gained 37.5 cents a share yesterday, to close at $50.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.body_text: **********The nation's 50 largest underfinanced pension plans have a potential combined shortfall of more than $14 billion, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said today. **********The listing of those pension plans by the guaranty corporation, a Federal agency that guarantees pension benefits in the event a corporation is unable to meet its obligations, immediately came under fire from the National Association of Manufacturers, which called it "misleading and potentially damaging." **********The agency said the companies on its list were not necessarily in poor financial health or guilty of failing to finance their pension plans properly. It said, however, that some of the plans were linked with financially weak companies that do pose a risk to the agency.  LTV Heads the List **********"Over 50 percent of the underfunding on this list are either probable or possible losses," said James Lockhart, executive director of the agency. And that, he said, "presents us with some serious concerns." **********The company with the largest potential shortfall, at $2.9 billion, is the LTV Corporation, an aerospace and steel company that has been operating under bankruptcy protection since July 1986. Responsibility for LTV'S unfinanced pension liabilities has been in dispute. The guaranty corporation recently returned the responsibility to the company, but the matter remains in litigation. Also on the list are two bankrupt airlines, Continental Airlines Holdings and Pan American World Airways. **********The manufacturers' association complained that the list "sows unnecessary fears and concerns." **********"It suggests, wrongly, that the security of retirement benefits is in jeopardy," said Michael Baroody, the manufacturers association's senior vice president. Information Is Questioned **********The business group also complained that the Federal agency was using outdated information. The list came from a survey of corporate annual reports for fiscal years that ended in 1989. **********The manufacturers said many of the companies were in full compliance with Federal law and were taking steps to speed up contributions to pension plans. **********The agency's statement said that over all, the defined pension benefit system guaranteed by the Government was well financed, with about $1 trillion in assets to back up some $800 billion in liabilities. **********Following are the 50 companies listed today and the size of their potential shortfall if the plans were to close and the pension guaranty corporation had to guarantee the benefits:  LTV Corp., $2.9 billion. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.main_headline: Iraqis Using Clouds to Cover Scud Firings, Meteorologists Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: WEATHER; Iraqis Using Clouds to Cover Scud Firings, Meteorologists Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.body_text: **********Iraq tends to fire missiles at Israel and Saudi Arabia under cloud cover, especially low-lying clouds, meteorologists said yesterday. The clouds presumably allow the missile launchers to hide better from retaliatory raids. **********On Wednesday, launching sites for Scud missiles in western and southern Iraq were periodically covered with low clouds. Both shot missiles, the western site firing at Israel and the southern site at Saudi Arabia. **********"There's a pretty good correlation," said Paul Knight, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University. "Evening or early-night cloud cover seems to correspond with the likelihood of an attack." **********Fred Gadomski, another Penn meteorologist, added, "There's a high degree of correlation."  At Height of Rainy Season **********If correct, the weather link could provide early warning of increased risk of attack for nations subject to Iraq's barrage. It could also help explain why eradication of the Scuds has been so difficult. **********Yesterday, a Pentagon spokesman said the military would have no comment on the possible linkage. **********The Persian Gulf area is now at the height of its rainy season. Baghdad, for instance, is covered by some clouds about 50 percent of the time on average. Meteorologists say the battlefield has been swept by several weather systems since the war began, producing intermittent periods of rain and cloudiness. **********After the initial allied attack, Iraq first struck back on the evening of Jan. 17 and 18 by firing several missiles at Israel and Saudi Arabia. Mr. Knight said low clouds covered both southern and western Iraq at the time. The skies then cleared partly, with the next evening bringing a lighter attack against Israel. Then, on the evening of Jan. 19 and 20, there were no launchings as skies cleared over the battle zone. **********But a new weather disturbance moved into the region. On the evening of last Sunday and early Monday, Iraq launched its biggest barrage against Saudi Arabia, some 10 missiles in all, correlating with what Mr. Knight called low clouds in southern Iraq.  Using Clouds as Cover **********Military experts say the Iraqis appear to be using the clouds as cover to make the mobile Scud launchers harder to find. Their period of vulnerability is greatest right after a missile firing. American early-warning satellites can spot the missile's fiery plume, allowing ground controllers to calculate the launcher's location. Moreover, military radars in the region can track the missile and aid the extrapolation process. Allied aircraft then hunt for the launcher, which usually starts moving right after firing. **********"They're hiding," said John E. Pike, head of space policy for the Federation of American Scientists, a private group based in Washington. **********Military experts say the clouds have no operational effect on Scud missiles or the capabilities of American early-warning satellites. Mr. Knight of Penn State said clouds were starting to build in western Iraq yesterday, meaning Israel might soon experience another attack. But Saudi Arabia would probably not be attacked, he added, since skies in southern Iraq were fair.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/27/world.main_headline: Zulu King Rebukes Mandela And Followers Over Violence
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/27/world.print_headline: Zulu King Rebukes Mandela And Followers Over Violence
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/27/world.body_text: **********The traditional King of the Zulus accused the African National Congress today of waging a campaign of violence against his people. **********King Goodwill Zwelithini, at a rally of 40,000 Zulus here, also said that South Africa's black people must work together to end factional violence and abolish apartheid, but he lashed out at the congress leader, Nelson Mandela. **********"I say to him, stop slinging mud and stop your people slinging mud," the King said. "Stop also, I say to Dr. Mandela, tolerating divisiveness. Stop this ugly vendetta against the Zulu people and their Zuluness." **********King Goodwill and Inkatha's political leader, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, were cheered when they arrived in leopard robes, carrying shields, spears and clubs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/busin.main_headline: Jersey Agrees to Bonuses For Mutual Benefit Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/busin.print_headline: Jersey Agrees to Bonuses For Mutual Benefit Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/busin.body_text: **********The chief executive of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company has retired in an arrangement that would bring him nearly $1.3 million, officials of the New Jersey Insurance Department said. **********The retirement of Henry E. Kates comes after a State Superior Court judge accepted on Tuesday a state takeover plan designed to prevent the failure of Mutual Benefit. With assets of more than $13 billion, Mutual Benefit is the nation's 18th-largest health and life insurer. **********The plan prohibits customers from redeeming their policies. The company will continue to pay health and death benefits and annuities. **********On Monday, Mutual Benefit approved bonus payments for Mr. Kates and six other senior executives. That package, valued at $2 million to $3 million, has been approved by the State Insurance Commissioner, Samuel F. Fortunato. He said the payments, negotiated last month, were necessary to keep the company's top managers in place during the restructuring. **********Mr. Kates's retirement package includes $937,500 in payments and $150,000 in deferred compensation owed by Mutual Benefit for 1989, said Jo Astrid Glading, an Insurance Department spokeswoman. Under the agreement, Mr. Kates must work as a part-time consultant for six months and must not have been involved in any ethics violations at Mutual Benefit. **********Another $150,000 in deferred compensation for Mr. Kates is pending in court, Ms. Glading said. **********The board also approved $542,000 in payments for Stephen J. Carlotti, who was named as the company's new chief executive, Ms. Glading said. Also approved was $433,000 in payments to Donald F. Haller Jr., the new chief financial officer. **********Four other senior executives are to receive $240,000 to $450,000. **********Mr. Fortunato has said he expects to see positive results from the state takeover within six months. He also said he was hoping that the state could revamp the company or oversee a merger or consolidation and avoid liquidation. **********The company has about 400,000 policyholders nationwide, and pension plans that cover more than 200,000 people have Mutual Benefit annuities. **********Mr. Fortunato said nearly $425 million has been withdrawn from Mutual Benefit in 1991. He added that the company's problems had been caused by its above-normal exposure in the real estate market. **********The Insurance Department has established a toll-free information line for Mutual Benefit customers. The number, 1-800-821-7887, is in operation between 8 A.M. and 6 P.M. on weekdays.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/03/busin.body_text: **********MGM-Pathe's new hit, "Thelma and Louise," is the latest reminder of an often-forgotten adage in Hollywood: money isn't everything. **********The film cost a relatively modest $18.5 million to make and already looks like a winner in a summer field in which many movies cost $40 million or more. **********" 'Thelma and Louise' is a hit in perspective," said Alan Friedberg, the chairman of Loews Theaters. "That means it is not a breakthrough film like 'Star Wars' or 'Raiders of the Lost Ark,' " he said. "But in the context of a film that does not have all the ingredients of mass appeal and without a big budget, either for production or marketing, it has all the ingredients of having legs and should reach the $50 million range." **********One phenomenon of the film business is that audiences can be stirred by a movie that on the surface lacks the components for success. **********"Thelma and Louise," which stars Geena Davis and Susan Sarandon, is the story of two women who leave for a vacation weekend and wind up as fugitives on the road. It is an often-funny but ultimately sad drama that was released at the beginning of the summer movie season, when audiences normally flock to lighter comedies and action films. **********Not only does the film lack a well-known male star, but it was produced and distributed by the MGM-Pathe Communications Company, which is under so much financial pressure that the film's release was delayed from late March because the studio apparently could not spend the money needed to market the film. **********Gregory Morrison, the studio's president of marketing, said MGM-Pathe spent about $8.5 million to preview the film and release it. He estimated that his competitors spent well in excess of $12 million each to promote their films. **********MGM-Pathe's problems are so great that this film, no matter how well it does, cannot turn the studio around. **********Still, Mr. Morrison said, "it will put us on solid footing, and it will certainly boost morale." **********And, he added, "It's good for our customers to show that there is life in the lion. It's a good launching pad for us." **********Even two mega-hits like "Silence of the Lambs" and "Dances With Wolves" could not save Orion Pictures from a financial overhaul brought on by its mountain of debt. **********In its first week, "Thelma and Louise" took in $7.7 million at the box office. That is less than "Hudson Hawk," for example, an action film that stars Bruce Willis and brought in $8.5 million at the box office. But per theater, "Thelma and Louise" did better.  1 Percent More Business **********More important, Mr. Friedberg said yesterday, "Thelma and Louise" did 1 percent more business on Friday and Saturday of this weekend that it had on the previous weekend at the same number of theaters. **********It had been expected to do less business yesterday than on the previous Sunday, which was part of a holiday weekend. In contrast, "Backdraft," the action film about firefighters that is directed by Ron Howard and stars Robert DeNiro and Kurt Russell, was down 18 percent from the previous weekend's two-day opening. Another industry executive noted yesterday that "Hudson Hawk" was down 43 percent, a disastrous drop. In general, even hit films do not do as well the second weekend as the first. **********Studio executives said "Thelma and Louise" was probably the fourth-highest grossing film of the weekend, after "Backdraft," "Soap Dish" and "What About Bob?"  Heavy Competition **********To prove itself a real hit, the movie faces heavy competition from coming releases. Over the weekend, Paramount's "Soap Dish" opened strongly. And theater owners appear to have an embarrassment of riches. **********The early word on Columbia Pictures' "City Slickers," with Billy Crystal, is very good. And Warner Brothers' "Robin Hood, Prince of Thieves," with Kevin Costner, is scheduled to open June 14. Theater owners say the only uncertainty is how big a hit it will be, given Mr. Costner's attractiveness to an older audience and the story's overall appeal. **********Despite all the publicity surrounding its rumored budget of well over $70 million, Carolco's "Terminator II: Judgment Day," starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, is also expected to do well. **********Whether "Thelma and Louise" will hold its own, particularly in the more suburban and rural markets, remains to be seen.  International Appeal **********One of the advantages that "Terminator II" and "Backdraft" both have is their international appeal because they are action movies with stories that are not inherently American. "Thelma and Louise," with its depiction of two women on their own, could well be a harder sell overseas, despite the fact the film was well-received at the Cannes Film Festival. **********But for now, MGM-Pathe is focusing on the American market. Mr. Morrison said the studio was advertising heavily on cable television, with spots on network television as well. **********Initially, the company was aimed its advertising at women. But having succeeded in luring that audience, "it is turning the dial slightly more toward men," Mr. Morrison said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/busin.body_text: **********After almost two years of struggling with its previous investments as the "junk bond" market collapsed, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the giant buyout firm that became a corporate titan in the 1980's, appears to be back on a roll. **********In one week, the firm, which has not made a large purchase in two years, began to snap up corporate properties again. It backed the bid that won Federal approval to buy the assets of the Bank of New England. And K-III Holdings, a company controlled by Kohlberg, Kravis, agreed to buy nine publications from Rupert Murdoch's debt-laden News Corporation for $650 million. **********The deals are vastly different from the firm's well-worn leveraged buyout formula. Kohlberg, Kravis became known in the 80's for breakups -- selling pieces of a company to reduce the mountains of debt used in the purchase. But in the 90's, it is turning to "build-ups," in which it enlarges existing companies by acquiring assets. A Consistent Philosophy **********In both the Bank of New England and Murdoch deals, Kohlberg, Kravis used its own capital to purchase the assets of troubled companies. The firm is injecting $283 million into the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., a financial services company, for the purchase of the Bank of New England assets. To support the Murdoch deal, it is expected to make another investment in K-III, a company formed by three former executives of the publisher Macmillan Inc. with backing from Kohlberg, Kravis. **********"The two deals are very similar in philosophy," said one executive with ties to Kohlberg, Kravis. "It is an investment of their funds' capital in a program of building up a business." **********The strategy is again putting Kohlberg, Kravis at the front of some high-profile deals. But even some investors with the firm say they do not believe the approach will enable the company to regain the fantastic returns on investments -- as much as 63 percent on an annualized basis on its first 16 deals -- it enjoyed in the mid-80's. **********The new deals are far smaller than the firm's mega-transactions, like the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. -- which, with financing expenses, ultimately cost Kohlberg, Kravis $32 billion -- negotiated in late 1988 and early 1989. But the deals signal that Kohlberg, Kravis is ready to start reaching into its deep pockets again. And the two new deals show that the firm is continuing to rely on borrowed money. **********In large part, the switch from selling assets after a leveraged buyout to buying assets from troubled companies reflects the current condition of the economy, investment managers and Wall Street professionals say. **********"I think building companies now makes extraordinary sense," said Scott Sperling, a partner at the Harvard Management Company, which runs the endowment fund for the university and is an investor with Kohlberg, Kravis. The buyout firm "has the ability to buy low," he said. "Backing a superior management team to acquire those sorts of pieces I think is a brilliant way of approaching the business." Built From Scratch **********From its beginnings in 1976, Kohlberg, Kravis used leveraged buyouts to rise from next to nothing -- it had just $3 million to invest in 1976 -- to control an empire that includes RJR Nabisco, supermarket chains, like Stop and Shop and Safeway Inc., and Duracell International Inc. Since its inception, the firm has acquired 36 companies at a cost of about $65 billion. **********The debt-driven buyout helped make the firm's founders extremely wealthy. Henry R. Kravis, George R. Roberts and their former partner, Jerome Kohlberg Jr., who left in 1987 over what partners said was his concern about the size of the firm's deals, are each estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars. At the same time, Mr. Kravis assumed a prominent role in New York society, particularly since his marriage in 1985 to Carolyne Roehm, a fashion designer. Mr. Roberts, who is Mr. Kravis's cousin, works out of the firm's San Francisco office and tends to shun publicity. **********In a leveraged buyout, a group of investors buys a company, often in cooperation with top managers, and pays for it mostly with borrowed money. In theory, the new owners begin cutting away at excess, dismissing unneeded employees and selling operations that have little to do with the core business. The company is then resold for a handsome profit. Tapping Pools of Capital **********Kohlberg, Kravis raised the equity used in the buyouts by selling its investment skills to institutional investors and money managers. Since 1978, the firm has tapped its investors' capital pools six times for the formation of different buyout funds, and recently went back to investors to replenish the fund collected in 1987. The firm says it manages the money of more than 70 institutions. **********In past years, when the firm put in only about 10 percent equity, it greatly increased the potential return for itself and its investors through the high degree of leverage. Now, with banks less willing to lend for highly leveraged transactions and the junk bond market essentially unavailable for raising large amounts of capital, Kohlberg, Kravis expects that the equity portion of deals could rise as high as 30 percent. **********With more capital required for leveraged buyouts, the firm is exploring other investment strategies, company documents and Wall Street executives indicate.  Using a Minority Stake **********Kohlberg, Kravis has also adopted a so-called "toehold" approach to investing, in which it takes a minority stake in a publicly held company and uses its own investment as a signal of its confidence in the concern. The best known of those is its 9.9 percent holding in First Interstate Bancorp. **********At the same time, Kohlberg, Kravis has been dipping into the capital markets to shore up the balance sheets of companies it bought in leveraged buyouts. Indeed, this month, Kohlberg, Kravis turned to the stock and bond markets six times, raising money for Safeway, Autozone Inc. and RJR Nabisco. A stock offering for Duracell International is awaiting approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission.  The Firm's High Fees **********The firm's investors are now wondering if the changes in investment strategy will be able to bring them returns close to those in the 80's, enough to justify paying the firm's high fees. Under the fee structure, Kohlberg, Kravis charges a 1.5 percent annual fee for managing the money invested with it, as well as investment banking fees, divestiture fees, consulting fees and a smattering of other charges. **********On its four largest deals, the firm is estimated to have charged its limited partners $240 million up front. And on top of that, the firm gets to keep 20 percent of any capital gains from an investment. **********Some limited partners in past Kohlberg, Kravis ventures voiced objections when the firm began seeking $1 billion to $2 billion to replenish the $5.6 billion buyout fund that the firm raised in 1987. The investors wanted Kohlberg, Kravis to cut its fees and change the method by which the firm treats gains and losses of companies in its portfolio.  Protected Profits **********Kohlberg, Kravis treats each company in its portfolio separately, giving itself 20 percent of the profits of every company that does well, while only taking 1 percent of the losses for the poor performers. The firm can profit even if the limited partners do not. **********"They make a lot of money whether or not I as a limited partner make money," said Mr. Sperling of Harvard, who has not decided whether he will invest in the new Kohlberg, Kravis fund. "We want them to make money, but only after we make money." **********Some institutional investors are finding that by using the asset-investing strategy by themselves they are able to produce returns equal to those from Kohlberg, Kravis when their costs of investing in the firm are considered. And that is leading them to stay out of this round of money raising. **********But despite the grumbling, Kohlberg, Kravis's track record is still bringing in the institutional investors. **********"I don't blame them for sticking to their guns on the fee issue," the manager of another fund that still invests with the firm said. "If I could get the money on those terms, I wouldn't change things either."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.main_headline: A Store on Fifth Avenue Will Be 'Totally French'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; A Store on Fifth Avenue Will Be 'Totally French'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/busin.body_text: **********With such formidable competitors as Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and Henri Bendel ensconced nearby, the Galeries Lafayette fashion store opening in midtown Manhattan this fall plans an aggressively French merchandising strategy to differentiate itself from its American rivals. **********"It will be totally French," Georges Meyer, Galeries Lafayette's chairman and chief executive, said of the store, which opens in September on West 57th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues. "Not French as Americans might expect a French store to be, but truly French in merchandise, assortments, presentation and floor organization." **********In making their first extensive remarks about merchandising since announcing plans for their first American store, Mr. Meyer and other Galeries Lafayette executives acknowledged that they were taking a calculated risk. Opening a new and unfamiliar store during a severe retailing slump means they will have to make an extra effort to create the niche the store needs to succeed. **********Some retailing experts already question whether being French will be enough for Galeries Lafayette to compete with existing high-profile, high-fashion stores in New York. Others said they were not sure shoppers would even notice much of a French difference.  Mix-and-Match Instincts **********But Mr. Meyer and Eugenia Ulasewicz, a former Bloomingdale's executive who is now president of Galeries Lafayette USA, said they were confident that shoppers would like the difference. **********For example, Ms. Ulasewicz said, the new store will offer blouses and skirts from many different designers or suppliers. That will let customers give full range to their mix-and-match instincts. American stores tend to concentrate on selling what their managers consider matching or complementary clothes, often made by the same company. **********And because French women "use a lot of accessories," Ms. Ulasewicz said, there will be several varied in-store boutiques, most featuring French designer scarves, handbags, gloves and jewelry. But, also in the French manner, these accessories will be displayed much more openly. Scarves, for example, will hang from wall clips, rather than lie flat on a glass showcase. **********While stores like Saks have somewhat similar displays, they are usually more limited and not designed as the major sales focus. **********Galeries Lafayette executives have already said that in a sharp departure from operations of their 20 stores in Western Europe and Singapore, the Manhattan store will sell only women's clothing and accessories. The others also carry men's or children's clothes. **********There will be only French designer labels, no Americans featured in the store, Ms. Ulasewicz said. But about 30 percent of Galeries private-label goods will be made by American suppliers, she said. **********Some of the French designers with their own boutiques and own salespeople in the store will be Sonia Rykiel, accessories; Gaultier Juniors, junior apparel, and Claudie Pierlot, sportswear. **********Still, Norman Matthews, a former president of Federated Department Stores and now a consultant, cautioned that Galeries might find it difficult to break into the local market. **********"This is a very tough and thin market for retailing, especially for stores with higher price lines," Mr. Matthews said. "Galeries will be hard pressed to develop a niche amid the confluence of Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman, Henri Bendel and a Barneys New York store to come. So it will take extraordinary merchandise assortments and fine customer service to convince affluent customers that the new store is the first place to shop." **********Mr. Meyer, in his first interview in New York since the company announced it would take over the space that formerly held Bonwit Teller's flagship store, said the decision to sell only women's clothing had come about partly because of the size of the store, on the Fifth Avenue side in Trump Tower. It has 80,000 square feet, half of which will be selling space, which is not be enough to "appropriately" accommodate anything other than women's apparel, he said. **********Another reason is simply pragmatic strategy. "We are hoping for first-year sales of about $40 million," Mr. Meyer said.
