"That means that we should get about $1,000 a square foot of selling space, which we can achieve more through the higher turnover in women's wear than in other types of clothes." **********Or, put another way, since Saks and Bergdorf do sell men's and children's wear and are much larger stores, Galeries had to select goods with the highest sales potential. **********Galeries, which will employ about 200 people, is starting off with one plus. Its 25-year lease with Donald J. Trump, owner of Trump Tower, gave the French store one year rent free. That time is being used to prepare the store for the September opening, when rental payments will begin. Ms. Ulasewicz declined to say how much rent the company would be paying. "It is quite high, but the fine location is worth it," she said. **********Ms. Ulasewicz said the store would carry three main types of clothes: "better, bridge and designer." In the first group, a jacket-skirt combination would retail from $400 to $700; in the "bridge," a trade term meaning clothes in between "better" and designer, the same ensemble would sell from $800 to $900. Designer clothes would start at $1,000. **********But the new store will not offer any haute couture, or "top of the line" clothes, in the belief that the United States market will not support very high-priced fashions in great volume. **********"I recently hired a team of buyers from different kinds of American stores to provide a variety of backgrounds," Ms. Ulasewicz said. "When we go to the market, we will be able to buy French clothes for a variety of people that our buyers have sold goods to for years. So we feel that we can then apply our knowledge of the American market to the designer and other clothes available from France." **********To find out whether American women would be interested in shopping at a store selling nothing but French clothes, the company conducted a survey last October of 3,000 shoppers and visitors at Trump Tower. **********"We happily found that many of them knew of us by reputation," Mr. Meyer said, "and others knew us by having been in Paris."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/08/busin.body_text: **********Canada's unemployment rate rose slightly last month from the April level, but Government economists said an increase in the country's manufacturing and construction sector was a sign that the economy was improving. The Government agency Statistics Canada said that the jobless rate for May was 10.3 percent, up from 10.2 percent the previous month. About 46,000 new jobs were created in the month, mostly in manufacturing. "It is encouraging that we saw some upturn in employment in the bracket hardest hit in the recession," said Peter Drake, a senior economist at the Toronto-Dominion Bank.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/01/busin.main_headline: For Independent Truckers, Roads Lead to Riches
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/01/busin.print_headline: For Independent Truckers, Roads Lead to Riches
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/01/busin.body_text: **********For months Rodney and Rogene Johnson spent up to 22 hours a day running their truck from Pittsburgh to the West Coast, hauling butter and cheese and bringing back produce. She would take over the wheel so he could crawl into the back of the cab and sleep. "The only time we weren't running was to load, gas up and eat," she recalled. **********The grueling pace -- averaging about 5,000 miles a week -- would go on for weeks in an effort to meet expenses and a $2,200 monthly payment on their new $80,000 Kenworth truck. "If you could make your truck payment and live, that was a lot," he recalled. **********The Johnsons have done better than live. Formed in October 1988, their trucking company, Buffalo Express, has grown to five trucks and six drivers, with further expansion insight. "Sometimes I could use 10 more trucks" Mr. Johnson said as he sat on the couch on one of his rare days at their ranch-style house in a suburb of Pittsburgh. **********Unlike airlines, which rarely see new competitors, trucking firms are joined every year by thousands of new start-ups like Buffalo Express, thanks to deregulation. The number of trucking companies has grown from 18,045 in 1980, when trucking rates were deregulated, to 45,791 in 1990. **********In part, their proliferation has to do with the low cost of entry. All an entrepreneur needs to get started is a truck and the proper authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission, compared to the tens of millions of dollars a new airline needs for gates, landing slots and planes, even before it has to cope with the vicious price wars typical of the industry. **********But the ease of entry has also driven up trucking's failure rates, as operators with too little experience or business sense rushed in -- and were edged out nearly as fast. About 13,000 companies have gone out of business since 1980. The failure rate peaked in 1986, when more than 200 of every 10,000 companies went under, compared with the pre-deregulation rate of about 50 per 10,000. The rate has since fallen to below 150 for every 10,000 companies. **********"One of the great American liberties is the right to fail economically," said Tom Donohue, the president of the American Trucking Association. **********The survivors, however, may be in for tougher times as large shippers reduce the number of trucking companies they use, in an effort to simplify billing and shipping. **********With foreign competition increasing and the recession dragging on, many companies recently have re-examined the costs of inventory and transportation. Many decided they were willing to pay higher rates in return for the reliability and more sophisticated handling that larger and established carriers offer. **********Procter & Gamble, for example, has set a goal of cutting down to 35 trucking companies by 1992, from 350. "This is happening all over the place," Mr. Donohue said, and it will tend to make it tougher for the smaller companies to make it. **********The trucking industry is divided into two main classes. "Less than truckload" carriers, who make up about a third of the business, haul small shipments from many points to large regional terminals and then truck the freight to destinations all over the country. Dominated by a handful of large companies -- including Yellow Freight System, Roadway Services and Consolidated Freightways -- this segment's high costs for building terminals and large networks have prevented any newcomers from entering. **********The remaining two thirds of the industry consists of "full truckload" long hauls, usually between a single sender and a single receiver. This part of the industry is fragmented into thousands of carriers, although a few companies, including Schneider National Inc., and J.B. Hunt Transport Services Inc., have taken advantage of deregulation and expanded to become dominant players. **********Upstarts like Buffalo Express concentrate on this segment. For the Johnsons, the path to success was long and arduous. It was also filled with lucky breaks that came from having made personal contacts with key customers who gave them the critical initial business. **********For years Mr. Johnson, who still has some of the self-mocking humor of the North Dakota farm country where he grew up, drove his truck for other companies. Generally he paid them commissions of 18 to 25 percent for supplying him with loads. Many years, he made barely enough to cover his expenses, he recalled. **********The couple were married in 1983 and began to share the burdens. The children of both their previous marriages were grown. She is 54 and he is 45. **********"He's got more miles and I've got more years," she quipped. **********After their marriage, Mr. Johnson taught his wife how to drive a big rig, and they joined the increasing number of husband and wife teams that now drive many of the nation's trucks. **********By working together and running day after day, they managed to save enough money to buy a new truck in 1987, trading in a 10-year-old Peterbilt for a Kenworth. But like other owner-operators, they still generally paid companies to supply them with loads. **********"We were still paying $25,000 to $30,000 a year to be tied to a company to get the loads," Mrs. Johnson recalled. **********For some six to ten weeks at a time they would drive most of the day -- up to 22 hours. They spent so little time in their apartment in Fargo, N. D., that they gave it up and put their furniture in storage. **********"We were just paying the rent for nothing," Mrs. Johnson said. "I was on the road for six years when we did not have a home. Home was where my truck was." **********After they gave up their apartment, they spent their rare days off mostly watching television and reading at motels in truck stops. Mrs. Johnson also knitted. "I kept myself occupied," she said. **********He bore the brunt of the driving. "I was really not that good a driver but good enough to stay between the ditches so he could get some sleep for a few hours," she recalled. **********Being confined to the cramped quarters of a tractor cab often strained the relationship, but the Johnsonskept on trucking. **********There were also periods when they were down to a few dollars after they made their truck payment and other expenses. Once, when an attempt to find a load of potatoes to haul from Billings, Mont., had failed, they were down to $2 while driving through Nevada. They decided to turn off at Las Vegas and cash in a coupon that gave them $295 in money to gamble, which Mr. Johnson turned into $340 by playing the slot machines -- enough to hold them over until they got paid for a haul. **********Their hard work enabled them to pay off the first truck in three years. **********The Johnsons also became regulars hauling for Pinnacle Food of Pittsburgh. While most shippers deal with truck drivers largely by phone, the dispatchers at Pinnacle made an effort to get to know them personally. One day in 1988 Mr. Johnson mustered the nerve to ask one of the dispatchers whether he could deal with him directly rather than through a trucking company to which he had to pay an 18 percent commission. **********When he was given a "yes," he scrambled to get authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission. Like any new trucking company, the Johnsons had to get authority from every state in which they wanted to operate, and affix what is called a "Bingo" stamp to their truck as proof. They also had to get a stamp proving that they were paying each state's fuel tax for trucks. Mrs. Johnson calculated the total cost of the fees involved at about $1,500 each year. **********To start, they got temporary authority from the I.C.C., good for seven days at a cost of $1,200. But they did not have fuel tax stickers required to operate in every state they wished. **********Boldly, they drove without all the required stickers and got them as quickly as they could, holding their breath every time they had to pass through scales in states where they did not have the sticker. "We were like outlaws," Mrs. Johnson recalled. **********Within four months, they had all their permits and could haul without fear. **********By May of the following year, they had landed another regular customer, a produce wholesaler in Pittsburgh. They decided to hire an owner operator who now paid them the 18 percent commission to get loads. **********But eventually Mr. Johnson decided he could get more reliable work by hiring his own drivers as employees. It was not an easy decision, because finding good drivers is hard even for large companies that offer good wages and benefits. Many employees do not want to put up with the long hours, the extended periods away from home and the loneliness of trucking. New drivers often leave for the same reasons. But Mr. Johnson felt he had no choice. "We have dedicated freight," he said. "We handle it or we lose it." **********The Johnsons hope that the training and personal touch they offer will help them keep employees. **********By 1990, the Johnsons had bought three more trucks with $270,000 in financing, given by a bank on the strength of their credit standing and the prospects of steady business from two major customers. **********Those two companies have sent other customers their way. But their new prosperity has not changed the Johnsons' frugal lifestyle. She still takes in sewing to make extra money and he is still working long hours for weeks at a time. **********On Mondays, he loads on the West Coast for delivery on Thursdays in Pittsburgh. He then loads again on Thursday nights to deliver on Sunday nights on the West Coast. Mr. Johnson had hoped that being his own boss would relax his schedule. But he must still answer to his customers. **********"You always get a boss," he said with resignation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/world.main_headline: Volcano's Ash Dismays Filipinos and Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/world.print_headline: Volcano's Ash Dismays Filipinos and Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/world.body_text: **********On both sides of the heavy steel gate that separates this city from Subic Bay Naval Station, the sprawling American naval base, there was a shared sense of hopelessness today. **********Five days after Mount Pinatubo covered much of this coastal region with layer upon layer of volcanic ash and sand, which has been turned into a quagmire by the constant rains, the situation had only worsened. **********There was only intermittent electricity today, little running water and a sense of concern about the future. **********There is talk by officials here and in Washington that the cleanup costs from the volcano, 35 miles northwest of Subic, may be so great and the future of the base so precarious that the United States may have to make some hard decisions on whether to keep Subic and the American-run Clark Air Base. The joint lease on the bases runs out in September, and talks had been suspended because the Filipinos had rejected an American offer as too low. Now, many Filipinos wish the lease had been signed.  'How Will We Make Money?' **********Here, in Olongapo, a typical city that depends on a military base to survive, many Filipinos strolling past the honky-tonk saloons along Magsaysay Drive this afternoon said the closing of Subic Bay would be an economic calamity. **********"Maybe the Americans won't come back because of the volcano," said a 21-year-old e bar hostess, who gave her name only as Miki. "The Americans always talk about how they might have to leave Subic and go home forever." **********"But how will we make money if they go?" she said. **********Because of the volcano the bar was virtually empty of customers. A Yearlong Cleanup **********"In some ways, life might be good -- better -- without the Americans," she continued. "But how will we survive?" **********Frankie Dana, a 27-year-old T-shirt salesman born in Olongapo, was hawking shirts stenciled with the words, "I Survived Mount Pinatubo." **********"My only buyers are Americans," he said, frantically trying to cover the shirts with a plastic sheet to protect them from a rainy season downpour. "Americans are all we have." **********The cleanup of Subic base, one of the largest American military installations outside the United States and a cornerstone of American security policy in Asia since World War II, will take months, if not a year or more, officials at the base say. **********Thick layers of ash emitted by Mount Pinatubo cover virtually every inch of the 100,000-acre installation. **********Soaked by rain, the ash, which has the appearance of caked, dirty snow and the consistency of wet charcoal, is jamming electrical generators and has contaminated much of the fresh water supply in Olongapo and at Subic. Scores of buildings at the naval base have collapsed from the ash's weight. **********"We got some running water today," said Petty Officer Jerry Moore, a base spokesman. "We were glad to see it, even if it's only for drinking. We still don't smell very good." **********Although volcano scientists say the major eruptions of Mount Pinatubo appear to be over, the Defense Department is pressing forward with the evacuation of nearly 20,000 Americans from the Philippines, including the families of all military and civilian workers at Subic and Clark.  Families Shipping Out **********Hundreds of the families waited in line this afternoon outside a bowling alley at Subic that was serving as an evacuation center. **********"I absolutely understand why the Navy is doing this, but it's still been tears all round for my family," said Petty Officer First Class Patrick Dunn, 34, of Kansas City, Mo., who had come to the evacuation center to see his Filipino wife, Eva, and their three children depart. **********"You can't keep families here when there are no showers and no electricity," he said. "I've never seen anything like this. This ash is everywhere and I don't know how you clean it up." **********Anne Comer, the wife of a Navy lieutenant assigned to Subic, held tight to 1-year-old Kathryn, the youngest of her five children.  Clouds of Volcanic Ash **********"We're supposed to be shipping out tonight and I have to leave my husband behind," said Mrs. Comer, 39, who looked weary from five days of ash storms and earthquakes brought on by the volcano. **********"Basically I've had no sleep since this began," she said. "The stress level is very, very high for everyone." **********Air traffic has been shut down throughout the central Philippines for several days out of fear that the swirling clouds of volcanic ash might cause jet engines to stall. **********The international and domestic airports in Manila, about 65 miles southeast of Subic Bay, have been closed to most flights for five days. **********That has required the Defense Department to evacuate the Americans by sea, aboard warships that have been put on a shuttle run this week between Subic and the Philippine city of Cebu, about 300 miles south of the base, where the international airport has not been affected by the ash. **********A city that grew up out of the Subic base to service the United States Navy and to entertain generations of American sailors, Olongapo and its 300,000 residents are nothing if not resilient. **********Several of the city's best-known places, with names like "The Body Shop" and "Love Disco" were shut down or destroyed by the volcano. **********But others have struggled to remain open despite the loss of electrical power and the six-foot-high mounds of volcanic ash and sand clogging the street.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********"Realizing the Benefits of a Good Name" (Forum, June 16) proposes a new corporate position, a chief reputation officer who would report either to the chief executive or to the board. Trouble is, there's already a chief reputation officer -- the chief executive. If a chief executive needs input before making a decision affecting the company's reputation, presumably he can get good advice from the chief communicator of the company. **********If the chief reputation officer set himself up as some sort of a czar, "the body would reject the transplant," as they say in the medical game.  FLOYD A. OLIVER Los Angeles, June 21

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/11/world.body_text: **********The Communists, overwhelming victors in Albania's first multi-party election in decades, proposed a constitution today that would embrace human rights and pluralism but fall short of full democracy. **********The draft of the document, due for approval when the new Parliament meets next week, also gives sweeping powers to the President, who is likely to be the Communist incumbent, Ramiz Alia. Mr. Alia lost his Parliament seat in the elections, but the proposed constitution says Presidents do not have to be Parliament members. **********The three-page document would drop the word Socialist from the country's official name, and emphasize human rights, the sanctity of private property and free enterprise, and the separation of party and state. But it leaves significant traces of the Stalinist past. **********It decrees a depoliticizing of the army and police and the Interior, Justice and Foreign ministries, but stops short of outlawing party politics at other ministries and state institutions. It would also enshrine the present Albanian flag with its Communist star. **********In two-stage elections that ended April 7, the Party of Labor, or Communist Party, won 168 of the 250 seats in Parliament seats. That was one more than required for the two-thirds margin needed to approve a constitution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/22/busin.body_text: **********A big turnaround in the United States economy could come by May or June, the Bush Administration's budget director, Richard G. Darman, said today. **********But he said chances for a full recovery were clouded by the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and by banks' lending policies. **********"We're in the process of turning," Mr. Darman said on "Newsmaker Sunday," a Cable News Network program. "I think that there's about a 70 percent chance, I would say, that people will look back at May or June and say, in one of those two months, we turned."But Mr. Darman expressed limited confidence in the Fed and said a tight monetary policy and the lack of credit could derail the recovery. **********"I think the real growth potential of the economy is higher than the Fed does," he said, "and I think that if the Fed continues to believe it's as low as it is, it's self-fulfilling." **********Mr. Darman said the Persian Gulf war helped to stimulate the economy by restoring consumer confidence, making the cost of the war fairly insignificant. He said the war's costs to the United States should not exceed the projected $15 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/15/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Arabs; Arabs in Many Nations Protest Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/15/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: The Arabs; Arabs in Many Nations Protest Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/15/world.body_text: **********Flags were at half-staff and tempers in full cry in many Arab nations today, as people took to the streets to grieve for Iraq's civilian dead and to damn the United States for what they called a deliberate massacre of women and children. **********Protests swept across several countries, including Yemen, the Sudan, Libya and Tunisia, which along with Jordan declared a period of national mourning. **********But on this matter, as on the war itself, the Arab world revealed its deep divisions. Countries like Egypt and Syria, which belong to the anti-Iraq coalition, blame President Saddam Hussein for the civilian deaths, accusing him of leading his own people to slaughter by refusing to withdraw his troops from Kuwait. **********No group was more outraged by the American action that Palestinians. In the occupied West Bank, they began what was scheduled to be a three-day commercial strike, while thousands of other Palestinians marched through the narrow alleys of refugee districts in Lebanon. Avoidance of Land War Seen **********Palestinian leaders based in Tunis and Damascus said the bombing in Baghdad on Wednesday was an "abominable crime." Some of them charged that it was part of an American war of extermination being waged against Iraq's people to avoid confronting the Iraqi Army in a ground war. **********Their accusations reverberated across the angry streets of Jordan, where half the people are Palestinians and where sentiment for Mr. Hussein as an Arab champion runs strong. **********"Is this how they are going to liberate Kuwait?" said Walid Tarabsha, a chemical engineer who was reading this morning's black headlines at a newsstand in downtown Amman. "Does this now give me the right too, to go out and kill every civilian I see?" **********That was not the view, however, from Arab nations intent on removing Mr. Hussein from Kuwait and from power, even though they also expressed pain over the deaths of civilians.  Syria Assails Hussein **********In a commentary, the state-controlled Damascus radio said in the Syrian capital: "The heart of every Arab bleeds when the pictures of death and destruction are shown, except for one heart that remains unmoved. It is the heart of the ruler in Baghdad, who could put an end to this if only feelings of pain could touch his heart." **********Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, also attacked Mr. Hussein personally, saying, "It is inconceivable for a ruler to make propaganda hay from the corpses of his citizens." **********The deaths in Baghdad were totally ignored by some Saudi Arabian newspapers and scantly covered by others. In gulf oil states like Dubai and Qatar, newspapers spoke scornfully of Mr. Hussein, accusing him of having remorselessly committed war crimes on a huge scale over the years. **********On Amman's sun-bleached streets and in the sullen lanes of the Beqaa Palestinian district 15 miles outside the city, no one could be found who believed the United States version of events: that a reinforced concrete building bombed in a residential neighborhood of Baghdad was a military command and control bunker and not the civilian bomb shelter the Iraqis said it was. Attacks Called Deliberate **********There was virtually universal agreement in the district that American bombers were deliberately going after civilians and that the targets included Jordanians trying to flee the war. On Wednesday, refugees crossing into Jordan from Iraq reported that 30 Jordanian civilians on the road from Baghdad, including four children, had been burned to death on Saturday when their bus came under an allied air attack. **********"The Americans knew these were civilian targets," said Mahmoud Daoud, a 34-year-old civil engineer. "American has failed in its military campaign. It has not stopped the Iraqi military. So now it is hitting civilian targets." **********The Jordanian Government, denouncing the bombing in Baghdad as a "horrible massacre," declared three days of national mourning and ordered that flags fly at half-staff on official buildings. Across the capital, people also draped black flags from lampposts. **********King Hussein, who last week abandoned his previously professed neutrality in the war to side with Iraq, demanded that the United Nations Security Council order an immediate cease-fire and send an investigating team to Baghdad. United Nations resolutions authorizing force to remove Iraq from Kuwait were being used, the King said, to "wage a war of systematic destruction against Iraq" that constituted a "flagrant and callous violation of humanitarian law." March on Embassy Blocked **********On Wednesday night, police officers turned away about 1,000 Jordanians who had tried to march on the United States Embassy in Amman. But apparently in an attempt to defuse rising tensions, the Government imposed no such restraints today. **********Hundreds of protesters stood outside the embassy's main entrance, where at one point they hurled stones and clumps of dirt scooped up from plant beds. Some of them then marched to the nearby Egyptian Embassy, where they broke several windows. In another part of the city, demonstrators also broke windows at a building that houses United Nations organizations. **********None of these protests led to injuries. But on Wednesday night, a German student in his early 20's was stabbed in the chest by a Jordanian man who was described by the authorities as emotionally overwrought after watching televised images of the Baghdad disaster. The police said he had attacked the first foreigner he saw, thinking he was an American. **********The victim was said by the German Embassy to be in fair condition at a military hospital. U.S. Seen as Losing **********For some street protesters, the civilian casualties in Baghdad had a positive note. To them, it suggested that the United States must be losing the war, because otherwise, they argued, it would not be resorting to what were viewed here as acts of desperation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/04/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Prices Modestly Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/04/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher yesterday in thin trading before the Fourth of July holiday. **********A report of a 3.3 percent decline in new home sales during May, the second straight monthly drop, was seen as a catalyst behind the price improvement. **********The gains held as the session wore on, despite reports from the nation's major auto makers that sales in the last 10 days of June reached 7.4 million units at an adjusted annual rate, a figure that was well above market expectations and was the best 10-day rate since December. **********"The car sales numbers should have upset the market, but they didn't," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., research firm. Employment Data Ahead **********With all American financial markets closed today, yesterday's activity mostly represented last-minute positioning before the Labor Department's scheduled release of June employment data tomorrow morning. **********Reports released earlier this week, particularly the June survey of the nation's purchasing managers, have portrayed an economy that seems slightly stronger than anticipated. **********But the latest statistics have not caused economists to massage their employment forecasts much. After a surprising increase of 25,000 jobs in May, most economists anticipate that non-farm payroll employment was unchanged to down slightly in June. Estimates range from a decline of 100,000 in payroll jobs to an increase of 75,000. Most analysts anticipate that the unemployment rate, which stood at 6.9 percent in May, will show a bit of an increase.  Delayed Reaction? **********Although the employment numbers often determine the tone for trading activity for the balance of each month, reaction to the June employment numbers may be delayed for a few days, traders and analysts said. Many credit market participants are taking Friday off, thereby creating a very long weekend out of the Fourth of July holiday. **********"I wonder how many people will be willing to take positions on Friday," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at the Paine Webber Group Inc., "because ultimate buyers and sellers are not likely to be around." **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities yesterday, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 7/8 late in the day, up 7/32, to yield 8.41 percent, down from 8.43 percent late Tuesday. **********Among note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 13/ 32, up 3/32, to yield 8.23 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 2/32, up 1/32, to yield 6.96 percent. **********Late in the session, the Treasury announced that it would sell $9 billion worth of seven-year notes on July 10. The size of the offering was roughly in line with market expectations.  Movement Into Bills **********Yesterday's sharp slide in stock prices -- the Dow Jones industrial average lost 38.02 points -- helped to push down short-term Treasury bill rates, as investors left stocks and moved funds into more liquid and safe securities like bills. **********By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.54 percent, down a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.66 percent. And one-year bill rates dipped by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.98 percent. **********Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was very light, traders said. Prices of most issues were unchanged to up 1/4 point. **********Trading was also slow in the tax-exempt municipal bond market. Prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged, dealers said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Oilfields; Extent of Kuwaiti Oil Damage Unclear
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Oilfields; Extent of Kuwaiti Oil Damage Unclear
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/world.body_text: **********With reports that most of Kuwait's oil wells have been set ablaze by Iraqi forces, Kuwaiti and other specialists said today that the full extent and severity of damage could only be determined when the installations were closely examined. **********These experts emphasize that the country's fundamental source of wealth -- oil in the ground -- is unaffected by what happens on the surface. **********The Pentagon said yesterday that Iraq had set ablaze 150 wells in the preceeding 24 hours or so, up from 50 a week ago. But specialists in oil fires said this does not necessarily imply major damage to the wells. That, they say, depends on the state of the "Christmas tree," the cluster of valves on top of the well. **********"If they set a fire on the Christmas tree, and leave a valve that's workable, you just turn it off," said Danny Clayton, a senior firefighter with Red Adair Co., Inc., of Houston. Referring to Saddam Hussein, Mr. Clayton said, "If he's doing this just to make a smokescreen, there may be no damage to some of the wells." **********If there are no workable valves, he said, a crew must excavate around the well until it comes to intact casing, and then put a new top on the well -- something like installing a new faucet on the end of a broken pipe while water is flowing out. The fire must be extinguished first, however. Small fires can be put out with water; firefighters use dynamite on larger ones to burn off the available oxygen. **********A major fire can take a team of six men about two weeks of work to extinguish, Mr. Clayton said. His company can dispatch two such teams, and he put the worldwide total at eight teams, raising the possibility that extinguishing all the fires would take weeks.  Relative Efficiency **********Prewar Kuwait used just 365 wells, in which oil was propelled to the surface by natural pressure, to produce 1.6 million barrels of oil a day, or about 4,400 barrels per well. By contrast, the United States produces about four and a half times as much oil, but has about 600,000 wells, with an average production of 12 barrels a day. **********Kuwaiti exile authorities have for months been buying goods and contracting for services in order to begin exploiting the country's oil reserves as soon as possible after the Iraqis leave. **********"Our goal is to provide relief to the population inside and restore production," said Fawzi al-Sultan, a Kuwaiti who headed the Kuwait Emergency Relief Program until the end of last year. A team in Houston has been buying wellheads, pumps and other spare equipment, he said. **********Crude-oil exports will resume within months, he said, "even with a scorched-earth policy." But rebuilding the refineries would take much longer, he acknowledged. **********Some other experts are less optimistic, noting that before oil shipments reach meaningful levels, pipelines, pumping stations and terminals must be rebuilt. Reconstruction of ports and roads may also be required. Much Rebuilding to Do **********Another problem in restoring Kuwait's oil industry may be rebuilding the country's basic services and installations. **********"You've got to produce housing or get trailers in," said Ken Miller, editorial director of OPEC Listener, an oil-analysis service, who formerly lived in Kuwait. "You have to get water, food, communications, everything." **********Mr. Sultan minimized this problem. Major contractors, he said, "go in self-sufficent. They're all used to it." After two or three weeks to open the harbor and airports, he said, productive work could begin. **********Even with working wells, the critical factor may be the loading terminal, other experts say. "We bombed the terminal to start with, they damaged it, and we bombed it again," Mr. Miller said. "The oil wells are no good without the infrastructure." **********John J. Healey, of Ebasco, an architect-engineering concern, said that the Kuwaiti export installations were among the largest and most modern in the world. "Everything's big and everything's expensive," he said. **********For the near term, Kuwaiti oil exports are not essential to the world market, with production from other countries having more than made up for oil from Kuwait and Iraq. **********Kuwait's prewar capacity was estimated by specialists at 2.4 million barrels per day; its quota from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was 1.5 million barrels per day. **********Kuwait was also a major exporter of refined oil products, and its refineries were among the most advanced in the world. Rebuilding them will also take years, experts think.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/13/busin.body_text: **********The American Stock Exchange yesterday disclosed details of its plan to allow listed companies to issue separate classes of stock with unequal voting rights for shareholders. **********The details were disclosed in a filing the Amex made yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Under the rules, Amex-listed companies would be able to issue "supervoting" shares, which would provide disproportionate voting powers to their holders, once the companies met certain conditions. **********Some companies retain separate classes of stock, having established them prior to the S.E.C. rule that disallows them. **********The plan has been a point of heated debate both on Wall Street and in Washington, and some industry executives predict that the proposal could send the issue of shareholder voting back to Congress. But the plan clearly would give the Amex a competitive advantage in getting companies to list their stocks on it, rather than on the New York Stock Exchange or the National Association of Securities Dealers' National Market System. **********While the S.E.C. is expected o take months studying the proposal, there appears to be strong resistance to it from many senior officials. "There is a strong feeling that this agency should not do anything that adversely affects shareholder rights," a senior commission official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. **********In a meeting yesterday with reporters in Washington, James R. Jones, the chairman of the exchange, denied that the move to provide unequal voting rights was designed to win a competitive advantage. **********Mr. Jones said that the most important element of the plan was that it would allow a supermajority of two-thirds of all shareholders, or a majority of stockholders not from management, to vote to set up new classes of stock. **********The issue of "one share, one vote" rose in the mid-1980's, after several companies attempted to switch to a two-class system. **********The system can be used to assure that control of a company stays within a family, even after the stock is sold publicly. It has been used by many media companies, including The New York Times Company and The Washington Post Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Uncertain Climate For an Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Uncertain Climate For an Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/11/busin.body_text: **********WOULD you buy stock in a money-losing textile business, one that is undergoing its second restructuring in two years, just before the crucial period when a depressed fashion industry will place its annual fabric orders? **********Forstmann & Company, which says it is the largest American company producing both wool and worsted fabrics, hopes the answer is yes. It filed an offering this week to go public, hoping to raise as much as $46 million. The bulk of the cash is likely to go to Odyssey Partners, which will maintain control of the company through a complex transaction. **********It is Odyssey's role that seems likely to provide the principal selling point for the stock, which is tentatively priced at $11 to $13 a share and is expected to be sold next month. "Essentially, the only way this deal works for them is if going forward, it works for everyone," said Wilbur Ross, an investment banker at Rothschild Inc. who represented the bondholders in the restructuring last year. **********At the same time, potential buyers will be watching with care for signs of a revival in the fashion industry. Most of Forstmann's annual sales come from orders placed between December and April, so the investors are being asked to buy shares without a firm indication of just how good, or bad, orders will be in 1992. **********The saga of Forstmann, which until 1986 was a subsidiary of J. P. Stevens, provides a capsule summary of what went wrong with many leveraged buyouts in the late 1980's, even those involving sophisticated investors. The first leveraged buyout, in 1986, was a success that culminated in a public stock offering in the summer of 1987. But the public overpaid then, and the stock price had plunged by the time the second leveraged buyout was done, in late 1988. **********That buyout was sponsored by Odyssey, a group formed by Jack Nash and Leon Levy, who gained fame and fortune running Oppenheimer & Company, the brokerage firm. Odyssey has compiled an impressive record in other deals, but so far it has been forced to throw good money after bad to protect its stake in Forstmann. Odyssey officials declined to be interviewed yesterday. **********The 1988 buyout price turned out to be too high, so last year it was time for the first restructuring. Odyssey put in more money, and bondholders agreed to a temporary reduction in interest payments. In all, Odyssey has sunk $13 million into Forstmann stock. When the current transactions are done, that stock could be worth only a few dollars. **********Odyssey also brought in new management last year, headed by Christopher L. Schaller, who had been a top exectutive at West Point-Pepperell. The new management's strategy is to emphasize fabrics for high-fashion women's apparel, which have relatively high margins, and move away from low-margin sales for military uniforms. Losses narrowed in the fiscal year ended October, despite a write-down of inventory. **********"The environment for companies like Forstmann has turned out to be quite inhospitable," Mr. Ross said. "Notwithstanding that, they came through pretty well." **********If Odyssey makes a profit on Forstmann, it will come from its most recent plunge, which apparently came this year. With Forstmann's bonds trading at deep discounts, Odyssey bought $46 million face value of its bonds. It has not disclosed how much it paid in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, but Mr. Ross said he had heard the average price was about 58 cents for each dollar of face value, or a total of about $27 million. **********Under the latest restructuring, Odyssey has agreed to exchange its bonds for a combination of 58 cents in cash, and 42 cents in stock, for each dollar of face value. Those shares may be the only ones it owns effectively, since the value of the old shares may plunge to almost nothing. Whether that happens depends on the value of the initial public offering. Under the complicated formula, if the new shares go for $11 each, the old shares will be exchanged for so few new shares that their value will be wiped out for practical purposes. But if the price is higher, the old shares will retain some value. **********Aside from Odyssey, the largest existing shareholders, whose investments may be wiped out, are two California financial institutions that went broke largely because of their investments in junk bonds, Executive Life and Columbia Savings and Loan. **********Bondholders other than Odyssey have about $54 million in bonds, and they will be offered the same exchange, with the company planning to take a maximum of $50 million in bonds from all holders, including Odyssey. **********The expectation is that few other bonds will be tendered, largely because the shares to be given to bondholders will be restricted -- they cannot be traded for two years. Richard Byrne and Michael Cherry, bond analysts at Merrill Lynch, said they believed that the outstanding bonds, which leaped from around 70 cents on the dollar to above 80 cents on news of the offering, were likely to trade at or near par, if the stock offering was a success. Most bond holders will choose to keep the bonds, they added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/world.main_headline: YUGOSLAVIA'S ARMY ISSUES ULTIMATUM TO REBEL REPUBLIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/world.print_headline: CONFLICT IN YUGOSLAVIA; YUGOSLAVIA'S ARMY ISSUES ULTIMATUM TO REBEL REPUBLIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/world.body_text: **********The Yugoslav Army issued an ultimatum today to Slovenia, saying that it would take "decisive military action" unless the secessionist republic agreed to an unconditional cease-fire, gave up control of all border posts and ended its cutoff of essential supplies to the army. **********The ultimatum came amid scattered skirmishes after the collapse of an accord mediated by three foreign ministers of the European Community to end three days of fighting between the national army and local militias in the breakaway republic. **********A senior national military officer, Col. Gen. Marko Negovanovic, made the military's demands known in a nationally televised address on Saturday night and warned that the nation stood at the "beginning of civil war."  'Ominous Factor' **********Despite the cease-fire declaration, fighting continued sporadically in Slovenia through Saturday night and this morning, and a Western diplomats said the army threat raised the possibility of even greater bloodshed. "It's a very ominous factor," a veteran diplomat said. **********At a meeting this morning between Slovenia's Defense Minister, Janez Jansa, and Gen. Andrija Raseta, a deputy commander of the national army based in Slovenia, the army issued a set of 12 detailed demands, including the return of troops wounded in the last three days of fighting; the resumption of supplies of food, water and electricity, which the military says the republic has cut off from army bases; and the return of prisoners, arms and materiel seized in combat. **********But the principal demand, that Slovenia give up its claim to frontier border posts, was rejected. According to information given to journalists in Ljubljana, the Slovenian capital, Mr. Jansa said this represented a "political demand" that was "incomprehensible" in the light of the accord mediated Friday.  Warning of 'Catastrophe' **********Reading from a prepared text Saturday night, General Negovanovic said: "The Supreme Command staff calls on all citizens and patriotic forces to oppose pushing our country and all its people into catastrophe." **********General Negavanovic warned that in Slovenia the army was coming under attack in a "dirty, cruel and deceitful way," and that in Croatia, which followed Slovenia's example in seeking independence, "a general mobilization is being carried out of all the armed forces of the republic of Croatia." **********In a meeting with military attaches from countries with diplomatic missions in Belgrade, a senior official of the army intelligence today catalogued abuses reportedly committed against the army and threatened an escalation of might against Slovenia, including the reinforced use of air power. **********Ljubljana today was said to be surrounded by confiscated trailer trucks, and road blocks of the Slovenian militia were everywhere, apparently in anticipation of army action. **********Army commanders have in the past threatened republics with intervention in the face of serious political crises. In January, for instance, the Defense Minister, Gen. Veljko Kadijevic, told Croatia that it faced stern military action if it continued to challenge the authority of the central Government. **********But in the face of the alarming use of force in northern Slovenia, the present threat appeared to exceed in seriousness any that have preceeded it. **********Diplomatic observers said the move in the army appeared to reflect both frustration in the command, whose forces have been outnumbered and harassed in carrying out their mission in Slovenia, and a high degree of independence from civilian control. **********"They are wounded, angry and not subjected to even a minimum of civilian control," a senior Western diplomat said. **********The army threat came after a day in which it became increasingly clear that the agreement mediated by the European Community foreign ministers from Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands was fast unraveling. Terms of the Agreement **********Under the terms of that agreement, Croatia and Slovenia agreed to suspend their moves toward independence. In exchange, the army agreed to return its units to their barracks and Serbia, the largest and most populous of the Yugoslav republics, agreed to drop its reservations to the appointment of a Croatian leader, Stipe Mesic, as chairman of the nation's collective presidency. **********Serbia's refusal to accept Mr. Mesic for the rotating chairmanship in voting in May was one factor that led to the fighting. **********A meeting of the eight-member collective presidency that had been called for Saturday to elect Mr. Mesic never materialized.  And Slovenia and Croatia, which both issued independence declarations on Tuesday, after months of pressing in vain for a looser federation of Yugoslav states. gave little indication that they were willing to halt carrying out steps toward independence. **********The federal Government responded by sending troops and tanks into Slovenia, attacking border posts, roadblocks and Slovenia's main airport. **********Dozens of casualties have been reported in Slovenia, while clashes in Croatia between Croats and ethnic Serbs have resulted in a handful of deaths. **********Slovenian officials said Saturday that in the three days of fighting, 20 soldiers of the Yugoslav Army were killed, plus 8 from the Slovenian side and 12 civilians. They said that among the wounded were 50 Yugoslav soldiers, 30 Slovenian militiamen and five federal police officers. **********On Friday the federal army said 10 of its soldiers had been killed in clashes. **********The Slovenian President, Milan Kucan, said at a news conference Saturday that he had been termed a traitor for agreeing to suspend the republic's efforts to secede, and that he could not be sure whether the Slovenian Parliament would approve the terms of the agreement. But he reaffirmed his support for independence, declaring, "There is no drawing back from what the Parliament adopted." **********Slovenian officials Saturday reported continuing efforts by the federal army to seize control of border crossing points, and there were reports of continuing movements of troops and tanks in the frontier region. There were no signs that army troops were returning to their barracks, as the truce required. Unprovoked Firing Charged **********In Belgrade, Defense Ministry officials conceded that troops had not yet begun their withdrawal, but they said that was because many units were still coming under fire from Slovenian militias without provocation. **********Despite initial euphoria at the accord, the head of the European Community mediation group, Foreign Minister Jacques Poos of Luxembourg, described the situation in Yugoslavia as "still dangerous." **********An official in Belgrade described the situation in Croatia, where there were reports of scattered violence, as "very tense." **********Belgrade television, which tends to be pro-Serbian, reported attacks Saturday night by radical Croatian separatists in the villages of Mirkovci and Osjek, Serbian strongholds. **********The immediate concern of the leaderships, however, was continued skirmishing at Slovenian posts along the borders with Italy and Austria. **********The fiercest fighting since the cease-fire was declared Friday night appeared to have been at Skofije, a border crossing to Italy, where according to the Belgrade television reports one person was dead and three wounded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/03/world.main_headline: In Hot Spots Like Gulf, He's Baker's Cool Hand
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/03/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: WASHINGTON AT WORK; In Hot Spots Like Gulf, He's Baker's Cool Hand
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/03/world.body_text: **********"Perhaps you should leave through the back door," Robert M. Kimmitt suggested after he scanned the note his secretary had slipped him. The State Department's third-ranking official had inadvertently left a European ambassador waiting outside his office for nearly half an hour and, a stickler for protocol, he did not want to appear to be favoring a journalist over an ambassador. **********Such long political antennae and stealth have been hallmarks of Mr. Kimmitt's fast career climb, keeping him close to the center of the action, but far, his critics say, from the fallout if things go wrong. **********In the 14 years since his father, Stanley Kimmitt, then the Secretary of the Senate, helped him get a summer job at the National Security Council, he has managed to serve in the Ford, Carter and Reagan White Houses. In 1990 and the Persian Gulf crisis, he came into his own.  Quietness Is Appreciated **********Now Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, he is point man for Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in the day-to-day handling of the gulf crisis. He oversees diplomacy at the United Nations, gathers and filters military, intelligence and political information from various advisers and experts, and coordinates policy with the White House and the Defense Department. In a capital where officials often equate power with the frequency their name pops up in the press, he does his work quietly. That is a skill Mr. Baker especially appreciates in his aides. **********A West Point graduate, decorated Vietnam War veteran and seasoned player of the bureaucracy, Mr. Kimmitt projects discipline, austerity and thoroughness, and honors rank. **********"I've always felt that the best way that one can serve in public service is to maintain as low a profile as possible and keep your boss out front where the proper focus belongs," he said. "I respect the senior-subordinate relationship, just as Secretary Baker does in his relationship with President Bush." **********Mr. Kimmitt's understanding of relationships works several ways. One of a handful of aides in the tight circle of political professionals who came with Mr. Baker from the Treasury Department and the White House, Mr. Kimmitt is more popular than some of the others with the State Department's career officers, many of whom have found their customary influence and access blocked. Filling his personal staff with members of the Foreign Service, he has reached out through the department for advice.  For Baker, a 'Capable Hand' **********Mr. Kimmitt is "helping me tremendously" on the gulf crisis, Mr. Baker said. "He has a military background and when you are dealing with military issues that really helps. Bob is a guy who has a wealth of experience. He has served the nation extraordinarily well. He is an extremely thoughtful and capable hand." **********Margaret D. Tutwiler, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, who watches over Mr. Baker's public relations, said: "Secretary Baker depends on Bob. Bob is very valuable to him. He is someone you can rely on." **********Before Iraq, Mr. Kimmitt was involved in a number of the Administration's more difficult but not necessarily most flashy foreign policy problems, including how to bring peaceful reform in South Africa and how to resolve the civil wars in Afghanistan and Cambodia. **********All his quiet deference notwithstanding, Mr. Kimmitt never lets you forget that even before his role blossomed with the gulf crisis, it was he who was Jim Baker's Baker. **********"Management of a crisis is complex, it is tiring, but it is not necessarily the most difficult task that I undertake," Mr. Kimmitt said. "Anytime I need to see the Secretary or to give him recommendations, that is done and done instantly." **********"The most difficult thing is policy formulation and implementation when you are trying to keep many different policy balls in the air. How do we get a cease-fire in Angola? How do we avoid tensions on the subcontinent? How do we continue to advance the prospects of democracy in this hemisphere, particularly in Panama and Nicaragua?" **********Mr. Kimmitt's colleagues characterize him as a mainstream Republican, a conservative not particularly driven by ideology whose advice on tactics and Congress is his greatest contribution. His attitude toward disputes with Capitol Hill reinforces that characterization. When Congress views a particular policy in a different way, he said, the Administration must be ready to compromise without retreating from principle. "My feeling is you take what you can get and then march forward again," he said. **********As for Congressional criticism that he and others in the State Department should have foreseen the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and warned Iraq against it, he strongly disagrees. In an argument that critics find disingenuous, he says that Washington sent plenty of signals, but that the international response was weak.  The Unseen Hand **********Last summer, Mr. Kimmitt sensed a Congressional rebellion brewing against the Administration's diplomatic backing of a guerrilla coalition in Cambodia that included the Khmer Rouge. **********Persuading Mr. Baker not only to distance Washington from the Khmer Rouge but also to open talks with Vietnam and Cambodia, he achieved the most far-reaching change in United States Indochina policy in at least a decade without even notifying Richard H. Solomon, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs and a proponent of the old policy. When the new policy began to lead to breakthroughs in regional peace talks, Mr. Kimmitt let Mr. Solomon take the credit. **********Asked about his being shut out of the decision to change policy, Mr. Solomon said: "I don't want to get into the game of who-whom. I happened to be in Paris at the time." **********"One of Mr. Kimmitt's alluring qualities is his discretion," said Richard Allen, who as national security adviser in the early 1980's was Mr. Kimmitt's supervisor. "People who are discreet and without their own agendas are hard to find in Government. He was the kind of fellow in which you can confide." **********But a reputation for discretion can have a downside. Mr. Kimmitt was one of only two people from the Carter White House whom Mr. Allen kept on at the National Security Council, a fact that has stimulated much speculation around Washington that Mr. Kimmitt might have been the official who passed on a Carter strategy book to the Reagan campaign in time for the televised debate between the two candidates. Former Representative Donald Albosta, a Michigan Democrat who led a House investigation into the matter, said he now wishes his aides had interviewed Mr. Kimmitt. **********"Why would Baker and everyone cuddle up to him after the campaign unless they wanted to cover up perhaps?" Mr. Albosta asked.  The Iran-Contra Scandal **********That speculation was fanned by allegations made privately by several former Reagan White House officials that Mr. Kimmitt, who was executive secretary to the National Security Council from 1983 to 1985, passed Mr. Baker, then White House chief of staff, classified foreign policy papers when other senior Reagan White House officials were trying to keep him out of policy discussions. **********Mr. Kimmitt flatly denies passing White House documents to any unauthorized people. He also says he had no involvement in the Iran-contra scandal. His signature was found on one document made public during the trial of Oliver L. North, indicating he had some knowledge of Reagan Administration attempts to persuade Honduras to aid the contras when Congress had prohibited military assistance. **********Mr. Kimmitt "must have known a fair amount or he was incompetent," Michael A. Ledeen, who was a consultant to the National Security Council in the Reagan Administration, said of the affair. "His name never came up because he got out in time." **********Mr. Kimmitt said he had no particular recollection of the document he signed. "Obviously if I had seen or heard something that I thought was out of bounds, I would have raised that with McFarlane or Poindexter," he said. **********Mr. Baker took Mr. Kimmitt with him to the Treasury Department in 1985 and then on to the Bush campaign, where he was charged with screening vice presidential candidates. The Questioning of Quayle **********Published accounts have said Mr. Kimmitt questioned Mr. Quayle about his military record and asked if there was anything in his past that could be embarrassing. Press reports that Mr. Quayle's father had helped him gain entrance to the National Guard, a popular and legal way to avoid service in Vietnam, later caused the campaign embarrassment. (The Vice President's office has repeatedly said that there were a number of vacancies in the National Guard unit in which Mr. Quayle served, and therefore he did not need his father's help to gain entrance.) **********Asked now if he questioned Mr. Quayle about his National Guard service, Mr. Kimmitt replied: "This will sound evasive but it is not. I felt and still do feel that I had a lawyer-client relationship with candidate Bush. As a result, I have never disclosed either to whom I spoke or what I asked of those people." **********In recent weeks, Mr. Kimmitt has battled with Central Intelligence Agency officials who would like to unleash the guerrillas in Afghanistan in one last effort to defeat the Soviet-backed Government of President Najibullah. Mr. Baker wants to work closely with Moscow to coax the rebels and the Najibullah regime into democratic elections. **********"If they have a problem at the agency it is with me carrying out a policy that has been set down by the Secretary and reaffirmed by the President during the June summit," Mr. Kimmitt said. "So I have no hesitation in saying that their problem is not with me but with the senior leadership of this department and this Government. I think they are just bucking policy." ROBERT MICHAEL KIMMITT Born: Dec. 19, 1947 Hometown: Arlington, Va. Education: B.S. in Engineering, United States Military Academy at West Point in 1969; J.D., Georgetown University Law Center in 1977. Career Highlights: 1978 to 1983, member of the National Security Council staff; 1983 to 1985, executive secretary and general counsel for the National Security Council; 1985 to 1987, general counsel for the Treasury Department; 1987 to 1989, partner, Washington law firm of Sidley & Austin. Interests: Watching his five children play rugby, squash; going to the movies; reading biographies and history.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/busin.main_headline: Record Coke Earnings On Strong Sales Abroad
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/busin.print_headline: Record Coke Earnings On Strong Sales Abroad
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/18/busin.body_text: **********The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink maker, yesterday reported a 13.2 percent earnings increase in the first quarter, to a record $320.9 million. **********Emanuel Goldman, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc., said the results were slightly better than most analysts had expected. The strong performance was attributable to Coca-Cola's international business. **********"Coca-Cola has again done best where it makes the most money, in Europe and Asia," Mr. Goldman said. Sales Are Up 15.8% **********The earnings in the 1990 period were $283.4 million. Its sales rose by 15.8 percent, to $2.48 billion from $2.14 billion. **********The company had an 8 percent rise in the volume of its fountain business, dispensers that combine syrup and carbonated water for the finished product. Coke got its start in the fountain business and still has a commanding market share of more than 60 percent. The rise was mainly because of a new contract with Burger King, the nation's second-largest hamburger chain, after McDonald's. **********In the United States, overall unit case sales rose by 4 percent, including a 2 percent gain in bottles and cans, which are primarily sold in supermarkets and other retail outlets. **********Worldwide unit case sales grew somewhat better, at about 5 percent in the quarter, with strong sales in Europe, Asia and Latin America.  Big Stock Buyback **********Coke's preferred stock dividends lowered the net income available to its common shareholders, but the company bought back three issues of preferred stock late last year. It bought back the fourth and last issue in the first quarter. Accordingly, preferred dividend payments dropped to $521,000 in the quarter from $4.87 million in the 1990 period. **********Net income available to common holders totaled $320.4 million, or 48 cents a share, up by 15 percent from $278.6 million, or 41 cents a share. **********Coke also said it had bought back about two million common shares in the quarter, which has the effect of helping to increase earnings per share. So far, it has bought back 20 million shares under a program to repurchase up to 40 million. **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Coke's stock rose 50 cents a share, to $56.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/busin.main_headline: U.S. Effort On B.C.C.I. Is Assailed
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/busin.print_headline: U.S. Effort On B.C.C.I. Is Assailed
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/02/busin.body_text: **********William von Raab, the former Commissioner of Customs, today accused the Bush Administration of dragging its feet on an investigation of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International and of barring him from sensitive information about the scandal-riddled bank when he pushed for stronger action. **********The Treasury Department, under which Mr. von Rabb served as Customs Commissioner, immediately replied that the commissioner was, indeed, kept away from sensitive information for fear he would disclose it. **********This exchange marked another chapter in a long-running feud between Mr. von Rabb and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Still, it also underscored the political tensions involved in the hearings on B.C.C.I. conducted today by the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on terrorism, narcotics and international operations. Big Point of Contention **********The question of whether the Treasury Department, the Justice Department and the Federal Reserve Board ignored warnings that B.C.C.I. was engaged in criminal activities and was the secret owner of First American Bankshares Inc., a company with strong political connections, has emerged in recent days as a big point of contention between the Administration and critics in Congress and elsewhere. **********Senator John F. Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat and subcommittee chairman, has been criticizing the Government and pressing for answers as to why the Government knew so much about B.C.C.I.'s potentially criminal tendencies, yet appeared to have ignored the evidence. Mr. von Rabb was one of several witnesses during a day of accusation and official denial that produced the following accounts: ***********Officials of the Federal Reserve said the bank was never informed that the Central Intelligence Agency knew at least five years ago that B.C.C.I. illegally controlled First American Bankshares, Washington's largest banking company. ***********The State Department said it learned in 1986 through the intelligence community that the organization of a leading terrorist, Abu Nidal, used a B.C.C.I. branch in Europe for commercial transactions. In his written testimony, A. Peter Burleigh, the department's coordinator for counterterrorism, said that information was used to disrupt Abu Nidal's commercial activities in an international effort. A number of countries, including East Germany and Poland under Communist governments, were approached as part of the effort with requests that they close down businesses in their countries that were working with Abu Nidal. ***********Jack Blum, a former investigator for the subcommittee, testified that he had been told by a former bank official that B.C.C.I. worked with "about 3,000 high-net-worth criminal clients," and that the rest of the bank's apparently legitimate banking activity was set up to shroud its business with those clients. ***********According to an affidavit introduced at the hearing, a former B.C.C.I. official who had been subpoened in 1988 to testify before the subcommittee told an undercover Customs agent that he had been advised by Clark M. Clifford, who represented B.C.C.I., to get transferred to Paris to slow down Senator Kerry's investigation. Robert S. Bennett, a lawyer for Mr. Clifford, the chairman of First American, did not return a call for comment last night.  Reports of Weapons Deals **********The hearing also brought out a number of allegations about the bank's involvement in illicit activities and weapons deals. These included statements that B.C.C.I. had been involved in financing a shipment of Scud missles to Syria and had assisted Pakistan in its efforts to obtain triggers for nuclear weapons. **********In his statements, Mr. von Raab said that he had been "eased out" of responsibility for a 1988 Customs investigation of money-laundering at B.C.C.I. in Florida, and that sensitive documents had been kept from him by order of officials with the Treasury Department just as the inquiry was reaching its peak. **********"I was told I was not to have information from the B.C.C.I. case," Mr. von Raab said, "They felt I was overzealous in my drug enforcement efforts, and they were uncomfortable with the way I worked with Congress and the press to push cases." **********He asserted this as part of his contention that the Government had been "lackadaisical" in its prosecution of criminal cases against the bank, which was indicted in 1988 for money-laundering at a Tampa, Fla., branch office. The bank pleaded guilty in 1990 and forfeited $14 million. Plea-Bargain Agreement **********More important, the plea-bargain arrangement included an agreement that the Justice Department could not prosecute B.C.C.I. for any illegal activities that the Government was aware of at the time. The deal formally entered in the Federal District Court in Tampa in 1990. **********At the time, the Justice Department had possession of tape recordings, made by undercover Federal agents, in which B.C.C.I. officials openly claimed to control First American Bank and could rely on the influence of its chairman, Mr. Clifford, a prominent Washington lawyer and Democratic presidential adviser. **********Mr. von Raab's criticism was a footnote to a long history of clashes with Mr. Brady and criticism of the Administration's drug enforcement efforts. Upon leaving his job in 1989, Mr. von Raab wrote an emotional letter to President Bush, warning him that that the Treasury Department, the State Department and the Justice Department did not have the zeal to fight a war on drugs. **********But today, the Treasury Department replied with unusual bluntness. Desiree Tucker-Sorini, a spokeswoman for the department, confirmed that Mr. von Raab had been precluded from seeing classified information in the B.C.C.I. investigation after a Federal prosecutor in the case complained that there had been leaks of sensitive documents that could jeapordize the case. Limited Distribution **********"The decision was made at that point to limit the classified information to the very pure definition of who needs to know," Ms. Tucker-Sorini said. "From then on, there was a limited distribution solely to the people investigating the case. No information was withheld from the people working on the cases." **********In response to the former Customs Commissioner's criticism that Federal prosecutors had allowed B.C.C.I. to escape serious penalties, Doug Tillett, a Justice Department spokesman, said that Mr. von Raab never made his objections known, and that the deal had been supported by others who brought the case against the bank in Tampa. **********But Mr. von Raab said much of the support developed as a result of the team of Washington lawyers, lobbyists and public relations firms hired by B.C.C.I. during its legal troubles. He said that after the bank was indicted for money-laundering, it was able to plead guilty and forfeit only $14 million -- relatively modest for a global bank with $20 billion in assets -- partly because of the "influence team working up and down the Eastern seaboard" on behalf of the bank. **********That team, he said, included Mr. Clifford and Patton, Boggs & Blow, a Washington law firm with close ties to the Democratic Party, as well as Hill & Knowlton, the public relations firm headed by Robert Gray and Frank Mankiewicz, both of whom had successful political careers before entering the public relations business. **********Robert S. Mueller 3d, who has headed the department's criminal division since last September, said none of the bank's lawyers had ever approached senior officials with the Justice Department on behalf of B.C.C.I. or First American. Mr. Mueller's predecessor, Edward S. G. Dennis, said in an interview that he could recall no contact with the bank's representatives. **********Mr. Mankiewicz, the vice chairman of Hill & Knowlton, also disputed Mr. von Raab's testimony, calling it "incredibly irresponsible and false." In a statement, Mr. Mankiewicz said no one at his firm, including Mr. Gray, had ever contacted anyone in the Administration or in Congress about B.C.C.I.                    --------------------       Peruvian Official Resigns **********LIMA, Peru, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- A Peruvian representative at the World Bank, a former official of Peru's central bank who also once worked for the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, resigned today. **********"Mr. Brian Jensen, who worked in B.C.C.I., has been in the post of alternative assistant in the World Bank," Peru's Economy Minister, Carlos Bolona, said at a news conference at the Government palace. "Mr. Jensen is definitely no longer in this post." **********Mr. Bolona said Jensen's relationship to B.C.C.I. "was the factor that determined his resignation." He did not say, however, that Mr. Jensen had been accused of any wrongdoing in connection with B.C.C.I. **********"We are trying to determine responsibilities," Mr. Bolona said. **********Mr. Jensen, who is also a former official of Peru's central bank, could not be reached for comment. **********Peru's Attorney General has opened an investigation into possible wrongdoing by former central bank officials in connection with B.C.C.I., which was seized by regulators in several countries last month amid allegations of widespread fraud. Earlier this week, the Manhattan district attorney's office accused two former Peruvian central bank officials of accepting bribes from B.C.C.I. in return for deposits. **********Peru's President, Alberto Fujimori, has said his Government would take strong action if it found crimes had been committed in connection with B.C.C.I. **********Mr. Jensen was general manager of Peru's central bank in 1984 when the bank approved the opening of a B.C.C.I. branch in Lima. The branch never opened, however. Mr. Jensen was employed by B.C.C.I. when Peru placed the reserves in the bank in 1986, during the administration of former President Alan Garcia. **********Juan Candela, who was central bank chief at the time the decision was made to deposit the reserves, said, "I do not know of any action that Mr. Jensen may have made on behalf of Peru." **********Mr. Candela said he was not aware of any bribes or commissions in connection with the deposits. He said the decision to place the reserves with B.C.C.I. was made after the bank offered Peru a $60 million credit line on the condition that Peru place $200 million dollars in the bank. **********"There were very few banks that were willing to lend money to Peru at that time," Mr. Candela said.
