https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/16/busin.main_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Children's Music Lures The Recording Giants
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/16/busin.print_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Children's Music Lures The Recording Giants
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/16/busin.body_text: **********With his pleasant tenor, gentle manner and sophisticated arrangements, Raffi, a Canadian singer-songwriter, is the Bruce Springsteen of the under-10 set, selling more than six million records over the years. **********It is far from clear who is the children's Madonna or MC Hammer or U2, but the success of Raffi and others is leading a number of big entertainment companies into the rapidly growing business of children's music. **********Sales increased last year by more than 50 percent, to $300 million, and while that is only a fraction of the $7.5 billion music business, some executives believe it will be one of the hot areas for growth. Conglomerates Expand **********Responding in part to a new baby boom, Time Warner Inc. and the Sony Corporation this year joined other entertainment conglomerates in the children's music business. **********Last year, MCA Inc. acquired the recording rights to Raffi and his library of albums. So although Raffi recently said he would no longer record children's music, MCA still has his existing hits. **********"There are going to be a lot more success stories coming out of this," said Geoff Bywater, senior vice president of marketing at MCA Records, who oversees children's music. "People going into the business know there is business to be had." **********Until the recent boom, only two big companies, the Walt Disney Company and A & M Records, which previously handled Raffi, competed in the market. Additionally, there are perhaps 200 small independent record labels, many operating out of performers' homes. For them, selling 10,000 copies is an achievment. The Dynamics Change **********But with the arrival of other big labels, which have both marketing prowess and large national distribution networks, the dynamics of the industry are changing. **********Most children's records had once been sold mainly in specialty shops instead of music stores. Now, more albums are being delivered to record and chain stores, increasing the chances of producing big-selling albums like Raffi's "Singable Songs for the Very Young," which has sold a million copies since 1984. **********"As an independent label, it's a lot harder to get into the chain stores," said Debbie Block, who runs Round River Records in Seekonk, Mass., which recently signed a marketing agreement with A & M for the label's premier artist, Bill Harley. **********The giant of the industry is Disney, which recently reinforced its dominance by selling nearly three million copies of "The Little Mermaid" and, in just a month, more than 700,000 copies of "Beauty and the Beast." Demographic Factors **********Disney is expanding its operations by moving beyond records tied to animated characters or soundtracks. It is recording artists like Parachute Express, a Southern California trio who gained attention by performing the music heard at Gymboree toddler exercise centers. **********The explosive growth of children's music is tied to several demographic and industry trends. Until this year, the number of births in the United States was increasing by more than 100,000 every year since 1987. **********Parents who grew up in the rock-and-roll era are eager to share their musical interests with their children, executives say. Because both parents often work, they also have the disposable income to spend on records. **********"I've always subscribed it to yuppie guilt," said David Lovald, sales manager at Silo-Alcazar Inc., a distributor of children's music in Waterbury, Vt. "You have two working parents looking for quality entertainment for their children that doesn't involve being glued to the TV." **********Executives say the Raffi phenomenon made the music industry recognize that quality children's performers could sell more than a few thousand copies if they appeal to adult tastes as well. **********"In the past, music was produced for the kids to be enjoyed by themselves," said Mark Jaffe, vice president at Disney Records. "But now parents are wanting to interact with them, so the music has to be very contemporary." **********As the industry grows, it is learning how to sell children's music to the mass market. Unlike the mainstream record business, there is no radio airplay to generate buying demand. **********Instead, sales build very slowly as parents learn of children's albums from friends and shops where salespeople know the music and play it for customers. And children's music can remain popular for years. **********"This forces us to be more creative marketers," said Tom McPartland, vice president of legal and business affairs at the Bertlesmann Music Group, which is considering entering the children's concert business to promote its growing roster of children's artists. **********Sony, which set up Sony Kids' Music this year, is contemplating such marketing ideas as sample tapes of its artists, like Tom Chapin and Tom Paxton, that would be included with tape players it sells for children.Some Skepticism **********There remains some skepticism in the industry as to whether the market is big enough to accommodate all the expansion. **********"There is a lot of arrogance at the major labels, where they think their money can buy whatever they want," said Leib Ostrow, the co-founder and chairman of Music for Little People, a Redway, Calif., children's catalogue and record company. **********Still, Mr. Ostrow recently sold 49 percent of his company to Time Warner's Warner Brothers Records division. Warner plans to start a label and distribute some records through Mr. Ostrow's company, while Music for Little People will use Warner's distribution system. **********Warner wants to challenge Disney by putting its animated characters, like Bugs Bunny, on records.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/world.main_headline: Bush Reluctantly Concludes Gorbachev Tried to Cling to Power Too Long
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/world.print_headline: END OF THE SOVIET UNION; Bush Reluctantly Concludes Gorbachev Tried to Cling to Power Too Long
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/world.body_text: **********Forewarned on Monday by President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia that Mikhail S. Gorbachev plans to resign on Wednesday, President Bush has reluctantly reached the conclusion that his friend and political ally clung to power too long and dulled the luster of his achievements, Administration officials said today. **********The officials said Mr. Bush decided in October, when he met with Mr. Gorbachev for the last time in Madrid, that the Soviet leader had lost the struggle for power with Mr. Yeltsin and had simply not yet acknowledged that to himself. **********But Mr. Bush, who supported Mr. Gorbachev with what seemed like single-minded dedication for three tumultuous years, still refused to turn his back on a fellow head of state, a stance that was reinforced by a lingering ambivalence in the Administration about Mr. Yeltsin. **********In this context, the idea that the Administration concluded long ago that Mr. Gorbachev was finished politically only served to underscore what some officials and outside critics have said for some time: that Mr. Bush's loyalty produced a distorted policy of propping up the Soviet Government beyond the point at which it was in the best interests of the United States. Once a 'Drugstore Cowboy' **********The story of relations between Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush is one of initial skepticism overtaken by pragmatic politics and personal ties. In May 1989, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, dismissed Mr. Gorbachev as a "drugstore cowboy" whose promise to halt arms shipments to Nicaragua could not be believed. **********By the end of that year, after the first Bush-Gorbachev summit meeting in Malta, Mr. Bush viewed Mr. Gorbachev as a promising diplomatic counterpart. By the time of the attempted hard-line coup in August, he considered him not only an ally in war and peacemaking in the Middle East but also a friend. **********Mr. Bush still retains his personal fondness and professional respect for Mr. Gorbachev and believes that he made possible the upheaval that led to the crumbling of Communist power in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, officials said. **********Out of deference to Mr. Gorbachev, the White House made no official comment today about the impending resignation. Mr. Bush, who is expected either to issue a written statement or to comment personally on the event on Wednesday, is certain to offer a positive overall assessment of Mr. Gorbachev's tenure. **********Still, many American officials were left with a sense that a great moment in history had somehow been diminished by the way Mr. Gorbachev was dragged from the world stage instead of making a grand exit.  Word From Yeltsin Monday **********Officials said Mr. Yeltsin told Mr. Bush in a telephone conversation on Monday that Mr. Gorbachev would resign on Wednesday. They said that freed the United States to let it be known that Washington would recognize the 12 remaining Soviet republics as independent states and move into a new era of relations after weeks of frustrating uncertainty. **********Administration officials said there was a strong feeling here that the departure of Mr. Gorbachev was long overdue and that he had lost his sense of timing, his personal force and his grasp of Soviet political realities. **********Mr. Bush's critics say he has been too slow to reach that conclusion. But Administration officials said today that the President and his advisers began moving toward that judgment when Mr. Gorbachev returned to Moscow in August after the coup attempt and tried to save the Communist Party from certain destruction. **********Then in October, at the meeting with Mr. Gorbachev in Madrid, Mr. Bush was left with the strong impression that his friend's time had passed, officials said. he concluded a joint news conference with Mr. Gorbachev in Madrid by patting him on the small of the back as they walked off the stage and muttering, "You're the master." **********But officials said that that was merely a gesture of friendship and loyalty and that by far the stronger impression the Americans took home from Madrid was hearing word that the Soviet delegation could not afford to pay its hotel bill and that the Spanish Government was picking up the tab. Gorbachev's 'Preplexed Look' **********"Gorbachev had this perplexed look that he couldn't believe what was happening," an official said. "His old strength was gone, and what surprised a lot of us was there were all these historic events going on and this guy was going around talking about himself, totally out of touch." **********Some Administration officials now believe that, as one put it, Mr. Gorbachev "waited too long." **********"The problem is that he's leaving at a level that's a lot lower than he would have had a month ago," an official said. "He's taken away from his own currency and cost himself a bit of his place in history by letting events pass him by. It's sad to see a man of such stature and historical importance misjudge events that way." **********Despite the President's reported judgment in October that Mr. Gorbachev's days were numbered, the Administration avoided any action that would have undermined him. This was, they said, a result partly of what one official called "the President's strong attachment to Gorbachev personally" and partly of a fundamental division among American officials about how to proceed. **********Some, like Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, urged Mr. Bush to side with the republics and abandon the center, while others, like Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, took the opposite view. Arms Worries Are Central **********For one thing, with uncertainty over who would control Soviet nuclear weapons a central factor in American decision-making, these officials argued that a central Government was the most reliable guarantor of atomic security. **********Some officials also mistrusted Mr. Yeltsin, who had at first impressed Mr. Bush and his top officials by the way he faced down the attempted coup against Mr. Gorbachev in August and then dismayed them by his offhand treatment of the Soviet President after the coup was smashed. **********"For a long time, the solution to concerns about Yeltsin and security-related fears about the Soviet Union falling apart was to prop up Gorbachev," an official said today, acknowledging that the United States had only been slightly quicker than Mr. Gorbachev himself to conclude that the Soviet Union would disintegrate. **********"Eventually, disintegration became an inevitability, and our policy changed to reflect it," the official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/22/busin.main_headline: First Fall in Net At 3M Since '85
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/22/busin.print_headline: First Fall in Net At 3M Since '85
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/22/busin.body_text: **********The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the Scotch tape and abrasives maker known as 3M, has reported its first drop in quarterly profits since 1985. It attributed the decline to the sluggish world economy. **********The company said its first- quarter net income fell 11 percent, to $300 million, compared with $335 million in last year's first quarter. The earnings were equal to $1.37 a share, down from $1.51 a year earlier. Sales rose to $3.39 billion from $3.16 billion. **********"A decline in U.S. economic activity and slower growth abroad held back demand in many 3M product lines," Allen Jacobson, the company's chairman, said on Friday. The company added that its earnings outlook for the rest of the year was uncertain. **********The company said a sharp downturn in its Brazilian business hurt earnings in the quarter, while United States sales rose about 2 percent from the 1990 period. Overseas, sales rose a modest 5 percent, ending a string of 12 consecutive quarters of double-digit gains.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.body_text: **********The peaceful and speedy transition in Zambia from Kenneth D. Kaunda's authoritarian leadership to the democratically elected Government of Frederick Chiluba is likely to send shock waves into Africa's long-entrenched regimes and embolden opposition groups, international election observers here say. **********They say the victory of Mr. Chiluba, leader of this country's labor union congress, and his new-born opposition party against Mr. Kaunda, one of Africa's "big men," should hasten Africa's "second independence" -- the end of the end of the post-colonial autocrats who rule their countries as personal kingdoms. **********Now that an African country has achieved the political pluralism that Western aid donors have been seeking, the United States plans to provide inducements to others to follow Zambia's example, Assistant Secretary of State Herman J. Cohen said over the weekend. Pressure on Old-Timers **********Few predict the lightning transformations that swept Eastern Europe in 1989. But the optimists believe that the example set here will put pressure on all the old-time leaders, one of whom, Felix Houphouet-Boigny, the 86-year-old President of the Ivory Coast, took office in 1960. **********Former President Jimmy Carter, who headed an election-monitoring group here, said, "It will be much more difficult for the oppressors to keep their people oppressed." **********Others were not so sanguine. An African ambassador who watched the elections here as part of a delegation from the Organization of African Unity was more cautious. "Some of the strongmen could react with fear and dig their heels in," he said. Several African ambassadors representing their countries in Zambia were "outraged," he said, that the O.A.U. had given credence to the elections by sending a delegation. Vary From Country to Country **********Thus, the impact of the Zambian elections will vary from country to country on this continent, depending on the status of opposition groups, the character of the governments and the personality of individual leaders. **********In the Sudan, for example, where a military dictatorship dominated by Islamic fundamentalists is in charge, it will be difficult for the Zambian result to even register. One of the Sudanese military leaders recently called multiparty democracy as alien to Africa as a "three-piece suit in the desert." **********In West Africa, movements toward democratization already taking place through national conferences that bring together governments and opposition groups, may get bolder, the international observers said here. **********But the Zambian experience, they said, will reverberate most acutely in East and Central Africa. There, former British colonies like Zambia, formerly Northern Rhodesia, inherited institutions -- a judiciary, a press and professional organizations -- that had not been entirely eroded and could be used by an opposition, said Richard Joseph, a professor of political science at the Carter Center of Emory University in Atlanta.  Looking to History **********Mr. Joseph cited Kenya, headed by President Daniel arap Moi, and Zimbabwe, now a one-party state that has been led since full independence in 1980 by President Robert Mugabe. "Moi and Mugabe are going to have to take a look and decide: 'Do I want to be a Kaunda or a Mobutu in the historical record?' " **********Mr. Kaunda will be remembered, Mr. Joseph said, as having led his country to independence and then having agreed to multiparty democracy. By contrast, he predicted, President Mobutu Seke Seso of Zaire, who resists power sharing as his country seems to disintegrate, will go down as a dictator who ruined his land. **********Mr. Carter expressed hope that in Kenya the Zambian experience would infuse the opposition with more courage to stand up to coercion. **********While few doubt that there will now be increased calls in Kenya for elections, Kenyans and other Africans say it may take time for the pressure to mount on either President Moi or President Mugabe as it did on Mr. Kaunda. The former Zambian President, apparently feeling little choice, legalized political party activity last December after food riots and an attempted coup. Mr. Moi has categorically refused to allow the formation of opposition parties and threatened to crush demonstrators "like rats."  Economic Advantage **********Mr. Moi has the relative advantage in Kenya of a stronger economy. Mr. Chiluba conceded in an interview that his campaign was helped by conditions in Zambia -- a lively labor movement and almost universal economic despair -- that did not exist in Kenya. **********On the diplomatic front, the Zambian elections may have a vital effect: It will be harder for the British Government, the main foreign backer of Mr. Moi, to maintain its public silence about his conduct. **********A British Conservative legislator, Anna Nicholson, here as an election observer, said she planned to raise the contrast between Zambia and Kenya in Parliament this week. "I think it's time we came out in the open for multiparty democracy," she said. "I think it is a disgrace that Moi has been able to get away with it for so long."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/31/busin.main_headline: Rite Aid Seeks to Buy Revco As Salomon Settles Lawsuit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/31/busin.print_headline: Rite Aid Seeks to Buy Revco As Salomon Settles Lawsuit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Two broad steps were taken yesterday to clean up the tattered trail left in the botched 1986 leveraged buyout of Revco D.S. The Rite Aid Corporation, a competing drugstore chain, offered to buy the bankrupt Revco, even as the architect of the buyout, Salomon Brothers, agreed to pay $29.7 million to settle a lawsuit from some of the investors in it. **********The offer by Rite Aid, the nation's largest drugstore chain, intensifies a battle for control of Revco that has been waged since the Ohio-based drugstore chain filed for bankruptcy in 1988. **********Under the Rite Aid plan, about $440 million in cash would be paid to Revco's senior creditors. In addition, the company would assume certain liabilities and distribute seven million shares of Rite Aid common stock to most of the junior creditors to settle other claims against Revco. **********The plan, which was put together by Rite Aid and five holders of Revco securities, is the only one submitted to the bankruptcy court that provides for payment of cash and publicly traded securities to settle claims by Revco's creditors. **********If accepted, the deal would greatly expand Rite Aid, which is based in Shiremanstown, Pa. The company operates 2,439 drugstores. Revco, which operated more than 2,000 drugstores in 30 states in 1986, has sold many of them during bankruptcy, and now owns 1,100 stores with about $2.5 billion in annual revenues. **********"We think now is the best of times to come into this process, because all of the other plans that have been produced didn't have any cash or had very little cash," said Martin Grass, president of Rite Aid. "We are hopeful that other creditors will be joining us over the next few weeks." **********Revco officials declined comment on the plan late yesterday. "We have heard that a plan was filed late this afternoon, but we have not seen it and don't know anything about it," a Revco spokeswoman said. **********Last week, Revco rejected a bid from another competitor, the Jack Eckerd Corporation. Eckerd proposed taking over Revco by issuing nearly $970 million in debt and $200 million in stock to buy Revco and retire its debt. **********Revco is pursuing its own plan of reorganization with three groups of creditors. **********Salomon's decision to settle closes the books on an embarrassing chapter in the firm's history, as it continues to deal with a much larger problem, the Treasury market scandal. **********Under its settlement, Salomon will pay $29.75 million to buyers of more than $800 million in securities that were used to finance the Revco buyout. Salomon, which said it still denied the allegations against it, was accused in the suit of failing to review the buyout properly and not disclosing the drugstore chain's financial troubles to investors. **********Salomon has reached a separate settlement with Revco as part of its reorganization plan. The firm has agreed to pay $9.5 million and assign any securities it may receive in the reorganization to Revco. That agreement settled charges that Salomon's deal left Revco essentially insolvent the day the buyout closed, leading to a claim known as fraudulent conveyance. **********The bid for the company and the settlement are added factors in what has evolved into one of the most complex bankruptcies stemming from the wave of mergers in the 1980's. Revco was taken private in 1986, increasing its debt level by $1.1 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/29/world.main_headline: Somali Capital a Grisly Battlefield As Civilians Die in Clan Warfare
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/29/world.print_headline: Somali Capital a Grisly Battlefield As Civilians Die in Clan Warfare
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/29/world.body_text: **********A week and a half of artillery and rocket barrages in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, have turned the city into a grisly battlefield that has left about 6,000 civilians wounded and possibly more than 1,000 dead, according to aid and medical workers who have returned here in the last few days. **********"I've been in war for eight years and I've never seen a slaughter like this," said Dr. Sam Toussie, an American surgeon, who was tending the wounded as part of a medical team financed by the United States Government. "We were getting 150 casualties a day at one hospital -- 75 percent were children and we were losing five an hour." **********Fighting broke out in Mogadishu, a city of about 1.5 million on the Indian Ocean, on Nov. 17 when Gen. Mohamed Farah Haideed tried to unseat the President of Somalia, Ali Mahdi Mohamed. Both men are members of the ruling group, the United Somali Congress, which is dominated by one of the country's major clans, the Hawiyes. But General Haideed is a member of a sub-clan of the Hawiye called the Habar Gedir, long resented by Mr. Ali Mahdi's sub-clan, the Abgals. **********Mr. Ali Mahdi was named president of Somalia earlier this year after insurgents of the United Somali Congress ousted President Mohamed Siad Barre, who ruled Somalia for 21 years, first with the assistance of the Soviet Union and then after 1978, with the help of Washington. Mr. Siad Barre, who is more than 80 years old, fled Mogadishu in January and remains in his home village in the southwest. **********Since Mr. Siad Barre fled, the people of the Isaak clan in northern Somalia have declared an independent republic of Somaliland with borders corresponding to those of what was once the colony of British Somaliland. In 1960 British Somaliland in the north joined with the Italian colony in the south to form Somalia, a country of about six million people. **********Somalia has an unusual religious and linguistic homogeneity for Africa. Most Somalis are Sunni Muslims and everyone speaks Somali. Yet clan hostilities are among the most strongly felt on the continent, differences that were accentuated by Mr. Siad Barre, who played one clan against another. **********A State Department official said that since Mr. Siad Barre had left, Washington "recognized Somalia as a country" but did not recognize any government, either in the north or the south. No 'Functioning Government' **********"We do not see a functioning government in Somalia," the official said. The Somali Embassy in Washington was told to close and the American embassy in Mogadishu is an abandoned ruin, he said. **********Through the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, the United States is financing Dr. Toussie's medical team, as well as supplying food through the International Committee of the Red Cross and other agencies, the official said. **********The southern part of Somalia has been in virtually continuous clan-based turmoil since the beginning of the year, with the fighting that broke out 10 days ago the most intense since January. **********Those who have witnessed the latest round in Mogadishu said that suppporters of General Haideed and President Ali Mahdi had divided the city along a north-south axis, with General Haideed's side controlling the airport, port and radio station.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/30/busin.main_headline: Omnicon Sells Stake In Telerx Marketing

The acquisition follows Medical Marketing's purchase earlier this year of KSF Publishing, which produces pharmaceutical journals and brochures for physicians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.main_headline: The Murky World of Newspaper Advertising
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.print_headline: The Murky World of Newspaper Advertising
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********"Rethinking Newspapers," (Jan. 6), was most illuminating. However, it neglected to address a significant point; that in a world of expanding advertising options, newspapers are failing to compete with other media. **********Imagine advertising on a network without knowing what program you were appearing on. You would buy time on ABC and not know if you were appearing on a soap opera or "Monday Night Football." Imagine television without the Nielsen or Arbitron ratings. That is what running ads in a newspaper is like. **********Newspaper research is a contradiction in terms. A newspaper will bombard you with data that tells you how affluent and wonderful their circulation is but not whether it is higher on an average Monday or an average Friday. Nor can they tell you the average readership of various sections, such as business, sports, travel. Who needs to know such obscure data? Only advertisers and their agencies. The Newspaper Advertising Bureau should look no further to find reasons why advertising is flat in this area. HOWARD WEXLER Riverdale, N.Y., Jan. 9

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.main_headline: With Scant Hope, North Africans Call For a Truce at U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: U.N.; With Scant Hope, North Africans Call For a Truce at U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.body_text: **********The United Nations Security Council met tonight to consider a call by five North African Muslim nations for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war. But a clear majority of the Council's 15 members opposed a cease-fire and none was expected to be approved. **********The cease-fire call came from Morocco, even though it has contributed troops to the American-led coalition against Iraq, and from Algeria, Libya, Tunisia and Mauritania. **********But the Council President, Bagbeni Adeito Nzengeya of Zaire, said that "a majority of the Council think they should take no further action until Iraq has complied with the 12 resolutions they have already passed." Those measures demand the unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. **********Nevetheless, Mr. Nzengeya said he would continue consultations with members about the North African demand, which is supported by at least two current Council members, Yemen and Cuba. No Chance of Approval **********With President Saddam Hussein of Iraq apparently uninterested in a cease-fire unless he can keep Kuwait, and the United States and its allies determined to force him out, most diplomats say the North African call for a cease-fire to allow time for new negotiations had no realistic chance of approval. **********The United States, Britain and France also reported formally to the Council, as required, on their military operations against Iraq, but gave no information that was not already public. **********Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, said London's objective was to liberate Kuwait, not to dismember Iraq. But the size of Iraq's forces in Kuwait requires military operations "on a considerable scale," he said. He said two Council members, identified by other diplomats as Yemen and Cuba, had accused the allies of exceeding their United Nations mandate by attacking a wide range of targets in Iraq but had given no reason why they thought this unjustified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/world.body_text: **********At an often stormy meeting of Yugoslavia's eight-member federal presidency that ended early this morning, the Communist-led national army drew back from its threats to use force to disarm paramilitary police units in the independence-minded republic of Croatia and to arrest high-ranking members of that republic's government. **********Croatian officials today called the decision a victory for Croatia's new democratic order and expressed confidence that it had created an atmosphere in which constructive negotiations about Yugoslavia's future could proceed. But it did not appear to resolve the core issues dividing this country's different peoples. **********At the meeting, Yugoslavia's Defense Minister, Gen. Veljko Kadijevic, agreed to call off a state of highest alert at military bases in Croatia and not to try to interfere in domestic political affairs, Croatian government officials said. The Croatian government had charged that high-ranking army officers were planning a coup to preserve Yugoslavia's unity and reimpose a socialist government. **********In exchange, Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, agreed to end the call-up of reserve paramilitary police units in Croatia, but not to disband those units or hand over any of their weapons to the army. Mr. Tudjman apparently also promised to purge nationalist extermists from the republic's government and the governing party, the Croatian Democratic Union.  Decision Called Historic **********"It can be called a historic meeting and a historic decision," Mr. Tudjman said in a speech before Croatia's Parliament this morning. "But I have no illusions that we haved entered some kind of paradise of peace." **********Neither the Defense Ministry nor the federal presidency have made any statement about the decision. **********While tension has eased in Croatia since Mr. Tudjman announced the decision, the level of anxiety remains high in Yugoslavia's largest and most populous republic, Serbia, since Belgrade television last night aired a 40-minute film, prepared by the federal Defense Ministry, that purported to show Croatian officials plotting attacks on army officers and their families and discussing a coming civil war. **********Mr. Tudjman said today that army law-enforcement officers had arrested 16 people in Croatia on charges of planning terrorist acts, organizing illegal paramilitary organizations and importing weapons illegally. **********The film's narrator alleges that Croatia's Defense Minister, Martin Spegelj, helped plan terrorist actions against Yugoslav Army troops. A Croatian official who asked not to be identified said the army's leaders wanted to arrest Mr. Spegelj. **********Mr. Spegelj attacked the authenticity of the films in a televised statement broadcast in Zagreb last night.  Restoration of Order Sought **********"The presidency of Yugoslavia," Mr. Tudjman said today, "for the first time said that legal order must be restored everywhere where it has broken down. That means that the highwaymen and rebels in Knin and everywhere else no longer have the right to call for the support from the federal leadership in Belgrade or the Yugoslav Army." **********But Croatia's Vice President, Stipe Mesic, said in an interview today that the Croatian government had no plans for a crackdown in the Knin region, which has a largely Serbian population. **********Yugoslavia is a loose federation of six highly autonomous republics that are home to many ethnic groups divided by historical and religious rivalries that have many times escalated into bloody armed conflicts. **********Since the Communist Party gave up its monopoly of power just over a year ago, the country has been the scene of a tug-of-war between republic leaders over the country's future political makeup. **********The governments of mostly Roman Catholic Croatia and Slovenia, the country's two most economically developed republics, are pushing for the transformation of Yugoslavia into a confederation of independent states, each with its own armed forces. The Communist government of mostly Eastern Orthodox Serbia advocates strengthening the present Yugoslav federation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/17/world.body_text: **********The Ethiopian Government has suspended the emigration of Ethiopian Jews to Israel because of what it said were unspecified "irregularities" by Jewish aid agencies. **********Before the Ethiopian announcement on Friday, the Israeli secretary of the Association of Ethiopian Jews, Rahamim Elazar, accused the Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam of moving to halt the program so as to put pressure on Israel to give it military assistance against renewed rebel activity in the north. **********A statement by the Ethiopian Foreign Ministry on Friday called the accusation "baseless, slanderous and contrary to the gesture of good will and humanitarian considerations" the Government says it has extended. **********In the statement, the Foreign Ministry said the emigration program would be resumed as soon as the problems were rectified. It did not identify the Jewish agencies involved. **********The program is aimed at reunifying families split by earlier emigrations. The exodus began in 1984, when an estimated 15,000 Ethiopian Jews were secretly airlifted to Israel. Making the Process Cumbersome **********The Government's statement on Friday said it had authorized the program on a case-by-case basis, requiring individual applications. **********"Gross and repeated irregularities were being committed in the process," the Addis Ababa leadership asserted, "and the concerned authorities of the Government had time and again requested that such irregularities be rectified. But the irregularities continued and increased to the point where it proved impossible to process applications." **********The initial emigration in 1984 was suspended after it was disclosed in foreign press reports. At the time, Ethiopia had no diplomatic relations with Israel. **********The two countries re-established ties in November 1989, but only about 3,500 of the Ethiopian Jews were allowed to emigrate last year. **********Under American pressure, the Ethiopian Government agreed to the stepped-up reunification program. About 2,000 people a month have been leaving for Israel since the first of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.main_headline: American Express and Japan Bank in Credit Card Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.print_headline: American Express and Japan Bank in Credit Card Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/24/busin.body_text: **********The American Express Company has reached an agreement with Sumitomo Bank Ltd. to establish a joint company that would issue personal charge cards and offer consumer loans in Japan, a senior American Express executive said yesterday. **********Under the agreement, which is expected to be announced today in Tokyo, the jointly run company would market the American Express gold card to Sumitomo clients, said G. Richard Thoman, chairman and co-chief executive of American Express Travel Related Services, which oversees the company's charge card. **********In addition, Mr. Thoman said, the new company would offer other loans, including lines of credit linked to the gold card as well as credit products contributed by Sumitomo. **********Under the agreement, the credit lines will be underwritten by the joint venture, with American Express and Sumitomo both bearing half of the risk of the loans. **********"This is an important strategic move for us," Mr. Thoman said in an interview. "Most banks and financial institutions realize they can't be everything to everyone. What we have tried to do is try to recognize this and move in areas that are complimentary." **********Both companies already have a presence in the card business in Japan. American Express issues charge cards there, and Sumitomo has a large franchise in issuing Visa credit cards, Mr. Thoman said. Those businesses will continue. Need for Upscale Product **********"They perceived that they needed an upscale product," Mr. Thoman said. "What we bring to this arrangement is in fact a product that fits the upper-income segments." **********In addition, Mr. Thoman said, Sumitomo came to the negotiations with "an enormously powerful distribution ability" that would be an essential element of the joint venture. **********In the interview, Mr. Thoman said that the joint venture was unrelated to the problems of deteriorating credits that developed last quarter in the company's charge card business. Mr. Thoman stressed that the negotiations began a year ago, long before the credit problems developed. **********Rather, he said that the move was part of a larger strategy at American Express for establishing joint ventures to expand the company's market base. **********The deal is the second joint-venture agreement this month that American Express has developed with a foreign bank. Earlier, American Express reached an agreement with Lloyds Bank, the British banking company, to issue a jointly sponsored corporate gold card. **********Unlike the agreement with Lloyds, however, the deal with Sumitomo focuses on the consumer, rather than the corporate market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/19/busin.main_headline: Baring Brothers Reported in Talks for Dillon Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/19/busin.print_headline: Baring Brothers Reported in Talks for Dillon Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/19/busin.body_text: **********Baring Brothers, one of Britain's oldest investment banking firms, is negotiating with Dillon, Read & Company to purchase a large stake in the American investment banking firm from the Travelers Corporation, financial industry executives said yesterday. **********The Baring negotiations come after almost a year of effort by Dillon executives to interest potential investors in many countries, including Japan, in purchasing part of the Travelers stake. The Baring negotiations were said to have begun, however, after Baring approached Dillon to express the firm's interest in a possible deal. **********Under preliminary terms, Baring would purchase about 40 percent of the company from Travelers, which would also retain 40 percent. The rest of the firm's stake would be held by its partners. **********While one executive said that the deal was still in tentative stages, others said it was further along. The negotiations "appear to be pretty close" to a conclusion, one executive with knowledge of the situation said. **********A spokesman for Dillon declined comment. Peter Baring, chairman of Barings, P.L.C., said, "I've got no comment at this time." **********Travelers' Financial Troubles **********Travelers has had financial troubles, because of a rising default rate in its mortgage portfolio and other real estate woes, and has been interested in selling a stake in Dillon to raise capital, even though the move would decrease its stake in one of its most successful investments. **********Travelers purchased Dillon, Read in 1986, at a price of $157.5 million, with an additional $67.5 million in employment contracts. That purchase price, about three times book value, is not expected to be matched in a deal with the venerable British firm. Negotiations were said to be more in the range of one to one and a half times the firm's book value. **********"Travelers would like to see some of its money back, and is the driving force behind this deal," one Wall Street executive said. "It is a very elegant solution." **********A deal with Baring would give Dillon a greater influence in the international investment banking business. But it would also raise questions about how Dillon's current international business would mesh with that of Baring. Similar deals, like the one in the 1970's that resulted in the business venture between Credit Suisse and the First Boston Corporation, struggled with difficulty in keeping both operations in business, until the two were made subsidiaries of a new holding company in recent years. **********If successful, the Dillon deal would unite two of the oldest financial firms in the world. Dillon, Read saw its beginnings in 1832, as the firm of Carpenter & Vermilye. Baring Brothers is a descendant of John and Francis Baring & Company, founded in London in 1762 as an agent for the Baring family's wool and dye business in Exeter. The Barings were originally North Germans who settled in Exeter in the early 18th century. **********In 1818, the infuence of its founding family was so great that it led the Duc de Richelieu to proclaim: "There are six great powers in Europe: England, France, Prussia, Austria, Russia and the Baring Brothers." **********The Baring family also extended its influence into the United States, becoming in the 19th century the foreign bankers most trusted by the United States Government. **********That influence began to wane following what has been named the great Baring panic of 1890, when concerns rose about the solvency of the company after it made a series of bad investments. Throughout the 20th century, the company kept itself relatively small, despite tremendous growth elsewhere in the banking and investment world. **********Dillon also avoided excessive growth. The firm was unscathed by the tumult on Wall Street in recent years, primarily because it did not join the huge rush of firms that built up beyond the demand for financial services. **********The deal would be the third major change in ownership of Dillon, Read in a little more than a decade. In April 1981, a controlling interest of the firm was purchased by the Bechtel Corporation. That again changed in five years when it struck a deal with Travelers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/01/world.print_headline: CONFLICT IN YUGOSLAVIA; Reports of Arms From Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/01/world.body_text: **********Arms from Lebanon's 16-year civil war are now being used in ethnic violence in Yugoslavia after militias here sold part of their arsenals to separatists in Slovenia and Croatia, security officials and news reports here said today. **********The security officials said $100 million worth of artillery, machine guns and ammunition have been sold on the Yugoslav market in the last four months. **********A Beirut newspaper, As Safir, reported that the Lebanese Forces had sent a shipload of weapons to a group in Yugoslavia. The paper gave no details. **********Ethnic unrest broke out in Yugoslavia last week after the northern republics of Slovenia and Croatia declared independence. Lebanese militia officials said the kinds of military hardware used here in factional violence are most suited for urban warfare, should the republics decide to fight the Yugoslav national army.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.main_headline: Will Intramural Squabbling Derail Debt-Ridden Sony?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.print_headline: Will Intramural Squabbling Derail Debt-Ridden Sony?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.body_text: **********Last month, Ron Sommer, the executive responsible for the Sony Corporation's consumer electronics business in the United States, was irritated by a report in the morning paper. His colleague Michael P. Schulhof, the head of the company's music and film businesses in New York, had told a reporter that Sony planned to make a digital tape recorder based on technology developed by rival Philips N.V. of the Netherlands. **********Such product decisions are the province of the hardware group, which is based in Park Ridge, N.J. And Mr. Sommer said in a recent interview that Sony has still not decided on such an introduction. "Maybe we both would have preferred that he hadn't made that comment," Mr. Sommer said. **********Mr. Schulhof, one of three non-Japanese on Sony's board, said he was commenting as a top Sony officer rather than as its ranking "software" executive. Yet it is not the first time people in hardware have felt upstaged by the music and film group, which is seen as the linchpin for Sony's growth as the electronics business matures. Ill will and jealous rivalries have been building between Sony's mainstay electronics group and its less profitable but flashier new sisters since Sony acquired the movie and record businesses in the late 1980's. **********"The software side has made a number of announcements that have caused a lot of concern on the hardware side," said David Lachenbruch, editorial director of Television Digest, a newsletter in New York, and a long-time chronicler of Sony. "My gut feeling is that there is a lot of disagreement and even rancor. It is very uncustomary for Sony, which has always had its act together." **********Tension between corporate groups can be healthy, even desirable. But at Sony, it threatens to undermine the synergies -- cross-marketing and coordinated product introductions -- that caused the company to link the businesses in the first place. Like a host of media companies from Time Warner Inc. to Paramount Communications Inc., Sony spent billions of dollars in the late 80's on the belief that one plus one would add up to three. Convinced of the benefits of producing film, video and music software and the hardware -- from VCR's to stereos -- to play it on, Sony paid $2 billion for CBS Records Inc. in 1988 and bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. the next year for $3.4 billion, plus the assumption of $1.5 billion in debt. Never again would something like the Betamax machine languish for want of products. **********Now, to keep from being eaten alive by its debt, Sony needs double-digit annual growth from its movie business, renamed Sony Pictures Entertainment last week. In fact, it is said to be planning to raise up to $3 billion in the United States and Japanese stock markets to pay down debt and finance entertainment operation. "Both wheels on the cart have to move at the same pace for synergy to work," said Darrel E. Whitten, an analyst with Prudential Securities in Tokyo. "If one of the wheels develops a flat, you have your worst nightmare." **********Some analysts already dismiss synergy as the leveraging of the 90's -- another fad dreamed up by investment bankers. But at Sony, the successful blending of software and hardware will take time, says Masaaki Morita, the brother of Sony chairman Akio Morita and the ranking Sony executive in the United States, the company's single largest market. As Mr. Sommer says, "If you don't know how to think in 20-year terms, your company dies." **********It would be a mistake to bet against Sony, which had worldwide sales of $25.6 billion in the year ended in March, nearly half of them coming from the businesses headed by Mr. Sommer and Mr. Schulhof. With products like the Walkman and the compact disk, Sony has shown a knack for designing irresistible products. Only Coca-Cola has a more potent brand name, according to Landor Associates, a research firm based in San Francisco. **********Sony executives say it has already seen the results of synergy. Mr. Schulhof said young Japanese consumers were so thrilled by Sony's link to a glamorous American entertainment company like CBS Records, now called Sony Music, that sales of its audio gear rose sharply in Japan after the acquisition. "It had a direct impact," said Mr. Schulhof. "It was measurable and it was financial." **********Yet some early opportunities for cooperation between software and hardware have produced more conflicts than results. "Synergy is a viable notion, but it can get stretched," said David J. Londoner, an entertainment industry analyst with Wertheim Schroeder in New York. "The classic example of it not working is digital audio tape." **********The digital audio tape (DAT) machine allows music lovers to make hiss-free digital-quality recordings on tape. Despite Sony's single-handed efforts to sell the virtues of the technology, DAT has suffered from a lack of support from the music industry. Fearing widespread copying, record companies have refused to release hits on the format. Sony Music released a few classical recording on digital tape, but otherwise refused to break ranks with the music industry. "Synergy does not mean coercion," Mr. Schulhof said. **********While he would have liked more support for the digital tape players, Mr. Sommer said he understands the position of his software colleagues. "Sony is a company that does not want to have consensus on everything," he said. "If Mickey does not want to support DAT, fine. I'm not going to kill him for that." **********The music companies softened considerably to digital recording last month, after the electronics makers agreed to pay them royalties for sales lost to digital home recording. Electronics makers like Sony, Philips and Matsushita were more receptive to the idea now that many of them own record companies. "The landscape has changed," Mr. Schulhof conceded. **********While Sony executives maintain that there will be no forced synergy, there is a danger that artists working for the company's entertainment businesses will object to supporting other Sony ventures. Such a conflict appears to have surfaced with the director Steven Spielberg and "Hook," Columbia Pictures' star-studded updating of the Peter Pan story, starring Julia Roberts, Robin Williams and Dustin Hoffman. **********Set for release in December, "Hook" is viewed by Sony as a test case for the many ties-ins possible with a single movie. Executives envision promotions of the "see the movie, win a Walkman" variety, as well as with other companies. But outside marketing people working with Sony and Mr. Spielberg said the director was uncomfortable with the planned deluge of promotion, fearing the commercialism would cheapen the movie and jeopardize his chance of winning critical awards. Executives working for Mr. Spielberg deny any such concern and say they are happy with the arrangement. **********The internal combat has become particularly intense as the company prepares to introduce for Christmas a handheld reference device called the Data Discman, which relies on outside development of disks containing electronic encyclopedias and other reference works. Accustomed to cutting quick deals with software publishers, with little worry about making money from the software, Sony hardware executives complain that the company's software executives have alienated outside software producers. **********Some outside software publishers say that hardware executives relish the prospect of a conspicuous failure by the software side. "I have been surprised by the intensity of the criticism from the hardware side," said one executive who insisted on anonymity. **********Peter Black, president of Xiphias, a Los Angeles production company that has signed a contract to develop material for Data Discman, said the tension is understandable. "The hardware guys represent the cash cow, the business that is in its maturity," he said. "They resent the new guys." **********Electronic products account for about 80 percent of Sony, with movies and music kicking in the remaining 20 percent. Operating income breaks down similarly, with the hardware side bringing in $1.76 billion to entertainment's $329 million. **********Mr. Schulhof said that eventually the entertainment business will contribute as much operating income as electronics, although he admitted such parity is years away. Mr. Whitten of Prudential Securities pegs growth of the music and entertainment business at about 15 percent per year, compared with 4 or 5 percent growth for consumer electronics over the next few years. **********Without such growth, Mr. Whitten said, Columbia's debt could drag down earnings. Sony is thought to have overpaid for Columbia Pictures and has kept spending lavishly on it. "Columbia Pictures was an expensive transaction," Mr. Schulhof acknowledged. **********Asked if Sony was comfortable with the level of investment in the movie business, Mr. Morita said, " 'Comfortable' is a very delicate word. Once we get the return on the investment, we will be comfortable." **********But some analysts doubt Sony will ever recoup its investment. "There is a disaster waiting to happen called Columbia Pictures," said Emanuel Gerard, an analyst with Gerard, Klauer, Mattison in New York. "I don't think Sony knows how to deal with this. They ought to be scared."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Frances C. Gaskin, a clinical nurse who is now an entrepreneur, has patented an array of shampoos and hair conditioners that she said offered better protection from the sun's ultraviolet rays than existing products. The key ingredient is melanin, the brownish-black pigment found in skin. **********Ms. Gaskin, who has previously patented melanin-based skin lotions, said melanin acts as a moisturizer that keeps both skin and hair from becoming bleached, dried and brittle. The key to the new formulation is a method for dissolving synthetic melanin, which typically exists in granular form, so it can be put into hair products. To break down the granules, Ms. Gaskin developed a method using enzymes. **********She has created a company, Frances Christian Gaskin Inc. in Albany, to market her products. **********Ms. Gaskin received patent 5,006,331.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/busin.main_headline: The Bank Merger; For New York, A Loss of Jobs And Revenues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/busin.print_headline: The Bank Merger; For New York, A Loss of Jobs And Revenues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/busin.body_text: **********The merger of Chemical Bank with Manufacturers Hanover may make a lot of banking sense, because the two weak banks, by combining, have a chance to emerge as a stronger, more vibrant lending institution. **********But for New York City and other communities, this merger and the larger consolidation in the banking industry will bring a lot of pain as institutions slim down, trying to determine the number of branches and employees that will make them more profitable and bring them into the new banking era. **********In the near term, however, the merger of the Chemical Banking Corporation with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation means the loss to New York City of as many as 5,900 jobs, fewer tax dollars paid to a revenue-starved city and 70 branches and untold office space coming onto an already-glutted property market. Industry Shrinking Faster **********The merger also signals a quickening in the pace of the banking industry's shrinkage -- a process that many analysts said was just beginning to get under way in New York City. While analysts think that Citicorp still has a lot of cost savings it can gain from simply streamlining its own operations, others looked to banking companies like Chase Manhattan, Marine Midland Banks and Bank of New York as potential merger candidates. **********New York has long been home to some of the nation's largest and most prominent banking organizations. But a combination of soured loans to third world countries, greater competition for bread-and-butter corporate lending, and newcomers invading their turf from regional cities and abroad have made these titans' futures precarious. **********Many banking analysts and economists viewed yesterday's merger announcement as just the beginning of a wave of consolidation. Indeed, Deputy Mayor Sally Hernandez-Pinero said yesterday that at a Gracie Mansion breakfast earlier this year, top bankers were in universal agreement that there would be more than one mega-merger before the year was out. **********"I was shocked," said Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, who nonetheless admitted to being impressed that two such stalwarts in an industry known for its conservatism would finally decide to take such a painful step to insure their long-term survival.  Another Blow to City's Jobs **********A new round of layoffs in the banking industry will hit the city just as the well-publicized contraction on Wall Street seems finally to be abating. Although the banking and brokerage industries have each lost about 10,000 jobs in the last 12 months, the pace of those losses in the brokerage industry has slowed to a monthly rate of about several hundred in recent months, while those in the banking industry are running at about 1,000 a month. **********"The banking industry's job losses will continue into the next year," said Rae D. Rosen, senior economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. She said she expected the local recession to continue into 1992, with the economy showing no sign of growth until 1993 or 1994. **********Coming on top of the 6,300 pink slips that were recently handed out to city employees, and the several thousand jobs that are expected to be cut from the Pan Am Corporation, this latest announcement is certainly not good news for the city.  Calls to Governor and Mayor **********In recognition of how important this development is to the local economy, John F. McGillicuddy, the chairman of Manufacturers Hanover, called Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York early yesterday, while Chemical's chairman, Walter V. Shipley, called Mayor David N. Dinkins. The response, Mr. McGillicuddy said, was not surprising. **********"No politician likes to hear about job cuts," he said at a news conference later in the day. **********The merger is expected to result in the loss of about 6,200 jobs, 95 percent of them in New York City. Those figures could be reduced still further, depending on the rate of attrition at the two banks over the coming months. **********Although some senior-level jobs are likely to be lost because of the consolidation of overlapping administrative functions, most of the cuts are expected to come from the banks' clerical ranks and back-office workers. And that could have important social consequences.  Minorities and Women Affected **********"Over half of the jobs in banks are clerical, and in the past they have provided a significant source of upward mobility for minority employees, and especially women," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. **********Aside from the job losses, New Yorkers will likely notice the closing or sale of 70 bank branches, which will be concentrated in Manhattan, especially downtown. There will be no closings of Chemical's branches in New Jersey or Texas. **********Bank executives yesterday gave no specifics on which branches in New York City would be closed, and little detail about what criteria they would use, although they gave assurances that no neighborhood would be left bereft. The New York State Superintendent of Banks, Derrick D. Cephas, who has been on the job for one week, said that his department would have some contribution to the final decision-making process. **********He noted that the closing of a branch that was next door to another branch would not matter, but that if there were only one branch in a neighborhood, "we would certainly take a different view," he said.  First and Third in Serving City **********According to a list prepared by the Department of Finance that ranks how well banks do in serving city neighborhoods, Chemical Bank was in first place and Manufacturers Hanover third. **********Both banks have also been active in philanthropic efforts that benefit the city: Manufacturers Hanover with its sponsorship of the New York City Marathon and corporate challenge races, and Chemical with its sponsorship of the Metropolitan Opera's concerts in Central Park and other outdoor venues. A spokesman for Chemical said those commitments would not change. **********The outlook is less bright, however, for the real estate market. The closing or sale of bank branches will put more pressure on the market for sublet retail space, which is already weak. In the 53 square blocks that make up the Grand Central business district, for instance, the vacancy rate for retail space is higher than 11 percent.  Effect on the Office Market **********Chemical's announcement that it intended to vacate its executive offices at 277 Park Avenue, at 48th Street, which it has leased until mid-1994, and to move into Manufacturers Hanover's headquarters across the avenue will also hurt the office market. **********Chemical currently leases about 750,000 square feet in its Park Avenue offices, and real estate specialists said the sudden arrival on the market of that much premium office space would hurt landlords with space available in less attractive areas or in slightly older buildings. **********"The impact on the city now will not be good in the short term," said Jerry L. Cohen, chairman of William A. White/Grubb & Ellis, a real estate firm. Further consolidation is expected in the two banks' back-office operations, situated in New York City, Long Island and New Jersey. **********Still, large bank mergers have been anticipated by many in the real estate industry for some time. Salomon Brothers' real estate analyst, David Shulman, said that he had been assuming that a transaction like this would occur for so long that it had become a precondition, in his mind, to future improvement in New York City real estate. He said that he, too, expected another merger involving large New York banks and that as far as he was concerned, the sooner the city got the pain over with, the better.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/world.main_headline: Harvesting Leads to Heart of South America
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/world.print_headline: Harvesting Leads to Heart of South America
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/world.body_text: **********Conversations with residents here often follow a familiar pattern: first, pride over living in a frontier city located at the geographic center of South America, and then, anxiety over the isolation. **********Traditionally, the rest of Brazil has cared little that buses take 32 hours to travel from this state capital to Rio de Janeiro on the Atlantic Coast. **********But while Rio slept, Cuiaba boomed. **********High-rises sprouting across the horizon here attest to the fact that the population of Cuiaba, capital of Mato Grosso, has increased tenfold in the last 30 years, and is now about 500,000. **********Paying for the clean streets and boutiques was an agricultural revolution that swept across fertile savannas around here, tripling soy and wheat harvests in the 1980's.  The River Route for Less **********With silos and warehouses packed with grain that can spoil before it reaches coastal ports, businessmen and politicians are drawing up ambitious plans for rail and river links that will open the heart of South America to the rest of the world. **********"By river, we can deliver one ton of soy to the Atlantic for $35," said Alfredo da Mota Menezes, a local university professor and author of a book on Latin American integration. "By truck, it now costs us $100 a ton." **********The river route requires the cooperation of five countries -- Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay. Flowing 2,230 miles down the Paraguay River to the Parana River, the waterway provides a practical test of a regional common market pact signed in March by presidents of all the waterway countries except Bolivia. **********The railroad would travel 1,067 miles from here to link up with existing lines in Brazil and would be financed by public and private capital. Promoted by a businessman the Brazilian press calls "The Soy King," the railway would test Brazil's new policy of encouraging private companies to build and control infrastructure projects.  Tracks Through the Grain Belt **********In May, Olacyr de Moraes, the railroad entrepreneur, received conditional approval from a state investment bank for a $250 million loan for a project that is budgeted at $2.5 billion. Mr. Moraes, the world's largest soy producer, plans to invest $300 million of his own money to start building the first stretch of track late this year. **********Cutting through Brazil's new grain belt -- Mato Grosso do Sul, Goias and Mato Grosso -- the trains would roll into this city by the end of the decade. **********Looking for a cheaper outlet to the sea, regional businessmen and politicians met in April to advance a project that would allow barges loaded with such products as soy, lumber and copper to travel from Mato Grosso to Argentina's Atlantic ports of Rosario and Buenos Aires. **********Known as the "Hidrovia Paraguay-Parana," the waterway would require $60 million in investments for dredging and for setting navigational markers. **********Spread among the five nations, the investment is small. But it remains to be seen whether the economic boom is strong enough to break Cuiaba free from longstanding parochial interests. **********In Santos, a major Brazilian port for exporting soy beans, an official with Codespa, the state port company, was asked about the Hidrovia project. **********Shaking his head, he responded: "The problem is that the soy would go out through Argentine ports."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.main_headline: Cairo Journal; Where Envoys Waltzed, Now the Wrecker's Ball
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.print_headline: Cairo Journal; Where Envoys Waltzed, Now the Wrecker's Ball
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/world.body_text: **********Glimpsed through wrought-iron gates, the elegant two-story building was just the sort of thing one might expect of an American embassy somewhere on the far side of the world: a whitewashed mansion framed by a wide marble staircase, and set against a deep yard of palm trees and dusty green grass. **********But after more than four decades of serving American diplomats, the old chancellery building in Cairo is gone. Its stone facade has been broken by a wrecker's ball, and a small army of Egyptian workers is now carting away the debris, clearing the site for the construction of an eight-story high-rise inside a walled embassy compound with the sunless feel of a Wall Street canyon. **********Like other buildings in other cities all over the world, the aging chancellery had become a dinosaur. Situated in a neighborhood of looping streets and mansions, a quiet, tree-lined quarter called Garden City that borders the din and clamor of central Cairo, the old embassy had great character and style. But it took up valuable space inside a cramped, three-acre compound that already houses one of the United States Government's largest overseas diplomatic missions. 'The Price of Progress' **********Diplomats here mourn the passing of the chancellery as an emblem of a simpler, less complicated era, when staffs were smaller, diplomatic life moved at a more measured pace and security concerns had not turned embassies into brooding fortresses. **********"It's a shame, especially when you imagine that old building being replaced by another high-rise," a staff member said. "But that is, sadly, the price of progress." **********What has happened in Cairo is not unique. In other foreign capitals too, the United States has been forced to abandon the gracious villas and mansions where it had maintained its diplomatic legations, and to replace them with modern buildings, wired for computer cables and high-speed electronics and reinforced to resist terrorist bombs. **********In the last few years, American diplomats have moved out of aging buildings in Georgetown, Guyana, and Sana, Yemen. "Some of the older buildings we have been in around the world are nice, and they have a lot of character," said a State Department official in Washington. "But they also are inefficient and -- most important -- vulnerable. Fifty or a hundred years ago, people were not building for today's truck bombs."  Tougher Look at Security **********After bombings at American embassies in Beirut and Kuwait in the early 1980's, the United States Government took a much tougher look at embassy security. In 1985 a Federal commission recommended an extensive Government program to beef up security at all American sites overseas. **********In Cairo, the task of redeveloping the embassy property was complicated by the astounding growth of the embassy. When Arthur Lowrie took up his post as the embassy's political counselor here in 1975, he recalls, the entire United States mission consisted of 40 Americans, including the Marine security guards. **********Just over 10 years later, the embassy had grown to nearly 600. Today, there are about 480 American staff members, including 110 members of a United States Aid to International Development mission, which is the largest since Vietnam. **********"It was an elegant old place," said Mr. Lowrie, who now teaches at the University of South Florida in Tampa. "There were tall windows and high ceilings with ornate plaster work, and a fireplace in the Ambassador's office. But even when I was there it was a bit cramped." Metaphor for a City **********In some ways, the passing of the chancellery is a metaphor for the city around it. Over the last two decades, as modernization has overtaken this tangled, teeming capital of narrow streets and rich but decaying colonial architecture, thousands of gracious buildings have fallen into total disrepair, or been swept away entirely to build new European-style office buildings. **********The chancellery building was constructed in 1929 as a private residence by a wealthy Egyptian family. Across the street on one corner was the British Embassy, which still occupies the site, overlooking the cocoa-colored waters of the Nile River. Across another street was El Walda Palace, the residence of King Farouk's mother. **********The United States Army bought the villa and its surrounding grounds in 1946, as the site of a military mission. A year later it became the United States Embassy in Egypt. **********As the staff inside the embassy grew, the green lawns and shady groves behind the chancellery were torn up and built over, replaced by marble patios and parking lots. The open-air courtyard where couples once danced at the annual Marine ball is now a 15-story building, from the top of which the Ambassador surveys Cairo, safely protected behind recessed, bulletproof windows. **********In designing the look of the new embassy compound, architects have sought to retain a traditional feel. Drawings of the new embassy high-rise show a two-story columned portico, overlooking a wide lawn of walks, gardens and palm trees. **********In many ways, the old chancellery building had all but disappeared from public view several years ago. The wrought-iron gates that used to afford some views of the interior of the embassy property were pulled down and replaced by steel plates and 20-foot-high, dun-colored walls, reinforced to withstand bomb blasts and constantly monitored by surveillance cameras. **********Among Egyptians who continue to profess their affection for Americans, and the strong ties that now bind the two nations, there is little admiration for the face the embassy compound now presents to Cairo. **********"I hate to say it, but the American Embassy these days reminds me mostly of another embassy that is also built like a prison," an Egyptian woman said. "You know it, the Russian Embassy, across the Nile."
