https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Getting the Benefit Of Military Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Getting the Benefit Of Military Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.body_text: **********THE primary economic benefit to the United States of the collapse of the Soviet empire is, potentially, the opportunity to make deep cuts in military spending and use the savings to eliminate the budget deficit, tackle domestic problems, or some combination of both. **********Of total American military spending, about 60 percent has gone to block the Soviet threat to Western Europe and deter Soviet nuclear attack. Yet military spending is still running close to $300 billion, in real terms nearly what it was in 1989, the year the Berlin wall came down and the Warsaw Pact collapsed. **********And Pentagon plans call for total military spending, including atomic energy and the strategic weapons stockpile, to come down only 22 percent over the next five years. Measured in constant 1992 dollars to eliminate effects of inflation, military spending is projected to decline from $295.2 billion in the 1992 fiscal year to $252.5 billion in 1996. Pentagon planners call this plan their irreducible minimum and say further cuts would jeopardize national security. **********But a new study for the Brookings Institution, "The Post-Cold War Defense Program," by William W. Kaufmann of Harvard and John D. Steinbruner, director of foreign policy studies at Brookings, contends that much deeper cuts in military spending could be made over the next decade without weakening national security -- and with important economic gains. The test of the United States as a superpower, they say, "will be whether it can now arrive at a more realistic balance between its military and economic power." **********Their "low option" plan for cutting the military budget calls for spending of $2.2 trillion over the next 10 years, compared with $2.5 trillion in Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's plan. But the Kaufmann-Steinbruner study maintains that the Cheney projections are too low, because they do not take into account real increases that will be required starting in 1997 for next-generation weapons procurement planned by the Pentagon. Allowing for such additional costs, the authors project the Pentagon's spending plans to reach a total of $2.8 trillion over the next 10 years, or $620 billion more than their low option plan. **********That plan would achieve its savings by scaling back both nuclear and conventional weapons. In the nuclear area that would include reconfiguring the B-1B bomber from a penetrating bomber to a less expensive cruise missile launcher; terminating the B-2 bomber program at 15 aircraft; deferring deployment of the small intercontinental ballistic missile, and reorienting the Strategic Defense Initiative to a research effort. **********For nonnuclear forces, the low option plan calls for continued upgrading of current combat aircraft, while delaying production of next-generation successors; postponing a range of capabilities aimed at enhancing the Army's ability to contain a Soviet attack; extending the life of the C-141 airlift aircraft and terminating the C-17A, and canceling the SSN-21 attack submarine and procurement funds for two new aircraft carriers. **********Despite these cuts, the plan would enable the United States to respond in the same way it did in the Persian Gulf war, except that four carrier battle groups would be used, instead of the six stationed in the Persian Gulf. **********Deeper cuts in military spending could be achieved, the study said, by adopting a "cooperative security" arrangement in which the leading military establishments, including the Soviet Union's, would be organized to prevent aggressive actions anywhere in the world. International regulations would guide the movement of forces, concentration of tactical aircraft and the nature of research activities. This arrangement would impose not only new global responsibilities on America's allies but also "a meaningful shift in the assumptions used to guide investment in U.S. forces." **********Cooperative security, by relying more on other nations' forces and slowing down reaction times, could bring total United States military spending down to $2 trillion over the next 10 years, helping to save a total of $800 billion. **********By the year 2001, American military spending would be less than half its current level. The huge cut would reduce the drain on national savings, stimulate capital formation and economic growth, create more jobs and provide resources to meet other critical national needs. **********But the cooperative approach would demand exceptionally committed leadership, here and abroad. It would require countries like Germany and Japan to increase their global responsibilities. And it would require the United States to accept restraints on its freedom to take unilateral actions. For the United States to accept such restraints would be, the authors say, "internally very difficult," but they insist that "international events mandate a serious effort to make this transformation and are likely to compel the United States to debate it as a viable security option." **********President Bush's effort this week to force Saddam Hussein to comply with United Nations resolutions shows how hard it would be for the United States to accept collective restraints on its freedom of action -- and how important it is to be perceived as acting in the common interest of peace-seeking countries. The big military savings and economic gains will demand political vision and large concepts of what is involved in creating a new world order.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/busin.main_headline: Accepting the Harsh Truth Of a Blue-Collar Recession
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/busin.print_headline: Accepting the Harsh Truth Of a Blue-Collar Recession
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/busin.body_text: **********For all the talk of a "white collar" recession, it is blue-collar workers who have been hardest hit by the current economic slump, losing more jobs and enduring far higher rates of unemployment. Five times as many blue-collar jobs have evaporated, and jobless rates are more than twice as severe. **********More and more, blue-collar workers are facing the harsh truth that though the economy will no doubt come back, their lost jobs are probably gone for good, given the relentless advance of automation and international competition. Last week's announcement by the General Motors Corporation that it plans to shut 21 assembly plants and shed more than 70,000 jobs over the next few years -- only about a third of the cuts will come from the salaried ranks -- was just the most recent indication that the squeeze on blue-collar factory workers will continue. **********So in places like Haverhill, Mass., a struggling industrial town in the state's northeast, workers are starting to train for new occupations, which offer brighter employment prospects but often pay far less. Losing a Way of Life **********When Robert Harrington, a machine operator, was laid off in July, he lost a $37,000-a-year position and a standard of living he may never recover. After 20 years, his job in a nearby plant that prints and binds telephone directories was eliminated in a cost-cutting program. **********By September, Mr. Harrington was not only out of a job, he was also divorced. Instead of a spacious colonial home, he now lives in a two-room apartment with his 15-year-old son, Robert. After he deducts his rent, utilities and other expenses from his unemployment check, Mr. Harrington figures that he lives on $12 a day. These days, a night on the town is a chicken fajita at McDonald's. **********Mr. Harrington is studying in a federally financed program to be a paralegal, or lawyer's assistant. If he lands a job, he will earn at least $10,000 less than in his old blue-collar job. **********"The money will be less, but I was looking for something that is recession proof," said Mr. Harrington, who is 38. "I don't want to go through this again." Traditional Target for Cost Cuts **********The unemployment rate in blue-collar occupations -- a broad category covering more than 30 million Americans, from skilled craftsmen to manual laborers, with varied talents, incomes and circumstances -- stood at 9.1 percent in November, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. By contrast, the white-collar unemployment rate was 4.1 percent. **********Since the peak of economic activity in July 1990, the blue-collar unemployment rate has increased by two percentage points while the white-collar rate has risen by one point. And the number of blue-collar jobs has fallen by more than a million, as desk jobs over all have declined by about 200,000. **********Of course, white-collar professionals like bankers and lawyers, who once considered themselves immune to recessions, have also lost jobs. Those layoffs have been well publicized, and many occurred early in the economic downturn, reinforcing the image of the white-collar recession. **********"But the traditional American way of cutting costs is to lay off blue-collar workers in times of recession, and that remains overwhelmingly the case," said Erica L. Groshen, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, who has studied the impact on workers in various occupations. 'Joe Middleman' As Odd Man Out **********In a series of interviews in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Michigan, blue-collar workers, regardless of occupation, expressed the concern that the hold they once had on middle-class status was increasingly precarious. "I am the working man -- 'Joe Middleman,' " said Gary Aldous, an out-of-work carpenter from Torrington, Conn. "But we seem to have an economy now that produces two classes, the rich and the poor. It seems as though this country is trying to eliminate people like me in the middle." **********The pinch on blue-collar workers has been tightening for years. From 1980 to 1990, after adjusting for inflation, the wages of blue-collar workers fell by 6.3 percent, while white-collar salaries rose 3.9 percent. "Even a strong economy did not arrest the decline of earning capacity of blue-collar workers," said Gary Burtless, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. **********The manufacturing sector, heavily blue collar, suffered more in the 1981-82 recession than this time around. In the previous downturn, 2.2 million manufacturing jobs were lost. Many of the cuts were made in the name of fashioning a lean and newly competitive corporate America that could hold its own against foreign rivals. The streamlining process succeeded in making American producers more vigorous and, recently, manufactured exports have been one of the few sources of strength in the American economy. **********Yet the process of squeezing more production from fewer workers is by no means over. This time, companies began shedding factory jobs 18 months before the recession began. Since January 1989, companies have eliminated 1.2 million manufacturing workers. "Manufacturing employment has been hard hit in this recession and for years before," said Thomas Nardone, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Fewer Auto Sales, Fewer Auto Parts **********Howard Miller, a 53-year-old machinist of Jackson, Mich., went to work for Jackson Drop Forge in 1958, which made forged steel parts for companies supplying the Big Three auto makers. He worked there until the place finally shut down in November 1990, laying off its last 60 workers. **********A member of the United Automobile Workers Union, Mr. Miller made more than $10 a hour, and when the forging plant was busy, he made $28,000 a year. But this year, such jobs have been scarce, as the Detroit auto makers are struggling and thousands of companies that supply the auto industry are retrenching again. **********Unlike workers for the Big Three, who thanks to their labor contracts collect more than 90 percent of their wages when laid off, workers for the subcontractors have no such safety net. Mr. Miller's state unemployment payments of $226 a week ended last May. His wife, Geraldine, died in June of a prolonged kidney ailment. **********Mr. Miller owes the hospital $1,700 and the funeral parlor $2,000. His 1988 Buick was repossessed in July. His house was paid off years ago, but he is behind on his property tax payments. A neighbor helps by cooking him meals and baking him bread. Mr. Miller used to bowl for recreation, but, he said, "I don't do anything anymore." **********Mr. Miller worked for two months this fall for a nearby company that repairs industrial machinery. As a part-time worker, he was paid $4.50 an hour, with no benefits. But the weakening economy brought that job to an end in November, and his prospects are bleak. There is very little forging work left near Jackson these days. The few machinist jobs available in the region require applicants who can handle computer-controlled equipment, a skill Mr. Miller does not have. **********The auto parts industry, with more than 650,000 workers, is America's largest manufacturing employer. But with increasing competition from Japanese suppliers, which are building new factories in America and hiring young workers, "the domestic parts industry is where the next shakeout is going to be," said Sean McAlinden, a labor economist at the University of Michigan's Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation. "And there's no retraining solution for the older workers in that industry." A Union Carpenter, Trying to Scrape By **********During the 1980's real-estate boom, Ron Richnavsky, a 29-year-old carpenter from Harwinton, Conn., had all the work he could handle. A union carpenter, paid $17.50 an hour plus benefits, he made up to $50,000 a year. In 1988, he and his wife, Linda, bought a $135,000 four-bedroom house for themselves and their three daughters, Nicole, Amanda and Danielle. "At the time, I was making good money," he said. "We thought we could handle it." **********Mr. Richnavsky has had some work this year, but not nearly enough. He is about six months behind on his mortgage payments of $1,200 a month, and the bank is threatening to foreclose, he says. His wife makes $130 to $150 a week in her part-time job as a waitress. His unemployment benefits amount to $300 a week. "We can scrape through," he said, "as long as I don't pay the mortgage." Blinded by the 80's **********Like so many other Americans, Mr. Richnavsky admits that he got caught up in the prosperity of the 1980's, assumed it would continue and took on too much debt. "When times are good, you don't think," he said. **********Mr. Richnavsky has thought about seeking training in another field -- "some kind of computer training," he said -- but not seriously. As a journeyman carpenter, he is a skilled craftsman who should be in demand when construction activity picks up. **********The amount of work may never again reach the superheated pace of the 1980's. The current 30 percent unemployment rates in construction in Connecticut, with the number of hours worked by the state's union carpenters cut by half since 1988, is the biggest slump in more than two decades, says John Cunningham, president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners Local 210, representing Fairfield and Litchfield counties. The situation cannot help but eventually improve, Mr. Cunningham says. Seizing the Chance For a Fresh Start **********In the lower Merrimack Valley of Massachusetts, the industrial northeast corner of the state, local government officials are not waiting for the recession to end. They are engaged in an aggressive effort, aided by Federal money under the Job Training Partnership Act, to retrain and find jobs for laid-off workers. Under the local program, the trainees receive unemployment benefits for an extended period of 10 months while they take courses to prepare for a new career. **********The lower Merrimack region includes high-tech industries and traditional manufacturing plants clustered around the cities of Lowell, Lawrence and Haverhill, which have unemployment rates of 12 to 15 percent. The well-known companies in the area include American Telephone and Telegraph, Wang, Digital Equipment and Raytheon, all of which have cut their payrolls. **********Ellen Reingold worked for 24 years as a electronics production worker for various companies in the region. Her most recent job was a yearlong stint at $10.50 an hour for Raytheon, debugging the electronic circuitry on the Patriot missiles of gulf war fame. But she was laid off last May. Mrs. Reingold, who is divorced with two grown children, was forced to sell her house in Haverhill, unable to make the $1,068-a-month mortgage payment. "It was either sell it or lose it after I lost my job," she said. **********In the good years, Mrs. Reingold made $30,000 as an electronics assembler. But in each of the last three years, she has been laid off for months at a time. Seeking a field that offers more steady work, she is studying for a career in medical transcribing, the task of typing up doctors' tape-recorded notes into a computer. Besides word-processing skills, she is studying medical terminology. **********Hospitals and clinics have stables of medical transcribers, she has heard. "They say there's a lot of work out there," said Mrs. Reingold, who is 41 years old. From Dying Job to a Healing One **********Some of the retraining students have embarked on striking career changes. Rene Martineau, a burly 48-year-old former printing superviser, is training to be a licensed practical nurse. A nursing job, he says, will pay only about half of the $50,000 a year he used to make. "But printing is a dying industry," he said. "It will all be done by computers soon. And there is a real shortage of nurses." **********Others see the recession as an opportunity. Michelle Dryver of Amesbury, Mass., has moved through a succession of mainly factory jobs since she graduated from high school eight years ago. She and her husband, Andrew, an assembler at a circuit-board plant, are scrimping to get by and have put off plans to start a family. **********But Ms. Dryver is now studying office management, accounting and word processing at Northern Essex Community College in Haverhill, as well as medical terminology and transcribing. "I should be able to get something more than dead-end jobs when I graduate," said Ms. Dryver, who is 26 years old. "This is a perfect opportunity for someone like me." **********Northern Essex Community College has about 1,000 of what the college president, John Dimitry, likes to call "our new breed of student," in the worker assistance program, a three-year-old endeavor. The students' grades, he said, have been about a full grade point higher than those of the younger students. **********"What this has taught me is that there is enormous flexibility on the part of the work force," Mr. Dimitry said. "They want to be retrained and educated, given the chance. It can be done and it is being done right here."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.main_headline: Haiti's Victors Working to Soothe Fears
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.print_headline: Haiti's Victors Working to Soothe Fears
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.body_text: **********Three days after a failed coup attempt set off a spree of looting and vengeful attacks that left at least 70 dead, supporters of Haiti's President-elect, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, have begun working to calm the fears of those who warned that the leftist priest's election last month would unleash a wave of revenge. **********After three nights of curfews and calls for order by Father Aristide and other political figures, life in the capital and other cities largely returned to normal today. But as Haiti cleans up from the violence, diplomats say damage to one target of the attacks, the country's Roman Catholic hierarchy, will prove difficult, if not impossible, to repair. **********There is no evidence that Father Aristide, who has long battled conservative Catholicism, directed attacks in which the capital's 221-year-old cathedral and the Vatican Embassy and residence were destroyed, the Papal Nuncio assaulted and his secretary gravely wounded. But diplomats and Haitian analysts say the incidents have badly hurt the new Government's image among the diplomatic corps and may have crippled ties between Haiti and the Vatican. Explaining the People's Reaction **********Several diplomats said in interviews that Father Aristide had been neither fast enough nor forceful enough in condemning the street violence that followed the failure of an attempted coup by a former leader of the brutal Tontons Macoute militia. **********In a brief statement read over a radio station Wednesday afternoon, Father Aristide called the destruction "hideous," but he dwelt on explanations of the people's violent reaction. His call for "vigilance without vengeance" was seen by many as advocating further popular mobilization against supporters of the deposed Duvalier family dictatorship that ruled Haiti for 29 years. **********"The attack was hideous, but at the same time they are saying, 'We have to get more Macoutes,' " said one senior Western diplomat. "Here we have the violation of a diplomatic premise and wherever that happens in the world it must be considered very grave." **********Many observers have expressed concern that Father Aristide's past statements, which come close to advocating violence openly, have set a tone for the people that will be difficult to contain.  United States Concerns **********The United States, Canada and the United Nations have publicly expressed strong concerns to Haiti's interim Government and, indirectly, to Father Aristide. **********"There can be no excuse for using the failed coup attempt as an excuse for exacting vengeance," a State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said in Washington. The Vatican has remained silent on the incidents. **********Father Aristide's spokeswoman, Marie-Laurence Lassegue, said the violence was an aberration. "I know this is something that has shocked a lot of people," she said. "But we don't think the people realized what they were doing, that this was an embassy. We have always respected embassies in this country and this is a great pity that will not be repeated." **********Nonetheless, other supporters of Father Aristide said the violence had been caused by criticism of Father Aristide, and the insurgent "Little Church" movement he has led, by Msgr. Francois Wolff Ligonde, the Archbishop of Port-au-Prince. 'Chills the Hearts' **********"Ligonde officially gave his benediction to the coup," said Jean-Claude Bajeux, a human rights advocate and former priest, expressing a widely held interpretation of a homily by the Archbishop in which he spoke of the "anxiety that chills the hearts of mothers and fathers" at the prospect of an Aristide Government. **********It has been widely reported here that the attacks on the home and office of the Papal Nuncio, Msgr. Giuseppe Leanza, were aimed at Monsignor Ligonde, who has been in hiding ever since. When crowds attacked the Nuncio's home in the wealthy Petionville area early Monday morning, Monsignor Leanza and two nuns were able to escape with the help of neighbors and the police, but the Nuncio's personal secretary, the Rev. Leon Karenga, was chased by the crowd, chopped at with a machete and nearly killed.

Mr. Rayfield, who is 56, has been general partner of Forstmann Rayfield & Company, a venture capital firm...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/23/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
M/A-Com's President Is a Venture Capitalist
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/23/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
M/A-Com's President Is a Venture Capitalist
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/23/busin.body_text: **********M/A-Com Inc., a military electronics equipment maker in Burlington, Mass., has named Allan L. Rayfield president and chief operating officer. Mr. Rayfield, who is 56, has been general partner of Forstmann Rayfield & Company, a venture capital firm in Southport, Conn. **********This is not the first time M/A-Com has reached outside for a top executive. Thomas A. Vanderslice, the chairman and chief executive, was chief executive of Apollo Computer Inc. before being named to the top post at M/A-Com in 1989. Mr. Vanderslice, 59, replaced Thomas F. Burke, who was killed in a car accident. **********Mr. Rayfield and Mr. Vanderslice had worked together before, first at the General Electric Company, where both spent more than 20 years, and then at the GTE Corporation in the early 1980's. Their career paths parted in 1984, when Mr. Vanderslice left GTE to join Apollo Computer. Mr. Rayfield stayed at GTE, becoming president and chief operating officer of the products and systems group. Mr. Rayfield reported directly to Mr. Vanderslice for three years at GTE. **********The two executives face a formidable task. Military contracts account for 80 percent of M/A-Com's sales, and analysts say growth will be hard to sustain as the Government sharply cuts military spending. **********M/A-Com reported a net loss of $105.4 million for the fiscal year that ended in September. But the company has moved to sell money-losing operations and it has posted a profit for each of the last four quarters. **********Company officials hope the spending slowdown will not be as severe in military electronics, including the semiconductors and communications equipment that M/A-Com makes for radars, navigations systems and missile-guidance devices. But communications industry analysts are less sanguine. **********"The market for military microwave equipment is shrinking, and there's excess capacity," said H. Elliot Rogers Jr. of Cowen & Company in New York. **********Mr. Rayfield said in an interview that M/A-Com was trying to increase its international sales of military electronics equipment. The company aims to increase sales of commercial communications equipment, Mr. Rayfield said, particularly to markets for cellular telephone, direct broadcast television and satellite communications hardware. **********Mr. Rayfield holds a bachelor of science degree from Pennsylvania State University and a master of science degree from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; 'Baby Bells' Are Accused of Overcharging
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/busin.body_text: **********The Consumer Federation of America, one of the nation's largest consumer groups, yesterday attacked the seven "Baby Bell" telephone companies for reportedly overcharging their customers by about $30 billion in the eight years since the January 1984 breakup of A.T.& T. **********The Consumer Federation said the regional Bell holding companies had overcharged telephone ratepayers and had used the money to invest in lightly regulated businesses that have made little or no profit for the seven holding companies. The group said the money would have been better used to reduce customer bills. **********The methodology underlying the Consumer Federation's charges is technical and arcane, and covers a wide variety of situations in 50 states. BellSouth, the largest Baby Bell, and the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, which represents state public service commissions, both declined to comment until they could study the group's charges and methodology. **********Next month is the 10th anniversary of the Justice Department consent decree that led to the 1984 breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The Consumer Federation's asccusations come when recent court decisions have freed the Baby Bells to provide information services, like stock quotations, over telephone lines, a service that had been banned by the 1984 accord. **********The Baby Bells' lightly regulated ventures include $2 billion in investments by Bell Atlantic and Ameritech in the New Zealand telephone company, and U S West's ownership of $1.6 billion worth of office buildings whose value has dropped sharply because of the recession. **********Along with the GTE Corporation, the Baby Bells provide the bulk of local telephone service in the country and encounter little or no competition in providing that service to business and residential customers. Their revenues exceeded $100 billion in 1990. **********The Consumer Federation, which claims 50 million members and represents 240 consumer groups, says that lightly regulated emerging businesses like information services would be open to pricing abuse. The group, based in Washington, is arguing that Congress should reimpose the ban on information services until the Baby Bells no longer enjoy a monopoly on local service. **********Mark N. Cooper, the Consumer Federation's director of research, said the Baby Bells had received about $12 billion in "excess returns" since 1985. The figure is based on the Consumer Federation's assumption that the Baby Bells, which were virtual monopolies before divestiture, should have continued to earn the same rate of return after divestiture. **********By the federation's calculations, Mr. Cooper said, the Baby Bells earned a nearly 1 percent higher return on equity, an important financial index, than all American manufacturers as a group. 'Excess Depreciation' **********Another $18 billion of the $30 billion in reported overcharges, Mr. Cooper said, comes from what he called "excess depreciation," which covers how a telephone company accounts for plant and equipment on its books. Such accelerated depreciation is intended to encourage a company to replace its outdated plant and equipment, by accounting for the depreciation as a higher cost of doing business. **********But Mr. Cooper argued that the Bells' depreciation practices simply meant that the companies could keep more of their customers' money, rather than reduce telephone bills.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/16/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 'A Big Jump' For Revlon's Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/16/busin.body_text: **********FOR the first time in five years, Revlon Inc. is making over the advertising for its flagship cosmetics products. The campaign, to make its debut next month, is a sharp departure from the elegant glamour of current ads. **********Models are dressed in denim and leather, for example, not evening gowns and designer dresses, and they are smiling and laughing, not pouting and staring. And in altering the way the company sells what its co-founder, Charles Revson, once called "hope in a jar," television commercials will feature the pop group Technotronic rapping a jingle with lyrics like "Yo! C'mon, move this, shake that body for me." **********"We're making a big jump here," Dick Tarlow, president of Tarlow Advertising, Revlon's in-house agency, said in an interview yesterday at his midtown Manhattan office. Joining Mr. Tarlow to provide a preview of the campaign before it is to be introduced on Monday were Jerry W. Levin, president of Revlon since April, and Michael Hammond, newly named president of Revlon North America, which combines the management of the Revlon and Almay brands. **********Revlon's reorientation is of interest not only because the company, owned since 1985 by Ronald O. Perelman, is a primary force in the nation's estimated $12 billion beauty business. Revlon has also been a leader in shaping trends in marketing imagery, from the model Dorian Leigh's dazzling Fire and Ice ads in the 50's -- "For you who love to flirt with fire . . . who dare to skate on thin ice" -- to the photographer Richard Avedon's formally stylized print ads of celebrities like Oprah Winfrey in the 80's. **********"Could we scare off a consumer by saying it's too much of a jump?" Mr. Tarlow asked rhetorically about the campaign's new direction. On the contrary, he replied, "I think we haven't kept up with our consumer," and the changes are intended to reflect the evolving tastes of Revlon's present customers. **********"I've felt in the last year we were not moving and the world seemed to be moving," he said. **********As evidence, the executives cited recent significant shifts in the ever-fickle world of fashion, like the woman who "wears a $30 pair of jeans with a $1,000 blazer," Mr. Hammond said. That new approach, mixing denim and diamonds, motorcycle jackets and mink, has been trumpeted by Vogue, the flagship of the fashion magazine field, under Anna Wintour, its editor in chief. **********To underscore the changes in the campaign, Mr. Tarlow has switched photographers, ending Revlon's longtime relationship with Mr. Avedon and replacing him with Patrick Demarchelier. Mr. Avedon "is one of the great photographers of the world," Mr. Tarlow said, "but for the type of advertising we wanted -- less formal, more casual, a relaxed attitude -- we think Patrick is better suited." **********In supporting the new campaign, which will retain a slogan introduced in 1986, "The most unforgettable women in the world wear Revlon," the company plans "significant and substantial increases in overall marketing budgets" next year, to exceed $150 million, Mr. Levin said. **********The increased spending, as well as the thematic revisions, are necessary, the executives said, given the intensely competitive nature of their industry. **********"Like most businesses, our competitors are not dummies," Mr. Tarlow said. "They keep getting better and better. If you don't get better, you'll get left behind." For instance, Cover Girl, which leads No. 2 Maybelline and third-ranked Revlon in the mass-market segment of the industry, has undergone a furious series of changes under its new owner, Procter & Gamble, including a new agency, Leo Burnett U.S.A., and a new campaign with the theme "Redefining beautiful." **********Mr. Levin, a former executive vice president of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, Revlon's corporate parent, scoffed at suggestions that the changes were intended to help dress up the company for sale. That speculation has intensified since the recent sale by Mr. Perelman of his Max Factor and Betrix cosmetics and fragrances companies to P.&G. **********"Revlon's not for sale," he said, adding that the only way to quash those rumors "is with the actions we are taking, to show we are in this for the long term."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.main_headline: Siemens Unit Gets Solar Energy Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Siemens Unit Gets Solar Energy Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.body_text: **********Siemens A.G., the German electronics concern, said one of its subsidiaries had won a contract to build the world's biggest solar energy system. The system, to be built in the Sahara, will supply the Cape Verde Islands, Gambia, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Mauritania and Senegal. **********The order to Siemens Solar G.m.b.H, worth a record 30 million marks ($20 million), will be financed by the European Community. The system has electricity production capacity of 640 kilowatts. Siemens Solar has about 25 percent of the world market for solar energy systems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/03/busin.main_headline: Fujisankei Names Chief Of Overseas Media Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/03/busin.print_headline: Fujisankei Names Chief Of Overseas Media Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Takashi Hoga has been named president of Fujisankei Communications International Inc., the overseas branch of Japan's largest media conglomerate, the Fujisankei Communications Group. It has directed Mr. Hoga, 56 years old, to develop Fujisankei International into an independent profit-making center, generating its own business. **********The Fujisankei Group gained notice in 1989 when it paid former President Ronald Ronald $2 million for a nine-day tour of Japan. A private corporation that includes 120 companies, the Fujusankei Group is the world's fourth-largest media organization, with an annual revenue of $5 billion. It owns the largest radio network in Japan, its largest television network and one of its leading newspaper groups. **********Based in New York, Fujisankei International produces international news and entertainment for Fujisankei's Fuji Television Network in Japan, as well as a daily morning news program in Japanese with English subtitles in the United States. The program, which was created by Mr. Hoga, can be seen in cities including Chicago, Atlanta, San Francisco, Los Angeles and New York, where the program, Supertime, is broadcast on WNYC, Channel 31, from 7 A.M. to 9 A.M. Monday through Friday. **********Fujisankei International, which markets itself as a link between American business and the Japanese consumer, produces a show similar to the Home Shopping Network that markets American and European products on Japanese television. Sales average $2 million a show. **********Mr. Hoga has spent 34 years with Fujisankei since graduating from Waseda University in Tokyo in 1957 with a degree in literature and drama. He joined the company's Nippon Broadcasting System radio network as a production assistant for drama serials. **********Three years later he became a production manager and a producer at the Fuji Television Network. Mr. Hoga established the network's London office and served as director of programming. In 1970 he began the first broadcast of American Major League Baseball in Japan. **********From 1979 to 1983 Mr. Hoga was general manager of the network's New York office, where he created the morning news program. He returned to Japan to head the sports division and created the annual Tokyo-New York Friendship International Marathon. In 1985 he became head of overseas development and in 1987 president of Fujisankei's Japan Executive Center, which organizes special events in Japan. **********Mr. Hoga and his wife, Hiromi, have two children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.main_headline: Excerpts From Report by Schwarzkopf on the Fighting in the Persian Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: MILITARY BRIEFING; Excerpts From Report by Schwarzkopf on the Fighting in the Persian Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from a briefing today in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of allied forces in the Persian Gulf, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: **********At 3 tomorrow morning Operation Desert Storm will complete its second week. Last week, at the end of the completion of its first week, Secretary Cheney and General Powell gave you their assessment of where we stood at that time. They have asked me to give you a similar assessment at the end of the second week. Let me start by covering the campaign objectives to date. . . . **********In our first phase what we wanted to do was disrupt leadership command and control; destroy centralized air defense command and control; attack combat aircraft in the air and on the ground to achieve air superiority; damage nuclear, biological and chemical storage and production capability; and commence attack on Republican Guards. **********Once we had that done we planned to go into a second phase, which was to destroy the air defense radars and missiles in the Kuwaiti theater of operation to achieve undisputed control of the air -- some people call that air supremacy. And finally, to sever supply lines in the Kuwaiti theater of operation. And once that phase was completed we planned then to isolate the Kuwaiti theater of operations, continue our attacks on the Republican Gaurds, and we have other objectives which I will not discuss further. **********In order to tell you, to measure our success to date, I think I will measure it against the objectives that I've just discussed. **********. . .          Leadership Objective **********Seventy-five percent of Iraq's command, control and communication facilities have been struck during our air campaign, and one-third of those are completely destroyed or inoperative. As a result, Saddam Hussein and the Iraqis have been forced to switch to backup systems, and those systems are far less effective and more easily targeted. . . . **********We have attacked air defense nerve systems striking 29 targets and more than 800 sorties. As a result, the Iraqis have abandoned centralized control of their air defense within Iraq and Kuwait, a very important point. This accounts, in part, for the very, very low attrition rate of coalition aircraft. **********. . . **********The Iraqi early warning system has completely failed, and their aircraft have been caught totally by surprise when we attacked them. . . . To date, based upon where their airplanes have been, we've attacked 38 airfields, and we've flown over 1,300 sorties against these airfields. The 38 airfields have all been struck at least once, and many of them have been struck at least four times. At least nine of them are nonoperational.  Destruction of Airfields **********But let me -- this is a very important point. We never had any intention to render all of the airfields inoperable. That was not our intention at all. Our intention is to render the air force ineffective. Now, there have been varying reports about how many of these airfields have been destroyed, and there have been varying reports about how much damage was done on the ground. I'll tell you, we can confirm at least 25 airfields destroyed on the -- airplanes destroyed on the ground. **********. . . **********Now, as a result of this type of operation, they decided to put all of their aircraft in hardened structures. They tried to hide their aircraft. Therefore, we commenced a systematic destruction of those hardened shelters. **********. . . **********The results to date of this type of attack is we have destroyed more than 70 of these hardened shelters and, quite frankly, the Iraqi aircraft are running out of places to hide. We now have reports that many of their smaller aircraft they have moved to roads and hidden them in residential areas that are close to the airfields because they know we're not attacking civilian targets. **********As you all well know, 89 of their aircraft -- and I should say these are their front-line F-1 Mirages, and their MIG-23 Fencers -- 89 of them have flown into Iran. The simple fact of the matter is, that now every time an Iraqi airplane takes off the ground, it's running away. As a result, Chuck Horner, my Centaf commander, has now claimed air supremacy. **********I'd like to talk a little bit about the isolation of the Kuwait theater of operations. One of the ways we do this is by destroying the bridges that lead into the Kuwaiti theater of operations area. . . . We have targeted a total of 36 bridges. Out of those 36 bridges, we have attacked 33 of them with over 790 sorties. Obviously, by shutting off the bridges, we shut off the supply lines that supply the forces in southern Iraq and in the Kuwaiti theater of operation. **********. . . **********This  [ refers to a map ]  is the the main supply route right here that comes down into Kuwait City. In the past, on any given day in the early part of the campaign you could look at that main supply route, at any given time you'd find about a thousand trucks on that M.S.R. Nowadays, whenever we look at it with any of our sophisticated systems the maximum we find is less than 100. That means about a 90 percent degradation in his supply rate. If you translate that over to what we know about his supply rate -- it takes him about 20,000 tons per day to support the troops in Kuwait -- we feel that we've reduced him to about 2,000 tons per day. **********We've got some anecdotal information that would also demonstrate that we're being very effective. We get many, many reports out of Kuwait that Iraqi soldiers are begging for food from Kuwaiti civilians; in many cases stealing it also. The enemy prisoners of war that we've taken have told us that they're receiving only one meal a day. That meal generally consists of a bowl of rice or a bowl of beans. And they have no water in which to bathe and, as a result, many of the enemy prisoners of war that we've taken are infested with body lice and many of them have open sores on their body. **********. . .          Republican Guards **********We're targeting the Republican Guards with about 300 sorties a day, 300 sorties a day. We're using very accurate bombing and even in bad weather, the many secondary explosions are confirming the fact that we're inflicting continuous damage on them. . . . **********Just from 12 noon yesterday until 3 this morning, that's a little bit more than a half a day, we have confirmation of 178 trucks destroyed, 55 artillery pieces destroyed or damaged, 52 tanks destroyed or damaged, and heavy secondary explosions from revetments and fires all over the area. **********We had one spectacular explosion n the 28th of January. Let me give you a reference. If, on a scale of 1 to 10, the eruption of a volcano registered 10, and the recent explosion at the Soviet rocket propellant plant would register a 9, the explosion, the explosion -- the secondary explosion we had the other day registered at 12. We now have confirmation that we destroyed over 125 storage revetments in the largest ammo storage area in the northern part of the Kuwaiti theater of operations. And needless to say, we are going to go back and visit it again to get anything else that happens to be left there. **********. . .          Battle of Khafji **********I'd like now to sort of report what's been going on last night and today. . . . Yesterday evening, We had an attack in that area by what was estimated to be an Iraqi mechanized battalion. They had crossed the border. It was engaged by a Marine light armored infantry battalion and tactical air. The result: 10 Iraqi tanks destroyed, four enemy prisoners of -- P.O.W. -- and the Marines lost two light armored vehicles. . . . Later on that same evening, another Iraqi battalion came across the border. These were again engaged by AC-130's  [ ground attack planes ]  and Cobras  [ attack helicopters ] . We destroyed four tanks and 13 vehicles. We have had reports that the Iraqis . . . did go into Al-Khafji. Of course, as you know, Al-Khafji has been abandoned and deserted since the very first day of Desert Storm, so there was no one there. . . . In the very early morning, Iraqi tanks and infantry again crossed the border. This time they were intially engaged by the Saudi Arabian National Guard and then Marine TAC-AIR engaged them and the enemy withdrew. Early this morning, 40 more Iraqi tanks crossed the border again at the same place they came across before. They were once again engaged by the Marine light attack -- light armored infantry. This time the result was 10 enemy tanks destroyed and they captured nine enemy prisoners of war. At the present time we have reports that the Saudis are moving forces into Al-Khafji to eject any Iraqi that may be in that area. . . . **********We have confirmed figures of 24 Iraqi tanks destroyed and 13 other vehicles destroyed. The Marines lost two light armored vehicles. Unfortunately, I'm very sad that I have to report to you that they lost 12 K.I.A.  [ killed in action ]  in that engagement and 2 W.I.A.  [ wounded in action ] . These are the first  [ American ]  casualties of any ground conflict -- the first K.I.A. of any ground conflict. **********. . .          Over 500,000 Troops **********One last announcement: Today, we went over 500,000 troops in the theater. **********Let me just finish up by giving a very brief closing assessment. By every measure -- by every measure -- our campaign plan is very much on schedule. Now, there's no way that I'm suggesting that the Iraqi Army is close to capitulation and going to give up. I think their actions last night have proven that to all of us. But I am quite confident that the direction we're heading in is going to lead to exactly the outcome that we all want to see. . . . **********QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS Killing of P.O.W. **********Q. General Schwarzkopf, the Iraqis claimed yesterday that a P.O.W. of unknown nationality was killed in one of the bombing raids on a place where he was being used as a human shield. What can you tell us about this human shield business and how you're dealing with that when it comes to bombing targets in Iraq? **********A. I'll tell you like I'd -- I'd really like to tell you how I'd like to deal with it, but I won't get into that. All I can say is that is a gross violation of the Geneva Convention. . . . The International Red Cross has inspected our P.O.W. camps. I challenge -- I challenge -- the Iraqis right now to do the same damned thing in their P.O.W. camps. And look at how they're treating our people and the other coalition P.O.W.'s. **********. . .          Flights to Iran **********Q. General, why do you think these 89 planes have flown into Iran? Can you give us a reason why you think that's happened? **********A. Well, you could really come up with three different -- I come up with three different scenarios. O.K., scenario No. 1 is, they are flying off to husband them for another day -- that's one of them -- O.K. -- husband their resources for another day. Scenario No. 2, you have that they are flying in there to launch an attack -- to launch an attack against us at some future date -- although the Iranians claim that that is not the case. And to date, I see no reason why we shouldn't believe the Iranians. Scenario No.3 is, we've had some reports that some of those people were defectors. So, it could be any one of those three things or a combination of all of them. But I think it's a very good sign that they don't feel confident where they are -- they've got to run someplace else to hide. And I'm delighted with that outcome. **********. . .          Numbers of Iraqis **********Q. General, could you tell us how many Iraqi troops and tanks have so far come across the border in these engagements down here? **********A. No, I really can't. I told you about a battalion, I think, in each case, and there's about 40 -- 40 tanks per battalion, and that -- and again, we're not in the business -- obviously, we're shooting, not counting, when they come across, so that's ---- Chances of Ground War **********Q. Given this entire presentation tonight about the effectiveness of the coalition air forces, is there a chance that there won't need to be a ground war? **********A. There's always a chance of that, but certainly, you know, I'm -- you know, as a military planner, you always plan for the worst case rather than the best . . . **********. . .          Oil Field Strikes **********Q. General, three days ago you gave us a briefing on the military effort to take out those manifolds at the Ahmadi oil fields, you talked about the air strikes that went in. A Washington newspaper ran a story saying that the Navy Seals were ready and willing to go in and do that job, but that you told them no. Is that true? **********A. Normally, in response to a questions like that, I would say that that report contains some inaccuracies. However, reverting to my old style, I would describe that report as bovine scatology,  [ laughter ]  better referred to by the troops as B.S. I don't know who that guy's source is, but he ought to get a new source, because his source is a liar. **********. . .          Nuclear Installations **********Q. You have mentioned that the -- you have destroyed all of the Iraqi nuclear reactor facilities. Do you have any information about the contamination? . . . **********A. Yes. We -- every target that we have attacked, be it nuclear, chemical or biological, we have very carefully selected the destruction means, okay, after a lot of advice from a lot of very, very prominent scientists. So we selected the destruction means in such a way that we absolutely almost to a 99.9 percent assurance have no contamination. You can -- I found one thing, none of the scientists will ever give you 100 percent assurance of anything -- but they will tell you that there are certain ways that you can limit that contamination. And everyone of those targets that we've attacked, we were very, very careful in the method of attack and the munitions we used to insure that we didn't have any contamination. **********. . .          Effects on Civilians **********Q. One for General Glosson, if you don't mind. Refugees coming into Jordan have been telling tales of convoys of civilian vehicles being strafed, people running in the desert and being strafed, bombs dropping everywhere. Given that frightened people exaggerate, nonetheless something must be happening. Can you tell us what you're hitting along that road and what happens if there are a lot of civilian vehicles in amongst what looks like a military target? **********BRIG. GEN. BUSTER GLOSSON. We're striking only military targets. Now, having said that, the Iraqi Government insists on storing Scuds in culverts and other things along the highway. . . . When we see those type of vehicles go into those facilities, we bomb them. We make every attempt to minimize any possibility of civilian casualties. And that's the best answer I can give you. **********Q. General, along those same lines, some of the refugees and Red Cross workers have brought back fragments of bombs, identified as cluster bombs, CBU. Are you using cluster bombs along that highway? And if so, how do you reconcile that with your efforts to minimize civilian casualties along this -- particularly this refugee route? **********GLOSSON. . . . Yes, we use the cluster munition to cover a wider area when the military situation dictates that. **********SCHWARZKOPF. Let me step in here. We have never said that there won't be any civilian casualties. What we have said is, the difference between us and the Iraqis is we are not deliberately targeting civilians, and that's the difference. There are going to be casualties. Unfortunately, that's what happens when you have a war. But we are certainly not deliberating targeting civilians. We never have and we have no intention of doing it in the future. And our enemy certainly is, and I hope that's obvious to everybody in this room since you've been under Scud attack. **********. . .          Political Factors **********Q. If Saddam Hussein were to have a briefing tonight in Baghdad and discuss two weeks of war, he would probably say that we -- that is, the coalition forces -- have thrown the best at him that they could. And still, he is able to launch an offensive. Now, as much as a distortion that may be, how much in your own thinking, when you're going in through his mental process, is the political dimension of this war a factor, the fact that it is going on, that the Arab peoples are looking at it, and that you have a political constraint as well as other constraints to end the war? **********A. This is strictly Norm Schwarzkopf's opinion now, all right? But it's an opinion based upon discussions with a lot of friends throughout the gulf area, some of whom happen to be very pro-Saddam Hussein. To date, Saddam Hussein has lied to them. He told them that Tel Aviv was a crematorium. We all know that's not true. To date, he has told them that he has shot down 170 American and coalition aircraft. Everybody knows that's not true. **********He has announced that he's going to do all sorts of other wonderful things. The other day he said a prayer for the dead, okay, about -- saying because Riyadh was going to be wiped out that night. That did not happen, okay? He has lied consistently about us damaging religious places. A lot of people know that that is not true. So, I think that one of the things that's happened out there is a lot of people who were supporters of Saddam Hussein, at least those who -- I'm not talking about the mob in the street because the mob in the street isn't going to change their opinion. **********But I'm talking about people who intellectually or at least reasonably thought that he was supporting a cause, have found that he is not delivering on his promises, and that's probably doing him some harm. And I think that eventually, they're going to find the same thing about this particular attack. O.K. With regard to Saddam Hussein saying that he has met the best that the coalition has to offer, I would only say, the best is yet to come. Who Owns the Sky? **********General Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, asserted on Jan. 23 that allied air forces had obtained air superiority over Iraq and Kuwait, and noted that he had helped write the Joint Chief's definition of this term when he was a captain. **********Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of allied forces in the Persian Gulf, said yesterday that his commander of Air Force operations in the region had asserted that the allies had achieved air supremacy over Iraq and Kuwait. **********The Air Force's manual on basic aerospace doctrine says air superiority exists when only one side in a conflict is able to carry out effective combat missions in its enemy's airspace. Air supremacy is defined by the manual as occurring when the enemy is also incapable of interfering effectively with those combat missions at any time or in any place.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/world.main_headline: Kuwait Will Begin Trying Collaboration Suspects
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Kuwait Will Begin Trying Collaboration Suspects
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/world.body_text: **********The first trials of people accused of collaborating with Iraqi forces during the seven-month occupation of Kuwait are to begin on Saturday. **********But defense lawyers claim that many of the collaboration charges have been trumped up by the Government, and that in many cases, confessions have been extracted by torture. Altogether 628 people are being held on collaboration charges, and all of them face a possible death penalty. **********Kuwaitis are riveted by these cases because the definition of collaboration appears in many cases to be vague. Some Kuwaitis who remained here during the occupation say they feel that they have been labeled quasi-collaborators by those outside the country simply for not fleeing. **********"People hint that we must have cooperated with the Iraqis," a Kuwaiti businessman said today. "Otherwise how could we have survived all this time? This is very serious and could mean big problems in the future." Will Trials Be Open? **********Kuwaiti defense lawyers say that if the trials are unfair or the rights of the accused are limited, they will refuse en masse to take part in the trials. It is unclear whether the trials are to be held in secret or will be open to the public and the press. **********Many of those who are to stand trial are Palestinians, a people subjected to continuing vengeance from Kuwaitis, who feel that the Iraqi invaders were aided by support from the many Palestinians here. Some of those charged, however, are Kuwaitis. **********Yasir Arafat's vociferous support for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq during the occupation did much to sour Kuwaitis on the Palestine Liberation Organization's leader and the Palestinian cause, a cause they supported with billions of dollars over the years. Although many of the 150,000 Palestinians still in Kuwait were born here, it is widely believed that the Government intends to expel them from the country to join the 170,000 Palestinians who fled and are now barred from returning. **********The trials, which have been promised and postponed repeatedly, may offer the first real look at the extent of collaboration by those who remained during the occupation, or, in the view of many defense lawyers, could turn into a ritual of show trials and retribution. **********The Kuwaiti Government has been reluctant to discuss the subject of the trials or the precise charges against those imprisoned for collaboration. Even the Government-controlled newspaper, The New Dawn, has not mentioned them. **********Amad al-Saif, one of the country's leading defense lawyers, represents about a dozen of those who are to stand trial. He said that torture of those accused was widespread and that many of the cases had been built on the flimsy evidence. **********"A lot have been tortured in recent weeks," he said. "The people I saw were tortured. They were hit by sticks; some of them had electric power used on them." **********As for the charges of collaboration, he was contemptuous. "Some of the cases are very silly," he said. "If you sell an Iraqi a car, you will be a collaborator." **********To be sure, there are cases that suggest collaboration, Mr. Saif said. In particular, he said, many people are accused of telling the Iraqis who was in the police or army, or with providing the Iraqi secret police with information about people they were hunting. **********Although these charges are serious, he said, he has yet to see any evidence supporting them. "We want to see the evidence that this talk is true," he said. "Until now, I have not seen any evidence." Concern About Fairness **********Kuwait's Deputy Minister of Justice, Abdul Aziz al-Dakheel, said there was no doubt about the guilt of those charged. "Some of these prisoners gave information to the Iraqis to help them enter Kuwait," he said. **********Because of recurring charges of abuses against the country's Palestinian residents, the Government is deeply concerned about the appearance of fairness at the trials, an official at the American Embassy said. **********Najeeb al-Waqyan, another prominent lawyer here, said he was not convinced that the trials could be conducted fairly. **********"They are facing a lot of problems in the prosecution," he said. "Now the military has to present evidence to prosecute. They don't know how to do this. They are in a rush to do this. It's never happened in Kuwait like this. It worries me that it will be a military court. I never in my life dealt with martial law. I worry quite a bit." **********Kuwait is still under martial law, and the trials will be held before a panel composed of civilian and military judges. Under martial law, Mr. Waqyan said, there is no appeal from the court's decision. If a death penalty is imposed, however, it must be confirmed by the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. Since he assumed power, Sheik Jaber has never confirmed a death penalty, the American Embassy says.  Hope for Defense Leeway **********Mr. Waqyan said he hoped that defense lawyers would be given greater latitude because no appeals are permitted. **********"Because there is just one court, I expect they have to give more rights to the lawyers, more rights to the defendents," he said. "But I don't know. I have to wait for the first trial. If it is not like this, we will withdraw. All the lawyers will withdraw if there is a kangaroo court." **********Kuwait's Deputy Attorney General, Hamid al-Othman, acknowledged that in the days immediately after the liberation of Kuwait, some prisoners who had just been arrested might have been tortured, but he said this had ceased. **********"I wish to believe that what you have heard is not true," he said. "The Kuwaiti people are people who are nonviolent. There may have been some cases that may have happened because of inner feelings. Those cases were very few. The Kuwaiti people have returned to what they were."
