https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/24/world.print_headline: Cause for Alarm?; The Peace Treaty Brings the Khmer Rouge Into Government, and That Frightens Many
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/24/world.body_text: **********The Khmer Rouge, which was responsible for the deaths of more than one million Cambodians in its genocidal four-year reign in the 1970's, is granted a degree of power and legitimacy under the United Nations peace treaty signed today that many diplomats, and certainly many Cambodians, find frightening. **********The peace treaty, signed in Paris by 19 countries, including the United States, allows the Khmer Rouge to share power in a coalition government that is scheduled to convene next month in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital. **********The United Nations treaty makes no provision for punishment of Pol Pot, the secretive Khmer Rouge leader, and his murderous deputies. Nor does it require the complete disarmament of Khmer Rouge guerrillas, who remain scattered in large numbers throughout the Cambodian countryside. Nor does it force the Khmer Rouge to abandon its goal of one day returning to absolute power in Cambodia. **********After listening to news reports today about the signing ceremony in Paris, a senior Western diplomat in Bangkok, the main listening post for Cambodia in that nation's long civil war, said, "I find myself a little queasy." **********"We all assume that Pol Pot and his henchmen will not find their way back to power," he said. "But we have no guarantee of that, none at all." **********Indeed, over the next several weeks, many of the same Khmer Rouge leaders whose savagery led to the execution or starvation of so many Cambodians in a reign of terror more than a decade ago will return to Phnom Penh to join, once again, in running the nation. Pol Pot Believed Alive **********Diplomats and intelligence officials say Pol Pot, whose plans for a Marxist, racially pure Cambodian society were conceived while he was a student in Paris in the 1950's, is still alive, hiding out, at least until recently, at a jungle camp in northern Thailand, near the Cambodian border. **********While Pol Pot has not been in seen in public for more than a decade, he is still widely believed to control the Khmer Rouge. **********Pol Pot has long been tolerated by the Thai Government, which has seen the Khmer Rouge, the largest and best armed of the guerrilla forces in the civil war, as a useful counterweight to Vietnam and the Vietnamese-installed Government in Phnom Penh. The Vietnamese Army ousted the Khmer Rouge in an invasion in 1978. **********With protection in recent years from the Thais and heavy armament and diplomatic support from China, its principal backer, the Khmer Rouge emerged as an indispensible participant in the negotiations that ended today with the signing of the peace treaty. 'Khmer Rouge 'Had to Be Part' **********"No matter how distasteful it is to do business with the Khmer Rouge, you cannot ignore the fact that there are 40,000 well-armed Khmer Rouge troops in Cambodia and Thailand," a European diplomat said. "Even if you managed to cut off the Khmer Rouge arms supply entirely, their guns will not rust overnight. They had to be part of the peace negotiations." **********Diplomats say the United States and other Western powers supporting the peace treaty are hopeful that China and Vietnam, which recently renewed diplomatic and trade ties after years of hostility, will forestall any attempt by the Khmer Rouge to reassert itself on the battlefield. **********The Bush Administration has said it is seeking to remove Vietnamese influence over Cambodia and allow the Cambodian people to select their own form of government, despite the risk of a return to power by the Khmer Rouge. **********Under the peace accord, foreign arms suppliers have agreed to cut off weapons shipments to the Khmer Rouge and to the two major non-Communist rebel factions involved in the peace settlement: the followers of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the one-time King of Cambodia, and the National Liberation Front of former Prime Minister Son Sann. **********The United States supplied tens of millions of dollars in aid to the two non-Communist factions in the civil war, although there were repeated assertions by human rights organizations and others that American aid ended up in the hands of the Khmer Rouge. **********Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France said this week that it would have been impossible to exclude the Khmer Rouge from the peace negotiations, whatever its reputation as an international pariah. **********"An accord without them would have meant a rapid resumption of fighting," he said. "We thought it more intelligent to bring them to effective disarmament." **********Yet diplomats tracking the peace process say they fear that the Khmer Rouge will circumvent the treaty's disarmament provisions -- all sides are required to reduce their arms and troop strength by 70 percent -- by hiding weapons and soldiers in remote jungle areas under its authority, far from the view of United Nations peacekeeping troops that are expected to enter Cambodia this year. **********The Khmer Rouge will also retain the option of buying weapons on the black market. Because it controls areas of Cambodia rich in gems and timber, the Khmer Rouge has few concerns about money; its annual revenues are estimated to top $80 million a year. **********For their part, Khmer Rouge officials describe as misplaced international concern any idea that they might consider staging a military takeover of Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge, they suggest, has hopes instead of returning to power without bloodshed, through the free elections called for under the United Nations plan. **********In a secret 1988 speech to colleagues that has circulated in Bangkok, Pol Pot outlined a strategy in which the Khmer Rouge would be restored to power through political organization -- winning over Cambodians one by one with Khmer Rouge-sponsored public works projects and through an image-building public relations campaign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/busin.main_headline: Fox Studio Said to Get $80 Million From Swiss
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Fox Studio Said to Get $80 Million From Swiss
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/busin.body_text: **********A Swiss insurance company has agreed to invest $80 million in eight future films to be produced by the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, the movie company, according to several executives close to the negotiations. **********A Fox executive declined to comment yesterday, but several movie industry executives said the agreement was signed last week. They added that the Swiss company, which was not identified, would have a one-third interest in each film. **********The agreement is noteworthy because until recently the Japanese had been the most visible and aggressive investors in the American motion-picture industry. Their presence has come from buying companies, as in the Sony Corporation's acquisition of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. and Matsushita's takeover of MCA Inc., or from making passive investments, as a group of Japanese institutional investors and banks did by putting $600 million in film production at the Walt Disney Company.  Sony Move Brings Criticism **********But the Sony investment, for example, attracted criticism in the United States and in Japan, and one movie industry executive suggested that the experience might have left other potential Japanese investors skeptical and cautious about additional stakes in American entertainment companies, at least for a while. **********Although details of the Swiss deal were not made public, a person with knowledge of the arrangement at Fox, which is owned by the News Corporation, said that the Swiss insurer would put $80 million toward the production and advertising of eight consecutive Fox films. **********After the films are released, Fox would recoup any costs not covered by the investment and would take a distribution fee, the person said. Then Fox and the outside investor would each try to recoup their direct investments and share in profits on a pro-rata basis.  Others Are Interested **********The Swiss are not the only Europeans interested in Hollywood investments.Canal Plus, the French pay-television company, continues to invest in American films, and Bertelsmann, the German publishing house that already owns RCA Records and Doubleday, the book publisher, has had preliminary talks with Fox, said several executives familiar with the discussions. **********But in the case of Bertelsmann, an executive with knowledge of the discussions said yesterday that the German concern appeared to be interested in the investment as a strategic business decision, rather than a passive one like the Swiss-Fox deal. **********A number of the movie companies have recently sought outside investors to help reduce their risk. Fox, for example, has an annual budget of about $400 million. While the Swiss are now Fox's largest single outside investor, the studio has said that it would be willing to make additional deals with other outsiders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.main_headline: Gulf Concession That Wasn't: U.S. Moves to Quell a Furor
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: WASHINGTON; Gulf Concession That Wasn't: U.S. Moves to Quell a Furor
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.body_text: **********The Bush Administration scrambled today to contain political damage from a Soviet-American communique that embarrassed Mr. Bush with some of his allies and brought simmering conflicts between the White House and State Department into the open. **********The statement about the war in the Persian Gulf -- drafted at the last minute on Tuesday night and, officials said, released without the President's knowledge -- was interpreted by some American allies as an offer of a cease-fire to Iraq and a link between the Persian Gulf and the Palestinian dispute. **********The diplomatic squall over that part of the communique overshadowed what Administration officials said was its real purpose: to keep the Soviet Union firmly in the anti-Iraq alliance by giving Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh a clear statement that the United States was not seeking to destroy Iraq, and to reassure President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that Moscow would be part of the postwar diplomacy in the Middle East. Inquiries From Allies **********As American officials fielded inquiries from Israel, France, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and other countries, State Department and White House officials conceded that the communique was badly worded and not adroitly handled by the State Department, which simply posted it in the press room in the early evening and presumed it would draw little notice. But instead Mr. Bessmertnykh went before television cameras in the State Department lobby and praised the statement as an important event. **********Beginning late Tuesday night, the White House went to extraordinary lengths to put political distance between Mr. Bush and the document, which marked an unusual break in the careful discipline the Administration has exercised on public statements about the gulf. **********Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, did not know of the statement until he was asked about it by a reporter early Tuesday night. **********He said Mr. Scowcroft then gave it to Mr. Bush, who read it for the first time in his limousine en route to the Capitol, where he delivered a State of the Union Address that found itself overshadowed on some television networks by what was supposed to be a routine statement by two foreign ministers. **********In the document, Mr. Baker and Mr. Bessmertnykh said: "The two ministers continue to believe that a cessation of hostilities is possible if Iraq would make an unequivocal commitment to withdraw from Kuwait. They also believe that such a commitment must be backed by immediate, concrete steps leading to full compliance with the Security Council resolutions." **********The communique also said the Soviet Union and the United States would work with the countries of the Middle East after the war to resolve other regional disputes, including the Palestinian issue. **********In many ways, this echoed previous American positions. But the first section was widely interpreted as softening Mr. Bush's vow that there will be "no pause for negotiations" in the war. The second was seen in some circles as establishing the "linkage" between Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait and the Palestinian question that Mr. Bush has sought to avoid. **********In Israel today, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir protested that "a political act that involves us, our fate, our future, was taken without consulting us, without even telling us beforehand." **********Mr. Bush, asked by reporters if he was angry with Mr. Baker, his closest friend and adviser, laughed and said, "There are no differences there." **********White House officials, who have long grumbled about the independence of the State Department, sought to put the best public face on the political squall. They said the United States had satisfied its allies that the statement was being misinterpreted and that it was not a change in policy. They said such things are not normally cleared with the White House. **********But White House officials privately complained about the matter. **********An official said the statement was drafted to "throw Bessmertnykh something to show that he's in a give-and-take relationship with Baker, something he can take home to show that he made the Americans state that we're not out to destroy Iraq, which has become a big issue for the Soviets." **********Another official said Mr. Baker was trying to establish with Mr. Bessmertnykh the kind of relationship he had with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who resigned last month. **********Officials said the communique was not circulated through the State Department's Soviet and Middle East desk officers, career officials who generally are not part of top-level decision making under Mr. Baker. **********Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said Mr. Baker had intended simply to post the statement and was surprised when Mr. Bessmertnykh read it to reporters. "We did not, at all candor, view this as any big deal," she said today. **********As a result, the State Department did not activate the public relations machinery normally used for an important Soviet-American announcement. That left senior White House and State Department officials frantically telephoning reporters late Tuesday to try to dampen publicity on the communique. **********"The sad fact," said one exasperated official today, "is that it really doesn't matter any more what's in the communique or whether it meant a change in policy. This thing has a life of its own. Everyone's saying two plus two makes five and no one believes you if you stand there screaming 'No, it's four! It's four!' " **********The Administration was as embarrassed by positive comments as well as by the criticism. A Western diplomat said that during a meeting today with Mr. Baker, the French Ambassador, Jacques Andreani, said that France was pleased with the communique.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/07/busin.body_text: **********The USX Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America will reopen negotiations today that could determine whether the nation's largest steelmaker can retain the edge in cheaper labor costs it has enjoyed over its rivals for two years. **********USX's contract with 18,000 steelworkers expires at the end of this month. Talks between management and the steelworkers on a new four-year contract broke down six weeks ago. Industry analysts and experts say it is too soon to tell if USX, which suffered through a six-month shutdown four years ago, will have another strike on its hands. **********"It would make no sense for the situation to result in a strike," said Ben Fischer, director of labor studies at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh. "But sense does not always govern these situations, and it is certainly a possibility." **********While many experts contend that the economy has declined too deeply for either side to accept a strike, some USX customers, preparing for the worst, are already lining up other suppliers, and USX has itself been building up inventories to keep customers in steel during a strike. **********Both sides are still far apart on all basic issues. The steelworkers are pushing for job protection for employees in case USX's steel business is sold or spun off as some shareholders hope and as management has said it will consider doing. The union also wants wage and benefit increases comparable to the 5 to 10 percent raises provided in 1989 by the five other leading steelmakers to employees over the life of their contracts. Harsher Climate Today **********These companies negotiated contracts when the market for steel was healthier. Because of the harsher conditions now, USX is proposing a more modest increase, tied to improvements in quality. Some analysts doubt that USX will succeed in selling its proposal to workers because the steelmaker is still faring better than many competitors. **********A strike would delight the company's besieged rivals. Steel industry operating profits plunged by half, to $890 million, in the first nine months of 1990 over the similar period of 1989. Steel prices have tumbled nearly 10 percent in the last year as demand has fallen for steel for automobiles and appliances. Contingency Plans **********A strike at USX would tighten supplies, cause steel prices to climb and give other steelmakers a chance to win customers from USX. **********Thomas J. Usher, who has been president of the company's steel division since September, said he was optimistic about reaching an agreement, although "neither side has changed their basic objectives." But he said the company has "a lot of different contingency plans" if a strike occurs. **********Still, a few customers say they have begun looking elsewhere for steel to keep a steady, uninterrupted supply. "We aren't abandoning USX altogether so far," said the purchasing manager of a large Midwestern steel service center. "But we have started increasing our purchases from LTV and others."  Pressure to Spin Off Steel **********The contract talks come at a time when USX is in transition. Steel, the company's main business just 10 years ago, now accounts for less than a third of its sales. And USX's largest investor, Carl C. Icahn, is again prodding the company to separate the steel operations from USX's vast energy holdings. **********Mr. Icahn, who holds 13.3 percent of USX's shares and last year waged an unsuccessful proxy battle on a resolution to spin off or sell the steel business, disclosed two months ago that he had formed a new shareholder committee to press again to unload the steel business. **********There are other reasons why the union is pushing for job protection. Union officials pointed out that the company conducted talks last year with British Steel P.L.C. about a possible acquisition of the steel business. USX also announced last fall that it was transferring the steel operation to a wholly owned subsidiary, which industry analysts saw as a move by the company to prepare the steel business for a sale.  Union Concessions **********The unions are also seeking to eliminate the Pittsburgh-based steelmaker's labor-cost advantage in an era in which $1 or $2 an hour in operating costs can mean the difference between profit and loss. USX spends $22.83 on labor to produce a ton of steel, compared with the $24.50 spent by the second-lowest-cost producer, the Inland Steel Corporation, and $26.85 by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest producer. **********The union contends that its workers made huge sacrifices during the money-losing years of the early 1980's, when they agreed to concessions that they say diminished their wages and benefits by 9 percent in 1983 and by an additional 8 percent in 1987. The union regained some of those wages under the 1987 agreement, but workers are still at roughly their 1982 pay level. **********"At this point we are apart on wages, benefits, health insurance for retirees, and, of course, the question of successorship," said Richard F. Fontana, a spokesman for the Pittsburgh-based union. "The question of protecting jobs if the steel company changes ownership is particularly important because of what is going on with Carl Icahn."  An Industry in Recession **********Mr. Fontana is also critical of the company's plan to link pay increases to improved quality, arguing that "the requirements for a payout are so difficult to achieve that we believe that it would be unlikely that a payout would be possible." **********Many analysts say that the company will press hard to maintain its labor-cost advantage. "It is a difficult time for USX to match the other pay levels because the industry is in a recession," said John Jacobson, a steel analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. **********Still, others contend that the company's steel business will fare better than most because USX derives more of its business than its major rivals from the pipe and tubular steel market, which is holding firm because of sales to the oil industry. "In profitability, USX has led the pack," said Christopher Plummer, an analyst with the WEFA Group, a market research firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. **********That will make it hard for USX to depict itself in the contract talks as having more formidable problems than its competitors. "They have a broader market scope because they are more tied to oil, energy and capital goods, instead of solely relying on the automotive market," Mr. Plummer said. "And USX has a completely funded pension plan, which most of the others do not. I think we will find that these will be difficult negotiations." Steel Labor Costs Per ton, as of Jan. 1, 1991 Bethlehem Steel $26.85 LTV Steel $26.60 National Steel $25.72 Armco $24.70 Inland Steel $24.50 USX $22.83 Source: The WEFA Group

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/23/busin.body_text: **********The assets of the nation's 555 money market mutual funds increased by $4.98 billion, to $466.34 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 204 institutional funds increased by $1.85 billion, to $139.35 billion. The assets of the 260 general-purpose funds were up by $2.04 billion, to $178.26 billion. The 91 broker-dealer funds rose $1.09 billion, to $148.72 billion, the institute said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/20/busin.print_headline: Patents; An Electric Blanket for Premature Babies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/20/busin.body_text: **********William C. McCormack, a retired pediatrician in Ames, Iowa, this week patented an electrical blanket for premature infants. **********Although premature babies are kept in incubators, they can become cold when nurses change intravenous tubes or other attachments. **********To minimize that risk, a part of Dr. McCormack's blanket is divided into strips that can be peeled back separately. Nurses needing to change something on the baby would need only to uncover that particular part of the body. **********Dr. McCormack received patent 5,008,515.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; J. C. Penney Prices A 30-Year Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.body_text: **********The J. C. Penney Company priced $250 million in 30-year notes yesterday, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. **********The notes have a 9.75 percent coupon and are priced at 99.397, to yield 9.812 percent, or about 130 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. **********The long issue, which is noncallable for 10 years, features 5 percent sinking fund payments that begin in the 11th year. In addition, the company has the option of doubling the amount of debt it retires in any given year, thus giving the notes an average maximum life of 20.5 years and an average minimum life of 15.5 years. **********Moody's rates the issue A-2, while S.& P. rates it A+.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/03/world.main_headline: The Yugoslavia Blowup: The Center Comes Apart
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/03/world.print_headline: CONFLICT IN YUGOSLAVIA; The Yugoslavia Blowup: The Center Comes Apart
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/03/world.body_text: **********One week into Yugoslavia's civil strife, the authority of the central Government is in shreds. **********With the collapse of the center, Serbia, the largest and most populous of the Yugoslav republics and until now the country's binding agent, is experiencing a dramatic surge of nationalism. **********So swift has been the collapse of the federal Government's authority that when the head of the country's collective presidency was installed on Monday morning it was at the urging of three visiting foreign ministers from other European countries. **********Tonight, angry demonstrators burst into the Parliament of Serbia while others outside, waving the Serbian flag, chanted "Serbia has arisen!" and demanded a Serbian army to answer the challenge from secessionist Slovenia.  For Its Own Defense **********The implication was that with reports of fighting from Slovenia and Croatia, and the federal army heeding no one in the Government but following instead the dictates of self-preservation, Serbia must be made capable of defending itself. **********To be sure, shredded remains of the central authority linger. Today, the newly installed federal President, the Croatian lawyer Stipe Mesic, a 57-year-old former Communist who was jailed by Tito in 1971 in a crackdown on Croatian nationalism, was in Slovenia seeking to negotiate a cease-fire. But Mr. Mesic, who is detested by the army leadership, was virtually helpless to control affairs. **********The tank battles in Slovenia, the bombing of the Slovenian capital, Ljubljana, the failure of an earlier truce hammered out by European Community mediators, all underscored that the road to any kind of negotiation to recast the bonds linking the country's six republics and two autonomous regions would be long and arduous. **********Increasingly, Yugoslavs have begun to talk of the horrifying possibility of civil war, in a land that lost one-tenth of its population, or 1.7 million people, in World War II. **********A month ago, the Government would have rejected any effort by the outside world to mediate an end to Yugoslavia's internal strife as interference in the country's internal affairs. **********But now the leaders of the central Government and several key republics are publicly asking the European Community and the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to send help. **********Like their neighbors in Eastern Europe, the peoples of Yugoslavia in free elections have been casting off the shackles of decades of Communist rule. But the successors to the Communists here are mostly former Communists themselves, like Slovenia's President, Milan Kucan, and the Croatian leader, Franjo Tudjman, who evoke old national aspirations as a means of overcoming the economic rot and social dislocation that are the heritage of Communism. **********Lamenting the country's headlong slide into violence, the Belgrade daily Borba wrote today: "We wanted a return to Europe, and instead we went back to our dukedoms and principalities. **********"We wanted modern leaders, freed of Bolshevism and careerism, and we elected instead leaders who bicker, stubborn people, little dictators, surrounded by sychophants." **********Were the tensions restricted to Slovenia and Croatia, Yugoslavia's problems with breakaway republics might be more manageable. But Serbs, the largest national group with 9.3 million people, increasingly perceive the killing in Slovenia as a useless sacrifice of Serbian sons, the largest bloc in an army that also includes Slovenes, Croats, Albanians and Montenegrins, in defense of increasingly meaningless Yugoslav borders.  Mothers in Protest **********Today, mothers of soldiers and other women marched in front of the old Hotel Moskva in downtown Belgrade with banners calling for heads to roll in the political leadership and the army. **********Belgrade television broadcast interviews with 18- and 19-year-old conscripts returning from Slovenian imprisonment with stories of humiliation and defeat. Tearful mothers poured out the stories of their lost sons. **********Partly, the Serbian anger is directed at the national leadership. Protesters outside Parliament waved banners calling Ante Markovic, the Croatian politician who is the federal Prime Minister, a "betrayer of our children." Others demanded the resignation of the Defense Minister, Gen. Veljko Kadijevic. **********More ominously, the demonstrators demanded a Serbian army, to defend not only Serbs in their republic but also the scattered groups of Serbs who live in other republics, most notably the 600,000 in Croatia. It is perhaps there that the nervousness is greatest. Serbs cannot forget that in 1941 when Croatia last obtained independence, as a Nazi puppet state, 500,000 Serbs were slaughtered.  Agreement on Self-Defense **********Last week the Serbian communities in Croatia and neighboring Bosnia pledged to work together not only in cultural matters and education, but also in their self-defense. **********Increasingly, too, the Serbian anger is a threat to the regional leader, Slobodan Milosevic, a former Communist who rode a wave of Serbian nationalism in recent years to enable his party, now renamed the Socialist Party, to emerge victorious in free elections. **********But tonight, intermingled with calls for a Serbian army to defend against Slovenia and Croatia to the north, were shouts denouncing Mr. Milosevic's "red gang" and cries of "Slobo, get lost!" **********In the end, Mr. Milosevic may be the main victim of the conflict in Slovenia, and there is irony in this, since it was his uncompromising policies that set in motion the developments leading to the present crisis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.main_headline: I.B.M. Gears Up for Battle Over Mainframe Disk Drives
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.print_headline: I.B.M. Gears Up for Battle Over Mainframe Disk Drives
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/25/busin.body_text: **********Here in what may be the biggest factory building west of the Mississippi River, the world's largest computer maker is fighting to protect its most profitable line of business. In a dust-free room clean enough to make computer chips, the International Business Machines Corporation assembles disk drives for its most powerful mainframe computers, turning out one drive every five minutes of every hour, five days a week. **********But now, those file-drawer-sized storage systems, which I.B.M. sells separately or packaged with mainframes, are at risk of becoming a victim to the same force that has stalled the company's mainframe business. Just as the microprocessor chip has made possible ever-more powerful and inexpensive desktop computers and work stations, new palm-sized disk drives are opening up similar possibilities in the storage segment of the business. **********Chained together by the dozens, or even by the hundreds, these drives, known by the acronym RAID, for redundant arrays of inexpensive disks, are faster, more reliable and have more storage capacity than I.B.M.'s systems. And because they can be manufactured in bigger quantities, they cost much less. The technology is largely unproven, yet more than 50 companies are rushing to develop it for mainframe computers. (Offered by such companies as Dell Computer Corporation and Compaq Computer Corporation, RAID is already available for personal computer networks.) **********But unseating I.B.M. could be a chore. The company has had the $5.16 billion mainframe drive market, which accounts for almost 40 percent of all drives, largely to itself for 35 years. Today, it controls 78 percent of the business. **********And it is looking to strengthen its position. It recently made disk drives a top priority by dramatically picking up its pace of product introductions at both the high end of the business, supplying mainframes, and the low end, for personal computers -- a newer business for I.B.M. **********The low end offers faster growth than the high end, which is still growing at a brisk 27 to 30 percent a year, the company reports. Yet the high end is far more lucrative, producing what analysts say are gross margins in excess of 60 percent. I.B.M. does not break out its profits or sales for disk drives. **********Even so, analysts say that I.B.M. must decide whether it will try to stretch its large disks for another generation or rapidly introduce an array product of its own, perhaps as early as 1993. In fact, I.B.M., determined not to be blindsided by this new technology the way it was taken by surprise by the popularity of reduced instruction set chip (RISC) computing for work stations, started its own RAID project. "I.B.M. will eventually counterattack, but I.B.M. is big and bigness is slowness," said James Porter, president of Disk/Trend, a Mountain View, Calif., market research firm. **********Among the computer companies gambling on RAID for mainframes, Storage Technology Inc. of Louisville, Colo., is the farthest along. It plans to introduce its first disk array product in January. "We made a conscious decision to skip one generation of disk technology while we came out with this new generation," said Ryal Poppa, Storage Technology's chairman. "We intend to maintain a two-year lead." **********Storage Technology's array, which is already widely known in the industry by the code name "Iceberg," will blend complex electronics and software with hundreds of 5.25-inch drives made by the Hewlett Packard Corporation. It will target the most profitable segment of the mainframe disk drive business: applications, known as "mission critical,"that cannot tolerate any down time or a single failure. (Because a RAID, unlike conventional drive technology, spreads information over many disks, it has a built-in backup should one disk fail.) Storage Technology says it will give customers a guarantee against losing data because of equipment failure. **********Its focus on fault tolerance has prompted some analysts and rivals to say the company is just skimming the cream. But Storage Technology says the segment is a natural extension of its leading tape backup business, which provides duplicates of a company's data on tapes. And early reports from a pool of several thousand potential buyers that have looked at Iceberg are positive. **********Iceberg's high visibility has put I.B.M. on the defensive. The computer maker has held briefings with customers, analysts and the press on its own high-end strategy. **********"The question is: When is I.B.M. going to be ready to compete with Iceberg?" Mr. Porter said. **********That is what Hitachi Data Systems wonders. Hitachi, I.B.M.'s closest competitor in the mainframe disk business, with 10.7 percent of the market, is the only compatible disk maker shipping drives that match I.B.M.'s top-of-the-line models. Although Hitachi says it is preparing its own disk array technology, it is waiting until I.B.M. sets the standard for RAID before entering the market with its own version. **********"We're well positioned to respond to any new product from I.B.M. quickly," said Gary Holtwick, vice president for peripherals at the Santa Clara, Calif.-based disk maker. **********By itself, new technology is unlikely to strip I.B.M. of its prowess in the disk drive business. But to underscore its determination to hold onto its dominance, I.B.M. next month plans to celebrate the 35th anniversary of the Winchester disk drive, which the company invented in San Jose. **********Industry executives say the computer giant also plans to introduce a higher-capacity version of its 3390 disk drive for mainframes in the second week of September. The 3390 was first shipped only 23 months ago. Its predecessor, the 3380, lasted for almost a decade. The decision to accelerate the product cycle is an indication that I.B.M. realizes it cannot rest on its laurels. **********"This technology product area spoils quickly," said Ray S. AbuZayyad, who is in charge of all disk storage products for I.B.M. **********I.B.M. signaled its determination to stay competitive earlier this year, when it reorganized its disk drive products into a single division, and appointed Mr. AbuZayyad, a savvy and aggressive engineer with 29 years of experience, to head it. **********The company has also fought its way into the most competitive part of the small Winchester business, for high-capacity disks, and has won contracts with both Apple Computer and Sun Microsystems against tough Japanese competition. **********I.B.M. managers also insist that they are going to push a key competitive advantage their company has over many smaller disk makers. I.B.M. is far more vertically integrated than most of its competitors, and says will use its high-end technology combatively, transferring it down quickly to the low end of the market for desktop computers, where players like Conner Peripherals and Quantum Computer compete. **********While some analysts predict that the advent of inexpensive disk arrays will strip much of the profitability out of the lucrative high end of disk drive business, I.B.M. says the complexity of these new drives -- integrating microelectronic controllers and software -- will protect margins. **********"If you were to take a single element of the system I would say yes," said Mr. AbuZayyad, "but integration will prevent that for the forseeable future." A LESSON I.B.M. LEARNED FROM NOT TAKING RISC **********For the International Business Machines Corporation, the progress made by a new disk array technology closely parallels the history of reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. First pioneered by I.B.M. in the mid-1970's, RISC was popularized by a group of researchers at the University of California at Berkeley in the early 1980's. I.B.M. was late to market with a competitive RISC chip and is still scrambling to catch up with one for the work station market. **********As with RISC, I.B.M. was a pioneer in RAID research, developing experimental arrays in the 1970's. However, the significance of the technology did not become widely apparent until 1987, when David Patterson, a Berkeley professor who led the RISC research and another Berkeley professor, Randy Katz, published a paper outlining the RAID idea as a simple way of taking advantage of the trend toward putting more and more bits of information into smaller and less expensive packages. **********Dr. Patterson said that combining RISC and RAID will remove the justification for buying a mainframe computer. "One of the arguments for mainframes has been much higher disk performance," he said. "RAID enables commodity disks to be combined to offer the capacity, performance and reliability normally associated with mainframes." **********Dr. Patterson said he was surprised at how quickly the RAID idea spread after they distributed copies of the original paper in 1987. Soon afterwards, he said, he saw copies come back from Japan with notations in Japanese writing. **********"It was like a cargo plane had spilled a load of our technical reports into the stratosphere," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/world.main_headline: Seoul Aches From 3d Day of Protests and Tear Gas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/world.print_headline: Seoul Aches From 3d Day of Protests and Tear Gas
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/world.body_text: **********Demonstrators, tear gas and violence filled several neighborhoods of the capital today for the third day in a row as protests over the beating death of a student by the police last week turned the ralies that usually begin at this time into the largest in several years. **********A May Day rally by students and some workers spilled from several university campuses into the streets here tonight, leading to a series of violent confrontations between 4,000 riot police officers and about 20,000 protesters. **********The police fired hundreds of volleys of tear-gas canisters and some demonstrators responded at one point by overturning a police vehicle with a dozen policemen inside. Demonstrators also threw rocks and gasoline bombs at the riot police. **********Although there were reports of injuries, no figures were available in press reports or from the police in what is turning into the worst spasm of violence since Roh Tae Woo became President three years ago. May Day often marks the start of a month of student protests in South Korea. **********Many demonstrators have demanded his resignation or the resignation of his Cabinet to take responsibility for the death of a 20-year-old student on Friday after he was beaten in the head with steel pipes by the police. **********After that student died, a 19-year-old student, Park Seung Hee, set herself on fire in the southern city of Kwangju in protest after shouting anti-Roh slogans. Today, yet another student, Kim Young Kyun, was reported to have immolated himself at a provincial campus in another bloody protest. Both are reported to be in critical condition. **********Mr. Roh dismissed his Interior Minister, Ahn Eung Mo, over the weekend in an effort to quell public outrage over the beating death of the student on Friday. Four riot policemen were also arrested. Student demonstrators have lost public support in recent years, but the killing last week appears to have brought out some renewed sympathy for them and anger at the Government's heavy-handed response.  Elections in June **********The tension has been compounded by the fact that local elections are coming up in June, leading the Government to want to contain the demonstrations but not to appear repressive. **********Today, the police superintendent of a principal Seoul district resigned, saying he was fed up with the endless cycle of violence between the police and demonstrators. The police official, Yang Hyeuk, expressed remorse over the death of the student who had been beaten, but he added that his men suffered abuse for trying to keep order.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/17/world.main_headline: High Court Letting U.S. Keep The Names of Haitians Secret
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/17/world.print_headline: High Court Letting U.S. Keep The Names of Haitians Secret
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/17/world.body_text: **********The Supreme Court ruled today that the State Department can withhold the names of Haitians interviewed by American officials after they had been denied refuge in the United States and forcibly returned to Haiti. **********The decision overturns an appeals court ruling in a suit brought by a Miami lawyer on a Freedom of Information Act request in 1990. The lawyer, Michael D. Ray, then represented three Haitians seeking asylum and was seeking to determine what happened to other Haitians who had been returned. **********The Bush Administration argued then and contends today, as it tries to get a Nov. 19 ban on forced repatriations lifted, that no harm comes to Haitian refugees who are taken back to their homeland under a 1981 agreement with the Government of Jean-Claude Duvalier. Appeals against the ban are now being heard in a Federal appeals court in Atlanta. **********Refugee organizations and human rights groups dispute the Administration contention, saying there is no reliable information on the fate of Haitians returned forcibly. They are especially concerned about 538 people sent back on Coast Guard cutters on Nov. 18 and 19 to a country under military rule since troops overthrew the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, on Sept. 30. **********Mr. Ray argued before the coup that the same lack of verifiable information prevailed in the past. He had asked the State Department to make available its records on interviews it said it had conducted in the 1980's with returned Haitians. Mr. Ray was provided with some documents, but with the names and in some cases the addresses or locations of interviews blotted out. **********The unanimous ruling today held that concealing the names of the Haitians protects their privacy and shields them "from any retaliatory action that might result."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/23/busin.main_headline: Colombia Hopeful on Huge Oil Find
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/23/busin.print_headline: Colombia Hopeful on Huge Oil Find
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/23/busin.body_text: **********The late Gen. Jorge Martinez was convinced as early as 1920 that a sea of petroleum lay deep below the surface of the impenetrable plains of eastern Colombia. **********Although he was awarded a good part of the land for his wartime bravery, the general never saw the oil that is beginning to gush from its wells today. **********Colombia and its foreign oil partners discovered earlier this year that the amount of crude oil in the region known as Cusiana, about 100 miles east of here, probably exceeds the wildest predictions of General Martinez. **********How much those riches may amount to is unclear, but industry executives are calling Cusiana the largest oil find in the Americas since the Prudhoe Bay discovery in Alaska in 1968.'World-Class Find' **********"I'm convinced that it's a world-class find," said Andres Restrepo, president of the state-run oil company Ecopetrol, which is working to develop the project with the British Petroleum Company; the Triton Energy Corporation, based in Dallas, and TOTAL-Compagnie Francaise des Petroles of France. **********While Mr. Restrepo stresses the need to be prudent in discussing estimates of potential reserves, one oil executive called Cusiana a windfall, with potential reserves of three billion to five billion barrels. Anticipating an economic boom, hundreds of Colombians have arrived in Casanare province, straining its services. **********The Finance Minister, Rudolf Hommes, said recently that the Cusiana find would enable Colombia to more than double its oil exports by 1995. Production is expected to begin as early as March, and analysts say that within three years the country could lift exports to 500,000 barrels a day, from the current 200,000. **********Colombia is currently Latin America's third-largest oil exporter, behind Venezuela and Mexico, but it is considered a marginal exporter in world terms. With 1.8 billion barrels of proven reserves, Colombia produces 450,000 barrels of oil a day. **********The promise of Cusiana's riches may serve to lure foreign capital back to Colombia, where guerrilla terrorism has kept investors at bay. **********Leftist rebels of the National Liberation Army, known by their Spanish initials ELN, have made it their mission in the last six years to try to force the authorities to nationalize the oil industry and throw out foreign investors. This year alone they have bombed the main Cano-Limon oil pipeline 59 times. **********The pipeline transports about 220,000 barrels of oil a day from the eastern Cano-Limon fields, previously Colombia's richest deposit with about one billion barrels of reserves, to Caribbean ports for export. **********Over the years, the pipeline bombings have spilled about 35 million gallons of raw crude into rivers and jungle forests, roughly three times the amount of oil lost in the 1989 Exxon Valdez disaster in Alaska, and Ecopetrol estimates that the attacks have cost the national economy about $700 million since 1986. **********The guerrillas' propensity for kidnapping foreign oil employees is also a disincentive to outside investment. Three engineers from the Natco Company, a drilling concern based in Tulsa, Okla., were released in November after a year in the hands of the ELN. Unconfirmed reports said the company paid a hefty ransom. Two Japanese and three French oil engineers were also kidnapped in 1991. **********But Patricia Correa, a private economic researcher in Bogota, believes foreign investors will be willing to overlook the rebel violence in the future. "With the discovery of Cusiana, there is much more interest in Colombia now," she said. "I expect levels of foreign investment to start reflecting that." **********Foreign investment is the key to exploration and development of Colombia's oil reserves -- especially in Casanare provice, where the Cusiana field is situated and where petroleum lies 17,000 feet below the surface, beneath rock formations. Each well takes a year to complete and costs nearly $20 million. **********Some analysts say they think Ecopetrol and its foreign partners will have to spend $3 billion just to get Cusiana's oil to market. **********If the three billion to five billion barrels of reserves are confirmed, Colombia stands to earn about $2.5 billion a year in oil exports by 1995, more than double its current earnings. Considering that Colombian law gives the Government 80 percent of all oil profits, the foreign partners stand to make about $620 million a year, based on the current price of $17 a barrel.Court Challenges **********But some citizens have taken the Government to court, claiming a share of the region's profits. The descendants of General Martinez, for instance, and several other families say they were awarded subsoil rights to Cusiana in a series of court and presidential decrees dating to 1920 **********Colombia's Attorney General and the Energy and Mines Ministry, citing other legislation, say all subsoil belongs to the nation. A final decision by the Council of State, made up of senior magistrates, is expected next year. **********The ELN has announced that a decision favoring the families would provoke a wave of rebel violence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/busin.snippet: WITH all the recent attention on term limits in Congress, perhaps it's time to consider bringing term limits into the boardroom.  The problem is the same: a system under which incumbents linger on and on, having to prove nothing and facing no chal...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/busin.body_text: **********WITH all the recent attention on term limits in Congress, perhaps it's time to consider bringing term limits into the boardroom.  The problem is the same: a system under which incumbents linger on and on, having to prove nothing and facing no challenge to their tenure. **********Establishing term limits for outside corporate directors could prove valuable, especially at companies in need of a jump-start in leadership, and shareholders with clout -- like pension funds -- should encourage such a move. **********Directors could be elected to three- to five-year terms; they would run initially with a publicly disclosed platform, and then run for re-election based, first, on how closely they made good on their earlier promises, and, second, on the attractiveness of their future promises. Competitive candidates, nominated by institutional investors could run against in-house candidates and they all would run on a common ballot. **********Of the winners, outside -- but not inside -- directors would be subject to term limits totalling no more than 10 years. New members could join the board as incumbents resign or retire. **********Term limits would force directors to focus more on shareholder expectations and less on building relationships with top executives, and might discourage high-dollar compensation packages for top executives. They would also permit the graceful elimination of unproductive directors. **********The result: a board guided by agreed-upon objectives, which could develop some esprit de corps, and yet one that does not get stale or too clubby. The idea is not to make leadership unstable but to encourage diversity and fresh thinking. **********Although critics might argue that term limits would discount valuable institutional memory, the limits would be applied only to outside directors so that the most significant experience would be retained. And term limits would not enhance the already-considerable power of the chief executive: Directors with a limited tenure are more likely to challenge the delivered management wisdom than those with a lifetime ticket. **********COMPANIES that stand to gain the most are ailing mature companies that have traditionally had the longest tenure for board members. Until recently, there were seven outside directors on the General Motors 20-person board who had served at least 10 years. (Of its 17-person board now, there are five long-term outside directors.) Sears, Roebuck has six outside directors with at least a decade of service. And they are not the only companies with such records. By pruning some deadwood -- and even active, constructive board members whose creative thinking days may have passed -- term limits on directors could push companies to do better.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/world.print_headline: Walesa Vetoes Election Law, But Won't Oust Legislature
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/world.body_text: **********President Lech Walesa vetoed an election law today for a second time, but backed away from his threat to dissolve the lower house of Parliament. **********He had threatened on Sunday to dissolve the legislature, which is dominated by holdover Communists from the previous Government, but apparently he decided he did not have clear constitutional power to do so. **********Mr. Walesa told workers at a pharmaceutical factory he would not dissolve Parliament because he could "never act against the law." **********The factory was the second stop on a nationwide tour Mr. Walesa was making to gauge public support for his showdown with Parliament over setting voting rules for Poland's first fully free parliamentary elections since World War II. The elections are planned for October.

Trump for about $320 million in 1985. **********The offer, which was made to Trump Castle Associates with notification to principal creditors, was roundly rejected by Mr. Trump. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/22/busin.main_headline: Rural Towns Trying to Lure Retirees to Bloster Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/22/busin.print_headline: Rural Towns Trying to Lure Retirees to Bloster Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/22/busin.body_text: **********Using advertising, videos, toll-free hot lines and booths at recreational vehicle conventions, small towns from Idaho to Alabama are fighting decline by marketing themselves to retirees. **********Many of the most aggressive towns are inland places far from the sunny retirement belt of Florida and the Southwest, like Guntersville, Ala., Hot Springs, Ark., and Chewelah, Wash. And they are having success, luring significant numbers of older people who find traditional retirement meccas overbuilt, crime-ridden and unaffordable. **********Many civic leaders say it is now far easier and more lucrative for rural towns to attract older people -- with their pensions and savings -- than new factories or office parks. Companies often demand millions of dollars in tax abatements and new roads and other repairs, they say. But retirees and their hundreds of thousands of dollars in assets are being enticed with a brochure, a tour, a handshake and a smile.  Healthy, Wealthy and Wise **********"These migrants are healthier, wealthier and better educated than most Americans," said Mark Fagan, a professor at the Center for Economic Development and Business Research at Jacksonville State University in Alabama, which is helping 94 Alabama municipalities attract older people. **********On average, Mr. Fagan said, the retired couples who have settled in Alabama have annual incomes of $35,000 and assets of more than $250,000. **********"They pay for their homes with cash and spend most of their income locally," Mr. Fagan added. "It is like having an export industry to bring in out-of-state dollars." **********In addition, the retirees place few demands on the most expensive of local services, the public schools. **********The marketing campaigns come after a decade in which many rural towns that depended on agriculture, mining and manufacturing had some of their sharpest population declines in this century, as young people moved away in search of jobs. **********With 20 million Americans expected to retire in the next decade, experts say, the futures of many towns may depend on their ability to grab a piece of the retirement trade. **********Most of America's 2,400 rural counties outside of metropolitan areas had sharp drops in population in the last decade. But some 480 counties, many of which include retirement resorts, saw their populations jump by 16 percent as retirees settled in year round. **********As a result, more than 200 rural communities that were losing population have tried to tap into the senior market with home-grown marketing campaigns, Mr. Fagan said, and growing numbers of other towns are inquiring about them. Many of the established programs are now reporting significant successes. **********Chewelah, a town with fewer than 2,000 residents, 45 miles south of Spokane, has attracted 35 retired couples in the last two years with ads in retirement magazines, a toll-free hot line and a video made for $750 by high school students, town officials say. These all boast of Chewelah's nearness to golf courses, ski slopes and hospitals. **********"If you had a heart attack in my office this very minute," Gloria Davidson, the town's Mayor, said in a telephone interview, "you would be in Spokane in 15 minutes by helicopter." **********The arrival of the retirees, Ms. Davidson says, has created jobs by spurring the opening of a bakery, a restaurant and a beauty shop.  Unpaid 'Ambassadors' **********Other places have added a more personal pitch. **********Kennewick, Richland and Pasco, Wash., together have trained 49 residents to act as unpaid "ambassadors" on their business trips and vacations. The ambassadors offer middle-aged people promotional literature and bumper stickers. Together with ads and a toll-free hot line, officials say, the campaign has attracted 35 retired households. **********In Alabama, the four-year-old state program has purchased $100,000 in ads in national retirement publications and advised towns on how to market themselves. The campaign has drawn 15,000 queries from out-of-state residents and several hundred retirees have settled in the state. **********Guntersville, Ala., a town of 7,000 along the Tennessee River that lost its major employer, a textile factory, in the early 1980's, attracted 250 retired couples in the last three years with magazine ads and commercials on ESPN, the cable sports network, during the network's coverage of fishing tournaments. **********The retirees, town officials say, have revived business in banks, real estate offices, marinas and golf courses.  Going Home Again **********In North Dakota, the Legislature this year financed Operation Back Home Again, a program designed to help towns across the state trace the graduates of their high schools as far back as 1950 and ask them to return for their golden years. In Mississippi, county development agencies and the Mississippi Power Company have set up booths at national boating, fishing and recreational vehicle conventions. **********Hot Springs, a lakeside city of 32,000 in central Arkansas, has attracted more than 500 households in the last two years with its ads in retirement magazines, town officials say. When retirees arrive, they are met by blue-coated volunteers, who offer tours of the town, including its new art galleries and shops. Meanwhile, the guides sing the praises of retirement in the Ozarks. **********"This is a garden," said Richard Bingham, a 59-year-old tour guide in Hot Springs who moved from South Pasadena, Calif., in 1987. Mr. Bingham recalls that rising pollution, crime and real estate prices made Southern California less and less inviting as a place to retire. **********So he sold his home there for $250,000 and bought a three-bedroom house on a lake in Hot Springs for $100,000. He also bought a 24-foot boat, and put $75,000 into a local bank. **********"It just got too darned crowded," Mr. Bingham said of California." It used to take me 30 minutes to drive to downtown Los Angeles. In the last year it took an hour and a half to two hours."  Traditional Areas Slip **********The dimming luster of traditional retirement areas may just be starting to appear in census findings, said Stephen Golant, a professor of geography at the University of Florida in Gainesville. **********In 1987, for example, Florida estimated that it would have 2,542,000 residents over the age 65 by 1990, based on past growth of the state's retired population. But the 1990 census found that the state had only 2,389,000 residents over 65, an indication, Mr. Golant said, that the migration may have slowed. **********The youngest people now making plans for retirement, who will be joined by the oldest members of the baby boom in the next five years, are increasingly asking about small towns far away from traditional retirement resorts, said Kate Greer, the editor in chief of New Choices, a magazine aimed at retirees. **********"I sense a real change in attitude," Ms. Greer said. "These people are asking, where do I really want to retire?" **********Mr. Golant cautioned, however, that rural towns could be disappointed in the long term by the arrival of retirees. Although Mr. Fagan estimates that each retired couple has the same economic impact as 3.7 factory jobs, Mr. Golant said the retirees did not create the types of well-paying jobs that towns would gain by attracting businesses. **********"Certainly they will generate jobs in recreation, personal services and health-related activities," Mr. Golant said. "But it is not clear the presence of retirees will generate higher-paying jobs that are generally related to management, research, technology and finance."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/busin.body_text: **********The President of Vietnam has signed a law sanctioning and protecting private business in hopes of reviving one of the world's most backward economies. **********The Communist Government has been relaxing central control of the economy and encouraging private enterprise since doctrinaire Marxist leaders retired and changes were adopted in late 1986. **********The law, which the National Assembly adopted on Dec. 21, was signed last Monday by President Vo Chi Cong, the official Communist Party newspaper Nhan Dan reported. The law will take effect on April 15. **********The law says Vietnamese citizens 18 and over have the right to open private businesses. **********The Prime Minister's approval is needed for involvement in production of explosives, poisonous substances and toxic chemicals; excavation of precious minerals, and large-scale production and supply of electricity and water. **********Approval is also required for any business involved in international tourism, the manufacture of radio transmitters or the providing of postal, telecommunications, radio, television, publishing and special import-export services.
