https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/world.main_headline: Havel Seeks Vote on Czech-Slovak Unity
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/world.print_headline: Havel Seeks Vote on Czech-Slovak Unity
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/world.body_text: **********Faced with mounting calls for separatism in Slovakia, President Vaclav Havel is pressing for a referendum to decide if the two regional administrations of this federated nation should go their ways as separate states, officials close to the President said today. **********The presidential aides said Mr. Havel, who was accosted by vocal critics in Slovakia on Thursday, was hoping that a referendum could be held as early as June, once enabling legislation was passed by Parliament. **********The officials said it remained unclear whether the referendum would involve all citizens of this nation of 15 million or just the Slovaks, a distinct linguistic and cultural group of some 5 million, who are concentrated in the eastern part of the country. **********But most officials interviewed this week appeared convinced that even if a vote was limited to Slovaks, a majority would vote for retaining the current federal formula that binds the Czech and Slovak Republics in a single state.  Havel's Attention Diverted **********As Slovak groups have increasingly called for greater autonomy or even secession, Mr. Havel, a former dissident playwright, has had to turn his attention from leading the drive for economic reform and greater democracy to deal with the challenge to the integrity of the multinational state, which was created after World War I from the ruins of the Hapsburg Empire. **********Just how inflamatory the issue is was made clear on Thursday, when television viewers saw images of Mr. Havel, who is Czech, confined to his car as an angry crowd demonstrating for a separate state in Bratislava, the Slovak capital, engulfed his motorcade and jeered him with cries of "Judas! Judas!" and "Provocateur!" **********In an address late Thursday that was televised nationally, Mr. Havel called upon the Slovaks to stay within the federated state, but assured them they were free to form a separate state, provided it was done in a legal and constitutional manner. **********As if to reassure the Slovaks of his good will, the President met on Thursday in Bratislava with officers of the Czechoslovak Army based in the Slovak Republic, and gave public assurances that force would not be used to impede the formation of a separate Slovak state if a majority of Slovaks chose that course. Referendum 'a Healthy Thing' **********"We believe there have been so many discussions, so many arguments and misunderstandings, that it is probably a healthy thing if a referendum is held," said Michael Zantovsky, the President's spokesman. **********Mr. Zantovsky said that various amendments to the legislation proposed by Mr. Havel were being discussed by the federal legislature and that one possible form for a referendum would be to ask Slovaks, "Do you want to secede from the federation?" **********Mr. Havel appeared to have allayed Slovak nationalist passions in November, when the federal legislature passed laws defining the powers of the regional governments. **********But the latest crisis was sparked by the continued emergence of radical nationalist groups in Slovakia. That led to a split in Public Against Violence, the Slovak counterpart of Mr. Havel's Civic Forum movement, which spearheaded the drive to topple the former Communist regime in late 1989. **********While Civic Forum in the Czech lands has divided in recent weeks largely over ideological questions involving the pace of economic change, Public Against Violence has been deeply split between opponents and supporters of a separate Slovak state. **********Officials in Prague are closely watching events in Yugoslavia, another federated state, where challenges to the leadership of Serbia, the most populous republic, have compounded political and ethnic strife there. And in the Soviet Union, millions of citizens are to vote on Sunday in a referendum reflecting their attitudes toward unity. **********But officials close to Mr. Havel emphasized the differences in the situation in Czechoslovakia, where violence or the threat of armed intervention have played no role and where the central Government has declared its willingness to accept dissolution of the federated state, if those involved so desire.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/20/busin.body_text: **********The Columbia Gas System Inc., one of the leading suppliers of natural gas to utilities in the Northeast, suspended dividend payments yesterday and said it might seek bankruptcy court protection unless it could renegotiate contracts with gas producers and bankers. **********On the news, the company's shares lost 40 percent of their value. The stock's opening on the New York Stock Exchange was delayed yesterday, pending the announcement. Columbia's share price later opened at $20 before closing at $20.75, off $13.75. With 4.4 million shares traded, the stock was the most active Big Board issue. **********The plunge helped send the whole stock market down, with the Dow losing 31.31, to 2,955.50.  [ Page D8. ] No Effect on Consumers **********There should be no immediate effect on consumers. Spot markets determine the price paid by local utilities, and the majority of the gas Columbia ships is for these companies. Even if it files for bankruptcy, the company anticipates operating under court protection. **********The company blamed warm weather in recent years for depressing gas prices on spot markets, leaving it locked into contracts to buy gas at much higher prices set years ago when supplies were tighter. The company said the gap between what it had to pay for gas and what it could sell for could amount to as much as $1 billion. **********In a statement, Columbia said "a substantial portion" of these losses would be charged against second-quarter income, probably producing a sizable loss.  Other Pipeline Companies **********Analysts said the rest of the pipeline industry appeared to be in better shape than Columbia, having previously negotiated old fixed-price contracts to reflect spot-market prices. "I think other companies have some spot problems, but nothing near the problems Columbia has," said Paul R. Ferretti, an analyst with Dillon, Read & Company. **********Still, the stock prices of other pipeline companies also fell, though not by nearly as much. The Ensearch Corporation's share price closed at $18.25, off 62.5 cents, while that of Consolidated Natural Gas Utilities fell $1.75, to $39.50. **********"While ll segments of the pipeline industry have been affected to some extent, Columbia was uniquely affected because of their mix of contracts, customers and structure," said Michael Baly, president of the American Gas Association. "We hope the contract problems at Columbia are the last chapter of the 'take or pay' era." Under such a contract, a buyer must purchase a certain amount of a product or make payments in lieu of the purchases. **********The company said a recent review had shown that its "potential exposure under its above-market-priced gas purchase contracts is substantially larger than previously projected." **********The company said it was offering gas producers $600 million in securities of its Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation subsidiary as an inducement to break the old, high-price contracts. But if those negotiations fail, or if banks withdraw lines of credit, the company said, it could "force the system, the pipeline subsidiary or both to seek protection from creditors under bankruptcy laws."  Paying $6.70 for $1.30 of Gas **********Columbia said the old fixed-price contracts obligated it to pay as much as $6.70 for a thousand cubic feet of gas at the wellhead, while the spot price is about $1.30. **********In an interview, John H. Croom, the chairman of Columbia, said the company was "caught in a fix" because of changing regulations. The local utilities that formerly bought gas from pipeline companies like Columbia are now allowed to purchase spot-market gas when it is cheaper. And the pipelines must transport the gas if they have available capacity. **********"We have had seven warm winters in a row," Mr. Croom said, "so that has freed up capacity." He said that last year, between 60 and 70 percent of the gas going through Columbia's major pipelines was transported for other owners.  Deadline of Oct. 1 **********The company set a deadline of Oct. 1 for concluding agreements with gas producers. "We must have strong encouragement from representative producers by the end of July and commitments from substantially all producers" by Oct. 1, the company said in a statement. **********Robert Oswald, Columbia's chief financial officer, said the size of the gas-contract problem had caused banks to cut off previously established lines of credit. **********After the announcement, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced that it was downgrading the company's senior debt from BBB+, to BB, and Columbia's commercial paper to B, from A-2. It said the company had $2.2 billion in debt outstanding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/10/world.main_headline: Givat Brenner Journal; Even in the Kibbutz, Socialism Is Under Challenge
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/10/world.print_headline: Givat Brenner Journal; Even in the Kibbutz, Socialism Is Under Challenge
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/10/world.body_text: **********The old recreation hall has become a play-for-pay amusement center for the children of the nearby town of Rehovot. While they romp, a tractor-hauled truck equipped with benches takes parents on tours around the factories and farms of this kibbutz, "the world's largest," a they like to joke here about this quintessentially Israeli institution. **********Around the swimming pool, townspeople who have paid admission take their ease, and in the clothing and furniture shops they hunt for bargains. **********The day-care center, which used to tend the children of the kibbutz, caters to day boarders. The laundry takes in outside washing, and the dental clinic is open to any patient. **********Kibbutz Givat Brenner is seething with debate about these paying interlopers in this once-exclusive commune of practicing socialists. 'A More Capitalistic View' **********But the most sensitive departure from the puritan tenets of the kibbutz movement goes beyond the intrusion of outside customers. Since earlier this year, a businessman who is not a member has been chairman of the board of the kibbutz's main enterprise, the orange-juice factory. **********"We are in a major economic crisis," said Amir Levy, the elected secretary who manages the kibbutz, where he was born 48 years ago. "We realize we need somebody who brings a more capitalistic view of what we're doing." **********Not all do. "Outside managers?" exclaimed David Bar, an agricultural entomologist. "This is fundamental. I don't like it. Are we unable to manage our industries? I don't believe it." **********Mr. Levy and Mr. Bar share friendship and a commitment to the ideals of the kibbutz -- equality for all members and provision of their basic needs. But in the debate sweeping the 270 kibbutzim over how to continue an institution that has played a role far greater than its 3 percent share of the population in the founding and life of Israel, they are at opposite poles. **********The crisis goes beyond the bank debt of around $4 billion that the collectives and their 125,000 members accumulated over the many years in which credit was easy to obtain for people who were considered the only aristocracy Israel ever had. In debates that have much in common with those in the remaining or former Communist countries of Eastern Europe, kibbutzniks are taking the pulse of socialism and question whether any life is left in it. **********"The old idea is dead, we have to admit it," Mr. Levy said. "We have entered the capitalist era." **********At a public meeting last year, Yehuda Harel said, "The socialist system in all its forms has been a total failure." Mr. Harel, a founder of the first kibbutz established on the Golan Heights, now heads his kibbutz's management-consulting concern, which wants to help kibbutzim to separate their businesses, to be run on a strictly entrepreneurial basis, from their communal life. **********Mr. Levy said he had arrived at the University of California in Santa Barbara, where he obtained a Ph.D. in sociology, imbued with the collective, anti-capitalist ideology of the kibbutz. **********"There I saw you could succeed by the opposite values of the kibbutz," he said. "I thought capitalism was exploitation. But I saw that with individualism, freedom, personal responsibility, you can succeed. In the kibbutz no one takes responsibility. **********"We will have to try to absorb some of the capitalist ideas and remain socialist. I don't know if it's possible, but there's no other way." **********Mr. Bar said that as a natural scientist he recognized Mr. Levy's sociological expertise, and that "I understand we're in a bad situation." **********"But I'm afraid if we continue this process, we will see outsiders eat in the dining room or renting apartments here," he continued. "I don't like it. I came to the kibbutz in 1957 to live together with my colleagues and friends. The kibbutz is a kind of nature reserve. The quality of life is the highest in Israel. I want to put some limits to what I give up." **********Mr. Levy, speaking for those who believe that the "old idea is dead," said the kibbutz model was undercut when the Israeli economy shifted from reliance on agriculture into higher technological gear, and industry became the main business of the kibbutzim and professional specialization a requirement. **********"The traditional kibbutz was built on agriculture, and to work hard and produce a lot was the goal," he said. "But now it's not enough to produce. We must sell and compete with the world." **********He said management was a professional skill, and under Mr. Bar's management the dining hall proved that running it was not his profession. Mr. Levy said he wanted to make the dining hall, the social center for the 1,000 adults and 500 children of Givat Brenner, a paying cafeteria rather than the traditional kibbutz mess hall of "this is what we all eat today." **********The present dining-hall system causes great waste as well as poor meals, Mr. Levy said, because no one feels responsible, no one cares and no one wants to work there. "If we pay, we will eat better, and it will cost half of the 6 million shekels we spend now," he said. **********"But for the others, the dining room is a principle, a temple," he said. He said deviations from tradition had an almost sacrilegious aspect for the "true believers" of the kibbutzim. **********If concessions to commerce like paying for meals continue, Mr. Bar said, soon members will be asking, "Why do we need the kibbutz?" **********"The dining room is part of my own home," he said. "If I pay, what happens to the idea? If it doesn't work, then we have to close the doors and say, 'It was a beautiful experiment, bye-bye.' Then this will be just a green neighborhood near Rehovot."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.main_headline: Iraqi Plea on Exports Rejected at OPEC Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.print_headline: Iraqi Plea on Exports Rejected at OPEC Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.body_text: **********OPEC today rejected a request by Iraq for a letter addressed to the United Nations asking for an end to sanctions barring Iraqi oil exports. **********The request was made by the Iraqi Oil Minister in what turned out to be the shortest meeting in more than a decade of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********At the one-day meeting, the group decided to retain the current overall production ceiling for its 13 members at the current level of 22.3 million barrels a day, an outcome that was widely expected by the oil industry. **********The Iraqi plea for help with the United Nations was firmly rejected by the Arab oil-producing countries in the Persian Gulf. The Saudi Oil Minister, Hisham Nazer, told his Iraqi counterpart, Ussama Abdul Razzaq, that four countries present at the meeting, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar, had fought a war against Iraq to expel its troops from Kuwait. Mr. Nazer said these countries were not about to plead with the United Nations to lift sanctions that resulted from the Iraqi aggression, according to several Arab delegates here. Demand Will Be Met **********OPEC officials said the quick decision to freeze the present level of production, which is estimated at above the ceiling, averaging a daily output of 22.8 million barrels a day, is enough to match anticipated demand for OPEC oil in the third quarter. **********The OPEC ministers agreed to meet again in September to review the supply and demand balance for world oil markets. **********That meeting could accomplish little more, however, since both Iraq and Kuwait have been out of the oil-exporting business altogether since Aug. 2, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Because of heavy damage done to the Kuwaiti oil industry and sanctions imposed on Iraq during the Persian Gulf crisis, neither country can export oil for at least another six months, OPEC officials estimate. **********This would allow Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, and the United Arab Emirates to continue to pump as much oil as they can to make up for the shortage from Iraq and Kuwait and reap additional benefits from surpassing their normal quotas. **********In its communique today, OPEC reaffirmed, however, that it still regards $21 as the ideal price for oil, even though the current price for OPEC crudes hovers near $17. **********The average price of a basket of crude oil monitored by the group stood at $17.68 last week. The price often quoted in the United States, for a premium light sweet grade of crude, is several dollars higher. **********On the New York Mercantile Exchange today, crude oil futures settled 11 cents to 15 cents lower, with the July contract at $21.02 a barrel. **********The organization's Secretary General, Dr. Subroto, who was elected to a new three-year term, said prices would be rising gradually throughout the year as demand for oil increases, which is what he anticipated. Also, Venezuela's oil minister, Celestino Armas, was elected the new president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/18/world.main_headline: Pope Tells Croats He Supports Them
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/18/world.print_headline: Pope Tells Croats He Supports Them
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/18/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II told Croatian pilgrims today that he supported their "legitimate aspirations" and said he would like to visit their republic soon. **********The Pope's statement, delivered at an open-air service in the Hungarian town of Pecs, near the border with Yugoslavia, was his strongest yet on the Yugoslav crisis. But it stopped short of an explicit endorsement of Croatia's independence drive, suggesting that Croatians should achieve their goals through international mediation. **********Church officials said he had inserted the remarks into his homily after meeting with Catholic leaders from Croatia. **********"Once again, I assure you that I am close to your legitimate aspirations, renewing my appeals to the international community so that they help you in this difficult hour of history," John Paul told the crowd. "I am hopeful to be able one day in the near future to visit you." **********Croatia is predominantly Catholic, and the Croatian primate, Franjo Cardinal Kuharic, stood beside the Pope as he celebrated Mass in Pecs today. Other Croatian Catholic leaders as well as several hundred lay pilgrims were also present. **********Since Croatia and another Yugoslav republic, Slovenia, declared independence in June, fierce clashes have broken out between local militias and units of the Yugoslav federal army. Rebel Serbs, members of the ethnic group that is the largest in Yugoslavia but a minority in Croatia, have also clashed with the Croatian police and militia forces. **********The Pope was in the second day of a five-day trip through Hungary, where he is seeking to encourage a rebirth of religious faith. Hungary is traditionally a Catholic country, but religious faith weakened over four decades of Communist rule.  Denounces Era of Atheism **********During that time, John Paul declared in Pecs, "An ironclad organization imposed on the nation an atheistic pseudo-culture, and wanted to make it a way of life." **********The Pope's homily in Pecs was devoted mainly to admonitions against sin and tributes to the Virgin Mary. He struck a different note later in a meeting with intellectuals in Budapest, saluting Christian writers, artists, scientists and doctors who were persecuted by Communist Governments. He said they should now seek to develop a free culture without regard to political or religious differences. **********"Faith and reason go back to the same primordial truth, which cannot contradict itself," the Pope said. "Regrettably, on the Christian side too, believers have sometimes insufficiently understood the legitimate autonomy of science and art, thus giving rise to disputes, controversies and polemics which have led not a few people to believe that science and faith are opposed to each other. It is to be hoped that this will not happen again. **********"On the other hand, it is likewise legitimate to hope that there has finally been overcome the negative preconception whereby scientists and artists too assumed a hostile attitude toward religious faith." **********John Paul encouraged researchers to pursue their studies freely, without fear of contradicting religious teachings. But he said intellectuals should acknowledge that religious faith could help people understand death, suffering, evil and other aspects of existence "which to scientific analysis appear incomprehensible if not totally absurd." **********In the same statement, the Pope strongly urged a return to religious instruction in public schools. This has been a delicate issue in Hungary for decades. Efforts by the Communists to restrict religious education contributed to bitter conflicts of church and state beginning in the late 1940's. **********The Pope asserted that modern Hungary was "profoundly threatened by the phenomenon of secularism" and that moral values "are not infrequently ignored, and even ridiculed." He said schools should stress religious values that parents tend to ignore. **********"Parents have too little time to devote to their children," he said. "Perhaps they too are deeply wounded in spirit, shaken in their basic convictions and consequently have no interest in the real and ultimate meaning of life." **********--------------------       Tanks Roll Into Town **********BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Federal army tanks rolled into a strategic Croatian town today and warplanes attacked positions of local militias in fighting that threatened an 11-day-old truce, officials said. **********About 23 armored vehicles and 11 army trucks entered Okucani, 70 miles southeast of Zagreb at the intersection of several major roads and near Yugoslavia's main north-south highway, the official news agency, Tanyug, said. Two air force planes bombed Croatian positions seven miles south, in Stara Gradiska on the border with the republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/world.main_headline: Chinese-Indian Talks Seem to Favor Beijing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/world.print_headline: Chinese-Indian Talks Seem to Favor Beijing
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/world.body_text: **********P. V. Narasimha Rao and Li Peng, the Indian and Chinese Prime Ministers, concluded two days of talks here this week with China gaining an Indian statement of support for Chinese sovereignty over Tibet, and India apparently getting little in return. **********Mr. Li, who left here on Friday, was the first Chinese Prime Minister to visit India in 31 years. The trip raised high expectations in the Indian Foreign Ministry, coming at a time when India, long a close ally of Soviet Union, and China are both ill at ease with the collapse of Communism in Europe. Both say they are seeking to create a new structure of relations in Asia and among developing countries generally. **********Yet after two days of conversation, Mr. Li on issue after issue secured accommodations from the Indians without yielding on any significant points of his own. **********The talks also brought some angry oratory against the United States and other wealthy nations. The two sides denounced what they called "the emerging international oligarchy," in the words of an Indian Foreign Ministry spokesman, and called for the creation of a world order where no country can "manipulate world affairs and play power politics." **********Mr. Li, facing international opprobrium for his Government's policies toward Tibet, elicited an unequivocal Indian declaration that Tibet was a part of China. In the past, India has provided asylum to hundreds of thousands of Tibetan refugees. **********For the Chinese Prime Minister's visit, though, Mr. Rao's officials rounded up hundreds of Tibetans and forcibly -- at times brutally -- halted protest marches to the Chinese Embassy. The harshness of police action against the Tibetans provoked an outcry in Parliament, and late Friday the Supreme Court ordered that all detained women and children be released from jail by today. **********Even with that, India, which has been seeking support for its policies in Kashmir, a predominantly Muslim northern region seeking independence, obtained no commensurate declaration from the Chinese. Mr. Li merely repeated China's position that India and Pakistan, which also claims Kashmir, should resolve the issue peacefully. **********Even India's concern about China's close relationship with Pakistan evidently did not come up in the two days of talks. The New Delhi Government, which charges Pakistan with arming Kashmiri separatists and harboring aggressive intentions, did not raise the matter of Beijing's significant weapons shipments to Pakistan, according to a Foreign Ministry spokesman. **********Likewise, India failed to extract any concessions from the Chinese over its territory occupied by China after a fierce border war in 1962. The Government, Indian newspapers report, had been seeking some movement on the dispute, but Mr. Rao and Mr. Li simply agreed to let talks between lower-level working groups continue. **********Mr. Rao did raise the issue of human rights with the Chinese leader, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said. But even then, he couched his remarks in terms that implied no criticism of China. **********"The Indian Prime Minister said we give central importance to the issue of development," the spokesman, Aftab Seth, related at a briefing. "We pointed out that India's system was fully transparent, open and democratic with an independent judiciary. He said it was not desirable to use the question of human rights as a condition for denying aid to developing countries." **********A senior Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, expressed frustration. "We don't know how to deal with the Chinese," he said. "We've always been a little afraid of them. Remember, Rao learned at the knee of Nehru. We Indians have never learned the art of tough negotiations." **********Mr. Seth rejected the idea that the Chinese Prime Minister got the better of Mr. Rao. "The visit should be seen in a broader context," he said. "It is a factor for progress and stability." **********Three agreements were signed: one calling for resumption of some border trade, a second establishing consulates in Bombay and Shanghai, and the third providing for greater cooperation in space-related research and technology.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/28/busin.main_headline: Higher U.S. Cost Is Seen In New Auction Rules
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/28/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Higher U.S. Cost Is Seen In New Auction Rules
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/28/busin.body_text: **********Changes announced last week to broaden participation in Treasury auctions will probably not have a noticeable impact on the quarterly refunding auctions next month, some analysts and Wall Street executives say. **********But they add that the changes in the auction rules, in conjunction with other shifts under consideration, could drive up the Government's borrowing costs in the future. **********The changes follow the Salomon Brothers bidding scandal, which has severely shaken faith in the decades-long manner in which business has been conducted by the Treasury, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the primary dealers of Government securities. **********With the economy soft and inflation under control, fundamental conditions remain favorable for the coming auctions. Moreover, the rule changes announced by the Treasury will not change the auction process much.  Some Short-Term Risk **********Nevertheless, by choosing to put the changes into effect at the start of the refunding auctions on Nov. 5, the Treasury has opened itself up to some short-term risk. **********The size of the refunding is expected to be announced on Wednesday. Most analysts expect the Treasury to sell a total of $38 billion worth of 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. **********The overall size of the auctions and the existence of the speculative 10-year and 30-year offerings make these quarterly debt sales the riskiest the Treasury conducts each year. **********And the auctions will take place in the week after credit market participants will have digested a series of important economic reports, including the Commerce Department's preliminary estimate on third-quarter economic growth, and October employment data from the Labor Department.  Potential Market Shift **********If those statistics are stronger than currently anticipated, the market's mood could suddenly shift. And a shift in market sentiment could make even the mildest changes in auction rules difficult and possibly expensive for the nation's taxpayers by driving up interest rates. **********"I don't think there will be any impact, but financial regulation is subject to the law of unanticipated circumstances," said Louis van B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm. "And when you change auction rules, the last place you want to experiment with is the refunding." **********Apart from the potential effects of the economic statistics, Mr. Crandall and others said that for the time being, the Treasury's decision to open the bidding process would not mean much. Until now, only primary dealers have been permitted to submit bids for clients. **********"Until the Treasury automates the auction process and allows customers to bid directly through a computer facility, it is to customers' advantage to continue bidding through primary dealers," said Richard M. Kelly, chairman of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a primary dealer. Choice for Customers **********Without an automated system, customers will have the choice of physically submitting tender offers to the New York Fed before auction time, or telephoning primary dealers to place their bids. The Treasury has made it plain that it will accelerate efforts to automate the process. But that job will not be completed before the refunding auctions. **********For the time being, the decision to increase the maximum amount of securities awarded to noncompetitive tender bids to $5 million, from $1 million, will also not have much impact. **********But Mr. Crandall said that under different market conditions, increasing the size of noncompetitive awards, which are made at the yield reflecting the average of accepted competitive tenders, will drive up borrowing costs. **********"There is no way that change is more favorable to the Treasury," Mr. Crandall said. "We are in a bull market right now, so it won't have any impact. But in a down market, where you have a wider dispersal of bids, the larger noncompetitive awards will produce higher yields for the Treasury. At the margin, this rule change can only be bad for the taxpayer."  Righting Another Wrong **********Along with promoting broader distribution of securities at the auctions -- which presumably will make it more difficult for dealers to gain control of a particular security at an auction -- the Treasury also intends to right another wrong Salomon committed by developing a way to prevent primary dealers from placing unauthorized bids on behalf of customers. **********The method under discussion would require customers to send letters of verification to the Treasury before the settlement dates of securities sales indicating they had bid for a certain amount of securities. **********Mr. Kelly, who served as a Treasury official in the Carter Administration, contends that policing firms and their customers in this manner would be inefficient and costly. **********"I already find customers who have indicated reluctance to send letters of any kind to the Fed or Treasury verifying an auction bid," he said. **********"Some customers might find this to be such a nuisance that they choose no longer to bid at the auctions but rather to purchase their securities in the secondary market," he added. "That in turn will transfer the auction risk to the primary dealers."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.main_headline: Ex-Brokerage Officials Accused of Stock Manipulation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.print_headline: Ex-Brokerage Officials Accused of Stock Manipulation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/05/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil securities fraud charges yesterday against three former top officials of the defunct brokerage firm Moore & Schley, accusing them of manipulating the prices of two stocks. **********The charges, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, were an outgrowth of an investigation into the trading of the Chase Medical Corporation's stock. The S.E.C. had previously said that shares of the small Florida health-care provider were "cornered" in late 1988 by two Moore & Schley brokers, whose clients had purchased all of the available shares. **********The new charges say the two brokers, who have pleaded guilty to criminal securities fraud charges and will be sentenced this year, were not acting as rogue brokers but were following the brokerage firm's policy. The firm ran out of funds in part because of losses caused by a collapse of what the charges say were efforts to corner Chase Medical's stock. **********The Moore & Schley officials who were charged yesterday are John J. Cranley Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., who was managing partner; Thomas Core of Manhattan, a partner and branch office manager, and Robert Sayegh of Manhattan, the partner in charge of trading. All three men are now employed by Jesup, Josephthal & Company, a Manhattan brokerage. **********Reached at his office, Mr. Sayegh said, "I have no knowledge" of the charges, but declined further comment. Mr. Cranley and Mr. Core did not return telephone messages. **********Mr. Cranley was also a director of the Institute of Clinical Pharmacology, an Irish company whose shares were underwritten in the United States by Moore & Schley. The price of those shares collapsed after Moore & Schley went out of business in 1989. The charges accuse the defendants of manipulating the stock's price. **********The latest charges appear to be based on statements by Vincent Militano and Milton Sonneberg, the two former brokers. Civil charges are still pending against them. **********The S.E.C. contended that the brokers and their customers had amassed a stake in Chase Medical that amounted to more than the number of publicly traded shares, hoping to profit from short-sellers, who had borrowed shares and sold them in the hope that the price would decline. **********Also named in the case were two of Mr. Militano's customers, John Kolb of Wantagh, L.I., and Carl Varrone of Dix Hills, L.I., who were accused of making large profits by trading in Chase Medical securities without putting up money, and of lying to S.E.C. investigators. Jonathan Lagemann, a lawyer for Mr. Kolb, said there was "no basis" for the charges. Mr. Varrone's telephone number is unlisted. **********The S.E.C. asked that the defendants be barred from violating securities law and required to surrender illegal profits, which it put at $50,000 for Mr. Kolb, $203,000 for Mr. Varrone, $245,000 for Mr. Militano and $178,000 for Mr. Sonneberg. It did not give figures for the other defendants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/busin.main_headline: Impact of Easing of Credit May Be Most Vital '91 Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/busin.print_headline: TROUBLED TIMES ON WALL STREET: AS THE BEAR WANDERS, AN INDUSTRY REMAKES ITSELF; Impact of Easing of Credit May Be Most Vital '91 Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/busin.body_text: **********As bear markets go, this one so far has been much more alarming to the brokers than to the investors. But if the current recession ends up lasting longer, and going deeper, than is currently expected, that relatively happy outcome could change. **********To be sure, 1990 was no fun for anyone involved in the stock market, with the possible exception of the short-sellers, who seek to profit from lower prices. For the first time since 1981, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index showed a loss for a year, falling 6.6 percent before dividends. **********In 1991, the most important issue for investors may be just how much impact the Fed's easing of interest rates has on the economy. Rebound or Lag **********If it helps to shorten the recession by getting businesses and consumers to step up spending, then the rebound that began last October may be not just a bear-market rally but the beginning of a bull market. But if the pressures of debt, and the banks' new-found fear of bad loans, keep a lid on economic activity, then this bear market could have a way to go. **********The carnage last year was worse for the brokerage industry than for investors. On Wall Street, the leveraged escapades of the 1980's left one big firm bankrupt and several others dependent on rich parents for capital infusions. With trading volume down and institutional commissions measured in pennies a share, few equity desks on Wall Street are making money. There are rumors of many more pink slips in this new year. Worst Showing Since 1974 **********Wall Street's problems are more accurately reflected in the performance of the vast majority of stocks, whose owners can only look at the narrower gauge of the S.& P. performance with jealousy. The Nasdaq composite, which measures stocks traded over the counter, fell 17.8 percent in 1990, its worst showing since it plunged 35.1 percent in 1974. **********The dismal performance seems not to have concerned a lot of investors much. It has become commonplace to note that many institutions are invested a lot more bullishly than their managers talk, and individual investors poured money into stock mutual funds for almost the entire year, although there were reports of a slowdown in the final weeks of December. In the aftermath of the 1987 crash, many investors concluded that the crash created great investment opportunities, and that bottom-fishing mentality has remained alive. **********Only a year ago, the conventional wisdom on Wall Street was that the economy was slowing, but a recession would be avoided. Now the general expectation is that there is a recession that began sometime this summer or fall, but that it will be relatively mild. 'A Complacent View' **********"I think investors now are taking a complacent view," said Abby Joseph Cohen, who began 1990 as chief investment strategist at now-bankrupt Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and ended it with the title of co-chair of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs. "They think the recession will be short and sweet, but we don't know how much damage it will do to corporate profits." **********Historically, stocks have performed poorly early in a recession, but have tended to rise in the last half of the downturn, as the market anticipates the recovery. Optimists have hoped that the rebound that began after most stocks bottomed in October might be evidence that the economic downturn will be a mild one, but Mrs. Cohen is among the analysts who think that the huge debt burden confronting corporate America may serve to extend this downturn. **********Those who are pessimistic recall the 1973-74 recession, where large stocks also outperformed the market as a whole in the early going. In 1974, the S.& P. 500 fell by 17.4 percent, while the Nasdaq composite was off 31.1 percent. The next year, the S.& P. dropped 29.7 percent, while the Nasdaq index plunged 35 percent.  Depressed Industries Lifted **********In 1990, big was best in stocks, and small was worst. Financial stocks were out of favor, and makers of consumer staples -- toothpaste and soft drinks and the like -- were the Wall Street darlings for their profits that kept rising despite economic problems. But the late rally tended to lift such depressed industries as banks and home builders more than other shares, though not nearly enough to allow them to break even for the year. **********Among the major gauges, the Dow Jones industrial average, composed of only 30 large stocks, was the best performer for 1990. In July, long after indexes of smaller stocks had peaked, the Dow average topped 3,000 in several sessions, but never was able to close that high, hitting 2,999.75 on two occassions. But it started down even before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, stirring war fears and driving up oil prices. **********For the year, the Dow fell just 4.3 percent before dividends, and less than one percentage point if those payouts are included. The Dow gets the most publicity, and its action may help to explain the relative lack of investor reaction.  Index Up 2.9 Percent **********Of the 20 largest companies in market capitalization at the end of 1989, 11 saw their share prices rise in 1990, and a capitalization-weighted index of the 20 was up 2.9 percent. **********By contrast, the Russell 2,000 measures the performance of the companies that rank from 1,001 to 3,000 in market capitalization. That index fell 21.5 percent in 1990. **********For fans of small stocks, the recent past has been a dreary history of underperformance, beginning in the summer of 1983, when seven years of outperformance by the small stocks came to an abrupt end. The Nasdaq industrial index is down six-tenths of a percent from where it stood on June 24, 1983. By contrast, the Dow industrials are up 112.1 percent over that period. **********But in the last couple of months of 1990, the losers early in the year started to do better. Some of the hardest-hit areas of the market rallied, among them the banks and the homebuilders. And the Russell 2,000 gained 11.2 percent in the final two months, while the S.& P. 500 added just 8.6 percent. **********The average New York City bank stock fell 39.5 percent in 1990, but it was up 21.1 percent over the final two months. Regional banks, which had not fallen as far, also did not bounce as high. The Nadsdaq bank index, down 34.8 percent for the year, gained 7.7 percent in the final two months. Expectations Confounded **********As 1990 began, the general expectation was for lower interest rates, but rates confounded those expectations and rose early in the year. Rates came down in late 1990 as the Federal Reserve tried to contain recessionary pressures, but long-term rates nonetheless were up for the year. The rate on 30-year Treasury bonds, at 7.97 percent a year ago, now is 8.29 percent. But the rate on three-month Treasury bills dropped from 7.60 percent to 6.44 percent. **********The rise in long-term interest rates may help to explain the relatively poor performance of utility stocks. The Dow utility average was down 10.8 percent for the year, despite the reputation of the stocks as the kind to own in downturns. **********Charles Clough, the chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, argues that utilities now represent the best values in the market, simply because their dividends appear to be safe at a time when the pressures of debt and recession are likely to make many other companies cut payouts. "Income may be the thing that is in short supply in the 1990's," he said, forecasting that interest rates will decline sharply. **********As it is, 1990 was one of the worst years for dividend payouts in recent years, although final figures are not in. The fact that many large companies did acceptably well helped overall dividend payments to rise, but more companies cut their payouts than in any year since 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/04/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Time's Blending Print With Video
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/04/busin.body_text: **********Even as the formidable impact of television news is forcing Time magazine to redefine itself, the Time Inc. Magazine Company is vigorously developing new ways to use television to market its magazines. **********Some Time magazine correspondents now carry small eight-millimeter cameras when they go out on assignments in order to shoot footage for possible use on network and local television. **********For instance, when William Dowell, the chief of Time's Cairo bureau, was in Kuwait last spring covering the oil fires, he also filmed them. After he had finished his report for the magazine, he narrated a piece for television and shipped it to New York. The footage was sold to "The McNeil/ Lehrer Newshour" and later to "CBS This Morning."  Looking to Be 'a Major Player' **********"We started about a year ago to familiarize ourselves with the whole TV-video end of the business," said Robert Miller, president of Time Publishing Ventures, who is exploring television possibilities for all the magazines. "At some point, I like to think we would be a major player in television." **********Joe Quinlan, a former television journalist, has been working at the Time Inc. Magazine Company for more than a year to combine the journalistic resources of the magazines with the television production and distribution companies owned by Time Warner Inc. **********"If there is a way to make ourselves available, almost like a joint venture, with these companies, we'll do it," he said. **********Entertainment Weekly magazine, for example, now produces a four-minute weekly program about its next issue for Home Box Office, another unit of Time Warner. **********"The next step is why doesn't Entertainment Weekly have its own program," Mr. Quinlan said.  Promoting the Magazines **********The primary purpose of these ventures into television is, of course, to promote the company's magazines. As a news-gathering operation, however, Time is also interested in disseminating information to the widest possible audience. Some people worry that this duality of purpose poses a troublesome blurring of the lines between the editorial and business sides and fear that it could lead to the manipulation of news for marketing purposes. **********On Oct. 19, the day before Time published its exclusive excerpts from Oliver L. North's new book about his role in the Iran-contra affair, Time distributed a television news spot promoting its report. The networks, the Cable News Network and many local stations broadcast parts of the news spot, attributing it to Time. **********But "NBC Nightly News," in what it says was an oversight, used parts of the news spot without identifying Time as the source. "It wasn't by design," said Don Browne, executive vice president at NBC News. "Our policy is to identify that kind of video, but it was late in the day and it didn't appear." **********As a result, many viewers were unaware that some of the video they were seeing was not produced by NBC as a news report, but by Time as a marketing tool.  'Some Kind of Alert' **********"Given the importance and reliance that people put on television news, I believe that they minimally should have some kind of alert when this stuff comes into their living rooms that it was produced by a promotional source," said Eugene Secunda, professor of marketing at Baruch College and co-author of "Shifting Time and Space: The Story of Video-Tape." **********The problem arises mostly at local television stations, which are under increasing pressure to get good ratings while cutting costs. Every day, these stations are offered an array of video news releases that are often more professionally produced than anything they could afford to do. The temptation is to broadcast these videos without giving credit. **********David Smith, vice president and senior consultant at Frank N. Magid Associates, a media and marketing research and consulting firm, said many video news releases were promotions disguised as news, like a tour of a tire factory that claimed to make a new kind of tire. **********"It might be done very much as a news feature story," he said. "Since it's just the way the station would do the same story, you are not as suspicious as you should be of the marketing angle." **********Professor Secunda sees other potential problems. "If you are Time and are trying to promote a particular issue, you use whatever influence you might have on various electronic media owned by Time Warner," he said. "But I do have a problem with the increased integration of media ownership so that Time magazine begins to have a certain favored edge or favored relationship with electronic media owned by Time Warner. It certainly begins to cut down on the diversity of points of view." **********Since neither of Time magazine's main competitors, Newsweek and U.S. News & World Report, belongs to a giant multimedia conglomerate like Time Warner, they do not have the resources to market themselves as efficiently on television. **********Diana Pearson, a spokeswoman for Newsweek, said the magazine did not produce video news releases and "would feel very uncomfortable trying to present a news story for someone else to transmit." **********Both magazines are involved to some extent in creating specials for television. Newsweek will do a program next spring with MTV on "kids and politics." U.S. News produced a multipart television series on winners of the Congressional Medal of Honor last year. **********"Every year, we do six television tie-ins or presentations on CNBC based on our back-of-the-book features on careers and best colleges," said Mortimer B. Zuckerman, chairman and editor in chief of U.S. News.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/08/busin.body_text: **********California's big banks are being hit with some big shocks, and the state's slumping economy is just one of them. **********A Labor Department report issued on Friday, showing that California's unemployment rate surged in June to its highest level in seven years, underscored the difficult economic climate facing the state's four largest banking companies: the BankAmerica Corporation, the Security Pacific Corporation, Wells Fargo & Company and the First Interstate Bancorp. **********The state's unemployment rate jumped to 8.2 percent in June, up from 7.7 percent in May and 5.1 percent in June 1990. It was the highest jobless rate in California since March 1984, when the rate reached 8.3 percent. The national unemployment rate in June was 7 percent, the Labor Department said.  Three Increase Reserves **********Analysts said the sharp rise in unemployment reflected broad problems in the state's economy, including the effects of a drought, the slowdown in Pentagon spending, an overbuilt commercial real estate market as well as the national recession. And the unemployment rate explains some of the problems behind the large increases in loan-loss reserves taken in recent weeks by Security Pacific, Wells Fargo and First Interstate. **********Because of the additions to their reserves, Security Pacific and Wells Fargo said they would post sharply lower earnings for the quarter ended June 30; First Interstate said it would post a loss for the period. **********BankAmerica said that it was having more problems in many parts of its loan portfolio but that they were more than offset by improvement in its loans to other countries. BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, said it expected its second-quarter earnings to be flat compared with the similar period a year earlier.  Basically Sound **********The California banks are still basically strong, analysts said, and no one sees evidence yet that any of them will suffer the devastating losses like those that crippled many banks in the Northeast, Texas and other markets suffering from prolonged economic and real estate troubles. **********But the deteriorating condition of the California banks' loan portfolios has burst a recent surge in confidence among investors that the banks would weather the recession without much difficulty. **********With business slow, more companies, especially those with heavy loads of debt, are having difficulty meeting all of their payments. Developers and owners of commercial real estate are having trouble filling office buildings and shopping centers, putting more real estate loans in jeopardy. **********"The common thread in what's happening to the banks is the softening California business climate and the slumping commercial real estate market," said Denise Petsis, an analyst at Argus Research in New York. **********After running up sharply this spring, Wells Fargo's stock closed at $66.50 a share on Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, up $1.125 for the day but down nearly a third from its peak of $98.75 in early June. First Interstate's shares have fallen from a high of $42.50 this year to $26.75 a share, up 12.5 cents on Friday. **********Security Pacific's shares have dropped from a recent high of $33.125 two months ago to $21.125 on Friday, down 12.5 cents on the day. Even BankAmerica, which was hurt the least by loan problems in the second quarter, saw its stock driven down from $40.375 a share earlier this year to $34.50 a share on Friday, up $1 for the day. **********In addition to the difficulties posed by the California economy, the banks are also paying a price for the business strategies they pursued in recent years. **********First Interstate, based in Los Angeles, was battered in the second quarter by its push into neighboring states, with its Nevada and Oregon operations reporting more loan problems. Security Pacific, also based in Los Angeles, suffered from loans it made in Britain and Australia. The problems of Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, were mainly with companies that borrowed heavily to finance buyouts or other transactions. **********"Each of their operations and loan compositions are different," Ms. Petsis said.  Tougher Regulation **********Moreover, the banks are contending with regulators who are suddenly applying stricter standards than ever, in some cases forcing the banks to deal more aggressively with potentially troubled loans than the institutions think is necessary. **********"It appears that regulators are applying the same generally tougher standards they were in the East last year," said Mark Lynch, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. **********At Wells Fargo, the company's addition of $350 million to its reserves for bad loans was made primarily at the direction of Federal banking regulators from the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, industry executives said. In announcing the step on June 25, Wells Fargo pointedly noted that it was counting among its potentially bad loans about $400 million on which the borrowers were up to date on all interest and principal payments. About half of those loans were related to buyouts or other deals that regulators called highly leveraged transactions. **********An industry publication, The American Banker, has reported that the regulators based their decisions about the loans' soundness on their assessment of the borrowers' prospects several years in the future, a new approach that Wells Fargo strongly objected to. **********A spokeswoman for Wells Fargo declined to comment, and a spokesman for the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency could not be reached. **********Similarly, regulators reportedly took a very hard line with First Interstate, creating serious disagreements with the bank's managers, especially in Nevada. Donald Snyder, chairman of First Interstate's Nevada bank, resigned in the wake of the intense regulatory scrutiny, as did the Nevada bank's president and several other top lending officers.  Softness in Real Estate **********One big uncertainty now facing California banks is the real estate market. Residential real estate is showing signs of bouncing back after a period of little sales activity and declining prices in many markets. The commercial market is very slow and is plagued by an excess of available space, especially in Southern California. **********In making its earnings projection last week, Security Pacific said it was adding $200 million in commercial real estate loans to its pool of troubled loans. Wells Fargo said real estate loans were not a serious factor in its problems. First Interstate reported some moderate problems and warned that the California real estate market "retains elements of unpredictability that may result in changes in the level of nonperforming assets, as well as in further exposure to credit losses." **********The other big question is how soon the state's once-robust economy will bounce back. Economists said California will probably lag the national recovery from the recession because the drought, continuing layoffs in the aerospace business and a bad slump in housing construction will continue for some months at least. **********The state's budget crisis is not helping, either. The package of tax increases and spending cuts being pieced together by Governor Pete Wilson and the Legislature to close a $14.3 billion budget deficit could leave consumers and businesses with less money to spend. More layoffs in state and local government could also result.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/busin.print_headline: FORUM; Advice Every Investor Should Ignore
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/busin.body_text: **********I Have been advising people about how to invest their money for 38 years. What I have learned is simple: You have to forget about forecasting the markets and the professionals who say they can. **********But what do you do now, with a war going on, with a recession, with a $3 trillion Federal deficit and a crisis in the savings and loan and banking industries? What do you do when there's not much happening to make you feel confident? The answer is the same. Concentrate on your needs. **********From my experience, it is important to remember that every buyer, every seller and every investor in the stock and bond markets is taking into account the same bad news. **********They have been buying, selling or holding whatever investments they have made based on that information. This means the bad news has already had its impact on the markets and on prices. **********Since the bad news is already factored in, it is only the unexpected news that will move prices one way or another. And since no one can forecast the unexpected, it is important to keep a cash reserve. These are uncertain times and no one really knows what will happen. **********However, to decide where to invest, I tell people to work backward. If you need $10,000 a year in income, look at Treasury bills, bonds and notes. If interest rates are 8 percent on a five-year Government bond, you must invest $125,000 at 8 percent to get the income you need. **********But the truth is, no one knows what interest rates and bond prices are going to be. So just buy whatever bonds you must have to live on at the current rates -- but no more -- and hope for the best. But buy only the highest-quality bonds. It's mindless to take risk -- any risk -- to get one more percentage point of income. And owning bonds, even Governments bonds, represents a risk. **********The problem with bonds is that inflation is grinding down the value of the money you make from them. So with your remaining investment capital, you should invest for growth in stocks. **********Historically, across the broad stock market, stocks have been high when the average price has been about 20 times the average earnings per share. But when you think about the price-earnings ratio, you must also think about inflation. **********The relationship between the rate of inflation and the price-earnings ratio of the broad market represents the impact of inflation on stock market prices. Based on what I have seen in the last 30 years, the annual rate of inflation -- now about 4 percent -- must be added to the price-earnings ratio, which is currently about 14. These two numbers together equal 18, which tells me that stocks are no great bargain either. **********Because stocks are no big bargain, I would not invest too much in the stock market. I would hold back and wait for a big market break before I invested more than a fifth of my money in stocks. I would watch for a break big enough to make the front pages of the newspapers before I bought more stock. But what to buy? **********To be honest, I really don't know. Who really does? So stick with a high-quality mutual fund. **********In the end, my advice is simply to forget the advice of professionals. Forget people who talk about market timing and asset allocation. That's just another way of telling you that they can forecast the unexpected. They can't. In the end, what I have learned, is that every investor is pretty much on his own.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/28/busin.main_headline: Economic Watch; Soviet Debt Deal May Add To Problems of the Republics
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/28/busin.print_headline: Economic Watch; Soviet Debt Deal May Add To Problems of the Republics
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/28/busin.body_text: **********Can anyone spare a dime? The leaders of the Soviet republics, who were hoping for a coin or three in return for assuming the Soviet Union's debts, were left empty-handed last week. While the West agreed to a delay in repayment of the principal through 1992, the deal offered no money to slow the republics' perilous financial decline. **********Indeed, the negotiation with the United States and its major economic allies in Moscow may have added to the republics' economic woes by highlighting both the division of interests between the Russian Federation and the Ukraine and Washington's indecision on aid. **********Russian leaders, eager to put the best possible spin on the agreement, point out that it gives the West explicit leverage over plans for creating a market economy in the republics. And that arrangement improves the prospects for a "grand bargain" on the financing of reforms. "It was a willing surrender by Russia," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. **********By conventional yardsticks, the Soviet foreign debt is quite modest. Official Russian estimates put hard-currency debts to governments, banks and private businesses in the range of $80 billion. Planecon, a Washington consulting firm specializing in Eastern European economies, pegs the net debt -- Soviet obligations less sums owed to Moscow -- at about half that. But even the higher official number "would be the envy of most developing countries," said Darryl McLeod, an economist at Fordham University. **********The $80 billion represents one and a half times current annual Soviet export earnings -- and just 7 percent of the Soviet G.N.P. Mexico, by contrast, owes 2.5 times as much as it earned from exports in 1990. Even South Korea owes foreigners the equivalent of 17 percent of its G.N.P. **********The catch, of course, is that the Mexican and South Korean economies are stable and growing, while lenders doubt both the capacity and the will of the former Soviet republics to service a foreign debt. While Soviet hard currency earnings will actually be higher this year than last because former East bloc trading partners are now required to pay their bills in dollars, signs of the rapid deterioration in Soviet creditworthiness are still plain to those who care to look. **********Soviet gold reserves, the former union's rainy day fund, now stand at 240 tons -- hardly enough to cover a month's worth of imports. The production of oil, along with natural gas and weapons, the Soviets' most reliable source of hard-currency revenues, has fallen by a sixth since the peak in 1987. And while David Johnson, an economist at Planecon, notes that the decline largely reflects poor physical management of the oil reserves, production problems are rapidly being compounded by organizational chaos. For example, critical oilfield machinery is desperately scarce because the factory in Azerbaijan has been plagued by the conflict between Muslims and Armenian Christians.  Spending on Imports **********What is more, the pressure to spend foreign exchange earnings on imports rather than interest payments grows as domestic deliveries of consumer goods falter. Morgan Guaranty estimates that Soviet factories idled for want of parts and supplies will make 15 percent less this year than last. The 1991 harvest was also smaller than expected because farms were short of everything from tractor fuel to fertilizer. And farmers are shipping less of what they produce because they are less than eager to trade food and fiber for rubles that buy nothing. **********It is thus no surprise that private foreign lenders are scrambling to trim their exposure, canceling short-term credits that had previously been renewed routinely. Even before the August coup attempt, Susanne Gehler of Morgan Guaranty in London predicted that Soviet short-term debts to Western banks and suppliers would be reduced by $5 billion this year. And with the cupboard otherwise bare -- hard currency reserves are reportedly down to a few billion dollars -- it was obvious the republics would be forced to default on billions in longer-term debts scheduled to be repaid next year. **********What was not obvious, is that the response to the impending debt crisis from the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada would be so limited, said Jeffrey Sachs, an economist at Harvard and consultant to the Russian government. **********The deal proposed by the Western finance ministers and signed last week by their counterparts from eight republics requires the republics to assume joint responsibility for Soviet debts and to keep current on all interest payments. In return, the Western governments agreed to look the other way when $3.6 billion in principal payments due this year and next fail to arrive. The finance ministers also implied that they would lean on Western (mostly European) banks that hold billions in Soviet i.o.u.'s to make parallel concessions.  Pawnshop Operation **********But the only cash the West put on the table was a $1 billion line of credit, to be secured by $1 billion of Soviet gold. This pawnshop operation does spare the republics the embarrassment of selling the last of their gold, but as Mr. Hormats of Goldman Sachs said, the Western governments "certainly got a lot for their money." **********One unintended result of the hard-nosed bargaining is a further fraying of the inter-republic fabric. While the Ukraine was reportedly willing to guarantee a share of Soviet debt, it balked at Western demands that each republic be responsible for the whole. That can only add to the temptation for the Russian Federation to go its own economic way, Ms. Gehler of Morgan Guaranty suggested. **********Western economists are virtually of one voice in urging the opening of borders to inter-republic trade. But the path of least domestic political resistance for Russia, which sells more within the union than it buys, is to require all trade with other republics be settled in dollars at world prices. This would give Russia the ability to divert substantial amounts of oil for sale in the West much the way the demise of the East bloc market created a surge in hard-currency sales for the Soviet Union. **********This might damage Russia's economic prospects almost as much as it damaged the oil-importing republics. After all, a substantial portion of Russian exports to other republics consists of manufactured goods that no one would buy if they had to pay hard currency. **********But Ms. Gehler of Morgan Guaranty pointed out that it took a year for the former East bloc economies to have second thoughts and begin to reconstruct internal barter arrangements -- a year in which trade between the Soviet Union and its former satellites fell by half, stranding hundreds of thousands of workers in enterprises with nothing worth selling. **********The best hope, said Graham Allison at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, is that the debt deal will suck Western governments into the elusive "grand bargain," rewarding a rapid Soviet transition to democratic capitalism with dollars, yen and Deutsche marks. While the agreement offers no money beyond the modest gold swap, it does say that the debt deferral would be renewed beyond 1992 if the republics follow the International Monetary Fund's advice on economic reforms. **********Such leverage, Mr. Allison said, "is a step down a slippery slope," toward taking broader responsibility for the economic fate of the shattered Soviet empire.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Once again, sales of Girl Scout cookies represent a leading economic indicator. Despite the refusal of certain stick-in-the-mud economists to look beyond housing starts and manufacturers' inventories, key questions about the vitality of our economy can be answered with but a single glance at the Girl Scout Pocket Order Form that I carried in my briefcase to the office through cookie-selling season. **********In fact, this year's economic revelations began a solid week before the date I had penciled in for my first call on Mahogany Row. I was still sharpening up my sales pitch when one of our senior vice presidents knocked on my door. **********"Turn in your merit badge, bub," said the heavy lifter. "The competition is eating your lunch." **********The facts behind this barb were quickly uncovered. This fast-track executive from another department was not only selling cookies for his daughter, he had already moved into my territory. **********Naturally, the development sparked my competitive spirit, especially when in the midst of our Monday morning management meeting, the lifter asked if I had any extra order forms. Being a marketing man, I knew that to achieve an edge, I needed "a point of difference." The next day, I drove home at lunchtime and brought back my 9-year-old daughter, Abigail, in full Brownie regalia.  In no time at all, she had passed her quota of 65 boxes and was eligible for her prize, a Cheetah charm. My reward was spiritual. **********This year, like last, the data I collected highlighted the fundamentally conservative nature of the American consumer. This is demonstrated, first, by strong Thin Mints sales. Thin mints represented a full 37 percent of my orders. Peanut butter cookies, both the patties and the sandwiches, were also strong performers, demonstrating, I suspect, a universal desire to return to a time when life's problems could be solved with a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. **********And the surprise hit this year was the Caramel DeLite, which accounted for 13 percent of our orders. Sales of this cookie, with a list of ingredients that would send nutritionists racing for their cholesterol testers, indicate that the hedonism of the 1980's hasn't vanished completely. It's just been relegated to the cookie jar.
