https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia will again have to borrow billions of dollars on international markets if it is to repay its Persian Gulf war contribution to the United States soon, Western diplomatic sources say. **********But senior Saudi officials said the kingdom currently had no plans to raise additional international loans. It resorted to borrowing $3.6 billion earlier this year, its first borrowing since the 1960's. **********"There are no specific plans at the moment for any new borrowing on international markets," said Hamad al-Sayari, governor of the Saudi Monetary Agency, the kingdom's central bank. **********The Western diplomats, who spoke on condition of not being identified further, said the United States had been seeking a timetable for Saudi Arabia to repay $8 billion it still owes in war costs. The Saudis pledged $13.5 billion in cash and ground support services. **********There have been moves in Congress to bar weapons sales to any country that does not provide a timetable for paying its gulf war contributions. **********One diplomat said the Saudis, facing their tightest budget crunch in years, had few options in raising money quickly. **********"Their only alternative is more borrowing on international markets," the diplomat said. "The downside is that they'll be criticized domestically for paying interest." The payment of interest is forbidden by Islamic law and has been criticized by Muslim conservatives.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/busin.body_text: **********President Fernando Collor de Mello has scored a populist victory here in a shouting match with the International Monetary Fund, which acceded to his demand yesterday that Jose Fajgenbaum, an Argentine economist, be removed as head of the fund's negotiating team in Brasilia. He is to be replaced Thursday by Sterie Baza, an American. **********In the morning, demonstrators greeted the President, waving signs reading, "Long live Collor! I.M.F., Respect our people!" and "Brazil is not a colony!" Headlines proclaimed "I.M.F. backs down," and "I.M.F. heeds Collor."  Debate Over Motives **********In more sophisticated circles, analysts were debating today whether Brazil's shouting match with the fund actually represented a new, populist turn in economic policy, or a clever piece of political theater. Some suggested that Mr. Collor might have stage-managed it to make an eventual accord with the fund more palatable at home. Debt-rescheduling talks with the fund resumed today after a three-day suspension. **********The confrontation between Brazil, the third world's largest debtor, and the fund started last Thursday when the Jornal do Brasil, a newspaper, reported that Mr. Fajgenbaum had said Brazil could straighten out its finances only when it changed clauses in its Constitution that mandate generous federal revenue sharing with states and muncipalities. **********"He's the one who should get his own house in order," President Collor snapped in response, demanding Sunday that the Washington-based organization recall him. "For someone from outside to come and give us tips is inadmissible."  Statements Are Denied **********Mr. Fajgenbaum denied that he had made the statements, but his denial had no effect. **********Many analysts here suggest Mr. Collor's highly confrontational stand was intended to defuse future left-wing opposition to constitutional changes of the kind the Fund representative was advocating. **********"He is playing up a basically insignificant thing to show the domestic audience how tough he is," one Brazilian businessman said, noting that by law Mr. Collor needs the Senate's approval for debt-rescheduling agreements. **********But other analysts feared the verbal sparring could signal a new phase of Brazilian intransigence that could slow Brazil's return to the good graces of the international banking community. **********An agreement to reschedule $8.5 billion in overdue interest has been reached with representatives of foreign commercial banks, but must be endorsed by 95 percent of the creditors before it takes effect. The pact, which is the only debt rescheduling of Mr. Collor's 16-month-old Government, has been ratified by 280 banks, or about half the total. **********"People here are very concerned; they don't want the arrears deal to fall through," Riordan A. Roett, a Brazil expert, said today from New York where he is a bank consultant. **********Brazil's left views the fund as a meddling policeman for capitalist banks. Now, Mr. Collor, a free market conservative, is taking the same view, giving rise to such anxieties. **********"The Government should reject this inadmissable interference and send this technician out of the country on the first plane," said Roberto Freire, a Congressman for the Brazilian Communist Party. **********Brazil has not had an agreement with the fund since early 1989. A new accord could involve the disbursement of up to $2 billion in low-interest loans to Brazil over 18 months. But the true significance of an accord is that it signals private bankers that Brazil's finances are in order.  Talks on $52 Billion in Debt **********Next month, talks are to start in New York over rescheduling Brazil's $52 billion medium- and long-term foreign debt. Without an I.M.F. accord, there is little chance that the bankers will sign an agreement. **********In constrast, Argentina's Central Bank president, Roque Fernandez, announced today that the fund is to approve a $1 billion standby loan to Argentina on Monday. **********Brazil's progress on debt talks -- and Mr. Collor's position -- will no doubt be of considerable interest to an American business mission scheduled to arrive in Brasilia in two weeks, led by Vice President Dan Quayle and by Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher. **********In recent days, Mr. Collor has openly expressed frustration with a perceived lack of support from the developed world.  Plan for Rain Forests **********During last week's summit meeting in London, Brazil expected that the Western powers would give Brazil $1.5 billion for a three-year rain-forest protection plan. Instead, they gave $50 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/busin.main_headline: Using Borrowed Money to Defend Foreign Economies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/busin.print_headline: Using Borrowed Money to Defend Foreign Economies
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********In the Business Diary on Jan. 20, the headline on the lead item read, "Why Can't America Make a VCR to Match Its F-117?" The article cited the manifest technological superiority of American weapons and asked: Why can't America "make the world's best VCR's? Or compact cars?" **********The answer is very simple. We put our best brains and much of our research money into designing high-technology weapons of destruction. Our competitors, in contrast, put theirs to work to develop computer technology and consumer goods. And they do that while we are spending money to defend their oil sources -- and having to borrow the money from them to do it.  NIELS H. NIELSEN  New York, N.Y., Jan. 21

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.main_headline: Dow Rises 28.46 Points in Thin Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.print_headline: Dow Rises 28.46 Points in Thin Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.body_text: **********After six declines in a row, buyers moved into the market yesterday, driving stock prices higher for the first time this year. **********Trading remained thin, though, suggesting that most investors were waiting for more promising news. **********Amid deepening pessimism over the economy and the Persian Gulf crisis, the Dow Jones industrial average had plunged 163 points, or 6.2 percent, in the six-day selloff. **********But renewed hope that something would be worked out soon to prevent war lifted the Dow 28.46 points yesterday, to 2,498.76. The advance was fairly widespread: 892 Big Board stocks moved higher while 598 fell. Moreover, 41 fell to new lows. **********Trading continued exceptionally sluggish, with volume slipping to 124.5 million shares, from 191.1 million on Wednesday, the day the Geneva peace talks collapsed. **********Yesterday's volume -- the deadest since New Year's Eve -- suggested that while some traders were looking for the silver lining, many more were waiting for further developments before investing in earnest. **********When the market opens on Monday traders are expected to take their cue from tomorrow's meeting in Baghdad between the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. **********Although stock prices weakened in London amid strong feelings that war seemed closer, traders in this country seemed encouraged by the rise in stock prices in Tokyo. The Dow shot ahead from the opening bell, weakened a little until about 11:15 and moved ahead for the rest of the day. **********Program traders, while active, had only minor impact on price levels. Birinyi Associates said that two buying waves lifted the Dow less than 3 points. **********Losing no time to take Pan Am out of the market averages after it filed for bankruptcy proceedings, the Dow Jones announced after the market close yesterday that it had replaced Pan Am in the Dow transportation index with Roadway Services, operator of Roadway Express, the big trucking company. Traded on the Nasdaq, it is the only Nasdaq stock in any of the Dow averages. **********Roadway rose 1 1/2, to 39 3/4, in heavy trading after rumors of the change circulated in the market. Standard & Poor's dropped Pan Am the day before in the S.&P. 500 and replaced it with Blockbuster, the video rental chain. Blockbuster fell 1/8 yesterday, to 25 3/8, after rising 2 1/8 on the news. **********The Pan Am bankruptcy step brought new developments in several other directions. Pan Am rose 3/8, to 3/4, in heavy trading. **********Kirk Kerkorian, the West Coast financier, said he had accepted an invitation by the Joint Labor Council of Pan Am employees to consider buying the carrier. T.W.A. said it was willing to provide Pan Am $25 million in financing while Pan Am's biggest creditor, the Pension Benefit Guarantee Corporation, asked the bankruptcy court to open the sale of Pan Am's London routes to competition and delay approval for UAL to buy the routes to give Pan Am more time to arrange financing. **********The Dow transportation index rose close to a full percentage point, with UAL, representing most of the gain, climbing 3 1/4, to 114 3/4.  Ford Dividend Cut Expected **********Ford Motor, widely expected to cut its dividend, rose 1/2, to 25 5/8, with 1.3 million shares changing hands after the car producer declared its regular 75-cents-a-share payout. **********General Motors rose 3/8, to 31 7/8, falling back from a high of 32 3/8, after Standard & Poor's said late Wednesday that it might downgrade the credit ratings for G.M., Ford and Chrysler. Chrysler fell 1/8, to 12 1/4. All three are expected to show fourth-quarter losses. **********Digital Equipment, which fell 1 1/8 on Wednesday after saying it would lay off 3,450 workers by June 30, rose 7/8, to 53 1/2, but traded as low as 51 3/4. I.B.M. rose 1 1/2, to 108 3/8 after Rick J. Martin of Prudential-Bache added the stock to the brokerage firm's "single best idea" list.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Supply; BIG SUPPORT TRAIN IS BEHIND ASSAULT
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Supply; BIG SUPPORT TRAIN IS BEHIND ASSAULT
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/world.body_text: **********Following fast on the heels of armor thrusting into Kuwait and Iraq, a vast logistical train must head into the desert to feed, fuel and arm the immense attacking armies of the alliance. **********Without this effort, the rapid progress reported from the war zone would quickly bog down as troops ran out of supplies, beginning with the fuel guzzled by tanks, helicopters and other heavy weapons. **********The logistical plan, set up and rehearsed in detail for many weeks, has been made easier to carry out because the advance met minimal initial resistance. As long as the advancing armies control the ground and the air along the lines of attack, their logistical trains will be relatively safe. **********But paradoxically, the success of the attack so far has probably strained the logistical system, since the rapid advance implies that large quantities of fuel have to be delivered over longer distances than expected.  Advance Ahead of Schedule **********The allied commander has reportedly told his troops to accelerate their pace today, and other senior officers told reporters that the advance was moving ahead of schedule. That means supplies are being used up faster than scheduled. **********To deliver the fuel, tanker trucks must scurry across the desert and transport aircraft must drop off bladders of fuel. **********Special mobile pumping equipment, designed so that many vehicles can simultaneously replenish themselves, allows units to pull in and quickly get back into combat. **********Eventually, pipelines may even be laid to speed the flow of fuel and to free trucks and aircraft for carrying ammunition instead. **********The problem of logistics is nothing new. Commanders have faced the implacable requirements of supplying their forces since Hannibal and before.  Normandy Advance Cited **********Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the allied commander, surely knows what happened to the World War II allies after their breakthrough in France after the invasion of Normandy. One hundred days after D-day, the advance was 200 days ahead of the schedule that logistical planners had provided for. The advance bogged down when it ran too far ahead of its supply train. **********In and around Kuwait, the distances are shorter, the armies smaller and the advance swifter. Even so, without plentiful fuel, General Schwarzkopf's forces would lose their freedom to maneuver across the desert, which is rich in crude oil but without the diesel and other refined fuels required by a modern army. **********The allies' main battle tanks, which are too big and heavy to be delivered by air, crossed the Saudi border carrying enough fuel to reach their first day's objectives deep in Iraq without refueling. They can go nearly 300 miles before refilling. But they measure their fuel consumption in gallons per mile, not the other way around, and every refill soaks up 498 gallons for their thirsty turbine engines. **********When the heavy mechanized and armored divisions begin fighting deep in enemy territory, firepower replaces maneuver in importance, and ammunition rises to the top of the cargo manifests. A multiple rocket launcher, for instance, can shoot only one volley of 12 rockets before it must load a new box of armament onto its rack. **********Finally, food and water rations will have to be delivered after about three days, and the wounded and dead will have to be shipped out. Refueling Base in Iraq **********In some cases, logistical bases may have been set up in advance of the ground forces, for example the helicopter refueling base reportedly set up inside Iraq by the 101st Airborne Division. The base supports the 101st's own activities and could be used as a forward gas station and ammunition dump for armored units approaching overland from the south. **********But most combat units that enter Iraq or Kuwait must set up their own staging areas, usually only after the assault has already moved safely past. The assaulting troops themselves carry a mix of supplies known as a "basic load," sometimes also called "a day of fire." **********Behind every battalion, brigade and division in the battle is a logistical support unit dedicated to passing supplies forward. A 500-man mechanized battalion, for instance, has 12 heavy trucks attached to it. They shuttle back and forth to fuel and ammunition depots 15 miles or so behind the main battle lines. **********The battalion's depots would be supplied from larger ones established by the brigade commander farther back, and he would get the brigade's supplies from the division's stocks, fed in turn from the corps's supplies back in the rear areas. Practice in Landing on Roads **********The fuel and ammunition could have been delivered to the way stations by motorized convoys on the ground, or by big Chinook transport helicopters, or even by C-130 aircraft.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/world.main_headline: GORBACHEV IS TOLD BY KOHL TO OFFER PROOF OF REFORMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/world.print_headline: GORBACHEV IS TOLD BY KOHL TO OFFER PROOF OF REFORMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany urged President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to provide concrete assurances of political and economic reform when he approaches Western leaders for assistance later this month. **********The Soviet President, for his part, pointed to the strife in Yugoslavia "as a lesson and a warning" that his commitment to a united and renewed Soviet Union was the only path. Serving up a graphic illustration of the problem facing Mr. Gorbachev, groups of Ukrainian nationalists waved protest banners at the airport and in Kiev, capital of the Soviet Ukraine. **********Mr. Kohl and Mr. Gorbachev made their comments at a news conference after holding their first meeting since the reunification of Germany in October. It was probably the last meeting Mr. Gorbachev will hold with a major Western leader before seven industrial powers meet in London, where their leaders are expected to discuss aid to the Soviet Union and then hear Mr. Gorbachev. Luxurious Setting **********At the news conference, held after almost five hours of talks at a luxurious Soviet Government estate outside Kiev, neither leader gave any indication that they had reached specific agreements. **********Their meeting, rather, appeared to have been a strategy session at which Mr. Kohl pledged to press Mr. Gorbachev's case in London, and at the same time sought to impress on the Soviet leader that his chances of aid depended on solid evidence of reform. **********"I would like to make clear to all citizens of the Soviet Union, without interfering in the internal affairs of your country, that the success of reforms in your country is not only in the interests of the Soviet population, but in the interests of all Europeans, and especially my compatriots," Mr. Kohl said. **********Mr. Gorbachev has reportedly been working on a presentation for London, and his Government has rushed through Parliament several laws speeding foreign investment. But negotiation on a new union treaty, one among the republics, are the keystone to any meaningful reform. This has been far slower than Mr. Gorbachev had hoped. The Ukrainian legislature, for one, has put off any further consideration of the treaty until fall. **********Mr. Kohl took pains to express his support for the beleaguered Soviet President, declaring that the Germans -- and he personally -- were conscious of their debt to Mr. Gorbachev for enabling the two Germanys to unify. "I simply do not intend to forget this," the Chancellor said. **********"Together with colleagues, I will speak out in London in favor of providing joint assistance in the process of reform and openness within our possibilities and strengths," Mr. Kohl said, adding that he intended to press the case by telephone before the summit meeting. But the German leader gave only vague answers to questions of what might emerge from the summit. **********Mr. Gorbachev similarly argued that Soviet national renewal was criticial for the world, and he seized on a question about events in Yugoslavia to give an impassioned defense of his position. **********"I think what is happening and what we are suffering through in Yugoslavia must force us all to think again and to understand that we must stay the path of renewal, and not disintegration," he said. **********"I will not step from this road under any pressure."  Kohl Prefers Rural Informality **********The two leaders' meeting today took place at Mezhigorye, amid sculptured gardens and forests on the bank of the Dnieper River where the Communist Party chief of the Ukraine used to live. The site was in keeping with Mr. Kohl's preference for meetings outside capital cities, where protocol can be replaced by the chumminess he favors. **********The schedule included a stroll through the woods, and the news conference was held on a lawn. The two men, who have formed a reasonably close relationship in several meetings over the last two years, exchanged quips and generally seemed optimistic as they walked to their news briefing. **********The choice of the Ukrainian capital, however, prompted some protests from Ukrainian legislators, who argued that the President had not consulted with them beforehand, thereby demonstrating a disdain for their claim of sovereignty. Demonstrators from the Rukh nationalist organization heckled the motorcade in Kiev, with one banner reading "Gorbachev, get out of the Ukraine." **********Mr. Gorbachev, nonetheless, took advantage of the visit to hold separate talks with Leonid M. Kravchuk, the president of the Ukrainian Parliament, and other Ukrainian leaders. He also arranged for Mr. Kohl to meet separately with the Ukrainians. "We have to show that we, too, can exploit foreign labor," he quipped.  Matter of Troop Withdrawal **********One issue that was said to have prominently figured in the discussions was Moscow's continuing troop withdrawal from eastern Germany. The Soviet command in Berlin announced today that it was cutting this month's scheduled withdrawal by 30 percent because of housing shortages at home. Germany is also miffed that contracts for housing projects financed by Germans have been granted to non-German firms. **********The leaders gave no indication whether they had reached any agreement on this matter. **********Germany has committed itself to $31 billion in loans, grants and credits to the Soviet Union since Mr. Gorbachev assented to unification. Much of the money has gone to provide housing and other aid for Soviet soldiers returning home. **********Asked about a possible visit by President Bush to Moscow later this month, Mr. Gorbachev said, "I do not exclude that there will be a meeting in July." He said no summit date been set, but that a series of contacts with Mr. Bush had given new impetus to negotiations on a treaty cutting strategic forces by half. **********--------------------       Qualified Approval for Treaty **********MOSCOW, July 5 (Reuters) -- The Parliament of the Russian republic today approved in principle Mr. Gorbachev's battered blueprint to hold the Soviet Union together, but attached tough conditions. **********After a day of wrangling and private negotiations, the Parliament approved the proposed union treaty but called on delegates to the final talks to impose restrictions, including control of taxation and foreign trade for the republic, two areas jealously guarded by Moscow, as well as a broad demand for joint management of all other aspects of political and economic life. **********Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian President, appealed for approval of the measure, saying: "The union treaty is an act of huge political importance, and just to reject it would mean political collapse and the destabilizaion of the country. We should bear in mind this is a negotiating process."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/12/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d held four and a half hours of talks today to try to wrap up the nuclear arms reduction treaty, but Mr. Baker said they had made only limited progress and certainly not enough yet to merit scheduling a Moscow summit meeting in late July. **********The two officials said that they had asked their experts to continue working on the three major outstanding issues holding up the accord and that they would meet again Friday to see if they can close the gaps. **********"We have made progress on some of these, but we clearly have more work to do," Mr. Baker told reporters after today's session. "We still have a good ways to go." 'Meaningful' Soviet Proposals **********Mr. Baker said Mr. Bessmertnykh had brought with him "meaningful" new proposals on the issues of how missiles transmit their data to earth so each side can monitor the other's tests, and on how to define new missiles that will not be covered by the treaty. **********Mr. Baker said he hoped that these Soviet proposals would pave the way for agreement in these areas once the experts have time to go over them fully. But he added that a third issue -- how many warheads should be allowed for each missile -- remained a problem. **********Both President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev have made completion of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start, a condition for holding a full-scale summit meeting in Moscow this summer. Asked if enough progress had been made today to fix a summit date, Mr. Baker answered: "We have not made that kind of progress today. There is still a lot of work to be done." 30 Percent Cut Is Sought **********Before opening the negotiations at the State Department, Mr. Bessmertnykh made it clear that he had come with the authority to reach the compromises necessary to finish the treaty, which will reduce the long-range nuclear missiles and bombers of the two superpowers by 30 percent. **********"We have the position, we have the authority and we have the will to finish the job," he told reporters, with Mr. Baker standing at his side. **********Last weekend, President Bush asked Mr. Gorbachev to send his Foreign Minister to Washington, after lower-level Soviet negotiators in Geneva told their American counterparts that they did not have authority to respond to a series of American compromise proposals for bridging the last differences in the strategic arms treaty. **********The remaining issues holding up the treaty are highly technical, so much so that experts have to do the hard negotiating and then report to Mr. Baker and Mr. Bessmertnykh on their progress. **********"The issues are so technical that in a certain way we are hostages of either crazy professors or some technicians," Mr. Bessmertnykh said. "But we are trying to break down the technicalities of the issue and to make the decisions." **********One of the thorniest issues, known as data denial, involves determining how much and by what means data from missile tests are beamed back to earth, so each side can easily monitor the other's tests and insure that the other side is not developing missiles restricted by the treaty. The draft treaty establishes a ban on encoding missile test data to deny it to the other side, but because the two sides use different frequencies, power levels and techniques, they have to work out common standards. These can involve major, and costly, electronic adjustments. **********Also because the United States tests its missiles over water and is an open society, the Soviets can easily pick up its telemetry signals from offshore ships and obtain other missile data through open sources. But the Soviets test their missiles over land, which makes the data harder to obtain, and have a closed society, so they are being asked to adopt more transparent methods of data transmission. **********The other major outstanding issues involve how to define what will constitute a new missile that will not be covered by the treaty and how each side should actually go about reducing the number of nuclear warheads in each of its missiles so it comes within the treaty limits, but does not allow for too much spare capacity that could be used in the event of a war. **********Earlier in the day, Mr. Baker found broad bipartisan support in the Senate for approval of the other major arms control treaty pending with the Soviet Union -- the non-nuclear arms reduction treaty, which he and Mr. Bessmertnykh finally concluded last month. **********The Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty, or C.F.E. -- which will require the Soviets to withdraw from Europe, or destroy, thousands of tanks, armored personnel carriers and artillery pieces -- was signed in November. But the Administration refused to submit it for ratification to the Senate because of Soviet attempts to reinterpret the treaty in a way that would have allowed them to keep several thousand extra pieces of equipment. After seven months of wrangling, the dispute was finally resolved. **********The Secretary's appeal for treaty approval found no opponents on the committee. Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat, explained why he would vote in favor, saying: "This treaty will eliminate a fundamental cause of tension in Europe since the end of World War II -- that is, the huge numerical advantage of Soviet conventional forces. This superiority threatened the security and prosperity of the West for many years. This superiority also fueled the nuclear arms race. In every strategic doctrine adopted by NATO for 40 years, from massive retaliation to flexible response, nuclear weapons were intended to compensate for the Soviet edge in conventional arms." **********Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican, also argued that the treaty was so tilted to the benefit of the United States and its NATO allies that "I predict it must pass the Senate by a large margin." Helms Doubts Relevance **********The only discordant note was sounded by Senator Jesse Helms, the conservative Republican from North Carolina, who argued that the treaty was largely irrelevant, given the fact that the Warsaw Pact has been disbanded and the Soviets have already been forced to withdraw -- at rates exceeding the treaty -- from most of Eastern Europe by the pro-democracy revolutions there. **********Even Senator Helms acknowledged: "It's true that there may be some marginal utility in the treaty. It does establish guidelines for withdrawal of Soviet troops, and it does set limits on the number of conventional arms and military vehicles that each group of the states party to the treaty may keep west of the Ural Mountains." **********But Senator Helms put Mr. Baker on notice that he would not be so forthcoming when the Secretary tries to win approval for the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, where the issue of verification will be much more important. **********"To put it as politely as possible, the Soviets are cheats and liars and scoundrels," Senator Helms said. "They've proved that through the years. I would get angry about this treaty if it meant anything, in my judgment. But it does mean something for Start. Start, unlike C.F.E., is a treaty that matters. Start needs full scrutiny, even though it may not be possible to ratify it in time to save Mr. Gorbachev."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/world.main_headline: Yeltsin Spurns Gorbachev on Meeting With Bush
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/world.print_headline: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW; Yeltsin Spurns Gorbachev on Meeting With Bush
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/world.body_text: **********President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic spurned President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's invitiation to take part in a summit meeting today with President Bush, saying that his republic would not be part of a "faceless mass audience" and was pursuing its own independent foreign policy with the United States. **********The bold move was intended not as a rebuff to President Bush, who saw Mr. Yeltsin later in a one-on-one meeting in the Kremlin, but rather as an unequivocal notice to Mr. Gorbachev that the Russian federated republic can no longer be counted on as an obedient member of the Soviet retinue, either in the domestic or the foreign arena. **********But Mr. Yeltsin also gave a tremendous lift to Mr. Gorbachev's attempt to forge a new union treaty, which the Soviet President hopes will save the crumbling union by refashioning it into a looser, federal structure. The Russian republic's President announced today that he was ready to sign the agreement after working out questions on taxation with Mr. Gorbachev at a meeting early this morning. **********Mr. Yeltsin pointed out that the same union treaty gave each of the participating republics the right to pursue its own foreign policy, as he had done today. But the dissonance between Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev today could presage future friction between the two leaders, who recently reached what appears to be a precarious peace after months of accusing each other of dictatorial ambitions.  Yeltsin Denies Campaign Plan **********Mr. Yeltsin told CNN in an interview that Mr. Gorbachev's last-minute invitation to him and to Kazakhstan's President, Nursultan Nazarbayev, to take part in expanded meetings between the American and Soviet leaders was suggestive of "past traditions" of discredited Soviet regimes, when republican leaders were pliant players in "mass audiences." **********Mr. Yeltsin said his decision to turn down the Gorbachev invitation, which Mr. Nazarbayev accepted, should not be seen as a step toward usurping power from the Soviet President. In an effort to spare Mr. Gorbachev a "headache," Mr. Yeltsin said he was eager to put to rest any rumors that he might challenge Mr. Gorbachev for the Soviet presidency in the first nationwide elections for a Soviet leader, which are expected to be held next year. **********After a 40-minute session in the Kremlin with Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Bush also stressed that his private negotiations with the Russian President were not intended to undermine the Gorbachev Government. He praised the new era of relations between the Russian republic and the United States that began with Mr. Yeltsin's visit to Washington last month after the Russian President was elected to his new post in a landslide victory. **********"President Yeltsin's visit to the United States was a big hit and furthered not only relations and understanding between the Russian republic and the United States but also the Soviet Union and the states," Mr. Bush said. **********Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin told reporters that they hoped for further economic and political cooperation and they pronounced their meeting a success. **********"I am satisfied," said Mr. Yeltsin. **********Mr. Bush said, "So am I." **********A Western diplomat who has been kept abreast of summit-meeting plans said the American delegation was told before the opening session with Mr. Gorbachev today that Mr. Yeltsin would not attend the meeting because he wanted to emphasize that the central Government would have limited, delineated powers in any new union agreement. **********"It was a declaration of political autonomy," the diplomat said. **********Perhaps more important than Mr. Yeltsin's decision to turn down the Gorbachev invitation was the compromise on the issue of taxation that Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Nazarbayev reached at a meeting that reportedly ended at 3 this morning. **********For months, the dispute over who would have the right to impose taxes in a newly configured union seemed unsolvable. Mr. Gorbachev originally wanted the central Government to keep sole control over taxation, while republic leaders were demanding that power to tax belonged to them.  Union-Treaty Talks **********Leaders from 9 of the 15 Soviet republics have been taking part in negotiations over the shape of the new union, with Georgia, Moldavia, and the three Baltic republics, Latvia, Estonian and Lithuania, refusing to take part. An Armenian delegation has started to attend the meetings but has not decided whether to support the treaty. **********Achieving a union treaty is critical to the Soviet Union's ability to attract aid from Western governments, who have said they see a redistribution of power from the center to the republics as a sign of the Gorbachev Government's commitment to change. **********Mr. Gorbachev's decision to hold union-treaty negotiations during Mr. Bush's first visit to Moscow underscores how important the success of those talks is to the Soviet President.  Social Invitation Accepted **********The tax compromise, which is expected to bolster the treaty's chances of passage, was suggested by Mr. Yeltsin, according to the independent Interfax news agency. Mr. Yeltsin proposed a system under which each republic would impose its taxes and then pay a fixed percentage to the central Government to cover national expenses, like defense, according to reports by Interfax and the Russian Information Agency. **********Though he turned down Mr. Gorbachev's working invitation, Mr. Yeltsin accepted a social invitation from the Soviet President to dine with Mr. Bush at a state dinner in the Kremlin. Mr. Yeltsin arrived late to the dinner, lingered for a long time with Mr. Bush on the receiving line and sat two seats away from Mr. Gorbachev, next to Barbara Bush. **********In a further gesture of support for Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yeltsin told Interfax that after his early morning meeting with Mr. Gorbachev he was convinced that the Soviet President had turned away from the conservative direction took earlier this year. **********"We, the democratic forces, are now sure that the Union President will not let us down, as he did in January, February and March of this year, and will follow the path of democratic reform," he told Interfax. "So we support him."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/world.main_headline: Condemnation And a Halt to Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/world.print_headline: THE SOVIET CRISIS: THE WESTERN ALLIANCE; Condemnation And a Halt to Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/world.body_text: **********Amid strong condemnations of the overthrow of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Western governments demanded today that the new Soviet leadership maintain the ousted leader's reform program and honor Moscow's international commitments. **********The English-speaking allies -- the United States, Britain and Canada -- announced the freezing of economic assistance to the Soviet Union, and European Community foreign ministers scheduled a meeting on Tuesday to discuss a suspension of the Community's $1.5 billion aid program. French and British officials said a summit of Community leaders may also be called to discuss the crisis. **********Some Western European leaders adopted something of a wait-and-see attitude. "We will know very soon," France's President, Francois Mitterrand, said of the new leadership's direction. **********Mr. Mitterrand, who said the first phase of the coup in Moscow had clearly succeeded, was among several Western leaders to receive a personal letter from the new Soviet leader, Gennadi I. Yanayev, in which he pledged that Mr. Gorbachev's program of reforms would continue. **********Mr. Mitterrand and Prime Minister John Major of Britain conferred by telephone, and both leaders also spoke during the day with President Bush, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers of the Netherlands, the country that currently holds the rotating presidency of the 12-nation European Community. **********After an urgent meeting of NATO ambassadors today, it was disclosed that foreign ministers of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization would probably meet in Brussels later this week to analyze whether the coup in Moscow could signal a resumption of the cold war. **********Canada, a NATO member, announced that it was freezing a $131 million program of food aid to the Soviet Union. "We have a Government there that we do not recognize," said Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. "Until that is resolved everything is suspended." **********Britain announced suspension of an $80 million technical assistance program with Moscow. **********Denouncing the "hard-line and reactionary coup," Mr. Major said the Soviet Union's future depends on continuing reforms. "It is in their interests to have reform and it is in the West's interest to see reforms," he said. "But the omens at the moment are not propitious." **********In a television interview, Mr. Mitterrand said the Moscow coup could rapidly become "a cold war act" if the new leadership were to reverse the reform process. **********Holding up what he described as "a rather astonishing letter" he had received from Mr. Yanayev, the French leader quoted it as saying: "Reforms will continue. Our choice is made. We will stick to democracy, glasnost. We will strive to build up the economy, including private enterprise. We shall continue the policy to guarantee civil rights and freedoms." **********Earlier, Mr. Mitterrand issued a statement demanding that Moscow guarantee the "life and liberty" of both Mr. Gorbachev and of the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin. He noted that Mr. Yanayev had assured him in his letter that Mr. Gorbachev is "in perfect safety and nothing threatens him." **********The Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said he was ready to cut short his vacation in Portugal. He expressed hope that Moscow would respect the sovereignty and independence of the countries of Eastern Europe. **********Condemnation of the coup also came from Italy, Spain, Belgium, Turkey, Finland, Denmark and Greece.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/17/world.main_headline: 4 Women Named to Kohl's New Cabinet of 20
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/17/world.print_headline: 4 Women Named to Kohl's New Cabinet of 20
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/17/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his coalition partners announced today that they had chosen a 20-member Cabinet to govern Germany for the next four years. **********Mr. Kohl, whose Christian Democratic Union won an easy victory in last month's election, is to be formally elected to his fourth term as Chancellor at a special parliamentary session scheduled for Thursday. **********Four women were named to the Cabinet, which has never before included more than two women. Three of the new ministers come from whatused to be East Germany. **********Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, whose active style has helped make Germany an important diplomatic power, is to continue in his post. **********Other prominent Cabinet members, including Finance Minister Theo Waigel, Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg, and Interior Minister Wolfgang Schauble will also keep their jobs. **********Mr. Schauble, one of the Chancellor's close proteges, was shot by an apparently deranged assailant in October. He remains in a wheelchair, but has resumed work. **********In the weeks of political negotiations that ended on Tuesday night, Mr.Kohl's Christian Democratic Union and its Bavarian sister, the Christian Social Union, have been under pressure from their small but vital coalition partner, the Free Democrats. The Free Democrats won over 10 percent of the vote in December and insisted that they get their share of power. **********Foreign Minister Genscher, the Free Democrats' most prominent figure, was one of five named today. Others will hold the housing, education, justice, and economics portfolios. **********Some German commentators expressed surprise at the choice of Jurgen Mollemann to be Economics Minister. He was Education Ministerand has no business experience. **********The ministry responsible for most social programs was divided into three, with each of the three ministerial posts going to a woman. There will now be a Health Ministry, a Ministry for Youth and Women, and a Ministry for Families and the Elderly. **********A fourth woman, Irmgard Adam-Schwatzer, a former Foreign Ministry official, was named Minister of Housing Construction. **********One of the three former East Germans named to the new Cabinet, Gunther Krause, was a senior aide to the last East German Prime Minister, Lothar de Maiziere. Mr. de Maiziere had been considered a likely Cabinet minister until he was forced to withdraw from politics last month after revelations that he had been an informer for East Germany's secret police.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Paper Raising Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/04/busin.body_text: **********The St. Louis Post-Dispatch said today that it would raise newsstand and vending machine prices for its daily and Sunday newspapers because of rising costs and declining advertising revenue. On April 15, prices will increase by 25 cents, to 50 cents for the daily paper and $1.25 for the Sunday paper. Rates for subscriptions will not change.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/28/world.main_headline: Bush Renewing Trade Privileges For China, but Adds Missile Curbs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/28/world.print_headline: Bush Renewing Trade Privileges For China, but Adds Missile Curbs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/28/world.body_text: **********Declaring that he is "trying to chart a moral course through a world of lesser evils," President Bush said today that he would continue China's trading privileges for another year. But he sought to lessen the political effect of his decision by imposing new restrictions on missile technology exports to China. **********"We want to promote positive change in the world through the force of our example, not simply profess our purity," Mr. Bush said in a speech to the graduating class at his alma mater, Yale University, that embodied his most detailed explanation to date of a China policy that has put him in regular conflict with Congress. **********"We want to advance the cause of freedom, not just snub nations that aren't yet wholly free," he said.  [ Excerpts, page A8. ] **********Mr. Bush said he would inform Congress this week that China's trading privileges -- known as "most favored nation" status -- are to be continued for another year. The move had been expected since the President said two weeks ago that he wanted to renew China's favorable tariff treatment. **********Many lawmakers have called for the privileges to be revoked to punish Beijing for its crackdown on political activity in 1989, an approach that Mr. Bush strongly rejected today in a move that is sure to lead to a confrontation with Congress. **********The White House announced that Mr. Bush was imposing three new sanctions on China, including blocking the sale to China of high-speed computers used for missile testing. He did not detail those actions in his speech and the White House went out of its way to say that they were not related to the extension of China's trading status. But Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had already proposed them in a recent memo to Mr. Bush as a way of countering Congressional opposition to the trade decision.  Senate Leader Is Critical **********China's trading privileges, guaranteeing the lowest available tariff rates on Chinese goods, expire on July 3. Mr. Bush's action will take effect immediately unless both houses of Congress approve measures to reverse it or attach conditions. At least five measures that would do so are pending. **********A measure of the Congressional displeasure likely to develop was quickly evident. The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, attending a parade in Maine, his home state, called the proposed sanctions a "joke," and pledged to "make every effort to reverse this mistaken policy put forward by the Administration." **********Most-favored-nation status is not normally granted to Communist countries considered in violation of human rights. Mr. Bush said his approach toward China was intended to promote the spread of democracy by remaining economically and politically engaged with the Chinese leadership, although he acknowledged that he still has strong concerns about China's human rights record and that he was following a path with "enormous potential for error and embarrassment." **********Mr. Bush flew here from his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me., under a cloak of secrecy imposed to comply with Yale's tradition of not announcing commencement speakers in advance. **********Students and guests protesting Mr. Bush's policies on civil rights, abortion and other issues were thickly scattered in the audience on the Yale Quadrangle and periodically heckled the President as he spoke. His announcement on trade with China drew hisses and boos, as well as some applause. **********Keenly aware of the growing political opposition, Mr. Bush sought to present his policy on China as a measured mixture of engagement and sanctions. Trying to draw a historic line between his policy and past American actions like the defiance of the Berlin blockade and the institution of the Marshall Plan, he said: **********"This nation's foreign policy has always been more than simply an expression of American interests. It is an extension of American ideals. This moral dimension of American policy requires us to remain active, engaged in the world. Many times, that means trying to chart a moral course through a world of lesser evils. That's the real world, not black and white. Very few moral absolutes." **********Addressing his critics, Mr. Bush said he would hold China to the strictest human rights standards and spoke of sanctions that he imposed against China after the violence in Tiananmen Square and the nationwide crackdown on political activity in 1989. **********The White House said Mr. Bush ordered three measures to limit the export of missile and satellite technology to China: ***********Licenses will be refused to companies that have applied to sell China 20 high-speed computers, valued at $30 million, that can be used for missile flight testing. ***********As long as the United States is not satisfied that China is abiding by inernational regulations restricting the flow of ballistic missile and nuclear technology, licenses will not be granted to American companies seeking to take part in seven proposed satellite launches by China. No such licenses have been requested. ***********American companies will be barred from selling any missile technology or equipment to the Government-run Chinese Precision Machinery Import-Export Corporation. The White House said this action was ordered in response to the Chinese corporation's sale of missile technology and equipment to Pakistan. Steps Outlined by Baker **********The White House sought to play down any connection between these three actions and Mr. Bush's decision to extend China's trading status. "One is not being done to sell the other," said a senior Administration official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. **********All three steps were outlined by Secretary of State Baker in a recent memo to Mr. Bush that proposed a strategy for selling his decision on Chinese trade to a reluctant Congress, officials said. **********The memo also talked about which members of Congress should be lobbied to help Mr. Bush's cause and proposed arguments for defending the decision on trade, some of which were included in Mr. Bush's speech today. **********Mr. Bush made it clear that he was firmly opposed to attaching any conditions to the Chinese trading privileges. **********"Some critics have urged us to revoke M.F.N., or endanger it with sweeping conditions, to censure China, cut our ties and isolate it," Mr. Bush said. "We are told this is a principled policy, a moral thing to do." **********Mr. Bush said continued trade with China was a "means to bring the influence of the outside world to bear" and rejected arguments that a threat to cut the trading rights is a useful lever to improve Chinese human rights policy.                    --------------------       Opposition in Congress **********WASHINGTON, May 27 (Special to The New York Times) -- In offering what critics called decidedly modest restrictions on technology exports to China, President Bush appeared today to have put his Administration on a collision course with Congress over renewing Chinese trade benefits. **********"The issue is joined," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who, citing human rights and other abuses, has introduced a measure to revoke most-favored-nation status that China has enjoyed since 1979. **********Without the benefits, soaring imports of Chinese goods could be subjected to an extra $6 billion a year in tariffs, according to the United States-China Business Council, making a significant proportion of them unmarketable here. China this year is expected to have the second biggest trading surplus with the United States after Japan. **********The disagreement on the issue, which does not closely follow party lines, covers views ranging from the tactical argument of carrot and stick to the moral argument of whether China should receive a benefit denied the Soviet Union, which is liberalizing human rights policies. **********The most-favored-nation designation needs to be renewed each year, a process requiring that the President certify that China is in compliance with the Jackson-Vanik amendment, a measure denying favored-nation status to countries denying free emigration. **********The President's contention that China can be induced by trade and other contacts to make accommodations on human rights, weapons proliferation and religious freedom is disputed by many Democrats and some Republicans. The critics find no appreciable shift so far and say it is also morally wrong for China to enjoy privileges denied the Soviet Union. **********"We don't want to reward them for behavior we find evil" and which may be getting worse, Senator Moynihan declared.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Canada; Canadians Enter Gulf War, Sparking Debate
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Canada; Canadians Enter Gulf War, Sparking Debate
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/28/world.body_text: **********Canadian forces went to war last week against Iraq, and although their role has been modest, the commitment to offensive action has stirred considerable debate here. **********Flying from their base in Qatar, four Canadian CF-18 fighters flew air cover for United States Air Force F-15E fighter-bombers. The mission, on Thursday, ended with the Canadian aircraft returning safely. On Friday, flying two similar missions, the Canadian aircraft returned without loss again. On neither occasion, according to official accounts, did the Canadian aircraft encounter hostile fire. **********But back at home the decision to involve the planes in the international coalition has come under attack.  Participation Is Backed **********This week, as the House of Commons in Ottawa voted formally to endorse Canada's participation in the war, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney countered critics of involvement by speaking forcefully in support of the allied offensive. **********But while he has spoken by telephone with President Bush on several occasions since the fighting began, the Canadian leader took pains to signal that Canada's made its commitment out of a concern to enforce United Nations resolutions against Iraq, and not, as some critics have contended, because of an eagerness to follow the United States. **********"A terrible wrong is being perpetrated in Kuwait by Saddam Hussein," Mr. Mulroney said. "The world community has a moral obligation to step in and stop it. Canada shares in this obligation." Liberals Change Stand **********In the Commons debate, a resolution endorsing the Government's actions was approved 217 to 47, after the opposition Liberals switched position in mid-debate, after the war broke out. **********Jean Chretien, the Liberal leader, who opened the week-long debate by demanding that Canadian forces be withdrawn from the Persian Gulf if war started, said that the party's vote for the resolution signaled its desire not to undercut the Canadian forces. **********But Mr. Chretien was embarrassed during the debate when his predecessor as Liberal leader, John Turner, demanded in the Commons that the Liberals honor the tradition of support for the United Nations begun under former Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson, a major figre at the founding of the United Nations. Role in U.N. Forces **********Canadian forces have not been in combat since the Korean War, and Canada's foreign policy in recent decades has leaned heavily against military intervention. In keeping with the Pearson tradition, Canadian forces in recent decades, have been deployed mainly with United Nations peace-keeping forces, aside from those committed to NATO. **********The Government made its initial commitment to the allied forces, three naval vessels, in mid-August. As war approached, it rejected calls for restriction of Canadian forces to a "defensive" role only. Shortly before the American-led attack began, Mr. Mulroney made it plain that Canadian forces would join in the the effort to drive Iraqi troops from Kuwait. **********Compared with U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf, now involving more than 470,000 military personnel, Canadian deployments are slight. With three naval ships and 26 CF-18's, ground-based versions of the F-18 Hornet fighters flown by the U.S. Navy, Canada has deployed about 1,900 members of the armed services. At American request, the Ottawa Government has agreed to send a 100-bed mobile military hospital to Saudi Arabia within the next few days, a move that will involve several hundred additional soldiers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.main_headline: Rubenstein Executive To Start an Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Rubenstein Executive To Start an Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/21/busin.body_text: **********One of the stars of the Howard J. Rubenstein Associates public-relations agency is leaving to start his own company, and it is expected that some of his high-profile clients will follow him. **********Dan Klores, 41, vice president of the firm, said he would open his company in about two weeks. In his 10 years at the Rubenstein agency, Mr. Klores represented such clients as Donald Trump and the singers Gloria Estefan and Paul Simon. He is also credited for a host of innovative promotional stunts like the New York Health and Racquet Club's annual one-mile race in which everyone runs backward. **********While Mr. Klores declined to name the clients he will represent at his own firm, he said that he would continue to represent Mr. Simon, working jointly with his old agency. **********Mr. Rubenstein, the president of the 38-year-old public relations firm, shrugged off the potential loss of clients as an inevitable part of the business. "He'll be a good competitor," Mr. Rubenstein said, "but then again, so will I."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/busin.main_headline: Surprise Gain At Hewlett: Stock Jumps
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/busin.print_headline: Surprise Gain At Hewlett: Stock Jumps
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/20/busin.body_text: **********The Hewlett-Packard Company today reported unexpectedly strong earnings, attributing the gain to sales of new products and cost-cutting efforts. Analysts said the quarter's strong results could mark the end of a malaise gripping the computer company that last year prompted the return of its co-founder and chairman, David Packard, to active management. **********The numbers were well above Wall Street analysts' estimates and sent the company's stock soaring $5.50, or 13.7 percent, to $45.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock was the Big Board's third most active, with a volume of 2.7 million shares, and the percentage gain was within the top 10 for the day.  New Machines Due **********Analysts said the stock move also reflected anticipation that new line of computer work stations to be introduced soon would be owerful and competitive. **********For its first fiscal quarter, ended Jan. 31, Hewlett-Packard reported earnings of $205 million, or 83 cents a share, up 18.4 percent from $173 million, or 72 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Its revenues rose nearly 10 percent, to $3.4 billion from $3.1 billion. **********"If you'd asked most analysts on the Street, they were expecting flat-to-down earnings," said Robert Herwick, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist Inc. in San Francisco. "This is at least a dime's worth of surprise." **********Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said its sales gains were strong across all its major product lines, including large multi-user computers, work stations, personal computers and printers. Orders grew 12 percent over the first quarter of last year, to $3.7 billion. Domestic orders grew 3 percent, while those from outside the country grew 20 percent. **********Besides the sales gains, Hewlett-Packard's bottom line benefited from reduced expenses. The company shut down for the December holidays and cut employment by 1,000 positions during the quarter through hiring controls and attrition. As a percentage of net revenues, operating expenses totaled 37.7 percent, compared with 38.8 percent. **********"Our backlog increased by $300 million during the quarter, but we remain cautious in light of continuing economic and political uncertainties, including weakness in the U.S. economy," said John A. Young, the president and chief executive.  Testing Sun and I.B.M. **********Next month, Hewlett-Packard is expected to announce a new line of work stations based on RISC, or reduced instruction set computing, which will significantly outperform comparably priced machines from Sun Microsystems Inc. and the International Business Machines Corporation. Analysts say the new machines, whose prices will start at $12,000, will do much to regain market share for Hewlett-Packard from its rivals. **********The new work stations "will signal that Hewlett-Packard is back and they're mad," said Mr. Herwick of Hambrecht & Quist. "Everything one hears about the performance of these new systems is amazing." **********Rather than compete directly with Sun for the lowest price, Hewlett-Packard is likely to challenge its rivals on the basis of price for performance, said Russell Crabs, an analyst with the Soundview Financial Group in Stamford, Conn. **********"The performance of these boxes will beat even I.B.M.," he said. "On a price-performance basis, they're going to look very inexpensive."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/world.main_headline: U.S. and Kuwait Sign Pact on Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/world.print_headline: U.S. and Kuwait Sign Pact on Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/world.body_text: **********The United States and Kuwait signed a military alliance today that broadens the long-term presence of American forces in the Persian Gulf region. **********The 10-year security pact is the first of several such accords expected to be signed with other gulf nations to allow access to ports by United States Navy ships, the storage of military equipment and joint training and exercises. **********The accord with Kuwait does not provide for a permanent American military garrison in Kuwait. **********With President Bush's decision on Wednesday to authorize American warplanes to fly into Iraq to protect United Nations inspectors if needed, today's action, which had been negotiated since the end of the Persian Gulf war, underscores the Administration's military commitment to the region.  Talks 'Progressing Well' **********"The purpose of the agreement is to enhance postwar security and stability in the gulf," the Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, said earlier this week. **********Mr. Williams told reporters today that discussions with other countries in the region "are progressing very well."   But some Administration officials have expressed impatience with the pace of talks with other gulf states.  Saudi Arabia is the centerpiece of the network of security arrangements the United States is trying to forge, but negotiations with the Riyadh Government have bogged down over issues like how many tanks the United States will be allowed to store there and who pays for maintaining pre-positioned equipment. **********The Army in particular wants to leave some of its heaviest equipment behind. The United States had originally sought to leave as much as a division's worth of equipment -- about 300 M1-A1 tanks and 300 Bradley fighting vehicles -- but those goals have been reduced in recent weeks in response to Saudi objections, Administration officials said.  Opponents to U.S. Presence **********Washington is also talking with Qatar, Bahrain, Oman and the United Arab Emirates. **********The pact signed today at the Pentagon by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and his Kuwaiti counterpart, Ali al-Sabah al-Salim al-Sabah, contained the broad outlines of the security arrangement. Mr. Williams said that senior military officers from both nations were still working out specific details like how much equipment would be stockpiled in Kuwait. **********The United States has reduced its ground troops in Kuwait to about 1,500, from about 4,500 earlier this summer.  Mr. Williams said the remaining American troops, which originally were scheduled to leave this summer, will remain for "a few more months."

This leaves Citibank as virtuall...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/busin.main_headline:
FORUM;
U.S. Banks Need an Overseas Presence
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/busin.print_headline:
FORUM;
U.S. Banks Need an Overseas Presence
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/27/busin.body_text: **********Recently a California-based bank-holding company, the Security Pacific Corporation, joined Chase Manhattan, Chemical Bank, Manufacturers Hanover, and several other banking giants in slashing its foreign operations. This leaves Citibank as virtually the only American money center institution with a large, sustained overseas presence. **********At the same time, while American banks shrink their international operations, their foreign competitors in Europe and Japan are preparing to expand both at home -- within their newly deregulated national and regional environments -- and abroad. These banks continue to expand even at a time when conditions in the world's stock and lending markets are difficult. **********In 1992, for example, European Community banks will be equipped with what is called the "single passport" that will enable them to pursue universal commercial, investment and insurance business anywhere in the community. And in Japan, where the laws already allow banks and industrial companies to hold each others' stock -- a practice barred in the United States since 1956 -- the Ministry of Finance has announced its intention to allow banks and securities firms to enter each other's fields. These domestic and regional reforms will give foreign banks added strength to compete. **********But while European and Japanese institutions are positioning themselves to increase their overseas commitments, American banks have redirected their strategy and presence almost entirely toward the domestic front. For these banks, opportunity is seen as Washington's moves to reverse the Depression-era Glass-Steagall and McFadden Acts limiting a bank's participation in the equity markets and in expanding across state lines. **********The outright repeal of these statutory restrictions by Congress will happen, but probably not this year. That is because Congress still fears that deregulation might lead to another crisis like the one that brought down the savings and loan institutions. Nevertheless, when these statutes and regulations are revamped, probably by mid-decade, the international flight of American banks will have placed them at a severe disadvantage vis-a-vis their more internationally minded and stronger foreign rivals. As a result, in the near term it is the large foreign banks with big American presences that will benefit most from any regulatory changes here. They will be able to apply the experience they gained internationally to compete in the United States. **********A study earlier this year by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, noted that despite the growth possibilities presented by Europe's 1992 program, American banking institutions continue to eliminate capacity in Europe. According to the G.A.O., many executives attribute this withdrawal to their inability to perform both debt-and-equity functions under the straitjacket of Glass-Steagall and the Federal Reserve Board's Regulation K statutes. These statutes set strict ceilings on the securities trading and underwriting functions of American banks operating outside United States jurisdiction. European banking institutions do not operate under these restrictions. **********Just this month, responding in part to the G.A.O.'s findings, the Congressional Task Force on American Bank Competitiveness, chaired by Representative John LaFalce, Democrat of New York, released a report calling for "reassessment and adjustment" of the American financial services structure to parallel more closely the norm in other developed countries. The report said that "inherent system inefficiencies" prohibiting product line and geographic diversification have resulted in the loss of international business and influence." **********The LaFalce report echoed the views of key Washington policy makers, including Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, that the present American bank regime is untenable. **********But repealing or revamping Glass-Steagall, the McFadden Act and Regulation K, will not be enough to save our banks from intense foreign competition if they continue to shut their overseas operations. If we follow today's trends into the future, by the mid-1900's the vast majority of industrial nations will maintain common standards of banking practice as well as rules for supervision. **********In that environment, the strongest, most internationally minded banks will be the most competitive. What that means for America's banks is that along with banking reform, they must reform their strategic vision and return to international competition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.main_headline: World Markets; Dollar's Gains Upset the Exchanges
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.print_headline: World Markets; Dollar's Gains Upset the Exchanges
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/31/busin.body_text: **********Oh, how the dollar has hurt Americans with investments abroad this year.  And with so little warning. **********The gains they realized in Europe, as markets rallied after the Persian Gulf victory, were cut in half or even more by the end of the first quarter, according to the Financial Times index of world markets. But until seven weeks ago they hadn't a worry about losing money when converting profits into dollars. **********The dollar hit its post-World War II lows against the German mark and Swiss franc and its 1991 lows against other major currencies in mid-February. But it has since jumped 17.3 percent against the mark, 15.9 percent again the lira, 16.6 percent against the French franc and 14.6 percent against the British pound. **********The gains of American investors are now being gobbled up by unfavorable exchange rates. The 28.5 percent gain in the Swedish market is cut to 17.2 percent when profits are converted into dollars. In Spain, the 26.5 percent rise is reduced to 14.2 percent. In Italy, the 12.6 percent rise is reduced to 0.66 percent. In Britain, the 15.4 percent jump is slashed to 4.6 percent, while in Germany, the 7.7 percent spurt falls to a 5.2 percent loss. **********Despite the dollar's move, some investment managers are not making major changes in their portfolios. Some of them had already expected the dollar to rise moderately this year -- even to its current levels -- but just not this quickly. **********And while there will be a loss on exchange when profits are brought back home, the higher dollar will be a benefit for many European companies that either export to the United states or have large operations here. The stronger dollar will make European exports more competitive here and the dollar earnings in the United States will grow when translated back into marks, pounds, francs, lire and guilders. **********"What we have been doing is placing emphasis on companies that are more export- oriented," said Sander Cseh of Cseh International in Philadelphia. For example, he likes Hunter Douglas of the Netherlands, a manufacturer of blinds and other window coverings with major business in the United States. But he has not "bet the ranch" on these prospects because he is not sure of how high and how long the dollar will rally. **********Some forecasters predict that it will rise to 1.80 against the mark by the end of the year, 6 percent above where it is now. Some say it will drift even higher. **********Nicholas Sargen, a director of international bond trading at Salomon Brothers in New York, thinks the dollar might peak at 1.80 marks, but is likely to fall below that level before the end of the year. He is not expecting a higher rise in part because of the impact of capital flows. For the dollar to continue to rise this year, he says, a significant amount of foreign capital would have to flow into the United States. He does not anticipate that happening. **********Traditionally, interest rates have been a key determinant of exchange rates. A country with higher interest rates than another usually has a stronger currency, other factors being equal, because the higher return attracts investors. **********But the movement of capital from country to country has become a much bigger factor,and can often overwhelm the interest rate factor. **********New data for the fourth quarter of 1990, Mr. Sargen said, showed that there was a net inflow of foreign capital into Germany of $18.7 billion. This surge, he said, helps explain the jump in the value of the mark near the end of the year, when it reached new highs against the dollar. The $18.7 billion inflow was even greater than the $16.7 billion in the fourth quarter of 1989, when money was flowing to Germany on the euphoric wave from the fall of the Berlin Wall and the opening of Eastern Europe. **********Although he does not yet have the data, Mr. Sargen now suspects that the flow of capital, mostly into German bonds, continued in the first part of this year, which helped bring the mark to its post-World War II record high against the dollar in mid-February. **********But he said those investors have been sent scurrying by the renewed focus on German political and economic problems since the end of the Persian Gulf war and the diminished fears that there would be a devaluation in the European Monetary System. That capital drain helped bring down the mark -- and push the dollar up -- quicky, adding to the momentum from the interest rate changes also now expected to favor the United States. **********The impact of capital flows to the United States can also explain the fall of the dollar in 1990. The total flow of capital shifted to a net outflow of $27 billion, compared with a net inflow of $88 billion in 1989. **********Mr. Sargen does expect there to be a reversal in 1991. But he does not think the United States bond market will be attractive enough to bring back the flows of capital that marked 1988 and 1989. "My story," he said, "is that the pendulum of captial flows that hurt the dollar last year will start to shift back. But there is no way we will get back to the good old days of the late 1980's."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/28/world.main_headline: Mandela Calls West Europe Racist on Sanctions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/28/world.print_headline: Mandela Calls West Europe Racist on Sanctions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/28/world.body_text: **********Nelson Mandela today accused the European Community of racism over its lifting of sanctions against South Africa this month against the wishes of his organization, the African National Congress. **********"This decision also once again shows clearly how Europe allies itself with white South Africa and has no regards for the lives, the views and the needs of black South Africa," the anti-apartheid leader said in a speech prepared for delivery at a conference of the National Union of Mine Workers, a black union that has supported the congress's call to maintain sanctions. **********On April 15, the nations of the European Community lifted sanctions imposed in 1986 that banned imports of South African iron, steel and gold coins. In December, the community lifted a ban on new investments in South Africa. Both moves, which were intended to encourage President F. W. de Klerk to continue dismantling apartheid, were opposed by the African National Congress, which said it should decide when sanctions were lifted. **********"We are the victims, yet they reward the jailer for letting a little more light into our hell-hole," Mr. Mandela said today. "It is regrettable that race still plays such a significant part in decision-making even as we enter the much-heralded 21st century." **********Lifting sanctions to reward Mr. de Klerk, Mr. Mandela said, would delay South Africa's economic recovery by delaying resolution of political problems. **********Mr. Mandela spoke a day after returning from a trip to Japan and Britain, having found little support for his pleas to hold the line on sanctions. Mr. de Klerk returned today from a trip to Britain, Denmark and Ireland and said at a news conference that the visits were "highly successful" in convincing their leaders that his reforms were irreversible. **********At a news conference today outside Mr. Mandela's home in Soweto, the African National Congress said it would not retreat from its ultimatum that the Government put a stop to the ongoing political violence and dismiss Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok and Defense Minister Magnus Malan, who head the police and the army. It announced on April 5 that it would refuse to join the Government in talks on a multiparty conference and subsequent negotiations on a new constitution if its demands were not met by May 9. It had previously demanded the release of all political prisoners by April 30. **********Mr. de Klerk said he would discuss with Mr. Mandela the threat to break off negotiations. **********Mr. Mandela did not attend the news conference by the congress. But its secretary general, Alfred Nzo said the organization would not attend a two-day conference called by Mr. de Klerk on May 24 and 25 to discuss the violence. Mr. Nzo said such a conference should be under broader sponsorship of anti-apartheid organizations.  Assassination Plans Charged **********The African National Congress also said it had uncovered "massive plans" to assassinate some of its officials and attack black communities before May 9, the deadline for its ultimatum. It blamed the plot on a "third force" with links to the security forces that was trying to scuttle the peace process. **********Previous incidents it mentioned included the assassination of Chief Mhlabunzima Maphumolo on Feb. 25 near Pietermaritzburg. The Natal Witness newspaper reported Friday that a man named Sipho Madlalahad had walked into its office and confessed to being one of the assassins operating on the instructions of the security and military police. **********The congress charged that "there are organized forces both within and outside the state who are bent on sowing fear, death and destruction within African communities." **********In response, Mr. Vlok's spokesman, Police Capt.
