Craig Kotze, asked the African National Congress to provide "all relevant information" so the police could investigate the charges. **********The South African Defense Force charged in a statement that the congress was trying "to create a climate for the A.N.C. to again blame all violence on everybody but themselves."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/21/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Short-Term Rates Drop Further
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates on short-term issues moved lower again yesterday and bond prices rose as the continuing crisis in the Soviet Union gave investors ample excuse to redirect funds into high-quality, safe securities. **********In addition to the Soviet crisis, traders said prices had also risen in anticipation that the Federal Reserve Board is about to lower short-term interest rates again soon and the idea that the economy may be falling back into recession. **********"Given those three factors, how can you bet against the market?" one government bond trader said. **********Compared with Monday, when trading activity bordered on the chaotic after news of the ouster of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, dealers said yesterday's session was much quieter. **********"People are just waiting, but right now the fundamentals for the market are in pretty good shape," another bond trader said. **********Traders hoping to see a sign from the Fed that it had eased policy yesterday were disappointed. The central bank refrained from conducting open market operations when the funds rate was trading at 5.50 percent, the rate widely seen as the Fed's current target.  Fed Panel's Meeting **********Market participants were watching the Fed's activities more closely than usual yesterday because members of its policy-making Open Market Committee were meeting in Washington. **********Recurrent weakness in the economy and the positive inflation outlook have led some analysts to forecast that the Fed would move almost immediately after yesterday's meeting. **********Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers, is not among that group. But he added that he expected the Fed would not delay too much longer. Moreover, to restimulate the economy the funds rate, which the Fed trimmed just two weeks ago, may have to fall much, much farther, he said. **********"I think they will wait for the employment report," on Sept. 6, Mr. Slifer said. "But we have a long ways to go on the funds rate," he added. **********"In almost every other business cycle, the funds rate has had to fall below the inflation rate in order to promote a vigorous recovery. Given where inflation is now, and where I think it will be by the end of the year, I think that means the funds rate will have to get down to 4 percent."  Bill Rates Down **********The Soviet crisis and anticipation of a Fed easing move helped to push down Treasury bill rates again yesterday. **********By late in the session, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.10 percent, down 5 basis points, or five one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped 8 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.13 percent. And one-year bill rates fell 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.16 percent. **********In the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 100 14/32, up 1/4 of a point, to yield 8.08 percent, down from 8.10 percent late Monday. **********Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 17/ 32, up 7/32, to yield 7.79 percent. And the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 11/32, up 3/32, to yield 6.12 percent. **********Activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by an offering of $993 million issue of securities backed by auto loan receivables from a financing subsidiary of the Security Pacific Corporation. **********The 6.70 percent securities, which have an average life of 1.34 years, were priced at $99.30 to yield 6.844 percent, 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 7/8 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing. **********The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for the transaction. The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, market participants said the prices of most issues were unchanged to up 1/8 of a point in quiet trading. **********Meanwhile, municipal bond traders said the prices of most widely quoted tax-exempt issues fell by about 1/8 of a point. CS First Boston

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF; Civilians Hurt, Iraq Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/world.body_text: **********The Baghdad radio said today that the Iraqi people were more determined than ever in the "showdown" with the West and said President Bush would be haunted "until doomsday" for civilian blood spilled on Iraqi soil. **********There were far fewer bombing and missile strikes on the capital late Thursday and early today than there were the previous night. But a major communications center in Al-Adhamiya district was destroyed, as was Al-Jomhouriya Bridge, which had remained partly intact after two earlier strikes. **********News dispatches from Baghdad are cleared by Iraqi officials in accordance with military security rules. **********The newspaper of the ruling Baath party reported that allied air raids had caused scores of miscarriages and premature births. **********The newspaper Al Thawra quoted Mohammed Ali al-Tawil, the manager of Al-Ilwya maternity hospital, as saying 35 to 45 premature deliveries were occurring daily there since Jan. 17 because of fear and a lack of proper medicine and nutrition. Travelers reaching Baghdad reported that intensive bombing and missile attacks continued on the southern port city of Basra and the northern city of Mosul.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/13/world.main_headline: Gains Reported in South Africa Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/13/world.print_headline: Gains Reported in South Africa Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/13/world.body_text: **********Nelson Mandela and President F. W. de Klerk reportedly made significant progress today in resolving several key issues that have stalled talks between the Government and the African National Congress on constitutional change. **********No full explanation was given on the details of what was achieved in today's discussion but a statement issued tonight by Mr. de Klerk's office said the delegations led by the two men had reconciled their varying interpretations of a crucial paragraph in the document they signed last August obliging the African National Congress to renounce its call for armed struggle against white minority rule. **********Before today's announcement of progress, the Government held that the Congress was violating this commitment by continuing to recruit people for its military wing. Freeing of Prisoners **********For its part the Congress had maintained that the abandonment of the armed struggle was to follow the freeing of all political prisoners and the return to South Africa of all political exiles. The Congress, which charged that the Government was obstructing the release and return of these people, had threatened to break off talks with the Government unless the prisoners and exiles were home by April 30. **********Both sides were reported to have made compromises today, but no details were disclosed pending approval by the Cabinet and the National Executive Committee of the Congress. **********As the Government was reporting but not detailing the progress it was making in the talks with Mr. Mandela in Cape Town, its prosecution of Winnie Mandela, his wife, on kidnapping and assault charges in Johannesburg encountered new difficulty after two prosecution witnesses balked at testifying against her. Disappearance of Witness **********The prosecution reported that the two witnesses had been frightened by the disappearance Sunday of a third main witness. However, Jan Swanepoel, the lead prosecutor, reported this afternoon that one of the reluctant witnesses, Kenneth Kgase, had given an assurance that he would appear in court tomorrow. **********Mr. Mandela, the deputy president of the Congress, had attended the first two days of his wife's trial in a show of support. He has accused the Government of harrassing her. **********Mrs. Mandela and three co-defendants are being tried on four counts of kidnapping and four counts of assault with intent to commit grievous bodily harm in connection with the abduction of four young men to her Soweto home on Dec. 29, 1988. **********The youngest youth, James (Stompie) Moeketsi Seipei, was later found with his throat cut in an open field. Mrs. Mandela's chief bodyguard, Jerry Richardson, was convicted last year of murdering the 14-year-old boy. Testimony at Earlier Trial **********At his trial, the three surviving youths testified that Mrs. Mandela initiated their beatings in her home before Mr. Richardson and her other bodyguards took over the assault. The Government planned to call them to repeat their testimony at this trial. **********On Monday, Mr. Swanepoel, the Deputy Attorney General of the Witwatersrand, told the judge, Justice M. S. Stegmann, that one of the youths, Gabriel Pelo Mekgwe, had apparently been kidnapped Sunday. **********The police have refused to comment on their search for Mr. Mekgwe. But The Star newspaper of Johannesburg reported today that he left a Methodist minister's residence in Soweto on Sunday night with three members of the African National Congress. Doubts on Testifying **********The Star quoted its informants as reporting that "no physical coercion was used to induce him to leave with them." It quoted the informants as saying Mr. Mekgwe had agonized earlier over whether to testify against Mrs. Mandela because of his loyalty to the African National Congress. **********Today, Mr. Swanepoel and Mr. Budlander both refused to comment on The Star's report. The Congress issued a statement saying it knew nothing about Mr. Mekgwe's whereabouts but would investigate the charge. **********"The A.N.C. denies and rejects any imputation that it is organizationally implicated in the disappearance of Mr. Mekgwe," the statement said. "The A.N.C.  reiterates its position that the law be allowed to take its course in this matter without interference from anyone."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/busin.body_text: **********The nation's senior banking regulators said today that more large failures like the Bank of New England would occur if the economy did not turn around by the middle of the year. **********Painting a glum portrait of the banking industry, both L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, told Congress that there was strong evidence that the economy's problems, particularly in New England, had only begun. **********"Almost everything we're seeing in unscientific samples shows we're not seeing any improvement and we might see some further decline," Mr. Seidman told the Senate Banking Committee. "I am not prepared to say that the economy has bottomed out."  What Kind of Recession **********Mr. Seidman said there would be more large failures if the recession was more than "short and shallow." Mr. Seidman defined such a recession as one in which the gross national product does not decline by more than 2 percent over two quarters and the economy begins to turn around within two quarters, in this case by midyear. **********When he announced that the Bank of New England was being seized by the Government on Sunday, Mr. Seidman said he did not anticipate other large failures soon. His remarks today did not directly contradict that position because many economists expect a mild economic decline. **********As a result of the threat of large failures, Mr. Seidman said officials and industry representatives had begun exploring ways for the Government to intervene before institutions face the brink of collapse, but he did not describe any specific measures. **********The fund that protects bank deposits is at its lowest level since its creation during the Depression, and is expected to lose $5 billion this year from failures, leaving it with $4 billion by the end of 1991. **********Regulators have based their estimates of the losses to the Federal fund that insures bank deposits on a forecast of a mild recession. **********Mr. Seidman said he still did not expect a Government bailout of the fund, which is financed by a levy on the industry, but he appeared to be considerably less optimistic than he was late last year. **********"It's not beyond the realm of possibility that taxpayer money will be needed," he said. **********"Clearly the banking industry is under stress," he said. "It is not, however, in a situation like the Great Depression or anything like that magnitude." **********The Bush Administration is preparing to present soon to Congress a package of proposals to overhaul the nation's banking system and the program that insures deposits. Despite the consensus on Capitol Hill that the support given Bank of New England would slow the drive to limit deposit insurance, which currently covers all accounts up to $100,000, Administration officials are preparing to reducecoverage so that it does not fully protect larger institutions, like pension funds, that break down their deposits into $100,000 increments so that they can be fully insured.  Treasury Proposals **********Treasury officials also said today that they planned to go forward with one of two proposals to limit the amount of coverage sharply for individuals. While technically the coverage of each account is limited to $100,000, the current system enables families and others to obtain protection of significantly more than that by putting the funds in different names and joint accounts. **********One proposal is to limit the total coverage for each depositor to $100,000 systemwide. The other would limit the number of $100,000 accounts protected to three for a depositor. **********Officials concede that either measure would be difficult to achieve, but would probably rely on a system that uses the depositor's Social Security number. **********At a morning hearing before the Senate committee and an afternoon session before the House Banking Committee, Mr. Seidman and Mr. Clarke came under heavy questioning about the way the Government handled the collapse of the Bank of New England.  Questions of Fairness **********Lawmakers criticized the decision to protect all depositors, including the estimated $2 billion in accounts of larger than $100,000, and $55 million in foreign branches that do not contribute to the bank insurance fund. They also raised questions about the fairness of protecting all accounts at larger banks, like Bank of New England, but not smaller ones, like Freedom National Bank, the minority-owned institution in Harlem that was seized by the Government in November. **********Mr. Seidman conceded that the current system was fundamentally unfair, but said he could do little without changes in the law. He said Freedom had failed to meet current standards, which require that its existence was essential to the community it served, and that it was cheaper to close it than to save all of its depositors. In the case of the Bank of New England, he said, a failure to protect all deposits would have further destabilized the area's economy. **********Mr. Clarke said the losses from the Bank of New England to the insurance fund "may well have been reduced" because the Government waited more than a year after the bank's difficulties began to appear to declare the institution insolvent. He said the decision to approve a new management team at the bank early last year had made it possible for the bank to sell many of its assets and reduce its overhead more efficiently than the Government might have done.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/busin.main_headline: Dirks Is Back, With A Hot Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; Dirks Is Back, With A Hot Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/busin.body_text: **********Ray Dirks has twice become famous on Wall Street. First he uncovered an insurance company fraud. Then he ran a brokerage firm that went bankrupt after underwriting a series of offerings that in his words "went down the tubes." **********Now the 57-year-old Mr. Dirks is back, promoting a hot insurance stock and promising that this time the quality of the companies he endorses will be higher than in the past. **********"If we do a deal now, we have to look for sales and earnings," Mr. Dirks said yesterday in an interview at Baird, Patrick & Company, where he now runs a division. **********Mr. Dirks's fame began in 1973 after he learned that the Equity Funding Corporation, then a hot insurance stock, had issued fradulent financial statements, and told his clients. That set off his first dispute with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which he says has a vendetta against him. The 'Short Busters Club' **********Mr. Dirks has been at Baird, Patrick since 1986, but it was only this year that the firm began promoting "Ray Dirks Research," which has focused both on insurance stocks, his longtime specialty, and on a "Short Busters Club," which recommends stocks that have been heavily sold by short-sellers betting the price will fall. **********Mr. Dirks now seems to have a great success in Conseco, an insurance company based in Carmel, Ind., which was heavily shorted earlier this year. That stock has zoomed in recent weeks, with Mr. Dirks as its greatest supporter on Wall Street. **********Yesterday morning, as Conseco reported quarterly profits, Mr. Dirks was ecstatic. "Two dollars versus $1.01," he said, referring to the company's operating earnings per share. "That's it. The shorts can forget it." **********As brokers gathered around Mr. Dirks, he told them to call as many clients as they could to recommend the stock. "It's a buy into the $80's, and maybe the $90's," he said. Conseco shares opened higher in New York Stock Exchange trading, but then weakened and ended the day at $72.50, down $2.375. Still, that was not bad for a company whose shares traded at $17 last October, and were at $55 at the end of March, when the "Short Busters Club" included it in a list of heavily shorted stocks worth buying. **********The argument for buying stocks that have been shorted is that the short-sellers, who borrow stocks and then sell them, must eventually buy them back. Thus there is guaranteed buying power. **********That works if the buyer knows more about the company's fundamentals, or about the market's psychology, than the short-seller. But even heavily shorted stocks can keep going down. Another insurance company that Mr. Dirks put on his "short busters" list of buy recommendations was First Capital Holdings, which in March was selling at $3 a share. Now, with a failure seen as possible, the shares trade around half that level. "We've got a disaster there," Mr. Dirks said. "You can't win them all." **********One that Mr. Dirks did win came in the Supreme Court, when the S.E.C.'s censure of Mr. Dirks for his role in the Equity Funding case was overturned. The Court said Mr. Dirks acted within the law in alerting his clients first and disagreed with the S.E.C.'s assertion that he had illegally passed inside information about the company. **********The Equity Funding case established Mr. Dirks's reputation, and he wrote two books. One, called "The Great Wall Street Scandal," chronicled the Equity Funding case. The next, called "Heads You Win, Tails You Win," was a book of conservative financial advice. Among other things, it recommended buying stocks selling below book value. **********With that reputation, in the late 1970's he effectively took over John Muir, an old-line Wall Street firm, which trumpeted "Ray Dirks Research" and handed out copies of his investment book. **********Muir became known for its underwriting of initial public offerings, which were generally highly speculative and far removed from the kind of investments recommended in the book. "We did 49 I.P.O.'s," Mr. Dirks recalled yesterday. "Plenty of them went down the tubes." One that did not, he proudly noted, was Digital Switch, now known as DSC Communications. **********At Muir, and again at Baird, Patrick, Mr. Dirks chose to place his desk in a noisy beehive of activity, not in a private office. "I'm an action junkie," he explained, adding that that applied to his investment style as well. "The 'Heads I Win' book was very sound philosophically, but it's really not my style." **********At Muir, "some of the worst deals we did were in the insurance business," Mr. Dirks recalled. **********The S.E.C. said negligence by Mr. Dirks had contributed to the Muir failure in 1981, an accusation he denied, and suspended him for six months from being a supervisor at a brokerage firm. His appeals of that decision failed. **********After Muir, "For a while, I got into penny stocks," Mr. Dirks said. "I did several deals, and some of them were quite successful, at least for a while." One company, he said, saw its shares rise from 10 cents each to $2, and Mr. Dirks helped arrange a $20 million financing for the firm. "It later went bankrupt," he added. **********He joined a small brokerage firm in 1984, and in 1986 went to Baird, Patrick, where his wife had worked as a broker since 1982. At Baird, he said, he has been involved in two significant underwritings, both for companies in the insurance business. Both companies, Pioneer Financial Services and Condor Services, are now trading below the offering prices. **********Condor went public in the underwriting arranged by Mr. Dirks. Based in California, it had been an insurance broker specializing in the insurance of garbage trucks. The money raised by the offering enabled it to become an insurance company as well, Mr. Dirks said, but results have been disappointing. The shares, issued two years ago at $7.50 each, closed yesterday in over-the-counter trading at $1.875. **********Mr. Dirks's support for Conseco, as a company that is likely to grow rapidly because of the popularity of the single-premium annuities it sells, and the doubts voiced by short-sellers who think the company's accounting is overly generous, were detailed in a Barron's article in February. The next day, Mr. Dirks said, S.E.C. investigators showed up at Baird, Patrick demanding to see records. Mr. Dirks said he was suspected of trading on inside information in Conseco, an idea he called "pure baloney." **********An S.E.C. spokeswoman would not comment on whether there was an investigation, or on Mr. Dirks's assertion of a vendetta. Mr. Dirks said S.E.C. investigators had shown up at every firm he has worked for since the Equity Funding case, but added that they had not got in touch with him in the first five years he was at Baird, Patrick. **********Mr. Dirks said that after his penny stock days in the early 1980's, "I started going back up in quality," and added that he had ambitions of making Baird, Patrick "a full service insurance firm" with a large institutional clientele. **********Whether he succeeds in that regard may depend in large part on whether Conseco continues to be the kind of winning stock he says he is confident it will be.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/world.body_text: **********Fighting subsided in Mogadishu today after rebels took the war-ruined Somali capital and forced President Mohammed Siad Barre to flee. **********The airport, where Mr. Siad Barre maintained a well-fortified bunker, was the last important point to fall to the rebels of the United Somali Congress, the British Broadcasting Corporation reported today. The deposed president and top aides were reported to have fled in a convoy of more than 40 vehicles, some of them tanks, the BBC said. **********A spokesman for the Somali Congress in Nairobi, Ali Mohammed Hirabe, said the group was preparing to form a "a broad-based democratic government." Other opposition forces would be invited to join, he said.  Clan-Based Politics **********The three groups that are to be included in the new government, the spokesman said, were the Congress, which is drawn from the Hawiye clan from the center of the country; the Somali National Movement, based on the Isaak clan from the north, and the Somali Patriotic Movement, whose members are Ogadenis from the south. **********But the other major rebel groups are also based on clans, and there is come question about how they can work together for the government of "national reconciliation" that the Somali Congress is calling for, experts on Somalia said. **********Mr. Siad Barre "will be remembered for destroying his country both economically and politically and for fragmenting Somalia's clans, a terrible legacy for the people who come after him," said Professor I. M. Lewis, a historian who specializes on Somalia at the London School of Economics. **********Mr. Siad Barre favored his own small Marehan clan in all appointments and in his final years singled out members of other major clans for brutal killings.  Kenya Offers Safe Passage **********Kenyan authorities said today that Mr. Siad Barre was reported to be in the southern Somali town of Kismayu, about 100 miles from Kenya. The Kenyan Foreign Ministry, which has maintained testy relations with Mr. Siad Barre during his 21 years of autocratic rule, said that Mr. Siad Barre would be accorded safe passage if he turned up at the Kenyan border. Senior members of Mr. Siad Barre's Government have already taken refuge in Kenya in the past weeks. **********There was speculation in Nairobi that Mr. Siad Barre, who is said to be about 82, might try to reach Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates, where his family landed soon after the fighting consumed Mogadishu a month ago. **********The only independent contact between Mogadishu and the outside world during the turmoil of the last few days has come by radio telephone from a team of doctors with the French humanitarian agency, Doctors Without Borders. Accompanying them are a British environmentalist and pilot, Murray Watson, and a journalist, Stephen Smith, with the French newspaper, Liberation. **********One of the French doctors who returned from Mogadishu to Kenya Sunday said some two-thirds of Mogadishu's approximately one million inhabitants had fled during the fighting. The doctor, Dr. Gastellu Etchegorry, said civilians were reaching his group's makeshift hospital with bullet or shell-fragment wounds. "The hospital floor is awash with blood," he said.  A Switch of Clients **********In the late 1970's, when the Soviet Union and the United States competed in Africa for clients, the two superpowers switched allegiances in the Horn of Africa. Washington picked up Somalia, a Muslim country with about six million people, from the Soviets after Moscow backed the Marxist revolution in Ethiopia, previously friendly to Washington. **********Under pressure from Congress, which cited Mr. Siad Barre's retaliation against civilians belonging to clans other than his own, Washington has reduced military and economic aid to Somalia to virtually zero over the last two years. **********But the legacy of the arms donations by the two superpowers, as well as from Italy, the former colonial power, allowed the fighting in Somalia to reach great intensity in the past two years, culminating in the battle for Mogadishu this month. Civilians were able to buy rifles and mortars in the markets of the city. And in the days before Mr. Siad Barre fled, Dr. Ethchegorry said, the president's forces had been "indiscriminately shelling the city, killing thousands of people."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/busin.body_text: **********Mattel Inc., the nation's largest toy maker, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings increased 51.5 percent, to $14.7 million, or 29 cents a share, from $9.7 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 19.2 percent, to $428.3 million, from $359.4 million. **********Mattel said quarterly earnings were reduced because it set aside $21 million after taxes to cover bad debts. **********For the year, Mattel, based in El Segundo, Calif., reported record earnings and revenues. Profits totaled $91.2 million, or $1.80 a share, up 32.8 percent from $68.7 million, or $1.38 share, in 1989, after taking an extraordinary charge of $11 million. **********Sales for the year rose 18.5 percent, to $1.47 billion, from $1.24 billion. **********Mattel rose 12.5 cents today, to $22.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.main_headline: Bank of New York Raises $600 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Bank of New York Raises $600 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of New York yesterday priced $600 million worth of 7.10 percent securities backed by credit card receipts to yield 7.24 percent. The First Boston Corporation was lead underwriter. The yield was 80 basis points, or 80-hundredths of a percentage point, above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 7/8 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing. **********The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.body_text: **********Fifteen thousand Iranians shouting, "Down with America!" and "Down with Israel!" turned out today to mark the 12th anniversary of the seizure of the United States Embassy here and denounce the Arab-Israeli peace talks.  Shopkeepers closed their businesses in the city's bazaar to join high school and university students who waved banners and burned an American flag outside the former embassy building.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/09/busin.main_headline: It's Official: Michael Jordan Is Now Promoting Gatorade
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/09/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; It's Official: Michael Jordan Is Now Promoting Gatorade
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/09/busin.body_text: **********HAVING finally confirmed one of marketing's worst-kept secrets -- that Michael Jordan would add Gatorade to his long list of product endorsements -- executives of the Quaker Oats Company, which makes Gatorade, and its advertising agency are wasting no time putting their new superstar to work. **********Just hours after a news conference in Chicago yesterday morning, at which Mr. Jordan's multiyear, multimillion-dollar agreement was announced, Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, which creates Gatorade's advertising, had a 60-second commercial on nationwide television featuring the guard of the Chicago Bulls basketball team. "Be like Mike. Drink Gatorade" is the theme of the spot, which will also run as a commercial in movie theaters starting next Friday. **********And for consumers who are not ardent television viewers, a poster-sized, double gatefold, or pull-out, print ad, showing Mr. Jordan clutching a cup of the drink, is appearing in the latest issue of Sports Illustrated. **********"We feel he is going to be such a valuable property for us, we wanted to use him right away," Peggy Dyer, vice president of Gatorade marketing at Quaker, said in a telephone interview from Chicago after the news conference, which featured Mr. Jordan swigging from a bottle of Gatorade. "We think he is going to have an immediate impact on our sales." **********In addition to the broadcast and print ads, Ms. Dyer said, displays decorated with likenesses of Mr. Jordan are being rushed to grocery and convenience stores across the country. Quaker's goal, she added, is to have the displays greet consumers as they shop today. **********"Because he is respected everywhere as a leader in sports and a proven performer," William D. Smithburg, chairman and chief executive of Quaker, said in a statement, "Michael is perfect to represent Gatorade." Mr. Jordan's appearance in Gatorade's advertising marks the first time the product has used a spokesman in the United States; overseas, athletes have served as endorsers for some time. **********But of course Gatorade is far from being Mr. Jordan's first product endorsement. Estimates of his total annual income from his 15 or so agreements with leading marketers range from $15 million to $20 million. Among them are McDonald's, General Motors (Chevrolet), General Mills (Wheaties) and Nike (Air Jordan). **********Ron Bess, president and chief operating officer of Bayer Bess, is not daunted at sharing Mr. Jordan's product-pitching skills with so many others. "We want to use Michael in a way that's distinctive," he said. "We feel Michael is an ideal fit with Gatorade, and he feels that way also." **********In joining Gatorade's team, Mr. Jordan is ending a two-year relationship with the Coca-Cola Company, from which he received an estimated $2.5 million annually to appear in advertising for Coca-Cola Classic. Industry executives say Mr. Jordan was willing to swap beverages because Quaker was willing to offer a multiyear contract versus Coca-Cola's one-to-two-year terms. **********Mr. Jordan's contract with Coca-Cola expired on July 31. Advertising trade publications reported that Quaker was waiting for it to expire before announcing a deal with Mr. Jordan. **********The announcement had been anticipated since June, when those publications began reporting that Mr. Jordan would switch to gulping Gatorade. They described Quaker's agreement with Mr. Jordan as being worth $18 million over 10 years; Quaker will not discuss terms. **********Industry analysts call the agreement a move by Quaker to bolster its commanding lead in the country's estimated $730 million market for such beverages at a time when competitors from Coca-Cola (Powerade) to Suntory (10-K) are pressing as never before. Packaged Facts, a New York marketing consulting firm, estimates that Gatorade commands 87 percent to 95 percent of its market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/21/world.main_headline: MOBUTU OUSTS FOE AND RENEWS CHAOS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/21/world.print_headline: MOBUTU OUSTS FOE AND RENEWS CHAOS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/21/world.body_text: **********Zaire plunged back into political chaos today when President Mobutu Sese Seko dismissed his arch-foe, Etienne Tshisekedi, as Prime Minister.   Mr. Mobutu, who appointed Mr. Tshisekedi as head of the country's first opposition-led Cabinet after anti-Government riots, called on opposition parties to find another candidate. **********But Mr. Tshisekedi, speaking to 2,000 supporters at his party headquarters, said he planned to move into the Prime Minister's office on Monday. Troops blocked his way on Saturday.   "I invite the people to put me back in office, since I was chosen by the people," Mr. Tshisekedi said. **********The pronouncements from both camps set the stage for a major confrontation in Kinshasa, the capital, which was torn apart by violence four weeks ago. Mobs, led by soldiers, rampaged through the city, destroying businesses, looting private homes and leaving a trail of destruction. Some 250 people were killed.  'No Longer the One' **********Mr. Mobutu, who has governed Zaire for 26 years, started the latest political battle last week when his spokesman declared Mr. Tshisekedi's Government, forced on Mr. Mobutu after the riots, unconstitutional.   "I'm the one who named him -- against my better judgment," the 61-year-old President said of Mr. Tshisekedi to a group of supporters aboard the presidential yacht Kamanyola, moored near the devastated capital.   "For me he is no longer the one," Mr. Mobutu said in remarks broadcast over the state radio and television. "I will ask the opposition to name another person." He accused Mr. Tshisekedi, a 58-year-old lawyer, of inciting violence.  Mr. Tshisekedi was barred from his office by pro-Mobutu troops on Saturday and was forced to hold the first Cabinet meeting outside in the broiling sun. The former Mobutu ally, who split with the President after charging that the country had become indescribably corrupt, told supporters he would return to the office with his followers on Monday and would force his way in.   The ambassadors of the three main Western powers in Zaire -- the United States, Belgium and France -- met Mr. Mobutu aboard his yacht before his statement. Diplomats said the ambassadors had told Mr. Mobutu that if he replaced Mr. Tshisekedi, the new Prime Minister should be someone from the opposition and should not be a technocrat or a general.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/01/busin.main_headline: Data General Quits Venture With N.T.T.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/01/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Data General Quits Venture With N.T.T.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/01/busin.body_text: **********The Data General Corporation has dropped a product development agreement with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation of Japan, company officials said today. **********The agreement to build high-speed hubs for private data communications networks was announced in 1987. The companies were to link voice, data and computers in large private communications networks like those used by corporations and universities. **********N.T.T. had planned to buy about $130 million of equipment to be developed by Data General. The purchases were to be made over five years beginning in 1989. **********But research found no strong market in Japan for such systems, said Jim Dunlap, a Data General spokesman. He said the agreement to drop the plan had been mutual. **********Barry Willman, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein in New York, said Data General's mounting financial pressures, a shift in the computer market and the company's increased emphasis on work stations had been responsible for the decision. **********Data General has not had a profitable year since 1985. Since then the company has suffered a string of losses. It lost $139 million in its most recent fiscal year on revenues of $1.22 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Pepsi Cancels Big Giveaway
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/busin.body_text: **********Pepsico Inc. decided last night that much as it wanted to promote Diet Pepsi it was not worth the risk of snarling the nation's telephone network in the process. **********As part of its Diet Pepsi commercials during the telecast of the Super Bowl this Sunday, Pepsi had planned to give $1 million to each of three randomly chosen callers to a toll- free telephone number that would be shown during the commercials. But last night the company scrapped the idea. **********As recently as yesterday afternoon, a Pepsi spokeswoman had insisted that the promotion would be done. "We don't know what to expect, and that's part of the curiosity," said Leigh Curtin, the spokeswoman. "We're very optimistic." **********But the company announced last night that it had canceled the promotion after discussing it with the Federal Communications Commission. "We did not want to do anything that would have even the slightest chance of disrupting our nation's ability to communicate," said David Novak, executive vice president for marketing and sales. **********Telephone industry experts had estimated that as many as 50 million calls could flood the nation's telephone network during the promotion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.main_headline: Jordanian King Is Said to Express Interest in New Talks With Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: JORDAN; Jordanian King Is Said to Express Interest in New Talks With Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/05/world.body_text: **********King Hussein of Jordan has recently expressed interest in reviving efforts to negotiate peace with Israel and a solution to the Palestinian problem, possibly along the lines of a 1987 agreement secretly worked out in London with a former Israeli Foreign Minister, a senior Israeli official says. **********The official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said that the Jordanian King wished to revive the so-called London Agreement, which he signed with Shimon Peres, then the Israeli Foreign Minister, now head of the opposition Labor Party, in April 1987. The agreement set guidelines for an international peace conference that would be attended by a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. Yitzhak Shamir, who was then and is now Prime Minister, was furious when he learned of the secret accord and blocked it in the Israeli Cabinet. **********The King mentioned the possibility of reviving peace talks along the lines of the London agreement, if Palestinians agreed to this proposal, in a recent meeting with Hans-Dietrich Genscher, Germany's Foreign Minister, the official said. Mr. Genscher discussed the suggestion with the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, in Cairo, and with Mr. Peres in Israel in mid-February.  A Signal From Jordan **********Arab and American officials said they viewed this and other signals from King Hussein as consistent with his effort to repair the diplomatic and economic damage resulting from the coalition view that he sided with Iraq in the Persian Gulf war. The King, they said, was apparently trying to shore up his own position by stressing that he is still committed to and capable of helping the Palestinians achieve what he called in a speech on Friday "their national rights on their national soil." **********Some Arab analysts have begun to argue that King Hussein could conceivably emerge in a strong position from the gulf war. President Hussein, his powerful neighbor, has been destroyed, Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, is widely viewed as discredited, and the Americans are likely to refocus on finding a solution to the Palestinian problem that plagues his country as well as Israel. "The U.S. and Arab allies may well conclude that he is the best they can do in the region and that he must be shored up," one Saudi analyst said. **********An Israeli official said that Mr. Peres and King Hussein have previously had more than 100 hours of private meetings. Jordanian officials, who have long said that Palestinians must decide who should represent them, have always denied that direct contactswith Israelis have taken place. Mr. Peres, in Israel, denied the first report of such a signal from King Hussein, which appeared a few days ago in the Israeli newspaper Maariv. But a senior Israeli official, familiar with previous discussions between the King and Mr. Peres, insisted that the report was accurate. New Plan From Peres **********On Thursday, Mr. Peres floated a new peace plan that provides for a joint Jordanian-Palestinian negotiating team. Prime Minister Shamir, for his part, is suggesting reviving his original peace plan, which calls for autonomy for Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza and for elections in those territories. **********Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, who visited Amman last week, said senior Jordanian officials expressed interest in resuming the effort to put together a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation that could negotiate with Israel. That effort failed because, among other reasons, Israel insisted that no members of the P.L.O. be part of the delegation. "I had the strong impression in Amman that King Hussein is willing to play an active and prominent role to deal with the Palestinian problem if the Palestinians in his country are willing to let him do that," Mr. Solarz said. **********President Bush recently characterized past relations with Jordan as "very pleasant," adding, "I have no personal animosity towards His Majesty the King."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/world.main_headline: Soviet Miners Vote an End to 9-Week Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/world.print_headline: Soviet Miners Vote an End to 9-Week Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/09/world.body_text: **********Soviet coal miners have voted to end a devastating nine-week old strike, averting a clash with President Mikhail Gorbachev and opening the way for radical reforms in the industry. **********The Soviet news agency Tass said the central strike committee in the Kuznetsk caol basin in central Siberia, the largest in the country, voted today to suspend the strike effective Friday. Miners in the other major Russian republic coal region, Vorkuta, backed their leaders' decision to return to work on the same day. **********Workers in the Ukraine's Donetsk coal basin field went back to work last week. **********The main demand of miners in the Kuznetsk region had been the resignation of Mr. Gorbachev, who they said had betrayed them over a previous strike deal in 1989 and now stood in the way of any reform. **********The decision appeared to be the first fruit of a cooperation agreement signed by Mr. Gorbachev, his chief rival Boris Yeltsin, the leader of the Russian republic. and leaders of eight other Soviet republics last week. **********The Soviet Government turned over contol of the Siberian coal industry to the Russian republic on Monday, marking a success for Mr. Yeltsin in his campaign to wrest economic and political authority from Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/21/busin.main_headline: Downtown Retailing; Cincinnati Puts a Mall In a Tower
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/21/busin.print_headline: Downtown Retailing; Cincinnati Puts a Mall In a Tower
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Tower Place at Carew Tower, a shopping center in the heart of this city, opens Wednesday as the $100 million bait that city leaders hope will lure shoppers downtown again. **********The 250,000-square-foot center eoncompasses the renovated Art Deco arcade of the 61-year-old Carew Tower, Cincinnati's tallest building, and the adjacent atrium-style Tower Place, which was completed this month on the site of the former L. S. Ayres department store. **********The downtown area has seen a net loss of 640,000 square feet of retail space in the last decade. At the same time, two shopping malls, each with more than a million square feet, have opened in the suburbs. **********A third suburban mall underwent an $85 million renovation and also has more than a million square feet of space. **********The $15 million Tower Place was developed by Faison Associates of North Carolina, while the Carew Tower arcade and Omni Netherland Hotel were renovated by the Belvedere Corporation of Cincinnati. **********Belvedere became the tower's lead investor early last year when Emery Realty defaulted on a $50 million loan. **********The project, which includes Ray Combs's Comedy Club, a fitness center and Morton's of Chicago steak house, is more than 90 percent leased, albeit without the prominent names that developers had initially sought. About 145,000 square feet are leasable in the 250,000-square-foot center. **********The 1.7 million people who live in the Cincinnati area could find outlets of many of Tower Place's 65 stores and restaurants -- the Limited, the Gap, Footlocker, Chick-Fil-A -- at suburban shopping centers where the parking is free. At Tower Place, parking costs $1.50 an hour up to a maximum of $8 for 24 hours. **********But Belvedere's president, Steven Stein, said the tenant mix was demographically correct. **********"Perhaps some people will ask why we didn't go out and spend a million dollars to bring Gucci to the Carew Tower," he remarked. "The reason we didn't is that I don't think that's our customer base." **********Also among the shops are the area's first Banana Republic and the third American shop of Goodebodies, a British retailer of bath products made from natural ingredients. **********Mr. Stein acknowledged when Belvedere started the Carew Tower renovation that visions of Gucci, Fendi and Louis Vuitton danced in his head. But with today's retail environment battering many high-fashion retailers, he said he was glad they were only visions. **********"We've got stores that are right for the 90's," he said. **********He pointed out that designer apparel was readily available downtown at Saks Fifth Avenue and Gidding-Jenny, a stylish boutique, that just reopened under a new owner after a six-month, $2 million renovation. Saks is in the midst of a million-dollar renovation. The city's 18-block skywalk system connects Saks, Gidding-Jenny and McAlpin's department store to Tower Place. **********Even if suburban shoppers do not flock downtown to buy lingerie at Victoria's Secret or books at Brentano's, there is a base of 82,000 downtown workers and 65 percent of them are women, Mr. Stein said. **********Tower Place at Carew Tower brings a retail focal point to downtown, retail experts say. Though plenty of shopping has always been available, there is a perception that it is difficult to park and move from store to store downtown. **********"It was until only three years ago that the largest concentration of retail was downtown," Mr. Stein said. "Ayres's closing caused the hub of the hub-and-spokes system to go dark." **********City leaders' next priority is to move Lazarus, a locally based department store, several blocks away, to a site across the street from the Carew Tower known as Fountain Square West, said Mark McKillip, the downtown economic development officer. **********Although the opening of Tower Place came a year and a half past schedule, its development was speedy compared with Fountain Square West, which has been idle since a department store, Elder-Beerman, pulled out in 1985. **********Demolition of the store is almost complete, but the potential developer of a new mixed-use project at the site was deterred by financing difficulties, and the city now plans to turn the prime parcel into a parking lot until the economic picture changes. **********City leaders, who have already invested $10 million in the Fourth Street retail district, do not want to lose momentum. **********Mr. McKillip said that after Lazarus is moved, the city would seek out another department store of 60,000 to 100,000 square feet for its old Parkade Garage site two blocks north of Tower Place.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/13/busin.main_headline: An Officer Moves Up At Kaiser Permanente
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/13/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; An Officer Moves Up At Kaiser Permanente
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/13/busin.body_text: **********Dr. David M. Lawrence, the new chief executive of Kaiser Permanente, a California-based health maintenance organization that is the nation's largest provider of health services, says that helping patients to be better informed about their needs is "one of the fundamental issues that we are all grappling with." Dr. Lawrence, 50 years old, succeeds James A. Vohs as chief executive of the Kaiser Foundation Health Plan Inc. and Kaiser Foundation Hospitals, which, with the Permanente Medical Group, serve 6.5 million members. **********Mr. Vohs, who is 62, is keeping his post as chairman of the common board of directors of the organizations. Wayne R. Moon, 51, Kaiser's president, succeeds Dr. Lawrence as chief operating officer. **********Kaiser, based in Oakland, had $8.4 billion in combined revenues and $384 million in net income last year. Kaiser has said it will spend $6 billion over the next five years to renovate and expand its facilities in California, where five million of its members live. **********Dr. Lawrence said that one-third of the capital spending would go for new medical and information technology and buildings to house it. One-third will be for new hospitals and offices to accommodate the more than one million members who have joined since 1988, and the final $2 billion is to renovate existing facilities. He said his first priority would be to make the giant health-care organization more sensitive to "the demands and needs and changing priorities of purchasers and individuals." **********He said, for example, that Kaiser and several other large H.M.O.'s were experimenting with ways to give information to patients with common ailments like colds and flu, to help them decide if they really needed to see a doctor. Kaiser already uses "advice nurses" to answer routine questions that might otherwise take up doctors' time, and he said that it was "looking at different ways to use the advice nurse system." **********Kaiser operates its H.M.O. prepaid health plans in 16 states. It has 31 hospitals and contracts with 8,600 physicians in independent group practices, called the Permanente Medical Groups. **********Dr. Lawrence joined Kaiser Permanente in 1981 as vice president and Northwest area medical director in Portland, Ore., where he had directed public health services for Multnomah County. He was Kaiser's regional manager in Colorado for three years, becoming senior vice president and manager of the huge Northern California region in September 1988, and vice chairman and chief operating officer in July 1990. He is a graduate of Amherst College and received his medical degree at the University of Kentucky and a master's degree in public health at the University of Washington. Dr. Lawrence, who also served in the Peace Corps, has board certification in general preventive medicine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/16/world.main_headline: Sweden's Socialists Suffer Major Defeat, But Rivals Are Split
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/16/world.print_headline: Sweden's Socialists Suffer Major Defeat, But Rivals Are Split
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/16/world.body_text: **********Sweden's long-governing Social Democrats suffered their worst election defeat in more than 60 years today when voters punished the party in a rebellion against the Western world's most extensive welfare state. **********Financial problems including high taxes and a stagnant economy prompted Swedish voters to swing sharply to the right, giving the five non-Socialist parties together about 53 percent of the vote. Prime Minister to Resign **********Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson, a Social Democrat, said he would resign on Monday. But it was unclear tonight whether all five of the non-Socialist parties would be willing to cooperate with each other, which would be necessary if they are to form a new government. The Social Democrats have led Sweden since 1982 and have been in power for more than five of the last six decades. **********Indeed, about the only thing certain tonight was that Sweden will not have a strong government. While Swedish voters apparently know what they do not want -- what they have come to consider a suffocating welfare state that costs too much and exerts too much influence over their lives -- the election results indicate that it is not clear what they want to replace it. **********Carl Bildt, the 42-year-old leader of the Moderates, said he would try to form a new government, but he predicted it might take three weeks. **********The Moderates received more than a fifth of the votes, making them the largest non-Socialist party. **********Calling the election a "historic defeat for the left," Mr. Bildt said: "It's a very strong mandate for change." Still, he admitted to being worried about a fragmented Parliament. **********The Social Democrats, the architects of the Swedish welfare state, got only about 38 percent of the vote. That was their worst performance since 1928. Size of Tax Burden **********All five non-Socialist parties have either vowed to cut taxes or at least intimated they would go along with some reductions. Last year taxes equaled 57.7 percent of Sweden's gross national product, the highest in the West. **********They have also promised to roll back the public sector and heed Swedes' requests for more personal choice by opening up social services like health care and child care to more competition from the private sector. But one of the five, New Democracy, which was formed only last February, wants to make much deeper tax cuts and to dismantle the welfare state. **********The four center-right parties -- the Moderate, Liberal, Center and Christian Democratic parties -- have been willing to form a coalition government. But they appear to be 5 or 6 short of the 175 seats in Parliament they need to do so. And it was unclear tonight whether they would be willing to strike a deal with New Democracy, which will have about 24 legislative seats. **********In another sign of discontent, the Christian Democrats, who are not currently represented in Parliament, did well. Preaching Christian family values, they blamed the Social Democrats for everything from rising crime to the high number of divorces and single-parent families. Together the Christian Democrats and New Democracy got about 14 percent of the vote. **********During the campaign, the Liberals vowed not to go along with a government that included or depended on the support of New Democracy. Tonight, however, Bengt Westerberg, the Liberal leader, seemed to soften his tone. "I'm not saying I won't take part, but a four-party government dependent on New Democracy wouldn't be a good government," he said. **********In all but 9 of their 53 years in power, the Social Democrats have had a minority in Parliament and have relied on support from other parties. But given the poor performance of the most likely allies -- the Left Party, as the Communists are now called, and the Greens -- that seems improbable this time. **********In a campaign strategy that did not work, the Social Democrats portrayed themselves as the party that would defend the welfare state. The Swedish 'Third Way' **********Over the last six decades, the Social Democrats built what they called the third way between the capitalism and Communism. Its hallmarks have been neutrality, free trade, centralized bargaining, relatively low corporate taxes, a high level of cradle-to-grave benefits for everyone and high personal taxes. **********This model has given Swedes one of the highest standards of living in the world and some mighty multinational corporations. But the public sector grew increasingly bureaucratic and inefficient, and the nation turned away from neutrality toward membership in the European Community, which has been applied for. **********In recent years, the country has been battered by high inflation, anemic economic growth, fleeing business investment and rampant worker turnover and absenteeism, which crippled companies and social services. **********Swedes have had to wait for years for cataract and other operations, and some have died awaiting heart bypass surgery. There have also been shortages of places in public old-age homes and day-care centers. **********The Social Democrats tried to deal with these problems by cutting the highest income tax rate but raising other taxes; raising interest rates; clamping down on public spending and cutting sick pay. **********Although absenteeism and turnover rates have dropped and inflation fell to zero from 10.4 percent last year, these steps angered traditional supporters like blue-collar workers. Moreover, the overall tax burden has not changed, and interest rates, while dropping, are still high. The economy is expected to show no growth in 1991 and 1992. And some economists predict unemployment will rise in the next year or so to as much as 5 percent, the highest level since the 1930's. **********"Now it's the Moderates turn," Mr. Carlsson said. He predicted that once Swedes "saw the consequences" of tax cuts in terms of lost benefits, "the parties which stand for social responsibility will gain ground again."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/busin.main_headline: A Disney Dress Code Chafes In the Land of Haute Couture
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/busin.print_headline: A Disney Dress Code Chafes In the Land of Haute Couture
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/busin.body_text: **********Should the French have to shave their beards or scrap their lacy tights for a Mickey Mouse job? **********The Walt Disney Company, which is in the midst of hiring some 12,000 people to maintain and populate its Euro Disneyland theme park near Paris, thinks so. But in making detailed rules on acceptable clothing, hair styles and jewelry, among other things, part of its terms of employment, the company finds itself caught in a legal and cultural dispute. A Court Is Investigating **********The controversy has risen above the usual labor squabble as critics in the press, at universities and elsewhere have joined in asking how brash Americans could be so insensitive to French culture, individualism and privacy. Most of the critics, and many people on the street, seem amazed, if not amused, that Disney found it necessary to put such a subjective and personal hygiene code in writing, and to make its violation a firing offense for everyone from the actors portraying Mickey and Minnie who greet visitors to the chambermaids cleaning hotel rooms. **********Disney executives say the planned April 12 opening of the $4.2 billion complex in Marne-la-Vallee, 20 miles east of Paris, is unlikely to be delayed by the conflict, which is being investigated by a district court. But they insist that any ruling that bars them from imposing squeaky-clean employment standards could threaten the image and long-term success of the park. **********"For us, the appearance code has a great effect from a product-identification standpoint," said Thor Degelmann, vice president for human resources for Euro Disneyland, which has its headquarters in Noisy-le- Grand. Mr. Degelmann, an American from Los Angeles, is in charge of hiring for the theme park. **********"Without it, we wouldn't be presenting the Disney product that people would be expecting," he added. "It would be like going to see a production of 'Hamlet' in which everyone looked different than you expected. Would you ever go again?" **********The rules, spelled out in a video presentation for job applicants and detailed in a guidebook, "Le Euro Disneyland Look," go way beyond height and weight standards. They require men's hair to be cut above the collar and ears, with no beards or mustaches. Any tattoos must be covered. **********Women must keep their hair in one "natural color" with no frosting or streaking, and they may make only "limited use" of makeup like mascara. False eyelashes, eyeliner and eyebrow pencil are completely off limits. Fingernails can't pass the ends of the fingers. **********As for jewelry, women can wear only one earring in each ear, with the earring's diameter no more than 2 centimeters (about three-quarters of an inch). Neither men nor women can wear more than one ring on each hand. **********Further, women are required to wear "appropriate undergarments" and only transparent pantyhose, not black or anything with fancy designs. **********Similar rules are in force at Disney's three other amusement parks in the United States and Japan. **********Though a daily bath is not specifically mentioned in the rules, the applicants' video depicts a shower scene and informs applicants that they are expected to show up for work "fresh and clean each day." Communists Warn Applicants **********In the United States, some unions representing Disney employees have occasionally protested the company's strict appearance code, but with little success. **********French labor unions began protesting the regulations in September, when Euro Disneyland opened its "casting center" at its corporate headquarters and began interviewing thousands of applicants who responded to the company's ubiquitous ad campaign, which invited them to "play the role of your life" and to take a "unique opportunity to marry work and magic." **********The Communist-led Confederation Generale du Travail (General Confederation of Labor) handed out leaflets in front of the center to warn applicants of the appearance code, which represented "an attack on individual liberty," it contended. A more mainstream union, the Confederation Francaise Democratique du Travail (C.F.T.D.) appealed to the Labor Ministry to halt what it termed Disney's violation of "human dignity." A Formal Complaint **********The conflict became more serious on Dec. 2, when a Government labor inspector lodged a formal complaint against the company, prompting a preliminary investigation by the prosecutor's office that sources say is likely to lead to court action in the weeks ahead. The complaint charged that the appearance rules constituted a form of disciplinary code that applied to all employees, and should therefore, under French labor law, be included in the company's internal employment regulations instead of as an attachment to the employment contract. **********The legal nuance is important, because if the code was written into internal regulations, it would first have to win the approval of the national labor inspector's office. A Government official said it would be difficult for Disney's particular restrictions to win approval, because they appeared to have little bearing on the work of all employees. **********"In certain cases, I could see a connection, but certainly not for 12,000 people," the official said. **********Robert Chabin, an official of the C.F.D.T., said "no more than 700" employees would be involved in theatrical work at the park -- parades, bands and the like -- and that for the other positions, the code "cannot be justified by necessity." **********French law prohibits employers from restricting individual and collective liberties unless the restrictions can be justified by the nature of the task to be accomplished and are proportional to that end.  Assault on Europe Is Seen **********But beyond whatever legal prescriptions arise, it is clear that many French people feel stung by the whole episode. Roger Blancpain, a professor of labor law and president of the International Industrial Relations Association, based in Geneva, said Disney's code represented a frontal assault on French and European social standards. **********"A certain kind of underwear?" he asked. "There's a limit, and that's going too far." **********He insisted that Euro Disneyland management "should have been aware of the environment it was operating in and shown more sensitivity." **********Mr. Degelmann, however, said the company was "well aware of the cultural differences" between the United States and France, and as a result had "toned down" the wording in the restrictions from the original American version. **********He said the conflict resulted from a "lack of understanding" about the nature of a Disney park, and said that many other companies, particularly airlines, maintained appearance codes just as strict. "We happened to put ours in writing," he added. 5 Percent Drop Out **********A generalized code, he said, was required because employees in "backstage" positions might be asked any given day to assume a job that would involve contact with the public, and therefore all workers needed to maintain an appearance appropriate for that possibility.  In any case, he said he knew of no one who had refused to take a job because of the rules, and he said that no more than 5 percent of the people showing up at the walk-in casting center for interviews, nearly 400 a day, had decided not to proceed after viewing the 15-minute video, which details transportation and salary as well as the appearance code. **********But Stephane Baudet, a 28-year-old trumpet player from Paris, said in an interview that he refused to audition for a job in a Disney brass band when he learned he would have to cut his ponytail, which flaps a few inches over his collar. He said he was also dissuaded by the long hours and low pay -- 6,000 francs ($1,150) a month, or about 20 percent more than the French minimum wage. **********"Some people will turn themselves into a pumpkin to work at Euro Disneyland," he said. "But not me."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/31/busin.main_headline: Money Movers Caught in the Turbulent Times of the 90's; John S. Reed: Brazen Image Is Tarnished
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/31/busin.print_headline: THE YEAR IN FINANCE: NEWSMAKERS IN 1991; Money Movers Caught in the Turbulent Times of the 90's; John S. Reed: Brazen Image Is Tarnished
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/31/busin.body_text: **********When John S. Reed became chairman of Citicorp in 1984, he inherited the nation's largest banking company, and one that was so confident of its abilities that it did not shy from risks that other bankers would not even consider. **********Today, with the economy in the first recession of his tenure, Citicorp is a more humble place. Its image has been badly tarnished by increasing loan losses, particularly the more risky kinds of loans for commercial real estate projects and corporate take-overs. A few months ago, the financial strain from bad loans forced the company to eliminate its common stock dividend. **********Mr. Reed, who has never been a lending officer, rose through the ranks at Citicorp as a strategic planner and all-purpose executive, whose greatest success was developing Citicorp's very profitable consumer banking and credit card businesses. **********Now he is back at the drawing board, figuring how to cut $1.7 billion of expenses by the end of 1992 without also cutting revenues. If successful, the cost cutting would restore Citicorp's profit margin to a level that could absorb the continuing losses of its corporate banking business. **********So far, the financial markets have been skeptical, however, and at one point Citicorp's stock price fell to $8.50, its lowest level in 11 years. Throughout the year there were persistent rumors about the company, among them that its leader would step aside. The company has denied most of the talk but acknowledges that as long as the economy remains weak, its loan losses will remain high. **********As the holder of 552,000 shares, if the cost-cutting plan is not successful, Mr. Reed has more than his reputation at stake.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.main_headline: New York Bangladeshis Cry for a Battered Land
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.print_headline: New York Bangladeshis Cry for a Battered Land
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/world.body_text: **********Mubashir Choudhury takes a break from his job at a Manhattan restaurant at least once a day to pray at the Madina Masjid, a small mosque on the corner of First Avenue and 11th Street. Usually, his thoughts focus on his love of God and his devotion to Islam. **********On Sunday night, Mr. Choudhury prayed for Bangladesh. **********He was joined by 15 or so other Bangladeshis, all whispering in Bengali, the language that links them to the millions of people whose lives have been devastated by the cyclone that struck their native country on April 29. **********"God, help our people," Mr. Choudhury said, bowing his head and clasping his hands as he kneeled on the carpeted floor. A Sense of Utter Sadness **********The cyclone has left many of the tens of thousands of Bangladeshis in the New York area with an almost unbearable sense of sadness. Of all countries, some said, their poor and troubled land could least handle such a calamity. **********In restaurants in the East Village and on lower Lexington Avenue, in food stores in Jackson Heights, Queens, and in mosques in Brooklyn, Bangladeshis told stories of frantic but unsuccessful attempts to telephone their relatives to learn whether they were still alive. **********More than a week after the disaster, few people have received news. **********"I keep trying to call, but there just are no lines," said Zebu Nahar Husain, who in the fall left Cox's Bazar, a resort town and one of the places hit hardest by the storm, for New York. She works at Kalustyan's Orient Expert Trading, a store on lower Lexington Avenue that sells Asian and Middle East food. **********Ms. Husain, 23 years old, said she feared that her family was suffering or dead. "I think about them all the time," she said. "I just can't sleep. I stay up every night and I have difficulty working."  The Next Dangers **********Absar Chowdhury, 35, who also works at Kalustyan's, said: "We are all scared because nobody knows who died and who survived. It's getting worse now as the days go on because there will be more casualties from famine and lack of medicine." **********Mr. Chowdhury's relatives are from Chittagong, the nation's second-largest city, where as many as 90,000 people may have drowned. **********In Jackson Heights, many Bangladeshis have sought news at the Ganges travel agency, which specializes in booking flights to the Indian subcontinent. But Inayet Rahim, an agent there, has had little to tell them. **********"We were not prepared for this," he said. "The last time it happened to this extent was so long ago. We felt shocked. A lot of people are trying to go back to the country, but they are not getting any seats because there are so few flights going there." **********The cyclone, in which at least 125,000 people have died, by official count, has led many Bangladeshis, Indians and Pakistanis to band together and send money to survivors. **********On Sunday, a number of local groups met at the United Nations to form a disaster relief committee that hopes to raise $100,000. Jamshed R. Khan, an officer of Bangladesh Shangshad, a social service group, estimated that more than 50,000 Bangladeshis live in the New York area, many of them recent arrivals. **********"We just want to help them in any way we can," said Mr. Khan, a marketing executive at Mobil Oil. "We need money and medical supplies. Everybody is very concerned. We see pictures on television, but nobody knows about their families. Even though I have been here for 27 years, my heart is there." **********On Friday, the Muslim sabbath, thousands of Bangladeshis packed into mosques in Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn. Prayers were offered for those affected by the storm. Some dug into their savings to help. **********But many Bangladeshi immigrants have low-paying jobs and little money to spare. More than 300 attended prayers on Friday at the Bangladesh Muslim Center at 1013 Church Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, and $146 was raised. **********For some, the storm prompted harrowing memories of the destruction wrought by cyclones they had lived through before they left the country. **********"Even if people live, they live in miserable conditions," said Gulam Kibriya, a 46-year-old accountant who came to New York in 1983, after services on Sunday night at the Madina Masjid. "Everything is scarce. They are helpless. They have no financial or technical resources." **********Iqbal Hossain, 31, who left Bangladesh in 1989, said he could not help thinking about how his country has been plagued by misfortune for so long. **********"We just passed a stage where we got rid of a dictator," he said, referring to the country's deposed military leader, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad. **********"We are now a democracy, and then this terrible tragedy happened. We fought so much; we should have time to get ourselves together. But now, everything has been washed away. Now, we have nothing."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.main_headline: Patents; Camera Can Capture All Sides of a Scene
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.print_headline: Patents; Camera Can Capture All Sides of a Scene
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Imagine trying to take a panoramic picture from inside the Grand Canyon. Most cameras, no matter how good or how wide their lenses, cannot capture more than one side of the scene at a time. **********Now, a news photographer for The Los Angeles Times has patented a portable and comparatively inexpensive camera that spins around on its handle and shoots a scene from all sides in one long exposure. **********Invented by Rick Corrales, the invention is a refinement of much larger and unwieldy "slit-scan" cameras used to photograph high school graduation classes and other large crowds. **********In contrast to conventional cameras, which expose a frame of film to a scene at one time as the shutter opens and closes, slit-scan cameras feature film that speeds across an exposed slit in one direction as the camera turns in the opposite direction. **********Before his camera, Mr. Corrales said, all slit-scan cameras used huge film, eight inches wide. Large chambers were required and the camera had to be mounted on tripods. The new camera, called the Spinshot, uses ordinary 35-millimeter film and is small enough to be hand-held. The resulting pictures consist of a long and narrow image, and use about six normal frames of film. **********Mr. Corrales said he had used the camera at work to capture the inside of a baseball stadium, a group of children jumping rope and earthquake destruction both up and down a street. **********The inventor began marketing an early model of the camera in June 1990. The new patent, Mr. Corrales's third on the basic idea, covers a spring-loaded version that requires no independent power supply. The new model is not yet available. **********Mr. Corrales received patent 5,021,813.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/busin.main_headline: Dollar Called Important As Factor in Fed Policy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Dollar Called Important As Factor in Fed Policy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/busin.body_text: **********The dollar, seemingly ignored by the Federal Reserve Board when it was weak, may be rising in importance as a policy consideration now that it is strong, credit market analysts say. **********There are good economic and political reasons for the Fed to be concerned. **********Export growth, one of the lone sources of consistent strength over the last year, is slowing. And the dollar's run-up against the German mark has been so sharp that the Bundesbank may be forced to raise German interest rates, which could push the cost of reunification to prohibitive levels.  Two Alternative Courses **********The Fed has at least two alternative courses if it wants to stem the dollar's rise: massively dumping dollars in the foreign exchange markets along with other central banks, or if it decides against intervention, it could ease domestic interest rates again. **********"Bringing the dollar down has to have a higher priority" than previously, said Lawrence Chimerine, senior adviser to Data Resources Inc., the economic forecasting firm. "I am hearing that export orders are starting to slow further, and given the debt overhang we have, the only real stimulus you are going to get from lower interest rates is in exports." **********In a weekly letter to clients, William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, wrote that "since the Fed has consistently identified the trade sector as being extremely important to any recovery process in the United States, the credit authorities may now be more willing to lower interest rates to brake the dollar's upward climb" to sustain export momentum.  Not All Are Convinced **********Not all economists are convinced that the dollar's rise will have much influence on how the Fed conducts monetary policy. **********"Our central bank normally cares about inflation or growth, depending on where we are in the business cycle," said Alan Sinai, president of Boston Company Economic Advisers.
