"Currency is a tangential concern. The strong dollar makes it easier for the Fed to ease if it wants to, but right now priority No. 1 is the economy." **********Although the predominant evidence supports the view that the economy remains in recession, analysts who have been predicting that an upturn would begin by midyear have more reason to believe in their forecast than they did a month ago.  Houses and Economic Index **********Recent reports on housing starts and sales suggest conditions in that depressed sector of the economy may have bottomed out. **********And Mr. Sinai noted that the increase of 1.1 percentage points in February's index of leading economic indicators was almost certain to be followed by another gain in March, given the run-up in stock prices, the growth in money supply and the sharp rise in consumer confidence that has occurred. Three straight months of gains in the index are almost always followed by an upturn in the economy, he said. **********Even the optimists concede that more bad news is coming. And strong dollar or no, Mr. Chimerine and others said that the Fed was not likely to ease policy further unless bond yields fell in the face of additional signs of economic weakness. **********Based on Wall Street forecasts, such signs will probably be seen this week, beginning with the March survey of the nation's purchasing managers, which is expected to be released today. Most analysts are expecting the report to show that although conditions in the manufacturing sector improved marginally from February, activity remains at a very low level.  Employment Data Due **********The most important news is not expected until Friday, however, when the Labor Department is scheduled to release March employment data. Based on recent trends in initial unemployment claims, John Lonski, a senior economist at Moody's Investors Service, projected that nonfarm payroll employment fell by 225,000 in March, following the February drop of 184,000. **********A decline of that size would almost certainly push up the unemployment rate from its current level of 6.5 percent. And some analysts said that if the report also shows little growth in hourly wages, the Fed might be tempted to respond by easing policy further. **********That view is far from uniform. **********The Fed, which lowered short-term interest rates after the last two employment reports, is not likely to move again until it sees a slowing in broad-based inflation measures like the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index. **********Analysts, who have been surprised and perplexed by the resilience of inflationary pressures in the midst of an economic downturn, expect to see an improvement in the March data, which are expected next week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/world.main_headline: U.N. Says Iraq Admits Research on Atomic Bombs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/world.print_headline: U.N. Says Iraq Admits Research on Atomic Bombs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/world.body_text: **********The Iraqi authorities for the first time have admitted in a written declaration that they conducted research on building atomic bombs, the chief of the United Nations inspection team said here tonight. **********Dimitri Perricos, the head of the seventh United Nations team to visit Iraq to supervise the disposal of Baghdad's weapons of mass destruction, said on the eve of his departure that the Iraqi authorities this week "made a declaration they had launched a research and study program on the weaponization process." **********Mr. Perricos added that Baghdad had merely confirmed what a previous team discovered, "so in a way, this has been a proven thing now." **********The previous team, led by David Kay, an American official of the International Atomic Energy Agency, seized large quantities of documents last month from the offices of the Iraqi atomic energy department. They showed that Iraqi scientists were actively pursuing a program to produce weapons-grade, highly enriched uranium and reprocessed plutonium for use in various nuclear weapons designs, officials said. **********In addition, United Nations teams have found evidence that Iraq obtained from Western and other foreign suppliers technology to test various industrial processes that could lead to large-scale production of bomb-grade uranium by the mid-1990s. **********But until this week, Iraqi officials continued to insist in their official statements that their nuclear program amounted to research into "peaceful" uses of atomic enrgy. **********Mr. Perricos, speaking to reporters outside his hotel, said he would not discuss the contents of the Iraqi declaration, but he characterized its significance by saying, "It was the first time that they themselves admitted that they had research and studies launched into a program of what they say we call weaponization and what they say they call just research." **********Referring to the Iraqis, Mr. Perricos said, "They, of course, insist that the whole program that they had was intended only to have them ready in case a political decision was taken" to go forward with a bomb program. **********This formulation by the Iraqis may be an attempt to shield President Saddam Hussein and his Government from a charge of violating the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty of 1968, which the international agency is charged with enforcing. Iraq signed the treaty and thus forswore the development of nuclear weapons. It also agreed to open all of its nuclear installations to international inspection. **********During this year's inspections by United Nations teams searching for secret nuclear research laboratories and equipment, Iraqi press organizations have attacked the United Nations for applying a double standard to Iraq by failing to insist that Israel sign the nonproliferation treaty and open its nuclear weapons centers to international inspection. **********Mr. Perricos declined to say when the next nuclear inspection team would arrive in Baghdad, but another United Nations official said Mr. Perricos would head the next team on Nov. 10. Another United Nations team will be responsible for disposing chemical weapons still here. A team of ballistics experts left last week after identifying and destroying a number of Scud missile sites. **********The United Nations official added that Mr. Kay, whose inspection mission last month escalated into a four-day standoff with the Iraqi authorities in a Baghdad parking lot, had resigned his post at the International Atomic Energy Agency, which is based in Vienna, to take a new and unspecified job. **********Mr. Perricos and his team arrived on Oct. 12 and conducted some "short-notice" inspections of weapons installations using German helicopters and crews. He said the team had destroyed some centrifuge equipment, which is used for enriching uranium, and some reprocessing equipment, which is used to separate usable uranium and plutonium isotopes for weapons production. **********He also said the team was still in the midst of a "painstaking" collection and measuring process to catalogue and remove all of the nuclear fuel that had been purchased by Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/04/busin.main_headline: Prices Drop on Notes and Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/04/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Prices Drop on Notes and Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Fresh signs of a looming economic recovery prompted credit market participants to sell Treasury notes and bonds yesterday, pushing up both short- and long-term interest rates. **********Results from the May survey of the nation's purchasing managers, which showed that conditions in the manufacturing sector improved for the fourth straight month, as well as a report showing that construction spending rose by eight-tenths of a percent in April, helped to spur the selling. **********Concern that recovery could fuel inflation was fostered yesterday by a spurt in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 spot commodity prices. The index rose by more than 2 points, to 217.69. **********The economic data were the latest in a string of reports over the past few weeks that strongly suggest the recession is coming to an end. **********"Every day that goes by, the chances of another Fed easing diminishes," said Richard Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers. **********"For the market, the issue will be whether the Fed stays neutral for a protracted period of time, or whether they move to tighten monetary policy. We think the recovery will be moderate, inflation will remain under control and that they won't tighten policy. But it will take the market some time to be convinced of that." **********The diminished prospect of another move by the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates helped to push up short-term money market rates and forced up rates on new three-month and six-month Treasury bills at the weekly auction.  Three- and Six-Month Bills **********At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.59 percent, up sharply from an average rate of 5.46 percent a week ago. **********Bids on six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.71 percent, up from an average rate of 5.65 percent at last week's auction. **********"I don't think the market is going to fall out of bed from here, but there are some jitters about the recovery story," said John P. Costas, a managing director at the First Boston Corporation. **********Mr. Costas said prices are likely to trade in a narrow range from now until Friday, when the Government is expected to release May employment data. **********Yesterday's drop in Treasury prices, which amounted to more than 3/4 of a point on some securities, came on thin volume. **********In the secondary Treasury securities market, the 8 1/8 percent benchmark 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 97 21/32 late yesterday, down 27/32, to yield 8.33 percent, up from 8.26 percent late Friday. **********"I think this strength in the economy we are seeing is temporary and will stall out as we move into summer," said Edward S. Hyman, president of International Strategy and Investment, an investment advisory firm. **********"But if bond yields go much higher, the issue of whether or not the recovery will continue will be a moot point because higher rates will snuff it out." **********Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 2/32 late yesterday, down 19/32, to yield 8.13 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes, which have been extremely strong lately, fell by 6/32 in price, to 99 30/32, to yield 6.78 percent. **********In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Ford Capital BV offered $300 million of five-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. **********The 9 percent notes, which mature June 1, 1996, were priced at $99.814, to yield 9.046 percent, 1.25 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 5/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing. **********The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********The slide in Treasury prices had a depressing effect in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds. Traders said that prices of most issues fell by 1/2 of a point to 5/8 of a point. **********In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted securities fell by about 3/8 of a point. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction three-month and six-month Treasury bills:  (000 omitted in dollar figures)               3-Mo. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/world.main_headline: Independent Newspapers and Broadcasters Draw Coup's Early Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/world.print_headline: THE SOVIET CRISIS; Independent Newspapers and Broadcasters Draw Coup's Early Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/world.body_text: **********As the Kremlin power shift took hold of the nation today, some of the earliest targets were the independent newspapers that had taken healthy root in the years of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's glasnost policy of press freedom. **********The new Kremlin group that seized power from Mr. Gorbachev attended to the newspapers quickly. In its second emergency proclamation of the day, it required them to reregister with the Government for approval to publish again. **********"If we introduce a state of emergency, we have to make certain provisions for reregistering the mass media," said Vice President Gennadi I. Yanayev after he assumed President Gorbachev's powers in behalf of the Kremlin's new State Committee for the State of Emergency. **********He added that the independent newspapers "have played a certain role" in bringing on the crisis that the emergency committee contends is engulfing the nation.  Printers Plan Not to Work **********Here in Moscow, the order spared only newspapers clearly loyal or unchallenging to the Government. But printers at one of these, Izvestia, the Government newspaper, said they would refuse to work in sympathy with the call for a general strike by Boris N. Yeltsin, the president of the Russian republic. **********Mr. Yanayev contended that the order did not block publication of the independent newspapers, but the effect was the same, since the Government can delay or complicate the registration process as much as it wants. **********Some of the targeted newspapers sought alternative ways to stay in touch with the public. Moscow News, one of the earliest and best-read of the glasnost newspapers, began distributing snippets of news via fax machines across the city.  Broadcasters Are Barred **********In addition to the newspapers, the Kremlin emergency committee also moved against the several independent broadcast news outlets. News workers of Radio Russia and Russian television were denied entry to their broadcast studios by soldiers. These outlets have become critical factors in assisting the growth of opposition politics. **********Such independent newspapers as Nezavisimaya Gazeta had been particularly bedevilling the Communist Party in recent months, publishing its red-ink accounts of members' declining to pay dues and quitting the party. The paper also had an exclusive account of Mr. Gorbachev's plan to force a new, more liberally worded charter on the party. **********The order from the Emergency Committee said the intent was to "temporarily limit" the ban on the newspapers, and to refer the issue to a "special organ" to be created by the committee. **********But reporters from the papers at Mr. Yanayev's news conference were unable to get a clear idea from him of how the Government registration process would work as they peppered him with questions about the disappearance of Mr. Gorbachev.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/busin.main_headline: Ortho Wins Damages In Dispute Over Drug
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Ortho Wins Damages In Dispute Over Drug
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/busin.body_text: **********A private arbitrator in a contract dispute between Amgen Inc. and its leading marketing partner for the drug erythropoietin, the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, has ordered Amgen to pay $164 million in damages. **********As a result, Amgen said yesterday that it would record a charge of approximately $88.5 million after taxes against earnings for the quarter ended June 30. The award to Ortho's parent, Johnson & Johnson, was higher than analysts' estimates. Amgen shares fell 87.5 cents, to $117, in over-the-counter trading. Johnson & Johnson's rose $1, to $84.50, on the Big Board. **********The arbitrator, Frank J. McGarr, a senior judge from Chicago, said no damage payment would be made until a final judgment was rendered on Amgen's claims against Johnson & Johnson for Interleukin 2 and a hepatitis B vaccine, two other products covered by the arbitration. The award to Amgen, if any, could lower the amount it must pay Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J.. The next hearing is scheduled for Sept. 9. **********Nevertheless, Amgen officials played down the significance of the award, which is the first significant decision to go against the biotechnology company based in Thousand Oaks, Calif. **********"The ultimate payment of damages in this arbitration is not expected to have a material adverse impact on the operations of Amgen," said Gordon M. Binder, Amgen's chairman and chief executive. **********Ortho and Amgen had a falling out in February 1989, just as erythropoietin, known as EPO, was nearing approval by the Food and Drug Administration. Ortho filed suit, contending that Amgen had not honored the terms of a 1985 contract, and asked the court to block F.D.A. approval for the drug unless Amgen also made the necessary filings for Ortho. The licensing agreement gave Ortho the right to sell the drug in Europe and the United States for patients other than those on kidney dialysis; Amgen retained the American dialysis market. **********Amgen received F.D.A. approval in June 1989 for kidney dialysis. In April 1990, Judge McGarr directed Ortho to buy all EPO it sells in the United States from Amgen. Ortho received F.D.A. approval in January to use EPO with the anti-viral drug AZT to treat AIDS patients. **********The damages awarded to Johnson & Johnson today reflect lost revenues from the 19 months it was delayed from entering the American market. **********Amgen also filed a motion in Federal District Court in Boston today, requesting that an order blocking Genetics Institute from selling EPO be reinstated, along with the escrow account for Genetics Institute's past shipments of the drug. A Federal appeals court ruled in March that Genetics was infringing Amgen's patent. Genetics Institute, based in Cambridge, Mass., has asked to have the case reviewed by the Supreme Court.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/busin.body_text: **********Amid the general market surge, the stocks of eight retailing companies reached 52- week highs yesterday, reflecting a perception among investors that the recession could end in the current quarter. **********The new highs included Albertson Stores, up $2.50, to $42; Dillard Department Stores, $1.125, to $106; Food Lion, 25 cents, to $16.375; Gap, 62.5 cents, to $47; Home Depot, $2.125, to $51.75; K Mart, $1.25, to $38.625, and Limited, $1.50, to $25.75. **********"We think the recession will end in the second quarter," said Daniel D. Barry, Kidder, Peabody's retail analyst in New York. "After being hammered last fall, retail stocks outperformed the market, and now the new highs are telling us that the end of the war will definitely lead to a pickup." **********Wayne Hood, a retail analyst at Prudential Capital Funding, said retailing stocks are historically among the first to respond to economic change.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/26/world.main_headline: Space Center or Not, Some Say It's Still a Jungle
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/26/world.print_headline: KOUROU JOURNAL; Space Center or Not, Some Say It's Still a Jungle
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/26/world.body_text: **********In the 10-year life of Arianespace, the French-led European rocket venture, France has not only built the world's busiest commercial satellite launching center here, but has also sought to create from scratch a modern French city in the heart of this onetime equatorial penal colony. **********Shiny Peugeots tool through Kourou's smooth new streets, pastis and familiar wines are served up in bars, and yellow- and blue-uniformed men from La Poste even deliver the mail by bicycle here, all contributing to a sense of urban French life. **********But residents of Kourou are finding that recreating a French ambiance amid the surrounding Amazonian jungle is no simple affair. **********As recently as the early 1970's, Kourou slumbered in oblivion as a quiet fishing village whose main distinction was a feature that many of its several hundred residents would have just as soon forgotten. **********For decades, the small port here served as the final point of embarkation for hardened French criminals and those convicted of political crimes being shipped off to Devil's Island, the infamous penal colony that lies off in the sunny distance. **********Since then, however, the billions of dollars spent on the Arianespace project, Europe's bid to join the highly competitive commercial satellite-launching business, have made once-forlorn Kourou a formidable magnet for thousands who have streamed here for honor or fortune. Hustlers Arrive, Too **********While about 1,100 French and European technicians have moved here with their families, overseeing the launching of 43 Ariane rockets to date, untold thousands of semiskilled contract workers, desperate job hunters and plain hustlers have rushed in as well, from Brazil, Suriname, Guyana, Colombia, Haiti and countries as far away as China. **********Despite the planners' attempts to recreate the feel of one of the many modern professional neighborhoods that ring Paris, many here say Kourou's ever-richer ethnic blend has led to a climate of deep-seated suspicions and festering jealousies that contribute to a sense of unease for all. **********"I have lived all over the world, in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, and never have I been to a place where it was more difficult to feel comfortable," said a shop owner transplanted from France, whose husband is the representative of an electronics company. "Here in Kourou, a city without a soul or a center, everyone detests everyone else." **********Ethnic division, if unsanctioned, is everywhere in evidence. Legionnaires and other French soldiers congregate in their own raucous bar, where few dark-skinned residents venture, while most other clubs here are either exclusively French or operate on an informal ethnic rotation, Brazilian one night, Creole the next. **********The population of Kourou was recently put at 14,000, but with its sprawling squatters' quarters and other makeshift neighborhoods housing clandestine residents, the city seems perhaps twice as large. **********As the French here have grown more insecure, their complaints about foreigners, blamed for everything from street-corner prostitution to a wave of armed robberies, have grown louder. Recently, graffiti slogans proclaiming the virtues of the National Front, France's far-right anti-immigration party, have begun springing up widely. **********"This is not at all like living in France," said Jacques Brugerie, a municipal counsellor originally from Strasbourg who says that allowing more people to move here from neighboring countries is the only way to develop Guiana. "There is the heat and the isolation, but most of all the incredible mixture of people. Some people get off the plane from Paris and want to go back home right away. They detest it immediately." **********Yves Dejean, a former Deputy Mayor of Kourou and director of logistics at the space center, says he tells newcomers from France: "You can't have any illusions. If you think this is going to be Paris or Toulouse, you are going to be miserable, but I don't, and I love it." **********Even more put out by the arrival of outsiders, which to many of them includes the French, despite the fact that Guiana became an overseas department of France in 1946, are the Creoles. **********The Creoles, black or mixed-race people whose ancestors came as slaves or arrived as refugees from a volcano explosion in Martinique early this century, are bitterly witnessing their decades-long dominance of politics and the professions slip away. Strikers Block Roads **********With their grip on local government threatened, the Creoles have lately turned to making the Arianespace center itself the target of demonstrations to gain leverage for social demands ranging from greater participation in the space program to better schools and housing, playing on French fears that they will revive a sporadic quest for independence. **********For the second time in the last year, just as preparations for a recent satellite launching were entering their final phase, striking members of the Guiana Workers Union, a Creole-dominated institution, used huge trucks to block roads leading in and out of the space center. **********Milling workers, echoing opinions widely heard among Creoles, complained how the preoccupation of France with space supposedly blinded it to social problems in Guiana. "The French come here for two or three years to make their money and go back to France," a striker said. "They don't care about the Guianese people, and if it weren't for their rockets, they wouldn't care about Guiana."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/15/world.main_headline: Tomb of Warlike Maya King Found in Guatemala
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/15/world.print_headline: Tomb of Warlike Maya King Found in Guatemala
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/15/world.body_text: **********Archeologists digging in the jungle of Guatemala have found the tomb and remains of an eighth-century ruler who they believe began the policies of militarism and territorial expansion that eventually led to the collapse of the classical Maya civilization. **********Dr. Arthur A. Demarest, an archeologist at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, announced yesterday that the discovery was made beneath the ruins of a pyramid at Dos Pilas, the ancient capital of the Petexbatun region of Guatemala. The tomb contained the skeleton of a man accompanied by a regal headdress of jade, conch and pearl, obsidian blades probably used in bloodletting ceremonies and ceramics inscribed with hieroglyphics. **********Scholars at the site said they were almost certain that the skeleton is that of Ruler 2, so called because the hieroglyphics giving his name have not been deciphered. A monument at the pyramid indicates that this is the burial site of that particular king, and the writing on pottery found inside the tomb is expected to confirm the skeleton's identity. **********"It looks like we've got a large dead king in there," Dr. Demarest said in an interview by telephone from Guatemala. Evidence of Relentless Warfare **********The discovery of the tomb, along with excavations of extensive fortifications at Dos Pilas and other evidence of relentless warfare, is expected to figure in new interpretations of the Maya as a more militaristic people than had been thought by earlier scholars. It could also illuminate the causes of the mysterious fall of lowland Maya culture beginning in the eighth century and culminating in the 10th. **********"This is going to change the textbooks radically," Dr. Demarest said. "Ruler 2 was a pivotal figure in the initiation of the catastrophic sequence of events in which the polity broke up into a dozen warring states that militarized the landscape within a period of 50 years and may have destroyed the ecology of the region." **********Ruler 2 reigned between 698 and 725 over the Petexbatun region, which spanned some 2,000 square miles along the Pasion River in northern Guatemala. Ruler 2 and his successor conquered neighboring city-states and created the largest kingdom in Maya history. The classic Maya period began with the rise of large cities and elaborate ceremonial centers around A.D. 250 and, in the south at least, collapsed by the year 900. **********Other archeologists said this was one of the most significant recent discoveries in Maya studies. But many of them were not yet prepared to accept Dr. Demarest's interpretation that a rapid escalation of warfare and territorial expansion doomed the Maya civilization. **********Dr. Jeremy A. Sabloff, an authority on Maya archeology at the University of Pittsburgh, called Dr. Demarest's research "very important and exciting," but said he doubted that a single factor, like destructive warfare, accounted for the fall of the Maya civilization. **********He noted that, contrary to some accounts, the entire Maya civilization did not collapse at the end of the classic period. The cities in the southern lowlands of present-day Guatemala declined, but in the north the major ceremonial centers of the Yucatan in Mexico were built. **********Dr. David Webster, an archeologist at Pennsylvania State University who specializes in Maya warfare, said the discovery "will tell us a great deal about the dissolution of these kingdoms and about the role of warfare in this dissolution." **********Excavations at Dos Pilas, Dr. Webster said, focused attention on a major shift in scholarly attitudes toward the Maya culture. Until recent years, scholars tended to idealize the Maya as a peaceful and industrious people. The only warfare was supposed to be the limited, ritualized battles fought between rulers as part of dynastic struggles, but rarely involving the common people. That interpretation reflected the apparent absence of fortifications at Mayan cities, but overlooked evidence on icons depicting warfare and human sacrifice. **********With his discoveries of moats, fortifications and other signs of widespread military activity, Dr. Demarest has become a leader in the revisionist thinking. **********"The Petexbatun kingdom collapsed into warfare far more destructive than we had ever imagined," Dr. Demarest said in explaining the new findings at Dos Pilas. "The landscape and settlement pattern became almost medieval as many smaller states fought for survival." **********In the turmoil, food shortages forced peasants into destructive farming practices in the fragile rain forest and drove people into overcrowded, impoverished cities for protection behind stone walls and trenches. The kingdom controlled by Dos Pilas disintegrated in 760, and the area was abandoned by 830. **********The tomb was found deep in the core of a major funerary temple on the east side of the Great Plaza of Dos Pilas. Archeologists found the tomb intact, but the stone vault on the verge of collapse. Once they can get inside for a more thorough investigation, they expect to find jade jewelry, ceremonial objects, carved bone and more pottery with hieroglyphic writing that could tell some of the history of this fateful period. **********Dr. Demarest's excavations, which involved more than 40 scholars and graduate students, are financed in part by the National Endowment for the Humanities and the National Geographic Society. A co-sponsor is the Institute of Anthropology and History in Guatemala City.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/world.main_headline: Though Jobless, a High-Level Apparatchik Sheds No Tears for His Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; Though Jobless, a High-Level Apparatchik Sheds No Tears for His Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/world.body_text: **********Nikolai S. Portugalov was a member of the Soviet Communist Party for 40 of his 63 years, holding the rank of senior counselor in its once all-powerful Central Committee when the whole structure crashed in ruins last month after the failed coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********"I never thought I'd be out on the street and accused of being a member of a criminal organization," Mr. Portugalov said in an interview today. "But I'm not shedding any tears for the party." **********He said he could not even remember his party card number, or think why he should even try. Mr. Gorbachev had already seen to it two years ago that the party card had stopped being a coveted badge of privilege, entitling its owner to supplies of food, clothing and housing not available to ordinary mortals. **********"I hadn't been to a party meeting for five years," he said. "The party had long since outlived its usefulness, and it was not reformable -- too inextricably bound up with the totalitarian state."  Popular Resentment Recalled **********It is easy to talk about the party that way now that it is gone. But more than a year ago, Mr. Portugalov had been saying popular resentment of the party was so great that he feared for his safety in the streets at night. **********Whether he really thought it was on its way out as early as four years ago, as he now says, is hard to judge. What is clear is that like thousands of other Central Committee staff members who have been clearing their personal belongings this week out of its collection of pre-revolutionary buildings in Old Square, this apparatchik is now unemployed. **********He did not seem particularly worried about it today. Neither did a few of his friends and colleagues from the party's international department, scuttling out a back entrance and carrying bags and briefcases full of books and personal effects past heavily armed police guards. **********Mr. Portugalov got many of his belongings out over the last week, and is not concerned about the rest. His apartment belongs to the Moscow city authorities, and he does not expect them to try to evict him and his ailing wife, Tamara. But he is prepared for a rise in the rent, which is now, including utilities, 50 rubles a month -- the equivalent of $1.56 at the official tourist exchange rate. **********In a reminder of the Stalinist past, Mr. Portugalov lives on Pavlik Morozov Lane, named after a young Communist Pioneer who was glorified by the party after being killed by relatives for having turned in his own parents to the authorities during the bloody collectivization of agriculture in the 1930's.  Party's Archives Sealed **********The party's archives and official files have all been sealed since Aug. 24, when Mr. Gorbachev, angry at support for the putsch from the party he headed, suspended its central apparatus and put party property into the hands of the Soviet Parliament. **********Since Parliament, too, will apparently soon be suspended by Mr. Gorbachev and the presidents of the Soviet republics, the Moscow city authorities have taken over responsibility for overseeing the Central Committee's dismemberment. **********Mr. Portugalov is one of the Soviet Union's leading experts on Germany, and his bespectacled face and polished German are familiar to practically every adult in that country, from the many television appearances he has been making on behalf of Soviet policies since the days of Leonid I. Brezhnev and Yuri V. Andropov. **********One reason he is not worried is that he thinks that people like him will continue to be necessary -- if not in the party, then outside it. He said he hoped now that he might join President Gorbachev's foreign policy staff, or, failing that, that some German news organization or German-Soviet joint venture would hire him, at some multiple of his 800-ruble-a-month Central Committee salary, $25 at the official tourist rate.  'I Was on Vacation' **********Mr. Gorbachev, who dismissed Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh last month for showing too much "passivity" and lying low during the coup, might not find Mr. Portugalov's account of his loyalty very convincing, though he swears it is undying. **********"I was on vacation at one of the Central Committee dachas on the outskirts of Moscow," he recounted today, "and on Aug. 19, I decided to take one of the buses that ferries people back and forth every Monday, to come in and pick up the newspapers; there aren't any out at the dacha. I came into the office and bought a paper in the lobby, and there I saw the strange announcement that Gorbachev was sick and had been relieved of his duties." **********"It's a coup, I thought to myself," he said. "It had been long enough coming, and talk of one had been in the air. But I decided I'd have nothing to do with these people until Gorbachev either said himself that he was resigning or was killed." **********From his talks with his colleagues, Mr. Portugalov estimated that a third of the members of the 150-member international department favored the coup, about a third opposed it, and a third were prepared to go either way. Valentin M. Falin, the department's chief, made his opposition clear about the time the coup failed, two days later, he said.  Listening to Voice of America **********Mr. Portugalov went back to the dacha with his papers and spent the next day tuned to the Voice of America, as Mr. Gorbachev did himself, coup-bound in the Crimea. He returned to Moscow the same day the President did, on Wednesday, Aug. 21. **********"On Friday, I went into the office again to pick up the papers," Mr. Portugalov said. He called his son, Sergei, a sports doctor, and asked him to meet him at the main entrance, No. 3, at 9 A.M. "He told me there was a mob there and that the entrance was closed," his father said. **********Meeting instead at the Dzerzhinsky Square station, the two men went to a back entrance to the Central Committee, and Mr. Portugalov went in to retrieve a few of the 300 or so books he kept at his office. He left with his son about noon, and took a taxi with the books back to the dacha. **********A few hours later, the rest of the Central Committee staff was advised to leave the building for their own safety, and the building was sealed. **********On Saturday morning, Aug. 24, Mr. Portugalov said, he came back into town again and called one of his Central Committee colleagues, Andrei Grachev, who was about to leave on a trip to Finland. "You won't get back in again," Mr. Grachev told his friend. "It's all sealed off."  'Let's Wait and See' **********"Let's wait and see what happens Monday," Mr. Portugalov decided. **********On Monday, Aug. 26, he approached the main entrance on Old Square and saw that, indeed, all the entrances had been sealed and barricaded. Going around to the back door again, just below the staff cafeteria and the party grocery store, he saw a crowd of his colleagues huddled on the steps in the rain. **********Some had left their bankbooks in their desks, others the keys to their dachas, others who knows what. "The police wouldn't let us inside," Mr. Portugalov said. "They said they had to make sure first that the files wouldn't be destroyed, and that we'd get in later." **********After some hours, the group of about 50 was told that they would be allowed into their offices under police supervision. The first group of four men allowed in took two hours to get out, and Mr. Portugalov decided to try again on Wednesday. **********Then he was told to appear at Entrance 5 on Friday, Aug. 30, and get a temporary pass. He finally got in at about 2 P.M. "The police let me into my office alone," he said. "They had left the telephones connected, but not the document shredders."  Policemen Looked 'Ashamed' **********Policemen searching the packages taken out of the building looked "ashamed," Mr. Portugalov said, but a reporter for Kuranty, an independent newspaper, shouted out a question: "How are you being paid?" **********"From the secret dollar funds you're all writing about!" Mr. Portugalov shouted back. **********He knew nothing about any laundered money or secret Central Committee funds, he said, but on Saturday, when he returned again to take away more books, a policeman seized 20 sheets of plain white paper -- hard to find in Moscow -- that Mr. Portugalov tried to bring out. "State property," the policeman insisted. **********Now that the Central Committee exists no more, Mr. Portugalov said, he had been told that like everybody else who worked for it, he would get two months' severance pay from the Moscow city authorities on Thursday, and an additional possible dismissal payment, a maximum of two more months' salary, later. **********But there will be no more Central Committee dachas next summer, and no Central Committee cars and drivers to take him around to appointments. The Central Committee store is closed, but, he said, there had not been much in it anyway for the last two years, since Mr. Gorbachev started reducing party perks. **********The main thing he was worried about losing access to was the clinic where he and his wife have been treated in the past. "It wasn't a Central Committee clinic," he said. "But my wife needs an operation to remove a splint in her leg, and I hope they'll still take her." **********And in the future, he said, the country will continue to need Communists, whatever they call themselves. Ivan S. Silayev, the head of the acting Soviet government now, had been a party member and a leader of the military-industrial bureaucracy for years, but Mr. Gorbachev and President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic have now put him in charge of a temporary committee to bring a market economy to the country. **********"I think they'll continue to need German experts too," he said. "And if they don't, maybe the Germans will have me."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.main_headline: CBS News Says Crew Vanished Near Front Lines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: JOURNALISTS; CBS News Says Crew Vanished Near Front Lines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/25/world.body_text: **********A four-man CBS News crew led by the veteran correspondent Bob Simon has been missing in a front-line region of the Persian Gulf war since early Monday, the network said yesterday after the crew's vehicle was found in the Saudi desert near the Kuwaiti border. **********Four sets of footprints, apparently those of the missing men, were found in the desert trailing northward from the car into Kuwait, Saudi officials said last night. There was no word on when the vehicle had been abandoned. **********It was the first report of any news personnel missing in the nine-day war. **********As concern arose that the crew might have been captured by Iraqi forces, CBS News had quietly asked the Pentagon and American military forces in Dhahran on Wednesday for help in finding the missing men.  No Sign of a Struggle **********CBS disclosed that its crew was missing after a Saudi military unit on routine patrol found the crew's Toyota Land Cruiser yesterday morning on the side of a road near Ar Ruqi, a Saudi town just south of the southwestern corner of Kuwait. There was no sign of a struggle, CBS said, or any indication of what had happened to the newsmen. **********Saudi trackers followed the footprints northward from the car into Kuwait, but were unable to proceed past a checkpoint manned by Iraqi troops, the Saudi Defense Ministry said in a statement. **********The statement said that $6,000 in cash, television equipment, some Iraqi currency and a wristwatch with a picture on the dial of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, had been found in the crew's vehicle. Many journalists who have visited Iraq in recent weeks have purchased the watches as souvenirs. **********"We hope they've hooked up with a friendly military unit and are off somewhere and just not able to communicate," said Tom Goodman, the director of communications for CBS News. "But the reality is we just don't know their whereabouts or condition."  Last Contact on Monday **********News correspondents in war zones are occasionally unable to communicate with their offices for two or three days. It is rare for reporters to be missing as long as Mr. Simon, who last contacted the CBS base in Dhahran at about 9 A.M. Monday. **********Pete Williams, the Pentagon's spokesman, said yesterday that all allied military commanders in the northern Saudi desert had been asked to be on the lookout for the CBS crew, but that no word on the missing men had been relayed. **********Mr. Simon, a 49-year-old correspondent who covered the Vietnam War, conflicts in the Middle East and Central America and other major news events in 24 years with the network, was accompanied by Peter Bluff, 47 years old, a CBS News staff producer; Roberto Alvarez, 37, a cameraman, and Juan Caldera, 31, a sound man. Mr. Alvarez and Mr. Caldera are a freelance team based in Miami who often work for CBS. **********Mr. Simon, who has frequently filed reports from Saudi Arabia since Iraq invaded Kuwait last August, took his crew into the gulf region several weeks ago. Like an increasing number of correspondents, he was dissatisfied with the Pentagon's pool arrangements for combat reporting. He went out without a guide or military escort last week to report from the front. Not a Violation of Rules **********Such independent reporting is frowned upon by American military officials, but does not violate the Pentagon's rules for journalists covering the war. **********The town Ar Ruqi, where the newsmen's car was found parked on the side of the road, is a short distance from the desert junction of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq. It is the heart of a combat no man's land occupied on the Saudi side by the First and Second Marine Divisions, and on the Kuwaiti-Iraqi side by Iraqi troops, who have crossed the border in recent days to engage in firefights with the Americans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Loss Posted By Tribune Co.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/busin.body_text: **********The Tribune Company said today that it lost $191.4 million during the fourth quarter of 1990 because of costs associated with The Daily News of New York. **********The Daily News was sold on March 20 to the British publisher Robert Maxwell after a five-month strike by nine unions. The Tribune Company registered a $185 million after- tax charge to its fourth-quarter earnings because of the sale. **********The $191.4 million loss compared with a 1989 fourth-quarter profit of $67.6 million, or 90 cents a share. **********Operating revenue for the quarter fell 21.4 percent, to $525.3 million, from $668 million in 1989, reflecting a downturn in all operations. **********Revenue from The Daily News was off 67 percent during the quarter, from $115.2 million to $37.9 million. **********Excluding the Daily News from the financial statement, the company said it would have earned $36 million during the fourth quarter. That is down 43.8 percent from $64.1 million in the corresponding period in 1989, again excluding The Daily News. **********For all of 1990, the company had a net loss of $63.5 million, compared with a profit of $242.4 million, or $3.17 a share, in 1989. Operating revenue declined 4.1 percent, to $2.35 billion, from $2.45 billion in 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/24/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********It is wonderful to see a well-run, well-managed, profitable and environmentally responsible American company. Unfortunately, there are clear economic concerns, even for 3M, that will continue to hamper further improvement of the environment. One of the biggest is foreign competition. **********I believe that tariffs equal to the cost of pollution control should be levied against imported goods made in areas under less stringent control. The idea behind environmental laws is to help the environment, not to hurt business. Under the tariff approach, our companies could remain competitive in the home market and foreign manufacturers would have some incentive, however small, to work toward a better environment. MICHAEL J. DEREVLANY  Yorktown, N.Y., Feb. 5

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.main_headline: The Big Contrasts In 2 Japan Pacts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.print_headline: TALKING DEALS; The Big Contrasts In 2 Japan Pacts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.body_text: **********TRADE experts and American and Japanese negotiators say differences between two recently concluded trade negotiations reflect disputes within the bureaucracies of both countries, the very different styles of the American negotiators and the character of the industries involved. **********Several hours before Saturday's agreement on American access to Japanese public works projects, a senior Commerce Department official publicly announced in Tokyo that the talks were at "a complete impasse" and that the United States would draw up sanctions against Japanese companies. **********But the final negotiations for Tuesday's bilateral agreement on trade in semiconductors were conducted in Washington without public comments on their progress or announcements of threats. **********The semiconductor dispute was handled by S. Linn Williams, deputy United States trade representative, and Naomichi Suzuki, the vice minister for international trade at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry in Japan. Both are elite agencies that deal with each other on many different issues and must work to keep relations cordial. **********President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, which includes many passionately free-market economists, also played a role in the negotiations. **********The semiconductor industries in both countries also depend heavily on exports to each other, so they had stakes in a friendly outcome. And the executives and workers in that industry tend to be young, highly educated and global minded. **********In the semiconductor dispute, the United States wanted the Japanese ministry to continue to put pressure on Japanese manufacturers to buy American computer chips. Japan wanted the United States to lift sanctions imposed in 1987 on imports of hand power tools and color television sets in retaliation for the low market share that American chip companies had captured in Japan. **********The semiconductor talks ended with an agreement nearly two months before the deadline, and with little acrimony. The final deal relied heavily on private companies, with a minimum of direct government oversight. **********The construction negotiations, by contrast, ended a month after their deadline and after the United States trade representative published in the Federal Register a request for public comments on how best to ban Japanese companies from American public works projects. J. Michael Farren, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, the official who declared the talks in Tokyo at an impasse, demanded repeatedly that the Japanese Government make major changes. **********Japan eventually agreed to offer preferential bidding procedures for foreign companies on at least 17 public works contracts. **********Japan had little to gain in the construction talks because it already had access to the American market, although Japanese companies have won few public works contracts in this country. "There was nothing really hanging out there that they wanted fixed, and therefore their energy level and desire to get things done were different," said an American negotiator who insisted on anonymity. **********The threat of a sanction against Japanese companies in the United States created an incentive to an agreement comparable to lifting the sanctions imposed in 1987, the official said. **********But a Japanese negotiator, who also insisted on anonymity, said Mr. Farren's and the Commerce Department's aggressive tactics put a strain on bilateral relations. Negotiations were more relaxed with Mr. Williams, he said. **********But American officials say the difference between the approaches to negotiations may be exaggerated by the Japanese. While the Commerce Department may have had jurisdiction over the construction negotiations and the trade representative oversaw the semiconductor talks, the two agencies also assigned officials to each other's negotiating teams. **********"Commerce is close to business; there's no doubt about it," said another American negotiator who also insisted on anonymity. But he added that this made little difference in negotiations. **********The Japanese official also acknowledged that bureaucratic considerations in Japan made a construction agreement more difficult. The construction, tranportation and foreign ministries were all directly involved in the talks and accepted a need for concessions. But other agencies with no stake in the outcome were reluctant to open their public works contracts to foreign companies. **********"Those other agencies have been a little difficult to extract from bureaucratic resistance, and we had to have some help from the Prime Minister's office," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/30/world.body_text: **********Shaping a New Union **********In Transition: After three hours of anguished debate, the Soviet Parliament voted to suspend all activities of the Communist Party pending an investigation of its role in the coup. It was an action that confirmed the demise of the old even as the search quickened for new forms of association and order. And after hurriedly arranged negotiations, delegations of Ukrainians and Russians concluded an interim agreement to respect territory and deal with each other to fill the fast-spreading vacuum of political power. Page A1. **********The Process Of Change: The Soviet Union, born in 1917, was pronounced dead in Moscow after a lingering illness. But even as the politicians delivered their funeral orations over a congential defect called Communism and over the decomposing superpower, a process of reincarnation was under way. News Analysis, page A1. **********A Nuclear Rival?: Leonid M. Kravchuk, the leader of the Ukraine, has made a hurried decision to abandon his Communist career and fully join the republic's drive for independence. The incongruities of the current Soviet trauma are such that Mr. Kravchuk could lean back in his chair in the Parliament and confidently entertain questions about what it is like being the head of a theoretical nuclear superpower called the Ukraine. Page A1. At Home and Abroad **********A Commander's Plea: The commander of a unit of elite Soviet "black beret" troops, Maj. Vladislav Makutanovicz, who was active in the fight against Lithuanian independence, appealed to European countries to grant asylum to him and his 80 men. Page A13. **********Helping Republics Directly: President Bush and Prime Minister John Major of Britain said some increased food aid to the Soviet Union would bypass the central authorities and go directly to the republics seeking autonomy. Page A14. Questions of Law and Commerce **********The Rule Of Law: Soviet lawyers taking part in a special program in the United States say it will take at least a generation to convince their countrymen that lawyers need not be thought of as lackeys for the state. At the Bar, page B20. **********Aid To Soviets: As the Soviet Union struggles on the brink of economic collapse and political dissolution, the urgent question facing the West is what posture to take on foreign aid to the Soviet Union and its seceding republics. Economic Scene, page D2. **********Making Trade Easier: In Washington, the Commerce Department shortened the list of products that can be exported only with the American Government's permission, reflecting a more permissive stance toward trade with the Soviets. Business Day, page D2.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/22/busin.body_text: **********COMPANIES A.T.& T. Admits the Human Error Was on Management's Side **********When a switching station went out in Manhattan last week it sent the entire region into conniptions. Hundreds of flights had to be diverted as the region's airports closed. Five million long-distance calls were blocked. It was the third major shutdown of A.T.& T.'s long-distance service in less than two years. This time, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company cited human error. An inattentive crew failed to notice when a generator switched off, said Robert Garnet, a company spokesman. Union officials countered that it was the alarms that failed. Grudgingly, A.T.& T admitted management and technical lapses. This did not go unnoticed by its biggest rival. "A.T.& T. has described its system as self-healing and fully redundant," said Daniel F. Akerson, executive vice president of MCI, which came out with a new ad campaign in response. "Clearly it's not. Their reliability is more advertised than delivered." Where Will the Chips Fall?  It may not be Operation Desert Storm, but the potato chip wars are heating up. After years of offering coupons and other promotional deals rather than cheaper prices, Frito Lay Inc., the nations No. 1 snack-food maker, has shifted strategies to win back market share lost to No. 2 Borden Inc. and No. 3 Eagle Snacks, a subsidiary of the Anheuser-Busch Companies. To do that, the division of Pepsico Inc. said it will cut costs. First, 1,800 jobs will go, saving the company $100 million. Those dismissals will mean a $91 million charge against Pepsico's third-quarter earnings. Which salty-snack maker will fare best? "It's a war and they are all bleeding," said Max Busetti, editor of the Food Industry Newsletter.  Salomon Raids the Piggy Bank  The scandal at Salomon Brothers Inc. tarnished its credit rating as well as its name. Though its rating is still higher than half of corporate America's, it is lower than Salomon's more reputable competitors. That makes it more difficult for Salomon to raise money cheaply in a business where profits are squeezed from fractions of basis points. Last week, Salomon disclosed that it had begun dipping into its rainy-day fund of securities, which may be worth as much as $15 billion. By selling securities to raise capital -- and agreeing to buy them back -- Salomon has set up an alternative to issuing commercial paper until Congress, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Treasury Department and the 33 state regulators investigating the firm say it has cleaned up its act. That may take time.  The B-2's Fading Purpose  The Northrop Corporation's B-2 radar-evading Stealth bomber is a plane without a mission. With Communism in collapse, there may be no need to sneak in under Soviet radar to drop a cache of bombs. But last week Congress learned that the Stealth's lack of mission may not be its only problem: in tests, the big B-2 showed up on radar. For Northrop, that is a big problem. With the Pentagon's budget shrinking, the B-2 was ailing Northrop's last cash cow. The Air Force said it wanted up to 75 planes -- worth about $60 billion -- and has ordered 15. But the B-2 is in real trouble in Congress. "We are not going to give a blank check to the program," said Senator Jim Exon, Democrat of Nebraska. Even without a blank check, Congress is in the hole for $30 billion on the B-2. Some fear that if the B-2 disappears, Northrop will drop off the scope as well. G.E. Plays It Safe Among the nation's biggest corporations, the General Electric Company -- with its high-tech emphasis -- is something of a risk taker. But last week G.E. showed itself to be very prudent. It announced it would take a $1.8 billion charge to cover medical and benefits obligations to future retirees. Most companies have until Jan. 1, 1993, to take the hit. G.E. decided to take it early. Dirty Diaper Business The rivalry between Toys "R" Us Inc. and Child World Inc. has reached a new level. Now they are fighting over, well, diapers. To lure customers into its stores, Child World announced a special on disposable diapers. But last week Child World said it learned employees from Toys "R" Us were slipping into its stores, loading up on diapers and reselling them. Child World threatened to sue Toys "R" Us. Child World was tipped off to the caper when three men in suits drove up to a Houston store and bought $100 worth of diapers each. Either something was fishy, or those three men had some baby. ECONOMY **********The Laggard Services Sector  If the future lies in services, as most economists are quick to say, the United States is in trouble. Economic growth in August was centered in mining and manufacturing. According to the Federal Reserve Board, factory and mine output rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in August. Though the gains were modest, this sector showed more vigor than the rest of the economy. "The manufacturing sector is the only area where we're seeing much strength," said David Wyss, an economist with DRI/McGraw-Hill. When Spending Hurts  As consumers rouse from their recessionary slumber, they are beginning to spend. Trouble is, as they do, more boatloads of goods are coming stateside. According to the Commerce Department, imports exceeded exports by $5.9 billion in July. That was the largest monthly trade deficit since January and was an increase of 55.6 percent over June's figure.  Housing Recover Falters  For the nation's home builders, six months of interest-rate cuts have not been enough to keep the recovery from sputtering. According to the Commerce Department, housing starts were up by a modest six-tenths of 1 percent in August, the smallest gain in three months. The number of new permits issued also fell 4.9 percent, which signals even fewer construction starts in the months ahead. Since new construction fuels growth in other areas -- plumbing, furnishings, labor and even banking and insurance -- analysts looking at the figures were disappointed. "These numbers show a housing recovery losing steam, at least through August," said Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Society in New York.  Perfect Resume for the R.T.C.?  Albert V. Casey, a former chairman of American Airlines and of First Republic Bank of Dallas, is now expected to fill one of L. William Seidman's jobs. Mr. Seidman is retiring next month as head of both the Resolution Trust Corporation and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Mr. Casey -- known as a tough manager -- is the leading candidate to head the R.T.C. The R.T.C. will manage the savings and loan bailout on a day-to-day basis. Mr. Casey has at least one qualification for the job few others could boast. Shortly after he became chairman of First Republic, it went under. It was one of the costliest bank failures in history.  The General Accounting Office said the savings and loan bailout will cost $191 billion.  INTERNATIONAL **********Honda's Short Road to Market  It had to be one of the swiftest new-product introductions in automotive history. Last summer engineers from the Honda Motor Company in Japan said they had developed a thrifty new engine. They called it the VTEC-E. Last week, Honda announced the debut of the Civic VX, which is equipped with the first of those lean-burn engines. Honda expects the Civic VX to get about 55 miles a gallon on the highway and 48 miles in the city. But what is really remarkable about the new engine is that while its mileage is only 10 percent better than the next-best Geo Metro, imported by the General Motors Corporation, the Civic VX has about 30 percent more horses under its hood. According to Honda's critics at G.M., the new engine does not represent any big technological breakthrough. But if it is so easy, why didn't G.M. bring one out? Keeping the Sushi Chefs at Bay The bluefin, which is native to the North Atlantic, is a delicacy in the world's sushi bars. Environmentalists now worry it may be dying out due to over-fishing. Big bluefins -- put on ice and loaded onto planes -- can fetch $10,000 to $15,000 in Japan. So the National Audubon Society is proposing to have the bluefin listed as endangered under an international treaty. That would be the first time a commercial fish was deemed endangered. The United States Fish and Wildlife Services is expected to decide by Oct. 4 whether to recommend protection of the fish.  B.C.C.I. Punishment  The slow-paced investigation of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International is finally yielding results. Last week, the Federal Reserve announced a $37 million fine against Ghaith R. Pharaon, a Saudi businessman, for acting as a front for B.C.C.I.'s 1985 purchase of the Independence Bank of Encino, Calif. Regulators also asked a Federal court in Manhattan to freeze Mr. Pharaon's assets. They were worried, it seems, that he would turn his holdings into transportable cash.
