https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraq; Iraq Issues a Call for Peace Hours Before Bush's Speech
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/world.body_text: **********Hours before President Bush announced a conditional suspension of offensive fighting today, Baghdad moved closer to capitulation, offering to relinquish all claim to Kuwait, release allied prisoners and accept responsibility for war reparations in return for an immediate cease-fire and the lifting of international sanctions. **********Shortly after the Iraqi offer was made known on Wednesday, three explosions rocked central Baghdad, and a Reuters correspondent there said the blasts, possibly from cruise missiles, were so great that the Rashid Hotel, where Western reporters in the city are staying, "heaved and shuddered." **********The decisions announced by the Baghdad radio were said to have been made on Tuesday at a meeting of Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council under President Saddam Hussein.  News of Allied Invasion **********Iraq's leaders told their people for the first time Wednesday that allied troops were fighting on their soil. The Baghdad radio reported an allied paratroop drop on the strategic Euphrates valley, 190 miles south of Baghdad, and urged soldiers to "tear the enemies everywhere in pieces." **********"Their aim has clearly become to invade Iraq," the radio said. **********The radio's reports and commentaries suggest increasingly that Iraqis are being asked to rally to Mr. Hussein personally in the defense of the homeland. "The soil of the cherished homeland is fortified thanks to the noble sons of Iraq and brave knight Saddam Hussein," a commentary said. **********The radio reported Wednesday night that Mr. Hussein had presided over a further meeting of the Revolutionary Command Council, top Baath party figures and state officials. The radio report indcated that he was looking to the Soviet Union to swing the United Nations Security Council in favor of his cease-fire offer. **********"Leader President Saddam Hussein and the conferees," the report said, "expressed the hope that the Soviet Union and other friendly states at the U.N. Security Council will adopt practical measures to prevent America and its allies from continuing their abominable crime against the people of Iraq and their armed forces and property."  Heavy Bombing Reported **********Peter Arnett, reporting for CNN from Baghdad late Wednesday night, said there had been heavy bombing in Baghdad since shortly after the Baghdad radio reported the new Iraqi positions. **********"The sky across the whole horizon outside the hotel was lit up with antiaircraft fire, including explosions in the sky and on the ground," Mr. Arnett said. "The explosions shook the Al Rashid Hotel, where we live, but we don't know yet what the targets were. It was the 42d night of bombing of Baghdad." **********Early on Wednesday, the Baghdad radio announced that Iraq completed its withdrawal from Kuwait at first light. The United States and its allies dispute the assertion. **********In Amman, protest marchers outside the Iraqi Embassy chanted, "Death to the United States and its allies!" The police sealed off streets leading to the American Embassy, half a mile away, and no violent incidents were reported. 'Hounding' of Hussein Assailed **********Jordanian officials, expressing indignation at what one termed "the hounding of Saddam Hussein," said it was becoming clear that the allies now wished to tighten the screws on the Iraqi leader so severely that, even if the fighting stops, a continued embargo would bring such deprivation to Iraqis as to lead to his ouster. **********In a separate statement Wednesday night, Foreign Minister Taher el-Masri of Jordan said Iraq had complied "with what has been demanded of Iraq in the past." He added, "We believe it is high time for the Security Council to meet and endorse an immediate cease-fire." **********After a meeting Tuesday night, moreover, Jordan's Cabinet "expressed its anxiety and dismay over the attempts by the countries of the alliance to go beyond international legitimacy and the Security Council resolutions to acheive their objectives," a Government statement said on Wednesday. **********Possibly seeking to salvage some pride, Jordan's Prime Minister, Mudar Badran, said in Parliament on Wednesday night that Iraq had already withdrawn from Kuwait and maneuvered to disguise its actions before the allied ground offensive began.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/world.main_headline: German Official Meets With Gorbachev on Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/world.print_headline: German Official Meets With Gorbachev on Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/world.body_text: **********Suggesting a degree of concern over the recent course of Soviet foreign policy, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany today spent more than three hours with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev discussing the stalemate in arms controls and other problems. **********At a news conference at the end of his two-day visit, Mr. Genscher said he and the Soviet Union had reached no conclusion over differences on putting into effect the East-West treaty limiting conventional arms. But he said he believed that a solution could be found. **********He offered no further details. **********Western governments charge that the Soviet Union has been trying to circumvent the treaty, which was signed in November, by redefining or relocating forces covered in the agreement. Concern Over Soviet Policies **********The issue is one of several that have combined in recent months to raise concern in the West over Mr. Gorbachev's adherence to his foreign policyof recent years, marked by efforts to end all vestiges of the cold war. **********The resignation of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, a toughening of Mr. Gorbachev's domestic politics, the military crackdown in the Baltic republics and a distinctly more visible role for the military have led Western analysts to question whether Moscow's foreign policy might begin to shift. **********The Germans have also noted that Mr. Gorbachev has failed to win parliamentary ratification for two of the several Soviet-German treaties that formed part of the broad agreement between Moscow and Bonn leading to German unification. The two that were not approved dealt with the phased withdrawal of the Soviet Army from Germany. **********A large part of Mr. Genscher's goal on this visit, his first to Moscow since German unification last October, was reportedly to assess Mr. Gorbachev's and Moscow's position. Diplomats said he came away from his meetings with Mr. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh "reassured" about Moscow's course. **********Mr. Genscher said that from what Mr. Gorbachev had told him, he had concluded that the Soviet President was "fully determined" to continue reforms. Issue of Honecker Transfer **********The only issue on which Mr. Genscher made a firm comment was the transfer of Erich Honecker, the former East German Communist leader, from a Soviet hospital in eastern Germany to the Soviet Union. He said he had told the Soviet leadership "with all seriousness about the position and expectations of the Federal Government" about the action. **********Soviet officials have insisted that Mr. Honecker was moved for additional medical help and that he is in no condition for another move. **********Soviet officials have privately questioned the earnestness of Germany's indignation, speculating that Bonn may be just as happy to have an excuse not to put Mr. Honecker, who is 78 years old, on trial. The former Communist leader is accused of having ordered border guards to shoot would-be escapees at the Berlin wall. **********Mr. Genscher also said he had spoken to the Soviet leaders at length about the hope of ethnic Germans in the Soviet Union for an autonomous homeland. Mr. Genscher said Germany was interested in helping Germans who want to to stay in the Soviet Union, presumably so they would not join the tide of newcomers to Germany.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/busin.main_headline: Grumman to Cut Space Station Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Grumman to Cut Space Station Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/busin.body_text: **********The Grumman Corporation said it would cut 110 more jobs at its space station support division in Reston, Va. The reduction comes on top of the 34 jobs cut in January. **********It said another 60 jobs would be lost at subcontractors, which include the Loral Corporation, Booz-Allen & Hamilton, Barrios Technology and Wyle Laboratories. Grumman said the combined job cuts amounted to a 30 percent decrease in the work force for the project. The job cuts are a result of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's decision to reduce the scope of the space station project.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/world.main_headline: In Managua, Angry Reminder of Sandinista Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/world.print_headline: In Managua, Angry Reminder of Sandinista Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/11/world.body_text: **********Nicaraguans have come to realize the lingering power of the Sandinista Front after a daylong Sandinista rampage of burning, looting, stoning and shooting. **********The Managua city hall, two radio stations and a peace monument were destroyed, dozens of trucks and cars were set ablaze, and the leader of an Organization of American States peace mission came under automatic-weapons fire during the fury on Saturday. The police stood by and watched. **********Although the catalyst for the outpouring of anger was bomb damage early in the day to the tomb of a Sandinista guerrilla hero, the deeper reason was the unresolved onflict over private-property rights in Nicaragua. **********The Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro -- its actions somewhat limited by continuing Sandinista Front control of the police and army under terms of 1990 accords by which the leftist Sandinistas ceded power -- did not fix blame for the violence. But it appealed for calm in a Saturday night television broadcast. **********Carlos Hurtado, the Minister of Government, who is responsible for internal security, said he knew of no deaths or serious injuries from the actions. Managua, scene of most of Saturday's action, appeared calm today. **********The incidents began when explosives damaged the mausoleum of Carlos Fonseca, the main founder of the Sandinista Front, who was killed 15 years ago Friday in battle with the National Guard of the former rightist dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle. While one group of Sandinistas quickly repaired the damage, others sought revenge. **********The first target was the office of Mayor Arnoldo Aleman, which was sacked and burned. Sandinistas asserted that the Mayor, who has made a crusade of ridding Managua of murals and other signs of the Sandinista era, instigated the mausoleum bombing. **********Armed groups set fire to the stridently anti-Sandinista Radio Corporacion, and in the city of Leon to Radio Dario, reportedly destroying both. **********Shortly after midday, a truckload of Sandinistas stopped at the two-story building that has recently served as headquarters of the former contra rebels and raked it with automatic-weapons fire for several minutes. **********Santiago Murray, an Argentine who heads the O.A.S. mission overseeing the contras' assimilation into civilian life, was in the parking area when the attack began. "The police were a block away," he said -- "watching." **********At the end of the day, former President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, leader of the Sandinista Front, addressed thousands of followers. He warned the National Assembly not to proceed with efforts to require the Sandinistas to give back property they acquired before they stepped down in favor of the elected Chamorro Government. **********The National Assembly adopted laws in August requiring Sandinista leaders like Mr. Ortega to return to the Government or previous owners the houses and farms they acquired under what has become known as "la pinata." Mrs. Chamorro, worried about the Sandinista reaction, vetoed the law, but she and the assembly are now working for a compromise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/17/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds; Playing the Adjustable-Rate Game
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/17/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds; Playing the Adjustable-Rate Game
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/17/busin.body_text: **********Looking for a fund that has everything? High yields? And stable principal? And guarantees by the United States Government or one of its agencies? **********A new breed of funds -- adjustable-rate mortgage-backed funds -- is one solution, although critics say there are problems. These new funds promise higher yields than money-market funds, less fluctuation than long-term bond funds -- and the credit safety of securities backed by American Government agencies. Investors have poured more than $1 billion into the first fund of this sort and rivals are racing into the market. **********Mortgage funds, of course, are not new; for years, there have been funds that invest in fixed-rate Government National Mortgage Association securities, and those of Ginnie Mae's cousins, Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae.  But adjustable-rate funds investing in offerings from these same agencies were developed to eliminate the volatility that has long characterized the fixed-rate funds. Prices for fixed-rate funds must move around to compensate for any shifts in market interest rates that cannot be reflected in the portfolio's fixed rates. **********Adjustable-rate mortgage funds also offer competitive yields as rates rise and a cushion against any sharp rate declines. **********But as fund groups rush into the market, some experts worry that investors don't understand the tradeoff that these funds require. "Trying to do it all in one investment is a loser's game," said Anthony J. Ogorek, an investment adviser in Buffalo, N.Y., who believes investors pay too much in total return for reducing volatility. **********For those willing to do so, there are now several options. The biggest -- and oldest -- of these funds is the Franklin Adjustable U.S. Securities Fund, sponsored by Franklin Resources, San Mateo, Calif. Its assets soared to $1.3 billion at the end of February; at yearend 1989, they were $76.2 million. **********Although it was set up in October 1987 as the Franklin Adjustable Rate Mortgage Fund, it languished until last year. Its name then was changed and sales shot up, partly because it was perceived as a safe haven during market turbulence and because of its solid record. For the 12 months ended Feb. 28, it yielded an average of 9.5 percent -- or roughly 2 points more than the average money market fund, said CDA Investment Technologies, which tracks mutual funds. Franklin's total return -- yield plus changes in principal value -- was 10 percent, compared with 9.2 percent for all bond funds. **********This success has drawn rivals: Pilgrim Group, Los Angeles, launched its fund in late February; Keystone Group, Boston, said it plans to introduce one this month, and others are in the works. **********What is the investor's tradeoff for lowering some of the interest rate risk? For one thing, monthly dividends fluctuate more than they would with a standard Ginnie Mae fund, potentially every month, said Jack Lemein, the Franklin fund manager. That could pose problems for people who rely on regular checks to cover their living expenses. **********Another problem is that the funds' yields will drop when interest rates fall. That's because the underlying mortgages will pay less over time as the borrowers' rates are adjusted downward. Even when interest rates rise, the funds will lag because the rates on the underlying mortgages are adjusted periodically, not immediately. And when mortgages are prepaid, the money often is reinvested at a lower rate. **********"Franklin's quest to significantly lower the fund's volatility has cost investors too much in total return," said Mr. Ogorek. **********Consider this, he said: In 1988 the Shearson Lehman Hutton Mortgage Backed Security Index rose 8.7 percent. The Franklin fund rose 6.4 percent, while the Vanguard Ginnie Mae Fund rose 8.8 percent, according to CDA. In 1989, the index rose 15.4 percent, Franklin gained 10.3 percent and Vanguard, 14.8 percent. Last year, the index increased 10.4 percent while Franklin gained 9.5 percent and Vanguard, 10.3 percent. **********Meanwhile, the "standard deviation," a measure of risk, for the Franklin Fund is 0.30 percent compared with 1.45 percent for the Vanguard Ginnie Mae Fund. While it is five times higher, 1.45 percent is hardly a risky rating. Municipal bond funds, for example, carry a 1.29 percent rating. **********Then there are sales charges. The Franklin fund has a hefty 4 percent sales load, so if you had invested $50,000 in it three years ago, you'd have $61,684 today, for an annual return of 7.25 percent. But if you had invested the cash in money funds for three years, yielding the Donoghue 12-month average at yearend, you would have earned a combined 7.93 percent return -- or more than a half point more than the Franklin fund. Your $50,000 would be worth $62,865. **********Mr. Ogorek's conclusion: You can do better by dividing your portfolio among various investments. But if you do want to invest in mortgage-backed securities, buy shares in a regular Ginnie Mae fund, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/world.main_headline: MANDELA'S GROUP QUITS DISCUSSIONS ON A NEW CHARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/world.print_headline: MANDELA'S GROUP QUITS DISCUSSIONS ON A NEW CHARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/world.body_text: **********The African National Congress announced today that it would refuse to discuss a new constitution with the Government until progress was achieved on its demands to end fighting between black factions that has claimed about 800 lives so far this year. **********The congress's secretary general, Alfred Nzo, announced plans for a consumer boycott, a general strike and demonstrations by its supporters to protest the violence, which pits congress loyalists against supporters of Inkatha, a rival black group. The congress says the fighting is permitted and at times actively abetted by the Government security forces. **********"Unless the Government and other parties implicated in the violence address this threat seriously by moving beyond rhetoric and posturing, unless they begin to take concrete and binding measures to end the violence, all South Africans will be losers," Mr. Nzo said.  An Important Forum Lost **********But in abandoning negotiations, the congress loses its most important forum for influencing the direction and pace of change in South Africa. A new constitution extending political rights to the black majority is the centerpiece of the negotiations that President F. W. de Klerk has proposed on the nation's transition to nonracial democracy. **********The decision was described as a consensus reached by the congress leaderhip after seven hours of closed talks on Friday, and did not presage any internal split over the issue. Nelson Mandela, the congress's deputy president, did not attend today's news conference but the decision clearly had his backing. **********There was no immediate response by President de Klerk, but he has said before that he would keep the door to negotiations open. The congress has been assuming that Mr. de Klerk would not dare start formal negotiations without its participation as the foremost black political organization.  Boycott of de Klerk Conference **********Pallo Jordan, the Congress's information secretary, conceded that his organization's options were limited. **********"The difficulty is you have an incumbent Government which occupies the effective seat of power and controls the levers of power," Mr. Jordan said. "And without its action, it's very difficult to know how to move the process forward." **********The congress confirmed that it would boycott a conference on the violence that President de Klerk has called on May 24 and 25. Instead, it proposed an alternative conference organized by church leaders that would bind all parties, including the police and army, to a code of conduct. **********"Rather than hastily and unilaterally convening a symbolic conference in an attempt to score tactical points, the Government must use its powers to curb the violence and to ensure that its own security forces act impartially," the congress said. "Until such time as progress is made in regard to these demands, the A.N.C. will not involve itself in constitutional discussions with the Government, or in any all-party congress to discuss the mechanisms for drawing up a new democratic constitution." Inkatha's Disappointment **********But it said it would continue pressing the Government in other talks for "firm commitments" on its terms for stopping the violence. Such discussions have been taking place, it said. **********The congress previously refused to join formal negotiations until the Government released all political prisoners, a process unfinished, and eliminated other obstacles. **********A further delay could also be in the leadership's interest, since it is believed reluctant to be drawn into substantive talks before the congress's national conference scheduled for early July, when an enlarged new executive committee will be chosen. Some members have said the current leadership conceded too much in renouncing in August the armed struggle against the Government. **********The Inkatha Freedom Party, the white liberal Democratic Party and the South African Chamber of Business expressed disappointment at the African National Congress's decision to suspend its participation. **********Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, Inkatha's leader, said he was not surprised that the congress was pulling out of multiparty constitutional discussions and calling for protests. **********"They intend dragging what should be sensitive, thoughtful discussions onto street corners," said Chief Buthelezi. "They want to keep the pot boiling for their own benefit." **********The Chamber of Business said the decision would hurt business confidence. Zach de Beer, the Democratic Party leader, said delaying negotiations was in no one's interest. **********Today's action made good a threat originally made on April 5, when the African National Congress said it would suspend talks unless the Government met seven demands by May 9. **********The congress demanded that Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok and Defense Minister Magnus Malan be dismissed, that counterinsurgency units be dismantled and disarmed, that weapons be outlawed at political events, that policemen involved in two fatal clashes with congress supporters be suspended and that the police assigned to crowd control not be issued live ammunition. **********It also demanded that single-sex migrant hostels be phased out and that an independent commission be created to investigate misconduct by the security forces. **********It subsequently delayed until May 9 its response to the passing of the April 30 deadline it set for the release of all political prisoners. **********After President de Klerk announced last week that he was banning the carrying of most tribal weapons in areas of unrest, the congress extended its deadline another week, with the insistence that spears be included. Mr. de Klerk has yet to respond. **********The congress said that to support its demands, it would call for a nationwide consumer boycott, the timing and duration of which would be left to the congress's regional branches; a nationwide general strike on a date to be determined in the next few days; mass demonstrations on June 15, a day before the annual commemoration on June 16 of the 1976 uprising in Soweto against white minority rule, and a day of fasting on Wednesday May 22, to show solidarity with political prisoners still in custody who have gone on a hunger strike to force their release. **********Today, the congress said it was "outraged at the cruelty" shown by prison officials toward some of the hunger strikers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.main_headline: Hallmark to Enter Cable TV In $1 Billion Cencom Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.print_headline: Hallmark to Enter Cable TV In $1 Billion Cencom Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.body_text: **********In its largest diversification effort to date, Hallmark Cards Inc. has agreed to invest about $1 billion in Cencom Cable Association, which has, directly and indirectly, about 550,000 cable television subscribers. The deal will instantly make Hallmark one of the leading forces in the nation's cable industry. **********The investment will be made through a Hallmark subsidiary, Crown Media, which already has a stake in cable systems in Wisconsin that serve 150,000 subscribers. **********Hallmark, a privately held company based in Kansas City, Mo., with sales of $2.7 billion last year, began diversifying into cable only in the last two years. **********"We are in the communciations business, and the greeting card is the most prominent manifestation of that," Irvine Hockaday Jr., Hallmark's president and chief executive, said in a telephone interview yesterday. "We see in cable an attractive investment on its own with long-term possibilities for cross-marketing." **********Cencom, a privately held company based in St. Louis, has about 150,000 subscribers in the St. Louis area. In addition there are 400,000 subscribers in systems that are owned by partnerships affiliated with Cencom and managed by Cencom. **********Hallmark began moving beyond its core greeting card business in 1984, when it bought Binney & Smith, the manufacturer of Crayola crayons, for $204 million. **********Three years later it began expanding into broadcasting with the purchase of the Spanish Internationl Communication Corporation, a group of nine television stations that carry Spanish-language programming. The group included WXTV-TV, Channel 41 in New York, and KMEX-TV in Los Angeles. That purchase price was $286 million. **********In 1988, it bought Univision Inc., the Spanish-language television programming network, for $265 million. **********Hallmark remains the largest maker of greeting cards, ahead of American Greetings and Gibson Greetings. Mr. Hockaday estimated that Hallmark had about 44 percent of the market and that about half of the company's revenues came from cards. **********He said Hallmark looks at expansion from two angles. On the one hand, the purchase of Binney & Smith was "a form of reinvestment in our core business." Many of Hallmark's card sales come from a franchised chain of card shops, which the company thought would also be good sites for selling Crayola products. "People use the word diversification loosely," Mr. Hockaday said. "I prefer to think of new channels of distribution." **********By contrast, he said, the more recent acquisitions, of Spanish-language television and cable, were an example of diversification as most people use the term. **********"We saw a market that is growing 4 to 5 times faster than the Anglo market," he said. **********As for the latest deal, he said: "We think the future of cable is attractive. But we also think there is a possiblity that it will provide us with cross-term marketing." **********As one example, he said that consumers seemed to have less time for shopping in stores and that probably held down greeting card sales, but "if you have a customer base of 550,000 subscribers some day, how much could you do with home shopping?"  Competition Grows **********Hallmark, which prints 11 million cards a day, has seen competition heat up at the same time that industrywide sales growth has slowed. **********The Greeting Card Assocation, a trade group that is based in Washington, said that card sales in the United States totaled about $4.6 billion last year and that it expects sales to rise to only about $4.7 billion this year. **********"We don't have a lot more greeting card companies," Mr. Hockaday said. "But in the mass channels, it is getting more competitive. That emphasizes the advantage of the card store." He said Hallmark was the only one of the three major card companies that had a network of franchised stores selling its cards.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/15/busin.main_headline: The War of the Christmas Catalogues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/15/busin.print_headline: The War of the Christmas Catalogues
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/15/busin.body_text: **********The next six weeks of Christmas shopping will be critical to the sales of many retailers, but none more so than mail-order catalogue merchants. **********While department stores generate up to 50 percent of their profits in the final two months of the year, many cataloguers count on the same period for 60 percent to 75 percent of their earnings. **********"The holiday season is going to mean the difference between profit and loss for most of the cataloguers this year," said Robert F. DeLay, an expert on the mail-order business. "This year is terribly important because things have been so flat." **********Hoping to put shoppers in the buying mood, Spiegel and some other mail-order companies sent out their Christmas catalogue weeks earlier than usual. Experts say some companies are also likely to re-send their catalogues, with new covers, after Thanksgiving. **********Cataloguers are also emphasizing their discounted merchandise and promising to deliver products in time for Christmas, even if orders are placed in late December. **********For much of the 1980's, mail-order sales grew by about 15 percent a year. That was triple the growth rate of most department stores and other retailers that depend on face-to-face sales. **********But the bleak economy and rising costs have caught up with many catalogue companies. The good news, at least for consumers, is lower prices from a few companies and a reduction in the 12 billion or so catalogues stuffed annually into the nation's mailboxes. **********Mail-order experts say that weaker companies are starting to be weeded out -- some merging with larger ones, others folding altogether. Most survivors will have to cope with permanently lower profit margins, analysts and industry executives say. **********As if the tough retailing climate were not enough, the catalogue companies have also been hit by a confluence of cost increases imposed by the United States Postal Service, which delivers the catalogues, and by shippers like United Parcel Service that deliver the goods. **********Even harder blows may yet land. The industry is feeling pressure from courts and state legislatures on issues that range from sales taxes to proposed privacy laws that would make it hard to send catalogues to people who did not request them. Most catalogue companies do not charge sales tax to customers who live outside the state or states where the company has offices. But revenue-hungry states are trying to change that. **********The various rising costs "could have some impact on the basic economics of the industry," said Richard C. Anderson, chief executive of Lands' End Inc., a mail-order retailer based in Dodgeville, Wis. "With these fierce price increases, it becomes rather difficult to survive if you are a smaller company."  'A Question of Size' **********The recent casualties include Royal Silk Ltd., which had offered popular moderately priced silk apparel through its catalogue. The company went out of business this summer after a costly expansion into retail stores. **********Sensing opportunity in the industry's plight, Montgomery Ward & Company said last month that it planned to re-enter the mail-order business with a line of speciality catalogues. Company executives said the pressures on weaker players made it "perfect timing" to start the new business. **********"In this business, it's very much a question of size," said Sharon E. Rappaport, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. "It's all dependent on volume," she said. "The larger you are, the better you are able to take advantage of discounts," in postal rates and buying merchandise.  Mining the Niches **********But size is not everything. Two of the nation's largest cataloguers, Sears, Roebuck & Company and the J. C. Penney Company are struggling to breathe life into their "big book" catalogues, which try to be many things to many people. **********Several companies, however, are doing a brisk business in more narrowly focused areas. A fresh-flower catalogue, Calyx & Corolla, for example, is attracting a lot of attention and customers with its offerings of orchids, anthuriams and birds of paradise. **********Children's clothing is another hot area. Hanna Andersson, a Portland, Ore., cataloguer that specializes in cotton clothing made in Sweden, is attracting legions of parents. **********Not all successful catalogues are aimed at the affluent. Fingerhut Companies, based in Minnetonka, Minn., is growing quickly by selling a wide range of goods on credit, primarily to lower-income families. **********Analysts said there is no true catalogue equivalent of the discount stores, which have revolutionized retailing by offering name-brand merchandise at lower prices than are found in department stores. But the new Ward venture, analysts said, may be taking aim at that market. And other mail-order merchants, including Lands' End, have been placing added emphasis on their lower-priced offerings and beefing up sections that feature discounted goods. **********The current cost pressures are forcing companies to alter their basic approach to the business. **********In April, after much agonizing, L. L. Bean Inc. reversed a 79-year tradition of free shipping and began charging its catalogue customers a $3.50 fee for each order. **********"It was something we were very reluctant to do," said Catharine Hartnett, a spokeswoman for the Freeport, Me., company, which mails 100 million catalogues a year. "We waited as long as possible before making the decision." **********Companies are also revising their blanket approach to mailing. Infrequent buyers are quickly dropped from mailing lists because they do not support the cost of paper and postage. Producing and mailing each catalogue costs about a dollar, according to industry estimates. **********And while it may not be apparent yet, mailers are also sending out fewer catalogues.  Smaller Books, Shorter Lists **********Some merchants are even shrinking their offerings to save money. **********"The next catalogue will be smaller," said Kevin Sweeney, a spokesman for Patagonia Inc., a Ventura, Calif., retailer of outdoor clothing. Patagonia recently laid off 120 people, or about one-fifth of its work force, because of a slowing sales. This year's holiday catalogue pages will be the size of an 8 1/2-by-11-inch business letter, in contrast to the Patagonia's previous oversized offerings. "Cost is the primary reason," Mr. Sweeney said. **********Responding to the same pressures, the Lillian Vernon Corporation decided to cut its catalogue circulation by 10 percent. The company also took steps to more carefully direct its mailing to proven catalogue shoppers, a move that paid off with higher revenue per catalogue mailed. **********Despite such measures, the Mount Vernon, N.Y., company recently reported reduced revenues and a loss for the first six months of its fiscal year.  Impact of Rate Increases **********It was in February that the United States Postal Service increased the third-class rates used by mailers by 40 percent. In the case of Lands' End, the increase will translate to $7 million more in expenses this year. **********Yet, even after the United Parcel Service added its own rate increase, many catalogue companies have been reluctant to pass along the price increases to already skittish consumers. **********The tax issue continues to hang over the industry. State governments are currently barred from charging taxes on sales by out-of-state companies that have no stores in a state. But last month, the Supreme Court agreed to hear a case that could overturn the prohibition on sales taxes for most catalogue purchases.  Two Views on Taxes **********Catalogue companies express concern that having to charge and administer state taxes will hurt sales and increase operating costs. **********But Ms. Rappaport of Morgan Stanley noted that several large cataloguers already charge sales tax, because they have retail stores as well. "I don't think that it threatens the viability of the mail order business," she said. **********Privacy laws, though, could be more damaging than either taxes or postal increases, said Mr. DeLay, publisher of The DeLay Letter, an industry publication in New York. He said that a California proposal would effectively require companies to obtain permission from consumers before sending them catalogues. Even if the proposal does not become law, he said, "down the road, there are going to be some restrictions." **********Which is why many cataloguers are afraid that the years of easy growth may be over. "When we got started," said Mr. Anderson of Lands' End, "we didn't have these problems."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.main_headline: Air War in the Credit Card Battle
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Air War in the Credit Card Battle
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.body_text: **********In its latest counterattack against growing challenges from Visa and Mastercard, the American Express Company said yesterday that it would sharply expand the ways travelers could accumulate frequent-flier credits. **********As do competing bank "affinity cards" with ties to airlines, American Express will give its card holders one frequent-flier mile for every dollar they charge on their Green, Gold, Platinum, Optima and Corporate cards. Any purchase, whether it be flowers, sweaters, college tuition or vacations, earns the miles, which are redeemable for free airline tickets or ticket upgrades to first class. **********But American Express's program, the company's first ever, hopes to spur both business travel and consumer spending, slowed by the recession, by offering some extras. For example, card holders could pool into a kind of "bank" the credits they buy with any version of the American Express card. Charges made on cards of the members' spouses and families count as well. Perhaps most significantly, the card holders could then allocate the pooled credits to as many as seven airlines, instead of one per card, as with present bank-card programs. **********The Membership Miles program, as its called, will be free the first year, but will cost $25 the second year. **********The arrangements between bank cards and airlines have proved to be one of the most effective marketing tools in the sharply competitive travel and credit card businesses. Competition among credit card issuers of all kinds has risen in recent years, as a glut of cards and a similarity of services, like rental-car damage insurance, have forced issuers to offer more and more incentives for using their particular form of plastic. The recession's effects on both consumers and businesses have intensified that trend. **********As the slump hurt the restaurant business, for instance, restaurateurs began to complain about the fee American Express charged merchants who accepted its cards because the percentage was generally higher than that of Visa and Mastercard. Earlier this year, American Express reduced the fee for some merchants. **********American Express has not been alone. Last March, Citibank, the nation's largest issuer of Visa and Mastercards, said it would guarantee, through a form of rebate, that purchases of most items using its cards were at the lowest available price. Profits Down **********In April, American Express announced a quarterly profit drop for the Travel-Related Services, which is mainly the credit card business, to $162 million, from $215 million a year earlier. Quarterly charge-card volume fell 1.3 percent, to $25.4 billion. **********Company officials cited a white-collar recession that slowed consumer spending and raised bad debts among its generally middle- to upper-class card holders. **********"It will be expensive, but necessary," said David F. Robertson, president of the Nilson Report, a credit card industry publication. "American Express needs to increase sales from their upscale customers." **********American Express, which once enjoyed nearly all of the market for airline tickets, has been steadily losing business to bank cards affiliated with major airlines. Frequent-flier programs, which flourished in the 1980's, were designed to build customer loyalty to airlines. **********The air carriers in the new American Express program are Delta Air Lines, Northwest, Continental, Southwest, MGM Grand Air, Midway and Pan American. They carry nearly half of United States air traffic. In addition, they have 24 affiliated airlines, many of them foreign carriers like KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Singapore Air, which could yield additional travel awards under existing programs. **********Delta, which did not previously have an affinity card, said the structure of the American Express program was attractive. "We've always resisted entering these programs, because we just didn't think it was right to get tickets by charging tires and what all," said Neil A. Monroe, a Delta spokesman, "But the difference here is that we're getting paid, which is nice, and we're only one of seven." 'Premier Affinity Card' **********American Express program does not include American Airlines and United Airlines, the nation's two largest carriers. Still, experts on frequent-flier incentives hailed the American Express program. "American Express has instantly become the premier affinity card with this program," said Randy Petersen, editor of Frequent, a Colorado Springs, newsletter for frequent travelers. **********Joe Brancatelli, executive editor of OAG Frequent Flyer magazine, agreed, but said, referring to the absence of American and United, "Thirty-six percent of my readers won't be able to cash in on it." **********Referring to his company's affiliation with American Airlines, James L. Bailey, senior executive in charge of Citibank Visa and Mastercard, said: "This is a marriage. We expect it to be monogamous." **********American Airlines agreed. "We're happy with the relationship," said Martin P. Heires, a spokesman for American. Sara Dornacker, a United spokeswoman, said the carrier considered the American Express program a competitor to its own card with First Chicago bank and therefore did not want to participate. **********Today, American Express has a nearly 42 percent share of the market for airline tickets, while Visa has nearly 20 percent, according to the Nilson Report. Big Spenders **********The affinity cards appeal strongly to frequent fliers, who tend to spend many times more than typical credit card holders. The Nilson Report estimates that United Airlines' affinity cardholders spend as much as three times more and American Airlines card holders as much as seven times more than a typical gold Visa card holder who spends $2,600 annually. **********"Our new program will encourage people to spend as much as possible with American Express," said Kenneth I. Chenault, president of the consumer card group. **********Typically, under these programs, a bank buys frequent-flier miles, at a penny or less per mile, from the airlines. American Express may pay cash but could also trade services, like cooperative advertising, to reduce expenses for the program, which analysts said could be costly in its first years. **********Mr. Chenault would say only that "American Express is not structuring this program as a loss leader," meaning a money-losing incentive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/world.main_headline: Suspect in Iranian's Death Eludes the Police
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/world.print_headline: Suspect in Iranian's Death Eludes the Police
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/world.body_text: **********For the second time in 10 days, a suspect in the slaying of former Prime Minister Shapur Bakhtiar of Iran slipped through the hands of the police because of a mix-up, a police spokesman said. **********The suspect's hotel registration card was inserted into a police computer after he checked into a downtown hotel on Monday, but a computer failure delayed the indentification process until Wednesday, said the spokesman, Thierry Magnin. **********By that time, the suspect, Ali Rad Vakili, had checked out, Mr. Magnin said. Mr. Vakili was carrying a Turkish passport with the name Musa Kocer, which was registered in the police computer when it checked names of people on the wanted list. **********Mr. Bakhtiar was fatally stabbed in his home outside Paris on Aug. 6, according to coroners' reports. Iranian exiles have blamed the Iranian Government for the assassination. Teheran has denied the charges. **********Mr. Vakili and another suspect, Mohammed Azadi, were briefly detained by the Swiss police when they tried to enter the country with forged Swiss visas on Aug. 7, one day before Mr. Bakhtiar's body was found. They were fined $133 and returned to the French police, who released them because their French visas were valid. **********There has been no trace of Mr. Azadi. A third Iranian suspect, Faridoun Boyer Ahmadi, vanished immediately after the slaying.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/11/world.main_headline: Census Likely to Renew Strife in Indian State
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/11/world.print_headline: Census Likely to Renew Strife in Indian State
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/11/world.body_text: **********A nationwide census this month is likely to worsen tensions in the remote state of Assam, where more than 5,000 people have been killed in ethnic, linguistic and religious clashes in recent years. **********Officials say they are worried about the potential political fallout from the count, which could confirm that Assamese-speaking people have been outnumbered by Bengali-speaking immigrant Muslims and Hindus, reducing the Assamese to a minority in their land. Aboriginal tribal groups and settlers from other parts of India also arerefusing to identify themselves with the Assamese. **********"I don't think the immigrant groups or the tribes are going to declare Assamese as their language," one top state official said. "If the Assamese become a minority, it'll start an upheaval that will be difficult to control," he added. **********The census is likely to revive a push to split Assam into linguistically based states. **********Rajmohan Gandhi, a lawmaker, earlier had compared the Assamese to the Arabs: "They have the oil; they have not been paid enough for it; their lands are being settled by others. Such Assamese see Bengalis as the area'sIsraelis, wanting to appropriate someone else's lands." **********In the last census conducted here, in 1971, the population of the oil-rich, tea-producing, thickly forested northeast Indian state was 14.6 million, with more than 50 percent declaring Assamese as their native language. But that figure included many immigrants from East Pakistan, now Bangladesh, who were actually Bengali-speaking, as well as aboriginal tribal groups who feared government harassment if they listed their true native language. **********Agitation against immigrants forced the census takers to drop Assam from the 1981 national census; projectionsplaced the state's population at about 21 million out of a total of 683 million Indians. The state recorded the country's highest population growth rate, more than 34 percent, from 1961 to 1971, and officials said that was largely because of unchecked immigration from East Pakistan. **********The state's volatile ethnic and linguistic mix has touched off frequent riots. The sharpest divisions have been between the Assamese and the Bengali speakers. Their antagonism goes back to the days of British rule, when Bengali professionals and officials ran the region and Bengali was made the official language. Bengali was replaced by Assamese after American missionaries allied with Assamese nationalists to restore the indigenous language. **********Relations between the two communites have been marked by suspicion,brawls and riots since 1961. A resurgence of the Assamese middle class and Hindu political power also led to a deterioration of social relations with the major tribes of the state, which are demanding an autonomous state not dominated by the Assamese. **********A large number of non-Assamese settlers came from other parts of eastern India in the 19th century to work on British tea plantations. Their descendants speak a patois of Assamese and Hindi, the main language of northern India, and they also are resentful of Assamese domination. **********This atmosphere has spawned armed groups, some of which are well armed and trained, and there is at least one current pro-independence insurgency, which is being persued by the Indian troops and paramilitary soldiers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/10/busin.main_headline: I.R.S. Operations Called Smoothest in Some Time
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/10/busin.print_headline: I.R.S. Operations Called Smoothest in Some Time
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/10/busin.body_text: **********With less than a week to go until April 15, the Internal Revenue Service is finding far less than the usual tax-season grumbling aimed its way this year. **********To be sure, there are still shortcomings, such as the trouble taxpayers have in making telephone connections for assistance, and new worries are being heard about the new electronic filing system that is intended to speed up refunds. But even some of the agency's most persistent critics say that day-to-day operations are generally the smoothest in a long time. The contrast to the experience of the mid-1980's, particularly to 1985, when computer problems caused extensive and costly delays, is especially sharp.  'Proceeding Successfully' **********"This year's filing season is proceeding successfully," Jennie S. Stathis, director of tax policy and administration issues at the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, told a House oversight panel late last month. **********A dimmer view, however, was taken by David A. Berenson, national director of tax policy for Ernst & Young. He said the apparently smooth flow of returns masked growing frustration with the complexity of the tax system and a related decline in the accuracy of tax assessment. "The level of inadvertent noncompliance has never been greater than it is now," he said. **********On the positive side, the refund pace has quickened a bit since last year, more of the elderly are using simpler forms, electronically filed returns are running well above expectations, instruction booklets and forms are better distributed, and the I.R.S. has markedly improved its accuracy in fielding taxpayer inquiries. **********"The filing season is going exceptionally well," boasted Fred T. Goldberg Jr., the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, who took over in 1989. "Our ongoing investments in quality and technology are continuing to pay off, much to the benefit of the taxpaying public." **********Mr. Goldberg also acknowledged a debt to those who write the tax law: Few changes were made affecting 1990 returns, a situation that benefits the I.R.S., as well as taxpayers. **********The latest reports show filings running 1 percent above last year's pace and distributed refunds up three-tenths of 1 percent. The reports are updated weekly, and issued on Wednesdays. As of March 29, 60,755,000 returns had been filed, and 40,639,000 refunds distributed with the size of the average refund so far this year up almost 6 percent to $899, from $849. **********One of the things that most pleases the I.R.S. is the boom in electronic filings, which have soared 80 percent so far this year, to 6.8 million, about 10 percent of the returns filed so far. The system is for the second year available nationally to nearly all taxpayers claiming refunds, even if they do not live in one of the three districts that currently process electronic returns, and the I.R.S. is testing it in several states with returns on which taxpayers have a balance due. **********Electronic returns are less likely to contain errors than returns filed on paper, which I.R.S. personnel must enter into a computer, and are quicker for the agency to process. **********But electronic filing is also a source of concern. One problem, according to a Congressional aide, is that fraud may be harder to detect. This has led the Administration to request additional money for I.R.S. enforcers. **********Moreover, according to the G.A.O., electronic filing must triple next year if cost-savings targets are to be reached, a goal that is prompting the I.R.S. to seek ways to make it more accessible.  Less Erroneous Information **********One of the most publicized I.R.S. problems of recent years, giving erroneous information to taxpayers who telephone for help, has eased, according to both the agency and outside monitors. The accuracy rate so far this season, as gauged by a formal program of test calls, has been running at 81.8 percent, up from 76.5 percent in 1990, the I.R.S. reported. **********Outsiders generally do not dispute that the information is better, partly because the agency has issued a standard question-and-response manual to aid its "assistors" in obtaining pertinent facts about a taxpayer's situation before trying to answer. "We believe that the development and nationwide use of this guide has already contributed a great deal to I.R.S.'s improved accuracy," Ms. Stathis of the G.A.O. told the House oversight panel. **********However, she said it remained "unclear" whether the availability of assistance to taxpayers had improved from last year, "and that is a concern." A Congressional aide who receives a weekly statistical breakdown that includes calls answered, busy signals and hang-ups described the chances of reaching an I.R.S. assistor as "way down" this year. Decision Pleases Retirees **********But there is no doubt that many retirees are pleased with an I.R.S. decision in December to permit income from pensions, annuities, individual retirement accounts and Social Security to be declared on Form 1040A, which is shorter and simpler than the 1040 long form that was formerly required. Nearly a million had made this switch by mid-March; an estimated 4.5 million are eligible. **********Despite this year's gains, the I.R.S. continues to face huge challenges, including the maintenance and modernization of its computers. At a March 20 hearing, Mr. Goldberg told the House oversight subcommittee that he monitored "key milestones each month personally" in this area. **********However, Howard G. Rhile, a senior accounting office official, said, "There is no system to track the modernization projects against cost, schedule and performance goals." **********A continuing sore point with Congressional and other critics is the I.R.S.'s low audit rate, which slipped well under the 1 percent level during the 1980's, and the fact that tax delinquents of relatively modest means are more likely to be enforcement targets than the wealthy. **********Mr. Goldberg, however, won plaudits in many quarters by resisting a Bush Administration budgetary effort last fall to have the agency concentrate on mail audits, which tend to be directed at ordinary taxpayers, on the ground that fairness should outweigh getting the maximum in short-run revenue. "I said I wasn't going to do it," Mr. Goldberg told the panel last month. The Office of Management and Budget retreated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/world.body_text: **********Parliament voted today to scrap the laws used to justify South Africa's longstanding racial discrimination in property ownership and residential selection. **********The new legislation, which repeals the Land Acts of 1913 and 1936 and the Group Areas Act, will take effect on June 30. The Land Acts reserved 87 percent of the country's land for whites, who currently make up less than 14 percent of the population. The Group Areas Act dictated where people could live according to their race. **********President F. W. de Klerk, whose National Party controls the whites-only house of Parliament, had previously announced that the laws would be eliminated before the legislature adjourned this month. The new legislation was also supported by the Democratic Party, which advocates an even faster dismantling of apartheid than the ruling Nationalists. **********Only the right-wing opposition Conservative Party opposed the move to end land discrimination, denouncing it as reckless and irresponsible. Opponent of Change **********"The bill makes white South Africa into every man's land," Jan Hoon, a Conservative Member of Parliament, was quoted as saying by the South African Press Association. **********But Peter Soal, a Member of Parliament for the Democratic Party, expressed his party's joy over the repeal. **********"We rejoice with all those who feel the yoke of oppression being lifted," Mr. Soal said. "We share their happiness in being released from the discrimination inherent in the laws which restricted blacks to 13 percent of the land of this country." **********The change was also endorsed by the House of Representatives and the House of Delegates, two smaller chambers representing people of mixed race and Indian descent respectively, though the mixed-race Labour Party abstained after its leader, Allan Hendrickse, contended that the new law perpetuated white privilege. **********The country's black majority remains excluded from Parliament. President de Klerk has invited black leaders to negotiate a new constitution that would extend political rights to blacks.  Conditions Set by U.S. **********Parliament also began discussing the repeal of the remaining legal pillar of apartheid, the Population Registration Act, which has classified every South African by race from birth. The repeal of the act is a key condition set by the United States Congress for lifting of American sanctions against South Africa. **********The Government announced last Monday that legal apartheid would formally end on June 30, once the three apartheid laws are repealed. **********"It is the Government's firm intention to turn apartheid into a political dodo," Hernus Kriel, the Minister of Planning, Provincial Affairs and National Housing, told Parliament in making the announcement. **********Mr. de Klerk has been criticized for not moving to restore land seized from blacks in the name of apartheid, though the Government announced two weeks ago that it was setting up an advisory commission to listen to appeals from those who wanted to go back to their old homes. **********The Government confronts a challenge to its sincerity in the plight of 112 black families who returned to their land at Goegevonden, a farm near Ventersdorp in the western Transvaal from which they were dispossessed in 1978. They have remained despite attempts by local white farmers and right-wing militants to remove them. **********A judge in Pretoria reluctantly ruled on Monday that the law required that the black families be evicted.                    --------------------       Move on Anti-Pretoria Sanctions **********ABUJA, Nigeria, June 5 (Reuters) -- Black African leaders took a major step today toward restoring links with South Africa in a declaration spelling out a new, more relaxed policy on anti-apartheid sanctions. **********The declaration, adopted at a summit of the 51-member Organization of African Unity and obtained by Reuters, said the organization would commit itself to review its sanctions policy if conditions were met.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.main_headline: Your Money; Tax Rule Benefits Night Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.print_headline: Your Money; Tax Rule Benefits Night Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.body_text: **********For thousands of urban workers, commuting late at night will become less worrisome, thanks to a regulation the Internal Revenue Service put into effect this week. **********When an employer pays for a taxi or car service to take employees to or from work because it would be unsafe to walk or take public transportation, employees will have to report only $1.50 a ride, not the actual value, as taxable income. **********The tax-forgiveness rule previously applied to people who occasionally worked late; it has now been extended to those who are assigned to the graveyard shift and are regularly given rides. **********"The service has done a fantastic job in taking some action to recognize the realities of urban life," said Avery E. Neumark, chairman of the fringe benefits subcommittee of the American Bar Association's section on taxation, which helped to persuade the I.R.S. to change its position. "This can be tremendously beneficial, because usually people who work at these hours don't make much." **********Law and accounting firms often employ word processers to transcribe documents overnight. Utilities have repair people and technicians who work late, as do broadcasters. People in a variety of service industries also work through the night. **********Some law and accounting firms paid employees extra, to cover the taxes on the taxi rides they had to report as income, said Mr. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie, a New York accounting firm. But some did not, and many workers were afraid to accept a night job or risked using public transportation in high-crime areas to avoid the tax liability. **********A taxi ride to the New York suburbs or the outer parts of the Bronx or Queens could easily cost $30, Mr. Neumark said. That would equal $7,200 a year; Federal, state and city income taxes on that amount, plus Social Security taxes, could be $2,900. **********To be eligible for the tax forgiveness, a worker has to meet two tests: he or she must be paid $60,535 or less in 1991 (the number is indexed for inflation and will rise in future years) and be eligible for overtime pay of at least time and a half for working more than 40 hours a week. **********In testimony before the I.R.S. this week, Mr. Neumark asked that only the first test be used. "The mugger doesn't ask, 'Are you an hourly or salaried employee?' " he said. **********That and a further recommendation to extend the regulations to cover transportation in employer-owned cars are being considered. In the meantime, the rules already adopted should help to raise the morale of urban workers fearful of crime, Mr. Neumark said, and "it puts them on a parity with workers elsewhere, who are not taxed on employer-provided parking."   Home Ownership **********When Americans start to look for new homes -- as many are doing this time of year -- the vast majority think first about the mortgage. How big and desirable a home they can buy is determined by how big a mortgage they can receive. Indeed, the conventional wisdom is that over the years the home's value will rise and its owner will receive tax deductions. **********But William J. Goldberg, who is in charge of personal financial planning for KPMG Peat Marwick, rejects that view. He is advising home owners to take a conservative stance and hold down their mortgage costs. **********"Back when there was high inflation, generally leverage worked in your favor," he said. "Fix your cost today, stretch, and pay it off with cheaper dollars." But since home values have declined in many regions, the opposite approach is now best, said Mr. Goldberg, a partner in KPMG's Houston office. With many economists expecting low inflation to continue, the situation may not change. **********In addition, tax deductions were more attractive when they meant the Federal Government was picking up half of the cost of real estate taxes and mortgage interest. Now a taxpayer in the top Federal bracket of 31 percent is still paying 69 cents on the dollar, he noted. **********"Vocational insecurity is also a factor," he said. With layoffs widespread, many employees are anxious about their jobs, he said, and many professionals like doctors, lawyers and accountants are finding their income is 20 to 30 percent lower than a year ago. People with relatively low monthly payments are in better shape to weather any storms. **********Mr. Goldberg advises people who are selling one home and buying another to put the equity from the first into the second, rather than make a minimal down payment. "Not many people can pay cash," he said, "unless they are moving from Los Angeles to Houston," or are selling a big home to buy a retirement home. But many can make a large down payment and limit the size of the mortgage. **********He also advises those who already have big mortgages to pay them down ahead of schedule, if possible. "The less your loan is, the better off you're going to be in the long run, barring fabulous inflation," he said. **********But he added one caveat: "Don't do it if you are going to need the money for tuition next year. Don't think of the house as a piggy bank, where you put the money in and get it back out."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/23/busin.main_headline: Foote, Cone Loses Account With Nintendo
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/23/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Foote, Cone Loses Account With Nintendo
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/23/busin.body_text: **********Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, yesterday lost its $20 million account for two Nintendo video game products -- the Nintendo Entertainment System and Game Boy -- 14 months after winning it. **********Nintendo of America Inc. of Redmond, Wash., has started a review and will announce a new agency next month. Bill White, Nintendo's director of advertising and public relations, attributed the move to "philosophical differences," but declined to give further details. **********Foote, Cone declined to comment on the loss. But advertising executives said the philosophical differences were creative: Nintendo prefers to choose from a range of competing campaigns for each product, they said, while Foote, Cone would focus on one approach. **********Leo Burnett U.S.A., Chicago, is considered by many to be the front-runner in the review. Nintendo awarded its $25-million Super Nintendo Entertainment System account to Burnett in April. Nintendo has temporarily assigned the accounts for Game Boy and Nintendo Entertainment System to Burnett until the review is completed.
