https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/03/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR; Allies Double Protected Area for Kurds in Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/03/world.body_text: **********American and allied forces doubled the size of their safe zone for Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq today, securing a region that included the hilltop summer palace of Saddam Hussein. **********By this evening, American officials said, there were no Iraqi troops left in the zone of roughly 1,500 square miles, except for a handful guarding President Hussein's summer residence, a red-tile-roofed Mediterranean-style mansion perched on a mountain west of here and surrounded by a high concrete wall. **********With some American and British marines lounging outside the palace gates and other pressing the security zone further eastward into Iraq, the Baghdad Radio announced tonight that the Government would blow up the palace, and it invited journalists to watch the explosion. **********The Iraqi Government has protested the presence of American troops in the north, and the threat to destroy the residence may stem from fears the allies will find sensitive communications gear inside. But American military officials say Iraqi soldiers will be allowed to remain in the palace, so the Iraqi leader's threat may be more a political gesture than a real warning. **********The safety zone carved out today is to run about 30 miles south from the border with Turkey and about 60 miles east from the Zakho area to a point a little beyond this village jutting above a spectacular mountain view. **********Long truck caravans of British marines, American paratroopers and French and Dutch troops ground along the ragged, steep roads near here all day, with helicopters beating overhead. **********The allies have sought to bring an estimated 800,000 Kurdish refugees out of the mountains along the Iraqi-Turkish border.  But their rapid advance into Iraq raises the question of whether the allies will move south to secure Dohuk, a provincial capital. Dohuk is politically sensitive because of its administrative importance, but it is also a city that military officers say must be part of the security zone because it is the home of many Kurdish refugees. **********Nazir Abdul Bahke, 21 years old, who came down from a mountain refugee camp to check his family home, was among the few people in the streets here, deserted first by their 5,000 residents and today by the Iraqi Army. His home, like many where the Iraqis had been, was looted. Did he feel safe now? he was asked. **********"If you want the truth, no," he replied. "We are scared they will do something to us." **********Speaking of the Kurdish fears, the allied commander in northern Iraq, Lieut. Gen. John Shalikashvili of the United States Army, said: "The whole purpose of this is to extend the security east from here to open up more villages and the town of Amadiya for the refugees in the camps so they can go home instead of having to come into the temporary campsite that we are building. **********"I would be surprised if the first villagers would not begin to come back to these towns where we are now located within the next couple of days, if they're not already on their way today." **********But relief workers and refugees noted that Kurds from cities further south and west like Kirkuk, Mosul and Erbil, as well as Dohuk, and the refugees clustered around the Iranian border were not protected by the security zone. **********"We think that it is very important for relief workers to be in all these cities, we think it is a guarantee that Saddam will not take military action against these cities and their populations," said Dr. Guy Causse of Doctors of the World, a French relief organization, in the Yekmal refugee camp. "We are prepared to stay longer than normal because of this situation."  Circumspect Manner **********Although senior military commanders say privately that the zone must be extended south, General Shalikashvili has been circumspect in public. **********"I think there are many factors that influence that," the general said today when asked about pressing toward Dohuk. "We have, after all, refugees that come from areas deep, deep south from here. And we have to do all that in a deliberate manner, to decide just how far south or in any direction for that matter, we want to extend the security zone." **********During the day's advance there was some tense, then merely odd, moments beginning when a British Royal Marine reconnaissance team reached Saddam Hussein's palace at about 10 this morning. **********First Lieut. Matthew Cawthorne of the Marines said his men had jumped off their vehicles and took cover at the ready, as they had been trained, which apparently alarmed several of the Iraqi soldiers who raised their AK-47 rifles before being calmed by their own officers. **********Lieutenant Cawthorne said the Iraqis had told him, "Our mission is to protect this place to our last drop of blood." **********That being said, the Iraqis, including a journalist in a army uniform who took television and still pictures, stood glumly around their Chevrolet Blazers amid a growing, milling crowd of foreign journalists, American marines perched atop their amphibious armored cars and the British marines who have set up their headquarters in a nearby cafe. **********"I am very happy for the peace, because this is our Government's decision," Col. Mohammed Raad, the Iraqi commander, told the journalists. "The Kurds are our brothers. We all hope they can come back to their homes." **********The agreement to let the military guards stay at the palace was intended, allied officers said, to keep it from being looted by vengeful Kurds. **********General Shalikashvili said he intended "to insure that the presence of the Iraqis is small enough and confined to the palace ground so that we can assure the Kurds who are in the mountains coming into this area that there is nothing here that threatens them."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/busin.body_text: **********William Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, the computer software maker, sold 500,000 Microsoft shares in late April, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********The company announced the sale today, and a spokeswoman said that as of March 31 Mr. Gates owned 39.3 million shares, representing a little more than 50 percent of the company's outstanding shares. **********The S.E.C. filing said Mr. Gates sold the shares at prices ranging from $100.50 to $103. Mr. Gates thus pocketed more than $50 million from the sales. **********Microsoft stock dropped 50 cents a share today in over-the-counter trading, closing at $109.75. **********Analysts said the effect of the sales was limited. **********"Percentage wise, it means nothing," said David Bayer, an analyst with Montgomery Securities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/24/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********"The Disability Dilemma" (Forum, Nov. 3) points out that employment prospects for people with disabilities are not as good as originally anticipated for white-collar jobs. But American business cannot fill many millions of jobs annually in fast-food chains, department stores and other establishments that require employees for customer contact, technical information processing, telephone marketing and back-room activities. **********Most American companies are regarding the Americans with Disabilities Act as an unabashed disaster. The costs and administrative burdens cannot be denied. But some companies have happily recognized the value of hiring the disabled and more will eventually realize that the law has the potential to wipe out a chronic and future shortage of qualified entry-level and skilled labor plaguing businesses. The law also has the potential to turn 43 million formerly disenfranchised disabled citizens into consumers and taxpayers with spending power the economy badly needs. STEPHEN E. MESSINGER  New York, Nov. 13

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/busin.body_text: **********Canada's gross domestic product fell by 1 percent in the fourth quarter, the Government has announced. It was the third consecutive quarterly drop in the measure. The economy shrank by two-tenths of a percent in the second quarter and three-tenths of a percent in the third quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/busin.body_text: **********South Korea's auto exports to the United States plunged in the first two months of the year from a year earlier, the Korea Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today. Association officials said exports to the United States, Korea's biggest export market, fell 21.2 percent, to 17,554 cars, accounting for 43.5 percent of this nation's total car exports. Korea's overall car exports were listed at 40,380 in the first two months of this year, up 2.7 percent from year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/09/world.main_headline: BRITISH HOSTAGE IN BEIRUT FREED, BUT TERRORISTS VOW KILLINGS IF MORE ARE LET GO
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/09/world.print_headline: THE HOSTAGE DRAMA; BRITISH HOSTAGE IN BEIRUT FREED, BUT TERRORISTS VOW KILLINGS IF MORE ARE LET GO
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/09/world.body_text: **********A pro-Iranian militant group in Lebanon today released John McCarthy, a British citizen who had been held captive for five years. **********As diplomatic efforts to gain the release of other hostages were intensifying in many capitals, the 34-year-old television journalist brought with him a letter from his captors to the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar. He said he thought it contained the captors' proposals for freeing the 11 remaining Western hostages in Lebanon in exchange for prisoners being held in Israel. **********But the hopes that at least one more hostage, presumably an American, would quickly follow Mr. McCarthy to freedom were set back when a murky and apparently new underground group announced that it had kidnapped a French medical worker living in Beirut and threatened to kill him if any more hostages are released. A French relief organization later confirmed that one of its employees was missing in the Lebanese capital.  Report on Other Hostages **********In an emotional appearance in Damascus, Mr. McCarthy said three well-known fellow hostages -- Terry A. Anderson, Thomas M. Sutherland and Terry Waite -- were alive and in good health. **********Despite the report of another kidnapping, both President Bush and the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, expressed some confidence that another hostage, an American, would be released soon. But it was unclear how disruptive the reported kidnapping by a previously unknown group would be. **********United States officials were monitoring the hostage situation through both high-level diplomatic contacts and what they declared were intelligence channels too sensitive to describe in any way. Several officials conveyed the impression that the United States was largely on the sidelines as events were unfolding. Kidnapping of Frenchman **********Bush Administration officials said they were offering nothing in return for the release of the hostages. They said international diplomatic efforts were focused on promoting the deal the kidnappers say they want: to exchange Arab prisoners held by Israel for the release of the remaining 11 Western hostages and captured Israeli servicemen. **********The sudden report of a new kidnapping in Beirut today, the first in more than two years, caught Bush Administration officials off guard. Initial reports from news agencies in Beirut said an anonymous telephone caller claiming to represent the Organization for the Defense of the Prisoners' Rights declared that a Frenchman named Jerome Leyraud was abducted. **********The caller asserted that Mr. Leyraud was a French intelligence officer working undercover with a relief agency. French Defense Ministry officials denied this allegation. **********Doctors of the World, a French relief agency, cnfirmed that Mr. Leyraud, its administrator for Lebanon, had been missing from his home and office since mid-afternoon. The janitor at Leyraud's apartment building in west Beirut told the Reuters news agency that the 26-year-old Frenchman was last seen leaving the residential building at about 2:45 P.M. carrying a towel that indicated he was going swimming.  Underground Groups **********Lebanon's shadowy kidnappers identify themselves by a number of organizational names, with some of them loosely affiliated with the Party of God organization, which operates openly as one of the contending political factions in Lebanon. Party of God leaders deny that they are involved in holding hostages, but say they know the kidnappers and communicate with them. **********Among the known hostage holding organizations are: Islamic Holy War, which holds Mr. Anderson, Mr. Waite and Mr. Sutherland, the former agriculture dean of the American University of Beirut; Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, which holds the Americans Alann Steen and Jesse Turner; the Revolutionary Justice Organization, which holds another American, Joseph J. Cicippio; the Organization of the Oppressed on Earth, which took responsibility for the killing of Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins in 1988; Holy Warriors for Freedom, which holds two German relief workers, and the Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Muslims, which said it killed the British journalist Alec Collett in April 1986. **********President Bush, vacationing in Kennebunkport, Maine, told reporters that he is still confident that an American hostage could be released. **********"I think those that follow this most closely feel that it is likely an American will be released," Mr. Bush said, adding that he did not know the time frame for the next release. "The ball is not in our hands," he said, "and the evidence is not all that hard. We keep getting assurances through third parties, but that's not good enough for me." **********Asked whether he had information that Mr. Anderson, a 43-year-old correspondent for the Associated Press and the longest-held hostage, could be the next prisoner released, Mr. Bush said: "We don't know that. I think that's what the latest rumor had, that it would be Terry Anderson." Swiss in Intermediary Role **********United States officials were careful not to reveal the specific sources of their diplomatic exchanges and sensitive intelligence. But officials said the Swiss Government was playing an active role as an intermediary between Washington and the Iranian Government. The officials also indicated that Syria was pressing its efforts to free the hostages. This was apparent today in scenes from Damascus, where Syria's Foreign Ministry and state television took a prominent role in helping to manage Mr. McCarthy's release. **********Mr. Perez de Cuellar, who was expected to rendezvous with Mr. McCarthy to receive a letter he is carrying from his kidnappers, the Islamic Holy War organization, said he remained hopeful that an American hostage would be released sometime today or Friday. **********"I have hope that the other hostage will be released today," the Secretary General told reporters outside the United Nations Secretariat in New York. "I have reason to have hope." Negotiations With Israel **********The diplomatic work now highlighted by Mr. McCarthy's release centers on negotiations that have sputtered for months between Israel and Lebanese Shiite Muslim groups. After he was released, Mr. McCarthy said in Damascus that he had not looked at the contents of the letter he was carrying to Mr. Perez de Cuellar but said, "I understand that the letter seeks the Secretary General's help in arranging the release of all prisoners and hostages being held in Lebanon, and for those held in Israel." **********"I believe they want to make a full exchange of the Western hostages, all the prisoners, civilian and military, who are currently being held in Israel, from Lebanon." **********British officials said they planned to press Israel to release several hundred Arab detainees in a bid to build on the momentum of Mr. McCarthy's release. **********Israeli officials quickly responded. Defense Minister Moshe Arens said Israel was "definitely ready" for a hostage swap provided that seven Israeli servicemen missing in Lebanon are accounted for. Some of the Israelis are believed to be still alive. **********Negotiations for such an exchange of hostages and prisoners between Israel and Lebanon's militant groups have been stalled on the question of how many Arab detainees Israel would release and whether the Lebanese groups would return the Israeli servicemen they hold. There are about 300 Lebanese detainees in Israeli jails, but in addition, there are thousands of Palestinian fighters and civilians, some seized in Lebanon, but thousands more detained in the West Bank and Gaza during several years of Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. Rockets Fired in Beirut **********The shadowy group trying to block today's hostage release efforts called itself the Organization for the Defense of Prisoners' Rights. This is the same name used by callers who took responsibility this week for firing rocket-propelled grenades near United Nations offices in Beirut to protest the first indications that hostages would be released this week. **********It was not clear how large or well organized the group is or why it is against the release of hostages. Its demands for the release of Arab detainees and the demands of Islamic Holy War are similiar, though one group may demand that Israel act concurrently in releasing Arab prisoners. **********"We shall not stop at this point if the deals and the trading persist at the expense of the dignity of our brethren imprisoned in Israel," the telephone caller representing the Organization for the Defense of the Prisoners' Rights said, according to an Associated Press dispatch from Beirut. **********In anticipation of the release of an American hostage, the Bush Administration sent a team of medical and psychological specialists today to Wiesbaden, Germany, another sign that the Administration had reliable intelligence information that a second hostage could be freed in Lebanon. **********Mr. McCarthy, in an interview aired by Syrian television, said that his Islamic Holy War captors told him Wednesday that they believed the time was right to settle the long hostage situation and had released Mr. McCarthy as a sign of their good will.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/busin.main_headline: A Hard Sell, Inspired by The Classics
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; A Hard Sell, Inspired by The Classics
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/busin.body_text: **********Americans bought more than 3.5 million Penguin Classics last year, everything from Aesop's "Fables" to the history of Xenophon. But sales of the classics have been flat for a couple of years and competition is more heated than ever. **********So Penguin U.S.A. recently embarked on a three-year promotion to persuade booksellers to carry more of the Penguin Classics -- presumably at the expense of its competitors. **********"Those sales have to come from somewhere," said Marcia Burch, the marketing director of Penguin's adult trade paperbacks. She laughed when she said it, but her remark exemplified how competitive -- some would say cutthroat -- the merchandising of even the world's great literature has become. Important Industry Segment **********Classics account for only a small percentage of the estimated 220 million adult paperback books that will be published this year. Yet they are not only a prestige item for publishers but also an important segment of an industry that is made up of segments -- everything from fiction to westerns to biographies to mysteries to reference books. And competition to dominate each segment is intense. **********Penguin's largest inducement, of course, is money: Stores that agree to carry at least 300 of its Classics paperback titles in a special section will receive the company's highest discount (46 percent) and free freight on all reorders of 10 copies or more. **********The publisher will give them free spinner racks with 48 pockets for displaying the books and free brochures and newsletters for customers, and will remit 5 percent of each store's 1990 gross sales of Penguin Classics toward promoting the line. **********Such promotions are essential to book publishers. "More and more, stores are willing to carry only one line of classics, or two at most," said Ellen I. Chodosh, the director of trade paperbacks for the Oxford University Press, whose 350 World's Classics titles compete with the much-larger Penguin line. Oxford also offers price incentives to booksellers, as well as the occasional coffee mugs, posters and similar inducements. **********"We are definitely the underdog to Penguin," Ms. Chodosh acknowledged. "But little by little, we'll take chunks out of the market." **********While Penguin and Oxford are the principal competitors in trade paperback classics, with books averaging $5.95 to $6.95 (but $19.95 for Penguin's recent oversized edition of the Koran), Bantam Classics and Signet Classics are fighting it out for dominance in the mass-market end of the business, where prices more typically range from $3.95 to $5.95. The more expensive classics usually include more extensive introductions, footnotes, bibliographies and appendixes. **********Last year, Signet -- which was bought by Penguin U.S.A. in 1987 -- sold about four million copies of its 300 classics titles. Since almost all classics are in the public domain, some titles like "David Copperfield" by Charles Dickens are published by all four publishers. Different Markets **********Yet there are significant differences in the kinds of books sold in the different markets. Lou Aronica, the publisher of Bantam mass-market books, said "Huckleberry Finn" by Mark Twain was Bantam's biggest-selling classic title. Penguin's best-selling title last year was "The Three Theban Plays" of Sophocles, translated by Robert Fagels. Runners-up were Chaucer's "Canterbury Tales" and "The Odyssey" by Homer, translated by E. V. Rieu. That book, with Mr. Rieu's translation, was the first Penguin Classic title in 1946. **********Other competitors are also beginning to publish classics. **********For example, Vintage Books, an imprint of Random House, has begun publishing trade paperback editions of the Library of America, a series of classic works by American writers. The Charles E. Tuttle Company, a publisher in Rutland, Vt., plans to distribute paperback editions of the Everyman's Classic Library from Britain, beginning with 35 titles this fall and adding more than 50 titles each year for each of the next five years. Also this fall, Alfred A. Knopf will begin publishing hardcover editions of the Everyman Classics. 86 Stores Signed Up **********Penguin says its promotion is running ahead of expectations, with 86 stores already signed up. These include the McCawber Bookstore in Princeton, N.J.; Tower's Bookshop in Washington; the William and Mary College Store in Williamsburg, Va.; Humboldt State University store in Arcata, Calif., and Schwartz Bookstore in Brookfield, Wis. **********Another recent enthusiast of the Penguin Classics is Jerry Harper, co-owner of Cyrano's Bookstore in Anchorage. "We just expanded our Penguin Classics section and they're selling a lot better than we expected," he said. "Our customers like them, and we're satisfied with the discount structure."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/world.main_headline: Gustav Husak, Czechoslovak Leader, Dies at 78
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/world.print_headline: Gustav Husak, Czechoslovak Leader, Dies at 78
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/world.body_text: **********Former President Gustav Husak of Czechoslovakia, the old-line Slovak Communist who came to the fore after a Soviet bloc invasion stamped out the Prague Spring of 1968 and fell with the collapse of Communism, died yesterday. He was 78 years old. **********The nation's official press agency reported that he died in a hospital in Bratislava, the Slovak republic's capital and his hometown, of heart, circulatory and respiratory failure. He had been hospitalized 10 days earlier. **********Mr. Husak's party career reflected the vagaries buffeting the eastern bloc formed by the Soviet Union after World War II. He spent years in jail in the Stalinist era, accused of "bourgeois nationalism," because he advocated a measure of autonomy for Slovakia, a constituent republic administered from Prague. **********He was ousted from the Czechoslovak Parliament in 1951, thrown out of the party -- an experience that was to be repeated early in 1990 -- and arrested on charges of treason and sabotage. Others around him were executed, but he was spared that, receiving a life prison term in 1954. The Rise to the Top **********The sentence was declared illegal in 1963, and the Communist Party returned his membership card. But it took five more years before he started to rise again through the party hierarchy and to the top. **********Once there, Mr. Husak presided over one of the sternest, least tolerant governments in Eastern Europe for the next 20 years. Mr. Husak, as the party's General Secretary, replaced Alexander Dubcek, the leader of the brief spell of reforms that were to give Czechoslovakia "socialism with a human face." Instead, it brought to the streets of Prague the tanks and guns of the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies. **********In 1975, Mr. Husak added the Czechoslovak presidency to his portfolio, also becoming militia Commander in Chief. Ten years later, the ascendance of Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the Soviet leadership and his subsequent campaigns for openness and social and economic restructuring began to reverberate through the Soviet satellites of Eastern Europe. **********Under some reform pressure, Mr. Husak yielded the party leadership to Milos Jakes in December 1987. Two years later his membership was suspended and he was expelled once again in January 1990. **********On Dec. 10, 1989, Czechoslovakia swore in a Cabinet with the Communists in the minority. After 41 years of party rule, a "Government of national understanding" took office, with 11 non-Communists and 10 Communists heading the ministries. **********With a huge crowd celebrating outside, Mr. Husak resigned and opened the way for Vaclav Havel, the dissident and playwright who headed the Civic Forum movement, to succeed him. **********Mr. Dubcek emerged from years in limbo, spent partly as a forester and a locksmith fitter, and became Speaker of the Czechoslovak Parliament. **********Gustav Husak was born on Jan. 10, 1913, in Bratislava. He joined the Slovak Communist Party in 1933 as a student and immersed himself in Marxist doctrine. Working for his doctorate in law in Bratislava he fell in with other intellectuals with Communist leanings. They were led by Vladimir Clementis. **********He practiced in Clementis's law firm in Bratislava and was jailed in 1940 by the German-backed Slovak puppet Government. Freed in 1943, he played a significant role in a revolt against the puppet regime a year later. He also began a career as a government official and party functionary. In 1948, after the Communists took sole control of the country, he was elected to the party's Central Committee. **********Soon afterward, a purge began of party stalwarts suspected of "nationalism" and of plotting to follow Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia out of the Soviet sphere of influence. The party chief, Rudolph Slansky, and Foreign Minister Clementis were the main targets, and Mr. Husak's close association with Clementis put him at risk as well. **********He was arrested in 1951 and convicted and sentenced in 1954. Six years later, in 1960, he was released, pending review of his case, and found a job with the Department of Buildings in Bratislava with enough spare time to write a history of the 1944 uprising. **********In his petition for rehabilitation, Mr. Husak acknowledged certain "negative" traits, like "too much self-confidence, a quick temper, frequent impatience, a tendency to demand too much from people." He also said that working for the party had meant neglect of his family and seeing his children "only occasionally." **********He became an early supporter of Mr. Dubcek, perhaps because of the previous leadership's condemnation of Slovak nationalism. He was also a principal architect of the federated system under which the Slovak minority of about 5 million and the nearly 10 million Czechs were given limited autonomy in their own regions, at least in theory. **********Mr. Husak was said to be a sophisticated man. Above all, he was considered a deft politician with a logical mind and the ability to tailor his oratory to an audience, speaking in polished Czech to a Prague audience and turning folksy and freewheeling back home in Slovakia. **********Since his ouster, Mr. Husak had been living quietly in Bratislava, reportedly suffering from stomach cancer. Roman Catholic Church officials said he had been given last rites 10 days ago. **********Little was known about Mr. Husak's life away from the office other than that he was a widower and a father. His wife, Viera, died in October 1977 in a helicopter crash on the way from a Slovak spa, Bardejov, to the Husak villa in Bratislava. She and Mr. Husak were married in 1975, some years after the death of his first wife.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/29/busin.body_text: **********About 200,000 shoppers are expected to descend on Bloomingdale's flagship store in Manhattan today, looking for that perfect gift. Behind the scenes, Bloomingdale's executives are trying to tie a bow on their most important Christmas season in years. **********After nearly two years in Federal Bankruptcy Court, dealing with uncertainty about its fate and the future of its legendary boss, Marvin S. Traub, Bloomingdale's is trying to put all of that behind it and buck all the gloomy projections for Christmas sales this year. **********"You may think I'm crazy, but I really believe we are going to have an outstanding fourth quarter," said Allen I. Questrom, chief executive of Federated Department Stores Inc., Bloomingdale's owner, in a videotape played to employees at a rally this week. **********Indeed, for Mr. Questrom's optimism to bear fruit, a miracle on 59th Street is essential. Of Federated's nine department store chains, Bloomingdale's accounts for the largest portion of sales, providing some 17 percent of Federated's $7.1 billion in revenues. And the New York store generates half of the operating profit for the 15-store Bloomingdale's chain. The retailer typically generates about 25 percent of its annual sales in the period from Thanksgiving to Christmas. **********"Questrom needs a showcase for not only the retail community, but to show the vendors that Federated is still alive," said Allan Mottus, a retailing consultant in New York. "He is going to use Bloomingdale's to do that." **********But more than Christmas is at stake. "We're not looking to just do Christmas business; we are really building towards the future," said Richard J. Mast, store manager for the Bloomingdale's store on 59th Street and Lexington Avenue. "We really made a special effort to put our best foot forward this year. We want to remind people in New York that we are a viable, strong company and a good place to do business." **********The store is considerably brighter, more festive and more welcoming this year. And if Mr. Mast's plans actually work, it will be a much more convenient place for customers to part with their money. From the looks of the place, said Alan G. Millstein, publisher of the Fashion Network Report newsletter, "it appears that they've opened up the checkbook."  'Just Fabulous' Windows **********One bit of evidence is in the windows, where zany Rube Goldberg-like contraptions featuring mechanical reindeer wearing red high-top sneakers are drawing bemused crowds. "They are just fabulous," a well-dressed window shopper said to no one in particular as she hurried by one morning this week. **********This year the store has dedicated 15,000 square feet of its second floor -- the equivalent of seven average-sized American homes -- to create an arcade of flashy Christmas shops selling such gifts as toys, gourmet food, lingerie, sports memorabilia and bar accessories. The horseshoe-shaped scheme is decorated in a jarring mix of green, red and hot pink, with modern archways lining the walkway to each shop. **********Although Bloomingdale's is still operating on a tight budget under the gaze of the bankruptcy court, it has aimed its extra spending at areas that customers will notice. This year, it has hired 150 more sales clerks than it had last year in an effort to minimize complaints about long waits. **********The store has also set up a Federal Express desk in the store -- the only such in-store site in the city, the company claims -- to help expedite the shipping of out-of-town gifts for last-minute shoppers. Gift-wrapping service has been expanded to more floors. And customers can drop off gifts for wrapping and continue shopping or go to a restaurant in the store and have the gift delivered to their tables. The store is also expanding its coat and package check-in service, and it has hired a Japanese-speaking guide to help tourists from Japan.  A Language Directory **********To accommodate foreign shoppers, who account for about a third of the Manhattan store's sales, the company has distributed to every person on the sales floor a directory of employees that speak foreign languages like Turkish, Indonesian, Romanian and two dozen others, as well as sign language. **********The company has also made it easier for its charge-card customers to cash personal checks. **********Many of these changes grew out of complaints from last year's shoppers and criticism from within the store's ranks. **********After Christmas was over, "I felt we needed to focus more on service," said Marian H. Goodman, the assistant store manager. She suggested publishing the phone number of individual departments in newspaper advertisements for shoppers who want to call for more information and providing more shelving to display sweaters, a perennial fast-moving Christmas item. **********Comments from a number of store employees were assembled into a three-inch-thick book that is being used in an effort to increase this year's Christmas sales.  Rumors and Uneasy Vendors **********Last year, the company was mired in bankruptcy court by the downfall of its owner, the Campeau Corporation. As a result, vendors were uneasy about shipping dresses, purses and perfume to the store. Rumors flew in the stockrooms that the store would be sold to Japanese investors and that the company's well-regarded chief, Mr. Traub, was planning to retire with no successor in line. **********The uncertainty showed. "I was aghast by how they did things on the cheap," said Mr. Millstein, the newsletter publisher. Shoppers had to look no farther than the store's windows for a sign of gloom. The uninspired window displays featured different colored globes, surrounded by merchandise of the same color -- a feeble attempt to recapture Bloomingdale's merchandising flair. **********"We didn't get a lot of awards for last year's windows," Mr. Mast, the store manager acknowledged. **********"We got three stumps," he said, referring to an insulting grade assigned by a critic who ranked window displays by awarding multiple Christmas trees for the best, and sawed-off stumps for the worst. **********But this year, the uncertainty has diminished. Mr. Questrom chose Michael Gould, an experienced merchant, to succeed Mr. Traub. And a plan for Federated to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection next year has the support of important creditor groups. **********Retailers work all year to prepare for the holiday season. "It's much like General Schwarzkopf planning the invasion of Kuwait," Mr. Millstein said. "It takes 11 months of planning to execute 30 days of business." **********Designers and merchandisers spent the summer ordering merchandise and laying out the store's design. After Labor Day, Bloomingdale's held a daylong management retreat outside of the store. **********The physical retooling for Christmas began earlier this month, with the final coat of paint drying as the store opened its doors this morning. Construction, painting and wiring has been going on around the clock. **********On Monday, last-minute loose ends needed to be tied up. At a meeting, a department manager complained that her newly constructed cash register stand had been scratched. "Hit them again" with paint, Mr. Mast said to a painter. **********Another manager noted that the newly installed lights were not highlighting the goods. So Mr. Mast reminded the electrician to get the light pointed in the right direction and to connect the red "Exit" signs before the fire department inspected the newly constructed area. Calming Jangled Nerves **********James Gundell, the recently appointed general manager of the store, tried to calm the jangled nerves of department managers concerned that meddling executives would rearrange displays. "I don't think we should let ego get in the way today," he said. "Let's just get through today." **********Most important, one manager was scrambling to make sure the hot items were in stock. Mrs. Goodman called a buyer to get more cashmere sweaters. "My business is going through the roof," she barked over the phone. "I have no problem with my on-order; it's my current on-hand that I have problems with," she said, ringing off after getting the buyer's promise to hunt down more $300 sweaters. **********Despite the last-minute chaos, "it's easier to focus on business this year," Mr. Mast said, "because we are not preoccupied with all those horrible bankruptcy thoughts." **********"People aren't going around thinking, 'Am I about to lose my job tomorrow,' " he added. "They are thinking about making sales."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/30/busin.body_text: **********Former directors and principal shareholders of Wieboldt Stores Inc. have agreed to pay $11.7 million to the bankrupt estate of the Chicago retailer, which collapsed after a failed leveraged buyout of the chain in 1985. **********Under the agreement, a group including the Ohio businessman Jerome Schottenstein, his family, and Julius and Edmond Trump agreed to settle claims against them without admitting or denying wrongdoing. The Trumps are not related to the developer Donald J. Trump. **********The agreement settles a fraudulent conveyance suit stemming from a flawed leveraged buyout. In such an action, the failed company sues former shareholders, advisers and managers, charging that the buyout left the company insolvent and improperly shifted capital from creditors to equity holders. **********A number of defendants have argued that claims of fraudulent conveyance do not apply in leveraged buyouts or similar transactions. But court-appointed examiners, including those in the bankruptcies of Revco D.S. and Interco Inc., have found there is a basis for such actions. **********Sachnoff & Weaver, a law firm representing the trustee for Wieboldt, said in an announcement that with the settlement, $30.825 million has been recovered for the estate since 1987 through litigation. The settlement came days before the case was scheduled to go to trial before a jury.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Chyron Accord With Creditors
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.body_text: **********The Chyron Corporation, a maker of television graphic equipment that is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors, said its two main bank creditors had agreed to a financial reorganization. It said the European American Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation had entered into a letter of intent with the Pelloni Capital Corporation of Florida on a proposed plan that would eliminate the entire interest of present shareholders. **********Under the plan, European American would receive $10 million in cash in satisfaction of its $19.8 million term loan to Chyron, plus accrued interest, and Manufacturers would receive $9.8 million in notes plus accrued interest. Unsecured creditors would receive unsecured performance notes on terms yet to be negotiated. Chyron said the proposal would not be filed with the bankruptcy court before June 17.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.main_headline: Goldstar's Stake in Zenith Involves Widespread Links
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.print_headline: Goldstar's Stake in Zenith Involves Widespread Links
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/26/busin.body_text: **********The chief executive of the Goldstar Company, the big South Korean consumer electronics maker, said today that his company's investment last month in the Zenith Electronics Corporation was part of a much broader and previously undisclosed cooperative agreement. **********The executive, Lee Hun Jo, said he doubted that Zenith, the last domestic television maker in the United States, could survive without the broad agreements with Goldstar on manufacturing operations, research and development, and marketing. **********He added that Goldstar would gain access to technologies that it had been "desperately seeking" to compete against much larger Japanese companies. These technologies include high-definition television. For the last seven months, he said, a team of Goldstar engineers has been working at Zenith laboratories to develop high-definition equipment. **********Mr. Lee's comments, in an interview at his company's headquarters tower overlooking the Han River in downtown Seoul, came a month after Goldstar purchased nearly a 5 percent stake in Zenith, which was expected to help the American company fight off a takeover threat from Nycor Inc., a Peapack, N.J., investment company. **********But the investment also had a broader signficiance: It is the first big Korean stake in a large American company, and a big concession by loss-ridden Zenith, which has advoated strict protectionism against foreign competitors. Indeed, Zenith succeeded in getting large penalties invoked against color television sets from Japan and Korea in the early 1980's. Zenith said the sets were being sold below cost, driving most of the American television equipment industry off shore or out of business. **********In today's interview, Mr. Lee said that Goldstar was "not inclined to be a white knight" for Zenith should Nycor gain ground in its effort to oust Zenith's current management. A "white knight" is a friendly acquirer sought by the target of a hostile takeover. Mr. Lee said he did not envision Goldstar taking more than a 10 percent share in Zenith in the foreseeable future. **********Mr. Lee, 59 years old, described a deal that appears to transfer some of Zenith's best technology to the Korean concern. That move has made Zenith a target for criticism in recent weeks on the ground that similar deals led to the loss of many key technologies to Japan in the last two decades.  Flat-Tension Screen **********The key element of the deal, in which Goldstar paid $15 million for its stake, is a license from Zenith for the Korean company to use Zenith's flat-tension screen technology to make television sets. So far the screens, which create a much brighter, flat image than ordinary television sets, have been used primarily on computer monitors. Goldstar plans to use them for commercial television sets, Mr. Lee said, but so far is prohibited from applying the technology to more lucrative computer screens. In the future, he said, "I will push for them to license us to use it on monitors as well." **********He added that the two companies were exploring much broader links: joint manufacturing in Mexico, where Zenith has a plant that is not being used to capacity; marketing of Zenith products outside the United States, where Goldstar is strong; even jointly using delivery trucks and service personnel. Most important, he said, joint research and development is already under way. **********It was a common fear of Japan, Mr. Lee seemed to suggest today, that drew him into talks with Jerry K. Perlman, Zenith's chairman and president, more than a year ago. For Zenith, which lost $52.3 million last year on sales of $1.4 billion, an alliance with a manufacturer of Goldstar's size may well be a matter of survival. **********"We need to globalize our operations and move our brand image from the low end of the market to the high," Mr. Lee said, describing a worldwide network of research operations and factories that sound much like what Sony and Matsushita Electric Industrial built through the 1980's. Goldstar's sales this year are expected to be about $5.13 billion.  Reaction From Japan **********But Goldstar's future faces one big hurdle: Like its major Korean competitors, its once-easy supply of Japanese technology is being choked off. As Japanese manufacturers have come to view Korea as a growing threat, they have declined to license their leading-edge products. **********For example, Koreans are not manufacturing the light, notebook computers that have proved a boon for Toshiba and NEC, or the lightest, handheld video cameras like those made by Sony and Matsushita. They are a generation behind in memory chip technology and further behind in more specialized chips. **********One critical area is high-definition television, in which Japanese makers have invested billions. Goldstar is hoping to make up for that technological shortfall by allying with Zenith, which in turn is allied with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********"We have had a team of 10 engineers in Zenith's laboratory, and they are making good progress," Mr. Lee said, adding that he had no interest in taking a management role at Zenith, which is based in Glenview, Ill. **********He dismissed industry allegations that Zenith, desperate for cash and an equity partner, was selling off its most vital technology. "They would not do that for a mere $15 million," he said. "The deal is not technology for money, but for a total business cooperation."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.main_headline: The Fed Eased, But Where's the Money?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH; The Fed Eased, But Where's the Money?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Economic indicators, like clothing styles, go in and out of fashion. It has been more than a decade since the money supply was the most-watched and most-feared statistic, the number that every trading room had a pool on, the one that could send stock and bond prices spiraling up or down if Wall Street's crystal balls had been cloudy. **********Perhaps, however, it is time to again delve into the arcane world of the M's. The figures released late Thursday were stunning, showing sharp declines for the final week of April. **********"With the amount of Fed stimulation that has taken place to date, there should still be a rising trend in money growth," noted Dan Bernstein and Ross Waller of Bridgewater Associates.  If the trend did not turn around, they added, "the Fed will have to do a major reassessment of growth prospects for the economy." **********The money supply figures were important when traders hoped they would fall, indicating that inflation was easing. Now inflation is low, and a larger money supply is desired as a sign that the Fed's easing has brought increased economic activity. There are some encouraging signs, such as evidence that layoffs are slowing, but also evidence that many with good credit are choosing not to borrow and invest, while those with poor credit still can't get loans. **********In January, Alan Greenspan pointed to last fall's extremely slow monetary growth as a symptom of the credit crunch. He indicated it was a major reason the Fed needed to ease further. That round of easing briefly pushed up monetary growth and gave heart to stock traders. **********But the money supply as measured by M2 -- basically most consumer savings plus cash, checking accounts and overnight corporate investments -- peaked in mid-April and has fallen sharply for two weeks. That statistic is an indicator of business activity and is not what those forecasting an early recovery had expected. **********"It raises questions about whether we are in some kind of credit contraction phase that would be associated with asset deflation, including real estate, stocks and corporate assets," said David M. Jones, the chief economist of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company and author of "The Politics of Money," a new book on the Greenspan Fed. Mr. Jones thinks this recession may last into next year, far longer than conventional wisdom expects. **********Concerns over the monetary figures probably played a role in Friday's sharp drop in stock prices, which erased the week's previous gains and left the Dow Jones industrial average down 18.69 points for the week, to 2,920.17. **********The money supply figures are notoriously volatile, and maybe in a few weeks the Fed will revise away the most recent drop. But if that does not happen, new questions will be raised about whether monetary policy alone is enough to get the economy moving again. **********And who knows what would be done then? As Mr. Jones put it, "The Administration hasn't got any clue about how to get out of the recession, except to tell the Fed to ease every day."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.main_headline: Stocks Mixed In Slow Day; Dow Off 2.23
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.print_headline: Stocks Mixed In Slow Day; Dow Off 2.23
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Wall Street mostly took a holiday yesterday. Stocks turned mixed and activity sank to the lowest level of the year as hundreds of traders stayed home for a long Fourth of July weekend. **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell to 2,932.47, off 2.23 for the day but ahead 25.72 for the week. **********Activity on both the New York and American stock exchanges and in the over-the-counter market fell to the lowest levels of the year. **********"It was just a post-July Fourth day," said Eugene E. Peroni, chief technical analyst for Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia. **********Monday's 51.66-point surge in the Dow in the wake of a big run-up in Japan's Nikkei stock index helped the Dow stay in the black for the week.   Earnings More of a Factor **********Since then, however, the Nikkei has been losing ground, dropping another 1 percent yesterday. Even so, the few traders around yesterday on Wall Street looked more to earnings than either the Nikkei or another piece of news on the economy. **********New employment data came out yesterday showing that while payrolls dropped in June they apparently did not decline enough to prompt the Fed to trim interest rates. The news toppled bond prices but had little impact on stocks. **********Along with the Dow blue chips, the Nasdaq composite fell a little, with high-technology stocks leading the way. The Standard & Poor's 500, peppered with the big stocks, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index, loaded with smaller stocks, both rose a bit. But the changes were far less than even 1 percent and in any case meant little because many traders were elsewhere yesterday. **********Except for a brief 12-point slide in the Dow at the start of trading, the blue chips jumped 28 points from their low by 10:30 but then began dropping. In a decline that lasted for the rest of the day, the Dow lost most of its gain by 1:30, moving aimlessly until the closing bell. **********Trading on the Big Board hit a new low for the year yesterday of 69.9 million shares, down sharply from 140.6 million on Wednesday. Volume was also down sharply from the previous 1991 low of 109.5 million on May 20, a quiet Monday, and was the lowest since Dec. 24, 1990, when 57.2 million shares were traded. **********The Nasdaq hit a 1991 low of 56.3 million shares, down from its previous low for the year of 92.02 million. Trading on the Amex hit a new low yesterday of 5.4 million shares, down from the previous 1991 low of 6.99 million shares. **********Mr. Peroni, the Philadelphia market watcher, pointed, though, to the market's "relative firmness." **********"Compared to the bonds' sharp selloff," he said, "this relative firmness in stocks indicates that investors who were in the market today are looking for quality growth plays in anticipation of a focused earnings turnaround in the second half." **********With Wall Street's attention fixed on I.B.M. and a few other technology stocks as one of the best ways to forecast the direction of stock prices, Mr. Peroni argued that the market was "apt to remain unsettled for several weeks -- until it becomes clear whether investors have fully discounted lower earnings expectations for I.B.M. and other recently depressed tech stocks." **********I.B.M. made the Big Board list of the 10 most active stocks, rising 1/2, to 98 5/8, in what appeared to be a reaction to its announcement with Apple Computer that the two would join forces to make personal computers easier to use. **********Apple led Nasdaq's active list, rising 2 1/2, to 45 5/8, with nearly three million shares changing hands. A big competitor, Microsoft, stood in third place on the list, sinking 2 1/4, to 61 3/4, with volume of 1.6 million shares. **********BankAmerica, which was down by 2 on Wednesday amid uncertainty over earnings, rose by 1, to 34 1/2, yesterday following its announcement after Wednesday's close of trading that it expected second-quarter earnings to be close to the $267 million it earned in the quarter a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/22/busin.body_text: **********Two leading Midwestern universities were raising money yesterday through debt securities. **********The University of Missouri priced $24 million in capital project notes through J. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.main_headline: Lithuania Criticizes Report on Treatment Of War Criminals
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.print_headline: SOVIET TURMOIL; Lithuania Criticizes Report on Treatment Of War Criminals
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.body_text: **********President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania yesterday criticized a report that his country was rehabilitating Nazi war criminals as it offered pardons to people convicted of collaboration by Soviet tribunals. **********In a letter to the World Jewish Congress replying to questions raised by its president, Edgar Bronfman, and released in New York by the organization, Mr. Landsbergis said he could "not agree with the insinuations that there are thousands of Holocaust suspects living here, who are being legally absolved as patriots of Lithuania." **********An article on Thursday in The New York Times quoted the Lithuanian prosecutor, Artusas Paulauskas, as saying that his office had issued more than 1,000 certificates of rehabilitation and expected to issue thousands more to people who he said were convicted without due process or on the basis of forced confessions or fabricated testimony. **********The article quoted officials of the Wiesenthal Center of Los Angeles, which is devoted to tracking Nazi war criminals, as questioning the decision to exonerate three people. The center provided the records of their proceedings, which were quoted in the report. In addition, The Times quoted an elderly Jewish resident of Vilnius, Ruiva Bogomalnaya, as identifying one of those being rehabilitated as a man whom she saw beat and kill people during the war. **********In his letter, Mr. Landsbergis said, "We can imagine that among the individuals repressed by the Soviets there were also Holocaust criminals." He added that he had asked Mr. Paulauskas to "investigate, with the utmost responsibility and concern, material pertaining to those individuals" mentioned in the article.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.main_headline: Small-Business Agency Gives Award to Woman
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Small-Business Agency Gives Award to Woman
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.body_text: **********Joann R. Schulz has been named the National Small Business Person of the Year by the Small Business Administration. She is the first woman so honored in the 27 years that the Federal agency has presented the award. **********Mrs. Schulz, who is 45, was cited for her work as president of DGR Inc. of St. Petersburg, Fla., a maker of ophthalmic products for eye surgeons. Mrs. Schulz took over the company in 1986 after the death of her husband, Richard, who had been president. His death came only a year after the company was founded and it was struggling. **********"The company could not afford to put all founders on the payroll," she said. "My husband was president, heading operations; another founder headed manufacturing. We also hired an assembler." **********When her husband died of a heart attack at 44, Mrs. Schulz thought her new position was temporary. She already headed a consulting firm, Regtech, which helped companies to obtain Food and Drug Administration approvals. **********"I planned to stay for three months, which became six months and then five years," she said. **********In 1990, sales totaled $4 million and pretax profit was $1 million. "This year, sales will be about $6 million and pretax profit about $1.5 million," Mrs. Shultz estimated. She said the company now had 75 employees. **********In March, Mrs. Schulz resigned as head of DGR to become president of a larger company, Phoenix Laser Systems Inc., a San Francisco optical products concern. She said she hoped to merge Phoenix with DGR, where she still owns 17 percent of the stock. **********Mrs. Schulz, who majored in chemistry and biological science, received her undergraduate degree from the University of California in 1973. She added a master's degree in biochemistry in 1977. **********Her first professional job was with an ophthalmic unit of American Hospital Supply. "I left in 1979 to work in the technical area, for Coburn Optical, then a division of Revlon and based in Florida," she said, adding that she took the job even though she did not like the general manager. "A year and a half later, in 1980, I married him," she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/02/world.main_headline: Angolan Revelers Celebrate the End of Civil War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/02/world.print_headline: Angolan Revelers Celebrate the End of Civil War
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/02/world.body_text: **********Thousands of Angolans danced and cheered in the streets early this morning in rousing imprompu celebrations marking the formal end of this country's 16-year civil war. **********I was too early to tell how well the cease-fire was being observed, Western diplomatic sources and relief workers said today, but so far there were no reports of renewed fighting. **********Although the cease-fire was initialed Friday night in Lisbon, the Luanda Government had delayed a series of events here to commemorate the occasion until today to coincide with the return of Angola's president, Jose Eduardo dos Santos. **********But people began lining the main avenues of this war-ravaged port city Friday evening, and by midnight the streets were crowded with revelers shouting "We've got peace! We've got bread!" -- an expression of hope that with the end of war will again come prosperity. Angola is one of the most richly endowed countries in Africa, but its economy has been devastated. **********"I've been waiting all my life for this," said Dolce Henriques, a 23-year-old student as she danced around Kinaxixe Park. "Look at this," she said, pointing at the crowd, "this is what peace is about. We're free." **********Bursts of automatic weapons fire could also be heard throughout the night. Firing weapons is a risky practice that often punctuates festivals here and a reminder that much of the civilian population is heavily armed. **********"This is probably one of the most armed countries on earth," said Susan Hurlich, an American anthropologist doing research here. A Western relief worker added, "Nobody is really going to feel safe here until they get rid of the guns -- and there's nothing in the cease-fire about that." **********The peace agreement came after more than a year of arduous negotiations in which Portugal, which was Angola's colonial master, and the United States and the Soviet Union, which backed the opposing factions, played a key role in encouraging the two sides to end a war that has taken 300,000 lives and produced no winners. **********Later this month, a United Nations force of 600 men is expected to arrive here to monitor the cease-fire. At the same time, a joint political and military commission will form a single 40,000-member army and prepare for internationally supervised elections in the second half of 1992. **********A de facto cease-fire has been in effect since May 15, and the two sides have largely complied with it, African and Western diplomats said today. Scattered and inexplicable incidents of violence have continued, however. **********Last Wednesday, a bomb exploded in the main market in Huambo, a provincial capital in the central highlands, killing 8 and wounding 20. The next day on Huambo's outskirts, a truck carrying civilians hit a land mine, killing 17 and wounding 30. **********The last full-blown fighting between the two sides took place in the eastern city of Luena in early May, Western relief officials said, when the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, besieged the area and the Government sent reinforcements in an effort to oust the rebels. The Angolan news service has also reported rebel incursions in Bia, Huambo and Kwanza Sul provinces in the west, but most of the incidents occurred before May 15. **********The celebrations here were notable not only for their high spirits, but also for the virtual absence of any visible Unita presence. A senior Unita delegation is expected to arrive here later today, Government officials said, but the rebels are not likely to take part in any of the commemorative events in this capital of 1.3 million. **********In Washington, a spokesman for Unita said the rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, would make his first trip to the capital in at least 15 years, sometime in July. For most of the bloody civil war, rebel forces have been headquartered in Jamba, a town in the southeast. **********Also conspicuous by their absence are the Cuban forces, at one point numbering 50,000. The Cuban Government hurriedly withdrew its remaining forces a week ago, a month before their scheduled departure, saying they had accomplished their mission.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Gambling Curbs On Money Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Gambling Curbs On Money Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.body_text: **********MONEY market funds are not supposed to be gambling devices. Yesterday, the Securities and Exchange Commission took steps to restrict the ability of fund managers to gamble in two different ways -- making risky loans or taking interest-rate risks by investing for long periods. The result may be to reduce slightly the yields available on money market funds, which compete with bank accounts for investor money, and have cultivated an image of safety. So important is that image that the fund industry generally backed the changes with enthusiasm. **********One step taken by the S.E.C. has not been widely publicized, and it is likely to affect the way some funds are run. Those funds, seeking to get as high a yield as possible, have invested in securities that do not mature for relatively long periods of time. **********In periods of falling interest rates, funds with longer maturities have been able to advertise higher yields. But now the S.E.C., which had allowed an average maturity of up to 120 days in money market funds, will restrict that to 90 days. **********Several funds now have average maturities longer than 90 days, and will have to cut back. They should have no trouble doing so because the new rule will take effect 90 days after it is published in the Federal Register, giving them ample time to roll over investments into shorter maturities. A list of money market funds, with their yields and average maturities, appears on page D9. **********The other change, which has received much more publicity, will restrict the amount of risky corporate loans -- known as low-rated commercialpaper -- that a fund can have in its portfolio. Under the new rules, a money market fund may invest no more than 5 percent of its assets in commercial paper that is not top-rated. **********The principal rating services are Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's and Duff & Phelps, and paper will be deemed to be top-rated if rated that way by two of the agencies, or, if only one rates the paper, by that agency. Previously, there had been no limit to such investments. **********In addition, investments in the paper of any one issuer will be limited to 5 percent of a fund's assets, if that issuer is top-rated, and to 1 percent otherwise. The old limit there had been 25 percent. Investments in United States Government securities are not restricted, and funds may continue to hold as much of those securities as they like. **********Marianne Smythe, the director of the S.E.C.'s division of investment management, said she understood that there were "very, very few funds" whose investments in paper that is not top-rated exceeds the new limits. She said the average money market fund now had about one-half percent of its assets in such securities, down from 10 to 15 percent in 1988. **********"Now, the ceiling allows substantial room for growth" in holdings of such assets, she said. **********Most of the rapid decline in such holdings was not caused by the pending S.E.C. rule. Instead, there was a general increase in credit quality concerns, spurred by commercial paper defaults by<biIntegrated Resources in 1989 and by Mortgage and Realty Trust last year. In each case, some money market funds held the commercial paper and would have suffered losses. But the sponsors of the funds, fearful of the bad publicity that would ensue from such an event, stepped in and took the losses themselves. **********Money market funds are a select group of mutual funds, subject to different rules from other funds. The S.E.C. chairman, Richard C. Breeden, emphasized that the change does not affect other mutual funds, which he noted were free to invest all their assets in risky securities, whether in long-term "junk bonds" or in low-rated commercial paper. **********One big difference in rules is that money market funds are not required to record their assets at market value every night, as are other funds, so long as the asset is expected to be redeemed on schedule at full value. A fund that buys a six-month Treasury bill, as many do, could see its value rise or fall based on daily interest-rate movements. If funds are "marked to market," they would show those gains or losses, leaving the possibility of capital losses for some investors, something that funds wish to avoid. **********Money market funds have become a significant investment vehicle for millions of Americans. The Investment Company Institute, a trade group, said taxable money market funds now had about $455 billion in assets, with more than 20 million accounts. Including tax-exempt funds, which buy short-term municipal securities, total assets are about $530 billion. **********Investors in tax-exempt money funds will not have the same assurance of high quality. While the S.E.C.'s rules on investment maturities will apply, those limiting concentrations of assets, and limiting investments in low-rated securities, will not.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.main_headline: Shell Oil Plans to Sell Its Alaskan Properties
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Shell Oil Plans to Sell Its Alaskan Properties
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/busin.body_text: **********The Shell Oil Company said today that it planned to sell its oil and gas properties in Alaska as part of an effort to shed high-cost production operations in the United States. **********The company also said it had halted drilling in the deep waters of the Chukchi Sea about 80 miles west of Barrow, Alaska, and near waters controlled by the Soviet Union. Shell drilled four wells in the area during each of the last three summers but has not disclosed any of its findings. **********Shell Oil, a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, has been hurt by losses in its domestic refining business and by depressed natural-gas prices. The company announced layoffs last July, and earlier had put a refinery and oil and gas properties in California up for sale. **********Unlike the other oil producers in Alaska -- ARCO, British Petroleum and Exxon -- Shell Oil has comparatively small holdings in the state. Current daily production averages 7,500 barrels of oil and 23.1 million cubic feet of natural gas. **********Many oil geologists say the Chukchi fields may hold three billion barrels of oil, which would make the area one of the largest discoveries in North America in 25 years. Shell Oil has the biggest drilling rights in the fields. **********A Shell spokesman, Holly R. Hutchins, said the company would "continue to be a very major presence in Alaska on the exploration side of the business." The company has seven years remaining on leases acquired in the Chukchi Sea in 1988. Mr. Hutchins declined to say whether Shell would resume its drilling in the Chukchi region next summer. **********The Chevron Corporation began drilling its first well in the Chukchi Sea on Sept. 7, using a vessel and workers released by Shell in August.
