https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/25/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; Network's Last Patriarch Offers a Survival Strategy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/25/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; Network's Last Patriarch Offers a Survival Strategy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/25/busin.body_text: **********LEONARD H. GOLDENSON, who is 85 years old, believes he knows television business: The ideas are not fresh enough, the programming is not risky enough and the executives are not young enough. **********In many respects, he said, the problems that the networks face today are not much different from those he faced in 1953 when he took control of a puny little network - five stations and eight affiliates - called the American Broadcasting Company. **********With the death of William S. Paley of CBS last year, Mr. Goldenson is the last of the television patriarchs. He was always the least well known, partly because the ascension of ABC followed so long after David Sarnoff's founding of NBC and Mr. Paley's master-building of CBS. **********But Mr. Goldenson also sought to avoid a high profile - mostly, he said, out of concern that he would bore people. "Anybody more deadly than a television executive, I haven't found yet," he said. **********For that reason, Mr. Goldenson has augmented his autobiography, "Beating the Odds," written with Marvin J. Wolf and published last week by Charles Scribner's Sons, with comments by more than 100 associates at ABC. The idea was to provide more than a single point of view on the rise of Mr. Goldenson's network, and also, he said, "to get away from the ego trip approach that Paley and Sarnoff had in their books." **********Most of the characters in ABC's story are present and former employees, including many of the most powerful executives in the entertainment industry: Michael Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company; Barry Diller, the chairman of 20th Century Fox; Brandon Tartikoff, the chairman of NBC Entertainment; Marcy Carsey and Tom Werner, the producers of some of television's most successful comedies, and ABC's own news president, Roone Arledge. **********Despite their similar roles, Mr. Goldenson said he had little interaction with Mr. Paley. He said he had a sense that "CBS and NBC looked down their noses at us." **********Mr. Goldenson said Mr. Paley was upset when ABC built a headquarters in Manhattan that was just one block from CBS's framed "Black Rock" building. "So I arranged to have an ABC logo put up on top of the building facing directly at CBS," he said. "And at night it was illuminated. **********Mr. Goldenson said his real revenge on CBS and NBC was the development of a revolutionary programming strategy. In the mid-1950's, when ABC found it could hardly compete with the entrenched strength of the other two networks, researchers from Columbia University devised an approach that came to define ABC - and redefine the business of television advertising. Mr. Goldenson described the strategy: **********"They came to us and said: 'What you've got to do is go after the young families of America; they're more apt to change and flip the dial than older people. Basically, they are the purchasing power of America.' **********"At that time, advertisers were not buying television on that bases. We brought that idea to the advertisers. We had to convince them that these people had the buying power." **********He added: "The idea sold. Surprisingly, CBS and NBC didn't respond to that until a number of years later. That was open sesame. They left the door open for us." **********Mr. Goldenston said the strategy for survival in what has become an even more competitive television environment ought to be exactly the same. "I wouldn't deviate from the strategy," he said. He did acknowledge, however, that Fox Broadcasting, under Mr. Diller, an ABC alumnus, was doing the same thing to get established that ABC did 40 years ago. "Barry's going for the offbeat, just as we did," he said. "The Simpsons' is what 'Batman' was for us." **********Even with cable channels taking away large segments of the audience and with the population getting older, Mr. Goldenson said that aiming shows at younger viewers remained the way for a network to succeed. "The population may be getting older, but the purchasing power is still people aged 18 to 49," he said. "The older people, even though they have the money, obviously don't want to spend it. And we're only after the ones that want to spend their money." **********As for cable, Mr. Goldenson said he recognized how powerful a competitor it had become and, in fact, steered ABC's own investments in three cable channels, Arts & Entertainment, Lifetime and ESPN. **********Mr. Goldenson argues that even with the diminshed reached of the networks - down from a high of about 92 percent of the nation's homes to what he expects will be about 58 to 60 percent by the time the decline levels off - they will remain a powerful force. **********"By the year 2000, we will pass 100 million homes with television," he said. "Sixty percent of that is still a fantastic audience." **********Mr. Goldenson's gave up most of his active role as chairman of the company in 1986 when he agreed to sell the company to Capital Cities Communications. He is still the chairman of the company's executive committee. He also watches all the pilots of the network's new programs, making recommendations about his favorites - and his non-favorites. **********"I didn't car for 'Twin Peaks' too much," he said. "It was a cult show; I thought it never had a chance."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad Scene; Agencies Hope Books Help Their Images
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad Scene; Agencies Hope Books Help Their Images
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/busin.body_text: **********FROM the time he began drawing cartoons as a teen-ager, John Emmerling wondered how the mind and body conspired to make ideas a reality. Later, running his own advertising agency, he thought he could help other business executives harness their own creativity. So he wrote a book, "It Only Takes One: How to Create the Right Idea and Then Make It Happen," which Simon & Schuster will publish later this month. **********But Mr. Emmerling acknowledges that more than altruism stoked his literary fires. "Early on," he said, "I realized, son of a gun, ad guy writes a book, pretty good for the ad guy's business." **********Inside every copywriter, it has long been said, is an author screaming to get out. But talk to the ad men and women who have written books and you will find that the screams are not from frustration, but for attention. Books are one of the advertising industry's most potent marketing tools. **********Today, Prentice Hall is scheduled to release "The Day America Told the Truth," a survey of American attitudes toward sex, morality, work and religion, written by James Patterson and Peter Kim, two senior executives at J. Walter Thompson. **********And Young & Rubicam is currently circulating "The One Place," a critical investigation by the agency of American education, which St. Martin's Press will publish in the fall. **********Like the book by Mr. Emmerling, the chief executive of John Emmerling Inc., these works appear unrelated to advertising. In fact, they are advertising's way of advertising itself. **********"A book gives an agency credibility," said Hank Seiden, the chairman of Ketchum Advertising/New York, who wrote "Advertising Pure and Simple" in 1976. "If you're in the process of soliciting business, it's wonderful. It's something the other agencies you're pitching against don't have." **********A book's effect on an advertising agency or executive can be monumental. When Jerry Della Femina wrote "From Those Wonderful Folks Who Gave You Pearl Harbor: Front-Line Dispatches From the Advertising War" in 1970, his agency, Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, was three years old and struggling to survive. He recalled that the week the book was published, the Schieffelin & Somerset liquor company got in touch with him. **********"They had read the book, and signed us as their agency," Mr. Della Femina said. "If it hadn't been for the book, I doubt this agency would be here. We're talking jobs, careers and fortunes made from the book." **********Agency executives believe that books can show off their knowledge and skills, even if the tomes are about something else. **********"The Day America Told the Truth," for example, is a collection of titillating revelations, drawn from proprietary survey research, about how Americans supposedly lead their lives. Among its conclusions: women are morally superior to men and "lying has become an integral part of the American culture." **********Mr. Patterson, the chairman of J. Walter Thompson North America, conceded that the book could tell advertisers as much about the agency as about the nation. "I hope it makes clients and potential clients question the research they're currently getting," he said. "To me, it just builds an argument for much deeper research in the product categories we're involved in." **********The Young & Rubicam book, to which the agency assigned a team of researchers, also has an advertising spinoff, even though its subject, the problems of the American educational system, seems far removed from marketing. The Y.&R. team recommended that schools should be open all day throughout the year, that schooling should begin for all children by the age of 2 1/2, and that teachers should receive more training in child development. **********Alex Kroll, the agency's chief executive, wrote in the book's introduction that Y.&R. reached these conclusions by acting "as if the education establishment in this country had approached us like a paying client in trouble." It interviewed experts, analyzed data, talked with children and visited schools. **********"One of our company's basic fundamental skills and reasons for being is understanding people and how they learn," Mr. Kroll said. "I don't know if anybody reading the book would say, 'Here's an agency that knows these things,' but it is a demonstration of it." **********To make sure the demonstration has an audience, both Y.&R. and J. Walter Thompson are sending copies of their books to clients. Mr. Emmerling, whose agency specializes in trade advertising for magazines, is using his book more directly, to prospect for new clients. **********"I've already done four presentations, including one in Toronto to 400 marketing people," he said. "I expect I'll get more lecture invitations, but I will be judicious about it. If it's a marketing company or someone with an ad budget, I'll be delighted to meet with them. A group of dentists meeting in Tucson, I'll take a pass." **********Books by advertising people can be a liability. Perhaps the most famous ad book ever written, "Confessions of an Advertising Man" by David Ogilvy, helped put Ogilvy & Mather on Madison Avenue's road atlas. But it has also proved something of a burden to the agency, said Graham Phillips, Ogilvy's chief executive. **********"When we break our own rules, clients remind us, 'This wasn't in David's book,' " he said. "They'll say, 'It says on page 6 not to use reverse type. So why are you using reverse type in this ad for us?' "

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/busin.print_headline: ...And of the Principles of Free Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/06/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor:  It is curious that Bill Totten's book on Japanese-American relations is published only in Japanese. If he has some light to shed, why doesn't he publish it in English? **********Maybe it is because he has subscribed to Japanese opinions for so long that he cannot see what is at the heart of the trade issue -- fairness. Let us remember what the son of the chairman of Sony once said, as quoted in a recent issue of Playboy: "My father's generation knew they were playing by different rules from the West when it came to trade, but they pretended they didn't understand the rules. That's why they won." **********Take the perennial example of Metglas, an extremely efficient electrical conductor, that has a $2.5 billion market. An American company spent 15 years developing the product. The Japanese patent office leaked information on the production process while waiting 12 years before awarding a patent to the American company. Simultaneously, the Japanese Government funded a five-year, $12 billion drive to develop its own version of Metglas. The original Japanese Metglas patent awarded to the American company will expire in 1993 -- after just three years -- because the clock started running when the patent was filed. **********To Mr. Totten's credit, even Peter Drucker argues that the trade imbalance with Japan is illusionary. However, the numbers are one thing and the Japanese way of doing business -- using their own definition of free trade -- is another. DAVID MEYERSON  San Francisco, Dec. 23

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Tape of 'Home Alone' Lacks Star in Pepsi Spot
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/15/busin.body_text: **********Fans of Macaulay Culkin who were hoping to see the young star do double duty on the videocassette of his hit film, "Home Alone," will have to content themselves with watching just the movie. Plans for him to appear in a commercial for Pepsi-Cola, to be placed on the tape ahead of the film, have fallen through. **********Pepsi and its advertising agency, BBDO New York, ran into scheduling conflicts that kept the spot from being filmed in time for the videotape release next Thursday, said Andrew Giangola, a Pepsi spokesman. Instead, the eight million copies of the tape, to be released by Fox Video, will carry a Pepsi spot called "Cool Kids" that was previously shown on television. Pepsi has been a pioneer in videotape advertising, creating special spots for the home release of films like "Top Gun." **********Pepsi is pegging an extensive and expensive promotional campaign to the video release of "Home Alone," which in its theatrical release became the third-ranking film ever in gross revenues. Consumers will be offered $5 off the $24.98 retail price of the tape through a mail-in rebate with a Pepsi purchase. And a Pepsi "Home Alone" sweepstakes will feature prizes including 115,000 copies of the tape.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.main_headline: Too Many A's Seen at A. M. Best
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.print_headline: Too Many A's Seen at A. M. Best
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.body_text: **********A. M. Best, the 92-year-old company on which thousands of American corporations and consumers depend for evaluations of the financial health of insurance companies, is being accused of grade inflation. A new study concludes that it is significantly easier for insurance companies to win a top rating from Best than from two other major raters of insurance companies -- Standard & Poor's and Moody's. **********The study was conducted by Joseph Belth, an Indiana University professor who is an expert on the insurance industry. He published his findings in the December 1990 issue of his Insurance Forum newsletter. The study comes at a time when the number of insurance-company failures is rising and public concern about the solvency of insurers is increasing. **********Professor Belth says that Best's apparent easing of requirements has caused some customers who buy its books, newsletters and other publications to lose faith in the rating agency. Some people in the industry agree.  Charges by Critics **********"The Moody's and Standard & Poor's process is much more rigorous and the results are more meaningful than Best's," said Peter Hutchings, chief financial officer of the Guardian Life Insurance Company, based in New York. **********The real issue, people familiar with the situation say, is whether Best has loosened its requirements in response to increasing competitive pressures from S.& P., Moody's and a few smaller firms like Duff & Phelps. **********Some critics have argued privately that to hold on to the thousands of insurance companies across the country that pay in some cases tens of thousands of dollars to buy its publications, Best has eased the requirements A+ companies must meet. **********Best vigorously denies this accusation. "Totally untrue," said Paul Wish, the spokesman for the A. M. Best Company, based in Oldwick, N.J. "The ratings in the books have nothing to do with the sale of the books." **********Mr. Wish, defending Best's rating system, said: "The major difference between us and them is that we take the long-term view. We look at an insurance company's long-term prospects, whereas Moody's and Standard & Poor's are more attuned to day-to-day changes in market conditions." **********An agency's rating is crucial to insurers because independent agents who sell life insurance steer customers to higher-rated companies. Some industry experts say that lower-rated insurers have to offer higher yields to attract consumers. A rating reduction can also force an insurance company to pay more interest when it borrows in the capital markets. **********And when many large corporations consider an insurance company, they want it to have top ratings from at least two major rating agencies.  Striking Differences in Ratings **********Professor Belth studied 100 life insurers rated by both the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Best. Of that group, 33 received Best's top A+ rating but were rated lower by S.& P. Over all, 53 of the 100 compared were rated higher by Best than by S.& P.; 36 were rated the same, and 11 were rated lower by Best. **********The study also found 62 life insurers rated by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and Best. Of that group, 34 were rated A+ by Best but received lower ratings from Moody's. Over all, 43 of the 62 fared better under the Best system than under the Moody's system; 16 were rated the same by both agencies, and 3 got a lower rating from Best. **********Some of the differences between Best's ratings and the other agencies' were striking. For instance, Best gave the Executive Life Insurance Company of Los Angeles a rating of "contingent A," meaning it has the third-highest rating but is under review. The same insurer was rated 12 notches from the top by Moody's (a Ba2 rating) and by S.& P. (a BB rating). Executive Life's parent, the First Executive Corporation, has suffered hundreds of millions of dollars in losses on its portfolio of high-yield "junk bonds," and many customers have cashed in their policies. **********"What all this suggests to me is that the Best system is significantly looser than that of the competition," Professor Belth said. "I am not saying that Best is selling out. I have no evidence of that. What I am saying is that it is easier to get a top rating from Best." **********Best said recently that its rating system essentially paralleled that of S.& P. and Moody's, meaning that a top rating from Best was equivalent to a top rating from S.& P. or Moody's, and so forth.  Differing Criteria **********Other factors may explain how Best ends up with higher ratings. The S.& P. and Moody's ratings are based on a fairly narrow criterion -- the ability of an insurer to pay claims. Best says it bases its ratings on the ability of an insurance company to meet all financial obligations. **********"The mechanics for rating are the same, but the underlying philosophy is different," said Mr. Wish, the Best spokesman. **********Whatever the reason for Best's higher ratings, there is little disputing that Best, while still important in the insurance business, has seen its influence wane in recent years. **********"While a decade ago most of the big brokers did not spend much time with it, today they have full-time research departments that get to know the insurers well," said Richard Heydinger, the senior insurance executive at Hallmark Cards Inc. in Kansas City, Mo. A Near Monopoly Until 1983 **********Nor is there much disputing that Best, which is privately held, has been facing new competition. For decades the company held a near monopoly on the business of rating insurers. Wall Street analysts published reports on publicly held insurance companies, but it was not until 1983 that S.& P. got into the business. Moody's started in 1986. Both companies still have much smaller operations than Best's but their influence has been rising as policyholders have grown concerned about the ability of insurers to pay claims. **********Recognizing that the risks insurers face have been changing along with the investments insurers make with their income from premiums, many industrial companies now subscribe to more than one rating agency. **********Moody's, S.& P. and Duff & Phelps tend to focus more than Best on an insurer's financial results. This emphasis reflects their background as bond-rating agencies. By contrast, Best, in making its rating, tends to look beyond the numbers at aspects of the overall quality of an organization, like experience of management, modernization of the back office and the speed of payment of claims. **********"Some people are saying that in a much more complex world, Best may no longer be as adequate as it used to be," said Richard Hackenberg, an executive vice president in Boston for Caroon & Black, the big insurance brokerage firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/world.print_headline: THE SOVIET CRISIS; Yeltsin's Remarks: A 'Reactionary Coup'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/20/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from remarks made in Moscow today by Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian federated republic, as translated by the State Department: **********I am reading. **********Citizens of Russia: On the night of 18-19 August 1991, the legally elected President of the country was removed from power. **********Regardless of the reasons given for his removal, we are dealing with a rightist, reactionary, anti-constitutional coup. Despite all the difficulties and severe trials being experienced by the people, the democratic process in the country is acquiring an increasingly broad sweep and an irreversible character. **********The peoples of Russia are becoming masters of their destiny. The uncontrolled powers of unconstitutional organs have been considerably limited, and this includes party organs. **********The leadership of Russia has adopted a resolute position toward the union treaty striving for the unity of the Soviet Union and unity of Russia. Our position on this issue permitted a considerable acceleration of the preparation of this treaty, to coordinate it with all the republics and to determine the date of signing as Aug 20. Tomorrow's signing has been cancelled. **********These developments gave rise to angry reactionary forces, pushed them to irresponsible and adventurist attempts to solve the most complicated political and economic problems by methods of force. Attempts to realize a coup have been tried earlier. Citizens' Rebuff Urged **********We considered and consider that such methods of force are unacceptable. They discredit the union in the eyes of the whole world, undermine our prestige in the world community, and return us to the cold-war era along with the Soviet Union's isolation in the world community. All of this forces us to proclaim that the so-called committee's ascendancy to power is unlawful. **********Accordingly we proclaim all decisions and instructions of this committee to be unlawful. **********We are confident that the organs of local power will unswervingly adhere to constitutional laws and decrees of the President of Russia. **********We appeal to citizens of Russia to give a fitting rebuff to the putschists and demand a return of the country to normal constitutional development. **********Undoubtedly it is essential to give the country's President, Gorbachev, an opportunity to address the people. Today he has been blockaded. I have been denied communications with him. We demand an immediate convocation of an extraordinary Congress of People's Deputies of the Union. We are absolutely confident that our countrymen will not permit the sanctioning of the tyranny and lawlessness of the putschists, who have lost all shame and conscience. We address an appeal to servicemen to manifest lofty civic duty and not take part in the reactionary coup. **********Until these demands are met, we appeal for a universal unlimited strike.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; Keeping Banks at Bay
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/busin.body_text: **********ON Matthew P. Fink's office credenza sits a framed photograph of President Roosevelt signing the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, the law that restricts commercial banks from entering the securities business, and more precisely, from Mr. Fink's point of view, from peddling their own mutual funds. **********The photo has had particular relevance lately for Mr. Fink, who recently became president of the powerful Investment Company Institute, the only trade group in Washington that represents mutual funds. **********Mr. Fink has spent most of the past few months successfully insuring that Congressional consideration of a banking bill would not erode what he considers are the safeguards that restrict banks from underwriting mutual funds. At the same time, he has been trying to influence a long-awaited comprehensive study by the Securities and Exchange Commission that is supposed to include significant recommendations to modernize the Investment Company Act of 1940, the highly detailed regulatory framework that governs every aspect of the mutual fund business. **********"We've had no major scandal since the act was passed," Mr. Fink said last week. "I'm committed to that by improving the regulatory structure." **********Mr. Fink's group also represents investment advisers. And here, scandal has struck as a result of the recent fraud charges brought against Institutional Treasury Management Inc., a California-based money manager. The advisers are expected to face increased supervision and regulatory fees in the wake of that case. **********When Mr. Fink, now 50, arrived at the institute 20 years ago, it had a few dozen staffers and represented 392 funds with assets of just $55 billion. The institute has grown -- now 114 staffers represent 3,500 funds with assets exceeding $1.3 trillion -- and Mr. Fink has risen with it, serving as a junior lawyer, lobbyist and then general counsel for 14 years before becoming president in October. "I've been the chief cook and bottle washer here," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/13/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Hollywood P.R. Figure Leaving
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/13/busin.body_text: **********Henry Rogers, one of the doyens of Hollywood public relations, who is credited with making Rita Hayworth a star, is leaving the profession after 56 years. **********Mr. Rogers, 77 years old, said yesterday that his contract with Rogers & Cowan, which he founded in 1950, had expired and that he "has had enough." The agency was sold in 1987 to Shandwick P.L.C. with a four- year employment agreement for Mr. Rogers and the firm's other principals. **********Mr. Rogers started out as one of the first independent public relations agents, working outside the movie studios. He made the transition from personal representative to the stars to today's high-powered world of corporate public relations, with his clients including Sylvester Stallone, A.T.& T. and the Ford Motor Company. **********Many of the movie industry's leading public relations agencies, like PMK and Andrea Jaffe & Associates, were established by people who worked for Mr. Rogers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/busin.main_headline: Sony, Nintendo's Partner, Will Be a Rival, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/busin.print_headline: Sony, Nintendo's Partner, Will Be a Rival, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/busin.body_text: **********The video-game industry has apparently become too big for the world's largest consumer electronics companies to ignore. The Sony Corporation said yesterday that it planned to enter the game market with a machine based on the latest Nintendo technology. **********Sony's system will not only play Nintendo game cartridges but also games on compact disks. **********The Sony machine, developed with Nintendo, will be introduced in Japan before the end of the year and in the United States next year. Sony's announcement stole some of the thunder from Nintendo's scheduled introduction today of its new, more powerful game system. **********Sony's interest underscores the growing importance of the $4.7 billion game market to the consumer electronics industry. **********"It is a very significant step," said Robert F. Kleiber, an analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. With compact disk technology and increasingly powerful computer chips, video games are becoming far more sophisticated. "I don't want to call them video games anymore," said Mr. Kleiber, who prefers the description "dedicated entertainment hardware." **********The Sony machine, called the Play Station, is expected to cost about $400, about twice as much as the new Nintendo machine, although no final pricing decision has been made. **********The Sony machine adds a compact disk player to the new Nintendo system. Because the Play Station incorporates Nintendo's new machine, Sony is making the machines under license from Nintendo. Sony has supplied computer chips to Nintendo for several years. **********While Sony and Nintendo have collaborated on the machine, Sony will clearly become a competitor of Nintendo. Under the arrangement, Nintendo could introduce its own machines incorporating compact disk players.  1988 Deal Is Disclosed **********Sony confirmed yesterday that it had retained all licensing rights for any compact disk game developed for the new system. The deal was negotiated in 1988 but had not been publicly disclosed. Typically, Nintendo has received licensing fees for any games that can be played on its machines. **********"I heard they gave the store away," Mr. Kleiber said. Apparently, when the deal was signed in 1988, Nintendo underestimated the impact of compact disks on the market. **********"By that oversight, Sony ended up with a very important business advantage," said Lawrence F. Probst, president and chief executive of Electronic Arts, a video and computer game software publisher. **********The timing of the announcement was curious, since it followed news reports yesterday that Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and Nintendo were considering collaborating on a compact disk-based game machine. Philips and Nintendo declined to provide any information on their plans. Industry executives speculated that Nintendo was looking to Philips to enter into a more favorable licensing agreement on compact disk games. **********Analysts said Nintendo risked confusing consumers by signing alliances with two hardware makers. A game designed for a Sony machine could not be played on a Philips machine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Continental Bank's New York Cutback
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/09/busin.body_text: **********Continental Bank N.A. will close its New York securities sales office this month as part of a consolidation, a spokeswoman said. Ellen Barry, said four fixed-income salesmen in New York were offered jobs in Chicago, where the bank has its headquarters. Closing the New York office will "certainly reduce overhead" and should not "affect the bank's ability to service its large East Coast institutional customers," Ms. Barry said. **********One Continental employee said that the bank's primary dealership and trading operations were profitable but that the bank's overall earnings "were still under pressure." The spokeswoman said the consolidation was not related to profitability. She said Continental, whose parent is the Continental Bank Corporation, had closed its Paris office in the last year and moved the staff to London.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/16/world.main_headline: For Soviet Foreign Minister, a Shrinking Portfolio
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/16/world.print_headline: For Soviet Foreign Minister, a Shrinking Portfolio
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/16/world.body_text: **********Reporting on plans to merge his Ministry of Foreign Affairs with that of Foreign Trade into a pared-down new Ministry of External Relations, Boris D. Pankin uttered what might well be the slogan of these confusing times. **********"We've agreed on the basic scheme," he said, "but in practice it still has to be worked out." **********The Foreign Minister gave the interview Thursday shortly before he set off for the meeting of the State Council, the interim collective executive, at which President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and leaders of seven republics agreed to work toward a loose new "Union of Sovereign States," with the republics deciding what powers to delegate central authorities. **********The State Council also confirmed the plan for a new Ministry of External Relations responsible for foreign policy and foreign economic relations, coordinated by a council of republican foreign ministers.  Authority in Flux **********That was the basic plan, at any rate. **********But like many other officials unexpectedly catapulted into a senior office by the coup, Mr. Pankin has discovered that a major part of his new job is trying to figure out what that job is and struggling to keep it from being swallowed by the republics, especially by the increasingly aggressive Russian republic. **********While Mr. Pankin was in Madrid acting as co-chairman of the Middle East peace conference late last month, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia suddenly announced that the Foreign Ministry should be cut by 90 percent, sending shock waves among the 12,700 staffers and diplomats. **********"The proposal to cut the Ministry by 90 percent was a metaphor, like telling someone 'I haven't seen you in a thousand years'," Mr. Pankin insisted. The current plan, he said, was to cut the total staff of the two ministries by half, and to reduce foreign missions sharply. **********"In essence, the decision was that our country needs a single foreign policy worked out by the Union of Sovereign Republics and enacted in their name and with the participation of the sovereign republics," he said. The responsibilities of the Ministry would include issues of disarmament, compliance with international agreements and treaties, representation at the United Nations and other international forums and bilateral relations.  Powers of Republics **********"All else remains with the republics," he said, listing economic, cultural, scientific and humanitarian relations and regional issues. **********Whether this division of responsibility will hold up, and how much control the republics will maintain over the center, and what republics will opt to participate at all, are all questions yet to be answered. **********According to an article in Thursday's issue of the newspaper Izvestia, the battle over the Foreign Ministry is not yet over. The paper quoted the foreign minister of the Russian republic, Andrei Kozyrev, criticizing "the men in the 'wedding cake' " -- those at the all-Union Foreign Ministry -- for failing so far "to draw lessons from the current developments." **********Mr. Kozyrev has been one of the sharpest critics of the central ministry, and in the Izvestia article he outlined the transfer of far more functions to republican foreign ministries than Mr. Pankin did. Among other things, he said the republics should take aver all regional departments of the central ministry, those sections directly in charge of relations with foreign countries. **********Izvestia said further that republics were demanding that ambassadors be appointed by the council of foreign ministers, and be responsible to the republic leaders. That would effectively strip bilateral relations away from the central ministry and leave it largely with the role of coordinating the actions of the republics. **********Mr. Pankin, however, did not seem ready to let his ministry be dissected without a fight. While he agreed that deep cuts were necessary and inevitable, he also argued that a concerted foreign policy was essential. **********The cost of administering Soviet foreign affairs, he said, was a fraction of what the United States or West European governments spent. The total expenditure in foreign currency, he said, was $150 million to $200 million, compared with $3.5 billion in the United States. **********Mr. Pankin also argued against any suggestion that he has not done enough. His three months in office, he said, had seen a major human rights conference in Moscow, a joint statement with the United States on Afghanistan, new agreements with the East European states, revival of relations with Israel and the opening of a conference on the Middle East, and new openings to South Africa.  Collapse of Hard-Liners **********All these were made possible by the collapse of forces that used to resist any movement toward a new foreign policy -- the old Ministries of Defense and Internal Affairs, the K.G.B. and the military-industrial complex. **********The minister talked in a reception room of the gloomy, neo-Gothic "wedding cake" Foreign Ministry building on Smolensk Square into which he was thrust after the August coup in large part because of his alacrity in condemning the putsch from his post as ambassador to Prague. His predecessor at the Ministry, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, was dismissed for the opposite reason -- for being too slow to say anything about the putsch. **********But in the current situation, Mr. Pankin said, even Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin were learning that taking responsibility did not win applause. **********"I'm in the same position at my level," he said. "It's hard to expect that people will applaud if we restore diplomatic relations with Israel, or talk to the Afghan mujahedeen now in Moscow. To me it is most important to follow my image of what is right, what is good for the country and the nation. For now that works. **********"If the country falls apart into 12 different states and doesn't need a Foreign Ministry, then it won't need a Minister, either. In the meantime, our line has been accepted and approved, also by Yeltsin. So I don't see any reason to desert."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/busin.main_headline: World Markets; Can a Rebound Turn Into a Rally?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/busin.print_headline: World Markets; Can a Rebound Turn Into a Rally?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/busin.body_text: **********In recent years, investors in the United States have increasingly been advised to diversify their portfolios by buying stocks overseas. But Americans who invested abroad at the beginning of 1991 probably are finding it would have been better to keep the money at home. **********Most of the bad news for overseas investors occurred very late in the year, although some stock markets seemed to be bouncing off the bottom last week, in the wake of a rally on Wall Street. **********In London, the Financial Times index of 100 leading stocks rose 71.4 points, or 3 percent, on Thursday and Friday. And in Tokyo, where the Nikkei index of 225 leading stocks closed just points above its 1991 low on Wednesday, the index climbed 1,042.33 points, or 4.8 percent, on Friday. Stock markets also rallied in Norway, where the market hit three-year lows at the beginning of the month, and even in Germany, which has been stubbornly sluggish most of the year. **********Looking back, the undoing of the Soviet Union has sent ripples though stock markets all year. The Persian Gulf War turned out to be a help, pulling markets out of the slide that began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. **********But the expectations for a moderate economic recovery in the United States turned out to be overly optimistic. The disappointing American growth, in turn, seemed to heighten the worry about the faster-than-expected slowdowns in economies abroad. And though stock markets generally do not slavishly follow Wall Street's lead, it seems they are waiting for a signal from that source now. **********According to the Financial Times world index, European markets as a whole are up just 4.1 percent in dollar terms since the beginning of the year. Japan is up only 5.9 percent, even with Friday's surge. **********Investors who decided a year ago to keep their money at home seem smart now, with the American market up 17.5 percent in the world index. **********The only markets really revving up have been outliers, like Mexico, which is up 109.5 percent; Hong Kong, up 40.4 percent; South Africa, up 36.0 percent; Singapore, up 29.4 percent, and Australia, up 25.6 percent. They have been propelled by factors distinct to their own economies, and some have been good choices for American investors because their currencies are tied directly to the dollar, so they were not hurt by fluctuations in that currency. **********Investing overseas looked a lot easier earlier in the year, even though the dollar was stronger and world markets suffered a sharp downturn in January as the deadline for the Persian Gulf War approached. In the first 16 days of the year, European markets fell 6.7 percent, on top of a decline of more than 18 percent between Aug. 2, 1990, the day of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and the end of last year, according to the Financial Times index. **********But by early March, the euphoria over the success of the Allied effort in the Persian Gulf had helped to push the Financial Times index of European markets up 12.6 percent in dollar terms, the high for the year. In September, the European markets hit their 1991 high in local currencies: a gain of 20.6 percent through Sept. 2. **********Japan's market reached its high point in dollar terms in February, up 17.8 percent, and in local terms, up 17.1 percent, in March. **********As a whole, the Financial Times's index of world markets is up 10.4 percent in dollar terms so far this year. But that is just two thirds of what the gain was when the index reached its high for the year just over a month ago, right before the American market took its big tumble on Nov. 15. **********The lost gains seem even more dramatic in terms of local stock market indexes, which are in the home currency and have a different blend of stocks than the Financial Times index. By this measure all the stock markets in the Group of Seven are below their highs by about 50 percent or more -- except in the United States. **********In Germany, the Dax index of 30 leading shares is up 11.5 percent for the year, after rallying to a 23 percent gain at its high. In Canada, the Toronto index of 300 shares is up only 3.2 percent after an 11 percent high. In Japan, the market was up 14 percent at its peak but then was down 10 percent until the Friday rally, which leaves it down 4.6 percent for the year. The CAC index of 40 shares in France has fallen sharply recently and is now up 11.2 percent for the year after reaching a peak gain of 24 percent. **********In Britain, the FT-SE 100 index reached an all-time high in September, putting it up 25 percent for the year. But that gain has now shrunk to 14.4 percent. In Italy, the 20 percent gain seen in June has evaporated. The Banca Commerciale Italiana index is now down 4.6 percent for the year. **********For the American investing abroad, the dollar's performance has been important. Its rise against European currencies contributed to the lackluster performance there. But it fell against the yen, helping turn losses into gains. And if the dollar, which was up about 25 percent against the German mark this year, had not fallen sharply recently, the small gains would probably have been losses. **********In Europe, the dollar is still up about 10 percent against the mark and that was enough to cut the stock gains, when they are translated back into dollars, to 4.1 percent in dollars from 10.6 percent in local terms by the end of last week. **********Right now, the outlook for next year is not great. While the recent declines would suggest there are bargains available, the list of negatives is hard to ignore. Among the problems: high interest rates in Europe and no likelihood of an easing soon; worries about the recovery in Britain and the United States and the slowdowns elsewhere in Europe and in Japan; downgrades in estimates of corporate earnings almost everywhere because of the sour economies, and worries about the course of events in the former Soviet Union, which have a dramatic impact in Germany. **********In addition, there is the dollar. If the American economy does begin to recover and confidence rebounds, the dollar is likely to begin to rise again. And that would cut into profits when investments overseas are turned back into dollars. **********In its most recent world investment report, Goldman Sachs takes a view that blends advice to practice restraint with the need to sell stocks. The firm concludes: **********"There are good reasons for believing that equities might underperform in the short term, including the possibility that markets are likely to remain nervous about the economy. However, investors might consider that equities do well in January, that it pays to buy undervalued markets in January and that by being out of the market now, investors could miss a significant up side."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/14/busin.print_headline: MANAGING; Fishing For the Workplace Imposter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/14/busin.body_text: **********Recently, an executive with a large pharmaceutical company was promoted to head an overseas office. Although the executive had been with the company for nearly two decades, and his performance was deemed consistently outstanding, top management hired an investigator to examine his credentials before sending him abroad -- and was dismayed. **********The executive did not have the Ph.D. in biology he claimed and the university he said he received it from did not even exist. "His certificate was a phony, from one of the diploma mills," said Jeremiah McAward, president of McAward Associates Inc., the New York-based firm that handled the case.  "The situation could have been terribly embarrassing if he'd gone to Europe and been uncovered as a fraud." **********Pre-employment background checks are commonly used by corporations, mainly as a way to avoid negligent-hiring liability suits by shareholders or customers. But midcareer resume investigations are also on the rise. Mr. McAward, whose firm conducts several hundred searches each month for corporations nationwide, does 20 percent of his business in that area, up from 10 percent in 1986. "Corporations today are more conscious of their image," he said. "They're wary not just of who they hire, but who they promote. They think top management should be like Caesar's wife." **********Many corporations, of course, uncover imposters themselves. One executive from a Fortune 500 company boasted of his participation in the Aspen Institute, an elite management society. At a dinner party one night, his boss introduced him to another member of the institute, who was astonished he had not met the executive. It turned out that the executive had never been a member. Although he wasn't fired, he's unlikely to be advanced. "I'm not sure we'd be comfortable with him in a more senior role," said a spokesman for the company. **********A variety of events can bring about a resume investigation: a promotion or transfer to a position of greater visibility, an assignment to a classified project, a move from a nonfiduciary role to a fiduciary one. An executive might also be scrutinized before being appointed to a management committee or elected to a board of directors. In such situations, the executive's corporate biography is usually rewritten and verified. **********Some investigations stem from less favorable circumstances. An executive may become the target of a witch hunt by industry watchdogs, or the subject of an expose by the news media. Colleagues or competitors may have blown the whistle, revealing damaging information. Jeff (Mad Dog) Beck, a rainmaker on Wall Street in the 1980's, worked at four different investment banks before The Wall Street Journal reported that he had fabricated stories about his work and family background. While some of his colleagues had long doubted his stories, no one wanted to challenge someone of Mr. Beck's status. **********Since checking credentials can arouse needless suspicion among people who aren't involved, experts advise sensitivity. "These investigations are generally done very, very quietly," said Tom Norton, president of Fidelifacts, an agency based in New York. "Once somebody's been at a company for a while, it's more a matter of reviewing records and making sure they're accurate. You don't want to draw attention to the process." **********Some people try to undo the damage before it can be used against them. According to a 1987 study by Personnel Administrator magazine, nearly 20 percent of 300 personnel managers at major American corporations have been approached by employees attempting to correct their records. Most ofthese employees were subsequently demoted or dismissed. **********Rather than track down credentials themselves, companies often turn to executive recruiters for help. "If we had a question about an executive's resume, we'd probably ask the recruiters who brought him in about it," said Peter Thorpe, a human resources administrator at Citicorp. **********But recruiters can't always help.  "The value of the working papers on an assignment is about three years," said Dwight Foster, executive managing director of Foster Partners, a recruiting firm affiliated with KPMG/Peat Marwick. "After that, the records may be destroyed." **********That's where the investigative agencies come in. Over the last decade, these businesses have proliferated, charging anywhere from $50 to $500 per search. With an employee's name, address, social security number and birthdate, they can access considerable information from computer data bases kept by universities and government agencies. While no comprehensive statutes regulate employees' privacy, employers do have to comply with the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which requires them to notify employees in writing of their intention to obtain certain documents like credit reports. **********Companies often want to examine employee's bank records, outstanding bills, loan defaults and tax liens before a promotion or a transfer. "If you've got a $2 billion operation in Europe, a guy who can't manage his own financial affairs might not have the kind of judgment necessary for that challenge," said one executive recruiter. **********Ultimately, the safest measure is to conduct a thorough background check at the start. Said Mr. Norton, who estimates that 30 percent of resumes he sees contain errors, "The first mistake is neglecting to investigate someone when you hire him. "  HOMING IN ON THE CHIEF OFFENDERS **********In faking credentials, it is academic records that people most often try to doctor. "There's a whole bunch of people who are all done with their Ph.D., except for their dissertation," said Dwight Foster of Foster Partners, a New York executive recruiting firm. "They don't see any problem with putting the Ph.D. on their resume, because they feel they've earned it." **********At Columbia University in New York, the registrar's office uncovers several thousand cases of misrepresentation each year. But it's tougher to determine authenticity if a degree is from an unknown institution. Agencies keep track of phony universities, as well as defunct ones. Foreign countries, particularly England, are popular locales for bogus alma maters. Even trickier are those universities where data has been destroyed. **********"One list we keep well guarded consists of bona fide schools that had fires in their record rooms," said Jeremiah McAward, head of McAward Associates. "An executive could say, for instance, that he graduated from the Sorbonne in 1963 and no one could doubt his word." **********Another common ploy involves passing oneself off as the past president of a defunct corporation. To prevent such shams, private detectives develop extensive libraries of old telephone books. "If somebody tells us he worked for XYZ company in 1965, we can immediately check whether XYZ ever existed," said Tom Norton, president of Fidelifacts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/21/world.main_headline: AIR FORCE TO CUT PHILIPPINES UNITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/21/world.print_headline: AIR FORCE TO CUT PHILIPPINES UNITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/21/world.body_text: **********The United States Air Force announced today that it would evacuate more than half of its uniformed personnel in the Philippines because of an erupting volcano that has coated a major American air base in ash, making it unusable. **********The pullout of 4,500 of the 7,000 active-duty workers assigned to Clark Air Base would be the first major withdrawal of American military personnel from the Philippines since Mount Pinatubo unleashed a series of deadly eruptions last week. The evacuation of their families was begun last week, and is almost complete. **********The evacuation announced today "was based on the conditions at Clark and the inability of Clark to sustain a large population over the short term," said Stanley Schrager, chief spokesman for the United States Embassy in Manila. "It's a real mess up there." **********Clark is 10 miles east of the volcano. **********American officials in Washington and Manila have suggested that Clark may be abandoned because of unacceptably high reconstruction costs. Clark has been buried under a carpet of volcanic ash that varies from six inches to a foot deep.  A Base Overtaken by Technology **********"I'd give you even odds that the Air Force will never reopen Clark," an American official said today. **********It is one of the largest American military bases outside the United States and at one time was the keystone of American air power in the Pacific. But the last air wing based at Clark was removed in early June as part of a scheduled redeployment, before Mount Pinatubo erupted. When the eruption began it was being used primarily as a refueling and logistics center. **********Officials say that the Subic Bay Naval Station is by far the more valuable of the American bases in the Philippines. It is a principal maintenance, supply and storage base for the 180 ships of the Pacific Fleet, and is the most convenient full-service port for Navy vessels in most areas of the Indian Ocean. Its shipyards employ thousands of skilled Filipino workers. **********The lease agreement permitting American use of Clark and Subic expires in September, and American and Filipino negotiators have been haggling over a lease renewal for months. American officials have suggested that as a result of the eruptions, the United States may seek a new lease only for the naval base. **********But Subic, about 35 miles south of the volcano, is also buried beneath the talc-like gray ash, which has jammed electrical generators, contaminated drinking water and shut down all but essential operations. **********Mr. Schrager of the American Embassy said today that there was "no intention at this point" of withdrawing the nearly 7,000 United States Navy personnel stationed in the Philippines. **********New eruptions this afternoon released a cloud of swirling gray ash nearly three miles high, dumping a new layer of ash on the base and creating fresh misery for hundreds of thousands of Filipinos who have struggled to dig out from beneath the ash and rock that rained down on their homes last weekend. **********"When will it stop?" said Regina Porceso, who fled to an evacuation camp in Manila on Sunday with five of her nine children after a portion of her home in Angeles, 50 miles north of the capital, collapsed under the ash.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/16/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Allies and Adversaries; Israel: Moments of Joy, Then the Letdown
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/16/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Allies and Adversaries; Israel: Moments of Joy, Then the Letdown
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/16/world.body_text: **********"For a few minutes," Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said tonight, "there was a ray of hope." **********Listening to the radio bulletin at 2 P.M. suggesting that Iraq had agreed to withdraw from Kuwait, thousands of Israelis were briefly delighted, looking forward to the prospect of putting their gas masks back into the closet and peeling the plastic sheeting off their safe-room windows. **********But after a few minutes, radio and television began reporting President Saddam Hussein's conditions, including Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Golan Heights. **********Hearts sank, and Mr. Shamir said, "it very quickly became clear that it was an act of deception."  'Saddam's War' **********Israeli analysts quickly drew conclusions from the televised scenes of celebration being shown on Baghdad streets after the announcement of the offer. That proved, as one television commentator put it, that "it's Saddam's war." **********"The people just want it to end," he said. **********Israelis are no less eager to see the fighting stop, and with it the missile attacks on this country. Just a day earlier, the chief of military intelligence, Maj. Gen. Moshe Shahak, said the latest Israeli assessment was that Iraq could indeed mount chemical warheads on its Scud missiles, even though all the Iraqi missiles launched thus far had carried only conventional warheads. **********Defense Minister Moshe Arens, asked about the Iraqi announcement tonight, warned Israelis that they had better remain prepared for further Iraqi missile strikes. **********"To our regret," said Avi Pazner, a senior aide to Mr. Shamir, "we see now that there will be no quick solution to this problem. The conditions that Saddam Hussein has put out make the situation as difficult as it was before."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/world.main_headline: Excerpts From Gorbachev's Speech: 'The Idea That Peace Is Indivisible'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/world.print_headline: Excerpts From Gorbachev's Speech: 'The Idea That Peace Is Indivisible'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from the address by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in Oslo as winner of the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize, as translated by the Nobel committee: **********Today peace means an ascent from mere coexistence to cooperation and common creative endeavor among countries and nations. Peace is movement toward globality and universality of civilization. Never before has the idea that peace is indivisible been as true as it is now. **********Peace is not unity in similarity, but unity in diversity, in the juxtaposing and reconciling of differences. And ideally peace means the absence of violence, an ethical value. But here we must recall Rajiv Gandhi, who died so tragically a few days ago. I consider the decision of your committee as a recognition of the great international importance of the changes now under way in the Soviet Union, and as an expression of confidence in our policy of new thinking, which is based on the conviction that at the end of the 20th century, force and arms will have to give way as a major instrument in world politics. **********I view the decision to award me the Nobel Peace Prize as an act of solidarity with the monumental undertaking which has already placed enormous demands on the Soviet people in terms of effort, costs, hardships, will and character.                    . . . **********As for the foreign policy aspect, there was the East-West confrontation, a rigid division into friends and foes, two hostile camps with a corresponding set of cold war attributes. Both East and West were constrained by the logic of military confrontation and were wearing themselves down ever more by the arms race. The mere thought of dismantling existing structures did not come easily. However, the realization that we faced, domestically and internationally, inevitable disaster gave us the strength to make a historic choice, a choice I have never since regretted. Policies and Peace **********Perestroika, which once again is returning our people to common sense, has enabled us to open up to the world, and has restored a normal relationship between the internal development of the country and its foreign policy. **********But all this takes a lot of hard work. To a people which believed that the Government's policies had always been true to the cause of peace, to them we proposed what was in many ways a different policy, which would genuinely serve the cause of peace, but differed from the prevailing view of what it meant, and particularly from the established stereotypes as to how we should protect peace. In a word, we proposed new thinking in foreign policy. **********We thus embarked on a path of major changes, which may turn out to be the most significant in the 20th century, significant for our own country and for its peoples, but also for the entire world.                    . . . **********Being resolute in the pursuit of perestroika, a subject of much discussion these days, must be measured by the commitment to democratic change. Resoluteness does not mean a return to repression, diktat or suppression of rights and freedoms. I will never agree to seeing our society once again being divided into reds and whites, into those who self-appointedly claim to speak and act on behalf of the people and those who are enemies of the people. Soviet Foreign Relations **********Resolution today means acting within the framework of political and social pluralism and the rule of law to insure conditions for continuing reform and preventing the collapse of the state and economic collapse, to prevent elements of chaos from assuming catastrophic proportions. All this means taking certain tactical steps, to search for various ways of addressing both short- and long-term tasks.                    . . . **********Ladies and gentlemen, international politics is another area where a great deal depends on the correct interpretation of what is now happening in the Soviet Union. It is true today and will remain true tomorrow. We are now approaching what might be the crucial point when the world community and, above all, the states with the greatest potential to influence world developments will have to decide on their attitude to the Soviet Union, and on the basis of real deeds. The more I reflect on what is happening in the world today, the more I am convinced that the world needs perestroika no less than the Soviet Union itself does. Fortunately, the present generation of politicians for the most part are becoming ever more deeply aware of this interrelationship, and also the fact that now, when perestroika has entered its critical phase, the Soviet Union is entitled to expect large-scale support to insure its success. **********Recently we have been seriously rethinking the substance and role of our economic cooperation with other countries, above all the major Western nations. We realize, of course, that we have to carry out measures which would enable us genuinely to open up to the world economy and become an organic part of it. But at the same time we have come to the conclusion that we need a kind of synchronization of our actions toward that end with the Group of Seven and the European communities. In other words, we're thinking of a fundamentally new phase in our international cooperation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/08/busin.body_text: **********The family-owned company of Alan Bond, the Australian financier, has been shut down with debts of more than $760 million. **********John Lord, of the Australian accounting firm Duesburys, was named to liquidate Mr. Bond's company, Dallhold Investments, at a federal court hearing here on Friday. **********Dallhold said in court papers that its total debts were more than $760 million (United States), while its assets totaled $30.4 million at best. **********The move to liquidate followed the appointment on Wednesday of receivers for Mr. Bond's last large asset, a stake in the Greenvale nickel-mining venture in Queensland. The mine and refinery has 900 workers and annual exports of about $188 million. **********Dallhold Nickel Management, which holds 72 percent of the nickel project, owes bankers $304 million, according to newspaper reports. The remaining 28 percent owned by the Queensland state government is not affected by the Dallhold receivership.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/19/world.body_text: **********Vietnamese refugees who fear they may be forcibly returned to Vietnam from Hong Kong have been staging demonstrations inside the largest of this British colony's detention camps and have been making plans for armed resistance should Britain and Hanoi conclude an agreement on the repatriations. **********Officials here had confidently expected an agreement on the mandatory return of tens of thousands of Vietnamese to be signed in Hanoi this week. **********But late today a British Foreign Office spokesman in the colony said: "We have indicated we are ready to sign, and they have indicated they are not. We don't know for certain at this stage what's causing the delay."  Tension in the Camps **********Inside the gritty camps, which house 59,000 Vietnamese refugees, the suspense and tension over their fate has grown "almost unbearable," said a relief worker who requested anonymity. **********"The people inside are afraid they will go to sleep one night, and without warning, the guards will come to take them away," the worker said. "Even the sensible people are so afraid they can't think very straight anymore." **********For three years, the Hong Kong authorities have insisted they had a right to deport Vietnamese who have been classified as nonrefugees through a screening process monitored by United Nations officials. But the process has been criticized by human rights groups as being unfair and inaccurate. **********In 1989, the British authorities carried out the first forced return of Vietnamese from Hong Kong, using riot police to herd 51 refugees, most of them women and children, onto an airplane in what they hoped would be a secret nighttime operation. But news of the action was reported and photographed, and it led to an international outcry that so embarrassed Hanoi it refused to accept any more refugees who were forced to return. **********Hong Kong officials said the delay over the new agreement has been because the Vietnamese were trying to work out the logistical problems of reintegrating the thousands of returnees. **********One Western diplomat said, however, there could also be internal political problems in Hanoi, with some officials there opposed to the agreement because of the American opposition. **********The United States led the protest over the 1989 incident, arguing that it was wrong forcibly to return people to a repressive government that might persecute them for their original flight. Hanoi is currently sensitive to American opinion because it wants to establish diplomatic and economic ties with the United States. **********United States Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon said today that America's position "has been clear for a long time. We are opposed to the forced repatriation of people from Hong Kong to Vietnam, particularly given the current circumstances in that country." U.S. Response Critical **********But it is uncertain how strongly Washington would protest a new British-Vietnamese deal on forced repatriation, and officials in Hong Kong have said the American response will be critical to the accord. **********Whatever the cause, the delay has only added to the wrenching tensions in the Hong Kong camps. **********In Whitehead Detention Center, the largest and most volatile camp, thousands of refugees have been staging peaceful demonstrations for the past two weeks, and some of their leaders said some have begun to plan hunger strikes, armed resistance and even suicide if guards come to take them away. **********Whitehead, which houses 25,000 people, is populated largely by Vietnamese who have been through the screening process and were told they do not qualify as genuine refugees fleeing persecution. **********Reporters are not allowed inside the detention camps, but they can sometimes get close enough to see the demonstrations at Whitehead, where as many as 15,000 Vietnamese march in circles behind high mesh fences looped with barbed wire. The protesters carry homemade banners and signs that read "Freeworld Save Us,' and "Dead Better than Red." **********"So far the demonstrations have been peaceful and orderly, but everyone is very, very anxious, and some extremists are pushing for more violent actions," said David Liu, a spokesman for Refugee Concern Hong Kong, an umbrella organization of relief groups that work inside the camps.
