https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.main_headline: Taking the Fast-Food Chains to Task
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.print_headline: FORUM; Taking the Fast-Food Chains to Task
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.body_text: **********I found out about cholesterol the hard way. I was a student in the greasy hamburger school of nutrition for my first 43 years and in 1966 I suffered a massive heart attack. I was thin; I didn't smoke; I exercised before it was fashionable. But a shocking 300 cholesterol level got my attention. **********An inquisitive mind combined with the cholesterol information available persuaded me to reduce my cholesterol level to 150. I began telling my story. Only my family accepted my cholesterol advice until 1984, when the Government, in a 10-year, $150 million study, validated the connection between high cholesterol and heart attacks. The time seemed right to take my "cholesterol kills" message to the public. **********I established the National Heart Savers Association in January 1985. We did the first citywide cholesterol testing in America in Grand Island, Neb., that year. We did not even know if people wanted to know their cholesterol level. In five days we tested 8,500 people in a city of 35,000. **********In the next two years we tested the cholesterol levels of more than 200,000 people in 16 cities. We also created "National Know Your Cholesterol Month" and got it approved by Congress. We tested the cholesterol levels of more than 20,000 Capitol Hill staffers, including more than 50 Senators and 100-plus Congressmen. We also sent 11,000 letters to food processors asking them to remove highly saturated coconut oil and palm oil from their products. But at the time, nobody listened. **********The food giants' lack of interest in our calls and letters led to our first "poisoning of America" campaign -- full-page national newspaper advertisements castigating the major food processors. We alerted the public to the "No Cholesterol" and "Pure Vegetable Oil" distortions on product labels that contained tropical oils. When ingested, these oils turn into deadly cholesterol. Outraged protests by consumers brought massive reformulations. **********Meat and high-fat dairy products make up three-fourths of our saturated fat intake. It was a natural evolution from these earlier efforts to our McDonald's "Poisoning of America" campaign. We called on the chain to lower the fat in its hamburgers and remove beef tallow from its french fries. **********Our national full-page advertisements brought dramatic results. A Gallup Poll showed 31 percent of the public had heard our message and 38 percent of them had decreased their visits to fast-food restaurants as a result. McDonald's, after citing an "eight year study," took just three weeks to remove beef tallow from its french fries after our advertisements ran. The other fast-food chains followed. **********The public does not realize the dramatic power it wields. The consumer's wish is big business's command. **********Another example of "people power" was demonstrated during the national food-labeling bill debate in the Senate last October. **********Many food processors did not want more detailed ingredient labeling of their foods for obvious reasons. After passing the House of Representatives, the bill languished in the Senate. We ran a series of four national advertisements citing opponents of the bill and asked people to call their senators and representatives to express support for food labeling. They did. **********I am proud to repeat the words that Representative Henry Waxman of California, the bill's author, said about me after the bill was finally passed: "His ads played such an important role in educating the public and the Congress. What he was able to do on his own as an individual is an inspiration. This bill is a tribute to his tenacity." **********The American people passed that bill. They made their wishes known to lawmakers and will be rewarded next year with the identification of cholesterol, saturated fat, sodium, calories, and other important nutritional information, on all packaged foods. **********The big picture is that Americans know lowering cholesterol can extend their life span. That awareness is not wasted on the food giants, which are now bringing to market a variety of delicious low-cholesterol, low-saturated-fat foods. **********The new 9 percent fat hamburger that McDonald's introduced -- down from 20 to 30 percent -- is also available to other restaurants and to supermarkets everywhere. With hamburger making up 44 percent of the meat we consume, the potential for lowering the cholesterol levels of Americans is truly mind-boggling. McDonald's and I are now working the same territory. The public's nutritional needs make for strange bedfellows.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.main_headline: J. C. Penney Fires Ayer After 8 Years and Hires Bozell
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; J. C. Penney Fires Ayer After 8 Years and Hires Bozell
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/busin.body_text: **********THE J. C. Penney Company yesterday abruptly dismissed Ayer Inc., its agency for eight years, and hired Bozell Inc. **********Executives of the nation's fourth-largest retailer said the change, effective Oct. 1, was unrelated to the quality of Ayer's award-winning work. Instead, they said, they were drawn to the abilities of Bozell/Southwest, as Bozell's Dallas office is known. **********While "we've been very pleased over the years with our relationship with Ayer," Robert B. Gill, Penney's vice chairman and chief operating officer, said in a telephone interview from Dallas, "the main thrust is that the resources down here available to us through Bozell are substantially larger and more in depth than what we could have." **********At 450 employees, Bozell/Southwest's office is 10 times the size of Ayer's office in Dallas, which opened in 1988 to serve Penney after the retailer moved its corporate headquarters from New York. **********Though Mr. Gill said the recession was not a factor in Penney's decision to change agencies, the soft retail environment is slowing Penney's ambitious program to change the company's image among shoppers. Once a plain-vanilla merchandiser of everything from ties to tires, Penney has in the last decade strived to transform itself into a modish national department-store chain concentrating on apparel. But during the recession, Penney's same-store sales growth has been hurt as many of its present or potential customers turned to discount retailers. **********Penney's sales this year "have been disappointing, as have those for most of the recession-sensitive retail industry," said a memo distributed to Ayer employees. "At times like this, an advertising agency's prior record of success is easily forgotten." **********A national image campaign that Ayer created soon after it became Penney's agency in 1983, "You're looking smarter than ever," is credited by retail analysts as helping change consumer perceptions of Penney. A replacement campaign, "Fashion comes to life." was introduced last year. **********Penney's billings this year were to total $45.6 million, said Ayer's New York-based top executives, who are deeply disappointed by yet another large account loss. And the timing could not have been worse: Penney's announcement came as another client, The National Sports Daily, announced that it was going out of business. **********"We've had nothing but praise from Penney," Jerry J. Siano, Ayer's chairman and chief executive, said at a news conference in his Manhattan office. "It's discouraging. It's just not understandable. What else can I say?" Mr. Siano and Thomas F. Maxey, vice chairman, deferred questions about the fate of their Dallas employees, who might seek additional accounts there to add to a now bittersweet recent addition, the Dallas Chamber of Commerce. **********Penney's shift brings to an estimated $600 million the value of the important national accounts being reassigned, or placed in review, since the recession began in July. Almost every client involved in this unusual spate of switching finds itself fighting fiercely for ever-scarcer consumer dollars. Among them: American Isuzu Motors, Avis, Club Med, Reebok, Subaru of America and Vons supermarkets. **********At Ayer, Penney's loss is the latest in a skein exceeding $200 million, including Burger King, Continental Airlines and Citicorp's New York branch banking. **********"It's no secret that Bozell has been courting the business ever since Penney moved from New York to Dallas," Mr. Maxey said. Bozell last year was named Penney's agency for a cable television shopping channel that was later discontinued. **********Liener Temerlin, Bozell's chairman, chuckled at a characterization of Bozell as nipping at Ayer's heels for Penney's favor. During a telephone interview from Dallas, where he is based, Mr. Temerlin described Bozell as having tried "to let them know who we are and what we can do." The cable account "gave us a chance to flex some creative muscles," he added. The Penney victory gives Bozell/Southwest the accounts of four of the five largest corporations with Dallas headquarters, Mr. Temerlin said, including American Airlines and Texas Instruments. And it brings Bozell/Southwest billings to $380 million, he added. That is very close to the billings of the largest of Bozell's nine full-service United States offices, the New York headquarters office. **********In addition to the spending coordinated through Penney's agency, the retailer also spends an estimated $275 million a year on advertising, like circulars, created in-house. Penney's total spending, at around $320 million, makes it the nation's 27th-largest advertiser.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/12/world.main_headline: ARMS ISSUE DRIVES U.S. SOVIET POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/12/world.print_headline: ARMS ISSUE DRIVES U.S. SOVIET POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/12/world.body_text: **********While confident that there is no threat to American security from the Soviet upheaval, the Bush Administration believes the system of control over Soviet nuclear weapons is in danger of breaking down and that the breakaway republics have not yet worked out a way to replace it, officials said today. **********As Washington watched a growing number of republics support the commonwealth formed by Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia, the safety of Soviet nuclear weapons has become the driving force behind American policy on the rapid changes in what Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, has taken to calling "the former Soviet Union." **********In public, President Bush and his top aides have taken care to reassure Americans that they have seen nothing to indicate that the 27,000 Soviet nuclear weapons are in danger of falling into the hands of someone who might consider using them. **********There also is no sign that any of the political factions in the Soviet Union are interested in taking control of the weapons for any reason other than to destroy them, officials said. Indeed, they said, some Administration officials have been suggesting that the United States should consider making separate deals to destroy nuclear weapons with some of the republics that have them on their soil. Assurances 'Pretty Good' **********"We have a keen interest, the whole world does, in the nuclear questions there, and frankly, assurances have been pretty good there," Mr. Bush told reporters at a White House photo session today. **********But Administration officials have been unable, or unwilling, to say precisely what guarantees they have received from President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and other republic officials. **********And it is clear both from public statements by Administration officials and from their private comments that Washington believes the decision by Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia to declare an end to the Soviet Union is a direct threat to the command structure that controls Soviet nuclear weapons. **********Replacing that structure with one equally centralized and equally reliable would be a top priority of the Bush Administration if Mr. Yeltsin's attempt to form a commonwealth of former Soviet republics succeeds, officials said. **********"I see no reason to alarm the American people, but it's something that we are following extraordinarily closely and we are in touch," Mr. Bush said today. Yeltsin's Position Called Strong **********The Administration has tried to follow a scrupulously neutral tone in public toward the struggle for power between the republics and Mr. Gorbachev, based on what officials said was a conclusion by Mr. Bush that taking sides could only worsen an already tense situation and run the risk of leaving the United States' seeming to be on the wrong side when the dust settles. **********But the Bush Administration was closely following today's moves by more republics to back Mr. Yeltsin and there were outward signs of a growing conclusion in the Administration that Mr. Gorbachev stood to lose the fight. **********In testimony before the House Armed Services Committee, Robert S. Strauss, the American Ambassador to Moscow, said today's developments put "President Yeltsin in a very strong position vis-a-vis President Gorbachev." **********"He obviously is much stronger politically than President Gorbachev, who's in the decline," Mr. Strauss said. **********"My personal view is there is a role for President Gorbachev, and a very significant one," he said, but added: "Unquestionably President Yeltsin and his various ministers are the people with whom we'll deal." **********Thus far, American policy toward the Soviet Union has been predicated on a conclusion by Mr. Bush's team of Soviet specialists in the White House that the struggle for power in the Soviet Union will be resolved relatively quickly, perhaps as early this week, officials said. Civil Violence Feared **********But if there is no quick resolution, that could strain Washington's studied neutrality. The President and his advisers are also considering what options they might have in that case, especially because of Washington's concerns about who is controlling Soviet nuclear weapons. **********These concerns are part of Mr. Bush's consideration of virtually every area of Soviet-American relations. For example, American willingness to help the Soviet Union get through what is expected to be a tough winter is not just based on humanitarian interests. It also is based on a fear that food shortages could provoke civil violence. The United States wants very much to avoid the kind of warfare that has rent Yugoslavia in a country that has nuclear weapons. **********Beyond that, compliance with treaties requiring the destruction of some Soviet nuclear weapons would be much simpler if the United States had a central miliitary authority to work with. **********But on Tuesday, Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, said, "We face a period of uncertainty as Russia and the other republics sort out possession of the weapons and establish new structures and procedures for controlling and operating them." **********And in a separate appearance on Tuesday, Mr. Strauss said: "Everyone says, 'We know we need a unified control and we will cooperate in getting it for you, in seeing that you have it.' Do we have that now? No."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/06/busin.body_text: **********Investors climbed on the Wall Street bandwagon yesterday, driving stock prices sharply higher and lifting trading volume to its highest level in almost a month. Several market indexes established new highs. **********The Dow Jones industrial average -- now only 27 points short of its July record -- soared 58.41 pints, or 2 percent, to 2,972.52. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index and the New York Stock Exchange composite index each advanced to new highs, a clear demonstration that investors were coming in across the board. **********Analysts could not point to any one factor to explain the wave of market euphoria but pointed to a steadily building series of individual events that together meant the economy was gradually improving.  'A Lot of Small Things' **********"It's a combination of a lot of small things." said Peter J. Canelo, chief investment strategist for County NatWest Securities. "One huge plus," he said, was that the dollar rallied yesterday against both the Japanese yen and the German mark. **********"This tells foreign investors that maybe the U.S. is not such a bad place to invest," Mr. Canelo added. **********Hugh Johnson, chief strategist for the First Albany Corporation, said, "The fundamentals don't look particularly inspiring, but I learned a long time ago you don't argue with the stock market." **********In an even stronger sign of broad stock buying, the Wilshire 5,000 index, representative of just about every stock, reached a record 3,582.30, up 68.48, or almost 2 percent. The buying frenzy broke the former record of 3,523.47, established just a week before the market collapse in October 1989. **********Trading volume, the strongest since Feb. 12, soared to 253.7 million shares, from 199.8 million on Monday. Only 3 stocks dropped to new lows, while 183 stocks rose to new highs, including Litton Industries, which rose 2 1/2, to 86 1/4, after a reaching a new high of 86 1/2. Program trading, typically 10 percent of the day's activity, accounted for almost 24 points of the Dow's gain, Birinyi Associates said. **********Except for a small selloff in the final 30 minutes, the Dow moved sharply higher throughout the session. Short-sellers, who sell borrowed stock and hope to profit from price declines, moved in several times during the day but were repeatedly forced to buy back their stock to avoid losses.  Big Board Steps In **********Buying was so heavy that the Dow was ahead 50 points by 2:39 P.M., at which point the New York Stock Exchange intervened and imposed its 50-point rule. **********When the Dow moves ahead 50 points or more, the Big Board bars program traders from buying any stock, in the S.& P. 500 for example, at a price higher than the previous price, in effect halting most activity for the rest of the day. The procedure is also used when prices are falling to prevent program trading from exaggerating price movements. **********Four stocks -- I.B.M., Philip Morris, Procter & Gamble and Westinghouse -- accounted for more than a fourth of the gain in the Dow blue chips. **********I.B.M., the leader, jumped 2 7/8, to 133 1/2, with almost 2.5 million shares changing hands. Philip Morris, a highly recommended growth stock, climbed 2 1/4, to 67 5/8, with 3.6 million shares changing hands. Procter & Gamble, which has its eyes on Revlon Inc., rose 1 5/8, to 84 3/4, while Westinghouse, project leader for an international group planning to upgrade the Soviet air-traffic control network, advanced 1 5/8, to 29 5/8. Trading in Westinghouse stock jumped to 3.1 million shares. **********"It's very hard to point to any fundamental development," Mr. Johnson said of yesterday's strong advance. "The market's been saying for some time that the recession is going to end and recovery will start at the end of the second or start of the third quarter." **********But, he said, "The reason it's doing as well as it's doing is the behavior of the market itself. A lot of investors -- institutional and individual -- still have meaningful cash positions and are feeling uncomfortable with them. There's a growing sense of urgency to get it into the market. The return on cash is looking more dismal with every passing day, and the market is looking better with every passing day." **********He said that "the stock market is saying that forecasts on the economy and on earnings are way too pessimistic" but added that he found it "hard to make the case for a strong recovery." **********Even so, he said, "My experience says I should take the message of the stock market seriously -- and buy." **********Ticking off a list of positive economic indicators, Mr. Canelo of County NatWest noted optimistic signals in the index of leading indicators, the purchasing managers index, the purchasing managers order index, commodity prices, the Barron's confidence index and the dollar. **********Asked when the Dow might break the record, which is just short of 3,000, he replied without being more specific, "in short order." He said that oil stocks in the Dow were "dragging it down" and from that standpoint "it's already there." **********Nevertheless, he added, "We have a good chance of going into the 3,100 to 3,200 area before valuations look too high. It won't be immediately," he went on, "maybe later this year." **********Looking at all the new highs, he said: "The leadership here is still in the small stocks. This is a broad, strong market move. It's telling us the turn in the economy will be sooner rather than later."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; New Atlantic Group Vice Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/27/busin.body_text: **********Melvyn R. Lewinter, chief financial officer of the Atlantic Group, one of the record labels in Time Warner's record division, has been named to the additional post of vice chairman. **********Atlantic is the second largest of Time Warner's record groups, after Warner Records. Within Atlantic are several separate record operations -- Atlantic Records, ATCO Records, EastWest Records America -- as well as the video operation A-Vision Entertainment and various subsidiary labels. **********In his new position, Mr. Lewinter will assume a more comprehensive role, the company said, working more closely with the creative areas while continuing to oversee the financial areas. **********Atlantic's video arm coordinates long-form music videos for sale in stores. **********Each of the record labels has its own staff of executives who search out new talent, as well as its own marketing and promotions staff. **********Mr. Lewinter said he hoped to aid in the coordination of those operations. **********Mr. Lewinter attended New York University, where he received a bachelor of science degree in accounting. He then began working at Mason & Company, a public accounting firm. From there he joined Musicor Records as vice president and controller, and came to Atlantic Records in 1970. Mr. Lewinter, who is married and has two children, lives in Manhattan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.print_headline: Saudis Lay Plans to Surpass Soviets in Production of Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia gave the first formal indication today that it may well surpass the Soviet Union as the world's largest oil producer within the next two years. **********While stressing that they would act cautiously and slowly, Saudi officials confirmed to other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, who began a meeting here today, that they would increase their production capacity significantly above its current level of between 8.5 million and 9 million barrels a day. **********Speaking in a closed meeting of OPEC ministers, Hisham M. Nazer, the Saudi oil minister, said the country's production capacity would be raised to 10 million barrels a day by 1994. **********The Soviet Union's oil output has slipped in the last three years from a high of more than 12 million barrels a day to an anticipated average this year of less than 10 million barrels. Many experts expect a further slide in 1992, allowing Saudi Arabia to become the world's top producer within the next few months. **********OPEC officials said that the Saudi statements, and subsequent comments expanding on them, were meant to accomplish a dual purpose: reassuring other OPEC members that Saudi Arabia will not provoke a collapse in oil prices by rushing to raise exports, and emphasizing that the country has every intention of becoming the world's prime oil supplier as global demand increases in the next decades. **********The Saudi declaration was also viewed within the organization as a reassertion of the dominant position the country has relentlessly staked out in the oil market since the Persian Gulf crisis began in August 1990. **********Saudi officials stressed that this significant expansion of Saudi production capacity had been under way for some time and that it was unlikely to be slowed or interrupted soon. **********The officials noted, however, that while they strongly favored moderate oil prices, they would be careful not to allow prices to collapse, stressing that the increase of output would be "gradual and predictable." **********Still, the Saudis left little doubt in the minds of several OPEC officials that they would reject any requests from other members to scale back production to push up prices. Key members like Iran, Algeria and Nigeria are advocating such a move. Agreement on First Quarter **********OPEC did agree today to a Saudi and Venezuelan proposal to keep prices and production at their current levels for the first quarter of next year. OPEC is now producing about 24 million barrels a day, of which Saudi Arabia alone claims 35 percent. **********The OPEC ministers are scheduled to continue their talks on Wednesday, concentrating on plans for the second quarter, when seasonal demand for oil is expected to fall. Iran's oil minister, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, told reporters that some agreement "in principle" should be arrived at that mandates a second look at OPEC's overall production should oil prices weaken in the spring. So far, the Saudis have adamantly refused to make such a commitment.  High Profile **********Some OPEC officials noted here today that the Saudis appeared to be acting as though they wished to communicate to their colleagues in OPEC that they were on their way to becoming the leading oil power, which entails new "global responsibilities." **********The Saudis' high profile at this and other recent OPEC meetings parallels the country's growing power in the Persian Gulf region since the war against Iraq. **********When the Persian Gulf crisis began, Saudi Arabia rushed to compensate for the huge shortage of oil supplies created by the cessation of exports by Iraq and Kuwait. Output was raised to 8.5 million barrels a day, from 5.5 million barrels. Now the Saudis are openly saying they will not give up this new share of OPEC's total production. **********"There will be no return to the policies of the 70's and 80's," a senior Saudi official asserted in a recent conversation, alluding to repeated cuts in Saudi production in that period, with the aim of lifting oil prices. The only direction Saudi production is going, the Saudis say, is up. **********Other OPEC officials do not dispute the notion that Saudi Arabia may soon become the world's leading producer, but they say that is not the goal of Saudi policy. "They want to insure there is plenty of oil to respond to the continuing rising demand," said a senior Arab delegate who insisted on anonymity. "They want moderate oil prices to help their Western allies and third-world allies, and they want OPEC to recognize they are the king of the jungle." **********The inflexible Saudi stand is causing some bitterness among the 12 other members of OPEC, prompting many delegates to complain about Saudi "arrogance."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/23/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation agreed with a consortium of 38 banks today on a new $1.75 billion revolving credit through the end of 1993. The new credit agreement is smaller than the $2.64 billion credit agreement it replaces, but it constitutes an important financial safety net for the No. 3 auto maker, nevertheless. **********Thomas Capo, Chrysler's assistant treasurer, said there was no current plan to borrow under the new credit line. "Depending on future business we may or may not draw on the line," he added. **********Chrysler said the new credit's covenants are less restrictive than the older one's, which means Chrysler may draw money fom it in harder financial circumstances.   Security May Include 11 Plants **********The banks "and holders of other senior Chrysler obligations" that were not specified, however, will be entitled to claim 11 Chrysler manufacturing plants and other assets as security if the company borrows more than $500 million. Under the previous agreement the banks could not have claimed Chrysler's assets as collateral. **********The credit agreement should reassure suppliers, lenders and others that the banking community is confident of Chrysler's ability to weather current hard times in the industry. Chrysler has been cutting $3 billion from its cost structure and trying to sell an equity stake in its Chrysler Financial Corporation subsidiary. **********Mr. Capo said the banks and the auto maker wanted to change their previous credit line because of "a much tougher environment for the auto industry and the banking industry." Banks have been under regulatory pressure to reduce the size of loans that could be judged as risky.   Borrowing Limit Extended **********Offering an example of a covenant that had been made more liberal, Mr. Capo said Chrysler's borrowings might now constitute up to 110 percent of the company's net worth, compared with a previous limit of up to 100 percent of the net worth. Banks routinely attach tests of financial soundness to loan agreements to make sure they will be repaid, even if a company's condition deteriorates. **********Mr. Capo said Chrysler's current borrowings were much less than 100 percent of the company's net worth, although he said he could not be more specific. He acknowledged that the banks were demanding collateral in the event of substantial borrowings because of the worsening business environment. **********The lead bank in the consortium is the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. **********As of Jan. 1, Chrysler had about $3 billion in cash and marketable securities. But Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman, said in a recent interview that the company was drawing down its supply of cash quickly because of the industry's deep recession.   Effort on Financial Unit Stake **********Chrysler is trying to sell its equity in Chrysler Financial to raise cash and improve the ratings of its debt securities. Chrysler executives expect the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service to raise the ratings on Chrysler Financial debt from below-investment-grade status if it is partly owned by a company stronger than Chrysler. With better ratings, Chrysler Financial could once again raise money in public debt markets. **********The parent company has not had strong profits for two years, and it has forecast a big loss for the current quarter. **********Beyond waiting for an upturn in the United States automotive market, Chrysler is racing to bring out two critically important vehicle models, a new Jeep and its L/H midsize model. Both models are expected in 1992, and automotive analysts say they could hold the key to renewed financial health.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/world.body_text: **********When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Government decided last fall to invite Canadians to express their feelings about Canada and its problems, it chose as its Pied Piper a former newspaper editor and language commissioner with a distinctly un-Canadian propensity for stirring things up. **********Four months later, the official, Keith Spicer, has more than lived up to his billing as a quirky fellow who says what many Canadian public figures may think but hesitate to say in this country, where public discourse generally remains within well-circumscribed proprieties. **********Just as irksome to those who prefer seemliness, Mr. Spicer has brought forth a babel of opinions on everything from laws requiring French alongside English on cereal boxes to the extravagant re-decoration of Mr. Mulroney's official residence, as well as much else not obviously helpful to those hoping to bind Canada together.  Mulroney and the 'Malaise' **********Mr. Spicer is chairman of the Citizens' Forum on Canada's Future, set up in November to query Canadians and to report back by July 1 with findings to help chart a course through what Mr. Mulroney, in a recent speech in Quebec, called a "deep-rooted malaise" in the country. **********Above all, anxieties are focused on Quebec and whether it will remain part of Canada. Yet as the nation faces resurgent demands for independence in the French-speaking province, the country is weighed down by a host of other strains. **********As the Spicer commission discovered when it opened its toll-free telephone lines, community gatherings and "electronic town-hall meetings" that use closed-circuit television to link groups as far apart as Vancouver, British Columbia, and Halifax, Nova Scotia, many Canadians are profoundly discontented. **********To judge from the opinions received, one measure of this is a bitter disdain for politicians, above all for Mr. Mulroney. Westerners Alienated Too **********Others include a political alienation among westerners that rivals Quebec's, and a tug-of-war between those who want to expand Canada's elaborate welfare state and those who point to the annual deficit equaling $26.5 billion in United States money, tax rates approaching 50 percent and a sagging economy as proof that the country is living beyond its means. **********In a rakish calf-length overcoat and broad-brimmed fedora, Mr. Spicer has marched into this maelstrom, acknowledging that his job is not easy. **********"There's a very high potential for fiasco," he said after he was appointed. As controversy has mounted, he has said he can accept becoming a figure of ridicule, as he has for some politicians and cartoonists. **********"I've never taken myself very seriously," he told the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation recently. "So if somebody wants to find me funny, that's just fine with me." **********Problems accumulated for the 57-year-old Mr. Spicer from the start. He chose as his first destination not one of the communities along the United States border, where 90 percent of Canada's 26 million people live, but Tuktoyaktuk on the Arctic Ocean, home to a few thousand Eskimos. Doing the Local Dance **********To warm things up, he began, arms akimbo, with a traditional local dance and readings from local poetry. One reporter listened as an elderly resident counseled him to be tough with Quebec, saying its citizens needed to be "spanked and sent to their room." **********In Quebec, this brought derision. Lucien Bouchard, a former Mulroney Cabinet minister who has become a separatist leader, dismissed the forum as "a monumental farce." **********Then Mr. Spicer went to Quebec, where he bantered in flawless French on radio programs -- and answered callers who told him that he was wasting his time trying to save Canada by saying he was not opposing separatism, just soliciting views. **********He elaborated on this in the CBC interview, saying, "I really don't care about the plumbing" of future political arrangements, whether they involved federal ties or "sovereignty-association," the code phrase used in Quebec for arrangements that would give the province independence and an economic union with Canada.  Furor in Parliament **********In Parliament in Ottawa, this prompted a furor. Mr. Mulroney rejected demands that he fire Mr. Spicer, and Mr. Spicer himself said, "If I wanted a job that had no stress, I'd be selling bananas in Martinique." **********As editor of The Ottawa Citizen newspaper, and before that as the official responsible for monitoring the equality of French and English, he gained a reputation for creativity but also for erratic administration. **********At the citizens' forum, both were on display: the toll-free telephone lines, television hookups and the "animators" needed to orchestrate community discussions required an Ottawa staff of 80 people, and a budget that rose to the equivalent of $24 million in United States money. **********Mr. Spicer had pledged to draw a million Canadians into the discussions, but midway through their eight-month life, with half the budget gone, barely 90,000 people have been heard, and many of these have been what a columnist in the The Toronto Star described as "cranks, bigots and the occasional bewildered patriot." "You lost the war!" one English-speaking caller shrieked at a Quebec disk jockey in a radio hookup, referring to the British triumph at Quebec in 1759. Another man advocated treason trials for separatists, with hangings for those found guilty. **********Mr. Spicer has responded with suggestions that Canada can use a little hurly-burly. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/busin.print_headline: YOUR MONEY; How to Protect Family Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/05/busin.body_text: **********People who own a business and hope their sons or daughters will carry it on should visit their lawyers soon unless they have done so recently. The reason: the tax law and Deficit Reduction Act passed just before Halloween last year makes it necessary to draw up new plans for the eventual transfer of the business to the next generation with as small a tax bite as possible. **********Actually, the history of the matter goes back farther than that, and it relates to an essential problem for the taxpayers: Gift and estate taxes run as high as 55 percent, but such a sizable tax bite could cripple many small businesses. **********Before 1987 there was a way out known as an estate freeze. It generally involved recapitalizing the business and issuing preferred stock, which enabled a family to pass on a business virtually unscathed, or using a trust or a buy-sell agreement to accomplish the same goal. Congress perceived this as an abuse and tried to correct it in 1987, by passing Section 2036(c) of the revenue code. **********"Section 2036(c) took a sledgehammer to these issues," said Gerald Morlitz, director of advanced estate planning for the Cowan Financial Group in New York, "and created what are now recognized as generally unworkable concepts." **********Indeed, that law brought such loud and widespread protests that in the 1990 tax law Congress repealed it retroactively, replacing it with a complicated set of rules for passing on businesses. It is as though the 1987 law had never existed, so succession plans written to conform to that law need to be redone. But at the same time estate freezes done before that are likely to run afoul of restrictions in current law. That is why business owners need to see their legal and tax advisers to plan how to make transfers to children. Family businesses, of course, can vary widely -- from well-established to start-up, from a one-person operation going to one child to one with a maze of owners and many heirs whose involvement will vary. The varieties of circumstances make it difficult to give any general advice beyond saying the matter should be addressed. **********"Generally, the new law is more liberal than Section 2036(c) for business interests but stricter for trusts," Mr. Morlitz said. "It is always more onerous than the law prior to the enactment of Section 2036(c)." **********Sam Radin, head of the National Madison Group, which advises other lawyers on trusts and estates, said that although it would be hard to give definitive answers before the Government issued regulations and case law developed, owners of privately held businesses should review estate plans. **********One thing that is clear, Mr. Radin said, is that buy-sell agreements between family members "have to meet rather tough conditions." Theremust be a bona fide business arrangement, and the price of property transferred from one family member to another must be equal to that in an arm's-length transaction with an unrelated person. **********Still, the new law also presents opportunities, provided care is taken to avoid its pitfalls, said Ross W. Nager of Houston, director of family wealth planning for Arthur Andersen & Company. **********For example, he said, the new law "allows the transfer of equity to children while parents retain control," which is frequently more desirable than an abrupt change. "Minority and marketability discounts are allowed and can substantially decrease the gift value," he said. **********It can also permit the consolidation of family wealth for management purposes, Mr. Nager said. And it permits a reverse freeze, which is a transfer of a preferred interest while retaining the junior interest through common stock. **********"If carefully structured, the preferred interest can provide a relatively high rate of return, possibly 16 to 18 percent, and still have a low gift-tax value due to lack of marketability and minority discounts," he said. "The result is an investment for the children with a rate of return which may actually 'pull' value away from the parents' junior interest over time." **********This could be helpful in funding a life insurance trust or a child's home purchase or reducing the parents' estate over time, he said. **********Also, Mr. Nager noted, the classic freeze is now explicitly permitted, and this can be useful in a start-up business or when the parents need dividends for retirement income, but problems could result if the parents' preferred rate of return is higher than the equity's appreciation rate. **********Indeed, there are so many pitfalls and permutations that it is imperative that business owners get expert, individual advice, lest a big, unexpected tax liability arise. The success of the next generation in the business could depend on it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/busin.main_headline: White House May Finish B.C.C.I. Inquiry Soon
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/busin.print_headline: White House May Finish B.C.C.I. Inquiry Soon
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/01/busin.body_text: **********The White House counsel, C. Boyden Gray, hopes to complete this week a review of the actions of a former White House aide who represented a key figure in the criminal investigation of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, an Administration official said today. **********The White House has been under pressure from members of Congress to conduct the review after the aide, Edward M. Rogers Jr., a former assistant to John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, announced that he had canceled his firm's $600,000 contract with Sheik Kamal Adham. **********Mr. Gray has been reviewing White House records, including phone logs, to determine whether there was any evidence that Mr. Rogers had improperly used his White House connections on behalf of Mr. Adham, the official said, adding that Mr. Gray has not yet drafted a report. **********But he said Mr. Gray hoped to do so within a few days, possibly by the end of the week. The official denied that the White House had been slow to complete the internal review out of concerns for how Mr. Rogers's contract with Mr. Adham, the former head of Saudi intelligence, might reflect on Mr. Sununu or on the President. **********The Justice Department said on Wednesday that it would not begin any criminal investigation of the contract until the White House internal review was completed. **********Last Friday, Mr. Bush sharply broke with Mr. Rogers in an unusually public way at a White House news conference, and Mr. Rogers subsequently canceled his contract, denying that he had done anything wrong but acknowledging that he had been mistaken in thinking his contract would not prompt controversy. **********White House officials have said Mr. Rogers never influenced other Bush aides on behalf of Mr. Adham. **********Mr. Rogers left the White House in August after serving as an aide to Mr. Sununu. He had previously worked as a political operative for Lee Atwater, the late Republican Party chairman. Letter From Schumer **********Mr. Gray began his review of Mr. Rogers's actions after Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, wrote to the President last week saying he was "disturbed to learn" of Mr. Rogers's contract with Mr. Adham, who is under investigation in connection with B.C.C.I.'s ownership of the First American Bank in Washington. **********Mr. Schumer also raised questions about whether Mr. Rogers might have been privy to information available to Mr. Sununu through the White House's monitoring of the B.C.C.I. investigation by the Government and members of Congress. **********Mr. Schumer's office said today that the Representative had not yet been contacted by Mr. Gray's office and declined comment on the course of the White House investigation. An aide to Mr. Schumer said, however, that Mr. Schumer wanted the White House to review telephone logs before Mr. Rogers left as well as calls made since.

FORUM;
Level the Playing Field for U.S. Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/10/busin.print_headline:
FORUM;
Level the Playing Field for U.S. Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/10/busin.body_text: **********Last month, David C. Mulford, a key Treasury official, accused Japan of uncompetitive practices in financial markets. But Japan is hardly the only nation with trade impediments, and financial markets are not the only arena where unfairness exists. China, Korea, Brazil, France -- to name a few -- also block free trade. It's time to change the way we handle this. **********Foreign companies have access to American markets, thanks to American laws. American producers of goods and services must have fair access to markets at home and abroad. **********Congress should enact legislation permitting American producers to institute an unfair-access action against their foreign competitors in the United States. Such a law would target the foreign manufacturer on the grounds that it had been party to -- or benefited from -- the American producer's inability to penetrate the foreign competitor's home market while the foreign company could operate freely in the United States. **********Assume, that a Nikon camera, a Japanese product, sells for $200 in Japan and about $200 in the United States. One can then assume that a distribution system for cameras exists in Japan and that Nikon has fair access to American markets. **********Now if a Polaroid camera, an American product, is sold for $100 in the United States but is barely available in Japan for less than $300, then action against Nikon or its American interests -- subsidiaries, agents or distributors -- can be taken. The reasoning: Polaroid has been denied fair access to camera distribution systems in Japan and Nikon benefited from and/or possibly caused Polaroid's inability to gain fair access in Japan. **********There is precedent for this sort of action in American laws governing the dumping of foreign goods in American markets. Antidumping laws provide guidelines to determine if foreign goods or services are being sold at lower prices in the United States than in the producers' home market. Penalties are assessed against the importer of record, and despite some unfairness in this practice, the law has encouraged pricing policies that are not predatory. **********With antidumping statutes as a guide, an unfair markets access law could be crafted to help pry open foreign markets by penalizing overseas companies that benefit from closed markets -- and our open ones. With such a law, American manufacturers would gain better access to foreign markets, America's position in trade talks would be bolstered and American producers would have their interests looked after according to the merits of each case. Unfair trading practices hurt many businesses, but generally only influential corporations and trade groups engage government attention. A fair-market access law would level the playing field for all American companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/14/world.body_text: **********The last of the once-isolated Himalayan Buddhist kingdoms is fighting for survival, victim of a South Asian population explosion that is changing demography on the roof of the world. **********Over the last six months, a campaign of violence and terror by small bands of ethnic Nepalese guerrillas in southern Bhutan, most of them Hindus based in India, has shattered the peace of this small mountainous nation. **********The militants' campaign is couched in the language of democracy and minority rights, but the goal of the movement is free access to the underpopulated forests and valleys of Bhutan for those of Nepalese origin. **********While there are about 600,000 Bhutanese, there are 32 million people of Nepalese extraction in overpopulated Nepal and India. Many prefer to be called Gurkhas, and they are heirs of a warrior clan who dream of a Gurkhaland stretching across the Himalayan foothills. The King Is a Modern Man **********Bhutan, now ruled by a modernizing King, Jigme Singye Wangchuck, had for 1,300 years of independence been the land of the Bhutia people, a group similar to Tibetans in language, culture and religion. Bhutanese say that over the last decade, illegal immigration across an unprotectable border with India has reduced the northern Bhutias to a fast-dwindling majority that is now about 60 percent. **********"If this continues, we are done for," Foreign Minister Dawa Tsering said. **********Bhutan's predicament raises questions about the rights of small, distinctive cultures to protect themselves by closing borders and introducing regulations on national dress and language. **********The Bhutanese see that as the other side of the more common separatist demand heard from Eastern Europe to Kashmir. **********Half a century ago, Bhutan was not alone among the Himalayan Buddhist states. There was Tibet, where Buddhist teachers known as lamas dominated society and often government. There was Sikkim and Ladakh. **********Tibet, crushed by Beijing in 1959 and absorbed into China as a region, is being remade by Han Chinese. Ladakh and Sikkim have been absorbed by India. In the forefront of Bhutanese concern is the fate of the Sikkimese, against whose ruler New Delhi plotted until he was finally overthrown in 1975 with the help of disaffected subjects, most of them also ethnic Nepalese. **********The King has personally taken charge of Bhutan's national defense and efforts to counter rebel assertions of human-rights abuses. He says he is prepared to abdicate if he cannot end the insurrection peacefully. **********"I have little to lose when what is at stake is the survival of the Bhutanese people," he said in an interview at Tashichleo Dzong, the monastery-fortress that is the center of religion and Government in Bhutan. Symbol of Bhutanese Culture **********The 35-year-old ruler had just returned from the south, where dozens of Government properties have been blown up or burned, bridges destroyed, and buses and trucks hijacked. **********At least 38 policemen or soldiers have been killed or wounded, the King said, and 168 people kidnapped for ransoms as high as $30,000. **********Because the King is the symbol of Bhutan's culture, the Nepalese make monarchy the focus of their movement, along with the regulations imposed on all Bhutanese citizens in 1988 requiring the wearing of national dress. **********The King, dressed in an embroidered silk kho, the national costume, said tiny, landlocked Bhutan is neither an economic nor military power, "so the only factor we can fall back on, the only factor which can strengthen Bhutan's sovereignty and security is our identity, our different identity. We are really the last bastion of Himalayan Buddhism." **********Bhutan's per-capita income shot up to nearly $400 last year, higher than in India, Nepal and Bangladesh. **********"We have free education and health care, and plenty of land," the King said, adding: "The whole of Bhutan has become fertile ground for economic refugees. It has become the promised land." **********The nearby Indian hill stations of Darjeeling and Kalimpong are controlled by Gurkha movements, the largest of which is the Gurkha National Liberation Front. Leaders of Bhutanese movements, including the Bhutanese People's Party and the Bhutanese Students' Union, operate from that region. To those people, the ethnic Bhutias are the regional minority. **********The militants have benefited from the backing of political parties to the left of the Communists in the Indian state of West Bengal and in Nepal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/busin.main_headline: Surge in Dollar Surprises Some, Worries Others
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/busin.print_headline: Surge in Dollar Surprises Some, Worries Others
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/busin.body_text: **********The dollar is back from its recent depths, buoyed by allied successes in the Persian Gulf and hopes for an economic rebound at home. The sudden rally has come as a surprise to currency traders, confounded some forecasters and begun to worry Government finance officials because of its potential impact on exports. **********In just seven weeks the dollar has leaped 17.9 percent against the German mark and nearly as much against other currencies, ending a 17-month downturn that brought it to historic lows against the mark and the Swiss franc and near record lows against the Japanese yen. **********After hitting bottom at 1.4475 marks on Feb. 11, the dollar surged on the war news, stirrings of economic life in the United States and hopes for falling interest rates abroad. Yesterday the dollar closed at 1.7065 marks. **********"It's incredible, isn't it?" said Liliana Nealon, vice president at Union Bank of Switzerland, noting that the dollar has jumped 3.6 percent just since Friday. "I really think the market is looking back and saying, 'Wow.' " **********For the world economy, the dollar rally is a mixed blessing, which is why the response from the United States and its economic partners has been relatively muted so far. **********It is an immediate boon for American tourists, who had clearly been suffering from sticker shock on visits to Paris, London, Rome and Berlin, but whose dollars now go further in all those places. It can also ease some inflationary pressure by making imports cheaper. **********The stronger dollar and the weaker mark are also welcome news to many Europeans. The shift has enabled countries in the European Monetary System, like France, Spain, and Britain, to lower interest rates to counter slowdowns or recessions. Before the dollar rally, lowering interest rates might have weakened the franc, the peseta and the pound and pushed them out of their fixed trading ranges within the monetary system. But the fall of the mark, the central currency in the system, has widened the room for maneuvering. **********For American exporters and manufacturers, however, the stronger dollar could make competition abroad and at home more difficult, as American exports become more expensive and foreign imports cheaper. But for this impact to be felt, the dollar would have to remain at these higher levels for some time. **********"I don't think it is a fluke," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist for Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. "It hasn't run its course, but it is bound to slow down." Mr. Kudlow had been expecting the dollar to strengthen, but the move has been so quick that many other forecasters, like Michael R. Rosenberg, manager of international fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch, have sought to catch the wave by quickly revamping their forecasts that the dollar would stay low. **********The rally has brought the dollar back to its levels of a year ago. But at 1.7065 marks to the dollar yesterday, it is still well below the average level of 1.88 in 1988 and the highs of more than 2 marks hit in the late 1980's. And it is still far below its all-time high of 3.475 marks in February 1985. **********For American companies with large sales abroad, profits will be hurt when the foreign earnings are converted into dollars. But the reverse will be true for Japanese and, especially, European companies that had been hit hard by a weak dollar. **********Some corporations seemed to have been caught unprepared. Mrs. Nealon said she has corporate customers who did not expect the dollar to rise much beyond a brief victory rally after the war. Now they hope to buy dollars when the value dips, only to find that the dollar just keeps rising, forcing them to pay even more. Affecting the Trade Deficit **********A stronger dollar could also slow or even eventually end the decline in the American merchandise trade deficit, which dropped to $100 billion last year. Some economists have advocated an even lower dollar to help reduce this troublesome deficit. But others, like Mr. Kudlow, contend that the deficit can continue to fall, even if a little more slowly, with the dollar at these levels. They say that American manufacturers are more competitive than they were a few years ago and that a modest economic recovery should not create a consumer boom that would cause a surge in imports and a rise in the trade deficit. **********The response by officials in the Group of Seven, composed of the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, was a little confusing yesterday but did not indicate strong opposition to having the dollar at present levels. **********In Bonn, Theo Waigel, the Finance Minister, said the United States and Germany could live with the current levels of the dollar. His comments, coming on his return from a meeting with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady on Monday, were taken by traders as clearance to push the dollar higher, and it shot up, passing 1.70 marks and closing at 1.7065, its highest level since March 27, 1990. **********In Washington, David C. Mulford, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, told reporters: "We are concerned about the rapidity of the rise. We are not seeking a stronger dollar." But he also said that Mr. Waigel's comment was accurate at the time of the meeting with Mr. Baker, which was Monday when the dollar closed in New York at 1.6840 marks. **********The dollar's surge started after it hit its low of 1.4475 marks on Feb. 11 in New York trading. At first many traders said the rally would be just a short-lived response to what was shaping up as a quick and easy victory in the war against Iraq. But the rally was pushed further on expectations of a rebound soon from the American recession and a slowing of economies abroad. **********Then in early March, the German Government said it would raise taxes to help pay for modernizing eastern Germany. By raising taxes, the Government would have to borrow less, making it suddenly more likely that German interest rates, which set the tone for Europe, would not rise further and even begin to decline. **********Foreign exchange traders concluded that interest rates would fall abroad, while remaining stable in the United States or falling only slightly. Such a narrowing of the interest-rate differential between dollars and others currencies makes the dollar more attractive to foreigners. **********One immediate effect of the dollar's rise is on the contributions from Germany and Japan to pay for the costs of the war. A report from Bonn yesterday said the German Government agreed to pay more marks to make up for the appreciation of the dollar. **********The Japanese have refused so far to cover the loss from the dollar rally. They made their pledge in yen but the United States wants it counted in dollars.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/busin.body_text: **********T. Boone Pickens has withdrawn a lawsuit against the Koito Manufacturing Company that had contended that the Japanese maker of auto parts maintained an illegal business relationship with the Toyota Motor Corporation, a spokesman for the Texas oilman said today. **********The decision was made when Mr. Pickens said in April that he would sell his 26.4 percent stake in Koito and abandon his two-year fight for a seat on the company's board, said the spokesman, who asked not to be named. Last month, Mr. Pickens sold his stake to Kitaro Watanabe, the Japanese stock speculator from whom he bought the shares in 1989. **********The spokesman added that the suit had been dropped because "we believed Japanese courts were working with Koito to deny us access to financial information." **********News of Mr. Pickens's decision was first disclosed by the Kyodo News Service in Tokyo. **********Mr. Pickens filed the suit last year with the Tokyo District Court, demanding access to Koito's accounts. The suit was aimed at shedding light on what he contended was Koito's illegal business relationship with Toyota. **********Koito is affiliated with Toyota in a cross-ownership relationship that is common in Japan. Mr. Pickens and other American investors say the system creates cozy business relationships that harm other stockholders. **********Mr. Pickens charged that Japan's industry was based on exclusionary business practices that benefited big corporations at the expense of smaller competitors and consumers. **********He also has said his failure to obtain a board set llustrated Japanese bias against foreign investors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/busin.main_headline: Rating Cut Is Expected For Insurer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/busin.print_headline: Rating Cut Is Expected For Insurer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/busin.body_text: **********The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, which is experiencing growing problems with its investments in commercial real estate, is expected to lose its top rating today from a leading rater of insurance companies. **********In addition, Mutual Benefit is expected to announce on Monday that it will lay off about 450 of the 1,500 people employed at its headquarters in Newark. Mutual Benefit is the nation's 18th-largest life insurer, with more than $13 billion in assets and 400,000 individual policyholders nationwide. **********The rating agency A. M. Best Company said on Wednesday that it would have an important announcement today about Mutual Benefit. While it is conceivable that A. M. Best could affirm its A-plus rating on the company's ability to pay claims, A. M. Best, which specializes in rating insurance companies, normally does not issue news releases except to change its ratings on the claims-paying ability of insurers. **********Two other top rating agencies, Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service, have lowered their ratings on Mutual Benefit, making it unlikely that A. M. Best would continue to give the insurer its top rating. **********The ratings of insurance companies are crucial to both policyholders and agents. Policyholders view them as a guide to the safety of insurers, and agents prefer to sell policies of companies that are highly rated. **********If Best does lower its rating, it will be because of Mutual Benefit's growing problems with commercial real estate. At the end of 1990, Mutual Benefit had roughly $5 billion, or approximately 40 percent of its $13 billion in assets, invested in commercial mortgages, primarily loans to developers of office buildings, shopping centers and apartment complexes. About 10 percent of those loans are delinquent or have resulted in foreclosure. **********Mutual Benefit is just one of several large insurers experiencing difficulties from investments. The Equitable Life Assurance Society and the Travelers Corporation also suffer from troubled real estate investments. U.S.F.& G., First Capital Life and Executive Life have had large losses on their holdings of high-risk "junk bonds." 3 Areas of Concern **********Insurance analysts are concerned about Mutual Benefit on three fronts: ***********Mutual Benefit's exposure to commercial real estate, a particularly troubled business of late, is well above the industry average. Many large life insurers focus on stocks and bonds. ***********Many industry analysts expect continued declines in the value of commercial properties. ***********Mutual Benefit's "capital and surplus," which is essentially its cushion to cover future losses, has dropped to $520 million. If the value of Mutual Benefit's $5 billion mortgage portfolio fell another 10 percent, the company would be insolvent. **********Despite those concerns, Tim Clark, an analyst at Standard & Poor's, asserts that right now "we are still dealing with a company that is fundamentally sound and not close to failure." **********But Mutual Benefit is badly in need of capital to reduce its vulnerability to future losses. Toward that end, it recently entered into "strategic alliance" talks with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. Those talks collapsed when the two companies could not agree on terms. **********Mutual Benefit has also announced that it will spin off its highly profitable group insurance business, based in Kansas City, Mo., and will sell shares in that unit to outsiders. An offering memorandum describing Mututal Benefit's group insurance operations is being circulated among institutional investors. **********The headquarters operation in Newark houses some of the operations for Mutual Benefit's individual life insurance business, where profits have slipped in recent years as it has been forced to pay ever-higher rates of return to policyholders. **********The exact number of Mutual Benefit employees to be dismissed will not be announced publicly until Monday. Marianne Green, a Mutual Benefit spokeswoman, said the cuts would be "major." The company has not disputed recent reports in New Jersey newspapers that as many as 40 percent of the 1,500 employees could lose their jobs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/busin.body_text: **********A subcontractor on the Patriot missile, now used to defend Israel and Saudi Arabia against Iraqi Scud missiles, was given a two-year prison sentence today for overbilling the Government more than $540,000. **********United States District Judge Roland S. W. Lew also ordered Michael M. Zarachoff, the 45-year-old president and owner of Temcom Inc., to serve five years' probation and to pay back taxes plus interest and penalties. **********The Burbank company's controller, Nanci Plath, 42, was sentenced to pay a $10,000 fine and spend five years on probation. **********Until the overbilling fraud was discovered in 1986 by Raytheon, the Patriot missile system's main contractor, Temcom made inch-long temperature sensors used in both the Patriot's antiaircraft and anti-missile versions. **********Mr. Zarachoff and Ms. Plath pleaded guilty on Dec. 4 to military fraud charges. **********The fraud was discovered by auditors at Raytheon, which was not implicated in any wrongdoing. The company had paid Temcom $193 for each sensor but later obtained them for $59 each after switching to another subcontractor, prosecutors said. The sensors monitor the temperature of electronic components in the missiles. **********An assistant United States attorney, Steven Madison, said Mr. Zarachoff and Ms. Plath had set up a shell company called R-Tube, which billed Temcom for goods and services that never were provided. The fake costs were passed on to Raytheon and ultimately the Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.body_text: **********Britain's gross domestic product fell six-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter from the previous three-month period, the Government said today. It was the third straight drop in Britain's output of goods and services, extending the country's recession. Two consecutive quarterly declines officially indicate a recession. The seasonally adjusted production measure was down 2.5 percent from a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Goodyear to Trim 600 Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/12/busin.body_text: **********The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, which is working to overcome low demand and intense price competition, said yesterday that it would lay off up to 600 workers at two American plants and one in Canada. **********The company said the layoffs were planned before the election last week of Stanley C. Gault as the new chairman and chief executive. Mr. Gault, who replaced Tom H. Barrett, who resigned after two years as chairman, has said he plans to cut costs. **********"The decision on these layoffs was made in May, and Mr. Gault was under the impression that we had announced them already," Sue Zajac, a Goodyear spokeswoman, said yesterday. She added that employees would be recalled depending on market conditions. **********The layoffs, all at plants that make passenger-car tires, will affect about 300 workers in Gadsden, Ala.; 230 to 270 in Union City, Tenn., and about 30 in Valleyfield, Quebec. They are in addition to previously planned production cuts at plants in Virginia, Kansas and Kentucky. **********The cuts are the latest in a series that will trim Goodyear's worldwide work force to 100,000 by next year, from the current 103,000 and 119,000 four years ago. **********"The layoffs appear to be helping the administrative expenses as a percentage of sales," said Harry W. Millis, a tire analyst in Cleveland. "It takes about a year for the reductions to be felt. They have probably cut about 100 percent of the people they can do without. If they cut any more, they will probably cut into muscle." **********Goodyear, based in Akron, Ohio, has not been alone in reducing its work force. General Tire Inc., owned by Continental A.G. of Germany; the Uniroyal-Goodrich Tire Company, a unit of Groupe Michelin of France, and Bridgestone/Firestone Inc., owned by the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan, have also made cuts. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Goodyear's stock closed down $1.125, to $32.125.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.main_headline: Bush Writes to College Papers In Appeal for Support on Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Bush Writes to College Papers In Appeal for Support on Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.body_text: **********In a letter distributed to college newspapers across the nation, President Bush has appealed for support for a possible war in the Persian Gulf, saying he might have to use force "to stand up for human life." **********The letter, sent to 460 colleges and universities this week and released by the White House today, was part of an effort to gain popular backing for Mr. Bush's gulf policy at a time when diplomatic efforts seem to have stalled and Congress is debating whether to authorize the President to use force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. **********In the past week, Mr. Bush has broadcast a nationwide radio appeal, distributed a videotaped address abroad to American partners in the coalition against Iraq and lobbied heavily among members of Congress for passage of a resolution giving him unequivocal support to use military force if necessary. Americans Urged to Leave Iraq **********At the same time, the White House has been making its final preparations for the possibility of war. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today that the United States was urging all American citizens, including journalists, to leave Iraq before the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for Baghdad's army to withdraw from Kuwait or face military force. **********Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Bush had received, but not yet acted on, a recommendation by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that the tours of duty of the reservists called up for the gulf operation be extended to two years from the current limit of 180 days. Under such an action, which the President seemed certain to approve, Mr. Cheney would have the authority to call up to 1 million reservists. But he said on Wednesday that he did not intend to call that many to active duty. **********Mr. Bush's letter sought to paint the crisis in the gulf in stark terms -- "black and white" and a choice of "good versus evil." **********It spoke of "atrocities" committed by Iraqi troops against Kuwaiti citizens and argued that the United States was under a "moral obligation" to "look this international terrorist in the eye and say: no concessions." 'Values Worth Fighting For' **********"There are times in life when we confront values worth fighting for," Mr. Bush said. "This is one such time." **********The White House said it did not know how many college newspapers planned to publish Mr. Bush's letter, which was distributed by mail and by fax. **********A random survey of large colleges and universities indicated that student newspapers at some institutions, like Northwestern University and Harvard University, have published news articles about the letter or planned to do so. **********Some college newspapers ran their own commentary with the letter. The Daily of the University of Washington, for example, printed an unflattering cartoon of Mr. Bush alongside the article that suggested, in the words of Hideki Tomeoka, the associate editor, that Mr. Bush's words were "rather silly." **********But others, like The Daily at Stanford University and The Daily at the University of Colorado, planned to print Mr. Bush's comments as a letter to the editor or as an opinion column on their Op-Ed pages. **********"I'm eagerly awaiting it," said Clint Talbot, editor of The Colorado Daily. "I have probably 20 to 30 Op-Ed pieces or letters about the gulf waiting to run. Interest is high and I'm sure everybody would like to see something from the President himself in our newspaper."
