https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/05/busin.body_text: **********The number of Americans applying for unemployment insurance jumped in late March to 543,000, the highest level since January 1983, the Labor Department said yesterday. The report suggested that the economy was still mired in recession. **********After the figures were released, interest rates on Treasury securities fell, as they often do on publication of statistics that indicate weakness in the economy. The data also suggested that the unemployment rate for March, to be announced by the Labor Department today, will show a rise from February's 6.5 percent level. **********But the sharp increase in initial unemployment claims for the week ended March 23 -- that is, applications for unemployment pay filed by newly laid-off workers -- ran counter to other recent data indicating that the recession was past its lowest point and that a recovery was beginning. Rising home sales and a rebound in consumer confidence with the end of the Persian Gulf war were among the recent optimistic reports. **********The conflicting data produced conflicting assessments. David Mullins, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, for example, said the latest unemployment insurance claims simply confirmed what the nation already knew -- "employment is weak and will continue to be weak, even after we start an upturn." He added, "The figures were not unexpected." **********Mr. Mullins's remarks seemed to suggest that even if the Labor Department's employment report was very negative, the Federal Reserve would not respond by lowering short-term interest rates another notch to stimulate economic activity. The Fed lowered rates on March 8, the same day the Labor Department announced that the unemployment rate rose to 6.5 percent in February from 6.3 percent in January and 208,000 private-sector jobs disappeared. **********The Labor Department itself was pessimistic about the initial claims level that it announced yesterday. "If you look back over the figures for initial claims in recent weeks, you don't discover a lot of upturn in the economy," said Thomas Plewes, an associate commissioner in the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. **********The 543,000 initial claims, seasonally adjusted, represented a rise of 33,000 from the 516,000 claims in the week ended March 16. Although the norm is for claims to fall in the spring when construction and other activities increase, Mr. Plewes said, initial claims have been moving gradually upward instead. **********The last time initial claims were this high was in the week ended Jan. 8, 1983, when they reached 546,000. The nation was then beginning a recovery, and the number of initial claims was moving downward, not upward as it is today. **********"What happens in the spring is that claims decline, but this spring initial claims are growing," Mr. Plewes said. **********Initial claims for most of March averaged 200,000 a year more than they did in March 1990, the Labor Department said, and the total number of people receiving unemployment insurance rose by one million over a one-year period to 3,475,000 in mid-March. **********Still, the relationship between unemployment insurance figures and total unemployment is not as close as it once was because state regulations governing unemployment insurance have tightened, making fewer unemployed people eligible for jobless pay. **********During the 1974-75 recession, for example, 67 percent of the nation's total unemployed people were eligible for unemployment insurance, compared with 45 percent in the 1981-82 recession and roughly the same percentage today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/04/busin.main_headline: Writers' Loyalties Are Split When Their Editors Depart
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/04/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: PUBLISHING; Writers' Loyalties Are Split When Their Editors Depart
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/04/busin.body_text: **********When editors or executives leave publishing houses, they take their Rolodexes and their paperweights -- but do they take their authors? **********Writers, after all, sign contracts not with editors, nor even with heads of publishing houses, but with the houses themselves. Still, they develop relationships with people, not institutions. Often when editors are recruited, it is not just for their talents but for the authors who may follow. **********Publishing houses recognize that they do not operate an assembly-line business. Changing a factory foreman may change the spirit of a shop but have little effect on the product. An editor, however, can have a profound impact on a book. So when an editor or editing publisher leaves, a house has to decide whether to give up an author and a book it signed up, or fight to keep them. **********The phenomenon of migrating editors and publishers has been growing over the last few years, as publishing houses restructure to meet changing conditions and more houses are taken over by media conglomerates. **********Just last week, the issue exploded when writers learned that James H. Silberman would be leaving Summit Books, which he helped to found as a division of Simon & Schuster in 1976. **********Writers and agents have been calling Simon & Schuster to get out of their contracts or to find out what will happen to their books. Meanwhile, the house has been trying to reassure the anxious authors. **********Mr. Silberman, who has not announced his future plans, joins a long list of editors and publishing executives who have migrated this year, including Michael and Cornelia Bessie, who moved their imprint from HarperCollins to Pantheon, and Henry Ferris, who is leaving Houghton Mifflin for Times Books, an imprint of Random House. **********At 30 years old, Mr. Ferris is on his way to his third job in publishing. He went from Bantam to Houghton Mifflin, where he developed a reputation for finding and cultivating young writers, particularly journalists. Last week, Times Books said he would be moving there as a senior editor. **********When he left Bantam, the company let two authors who worked with him follow him, but they refused to let two others go. Houghton Mifflin, Mr. Ferris said, "has been very gentlemanly about letting me take authors with me, and Times Books has been very welcoming in wanting these authors to come along." **********Deciding who has custody of authors highlights a general problem that publishing houses frequently face when the creative and the financial sides of their business come into conflict. One publisher, who spoke on condition of anonymity, noted that losing a top author could shake a house's balance sheet. **********If authors have already written best sellers, or there are high hopes that they will, publishing houses generally make a concerted effort to persuade them to stay. Typically, they offer such writers the opportunity to choose anyone in the company to edit their books, hint at -- or agree to -- contracts for future books or promise hefty publicity campaigns. **********Such promises were not enough to persuade either Margaret Atwood or Pat Conroy to stay at Houghton Mifflin when their publisher, Nan Talese, left to start her own imprint at Doubleday a few years ago. **********When Dan Frank left Viking as editor in chief last December, one of the writers who followed him to Pantheon was James Gleick, author of the best-selling book "Chaos," who was three years into a contract with Viking to write a biography of Richard Feynman, the physicist. **********But Mr. Gleick had a clause in his contract that allowed him to leave Viking if Mr. Frank did. Publishers are reluctant to agree to such "editor out" clauses and usually reserve them for best-selling authors. **********Having such a clause is often an unnecessary insurance policy, since most publishing houses eventually let writers leave with their editors or publishers if a book is not in production. The theory is that a house cannot force someone to write a book for it any more than one can force someone to fall in love. **********The clause cuts through the initial hemming and hawing that publishers go through when confronted by a writer who wants to follow a departing editor. In most cases, said Martin Garbus, a lawyer involved in the publishing industry, a house can get back any advance it has paid on a book contract, plus interest. **********Lately, however, Mr. Garbus has been fighting a trend in which publishers demand a portion of the book's eventual profits. **********Of course, there are times when a publisher is relieved when an author asks to follow an editor and is happy simply to get back the advance. **********Sometimes, publishing houses can be unusually gracious. When Jonathan Galassi left Random House Adult Trade for Farrar, Straus & Giroux a few years ago, Random House let him take a book that had already been listed in its catalogue, "That Night," by Alice McDermott. **********There are many cases, however, in which publishing houses hold writers to their contracts against their will. **********"It can be a very difficult situation if a publishing house, for public relations purposes, wants to take a stand and prove that everything is continuing as before and the writers are part of the house," said Charlotte Sheedy, a literary agent in New York. **********Ms. Sheedy said some of her clients had trouble finishing their books when publishers refused to let them follow an editor who left. "Twice, when the publishers wouldn't let the writers go, the writers couldn't go on working," she said. **********Ann Roiphe wrote three novels with Mr. Silberman at Summit, including her latest, "The Pursuit of Happiness." When she learned of his departure, she said she was distraught and feared that, "I will never have an editor who'll work with my words, my meaning, my text, as Jim did." She said she could not decide what she would do until Mr. Silberman decided what he would do. **********Mr. Gleick said that despite his attachment to Mr. Frank, his commitment to his project was stronger. **********"My interest in Dan is not emotional; it's cold blooded," he said. "Dan's a good editor. He cares, and he did a fine job on my last book. I'm hoping for the same outcome."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.main_headline: Stocks Drop Amid Worry on Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.print_headline: Stocks Drop Amid Worry on Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices fell yesterday in a session dominated by technical trading. Also pulling prices down were a falling bond market and a report on inflation interpreted on Wall Street as less than encouraging. **********The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 3.96 points, to 2,948.27, finishing the week with a loss of 6.93. Volume was heavy, with 237.7 million shares traded, compared with 231 million shares on Thursday. The broad market was weak, with 1,028 stocks declining and only 561 advancing. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks closed up 0.09 point, to 373.59. **********At 3:30, heavy buying pressure developed from the unwinding of arbitrage positions in futures indexes, repeating a pattern of the morning, traders said. The late imbalance of orders from buy programs helped erase a healthy deficit for the blue chips -- down 25 points at one time -- but late institutional selling kept the Dow average in the minus column, traders said.   'Triple Witching Hour' **********Activity centered on the "triple witching hour," involving stock index and options and futures expirations, created turbulence that kept some investors out of the market and distorted market patterns. **********But it was clear that a report on producer prices for February was intrepreted by traders as a bad one for inflation prospects. Prices fell six-tenths of a percent, but the core report, minus volatile food and energy prices, was up four-tenths of a percent. **********Data on industrial production and plant capacity utilizations indicated the economy was still soft and the prospect of continued recession weighed on traders. The capacity utilization rate, at 79.1 percent, was down eight-tenths of a percentage point in February, while industrial production for February declined eight-tenths of a percent. **********But traders said that the economic news did not provide enough cloudy weather to dispel the expectation that the Dow would soon pass 3,000.  'On the Defensive' **********Thursday's and yesterday's performance, with recent market leaders like technology and health-care stocks flagging, "puts the market, on a short-term basis, back on the defensive," said Peter G. Grennan senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers. **********But he still says the market's all-time closing high of 2999.75, reached in July, will soon be breached. "There's no sound fundamental reason why it shouldn't close above 3,000," Mr. Grennan said. "It's psychological at this point." **********Warner-Lambert shares tumbled 3 7/8, to 74 3/8, on remarks attributed by Reuters to a Food and Drug Adminstration statistician that the company's new Alzheimer's treatment had no benefit. The F.D.A. has not yet decided whether to approve the drug. **********Some other health-care stocks showed weakness. U.S. Surgical fell 4 1/8, to 102 3/8. Medtronic dropped 4, to 110 3/4.   Declines in Technology **********Among declining technology stocks, I.B.M. fell 1 1/2, to 126 5/8, and Digital Equipment lost 2 1/4, to 74 3/4. **********GTE, the third-most-active stock, fell 3/4, to 32 3/4, after a Smith Barney analyst, Charles Schelke, downgraded his rating to a hold from a buy. **********Merrill Lynch rose 1 5/8, to 32 1/4, apparently on the strength of a report by Guy Moszkowski of Sanford C. Bernstein, who raised his 1991 earnings estimate on the brokerage firm. **********Bandag, a maker of tire retreading equipment, plunged 7 1/2, to 90. It said first-quarter earnings would be 10 to 15 percent below the $1.08 a share earned in the first quarter of 1990. **********Lands' End, the clothing mail order company, rose 1 5/8,, to 21 1/2, even though it said Thursday that its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Jan. 31, was hurt by shortages in inventory that prevented it from converting demand into sales.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/11/busin.body_text: **********California regulators placed sharp operating restrictions on the First Capital Life Insurance Company today. It was the second time in a month they have moved against a large insurer burdened with a deteriorating portfolio of high-risk "junk bonds." **********Faced with a flood of customers seeking to cash in their policies after reports of the company's financial problems, the California Insurance Department ordered a freeze on policy withdrawals and loans and barred the insurer from issuing new policies or transferring funds to its parent, the First Capital Holdings Corporation of Los Angeles. **********As a result of the action by the California regulator, Shearson Lehman Brothers, which owns 28 percent of First Capital Holdings, said that it planned to take a $144 million pretax charge against its second-quarter earnings. Shearson is the brokerage subsidiary of the American Express Company.  'Hazardous Condition' Found **********The heavy volume of policy surrenders At First Capital Life had the same effect that a run has on a bank, diminishing the company's supply of cash and endangering its ability to meet future obligations. First Capital Life has 190,000 customers in 49 states. Regulators said the company would continue to pay all death benefits and make regular payments to holders of annuities. **********California regulators said policy surrenders and loans had increased steadily from $10 million a day last week to $100 million on Thursday alone. **********"I have issued a cease-and-desist order to put a halt to the wave of policy surrenders and loan requests that were threatening the long-term viability of the insurance company," said John Garamendi, the California Insurance Commissioner. "On the basis of the Department of Insurance's financial examination I have concluded that First Capital Life is in a hazardous condition." **********The company's troubles follow similar ones at the Executive Life Insurance Company, which was seized by California regulators on April 11 after a rapid deterioration in the value of the junk bond portfolio purchased by its parent, the First Executive Corporation of Los Angeles. **********First Capital is generally considered to be in somewhat stronger financial condition than was Executive Life, largely because the default rate among its junk bonds has been lower than on those owned by Executive Life. First Capital Life has just over 40 percent of its $4.5 billion in assets invested in junk bonds. **********Mr. Garamendi stopped short of seizing control of First Capital, although he made clear that the regulators would be closely involved in managing the company. Regulators said seizure of First Capital Life was still possible, especially if the insurer's finances continued to deteriorate or were found to be in worse condition than now believed. **********"The action I have taken is intended to stabilize and begin the process of rehabilitating the company," Mr. Garamendi said in a statement. "It will give us the necessary time to develop a long-term strategy to return the company to financial health." **********Mr. Garamendi said he would continue efforts to sell the company's universal life insurance business, a transaction that the company said earlier this year could bring $150 million. He said he would keep trying to bring new capital into the company, including further negotations with Shearson Lehman, First Capital Holdings' largest shareholder, which this week came under intense pressure from Mr. Garamendi to inject new funds into First Capital Life. **********Shearson Lehman stopped short of rejecting the call for a capital infusion to First Capital Life but left unclear what financial aid, if any, it might be willing to provide. Neither Mr. Garamendi nor Shearson has said how much additional money would be needed to restore First Capital to health. **********"We are confident that the company has the resources to meet at least the principal payments of its policyholders," said a Shearson spokesman who asked not to be identified. Apparent Backing Off **********The Shearson spokesman also appeared to back off from the company's earlier offer to the California regulators to guarantee payments to customers who bought annuities or other First Capital products through Shearson. Such a deal "would invite an open-ended commitment, and we are in no position to make such a commitment," he said. **********Mr. Garamendi said he would try to reduce the percentage of junk bonds in First Capital's portfolio, presumably by selling them. Traders cited rumors that First Capital and First Executive were selling large quantities of investment- and lower-grade bonds as the reason for falling prices in the bond market today. **********The rumors were apparently unfounded. A spokesman for First Capital Holdings said no bonds had been sold today. **********The California action left uncertain the prospects for another subsidiary of First Capital Holdings, Fidelity Bankers Life Insurance of Virginia. Fidelity Bankers has about 37 percent of its $4 billion in assets in junk bonds. A spokesman for Virginia's Bureau of Insurance said no regulatory action had been taken against Fidelity Bankers, although examiners were monitoring the company's situation. **********First Capital said surrenders of Fidelity Bankers policies were up, but that they remained at a manageable level.  Peter Cohen a Director **********Mr. Garamendi said he would work with the president of First Capital Life, Fred A. Buck, and the outside directors of First Capital Holdings to resolve the insurer's problems. The four outside directors include several with close ties to American Express and Shearson Lehman. Among them is Peter Cohen, Shearson's former chief executive. **********Mr. Garamendi said at a news conference that the president of First Capital Holdings, Gerry R. Ginsberg, had been removed from oversight of the First Capital Life subsidiary by the board. The company's founder and chairman, Robert I. Weingarten, resigned in March after disclosing that declines in the value of the junk bond portfolio caused a fourth-quarter loss of $24.7 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/busin.main_headline: House Panel Approves Wider Bank Ownership
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/busin.print_headline: House Panel Approves Wider Bank Ownership
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/27/busin.body_text: **********The House Banking Committee agreed today to permit industrial companies like retail chains and even automobile manufacturers to own banks. **********This gave a tentative lift to the Bush Administration's plan to overhaul the nation's banking system. But the overall measure that would also let commercial banks operate across state lines, merge with investment banks and in some cases sell insurance, would have to clear many further hurdles before it could become law. **********The committee plans to try to complete work on the measure tomorrow. It then must go to the Energy and Commerce Committee, where significant opposition has developed, before being taken up by the full House of Representatives. **********In the Senate, the Banking Committee has not begun work on the measure officially. Senate committees often do not begin drafting controversial bills in public until all the important deals have been struck in private. **********Still, the slow pace in the Senate makes it increasingly unlikely that broad legislation revamping the 60-year-old banking rules will be enacted this year. A Need for Expansion **********Since the Depression, banks have been limited basically to taking deposits and making commercial loans. The Administration and its supporters maintain that in today's financial world, banks can attract sufficient capital to compete and prosper only if they are permitted to expand into other lines. **********The legislation includes what its supporters say are thick "fire walls" that would separate banking from other businesses under the same ownership. For example, insured deposits could be used only in traditional banking activities, and banks could not lend money to their commercial affiliates. **********Nonetheless, opponents contend that savvy bankers and their lawyers will find ways to breech the fire walls, and that taxpayers will be left paying for the banks' bad investments. "You're playing with fire," said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa. **********The key vote today came on a proposal by Mr. Leach to continue to prohibit ownership of banks by commercial concerns. The proposal was rejected, 32 to 20. **********There was no discernible pattern to how the lawmakers voted. Eleven Democrats and nine Republicans supported Mr. Leach; 20 Democrats and 12 Republicans opposed him. **********Some liberal Democrats, like Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, the committee chairman, and Joseph P. Kennedy 2d of Massachusetts, voted to prohibit industrial enterprises from buying banks. Others like Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn and Barney Frank of Massachusetts supported the Bush Administration, voting to permit such purchases. **********One proposal that was rejected tonight seems likely to provoke a partisan fight when the measure reaches the House floor. **********This was Mr. Schumer's amendment that would have created two categories: core banks offering insured deposits paying only a limited rate of interest and that could lend no more than 3 or 4 percent of their equity to any one borrower; and other banks operating with uninsured deposits that could pay higher rates of interest and lend as much as they wanted to any depositor. **********The proposal was rejected by a vote of 28 to 23, but Mr. Schumer vowed to offer it again to the full House. **********The Bush Administration and most Republicans opposed the idea, mainly on the grounds that it might stifle competition or cause banks to lose deposits. **********But many Democrats supported it as a way to guarantee that insured deposits were not used for risky activities like big loans to underdeveloped countries or for leveraged buyouts. That, the Democrats said, would lessen the likelihood of taxpayer bailouts. **********No other issue this year has generated so much lobbying. The meeting room was jammed with representatives from dozens of interests, the hallway outside was clogged, and proceedings were piped into another room on the floor above so lobbyists who were too late to get into the Banking Committee's room could hear what was going on. **********The ghost of the savings and loan disaster hovered over the debate today. Those who want to let banks get into other lines of business said that was the only way banks could survive and prevent another costly taxpayer bailout.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: LEBANON; ISRAELIS STRIKING P.L.O. IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/world.body_text: **********For the first time since the Persian Gulf war began, Israeli commandos ventured beyond their self-proclaimed security zone in southern Lebanon today to raid Palestinian guerrilla bases. The Government here warned that such strikes would continue unless the Lebanese Army ejected "terrorist organizations" from the region. **********Moving before dawn, the Israeli units attacked a training base of the Palestine Liberation Organization and artillery batteries in Iqlim al Toffah, a hilly district a few miles north of the Lebanese zone that Israel patrols with the help of local militia units it has trained and equipped. **********The military thrust and the warning from the Israeli Defense Ministry followed 10 days of attacks and counterattacks by the two sides, including the heaviest rocket assaults on Israeli targets in the security zone in recent years.  Link to the Gulf War **********The rocket attacks are viewed here as an extension of the gulf war, since the Palestine Liberation Organization has advertised them by saying it hopes to open a symbolic second front against Israel in support of Iraq. **********Officers in Israel's northern command said the army was now shelling and bombing Palestinian targets in southern Lebanon every night, using tanks, helicopter gunships, jets and ground troops. **********Military analysts here have speculated that the Israeli Army's fierce response to the Palestinian attacks is linked to frustration over being prevented from responding to Iraqi missile attacks on Israel. Military and political leaders here have reacted defensively to the idea that Israel may be viewed as a paper tiger because it has not retaliated. **********But Israeli strikes against Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon are not uncommon, and the military said nothing today to suggest that the fighting in Lebanon is meant to compensate for the restraint used against Iraq. Israel has traditionally responded to almost every guerrilla action to show that no attack against this nation will go unpunished. **********The strikes come when the P.L.O. has been politically weakened by its continued support of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq at the expense of most of its previous Arab sponsors. **********Hours after Israeli soldiers withdrew from Iqlim al Toffah this morning, Lebanese Government troops arrived in the region as part of their first movement into southern Lebanon since 1975. **********For years the area has been controlled by Arab guerrilla groups fighting Israel and one another. It now serves as a base for the P.L.O.'s Fatah wing, led by the organization's chairman, Yasir Arafat, and for several other guerrilla groups. **********In a communique issued by the Defense Ministry, Israel said it "expects the deployment of Lebanese Army units north and west of the security zone and in the Jezzin enclave will bring about the removal of terrorist organizations from these areas." **********The statement warned that "Israel will continue to exercise its right to self-defense if terrorist attacks are carried out against it from Lebanon." **********Some of the Lebanese troops moving into the Iqlim al Toffah district took up positions less than a mile from Israel's security zone. The troops intend to take over the Palestinian posts, but the Israeli radio reported today that the Palestinians were trying to negotiate freedom of movement so they could respond to Israeli troops.

"It was an opportunity for me to begin a financial investment...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.main_headline:
Your Own Account;
When Singles Share Real Estate
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;
When Singles Share Real Estate
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Five years ago, Mary Beth Mullen and her sister, a mother of two who had recently been divorced, decided to join forces to buy a house because neither could afford to do it on her own. **********"It was an opportunity for me to begin a financial investment in home ownership, which was very important to me," said Ms. Mullen, who is now 38. "I wasn't in the position to purchase a property on my salary unless it was very small. Together we bought something very wonderful, a late 1800's historic home in Annapolis." **********Real estate experts say that more single people are buying homes together for a variety of reasons, including the fact that many people are marrying later and that home prices are out of the reach of many singles like Ms. Mullen, who develops educational programs for the Smithsonian Institution. At this time of year, many singles also consider looking for a partner to buy a weekend or summer cottage. **********Although these deals can work out well for both parties, there are lots of pitfalls. If you do not structure the deal carefully, it can turn into a financial and emotional disaster. **********"You are entering a murky world and you may not be able to exit if you don't do things properly," said Nadine Gordon Lee, a partner at Ernst & Young in New York City. **********Two people who are not married to each other should always have a contract before they enter into a deal. It should address all aspects of running the household, taking care of maintenance, paying the bills, insuring the property and, eventually, selling it. **********"I would want to know something about the other person's financial situation, too," said David A. Tane, a real estate lawyer with Gallet Dreyer & Berkey in New York, who has handled a number of such agreements for singles. **********Proper titling of the property is an issue, too. A husband and wife typically hold title to a home as "joint tenants with rights of survivorship." If one dies, the property passes to the other. But that is not necessarily appropriate for two singles who may each want to pass the property on to his or her own heirs. Instead, title should probably be held as "tenants in common." That way, you control what happens to your share. **********That's what Ms. Mullen and her sister, an account manager at a direct-marketing firm, did. Because her sister, Barbara Cullen, had some money for a down payment and because she would be making a home for her two children, she paid two-thirds of all expenses, including mortgage, utilities, food and insurance. Ms. Mullen paid the other third. (Ownership of the house is also split that way.) They had a contract drawn up by a lawyer and set up a household account to which each woman contributed her share of the money to run the household once a month. **********The two sisters took turns handling the household account, each a year at a time. "That gave us both a better idea of what the expenses were," Ms. Mullen said. Each woman also purchased her own furnishings. They bought only one thing together: a chandelier that was designed especially for the house. Repairs came from the household account. **********Naturally, there were aggravations from time to time. "It was hard to suddenly share one bathroom again and hard for my sister to go back to living with a sibling after being married," Ms. Mullen said. "And I had to learn not to impose my feelings on the kids." But all in all, it worked out for everyone. "I thought it was a very smart thing to do with my money," Ms. Mullen said. "If I was bugged because someone squeezed the toothpaste in the middle, I got over it." **********Things haven't gone quite so smoothly for Joan Hamilton, a manager in the personal financial services group at Price Waterhouse. She and a friend bought a house in St. Louis in February 1988 for many of the same reasons. Although the two of them decided to split costs in half, they didn't think to draw up a contract at the time. **********Their informal agreement has worked for some things. "I'll buy groceries one week and she'll buy the next week," says Ms. Hamilton, 26. But when the house needed major repairs, like a new roof, the friends ran into a snag. They hadn't provided for how decisions would be made and they found they couldn't agree. They got three estimates, with a range of $2,000 between the high and the low. **********"We're at odds about how it should be done," Ms. Hamilton said. "She wants to choose the cheapest one and I want the more expensive." **********Even more important, they didn't provide for a way out of the contract. "I'm ready to sell and she's not," Ms. Hamilton said. Although they are working things through, "it's not as efficient as it would have been if we had set it up up front," Ms. Hamilton said. **********Still, she doesn't regret the deal. "I've loved it," she says. "It's been wonderful to have an equity interest in something."WHEN IN DOUBT, SPELL IT OUT **********An agreement to buy real estate with a friend or relative should include the obvious financial details, like the portion of the purchase price supplied by each partner and who will be responsible for maintenance, utilities and insurance. **********But it should also address more subtle things, like who will take responsibility for and make decisions about decorating and keeping household accounts. For example, if one of the two travels a great deal and is counting on the other to take up the slack, spell it out. Will the homebody be compensated for this role? **********The agreement also should clearly address how you will dissolve the partnership. Will one person have the option to buy the property at a specific price? If not, what will trigger the sale? Should the property be sold if one person is transferred to another city, gets married, loses a job? If one of the partners dies, will the other have the first right to buy his or her share? **********Think, too, about how the sale price will be set. For example, you might get three appraisals and make the middle one the sales price. Or you might say you will put it on the market and take the best bid within a specified time period. **********If you have a particular time frame in mind, address that in your agreement. "I've done agreements that say: 'In the fifth year of ownership, one or the other can force the sale,' " said David Tane, a lawyer with the New York firm of Gallet Dreyer & Berkey. If you do not address these things, you may have to go to court and seek an action to partition the property, which could cost a great deal in legal fees. **********You might also specify in your contract that any dispute will be settled by the American Arbitration Association. "Think of everything you could possibly disagree on and address that in the contract," Mr. Tane advises. **********Finally, "unless you're really of the same mind about everything," Mr. Tane said, you and your partner should use different attorneys to draw up the agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/23/busin.body_text: **********The Massachusetts Health and Educational Facilities Authority entered the tax-exempt market yesterday with a $69.2 million issue of revenue bonds through Morgan Stanley & Company as senior manager. **********Underwriters tentatively priced the bonds, which are for the Fallon Health Care System, with a maximum yield of 7.075 percent for an issue due 2020. **********For serial bonds with shorter maturities, yields ranged from 4.8 percent in 1992 to 5.8 percent in 1996, 6.3 percent in 2001 and 6.7 percent in 2004. For other long maturities, bonds were priced to yield 7.028 percent for an issue due 2011 and 6.938 percent for one due in 2021. **********The bonds, which cannot be subjected to early call by the issuer, are also insured by the Capital Guaranty Insurance Corporation, covering interest and principal payments. For that reason the bonds are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/21/busin.main_headline: A Vote of Confidence in Outward Bound
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/21/busin.print_headline: A Vote of Confidence in Outward Bound
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/21/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Based on feedback from the 300 or so of our Home Depot managers who have taken part in Outward Bound programming in the last seven years, our involvement has been valuable. ("Back From the Great Outdoors," Managing, May 19.) We do not require managers to attend Outward Bound. We offer it without arm-twisting. In fact, more company employees than we can accommodate ask to take part. **********The challenges that Outward Bound presents to our employees seem to have translated well back in the "real world" in terms of more creative and more effective problem-solving as well an avoidance of traditional corporate turf politics. The programs also offer the opportunity for managers to work with peers from other areas of the country and to get to know each other on a personal basis. The programs have helped strengthen our management team and reinforce our progressive corporate culture. ARTHUR M. BLANK  Atlanta, July 2    The author is president of The Home Depot, a do-it-yourself home furnishing chain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/12/busin.main_headline: Pan Am Obtains Access To $50 Million of Loan
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/12/busin.print_headline: Pan Am Obtains Access To $50 Million of Loan
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/12/busin.body_text: **********Pan Am got access yesterday to $50 million of the $150 million loan that was authorized by a bankruptcy judge on Thursday night. **********The money, which the ailing carrier had said it needed to avert a shutdown within days, came from a bridge loan arranged by the Bankers Trust Company and United Airlines.It is aimed at keeping Pan Am flying until it can complete the sale of its London routes to United. **********Pan Am, which filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors on Tuesday, would get a payment of $290 million from the route sale. That would be enough to repay the loan and to buy time to try to reorganize. **********On Wednesday the airline said that it was down to $27 million in cash and that it had not been paid what it was owed by credit card companies like American Express, which withheld a $5 million payment, and Mastercard, which paid only $100,000 of $1.5 million. Credit Card Payments **********A spokesman for Pan Am said that the payment from the credit card companies had not been made by yesterday but that the airline was working with the companies to make the payment. **********Important vendors have continued to extend credit to the airline and have not demanded payment before delivering services. **********At a hearing in lower Manhattan on Thursday night, Judge Cornelius Blackshear said, in approving the loan, that the confidence of the public, travel agents and credit card companies was crucial to enable the carrier to keep operating. The infusion of the $50 million was expected to provide that confidence. **********The money is expected to last the carrier until the Transporation Department makes a final determination of whether Pan Am's London routes can be transferred to United. The agency has already issued a preliminary order supporting the transfer to Pan Am. **********If the department issues the final approval, which is expected near the end of January, Pan Am would get the remaining $100 million of the loan approved Thursday night. **********The approval of the British Government is also needed for United to fly into Heathrow Airport, as Pan Am does now. **********The British, however, have told United States negotiators from the State and Transportation Departments that in return for giving United and American access to Heathrow, it wants extensive concessions. **********These include allowing British carriers to fly beyond the destinations that they fly to now and giving them access to the computer reservation systems of American carriers so that their flights would be displayed more favorably. **********Negotiations are due to begin on Monday. The British have said they are prepared to negotiate for the rights to Heathrow, but from the point of view of the American negotiators are asking too high a price.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.body_text: **********The third- and fourth-largest banks in Austria announced plans yesterday for a merger that would create the largest bank in the country. **********The Zentralsparkasse und Kommerzialbank, known as Z Bank, is Austria's No. 3 bank and its largest savings bank with 219 domestic branches, but only seven offices abroad. **********Its new partner, the Oesterreicheische Landerbank, is No. 4 with 139 offices, and is more active in corporate finance, securities markets and overseas markets, where it has 23 branches. **********When combined, the two banks will become larger than Creditanstalt, now No. 1. Together they will have assets of $45.5 billion, which greatly increases their stature in Europe but is not enough to place the merged venture among the world's 100 largest banking companies. **********They expect the merger to be completed by Sept. 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.body_text: **********Sales of previously owned single-family homes rose 2.2 percent in December, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.22 million units, the National Association of Realtors reported today. **********The improvement was based solely in the Middle West, the group said. Elsewhere, sales continued to slide. **********The gain followed a 3 percent rise a month earlier. The November increase was the first since August. **********The real estate trade group attributed the improvement to declining mortgage rates. A survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation showed that the average rate for a 30-year, conventional fixed-rate mortgage was 9.68 percent by the end of December. **********The realtors said the national median price of an existing home in 1990 was $95,500, up 2.6 percent from 1989. But the median price in December was just $91,900, down 4.6 percent from January 1990, reflecting the falling values of homes since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. **********For 1990 as a whole, sales of previously owned single-family homes totaled just 3.29 million, down 4.3 percent from 3.44 million a year earlier. It was the lowest number of sales since 3.21 million homes were bought in 1985.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/world.main_headline: French Doctor Is Optimistic on Disaster Relief
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/world.print_headline: French Doctor Is Optimistic on Disaster Relief
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/16/world.body_text: **********For the last two decades, first as a doctor and more recently as a senior French Government official, Bernard Kouchner has traveled with emergency teams to the scene of scores of natural and man-made disasters. Now, for the first time, he says he is feeling optimistic. **********It is not that disasters are being prevented. "There are more and more because we hear more about them," he said. "The volcano in the Philippines, an earthquake in Georgia, the aftermath of Kurdistan and Bangladesh, famine in the Horn of Africa. Just that!" **********As co-founder of the French group Doctors Without Borders, he has argued that repressive governments have no right to keep aid away from the needy. And during the Kurdish refugee crisis, the principle of "humanitarian intervention" was accepted by the United Nations. **********"I think a universal conscience is taking shape," he said in a recent interview. "It's beginning to demand a minimal respect for human rights. It is an important advance that people recognize that suffering belongs to everyone, that it is not affected by borders." **********A 51-year-old gastro-enterologistturned-politician, Dr. Kouchner can share credit for this change because, as the top French official for humanitarian affairs, a sub-Cabinet position, he helped bring the plight of the Kurdish refugees to the attention of the Security Council after the gulf war. **********On April 5, the Council approved a resolution demanding that Iraq give access to Kurdistan to international aid groups and instructed the Secretary General to mobilize United Nations agencies to help the refugees. **********The resolution fell short of creating "a right of humanitarian intervention," but Dr. Kouchner believes it took a step in that direction. "The United Nations has already approved a right to assistance requiring governments to provide access corridors for humanitarian aid," he said. "Now we must codify the right to intervene." **********"It may take 20 years, but it's a beginning. At Auschwitz, most people didn't know and nothing was done. In Biafra 25 years ago, people knew, they saw what was happening and they did nothing. Now in Kurdistan, people knew, they saw and they did something." **********When humanitarian intervention should be allowed is more complicated, he acknowledged. "We can't start by saying, after 703 victims, we will intervene. And people will ask, why this country and not that country? But we can start by conditioning aid to human rights -- and that's intervention." **********But he also said that the famine in war zones of the Sudan and the Horn of Africa cannot await debate. This year, he led a truck convoy with 850 tons of food into the southern Sudan. **********Dr. Kouchner sees his job as one of drawing public attention to imminent or existing disasters. For this reason, he said, the press is his most important ally. **********The so-called "French doctors" -- as Doctors Without Borders and Doctors of the World are known -- are invariably found at the scene of catastrophes. The paradox is that Dr. Kouchner, who co-founded Doctors of the World after breaking with Doctors Without Borders in 1981, is not on speaking terms with either group. **********They accuse him of being preoccupied with self-promotion. "They reproach me for having succeeded, which is very French," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.main_headline: Sears Backed on Visa; Banks Grow Concerned
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.print_headline: Sears Backed on Visa; Banks Grow Concerned
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.body_text: **********A Federal court has ruled that Sears, Roebuck & Company can issue Visa cards, and the move is expected to intensify competition in the credit card business, which is already being reshaped by the entry of companies other than banks. **********In a ruling in Salt Lake City on Friday, Judge David Sam of United States District Court granted a preliminary injunction against Visa U.S.A. Inc. that permitted Sears to issue Visa cards pending the resolution of a lawsuit Sears has against Visa. **********The retailing giant contends that Visa has been trying to prevent it from issuing a Prime Option Visa card, which like Sears's Discover card would not carry a fee but would, the company says, have the cachet and wide merchant acceptance of the Visa name. **********The decision, which Visa asked the judge to reconsider yesterday, allows Sears to proceed with an ambitious plan to issue the no-fee Visa card next month to some seven million households that are Sears customers. **********Analysts said Sears's new card was a prime threat to the hold by banks on the issuance of Visa credit cards. Visa is an association of banks that issue credit to consumers through the Visa credit card. Recently, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company successfully issued its Universal Visa credit card, which competes with the Visa bank cards, and banks fear that their credit card business will be undercut by such well-capitalized non-bank competitors. **********"This is a considerable and substantial threat to traditional bank issuers," said Allen R. DeCottiis, the president of P.S.I., a research and consulting firm in Tampa, Fla. "Visa banks are extremely concerned. They paid to build the Visa infrastructure and now others are allowed access. A.T.& T. and Sears are two giants at the gate of Visa, and they are a threat to all other issuers." **********David Brancoli, a spokesman for Visa, based in San Mateo, Calif., said the bank association opposed the new Sears card. He said that while competition among different Visa issuers would benefit consumers, consumers would benefit even more from competition among different brands of cards -- for instance, Visa cards vying against Sears's existing Discover credit cards, or Mastercards. **********"The consumer benefits more from major brand competition than from competition within a brand," Mr. Brancoli said. **********James Flynn, a Sears spokesman, predicted that the Prime Option card would be a big deal because it does not carry a fee and because of a new repayment schedule about which he would not elaborate. **********But Mr. Flynn rejected the idea that Prime Option would compete with Sears's existing Discover card, which last year contributed $117 million to Sears's profits from about 40 million cards issued. "It won't cannibalize our other card," he said. **********Sears plans to issue its new Visa cards through Mountainwest Financial,, a savings and loan association based in Sandy, Utah, that Sears bought last year from the Resolution Trust Corporation. Sears therefore sought the injunction against Visa in the district court in Utah.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/busin.snippet: When Willie Nelson, the country singer and songwriter, found himself without assets to cover his tax bill last year, he worked out a deal with the Internal Revenue Service to accept less than the $32 million it was asking for. The arrangement also...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/busin.main_headline:
Your Own Account;
Cutting a Deal With the I.R.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;
Cutting a Deal With the I.R.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/busin.body_text: **********When Willie Nelson, the country singer and songwriter, found himself without assets to cover his tax bill last year, he worked out a deal with the Internal Revenue Service to accept less than the $32 million it was asking for. The arrangement also allows Mr. Nelson to keep at least $500,000 in profits from his new collection of songs to pursue a lawsuit against Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm that he claims gave him bad advice on some tax-shelter investments, according to Jay Goldberg, a New York lawyer who negotiated the deal for the singer. **********Mr. Goldberg says the I.R.S. views Mr. Nelson's lawsuit as a valuable piece of property that he will be unable to develop unless he has this money to cover expenses. "The I.R.S. looked at it as a business decision," Mr. Goldberg said. "They stand a chance of making more money if he wins the case." The I.R.S. is prohibited from commenting on matters concerning individual taxpayers, said Don Roberts, a spokesman. **********As a result of the lingering recession, accountants say they are seeing more and more clients with Mr. Nelson's problem, albeit with bills in the thousands rather than the millions. If you are one of them, you should not ignore the I.R.S. "If the taxpayer digs in his heels and does nothing, then we begin enforced collection, seizing bank accounts, wages or property," Mr. Roberts said. **********If that happens, you could be on the street and still have your debt unresolved. "If the I.R.S. seizes your house, they'll sell it at much below the market price -- maybe 50 to 60 percent of the value," said Robin F. Davies, tax manager at the accounting firm of McGladrey & Pullen in Schaumburg, Ill. "They reduce your tax bill only by what they get. You still owe the rest. And you don't have a home." **********Here's what you should do, depending on the severity of your cash crunch. If you can avoid it, don't liquidate investments and trigger a big tax gain, which will only cause additional tax problems going forward. Look first at tax-deductible ways to borrow the money, such as a home equity credit line, which is tax deductible up to $100,000 in principal. But you must liquidate investments if you have no other way to come up with the money. **********If you can't borrow anything and have no assets to sell, you must try to work out an arrangement with the collections department at the I.R.S. Before you make an appointment, pull together a balance sheet and income statement. "The burden is on you to show what you can afford to pay and to back it up credibly," said Larry Elkin, manager in charge of personal financial planning at Arthur Andersen & Company in New York. **********Being cooperative and showing evidence that you intend to pay is crucial, accountants say. It's not in the best interest of the I.R.S. to throw you out on the street if there's evidence that payment will be made. "If you can show some means by which you will repay, they will be open to a discussion," Mr. Elkin said. After all, interest and penalties are accumulating, so the I.R.S. can afford to be patient. **********Before making a promise to repay though, look at your other debts and make certain that you will be able to maintain the repayment schedule. "Somebody who has serious tax problems probably has serious financial planning problems in general," Mr. Elkin said. "The fact that they could be exposed to such a liability means their finances have probably been on automatic pilot." **********If you have a lot of additional debt, you may need to work out a package deal to pay off all your creditors. "Otherwise you may find that you've promised too big a share to the I.R.S. and you can be forced into bankruptcy by the weight of other people's claims," Mr. Elkin said. **********Suppose your situation is closer to Mr. Nelson's: You owe a whopping bill to the I.R.S. and you have absolutely nothing. For example, Ms. Davies has a client in this situation: he owes $65,000 and his total assets amount to $2,000. He has no home and he was recently in a bad automobile accident. **********Ms. Davies is working on an "offer in compromise" for her client. This is an offer to settle the debt for something less than what is owed. It might be a lump sum or it might be a lump sum plus payments over a specified period, like five years. **********"The taxpayer might offer to settle for 10 or 20 cents on the dollar," said Mr. Roberts of the I.R.S. "We review the offer based on the financial statement to see whether it would be accepted." **********Offers in compromise are far from common. Mr. Roberts said only 9,000 were received in 1990. He would not say how many were accepted. But he did say the amount offered must exceed the total value of equity in the taxpayer's assets. **********Offers in compromise that have been accepted are public information. "You can read through them to see the initial liability assessed by the I.R.S. and what they settled for," Ms. Davies said. **********Finally, a bankruptcy filing can sometimes wipe out a tax debt. Bankruptcy judges have discretion to discharge tax debts that are more than three years old. **********"That's one weapon you can use with the I.R.S.," Mr. Goldberg said: " 'If you don't negotiate with me, I'll go bankrupt.' "PONDERING AUTOMATIC EXTENSION **********The Internal Revenue Service has reversed an earlier decision to give most taxpayers an automatic extension on their filing deadline from April 15 until Aug. 15. The I.R.S. said it needed more time to study the proposed change, which was to have taken effect next year. **********About five and a half million taxpayers used Form 4868 to ask for the four-month extension this year, according to the I.R.S. The agency said it had proposed giving a so-called paperless extension -- dispensing with the need to formally request one -- to save time and money. The I.R.S. estimated that an automatic extension would save 7.6 million hours of taxpayers' time and $5.5 million in processing costs for the agency. **********The I.R.S. said a number of taxpayers and tax preparers had raised concerns about the proposed change. Therefore all taxpayers who seek an extension next year will again be required to file Form 4868 by April 15. **********Accountants say that many taxpayers are not well served by delaying their returns until August. For one thing, if you use a professional to prepare your taxes it costs more, perhaps 25 or 30 percent, according to Robin F. Davies, tax manager at the accounting firm of McGladrey & Pullen in Schaumburg, Ill. That is because the taxpayer must still make a good-faith effort to compute and pay all taxes by April 15 even though the return is not filed then. **********Further, those who have refunds due lose out on four months' interest. The I.R.S. says nearly 80 percent of the taxpayers who filed Form 4868 last year ultimately received refunds. -- MARY ROWLAND

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.main_headline: Mutual Fund; Shortening Up on Money Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.print_headline: Mutual Fund; Shortening Up on Money Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/11/busin.body_text: **********To make money market funds safer for investors, the Securities and Exchange Commission tightened standards on June 30, requiring these funds to shorten their average maturity to 90 days, from 120 days. That forces funds to invest in shorter-term, presumably safer, instruments. One fund chose to change its marketing approach -- and its name -- rather than its investment strategy. The Neuberger & Berman Ultra-Short Bond fund is perhaps the only hybrid, part money fund and part short-term bond fund. The average maturity of its holdings is 30 days to a year. The fund has never been a true money market fund. When interest rates climb, the fund performs worse than money market funds but better than short-term bond funds, which have average maturities between one and five years. When rates fall, they outperform money markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/world.main_headline: AFTER THE WAR: The Arabs; Key Parts of Statement By the Arab Ministers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: The Arabs; Key Parts of Statement By the Arab Ministers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from a statement by the Foreign Ministers of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Oman, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt and Syria after talks on Sunday with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Saudi Arabia, as translated by Reuters: **********The ministers expressed their appreciation for the decisive contribution by the United States of America to the liberation of Kuwait and in supporting international legitimacy. **********They also expressed their appreciation for the contents of the address by his excellency President George Bush to the American Congress in which he gave positive treatment to the issues of security in the region and the Palestinian question. **********They expressed their resolve to continue to work with the President of the United States and his Secretary of State in order to realize success on these issues. **********They expressed their realization of the importance of the joint action in order to prevent the repetition of an aggression similar to that which took place on Kuwait. **********These states strive to make the Middle East a zone free of weapons of mass destruction, and work for the realization of this through the competent international bodies. **********These states regard the arrangements which are to be agreed upon by them as basis on which they can build to realize a new Arab order. **********They also think that the current phase following the liberation of Kuwait provides the best circumstances for confronting challenges to security and stability in the region, and for realizing a just and comprehensive solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict and the question of Palestine. **********These states believe that convening an international peace conference under United Nations auspices is a suitable framework for ending the Israeli occupation of Arab territory and guaranteeing the national rights of the Palestinian people on the basis of the related United Nations resolutions. Lebanon Question Cited **********These states will endeavor to realize and implement the Taif accord on the Lebanese question, and will work to assist the Lebanese authorities in this regard. They therefore demand the full and unconditional implementation of Security Council Resolution 425. **********While reaffirming their eagerness to respect Iraq's sovereignty and territorial integrity, they are concerned over what is now taking place in Iraq and over what the Iraqi regime is doing to suppress the uprising of the Iraqi people. **********They are also eager to develop friendly relations with Iran, and are looking forward to cooperating with it on the basis of mutual respect and the principles of international law which govern friendly relations among states. . . . **********With regard to economic cooperation, the parties of the Damascus declaration consider that improvement of economic performance contributes to the bolstering of political stability and serves the interests of security and stability in the region. Sovereignty Emphasized **********Economic cooperation among them is based on respect for the sovereignty of each Arab state over its own natural and economic resources, and the strengthening of the bases of their economic cooperation as a first step on which they can build with other Arab states. **********They will endeavor to adopt economic policies that can realize balanced economic and social development as a prelude to the establishment of an Arab economic grouping. **********They also endeavor to encourage the private sector to participate in this operation. The Gulf Cooperation Council member states attach great importance to the bolstering of development efforts in the Arab world. **********The Foreign Ministers of the states which are parties of the Damascus declaration and the American Secretary of State feel that their meeting today constitutes a unique opportunity not only to celebrate the liberation of Kuwait, but also to restate their commitment to the search for security and peace in the Middle East region. **********This duty is not shouldered alone by the Governments represented here today, but by the peoples of the entire region and the other parties from outside the region who wish to play a constructive role. **********They . . . have to confront the difficult challenges before them, while insisting on these principles and showing the same determination and resolve with which they managed to defeat Saddam Hussein.
