https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/busin.main_headline: Eastern Europe's Hardships Grow As Trade With Soviets Dries Up,
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/busin.print_headline: Eastern Europe's Hardships Grow As Trade With Soviets Dries Up,
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/06/busin.body_text: **********For years, the nations of the Eastern bloc grumbled that Moscow's arcane system for trade with its allies was little more than a swindle. Just give us a chance to sell our goods for cold hard dollars, they insisted, and we will show you who comes out ahead. On Jan. 1 they got their wish, and they have rued the day ever since. **********Exports from the region's nascent capitalist economies to Moscow have collapsed, and imports from the Soviet Union, aside from oil and natural gas, appear to be down sharply. **********Since Jan. 1, the Soviet Union has been importing considerably fewer Eastern European goods than in previous years. It has said it does not have the dollars to pay for the goods. **********"The Soviets are unwilling or unable to pay -- that is the crux," said Lazlo Lang, an economist at the Central European Research Center in Budapest. "What they want is to squeeze out as much net hard-currency income from Eastern Europe as possible." **********Virtually overnight, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Hungary and the region's other nations lost a leading market. **********Beef, sparkling wine, even thousands of tons of slaughtered geese are piling up in warehouses across Eastern Europe. Hundreds of thousands of workers have been furloughed and their pay reduced, as their factories, tailored to fill the Soviet demand, suddenly were bereft of customers or contracts. Economic planners from Budapest to Warsaw, still trying to cut the last of the Communist-era subsidies for domestic industries, are besieged with pleas for government bailouts.  'A Catastrophic Situation' **********"I negotiated this new regime for trade for Poland," said Dariusz Ledworoski, the Minister for Economic Cooperation, "and I would have to admit that we are in a catastrophic situation." **********Economists attribute the developments to confusion in the Soviets' lumbering trade bureaucracy, as well as a severe shortage of dollars. Some officials in the post-Communist countries, however, question whether the sudden halt in trade could also be Moscow's none-too-subtle method of underscoring warnings to its former satellites not to join NATO. **********Whatever its causes, the disruption has jolted the fragile economies of the Soviet Union's neighbors, all of which are struggling to foster free-market systems. In the last few weeks, senior officials from Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary have held frantic meetings with Western financial organizations, searching for bridge loans or other means to underwrite trade with the Soviet Union.  Moscow Spurns Pleas **********The officials have also suggested to the Soviets that the system of dollar payments be dropped in favor of barter, as was once the case, or some other mechanism. Moscow has spurned these pleas, even though the slowdown in trade appears to be causing equally disastrous consequences for Soviet industries. **********Poland's exports to the Soviet Union fell to about $440 million in the first quarter of 1991, Polish Government officials have estimated, a decline of 80 percent from a year earlier. Czechoslovakia's quarterly sales to the Soviet Union were estimated at $323 million; officials said that was a 36 percent decline. **********In Hungary, unofficial figures indicate that first-quarter exports totaled about $70 million, a decline of 85 percent from last year's approximate volume. Press reports in Bulgaria say only $57 million was exported in the first quarter to the Soviet Union, a small remnant of what was the country's most lucrative market last year. **********Precise calculations of the differences in trade are impossible because the transactions were conducted in rubles last year, and the Soviet Union had provided oil and natural gas at highly subsidized prices; now it sells them for dollars. Some Eastern European nations have paid cash and continued their imports, while others have cut back.  A Too-Rapid Pace **********The Eastern European countries had been planning on a much slower transition. They had hoped that over the next few years trade with the Soviet Union would serve as a useful cushion while companies gradually made themselves competitive in Western markets. **********Now Czechoslovakia, which was particularly tied to the Soviet Union, and other nations face an unexpectedly early test of how well they can survive largely on their own. **********During the Communist years, trade between the Soviet Union and its satellites was a particularly telling illustration of the inherent absurdities of centrally run economies. Under the umbrella of the Comecon trade organization, goods were produced and sold among the countries with little regard to quality or cost. Transactions were conducted in an artificial currency -- the transfer ruble -- that was of even less value than the Soviet ruble. **********One joke circulating in Poland summed up the system this way: "One dead dog for two dead cats." **********Moscow continually contended it was the loser because it was not only trading oil at artificially low prices but was accepting shoddy products that could not be sold elsewhere. Poles and residents of other satellite nations acknowledged that their goods were not always the best, but said that they were cheated even more by the Soviet-set prices for raw materials.  Dealing With Dollars **********Western analysts agree that the unreformed Soviet economy was ill prepared to begin trade on a dollar basis. They said current exports earn Moscow barely enough money to repay Western loans and buy equipment for the decrepit oilfields that are the most important source of hard currency. **********Claus Wittich of the Vienna-based United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said the Kremlin's decision late last year to impose tight centralized controls on disbursement of the scarce hard currency further constricted trade. "It was completely unclear who had the authority to spend from the new fund, which was apparently being decided at the level of the cabinet," Mr. Wittich said. "It was a prescription for chaos." **********The effect of the slowdown in Soviet trade varies from country to country, but has exceeded expectations in every case. **********Poland, which has been among the most successful in reorienting its manufacturing and exports toward Western markets, expected a 25 to 50 percent decline in its Soviet sales. **********Mr. Ledworoski, the Minister of Economic Cooperation, said the 80 percent decline in exports to the Soviet Union was by itself responsible for Poland's $300 million trade deficit in the first quarter of 1991. About 200 companies, employing about 130,000 people, had subsisted on sales to the Soviet Union; Mr. Ledworoski acknowledged that many of them produced outmoded goods not suitable for sale anywhere else. **********"Computer printers are one example," he said. "In the world, they are very cheap. The Soviet Union bought from us because they didn't have to pay hard currency. If they do pay hard currency, why would they buy our old-fashioned machines?" **********At the moment, most Polish companies have cut off further deliveries to the Soviet Union because Moscow is $130 million in arrears on items bought earlier this year.  A Meeting of Prime Ministers **********Poland is nonetheless eager to sell in the Soviet Union, particularly as the European Community continues to erect customs barriers. Recently, Prime Minister Jan Krzystof Bielecki of Poland went to Moscow and offered 100,000 tons of meat and a million tons of grain. Startled by the huge surplus, the Soviet Prime Minister, Valentin Pavlov, raised an eyebrow and asked whether Poland had some new connection to God. **********"No," an aide quoted Mr. Bielecki as replying. "For that we have the Pope. For this, we have economic reform." The Soviets have not yet said whether they would buy Poland's agricultural surplus. **********In Hungary, Mr. Lang, the economist, said many industries had temporarily shut production lines and furloughed employees. By fall, he said, these companies would exhaust their reserves and might be forced to dismiss as many as 150,000 workers. This would more than double Hungary's unemployment rate of 3 percent. Mr. Lang noted that the Hungarian economy, while strongly tied to the West, retained symbiosis in some respects with the Soviet Union. **********Right now, he said, 4,000 tons of slaughtered geese are sitting in warehouses. Until this year, the Hungarians did a brisk business. The goose's liver would be removed to satisfy Western demand for pate, and the rest of the bird would be sold to the Soviet market. But Mr. Lang said there was little demand elsewhere for geese without livers. **********Economists say Czechoslovakia is facing one of the most wrenching adjustments. The country began its program for instituting free-market changes only this year at the same moment that it moved to dollar trade with the Soviet Union. **********Petr Pithart, the prime minister of the Czech region, said recently that Czechoslovakia had proposed widespread barter to the Soviets as a possible solution. Right now, the Soviet Union is permitting such deals only in limited instances.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: France; French Policy Upsets Friend and Foe, at Home and Abroad
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: France; French Policy Upsets Friend and Foe, at Home and Abroad
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/world.body_text: **********France has yet to experience the pain of losing any planes, pilots or soldiers in combat in the Persian Gulf, but the week-old war has already made itself felt here through political in-fighting, rising social tensions and a crisis in French relations with longtime Arab allies. **********As a result, while closely following events in the gulf -- where France has stationed 10,000 troops, 54 aircraft and a dozen warships -- the Government has been just as busy dealing with the domestic and foreign repercussions of its participation in the war. **********French opposition parties have criticized the war strategy, pro-Iraqi demonstrators in North Africa have denounced France, relations with Israel have been strained, the huge Arab immigrant population here is unhappy, and American and British allies harbor quiet doubts about France's role. **********At the heart of many of these difficulties, political experts say, is France's traditional desire to adopt an independent posture in world affairs so as to exercise its influence as a broker. In the gulf crisis, this approach has alienated both friend and foe.  French Offer to Iraq **********During the countdown to the war, President Francois Mitterrand proposed that Iraq be offered the guarantee of an international peace conference on the Middle East in exchange for withdrawal from Kuwait. Washington and London immediately opposed "rewarding" Iraqi aggression, while Baghdad never even responded. **********But, with an eye to the future, the initiative nonetheless seemed to serve France's purpose of showing the Arab world that France's policy in the Middle East was very different from that of the United States or Britain. **********At the outbreak of war, France again risked annoying its allies when Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement, who was already known to oppose the use of force against Iraq, announced the signing of a "protocol" with Washington declaring that French troops would operate only in Kuwait. France's objective, he insisted, was to liberate Kuwait and not to destroy Iraq.  Giscard Critical of Curbs **********Opposition parties called for Mr. Chevenement's resignation, and former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing said acidly that it would have been as if allied forces in World War II had tried to liberate France without attacking Nazi Germany. **********After the first Scud missiles hit Israel last week, France faced a new diplomatic headache when a senior member of the Israeli Parliament, Eliahu Ben-Elissar, charged that France's huge arms sales to Iraq in the 1980's were "in large measure responsible" for Baghdad's ballistic missile ability and non-conventional weapons. **********Finally, in a hastily arranged television interview on Sunday, Mr. Mitterrand responded to his critics, stating first that while France's initial air raids into Kuwait were the result of a "plan of action" worked out among the allies, its air and ground forces were not forbidden to enter Iraqi territory. **********He stressed that France had sold weapons to the Iraqis during their war against Iran at the insistence of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, but that it never supplied missiles. He added that France had repeatedly rejected Iraq's requests for nuclear technology after Israel destroyed an nuclear plant outside Baghdad in 1981.  Public Support for Mitterrand **********Perhaps the only good news for Mr. Mitterrand in recent days has come from polls reporting that French public opinion, which was badly divided over participation in a gulf war before Jan. 16, is now supporting the Government. The latest poll showed 73 percent of those questioned approved of the President's handling of the crisis. **********But the mood in the country remains somber, with memories of terrorist bombings in Paris in 1986 feeding fears of reprisals by pro-Iraqi guerrillas and prompting a wave of panic-buying in the days before the war. Over the last week, shops and restaurants have been virtually empty, while sales of firearms have jumped. **********The source of much anxiety are the four million Arab immigrants here, many of whom have made no secret of their unhappiness at seeing Western forces attacking an Arab nation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/busin.main_headline: Moody's May Lower Chrysler Debt to 'Junk Bond' Status
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/busin.print_headline: Moody's May Lower Chrysler Debt to 'Junk Bond' Status
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/busin.body_text: **********Another big credit-rating agency said today that it would review the Chrysler Corporation's creditworthiness and could lower the struggling auto maker's rating to "junk bond" status. **********Moody's Investors Service Inc. pointed to increasing competition in the auto industry and its potential negative impact on what it termed "Chrysler's already weak automotive position." **********Moody's, based in New York, also said it would review the credit ratings of the Chrysler Financial Corporation, the financing and insurance unit of the nation's No. 3 auto maker. Profits from Chrysler Financial recently have dulled the sting of losses in the company's car- and truck-making operations. **********Last Thursday, Fitch Investors Service Inc. dropped Chrysler's rating by two notches to its highest noninvestment, or speculative, grade. Earlier this month, the Standard & Poor's Corporation placed the Big Three auto makers -- Chrysler, General Motors and Ford Motor -- on its credit-watch list, putting the companies on notice that their securities ratings could be lowered. **********A slip of one notch in the S.& P. rating would send Chrysler to speculative, or junk bond, status. **********The ratings are an indication of Wall Street's assessments of a company's creditworthiness. Lower ratings tend to translate into higher borrowing costs for a company as investors demand more income for their risk. **********Chrysler is now rated at Moody's lowest investment-grade rating. **********Moody's said it would look specifically at the auto maker's mini-van and sport-vehicle products. **********"We're very aware that our minivans and sport utilities face increasing competition," a Chrysler spokesman, Steven J. Harris, said, reading from a prepared statement. "But we are confident that they remain the class of the field and are able to withstand the assault, despite the unwarranted negative publicity attendant to the Ultradrive transmission." **********In December, the Center for Auto Safety asked Chrysler to recall 500,000 vehicles with the Ultradrive transmission. The Washington-based consumer group said the high-tech electronic transmission, used in the popular mini-vans, among other vehicles, was unreliable and unsafe. **********The group said complaints about the Ultradrive transmission were responsible for 25 percent of all complaints against auto makers. **********Chrysler denounced the recall request, calling the group's claims "grossly exaggerated" and charges of safety hazards "totally irresponsible."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/18/busin.body_text: **********Litton Industries said today that it was scaling back operations of its disappointing Integrated Automation division. The decision will result in a $100 million after-tax charge in the company's fourth quarter, which ends July 31. **********The division, based in Alameda, Calif., is small, with annual revenue of less than $50 million. But the charge includes $70 million of good will resulting from Litton's acquisition of Integrated in 1987. Good will is an accounting term for the difference between the price paid for an entity and the value of its physical assets. **********Litton, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said the decision to phase down Integrated reflected the disappointing growth prospects for the division's inspection and process-control business, which supplies computerized quality-control systems for factories and warehouses. Another element of the operation, document imaging -- the translation of engineering blueprints into computer files -- might remain viable, Litton said. **********Without offering specifics, Litton said Integrated's problems were created at least in part by overambitious estimates of the division's prospects when it was acquired, as well as some early management problems. **********"The current recession has accelerated these problems, which will not substantially reverse once the economy turns," said Alton J. Brann, Litton's president. "It is right, therefore, to stop our losses now." **********The company said the charge would cut $4.50 a share from its earnings for the year. **********Byron K. Callan, an analyst with Prudential Securities, said that before today's announcement Litton's earnings had been expected to reach $7.55 a share this year. Last year, Litton earned $7.26 a share on net income of $178.81 million. **********"It's a strategic setback for them, compared to what they were saying a year ago when they wanted to be a systems-integration player in industrial automation," Mr. Callan said, adding that the decision came as a surprise. "But I don't think this reflects a broader reassessment of their drive to increase the commercial share of their business." **********In trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Litton's stock closed down 50 cents a share, to $79.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/world.body_text: **********Shrugging off President Bush's threatened use of a veto, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel and its supporters in Washington would keep pressing the United States Congress for swift approval of $10 billion in loan guarantees intended to help resettle Soviet Jewish immigrants here. **********Although Mr. Shamir spoke in conciliatory terms and emphasized that he still supported the Middle East peace conference sought by the United States, the thrust of his remarks was that Israel was prepared for a bitter fight if it came to one. **********Mr. Bush has demanded that Congress delay consideration of the loan guarantees for 120 days, saying that debate on them now could upend negotiations that would bring Israel and its neighboring Arab countries to the peace talks. Acknowledging the formidable strength of pro-Israel lobbyists on Capitol Hill, the President raise the stakes in the confrontation on Thursday by promising to veto any early Congressional action. **********Mr. Shamir described the dispute as "an internal American conflict," between the Bush Administration and Israel's Congressional supporters. But he made clear that he expected Jewish groups in the United States to ignore the President's warning and to press their demands for immediate passage of the aid package. U.S. Jews 'Very Active' **********"We don't see any reason to change our position," the Prime Minister said soon after returning from a visit to France. "We will continue to follow our own way because we are convinced that it is the correct and just way." **********At a meeting with French Jews in Paris this morning, he gave the dispute an extra emotional fillip by invoking memories of the Nazi horror. American Jews had been accused of not having done enough at the time to stop the mass killing of Jews in Europe, Mr. Shamir said, according to the Israel state radio. But they "have learned a lesson from the Holocaust" and therefore, he said, "they are now united and very active, to the surprise of political circles in their country." **********Mr. Bush's veto threat, and perhaps even more the vehemence with which he delivered it, left Israeli Government officials and politicians variously stunned, bewildered, angry and hurt. Some were especially outraged by the President's comment that "American men and women in uniform risked their lives to defend Israelis in the face of Iraqi Scud missiles" in the Persian Gulf war. **********What Mr. Bush seems to have forgotten, they said, was that Israel's restraint in absorbing missile attacks without retaliation had helped keep the anti-Iraq coalition together. **********"Look how cynical he is and how he pays us back," said Eliakim Haetzni, a member of Parliament from Tehiya, a right-wing party in the governing coalition. **********Government officials said they hoped to avoid a head-on collision with the Bush Administration and would discuss their grievances with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who is expected to arrive here on Monday to give the planned peace talks another jolt. But some commentators called this the most serious rupture between the two countries in 35 years, and warned that the ground for possible compromise had been greatly reduced by Mr. Bush's threat. **********Politicians on the right, including close allies of the Prime Minister, insisted that they had to be more aggressive than ever in pressing their case. It rests heavily on the argument, restated by Mr. Shamir today, that there should be no linking of the requested guarantees -- the "humanitarian aid," in their view -- and peace talks that they see as a political matter. **********Some argued that American evenhandedness in the peace process had been compromised and that Mr. Bush in effect had given Arab leaders an unsolicited gift that would cause them to step up their demands at the conference table. Soviet and Baltic Immigrants **********"The tendency here is to jump and say, 'This guy hates our guts -- how can you trust him?' " said Dore Gold, a defense expert at the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies at Tel Aviv University. **********But other commentators and politicians, especially on the left, asserted that Mr. Shamir had brought the crisis on himself and perhaps in the process had imperiled financial aid that Israel says it badly needs to absorb hundreds of thousands of expected immigrants from the Soviet Union and the Baltic republics, which are now independent. **********Although Mr. Bush has not raised the matter explicitly this time, his irritation, they said, is obviously over Mr. Shamir's insistence that Israel will continue to build Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. While Israeli leaders say that none of the immigration aid will go to the territories, that money frees up Government funds to be spent there. **********"Whoever thought it was possible to take billions from America and spit in America's face by establishing new settlements was deluding himself," wrote Rami Tal, a Washington-based reporter for Yediot Ahronot, the country's largest newspaper. **********"George Bush has now dragged the Israeli Government, shouting and cursing, to its hour of truth."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/15/busin.print_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Anarchy at Another Show? No, Just a Spoof of the Clios
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/15/busin.body_text: **********ANARCHY reigned at yet another advertising awards show last week, with executives storming the stage and grabbing statuettes. **********But unlike the disaster at the Clio Awards last month in New York, the pandemonium at the first annual Doggie Award show here was choreographed. The show was a spoof, although a larger point was made. **********"With this Clio fiasco last month, we thought that if that's what's become of advertising awards competitions, we would start our own," said Paul Berger, president of a fledgling advertising organization called Club Ad Dog. **********At the Doggies, held in Mr. Berger's backyard in Los Angeles and given a tongue-in-cheek write-up by Adweek magazine, about 30 people lined up to rush the stage and grab the trophies: little toy dogs with bobbing heads painted gold. **********"We almost knocked over the table, just like the big guys back East in New York," Mr. Berger said. **********Last month, the Clios were abruptly canceled because of financial and organizational problems at Clio Awards Inc., after a chaotic scene at a preliminary round of awards. Advertising executives, angry that a public relations man and a caterer were doling out awards based on an incomplete list of winners, stormed the stage and started grabbing. Now, the Manhattan District Attorney's Office is conducting a preliminary investigation of the Clio organization. **********Like many advertising executives, Mr. Berger, a 33-year-old freelance copywriter, was appalled at the spectacle of the venerable Clio institution collapsing. He also felt frustrated by what he viewed as the cumbersome, ill-defined and boring agenda of the large Advertising Club of Los Angeles. **********In keeping with Ad Dog's focus, summer meetings are held in Mr. Berger's backyard, where he sets up a big projection screen. Munching popcorn and sipping lemonade, Ad Dog members watch reels of old Clio-winning advertising. They hoot and jeer, pick their favorites and try to learn something about good advertising. **********"I'm telling people around the office about it," said Michael A. Teslow, an account manager in the public relations division of Ogilvy & Mather in Los Angeles, who attended the Doggies. **********At last week's meeting, members watched a reel from the 1967 show and gave Doyle Dane Bernbach their unofficial "best in show" award. D.D.B.'s clips included a classic Burlington sock commercial for midlength socks that showed a man dancing wildly to frantic Greek folk music, trying to get the sock to fall down around his ankle. It wouldn't; the competitor's sock did. **********Another favorite, from Jack Tinker & Partners, showed large athletes gathering at a sporting event: a pie-eating contest. Afterward in the locker room, a veteran offers a rookie advice about using Alka-Seltzer. The tag line says that Alka-Seltzer is endorsed by the professionals who eat for a living. **********Mr. Berger has more plans for his organization, including work on pro bono campaigns. **********"We're just starting out," Mr. Berger said. "We thought maybe L.A. would enjoy a club that's a little more informal and doesn't take itself too seriously."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.body_text: **********As chief executive of the nation's largest public pension fund, Dale M. Hanson is an investor with an attitude. **********Under Mr. Hanson, the California Public Employees Retirement System, as the pension fund is formally known, recently assailed the ITT Corporation for the $30 million in compensation it gave its chairman, Rand V. Araskog, during the last four years when ITT's shares fell 10 percent. **********Mr. Hanson also shook up Sears, Roebuck & Company this spring by supporting the unsuccessful campaign of a dissident shareholder, Robert A. G. Monks, for a seat on the Sears board. Low-Key Prodding Preffered **********Calpers is not always so confrontational, preferring instead to rely on low-key, behind-the-scenes prodding when possible. Either way, Mr. Hanson has pushed Calpers, whose $58 billion investment portfolio includes stakes in some of the nation's largest corporations, to the forefront of a growing and increasingly successful effort to pry open board rooms and make corporate America more accountable to shareholders. **********"We primarily view our corporate governance efforts as a fiduciary responsibility, no different than if we bought a building and the manager did not care for the building in a way we thought proper," said Mr. Hanson, who is 48 years old and takes issue only with companies in which Calpers owns stock. **********Making shareholders "an equal side of the triangle" with corporate management and directors can only help build value for the stock and for the Calpers portfolio, Mr. Hanson said. **********Of the 12 shareholder resolutions filed or proposed by Calpers during the annual meeting season this year, the pension fund won outright victories or forged compromise agreements on 10. Those results were a sharp improvement over the .500 winning percentage Calpers has typically posted on the dozen or so proposals it has made in each of the previous several years. **********Faced with a potentially messy fight with Calpers or other pension funds, more and more companies are listening closely when large shareholders seek their ear and their respect. **********Sometimes Mr. Hanson wants regular meetings with management when a company is performing poorly. Sometimes he wants companies to drop provisions that seem aimed at deterring a raider but often serve to entrench -- and enrich -- management at the expense of shareholders. Frequently, Mr. Hanson wants a company to change the composition of its board by installing more directors from outside the company, who are presumably more responsive to shareholders. **********Increasingly, Mr. Hanson said, Calpers will also focus on how much chief executives earn, an issue that he sees as cutting to the heart of whether companies are run for the enrichment of management or the benefit of shareholders. **********The ability of Calpers to advance an agenda, often without a public fight, has become clear in the last year in its relations with the General Motors Corporation. **********The company made the Calpers hit list last year when Mr. Hanson sent a letter pointedly asking what the company would do to forge closer ties to large shareholders, and how the board would evaluate the performance of the successor to Roger B. Smith, G.M.'s former chairman. **********Early this year, Mr. Hanson told a G.M. executive that Calpers was planning a shareholder resolution at G.M.'s annual meeting to insure that a majority of the auto maker's board continued to come from outside G.M. Mr. Smith had tried unsuccessfully several years earlier to expand the board by adding insiders. **********After his chat with the G.M. executive, Mr. Hanson got a call from Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s new chairman, who wanted to know more. Mr. Hanson told him that a commitment to maintaining a majority of outside directors would allow G.M. to signal that its board was intent on representing shareholders, not just management. **********Mr. Stempel thought about it -- and then agreed with Calpers. Mr. Stempel even offered Calpers lawyers an opportunity to help draft the change in G.M.'s bylaws. **********"We were delighted," Mr. Hanson said. He added that Mr. Stempel's response was "a breath of fresh air" in the effort to bring together large shareholders and managements. **********Mr. Hanson, who took the top Calpers job four years ago after serving as the No. 2 executive of the Wisconsin state pension fund, still has detractors. Some corporate executives say activist pension funds like Calpers are often ill informed or unqualified to advise companies. **********Moreover, they say, the long-term investment philosophy that pension funds espouse is sometimes abandoned the moment a corporate raider comes along with an above-market offer for their shares, making the funds unreliable partners. **********But Mr. Hanson said he generally received positive responses from executives. "Most of the companies we meet with, after they find out we don't have horns and a tail, find out we're fairly articulate and that we've spent a lot of time learning their company," he said. **********That Mr. Hanson seems to be getting across the message that he has no interest in meddling in the day-to-day management of the companies in which Calpers invests apparently has helped open the lines of communication for others. **********"We're still seeing some companies that are very recalcitrant about any dialogue with shareholders," said Clifford L. Whitehill, the general counsel of General Mills Inc. who is also counsel to a task force on corporate governance formed by the Business Roundtable, an association of large corporations. "But as a result of dialogue between a number of companies and a number of institutions, with Calpers at the forefront, we have come a lot closer to understanding our common goals." **********The Calpers role in shareholder rights grew from the anger felt by Jesse M. Unruh, the late California State Treasurer and a Calpers board member, over "greenmail" payments companies made to raiders to avert takeovers. Mr. Unruh helped to create the Council of Institutional Investors, a group of large public-sector pension funds, as a means by which large shareholders could flex their muscles in dealing with the companies they partly owned. **********Gradually, corporate America has felt Calpers's clout. Last year, when the investor Harold C. Simmons fought for control of the Lockheed Corporation, contending in part that the company was poorly managed, Mr. Hanson agreed with Mr. Simmons and voted Calpers's shares against Lockheed's board. **********Mr. Simmons lost, but Mr. Hanson succeeded in shaking up Lockheed's chairman, Daniel M. Tellep. "When Calpers voted against us, that stung," Mr. Tellep said. "Ultimately, I came to realize that we should never have gotten into a position where Calpers had to vote against us to get our attention, so I resolved to get to know them."  Bypassing the Analysts **********Mr. Tellep now meets with all of Lockheed's institutional shareholders instead of communicating only through Wall Street analysts, as Lockheed had done in the past. **********Lockheed also asked Calpers and others for suggestions when it elected three new outside directors last year. And in April, Mr. Tellep enthusiastically accepted Mr. Hanson's invitation to speak to the Council of Institutional Investors on his experiences in recognizing the role of Lockheed's large shareholders. Mr. Tellep entitled his speech "The Painful, Rewarding Education of a C.E.O." **********In other cases, the outcome was more muddled. In response to a Calpers proposal, ITT changed its bylaws regarding the process of setting executive pay. But when Calpers voted against the incumbent ITT board to protest Mr. Araskog's compensation, the pension fund attracted little support from other shareholders. **********Sears agreed to meet twice a year with large shareholders after Calpers proposed a measure to establish a shareholder advisory committee.  Keeping an Eye on Sears **********Mr. Hanson said he remained concerned about Sears's performance, particularly the difficulty the company has had reinvigorating its retail business. The pension fund plans to continue to monitor the company's progress, and Mr. Hanson said he would like to see Sears's board at least consider revamping the company, perhaps by spinning off some or all of its financial-services businesses. **********Mr. Hanson also said Calpers was likely to take on more companies over the issue of executive compensation. He said his objection was not to huge paychecks in and of themselves. Rather, he said, directors have no place approving pay packages that enrich chief executives who preside over falling stock prices and eroding business prospects. **********"This is going to be one of the big issues of the 90's," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.main_headline: Orion May File for Bankruptcy Protection
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Orion May File for Bankruptcy Protection
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/18/busin.body_text: **********The Orion Pictures Corporation, troubled by large debts and a severe cash crunch, said today that it might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection if it cannot raise new money by the end of August. **********The struggling studio, which had box office hits with "Dances With Wolves" and "The Silence of the Lambs," said in a quarterly financial report to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had borrowed all of the available amounts under a $300 million credit agreement with banks. It said it had $70.79 million in outstanding letters of credit. **********"The company does not believe its bank consortium will agree to increase the available amount under this agreement," Orion said. Deadlines Approaching **********Orion said it must repay $50 million of its loans by Aug. 31 and make an interest payment of about $13 million on Aug. 15. It said it also owes about $3.9 million in other debts coming due this month and in August. **********The New York-based movie company already missed paying a $1.2 million interest payment on July 1. **********"If the company is unable to meet its obligations when due, it may be forced to seek protection under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code," Orion said. **********Although Orion's revenues were helped by the two recent motion pictures, the small studio has suffered serious financial troubles for years. Orion lost $63 million in fiscal 1990.  Woody Allen's Movies **********The company, which also has been mentioned as a possible takeover target, produced several of Woody Allen's movies. It also produces and distributes television programs. **********Orion said it was exploring ways to improve its finances, like completing exchange offers to attract equity capital from an unidentified new investor or renegotiating payment under the credit agreement with its banks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.main_headline: U.S. Presses Europeans To Ease Curbs on Meat
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.print_headline: U.S. Presses Europeans To Ease Curbs on Meat
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.body_text: **********The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, today escalated a trade conflict with the European Community over its ban on practically all imports of American meat -- and at the same time suggested a resolution may be in the offing. **********The mixed signals came as the United States, the European Community and nearly 100 other countries are engaged in delicate talks over farm subsidies, trying to find a basis for resuming the talks that collapsed last month in Brussels. **********Trade officials said Mrs. Hills's action was intended to show the seriousness with which the United States takes the meat issue, and at the same time to leave room for the informal talks to continue. Inquiry Begun **********The escalation was an announcement by Mrs. Hills that she had opened an investigation of a complaint brought by the American meat industry that the European ban violated the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world's trade charter, and discrimated against American exporters. **********Such an investigation, which generally lasts a year, could lead to retaliatory action by the President. The United States is losing about $30 million a year in exports. **********The community justified its action on the ground that its meat inspectors had found that health standards were not adequate at American slaughterhouses -- a charge challenged by the American Government and meat industry. **********Washington has demanded scientific proof of the accusations, which the community has not produced. Washington maintains that the charges are a ruse to block meat imports in order to reduce a mountain of surplus European meat caused by big farm surpluses. Talks Sought **********The olive branch offered by Mrs. Hills was her use of a provision of the trade law that delays formal procedures for up to 90 days to let informal bilateral discussions continue. **********"There are signs that additional bilateral discussions could produce an agreement," Mrs. Hills said in today's announcement. Another trade official, who insisted on anonymity, said, "The Europeans have given evidence of a serious willingness to resolve the issue." **********J. Patrick Boyle, President of the American Meat Institute, welcomed today's action. "Our goal is to reopen the E.C. market to U.S. meat products," he said. **********The United States has acted against European products also for health reasons. In one recent case, Americans were almost deprived of Beaujolais Nouveau from France because of a United States ban on a fungicide called procymidone, which is used in France and 25 other wine-making countries. Only a last-minute arrangement cleared the way for the imports.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/world.main_headline: Baker Doubtful Commonwealth Will Last Long
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/world.print_headline: THE END OF THE SOVIET UNION; Baker Doubtful Commonwealth Will Last Long
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/22/world.body_text: **********After a week of visiting the crumbling Soviet Union, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d left believing that the republics' new commonwealth has little chance of long-term survival, and that Washington will soon be dealing with a dozen independent states with different policies and varied prospects for success. **********By that view, the former Soviet republics are now so enamored of the idea of independence that they cannot work together for long in a meaningful commonwealth, with joint economic and military policies, until they feel the real costs of coming apart. **********That assessment was given to reporters traveling with Mr. Baker as he prepared to return to the United States today to brief President Bush on his visit to Russia, Kirghizia, Kazakhstan, Byelorussia and Ukraine -- all of which will probably be recognized by Washington before the end of the year. Brittle Commonwealth **********Summing up Mr. Baker's overall impressions, reporters were told: "Whether there is a commonwealth or not, we are going to end up dealing with sovereign, independent nations. Instead of dealing with one foreign minister, it might well end up being 12." **********"The richness of our relationships will depend from republic to republic on the degree to which they embrace democracy and free markets" as well as the republics' fulfilling their assurances to the United States on nuclear security, an official said. **********The "only thing that is for sure," reporters with Mr. Baker were told, "is that you should have gone out and bought some Rand McNally stock some time ago" -- referring to the map company, which must revise its publications. **********Mr. Baker's visit, destined to be the last by an American Secretary of State to the Soviet Union, was a bizarre journey in many ways, turning up a few clues from three scenes in particular. **********The first scene could be called sauna diplomacy. **********Last Wednesday, Mr. Baker visited Kazakhstan, near the border with China. As he was meeting there with President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the Kazakh leader suggested that he and Mr. Baker get away from the conference table for a more informal chat -- in his sauna. **********So at 1:30 A.M. the two men drove up to a villa in the mountains, stripped naked, and, with a State Department interpreter in tow, retreated into the sauna. There, as the snow fell heavily outside, the Kazakh from the steppes of Central Asia and the Texan from Houston, discussed the fate of the Soviet Union until almost 3 A.M. **********Earlier in the day, while Mr. Baker was visiting Bishkek, the capital of Kirghizia, the President of that republic dressed Mr. Baker in a multicolored Kirghiz robe and hat, so he could get a better feel for the local color. **********And Mr. Baker did see a lot of local color. In fact, if he drew one conclusion from his trip, it was that the United States is going to have to deal with a lot of different local colors -- probably too many -- from now on. **********Mr. Baker concluded that forces pulling the Soviet Union apart are so strong that the individual republics will soon be pursuing their own homemade economic policies -- with their own currencies, degrees of free-market drive and possibly protectionist practices. **********Republics like Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Kirghizia, which are rich in natural resources, have quick-footed leaders eager to cut deals with Western businesses, and relatively homogeneous populations. But the prospects are less clear for republics like Russia, which has a high potential for infighting among the leadership and 100 ethnic minorities that could pull the republic apart further from within. **********In fact, reporters were told that Mr. Baker left Russia feeling that "things have broken down there -- everything has broken down." The distribution system has collapsed, middle-class families are having to forage for food and crime is rampant. Without emergency food shipments, officials said, social unrest is likely in the cities before the winter is out. **********If the West is lucky, reporters were told, the commonwealth will be able to maintain at least a common defense policy that will allow for a single, unified command over nuclear weapons until they can be dismantled in every republic except Russia. But even that remains questionable. Toeing U.S. Line **********Another scene could be called the pro-American competition. **********Wherever Mr. Baker went on this trip, leaders seemed to be competing to see who could seem the most pro-American, pro-democratic and pro-capitalist. **********President Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan told Mr. Baker that he now keeps a copy of the "Baker five principles," in the top drawer of this desk. Those principles were laid out by Mr. Baker as a sort of informal yardstick for United States relations with the newly independent republics. They are very general principles -- things like "we support democracy and the rule of law" and "the safeguarding of human rights." **********The leader who managed to seem most pro-American was Askar A. Akayev, President of Kirghizia, who said at his news conference in Bishkek with Mr. Baker: "I think if one looks at the memorable speech of the Secretary of State that he gave on Dec. 12 at Princeton and those principles which he enunciated there, and also the fact that the United States has taken a leadership position in not only implementing those principles but also in all the programs and aid that the United States is heading up, this will give us an opportunity to make this transition thanks to the United States." **********Those extraordinary displays by former Soviet officials were at once encouraging and disconcerting to the Baker party. They were encouraging because the values the leaders were espousing were Western values instead of worn-out Marxist ones, but they were worrisome because some of the performances seemed as thin and empty as the apocryphal "Potemkin villages" the Russian field marshal supposedly built along the route of Catherine the Great's tour of the Crimea to impress her. **********Mr. Baker had a news conference in Kiev with President Leonid M. Kravchuk, during which Mr. Kravchuk seemed to say everything Mr. Baker wanted to hear. Later, Dora Chomiak, a recent Princeton University graduate who has been working in Kiev, commented on the coverage of the Baker visit by American correspondents. **********"It's pretty funny," said Miss Chomiak, who works for the Ukrainian-American Renaissance Foundation. "I mean, I hear you reporting that Kravchuk promised this and Kravchuk said that, and I have to tell you he says a lot of things that the people want to hear, but a lot of it never gets done. Or when it does, it's sort of slapped together. Right after Kravchuk signed the first commonwealth agreement in Brest, he came back to the Parliament here to get it ratified and it was really a farce. I mean, they didn't debate it. Half the members didn't even know what they were voting on." **********A third scene could be called Greetings and Farewells. **********When Mr. Baker's delegation got word that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia intended to meet them for the first time ever in the Kremlin, seated in the same room, at the same table and in the same chair in which President Gorbachev used to meet them, they bristled. They saw it as a crude attempt by Mr. Yeltsin to rub Mr. Gorbachev's nose in his political defeat. When Mr. Baker shook hands with Mr. Yeltsin that day in Catherine's hall, he looked stiff and uncomfortable. **********Eight hours later, Mr. Baker was holding a news conference with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. It was an emotional scene as they met in the building where they had done so much business together. Mr. Shevardnadze bear-hugged several members of Mr. Baker's staff when they left. Mr. Baker kept calling him "my friend and colleague." **********Why will Mr. Baker miss Mr. Shevardnadze? Reporters traveling with the Baker party were told: "I will miss him because he was a man of great integrity" and because "he's a very reasonable, rational person." **********American officials don't like Mr. Yeltsin. In part it is because they believe he is less predictable than Mr. Gorbachev and in part because he did in their friends. The terms they use to describe him are: "crude," "populist," "peasant-like," "impulsive." **********"By the end," said an American official, "Baker could deal with Shevardnadze as though he were an allied foreign minister. Yeltsin is more gruff, feisty, rude. Even though we like his politics more, we still find the man off-putting. The way he drove the final nails into the coffins of Gorbachev and Shevardnadze, with such alacrity, made us all shudder." **********The "funny thing" is, though, the official said, "Yeltsin was always closer to our ideas of what needed to be done inside the Soviet Union than Shevardnadze or Gorbachev. He was actually listening while we were lecturing and the other guys were not. But it was like in deposing Gorbachev he deposed our friends, and it is going to take time to get over that."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/world.print_headline: British and Irish Move on Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/world.body_text: **********Making way for what they called a historic opportunity to address the future of Northern Ireland, the British and Irish Governments suspended their own six-year-long consultations over the troubled province today in favor of new negotiations beginning next week in Belfast. **********At a meeting here, Peter Brooke, the British Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, and Gerard Collins, the Irish Foreign Minister, said the two Governments would suspend meetings of the Anglo-Irish Conference until at least July 16 to give the new diplomatic initiative a chance. **********Mr. Brooke, the architect of the initiative, is scheduled to begin the process on Tuesday, when he sits down with representatives of most of Northern Ireland's internal political parties to discuss an agenda for the meetings. **********Those talks will be the first stage in an attempt to build a new political framework for Northern Ireland intended to satisfy warring Catholic and Protestant factions and to improve relations between Dublin and Belfast. **********In two later stages over the next 10 weeks, the process envisions negotiations between political leaders in Northern Ireland and the Government in Dublin, and then talks between the Irish and British Governments. **********While some critics give the talks little chance of success, since they exclude Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, because it has not renounced the use of violence, the Irish Foreign Minister today described the coming negotations as a "wonderful opportunity" to bring some sort of peace to Northern Ireland. **********Until now, the British-Irish agreement, signed in 1985 between Margaret Thatcher and Garret FitzGerald, who were the Prime Ministers then, provided the only formal venue for discussing the future of Northern Ireland.
