https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/busin.main_headline:
Commercial Property Market;
Business Subleases on Rise in Meadowlands Complex
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/busin.print_headline:
Commercial Property Market;
Business Subleases on Rise in Meadowlands Complex
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/busin.body_text: **********As a result of a sublease signed this month, Sango, a Japanese importer, will take occupancy of 100,000 square feet of space that Gucci America Inc. no longer needs at its distribution center within a sprawling industrial park in the Hackensack Meadowlands here, seven miles west of Manhattan. **********This kind of subletting is playing an increasingly important role in the commercial-space market, as companies with large blocks of available space shrink their operations or postpone planned expansions. Their decisions add to the already swollen inventories of available space while creating leasing opportunities at below-market rents for other tenants. **********Sango, a marketer of chinaware, stoneware and flatware, which now has offices and a showroom in Manhattan and a warehouse in Pennsauken in southern New Jersey, will consolidate most of those operations into the new Meadowlands space, said Lawrence Tannenbaum, vice president of the company. Sango, a unit of Kasuga Sales Ltd. of Japan, signed a nine-year lease with options for 10 more years. Neither Sango nor Gucci would discuss the terms. **********Sango is retaining its showroom in Manhattan's Giftware Building at 41 Madison Avenue at the corner of East 26th Street. Mr. Tannenbaum said the company also planned to open a retail outlet at the Secaucus site. **********Gucci will continue to occupy the remaining 200,000 square feet it leases for a distribution office and retail location in the low-rise building along Hartz Way, close to Route 3. Gucci would not comment on the reasons for the space cutback. **********The site is part of Harmon Cove, a 250-acre industrial complex with 16 million square feet of office, warehouse and retail space that Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus has been developing since the 1970's. **********The real estate recession has taken its toll on the Meadowlands region, which over the last two decades had been transformed from mostly empty marshlands into a bustling commercial, industrial and residential precinct. At 25 percent, the vacancy rate for industrial space in the 32-square-mile region, which takes in parts of 14 communities in Hudson and Bergen counties, has nearly doubled since 1988, according to the East Rutherford office of the brokerage firm Cushman & Wakefield. **********Of the 10.7 million square feet of available space in the region, 9.5 million are leased directly and 1.1 million are subleased, said Stanley Danzig, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield. Indications are that subleasing in the Meadowlands region will rise, Mr. Danzig said. **********At the same time, rents have dropped by 33 percent, to an average of slightly more than $4 a square foot, Mr. Danzig said, adding that sublet space could be as much as 25 percent lower. Meanwhile, the construction of new space has slowed, which will help bring supply back into balance with demand, he added. **********With only about 1,200 of nearly 20,000 Meadowlands acres left to develop, the emphasis for future growth will be on infrastructure improvements -- including a rail station to link the area to different parts of the state -- and on affordable housing, said Robert Grant, a spokesman for the state's Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission. The commission, along with the Army Corps of Engineers, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency and the state's Department of Environmental Protection and the Sports and Exposition Authority, oversees development in the region. **********In the older industrial areas of the Meadowlands there will be opportunities for redevelopment, Mr. Grant noted. Despite the level of vacancies, leasing activity in the Meadowlands continues, albeit more slowly, as companies, looking for good deals, expand within or relocate to the area. The latter will "always include firms that need to service Manhattan," and want to take advantage of the area's location as well as save on taxes, utilities and services, Mr. Danzig said. **********Another draw, he said, is that at some projects, companies are permitted to use 10 percent of their space for retail operations. **********Those factors were among the reasons for Sango's move. The company searched for a new location in the metropolitan area for 18 months before choosing the Gucci site, said Norman Sturner, general partner of the Murray Hill Properties Corporation, which brokered the lease. He said the site afforded the company not only one of the most accessible spots within the park, but also one of the most heavily traveled. **********It lies in a section of the park that over the years has become recognized as a retail outlet center. Besides Gucci, other businesses with outlets there include Liz Claiborne Inc. and the Mikasa Company. **********The move into one location will enable the company to operate more efficiently, said Mr. Tannenbaum of Sango, noting that the setting "is exactly what we wanted." He said his company plans to relocate its offices into the space by December. No timetable has been set for the warehouse move. **********Ernest Christoph, a Hartz Mountain vice president, said the vacancy rate in the Harmon Cove complex was only 5 percent and his company was willing to make aggressive deals to draw tenants. Rents, he added, are competitive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/world.main_headline: Inquiry on Deaths Going Nowhere in Romania
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/world.print_headline: Inquiry on Deaths Going Nowhere in Romania
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/world.body_text: **********The Romanian revolution tore through this graceful Transylvanian city with startling ferocity. Rifle fire crackled from the rooftops, automatic weapons echoed through apartment buildings in the city center. When it was over, 98 people lay dead and hundreds were wounded. **********In the heady weeks after the December 1989 revolution, three senior police and security officials were tried and sentenced to long prison terms. A commission was formed to pursue the investigations, and people here believed that they would some day know thetruth about what had happened in those confusing weeks in December. **********In Sibiu, as in much of Romania, the truth is proving elusive. The three officials jailed last year have been released on appeal. The investigating commission seems stymied, important witnesses are refusing to cooperate, and prosecutors are ascribing many of the civilian deaths to "accidents" for which no one can be held responsible. **********Similar tales are unfolding in the provincial cities that bore the brunt of the fighting and dying in the revolution that ousted the dictatorship of President Nicolae Ceausescu. From Timisoara, the western city where the firstshots were fired, to Cluj, where the army officer who shot a protester in front of numerous witnesses has yet to be prosecuted, the wheels of Romanian justice are turning slowly. Embarrassing Current Leaders? **********Critics charge that the pace of these inquiries reflects a reluctance to pursue questions that might embarrass the National Salvation Front, an alliance of former Communists that took control immediately after the execution of Mr. Ceausescu. **********No one has explained with any precision the roles played by the various allied and competing factions in thedisintegrating Ceausescu apparatus; the front's leader, President Ion Iliescu, has done little to dispel the confusion. **********"I believe this Government tries to cover up everything, including Comrade President, who is surrounded by Securitate men," complained Octavian Horhoi, a 61-year-old retired music professor, referring to the secret police. Mr. Horhoi was shot through the upper arm in the corridor of his apartment building in Sibiu. **********"They keep saying: 'We're going to find the man who shot you.' It is all a big lie," said Mr. Horhoi, who is a member of a local association of people wounded during the revolution. **********Officials here insist that the lack of results in assessing responsibility for the deaths reflects the chaotic events, not instructions, subtle or otherwise,from the Government. **********The inquiry into the revolution is taking shape in a nondescript house on a small side street. Eugen Cosmo, a 60-year old lawyer who has been a prosecutor for 35 years, sits beneath a map dotted with colored pins for the people who died from Dec. 21 to Dec. 27. **********One curious fact continues to baffle people in Sibiu: Nearly all of those who died were killed from Dec. 22 through 27, after the Army had begun supporting the anti-Ceausescu forces and after the major contingent of secret police had been locked up. **********"No member of the Government has made any pressure on this commission," Mr. Cosmo contended. "It is the complexity of the situation, coupled with the fact that we have to find only the truth, which has prolonged this work."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/15/world.main_headline: MUBARAK STEPS UP ATTACK ON SHAMIR
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/15/world.print_headline: MUBARAK STEPS UP ATTACK ON SHAMIR
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/15/world.body_text: **********With no visible progress in American-sponsored Middle East peace efforts, President Hosni Mubarak and other Egyptian policy makers have begun venting increasing frustration at Israel, criticizing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and seeking to encourage political opposition to him among Israelis. **********The differences between Israel and the only Arab nation formally at peace with it has brought relations between them to their most strained since Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon, Israeli newspaper commentators have said. Increasingly, Mr. Mubarak has said he is losing hope of a peace settlement. **********Seven members of Israel's opposition Labor Party met here Thursday with the new Egyptian Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, who has said Israel's continued settlement of the occupied West Bank "poisons" peace efforts. **********The leader of the Israeli delegation, Haim Ramon, said they had told Mr. Moussa "that Egypt continues to fulfill a very important role in the peace process regardless of the position of the Israeli Government."  Invitation to Levy Seen **********Nawaf Masalha, an Arab member of the Israeli delegation, was quoted as saying Mr. Moussa had pledged to invite the Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, to come to Cairo to discuss the situation. **********While the visit of the Labor legislators has stirred controversy in Israel, Western diplomats here said Egypt saw it as a chance to persuade Israelis that their Government's rejection of United States proposals meant that they were missing an important chance to make peace. **********Mr. Shamir last week rejected suggestions by President Bush intended to overcome Arab-Israeli differences on how a Middle East peace conference should be held. Mr. Shamir said he opposed Arab demands for a United Nations role in the conference. Israel is pressing for a one-time peace conference with no powers to enforce decisions, followed by direct one-on-one negotiations with its Arab neighbors. **********Arab nations, Syria in particular, want a United Nations role to underline the purpose of a conference to trade occupied land for peace -- an idea Mr. Shamir rejects. **********While Egypt has taken a more flexible line on the mechanics of a peace conference, Mr. Mubarak has issued increasingly blunt warnings to Mr. Shamir that Arabs will not accept peace without the return of occupied land. "You cannot keep the land and peace together," he said in an interview published on Wednesday in the Financial Times of London. **********"Mr. Shamir will get very angry when I speak very frankly, and I'm still telling him, Mr. Shamir, I'm not against him," the Egyptian leader said. "But I cannot sit like this, and he is saying no for land for peace, no for this, no for that. I can't understand Mr. Shamir, frankly, nor his intentions."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/26/busin.body_text: **********Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks fell 2.4 percent in mid-June, but the decline did not dampen hopes that the auto market is recovering. **********The nine United States and Japanese auto makers that assemble cars in North America sold 212,116 cars in the June 11-20 period, a drop of four-tenths of a percent from the 212,910 cars sold a year earlier. **********For the period, the seasonally adjusted annual rate of domestic car sales was 6.5 million, still a good deal lower than the 7.4 million trend of the last few years, but significantly higher than the 5.5 million rate for April, when the market seemed to reach a trough. The rate was 6.3 million in early June.  'Very Encouraging' Numbers **********The light-truck sales of the six American and Japanese truck manufacturers dropped 5.7 percent, to 121,364, from 128,718 a year ago. **********Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, called the sales figures "very encouraging." **********John Casesa, automotive analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York, said: "The automotive recovery definitely is coming in fits and starts. This period I would characterize as better than expected." **********The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest producer, sold 101,743 cars, a drop of six-tenths of a percent from a year earlier, and 50,248 light trucks, down 1.9 percent. But for the first time in five years G.M.'s Chevrolet division could boast of higher year-to-date car and truck sales than its chief rival, the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company. **********David Hudgens, a Chevrolet spokesman, said the division planned to send congratulatory messages by computer to its 4,700 dealers. G.M.'s Buick, Oldsmobile and GMC truck divisions posted gains, while sales of Cadillacs and Pontiacs were down. **********Joel Pitcoff, a Ford sales analyst, said Chevrolet had been selling heavily to fleet buyers, like car-rental companies, while Ford sold proportionately more cars at retail. Ford, the nation's No. 2 auto maker, sold 51,091 cars, a 14.8 percent decline from a year earlier, and 40,071 light trucks, a 13.7 percent decline. **********Ward's Automotive Reports estimated that the Chrysler Corporation, which reports its sales only by month, sold 21,750 cars in mid-June, a 12.5 percent drop, and 25,250 light trucks, a 6.4 percent drop. **********The three largest Japanese producers all posted sharp increases in sales of cars and light trucks built in North America. In recent months Japanese auto makers have begun to use dealer rebates and subsidized leasing plans more aggressively in an attempt to continue to increase their share of the weak market. **********The Honda Motor Company sold 18,077 cars, up 60.3 percent from the 11,280 sold a year earlier. Sales of Honda's Accord model, which carries dealer rebates of up to $750, reached 12,203, compared with 5,973 in the 1990 period. Earlier this year, Honda's inventory of Accords became uncomfortably swollen. **********The Toyota Motor Corporation's sales of domestically built cars rose 31 percent, to 10,387, from 7,936 a year earlier. Camry sales were up 36.3 percent, and sales of the smaller Corolla model rose 22.9 percent. Toyota said its total vehicle sales, including imports, were up 25 percent in mid-June. The auto maker said sales of its recently introduced Paseo coupe and its redesigned Tercel subcompact had been strong. **********The Nissan Motor Company said its car sales advanced 14.9 percent for the period, to 3,634, while light-truck sales gained 7.8 percent, to 3,737.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; Back From Retirement
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; Back From Retirement
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/13/busin.body_text: **********Stung by the need to take a $1.68 billion write-off, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation called one of its executives out of retirement last week to stanch the financial hemorrhaging at the company's troubled credit subsidiary. **********Leo W. Yochum, who is 64 years old, left Westinghouse in 1988 after 17 years as chief financial officer. He returns as chairman and chief executive of Westinghouse Financial Services Inc., reporting directly to the parent company's chairman, Paul E. Lego. He replaces William A. Powe, who was named a special consultant. **********Mr. Yochum (pronounced YOCK-em) said his mandate is to shrink the subsidiary's $11 billion portfolio, about half of which is invested in real estate. In announcing the write-off -- which represented the reduction in the value of investments in leveraged buyouts and junk bonds as well as real estate -- Mr. Lego said distress sales by the Federal Resolution Trust Corporation were undermining the value of real estate properties. Because of the write-off, the company had a net loss of $1.48 billion for the third quarter. **********Mr. Yochum said his first priority is to make sure the company can obtain funding in the credit markets to "finance the assets we have." After that, he said, the company must decide which properties to retain until prices improve and which to discard. **********Wall Street analysts said Westinghouse turned to Mr. Yochum in part because he had earned the respect and trust of money managers and credit rating agencies during his long tenure as chief financial officer. That credibility will prove useful as he seeks to rebuild the finance subsidiary's portfolio, they said. **********Mr. Yochum, who joined Westinghouse in 1951, was named corporate director of audits in 1962. He became corporate controller and vice president in 1967. **********During his retirement, Mr. Yochum indulged his appetite for travel. "I had a lot of fun," he said, traveling more "in those years than in all the years before." For now, though, his travels will largely be restricted to trips between his home in suburban Pittsburgh, near Westinghouse headquarters, and his Manhattan apartment, which will become his base when dealing with Wall Street.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/world.main_headline: Winnie Mandela Takes Stand To Deny Role in Abductions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/world.print_headline: Winnie Mandela Takes Stand To Deny Role in Abductions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/world.body_text: **********Winnie Mandela, the wife of the African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, took the witness stand in her defense today to deny that she helped kidnap four young men and assaulted them in her home in Soweto. **********Mrs. Mandela testified that she was visiting a friend several hundred miles away in the Orange Free State when four youths were taken from a Methodist Church home in Soweto on Dec. 29, 1988, and beaten by her bodyguards. She said she only learned of the incident several days after her return. **********The youngest of the youths, James (Stompie) Moeketsi Seipei, was later found in a Soweto field with his throat cut. He was 14 years old. Jerry Richardson, the coach of the soccer team that protected Mrs. Mandela, was convicted of the murder and sentenced to hang. **********The surviving youths testified at his trial that Mrs. Mandela had led the assaults on them inside her house. Two of the witnesses, Kenneth Kgase and Barend Thabiso Mono, gave the same evidence at the current trial. Before he was to testify, the third youth, Gabriel Pelo Megkwe, disappeared, as have four of Mrs. Mandela's co-defendants.  Home in Exile **********Under the questioning of her attorney, George Bizos, Mrs. Mandela said today that she had left to visit Brandfort, a town in the Orange Free State, hours before the young men were removed from the Methodist home. Mrs. Mandela was exiled by the Government to Brandfort in 1977 for nine years. She said she went back to help revive a social welfare program there. **********Mr. Bizos told the judge, Michael S. Stegmann, that he would present the driver of Mrs. Mandela's car and a friend in Brandfort with whom she said she stayed to support her alibi. **********When she returned to Soweto, Mrs. Mandela said, she was told that the four young men were staying at her home to escape the homosexual overtures of a white minister at the Soweto church house. She said she paid them no notice because young people in trouble frequently stayed at her home. **********Mr. Kgase and Mr. Mono have separately testified that Mrs. Mandela slapped, punched and whipped them to make them say they had sexual relations with the white minister before turning them over to her bodyguards for more brutal beatings. They have denied any homosexual activity. **********When emissaries from a local group later came to her house to ask whether young men were being held there, Mrs. Mandela said she was outraged but told them to look for themselves.  'I Knew Nothing' **********"I told them I knew nothing about their allegations," Mrs. Mandela said. **********Mrs. Mandela said she later asked Mr. Richardson whether the four youths had been assaulted in her home. **********"He said there were slappings when these children first came," Mrs. Mandela said. **********Mrs. Mandela looked composed throughout her testimony. She faces cross-examination later this week from the prosecutor, Jan Swanepoel. **********Mr. Mandela, who initially accompanied his wife to court, was absent today, attending a two-day meeting between the African National Congress and the Pan-Africanist Congress in Harare.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/06/busin.body_text: **********The Canandaigua Wine Company confirmed today that it was negotiating to acquire all of the assets of Guild Wineries and Distilleries, a grape growers' cooperative based in Woodbridge, Calif. Guild is best known for Cook's champagne and is the seventh-largest winery in the United States. Canandaigua is the third-largest, and the largest in New York. **********"Our wine products are primarily popularly priced, non- California brands," said Richard Sands, president and chief operating officer of Canandaigua. "We view Guild's brands as a very appropriate complement to our portfolio." Acquiring Guild would "give us a very strong entry into the dynamic California wine market," he added. **********Mr. Sands would not comment on the status of the deal, but wine industry sources said it was likely to be completed later this week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.main_headline: Malaysia Trading Plan Seeks a Unified Voice
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.print_headline: Malaysia Trading Plan Seeks a Unified Voice
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.body_text: **********East Asia may be the site of some of the world's fastest-growing economic powers, but historically it has always been so fractious and competitive that it could never be organized into anything resembling a trading bloc. **********Now, with the the unification of the European market approaching and feelings of alienation from the United States rising, Malaysia is trying a debated effort to organize the region into what it delicately calls an "economic grouping" of Asian nations. Little Discussed in West **********The plan, laid out two months ago by Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysia's Prime Minister and the steward of one of Asia's biggest economic success stories, has been little discussed in the West, but it has become one of the hottest topics in East Asia. **********It is still far from clear that Mr. Mahathir's East Asian economic grouping will ever come to pass, especially in a region that has never been able to translate its political alliances into economic ones. While his idea has attracted some support, its success hinges on the willingness of one participant: Japan, whose economy is the linchpin of the rest of Asia. **********So far, Japanese politicians are skittish about any economic alliance that would seem to pit it against Europe and the United States, which has developed a free-trade agreement with Canada and is working toward one with Mexico. **********The next few months will be crucial, as Malaysia completes its first round of explanations and seeks to create a formal trading body. It could pick up more support, especially if the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade talks fails, paving the way for fiercer direct competition.  Trade Barriers Common **********Many Asian countries are known for erecting huge trade barriers to protect their infant industries. Malaysia produces manufactured goods that it cannot sell to its closest neighbors, and it slaps huge taxes on imported cars and other goods. **********But Mr. Mahathir, who in 10 years as Malaysia's Prime Minister has become a powerful and sometimes feared figure in Southeast Asian politics, has clearly struck a chord with his idea for a more organized and aggressive Asian economic alliance. **********"Singly, we will have no hope of arguing our case," he said. "Only together will we have more bargaining power and be in a better position when negotiating for free trade." **********No one, not even some of Mr. Mahathir's Cabinet members, can define precisely what kind of economic bloc he is trying to form. Everyone seems to agree that it would include the six members of the Association of South East Asian Nations, or Asean: Thailand, Singapore, the Philippines, Indonesia, Brunei and Malaysia. Mr. Mahathir has said that the group will also include Vietnam, Myanmar (formerly Burma), Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea. **********But the list excludes countries populated chiefly by non-Asian races, including Australia and New Zealand. For weeks, Malaysia's Minister for International Trade and Industry, Rafidah Aziz, has been traveling through Asia seeking members. **********"What we are talking about is enhancing regional trade among countries with commonalities here in Asia," said Mrs. Rafidah, who supports Mr. Mahathir. **********The Prime Minister's plan has not been welcomed by everyone, and Malaysia has been amending parts of it. Indonesia has expressed no enthusiasm, and Taiwan and Hong Kong, among others, have been silent. **********The reasons for the objections are not clear, but some Asian officials say they fear that a poisoning of relations with the United States or Japan could hurt their best chances for export. Last week, Mr. Mahathir said he thought the United States was trying to influence some nations not to join the trade group, which American officials in Kuala Lumpur deny. **********In the last two months, since Mr. Mahathir took his Cabinet and neighboring nations by surprise with the proposal, the description of the trade grouping has begun to shift. He originally spoke of a trading bloc, immediately prompting fears that he was looking for a way to create trade barriers against countries outside Asia. **********The word "bloc" was then deemed offensive because it could scare away Japan and could raise the ire of American officials, who have not supported the plan. Malaysia now is speaking of a "grouping" that would work within multilateral trading groups, like the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. **********Officials in Kuala Lumpur also insist it would "complement" other organizations, like Asean, a 24-year old political alliance that has never been effective as an economic entity.  The Plan's Objective **********The object, Malaysia says, is to turn Southeast Asia into a leading exporting force and an investment haven, to give it power to match Europe and America. So far, exporting is dominated by Japan and, to a lesser degree, the nations known as the "four tigers": South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore. Only Japan enjoys such political influence. **********"The whole line is that this will not exclude anybody, as long as they look Asian," one Western diplomat here said. "But no one can say what 'complement' means. And this is hardly a group of like-minded countries they are getting together." **********Indeed, it is a collection of nations at different stages of development. **********At one end of the spectrum are the "tigers." They have grown so quickly in the last decade that they are looking for cheap labor and investment opportunities abroad. Then comes nations like Thailand, perhaps Asia's greatest success story in the late 1980's, though it has begun to show signs of choking on its overexpansion. Malaysia follows, a country that has quickly moved beyond the days of tin and rubber plantations to become a manufacturing center. **********But also in the group are countries mired in problems of economic reform, like China, Myanmar, North Korea and Vietnam, all of which have discussed various degrees of economic reform, but have actively resisted political liberalization. Each has considerable poverty and lack a skilled work force. Capitalists and Communists **********If they joined, it would be the first time that some of the world's most fervent capitalists, like the Singaporeans, joined some of its most unreconstructed Communists, like the Vietnamese, in a trading group. **********But the critical element to the grouping is Japan, which still has no formal relations with North Korea and is on strained terms with Myanmar and Vietnam. Some Japanese officials have suggested that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu may be unenthusiastic about the proposal. **********So, at first, were most other countries. But Singapore changed its mind last month, and its new Prime Minister, Goh Chok Tong, said the grouping would give small Asian countries a voice they now lack. The Philippines has also been mildly supportive, and China termed the idea interesting. Indonesia and Thailand, Malaysia's biggest competitors, have all but dismissed the concept. **********The United States has said little, but American diplomats in Asia seem unenthused, particularly because the United States would be excluded. **********"It will take some time to fully develop a view," said one American diplomat here, "because no one can quite figure out what the idea is yet."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.body_text: **********Crossland Savings, one of the largest savings institutions in New York state, announced yesterday that its losses from bad loans had accumulated to the point that it had agreed with Federal regulators to seek a merger with a stronger company. **********Until a partner is found, the Brooklyn-based savings bank will remain open for business, and its deposits will continue to be insured up to the maximum of $100,000 per account allowed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. **********Crossland, which changed its name in 1985 from Metropolitan Savings Bank to reflect its grand plans to expand nationwide, was a victim of the downturn in the New York real estate market. As developers defaulted on loans for projects, Crossland's cushion of capital to absorb additional losses all but disappeared.  Announces $123 Million Loss **********Yesterday, as a Federal bank examination neared completion, Crossland announced a second-quarter loss of $123.1 million, equal to $8.84 a share. Losses have totaled $741 million in the last two-and-one-half years. **********The company was unable to replenish its capital base as outside investor groups, like the Coast to Coast Financial Corporation, controlled by the Pritzker family of Chicago, shied away. By yesterday, its capital shortfall was so great that a proposed plan to convert debt and preferred stock to new equity would not have been enough to meet minimum Federal standards. **********Although Crossland is insolvent by the regulators' accounting rules, it will not be closed. "By allowing them to remain open we have learned that you can avoid the deterioration in values that normally occurs with a Government conservatorship," said a senior official in the Office of Thrift Supervision, who insisted that he not be identified. He added, "With core deposits of $6 billion, it is a very attractive company." Large Cost to Government **********Because any buyer of Crossland would accept only the financially sound parts of its business, however, F.D.I.C. officials estimate that a merger would cost the Government agency $500 million to $1 billion, making it one of the 10 most expensive bank collapses in history. **********Crossland, with $9.9 billion in assets, vies with the Dime Savings Bank, of Garden City, L.I., as the largest savings institution in the New York market. **********Regulators predicted that a buyer for Crossland could be found in two to four months, and said that the Republic National Bank of New York had already expressed an interest, as had two other unidentified banks. Republic, which acquired the Williamsburg Savings Bank and the Manhattan Savings Bank on favorable terms in the late 1980's, is one of the strongest banks in the country. **********"Any of the large banks in the city would be interested in their branch network," said Gary Gordon, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. Other banks will shun Crossland's holdings of troubled real estate loans, he said, but he noted that the institution's branches were extraordinarily effective at collecting consumer deposits, which average more than $200 million a branch and exceed $300 million at some branches.  Dim View for Shareholders **********Howard Rosencrans, an analyst at H. D. Brous & Company, a securities firm in Great Neck, L.I., said he expected that Crossland's value to common shareholders, as well as to holders of its $330 million of preferred stock, "will be wiped out by whatever merger occurs." Crossland's common stock fell 25 cents yesterday, to 50 cents a share, on the New York Stock Exchange, which plans to de-list the company's issues. **********Mr. Rosencrans said that as losses mounted in the last two years, prospects of a rebound grew dim "and the main goal of management has been to prevent a run by depositors." Crossland's chairman, Maurice L. Reissman, who is 48 years old, will remain the company's top officer, at least until a merger is arranged. **********The slide in Crossland's fortunes was swift. As recently as 1988, when the company was $15 billion in size and looking for more acquisitions, Mr. Reissman could boast that "we are one of the better banks in terms of asset qualtiy" and "one of the most profitable thrifts in America." **********The company is planning to sell all of its operations outside the New York metropolitan area, including small savings institutions in Florida, Oregon, Virginia and Washington state, and a large mortgage-banking company in California.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/22/busin.main_headline: The Car Is Dead. Long Live the . . .
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/22/busin.print_headline: The Car Is Dead. Long Live the . . .
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/22/busin.body_text: **********The people who say they have the alternative to the car have put their show on the road. Ragtag and quirky, maybe, but definitely alternative. **********The "Festival of Solar, Electric and Human-Powered Vehicles" toured Washington for three days this week and then began a six-day trip to New York. It featured experimental bicycles and cargo tricycles, high-tech electric go-carts and a solar-powered plastic car, a lot of enthusiasm, a lot of rain and heat, and a sense that a long evolutionary struggle lies ahead. **********If the automobile is the dinosaur, as the festival's organizers maintain, then perhaps these are the primitive mammals that will supplant it -- still scurrying in the underbrush for fear of being squashed, but confident that technology is evolving their way. **********In Washington, tourists gawked and Congressmen ignored them, but at least workers at the Environmental Protection Agency gave them an attentive welcome. Lightwheels, the New York group that organized the event, planned to proceed to New York under alternative power, keeping to the back roads. The idea was to somehow look inconspicuous, since there was no parade permit. **********But this morning, facing an expected high of 95 degrees and a shortage of riders, most of the vehicles went into the back of a lumbering second-hand U-Haul truck on the way to a display at Harford Community College in Bel Air, Md. **********Still, imagination and ingenuity were as powerful as internal combustion. John G. Tetz, a designer at Bell Laboratories, brought his redesigned bicycle, to which he had grafted the engine of a weed trimmer. Delivering two-tenths of a horsepower, it was not selected for speed, but to assist on hills without weighing the rider down when it wasn't running. **********Mr. Tetz rode (drove?) from Florida to New Jersey earlier this year on 107 ounces of gasoline. "I only talk ounces," he said. For those who insist on talking miles per gallon, that comes to well over 1,000. **********A rider can supply far more energy over a day at moderate effort, said Mr. Tetz, so using the engine on hills aids human efficiency. The problem, he said, is that his device is for serious transportation, which is not what comes to mind when people see a bicycle married to a Weed Eater.   Ugly Duckling With Solar Cells **********Darrell E. Murphy, an electrical engineer at a Tennessee nuclear plant, brought a homemade electric car -- the Sundriver -- that charges itself with solar cells on the hood and roof. His car looks like an ugly duckling, he volunteered, and in the leading electric car race, the American Tour de Sol, he came in behind the General Motors entry this year and last. But G.M.'s car cost millions to develop, he pointed out; his budget was limited to "whatever is in my pocket that day." **********The car, his sixth, cost less than $10,000 for materials, including $2,800 for the solar cells, he said. It carries four Sears lead-acid batteries of the kind commonly found on motorboats and goes 30 to 35 miles on a charge, whether by sun or house current. It had to come up from Sale Creek, Tenn., on a homemade trailer behind a factory-made Chevy pickup truck. **********The solar car is built mostly of plastic plumbing pipes. Freed from its trailer for a ride in the sunshine this morning, it squeaked down the road as a plastic car might be expected to -- but not loud enough to drown out the chirping birds. Because its range is so short, taking the electric car on the road is a two-man operation, with an assistant driving the pickup truck. **********For most of these eco-inventors, commercial production is a dream so far. Mr. Murphy hopes to mass-produce his car if he can patent the plastic frame and then find a rich, environmentally minded backer. Mr. Tetz is also looking for support; not even the McCulloch Corporation, which gave him the weed-trimmer motor, seems interested. **********George Bliss of New York City brought a cargo tricycle -- the "Maxi-Loader Dump Trike" -- with a capacity of more than 400 pounds, that his company, Human Power Research, has recently begun selling in Manhattan as an alternative to delivery vans. He built his first after the city towed his van and he could not afford to pay the parking tickets to retrieve it from the pound. **********He also brought a gaggle of pedicabs, or bicycle rickshaws, which are still awaiting a market. Some of the pedicabs have sidecars in which the passenger faces the person pedaling. "Tandem bicycles are considered the height of romantic, but you can't have a conversation on them without turning around and endangering your life," Mr. Bliss said. **********As the former manager of a salvage shop, his creations incorporate some obviously recycled parts, like chaise longues. One has a rattan seat on a bentwood chair under a huge umbrella. It is the Whimcycle, Mr. Bliss said, inspired by the fanciful machines in Dr. Seuss's "The Cat in the Hat."   Attention and Companionship **********It runs against the basic premise of the Industrial Revolution to substitute muscle for machine, but Mr. Bliss has found his pedicabs get warm public attention. He pedaled one on the Five Borough Bicycle Tour in April, his passenger a woman he had met at a party the previous evening. Spectators hailed him by shouting that chivalry was not dead. **********Other participants hoping to hit the mass market include John Benditt. He is lobbying the Department of Energy for a $150,000 grant to develop and begin manufacturing his Recumbent Electric Muscular Moped, an all-terrain vehicle that is a study in minimalism. His existing model looks like a high-tech go-cart, with three wheels and a fiberglass shell. He plans a four-wheel model with a plexiglass windscreen. **********A recumbent design lets the rider sit with legs stretched out to the pedals, a position that allows greater muscle efficiency and lower wind resistance than a conventional bicycle. Although Mr. Tetz's weed-trimmer bicycle also uses this approach, Mr. Benditt's version is assisted by an electric motor. A small battery can be charged on house current and by generating electricity from some of the energy the moped loses in braking. It can cover 25 to 30 miles at a top speed of 25 miles an hour. **********An energetic human would provide about 25 percent of the power, but someone who would settle for a shorter range would not have to pedal at all. Mr. Benditt plans to add solar cells to recharge the battery and a propeller to make his moped amphibious, among other refinements.   Mechanics and Philosophers **********Mr. Benditt describes himself as a mechanic and jack-of-all-trades, a description that fits most participants. In previous years, people like these might have built better mousetraps; in the biotech future, perhaps, a better mouse. Right now, in an era of rising pollution and oil imports, men like these focus on transportation. (All of the festival participants were men, although women have observed the benefits of alternative vehicles from the pedicabs' passenger seats.) **********But there is also an element of social engineering, especially by the organizer, Steve Stollman, a New York City cabinetmaker who calls cars anti-human. "The automobile is the perfect expression of what not to do -- to poison people, threaten to kill them, and take up their space," he said. Cars isolate people from one another, too, he said. He says he doubts that Detroit can combine the environmental benefits of the bicycle with some of the creature comforts of the car. Reform, if it comes, will come from the bottom up, he said. **********The vehicles are scheduled to roll into New York on Tuesday. Lightwheels will exhibit some of them at the Urban Center of the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue at 51st Street, from July 10 until Sept. 6.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Network Sales Executive In New Role After 25 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/busin.print_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Network Sales Executive In New Role After 25 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/busin.body_text: **********JERRY DOMINUS, the vice president of sales at CBS for seven years, had an unusual lunch partner recently -- Larry Hoffner, who runs sales at NBC. **********"We found we had a lot to talk about," Mr. Dominus said with a laugh. **********The reason: Jerome Henry Dominus is scheduled to start his new job today as senior vice president and director of national television and programming in the United States for J. Walter Thompson. **********Executives often move back and forth between television and advertising, especially between television sales and agency media buying. After all, who would know more about how to strike a hard bargain with a network sales executive than a former network sales executive? **********But in the case of Mr. Dominus, the change seems particularly noteworthy. He ran all of CBS television advertising sales for seven years until 1989, when the company undertook a reorganization. Since then, he has headed prime-time sales, among other duties. **********By switching sides, the 52-year-old Mr. Dominus offers another reminder that there is a growing world beyond the original three networks. Indeed, the prime reason for leaving CBS, he said, is to "broaden his palette" and make advertising buying decisions in the cable and syndications markets, as well as with other networks. **********"The networks are absolutely the single most powerful medium available to any marketer and will continue to be by a wide margin for many years," Mr. Dominus said last week. "But they just are not where they were when I started the business." **********The change in the networks' status leaves network television work "intellectually more stimulating and demanding," he said. "And there are still many, many exciting and glamorous aspects of the business. But of course it's become much more competitive." **********His decision to leave comes at an important time for advertisers and clients. Every year around this time, the networks and advertising agencies who buy commercial time for clients begin what Mr. Dominus likes to call a "multibillion-dollar crapshoot" -- the negotiating of long-term advertising deals in the "up front" season in advance of the fall television season, and then later the filling out of advertising schedules in the "scatter market." **********Last year, for the first time in years, demand for commercial time in the scatter market was weak, bringing prices down to the point that better deals were struck there than in the normally cheaper up-front market. **********Smart deal-making is crucial because the fluctuation in price for a typical 30-second network commercial during prime time can be staggering: from $80,000 to $300,000, many advertising and television executives say. The same piece of commercial time can fetch a dozen different prices. **********"Everyone is trying to figure out a strategy," Mr. Dominus said. **********Many media buyers say some advertisers have gone ahead and quietly struck long-term deals, believing that tradition will return and the best bargains will be offered early. Mr. Dominus said that could be a smart move because if too many advertisers waited for the scatter market, demand would outstrip supply and prices would rise. Other buyers say they are determined to wait. **********Reflecting on his 25 years at CBS, Mr. Dominus said he was proud of several achievements, including the aggressive multimedia promotions CBS had undertaken. Among them was a contest giving away a full-sized replica of the house at Southfork Ranch on "Dallas." **********The promotion linked the viewing of "Dallas" with coupons tied to the show that were placed in newspapers by "Dallas" advertisers. **********"This re-enforced the value of network advertising for a payoff in another medium," he said. "Finding other ways to expand on that relationship is one thing I'm looking forward to."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/busin.main_headline: Leaders of Plastics Industry Seeking 25% Recycling Goal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/busin.print_headline: Leaders of Plastics Industry Seeking 25% Recycling Goal
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/busin.body_text: **********Perceiving a strong public demand for environmentally sound products, leaders of the plastics industry said today that they would seek to recycle 25 percent of all plastic bottles and containers produced every year by 1995. **********The most recent figures from the Environmental Protection Agency show that only slightly more than 1 percent of all plastic products are currently recycled. **********John E. Pepper, the president of Procter & Gamble, one of the largest users of plastic packaging, cited "a real sea change" in environmental concerns in the last several years. "I have never seen an issue change with such force," he added. **********The Society of Plastic Industries said legislation to curb the use of plastic packages was pending at some level in 49 states. **********Mr. Pepper and Edgar S. Woolard Jr., the chairman of the Du Pont Company, said plastics producers and users would spend $20 million a year through their trade group, the Council for Solid Waste Solutions, to help promote plastics recycling. **********They said the assistance would take the form of information for communities seeking to recycle; matching collectors with processors, and buying recycled plastic to use in new products. **********About 1,500 municipalities in this country operate curbside recycling programs, one-third of which include plastics. **********Mr. Pepper said people believe that plastics are hostile to the environment, even though paper and paper products constitute a far larger component of trash. **********"Plastics is the new kid on the block," he said. "They are made of chemicals by oil companies, so they cannot be good for the environment." Yet, he said, many of the most popular types of plastics can easily be recycled if they are collected. **********According to officials of the council, which held today's news conference, the capacity to reprocess plastics has been growing faster than plastic collection. They said the 900 companies in the business were running at only 66 percent of capacity. **********This is in contrast to old newspapers, which quickly produced a glut a few years ago in the Northeast when many communities began collection programs. The reason was the lack of capacity to process then into new products, a situation that has improved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/17/world.main_headline: Volcano Stills City by Base In Philippines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/17/world.print_headline: Volcano Stills City by Base In Philippines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/17/world.body_text: **********This once-thriving city of nearly 300,000 people has begun to look like the ghost town that many residents fear it is now destined to become. **********Hastily scrawled "For Sale" signs are set in the windows of shops and restaurants that have been shuttered since early last month, when a volcano showered Angeles with a dense layer of ash and forced the evacuation of the area's largest employer, the American-run Clark Air Base. **********Now comes word from American officials that the United States plans to abandon Clark entirely because of the damage caused by Mount Pinatubo, a move that would mean economic catastrophe for Angeles and other cities and villages that have grown up in the shadow of the 89-year-old base. **********"If the Americans close the base, I must close up my school," said Rolando Cataquian, a 32-year-old teacher whose school provided high-school level tutoring to the Philippine wives of American servicemen stationed at Clark. All but 3 of his 33 students in the summer term have been evacuated from the Philippines, and Mr. Cataquian says he will soon be forced out of business.  'People Will Suffer' **********"Some people say it will be a good thing if the Americans leave Clark," he said. "I can tell you that people in Angeles do not believe that. If the Americans leave, there will be so many people out of work. People will suffer." **********Most of the 15,000 Americans have already left, driven away by Mount Pinatubo. With scientists saying eruptions may continue for several years, the economy of Angeles is already in grave peril. But a permanent shutdown of Clark would cost the jobs of 40,000 Filipinos employed at the base before the eruption and result annually in the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue to local businesses. **********The Philippine Government once proposed that Clark be replaced by a civilian airport or by an industrial park, but those plans have been put on hold because of Mount Pinatubo. **********Angeles has long had a reputation among American servicemen as a city of vice -- of massage parlors and 24-hour honky-tonk bars -- and to some degree that reputation is deserved. **********The main streets of the city are lined with businesses that cater exclusively to the licentious pleasures of American air men. It is for that reason alone that some prominent Filipinos, appalled by the prostitution and public drunkenness around the base, are pleased at the prospect of an American withdrawal. Others see the bases as an unwelcome vestige of the days when the Philippines were a United States colony.  Streets Clogged With Ash **********Yet a walk through the city, along wide streets still clogged by the talc-like volcanic ash, would suggest that few critics of the base are to be found among the residents of Angeles. Directly or indirectly, most Filipinos who live here depend on Clark for their livelihood, and they are frightened by the American threat to pull out. **********"The Americans have brought influences that are good and bad," said Carlos de la Cruz, secretary of the Clark Field Baptist Church, which is a few hundred yards from the entrance to the base, and a block from a cluster of saloons and a massage parlor. **********"Personally, I believe there is much more good because of the Americans," he said. "Isn't it good that the Americans can provide jobs?" Since the eruption, the church has lost the American half of its 300-member congregation, and Sunday offerings are down from $1,500 a week to less than $300. **********The church's American pastor has gone home to the United States, and it is not clear whether a permanent replacement will arrive. Mr. de la Cruz said the church may soon have to lay off some of its six Philippine workers. **********Because of jobs created by the base, Angeles has long been an affluent city in a nation in which the per-capita income is less than $1,000 a year.  Pizza Hut and Dunkin' Donuts **********The American influence is everywhere in the city. There is a McDonald's, a Pizza Hut, a Kentucky Fried Chicken, a Dunkin' Donuts, a Bank of Boston branch office, a Goodyear auto center. All employ many Filipinos. **********"I am very pro-bases," said Len Medina, a 27-year-old Angeles native who is the day supervisor at the Pizza Hut. "These are good jobs we have." **********Residents of Angeles are conversant in the details of base negotiations between the Philippines and the United States. They seem well aware that the United States is closing military bases at home, and that many Americans are losing jobs because of Pentagon cuts. **********But Mariz de Jesus, a 35-year-old hostess at the U & I Canteen, said the plight of Filipinos would be far more bleak. "It is not the same," she said. "If the Americans leave from Clark, there is no hope for us. We cannot go someplace and look for better jobs. There are no other jobs."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/02/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; For Luck, and Memories, a Little Bit of Lace
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/02/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: War Notebook; For Luck, and Memories, a Little Bit of Lace
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/02/world.body_text: **********Tucked inside the Kevlar helmets of the many soldiers are the most sentimental mementos of loved ones far away: photographs, letters, lacy pink panties. **********For many male members of the 82d Airborne Division, frilly undergarments from their wives or girlfriends are the most vivid reminders of sweethearts left behind. **********"When I put my helmet on I think of her because of the perfume," said Sgt. Sal Garcia Jr., 24, of Norwalk, Calif., as he doffed his head gear to reveal his scented battlefield luck charm. **********"It motivates me to get through another day because I know someone is there waiting for me," he said. **********It took Specialist 4 Michael Luoma, a 21-year-old medic from Calumet, Mich., two months to persuade his girlfriend to send a pair of pink panties trimmed with white lace. **********Now that it has arrived, keeping it clean in the huge dust bowl that is Saudi Arabia is another matter. **********"It's pretty embarrassing to wash them" he said. "Definitely, they make you think of home."  Guard Duty for the Band **********The First Armored Division's band has traded in its tubas, trombones and trumpets for M-16's and guard duty at an encampment here. **********Army band members are trained to provide security for combat units during wartime, and that's what most musicians here are doing. **********The First Armored band, though, is still squeezing in some foot-stomping tunes for some of the army's most highly trained tank crews. **********"We are still trying to entertain the soldiers as much as we can," said Chief Warrant Officer Donald Simpson, the division's band leader. **********But the martial music they have always played has suddenly taken on new significance. **********"It's hard to get mentally ready to pick up your horn and play because you're not sure whether or not you got to get your gas mask ready," Specialist 4 Jodi Walz, a trumpeter, said. **********There are distinct advantages for the musicians who, like all performers, crave the limelight. **********"We're the only game in town right now," said First Sgt. Michael Morgan, another trumpeter. "So when we get a chance to play, they really appreciate it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/01/world.print_headline: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW; Ukrainians Await Bush With Skepticism
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/01/world.body_text: **********On the eve of his first venture into the heated world of Soviet politics in the provinces, President Bush was denounced today by the Ukraine's leading independence movement as having been "hypnotized by Gorbachev" at the summit meeting. **********The Ukrainian popular movement known as Rukh, the umbrella group for more than a dozen of the republic's opposition parties, offered Mr. Bush an advance sample of the sharp-edged politics that await him in this rich, sprawling republic, which the President will visit on Thursday on his way home from Moscow. **********Ukrainian politicians cautioned him today to expect the six-hour visit to be no easy, folksy photo opportunity. **********Ivan Drach, the Rukh chairman, said Mr. Bush was so supportive and uncritical of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that Mr. Bush would arrive here as the Soviet leader's "messenger," with no real appreciation of the suffering that the Ukrainian republic has seen under the Kremlin because of its yearning for independence. **********"We must remember that as President, Bush has consistently snubbed the democratic movement" in the republic, Mr. Drach said at a news conference as officials of the United States consulate here listened in the audience.  Bush's Touchy Touchdown **********Forewarned, the President will be touching down in one of the nation's most important and politically fractious republics, one that accounts for a quarter of the nation's food and a third of its industrial production. **********Mr. Bush will be visiting a rapidly warming caldron where the President of the Ukrainian Parliament, Leonid M. Kravchuk, has been among the fastest to rush to the head of the nationalist parade and hedge his allegiance to the Kremlin with increasingly militant demands for sovereignty. **********As insurgent politics have taken hold in the Ukraine, few Communists have been so thoroughly born again as the popular Mr. Kravchuk, the son of a peasant who rose to initial power as ideology chief of the Ukrainian Communists. Mr. Kravchuk has adapted by dropping the Russian language from his public appearances and speaking only Ukrainian. **********More painful for Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Kravchuk's Parliament has blocked the Soviet leader's hopes for early adoption of a treaty of national unity with the sovereignty-hungry republics. **********For decades the Ukraine has seethed with the memories of Soviet economic exploitation and wholesale terror. An estimated 10 million people perished in the famine that resulted from Stalin's policies 60 years ago. **********Nowadays, with politics opened up by the reforms of Mr. Gorbachev, the Ukraine seethes with outspoken ethnic groups and dozens of political parties that broadcast every variety of independence and sovereignty demands. **********A year after the republic's Parliament declared its sovereignty over the laws of the national Government, the Ukraine is taking the first steps toward forming the officer corps of its own army. Officials are trying to produce the first Ukrainian currency. **********Mr. Bush will find few stops free of controversy on his itinerary through this city, the third-largest in the nation, with 2.5 million people. **********Some Ukrainian Jews complain that the nearby memorial at Babi Yar, the Nazi killing ground that Mr. Bush will visit during his tour, offers scant recognition that tens of thousands who died there were Jews. **********The Parliament where he will speak still has a Communist majority, but it is one that recently scrambled to stay abreast of the sovereignty fever, rejecting the party's call to vote for the speedy debate sought by Mr. Gorbachev for the proposed union treaty. **********Instead, the Parliament, mindful of the public's growing militancy, has refused to even consider the measure until September.  Miners Court Intellectuals **********With 52 million residents, the Ukraine is the nation's second-most-populous republic. Long divided politically between the Russianized and conservative eastern provinces and the Western bastions of independence, the Ukraine is busy with change: the disgruntled, underpaid coal miners of the east have began making alliances with the independent-minded intellectuals of the west. **********Even Communist hard-liners are talking of independence, if only to avoid being swept up in the reshaped national union that they fear President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic will come to dominate with his increasing anti-Communist policies. **********"The biggest mistake President Bush can make is if he does not pay full attention to democratic movements in republics, and supports only Gorbachev," said Aleksandr Burakovsky, chairman of Rukh's council of nationalities. Such sentiment, heard frequently, points to Mr. Bush's political problem in needing to pay credible heed to nationalist movements yet avoid seeming to be a severe critic of Mr. Gorbachev. **********President Bush had best avoid any sign of stopping here as if it were a colorful outpost of Mr. Gorbachev's Soviet realm, said John P. Hewko, an American lawyer working as a consultant on the problems of reforming the center-dependent Ukrainian government into something more sovereign. **********"The most important thing about the visit is that it will put the Ukraine on the map," Mr. Hewko said. "The whole world will finally be paying attention."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Child World Sale Completed
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.body_text: **********The CNC Holding Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell the 82 percent of Child World Inc. it owns to WC Acquisition, an investment group headed by two former senior executives of Toys "R" Us Inc., W. John Devine and Ronald Tuchman. **********Under the terms of the non- cash deal, first announced Feb. 20, CNC will rid itself of much of Child World's debt and restructure about $60 million of its own debt, a person familiar with the agreement said. CNC will then be free to concentrate on its other retailing operations. **********After the sale, a subsidiary of WC Acquisition will merge with Child World, whose public shareholders will receive $2 a share for their stock, as previously announced. **********That is far less than the price of the shares when they were sold to the public in August 1985 at $16.75 each. CNC, formerly the Cole National Corporation, acquired Child World in 1981 and later sold about 18 percent of it in a public stock offering. **********Child World, the nation's second-largest toy retailer after Toys "R" Us, ran into trouble last year when the recession hurt its sales and led to a dismal Christmas season. Last December, it halted certain debt payments and worked to restructure $122 million in bank loans and $212 million of past-due trade debt. **********Under the restructuring plan, Child World's big vendors will be paid 63 percent of what they are owed by the end of November and the rest over five years. Vendors with smaller claims are being paid in full prior to closing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/world.main_headline: U.N. to Impose New Arms Curbs on Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/world.print_headline: U.N. to Impose New Arms Curbs on Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/09/world.body_text: **********The United States and its allies are planning to usher a new resolution through the Security Council imposing a tight new web of industrial and scientific restrictions meant to prevent Iraq from ever reacquiring weapons of mass destruction. **********The proposed resolution, which is expected to be approved by the Council in the next week or so, would bring detailed restrictions into force to back up the Council's general order in April forbidding Iraq to keep or acquire nuclear, chemical or biological weapons or ballistic missiles. That ban, formally accepted by the Baghdad Government, was among the terms set by the United Nations for a cease-fire formally ending the Persian Gulf war. **********The draft resolution would require Iraq to report on a range of scientific and industrial activity and provide detailed lists of any machinery, chemicals or other materials that could be used in weapons. It would also provide for highly intrusive inspections to guard against cheating by the Iraqis.  Requiring New Laws in Iraq **********The plan would require Iraq to adopt laws making it a punishable offense for any citizen to try to develop weapons of mass destruction or possess or manufacture forbidden materials. **********The new resolution would detail the price that Iraq must pay in surrendering national sovereignty for its invasion of Kuwait. **********But it could also lead to further confrontations between the Security Council and Baghdad, and to a threat of renewed allied air attacks if Baghdad balks at the terms or tries to obstruct United Nations arms inspectors. **********Such a standoff developed last month, when the Iraqis held a United Nations team captive for four days in a parking lot to prevent it from departing with information it had gathered during a nuclear inspection. Hydrogen Bomb Evidence **********Concern about the real scale of Iraq's nuclear ambitions was increased tonight when a senior United Nations official disclosed that Baghdad appeared to be trying to build a hydrogen bomb. **********Hans Blix, who heads the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency, told the Security Council that his inspectors had found evidence that Iraq was planning to produce a substance called lithium 6, whose only known use is in the production of thermonuclear or hydrogen weapons, which have far greater explosive force than atomic bombs. **********Mr. Blix said the evidence was in documents recovered by his inspectors in raids on Iraqi nuclear sites last month. These documents indicated Iraq that hoped to produce up to 200 pounds of lithium 6 annually. But they did not show whether it has produced any yet. Mr. Blix said the amount of lithium needed for a hydrogen weapon was closely guarded secret known only to those powers who have developed them. **********Even as the Security Council is planning to monitor future military activities in Iraq, United Nations inspectors have been destroying its banned weapons that survived the gulf war air raids intact. **********Today, ballistics experts supervised the destruction of the smaller of Iraq's two "superguns," which are huge cannons capable of hurling shells at least 400 miles away and which Iraq could have used to attack neighboring capitals. **********At a site in the mountains 110 miles north of Baghdad, the United Nations inspectors watched as Iraqi workers made slits and holes in the 150-foot barrel of the 350mm gun that stood in a well-camouflaged site, rendering the weapon inoperable. **********Iraqi officials told the United Nations team that they had test fired this gun at a range of 125 to 160 miles. That is more than twice the 75-mile range of Big Bertha, the huge cannon Germany used to shell Paris in World War I. **********On Tuesday, the inspectors verified the destruction of the much larger 300-foot gun, which Iraq was planning to build but never assembled. As they did today, workers had cut holes in sections of the barrel and removed the flanges or projecting rims, making it impossible to join the sections together. The bigger gun's range has been estimated at more than 400 miles. Iraq had plans to build five such cannons.  Explosive Is Blown Up **********The inspectors also blew up several tons of the specially imported Belgian explosive that was used in the guns. **********Iraq's supergun project was discovered last year after British customs agents blocked shipment of sections of the British-built barrels, which Iraq said were piping intended for a petrochemical plant. **********The 11-man team of ballistics experts is lead by Douglas M. Englund, an American Army colonel. The experts have also been flying around the western Iraqi desert in helicopters searching for undeclared scud missiles sites. In one day they found 16 such undeclared launchers. The experts also verified the destruction of missile fuel storage tanks. **********Diplomats say that when the new resolution is added to the reparation payments and the arms and trade embargo already ordered by the Security Council, Baghdad will find itself subject to many of the same restrictions that the victors imposed on Germany at the end of the two World Wars. **********In 1918, the Allies ordered Germany to pay heavy reparations for war damages and demilitarized the Rhineland. In 1945, they banned Germany from possessing nuclear or chemical arms. **********Under the Security Council's compensation plan, Iraq can never be made to pay more in any one year than President Saddam Hussein was spending on foreign arms before the Persian Gulf war, about $5 billion, according to United Nations calculations. **********"This time we are only taking his gun money, not his meat and potatoes money," said a diplomat involved in preparing the resolution. **********The new inspection plans were drafted by the International Atomic Energy Agency, whose inspectors face the task of removing Iraq's destructive nuclear material, and by the special commission set up by the Council to oversee the elimination of Iraq's other weapons of mass destruction.  Wide Access for Inspectors **********The plans would give inspectors of the atomic agency and the special commission the freedom to travel wherever they want inside Iraq by helicopter or any other means of transport, to enter all buildings and sites and to remove forbidden materials. **********Iraq would be required to submit detailed reports every six months on a range of industrial and scientific activities that might have military applications. **********Under the atomic agency's plan for enforcing nuclear restrictions, Iraq must provide new inventories of all its nuclear materials and installations within 30 days. It must also give details of "existing and proposed" nuclear programs planned over the next five years, and list all sites with access to an electricity supply exceeding 10 megawatts. Many nuclear processes, including the enrichment of uranium to make explosives, require huge quantities of electricity.
