https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/18/world.body_text: **********A Russian trade union leader today rejected President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new ban on strikes, saying it was intended to cure the symptoms but not the causes of Soviet economic problems. **********Mr. Gorbachev issued an order on Thursday banning strikes in critical industries but offering workers more of the profits in an effort to prevent economic chaos. **********Although the decree called for harsh measures against strikers, it was not clear how Mr. Gorbachev could enforce the order. It threatens prosecution of strikers in the coal, oil, natural gas, chemical and petrochemical industries. **********Igor Klochkov, chairman of the Russian Federation of Independent Trade Unions, rejected Mr. Gorbachev's decree. **********"No decrees, no moratoriums, can cure our sick society or reduce social tensions," Mr. Klochkov said at a news conference. "All they can do is cure the symptoms." **********The strike movement, he said, "will become more disruptive if it is made illegal."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/busin.main_headline: G.M. Chief Urges Higher Gas Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/busin.print_headline: G.M. Chief Urges Higher Gas Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Government should raise gasoline prices to push consumers toward more fuel-efficient cars and trucks, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation said today. **********Robert C. Stempel said at the auto maker's annual meeting here that increased sales of such vehicles would help G.M. and other auto makers meet the Government's corporate average fuel economy requirements, which set out minimum miles-per-gallon averages for auto makers' fleets. **********"As long as gasoline prices remain low, there is little incentive for Americans to purchase more fuel-efficient vehicles," Mr. Stempel said. "If the Government undertakes policies to conserve energy, we urge it to focus on harnessing market forces to reduce energy use." **********Car producers have complained that regulations mandating fuel efficiency allow Government interference in marketing operations of auto makers and do not take into account buying trends. **********The shareholder meeting was held about 35 miles northeast of G.M.'s new Saturn car making plant in Spring Hill, Tenn. It was the first time in 27 years that G.M. has held its annual meeting outside Detroit. **********G.M. offered shareholders a tour of part of the Saturn factory that began shipping cars to dealers last October. In a sense, the $3 billion Saturn project holds a large part of G.M.'s future. The cars are intended to compete directly with Japanese vehicles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/world.main_headline: Mission to Yugoslavia To Monitor Cease-Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/world.print_headline: CONFLICT IN YUGOSLAVIA; Mission to Yugoslavia To Monitor Cease-Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/05/world.body_text: **********The 35 nations of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe agreed today to send a mission to Yugoslavia to monitor troop movements and help stabilize a cease-fire. **********After a marathon session that ended eary today, delegates urged acceptance of a cease-fire, the return of all troops to barracks and a three-month suspension of the declarations of independence by the republics of Croatia and Slovenia. **********Delegates, who said the first major test of the conference's crisis management procedures had been a success, also supported efforts by the European Community to mediate in the crisis and find a peaceful solution. **********The conference, comprising all European countries plus the United States and Canada, unanimously adopted a declaration in Prague that said the mission would be carried out "at the invitation of the Yugoslav authorities and in full cooperation with them." **********On Thursday the conference offered to send a "good offices mission" to Yugoslavia. **********"This mission will be at the disposal of the Yugoslav authorities as long as they deem it necessary," said the agreement, reached after the Soviet Union dropped its objections.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/07/world.main_headline: NATO CHIEFS SEEK TO DEFINE ITS ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/07/world.print_headline: NATO CHIEFS SEEK TO DEFINE ITS ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/07/world.body_text: **********With NATO still looking anxiously for its place in the post-cold-war world, leaders of the 16-nation alliance who meet in Rome on Thursday are expected to point once again to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe to justify the 42-year-old pact's continued existence. **********This time, though, with the Soviet Union no longer posing a credible military threat to the West, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be responding to requests by Moscow and its former satellites that the alliance expand its political role and become a security pillar for all of Europe. **********At their two-day summit meeting this week, President Bush and other NATO leaders therefore plan to approve creation of a new 25-nation cooperation council as a way of giving a formal structure to growing links between the alliance and the former Soviet bloc, including the three newly independent Baltic countries. **********Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, in particular, have been seeking security guarantees from NATO, even signaling their desire to join the alliance, while only last week President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he strongly favored turning NATO into a broad political organization.  Meeting Planned for Brussels **********The council, which should hold its first meeting at the foreign ministers' level in Brussels on Dec. 20, will have a mandate to discuss regional security issues and promote confidence-building measures at a time of growing nationality disputes across the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. **********But while NATO seems agreed on how to deal with its former enemies, there is no such consensus about its own military and political future and, above all, its relationship to other competing European organizations. And this debate is certain to continue well beyond the Rome meeting. **********The military side of the issue looks relatively simple, with the NATO leaders due to endorse an 18-month-long strategy review under which the alliance will reduce its troop strength and create a new rapid reaction corps.  Decisions Already Made **********In practice, though, NATO leaders will be formalizing decisions that have already been made, including the gradual cutback of American troops stationed in Europe and the elimination of all but 700 warheads of the alliance's current arsenal of 3,600 nuclear weapons in Europe. **********The unresolved question is whether NATO should lift its ban on "out of area" operations, a rule that prevented the alliance from playing more than a consultative role in the Persian Gulf war, even though many of its individual members participated. **********Far more complicated, however, is the political profile that NATO should adopt, specifically whether it should acknowledge that the collapse of Communism in Europe has removed its principal reason for existence or whether it should redefine its role. **********The United States has repeatedly stressed that it sees its place in Europe in the context of a strong NATO. Its European allies are eager for some American troops to remain here as a shield against instability in the former Soviet bloc and as a counterweight to Germany's growing power.  Europeans Seek Greater Role **********But as the European Community moves toward increased economic and political union, many European governments believe they should play a greater role in their own defense. **********The demand by former Soviet bloc nations for closer ties to NATO reflects disappointment that the European Community has discouraged them from seeking membership and their recognition that the European Security Conference has little real power. **********"We regard NATO as our long-term partner and we intend to develop our relations with this organization on a solid and wide-ranging basis," the Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Yuri Deryabin, said recently after a visit to NATO's headquarters in Brussels to discuss closer ties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/busin.main_headline: A.T.& T. Plans to Offer Faster Data Transfer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/busin.print_headline: A.T.& T. Plans to Offer Faster Data Transfer
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/19/busin.body_text: **********A.T.& T., the world's largest telecommunications company, announced yesterday that it was offering a new form of data transmission nearly 30 times as fast as current methods. **********Known as frame relay, the service will substantially speed the transfer of text, numbers and images among banks, hospitals, insurance companies and others whose fast computers have outpaced the capacity of telephone lines to transfer data quickly to remote offices. **********Frame relay's usefulness is confined to data transfer, so it is expected to appeal mainly to large business and institutional customers. But perhaps frame relay's real significance is as a transition technology to an emerging method known as cell relay, which is 2,770 times as fast as current methods. **********Cell relay, available in perhaps three to five years, can carry voice, video and data, and would make possible video-conferencing, conversations and the swift transfer of information simultaneously -- the "multimedia" promise of the Information Age that has been slow in coming.  Raising the Transfer Speed **********Current technology, known as X.25, transfers data at no more than 56,000 bits, or binary digits, a second. Frame relay works at 1.54 million bits a second and cell relay at 19.4 million bits. **********In a demonstration for reporters, American Telephone and Telegraph Company officials transferred the detailed color image of a living human brain from a hospital computer in Atlanta to the conference room in midtown Manhattan. A kind of X-ray without an X-ray, the magnetic resonance image took less than a second to arrive in New York. If the same image had been transferred by X.25, it would have taken more than an hour. **********A.T.& T. plans to make frame relay available early next year. Its principal competitors, MCI and U S Sprint, have already announced frame relay offerings for next year. Also, companies like Wiltel in Tulsa, Okla., and the giant BT, formerly British Telecommunications, are also offering such services. **********But A.T.& T. is by far the largest company in the nascent market and by that fact alone will sharply expand frame relay's availability. A.T.& T. has nearly 500 "points of presence," or physical locations where business customers can link to its network. **********The Yankee Group, a high-technology consulting firm, estimates that the market for frame-relay service and equipment could total at least $721 million by 1995, but other analysts, like the Gartner Group, say the market may easily exceed $1 billion by then. **********By waiting for its long-distance rivals to announce their plans, A.T.& T. forced them to show their hands, while still making a frame-relay offering at the same time as its competitors, said Berge A. Ayvasian, an analyst at the Yankee Group. **********In the same news conference yesterday, A.T.& T. announced two other services, a telephone referral service now being tested by Domino's Pizza and an information access service for business executives and others with portable computers. **********The referral service, known as Store Locator, would allow a company to offer a single easy-to-remember telephone number nationwide beginning with the prefix 950. Domino's, which is still market-testing the technique, would use it to allow a pizza customer to dial 950-1430 anywhere in the country and get the nearest Domino's store. **********The laptop computer service, known as Information Access Service, would allow business executives on the road to dial a toll-free number, 950-1-ATT, and gain access to customized data bases. **********Separately, Alex J. Mandl, A.T.& T.'s new chief financial officer and group excecutive, told securities analysts that the company's financial performance in the fourth quarter, ending Dec. 31, was being hurt by the recession. "We are disappointed with the sluggish economy and we are experiencing some effects from that," he said, but was not more specific.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Interest Rates Are Little Changed
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates were little changed yesterday, as traders waited for some sign that the Federal Reserve would ease monetary policy and encourage lower interest rates. **********Although the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market slipped below 5 1/2 percent, its recent level during the afternoon, there was no signal from the Fed that it would supply the extra funds that would bring the overnight rate down on a sustained basis. **********Still, the decline in interest rates has already gone far enough that many high-quality companies decided that the time was ripe for selling new bonds. **********By late in the day, nearly $2.8 billion of new securities had been issued by such blue-chip borrowers as the Boeing Company, the Ford Motor Company and the General Electric Company. **********The flurry of new corporate issues came at a time when many investors and economists say that the economy is weak enough to justify at least one more push downward on short-term rates by the Federal Reserve. The drop in long-term Treasury bond yields to about 8 percent, from 8.48 percent as recently as July 23, is a sign, they said, that the financial markets do not expect a a resurgence of inflation. With inflationary expectations dampened, many analysts say the Fed has more leeway to reduce short-term interest rates. **********Many analysts expect the Fed's next move to include a cut in the discount rate it charges banks to 5 percent from 5 1/2 percent and a drop in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market to 5 1/4 percent from 5 1/2 percent. Another move by the Fed to lower short-term interest rates could also set the stage for a cut in the prime lending rate charged by banks to 8 or 8 1/4 percent from 8 1/2 percent. **********"It's pretty clear that the economy has stabilized and is scraping along at a low level of activity," said Marshall B. Front, an executive vice president at Stein, Roe & Farnham, a Chicago-based investment management firm. "I expect the Fed will ease one more time, but that long-term bond yields are at or near their lows for this cycle," Mr. Front said.  Gradual Rate Rise Seen **********Although Mr. Front does not expect Treasury bond yields to drop much below 8 percent, he said the rise in rates would be very gradual, and continue to cause many investors to seek longer maturities to earn higher interest rates than are available on money market instruments due in less than one year. **********Treasury notes and bonds were little changed yesterday. The 6 7/8 percent notes due in 1994 were offered at 100 28/32, unchanged, to yield 6.53 percent whle the 8 1/8 percent bonds due in 2021 were offered at 100 3/8, down 1/8 point, to yield 8 percent. **********Good quality corporate bonds are in strong demand from invesotrs like Mr. Front because their higher yields offer more a cushion to absorb the gradual price declines that will result when long-term bond yields turn up. Because the economy is improving, many analysts expect that credit ratings on many large companies that have borrowed recently will be stable. **********The Ford Motor Company offered two issues totaling $700 million yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Both were noncallable, meaning the company cannot repay them before maturity, and investors can count on receiving the semiannual interest payments as long as they hold the bonds. **********Ford's $350 million of 9 percent securities due in 2001 were offered at 100, to yield 9 percent, or 1.28 percentage points more than 10-year Treasury notes. The companion issue of 9 1/2 percent securities due in 2011 were offered at 99.918, to yield 9.509 percent, or 1.5 percentage points more than comparable Treasury issues. Both issues were rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's **********The Boeing's $250 million issue of 8 3/4 percent noncallable debentures due in 2031 were offered by First Boston at 99.328, to yield 8.811 percent. The debentures, rated Aa-3 by Moody's, yield about eight-tenths of a percentage point more than 30-year Treasury bonds. **********G.E.'s $500 million of 7 7/8 percent notes due in 1998 were offered at 99.895, to yield 7.895 percent through its subsidiary Kidder, Peabody & Company. The triple-A rated notes were offered with a yield that was 36-hundredths of a percentage point more than seven-year Treasury notes. **********In other financing activity, the General Motors Acceptace Corporation issued $916 million of securities backed by car loans with an estimated average life of about two years at a yield of 6.91 percent through First Boston.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.main_headline: All About/Golf Courses; Can Builders Rely on a Fairway View to Sell Homes?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.print_headline: All About/Golf Courses; Can Builders Rely on a Fairway View to Sell Homes?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/24/busin.body_text: **********Developers discovered during the 1980's that they could sell whole subdivisions built around golf courses as readily as the new residents could sink one-foot putts. But by now, they have built so many homes on the links that many projects have turned out no better than the slices into the woods. **********There are 13,951 operating golf courses in the United States, with hundreds opening each year as more people take up the sport.  The National Golf Foundation, a developers' trade group based in Jupiter, Fla., reports that 289 new courses opened last year; 561 are under construction and 781 are planned. **********Golf is a $20 billion-a-year industry attracting 25 million people playing at least one round a year.  The golf foundation counts 5.5 million golfers who play more than 25 rounds a year and 6.6 million who play 8 to 24 rounds. **********But turning these encouraging statistics into profitable developments is risky. Some golf course developers fear that they are going through the same cycle as hotel and office developers -- a rush to build followed by a glut and a crash. Scores of golf course developments have faced foreclosure or filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the last two years. Already, more real estate workout specialists are concentrating on golf courses in foreclosure or in the hands of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which holds property from failed savings and loans. **********The 200-Acre Amenity  Luring Buyers In a Slow Market **********Despite the hazards, some developers are profiting by building golf courses as giant amenities in the middle of new planned communities. Expensive homes on golf courses have a huge sales advantage when builders of ordinary subdivisions are being buffeted by weak markets and scarce financing. **********To be sure, a golf course is a more expensive amenity than a marble bathroom. An 18-hole course can use more than 200 acres. To help recoup their costs, developers charge large premiums on the homes. The premiums range from 30 percent to 100 percent over the cost of comparable homes.Homes on the links usually start at about $350,000 and often exceed $1 million. **********"We are really community developers, and golf is to the community as a face is to a portrait -- it provides that sense of identity, place," said Gerald Barton, chairman of the Landmark Land Company, a leading golf course builder. **********Many developers would not think of building a course without homes. In Florida, homes lined 76 percent of courses opened in 1990; in South Carolina, 71 percent. "On a stand-alone basis, golf is a money loser," said J. Steven Manolis, head of Salomon Brothers' real estate investment banking group and an avid golfer himself. "But when the costs are allocated to each land lot it can be a big money maker." **********Easier said than done. Building a good course is very labor- and capital-intensive, requiring specialized designers. New courses usually cost from $1.8 million to more than $12 million, depending on location and features, according to Kent E. Crippin, a golf course development specialist with Grant Thornton, the accounting and consulting firm. Stephen Wynn, chairman of Golden Nugget Inc., built his own course in the Nevada desert more than a year ago at a cost said to exceed $30 million. **********A developer generally goes deep into debt building the course, the clubhouse, the pro shop, the watering system first, then adding the residential areas. The premiums charged to homeowners can return as much as half the cost of building the course, but the rest can only be recouped over time from greens fees, club memberships and pro shop sales. **********The course and the homes must be designed for either mass or class, Mr. Barton said. "To me golf is like the restaurant business," he said. "You make money at the bottom, like at McDonald's, and you make money at the top, like at Lutece. But you starve in the middle." U.S. Is 'Well Golfed'  Another Industry May Go Offshore **********A dearth of financing is the despair of developers who want to build residential courses, but may mend the industry by restraining supply. Despite claims by the National Golf Foundation that there is sufficient demand to add a new golf course every day, many, including some builders, point to a glut. "The real future in golf is quality golf outside the U.S.," said Mr. Barton, whose company has built 3 of the 100 courses worldwide judged to be the best by Golf magazine. "That doesn't mean that there won't be good business here, but we're pretty well-golfed here already." **********Unique properties like Pebble Beach, on California's Monterey Peninsula, which the billionaire Marvin Davis recently sold to a Japanese company for about $780 million, always hold their value. The fee to play there is about $170 per round, for those who can get reservations. But few layouts enjoy such spectacular scenery, design or reputation. **********Developers sometimes find that even if they can sell homes, the course fails to draw enough players to yield a profit. Many who buy houses on courses are drawn to the setting not the sport. **********Banks and private financing sources like the General Electric Credit Corporation and the Westinghouse Credit Corporation are scrutinizing golf developments. Mr. Crippin, who often reviews plans before builders seek financing, says builders are often unreasonably optimistic. He reviewed two plans recently that based income projections on 365 playing days a year -- for sites in Michigan. **********In determining how much revenue a course can generate, lenders look at the proximity of competing courses and the prosperity of the area. Golf is expensive, for players and developers alike. Most new golf courses built in the 1990's will require public financing, Mr. Crippin said. Local governments and private developers have already joined to build a few residential golf developments. Cities hope to put vacant land to good use and attract wealthy residents. Miamisburg, Ohio, formed a joint venture with private builders and financed a development with revenue bonds. **********The Eco-Noose Bearing the Cost Of Preservation **********Where developers see roughs and greens, environmentalists often see only pristine wetlands and wildlife habitats. The most scenic locations for golf courses are often the same natural vistas that conservationists most want to preserve. Golf developers may have to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars changing their plans and negotiating with cities and states to win the necessary building permits. **********As environmental regulations become tighter, the added costs of meeting them ultimately mount into the millions. "Being sensitive to ecological concerns is going to be a big issue," said Landmark Land's Mr. Barton. "It's definitely going to be an added cost." **********Developers who have cleared forests for fairways must reckon with run-off problems that can turn brooks into rain-fed rivers. Insecticides may keep the courses in bloom, but they can also poison groundwater. And waterfowl often have legal protections that prevail over those who would destroy the birds' homes. **********Golf course designers are responding with courses that require less maintenance, with plants and lawns that can usually get by on rainwater alone. To minimize expense and environmental damage, they try to mold their layouts to the land. **********THE BOOM IS ABROAD **********WHen membership in a Japanese golf club can cost as much as $2.4 million, and tee times must often be reserved more than a month in advance, Japanese golfers often decide to fly to the United States. When they arrive, they are finding an increasing number of courses owned by investors from home. **********The sport's popularity is growing most rapidly outside the English-speaking countries. Golf Digest Almanac estimates that over the last 15 years, the number of golfers has more than tripled in Continental Europe and more than doubled in Asia. About 30 percent of the gains in Europe have come in Finland, Austria, Sweden, Belgium and Norway. American golf course developers say there are so few top-rated courses outside the United States, Britain and Ireland that they might look abroad for projects. "The boom is more in Europe and in Asia in part because there isn't much quality in courses outside of English-speaking countries," said Gerald Barton of Landmark Land. **********In part because land for courses at home is so scarce, the Japanese have invested more than other countries in American courses. Japanese companies own or have interests in about 160 American golf courses, according to Golf Course News, an industry newspaper. The purchase by Japan's Cosmo World of the famous Pebble Beach course was only the most publicized deal. A few months later, Landmark Land announced the sale of most of its best courses for more than $739 million to a group of investors led by the Daiichi Real Estate Company. The sale includes the Palm Beach Polo and Country Club, PGA West, La Quinta, Mission Hills and the new Kiawah Island course in South Carolina. Japanese companies also own almost all of the private courses in Hawaii. **********But American developers, hoping for what some call a "Tokyo take-out" to rescue their floundering projects, should not count on the Japanese. Higher interest rates, tighter credit and falling land values at home have squeezed Japanese investors. The Kyowa Company, a major investor in golf courses, had to seek bankruptcy protection a few months ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/busin.main_headline: Real Estate Executive Likes Deal With NCNB
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Real Estate Executive Likes Deal With NCNB
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/04/busin.body_text: **********Guerrino Savio, president of SCI Real Estate Development Ltd., the United States arm of one of Italy's biggest developers, says he got a bargain on Friday when his company paid $120 million to the NCNB Corporation for 1.8 million square feet of office space in Texas, plus eight land parcels. **********"The price was much, much lower than anything you could buy in Italy right now" in major commercial real estate markets, Mr. Savio said. **********His company, based in Manhattan, was bruised by setbacks in the last few years in Boston, New Haven and White Plains, where it has developed office projects and condominiums. **********But the deep pockets of its parent company, SCI -- whose leading investors include the Romanengo family of Genoa, Italy; subsidiaries of the Pirelli Group and Fiat, and the Bozzo Group of Switzerland, a worldwide coffee trader -- enabled it to avoid defaults and look for income-producing properties in other regions. **********The deal with NCNB, which took eight months to put together, was made by a partnership including SCI Real Estate and ROEV General Inc., which is backed by the Haggiag family of Rome. **********"We were looking for some activities to perform while our real estate development activity in the Northeast was basically frozen," said Mr. Savio, who has headed SCI Real Estate since it was formed 1980. **********Indeed, with few prospects for finding tenants on a three-story office project in White Plains, SCI halted construction this year after the steel supports were in place, rather than spend another $5 million to complete the project and have it sit empty for what could be several years. SCI also spent $25 million to buy out various partners so it could remain in control of the project. **********In the deal with NCNB, the banking company's Texas unit will continue to occupy 70 percent of the office space. **********"We will have an income from day one, so this deal will give us a window" into learning the Texas market, Mr. Savio said. **********"In terms of recovery, there is no doubt Texas is ahead of Massachusetts, Connecticut and New York." He added that SCI planned similar investments in United States real estate, but probably not for some time. "We want to be perfectly at ease in managing these properties," he said. **********Mr. Savio, 44, joined SCI in New York after several years as managing director of a public-private partnership that developed housing and office parks in Turin, Italy. He graduated from the Polytechnic of Turin with a master's degree in architecture in 1971. He lives with his wife, Helen, and two daughters, in Chappaqua, N.Y.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/world.main_headline: Baker Says Anti-Iraq Allies, Except Syria, Agree on Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Baker Says Anti-Iraq Allies, Except Syria, Agree on Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that except for Syria, the nations of the anti-Iraq coalition were in agreement on the timing and necessity of force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait after midnight Tuesday. **********Speaking to reporters at the end of his 10-nation tour, which involved talks with Washington's major military allies in the force against Iraq, Mr. Baker indicated that as far as the United States was concerned, both it and its allies were ready to open fire on Iraqi forces in Kuwait anytime after midnight Tuesday, Eastern standard time. **********No further consultations are necessary, save for the precise hour of attack, unless Iraq makes some serious gesture to leave Kuwait before the deadline, American officials indicated. **********"As we conclude this trip," Mr. Baker said after his talks this morning with President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, "it seems to me that the international coalition is well prepared politically, economically and militarily for any eventuality as we move toward midnight Jan. 15."  'No One Has Balked' **********"No one has balked," a senior Administration official said of Mr. Baker's visit to Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the United Arab Emirates, Turkey, Switzerland and Syria and to the exiled Kuwaiti leadership in Taif, Saudi Arabia. **********"France will fight," the official said, "if that is what it comes to. With respect to France, the deadline is real. In my opinion, France and other countries will want to do everything they can in order to try and achieve a political solution before midnight on the 15th of January. But if the balloon goes up, the French will be there." **********Although the Soviet Union has apparently decided to use the diversion of the Persian Gulf crisis to crack down on the Baltics, much the way Moscow used the 1956 Suez crisis to invade Hungary, Mr. Baker did not appear to be particularly concerned now that events in the Soviet Union would disrupt the Administration's gulf strategy. **********The senior Administration official traveling aboard Mr. Baker's aircraft said Washington saw no signs that events in the Baltics were either diminishing the Soviet commitment to see Iraqi troops out of Kuwait or were leading President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to conclude that he could now more easily defy the international coalition.  Incentive for Gorbachev **********If anything, the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, now has more incentive than ever to toe the American line in the gulf, in hopes that this might reduce the negative impact and publicity that his Baltic crackdown is generating with the American public and American decision-makers. **********At the same time, though, the Bush Administration is clearly going to calibrate its response to the crackdown in Lithuania to make sure that Washington does not alienate Moscow to the point where it diminishes its support for America's gulf policy. **********Still, juggling two full-blown crises at once is clearly taxing senior Administration policy makers. Mr. Baker telephoned the President three different times from three different countries on Saturday and at least twice on Sunday as he traveled from Turkey to London. **********The senior Administration official said that of the 28 nations with "ground forces" in Saudi Arabia, only Syria's 15,000-man force is not certain to take part in any offensive action to dislodge Iraqi troops from Kuwait and Syria would prefer instead to confine its role to simply defending Saudi Arabia.  Defending Palestinian Cause **********President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, American officials said, has become concerned about how Mr. Hussein has successfully depicted himself as the leading defender of the Palestinian cause, a role that Mr. Assad believes rightly belongs to him, and is therefore leery about siding with Western powers in an offensive against Iraq. **********The Syrian leader feels that going beyond using his troops to defend Saudi Arabia could undermine his Arab nationalist credentials, although he is still considering Arab requests for a more offensive role. **********The official said that while France, like others, was doing all that it could to find a political solution -- even dangling an international conference before Mr. Hussein as a face-saving cover for him to withdraw from Kuwait -- President Francois Mitterrand has assured Mr. Bush that his forces will be engaged if and when the fighting has to begin after Jan. 15. **********The official said some countries that have sent only small naval or air units to the gulf and no ground forces were not certain to take part in any fighting because their units were originally sent either to defend Saudi Arabia or to help impose the United Nations naval embargo on Iraq and their legislatures have not taken action yet to reassign them for offensive purposes.  Major Deployments by 4 Nations **********Nevertheless, these small naval and air units, from countries like Greece, have virtually no military significance, since in the event of a war the vast majority of air and naval power will be deployed by the United States, France, Saudi Arabia and Britain. **********The key points from the perspective of American officials is that all the countries that have committed ground forces have signaled their willingness to use them. **********The Administration official would not comment on limitations that President Ozal has imposed on the use of Turkish bases in a war to drive Iraq out of Kuwait, limitations that Mr. Ozal reiterated to Mr. Baker in their talks today. **********The Turkish public remains highly ambivalent about the gulf crisis and their Government's involvement. **********These reservations are based in part on a neutralist tradition in the Turkish Army, but even more on a concern by Turks that if Iraq is devastated by war, a power vacuum would be created that would generate chaos on their eastern frontier, which has been unstable for years because of the presence of millions of Kurds seeking independence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/25/world.main_headline: Congo Political Conference Gives Africa a Democratic Model
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/25/world.print_headline: Congo Political Conference Gives Africa a Democratic Model
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/25/world.body_text: **********It seemed somehow appropriate that when a national conference on the political future of this Central African country ended recently, all 1,500 delegates solemnly took turns dipping their hands in the reflecting pool outside the Congolese national assembly hall. **********The ceremony was meant to symbolize the washing away of the bile that often marred deliberations at the three-month conference. It was also an act of reconciliation, and a way of affirming the momentous changes that had taken place in what political leaders are calling Congo's democratic coup. **********In the process, the conference forced the 12-year-old Government of Gen. Denis Sassou-Nguesso to name a new Prime Minister, dismiss a Cabinet, rewrite the Constitution and schedule the nation's first free elections for the second half of 1992. **********The conference also adopted a new national anthem, changed the colors of the flag and removed the word "people's" from the country's formal name, the People's Republic of Congo.  Change in Past Practices **********And although General Sassou-Nguesso remains President, the perquisites of the office are greatly diminished. He is forbidden even to travel outside the country without first getting approval from leaders of the transitional Government. **********By African standards, the conference was probably the most sweeping repudiation of past practices since the early days of independence three decades ago. **********Before the conference, Congo was among Africa's most determinedly Marxist-Leninist countries and a close ally of Cuba, the Soviet Union and what used to be East Germany. Today, as a result of policies adopted at the conference, the country could soon become free and democratic. **********"The remarkable thing is that the revolution occurred without a single shot being fired," a Western business executive said. "And if it can happen here, it can happen anywhere." **********Indeed, President Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo announced recently that he would hold a national conference similar to Congo's. Could Be Used as a Model **********Elsewhere, opposition leaders in more than a dozen other African countries -- including Cameroon, Chad, Ghana, the Ivory Coast, Sierra Leone and Zaire -- have said they hoped to use the Congo conference as a model for democratic change. **********"The Congo was a very, very important example for us," said Buana Kabwe, chairman of the Zaire League of Human Rights. "And if the same thing doesn't happen here, then Mobutu could be in trouble," he predicted. **********The events leading to the conference began last fall after an eruption of mass demonstrations and strikes. That led to a showdown between the Government and leading trade unions, with General Sassou-Nguesso demanding an end to the turmoil. The unions, in turn, called a general strike that all but shut down the country and that, diplomats say, showed that the Government had totally lost control. **********The turning point, though, came when General Sassou-Nguesso agreed to the national conference to chart Congo's political future, a concept that had been tried only once before on the continent, in Benin. There, in January 1989, conference officials stripped then-President Mathieu Kerekou of most of his powers, replacing him with a new Prime Minister and a transitional Government.  Echoes of the Past **********From the beginning, the conference here appeared headed in the same direction as opposition leaders used the forum as an indictment of the Sassou-Nguesso Government. At one point, in fact, the President and his predecessor, Gen. Yhombi Opango, were accused by several delegates of being responsible for the death of Congo's first President, Marien Ngouabi, in 1977. **********Another opposition leader, Albert Roger Massema of the Cause movement, asserted that the Government knew in advance about the bomb that killed 171 people on a flight of the French airline U.T.A. from Brazzaville, the Congolese capital, to Paris in September 1989. The plane exploded over Niger, after making a stopover in Ndjamena, Chad. **********Several conference delegates also called for the foreign bank accounts of all senior officials to be frozen and their assets returned to the country. Indeed, as allegations of official misconduct increased, an order was issued from the conference forbidding all high-ranking officials from going abroad. **********To those who watched the deliberations here, it was also a reminder that people can eventually find a way to resolve their differences in a way that takes traditional African values into account. It was often remarked here that the conference was like a village meeting where elders reach agreement through a long process of debate and consensus. **********"Without any question, it's a uniquely African process for resolving problems," said James Phillips, the United States Ambassador here. "This is how they do it in the villages."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/world.main_headline: YELTSIN NOW SAYS GORBACHEV IS ALLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/world.print_headline: YELTSIN NOW SAYS GORBACHEV IS ALLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/12/world.body_text: **********After months of criticizing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a virtual dictator, the Russian republic's leader, Boris N. Yeltsin, said in an interview published today that Mr. Gorbachev was in fact "an ally" of the democratic movement. **********Mr. Yeltsin said that by signing an agreement with 9 of the 15 Soviet republics that calls for a major power shift from the center to the constituents, Mr. Gorbachev had demonstrated that he "today is clearly in favor of reforms, which is very important and which makes him our ally." **********The statement by Mr. Yeltsin, which was reported by the independent Interfax news agency, confirmed the significant turnaround in the often tempestuous relationship between Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin, once close political allies who have contested one another bitterly over the pace and style of change in the Soviet Union's difficult path toward a more democratic political and economic system. **********Mr. Yeltsin rallied anti-Gorbachev forces earlier this year by calling for the Soviet leader's resignation, accusing him of abandoning the original guiding principles and goals of his democratization and economic restructuring programs.  Fear of Crumbling Union **********Mr. Yeltsin acknowledged that his relationship with Mr. Gorbachev had indeed been quite strained, but he said that such a "personal question" should not be allowed to "overshadow the fact that we are the leaders of two state structures: Russia and the Union," and that "unless we combine our efforts, the Union may just fall to pieces." **********Tense personal relations between the two leaders at times have clearly added fuel to the country's political conflagrations in recent years. Mr. Yeltsin was fired from the Communist Party Politburo in 1987 when he broke with party precendent and criticized Mr. Gorbachev, Yegor K. Ligachev and other leaders for moving too slowly to enact the perestroika program. **********Mr. Yeltsin, who won seats in the union and Russian republic parliaments by wide margains, has standing in popular opinion polls now several times higher than Mr. Gorbachev. Mr. Yeltsin quit the Communist Party last July. Until their latest reconciliation, many people here believed that the country would continue to flounder unless the two leading politicians found a common language.  Breakthrough at Plenary Session **********The breakthrough moment came last month, on the eve of a Communist Party plenary session. Expecting strong criticism from his party colleagues, Mr. Gorbachev compromised with the nine republican leaders promising them greater powers, including the right to control their own exports and properties. The leaders of Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldavia, Armenia and Georgia refused to sign the declaration. **********In exchange for Mr, Gorbachev's compromise, Mr. Yeltsin, a populist who has great authority with the country's millions of disgruntled workers, was able to settle a strike among Soviet coal miners that had threatened the already disintegrating economy with further collapse. On May Day, Mr. Yeltsin met with miners in Siberia and announced a plan that will transfer control of the Russian mines to the republic authorities, who have, in turn, promised to allow the miners to privatize their coalfields if they wish. **********Mr. Yeltsin, who is also the nominal head of the country's pro-democracy, opposition groups, has drawn fire from some of his colleagues who believe he reversed field too quickly with Mr. Gorbachev. **********Some leaders of the Democratic Russian opposition movement, including Yuri N. Afanasyev, the historian, said that while they will support Mr. Yeltsin in June's popular election for the Russian presidency, they are wary of any deals with the Soviet leadership. **********"We must finally admit that Gorbachev's day is over," Mr. Afanasyev said at a recent meeting of Democratic Russia. "There should be no nostalgia."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/14/busin.main_headline: Market Place; The Setback at Convex: Challenge or Catastrophe?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/14/busin.print_headline: Market Place; The Setback at Convex: Challenge or Catastrophe?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/14/busin.body_text: **********The Convex Computer Corporation will report a big quarterly loss in a few days, and analysts say the company will probably complete 1991 with its first yearly loss since it became profitable in 1983, a year after it was organized. **********Convex, which makes high-performance computers priced mostly between $300,000 and $2 million, was hit during the summer with numerous problems: delays in fine-tuning important new products, the slumping market for high-performance computers and its first head-on confrontation with the colossus of supercomputing, Cray Research Inc. **********The company said late last month that revenues for the quarter would be as low as $35 million, compared with the $50 million that had been anticipated on Wall Street, and that its loss for the quarter would be at least $5.8 million. **********The company's shares, which traded as high as $19.75 in the spring, have fallen in recent weeks to a range of $10 to $12. They closed on Friday at $11, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Are these early warnings of an approaching catastrophe for Convex, or just the rough edges of a temporary setback before orders and sales revive in 1992? Probably the latter, analysts say, but Convex has some harsh realities to wrestle with. **********The first is that it will be dueling more frequently with Cray at the lower-price end of supercomputing. And sooner or later, Convex must contend with inroads from a growing crowd of companies like Sun Microsystems Inc. that make ever-more-powerful computer work stations used primarily for engineering and scientific computing. **********Buyers of engineering work stations now can knit together several machines, each priced at $10,000 or less, into systems whose performance can compete on some tasks with Convex's older models, which are priced near $300,000. **********Convex built a solid reputation in the last six years by dominating smaller rivals like Alliant Computer Systems and Floating Point Systems, as well as by outwitting the Digital Equipment Corporation with faster designs and more flexible software for minisupercomputers. Typical users of those machines were military and university researchers, corporate scientists and engineers, but many of their budgets were crimped this year by recession and declining Pentagon spending. **********"It's a very unforgiving market out there right now," said Gary Smaby, president of the Smaby Group, a research firm in Minneapolis that specializes in supercomputers **********Still, Convex, which is based in Richardson, Tex., near here, is considered a company with "a very strong management team and will be a long-term, viable player," said Jeffry Canin, an analyst at Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco who covers the market for scientific and engineering computing. **********"But now Convex has to go into the big leagues against Ditigal, I.B.M. and, more ominously, Cray," he said. He estimates that Convex will lose $8.3 million in 1991; until late September, he had figured it would break even. He and Richard Edwards, an analyst at Robertson, Stephens & Company in San Francisco, both said the company should earn 50 cents a share next year. **********Cray Research, based in Minneapolis, has for years assembled the industry's fastest and most expensive machines, priced as high as $30 million. But Cray has been slower than Convex in marketing and may be bloodied before it learns to deal in a more freewheeling market for computer sales. **********Analysts expect both companies to generate sales growth approaching 10 percent next year, but they are counting on a revival in capital spending. **********"This whole industry has become a highly speculative" recommendation based on levels of capital spending in 1992 and 1993, said Joseph Payne, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons. "We're putting Convex in the hottest category, but more because of the quality of their systems software than the new products themselves. People now are more concerned about systems software features than raw computing performance." **********Convex seems to have laid the groundwork for a solid recovery next year, analysts said. Its financial health is good, with little debt and more than $90 million in cash, and technical problems with gallium arsenide circuits in its new C3800 and C3400 supercomputers appear to have been solved. **********The company's chief executive, Robert J. Paluck, and its chief technical officer, Steven J. Wallach, gambled that research with gallium arsenide circuits had advanced to the point where the speedy computer chips could be mass produced at high quality. **********They calculated that the chips would prove faster and generate less heat than conventional silicon chips. So to obtain more speed and power, Mr. Wallach designed as many as eight processors with gallium arsenide circuits into the new C3800 model, compared with a maximum of four in previous models. **********It was problems earlier this year at the Texas Instruments Corporation and Vitesse Semiconductor, makers of the chips used in the C3400 and C3800 models, respectively, that forced Convex to delay shipments. **********But output of the chips and new Convex models should pick up before the year ends, said George E. Lindamood, director of high-performance computing at the Gartner Group, a research firm in Stamford, Conn. "They have taken the handcuffs off their salesman, saying it's safe now to go out and sell these things," he said. **********Convex installed two C3800 computers, at more than $2 million each, on schedule late last month. The company also outdueled Cray two weeks ago in winning a $14 million order from the Air Force for four new C3800 machines. **********Cray is expected to throw a counterpunch before the end of the month, though, with "subcompact" supercomputers priced below $500,000. Convex customers have withheld orders that might already have been booked until they get a look at the Cray model, some analysts said. **********Cray Research once vowed never to use its resources to build a computer priced below $5 million, but the company had to change course as Convex began stealing orders in the low-price range of supercomputing in the last few years. Cray agreed to pay $3.25 million last week to acquire some assets of a defeated Convex rival, Floating Point Systems, which is now known as FPS Computing. FPS entered bankruptcy reorganization proceedings last week. **********"These guys are going to see each other quite a lot in the days and months ahead," Mr. Lindamood said of Convex and Cray. "There is going to be a lot of blood on the floor on the issue of price and performance."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/16/busin.main_headline: Reynolds Net Drops 65% on Slack Demand
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Reynolds Net Drops 65% on Slack Demand
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/16/busin.body_text: **********The Reynolds Metals Company, citing lower prices for fabricated products, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings plunged 65 percent. The company attributed the decline to the recession, saying the downturn had reduced demand for aluminum products used in the automobile, construction and manufacturing industries. **********Reynolds, the nation's No. 2 aluminum producer behind Alcoa, said its net income fell to $27.5 million, or 46 cents a share, from $77.7 million, or $1.31 a share, in the corresponding period last year. Sales dropped slightly in the quarter, to $1.37 billion, from $1.4 billion in the 1990 period. **********Reynolds's report came on the heels of similarly bleak results from Alcoa, which on Friday announced a 35 percent drop in first-quarter earnings, and Alcan Aluminium Ltd., which last week reported a $1 million loss for the quarter.  Pricing and Volume **********William O. Bourke, Reynolds's chairman, said the recession was largely to blame for the company's troubles. "While the price of primary aluminum ingot was down only slightly from year-ago levels, lower prices and volume for a number of fabricated products further eroded margins," he said. **********Reynolds's stock gained $1.625 yesterday, to $57.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Peter Anker, a metals analyst with the First Boston Corporation, said that Reynolds's results were 'pretty much on target," adding that the company's executives had "prepared us by talking about the problems they were having with pricing and volume." He said he expected the second quarter would not be "a lot different from the first quarter, although there could be recovery in the second half of the year." **********Terry Olbrysh, a Reynolds spokesman, said that sales in the can market had remained strong and that shipments to the aerospace industry had also remained firm. He added, however, that Reynolds had seen a significant downturn in business involving "anything related to automotive and building and contruction, including electrical cable." **********Mr. Olbrysh said the company had seen a downturn in business from its distributor network of 25 service centers that cut and shape the metal to customers' specifications. **********Reynolds, based in Richmond, said its non-metals business in consumer products had seen continued growth. The company's consumer products division, which accounts for about 12 percent of its sales, includes plastic film, packaging and containers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/world.main_headline: Warsaw Pact Formally Ends 36 Years As a Military Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/world.print_headline: Warsaw Pact Formally Ends 36 Years As a Military Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/01/world.body_text: **********The Warsaw Pact, which held Eastern Europe under tight Kremlin control for 36 years, formally ended its existence as a military force Sunday when Soviet commanders surrendered their powers. **********Gen. Pyotr Lushev, the pact's commander-in-chief, and Gen. Vladimir Lobov, chief of staff, gave up their powers under an agreement among the pact members: the Soviet Union, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria and Romania. **********The political structure is expected to disband later this year. **********Tass, the official Soviet news agency, warned former members of the pact, which was set up to counter the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, that they would threaten Soviet security interests if they joined the rival alliance. In a radio interview, the German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, also said it would be unwise for East European countries to try to join NATO. **********The Warsaw Pact began to disintegrate after peaceful revolutions swept the Soviet bloc in 1989. Its chief front-line member, East Germany, merged with West Germany last October.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/busin.print_headline: PATENTS; Mouthpiece Enriches Wind Instrument Tones
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/01/busin.body_text: **********Philip L. Rovner, owner of a small company in Timonium, Md., that makes components for woodwind instruments, patented a mouthpiece this week that he said produces a richer saxophone and clarinet tone. **********Like a traditional mouthpiece, the new device has a reed, which vibrates as a person blows on it, and a "window," or passageway that allows air to pass to the instrument itself. **********The difference, Mr. Rovner said, is that the window in his mouthpiece is about twice as long as that of conventional products. As a result, he added, the mouthpiece transfers more of the vibration in the reed to the air flowing through the instrument, yielding a more powerful sound. "Other mouthpieces sound muffled by comparison," he said. He received patent 5,018,425.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/22/busin.body_text: **********Net withdrawals at the nation's savings institutions jumped to $10.6 billion in April, the highest level in a year, according to a Government report today. The outflow was the largest since April 1990's record $15.1 billion withdrawal and was the 34th outflow in 35 months, the Office of Thrift Supervision said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/busin.main_headline: Olivetti Head Charged in '82 Bank Failure
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/busin.print_headline: Olivetti Head Charged in '82 Bank Failure
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/13/busin.body_text: **********A Milan appeals court today indicted Carlo de Benedetti, the financier and computer executive, on charges of complicity in the bankruptcy of Banco Ambrosiano, Italy's largest banking scandal. No trial date was set. **********In April 1989, lower court judges, after investigating the 1982 collapse of Italy's largest private bank, indicted 35 people but cleared Mr. de Benedetti, who heads Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, the Italian computer company, of wrongdoing. A prosecutor appealed the decision. **********Mr. de Benedetti said today that he was upset by the "extremely unjust" indictment, which he said had "no legal or factual basis." The charges carry a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison. Loans of $1.3 Billion **********Banco Ambrosiano, based in Milan, failed when it could not collect $1.3 billion in loans made to 10 shell companies in Panama and Luxembourg that were owned directly or indirectly by the Vatican Bank, formally called the Institute for Religious Works. The Vatican Bank had issued guarantee letters for the loans. **********Mr. de Benedetti was notified in 1987 that he was being investigated for possible extortion in connection with the sale of his 2 percent share of Banco Ambrosiano shortly before its collapse. The prosecutor had contended that Mr. de Benedetti had received favorable financial terms for the sale after threatening to disclose how the bank was administrated. **********When he was cleared in 1989, Mr. de Benedetti said he had "always acted in the full respect of the law" and carried out his duties as administrator "with transparency." When he was questioned last year by the appeals court, he said he informed it of "the total honesty of my behavior." **********The financier was named Banco Ambrosiano's vice president in November 1981, when he became a shareholder, but sold the shares two months later. **********The appeals court, in indicting Mr. de Benedetti today, rejected the prosecutor's contention that extortion was involved in the sale of the shares and indicted him instead on the bankruptcy charge. **********Mr. de Benedetti resigned his position after selling his stake. He has cited disagreements with Banco Ambrosiano's chairman, Roberto Calvi, as the reason for his departure. **********Mr. Calvi, whose nickname was "God's banker" because of his Vatican connections, was found hanged under Blackfriars Bridge in London in June 1982. Two months later, Banco Ambrosiano collapsed. **********The Vatican Bank was Banco Ambrosiano's largest shareholder. It agreed in 1984 to pay $250 million as part of Banco Ambrosiano's bankruptcy settlement but said the payment was not an admission of responsibility. **********Italian courts ruled in 1988 that a treaty between Italy and the Vatican prevented the prosecution of three Vatican Bank officials, including United States Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, the bank's president at the time. Archbishop Marcinkus, of Cicero, Ill., retired from papal service last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.snippet: Charles Bayless is uniquely qualified to do a daily dance on the brink of bankruptcy. He was a potent force as chief financial officer at the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the first utility since the Depression to seek bankruptcy protec...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.main_headline:
Making a Difference;
A Risky Game of Chicken for an Ailing Tucson Utility
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.print_headline:
Making a Difference;
A Risky Game of Chicken for an Ailing Tucson Utility
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/21/busin.body_text: **********Charles Bayless is uniquely qualified to do a daily dance on the brink of bankruptcy. He was a potent force as chief financial officer at the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the first utility since the Depression to seek bankruptcy protection, filing after regulators denied a rate increase in 1988. **********Now, as head of the financially strapped Tucson Electric Power Company, Mr. Bayless is engaged in another high-stakes game of chicken, threatening a Chapter 11 filing if Arizona regulators don't come through in June with some type of rate relief. If history is any indication, Mr. Bayless won't be the one who blinks. **********When Mr. Bayless, 48, took control last year, Tucson Electric was a $3 billion company with a whopping $2.7 billion in debt, a legacy of years of overly ambitious expansion. As the state's economy soured, so did the utility's fortunes, and auditors say they have grave concerns about the company's ability to remain solvent. **********Tucson Electric's only hope is rate relief, analysts say. "There's no way Bayless and the creditors can do it alone," said Barry Abramson, an analyst at Prudential Securities. **********Regulators have been mum on their plans. And Mr. Bayless's office said he was unavailable last week to be interviewed. **********Now Wall Street is waiting to see if Mr. Bayless gets what he wants. "It could go either way," said Bert Kramer, a Paine Webber analyst.
