https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/world.main_headline: First Briton in Space Goes Aloft With 2 Astronauts on Soviet Craft
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/world.print_headline: First Briton in Space Goes Aloft With 2 Astronauts on Soviet Craft
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/world.body_text: **********A 27-year-old chemist today became the first Briton in space when she and two Soviet astronauts blasted off here aboard a spacecraft on an eight-day mission. **********Helen Sharman, accompanied by Anatoly Artsebarsky and Sergei Krikalyov, lifted off in a Soyuz TM-12 craft from the Baikonur space center in Soviet Central Asia. **********Soviet television showed the slim brown and white rocket rising smoothly from the launching pad and disappearing into the clouds after a few seconds. A brief shot of Britain's first astronaut as the seconds to blast-off ticked away showed her looking calm but pensive. **********Miss Sharman, nicknamed "the Woman from Mars" after the Mars candy company where she worked before winning a contest to join the space flight, spent two years training in the Star City Space Center near Moscow. **********She is the first woman on a Soviet space mission since Svetlana Savistskaya, a Soviet citizen, went up in 1984. **********Valentina Tereshkova, the Soviet astronaut who was the first woman in space in 1963, was at the Baikonur center to watch the launching. Former Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, one of the leading candidates in next month's Russian republic elections, was also there. **********Soyuz TM-12 is to rendezvous in space with the orbiting Mir station manned by two other Soviet astronauts, Musa Manarov and Viktor Afanasyev. **********Mr. Krikalyov and Mr. Artsebarsky are to stay aboard Mir, the centerpiece of the Soviet space program. It has been manned for all but a few months since it was put into orbit in February 1986.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/12/busin.main_headline: Stocks Gain In Slow Day; Dow Up 14.98
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/12/busin.print_headline: Stocks Gain In Slow Day; Dow Up 14.98
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/12/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices rose a little yesterday in sluggish trading as investors waited for further news on the direction of second-quarter earnings. **********Summing up what appeared to be the tenor of the market, Edwin Walczak, chief investment officer of Vontobel U.S.A., the American arm of Bank Vontobel of Zurich, said: "There's not a lot going on. Usually you get four or five calls a day. But the market's been so flat for so long, I haven't gotten a call from a broker in two days." **********The Dow Jones industrial average, with a little help from Walt Disney, Alcoa and United Technologies, moved 14.98 points higher, to 2,959.75. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 1.23, to 376.97. The smaller stocks in the Nasdaq composite also managed a small advance. The American Stock Exchange's market-value index edged into negative ground.  Advance for Disney **********Disney rose 1 3/8, to 121 1/4, although Reuters said Jessica Reif of Oppenheimer & Company cut her earnings estimate on Wednesday because of continued weakness at Disney's theme parks. **********Alcoa rose 1 3/8, to 69 3/8. On Wednesday Jordan Estra, another Oppenheimer analyst, lowered his earnings estimate on Alcoa and other aluminum producers because of lower aluminum prices. **********United Technologies rose 1 1/4, to 45 3/8. Its Hamilton Standard aircraft components division announced Wednesday that it would lay off 700 by Sept. 1 because of the loss of government work and a drop in air travel. **********The three stocks accounted for almost half the gain in the Dow. **********Activity on the New York Stock Exchange, which has been at depressed levels for most of the week, fell yesterday to a slow 157.9 million shares, down from a strong 178.9 million the day before. Only 250,000 shares of yesterday's total changed hands in the after-hours session introduced last month. Some Program Trading **********Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, spotted an hour and a half of heavy buying and selling but by the end of the day the trading lifted the Dow less than 3 points. Program traders, though, really do not care which way the market is moving, making a profit on the small differential in price between, say, the price of an S.& P. 500 futures contract and the 500 stocks themselves. **********After the downturn in the market late Wednesday, bargain hunters moved in at the start of trading yesterday, lifting the Dow about 20 points. The market soon began to drop, losing all of its gain by 11 A.M. By noon the Dow began building, rising 22 points over the next three hours. Then the market dropped sharply almost instantly and quickly rose again. **********In the biggest advance of the day, Glenmore Distilleries more than doubled on the American Stock Exchange, rising 23 1/4, to 41 3/8, after United Distillers, a unit of Guinness acquired the company. **********Among the movers, Eli Lilly, which fell as much as 2 1/4 during the day, closed at 71 1/2, off 1 1/8, with 2.3 million shares changing hands. It was the third-most-active Big Board stock. **********Dayton Hudson, the store chain, which fell as much as 5 during the day, ended at 69 3/4, down 2 3/8. It reported a 9.3 percent sales gain in the five weeks ended July 6 but said sales increases in June reflected high clearance markdowns.  CPC Tumbles **********Showing how ruthless investors can be about earnings announcements, CPC International, the food company, reported lower than expected second-quarter profits, adding that weakening foreign currency might upset its forecasts of double-digit growth. John McMillan of Prudential Securities immediately trimmed his earnings estimates for this year and 1992. **********CPC, down as much as 4 5/8 at one point, dropped 2 3/4 by the close, to 83 3/4. **********In chemicals, Loctite rose 1 1/2, to 35 7/8, and Dow Chemical rose 1 3/8, to 54 1/8. **********In technology, Microsoft rose 1, to 66 1/4, and Motorola 1, to 64 3/8. Digital Equipment fell 1 1/4, to 62 3/4, and Intel 1 1/4, to 45 1/2. **********Among the military stocks, McDonnell Douglas rose 1 3/8, to 57; Raytheon 1 3/4, to 81 3/4, and Northrop 1, to 27 1/8. **********In biotechnology, Amgen rose 1 1/2, to 125 3/4, and Genzyme 2 5/8, to 35 7/8. Bloomberg Business News said Teena Lerner of Lehman Brothers called Genzyme "a buy with high risk." It said she reported strong sales gains for a Genzyme drug to treat Gaucher's disease, which causes anemia and the enlargement of the liver and spleen. **********As a sign of their importance, Denise Gilbert, formerly with County NatWest and now with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, has begun following biotechnology. Reuters said she has a buy ratings on Amgen, Chiron and Cygnus Therapeutic Systems. Chiron rose 1 1/4, to 56 1/2. Cygnus rose 1/2, to 13 1/4.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/world.main_headline: Political Terrorism Is Rising in Soviet Union, K.G.B. Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/world.print_headline: Political Terrorism Is Rising in Soviet Union, K.G.B. Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/07/world.body_text: **********Political terrorism ranging from bombings to hijackings is increasing in the Soviet Union, the K.G.B. said today. **********It blamed ethnic disputes and waning Government power, and said foreign groups were partly responsible. **********"The stable immunity against terrorism that has existed in the Soviet Union for years seems to have been broken," said Maj. Gen. Valery Vorotnikov, head of the K.G.B.'s Department for Protecting the Soviet Constitutional Order. "The Soviet leadership now has to consider this kind of crime as as serious threat to national security." **********Terrorism against elected and public officials is increasing, General Vorotnikov said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/16/busin.main_headline: Executive at Citicorp To Help Lead Quotron
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Executive at Citicorp To Help Lead Quotron
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/16/busin.body_text: **********Thomas J. Cirillo has been named president and chief operating officer of Quotron, a provider of stock and foreign-exchange trading information owned by Citicorp. Mr. Cirillo, who joined Citicorp in 1979, was most recently division executive in charge of much of Citicorp's leasing activities in the United States. **********The 42-year-old Mr. Cirillo will succeed Paul F. Glaser, who is retiring on May 1 at age 65. He will report to the subsidiary's chairman and chief executive, Leland H. Amaya. **********Quotron has not made a profit since it was acquired by Citicorp five years ago, and in 1990, it had a loss exceeding $200 million. In February, according to the American Banker, a trade newspaper, Quotron signed a contract renewal with its largest customer, Paine Webber, but at a substantial price concession that could cause Quotron to lose money on the deal. Executives at Citicorp declined to comment on Quotron's financial problems. **********In a telephone interview, Mr. Cirillo said Quotron planned to develop a new data center, data network and support system that would "improve customer delivery and our service to the customer." He added, "When it is completed several years from now, the new infrastructure will give our customers better tools to work with." **********He said Quotron's ability to serve its customers "is constrained by our technology, adding, "that's why we are undertaking this new project." **********The project, still in the planning stages, will be carried on in New York, Los Angeles and other cities, he said. **********Asked if Quotron was suffering in part because of the Wall Street consolidations, Mr. Cirillo replied: "The overall economic effect has hurt, and we would like a better Wall Street climate. But, while we have to await the new infrastructure, we will continue to make improvements by broadening our product and improving our service." **********Mr. Cirillo is a native New Yorker. He attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology but did not complete his undergraduate studies. After leaving M.I.T., he spent 10 years in the systems industry as a consultant on software before joining Citicorp. **********Currently, Quotron has about 85,000 terminals operating at financial companies, down from about 100,000 in 1989. As the financial community continues to consolidate, Quotron expects the number of terminals to drop to about 80,000 by year-end.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Johnson & Johnson Has New Product
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/busin.body_text: **********Using peat moss instead of synthetics, Johnson & Johnson has developed a natural extra-thin sanitary napkin that it says absorbs 12 times its weight in liquid. The brownish peat pads began appearing on grocery shelves in Canada several weeks ago, a spokesman, Robert Kniffin, said. The company, based in New Brunswick, plans to sell the product in the United States but will not say when. **********The peat moss pad absorbs as well as standard sanitary napkins but is one-fifth as thick and therefore more comfortable, Mr. Kniffin said. Moss is also a "natural plant" that "naturally absorbs" as it moves liquid away from the pad's center through capillaries that keep it dry, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; B.S.B. Picks: No Visine. Nix.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/04/busin.body_text: **********Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., New York, has decided it needs lice medicine more than eye drops. **********The agency announced yesterday that it had decided to accept an integrated marketing assignment for Nix, a pediculicide made by the Burroughs Wellcome Company, though it would cost Backer another account: Pfizer's Visine eye drops. Visine was at the agency 22 years, dating to the days of Ted Bates Advertising. **********A Pfizer spokesman said yesterday that Rid, its lice medicine, competed with Nix. While Backer did not handle the Rid account, Pfizer was uncomfortable with the arrangement, he added, and had asked the agency to choose between the accounts. **********Advertising executives estimated the Nix account's billings at slightly less than those of Visine, which last year were about $8 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/17/busin.main_headline: Lilly Chief to Retire; Successor Is Named
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Lilly Chief to Retire; Successor Is Named
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/17/busin.body_text: **********Eli Lilly and Company announced yesterday that Richard D. Wood would retire as chief executive, president and chairman of the company's executive committee on Oct. 31. Vaughn D. Bryson, an executive vice president and longtime employee of the big Indianapolis-based pharmaceutical company, will succeed Mr. Wood in the three posts on Nov. 1. **********Mr. Wood, who will be 65 years old next month, will continue as chairman of Lilly's board of directors and as a member of the executive committee. **********Although Mr. Bryson's promotion had been expected, the timing of the announcement surprised analysts and company employees. Mr. Bryson, who is known as a more outward-going personality than Mr. Wood, may be called on to present Lilly's case for Prozac, its best-selling antidepressant drug. On Friday, at an advisory committee meeting of the Federal Food and Drug Administration, Lilly and other companies that make antidepresssants will present evidence on whether the products can be held responsible for suicidal and violent behavior. **********Edward A. West, a Lilly spokesman, said the company welcomed the F.D.A. hearing. He added yesterday that attempts by defendants in 13 criminal cases to blame Prozac for their violent behavior had failed. He said judges had also dismissed seven civil suits that sought to link Prozac to suicide attempts. None of the dozens of such lawsuits have yet reached trial. **********Security analysts said Lilly had "a publicity problem" with Prozac, which has been attacked by members of the Scientology church in newspaper advertisments and television appearences. The company "will have an opportunity on Friday to clear the air," said Barbara Ryan, a drug analyst with Prudential Securities. **********Analysts said they had rarely a chance to speak with Mr. Wood, who was also on the boards of the Amoco Corporation, the Chemical Banking Corporation, Dow Jones & Company and the Chubb Corporation. "Vaughn Bryson is a warmer creature," Ms. Ryan said. **********Mr. Bryson, 53, joined Lilly in 1961 after graduating from the University of North Carolina, where he was a pharmacy major. As executive vice president, he headed the company's medical device, diagnostic and Elanco animal health units and was also responsible for finances, government affairs, community and media relations and information systems. He formerly directed operations in Canada, the Far East and South Africa, later moving to London as a vice president for Europe, the Middle East and Africa. He was born in Gastonia, N.C. **********Mr. Wood, who was born in Brazil, Ind., joined Lilly in 1950. He was a financial and marketing executive before becoming president in 1972 and chairman and chief executive in 1973. Lilly's net income has risen tenfold since then, to $1.13 billion last year on sales of $5.19 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.main_headline: Chasing Few Buyers With Too Many Tires
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.print_headline: Chasing Few Buyers With Too Many Tires
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/busin.body_text: **********Tom H. Barrett has had a gruelling two-year tenure as chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. Since he took over, Goodyear, once known by its rivals as The Gorilla because of its dominance of the world tire business, has lost the lead to France's Groupe Michelin. And the tire business has taken a turn for the worst. **********None of the top companies -- not Michelin, Goodyear or Japan's Bridgestone Corporation -- is faring well. And the uncertainty over oil prices, the unending price cutting and chronic overcapacity among tire producers, plus anemic auto sales, are likely to keep the industry in a tailspin. **********There are simply too many tires chasing too few buyers. Despite consolidation of the industry into the hands of a few global companies over the last decade and the idling of dozens of plants, producers have been unable to raise prices as industry costs have increased, leaving them little choice but to cut their own costs to make money. **********And here, no company has been any more aggressive than Goodyear. As the only publicly traded tire company among the top five, which also includes Germany's Continental and Italy's Pirelli, Goodyear is under greater pressure from investors than its rivals to post quarterly improvements. **********Mr. Barrett and his top managers decided last summer to slash the company's capital spending and flatten the layers of management in its North American operation. Over the next two years, Goodyear expects to lay off about 3,000 employees, nearly 3 percent of its work force worldwide -- the largest layoff in its history. **********"We have taken some actions that have been difficult, but they will help this company compete," said Mr. Barrett, a plain-spoken man from Topeka, Kan., who has been with Goodyear for 37 years, principally in manufacturing. "These are difficult times for us. And I get a little impatient that we're not moving as fast as we should in some areas." **********With up-to-date plants that are as efficient as any in the industry, Goodyear may now be poised for an improvement. Indeed, since the company announced the restructuring, its stock price has climbed. It is trading at around $20, up from $14 in November. Still, that's well down from the $50-plus range of 1989 and last week, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said it was considering downgrading some of the company's ratings. **********"A lot of what they're doing is positive, but it's not payting off yet," said Dennis Byrne, a professor of economics at the University of Akron and a tire industry consultant. **********Harry W. Millis, an independent tire analyst in Cleveland, said "Oil prices will probably be lower than people expected and Goodyear has done a lot of cost cutting that will show up in the next year," He expects the company to earn $120 million this year. That would be well below its performance in 1989, when it netted $206.8 million on sales of $10.8 billion, but better than 1990. The company has yet to report results for all of last year, but analysts project a net loss of at least $30 million on sales of more than $11 billion. **********Tire makers are being tarred in part because they are captives of the auto market. The slump in auto sales has already caused auto makers to slash the price they're willing to pay for new tires by about 20 percent. At the same time, competition in the replacement market, which accounts for about two-thirds of the industry's roughly $47.5 billion in worldwide sales, is forcing companies to cut prices so deeply that profits are thinner than they have been in decades. **********"The industry just doesn't seem to make any sense," said Professor Byrne. "It seems as though the major goal among the tire companies is to get market share and they will do anything to sell more tires than the next guy." **********Earnings might have been healthier if companies had been shouldering less debt. Each of the top five has taken on a mountain of debt in the last five years either to make an acquisition or, in the case of Goodyear, to fend one off. For instance, Michelin, which recently said that it would report a $400 million loss for 1990, assumed $800 million in debt in its purchase last year of the Uniroyal Goodyear Tire Company. The acquisition vaulted it into the market-share lead, but brought its debt to $6 billion. **********Goodyear is the only top-tier tire maker not to have merged in the last decade. Still, it has yet to recover from a 1986 takeover attempt by Sir James Goldsmith, the British investor. To fight off the pursuit, Goodyear sold its highly profitable aerospace division to the Loral Corporation for $650 million and took on $3.8 billion in debt, largely to finance a $2 billion stock repurchase plan. The company's ratio of debt to equity soared to more than 70 percent, from 30 percent, and has since fallen back only to the 60 percent range. **********And Goodyear has suffered other headaches that rivals have not. A big one: The unprofitable 1,750-mile crude oil pipeline between California and Texas that it bought in 1985 as a way to diversify. Although the pipeline is designed to carry more than 400,000 barrels of oil a day, it is handling only about 100,000 barrels. **********"The revenues are probably not running more than 10 percent of what they had anticipated," said Mr. Millis. "What should have been a $100 million-a-year positive is a $110 million to $120 million drag on earnings." **********War in the Persian Gulf, should it push oil prices up, might yet make the pipeline pay.  "The question is how good a project it turns out in the long run," Mr. Barrett said. "It has the possibility of doing what we projected." On the other hand, he added, "I'm not saying it's a great investment." And an oil-price rise would hit its basic business hard (box, lower right). **********Mr. Barrett is putting more faith in the measures he has taken to retread Goodyear's tire operation. Under his management, the company has established 28 regional offices that report directly to headquarters here. Previously, 43 district offices reported to five regional divisions, which in turn reported to headquarters. In addition to realigning the company's divisions, Goodyear slashed its capital spending budget by about $125 million, to about $575 million last year. And it expects to cut the capital budget further, to $450 million this year. **********But the retrenchment has zapped morale of Goodyear's 109,000 workers. Said one senior-level executive, who asked to remain anonymous: "People see the layoffs coming, which have never been part of the Goodyear tradition, and wonder when it's going to end. Employees are feeling a sense of fear of the future that is unusual around here." **********When will Goodyear be able to raise prices and lift profits? "I don't see anything in the short term that's going to change and improve conditions in the industry," said John J. Nevin, now retired, who was chairman of Firestone until it was acquired by Bridgestone four years ago. "You've got a recognition on the part of tire makers that, to survive, they have to maintain strong positions around the world." **********Professor Byrne contends that 15 to 20 percent of the worldwide tiremaking capacity needs to be shut down before supply and demand come into line. Michelin announced in December that it would close some old Uniroyal-Goodrich capacity. And Goodyear said it is considering some shutdowns of plants. Overall, though, tire makers have been slow to mothball plants. **********Some industry executives hope that further consolidation will improve conditions. Fifth-place Pirelli S.p.A., which purchased the Armstrong Tire Company of New Haven, Conn., in 1988 but is still considered a regional southern European player, last year proposed a merger with fourth-place Continental A.G. of Germany. That would create an $8.4 billion company with about 14.5 percent of the world market. Continental said in January it had no interest in such a move. But Pirelli, which claims it can muster more than half the voting shares of Continental, said it will take the issue before shareholders next month. **********Mr. Barrett, meanwhile, seems only mildly daunted by the prospect of resuscitating the old gorilla. "I think you're going to see some improvements for the industry," the Goodyear chairman said. "I feel that Goodyear is a position to maybe improve at a better rate than the rest of them."  OIL PRICES ANOTHER PROBLEM **********One wild card in any recovery scenario for the tire industry is oil prices. Higher oil prices after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait put a dent in tire markers' margins. Tom Barrett, Goodyear's chairman, said their costs have increased at least 3 percent since August because of the oil price increases. **********That, some analysts say, could mean the difference between making or losing money. The average passenger tire takes about seven gallons of oil or derivative products to produce. **********"Under those circumstances you get killed on the cost-price relationship," said Harry W. Millis, an independent analyst in Cleveland. "You can only squeeze out a little black ink, if you're lucky." **********Dealers have been resistant to increases in the price of tires, balking at the latest attempt by tire makers to raise prices last fall.  Even when they do stick, price hikes are not always helpful. When Goodyear raised prices in the fall of 1988 by about 15 percent, dealers rebelled: Its share in the United States replacement market dropped to about 26 percent, from about 30 percent. Only after lowering prices to match the competition did market share climb back to nearly 30 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.main_headline: Market Place; A Lull for Mutual Funds Is Brief
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.print_headline: Market Place; A Lull for Mutual Funds Is Brief
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/busin.body_text: **********The sharp fall in stock prices in mid-November caused only a mild tremor among mutual fund investors, fund managers said yesterday. Although some funds saw a brief outflow of money after the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 120 points on Friday, Nov. 15, the cash resumed pouring in soon after. **********"When we had the down blip, sales slowed," said Robert Leo, director of mutual funds for Shearson Lehman Brothers, referring to the drop in stocks. "But redemptions were a non-event. People almost take these 100-point days in stride now." **********The Janus Group saw more than twice as many buy orders for stock funds on Monday, Nov. 18, as on any day in the fund group's history, said Jack Thompson, an executive vice president. "We continue to see steady purchasing of equity funds. Our hope is that they have become long-term investors."  A Good October **********Over all, many fund groups said the flow of money into stock funds this month was lower than in October, but was still good. Figures released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, a trade group, showed that $4.8 billion flowed into stock funds last month, the most for any month since April 1987. **********"The momentum in equity funds has slowed this month, but has remained relatively positive," said Steve Norwitz, a spokesman for T. Rowe Price Associates. He said sales slacked late in the month, but that there was no increase in redemptions. **********November has also been a good month for bond funds, managers said, with investors especially interested in funds that invest in bonds that mature in five to 10 years. Such bonds still produce relatively high yields, despite the fall in interest rates. **********This year has been a banner one for mutual fund companies in general, with cash pouring into both stock and bond funds as investors react to rising stock prices and falling interest rates. Substantial amounts of money have been moved out of bank certificates of deposit and out of money market mutual funds. **********In October, bond funds took in a net $9.6 billion, the most in any month since March 1987, just before bond prices fell, and more than the $9.3 billion cash inflow in all of 1990. Through the first 10 months, $56.7 billion has flowed in, more than in any full year since 1986, when $108.6 billion came in as interest rates plunged. **********For stock funds, the picture is even more graphic. Through October, those funds have taken in a net $27.5 billion, more than in any previous full year. The old record was set in 1986, when $21.9 billion poured in. That pace picked up in 1987, with $29 billion coming in during the first nine months. But $10 billion flowed out in the final quarter of that year, as investors reacted to the October stock market crash. **********Since then, many investors have come to believe that falling prices provide a buying opportunity, not a reason to panic, although prices have generally continued slipping since the sharp drop in mid-November. **********Mutual fund investors were buying more shares this fall despite a general decline in consumer sentiment. In a survey by the University of Michigan for Fidelity Investments, the level of consumer sentiment about the future of the economy fell for the fourth straight month in November, Michael Hines, a Fidelity spokesman, said. **********But that same survey found that many more investors intended to buy stock funds in the next quarter than had planned to do so last summer, when sentiment was much higher. **********That apparent contradiction may be explainable by an investor perception that with good returns no longer available on short-term investments, more risk must be taken. That has caused many to move into stocks, which have performed well this year. **********The professionals who manage stock funds were a bit less optimistic than their investors in October, putting only a part of the flood of new money to work. As a result, the percentage of stock fund assets that was in cash in October rose to 8.7 percent, from 8.2 percent in September and a low of 8 percent in August. In October 1990, when stock prices were bottoming, 12.9 percent of stock fund assets was in cash. **********But optimism among managers of junk bond funds appears to be running at a high level. At the end of January, those managers had 12.4 percent of their assests in cash. But junk bonds have performed well this year, and the cash portion in junk portfolios has been at 5.5 percent for the last two months, the lowest since September 1987. **********In October, $317 million came into junk funds, bringing the total for 1991 to $2 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.main_headline: Baker and Saudi King Talk About Timing of an Assault
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Baker and Saudi King Talk About Timing of an Assault
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia today to discuss the timing of an attack on Iraqi forces in Kuwait if they have not withdrawn from that country by the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline, senior Administration officials said. **********Mr. Baker declined to speak with reporters after his meeting with the Saudi ruler, and neither side indicated what, if any, decisions were made. The Saudis and Americans have an understanding that no war will be launched from Saudi territory without the prior agreement of King Fahd and President Bush. **********As Mr. Baker flew to Saudi Arabia from Geneva, after his fruitless talks with Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, a senior official aboard his jet said the Secretary of State wanted to get King Fahd's "views and ideas" on when to move militarily against Iraq after Jan. 15, in order to communicate those views to Mr. Bush. **********A senior Administration official said Mr. Baker told King Fahd that the United States was expecting Saudi Arabia to continue its financing of American troops in Saudi Arabia during 1991, and that since the number of American forces had grown considerably in recent weeks, the assistance would have to be greater than the $5 billion committed by the Saudis for 1990. Saudi Troop Money for '91 **********A senior Saudi official said King Fahd told Mr. Baker that his country had a commitment to "responsibility sharing" and would support American troops in Saudi Arabia during 1991 just as it did last year. In 1990, the Saudi Government paid virtually all of the "in country" costs of the American military, including fuel, food, water, transportation and communications bills. **********Mr. Baker scheduled a meeting for early Friday with the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, to discuss precise amounts of money and how they will be paid out in the coming year, American officials said. **********After that meeting, Mr. Baker is scheduled to go to Abu Dhabi to meet with leaders of the United Arab Emirates, then to Taif, Saudi Arabia, where he will see the exiled Kuwaiti leadership before ending the day in Egypt. On Saturday, he will get the views of the Syrian leadership and Sunday he meets with the Turks, British and Canadians before returning to Washington. **********After Mr. Baker and King Fahd held their larger meeting with full delegations, Mr. Baker asked to speak to the King privately. They went to a small room in the King's Riyadh palace, where at one point Mr. Baker asked Lieut. Gen. Howard Graves, representing the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to join him and the King. U.N. Chief's Baghdad Effort **********While no details of their talks were made available, officials indicated that it was at that private session that the timing of a possible war after Jan. 15 was discussed. **********Administration officials said Mr. Baker also read to King Fahd the letter that Mr. Bush had tried to send Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, through Foreign Minister Aziz. Mr. Aziz refused to accept the letter, which has not been made public. **********Before leaving Geneva today, Mr. Baker emphasized to the Iraqi leadership that they still have five days to withdraw from Kuwait unharmed. **********"I am very pleased," Mr. Baker said, "that the Secretary General of the United Nations is going to Baghdad to make an effort on behalf of the international coalition to find a peaceful, political solution to this crisis. I continue to believe that peace is possible. We certainly continue to strongly prefer a peaceful and political solution. I believe that the path to peace is open. The choice is that of the Government of Iraq, and I hope that they will choose the path to peace." Impression on Aziz **********Administration officials said the visit by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to Baghdad on Saturday was an important 11th-hour mission after Mr. Baker's failed talks with Mr. Aziz. American officials said the important thing now about the Aziz-Baker talks was not what Mr. Aziz brought to Geneva -- which was nothing -- but what assessment he will give to President Hussein about America's intentions and resolve. **********If Mr. Baker succeeded in impressing on the Iraqi diplomat Washington's willingness and ability to attack after the Jan. 15 deadline, and if that impression has any effect on Iraq's willingness to compromise on Kuwait, American officials say it should become apparent in the meeting between Mr. Hussein and the Secretary General. **********"If Iraq is going to comply with the U.N. resolutions, given the history of Saddam Hussein, they will do so only at the last minute," the senior American official said. **********The official hinted that if Iraq is already in the process of moving out of Kuwait, but not fully out by Jan. 15, the United States would probably hold its fire, at least long enough to see if the withdrawal was serious or just a ruse. **********"Midnight on the 15th is a very important time," the official said. "We will have to see what the situation is at that time, and I can't speculate on that in advance. Suppose he is actively moving out? I can't answer those kinds of questions."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/13/busin.main_headline: In Defense of Peat Marwick and Reputation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/13/busin.print_headline: In Defense of Peat Marwick and Reputation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/13/busin.body_text: **********To The Editor: **********I consider the article "The Partners Revolt at Peat Marwick," Nov. 18, irresponsible. This ill-disposed publicity for my former firm and certain of its partners and me is undeserved and regrettable. **********The characterization of a letter which I sent to the partners is distorted. I received a telephone call from a Times reporter on Oct.  16. I repeatedly praised KPMG Peat Marwick, its partners and those recently elected to lead the firm. Not one negative comment of any type was made. **********When she attempted to delve into internal firm matters (including my letter), I responded "KPMG Peat Marwick is a private partnership and I do not believe that it is appropriate for either you or me to comment on their confidential internal affairs." **********Unfortunately, it appears that several former and/or current board members and partners violated their confidentiality commitment in disclosing private information to the reporter. And they were dastardly in misrepresenting the facts contained in my letter and maligning me personally. Their spin and perspective placed on my letter and me appears designed to serve their own egotism and ulterior motives. I surmise that some (or all) of the sources were disgruntled losers in the October election who allowed their emotions to overcome their good judgment. At any rate, they did themselves and their firm a grave disservice. **********Many business people subscribe to the premise that it is useless to try to correct erroneous and misleading information in the press. I do not accept this proposition. We must provide correctives as counterbalances in order to protect our institutions and reputations. I worked for more than 30 years to build both my firm's and my personal reputation. I was the managing partner of the Detroit office for over 10 years and also a board member. I served as the international president of the National Association of Accountants and was selected Michigan's 1985 Professional Man of the Year. **********If in fact my letter to the partners helped them elect a leadership team that both they and I believe will lead their outstanding firm to even greater success in the future, then I am very proud of this legacy.  CHARLES T. SMITH Jr.  Greenville, S.C., Dec. 24

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/busin.print_headline: Pohl, as Expected, Says He Will Quit Bank Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Karl Otto Pohl, Europe's most powerful financial leader and the architect of a strong German mark, announced today that he would resign as president of the Bundesbank in October. **********Although his term has four years to run, the move had been expected since two leading West German newspapers reported it on Monday, and financial markets today showed little reaction. **********Mr. Pohl, who recently called the Bonn Government's handling of the economic aspects of German unity "a disaster," adamantly denied that pressure from Bonn had been a factor in his decision, adding that "tensions and differences of opinion between the federal Government and the Bundesbank," were normal. **********"My departure is not a demonstrative act or a sign of resignation, but is part of my longer-term life plan," Mr. Pohl said at a news conference at the Bundesbank in Frankfurt. "I ask you to understand and respect that after more than 21 years in public service, I need to devote myself to my family and my private interests more than has been possible until now." Policy Change Not Expected **********A successor will be appointed by President Richard von Weizsacker within the next two weeks. German political leaders and economists said the Bundesbank's tight monetary policies, tough anti-inflation stance and political independence would remain, regardless of who succeeded Mr. Pohl. The Bundesbank policies have occasioned differences with Washington and other Western allies, as well as with the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. **********"There is no plausible reason to expect the Bundesbank's monetary policy to be any easier because of Mr. Pohl's departure," said Norbert Walter, chief economist for Deutsche Bank A.G. in Frankfurt. **********Chancellor Kohl said on Wednesday: "We will not do anything that will endanger the stability of the German currency. We will not follow a policy of easy money." **********Hans Tietmeyer, 59 years old, a member of the bank's seven-man board, is the front-runner by virtue of his extensive international experience and friendship with Mr. Kohl. He is also a Christian Democrat and was state secretary in charge of international monetary affairs at the Finance Ministry from 1982 until late 1989, when he joined the Bundesbank. Mr. Kohl promptly called him back to be his personal adviser on monetary union with East Germany last year.The Second Candidate **********The other leading candidate is Helmut Schlesinger, currently the Bundesbank's vice president, but he is a less likely choice because he is to retire in December 1992. Mr. Schlesinger is the primary architect of the Bundesbank's rigid anti-inflation policy. **********Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d was quoted in November 1987 as saying of the Bundesbank's policy-making: "It's a little clique headed by Helmut Schlesinger. They are rigid monetarists bent on zero inflation, no matter what." **********But some Germans say it is the institution itself that shapes the policy and the person. When Mr. Pohl, a former financial journalist, was appointed head of the Bundesbank by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt in 1980, he brought with him a reputation as a Social Democrat who supported expansionary monetary policy. "Instead, he adopted the Bundesbank's policies," Mr. Walter said. **********That pragmatism, combined with a deft public relations touch, an easy-going style and a sense of humor, helped Mr. Pohl promote -- and occasionally defend -- the Bundesbank's views on strictly controlling inflation, if necessary by repeatedly raising interest rates. The bank flourished under his guidance and he was reappointed to a second eight-year term in 1988 by Mr. Kohl, head of the conservative Christian Democratic Union. A Powerful Post **********"Whoever takes the job steps into leadership of the most powerful central bank and economy in Europe," said Jonathan Hoffman, an international economist with Credit Suisse First Boston in London. "No matter how capable he ma be, no other European central banker can claim that. The Bundesbank president is ex officio the most powerful monetary leader in Europe." **********Rumors have placed Mr. Pohl, 61, in chief executive jobs at banks and businesses in Germany, France, Switzerland and New York, but people close to him said he had not made a decision.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/world.main_headline: GORBACHEV BACK AS COUP FAILS, BUT YELTSIN GAINS NEW POWER
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/world.print_headline: AFTER THE COUP; GORBACHEV BACK AS COUP FAILS, BUT YELTSIN GAINS NEW POWER
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/22/world.body_text: **********A coup by hard-line Communists collapsed on Wednesday as abruptly as it began, and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev returned to Moscow early this morning to reassert control. **********Mr. Gorbachev landed at Vnukovo Airport on his return from his summer retreat in the Crimea, where he had been placed under house arrest early Monday at the start of the short-lived putsch. **********In impromptu remarks to Soviet television that were aired later on a morning news program, Mr. Gorbachev appeared weary but clearly angered by the efforts of the conspirators to get him to surrender power. 'The World Should Know' **********"The whole world should know about this, what exactly was being plotted," he said upon arriving at the airport, "and what it is that they did not succeed in getting from me." **********Mr. Gorbachev described the coup leaders as "a miserable group" that had tried to "break" him and " to influence his family" by surrounding them with troops and isolating them for 72 hours. **********The Soviet President congratulated the Soviet people for having had the "responsibility and dignity" to resist the takeover. **********He particularly thanked the President of the Russian federated republic, Boris N. Yeltsin, for standing up to the coup leaders. **********Mr. Gorbachev was expected to meet with the Russian leader later today.  'In Full Control' **********Mr. Gorbachev's wife, Raisa, was also shown on morning television disembarking from the plane at the airport while holding a small child wrapped in a blanket. The Gorbachevs left for their country house in a Moscow suburb. **********The Soviet President had said in a statement reported Wednesday by the evening television news program Vremya that he was "in full control of the situation" and that he would resume his full duties within a day. **********The evening program also reported that he had restored contact with the Cabinet and the Defense Ministry -- both under acting chiefs now that their leaders were disgraced -- and to have talked by telephone with Mr. Yeltsin and President Bush. **********Only one of the coup leaders -- the K.G.B. chairman, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov -- was reported under arrest early today. It was the first time a K.G.B. leader had been arrested since Lavrenti P. Beria was detained, tried secretly and shot in 1953 in the power struggle that followed the death of Stalin. **********Reuters reported from Moscow that two other coup leaders, the Defense Minister, Marshal Dmitri T. Yazov, and Nikolai I. Tizyakov, had been detained, according to Sergei Stankevich, a member of the Soviet Parliament and an adviser to Mr. Yeltsin. But this report could not be independently confirmed. There were also unconfirmed reports that the other members of the State Committee for the State of Emergency would be put on trial. **********The coup crumbled Wednesday as abruptly as it began, without any formal announcement from its leaders, who sent tanks into Moscow on Monday and declared themselves in command. **********It seemed simply to fizzle under the disdain of masses rallying to the summons of Mr. Yeltsin, who rose to condemn the coup almost from the moment it became known, and the irresolution of plotters who failed to garner support or even to maintain the loyalty of their forces. Communist Party Denounced **********On Wednesday, Mr. Yeltsin declared that the Communist Party had been "the organizing and inspiring force" behind the coup, and the implication was that with its last, desperate rear- guard action the once-formidable force that had controlled the Soviet Union for more than 70 years might finally be exhausted. **********It remains a question whether Mr. Gorbachev, after his ordeal, will bolt the party he heads, as have Mr. Yeltsin and other former Gorbachev aides. **********The awareness that the coup had failed came with the first gray light of dawn, when it became evident that army tanks had not moved against the headquarters of the Russian republic's government in the capital. Focus of Resistance **********Relief spread among the thousands of Muscovites who had spent two drizzly nights at makeshift barricades around the building, called the "White House," a wedding-cake-like building on the banks of the Moscow River, from which Mr. Yeltsin marshaled the anti-coup forces. **********Within hours, reports swept through a jubilant Moscow that the members of the Emergency Committee were in flight, and long columns of tanks and armored personnel carriers began to leave the capital, some decorated with Russian flags, to the cheers of jubilant Muscovites. **********Like the marchers in Leipzig or the demonstrators in Prague who had brought down Communist regimes through the sheer force of their determination, Muscovites, even those who had not directly taken part in public demonstrations, felt a personal satisfaction in facing down forces that had held them so long in thrall. 'Weren't We Great?' **********"Weren't we great?" exclaimed one woman, capturing a joyous sense that the nation had united to thwart the long-awaited counter-offensive by the forces of the former Communist dictatorship. "Leave, just please leave," another woman shouted at the tanks. **********According to the spokesman for the Russian republic's government, the Russian vice president, Aleksandr Rutskoi, and its prime minister, Ivan S. Silayev, along with other members of the Russian government, flew to the Crimea Wednesday evening and met with Mr. Gorbachev. While they were there, two members of the Emergency Committee -- the Defense Minister, Marshal Yazov, and the K.G.B. chairman, Mr. Kryuchkov -- flew there with the chairman of the Soviet Parliament, Anatoly I. Lukyanov, and the deputy chief of the Communist Party, Vladimir A. Ivashko. **********The spokesman said that in the course of a long talk between Mr. Gorbachev and the Russian delegation, Mr. Gorbachev was informed about the siege and the attempt to seize the Russian republic's headquarters. Mr. Gorbachev received Mr. Ivashko and Mr. Lukyanov but refused to receive Marshal Yazov and Mr. Kryuchkov. Then Gorbachev, who was in good health, after a rest, flew back with the Russian delegation, thanking members of the Russian government and condemning members of the Emergency Committee. **********Mr. Kryuchkov flew back with Mr. Gorbachev and the Russians, and was arrested at Vnukovo airport by the Russian Interior Ministry. Mr. Ivashko, Mr. Lukyanov and General Yazov were reported to have returned on another plane. **********There was no immediate information on other members of the committee, except for Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov, who was in the hospital with hypertension. The independent Interfax news agency quoted Mr. Rutskoi as saying that the other members of the coup leadership would be arrested later, and that they would all be tried. **********Vremya said Mr. Gorbachev expected that the "adventurists" would carry "full responsibility" for their actions, and the Soviet Prosecutor General's office announced it had opened an investigation of the Emergency Committee on charges of committing a "state crime." It was not known if the investigation would extend to others. Wednesday, Mr. Tizyakov was stripped of his job by his organization because of his role in the coup. **********But even as Moscow waited for Mr. Gorbachev to reappear, it was evident that the balance of power and the course of the Soviet Union's history had shifted, that the Communists who had fought a rearguard action against change had suffered a potentially fatal blow, that Mr. Gorbachev himself was now beholden to the anti-Communist forces that had rescued him, and above all to Mr. Yeltsin. **********Mr. Yeltsin was the indisputable man of the hour, and the advocates of economic and political reform were clearly ascendant. **********It was Mr. Yeltsin's dramatic condemnation of the coup virtually at the same time as the rebellion first became known early Monday morning that roused resistance across the Soviet Union and made his headquarters on the Moscow River into a rallying point of the opposition.  Symbol for Foes of Coup **********The image of Mr. Yeltsin addressing supporters from atop one of the tanks that had come over to his side became the icon of resistance. His statements were published by liberal papers across the Soviet Union and read out at mass rallies from Kamchatka on the Pacific Coast to Leningrad on the Baltic. **********Thousands of Muscovites heeded his call and formed a cordon around White House, sealing approaches with makeshift barricades of buses, trucks and building materials. All across the nation, liberal politicians and supporters of Mr. Yeltsin organized demonstrations and mass meeting. **********He issued decrees declaring the actions of the junta unconstitutional and assuming temporary control over all government and security forces on Russian territory. **********Addressing the Russian Parliament on Wednesday, Mr. Yeltsin declared that it was the defection to his side of several military units that had prevented the junta from interning the Russian government. **********Mr. Yeltsin said that instead of obeying the coup leaders' orders, the Tulskaya Division had protected the Russian parliament from attack. He expressed gratitude to the troops and their commanders for their action. **********The normally fractious Parliament repeatedly rose to unanimously cheer Mr. Yeltsin as he denounced the coup in ringing tones: "This is an impudent coup, unprecedented in the conditions of a genuinely developing democratic society." **********One immediate consequence of the curbing of the far-right forces was the virtual certainty that the union treaty, the radically new federal organization that the Communist had tried to block through their coup, would quickly come into effect. The treaty, negotiated between Mr. Gorbachev and 9 of the 15 republics, would devolve many of the powers of the center to republican governments in a "Union of Soviet Sovereign Republics." **********Flexing his new muscles, Mr. Yeltsin declared that since Mr. Gorbachev had intended to sign the union treaty on Tuesday, he would henceforth consider it in force and was immediately declaring Russian federated republic economically sovereign and master of all its resources. **********The developments also portended an end to efforts to bring the independence-minded Baltic states to heel. Reports from Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia said that Soviet forces had begun lifting their siege of radio, television and communications centers, including centers that had been held by Moscow-controlled forces since January. Backing and Filling **********Elsewhere, the collapse of the coup precipitated frenzied efforts by officials, institutions and news organizations, many of which had lain low for two days, to demonstrate their disgust with the plotters in a day-long flurry of news conferences. **********The Defense Ministry, now under Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev, the chief of staff, the Cabinet, now under Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir I. Shcherbakov, and the Soviet parliament all issued statements declaring fealty to Mr. Gorbachev. **********Leaders of the Communist Party declared that the coup had been "inadmissible" and that from the outset they had demanded a meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, without success. At the same time, a Central Committee secretary, Sergei Kalashnikov, warned journalists against using the term "junta," arguing that leaders of the plot were "people who made a blunder in the estimation of a difficult situation." **********Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh and Mr. Ivashko, the deputy chief of the Communist Party, separately explained their silence over the past two days by saying they were sick. No Change in Foreign Policy **********Mr. Bessmertnykh told a news conference that Soviet foreign policy would remain unchanged. "It is the same as was formulated by the President of the Soviet Union," he told a press conference. **********The tone of official news organs changed radically through the day. Vremya, the main evening news program that had toed the junta's line, now portrayed the collapse of the coup as a great triumph for constitutional order and showed long portions of Mr. Yeltsin's speech to the Russian parliament. The Russian republic's radio and television stations, silenced for two days, returned to the air. **********The Presidium of the Soviet Parliament quickly issued a resolution declaring the removal of Mr. Gorbachev illegal. **********The head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Aleksy II, pronounced anathema against the leaders of the coup.  Impact on Liberalization **********Already in the immediate aftermath of the short-lived coup, questions surfaced about its significance for the future of the tumultuous process of perestroika that Mr. Gorbachev had launched six years earlier. **********In his speech to the Russian republic's Parliament, Mr. Yeltsin described the putsch as the last gasp of an order doomed by the union treaty. **********"Objectively the new union treaty would strip virtually each of the architects of the putsch of their offices, and herein lies the secret of the conspiracy and the main motivation behind the actions of the parties to it," he said. "Their demagoguery about the fate of the homeland is little more than trickery concealing their personal selfish interests." **********In the future envisioned by the union treaty, the central Government would lose many of its powers, and it would also be subject to new elections in which Communists would stand little chance of survival.  A Boost for Gorbachev? **********For Mr. Gorbachev, however, the coup also held out hope of a political boost at a time his fortunes were rapidly ebbing. His resistance to the plotters, who had tried unsuccessfully to involve them in the declaration of a state of emergency, restored his credentials and promised at least a brief new public acceptance. The many expressions of allegiance, including Mr. Yeltsin's, also contributed to Mr. Gorbachev's legitimacy. **********In the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, a swirl of celebrations was marred when an unidentified vehicle tried to breech the barricades around the parliament. One of two occupants got out of the truck and shot a Lithuanian security guard to death. **********Security guards wounded and seized one occupant before the truck escaped. Officials said he was a member of the special Interior Ministry troops that have been responsible for most of the previous acts of violence in the republic. **********At the peak of the coup, Estonia defiantly joined Lithuania and Latvia in declaring independence. **********The slain Lithuanian joined three unidentified Muscovites who were killed Tuesday night in a skirmish with Soviet tanks, and an unidentified person who was reportedly killed in Latvia on Monday. The victims were commemorated in several memorial services in Moscow and in other cities Wednesday, and the melee was shown repeatedly on television. **********In a little-noted footnote to the coup, the Moscow military commandant lifted the 11 P.M. to 5 A.M. curfew announced on Tuesday. The curfew had been universally ignored.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.main_headline: Democrats Wary on Baker's Planned Trip to China
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.print_headline: Democrats Wary on Baker's Planned Trip to China
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.body_text: **********Congressional Democrats today offered muted criticism of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's planned visit to China, saying the trip would be a pointless exercise unless Beijing agrees to improve its record on human rights and arms proliferation. **********In China, the Foreign Ministry praised the visit as "an important event in U.S.-China relations." The White House has not sent a senior official on a public visit to Beijing since Chinese troops massacred pro-democracy student protesters in Tiananmen Square in June 1989. **********The Administration has argued that China is too big and too important for the United States to keep in diplomatic isolation, however distasteful its policies. Other major industrialized nations have effectively resumed normal relations with China. **********Congressional critics argued today that the Administration nevertheless must show continued displeasure with China's behavior and said they were particularly dismayed by increasing reports that the Chinese are providing allies in the Mideast with nuclear technology and help in producing weapons. **********The Chinese are also reported to be supplying Pakistan and Iran with missiles or missile-making technology. **********Two leading Democrats critical of the Administration's China policy, Senators Alan Cranston of California and John Glenn of Ohio, said today that they did not oppose Mr. Baker's visit, but both said the Administration must deliver a powerful message to Beijing about its international and domestic behavior, or face a strong Congressional reaction. **********Mr. Baker's trip comes as the House and Senate are negotiating the final wording of legislation giving China most-favored-nation status in trade dealings. The Senate version of the legislation contains an amendment that would revoke that status if China later provides medium-range missiles or nuclear-weapons technology to either Syria or Iran. **********Mr. Baker "should tell the Chinese leaders that for most Americans, China is probably their least most-favored nation," Senator Cranston said in a statement. He said the Chinese were guilty of aiding the nuclear programs of "renegade countries like Iran," of using slave labor to make products for export, of promoting the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia's civil war and other offenses. **********"I do believe in people talking to each other, provided there's a message that's appropriate under the circumstances," he said in a later telephone interview." **********Senator Glenn said that Mr. Baker must emerge with an arms-control accord, like a binding pledge by China to sign and abide by the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, if his trip was to be judged a success. **********Outside experts have speculated that Mr. Baker will achieve that or a promise by China to join another arms-control pact, the Missile Technology Control Regime. **********--------------------       China Offers Details **********BEIJING, Nov. 4 (Special to The New York Times) -- In response to recent reports that China transferred nuclear weapons technology to Iran, the Foreign Ministry made public some details today about its nuclear cooperation arrangement with Iran. **********The statement, carried by the New China News Agency, said that in 1989 and 1991 Chinese companies signed commercial contracts to provide Iran with a minitype reactor and an electromagnetic separator that produces fissionable isotopes. **********Reports from Washington have said that the equipment China has sold to Iran can be used to build a nuclear bomb. But China has said that it transferred nuclear technology to Iran for civilian uses only. **********"These facilities are used for nuclear medical diagnosis and nuclear physics research, isotope production, education and personnel training," the statement said. "Guided by the internationally observed regulations, China had requested the International Atomic Energy Agency to enforce safeguards before these facilities were shipped."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/17/world.main_headline: 2 Rebel Armies Create Chaos As Colombia Longs for Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/17/world.print_headline: 2 Rebel Armies Create Chaos As Colombia Longs for Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/17/world.body_text: **********No celebrations broke out the other day when geologists confirmed a large oil discovery that doubled Colombia's proven oil reserves. **********The remote eastern department of Casanare, site of the Cusiana oilfield, was without power because of guerrilla sabotage. **********Colombians know that standing between them and an oil bonanza are two battle-hardened guerrilla armies bent on sabotaging the nation's economy. **********In the first direct peace talks in six years, Government representatives started negotiating on June 3 in Caracas, Venezuela, with commanders of the two groups, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia and the National Liberation Army. Monthlong Rebel Offensive **********But, parallel to the peace talks, the guerrillas mounted a monthlong offensive that has killed 108 people and has caused millions of dollars in economic damage. **********The guerrillas recently planted 16 sticks of dynamite at an interior heliport where Colombia's President, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, was scheduled to land. The police found the bomb hours before the President's arrival. **********"These incidents worsen the climate for dialogue," President Gaviria said in an interview here. "In Colombia today, there is no reason to keep fighting." **********Two weeks ago, guerrillas killed two policemen in an unsuccessful attempt to kidnap the Mayor of Cali, Colombia's third-largest city. Oil Exports Decrease **********The guerrillas recently toppled 11 power pylons, cutting electricity to half of this nation of 33 million people. **********Disrupting land traffic, the guerrillas have cut railroads and have damaged or blown up 11 road bridges. And the guerrillas dynamited a multi-million-dollar radar station, depriving Colombia's Caribbean coast of air protection. **********The other day they blew a hole in the airport tarmac of the Caribbean port city of Cartagena. Because of the sabotage, Colombia's top tourist destination is to be cut off from jet service through the end of the month. **********And in 18 attacks on Colombia's two largest oil pipelines, the guerrillas have slowed oil exports to a trickle in the last month. **********In the first six months of this year, the guerrillas carried out 127 attacks on oil installations in Colombia. Compared with the same period last year, oil production dropped 5 percent and the country lost $87 million in oil export revenues. **********As civic protests against the violence are planned in Colombia's major cities, the guerrillas say they are reacting to an invasion of their mountain headquarters in December. **********"The army offensive against us has been permanent, so as a necessary response, the guerrilla developed its own offensive," Alfonso Cano, a commander of the revolutionary armed forces, said in a telephone interview from Caracas. **********But many analysts here say the guerrillas are trying to strengthen their hands in negotiations, which are expected to resume this month. A New Constitution **********"They can only be trying to cause an impression," said Antonio Navarro Wolff, a former guerrilla who now leads the M-19 Democratic Alliance party. "Even the toughest guerrillas can't be thinking of a military victory." **********The guerrilla offensive flies in the face of a widespread public mood here that peace finally has a chance in Colombia. **********The leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel, Pablo Escobar Gaviria, surrendered last month. On July 5, a new Consitution went into effect that guarantees new rights for political minorities. **********Members of four recently disarmed guerrilla groups helped to write the Constitution, which reserves congressional seats for the National Liberation Army and the Revolutionary Armed Forces, if they disarm this year. **********The two active guerrilla groups seem increasingly isolated. **********Newspapers are universally hostile to the guerrillas. Membership in the Communist Party of Colombia, long a pool of urban supporters, has dropped in the last year from 60,000 to 12,000. **********"The whole thing is completely anarchronic -- they live on horseback and cook on campfires," said Clara Lopez Obregon, a left-wing politician here. "You can't take over a city of 6 million people on horseback." **********Shorn of urban support, the guerrillas have fallen back on their original power base, Colombia's rural peasantry. **********But when Colombia's Marxist guerrilla movement started in the early 1960's, Colombia was 75 percent rural. Today, it is 75 percent urban.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/busin.body_text: **********Here in the small and discreet principality that was the ultimate stronghold of Robert Maxwell's financial empire, his name is still whispered with a certain deference, and lawyers are quick to defend his interests. **********Many of those interests are centered in the Maxwell Foundation, one of at least two Liechtenstein-based entities that acted as holding companies for Mr. Maxwell's web of more than 400 worldwide businesses. The other known Liechtenstein unit is Swico Anstalt, or Swico Establishment. **********Long the object of intense conjecture, the secretive units appear to hold a key to the unresolved question of how much money the Maxwell family still has -- and to whether there might be more money for Mr. Maxwell's debtors to recover. **********The foundation is said to have existed for more than 20 years. And in June 1988, Mr. Maxwell told one of his own newspapers, The Daily Mirror, that he had accumulated $:1 billion, or about $1.9 billion at the current exchange rate, in Liechtenstein. He did not elaborate as to how. **********While no actions have been taken against the foundation, the Maxwell creditors are trying to peer over the high walls surrounding the foundation. Even as the creditors move closer, however, lawyers representing the foundation are already stiffening their guard. **********"Creditors certainly have absolutely no rights on assets held in the Maxwell Foundation," warned Werner Keicher, the lawyer responsible for Mr. Maxwell's affairs in Liechtenstein. The terms of the foundation precluded such claims, he argued. **********His remarks appeared to herald a possible conflict with the many officials seeking to recover assets to pay off the more than $4.4 billion of debts left behind by Mr. Maxwell, whose media empire collapsed this month after he died under mysterious circumstances in early November. One of the issues involved may well be whether Mr. Maxwell really controlled the assets, which seems likely, in the eyes of many analysts. **********In any case, the creditors will be examining the possibility of tapping the assets of the foundation. "As in any insolvency, I have to look for every route by which assets can be realized," John Talbot, the Arthur Andersen & Company accountant now in control of the Maxwell private companies, said in a recent interview. He could not be reached for further comment on Mr. Keicher's statement. **********But the very secrecy being used to protect the foundation is seen as a signal that there is something of value there. "I doubt that Mr. Keicher would be posturing so quickly if the coffers were empty," said Peter Phillips, a partner in the Buchler Phillips accounting firm, which is acting as the receivers of Mr. Maxwell's personal estate. "We intend to find out if his claim is legally correct." Stakes in 2 Companies **********According to a report on the Maxwell holdings completed by the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand Deloitte and submitted to creditor banks on Dec. 3, the foundation and Swico directly hold 14.96 percent of the Maxwell Communication public company and 24.8 percent of the private Robert Maxwell Group, whose properties include The Daily News in New York and a host of newspapers from Nairobi to Budapest. **********On the basis of the 14.96 percent Maxwell Communication Corporation holding, the Liechtenstein units would have received dividends of more than $25 million last year alone. **********But they may have received more. The last Maxwell Communication annual report stated that the "Maxwell Foundation and its subsidiaries" held 37.7 percent of the company. It gave no further details. **********Under Liechtenstein's law, the terms of a foundation like Mr. Maxwell's are confidential. The founder, or settlor, asks a local trust company to establish the foundation and then passes assets to it. Once this is done, the foundation becomes an independent legal entity run by its board, which usually consists of three people. Although he may be named as a beneficiary of the foundation, the settlor is no longer the owner of its assets. **********"The assets belong to the foundation, whose sole organ is the board," said the director of a large trust company called Prasidial-Anstalt (which has no relation to the Maxwell entities). "The settlor no longer has any part of it once the bylaws have been established which set out how the assets and their yields should be employed." Wide Range of Benefits **********For Mr. Maxwell, this setup had obvious advantages. For tax purposes, he was not the owner of whatever assets were controlled by his foundation. Moreover, for the purposes of intercompany transactions within his group, which were frequent, he could contend that units controlled by the foundation were not controlled by him. (There is little question, however, that the other Liechtenstein entity, Swico, was directly controlled by Mr. Maxwell.) **********The glossy prospectus of Mr. Keicher's General Trust Company also states, "In the case of family foundations the founder may determine that creditors may not deprive foundation beneficiaries of acquired foundation benefits by means of injunction, levy of forced execution or bankruptcy proceedings." **********The director of Prasidial-Anstalt, who insisted on anonymity, said that in practice, the assets of a foundation should be impregnable to creditors if it was set up on a bona-fide basis at a time when the founder had no reason to expect bankrutpcy. **********"But if it was done at a moment when the settlor knew he was in danger of losing his money to creditors, the creditors may have a case in court," the director said. **********In the case of Mr. Maxwell, the foundation seems to predate his financial worries, though his swashbuckling style led to extreme highs and lows throughout his business career. The 'Liechtenstein Defense' **********Just why Mr. Maxwell chose to operate through Liechtenstein was something the late businessman never cared to discuss. But as a Czechoslovak-born Jewish immigrant, he was sensitive to claims from some British critics that his holdings showed he remained an outsider. Employing what became known as the "Liechtenstein defense," some directors of British companies that Mr. Maxwell had sought to take over successfully used gibes about the mysterious Liechtenstein connection to fend him off. **********There is evidence that in the last year of his life, Mr. Maxwell sought to overcome such criticism, perhaps in anticipation of floating some of Maxwell Communication's businesses in the United States. **********The last Maxwell Communication annual report states that control of the board of a subsidiary of the Liechtenstein-based Maxwell Foundation was passed to one of Mr. Maxwell's British holding companies, Headington Investments. As a result, the report said, Headington became Maxwell Communication's ultimate parent. **********But the holdings of the Liechtenstein entities apparently remained considerable to the last -- as underlined by the Coopers & Lybrand report to banks as well as by Mr. Maxwell's unusual decision to visit the principality this year. It seems that only if investigators can penetrate them will the truth about the Maxwell finances be known. **********To date, the Maxwell interests have been well protected. Because the economy of Liechtenstein relies heavily on its reputation as an impenetrable place for the wealthy to place their assets -- 2,500 of the country's 28,000 people work in trust companies or banks -- circumspection is a national trait. **********Indeed, when Mr. Maxwell made a rare and little-publicized visit here on April 24, the one local newspaper that covered the event did not even mention his Liechtenstein interests in a report that focused on how the "media Czar" had been charmed by the principality. Support for Share Price **********That April visit coincided with what Mr. Talbot of Arthur Andersen called a peak moment in Mr. Maxwell's attempts to support the price of shares in his Maxwell Communication public company that had been pledged to banks as collateral. The price-support plan, which is being investigated by Britain's Serious Fraud Office, was run through offshore investment trusts, which funneled more than $236 million into Maxwell Communication.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Flour Tax refund Will Improve Net
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.body_text: **********The Fluor Corporation said today that it will receive a Federal income tax refund, plus interest, that will add more than $12 million, or 14 cents a share, to second-quarter net income. The refund resolves a tax dispute between Fluor's St. Joe Minerals unit and the Internal Revenue Service for the tax years 1975 through 1981. **********Fluor said the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation had approved the refund, and the I.R.S. was computing the interest. Fluor stock lost 87.5 cents a share on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $47.125.
