https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Reebok Buyback Of Pentland Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/21/busin.body_text: **********Reebok International Ltd. will repurchase almost 24.5 million of its shares from the Pentland Group P.L.C. The purchase would reduce the British company's stake to about 13 percent from 31.6 percent. The move will also cut the number of Reebok stock outstanding to about 90 million from slightly more than 114 million. **********Reebok will pay Pentland more than $396.1 million, and the British concern will retain its two board seats. Kenneth R. Lightcap, Reebok's vice president of corporate communications, said there was no bad blood between the companies, but some analysts said Reebok was nervous about a possible hostile takeover last year. Reebok closed yesterday at $18.50, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/17/busin.main_headline: Wall Street; A Steinberg Extended Family Affair
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/17/busin.print_headline: Wall Street; A Steinberg Extended Family Affair
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/17/busin.body_text: **********In April 1988, Manhattan society watchers were agog over the lavish wedding of Laura S. Steinberg, the daughter of Saul Steinberg, who is chairman of Reliance Group Holdings, and Jonathan Tisch, president of Loews Hotels. Mr. Tisch is the son of Preston Robert Tisch, president of the Loews Corporation, and the nephew of Laurence A. Tisch, the chief executive of CBS. **********This was no match, it was a merger, the Wall Street wags said. At the couple's engagement party in 1987, a Tisch family member is said to have joked: "If they get married, it will have to be cleared by the S.E.C." **********The Securities and Exchange Commission really does have to clear the latest Steinberg-Tisch family project. Jonathan Steinberg, Saul's son and chairman of a publishing company called Financial Data Systems, is taking his company public. Brother-in-law Jonathan Tisch, a board member, and the elder Mr. Steinberg are helping out. **********Also assisting, although they may not know it yet, are the public shareholders of Reliance Group Holdings, which is 80-percent owned by the Steinberg family. This deal is so speculative it carries the underwriter's warning that "no person should consider investing in the securities offered hereby who cannot afford to lose his entire investment." Yet Reliance's insurance unit is investing $1 million in this risky venture. **********That $1 million investment of Reliance stockholders' money should be put into perspective. It is about half the amount the Steinbergs are estimated to have spent out of their own pockets on the 1988 nuptuals. But it is also one-fourth of the entire net profits of $4.1 million reported by Reliance Group Holdings in the first half of this year. **********Even those meager profits were wiped out in the third quarter. On Thursday, Reliance reported that a $103 million addition to its insurance reserves and a $63 million investment write-down had produced a loss of $161 million for the first nine months of this year. Past profits at the company have been erratic, bouncing from $126 million in 1987 to just $22 million in 1989 and then back to $118 million last year. **********Profits of any sort, erratic or not, have been elusive at Financial Data Systems, the company that young Mr. Steinberg is offering to the public. **********Mr. Steinberg, who is 26 years old, attended the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania and worked from 1986 to 1988 as a mergers and acquisition analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company before striking off on his own. He built the base for Financial Data System in October 1988 by purchasing the Penny Stock Journal, a small-stock investment newspaper. He changed the journal's name to Individual Investor -- a nameplate that has provoked some unresolved complaints from the American Association of Individual Investors, a nonprofit group in Chicago. In 1989, he added two specialty investment newsletters to the fold. **********But growth is expensive. While revenues were inching up, Financial Data lost $1.24 million in 1989, $1.19 million in 1990, and $247,852 in the first half of 1991. However, the preliminary prospectus filed with the S.E.C. blames some of the company's past weakness on its inability to spend money promoting its publications. With the $3.78 million from the public offering, Financial Data could boost advertising, increase its circulation, and possibly make some acquisitions. **********Indeed, the proceeds from the proposed offering are essential if the company is to simply keep itself afloat long enough to fulfill Mr. Steinberg's ambitions. He and his father have extended more than $1 million in loans to the company, and have guaranteed the company's borrowings from National Westminster Bank, whose chairman, Thomas J. Stanton Jr., is an outside director of Reliance Group. "It is unlikely that the company would be able to borrow additional funds" from the Steinbergs "or that they would be willing personally to guarantee the company's debt in the future," notes the meticulously candid prospectus. **********In fact, financial hardships forced the company to cancel the July issue of Individual Investor. Fortunately, Jonathan Tisch stepped up with an equity investment of $100,000 in August, the prospectus reports, and the company raised another $400,000 in September by selling a private note issue to a small group of investors, including Barbara Steinberg, the young Mr. Steinberg's mother. **********But family ties cannot erase all business considerations, of course. The September note issue will be fully repaid out of the public offering, and Jonathan Steinberg has personally promised to protect Mr. Tisch from any loss on his shares. According to the prospectus, Mr. Tisch can require his brother-in-law to repurchase his Financial Data shares anytime after Aug. 7, 1992, for a price equal to the $100,000 he originally paid plus $20,000 for each year he continues to hold the shares. **********That arrangement does not apply to the shares to be offered to the public or to Reliance. Financial Data plans to sell the public 360,000 units, each priced at $9 and each consisting of three common shares and two warrants to purchase additional shares in the future. Simultaneously, it will sell an additional 111,111 units at the same price to Reliance. After the offering, the Steinberg-Tisch clan and Reliance will own 67 percent of Financial Data. **********Brian T. Martin, a spokesman for Reliance Group Holdings, declined to comment on the investment "because it is currently in registration." He noted, however, that the stake "is $1 million by a company with $9 billion in assets in its portfolio." **********Whatever the stake means to Reliance, it was clearly a big plus for the little publishing house, according to its underwriter. "I'll tell you why we liked this deal," said Roger Gladstone, a principal of GKN Securities, in response to queries on Friday. "We like the fact that Reliance Insurance is putting in $1 million. It was comforting to me that they were investing at the same price as our shareholders."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/busin.main_headline: Disney Picks California Theme Park Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Disney Picks California Theme Park Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/13/busin.body_text: **********The Walt Disney Company said today that it had chosen a site adjacent to Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., for its next theme park, ending consideration of a competing site in Long Beach, Calif. **********Disney executives stopped short of guaranteeing that the project would be built. They said the company must still deal with a number of environmental, regulatory and economic issues related to building in an increasingly congested urban area. **********The company built Disneyland in Anaheim 36 years ago, when Orange County, south of Los Angeles, was largely strawberry fields and orange groves. The area is now heavily developed and choked with traffic. **********Today Disney executives seemed to be dangling the prospect of a huge influx of jobs and tax dollars into Southern California's battered economy if state and local governments would cooperate on plans for the $3 billion, 470-acre Anaheim project. **********The project, called the Disneyland Resort, would open at the end of the decade and would include a new theme park known as Westcot Center, as well as hotels, a huge lake and a shopping mall. **********If completed, Disney said, the new project would create nearly 28,000 new jobs, and would generate $55 million a year in additional taxes and fees for the city of Anaheim and Orange County, and $70 million a year in new tax revenue for the state. **********"We've never built a mega-project like this in an existing urban environment," said Peter Rummell, president of Disney Development, the subsidiary in charge of the project. "The economic feasibility of the project still has to be proven." **********Disney is now putting the final touches on Euro Disneyland, outside Paris, and it also operates Disney World in Florida. The company licenses its name to Tokyo Disneyland in Japan. **********The centerpiece of the new project is the Westcot Center, a complex inspired by the highly sucessful Epcot Center at Disney World. it would contain themed pavilions about foreign countries, the human body and other subjects. The project would also include an elaborate system of parking lots and people movers to cope with the traffic it would create. **********Disney has long been interested in a second theme park in Southern California. For the last several years, it has been openly considering both Long Beach and Anaheim. Some analysts said the company had been playing the two cities off against each other to get the best possible deal for itself and to minimize regualatory objections. **********In ruling out Long Beach today, the company said that the time and expense of winning the necessary approvals for that site made the project unfeasible. The Long Beach project would have been built partly on landfill along the city's harbor, and that plan raised questions among state and regional agencies about its effect on the harbor and the Pacific Ocean. Delighted and Excited **********Officials in Anaheim said they were optimistic the project would be built. "The City of Anaheim is delighted, excited and enthusiastic about the decision to build a second attraction here," Anaheim's City Manager, Jim Ruth, told The Associated Press. "We think we have arrived at a plan that is environmentally and economically sound." **********Still, Disney must make a final decision about the Anaheim project at a time when its theme parks are suffering from the economic downturn and a decline in tourism.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.main_headline: Little Room for Error In Chrysler's Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Little Room for Error In Chrysler's Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/07/busin.body_text: **********It has long been the case at the Chrysler Corporation that whenever auto sales turn sour, the margin for error becomes razor thin. **********So when reports emerged recently about serious defects in an automatic transmission that Chrysler has used in some of its most popular models, including its vaunted mini-vans, Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, put on the warning lights. Declaring that the problem could crush the company, he ordered an unusual campaign to cater to disgruntled owners and minimize any damage to the image of the No. 3 auto maker. An Unanswered Question **********Thursday morning, in a board meeting in New York, Chrsyler directors will hear that the worst of the transmission trouble is over. That will surely be welcome news for a company trying to shore up its balance sheet and peddle showrooms full of warmed-over models during a sales slump. But the question of how long Chrysler can last in such a treacherous market will probably not be answered at the meeting. **********Only a year ago, Mr. Iacocca said it would take a "nuclear war" for him to recommend a dividend cut; that war appears to be at hand. Financial analysts predict that a cut in the quarterly payout from 30 cents to as little as 5 cents a share is likely to be announced at the meeting because Chrysler is pressed for cash. The General Motors Corporation set a precedent for the Big Three auto makers earlier this year by halving its dividend. **********"I don't think Chrysler will omit the dividend altogether, since most state and local pension funds aren't allowed to own stocks that don't pay dividends," said Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. **********A dividend cut would represent little more than a prudent cost-cutting measure, since it would save the company only $67.5 million a quarter. But, like faulty transmissions, it is one more indication of how vulnerable Chrysler has become in a relatively short period since regaining its health in the mid-1980's. **********One reason that profit has been poor, automobile analysts say, is that Chrysler has not spent enough money on new vehicles in recent years; no new models will be ready until next year's introduction of a new Jeep and a new midsize car, code-named L/H. With few exciting products, expensive rebates have been necessary to support sales. **********Critics of the company say Chrysler wasted time and money in the mid-1980's on non-automotive projects like buying back $2 billion worth of stock and acquiring Gulfstream, an aircraft manufacturer. **********While Chrysler has been grappling with its transmission woes, it has also tried to shore up a weak balance sheet caused by two years of eroding profit margins. Executives are searching for a buyer for an equity stake in the Chrysler Financial Corporation subsidiary and are conferring with a consortium of 38 banks on new financing.   More Modest Credit Line **********Chrysler's bankers, led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, are busy redrawing the terms of a new, more modest credit line of about $1.7 billion to replace a $2.6 billion loan agreement. Under the proposed new loan, about $1 billion would be available to Chrysler and about $700 million to Chrysler's financial unit. With a smaller financial cushion, Chrysler will have to hope that the overall market turns quickly and that its new 1992 models are big hits. **********The recent lowering of the quality ratings on the debt of Chrysler and Chrysler Financial to "junk bond" status has precluded both units from borrowing in public debt markets. But Chrysler hopes that if it can sell a minority stake in Chrysler Financial to a stronger company, the rating agencies will upgrade Chrysler Financial's securities to investment-grade status, which will permit it to borrow from the public at favorable rates.  Much-Needed Capital **********A sale of an equity stake in the financial unit could also provide Chrysler with several hundred million dollars of capital at a time when it is pressed because of slow sales and heavy outlays for new vehicles. **********Financial analysts say they believe Chrysler has a list of more than a dozen financial-services companies it believes could be potential buyers. **********During the last week, Chrysler dealers have reported that telephone calls by company officials and other measures designed to satisfy customers have quieted consumer worries about the balky transmission, known as the A-604 Ultradrive. It is used in several car and mini-van models powered by Chrysler's 3.3-liter V-6 engine. **********Since Ultradrive first appeared in 1988, Chrysler has replaced 19,000 of the transmissions, many of which shifted permanently into second gear or had trouble shifting in cold weather. The company dealt with complaints case-by-case, rather than with a public recall. **********Late last year, after two years of technical changes, Chrysler declared that design and manufacturing problems with the 1991 Ultradrive were virtually nonexistent. But when Consumer Reports, the product-testing magazine, reviewed a 1991 New Yorker sedan, the transmission problem cropped up again. **********As a result, the magazine dropped its recommendation on Chrysler's new mini-van models on Jan. 24, since many of the vans are equipped with Ultradrives. Since half of Chrysler's 1991 operating profit may come from mini-vans, according to financial analysts, Mr. Iacocca warned dealers and company officials that the problem was a potential wildfire that threatened the company.  Help for Customers **********Frank De Joseph, service manager for Potamkin Chrysler-Plymouth in Miami, said that since late January, he had been flooded with suggestions from Chrysler about how to placate any customers who have transmission problems. **********"Anything they need, whether it's dropping the $100 deductible or renting them a car, the company's attitude is, 'Just do it,' " Mr. De Joseph said. In the last month, he said, only one service customer had inquired about Ultradrive. No one has brought an Ultradrive in for repair and few, if any, new-car customers tell the franchise's salespeople they are concerned, he said. **********Chrysler dealers all over the country who had repaired or replaced numerous Ultradrive's on 1989 and 1990 models are saying that the scare about the 1991's is over. Moreover, a Chrysler spokesman said 50,000 phone conversations with owners in recent weeks suggested that few, if any, had experienced transmission problems. Meeting With Testers **********Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's president, visited Consumer Reports engineers in Yonkers this week to deliver results of Chrysler's engineering research into transmission problems and explain why he thinks the current models are improved. Chrysler executives would not say what they had hoped to gain from the private meeting, but a spokesman said he presumed Mr. Lutz would ask Consumer Reports to consider restoring the recommendation on mini-vans. **********Another predicament that directors may have to face this year is executive succession. In the last 18 months, Chrysler has lost several key executives because of retirement and because some, disillusioned over the auto maker's long-term prospects, took other opportunities. Mr. Iacocca's heir apparent, Gerald Greenwald, left last summer to organize an employee buyout of United Airlines, which failed. **********Mr. Iacocca, who is 66 years old, has hinted at retirement and then changed his mind. Mr. Lutz and Robert S. Miller Jr., vice chairman, are likely candidates to succeed him. **********At one point, Mr. Iacocca was working under an employment contract until the end of 1991. But last September, the board changed that to an open-ended agreement and a spokesman said Mr. Iacocca was working on a quarter-to-quarter basis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Kramer, Author of Insurance Study; Comparing Risks: Banks vs. Insurers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Kramer, Author of Insurance Study; Comparing Risks: Banks vs. Insurers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/08/busin.body_text: **********The rising trend of insurance failures in the 1980's, coupled with the nationwide slump in commercial real estate, has led to increased concerns that insurers might be vulnerable to some of the same problems confronting the banking industry. **********A recent study commissioned by the Insurance Information Institute, "Rating the Risks, Assessing the Solvency Threat in the Financial Services Industry," concluded that the insurance industry's problems were not nearly so severe as those in banking. Orin S. Kramer, a consultant based in New York, discussed the study, which he wrote. **********Q. What are the problems shared by banks and insurance companies? **********A. Over the past two decades, each sector has experienced declining profitability, the loss of attractive customers to alternative markets, rising risk levels and increased insolvencies. Each of the sectors also suffers from excess capacity. But the similarities should not obscure the fact that there are sharp differences among individual institutions and between the sectors. **********Q. Banks are suffering mightily from problems with real estate loans. How much expo sure do insurers have in real estate? **********A. Real estate and mortgages represent only 3 percent of assets for property and casualty insurers and 22 percent for life companies. But at least relative to the banks, there are three factors that mitigate the life insurance real estate exposure. **********First, over the 1980's commercial real estate investment by insurers declined, whereas for banks it was the fastest-growing loan category. Consequently, most insurers have a more seasoned loan portfolio. Second, banks are more heavily involved at the riskier front end of the real estate financing process, making loans for construction and providing financing until long-term lenders are found. Nonperforming commercial real estate as a percentage of assets is more than 60 percent higher for banks than for insurers. **********Q. What are the other major risks for insurance companies? **********A. For the property and casualty sector, the major risks arise out of public policy. For example, there is the risk that the courts will impose significant environmental cleanup liability, the threat of more restrictive rate regulation and the absence of a Federal backup facility to handle a severe earthquake. **********Q. What about the life insurance companies? **********A. Beyond real estate, their higher-risk category of assets is "junk bonds," where there are a couple of companies that have excessive exposures and are now paying the price. But for the sector as a whole, non-investment-grade bonds represent under 4 percent of assets. A substantial share of those bonds are private placements, which have special covenants and tend to be well secured. **********Q. How did you compare the risks of industries as different as banking and insurance? **********A. Except under the most extreme scenarios, whatever solvency threat that may exist is limited to the weakest players. One test we did was to ask how long it would take for the bottom 20 percent of companies in each sector to exhaust their capital, assuming they continued to earn or lose money at the average 1987-89 rate. **********The bottom fifth of the property and casualty industry was profitable every year from 1987 to 1989. But the bottom fifth of the life industry had negative income in two of the three years and would exhaust its net worth in the year 2028 if those results continued. For banks, the losses in 1987-89 of the bottom fifth of the industry were great enough that they would exhaust their capital by the end of 1994. **********Q. Is a solvency crisis likely for any of the three industries you studied? **********A. It is important to distinguish between theoretical possibilities and realistic probabilities. While I can imagine conditions that might produce insolvency for a major insurance company, I think that is extremely improbable over the next several years, and a generalized insurance solvency crisis is even less likely. For the banking industry, there will clearly be enough trouble to require a replenishment of F.D.I.C. resources. **********Q. What should regulators be doing? **********A. If I had to cite a single theme, they should aim to preserve the stability of the financial system, not avoiding failures per se. The long-term health of the financial system requires that it be cleansed of excess capacity, and failures are part of the short-term price to be paid for a healthier system over the long term.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/25/busin.main_headline: Top Pay Listed At L.A. Gear
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/25/busin.print_headline: Top Pay Listed At L.A. Gear
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/25/busin.body_text: **********L.A. Gear Inc.'s two top executives earned $3.47 million and $2.54 million in the 1990 fiscal year while the company's profits fell 43 percent. **********The pay was disclosed last week in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. It followed word that L.A. Gear, the No. 3 sneaker maker, after Nike Inc. and Reebok International, expects a first-quarter loss for 1991 after a fourth- quarter deficit of $7.1 million. **********The company's chairman, Robert Y. Greenberg, was paid $500,000 in the quarter ended Feb. 28, but decided to work without pay beginning in the current quarter until L.A. Gear's losses end, said Kevin Ventrudo, the company's chief financial officer. **********Mr. Greenberg received $3.47 million in 1990, and the executive vice president, Sandy Saemann, made $2.54 million, according to the S.E.C. filing. **********They earned even more in 1989: $5.4 million and $5.3 million, respectively. Their bonuses, tied to the company's performance, fell in 1990.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.print_headline: RALLY ON WALL ST. GAINING STRENGTH; DOW SURGES 71.54
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/12/busin.body_text: **********The stock market caught fire yesterday, scoring strong new gains in heavy trading and rising to its highest level since just before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. **********Building on a 100-point advance last week, the nation's most widely followed market index, the Dow Jones industrial average, soared 71.54 points yesterday, or 2.5 percent, to a high for the year of 2,902.23. **********Stock prices were battered in the fall by a weak economy, soaring oil prices and the prospect of war, with the Dow hitting bottom on Oct. 11 at 2,365.10. But stocks took off in January when war became a reality, and they have barely looked back. The Dow has now risen more than 15 percent since the war began on Jan. 17 and has regained all the 534 points it lost in the months after the invasion.  A Sense of Optimism **********In addition to optimism on the war's outcome, the surge is a clear sign of confidence that recent moves by the Federal Reserve Board to bring interest rates down will pull the economy out of recession relatively soon and restore consumer confidence. **********The Dow is now less than 100 points away from its record high of 2,999.75, reached on both July 16 and 17, and one of Wall Street's most influential analysts expects further gains. **********"I still believe we're going to go higher," Steven G. Einhorn, co-chairman of the investment policy committee of Goldman, Sachs & Company, said yesterday. But he declined to predict how high the market would go. **********A week ago, Mr. Einhorn became one of the most important voices in the investment community to sound the beginning of a bull market by saying he thought the bear market was over. **********Almost every important market barometer climbed yesterday above the levels they had set before the Iraqi invasion. **********The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, representing the most important stocks, advanced nearly 2.6 percent to a new high for the year and is now less than a point away from the record high it set on July 16. The New York Stock Exchange composite index, covering roughly the same group of companies, rose 2.4 percent to a new 1991 high and is now also less than a point away from its July record. **********Allowing for the possibility of a decline, but still exceptionally enthusiastic about stocks, Mr. Einhorn said, "If on a short-term basis we may have gotten too far too fast, any correction should be small and there's still time and price left in the bull." **********Traders said Wall Street money managers, hoarding a huge pile of cash running into the billions of dollars, met over the weekend or early yesterday morning and decided to commit hundreds of millions of dollars to stocks over the next few days. **********With so much money pouring into the market, short-sellers were forced to rush in to avoid huge losses, and their buying, of course, drove stock prices still higher. Short-sellers borrow stock and hope to profit by replacing it later at a cheaper price, if the market drops. **********Acknowledging that there is skepticism about the advance, Mr. Einhorn said, "There's no bad news affecting the market, and slowly but surely it's forcing the money managers into the market." **********Based on figures compiled by Indata, an investment service in Stamford, Conn., 54 mutual funds it surveys pumped some $165 million into stocks in the week that ended Friday. On the strength of yesterday's strong advance, new money going into stocks now and in coming days should continue strong. **********To the casual investor, yesterday's picture of the rise in the Dow looked like the side of a mountain. At 10 A.M., the Dow was ahead 10 points, by 11 it was up 30 and by noon, 40 points. By 2:30 the market had climbed 55, momentarily fell back and then climbed sharply the rest of the day.  A Surge in Volume **********Trading volume, which had been a strong 187.8 million shares on Friday, soared to 265.4 million, the fifth-highest volume so far this year. **********Birinyi Associates said seven heavy waves of program buying lifted the Dow 28 points. **********To prevent the market from feeding on itself, the New York Stock Exchange intervenes whenever the Dow rises or falls 50 points or more. Officials of the exchange intervened at 2:09 P.M. yesterday, preventing program buyers from buying on an uptick, that is, from buying when the last sale was at a price higher than the previous one. Program buying generally subsides after such intervention. **********And in the credit markets, interest rates kept sliding yesterday, with long-term rates now at their lowest levels in more than a year. **********The New York Stock Exchange said 4.4 stocks advanced for every one that fell, the highest ratio since the war started. **********While not setting records, 162 stocks reached highs for 1991, from I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson and A.I.G., the insurer, to Merrill Lynch, Gillette and International Flavors and Fragrances. **********I.B.M.'s shares, which are recognized leaders of Wall Street thinking, climbed to a new high for the year of 132 1/2, closing at 132 3/8, up 2 7/8. Johnson & Johnson, just one of several drug stocks to score new highs, rose 2 5/8, to 79 7/8, a new 1991 record. A.I.G., one of several insurance stocks to hit new highs, jumped 2 5/8, to a new high of 90. **********Merrill Lynch, the investment house, which is expected to reap big benefits from the market rally, climbed 2 1/2, to 29 1/4, after hitting a new high of 29 1/2. Gillette, the razor-blade maker, hit a new high of 70, before ending at 69 3/4, up 2 3/8. International Flavors, responding to a strong year, jumped 4 3/4, to a new high of 86 1/2. **********Mr. Einhorn of Goldman, Sachs said he was committed to growth stocks, like drugs, tobacco, specialty retail companies, technology, household products, personal-care products and food, and was urging the sale of cyclical stocks, like chemicals, paper and some metals. **********As to whether the upturn in cyclical stocks would last much longer, he said, "I don't think it will." He urged investors to "use the relative strength of the cyclicals to move away from them and buy growth stocks." **********With the market so strong, it was difficult to find a segment that did not move higher. But gold prices slid $3 an ounce, to $367.10, in New York, depressing gold shares. Newmont Gold dropped 1 5/8, to 35 1/2.  Strength in Transportation **********Even though crude oil prices were up 55 cents a barrel, to $22.50, raising the possibility of higher fuel prices, the Dow transportation index nevertheless jumped 2.3 percent, lifted by strong gains for AMR, the parent of American Airlines; Delta Air Lines and Federal Express. **********In an impressive rally, 27 of the 30 Dow industrials moved higher, with Minnesota Mining ahead 3 1/4, to 90 5/8, and Alcoa ahead 3 1/8, to 68 3/8. Gains of two or more points were scored by I.B.M., Merck, Procter & Gamble and Philip Morris. Others climbing at least a point were Woolworth, Westinghouse, Sears, Eastman Kodak, International Paper, Coca-Cola, Exxon, McDonald's, American Express, Du Pont, General Electric, United Technologies, Primerica and Texaco. **********The three Dow stocks to decline were General Motors, which cut its dividend last week, and fell 3/8, to 36 7/8; Boeing off 5/8, to 51 3/8, and Allied-Signal, down 1/8, to 30. **********Reflecting the exceptional rise in bank stocks, the New York Stock Exchange's financial index jumped 3.02 percent. Wells Fargo rose 3 1/2, to 74 3/4, and Barnett Banks of Florida climbed 2 3/8, to 26.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/busin.main_headline: A Defeated Republican Will Be S.B.A. Director
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A Defeated Republican Will Be S.B.A. Director
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/busin.body_text: **********Patricia Saiki, a Republican who lost a close race to Senator Daniel K. Akaka of Hawaii in the fall, has been nominated as the director of the Small Business Administration. **********The position was left vacant by the resignation of Susan S. Engeleiter, a Republican who got the post after losing a close race to Senator Herbert H. Kohl of Wisconsin in 1988. **********Ms. Saiki, 60, served in Congress for 4 years and spent 14 years in the Hawaii Legislature. She had been mentioned as a candidate for Secretary of Education when Lauro F. Cavazos resigned in December, but that post went to Lamar Alexander, former Tennessee Governor. **********Also mentioned for the education post was former Representative Lynn Martin of Illinois, another Bush loyalist who lost an election. The 50-year-old Ms. Martin, who lost to Senator Paul Simon, went on to become Labor Secretary. **********The S.B.A. has often been in hot water and the subject of complaints by minorities. In 1988, Congress revised some of the agency's rules to curb abuses by "front" companies, like the Wedtech Corporation, that resorted to illegalities to keep their status as minority companies eligible for no-bid contracts. **********Ms. Saiki, whose nomination is subject to Senate approval, said in a statement that her selection was an honor. "Small business is the backbone of the American economy," she said, "creating two out of every three new jobs and producing 40 percent of the gross national product. **********She added that "in my home state of Hawaii over 90 percent of the businesses are small businesses." **********Ms. Saiki has also had experience in Hawaiian big business. She served on the board of Hawaiian Airlines for 13 years and on the board of Amfac Inc., Hawaii's largest private landowner, for 14 years. **********During her Congressional terms, from 1986 to 1990, Ms. Saiki was a member of the Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee. She was listed as the committee member who received the most money from finance-related political action committees during the months before the 1990 elecions. From January 1989 through November 1990, she received $194,692 from finance-related political action committees, or 20 percent of the total she received from such committees in that period. **********Ms. Saiki, a Hilo native, taught in junior and senior high schools for 12 years before entering politics. She now lives in Alexandria, Va. She is married and has five children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/08/world.main_headline: History's Refraction Illuminates 2 Views Of a Date of Infamy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/08/world.print_headline: PEARL HARBOR REMEMBERED; History's Refraction Illuminates 2 Views Of a Date of Infamy
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/08/world.body_text: **********On Japan's airwaves this week, the battleship Arizona has sunk a dozen times, the aging Zero pilots have been interviewed so many times that dedicated viewers know their exploits by heart, and a stream of commentators have talked -- and talked, and talked -- about how the United States and Japan must seize this weekend to reaffirm the most critical alliance linking East and West. **********But in subtle and telling ways, the images and explanations being offered here and in the United States to explain how two great powers came to battle each other are strikingly different. **********For many Japanese, this has been a long week of trying, once again, to find comfort in a carefully sculpted interpretation of history that overarches the country's memories of the war. In dramas and documentaries, the Japanese have watched this week as their fathers and mothers made a futile effort to steer the country away from war, as a small group of military leaders drove a peaceful people to ruin, and as their country rose from its defeat to be as technologically powerful as the nation to whom it eventually surrendered. **********Perhaps the clearest cleavage of interpretations came in the studios of NHK, the giant semiofficial broadcaster, which struggled for months with producers from ABC over a documentary that was aired this week in both countries. Although American and Japanese viewers saw nearly identical film, they heard very different scripts, and they were differences that went beyond the imprecision of translations. 2 Views of Rape of Nanking **********In an 18-second clip about Japan's 1937 capture of Nanking, the then capital of China, ABC reported that "Japan's claim it was liberating China was ludicrous to Americans, particularly when hundreds of thousands of Chinese men, women and babies were murdered in what was called the Rape of Nanking. The U.S. sent China $50 million in war relief." **********But in Japan, where the Rape of Nanking is not mentioned in textbooks and the country's right wing contends that the incident was a fabrication, viewers heard nothing about war atrocities. **********Though NHK's version of the documentary showed vivid footage of Chinese being shot in a ditch, the voice-over said simply, "In a totalitarian attempt to grab land and wealth, the Japanese military had led the country into an eight-year war in Manchuria and China," an invasion that caused tension with the United States. **********At a luncheon with foreign correspondents on Friday, Mikio Kawaguchi, the chairman of NHK, said there had been no effort to rewrite history for a Japanese audience, simply an attempt to explain things differently to American and Japanese viewers, who "have a different way of looking at history and life." **********"Even though both sides were sincere in their efforts, the methods they wanted to employ to portray what they saw as truth were different," Mr. Kawaguchi said of his company's joint venture with the American network. "There were perception gaps. The two sides had such disagreements that they feared they might be headed into a second Pearl Harbor." A Weeklong History Lesson **********Without question, Japan learned a lot of history this week. Many young people said that until the flurry of programs, they had not been certain why Pearl Harbor prompted such strong emotions in America. At the same time, the tone of much of the coverage paralleled the tone of the little that is taught about the war in schools: Japan was more a victim than an aggressor. **********Several broadcasts explored the internment of Japanese-Americans in the United States. Several reported arguments that President Roosevelt had known about the attack in advance and done nothing to stop it. Others found a simple answer for Japan's ultimate defeat: The country was simply outproduced by the United States. A lengthy program today, "The Secret Story of the War Over Steel," showed how the giant American steelmakers that provided the hardware for Japan's defeat later fell to Japanese competition. **********Japanese television warmed to another popular theme here: that the Japanese military, rather than the Japanese people or even political leaders, was solely responsible for plunging the nation into war. **********On Friday night, for example, viewers tuned into a vivid drama called "Defeat in Showa 16," a title suggesting that Japan lost the war as soon as it began in 1941. The Japanese calendar begins anew with the ascension of each new emperor, and 1941 was the 16th year of the Showa era, Emperor Hirohito's reign. Shouting at the War Institute **********Based on fact, the drama was the story of a railway executive, a bureaucrat and other Japanese who were drafted into the Government's "Total War Research Institute." The institute was charged with determining what would happen if the country gave everything -- from its steel works to its samurai spirit -- to the cause of "liberating" the country from encirclement by Dutch, British and American colonialists. **********In the show, the young men of the institute concluded that the Government's war plans were madness. There were frequent shouting matches with the military brass, but the young men's voices were drowned out. Many historians and older Japanese say that the spirit of such dramas is accurate. **********"Everyone knew that relations were at a critical position, even though there was no indication war would be coming so soon," said Junnosuke Ofusa, who joined The New York Times bureau in Tokyo in 1930 and helped guide the newspaper's coverage of Japan for the next five decades. Mr. Ofusa, who retired several years ago, said that "no one said outwardly that it was a bad idea, because the military police were everywhere. But the Japanese people knew there was little chance of winning the war." **********At the same time, some Japanese bridle at placing all of the blame on the military, because the argument is often used to absolve the rest of the country. **********"Of course the military had much of the power," Seiki Nishihiro, a former Deputy Defense Minister, said the other day, discussing the coverage of the anniversary. "But the mass media and everyone else followed, so not only the military was responsible." **********Bubbling just beneath the surface of the coverage was the question of whether, and how, Japan should apologize for the Pearl Harbor attack. **********Government spokesmen, who have spent much of the last year fretting about the anniversary celebrations, were openly distraught. While they were issuing statements of "regret" or "remorse" or "self-reflection" -- a great deal of time was spent trying to figure out which word best described Japan's position -- Parliament was going in the other direction, scuttling any parliamentary apology altogether. **********"Why should we fling mud at the history of Japan?" Masayuki Fujio, a senior politician, asked the other day, in a remark that was quoted in the Japanese news media throughout the weekend. **********But the week was so painful that this country, which planned no formal events to commemorate Pearl Harbor, seems eager to have the anniversary behind it. "In a sense it is a kind of Pearl Harbor week anyway," said a weary-looking Taizo Watanabe, the Foreign Ministry's chief spokesman. "So many questions asked, so many answers and apologies from us." **********With one more apology on early Sunday morning here, after President Bush's address at Pearl Harbor, the Japanese hope it will be all over, so they can go back to topics that are easier to discuss. **********"Ask me about anything else," a senior Government official said the other day. "Ask me why the trade deficit is getting bigger again. Ask me about why we are so slow to open the rice market. Just don't ask me about Pearl Harbor."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/busin.main_headline: Japan's Top Securities Firms Report a Big Drop in Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/busin.print_headline: Japan's Top Securities Firms Report a Big Drop in Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Japan's major securities houses today reported their worst earnings in years, reflecting last year's stock market crash and a near-cessation in new issues of securities. **********The so-called Big Four -- Nomura, Daiwa, Nikko and Yamaichi Securities -- reported declines in net income ranging from 52 percent to 67 percent. Smaller firms, which had been attempting to narrow the gap between themselves and the giants that control the markets here, suffered an even more severe drop in profits -- in many instances more than 90 percent. **********It was a humbling conclusion to a year that the giant brokerage houses had entered with aspirations of becoming the dominant global players in all the major financial markets.  Numbers Are 'Quite Miserable' **********"Generally, these numbers were a little better than expected because of some improvement in the fourth quarter," said Vera Sinn, an analyst with Baring Securities. "But over all they're really quite miserable." **********And Alicia Ogawa, an analyst with S. G. Warburg Securities, said, "The big question is the next year." **********Analysts were cautious about prospects for the current fiscal year. The markets have stabilized, with the closely watched Nikkei index up nearly 30 percent from its low point of last fall, and the underwriting business is slowly picking up. Analysts said they expected profits to rebound about 20 percent to 30 percent this year, leaving them far below the level in 1989.  Declines Expose Dependency **********What the declines exposed is how dependent the major securities houses remain on a strong stock market and brisk trading volume, despite their efforts to diversify. **********Nomura Securities, the world's largest brokerage house, reported a 51.8 percent decline in net income, to $769.9 million, at current exchange rates, for the fiscal year ended on March 31, from $1.6 billion in the previous year. Nomura's revenues tumbled 30 percent, to $5 billion, and most of the decline came from a steep slide in commissions. **********Daiwa Securities' net income plunged 59.3 percent, to $434.4 million, down from about $1.07 billion. Revenues slid 28 percent, to $3.5 billion. **********Nikko Securities suffered a 67 percent drop in profits, to $289.5 million, from $877 million, while revenues fell 37 percent, to $2.75 billion. **********Yamaichi Securities' net income declined 60.6 percent, to $282 million, from $715.7 million. Revenues fell 37 percent, to $2.63 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; Retailing's Modest Napoleon
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; Retailing's Modest Napoleon
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/busin.body_text: **********To command its first foray into the competitive and economically battered New York City retail scene, Galeries Lafayette chose a self-effacing general. **********"I'm a suburban mom," said Eugenia Ulasewicz, president of the United States subsidiary of the French department store chain, which opened its first American store yesterday in Trump Tower. **********She is also, those who know her say, a savvy merchant who proved her mettle during a 15-year tenure at one of the most sophisticated retail operations in America, Bloomingdale's. **********At 38, Ms. Ulasewicz is younger than most who are in command of a major store. But Georges Meyer, Galeries Lafayette's chairman, chief executive and chief visionary, said the active approach she had taken while running four Bloomingdale's stores with $225 million in sales more than outweighed her youth. "You know, Napoleon was in his 30's when he became an emperor," he said. **********Ms. Ulasewicz also had experience renovating the Bloomingdale's store in White Plains, which came in handy as extensive changes were made in the former Bonwit Teller space that became Galeries Lafayette's first American home. **********"I was trained by the best, Marvin Traub, so I was able to have a certain amount of composure about this," she said, paying tribute to the departing head of Bloomingdale's. "If I could run four stores, there is no reason I can't run this one." **********A native of New Jersey who now lives in Connecticut, Ms. Ulasewicz did not speak French when she found herself on an airplane to Paris to meet Galeries Lafayette executives last year. But she is being tutored and her son, Dennis, who is 5, is also taking French in school. "I'll probably be learning from him pretty soon," she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/world.main_headline: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwait; Palestinians in Kuwait Face Suspicion and Probable Exile
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR: Kuwait; Palestinians in Kuwait Face Suspicion and Probable Exile
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/world.body_text: **********Saleh Ismail stood trembling in front of the Kuwaiti security officer who had him brought up from a basement. **********The 48-year-old Mr. Ismail is one of an unknown number of Palestinians being arrested here daily as Kuwaitis turn in those they accuse of informing on members of the Kuwaiti underground and spying for the Iraqi troops who occupied their country. **********In the presence of the officer, Mr. Ismail acknowledged that he had told the Iraqis, under threat of torture, of two Kuwaitis whom he knew to be underground members.  Palestinian's Fate in Question **********"What we do with him depends on whether we find these two Kuwaitis," said the Kuwaiti officer, First Lieut. Tariq al-Amiri. "If they are dead or have disappeared, we will send him to the General Command headquarters, where those accused of war crimes are held." **********In the last two weeks, life for the estimated 150,000 Palestinians who remain in Kuwait, out of about 450,000 who once lived here, has become fearful and uncertain. Kuwaitis say the anger against Palestinians is such that there is little chance most of those who left during the seven-month occupation can ever come back to live here again and relatively few of those remaining will be able to stay. **********Palestinians and other foreigners forced to leave Kuwait have said that they had been tortured by the Kuwaiti authorities while detained under suspicion of collaboration. The Washington Post today quoted three former detainees, among hundreds expelled by Kuwaiti troops at the Iraqi border in recent days, as saying that they had been beaten and tortured. A Rumor Mill **********None of the Palestinians interviewed here made such statements, though reports and rumors of abuses have proliferated in Kuwait's chaotic postwar atmosphere. **********While many Palestinians are said to have collaborated with the Iraqis, many others are said to have protected their Kuwaiti neighbors and expressed strong hostility toward the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, for his support of Iraq throughout the gulf crisis. Nevertheless, the outlook for Palestinians seems dim. **********"If I were a Palestinian, I wouldn't want to be here," said a senior Cabinet minister, a member of the ruling Sabah family, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "We will protect them. We will give them their due. But they will be pushed out because life will unquestionably become difficult for them." **********Ordinary Kuwaiti citizens are, by and large, hostile to the Palestinians and far less restrained in their comments about what should be done with them. **********"The only Palestinians who can stay here are the ones that are absolutely necessary, and only for a few years, not forever," said Abdelaziz Abu Abbas, a retired official of the Defense Ministry. "I think we should abolish this business of permanent residence for Palestinians. When all is said and done, I do not think more than 30,000 Palestinians should live in Kuwait, and they should be the ones that proved to be absolutely faithful to Kuwait throughout the occupation." **********That, a European ambassador said, is easier said than done. Shopkeepers and Bureaucrats **********Palestinians once were a vital element of Kuwait's economy, running many of the small shops and service industries owned by Kuwaiti citizens and also filling the need for doctors, engineers and aides in Government ministries. Of the estimated two million people in Kuwait before the Iraqi invasion, only about 700,000 were native Kuwaitis and most of the rest were expatriates. Of these foreigners, the Palestinians constituted the largest and most skilled group. **********"The reason things are going very slowly now is that when a Kuwaiti minister pushes the button on his desk, the Palestinian aide is not there to respond," the European ambassador remarked. "It is not easy to operate the first floor when the ground floor is missing." **********Kuwaitis say Palestinians leaving the country will be able to move to Jordan, since most Palestinians who live here carry Jordanian passports. Such emigration would likely add to Palestinian nationalist passions and to unemployment in Jordan, where the Palestinians already make up 55 to 60 percent of the population. **********At the Jabiriya police station Mr. Ismail on Tuesday denied having been mistreated, and he bore no signs of physical abuse, nor did three other detained Palestinians who were observed there today.  Telltale Register **********Mr. Ismail's fate was sealed the day after the Iraqis were driven from Kuwait. Lieutenant Amiri, who was himself a member of the Kuwaiti underground, found a register left behind by Iraqi security officials who had used the station as a headquarters. In the register, an Iraqi intelligence officer identified as Said al-Ito jotted down testimony given by Mr. Ismail on Sept. 17, a month and a half into the occupation. **********In that testimony, which Mr. Ismail acknowledges to be true, the Palestinian identified two Kuwaitis who were clients of his mechanic's shop as members of the underground. **********"Sir, I was forced to tell by the Iraqis, after they threatened to pull out my nails," Mr. Ismail said. He was interrupted by Lieutenant Amiri, who said the Palestinian was "fraternizing" with the Iraqis for months, received liquor from them, and that he was found living with an Iraqi woman when the police went to get him at his apartment. **********"Isn't that true?" Lieutenant Amiri asked Mr. Ismail. The Palestinian lowered his gaze and murmured that he was sorry. Then he stood silently against a wall smeared with traces of blood from people who Lieutenant Amiri said were Kuwaiti victims of Iraqi torture in the stationhouse. Iraqi Torture Device **********Next, Lieutenant Amiri opened his drawer and pulled out an electrical cord that looked somewhat like a stethoscope -- except that it had stripped wires to be placed in the ears, and a plug on the other end to go into a wall socket. **********"This is what the Iraqis used on Kuwaitis denounced by Palestinians like this guy," the lieutenant said, pointing to Mr. Ismail, who appeared to melt into the wall he was leaning against. **********A few miles away, in a largely Palestinian neighborhood called Al Hawali, Yosra, a 39-year-old Palestinian woman, sat in her living room telling of her anxiety about possibly having to leave Kuwait. She recalled that this is the country where she has lived since she was 13, where she married a Palestinian man who works at Kuwait University, and where her 16- and 20-year-old daughters were born and raised. **********She gazed at her best frind, Soheila, a Kuwaiti woman, and said she was deeply troubled by what had happened on Tuesday at a checkpoint when the two of them ventured out. Riding in the Kuwaiti woman's car, the two women, who spoke on condition that their family names be withheld, were stopped by a Kuwaiti Army officer, who asked for their identification papers. Bad for Everyone? **********"The officer told Soheila, 'You shouldn't ride with this woman,' when he saw that I had a Jordanian identity paper," the Palestinian woman recalled. "Today I heard at supermarkets they gave food to the Kuwaitis, but told Palestinians with Jordanian identity cards to return tomorrow. It's getting very bad in here." **********Her Kuwaiti friend interrupted, saying that the officer at the checkpoint was joking. She added that the supermarkets had little food for anyone. **********"You are exaggerating, Yosra, as you always do," the Kuwaiti woman said. "The country is in a mess -- that's all." **********While the attitude toward the Palestinians is overwhelmingly hostile, Kuwaiti officials dispute a P.L.O. assertion that they have arrested about 6,000 Palestinians since the occupation of Kuwait ended on Feb. 26. And they say that they will do their best to protect those who are still here. But even senior Kuwaiti officials do not disguise their antipathy toward Palestinians and the P.L.O. Reduced Role in the Future **********"We are not interested in the present leadership of the P.L.O., which has lost sight of the Palestinian cause," said Suleiman al-Mutawa, Kuwait's Planning Minister, in a conversation the other day. **********"I think we will need some Palestinians, but they will have to be those who have not abused Kuwaiti hospitality," Mr. Mutawa said, "and clearly, from now on, only Kuwaitis will occupy key positions in the country's businesses and Government offices. I recognize that in order to accomplish all this in a civilized fashion, we must restrain the popular sentiments about Palestinians, which are quite hostile. We will need wisdom, firmness and understanding." **********Many Kuwaitis say that despite many instances of Palestinian collaboration with the Iraqis, other Palestinians performed heroic deeds to protect them. **********For instance, everyone here concedes that the director of the P.L.O. office in Kuwait, Auni Batash, issued false Palestinian and Jordanian identification cards to Kuwaiti Army officers to protect them from the Iraqis, until Iraqi officers ordered Mr. Batash to leave the country for Jordan. Perils of Generalization **********"The picture is mixed," said Adel Qabazad, a Kuwaiti engineer who participated in the discussion in the house of the Palestinian woman, Yosra. "What is happening to the Palestinians at checkpoints used to happen to Kuwaitis, but many Palestinians proved to be more than good neighbors. They brought us food when we could not get out and they protected us. Others were traitors and collaborators. You can't generalize."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.main_headline: Todd Shipyards Is Sued by Holders
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Todd Shipyards Is Sued by Holders
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/27/busin.body_text: **********The Todd Shipyards Corporation said Burton Borman, the leader of a group of dissident shareholders, filed suit against the company and its directors in Delaware Chancery Court in Wilmington. The suit seeks reinstatement of July 10 as the record date for a special shareholders' meeting and convening of the meeting within 60 days of that date, the company said. The special meeting, which had been set for Aug. 15, was canceled by the company on Thursday. **********Mr. Borman's group controls 5.1 percent of Todd's common shares and is seeking control of the company. It told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it planned to solicit proxies for representation on the company's board. Its slate of nominees included Mr. Borman and four other members of the group, including the retired Adm. Elmo Zumwalt Jr. The company's shares rose 12.5 cents, to $5.75, on the New York Stock Exchange today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/16/busin.main_headline: Mutual Funds; Report Card Time for Morris Smith
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/16/busin.print_headline: Mutual Funds; Report Card Time for Morris Smith
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/16/busin.body_text: **********When stewardship of the $16 billion Fidelity Magellan Fund, the nation's largest stock fund, changed hands last year -- going to Morris Smith after the retirement of the acclaimed stock picker Peter Lynch -- most fund experts advised investors to sit tight. Mr. Smith had built a solid track record managing Fidelity's Over-the-Counter Fund, they noted, so it made sense to give him a chance with Magellan. **********One year later, the question posed to a half-dozen experts is: What now for Magellan? Buy, sell or hold? The experts are split. **********Mr. Smith took the helm on June 1, 1990, and Magellan dropped 8.1 percent in the next six months, finishing 1990 down 4.5 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc., which tracks mutual funds. It was the first year the fund had lost money since 1974, before Mr. Lynch's tenure. But the showing was still better than a 5 percent drop in the Lipper Growth Fund Index for the year. **********And after one full year on the job, Mr. Smith has steered Magellan to a return of 17.2 percent, compared with a jump of 11.7 percent in the Lipper index for the year that ended on May 31. Since the beginning of 1991, Magellan has risen 26.7 percent, compared with 21.4 percent for the index. **********Jack Bowers, editor of Fidelity Monitor, an investment newsletter based in Rocklin, Calif., said Mr. Smith "is off to a great start in continuing the Magellan legend." **********Mr. Bowers rates the fund a "solid buy," but he -- like nearly everyone else who recommends Magellan -- says there are limits to how well such a large fund can perform. **********Even under Peter Lynch, the amount by which Magellan beat the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell as the fund's assets grew. In each of the last four years of Mr. Lynch's stewardship, Magellan beat the S.& P. 500 by no more than 6 percentage points. That is a respectable showing, but a far cry from his 15- and 20-point spreads in earlier years, when the fund was easier to maneuver. **********Theory has it that a large fund has so much money that a great deal is left over after buying the manager's favorite small stocks. As a result, the fund must hold a large chunk of blue-chip stocks, and this causes it to track the broad market more closely. **********John Rekenthaler, senior analyst at Morningstar Inc., the Chicago-based mutual fund consultants, concludes, "If you're looking for a fund that has a good chance to perform roughly like the broad market, perhaps a couple of percentage points better, Magellan is clearly a solid core holding." **********But Sheldon Jacobs, editor of the No-Load Fund Investor, in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., says it is time to switch out of Magellan. Mr. Jacobs compared its performance with 14 other Fidelity aggressive growth and growth funds. In all cases, he concluded that Magellan's performance had been average. **********Both Mr. Jacobs and Mr. Bowers say that for investors who want growth and are willing to accept slightly more risk, there are better choices. They recommend Fidelity's Contrafund, Emerging Growth, Stock Selector and Growth Company funds instead. **********One caveat: Investors who have large unrealized gains in Magellan must pay taxes on their gains if they sell, Mr. Jacobs warns. Unless there are offsetting investment losses elsewhere, it may not pay to switch. **********Investors in search of higher growth probably should look elsewhere, but they should also take into account the 3 percent front-end sales charge that they paid when they bought their shares, says Eric M. Kobren, editor of Fidelity Insight, a Wellesley, Mass., investment newsletter. After paying a sales load to buy a Fidelity fund, investors can switch into another Fidelity fund without paying another sales charge. So investors leaving Magellan can minimize their costs by buying shares in another Fidelity fund or by parking the money in a Fidelity money market fund, he said. **********Norman G. Fosback, editor of the Fund Forecaster in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., strongly recommends Magellan on the basis of past performance. "We haven't noticed any significant change in volatility or relative performance since Peter Lynch left," he said. **********But Robin L. Carpenter, director of the Economics Office, a Cambridge, Mass., concern that analyzes money manager performance, says Mr. Lynch and Mr. Smith differ significantly in management styles. **********For one, he says, the fund's beta has risen from an average of 0.86 under Mr. Lynch to 0.97. Beta measures a fund's volatility compared with movements in the S.& P. 500-stock index. A fund with a beta of 1.0 rises or declines at the same rate as the S.& P. 500. A fund with a beta of 1.5 moves up 15 percent for every 10 percent rise in the S.& P. or down 15 percent when the S.& P. drops 10 percent. The change in Magellan's beta suggests that while the fund is still not subject to violent swings, it is a bit more volatile under Mr. Smith than under Mr. Lynch. **********While the difference is small, it is statistically significant, Mr. Carpenter says. He also points to the fact that Magellan's beta has actually been greater than 1.0 for the last three months, the longest stretch in the last five years. This higher level has paid off so far, because the stock market has been strong. Of course, it could hurt in periods of market declines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/world.body_text: **********Andre Cools, a leading politician in the French-speaking eastern part of Belgium, was shot dead today on a street in Liege. **********Mr. Cools, 64 years old, had been a Deputy Prime Minister of Belgium and chairman of the French-language part of the Socialist Party. He was a leader in the group of politicians who emerged in Wallonia, the French-speaking part of Belgium, after World War II. **********Mr. Cools was killed as he walked with a woman from an apartment building to his car at 7:45 A.M. The police said a gunman, described as in his 20's and wearing jeans, fired at least four times and fled. The woman, who was wounded in the attack, was identified as Marie-Helene Joiret, 31 years old, a Socialist City Council member in Flemalle, where Mr. Cools was Mayor. The woman also headed a government-financed center for contemporary art. **********Without elaborating, the Liege judicial police said they were working on the assumption that the killing was a "personal matter," although possible political motives were not ruled out. **********Mr. Cools, the son of a miner and trade-union activist, rose to prominence in the 1950's when Socialists eroded Catholic power in Wallonia. He had been a member of the national Chamber of Deputies, the lower house of congress, since 1958 and had headed the French-language Socialist Party from 1973 to 1981. He retired from ministerial functions a year ago but remained a local power in Wallonia. **********His party was involved in a scandal in Liege last year when the Mayor was accused of taking bribes from a parking-meter company and resigned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Warner-Lambert Meets With F.D.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/28/busin.body_text: **********The Warner-Lambert Company met with officials from the Food and Drug Administration to discuss Cognex, its Alzheimer's drug. The F.D.A. refused to approve the drug last week and called for new tests to determine its safety. **********According to Warner-Lambert, F.D.A. officials said at the meeting that the agency would continue its review based upon new analyses of already-completed studies. **********Warner-Lambert said it would submit data from its studies on Monday and that it expected to meet again with the agency in mid-April in an effort to attain approval without further studies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; GTE and Contel Merger Advances
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/19/busin.body_text: **********A merger of the GTE Corporation and the Contel Corporation has been approved by the United States Department of Justice and 11 of 18 state regulatory agencies, the companies said. The companies said they were confident they would receive the remaining state approvals as well as a needed approval from the Federal Communications Commission. The merger was announced last July and was approved overwhelmingly by shareholders of both companies in December.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/busin.main_headline: Proposal Has Supporters, But Many Raise Objections
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/busin.print_headline: Proposal Has Supporters, But Many Raise Objections
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/busin.body_text: **********The Treasury's proposal to overhaul the banking system was applauded yesterday by executives of some of the nation's largest banks, but it provoked objections from competing financial companies and from smaller banks. **********Although the latest Treasury suggestions have the backing of the President, bankers remain cautious because many earlier efforts to change the banking laws have failed. A key issue in the minds of many bankers is whether heavy losses in the federally guaranteed deposit insurance program will be seen as a reason to control banks more tightly rather than grant them the power to enter new businesses. **********"If we bankers are going to bear the burden of financing Federal deposit insurance, it is important that we get some quid pro quo in the form of changes in regulations that allow us to compete in the modern world," said John Rau, president of LaSalle National Bank in Chicago. "I'm worried that the people in Congress will want us to shoulder the losses of the F.D.I.C. but then say it is too risky to let banks broaden their activities."  'Sound, Sensible Package' **********Richard L. Huber, vice chairman of the Continental Bank Corporation in Chicago, said, "The Treasury has presented a sound, sensible package, but I would not bet a great deal of my personal money on it becoming law." **********Patrick Forte, director of the Association of Financial Services Holding Companies, a group that represents large banking and other financial companies, was more optimistic about prospects for the plan. "Legislators in Washington are not particularly proud of the mess we are in," he said, "and I think this package will become law." **********He said the most likely amendments would preserve more of the regulatory powers of state authorities and reduce the Treasury's oversight of banks. **********Many Treasury proposals, like allowing a full range of securities sales and trading, conveying more power to sell insurance products, and developing a nationwide network of branches, have long been strongly backed by large banks. The chairmen of Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan all issued statements yesterday supporting the proposals. 2 Groups Speak Up **********But among smaller banks, and at firms whose businesses would become more open to competition from banks, the Treasury proposal was criticized. The small banks that make up the Independent Bankers Association of America, for example, do not like the idea of allowing nationwide branches. And the Securities Industry Association, which represents Wall Street firms, again warned that bank activities financed with insured deposits should be kept separate from securities trading. **********Some of the strongest complaints of bankers concerned a proposal to limit a customer's insured deposits at a single bank to $100,000 for ordinary accounts and to $100,000 for an Individual Retirement Account. **********Thomas E. Hales, chief executive of the Union State Bank in Nanuet, N.Y., warned that the proposal "is going to kill the small banks." "Even before this gets to Congress," he said, large depositors at small banks will begin shifting funds to Treasury securities or to larger banks, "which will still be perceived as too big to fail." **********Jeffrey Gerhart, president of the First National Bank of Newman Grove, Neb., also said deposit insurance limits should not be narrowed. "People want to put their money where they live and feel safe about it." **********Edward Yingling, the top lobbyist for the American Bankers Association, said he expected the Treasury proposals to be supported by banks of all sizes. "We are getting rid of the idea that some banks are too big to fail," he said. Opposition From Insurers **********The Treasury sugggested that Federal prohibitions on the sale of insurance by banks be removed and that states be allowed to set rules for such sales. **********Insurance agents, who have long fought to prevent banks from entering their business, are sure to fight the Treasury proposal. Banks have long sought a bigger piece of the brokerage fees and commissions paid to insurance agents for property and casualty insurance, which amounted to more than $23 billion in 1989, saying it is a low-risk business that is a natural extension of banking activities. Life insurance products like annuities are also incresingly attractive to banks, because they are an alternative to ordinary savings accounts or certificates of deposit. **********The Treasury proposal to allow industrial companies to own banks drew criticism even before the Treasury study was issued. **********E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said late last week that he doubted whether Federal regulators could keep a tight rein on potentially abusive practices if a banking company was controlled by a nonfinancial corporation, and questioned the accuracy of claims that the banking industry needs access to the capital of these companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.main_headline: Short-Term Yields Fall A Bit More
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.print_headline: Short-Term Yields Fall A Bit More
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.body_text: **********Yields on short-term certificates of deposit continued the downtrend of the previous week. In fact, the Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., noted that the drop this week was a little more pronounced than it was a week ago. **********Robert K. Heady, publisher of the Monitor, said yesterday: "Deposit rates continue to decline even though they touched what we might call a theoretical 'bottom' of a down cycle three weeks ago. This reflects a further softening of the economy and indicates a longer period of recovery than many economists originally anticipated." **********Analysts at the Monitor said they believed that the decline in yields would continue. **********The yields on three-month Treasury bills at the auction on Monday, however, were not much changed from the previous week. Largest Gains in Yields **********The largest change in the return on money market accounts among the banks in the New York area was registered by the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company. The yield dropped 26 basis points to 4.85 percent. **********The largest gain for six-month certificates of deposit was by First Nationwide, where yields rose 20 basis points, to 5.90 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Hudson City Savings and four other area institutions reduced their three-month certificate yield by 10 basis points. **********Among major New York commercial banks the average six-month certificate of deposit lost 6 basis points, to 5.59 percent. The average money market account at these banks dropped 2 basis points, to 5.12 percent. **********The same banks reduced the average yield on three-month certificates of deposit by 4 basis points, to 5.41 percent. **********Depositors nationwide saw their three-month certificate yield decline by a basis point, to 5.72, while the six-month certificate rose a basis point, to 6.00 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/26/busin.main_headline: RETAILERS REPORT SALES FELL SHORT OF DIM FORECASTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/26/busin.print_headline: RETAILERS REPORT SALES FELL SHORT OF DIM FORECASTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/26/busin.body_text: **********Retailers would probably like to forget Christmas 1991. While most merchants had been prepared for a sluggish season, many said sales turned out to be even worse than expected. Even the last-minute shopping frenzy was not enough to give merchants anything to cheer about. **********As recently as a month ago, many retailers had hoped to exceed last year's sales by 5 percent. But results through the close of business on Monday indicate that spending will be flat or up slightly in December. The major retail chains are scheduled to release their final monthly sales results next week. **********"We are disappointed with the season," Stephen E. Watson, president of the Dayton Hudson Corporation in Minneapolis, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday. 'Too Little Too Late' **********Business surged in the final days, and a number of retailers said that Monday was the busiest day of the year. But Mr. Watson said, "In our view, it's really been too little too late." Dayton Hudson, which relies on California for one-third of its business, was hit hard by the slowdown in that state's economy. **********This is the third consecutive sluggish Christmas shopping season -- the make or break season for retailers -- and many analysts say this year's dismal results are likely to force thousands of companies into bankruptcy. **********The economy received most of the blame for the weak sales, but retailers also said they had no hot product this year. The wave of layoff announcements in the last two months did not help either. Bad News From G.M. **********The General Motors Corporation said last week that it would close 21 plants and lay off more than 70,000 workers, striking directly at consumer's already flagging confidence. **********"That was not helpful," said Mr. Watson of Dayton Hudson, which has department stores and Target discount stores in Michigan. Going into the Christmas selling season, Dayton Hudson had planned for sales to increase by as much as 7 percent over last year. But Mr. Watson said sales at the nation's fourth-largest retailer, would be flat or show a small gain for December. **********Lasker M. Meyer, vice chairman of Specialty Retailers Inc. in Houston, which operates 165 Palais Royale and Bealls department stores, also felt the announcement by General Motors put a damper on sales in the final week. "It could be totally coincidental, but news like that really makes a strong impression on people," Mr. Meyer said. "It makes them start worrying about their own jobs." Predictions Fall Short **********The chain started the holiday sales season predicting a 5 percent sales increase over last year, but Mr. Meyer said its sales for the period would only equal those of 1990. **********In addition to grappling with a drop in consumer confidence, merchants said they lacked a "must have" new product to draw people into stores. One telling sign of the lack of fresh merchandise could be found in the notoriously fickle toy aisles where Ninja Turtles remained a hot product for yet another year. **********"It was probably the least exciting merchandising Christmas in recent history," said Julian M. Seeherman, chairman and chief executive of Venture Stores Inc., a Midwestern discount chain with about $1.5 billion in sales. "This year in particular you needed something new to try and break the consumer apathy." Venture's sales are likely to be better than last year, but not up to expectations. **********Sales at Sears, Roebuck are also expected to be flat or down slightly for the month, analysts said.
