Long Lull in December **********Sears, like other retailers said business was strong at Thanksgiving and in the last few days, but quiet for much of December. "For the first two and a half weeks in December, we were soft and somewhat below our expectations," said Matt Howard, senior vice president of marketing for Sears. The stores had a strong finish. "Monday was exceptionally strong," he said. **********Mr. Howard said consumers were out in force, but they were simply buying less. "The size of the ticket over all for most retailers is probably smaller this year," he said. **********Nonetheless, the number of customers shopping at Sears, and the number of transactions the company processed were up for the fourth quarter. Some Bright Spots **********There were bright spots. With consumers searching for bargains, discount retailers like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the K Mart Corporation are expected to post solid gains. "K Mart had a very good month," said Robert Roth, a retail analyst with Merrill Lynch. The company did booming business on Monday and said it expected sales to be up by 8 or 9 percent compared with December last year. **********"Everybody is talking recession and depression; in this store that's not been the case," said Curtis Williams, general manager of a K Mart store in the Altanta area, near Marietta. Business jumped 25 percent on Monday, compared with Dec. 23 last year, he said. **********A Wal-Mart spokeswoman said, "We are pleased with sales for the holiday season this year." **********The Gap, with its tables full of $36 jeans, $20 turtlenecks and $35 cotton sweaters, is also expected to do well this Christmas. **********Merchants like the Gap and Wal-Mart benefited from the twin themes of value and the desire for basic merchandise, both emerged early and dominated consumers quest for gifts this year. **********Mr. Howard of Sears said sheets, towels, portable electric tools, exercise bikes, jeans, turtlenecks and terry cloth robes had sold well. **********J. C. Penney scaled back its hopes for the month after "business fell apart the beginning of December," said Harvey McCormick, a company spokesman. He said the company expected sales for the month to be flat or slightly better than a year earlier, although analysts felt that Penney's might be down for the month. Last-Minute Rush Is Slow **********Cheryl Engstrom, a spokeswoman for Nordstrom Inc. in Seattle, said sales had not picked up as sharply as the company had anticipated. Although there has been an uptick in sales over the last couple of days, the results are not likely to meet the company's projections for the holiday selling season. "Shoppers have been slower than ever getting off the dime this year, and it looks like some of them may never take off," Ms. Engstrom said. **********She said Nordstrom's specialty apparel stores had not done as well as its outlet divisions, Nordstrom Rack and Place Two. "Those have been doing great, which just reinforces the trend that our customers are shopping for price," Ms. Engstrom said. **********In a season marked by many sales, retailers continued to cut prices aggressively up until stores closed on Christmas Eve. Sales Before Christmas **********At a Bombay Company home furnishing store at the Oakland Mall near Detroit, the after-Christmas sales tags were being hung on items earlier than planned. "We're pulling out all the stops," said the store manager, Kathy Gurtek. **********Such last-minute price-cutting was widespread. "If a competitor's price goes down, we'll tag our price down," said Wayne Inouye, vice president of merchandising for the Good Guys Inc. He said that a competitor, had recently dropped the price of a popular Sony camcorder to $600, which is $100 less than the advertised price a month ago. Good Guys matched that cut and others, a policy that has caused the company's stock price to drop recently. **********Even though retailers ordered merchandise carefully this year, they are gearing up for huge after-Christmas sales. Sears will run extensive advertising for its post-Christmas "Best Week to Buy" sale. **********Still, some chose to give the most practical gift of all this year, cash. Barry Levine, a 44-year old talent manager in Los Angeles, gave money to his brother, an unemployed engineer. "You can't eat a sweater," Mr. Levine said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.main_headline: War and Peace: A Sampling From the Debate on Capitol Hill
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; War and Peace: A Sampling From the Debate on Capitol Hill
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/world.body_text: **********Senator George J. Mitchell Democrat of Maine **********Today the Senate undertakes a solemn constitutional responsibility to decide whether to commit the nation to war. In this debate, we should focus on the fundamental question before us: what is the wisest course of action for our nation in the Persian Gulf crisis. **********In its simplest form, the question is whether Congress will give the President an unlimited blank check to initiate war against Iraq at some unspecified time in the future under circumstances which are not now known and cannot be foreseen.                . . . **********This is not a debate about whether force should ever be used. No one proposes to rule out the use of force; we cannot and should not rule it out. The question is should war be truly a last resort when all other means fail or should we start with war, before other means have been fully and fairly exhausted. **********This is not a debate about American objectives in the current crisis. There is broad agreement in the Senate that Iraq must fully and unconditionally withdraw its forces from Kuwait. The issue is how best to achieve that goal. Most Americans and most members of Congress, myself included, supported the President's initial decision to deploy American forces to Saudi Arabia to deter further Iraqi aggression. We supported the President's effort in marshaling international diplomatic pressure and the most comprehensive embargo in history against Iraq. **********I support that policy. I believe it remains the correct policy, even though the President abandoned his own policy before it had time to work. The change began on Nov. 8, when President Bush announced that he was doubling the number of American troops in the Persian Gulf to 430,000 in order to attain a credible offensive option. The President did not consult with Congress about that decision; he did not try to build support for it among the American people. He just did it. **********In so doing, President Bush transformed the United States' role and its risks in the Persian Gulf crisis. In effect, the President, overnight, with no consultation and no public debate, changed American policy from being part of a collective effort to enforce economic and diplomatic sanctions into a predominantly American effort, relying upon the use of American military force. **********Despite the fact that his own policy of international economic sanctions was having a significant effect upon the Iraqi economy, the President, without explanation, abandoned that approach and instead adopted a policy based first and foremost upon the use of American military force. As a result, this country has been placed on a course toward war. This has upset the balance of the President's initial policy, the balance between resources and responsibility, between interest and risk, between patience and strength.                . . . **********It may become necessary to use force to expel Iraq from Kuwait, but because war is such a grave undertaking, with such serious consequences, we must make certain that war is employed only as a last resort. Representative Robert H. Michel Republican of Illinois **********I speak from the prejudice of being a combat veteran of World War II. And those of our generation know from bloody experience that unchecked aggression against a small nation is a prelude to an international disaster. **********Saddam Hussein today has more planes and tanks and, frankly, men under arms, than Hitler had at the time when Prime Minister Chamberlain came back from Munich with that miserable piece of paper -- peace in our time. I'll never forget that replay of that movie in my life. **********And I have an obligation, I guess, coming from that generation, to transmit those thoughts I had at the time to the younger generation who didn't experience what we did. Saddam Hussein not only invaded Kuwait, he occupied, terrorized, murdered civilians, systematically looted and turned a peaceful nation into a wasteland of horror. He seeks control over one of the world's vital resources, and he ultimately seeks to make himself the unchallenged anti-Western dictator of the Mideast. **********Either we stop him now, and stop him permanently, or we won't stop him at all. **********Now the President has clearly presented the reasons why we can't stand by idly. In his words, and I quote them -- we're in the gulf because the world must not and cannot reward aggression, and we're there because our vital interests are at stake. Now we're told by some that we must show patience. We must wait for sanctions to work. **********We must wait six months or a year before forces are used. We must stay the course. My question is this -- stay what course? A course that allows Saddam to know he is freed from surprise attack, free from sudden offensive movement for six months or a year or more? And I guess to you who advocate that course, I would have to ask you to do -- what you would do about the attitude of the American people in that interval period of time? How long is the American people -- will the American people put up with that? Senator Strom Thurmond   Republican of South Carolina **********Mr. President, how much longer can we expect them to maintain their combat readiness? How much longer can we expect our soldiers' families to carry on under the tremendous burdens they are carrying? They are not only dealing with the uncertainty of not knowing how much longer their loved ones will be gone from home but also with anguish that war could break out at any moment. **********Mr. President, the Congress must act and let its voice be heard. The time to end the debate is now. I implore this body to demonstrate to the world and especially Saddam Hussein that we are behind our President and the United Nations. A vote in support of the President is a vote for peace. I urge my colleagues to stop the debate and show our solidarity with the President and resolve to get Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. Solidarity, we need it now, not division, but solidarity. Senator Edward M. Kennedy   Democrat of Massachusetts **********I urge the Senate to vote for peace, not war. Now is not the time for war. I reject the argument that says Congress must support the President, right or wrong. We have our own responsibility to do what is right, and I believe that war today is wrong. **********War is not the only option left to us in the Persian Gulf. The President may have set Jan. 15 as    his    deadline, but the American people have not. Sanctions and diplomacy may still achieve our objectives, and Congress has the responsibility to insure that all peaceful options are exhausted before resort to war. Unless we reach that stage, Congress ought not to authorize the President to use force. **********At this historic moment, it may well be that only Congress can stop this senseless march toward war.                . . . **********Let there be no mistake about the cost of war. We have arrayed an impressive international coalition against Iraq, but when the bullets start flying, 90 percent of the casualties will be Americans. It is hardly a surprise that so many other nations are willing to fight to the last American to achieve the goals of the United Nations. It is not their sons and daughters who will do the dying. Most military experts tell us that a war with Iraq would not be quick and decisive, as President Bush suggests; it'll be brutal, and costly. It'll take weeks, even months, and will quickly turn from an air war to a ground war, with thousands, perhaps even tens of thousands, of American casualties. **********The Administration refuses to release casualty estimates, but the 45,000 body bags the Pentagon has sent to the region are all the evidence we need of the high price in lives and blood that we will have to spare. Military experts have used Israel's two recent desert wars as reliable indicators of the casualties we will suffer. In the Six-Day War in 1967, Israel suffered 3,300 casualties out of a force of 300,000, including 7,000 dead. In the heavier fighting that lasted 20 days in the 1973 war, Israeli casualties were 11,000 out of a force of a similar size, with 2,600 dead. **********In other words, we're talking about the likelihood of at least 3,000 American casualties a week, with 700 dead, for as long as the war goes on. Senator John C. Danforth   Republican of Missouri **********The one and only chance to accomplish our objectives without war is to maintain sanctions accompanied by a credible military threat. Without a credible military threat, our alternative is sanctions followed by nothing at all. The key to peace is maintaining a credible military threat, and this is precisely the point our pending votes will address. **********Those who would give sanctions a chance before military action is even possible would decouple the two components which must be kept linked if we have any chance of getting Iraq out of Kuwait without a fight. They would foreclose any possibility of a just peace. **********This is why I cannot vote for sanctions alone. This is why I cannot vote to deprive the President of the credible threat of force. It is indeed a supreme irony that it is only through the threat of force that a stable world can be maintained. But that is an irony that we have recognized ever since World War II. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan   Democrat of New York **********Suddenly, on behalf of Kuwait, in opposition to Iraq, we see the largest array of armed force since the -- mankind has seen since the Second World War. And we see a President declaring -- assserting that he has the right to send those armed forces into battle independently of any judgment of the Senate. . . . **********Now how could this happen? The first post-cold-war crisis, as we have had it described. I'd like to suggest, Mr. President, and I hope this might help us think about the subject -- I'd like to suggest that despite the assertions that this was the first post-cold-war crisis, and the way in which we've proceeded in that mold and which manner obtained the universal support of the country, and the Senate here -- or as near to it as makes no matter -- suddenly there is an institutional lurch back in to the manner and mode of the cold war.                . . . **********Then the assertions we have heard in the past months, after the lurching from a defensive, deterrent position -- which we responded to very well -- into an offensive position, on Nov. 8; a measure taken in secret and that certainly suddenly turned what had been a collective security operation, with the complete support of the country and the world, into a crisis situation. And all through those things, the President as Commander in Chief, secretly moving to create the ongoing permanent Orwellian crisis.               . . . **********What we find here is a kind of time warp in which we don't -- we're acting in an old mode with response to a new condition. I find it, for example, extraordinary that the President should so personalize the encounter with this particular thug in Baghdad -- the most recent thug in Baghdad, not the last by any means; there'll be others, they'll succeed each other. We are not in an international crisis in the sense that events that took place on Aug. 2 necessitate the confrontation of the largest set of armed forces since World War II. Nothing large happened. A nasty little country invaded a littler, but just as nasty, country.                . . . **********Mr. President, our armies have been on the Rhine for 45 years, and that is to stop a Roman legion. I mean, we're still at Panmunjom. We have had naval force with some land facilities -- a base facilities -- in the gulf since the Second World War. **********Well, 12 months have passed, 18 months have passed, life will go on and we will not have the wrenching Constitutional crisis that will come about with the President committing a massive use of our armed forces in a distant region of the world without the specific declaration of war by Congress. Senator Orrin G. Hatch   Republican of Utah **********Mr. President, I have been watching this debate with a great deal of interest today and frankly I'm very concerned about some of the comments that have been made. I think President Bush has gone the extra mile in trying to avoid the use of force. I don't think there's any question about that. And I think it's time for Congress to help rather than hinder the President. **********I think it's time for the Congress to join with the President and get behind him and our young men and women over there sitting in the sand and show that we're willing to back the use of force. I never thought I'd see the day when a timid organization like the United Nations would come out and agree and authorize the use of force by Jan. 15 and all members of Congress are unwilling to back their resolution, some of them. **********Unless Saddam Hussein believes that the threat of war is real, he will not budge. I think we've learned that. The only way to avoid war, in my opinion in this particular situation, is to be prepared to go to war and to show that our resolve is for real. If Hussein won't even accept a letter from President Bush, he certainly is not going to accept Congressional clues that Iraq pull out from Kuwait. Our actions should be decisive. **********If we back the President overwhelmingly we will maximize the pressure on Iraq, we will enhance the chances that we can avoid war. If the vote is close, Saddam Hussein can conclude that he can divide our country if he will only hold out. If we fail to back the President, war will become inevitable.  Senator Bill Bradley   Democrat of New Jersey **********President Bush and Secretary Baker apparently have not addressed these four most probable outcomes from using massive military force. They have not apparently thought through how to deal with the potential power vacuum in Iraq, or how to cushion the negative Arab reaction to the use of massive force or how to resist pressure from our Arab coalition partners to sell out Israel, or how to prevent an isolationist reaction to a bloody war whose purpose has been inadequately explained. **********Because they have not prepared for tomorrow's reaction, they should not commence offensive action today.  Senator Claiborne Pell   Democrat of Rhode Island **********As amongst those who've served their country in war, and one who has pressed in the United States Senate for the toughest possible nonmilitary response to years of Iraqi lawbreaking, I believe that at this time, peace and the continuation of comprehensive sanctions is the wisest course, strongest course, best course for our nation.  Senator Arlen Specter   Republican of Pennsylvania **********I personally remain hopeful, Mr. President, that war will be avoided. But it seems to me that the best way to avoid a war is to put Iraq squarely on notice with a very strong support by the Congress of the U.N. resolution and the President that we mean business and we're prepared to fight. **********We wonder about the state of mind of Saddam Hussein. We wonder if he's a madman, Mr. President, and I submit that he is not. Senator Shelby and I had an opportunity to visit for an hour and 20 minutes with President Saddam Hussein just about a year ago today and I found him very poorly informed about the U.S. policy, very poorly informed about Western attitudes, did not have an understanding of our attitude about the problems of the Mideast. But he was certainly far from a mad man. **********And there was later another Senate delegation with Senator Dole and Senator Metzenbaum and Senator McClure, Senator Murkowski, Senator Simpson and those senators also had a discussion with President Saddam Hussein and concluded that he was not a mad man. And we wonder what is his calculation. **********It seems to me that if the current course is followed and force is used, that President Saddam Hussein will lose his country but he must have some other calculation. He may have a calculation of involving Israel in a war. He may have a calculation of trying to bring the coalition into disintegration so the Arabs will fight the Israelis. Or what he really may have in mind, and it's obviously speculative to try to figure out what is President Saddam Hussein's state of mind, he may have in mind the state of mind of the United States Congress. And that is a more perplexing state of mind than the mind of Saddam Hussein. **********The comments have been made, I think it was the distinguished majority leader who raised that question about what was the will of Congress, doubt about the will of the Senate, always doubt about what we are undertaking, but if we unequivocally put Iraq and its President on notice of our intentions by a solid vote, it is my judgment that we will have an excellent chance to avoid that war.  Representative Richard A. Gephardt   Democrat of Missouri **********I want to say tonight that if Saddam Hussein listens to this debate -- and we're told that he does pick up some American television -- I hope that he will take no comfort from this debate. We are united in our purpose in this country and in this Congress. Some have expressed concern that when there is a division of opinion even on strategy, that that lends help to the other side. I hope that we'd never mistake disagreement on means as disunity within our country. I can't remember a time when our country has been as unified around a set of goals, as focused on what we're trying to do, in as much agreement and unity as I think we are tonight.  Representative Patricia Schroeder   Democrat of Colorado **********I rise in support of the gentleman from Indiana and Congressman Gephardt's resolution. I think it fits exactly what we know about leadership. What we have learned over and over and over again about leadership is first you commit the nation and then you commit the troops. Tonight we're talking about are we going to go even further and commit the troops way beyond where the nation is committed. I think the Hamilton-Gephardt resolution fits exactly where we are in our commitments. **********No. 1, it protects U.S. forces. It allows use of force if our U.S. forces overseas are attacked. That's very important. **********No. 2, it keeps our commitment to defend Saudi Arabia and use force if Saudi Arabia is attacked. The American people support that, and that makes sense. **********Then it also allows for use of force if the sanctions are violated in any manner, and that's our commitment, and that makes sense. What it does not do is say that we're going to put everything out there and go for it on the 15th. I do not know why we cut off our options and decided that on Jan. 15 we had to give the President what is the equivalent of a declaration of war.  Senator William V. Roth Jr.   Republican of Delaware **********The fact remains, such a united coalition is truly historic. A coalition that reflects the worldwide concern about Saddam Hussein, his belligerent character and frightening objectives. This alignment is the result of several important factors, factors that we must consider as we debate the resolutions before us. **********Perhaps the first and foremost factor concerns Iraq's growth in both quantity and quality of military power. It continues at a threatening pace, despite the fact that Hussein's war with Iran is long ended. **********Let no one be caught sleeping. To close an eye now would allow him the deadly latitude to consolidate his power and amass a nuclear arsenal. He is willing to bend any law and make almost any sacrifice toward these ends. He is an unpredictable as a desert storm and as deceptive as a mirage. **********One can only imagine what devastating consequence would fall should his dominance be allowed in the oil-rich Middle East. And this is the second reason why he must be stopped. When I speak of the danger that would result from his control of this region, I'm not talking about consequences to major oil companies -- quite simply, I'm talking about jobs. I'm talking about the raw material of human endeavor. **********Oil runs the economy of the world. It fuels our factories, heats our homes. Carries our products from manufacture to market. It's as basic to the economy as water is to life. And the free trade and international supplies is critical, not only for the industrial democracies, but the fragile third world nations that depend on this precious resource even more than we do. **********Any attempt to disrupt these supplies will send a devastating quake to these economies, lengthening unemployment lines, boosting inflation in the industrial democracies and crushing the economies of developing countries where day to day existence depends on imported energy sources.  Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.   Democrat of Delaware **********If there's a war, 95 percent of the casualties on the world's side will be American. If there's a war, we will prevail, we will win the battle, but 95 percent of the enmity of the Arab world outside of Iraq, to the extent there is any, will be directed at the United States.                . . . **********In light of this, Mr. President, it seems almost impossible to believe that we're having a serious argument in this country today about whether under the Constitution the President alone can take a nation to war. The Constitution's language says that the war powers rest with the Congress. And from James Madison to John Marshall, the Constitution's fathers all understood this to be a key principle of the republic. **********And lest anyone in this body or anyone listening wonder why I'm raising this question since there's already a resolution before us, I'm raising it because the President continues to insist he does not need, does not need the will of the people spoken through the Congress as envisioned by the Constitution to decide whether or not to go to war. **********On Tuesday President Bush asked this Congress to debate and decide whether to take the nation to war yet unfortunately the President stopped short of abandoning his previous claim that he has the power acting alone to start a war. **********And just yesterday, as I mentioned earlier, the President himself said that he alone has the constitutional authority to initiate war. No President before him has ever said anything like that. No President in our history has ever made such an assertion. To put it simply these views are at odds with the Constitution. They may accurately describe the power of leaders of other countris, but they do not describe the power of the President of the United States.                . . . **********If the President, at least in his statements, appears willing to violate our Constitution to achieve those objectives, if this crisis is really about upholding the law of nations, I suggest the President acknowledge that he start here by upholding the law at home and clearly acknowledge that only the Congress can take this nation to war.  Senator Paul D. Wellstone   Democrat of Minnesota **********I rise to speak in this chamber for the first time with a very heavy heart. I wanted my first speech to be about children and education and health care and a credible energy policy and the environment. I never thought that the first time I would have an opportunity to speak in this chamber the topic would be such a grave topic -- life and death, whether or not to go to war, to ask America's men and women, so many of them so young to risk life and limb, to unleash a tremendous destructive power on a foreign country and a far away people. This is the most momentous decision that any political leader would ever have to make and decide we must. **********And let no one doubt that the Congress has the responsibility to make this decision. The Constitution is unambiguous on this point: Congress declares the war, not the President.               . . . **********The policies that I am afraid the Administration is pursuing, the rush to war that I am afraid is so much of what is now happening in our country and the world, will not create a new order, Mr. President, it will create a new world disorder. What kind of victory will it be? What kind of victory will it be if we unleash forces of fanaticism in the Middle East and a chronically unstable region becomes even more unstable further jeopardizing Israel's security?                . . . **********Some causes are worth fighting for, some causes are worth fighting for. This cause is not worth fighting for right now. We must stay the course with economic sanctions, continue the pressure, continue the squeeze, move forward on the diplomatic front and Mr. President, we must not, we must not rush to war.  Senator Paul Simon   Democrat of Illinois **********Mr. President, there is a grim mood here in Congress as I do not recall. When you and I were elected to the House, Mr. President, in 1974, we were already involved in the Vietnam War but it was being pulled down and I have not experienced this kind of a mood before in Washington D.C. We face unprovoked aggression. No question about it. And there is no question in the minds of anyone here that Saddam Hussein and the Iraqi troops have to get out of Kuwait, one way or another. **********When you grow up in rural America and live in rural America you learn something very simple: don't corner a rattlesnake. Give the rattlesnake a way to get out. And that's what we have to do in the situation over there. But I have to say the diplomatic option looks very, very difficult. **********The second option is the economic option, sanctions. This was imposed by the President, and the President and the Secretary of State and Secretary of Defense appear to have all but given up on this. And I suggest the evidence is pretty overwhelming that this has a chance to succeed if we stick with it. No one can guarantee it but I think it has a chance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; A New Fight Over Lockheed
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/14/busin.body_text: **********Harold C. Simmons, the investor who owns nearly 20 percent of the Lockheed Corporation, has decided to wage another proxy fight to unseat the military contractor's board. **********But in announcing his move on Tuesday, Mr. Simmons also said he would be willing to cancel the proxy contest if Lockheed would allow a shareholder vote on a proposal to expand the board by three seats and give them to Mr. Simmons and his representatives. **********Lockheed, which has fought all efforts by Mr. Simmons for board representation, said it would consider the proposal. **********Mr. Simmons has been considering another proxy contest since last spring, when he lost a bid to elect his slate of directors. **********Although Lockheed's stock price has rebounded substantially in the last six months and the company's earnings have improved, Mr. Simmons's 19.8 percent stake is still worth less than the $530 million he paid for it. **********Lockheed's stock fell 87.5 cents today, to $39.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.main_headline: Intel Executive Is Chosen To Be President of Maxtor
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Intel Executive Is Chosen To Be President of Maxtor
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.body_text: **********The Maxtor Corporation, a disk drive maker based in San Jose, Calif., yesterday named Laurence R. Hootnick president and chief executive, effective immediately. Mr. Hootnick was most recently president of the Intel Corporation's embedded controller and memory group. **********Mr. Hootnick, 49, succeeds James M. McCoy, Maxtor's founder, who has served as interim president and chief executive since January. George M. Scalise abruptly resigned from those positions in an apparent management shake-up after Maxtor reported a loss of $4 million for the quarter ended on Dec. 29. Mr. McCoy will continue as chairman. **********Analysts said Maxtor's difficulties stemmed from the acquisition of the Miniscribe business, which sells inexpensive hard-disk drives for use in personal computers. In contrast, Maxtor's specialty has always been to be first in the market with the highest-capacity, fastest disk drives for larger computers. That market commands a higher price and allows a higher cost structure for the company. Maxtor must accelerate the consolidation of the two businesses, the analysts said. **********"Our search to identify an outstanding C.E.O. for our company has been successfully completed," Mr. McCoy said in a statement. "With Larry's addition we can accelerate our return to a leadership position in the disk-drive marketplace." Mr. McCoy, 43, said he planned to remain active in the company. Mr. Hootnick said in a statement, "I'm excited about working with Jim McCoy to bring Maxtor back to pre-eminence." **********Mr. Hootnick was considered one of Intel's top executives, but not a likely candidate to become chief executive. In his 18 years there, he held a variety of positions, including chief financial officer and corporate senior vice president for sales and marketing. Mr. Hootnick holds a bachelor of science degree in industrial management from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a master's in business administration from the University of Maryland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/busin.main_headline: Jockey to Solve Big Mystery Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Jockey to Solve Big Mystery Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/11/busin.body_text: **********All summer, passers-by have wondered about the identity of the model on a Jockey International Inc. billboard in Times Square. At a news conference this morning, Jockey will disclose that she is Nancy Hogshead, an Olympic gold medalist swimmer. **********The sign, 18 feet by 90 feet, has carried the image of a woman with an obscured face, dressed in black bikini underwear and hosiery. The hidden identity raised speculation as to who she is; Sports Illustrated guessed last month that it was Ms. Hogshead, but the company declined to confirm the report. **********At the news conference, Ms. Hogshead is to be introduced as Jockey's first celebrity spokeswoman, and the veil that was covering her face on the billboard will be removed, a company spokeswoman said yesterday. Ms. Hogshead will continue to appear in Jockey ads and at Jockey-sponsored events.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/30/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********"Breaking Chaos Into Constituent Parts," (Managing, June 2) -- about 10 Goldome branches being absorbed by Manufacturers Hanover -- was fascinating and obviously a self-serving piece of information delivered by Manufacturers. **********It may well be true that signs, etc. were in place, but a visit during the first week of the takeover to the branches would have indicated a great deal of consternation on the part of the depositors. Many were arbitrarily assigned to branches many miles away from the branch where they had done business for years. **********In many instances, interest was calculated to May 24, even though the takeover did not occur until May 28. In walking into a branch, one encountered huge numbers of personnel, few of them ready to give depositors information or help. Many tellers were doing nothing, while there was just one window for exchanging accounts. **********The customer was not seen as a priority. A lot of unhappy depositors of Goldome have become totally disenchanted with Manufacturers. All of this was preventable. **********Obviously, Manufacturers was interested in telling stories to the press rather than being concerned about its new customers. One cannot help but wonder whether this kind of attitude is not at the root of the difficulties banks are encountering. RALPH R. REUTER Bronx, N.Y., June 5

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.main_headline: Johnson-Merck to Buy German Drug Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.print_headline: Johnson-Merck to Buy German Drug Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.body_text: **********Johnson & Johnson and Merck & Company said yesterday that they had agreed to buy a German drug company as a "first step" into the $5 billion European consumer drug business. **********The Johnson & Johnson-Merck Consumer Pharmaceuticals Company, a 50-50 joint venture, agreed to buy Woelm Pharma G.m.b.H., a subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc Rorer that is based in Eschwege, Germany. Pamela Adkins, a spokeswoman at Merck headquarters in Rahway, N.J., said the joint venture was "studying additional opportunities" in Europe. **********Analysts said Johnson & Johnson-Merck planned to plunge heavily into Europe, where the market for over-the-counter drugs would be twice as large if Europeans could be persuaded to buy antacid and aspirin pills as frequently as Americans do. **********The joint venture, established in 1989 to adapt Merck prescription drugs for the over-the-counter market, is also in a race with the SmithKline Beecham Corporation in the American market for Government approval to sell over-the-counter versions of their strong-selling anti-ulcer drugs. The joint venture hopes to have a version of Merck's Pepcid, which has prescription sales of $300 million a year, on drugstore shelves by 1994. SmithKline is trying to hit the consumer shelves first with a version of Tagamet, a drug with sales of $1 billion a year. **********Viren Mehta, an analyst with Mehta & Isaly Worldwide Research, in New York, said the joint venture company would pay about $90 million for Woelm, which makes cough and cold medicine, laxatives and vitamin brands that have total annual sales of about $40 million. The deal does not include Woelm's popular garlic-based medicine, Ilga-Rhoja, or the Armour blood products line. **********Mr. Mehta said Johnson & Johnson-Merck, in another European move, was also one of several companies talking with the Sara Lee Corporation, which is auctioning two consumer medications with combined sales of $200 million. The products are Rennie, which Sara Lee said was Europe's largest-selling antacid, and Aspro, a popular aspirin product in Europe and Australia. **********Spokesmen for Johnson & Johnson, Merck and Sara Lee said they did not comment on rumors of mergers and acquisitions. Mr. Mehta said the Sara Lee products would attract bidding in the $600 million to $800 million range. A European Nucleus **********Buying Woelm will provide Johnson & Johnson-Merck with a European nucleus, including cash flow, a factory and expertise in getting drugs approved by European government agencies, Mr. Mehta said. "It will act as a magnet to speed up their acquisition strategy," he added. **********Johnson & Johnson-Merck has about $125 million in sales, mainly of Mylanta, an antacid that the joint venture obtained early last year from ICI America Inc., a unit of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. of Britain, in a $450 million deal. Merck said that Mylanta became the best-selling American liquid antacid earlier this year, overtaking Maalox. **********Denise Stovell, a Sara Lee spokeswoman, said her company got Aspro and Rennie in 1984 when Sara Lee acquired the Nicholas Kiwi Company's line of pharmaceuticals, household products and shoe polish.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/02/busin.body_text: **********COMPANIES Akers Rattles a Few Cages at Buttoned-Down I.B.M. **********Rarely does the International Business Machines Corporation reveal its inner workings to the world. But last week it did when the contents of a tough speech given to a group of managers by John Akers, I.B.M.'s chairman, leaked out. It was an accident, the company said. Initially, investors did not like what they saw. I.B.M.'s stock dipped to $104.25 from $105.12 while the market rallied to new highs. Later, investors had a change of heart. The speech showed Mr. Akers struggling to do exactly what Wall Street wants: toughen up the company's country-club culture. According to the notes of the speech, Mr. Akers said I.B.M. had "too many people standing around the water cooler." Mr. Akers also said he would tolerate no further loss of market share. By the end of the week, the tough talk sank in. Big Blue's stock closed on Friday at $106.12. The only question now is whether the accidental release happened on purpose. A Fast Train for Texas?  Japan's bullet trains cruise at 150 miles per hour and France's TGV -- for Train a Grande Vitess -- was clocked at 320 m.p.h. American coaches lumber along at less than 100 m.p.h. That may change. Last week, the Texas High-Speed Rail Authority voted to award GEC Alshom of Paris -- the builder of the TGV -- and the Morrison Knudsen Corporation of Boise, Idaho, a construction company, a contract to build a 200 m.p.h. rail line between Dallas and Houston by 1998. San Antonio would be added later, creating a 620-mile triangle. There is one catch: The consortium has to raise its own money to build the system, at a hefty estimated cost of $5.7 billion. So far, the companies have just $167 million in capital. Will they be able to raise the rest? "There is a feeling of confidence that the TGV consortium can pull it together," said Steven Polunsky the Texas High Speed Rail Authority. Macy's Inexplicable Strategy  R. H. Macy & Company has big plans. The retailing chain figures if it opens 11 new stores over the next five years it can increase sales from $2.2 billion last year to $3.6 billion. That is a gain of 41.6 percent. It also wants to invest in technology and a new advertising campaign. Very aggressive actions in such a sluggish market. The trouble is, Macy's has little cash -- less than at any time since a leveraged buyout took it private in 1986. And it has a storeroom full of debt, $3.4 billion. It is losing money too -- $100.9 million last quarter -- as sales slide and margins thin. This has the analysts scratching their heads about Macy's plans. They are concerned about opening new stores "I am concerned about Macy's acceleration of store openings at a time when it is so important to gain existing-store productivity." said Walter F. Loeb an independent analysts in New York. The big store's creditors are getting nervous. A Disney Bails Out L.A. Gear  L.A. Gear Inc., the athletic footwear maker, grew quickly by spotting fads on the playground. But now it's stumbling badly. It lost $12.5 million in the first quarter on sales of $171 million on top of losing $9.1 million in the final quarter last year. L.A. Gear's creditors, jittery from the losses, cut its credit line to $300 million from $360 million. The company needed cash. Last week it got it. Roy E. Disney, said he would buy 30 percent of the sneaker company for $100 million. The deal is the first for Trefoil Capital Investors, a $450 million investment fund formed by Mr. Disney's firm, Shamrock Capital Advisers Inc. of Burbank, Calif., to rescue ailing companies. In exchange for the money, Mr. Disney gets control of the compay's operating plan. Ameritech Spruces Up  The Ameritech Corporation, based in Chicago, provides local telephone service in five Midwestern states. Pretty ho-hum, as businesses go, but a good provider of cash. Last week the company decided to dump its dowdy image and said it would buy Cybertel for $512 million from JMB Reality of Chicago and its partners. Cybertel is one of two companies providing cellular telephone service in St. Louis. Analysts think Ameritech cut a good deal. It will pay $195 for each "pop" -- slang for a cellular customer. Prices have been as high as $350. Best of all, Cybertel has only 40,000 customers, plenty of room for growth.  That gives Ameritech's image an overhaul.  A Challenge to T.W.A.  To pare down some of its $2.7 billion in debt, Trans World Airlines Inc., sold its routes to London to American Airlines for $445 million. Last week the sale was put in doubt. The city of St. Louis, T.W.A.'s hub and its unions asked the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeal to reverse the sale. The challenge is moot, T.W.A.'s lawyers said. The deal is already done. T.W.A. negotiated a deal to buy back some of its debt from Connecticut National Bank at 77.5 cents on the dollar. The bank was threatening threatening to reposses 10 airplanes and 62 engines.  INTERNATIONAL **********Resistance to Favoring China  ast week, President Bush told the graduating class at Yale University that he would renew China's trade privileges for another year. But he added a disclaimer. He was trying to "chart a course through a world of lesser evils," he said. Maybe so, but getting Congress to agree that China is a "lesser evil," will not be easy. Three measures have already been introduced to revoke China's most-favored-nation status, which grants its goods low tariffs. China has not changed policies since 1989 when it cracked down on political activity, the bills' authors say. To mollify Congress, Mr. Bush said exports of supercomputers, missiles and nuclear technology would be restricted. Not enough to stop a fight in Congress. "The issue is joined," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. Mr. Bush may lose the fight.  A Reward for Egypt  uring the gulf war, Egypt's crippled economy lost billions of dollars. But now it is being rewarded for having joined the fight against Iraq. The United States and other Western creditors agreed last week to forgive $20.2 billion of Egypt's Government debt -- almost half of Egypt's $50 billion in debt. Welcome relief for this struggling nation. But what will follow forgiveness? Most economist say more borrowing. Primakov on a Mission  Yevgeny M. Primakov, the wily Soviet envoy who tried (and failed) to get Saddam Hussein to quit the war, saw President Bush last week. He said he thinks Washington will come up with $1.5 billion in credits so the Soviet Union can buy grain. The Administration is not so sure. It wants to see a reform plan for the Soviet economy it can believe in. So far it has not. The last plan called for more (not less) central control. Precisely the wrong direction. The latest plan, Mr. Primakov said, will do the opposite. But it is not quite finished. The Administration wants to see more before it gives the nod. THE ECONOMY Good News, With a Caveat  There was optimism but it was tinctured with a dash of gloom. Sales of existing homes were up 3.4 percent for April, the third increase in a row according to the National Association of Realtors. The Commerce Department confirmed the good news. Sales of new homes climbed 1.2 percent in April. These figures indicate the housing slump may have reached its final days. But the Mortgage Bankers Association cast some doubt. It said 4.95 percent of the nation's homeowners were at least 30 days late on their mortgage payments in the first quarter, a sign that tough times remain. The delinquencies rate was 4.71 percent in the fourth quarter. Before the recession hit, the rate was 4.41 percent. Rising delinquencies mean future foreclosures -- bad news for the nation's home lenders. "The economy is staging a recovery," said Richard Peach, deputy chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. "But we don't expect it to be terribly strong." The Factory-Orders Omen Factory orders rose 1.8 percent in April, according to the Commerce Department, the first increase in six months. Spending increased for both durable and nondurable goods. It was a better showing than most analysts had expected and followed declines of 2.9 percent in March and 0.6 percent in February. The new figures, released last week, show that inventories are shrinking and companies are ordering new goods. The Federal Reserve Chairman, Alan Greenspan, last month said an increase in factory orders would indicate that the economy is turning around. But economists caution the lag can be long between a pickup in orders and employment growth. **********The G.N.P. Inches Back  The gross national product fell by 2.6 percent in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said last week. Everybody already knew that. But they did not know that the G.N.P. was down two-tenths of 1 percent less than the department's original estimate. The recession may be deep, but it's no Grand Canyon. Even better, the Commerce Department reported that corporate profits in the first quarter fell less than in the two preceding quarters. They were down three-tenths of 1 percent following declines of 1.9 percent and 3.9. The recession may have reached its nadir. **********Hope From Consumers Consumer spirits remain up, but they are not as buoyant as before. "We got dancing in the streets when the war was over," said Fabien Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center. "That is giving way to a somewhat more sober assessment." Nothing to worry about -- so far. Confidence, which is measured by a survey of current attitudes and future expectations is still in what analysts call the "hopeful range." That means consumers are willing to spend.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/14/world.main_headline: INDIA HOLDS DOZEN IN GANDHI KILLING
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/14/world.print_headline: INDIA HOLDS DOZEN IN GANDHI KILLING
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/14/world.body_text: **********Seven weeks after the assassination of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, security officials have arrested more than a dozen Sri Lankans and Indians on suspicion of being accomplices and have begun a widespread hunt in southern India for a Tamil militant from Sri Lanka who is believed to be the central plotter in the carefully planned killing. **********An official of the Central Bureau of Investigation said the key planner in the conspiracy is believed to be a bespectacled man in his 30's who was photographed at the assassination site; the photographer who took the picture was one of the 17 people killed in the bomb blast on May 21. **********The wanted man, who apparently fled the scene of the bombing, is known as Shivarasan and is believed to be the head of an intelligence squad of a militant Sri Lankan separatist group, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. Because he reportedly lost an eye in an earlier bomb blast, the suspect also has the nickname "One-Eyed Jack." **********Mr. Gandhi, who was campaigning to regain power as prime minister, died in the explosion at the rally in Sriperumbudur, a village in the southern state of Tamil Nadu. The police believe that a woman in her 30's detonated the bomb around her waist as she bowed to touch Mr. Gandhi's feet in a gesture of respect. The woman, believed to belong to a suicide squad of the Tamil Tigers, was among those killed with Mr. Gandhi.  Tigers Deny Involvement **********Security officials decline to discuss the motive for the assassination, or even to confirm that the plot was planned and carried out by the violent group seeking a separate state for the Tamil minority in northeast Sri Lanka. Officials of the Tamil Tigers, which has carried out bombings and assassinations in Sri Lanka, have denied any involvement in the Gandhi killing. **********Privately, officials speculate that the group plotted to kill Mr. Gandhi before his probable election as Prime Minister in large part because security for him during the campaign was relatively light. Mr. Gandhi had sought to keep his campaign security at bay partly because of criticism that in his earlier losing campaign in 1989 he had traveled excessively by helicopter and kept aloof from crowds. **********Officials believe that the Tamil group may have meticulously planned the killing at its highest levels out of concern that Mr. Gandhi's policies would seek to destroy it if he was re-elected. As Prime Minister from 1984 to 1989, Mr. Gandhi sent Indian troops to neighboring Sri Lanka to try to end the years of ethnic strife between the Sinhalese majority and the Tamil minority. Indian troops engaged in violent clashes with the militants for more than two years, and were pulled out in March 1990, a few months after Mr. Gandhi left office. **********A widely read news magazine, India Today, said in an account of the assassination that the decision to kill Mr. Gandhi was made in November by the head of the organization, identified as Pirabhakaran, who summoned four key associates, including Shivarasan, to the jungles of Jaffna, the Sri Lankan base for the militant group. **********While Shivarasan was assigned to plan the assassination, the other three were given tasks such as preparing a back-up team to arrange shelter for the assassins before and after the killing, and to prepare a base in Madras to insure proper communications and couriers for messages. **********Indian security officials refuse to discuss the specific details disclosed by the magazine, as well as by other Indian publications, but acknowledge that they believe that the killing was carefully planned and involved a substantial number of Sri Lankans and Indians. At least two dozen senior security officials are working full time on the case, mostly in Madras and New Delhi. Officials said hundreds of police officers, mostly in Tamil Nadu, were engaged in the hunt for susspects.  Still in India, Officials Say **********Security officials said on Friday that they believe Shivarasan as well as two accomplices -- a 22-year-old woman called Subha, and a 19-year-old unidentifed man -- remain in southern India. **********Security officials have released photographs of Shivarasan, as well as a highly detailed description of him based on interviews, interrogations and photographs. **********The description notes that Shivarasan wears a white cyanide capsule around his neck -- a practice that one official described as not unusual for a commando of the Tamil group. There are no known details about Shivarasan's personal life or background. **********Details about the woman who killed herself in the bomb blast are also hazy, although there have been reports that she harbored a deep hatred of Indians because two of her brothers had been killed by Indian forces in Sri Lanka. There have also been reports that the woman, called Dhanu, had been raped by Indian soldiers during the Sri Lankan operation. Indian officials declined to discuss the reports. **********Security officials acknowledge that the photos taken at the assassination by a photographer, Hari Babu, and later recovered, were pivotal in the identification of the suspects. The slain photographer's camera was recovered with the film intact.  Last Photo of Blast Flame **********Officials believe that the 21-year-old photographer was assigned by Shivarasan to take photos of the campaign event, in line with the militants' tradition of recording its operations. But the photographer moved too close to Mr. Gandhi, depriving the militants not only of their documentation but providing security officials with major clues. His pictures included shots of the woman who was apparently carrying the bomb, Shivarasan posing as a journalist and other suspects in the crowd. His 10th and last photo was one orange-flame frame of the explosion. **********In recent weeks, the police have seized about a dozen Indians and Sri Lankans, all believed to be linked to the Tamil Tigers. Those under arrest are suspected of organizing shelter for Shivarasan as well as the woman with the bomb. Other suspects are being held for setting up communications equipment and working on the bomb. **********Security officials in New Delhi indicate that Shivarasan may be seeking to flee to Nepal, but they believe that he remains in southern India, in hiding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/busin.main_headline: Job Data Are Not Expected To Affect Fed Rein on Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Job Data Are Not Expected To Affect Fed Rein on Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/29/busin.body_text: **********Ordinarily, most of the focus of the credit markets this week would be on the Government's report on April employment for a sign of the nation's economic condition. The report is scheduled to be released Friday morning. **********But this is no ordinary period because no matter how many more nonfarm jobs vanished this month, the Federal Reserve last week repeatedly signaled that it had no intention of lowering interest rates in the foreseeable future. **********The signals were sent when the Fed intervened six times in seven business days to drain reserves from the banking system in an effort to prop up the Federal funds rate. Not only is the funds rate the only one that the Fed controls with any degree of certainty, but it is also the rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans and is the rate from which most other interest rates are scaled upward. Banks Amply Supplied **********Specifically, the consensus among money market analysts is that the Fed wants the funds rate to be 6 percent. That would make it the same as its discount rate, which is what the Fed charges banks for loans. But commercial banks have indirectly been sending their own signals -- that they are amply supplied with lendable reserves. Indeed, the Federal funds rate traded as low as 5.5 percent last week while the Fed was draining bank reserves. Last Friday, the funds rate traded at 5 7/8 percent for most of the day before briefly touching 6 percent at the close. **********As for the employment data due out before the markets open on Friday, consulting economists at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc. believe that the figures will show another drop of 200,000 nonfarm jobs and that the nation's unemployment rate will thus rise by two-tenths of a percentage point, to 7 percent.  A More Narrow Focus **********But investors and traders in Treasury and other fixed-income debt issues tend to have a more narrow focus. Late last week, many credit market participants were speculating over what effect, if any, yesterday's meeting in Washington of the Group of Seven industrialized nations would have on interest rates and the value of the dollar and, by extension, values of Treasury and other fixed-income debt issues. **********The next tests of the fixed-income market are due on May 7, 8 and 9, when the Treasury will auction what is expected to be a record amount of notes and bonds. The Treasury will announce the size of the auction on Wednesday afternoon. **********In the Treasury securities market last week, two successful auctions were completed. One consisted of $12 billion of two-year notes and the other was $9 billion of five-year notes.  Rise in Price of Long Bonds **********One measure of the market's satisfaction was seen in the rise in price of the Treasury's benchmark long bonds. The offered price of the 30-year bonds rose to 96 9/32 from 95 29/ 29 during the week, while its yield declined to 8.20 percent from 8.24 percent. **********"Perhaps the Bank of America sent the clearest signal when it reversed an earlier cut in its prime lending rate to 8.75 percent and lifted it back to 9 percent," said John G. Lonski, senior economist at Moody's Investors Service. "Perhaps the big West Coast bank acted on the expectation that a near-term easing of Fed policy was significantly less likely than originally thought when it cut its prime earlier in the week." **********Major commercial banks have asserted that they have to rebuild their profit margins and become more prudent in their lending practices. Still, Mr. Lonski summed up the view of many money market analysts last week, saying, "Until banks seek out loan customers more aggressively by way of narrower spreads between their prime rates and their basic cost of funds, this recession may be far from over."  A More Optimistic View **********A somewhat more optimistic view was offered by Eugene J. Sherman, senior vice president and chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. "On one hand, the monetary policy has been, and is likely to continue to be, mildly restrictive," he said. "For example, the growth of the money supply since 1987 has been half the rate of growth that prevailed in the prior 17 years. Looking ahead, we believe that the Fed will not squander the investment in conservative money management it has made over the last four years by easing excessively in the months ahead." **********But Mr. Sherman said he did expect an economic pickup to put some upward pressure on interest rates in the second half of 1991. The Federal funds rate, which has been ranging from 5.75 percent to 6 percent so far in the first half, may be allowed to go as high as 6.25 percent in the second half of the year, he said. He also expects the discount rate on 90-day bills to range from 5.85 percent to 6.20 percent in the second half. In recent weeks, the bill rate has moved from 5.90 percent to 5.65 percent. **********Mr. Sherman said he also expected long-term Treasury bond yields, as measured by the 30-year bond, to decline to 8 percent or 7.5 percent in the second half from the current level of 8.20 percent.
