It is clear that there is substantial economic distress and that con...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/10/busin.body_text: **********Last Tuesday's election results confirm what recent polls and confidence surveys have shown: Voters believe the recent downturn was far worse than many in the Administration say. It is clear that there is substantial economic distress and that conditions are not improving. **********Some Administration officials now admit that the strategy of relying on the post-Persian-Gulf-war euphoria and the Federal Reserve to turn things around has not worked. The recent "beat up on the regulators" strategy will not work either. Pressuring banks to make more loans will have little or no effect because many banks are unwilling or unable to do so because of their high numbers of nonperforming loans and eroding capital positions. And economic malaise will most likely continue -- unless we speed the recovery process and simultaneously deal with our long-term problems, like weak productivity growth and the loss of international competitiveness. **********This can best be accomplished by generating a public and private investment-led recovery that emphasizes long-term investments to increase productivity and add capacity. Our investment needs are enormous: We must upgrade factory equipment, reduce dependence on foreign oil, upgrade our infrastructure and build communications and data-handling systems for the future. **********Creating an investment-led recovery will not be easy in light of weak profits, poor sales and the overleveraged conditions of many companies. And we must avoid programs that will widen the already mind-boggling budget deficit. **********Unfortunately, many proposals now on the table avoid the long-term problems, provide little stimulus and actually deepen the deficit. For example, the apparent centerpiece of the Administration's growth package is a reduction in the capital gains tax. But that would cut revenues over time by giving large tax cuts to those who had them in the 1980's and didn't sufficiently alter investment behavior and spur economic growth. **********An effective investment-led recovery program -- offering substantial incentives for new investment without raising the deficit -- should: **********1. Restore the old investment tax credit, which has an excellent track record in stimulating investment. A relatively large credit -- 20 to 25 percent -- is needed to provide a big incentive for new investment. Only investments in productivity-enhancing equipment that would be incrementally above the historical pattern of investment during a selected base period would be eligible. For instance, the average of investment during the last three years could be used, or 90 percent of average to allow for recession-related slippage. This means that the credit would not apply for most investment that would have occurred without it. **********2. Adopt a sliding-scale capital gains tax. This would incorporate a sizable increase in the capital gains tax rate on assets held for short periods, with the rate declining to almost zero for investments held five years or longer. The relatively low long-term rate would apply only to investments in productive assets and not to vacation homes and other unproductive investments. The new tax should apply only to new investments, to avoid losing substantial tax revenues for investments made in the past. This, plus the higher rate on short-term gains, will prevent any significant increase in the deficit. **********3. Incorporate tax changes to stimulate consumption and thus improve the investment climate. This can be done without widening the deficit by shifting the tax burden more to the upper income groups, providing purchasing power to those more likely to spend. Shifting the structure of personal income taxes (for example, Representative Dan Rostenkowski's proposal of new taxes and credits) or raising the Social Security wage ceiling and lowering the tax rate in a revenue-neutral manner, would achieve this objective. These changes would provide tax cuts for the majority of American families, provide a modest stimulus and make the tax structure more progressive. **********4. Increase public investment. A much-needed rebuilding and upgrading of our infrastructure is essential to accelerate growth and improve competitiveness. This can be financed by $10 billion to $20 billion raised by privatizing parts of government-owned energy facilities. For example, privatizing a small part of the Tennessee Valley Authority could help finance high-speed rail in the South. **********This program will help the economy in both the short and the long term without widening the deficit. And it would address the fairness issue more effectively than programs that have come from the Administration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appointed a conservative economist today to be the new Soviet Finance Minister. **********A new Cabinet list released in Parliament and signed by Gorbachev named the economist, Vladimir Orlov, to replace Valentin Pavlov, who was appointed Prime Minister in January. **********Mr. Orlov's appointment must be confirmed by Parliament. **********Mr. Orlov, an advocate of very gradual transition to market economics, is deputy chairman of the Soviet Parliament's Economic Reform Commission. **********The list also indicated that Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov and Vladimir Kryuchkov, head of the K.G.B., seen by radicals as stalwarts of communist orthodoxy, would be retained in their posts. **********The cabinet is the first to be drawn up under new power structures allowing Gorbachev direct control over his ministers and giving him sweeping authority to direct policy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/10/busin.main_headline: Abu Dhabi Is Said to Seize 30 Former B.C.C.I. Officials
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/10/busin.print_headline: Abu Dhabi Is Said to Seize 30 Former B.C.C.I. Officials
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/10/busin.body_text: **********The Government of Abu Dhabi completed a roundup of former executives of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International yesterday, bringing the number of people detained in the two-day sweep to more than 30, according to advisers to the emirate. **********The Abu Dhabi sweep brought in senior executives of the bank, including Swaleh Naqvi, the former chief executive who has been charged with orchestrating the multibillion-dollar fraud that prompted regulators in several countries to seize the bank on July 5, and his successor, Zafar Iqbal. **********The Government did not announce its action, and details from its American and British representatives and news reports from Abu Dhabi were sketchy. But the sweep was interpreted by advisers and former B.C.C.I. executives as an effort by the bank's primary shareholder to discern the depth of the fraud quickly and to show itself to be taking action. **********"The Abu Dhabi authorities have finally woken up and decided to act," said Masihur Rahman, a former chief financial officer of the bank, who has cooperated with American investigators. **********Abu Dhabi's role in the collapse of B.C.C.I. is uncertain. The Government of Abu Dhabi and its ruler, Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahayan, own 77.4 percent of the bank. The emirate protested the seizure of the bank in July, contending that it was not consulted and that the shutdown occurred as it was proceeding with a rescue plan for B.C.C.I. **********But Robin Leigh-Pemberton, the governor of the Bank of England, testified before a parliamentary committee on July 23 that one reason the British central bank pushed for a closing of B.C.C.I. was that "representatives of the main shareholders" were involved in the "massive and widespread fraud." **********Representatives of Abu Dhabi insist that Sheik Zayed and his Government were vigilant in trying to get to the bottom of the fraud. Last December, the Abu Dhabi Government created a "board of investigation" composed of the emirate's financial experts and outside auditors to scrutinize the bank's troubles. **********"The Government of Abu Dhabi has been investigating this matter for a long time in cooperation with other authorities around the world," said W. Caffey Norman 3d, a partner at Patton, Boggs & Blow, a Washington law firm representing the Abu Dhabi shareholders. **********The detention of B.C.C.I. executives began on Sunday, when about 20 officials were summoned to the bank's Abu Dhabi offices, questioned for seven hours in a conference room and then carted away in vans to an undisclosed place, according to a Reuters report from Abu Dhabi. An additional dozen or so B.C.C.I. officials were rounded up yesterday.  Top Officials Detained **********The bank executives being detained include top management personnel, senior regional executives and some internal auditors. It was not clear yesterday whether any of them were formally charged, nor how long they will be detained. Reuters quoted a banking source that it did not identify as saying that families of the executives were told that the abrupt detention was part of an effort to complete the B.C.C.I. inquiry quickly. **********American investigators were somewhat puzzled by the timing of the Abu Dhabi move yesterday. They noted that the central figure, Mr. Naqvi, has been in Abu Dhabi for the last eight months, essentially under house arrest. Mr. Naqvi and about 6,000 private files he kept apparently lie at the heart of B.C.C.I. fraud. **********Mr. Naqvi has been indicted in the United States on fraud charges by a Manhattan grand jury and in Florida on money-laundering charges. Although Abu Dhabi has no extradition treaty with the United States, the Manhattan District Attorney's office is preparing documents to request that Mr. Naqvi be sent to the United States. **********One explanation for the roundup, a banker in Abu Dhabi said, is that Sheik Zayed, after some debate within the Government, has sided with the advocates of more forceful action in the B.C.C.I. case. A British court has given Abu Dhabi until December to decide whether to bail out the bank or allow an institution with more than one million depositors worldwide to be liquidated. **********"They have to get to the bottom of the problem -- the size of the losses and the extent of the misconduct -- before they decide what to do next," the banker said. Estimates of B.C.C.I.'s losses have ranged from $4 billion to $15 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/world.main_headline: Polish Primate Sees U.S. Jews Friday
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/world.print_headline: Polish Primate Sees U.S. Jews Friday
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/world.body_text: **********There may be no empty chairs tomorrow when Jozef Cardinal Glemp of Warsaw, Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, meets with officials of American Jewish organizations in Washington, but there will be some missing faces. **********While Catholic-Jewish cooperation has increased lately, especially in Eastern Europe, some leaders of major Jewish organizations are refusing to meet with Cardinal Glemp, the Archbishop of Warsaw, who is beginning a visit to the United States. **********Since August 1989, Cardinal Glemp has been criticized by leaders of Jewish groups for a sermon they said was laced with anti-Semitic stereotypes. On the Catholic side, the events have provoked disappointment and even exasperation. **********The actions surrounding the Glemp visit have also revealed contrasting and sometimes conflicting differences among Jewish groups about how to conduct interreligious conversations. On Monday, Seymour Reich resigned as head of the International Jewish Committee for Interreligious Consultations, protesting what he described as the group's inability to reach a consensus about meeting with Cardinal Glemp. The committee is an umbrella group of Jewish organizations established to carry on dialogue with the Vatican and other religious bodies.  A Symbolic Rebuke **********Mr. Reich's action was also meant to be a symbolic rebuke to the Jewish groups whose representatives will meet tomorrow with the Cardinal. **********A dozen representatives from six Jewish organizations will attend the meeting. Dr. Eugene Fisher, chief adviser to the American bishops on Catholic-Jewish relations, said. "Most of those with whom we have been in dialogue over the years are coming," he said, adding that the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and one or two individuals were exceptions. **********Cardinal Glemp will visit 14 cities with large Polish-American populations between last night, when he arrived in the United States, and Oct. 7. A similar trip planned for 1989 was canceled after the reaction to his sermon raised the likelihood of demonstrations. **********The gesture by Mr. Reich, a past president of B'nai B'rith International, was a setback to extensive efforts by Catholic and Jewish officials to smooth the Cardinal's trip. **********On Aug. 23, the Cardinal made public a letter to Archbishop Adam Maida of Detroit expressing regret for having suggested in the 1989 sermon that Jewish demonstrators who scaled the walls of a convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp intended harm to the nuns. He also called anti-Semitism an evil "contrary to the spirit of the Gospel." **********Reversing an earlier stance, Cardinal Glemp has supported the shift of the convent to the site of a center for interreligious discussions, now being completed several miles from the former concentration camp. In January he also signed a letter from all Poland's bishops denouncing anti-Semitism and expressing sorrow for past injustices to Jews. **********Prominent Jews like Rabbi Jack Bemporad and Rabbi A. James Rudin, although believing that Cardinal Glemp has still not addressed other aspects of his 1989 sermon, said this week that his more recent statements and actions constitute sufficient "first steps" and evidence of good intentions. **********"I don't see how not meeting with someone would in any way help the relationship between Catholics and Jews," said Rabbi Bemporad of Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y., who is co-chairman of interreligious affairs of the Synagogue Council of America, which represents Reform, Conservative and Orthodox Jews. Rabbi Rudin oversees interreligious affairs at the American Jewish Committee. **********Other leaders disagree with this "quiet diplomacy" approach. Besides Mr. Reich, Abraham H. Foxman, director of the Anti-Defamation League, said Cardinal Glemp should explicitly repudiate for each specific statement he made in his speech, including a historical reference to "the Jewish innkeeper who got peasants drunk" and a suggestion that Jews held the mass media at their "disposal in many countries." **********Rabbi Avraham Weiss of the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale, who led the group invading the convent's grounds in 1989, said on Monday that he was going to pursue a suit for defamation against Cardinal Glemp. **********A paper for the visit written last month by Bishop Henryk Muszynski of Wloclawek, Poland, contrasted "widespread development in the dialogue between Christianity and Judaism" with "increasingly disturbing statements in the United States against the church and the Primate of Poland." **********Bishop Muszynski's concern is considered significant because he heads the Polish bishops' Committee for Dialogue with Judaism and is known to be a major force in getting Poland's hierarchy to issue January's statement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/17/world.main_headline: DISSIDENT IS SEIZED IN SOVIET GEORGIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/17/world.print_headline: THE SOVIET TRANSITION; DISSIDENT IS SEIZED IN SOVIET GEORGIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/17/world.body_text: **********The Georgian Government authorities arrested the leader of the non-parliamentary opposition tonight, an aide said, after thousands of people demonstrated in the streets against the popularly elected authoritarian President of the Caucasus republic. **********President Zviad Gamsakhurdia, who has declared Georgia independent of the Soviet Union, ordered a Moscow-bound plane carrying Georgi Chanturia, head of the National Democratic Party, to return to the airport in Tbilisi, where the police drove him and two aides away, according to one of his assistants. **********"They were going to hold a press conference in Moscow on Tuesday," said Berian Bendelyani, reached by telephone at the party's headquarters. "We don't know where they've been taken." The headquarters is on Tbilisi's Rustaveli Boulevard, which has been blocked by barricades for the last week by the growing opposition to Mr. Gamsakhurdia's rule. Mr. Bendelyani said the arrests had been witnessed by another of the party's leaders.  Vote Was Boycotted **********The 52-year-old Mr. Gamsakhurdia, who served prison sentences under Communist rule for insisting on Georgian independence, was elected with 87 percent of the popular vote in last May's elections, which was boycotted by Mr. Chanturia's party because it was against a vote while Georgia was still effectively under Soviet control. **********But the president has become increasingly sensitive to criticism, denouncing the non-parliamentary opposition, his own former prime minister and foreign minister, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and even President Bush for joining in what he sees as a plot against him to keep Georgia in Soviet hands. **********The rallies in Tbilisi today were the largest in a series that began Sept. 2, when special police forces loyal to Mr. Gamsakhurdia used batons and fired shots at a crowd, wounding 20 people, several of them seriously. **********Mr. Chanturia's party then began blocking the streets nightly, and calling on Mr. Gamsakhurdia to resign. Today Nodar Notadze, the leader of the small opposition in the parliament that was elected last November, told the crowd that the president had lost the moral right to rule on Sept. 2.  Prime Minister Denounced **********He was joined by Tengiz Sigua, the prime minister who resigned last month. Mr. Sigua was recently accused by the president of "trying to create a bloc against me with the chief of the national guard." **********"He must resign," Mr. Sigua said today, according to a report from Tbilisi by the Reuters news agency. "Then we can have rapid land reform, privatization and can guarantee human rights." **********Mr. Gamsakhurdia has said that economic reform cannot begin in Georgia, an ancient nation of 5.5 million people, until the Soviet Union recognizes its independence. Denouncing his non-parliamentary opponents for blocking the streets and causing chaos, he said 10 days ago that "if they commit crimes -- beating, shooting people -- we will punish them." **********Why Mr. Chanturia, whose voice was hoarse from speaking at the nightly rallies, was arrested today was not known. A staff member who answered the telephone in Mr. Gamsakhurdia's office tonight said there was no information about the arrests, which were first reported on the late-night news on Soviet central television.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/13/world.main_headline: A Blood Feud Feeds Unrest In Soviet Area
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/13/world.print_headline: A Blood Feud Feeds Unrest In Soviet Area
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/13/world.body_text: **********The scourge of inter-ethnic vendetta has a bucolic routine to it here in the Caucasus as the Azerbaijani people talk mundanely of "blood for blood" and little mourn the latest death-stained flight of their Armenian neighbors. **********"In these mountains it is a centuries-old habit that we have blood for blood," said Ramiz D. Sadykov, a commander in the local militia. "Among these simple people you can't explain to someone who has just suffered the slaying of a loved one that most of their other neighbors are good people." **********While the outside world puzzles over the latest local flareup of nationalist gunplay and hatred in terms of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's struggle to hold the polyglot Soviet empire together, the Azerbaijani people here perceive an old vendetta mushrooming in less theoretical forms. **********In the tree-shaded tea shop here, one of the centers of political life, they talk of threatened mountain water rights, tragically crossed ethnic roots and fear of the "bearded ones" -- the armed settlers and guerrilla experts who supposedly came from neighboring Armenia and made aggressive enclaves of the few remaining Armenian villages here in Azerbaijan. **********Such an aggressor's role and intent is denied by the Armenian republic, which charges that the Gorbachev Government unfairly sided with pro-Moscow Azerbaijani authorities in directing tank and troop attacks against two minority Armenian villages, Chaykend and Martunashen. **********The villages were flashpoints in a growing pattern of violence in which more than 30 people, including a number of soldiers and police officers, have died in recent raids and ambushes along the border. **********"All this has deep roots and the invisible hand of the Kremlin," said Yusip Akhperov, a local Azerbaijani wary of the Kremlin's military support here lately even though it is directed against armed bands protecting Armenian villages. "This struggle turns on the larger question of whether to keep the union." **********"For us, you see, union has come to mean the same thing as prison -- a psychosis of propaganda in which the Kremlin fills our heads with their needs, not ours," he continued, sipping tea with a half-dozen colleagues.  'We Have to Believe' **********Vaghif Khasumu said across the tea table: "No, no, we have believed in the union for years. We have to believe. Everything comes from the center." **********The Azerbaijani republic has endorsed Mr. Gorbachev's plan for maintaining union while the Armenian government has rejected it. **********The eruption of local village violence saw all the Armenians -- more than 4,000 people -- flee in a matter of days from the two remote villages, 30 mountainous miles south of here. Armenia charged that Soviet and Azerbaijani soldiers, trailed by local looters and rabble-rousers, used a passport check as a provocation to drive the Armenians out in a de facto resettlement. **********But the Gorbachev Government charged that Armenian gangs were the provocateurs in destabilizing the region and refusing to obey the Kremlin's year-old order to disarm. **********The village fighting was part of a pattern of violent resegregation, a great cross-stream of hundreds of thousands of Armenians and Azerbaijanis who began clearing out of each other's home republic because of rising conflict in which hundreds have been killed in the last four years. 100,000 Flee City **********This city of 350,000 itself echoed a year ago with the unrest of the anti-Armenian pogroms in Baku and saw at least 100,000 Armenians flee Gyandzha to safer ground in Armenia and Russia. Underlying all this is the ancient dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh, the large Armenian mountain enclave within Azerbaijan, which, in the Gorbachev era of openness, has been pushing for incorporation with Armenia. **********Government authorities declared the two latest afflicted villages out of bounds to foreign correspondents, and details of this episode remain elusive beyond the initial account of heavy machine-gun fire and rocket attack spreading terror across the landscape. **********The two sides offer accounts differing in all crucial points and totally absolving themselves of blame. But as it now stands, the two villages emptied of Armenians are to be filled with Azerbaijanis who themselves were made refugees in earlier bouts of violence. **********In their conversation in the Gyandzha tea room, the men regularly cited past instances of intermarriage and coexistence with the Armenians. "But since war has come here, it is better to answer to it," said Fikrat Babev. **********"The Armenians thought Soviet power had become a toy, and now they know they were wrong," said Mr. Akhperov, betraying satisfaction with the Kremlin's suddenly active military role in this part of the inter-ethnic strife. But he still contended that the violence was more a phenomenon of modern Communism than ancient vendetta. "We must remember we are 70 years behind civilization because of the Bolsheviks," he said, "and right now Christian Armenians and Muslim Azerbaijanis are simply incapable of living as neighbors." Regional Leaders Meet **********MOSCOW, May 12 (AP) -- President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the leader of the Russian republic, Boris Yeltsin, met for five hours today with leaders of 14 of the 16 small autonomous regions within Russia, news reports said. **********The leaders represent about 20 million of the 147 million people in the huge republic of Russia. **********It was agreed at the meeting that the autonomous regions, based on decisions of their individual legislatures, would sign Mr. Gorbachev's new union treaty as equal parties, the independent Interfax news agency reported. The treaty redefines relations between the central Government and the republics and autonomous regions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/busin.main_headline: Bell Units' Rivals Gain At F.C.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/busin.print_headline: Bell Units' Rivals Gain At F.C.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/busin.body_text: **********In a move that could greatly increase competition for many local telephone companies, the Federal Communications Commission proposed a rule today that would force them to let rivals plug directly into local telephone systems. **********The proposal, which officials hope will be adopted within 12 months, will be a big help for the growing number of operators of high-speed fiber optic lines that bypass the traditional telephone system. These companies allow customers to reach their long-distance carriers at prices considerably lower than the access charges imposed by local telephone companies. Access charges account for about 40 percent of the cost of long-distance service. **********Over the long term, the measure represents an important step in chipping away at the near-total domination of traditional telephone companies in their local markets. Large corporations have begun to consider the newer services in developing local private networks to link their offices. Issues Are Unresolved **********F.C.C. officials said they considered the measure a priority although many issues remained unresolved, particularly those concerning rates that telephone companies would charge for making connections. **********The heart of today's proposal is a requirement that telephone companies with revenues greater than $100 million a year let the aspiring rivals set up switching equipment on or very near their premises. This will cover most local phone companies that serve mid-sized and large cities. At the moment, bypass companies account for less than 1 percent of the local telephone market. **********The measure will mean that a fiber optic company can run lines directly to the neighborhood switching stations and then use the telephone company lines to reach individual customers.  Deeper Market Penetration **********Under the proposal, the telephone companies will have to offer special rates that reflect the narrowed use. As a practical matter, the change will make it economically feasible for the bypass companies to penetrate much more deeply into local markets than they can now. **********At the moment, these rivals serve only customers who are connected directly to their fiber optic lines. These lines are analagous to superhighways: They are excellent for relaying heavy volumes of traffic along a busy corridor, but they do not offer the equivalent of backroads that reach throughout a community. **********Today's proposal will address this "last mile" problem by allowing new providers to run high-speed lines to the telephone company's neighborhood substations scattered around a city. Customers will use the telephone company only for a tiny segment of their service, and use the bypass company for the rest of the service. **********The proposal was greeted enthusiastically by Metropolitan Fiber Systems of Oak Brook, Ill., which operates fiber networks in 11 cities, including New York, and had proposed the new rule. "Over all, we truly do applaud the F.C.C. on the action they have taken," said Royce Holland, chief executive of Metropolitan Fiber. "This is a giant step in opening up this last bastion of monopoly control to competition." **********It was also applauded by long-distance carriers, including both A.T. &T. and the MCI Communications Corporation, which stand to benefit from lower access charges. "This will speed the day when there are more choices for consumers at the local level," said John Houser, an MCI spokesman. "This will speed the day when access charges will be lower," **********The regional Bell companies had mixed reactions. Some have long predicted that competition is inevitable, but some expressed concern about being forced to encourage competition when their prices reflect obligations imposed by state utility commissions. **********"What we're worried about is that we're still restricted as to what markets we are allowed to expand into, while others are now expanding into our markets," said William F. Adler, executive director of Federal regulatory relations in the Washington office of the Pacific Telesis Corporation. Local Companies Restricted **********Unlike their new competitors, who can choose to provide service only through the most lucrative high-traffic areas, the local telephone companies are obligated by state and Federal governments to make service available to everyone in their jurisdictions and to keep prices for residential customer comparatively low. **********The upshot is that prices to residential customers are frequently artificially low, while prices for large corporate customers artificially high. **********Metropolitan Fiber Systems is considered the largest player, with plans to add nine operations by the end of 1992. Other significant providers are New York Teleport of New York City and the Institutional Communications Company in McLean, Va. **********Thus far, competing providers have tended to push down prices on business lines in the markets they have entered. Mr. Holland, of Metropolitan Fiber, said his company usually charged about 10 percent to 20 percent less than the local telephone company, but those prices were eventually matched. **********Mr. Holland said about 18 cities now had a competing provider of local telephone service and that the market would be saturated if his company simply expanded according to its current plan. If the rule is adopted, however, bypass companies would probably be able to generate profits in as many as 50 more cities. **********The F.C.C. took another action intended to lower customers' bills, this one for calls made from the United States to foreign countries. The F.C.C. has long contended that state-owned telephone companies in Europe and Latin America charge excessive prices for receiving calls and that these charges currently drain about $3 billion a year from the United States. **********In the action today, the F.C.C. ordered American long-distance companies to negotiate rates with foreign telephone companies that reflect the declining cost of new technology. If the negotiations do not result in lower rates, F.C.C. officials said they would consider prohibiting Americans from paying rates higher than those it considered fair. **********In moves concering radio broadcasters, the F.C.C. proposed relaxing rules that currently limit a company from owning more than 12 AM and 12 FM stations, as well as rules that bar a company from owning both an AM and FM station in one market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.main_headline: Business and Health; The Drug Makers' Defense on Costs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.print_headline: Business and Health; The Drug Makers' Defense on Costs
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/14/busin.body_text: **********PHARMACEUTICAL executives jousted with Government economists last week over a draft report to Congress that questions the drug industry's main justification for charging thousands of dollars per patient annually for some drugs. **********The companies say they have to set high prices to recoup heavy costs of finding and testing a new drug and obtaining Food and Drug Administration approval. The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group, often cites a 1987 estimate of $231 million. **********Economists at the Office of Technology Assessment, a Congressional advisory bureau, said in the draft report that such numbers were unverifiable, if not meaningless. Critics say the estimates involve guesses about the rates of success and failure in finding new drugs, the time expended, and the cost, in theory, of borrowing money. **********At a meeting last week of the technology office's Advisory Panel on Pharmaceutical Research, drug industry spokesmen insisted that the high estimates were basically correct, even if they could not be verified. "You do know the order of magnitude," said Judy C. Lewent, chief financial officer and vice president with Merck & Company, the world's largest drug company. **********"Success rates are highly dependent on the state of knowledge about a compound at the start" of a research project, said Jacob Stucki, who retired as vice president for research at the Upjohn Company. He said drug companies often had a "much greater success rate with compounds acquired from outside" laboratories. The up-front costs for such drugs and royalties later are not counted with research in company financial statements. **********Ms. Lewent and George B. Rathmann, the retired chairman of Amgen, a biotechnology company in Thousand Oaks, Calif., conceded that not enough was known about the cost of developing a drug. "By the time you get the story right, it's out of date," said Mr. Rathmann, who has moved on to found Icos, a start-up biotechnology company. **********Another panel member, Lewis A. Engman, a Washington lawyer and former president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said that he had often cited the estimates of research costs, but that even ball park figures were enough to show that the number was large. "Granted that there are many variables and we don't know what they are," he said, "does it matter if the estimate is $250 million, or even $400 million?" **********Nancy L. Buc, a Washington lawyer who is a former chief counsel with the F.D.A., identified the political stakes: "If the number is seen as really big, it is less distressing to politicians to allow returns that are seen as perhaps too big." Otherwise, she said, Congress might decide to "tinker with taxes" paid by drug companies. **********At a time of rising alarm about health-care costs, these are not idle concerns. Robert B. Helms, a former executive director of the American Pharmaceutical Institute, an industry-sponsored policy group, said there was talk in Washington of adopting European-style controls on drug prices or even subjecting pharmaceuticals to "public utility regulation." To discourage such ideas, he said, the technology office report should cite the savings that drugs permit by taking the place of even more costly hospital care. **********Economists say the companies spend heavily for research because the payoffs can be enormous. Ms. Lewent of Merck said increased profits would be "chased by research and development costs" as long as the companies had the money. Merck plans to spend $1 billion this year for research and development. Mr. Rathmann, who recently helped raise $30 million for Icos from investors, said they hoped for a return in 10 years of "42 percent compounded." He added: "If there had not been profitability, there would not be a biotech industry today. The products would not be out there." **********Dr. M. Leigh Thompson, a group vice president with Eli Lilly & Company, said medical needs, not economics, were the starting point for drug research. He added that spending on research and development by the drug industry, which was $9.2 billion last year, was less than 2 percent of the $676 billion in national spending on health care. **********Ms. Lewent said, "The science opportunities that the industry now sees are orders of magnitude greater than have been seen for a long time." She added, "The hard core issue" is that pharmaceuticals are "an industry that shows itself to be adding to social returns in a competitive environment." **********But Jeffrey Levi, a representative of AIDS Action, a patient advocacy group, said the Congressional technology office economists should ask: "Are the companies producing drugs that are accessible to the people who need them?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.main_headline: Trade Issues Enter Crucial Political Phase
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.print_headline: WASHINGTON MEMO; Trade Issues Enter Crucial Political Phase
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.body_text: **********At their meeting Thursday, President Bush warned Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu that Congressional concerns over Japanese trade practices could damage the relationship between the two countries. In Houston Sunday, Mr. Bush presumably told President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico that American lawmakers would require Mexico to adopt stronger environmental measures and perhaps take other steps before Congress would accede to a bilateral free-trade pact. **********In part, this is an age-old dance: Lawmakers, prepared to accept a trade accord eventually, appease local interests by threatening to block the agreement. And Presidents, stepping in tune with the music, emphasize the Congressional threats when they try to win overall trade concessions from other countries. **********But these days, beyond the familiar two-step is a genuine political tension between the President and Congress, and it will reach a critical point soon after Congress returns today from a two-week recess. One of the most important orders of business will be the request by Mr. Bush that Congress extend his authority to conduct trade negotiations without line-by-line Congressional review. **********National leaders may disagree about the economic benefits of removing trade barriers, but few doubt that doing so leads to smoother diplomatic relations. President Bush, like every President since World War II, Republican and Democrat, has been a strong advocate of free trade. **********Members of Congress tend to be parochial. If tariffs or import quotas help businesses and protect jobs in their states and districts, lawmakers generally support them, regardless of their international effect. **********It is not coincidental, for example, that South Carolina's Senators -- Strom Thurmond, a Republican, and Ernest F. Hollings, a Democrat -- men who could hardly be less alike in temperament, politics and ideology, are the leading Senate opponents of renewed international trade talks. If those talks are successful, textile imports would probably increase, hurting a major South Carolina industry. **********Two big trade issues are on the table. The first is the resumption of international trade-liberalization talks, which broke down in December but seem ready to resume soon. The talks are held under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The second is President Bush's desire to negotiate a free-trade pact with Mexico like the one President Ronald Reagan made with Canada. **********The outcome of both issues turns on whether Congress extends the "fast track" procedures, which will automatically be extended for another two years unless the House or the Senate votes by June 1 to discontinue them. Under these rules, in effect since the 1970's, the President must consult with Congress before entering into a trade agreement, and Congress has the authority to approve or disapprove the eventual agreement, but Congress may not amend it. **********An unusual Congressional coalition is trying to block extension of the rules: ***********Democrats who are on shaky ground after the Persian Gulf war and want to look tough on a foreign-policy issue. ***********Lawmakers from the Rust Belt who fear that a Mexican trade agreement would encourage manufacturing companies and jobs to move across the border. ***********Those from farm and textile states who believe the GATT negotiations will reduce the protection American farmers and textile companies now have. ***********Those (primarily from Florida and California) who want to avoid competition from Mexican fruit and vegetable growers. 'Point of Leverage' **********"Fast track is the only point of leverage that exists now, because the Administration needs it to proceed," Representative Byron Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat, said in an interview. "So all of us who oppose one thing or another have joined forces." **********Mr. Dorgan, who bows to few others in adhering to liberal principles, is worried about his home-state farmers. He is the principal sponsor of the House resolution to stop continuation of the fast-track rules. **********One anomaly is that the issue has pitted liberal Democratic politicians against the majority of liberal Democratic economists, who consider the law of comparative advantage as fundamental. This precept holds that a nation should specialize in producing and exporting goods that it can make at a relatively lower cost and import goods for which it is a relatively high-cost producer. **********"Protectionist measures usually rob from the many to give to the few and harm the efficiency of the world economy in the bargain," wrote Alan S. Blinder, a prominent economics professor at Princeton, in his 1987 book, "Hard Heads, Soft Hearts." **********Increasingly, politicians are taking issue with liberal economic doctrine. "Academics are just out of touch with the everyday concerns of working families," a Democratic strategist said. "They are indifferent to who makes the laptop computer on which they compose their free-trade arguments." **********Charles L. Schultze, a top economist in the Johnson and Carter Administrations who is now at the Brookings Institution, dismisses arguments like that with the observation that politicians invariably go out of their way not to inflict direct harm, even if the indirect harm they spread is much more severe. **********In the last decade, a small number of prominent economists, many of whom have ties to organized labor, have developed the view that free trade may be an outdated notion. After all, they note, Japan has fared pretty well with one of the most restrictive trade policies in the world. **********One of these economists, Jeff Faux, president of the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research center in Washington, says the law of comparative advantage only holds when there is full employment and thus a new job for anyone who loses one.  The Effect on Jobs **********"When you look at the history of people who have been knocked out of jobs by imports," Mr. Faux said in an interview, "they haven't climbed the ladder into better, more productive jobs. They've stayed out of work or moved down the ladder to worse jobs." **********For their part, politicians tend to be swayed by constituents, not theories. Take Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee. He has not been averse in his career to carrying the legislative water for important constituents, like oil and gas producers. Now he is a strong advocate of a Mexican free-trade pact. Why? Largely, his colleagues say, because the Texas border towns, among the poorest communities in the nation, would benefit from increased commerce. **********Mr. Bentsen, whose committee handles trade matters, is expected to call for a vote in the next few weeks on a measure sponsored by Mr. Hollings that would block the fast-track procedures. But Mr. Bentsen's colleagues say he will do so at a time when the Hollings measure is sure of losing rather than allow Mr. Hollings to bring it to a vote at a time more favorable to him.  Gephardt's Role **********On the other side of Capitol Hill, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, is a leader in the fight for trade restrictions. Mr. Gephardt comes from St. Louis, which is threatened with the loss of manufacturing jobs to Mexico, where the average wage is one-seventh of that in the United States. **********Over the years, Mr. Gephardt has metamorphosed from being a back-bench Congressman who rode the trade issue to prominence to being an unsuccessful Presidential candidate in 1988 who based his campaign on the trade issue to his current status as House majority leader with considerable influence over trade legislation. Many colleagues believe he is planning another run for the Presidency next year. **********Given President Bush's popularity and the support he enjoys on the trade issue from House Republicans, opponents of the fast-track rules have an uphill fight. They almost certainly cannot win unless Mr. Gephardt takes a prominent role, and even then the odds are against them. **********The prevailing view in the Capitol is that Mr. Gephardt will continue to speak out on trade, but that when push comes to shove he will probably back off and not support the Dorgan resolution. **********"If Gephardt is going to do something to take on the President," said one Democrat who has talked to him about the matter, "he wants to win. He doesn't want to go head to head with Bush and lose." **********Some lawmakers suggested that the Ways and Means Committee might bottle up the disapproval resolution so that it never reached a vote by the full House. **********"They'd be complaining on the floor and thanking me in the cloakroom for not making them vote," said Representative Sam M. Gibbons, a Florida Democrat and a committed free-trader who heads the trade subcommittee. **********"Down deep in their bellies," Mr. Gibbons said, "they know free trade is the right thing."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Loss at TV Broadcaster
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/busin.body_text: **********Pinelands Inc., the parent company of the television station WWOR, said today that it lost $2.1 million in the first quarter despite a 5.8 percent increase in revenues. WWOR is an independent station broadcasting in the New York City area. Pinelands said its revenues in the three months that ended on March 31 were $34.3 million. In the first quarter of 1990 the company had a loss of $685,000 on revenues of $32.4 million. Provisions for income taxes and increased operating expenses were blamed for the higher loss.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/world.main_headline: Bush Appeal to Addis Ababa Clears Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/world.print_headline: Bush Appeal to Addis Ababa Clears Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/25/world.body_text: **********Israel began transporting 16,000 Ethiopian Jews to Israel today in an intensive airlift that had secretly been agreed to by a besieged Ethiopian Government on the brink of collapse. **********With rebel forces now within eight miles of the capital and gunfire ringing out, Israeli and Ethiopian planes took off at the rate of two an hour through the day and night, each carrying about 350 of the Jews. **********Israelis supervising the evacuation of what are believed to be the last Ethiopian Jews in the country said they expected the operation to end on Saturday. The Jews are black Africans and members of Beta Israel, or the House of Israel. In 1973, Israel traced their ancestry to biblical times, establishing their right to immigrate to Israel, but the Ethiopian Government barred their departure for political reasons.  Schedule Is a Secret **********Because of fears that the safety of the Jews could be imperiled by those who resent their free departure and envy the benefits that they have received from the Israeli Embassy while waiting to go, the schedule for their evacuation had been a closely held secret. **********The complex logistics for the flights had been in place for weeks, but Israeli officials said today that a letter from President Bush to the new Ethiopian leadership on Thursday provided the breakthrough that persuaded officials here to allow the Jews to leave all at once. **********Early this morning, Israeli relief workers went to the neighborhood where the Jews have been housed since being brought here beginning last August from traditional areas outside the capital. The Israelis entered the mud huts, waking families to tell them that the time had come for them to go.  A Moment of Panic **********A near panic broke out as the Jews were told to board buses for the Israeli Embassy, where they were assigned flights for the 1,800-mile journey to Tel Aviv. But Israeli guards in plainclothes and Ethiopian soldiers bearing Kalashnikov assault rifles and sticks managed to calm the crowd. **********Among the first aboard the buses to the airport was a boy born only a few hours earlier. The mother said she named him Israel. **********Demelash Aysheshin, a 21-year-old Ethiopian Jewish teacher, compared the exodus to the departure of the ancient Jews from Egypt, led by Moses. "Isaiah's prophecy has finally been fulfilled," he said. "All Israelites can now return to Canaan, the land of our forefathers."  'It's a Miracle' **********"It's a miracle," said Asher Naim, Israel's Ambassador to Ethiopia. **********With the position of the Ethiopian Government deteriorating in the last month, the Jews had essentially become bargaining chips. Before his flight into exile on Tuesday, President Mengistu Haile Mariam ordered their emigration slowed, hoping to gain arms from Israel and perhaps aid from Washington in exchange for a controlled departure. **********Israeli diplomats said the bottleneck ended after President Bush sent a letter to the Acting President, Lieut. Gen. Tesfaye Gebre-Kidan, saying that the United States would help mediate a settlement to the civil war in return for the immediate emigration of all the Jews. **********In a last-ditch attempt to hold the line against the steady rebel advance and negotiate something other than an unconditional surrender, General Gebre-Kidan agreed, diplomats said. State Department and White House officials also pressed representatives of the rebels to halt their advance on the capital until the Jews were safely off the ground. The rebels reportedly agreed shortly before midnight on Thursday. Mass Emigration Began in 1984 **********The mass emigration of Jews from Ethiopia began with a clandestine airlift in 1984. In that effort, called Operation Moses, 12,000 Jews were relocated until disclosure of the operation brought Ethiopia under criticism from Arab neighbors, causing Addis Ababa to halt the airlift. **********The flow of Jews from Ethiopia resumed in 1989 at a rate of a few hundred a month, when Israel and Ethiopia restored diplomatic ties after a 16-year hiatus. Ethiopia cut off the flow intermittently in an effort to obtain Israeli arms. The current effort is called Operation Solomon, after the ancient King of Israel. **********Ethiopian Jewish tradition holds that the Jews descended from the leading families of Jerusalem who accompanied Menelik, son of Solomon and the Queen of Sheba, on his journey to Africa. **********The origins of the Ethiopian Jews is still debated. Some biblical experts suggest that they are descendants from the lost tribe of Dan, while anthropologists say they might have migrated from Egypt or Yemen. In the 18th century, they faced the threat of death for their beliefs, but by the 20th century their freedom of religion greatly improved.  Religious Practices From Bible **********Their religious practices come from the Bible, and until recent years they were unaware of Jewish practices derived from the Talmud or relatively modern rabbinical teachings. Ethiopian Jews sacrifice goats and lambs at Passover, and Saturday Sabbath services incorporate rituals unknown to Jews outside Ethiopia. **********On one of the buses leaving today, an 18-year-old boy named David Degafan said that, once he reached Israel, he would study to be a doctor. "In the letters we receive from our families, they tell us to come quickly," he said. "They say Israel is a beautiful country." **********Around him, mothers dressed in ornate shawls and embroidered pleated dresses calmed their babies with tin cups of milk and water. A few men waved off flies with traditional swatters made from the bleached white hair of monkey tails. **********The Jews later huddled on the airport tarmac surrounded by Israeli guards with pistols tucked in their pants and larger-caliber weapons hidden in backpacks. As the Ethiopian Jews waited for their El Al and Ethiopian Airlines charter flights, in the distance Ethiopian soldiers unpacked sacks of grains from military cargo planes.  'You Have to Hold Their Hands' **********"I am very anxious to see Israel for myself," said Shemlis Bitaw, a 65-year-old man who wore a copper hoop earring and a bright orange and green scarf around his head like a turban. "I want to find a patch of land and plant cabbage as a farmer." **********Israeli officials said two planes an hour -- C-130's, Boeing 747's, Boeing 727's and Boeing 757's -- would work through the Jewish Sabbath until all the Jews were gone. **********Ethiopian Jews have worked as blacksmiths, weavers and potters. The gap between their culture and the modern world was illustrated with almost disastrous effect last year when some of them tried to start a fire to make lunch in the back of an aircraft taking them to Israel. **********Ambassador Naim said the emigration would force major adjustments for them and the Government of Israel. "You have to hold their hands and tell them how to use a toilet and a refrigerator," he said. "You need a social worker for every three or four families." **********He said resettlement would cost Israel hundreds of millions of dollars a year. "We told them it wouldn't be an easy adjustment," he said. "But they don't care. They want to come to Israel."  HOW AIRLIFT CAME ABOUT **********BOSTON, May 24 (Special to The New York Times) -- The airlift of the Ethiopian Jews came about after two separate appeals from President Bush to the Ethiopian Government, the White House said today. **********Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said Mr. Bush, who was in Boston today to speak to a foreign trade group, wrote to President Mengistu in April urging the release of the 16,000 Jews and followed up with a cable to Addis Ababa on Wednesday. **********The first letter was delivered by Rudy E. Boschwitz, the former Minnesota Senator who was serving as the President's envoy to Ethiopia at the time and was charged with two missions: to try to arrange a conference between the Ethiopian Government and rebel groups and to deliver the letter, Mr. Fitzwater said. **********The conference will be held in London on Monday. **********The United States also had been working behind the scenes with the Israeli Government, Mr. Fitzwater said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel telephoned Mr. Bush about 11 A.M. today, while the President was aboard Air Force One, "to thank him for the American role in the release" of the Jews, he said. **********"We have been informed that the operation is proceeding smoothly," Mr. Fitzwater said, adding that Mr. Bush was "delighted" by the news. "We want to express our appreciation to Acting President Tesfaye Gebre-Kidan of Ethiopia," he said, adding that the White House understood that the Ethiopian decision to allow the Jews to leave "was taken in reponse to a letter from President Bush." **********Mr. Fitzwater said the United States had not talked to Israeli officials about where the Ethiopian Jews would settle. The United States and Israel have been at odds over the continued establishment of settlements in the occupied territories.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/25/busin.body_text: **********Columbia Gas System Inc., the embattled utility that serves 15 mid-Atlantic states, said it missed a $10 million short-term debt payment today, its second default in less than a week. **********The company said Wednesday that Columbia and its pipeline subsidiary might seek bankruptcy protection unless they could renegotiate bank credit lines and their natural-gas purchase contracts that are well above current market prices. **********Columbia missed a $15 million payment the next day on commercial paper and short-term notes in what analysts called a move to save cash. **********Bill McLaughlin, a Columbia Gas spokesman, declined to elaborate on the latest default, except to say that the company's officers "are working hard to obtain continuing bank financing and to address various issues including short-term paper and other short-term maturities." **********He said Columbia's other commercial paper and short-term notes do not come due until July 8. **********The company, based in Wilmington, Del., has said it is facing severe problems because it signed long-term contracts to buy natural gas at prices that are now far above the market level. **********Gas prices have fallen to a 15-year low of about $1.30 a thousand cubic feet, but Columbia has been paying as much as $6.70 under contracts written in the 1980's. **********The utility has estimated its losses from the contracts at $1 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/20/world.main_headline: DOUBTS OF BRITISH ON EUROPE KINDLED
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/20/world.print_headline: DOUBTS OF BRITISH ON EUROPE KINDLED
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/20/world.body_text: **********Angry doubts about Britain's future in a united Europe have been raised again in this country after the European Community threatened to take legal action to halt seven major British construction projects, including a high-speed rail link between London and the new English Channel tunnel, on environmental grounds. **********British officials said environmental consequences had been fully considered in the planning of all the projects where construction is already under way. In addition to the proposed high-speed rail corridor between London and the Channel, the projects in question include two expressway extensions, a bridge approach and three private industrial sites. **********Although officials at the European Commission's headquarters in Brussels said that they only wanted the British Government to prove that it had complied fully with a 1988 community directive on the environmental impacts of all major projects on the British Government, ministers and other critics of the European union have accused the community of meddling. **********The dispute underscores the political and legal difficulties as Europe begins to move tentatively toward a federal system, governed by uniform regulations and standards.  Environmentalists Protest **********The European Community became involved in the dispute after protests by British environmentalists and local groups, which argued that the Government headed by Prime Minister John Major had not published detailed environmental impact statements as required under a directive agreed to by all community members. **********If the European Commission, the community's year-round executive arm, concludes that the environmental assessments were not made according to its regulations, it could seek an injunction halting construction and ask the European Community's Court of Justice to render a final judgment on whether the projects represent a threat to the environment. **********David Howell, a senior member of Parliament from Mr. Major's Conservative Party, said the dispute proved that the community's powers must be restricted rather than expanded. "They are our servants, not our masters," he said in an interview published Friday in the Evening Standard, a London newspaper. **********Prime Minister Major has been attempting to avoid a divisive battle within Conservative ranks over the issue of European unity, mindful that a sizable contingent in the party is leery of yielding parts of British sovereignty in order to create a larger European political and economic union that might eventually include a common currency or military policy. **********Mr. Major must call a general election sometime before next summer.  Letter From Brussels **********Immediately at issue in the dispute over the construction projects is a letter sent to the British Government on Thursday from Carlo Ripa di Meana, the community's commissioner for the environment. Mr. di Meana said London had failed to follow community procedures in the way it assessed environmental effects of the projects. **********British officials chose the final route for the Channel rail link only 10 days ago, a decision that brought accusations that the decision had been made on political grounds. **********The Conservatives decided to abandon the route orginally chosen by British Rail, in part, because it cut through several communities south of London where there are substantial Conservative majorities. Instead, they chose a route that runs east from London, through less sparsely populated regions, including marshlands that critics say are environmentally fragile. **********Among the other projects under question is a bridge approach that is planned to cut through an 8,000-year-old forest in Greenwich, southeast of central London, as well as three private industrial undertakings: a hospital incincerator, a soft-drink factory and a refinery.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/29/world.main_headline: The 'The' That Brought Mideast Rivals to Table
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/29/world.print_headline: THE MIDDLE EAST TALKS; The 'The' That Brought Mideast Rivals to Table
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/29/world.body_text: **********One word deliberately left out of the text of the Security Council resolution on the framework for resolving the 1967 Arab-Israeli war has provoked considerable disagreement through the years, but in a way it has also made this week's peace talks in Madrid possible. **********On the one hand, the ambiguous wording of Resolution 242 is a product of the equally ambiguous interpretations of the 1967 Middle East war. **********Israel and its supporters state unequivocally that Egypt and Syria were about to attack Israel, and that Jordan joined in the war after it began. They assert that Israel had no choice but to strike pre-emptively and to destroy the Arab air forces on the ground, opening the way to an incredible six-day defeat of Egypt, Syria and Jordan and leaving Israel in control of the Sinai, the Golan Heights, the Gaza Strip, the West Bank of the Jordan and east Jerusalem. **********But the Arab nations deny that war was inevitable and argue that Israel's pre-emptive strike against them actually meant that Israel started the war and gained control over all that territory through aggression. Ambiguity Was No Accident **********Resolution 242, adopted in November 1967, was the result of months of negotiations in which the United States and the Soviet Union played major roles. It was an effort to come up with a document that met the Arabs' desire for the return of their captured lands, and Israel's insistence that it was now time for the Arabs to end their state of war with Israel and to recognize it. For this resolution to pass, it was necessary that it be ambiguous. **********The resolution calls for "withdrawal of Israeli armed forces from territories occupied in the recent conflict." But because the resolution calls for withdrawal of Israel "from territories," Arabs have remained free to insist that Israel must pull out of all of the West Bank, the Gaza Strip, the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem. But the vagueness of the sentence also lets the Israeli Government say the resolution means only that they have to return parts of the occupied territories -- something they say they have already done by giving the Sinai back to Egypt after the 1979 peace treaty. **********In this, the Israelis are supported by Arthur J. Goldberg, who was the United States representative to the United Nations in 1967. He wrote later that the omission of the words "the" or "all" "were not accidental." He said "the resolution speaks of withdrawal from occupied territories without defining the extent of withdrawal." **********But William B. Quandt, a former National Security Council official and now an analyst with the Brookings Institute, a study center, said "one thing everyone agreed on at the time was that the phrase referred to territories on each front of the war -- the Egyptian, the Jordanian and the Syrian fronts -- and was not just relevant to Sinai. **********"Israel knew that perfectly well," he added. "It was only when the Likud party came to power that it redefined it as only referring to Sinai." **********Israel's present Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, heads the Likud party that first came to power in 1977.  A Shot at Prevailing **********Since this week's peace conference is being framed around Resolution 242, the Israelis and the Arabs alike have agreed to attend, in part, because each believes it stands a chance to win vindication if its view of the resolution is transcendant. **********But the divergent views of Resolution 242 were never plainer than when Palestinian and Israeli leaders spoke about this on Sunday on the ABC News program "This Week." **********Haider Abdel-Shafi, the Gaza Strip doctor who leads the Palestinian delegation, said Israeli "withdrawal should be almost total from all the occupied territories." **********He continued, "And the argument that the withdrawal from Sinai would be enough or it is substantial -- well, Sinai is one thing and Palestine is something else." **********But the Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, insisted that "Resolution 242 talks about withdrawal from territories and not 'the' territories. That was a subject that was discussed at the time, and the absence of the word 'the' is quite deliberate and not accidental."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/busin.main_headline: Dow Off 10.73, to 3,045.62, in Light Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/busin.print_headline: Dow Off 10.73, to 3,045.62, in Light Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/busin.body_text: **********Stocks closed lower yesterday in light trading as investors worried that the Fed would not cut its discount rate soon with the Government's quarterly refunding beginning today. Easier credit would buoy economic and corporate growth, many traders believe. **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 10.73 points to finish at 3,045.62. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 155.7 million, down from 206.5 million shares traded on Friday, as declining issues outpaced gainers by 974 to 658. **********Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers, described yesterday's market performance as not the most sterling. "There will not be much coming data from Washington this week, he said. The focus will now turn to the refunding by the Treasury and possible Fed action because of the absence of economic news and because third-quarter corporate earnings results are largely over." **********The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was down 1.04, to 390.28, with the Big Board composite off 0.58, to 215.43. Trading on the American Stock Exchange lowered that composite by 2.75 points, to 384.10. **********The Nasdaq composite index was down 3.43, to 537.50, while the Russell 2000, a narrow measure of small stocks, was down 0.76, to 183.86. **********Initially, stocks opened lower, and losses widened as bonds slipped in a moderate selloff ahead of the Treasury's refunding. Analysts said some investors were cashing in after last Friday's sluggish report on jobs and a decline in the index of leading economic indicators showed a stumbling recovery. **********Investors are expected to remain mainly on the sidelines during most of the week, because they are uncertain whether the Fed is going to act and therefore are not sure what tack to take. **********In market activity, Compaq Computer, hurt by the recession and increased competition, fell 1 1/8, to 26 3/4, after The Houston Chronicle reported over the weekend that James M. Harris, a co-founder, and two other senior executives had left the company. On Friday the company sent out the first layoff notices that are going to 1,400 employees. **********Shares of Agouron Pharmecuticals closed unchanged at 18, after the company said it had received approval from the United States Food and Drug Administration to begin tests on human beings of a psoriasis treatment. The stock was as high as 18 1/2 yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/25/world.main_headline: Excerpts From Address by Saddam Hussein
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/25/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: IRAQI STATEMENT; Excerpts From Address by Saddam Hussein
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/25/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from an address today over the Baghdad radio by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, as monitored and translated by The Associated Press here: **********O great Iraqi people! O brave men of our heroic armed forces! O faithful and noble people, wherever you are, among the sons of our nation and humanity! **********At the time when the United Nations Security Council decided to discuss the Soviet peace initiative, which we endorsed, the treacherous committed treachery. The despicable Bush and his treasonous agent Fahd, and all those who supported them in committing crimes, shame, and aggression, committed the treachery. **********Those cowards who have perfected the acts of treachery, treason and vileness, committed treachery after they departed from every path of virtue, goodness and humanity. They have committed treachery and launched their ground offensive on a wide scale Sunday morning at our armed forces. **********They even betrayed those who along with them signed the infamous resolutions which were adopted at the United Nations Security Council prior to the military aggression against our country. **********They deluded themselves that by those resolutions, they were protecting international legitimacy. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/11/busin.main_headline: Drexel's Bankruptcy Plan Offers Creditors $2.1 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/11/busin.print_headline: Drexel's Bankruptcy Plan Offers Creditors $2.1 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/11/busin.body_text: **********Almost 15 months after the powerful investment house of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. collapsed, it proposed a reorganization yesterday under which it would emerge from bankruptcy as a much smaller company. **********Under the plan, about $2.1 billion would be distributed to the thousands of creditors and other claimants of the firm, which has assets of about $2.48 billion. The money would cover all the lawsuits filed against the firm involving securities law. Among the suits is a multibillion-dollar claim by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, stemming from the savings and loan crisis. **********The agreements are subject to a resolution of a $5 billion claim against the firm that was brought this year by the Internal Revenue Service. Federal Judge Milton Pollack, one of two judges overseeing the case, has criticized the I.R.S. claim as overblown. **********The firm also faces other steps before the plan can take effect. After some preparatory steps, the reorganization plan will be presented for a vote of 14,000 creditors. If approved, it could be confirmed by the court by the end of 1991. **********Drexel reached an agreement in principle with its creditors and claimants in February, when Judge Pollack threatened to liquidate the company if a resolution was not worked out. That tentative plan received the approval of all but one of the creditor and equity committees last month. The plan cannot take effect unless all the committees approve it. **********Many details in an outline of the agreement, which was in a filing said to be more than 400 pages long, were not immediately available. But Judge Pollack issued a statement outlining the plan. **********He said the reorganized company -- which would be temporarily named Newco -- would have initial assets with an expected value of $300 million to $400 million. Those assets will consist primarily of Drexel's securities positions, which are relatively illiquid. Such investments, which are extremely difficult to sell. **********The new company would have about 20 employees, in contrast to the 10,000 people the firm employed at its height. **********The creditors and claimants would receive much of their money through a liquidating trust. Drexel's interest in investment partnerships and business partnerships would be held in separate entities for the claimants and creditors. **********Three trustees approved by the creditors committees and other claimants would run the liquidating trust. Among other responsibilities, the liquidating trust would defend against disputed claims and dispose of assets. **********The plan, drawn up after months of intense negotiations with the creditors committees and other claimaints, would allow Drexel to survive, first to manage its own troubled assets and then stay in the investment advisory business, focusing on financially troubled companies. **********Drexel, a third-tier firm until the 1980's, built itself into one of the most powerful forces on Wall Street during that decade, riding on the profits from its "junk bond" financings, many of which were used for corporate takeovers. But the power had come in part from criminal activities at the firm's junk bond division, headed by Michael R. Milken, who was sentenced to 10 years in prison for securities law violations. **********In 1989, Drexel pleaded guilty to six felony charges stemming from actions taken by Mr. Milken and others in the junk bond division, and agreed to pay $650 million to settle the charges. By February 1990, Drexel's parent sought protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law. **********Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., the parent of the brokerage subsidiary that made its fortune in the junk bond market, filed for bankruptcy in February 1990. Numerous subsidiaries, including the brokerage firm, subsequently filed for bankruptcy.
