https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/12/busin.main_headline: Germany Holds to Rates Despite Inflation Surge
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/12/busin.print_headline: Germany Holds to Rates Despite Inflation Surge
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/12/busin.body_text: **********The German central bank decided today not to raise its key interest rates, a move that appears to signal a priority on international economic concerns and not containing inflation, at least for now. **********By keeping its rates unchanged despite a recent surge in German inflation, the Bundesbank confounded the expectations of many financial market participants. The decision pushed the dollar sharply higher in foreign exchange trading and may have cleared the way for Britain and the United States to lower their key lending rates soon in a bid to hasten the recovery of their economies. **********But many experts believe the Bundesbank's central bank council, which establishes policy, will lift rates after its five-week summer recess ends on Aug. 15, particularly if inflation continues to heat up and eastern Germany's economic woes worsen. **********Speculation that a rate increase was imminent was fueled by figures on Tuesday showing that Germany's inflation rate climbed to a 3.5 percent annual rate in June, compared with a 3 percent rate in May. Pohl's Last Council Meeting **********The council was led for the last time by Karl Otto Pohl, the Bundesbank's president, whose resignation will take effect at the end of July. The council left Germany's discount rate at 6.5 percent and the short-term Lombard rate at 9 percent. The two rates were last changed in late January. **********In what is seen as a mild tightening of monetary policy, the bank did revise downward its 1991 targets for growth of Germany's M-3 money supply, the nation's broadest monetary measure. The target corridor was moved down to 3 percent to 5 percent annual growth, rather than 4 to 6 percent. **********Finance Minister Theo Waigel said the move did not represent a change of course. "The revision of the money supply goal is not linked to any change in the Bundesbank's monetary policy," he said. **********The Bundesbank's lack of action on interest rates may also reflect a desire not to create friction before the economic summit meeting this weekend in London of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations, rather than new-found sensitivity to complaints from the Bush Administration or Germany's European trading partners, economists said. Chastising by Brady **********Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has repeatedly chastised the Bundesbank for its rigid anti-inflation policy, which be believes is inhibiting chances for economic recovery in other European nations and in the United States. But bankers in Frankfurt said the Bundesbank would not hesitate to raise rates if it believed inflation was getting out of hand, regardless of international pressure. **********"It all depends on where inflation is when the council comes back from vacation," said Hans D. Roth, director of the Manufacturers Hanover Bank G.m.b.H. in Frankfurt. "If it is over 4 percent, the Bundesbank will probably do what it always does and raise rates." **********Germany's leading economic research institutes are forecasting that inflation will rise to a 4 percent annual rate in the last quarter of 1991. That prognosis is based on the inflationary effect of higher taxes on some consumer items such as motor fuels that took effect on July 1, as well as growing inflationary pressure in eastern Germany. **********Inflation in eastern Germany, where price and rent controls are being eliminated, is nearly five times as high as in western Germany. In May, inflation in eastern Germany was running at a 14.6 percent annual rate, according to the Federal Statistics Office. June figures are not yet available.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/23/busin.body_text: **********The New York Telephone Company today proposed a reorganization plan under which it would be barred from doing business with virtually every other subsidiary of the Nynex Corporation, its parent company said. The move is intended to avoid the types of situations that led to wild parties involving Nynex employees and potential vendors. **********The New York Telephone plan would expand the 11-member board of directors by adding two non-company people. That would create a 13-member board with 10 members from outside the utility. **********The plan also would create a statewide consumer council to advise the board, and it would link the salaries of top company officers to New York Telephone's performance. Those salaries are now based on the performance of Nynex and New York Telephone. **********Peter Muller, a New York Telephone spokesman, said the provision would prevent the utility from dealing with companies like the Materiel Enterprises Company, a purchasing subsidiary that gave parties in Florida for potential vendors, including Nynex employees. **********The Public Service Commission ordered the study last fall.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/world.main_headline: Market Unmoved by Iraqi Export Action
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/world.print_headline: Market Unmoved by Iraqi Export Action
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/20/world.body_text: **********The world oil market appeared to take little notice of the United Nations' decision yesterday to allow Iraq to resume limited exports, because buyers had been expecting the move for weeks. But experts said Iraq could still cause a price jolt, because President Saddam Hussein might not go along with the conditions tied to the sale or because bureaucratic problems could delay exports. **********In the long term, however, a return of Iraqi oil to world markets would tend to push prices lower, and some analysts believe that this United Nations decision, which covers a six-month period, is likely to be the beginning of uninterrupted sales by Iraq. **********The United Nations said Iraq could export $1.6 billion worth of oil over six months, which at current prices comes to about 500,000 barrels a day. This is a substantial increment on world markets; for example, the combined quotas of all the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is now 22.3 million barrels a day. OPEC is scheduled to meet on Tuesday in Vienna, and the organization may set a new quota based on anticipated demand for oil and production from around the world, including Iraq. **********Before the war, Iraq's quota was 3.14 million barrels a day, but according to Thomas Blakeslee, an oil expert at Pegasus Econometric Group, of Hoboken, N.J., "they need approximately $1 billion in parts to get production back up to those levels." Mr. Blakeslee said 500,000 barrels a day is the maximum that the country could export now; others put the figure slightly higher. **********The exports would be through a pipeline across Turkey, which before the war handled 1.2 million barrels a day, according to Mr. Blakeslee. **********Iraq will face problems in re-entering world markets, experts say. "All the other sellers have locked their markets up," said Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, in New York. "They're going to have to force their way into the system," he said. Normally an exporter can offer a buyer continuity, he pointed out, but all Iraq can offer is price, so the price will probably be lower than usual. **********On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil promised for delivery next month closed yesterday at $21.76 a barrel, down 8 cents. Before the war, Kirkuk crude, the type that Iraq would be exporting, usually sold for $2.75 to $3 a barrel below the price on the Mercantile Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/world.main_headline: P.L.O. Ousts Top Official From Main Policy Body
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/world.print_headline: P.L.O. Ousts Top Official From Main Policy Body
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/world.body_text: **********The Palestine National Council, the highest legislative body of the Palestine Liberation Organization, dropped Abu Abbas, whom Washington accuses of being a terrorist leader, from its ruling executive council today, apparently to meet American conditions for resuming a dialogue with the P.L.O. **********Yasir Arafat, chairman of the P.L.O., told a news conference that the resignation of Abu Abbas met United States conditions for a resumption of the dialogue cut off last year. He called on Washington to resume direct talks with the P.L.O. **********Abu Abbas, the head of the Baghdad-based Palestine Liberation Front, is accused by American officials of being behind a failed raid by Palestinian guerrillas on a Tel Aviv beach on May 30, 1990. Because of the refusal of the P.L.O. to condemn the attack or to punish or to dismiss Abu Abbas, Washington broke off the dialogue, which it had begun with the P.L.O in late 1988. **********Mr. Arafat refused to meet the condition of condemning the attack and insisted that Abu Abbas's removal was all that was necessary.  Awaiting U.S. Response **********"Now the ball is in the other court, in the American court, since this was the main reason for suspending the dialogue, Abu Abbas," Mr. Arafat said. "I am now waiting and expecting something from the American Administration. I hope to resume the dialogue. Please?" **********[ In Washington, a senior State Department official said that not only had the Palestine National Council not met the original American conditions, but that the United States refusal to talk to the P.L.O. was also based on that group's support for Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.  ] **********Mr. Arafat said the Israeli conditions set down for the convening of a peace conference were unacceptable, but refused to say whether the conditions, if adhered to, would result in a P.L.O. condemnation of the U.S.-brokered meeting. Arafat Re-elected President **********The Israeli Government has demanded that any Palestinian delegation be part of a joint Jordanian delegation. Israeli officials refuse to meet with anyone formally linked with the P.L.O., which they brand a terrorist organization. The Israelis also refuse to accept Palestinian delegates from East Jerusalem or the notion of land for peace as a precondition for any conference. **********These demands were bitterly denounced by Mr. Arafat, who was re-elected president of the State of Palestine at the conference. **********"If the American Administration, because of the Israeli lobby, says yes to Israeli conditions, fine," Mr. Arafat said, "but I don't have to say yes." **********"Give me an example in history when your opponent names your delegation?" he asked. **********He said it was the job of the Americans to curb the demands of their "spoiled, naughty baby Israel."  Jordan Could Be Partner **********Although he demanded that the P.L.O. name any delegation, Mr. Arafat did not rule out the possibility of a joint delegation with Jordan. **********"This is still under discussion," he said. **********Palestinian officials in Algiers are optimistic that the P.L.O. will eventually sanction the participation of Palestinians in a peace conference. They also hope to wrest as much as they can from the Bush Administration during the preliminary talks now being held between Palestinian leaders from the West Bank and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. **********"We give our hand as a brave people," Mr. Arafat said. "We do not surrender to Israeli conditions, which our people and the people of the Arab countries refuse." No Demand on Settlements **********"They want to make peace with whom?" he asked of the Israelis. "Qatar?" **********Mr. Arafat, while calling for an end to the building of Jewish settlements in the occupied territories, did not demand a freeze on the construction of settlements as a precondition for any conference. **********He said he was simply voicing his support for the Bush Administration's policy on settlements. **********"When we call to stop settlements, we call to stop an illegal operation," he said. **********In an effort to reach out to liberal sectors in Israeli society Mr. Arafat praised a letter he received from 28 members of the Israeli Parliament expressing a desire for peace. Mr. Arafat said he knew there were leaders who did not share the hard-line position of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Housing Minister Ariel Sharon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/22/busin.main_headline: House Leaders Decide Against Vote on S.& L. Bailout Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/22/busin.print_headline: House Leaders Decide Against Vote on S.& L. Bailout Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/22/busin.body_text: **********House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said today that the pay-as-you go means of providing new money for the savings and loan bailout would probably not be permitted to go to the full House because it stood little chance of passage. **********Such a plan, approved by the House Banking Committee, 27 to 25, on Wednesday night, would provide $20 billion outright; any additional money would have to come from cuts in other programs. **********The decision by the House leadership to put off the bill lets the lawmakers avoid a political test of whether they would be willing to pay for the bailout by cutting spending on other Federal programs. **********It also puts off a confrontation with the Bush Administration. The White House has been seeking $80 billion for the bailout outright, without reopening the budget agreement of last year. The Administration says almost all the $80 billion provided by Congress since the bailout began more than two years ago had been spent. **********Mr. Foley, Democrat of Washington, said he would press ahead with a proposal supported by the Administration to provide as much money as may end up being needed to wrap up the bailout without further Congressional action. **********The open-ended measure also stands little chance of passage. It was defeated in the Banking Committee earlier this week by a vote of 40 to 7. "It is not sort of a blank check," Mr. Foley said at a news briefing today. "It is giving the Administration the tools and the responsibility to carry out an extremely important policy." **********The proposal is also attractive precisely because it would not require further Congressional action. In March, the full House rejected four financing measures for the bailout before finally approving one. **********Asked today why the members had been having so much difficulty approving a financing measure, Mr. Foley said: "Words can be tyrannical. The words 'S.& L. bailout' have contributed more to disinformation about depositors' insurance protection acts, such as the one we are about to consider, so that the public has no real notion of what this money is being advanced for. **********"If people understood that clearly, I think they would not be critical of a member who votes for it, but the reverse, critical of a member who does not vote for it." **********Another possibility that Mr. Foley discussed with other lawmakers would be to provide stopgap financing until Congress returns next year. No financing measure has yet been introduced in the Senate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.main_headline: Too Many People and Not Enough Places to Go
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.print_headline: Too Many People and Not Enough Places to Go
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.body_text: **********As Memorial Day arrives and the children are let out of school, attention turns to the coveted summer getaway. But the hottest travel destinations are swarming with tourists. Getting away from the crowds has become a mission impossible. And that's not the only price society is paying for the explosion in world travel. **********There is the sewage backup into the Mediterranean to consider and the desiccation of East African game parks because of heavy tourist traffic. Plan on venturing into the central valley of the Yosemite National Park in July or August? Your experience may be more akin to a stroll down Madison Avenue during lunch hour. **********The solution is simple, but hardly welcome: restricting access. Some United States national parks have already been forced to close temporarily during the day to allow crowds to thin. And such closures are likely to become more widespread. **********"It used to be that if one area was built up, you could always move on to somewhere else," said Martin Brackenbury, president of the International Federation of Tour Operators in London. "But increasingly we are not in a position to escape the mess we've created." **********The trend is playing into the hands of theme park owners. Disney World, for one, attracted more people than Britain last year. Last year, 28.5 million visited the park, making it the fourth-largest tourist destination after France, the United States and Spain. Many vacationers figure they can escape pollution, if not the crowds, yet get an enriching experience in Disney's ersatz foreign lands. **********The hotel industry has taken some pointers from Disney. To please -- and control -- the dense crowds, hoteliers and resort operators have learned how to simulate cultural experiences. A Calypso band evokes the spirit of the Caribbean, flamenco dancers give guests a taste of Spain. The gimmicks, used perhaps most heavily in the country of origin, lead some to question the authenticity of any travel. **********By at least one measure, tourism is the world's largest industry. While it is the third-largest household expenditure after food and housing in most industrial nations, it employs more people than any other single industrial sector, according to figures compiled by Wharton Economic Forecasting Associates. **********And it is growing fast. The industry, which includes spending on lodging, transportation and restaurants, has an infrastructure worth $3 trillion, estimates WEFA. In 1989, the latest year for which figures are available, the industry invested nearly $360 billion in new structures and capital equipment, up from $276 billion in 1987, according to WEFA. **********Today, the industry employs 112 million people, or one out of every 15 workers worldwide, and is expected to maintain a healthy 8.7 percent growth rate through 1992. The potential is clearly enormous, considering that only about 10 percent of all Americans hold passports. **********The growth is remarkable for an industry that is 40 years old. Before World War II, traveling for pleasure was the province of the rich, a characteristic that is still played up in advertisements. But improved standards of living and the ready availability of flights have enabled more people to indulge. "The growth in tourism is a function of increased disposable income and increased leisure time," said Paul Turk, an analyst at Avmark, an air travel consulting company in Washington. **********The trouble is, too many people are converging on too few places. More than 425 million people -- about 10 percent of the world's population -- traveled from one country to another in 1989, according to the World Tourist Organization of the United Nations. Mr. Brackenbury estimates that half the world's population will be traveling by the year 2000. **********That kind of traffic has helped defeat an essential purpose of travel. "Once tourists begin to show up, it immediately changes the character of the place and the original experience is gone," said Douglas Frechtling, associate professor of tourism at George Washington University. "From then on, it's just a matter of degree." **********For example, the south of France, which millions of tourists visit every summer, has adjusted after a few disastrous years, when its infrastructure sagged under the strain and sewage overflowed into the once-azure sea. Now, the problem is sewage discharged from a growing fleet of pleasure boats, Mr. Brackenbury said. **********The east coast of Spain, known affectionately as the Costa Concrete in honor of its tourist sprawl, has also cleaned up its act. Benidorm, long considered the overbuilt nadir of the Spanish tourist industry, has won several awards for the cleanliness of its beaches. Spain derives 25 percent of its export earnings from tourism, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit, a consulting group in London. **********But the Italian coast of the Adriatic Sea has never gotten over the publicity surrounding the sudden growth of brown algae in 1989. "It was like swimming in brown mucous, not exactly anyone's idea of holiday pleasure," said Mr. Brackenbury. **********The problems of pollution are most noticeable at places whose draw is their supposed pristine condition. The Grand Canyon has banned small planes from flying below the canyon rim, but the local airport is still the third busiest in Arizona, after Phoenix and Tucson. And at the height of the summer, about a quarter of a million people crowd onto the floor of the Yosemite Valley every day. Duncan Morrow of the National Park Service said he sees more parks closing for increased periods, waiting for their parking lots to empty. **********Overseas, the garbage tossed out in the foothills of the Himalayas by tourists has become legendary. And some of the East African game parks are being turned into dust bowls by the tourists ferried around in four-wheel drive vehicles. "You think you're seeing the animals in the wild, but by definition you're not because tourists are looking at them," said Dr. Frechtling. **********Circumstances like the destruction of the Brazilian rain forest, the depletion of the ozone layer and the oil spill in Alaska have driven home the fragile state of the world, sensitizing many to the adverse cultural, social and physical effects of tourism, he added. **********But even those places that have tried to control the growth of tourism, the demand to keep masses of people content in a confined area inevitably leads to an experience that is somewhat manufactured. So why not, the thinking goes, have an entirely manufactured experience. "In a sense, the Montmartre experience is in the eye of the beholder," said Dr. Frechtling. **********Disney argues that in offering a small slice of a foreign culture, it will whet people's appetites for travel. Yet spending two weeks in Maui hardly represents a close encounter with traditional Hawaiian culture. **********"The difference is that it's not in a compact area and not operated by one company," said Dr. Frechtling. "The trick is to manage large numbers of people while giving them a quality experience that they will treasure when they go home. Disney does that very well." AMERICANS ARE STAYING TOO CLOSE TO HOME **********The crowds at Yosemite might be worse than usual this summer. That is the natural conclusion to be drawn from a recent survey of Americans' travel plans. **********According to the study, released last week by the United States Travel Data Center, a Washington-based consulting firm, Americans will make almost as many trips this summer as the nearly 326 million trips 100 or more miles from home that they took last summer. The recession -- and, to a lesser extent, safety concerns lingering from the war in the Middle East -- will keep people closer to home this season and force them to cut corners in other ways. More people are driving instead of flying, taking shorter vacations and staying with friends and relatives rather than in hotels, concluded the study, which is based on interviews conducted with 4,500 Americans over three months. **********International travel fell during the war, helping push International Leisure Group, a giant British holiday tour company, as well as Eastern Airlines into bankruptcy. While the war victory initially spurred Americans' travel plans, the recession quickly cooled their interest, according to separate surveys by the consulting firm of D. K. Shifflet & Associates in McLean, Va. In March, in the wake of the war, 76 percent of the 300 people interviewed said they planned to take at least one trip in the next six months, up sharply from 51 percent in February. But by April, that figure fell to 58 percent. **********"The economy has been, in terms of domestic travel, a far greater factor than the war," said Richard Hebert, a spokesman at the American Automobile Association. "Things got better in April, but the feeling is things didn't get better enough." **********In Hawaii, for example, incoming tourist traffic declined by 12 percent in April from a year ago, according to Gene Cotter of the Hawaii Visitors Bureau. That is a big deal for a state that earned 40 percent of its gross national product last year from its seven million tourists. "It's recession-related and war-related, but probably more on the recession side," Mr. Cotter said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF; War Summary
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/23/world.body_text: **********BUSH GIVES IRAQ A DEADLINE **********President Bush demanded that Iraq begin pulling out of Kuwait by Saturday noon or face an allied land invasion. The demand was a setback for a Soviet peace plan, which was more lenient to Iraq and had been accepted by Baghdad. The leading countries in the allied coalition backed Mr. Bush's stance, but Iraq called it "shameful." Officers at the allied Central Command said the land attack could come as early as Sunday dawn. KUWAITI OIL INSTALLATIONS SET AFIRE **********Allied fighter-bombers and artillery pounded Iraqi forces in Kuwait, as Iraq began to destroy Kuwaiti oil wellheads and transmission equipment. The allied command said that about 150 of the country's 950 wells were ablaze. Despite thick smoke over much of the country, allied planes flew 1,000 missons over Kuwait, the most since the war began. The allies reported three clashes between Iraqi and allied forces along the Kuwaiti-Saudi border. WAR LOSSES Allies Forces **********Troops: A United States marine was reported killed and five others wounded by Iraqi artillery fire. After 36 days of combat, 24 Americans have been reported killed, 28 missing in action, 33 wounded and 9 as prisoners of war. Iraqi Forces **********Troops: The Allies said that fighting along the border produced 100 more Iraqi prisoners of war. **********Armory and weaponry: The allies reportre 18 Iraqi tanks and 15 other vehicles destroyed. **********Central Command said 100 sorties were flown against Scud missle targets, destroying seven mobile launchers and four Scuds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Anxious to revive the economy, the Bush Administration is publicly prodding the Government's bank supervisors to ease up on credit standards so that commercial banks will make more loans. But the White House tactic, first sounded a week ago and reiterated yesterday by the President, stirred up a fuss this week among the supervisors, who insist that they are not at fault. **********Banks are not making more loans, regulators and bankers say, mainly because demand for loans has fallen and not because regulators have clamped down too much. In addition, many bankers acknowledge that they have voluntarily raised their credit standards in the last year or so to eliminate potential borrowers who might not be able to repay their debts. **********The Administration's position, spotlighted at a much-publicized White House meeting last week, is that excessively cautious regulators are inhibiting bankers, who then turn away too many customers.  Longtime Customers Hold Back **********"I think the regulators are not being treated completely fairly at this time," said Robert Hawkins, president of Southern Commercial Bank in St. Louis and president-elect of the Independent Bankers Association, which represents many midsized banks. "They are entitled to a portion of the blame. But bankers can't be busy making new loans when they are busy trying to collect bad ones already made. And we are not seeing many good loan applications. The good borrowers are holding back." **********Mr. Hawkins says, for example, that he would love to lend to some of the small machine shops and retailers in south St. Louis whose owners are his longtime customers. But they don't ask, he said. **********"They've basically cut back," he said. "I'm thinking of a guy I helped put into business 25 years ago: he has very little debt; he knows what he is doing. He makes pulleys for trucks and farm machinery. But he's not seeing strong demand, and he says the machinery he now has in his shop he can live with for a few more years." **********Indeed, a monthly survey of 2,000 small companies by the National Federation of Independent Business shows that only 36 percent are borrowing regularly from banks, one of the lowest percentages in a decade. The group says the biggest reason for the decline is that people are not asking for money because the economy is too weak. **********The White House, hwever, is putting the blame on bank regulators, much to the regulators' irritation. "I respect the Bush opinion, but I happen to disagree with it," said Paul Fritts, executive director for bank supervision at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which not only insures deposits but also regulates small and midsized banks. "The examiners can't speak out, and they are easy targets." **********His boss, L. William Seidman, the F.D.I.C.'s chairman, agreed. "If we could cure the credit crunch by sending all the field supervisors on a world tour, we would," he said. "It would be a very low-cost solution. There aren't that many supervisors, only about 8,000 of them."  Applying Pressure to Take Risks **********The White House campaign reflects the Administration's concern that the incipient economic recovery might fail to materialize in time for the 1992 election. The Federal Reserve has been pushing down interest rates, and might continue to do so, but the lower rates have not increased bank lending as they did in the early months of past recoveries. So the White House appears to be putting pressure on the banks -- largely through the regulators -- to take more lending risks. **********"If we are going to get a pickup in economic activity, then that vast portion of the economy that depends on banks to finance inventories and receivables -- unpaid bills -- has to get credit, or the recovery could possibly stall out," said John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor and the chairman of the Fed's committee on bank supervision. **********Although Administration officials acknowledged in interviews that weak loan demand and timidity among bankers were factors in the credit crunch, the White House nevertheless made the regulators the focus of concern at last week's meeting of the President's Economic Council. Overregulation is also likely to be the theme at a White House meeting set for early next week -- in a fresh debate about who is most responsible for the cutbacks in bank lending: the bankers, the borrowers or the regulators.  Banks Buy Treasury Issues **********Rather than make loans, commercial banks have increasingly invested deposit money in safe Treasury securities, and more than $510 billion of these are now held by banks, an increase of $60 billion since the end of last year. The banks' outstanding commercial and industrial loans, on the other hand, have fallen gradually, to about $620 billion. **********The Administration, in effect, is jawboning the regulators first and the bankers second to reverse this trend. The chief beneficiary would be the thousands of small companies -- operations with annual revenue of less than $30 million and fewer than 100 employees -- that rely on bank credit to stockpile goods and to cover wages and other expenses until overdue bills are paid. **********"A major cause of the credit crunch is overregulation, and there is no doubt about it," Robert A. Mosbacher, the Secretary of Commerce, said in an interview. "The regulators are intimidating bankers, so that in many cases the bankers have not been able to use their experience to work with lenders."  Going Straight to Washington **********Somewhat less bluntly, other officials are suggesting that an appeals system might be created so that bankers could go over the heads of field supervisors, to top regulators in Washington. Or capital requirements might be eased; that is, ways might be found to make it easier for banks to meet a new standard, effective on Jan. 1, that will require them to keep on hand enough capital -- essentially cash in reserve -- to equal 7.25 percent of outstanding loans. **********To meet the requirement, many banks have called in loans or slowed lending in some areas. One is auto leasing, in which a bank, working through an auto dealer, purchased a car and then leased it to a consumer. Since many banks have withdrawn from this field, the business is going to huge private lenders like GE Capital, which has $75 billion in outstanding loans of various kinds. **********GE Capital is as concerned about creditworthiness as the banks are, said James A. Park, the senior vice president for finance. "But we are finding that we can acquire safe lending segments, like auto leasing, that banks want to get out of," he said. **********Whatever the final decision on capital requirements, the Administration's effort is directed at getting the regulators to be "more balanced," as John E. Robson, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, put it in an interview. "We have a lot of incidents in which we believe the regulators have been too harsh," he said. "And we also know that the bankers are willing to use regulators as an excuse when they don't want to give a loan." **********Susan Krause, senior deputy for bank supervisory policy in the Office of the Comptroller, which regulates large banks, shifted most of the responsibility for credit cutbacks to the bankers. "They are getting out ahead of the regulators in their caution in making loans," she said, although she agreed that her field supervisors were sometimes overly cautious in one important area: valuing real estate that serves as loan collateral. Downgrading of Real Estate **********A developer might owe, for instance, a $900,000 construction loan for an office tower appraised in the late 1980's at $1 million. He might be making regular payments on the loan, but if the office building's value is marked down to $800,000 because of the current glut of unoccupied office space, the loan might be downgraded, particularly if future rental income seems problematic to the regulators. The downgrading can make a bank seem weaker than it may actually be. **********Bankers say that pressures from regulators make them gun-shy, even when dealing with someone like Harry E. Featherstone, chief executive of the Will-Burt Company in Orrville, Ohio, a manufacturer of metal parts for various industries. **********Mr. Featherstone last month obtained a $500,000 loan from Society Bank in Cleveland to buy a German-made laser that cuts steel. It was a big loan for a company with less than $20 million in annual revenue and $1.5 million in debt already outstanding. **********"We went into immense detail with the bank, which we have not had to do before," said Mr. Featherstone, who remembered that in 1985 he once borrowed $3.5 million on his signature. "We practically had to dissect the machine for the bankers and to explain how much it would save us. Now they call me every two or three weeks to ask me how things are going. They are nervous, and I don't blame them."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.main_headline: GUERRILLAS IN PERU KILL 16 IN CAPITAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.print_headline: GUERRILLAS IN PERU KILL 16 IN CAPITAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/05/world.body_text: **********In this capital's worst massacre in five years of political violence, unidentified hooded gunmen invaded a downtown chicken barbecue here on Sunday night, shooting 16 highland Indians to death and wounding 4, the authorities said. **********Today, several police officials blamed the massacre on the Shining Path, a radical movement which first launched its campaign of bombings and violent attacks a decade ago. **********But one official in the Attorney General's office said the attack here appeared to be the work of a paramilitary death squad. It was pointed out that in contrast to the methods usually employed by Shining Path, the killers used silencers on their weapons and used two vehicles stolen Saturday, one from the Presidential Palace and one from the Ministry of Foreign Relations. **********It was not clear why the Indians were the target of the attack. **********Moreover, although the attack took place 25 yards from a police station, the police did not initially respond to neighbors' appeals for help. **********Officials of Peru's democratically elected Government routinely deny charges that they are fighting terrorism with terrorism, a strategy that became known as the dirty war when employed by Argentina's military rulers in the late 1970's. **********"The dirty war is not our way," Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori, last week told a visiting delegation of the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, a group sponsored by the Organization of American States. **********Indeed, human rights advocates here say military abuses diminished after Mr. Fujimori ordered greater respect for human rights in order to win United States military aid. Last week, for the first time in recent history, Peru's Army announced that an officer would be tried for killing Indian peasants. **********"There has been a dramatic reduction in the number of disappearances," Diego Garcia Sayan, Executive Director of the Andean Commission of Jurists, said here last week. "Will this last? We don't know." **********At the same time several Peruvian experts on the Shining Path and the conflict it has generated said that the use of death squads was rooted in the frustration of security forces who after arresting suspects would sometimes see them freed by judges they believed were either intimidated or bribed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/01/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Sets Refunding Details
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/01/busin.body_text: **********The Treasury announced plans yesterday to sell $38 billion of notes and bonds next week as part of its regular quarterly refunding, but the record size of that package did not prevent modest price increases in trading of existing government securities. **********Dealers and investors were well prepared for the size of next week's offerings, which are needed to finance a budget deficit forecast at about $282.2 billion for the year ending Sept. 30. **********The Treasury said it planned to auction $14 billion of three-year notes due Aug. 15, 1994, next Tuesday, followed by $12 billion of 10-year notes due Aug. 15, 2001, on Wednesday and $12 billion of 30-year bonds due Aug. 15, 2021, on Thursday. The three-year notes are available in minimum amounts of $5,000 while the 10-year and 30-year issues may be bought in amounts as small as $1,000. **********Late yesterday, securities dealers were offering the new three-year issue with a yield of about 7.13 percent, the 10-year notes at 8.13 percent and the 30-year bonds at 8.33 percent. **********The yields of the newly announced issues, which securities dealers trade with an understanding that delivery does not occur until they are issued, reflected the improved prices in yesterday's trading of outstanding Treasury notes and bonds. Some long-term Treasury issues rose more than 3/8 point, with the 8 1/8 percent bonds due in 2021 rising 14/32 to 97 23/32, to yield 8.33 percent, down from 8.37 percent yesterday. **********Price gains were smaller for shorter maturities, with five-year notes rising 7/32 to 100 19/32 and a yield of about 7.73 percent. As recently as July 24, the five-year issue was auctioned at an average price of about 99 30/32, to yield 7.89 percent. **********Although the volume of Treasury securities purchased by investors has not been heavy in the past week, securities dealers said the demand had been steady. Because securities dealers typically establish large "short" positions in advance of Treasury financings, meaning they sell securities they do not own, planning to buy them at the Treasury auctions, even a small amount of buying can cause prices to rise as dealers scramble to buy the securities needed to fill customer orders. **********"The market has been fairly quiet, but there have been good consistent bids that keep prices firm," said Allan R. Leslie, vice president at the Discount Corporation of New York, a primary dealer in Treasury securities. He said the modest buying had been enough to keep traders and speculators from focusing heavily on signs of some strength in the economy, which is ordinarily bad for bond prices. **********For example, an increase of five-tenths of one percent in the Index of Leading Economic Indicators for June was shrugged off yesterday. While the increase was a reminder that the economy is now recovering from a recession, other data showed that the pace of the recovery remained slow. A 1.4 percent decline in new factory orders for June, and a drop in order backlogs of 1.1 percent are not enough by themselves to show that the recovery is faltering. But if orders and backlogs continue to fall, the recent increases in industrial production, which are key to economic recovery, may not be sustainable. **********The most important economic report for the credit markets, analysts said, will be the July employment numbers scheduled for Friday. A survey by Money Market Services, an economic analysis firm, showed that an increase in non-farm payrolls of 50,000 workers is expected. **********In the corporate market, prices of outstanding bonds improved modestly, in line with the Treasury market. In one sign of solid investor demand for new issues, underwriters led by Salomon Brothers increased the size of a 40-year debenture offering by Arco to $200 million from $150 million. The 9 1/8 percent debentures, which are not callable, were offered at 99.20, to yield 9.20 percent. **********In government agency financing, the Federal Home Loan Banks offered $100 million of three-year bonds at a yield of 7.31 percent, or 16 hundredths of a percentage point more than comparable Treasury notes. A $100 million five-year issue was offered at 8.02 percent, or 265 hundredths of a percentage point more than comparable Treasury notes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Japanese Criticized by Chip Makers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/07/busin.body_text: **********As Administration negotiators near a trade agreement with Japan on computer chips, Sematech officials said today that American chip makers faced long delays, or higher prices, in trying to buy advanced equipment from five Japanese companies. **********Chip makers in the United States have complained privately for several years about Japanese companies withholding their best technology from American buyers as a tactic for giving chip makers in Japan a head start in adapting their methods to the latest advances. **********The complaints came as trade negotiators from Japan and the United States are set to meet Wednesday and Thursday in Washington in a fifth session of talks on a new chip agreement to replace a five-year pact that expires this summer. Difficult to Prove **********Past accusations by American chip makers against Japanese equipment suppliers have proved difficult to verify, often because American companies feared Japanese reprisals, like order cancellations. **********But Sematech, whose members include 14 powerful domestic chip producers and users, said today that it had evidence that Japanese companies were withholding new technology "as part of their nation's strategy for worldwide domination of the critical semiconductor industry." **********It said Hitachi, Canon, Nikon, Tokyo Electron and Dai Nippon Screen were making equipment sold openly in Japan that was either not available to manufacturers in the United States or available after months of delay. Sematech is the research consortium financed by Congress and large computer makers since 1988 to develop advanced methods for the American chip-making industry to overtake competitors in Japan. **********In a separate report completed last month, the Commerce Department said that the United States' share of worldwide sales for chip-making equipment had declined to 49 percent in 1988 from 75 percent in 1980, while Japan's share had risen to 39 percent from 18 percent in the same period.  'Negative Repercussions' **********The report said the domestic industry would suffer "negative repercussions" if allegations of foot-dragging in sales by Japanese equipment makers were true. **********The General Accounting Office is investigating the new Sematech allegations as part of a report on the semiconductor industry complaints it expects to complete by August. Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, asked for the report earlier this year. **********In a more detailed statement, the Senate Finance Committee in Washington said many Japanese suppliers at a trade show in Japan last October demonstrated little interest in selling their most advanced equipment to companies in the United States.  Higher Prices and Delays **********Delivery schedules for orders included delays ranging from 6 to 18 months, according to the finance committee report. "Some Japanese suppliers quoted prices 20 to 30 percent higher for American buyers," the report added. The types of equipment available in Japan but not to chip producers in the United States, include advanced steppers produced by Nikon; precision heating equipment made by Tokyo Eletron Ltd. and Kokusai, and a machine from Hitachi that helps set electronic circuits on chips called an ion implanter, according to Sematech.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Morse Shoe Inc., operator of the Fayva stores, has submitted a bankruptcy plan that would move most of the control over the discount shoe company to the bondholders. **********A Morse management team, which bought out the company four years ago, will remain but will control only 5 percent of the company under a new stock issue, said Thomas J. Galligan 3d, the company's president. **********Citicorp, which owns a majority of the company, would give up most of its share to the bondholders, including the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Kemper Corporation. **********Morse operates 485 stores and 504 footwear departments in discount department stores. It filed for Chapter 11 protection under the Federal Bankruptcy Code in January, saying it was profitable but was staggering under the debt it incurred after the buyout. The plan is pending before the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Boston and also requires the approval of the bondholders and creditors. **********Under the plan, $228 million in debt held by subordinate bondholders would be exchanged for just under a 95 percent equity stake and an equal percentage of a new issue of $50 million in convertible notes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/26/world.print_headline: Pretoria Spent $35 Million To Influence Namibian Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/26/world.body_text: **********The South African Government admitted today that it gave more than $35 million to seven political parties that opposed the leftist South-West Africa People's Organization in pre-independence elections in neighboring Namibia. **********The organization, known as Swapo, went on to win the elections for a constituent assembly in November 1989, which were held under United Nations supervision. But it received only 57 percent of the vote, well short of the two-thirds majority it needed to introduce a socialist-oriented constitution in Namibia. The territory gained independence from South Africa in March 1990. **********South Africa had previously denied allegations that it gave money to Swapo's opponents in the election. The admission seemed to broaden the current scandal over covert Government payments to South Africa's Zulu-based Inkatha movement and Inkatha's affiliated labor union.  Botha Admits Payments **********The Namibian payments were acknowledged at a news conference today by Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha. The most prominent recipient was the Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, which won more than a fourth of the vote and now sits as the official opposition in the Namibian Parliament. Defending the outlay of "a considerable sum" -- more than 100 million rand -- to limit Swapo's election victory, Mr. Botha noted that South Africa had just fought a bitter counterinsurgency struggle against the organization. Swapo fought a 23-year guerrilla war against South African rule. **********The Foreign Minister also argued that Swapo received many times that amount from supporters abroad. **********"We were at war with Swapo, my friend," Mr. Botha said. But after the elections, he said, "We never tried to subvert the independence of Namibia." **********Mr. Botha spoke at a tempestuous news conference at which he also defended the Government's decision to spend about $87,000 to finance two rallies by the Inkatha movement, the main rival of the African National Congress. His defiant air seemed to reinforce local news reports that President F. W. de Klerk intends to ride out the scandal rather than give in to demands that some of his ministers be dismissed. **********Mr. Botha said the secret payments were part of a broader campaign against international sanctions, which he said had cost South Africa about $28 million over the last five years. Unlike the African National Congress, the Inkatha movement opposed sanctions as a means of pressuring Pretoria to dismantle apartheid. **********When one journalist referred to the covert operation as "dirty tricks," Mr. Botha snapped, "I do not consider it a dirty trick to try to keep the economy of the country strong." **********Mr. Botha said his Government was being judged unfairly on decisions it made in an earlier period when South Africa was isolated from the rest of the world and at war with the African National Congress, which President de Klerk legalized on Feb. 2, 1990. He said the congress had "received millions" from its supporters abroad. **********"Now that summer is coming, few people remember how bitter the cold was," Mr. Botha said.  Mandela in Cuba **********MEXICO CITY, July 25 (AP) -- Nelson Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, arrived today in Cuba, the official Cuban press agency said. **********Mr. Mandela arrived from Jamaica, where he had told a joint session of lawmakers that the world should maintain economic sanctions against South Africa. President Bush removed most of the American sanctions on July 10.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.body_text: **********The Philadelphia Stock Exchange will give quick consideration to a proposal it received last week from another exchange to merge their options markets, its top official said today. **********"We have received a proposal," Barry Tague, the exchange's chairman, said in a telephone interview. "Yes, it is material, and we are going to deal with it very soon." **********Traders said they understood the offer had come from the Chicago Board Options Exchange. The Chicago exchange has declined comment. **********Mr. Tague said the proposal called for merging the two exchanges' options businesses. He would not discuss proposed financial terms. **********Philadelphia has halted the sale of exchange memberships and foreign currency options seats until the board acts on the proposal. The exchange trades equity and currency options and stocks. **********Philadelphia, the nation's oldest stock exchange, received a previous merger offer from the Chicago board last fall. The American Stock Exchange and New York Stock Exchange have also proposed a merger or joint ventures. **********Industry officials say there is pressure for options exchanges to consolidate because of a Securities and Exchange Commission plan to end their monopolies on certain stock options.
