https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/24/world.main_headline: Algerian Militants in Big Election Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/24/world.print_headline: Algerian Militants in Big Election Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/24/world.body_text: **********In a strong show of force on the final day of campaigning for Algeria's first free multiparty parliamentary elections, the Islamic Salvation Front, the largest opposition party, packed a stadium here today with more than 100,000 supporters who chanted slogans demanding an Islamic government. **********"We recognize no constitution and no laws but the laws of God and Islam," the crowd in the stadium intoned. **********Nevertheless, the most hard-line and fundamentalist faction in the front decided after much wavering to take part in the balloting. **********Adherents of the front arrived at the stadium from all over the country in an impressive demonstration that caused some politicians here to revise earlier views that the fundamentalists had lost some of their luster over the last two years. These politicians had maintained that the appeal of the fundamentalists had been damaged by what was described as their lack of success in administering local municipalities, where they won significant election victories in 1989. Watched by Neighbors **********Despite the stadium turnout, Government officials and many of the country's recently sprouted independent newspapers say they have no clues to the outcome of the elections, set to begin on Thursday. **********The Governments of neighboring Tunisia and Morocco, where Islamic fundamentalists have posed a significant challenge but have not been allowed free expression of their views, are watching the election here with some apprehension. They fear that it may bring pressure on them to democratize their systems and remove curbs imposed on the fundamentalists. **********The Algerian elections, in which 5,712 candidates are contesting 430 seats in Parliament, are also being watched with anxiety in the more distant reaches of the Arab world, where free and honest elections are very rare. **********Today's strong show of public support by the Islamic Salvation Front, and equally impressive gatherings staged by another important Islamic fundamentalist party, the Hamas movement, have caused some officials from the governing National Liberation Front to worry about the possibility of losing power by the time a second and decisive run-off is completed on Jan. 16. Hamas Stresses Democracy **********"I think Islamic voters will overwhelm everyone," said Rashid Kheloufi, an adherent of the Hamas movement, which calls for an Islamic state in Algeria but, unlike the Islamic Salvation Front, has not advocated taking power by force and insists on assuming leadership only through democratic practices. No such assurances have been made by the Islamic front. **********The National Liberation Front has governed Algeria since it won independence from France in 1962 as a single party and is now widely discredited as corrupt and inefficient. About the only thing that is shared by all the other 58 parties that came into existence over the last year is a determination to oust the governing party. **********A senior official said the Government's expectation from its soundings was that the Islamic Salvation Front may get between 25 and 30 percent of the vote. **********The Government official, who insisted on anonimity , said he thought the National Liberation Front may get a similar percentage, while the two other big secular social democratic parties may together get 30 percent of the vote.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/world.main_headline: Romanians Are Told of Nation's Role in Mass Killing of Jews
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/world.print_headline: Romanians Are Told of Nation's Role in Mass Killing of Jews
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/02/world.body_text: **********For the first time, half a century after the event, the enormity of the killing of more than half of Romania's 750,000 Jews by Germans, Hungarians and Romanians was told today for all Romanians to hear -- their memory mourned by the Government and a monument unveiled to their martyrdom. **********Many of the speakers, particularly Elie Wiesel, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, who was born in Romania and is the sole survivor in his family, used the occasion to warn against the current rebirth of anti-Semitism. **********This sentiment, together with a broad range of extreme nationalist views, is finding many outlets in the country's newly free press and is usually met with only embarrassed silence by those who dislike it. **********Until now, Romanians have been told by their Communist governments that Germany and Hungary, with the help of some Romanian "fascists," had killed hundreds of thousands of Romanians, including Jews. The fate of Romania's Jews, killed because they were Jews, was never acknowledged, although few other Romanian civilians died except in acts of war. **********The facts, widely known elsewhere, were never acknowledged here: that a great number of Jewish men, women and children were killed in pogroms of a brutality that sometimes shocked even the Germans, pogroms carried out by the Romanian military and the police. Or, the Jews worked, starved or froze to death in concentration camps established and run by Romanians. **********As a result, many Romanians have professed unawareness that the killing of the Jews was also a Romanian matter. **********"They were murdered twice," Chief Rabbi Moses Rosen said in an address in the ornate Choral Synogogue. He poured into it all the passion pent up in the years beginning with the Bucharest pogrom of January 1941 -- a total of 400,000 deaths that could be spoken of only abroad or to Jewish audiences here.  Cabinet Members Attend **********"They were murdered in the Holocaust of the Jewish people, and we were forbidden to weep for our dead," said the Rabbi, who is now 78 years old. **********The ceremony today had the blessing of the Government of President Ion Iliescu and Prime Minister Petre Roman, although neither attended. Mr. Iliescu had agreed to speak, but he and Mr. Roman went to Prague for the final meeting of the Warsaw Pact leaders. **********Both sent messages of sympathy through senior associates, and Mr. Iliescu had a wreath placed at the monument in the synogogue's forecourt. Several Cabinet members attended, and the head of the governing National Salvation Front, Ion Aurel Stoica, spoke, calling the fate of the Jews "a tragedy for the whole Romanian people." **********Rabbi Rosen drew gasps followed by ringing applause for the candor with which he condemned the Government's inaction in the face of open anti-Semitism. He said he had told Mr. Iliescu and Mr. Roman that there was an atmosphere of "terror and fear." **********"You can't fight fascism with fear," he said he told them. "This is the time of truth." He demanded that people here be told of the full Romanian role in the killing of the Jews and denounced the recent rehabilitation of Marshal Ion Antonescu, the wartime leader and ally of Hitler, who was executed as a war criminal.  The Danger of Fear **********"The Government is afraid, I'm sorry to say," he said. "It can be fatal to a young democracy." **********The Rabbi said that in recent days, Romania's lower house of Parliament had struck the word "anti-Semitism from the draft of a police law that would bar "racism, anti-Semitism, fascism and xenophobia." The Romanian Senate has restored it, he said, but the lower house has not acted a second time. **********The monument, unveiled with patriotic music by a military band, is a stark bronze candelabra posed on a block of marble, whose inscription specifies that 400,000 Jews fell victim to "German, Romanian and Hungarian fascists." **********Along a wall flanking the forecourt, separate tablets were put up listing the various places of death and the numbers of those killed. Mr. Wiesel unveiled the plaque commemorating the 130,000 Jews of his native northern Transylvania, which Hitler detached from Romania in 1940 and incorporated into Hungary. **********Mr. Wiesel said he had come because Rabbi Rosen had told him of the new wave of anti-Semitism. **********"I address my words to the leaders of this country," he said. "I hope you know that your representatives have great difficulties in the world to mobilize sympathy, political and economic support for your country. Your image is not the best. You must know that. **********"You must know that unless these anti-Semites are shamed in society, you will suffer. You will be isolated. The world is following this with astonishment, dismay and outrage." A Warning to Enemies **********American Jews, notably Israel Singer, general secretary of the World Jewish Congress, and Rabbi Arthur Schneier of the Appeal for Conscience Foundation, denounced the new wave of anti-Semitism. Mr. Singer challenged those "who think it's open season on Jews again." **********"Take heed!" he said. **********Mr. Wiesel closed with an appeal to Romanians. Much of his writing, he noted, draws on his hometown of Sighet, in the Carpathian Mountains. Despite the end of his childhood, which took him from Sighet to Auschwitz, he said, "I somehow think about it with fondness." **********"I plead with you," he said. "Allow me in the future, too, whenever I speak of the geography of my childhood, to speak of it with fondness. And that depends on you."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.print_headline: AFTER THE COUP; The 3 New Top Security Appointees
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.body_text: **********Vadim V. Bakatin Chairman of K.G.B. **********Vadim V. Bakatin, who takes over the K.G.B. without any known background in the intelligence and internal security agency, is among the most liberal figures in the Soviet leadership. His appointment appears to presage a major overhaul of the agency and the dismantling of much of its secret police operations, American officials say. **********Administration officials expressed enthusiasm for Mr. Bakatin's appointment, characterizing him as a man of great intelligence and candor who has repeatedly shown loyalty to the cause of reform even when his progressiveness stood in the way of his career advancement. **********Mr. Bakatin had been one of the main proponents of glasnost and perestroika until he was dismissed as Interior Minister late last year during a resurgence of the right in the Communist Party. He is known as an proponent of due process of law and of radical economic reforms, including the attraction of foreign investment and the steady elimination of subsidies and price controls. **********"He is going to clean up the K.G.B., no doubt about it," said an Administration official who monitors Soviet intelligence agencies. "He'll get rid of the cowboys and insist the K.G.B. follows the law."  Promoted U.S. Exchanges **********As Interior Minister, Mr. Bakatin promoted personnel exchanges between his ministry and the United States Justice Department, as well as between Soviet and American local police forces. **********Condoleezza Rice, a political scientist at Stanford University, said, "He sought out Western ideas on how police forces should behave in a democracy." Ms. Rice, who met Mr. Bakatin briefly last year when she served as a staff member in the National Security Council, said, "He is open and outgoing and easy to talk to." **********A civil engineer by training, Mr. Bakatin comes to the K.G.B. as an outsider to the security force, although he has spent most of his career in law enforcement. As Interior Minister he worked closely with the K.G.B. fighting crime and corruption, but Western analysts said he had never been a member of the K.G.B. and had no known record of political repression. **********Born in 1937 into a middle-class family in the Siberian coal mining town of Kiselevsk, Mr. Bakatin graduated from a technical institute and worked on several construction projects before he went to work for the Communist Party in the early 1960's.  Taste for Things Western **********He is known for his taste for things Western -- ranging from his love for tennis to a fondness for be-bop jazz, the Beatles and Elvis Presley. **********Mr. Bakatin worked his way through the ranks of several regional party organs before he was promoted by Mr. Andropov to be an inspector of the Communist Party Central Committee. He returned to regional party work in 1985, serving as first secretary of the party in the cities of Kirov and Kemerovo. **********His active support for Mr. Gorbachev led to his appointment as Interior Minister in 1990. Though he was removed from his post, he continued to serve as a member of the Soviet Security Council. **********In an interview with the Soviet press in May, Mr. Bakatin identified himself as a "radical centrist." **********Mr. Bakatin ran against Boris N. Yeltsin for President of the Russian federated republic, campaigning for even more radical change, but came in third place in the election.  Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov Defense Minister **********Col. Gen. Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, the new Defense Minister, had been commander of the Soviet Air Force, and his refusal to obey orders from the coup committee helped bring about its downfall. **********One of his first acts as Defense Minister was to resign from the Communist Party. **********Administration officials said they were pleased with General Shaposhnikov's appointment because he seemed to be the kind of officer who would support a sweeping reform of the Soviet economy and reducing the size of the Soviet military. In speeches over the last year, they said, he has argued in favor of giving priority to economic development as a matter of national security. **********American officials compliment him for accepting the demise of the Warsaw Pact as a development that could not be avoided, and they say they believe that he will work to remove Communist Party influence from the armed forces. "He can be expected to move toward a smaller, more professional military," an Administration official said. Approved by Yeltsin **********A State Department official said his appointment was approved by Mr. Yeltsin because "Yeltsin believes he will support what needs to be done to the military, a reduction in the size and a conversion to an all volunteer force." **********Stephen Foye, an analyst of the Soviet military for Radio Free Europe, said General Shaposhnikov "is very forward-looking." **********"He has spoken very favorably of increased competition in the defense industries," he said. **********An American military intelligence official described the general as "hard-charging, a fighter pilot's fighter pilot." He reportedly works about 75 hours a week, but is also known for hard living, including chain smoking and hefty eating.  Unusually Young for Post **********At age 49, he is unusually young to have risen to the Soviet high command, a point American analysts make to explain his fresh approach to many issues. He was born in 1942 in a small Russian village to a working-class family. At age 21, he joined the Communist Party and graduated from the Kharkov Aviation Institute, after which he served as an air force pilot. **********After serving in East Germany, he was appointed first deputy commander of the air force in 1988, and then was elected to a seat on the Communist Party Central Committee. He was promoted to air force commander in July 1990. His principal priorities for the service were better training and more efficient and economical equipment. 'Substantial Cuts' Seen **********"His appointment probably means a more rapid transition that could bring substantial cuts in the armed forces and less holding back by the old guard," he said. **********General Shaposhnikov's ascendency does not mean that conservatives will no longer have a place in the military. **********His new principal deputy, the General Staff chief, is Gen. Vladimir Lobov, a hard-liner who has long called on the Soviet Union to seek military superiority over the West. Last posted as Chief of Staff of the Warsaw Pact military alliance, he is one of the Soviet Union's leading strategic theorists. General Lobov, who is 56, has tended to bend his political philosophy with the leadership and has not overtly opposed President Gorbachev. **********The new No. 3 man in the armed forces, the Deputy Defense Minister, is Lieut. Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, 43, a liberal. As commander of Soviet paratroops, he refused to deploy his forces in support of the coup committee this week. He served for five years in Afghanistan during the war, an experience that apparently made him skeptical about deploying military force abroad. Viktor P. Barannikov Interior Minister **********Viktor P. Barannikov, the new Interior Minister, is a close ally of Mr. Yeltsin, who has long worked to make the Russian police independent of the central Soviet authorities. **********In his former post as chief of the Russian federation's Interior Ministry, Mr. Barannikov concentrated on criminal investigations and eradicated Communist Party cells from his agency. Administration officials said they expected him to continue his reform policies. "His priority will be to make an effective crime-fighting unit out of the Interior Ministry as opposed to an instrument of internal repression," an Administration official said. **********Mr. Yeltsin promoted Mr. Barannikov, who at the time was first deputy minister of internal affairs in the Russian republic, to become the chief police officer in his Government late last year. Least Known to Washington **********Of the new appointees, he is the least well known to the Bush Administration. A State Department official said it was not even known whether he is married or has children. He is believed to have been born in 1941, and he has been involved in regional and national police work since 1961. **********American officials said they were pleased about his appointment because he struggled in his former post against hard-liners in the Soviet Interior Ministry who wanted to subordinate his agency. He insisted that the militia of the Russian federation be commanded by Mr. Yeltsin and not by Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/busin.main_headline: Top Japanese Executive To Step Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/busin.print_headline: Top Japanese Executive To Step Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/14/busin.body_text: **********Seiji Tsutsumi, founder and chairman of the Saison Group, said Saturday that he planned to step down from active management of the large Japanese conglomerate and hand over authority to a collective leadership. **********Mr. Tsutsumi, 63 years old, has been slowly withdrawing from day-to-day management of Saison, which operates Japan's largest department store chain, Seibu. He had already given up some of his titles at affiliated companies. But the suddeness of the announcement that he would reorganize the group's leadership and become an adviser surprised many Japanese executives. **********In a recent interview, Mr. Tsutsumi said he was grooming the next generation of top executives and giving them control of parts of the group, which he said had become too big to be managed by one person. **********Saison has interests in supermarkets, convenience stores, financial services, travel services, hotels, property development, trade and manufacturing. Among its properties is the Inter-Continental Hotel chain, which was acquired in 1988 for $2.2 billion.  Six Divisions Planned **********At a news conference on Saturday, Mr. Tsutsumi said Saison would be run as of March 1 by four or so executives who had run parts of it. He insisted he was not retiring. **********He also said Saison would be reorganized into six divisions: retailing, wholesale distribution, foreign trade, financial services, property development and restaurant management. **********Mr. Tsutsumi, who created a fortune estimated at more than $1 billion while establishing himself as a leading poet and novelist, comes from one of Japan's wealthiest families. When his father died, Mr. Tsutsumi received just a third-rate department store, with the rest of the fortune left to a half-brother, Yoshiaki Tsutsumi. **********Seiji Tsutsumi built the store into an empire. Yoshiaki Tsutsumi is said to be worth $7 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/31/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Medical Concerns Settle Patent Cases
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/31/busin.body_text: **********Medtronic Inc. said that it and Cardiac Pacemakers Inc., a unit of Eli Lilly & Company, had settled all litigation between the companies. In various cases dating to 1985, Medtronic said, each company had accused the other of infringing certain patents covering implantable pacemakers and defibrillators used to treat abnormal heart rhythms. **********The companies agreed to cross-license all patents covering cardiac stimulation devices that electrically manage the heart's rhythm, Medtronic said. The companies also agreed that Medtronic would supply certain products to Cardiac Pacemakers for an unspecified period. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Medtronic's shares rose $1 each, to $118.375.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.body_text: **********Germany urged its trading partners today to start a rapid effort to bring their economies in line as part of efforts to form an economic and monetary union. **********Horst Koehler, state secretary in the German Finance Ministry, called on other nations in the European Community to reduce inflation rates and curb government budget deficits this year. He said such measures would help narrow differences among the economies of the dozen nations of the trading bloc. **********His proposal was outlined in discussions of community finance ministers on plans to form an economic and monetary union. Their goal is to create a single currency and central bank by the end of the century. **********People in the community said that during the talks Germany, Denmark and the Netherlands expressed reservations about a possible compromise on beginning the second stage of monetary union on Jan. 1, 1994. The first phase began in July, with agreements for closer coordination of economic and financial policies. **********The countries were said to be worried that the compromise would imply an automatic beginning of the second phase of the three-part plan, whether or not national economies were adequately prepared.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 'Thirtysomething' Turns To the Classified Section
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/23/busin.body_text: **********Although ABC is canceling "Thirtysomething," the weekly ABC drama that involved an advertising agency in many of its story lines, that fictitious agency lives on, in a way, via classified advertising. **********Among the ads appearing in help-wanted section of The New York Times on Sunday was one seeking a public relations account executive "who is ready to move UP!" The ad listed an address and a fax number in care of DAA -- the name of the agency on the television series, which is ending its run on Tuesday after four seasons. **********The actual identity of this DAA is Jericho Promotions, a New York firm that handles public relations for clients including the Deutsch Inc. ad agency. When Jericho advertised under its own name, "I never got responses like tese," said a partner, Eric Yaverbaum. The tally so far, he said, is 447 resumes and counting. **********The ad asked applicants to contact "Myles Trentel," a garbling of Miles Drentell, the name of the series character who headed DAA. Asked if it was changed for legal reasons, Mr. Yaverbaum replied, "We didn't have the right spelling on the name."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/03/world.main_headline: Kuwaitis Urged to Halt Attacks on Palestinians
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/03/world.print_headline: AFTER THE WAR:; Kuwaitis Urged to Halt Attacks on Palestinians
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/03/world.body_text: **********American military and diplomatic officials are pressing the Kuwaiti Government to prevent further attacks against Palestinians like those that occurred in the first weeks after the end of the Iraqi occupation. **********A half-dozen younger members of the royal Sabah family formed what a Western diplomat called "goon squads" and carried out some of the attacks, diplomats, Kuwaitis and Palestinians say. Other attacks came at the hands of low-ranking Kuwaiti troops and armed civilians at roadblocks. **********"We're putting severe pressure on them that 'you don't want to look like Iraqis,' " said Col. Ron Smith of the 352d Civil Affairs Command, which is working with the Kuwaiti police. The command has taken over much of the day-to-day running of Kuwait and is also giving advice on the reconstruction of the country.  Palestinians Abducted and Slain **********The pressure, say diplomats and Palestinians, appears to have made a change from the early days of liberation, when resentment of the Palestine Liberation Organization's support for Iraq led to abductions, beatings, arbitrary jailings and at least 10 deaths, according to accounts by human rights organizations, journalists and Western diplomats. Many Palestinians, who served as the major work force here before the war, were rounded up and expelled from the country. **********Nevertheless, as recently as last Wednesday night, Lieut. Col. Ed McCarty, a legal officer with the Civil Affairs Command, found the bodies of two men identified as Palestinians in a garbage dump. **********There was "clear evidence of their having been tortured before they were killed," he said. **********"What really upsets us is the indifference to finding the murderers," said Colonel McCarty, a reservist who is a Nassau County judge in civilian life. "These bodies cry out for justice." **********Ambassador Edward Gnehm of the United States is known to have personally warned Crown Prince Saad al-Sabah that human-rights abuses against Palestinians and other foreign Arabs would lessen international support for Kuwait. **********"There is credible information there have been some abuses," Mr. Gnehm told reporters. "I have furnished the Government with the names of places and people. The Government has never denied that these things are going on." Crown Prince Warns Family **********The Crown Prince, a diplomat said, has warned the group of younger sheiks in the Sabah family that if their activities continued, he would "hang them from the lampposts." **********A Western diplomat working closely with the Kuwaiti Government said; "We're not getting the same number of reports of detentions. Some of the things we've been trying to press on the Government have been working." **********Top-ranking Palestine Liberation Organization officials here, meeting privately a few days ago with a long-serving European diplomat, said that the situation appeared to have improved over the last two weeks and that they did not want to make any public statements for fear of stirring up trouble. **********United States Army officers have several times dissuaded the Kuwaitis from conducting an armed sweep through the main Palestinian neighborhood, Hiwali, to search for weapons, believing that it would almost inevitably lead to gunfire and deaths. **********The Hiwali district -- called "Little Palestine," the home of the middle-class professionals, technocrats and Government servants who once kept Kuwait functioning -- is a tense, fearful place these days, surrounded by roadblocks and barricades of bulldozed earth. **********As Palestinians stood in a long bread line the other day to get five round pieces of Arab bread -- half the ration of Kuwaitis -- a few came over to whisper to a reporter of beatings of their relatives. "They are taking the Palestinians and dumping their bodies in the desert," a man said, looking nervously over his shoulder. Vendettas Become Apparent **********The attacks on Palestinians, predictable in this part of the world where tribal vendettas are a way of life, became apparent soon after American-led allied forces chased the Iraqis away. **********A Western diplomat briefing journalists soon after liberation told them there had been no human-rights abuses, then listened in mounting dismay as journalist after journalist around a long table gave accounts of what they had seen and heard. **********Some reporters found bodies dumped in vacant lots. Others saw Palestinians being beaten at roadblocks. Palestinian doctors and nurses in the hospitals told of beatings and deaths, and gravediggers of nameless bodies buried in the cemetery. **********The human-rights group Middle East Watch estimates that at least 10 people were killed, possibly more, and some 2,000 abducted or imprisoned. Diplomats gave credence to the report. **********A major goal of the Army's civil affairs team from the planning stages, along with Special Forces troops serving as advisers to the Kuwaiti Army, officers said, has been to try to protect the Palestinians and others from vengeance. In one case, Colonel McCarty recalled, Special Forces troops saved a prisoner from a mob trying to kill him, while in others they stopped beatings or torture. Astonishing the Authorities **********"Frankly, we've been very, very fortunate because the Kuwaiti society is so passive," said Colonel Smith, the police adviser. "Which is not to say that there haven't been bodies turning up." **********In many cases, the Americans' insistence on such niceties as due process seems to be met with amused astonishment. **********As Colonel Smith and Sergeant Damico made their rounds the other day, a police general stared at them, stroking his mustache, his impassive face sometimes betraying the hint of a shrug as he listened to reports of alleged police misconduct. Frequently, he broke off to talk on the telephone. **********Later, an army colonel commanding a police station grumbled to the Americans about their reports: "The Crown Prince is very angry. He will shoot my minister, who will shoot my general, who will shoot me. **********"All you ask about is the Palestinians. And they are the very worst people." **********From across the room, another colonel put in, "We don't want the Palestinians or the Jordanians anymore." **********"But who will change the oil in the police cars?" asked Colonel Smith, trying to make a joke out of the Kuwaitis' total dependence on total labor. **********"Egyptians," the second colonel replied, shrugging.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.main_headline: Chief Adds Retail Job At Prudential Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief Adds Retail Job At Prudential Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/11/busin.body_text: **********Little more than a month after taking over as chief executive of Prudential Securities, Hardwick Simmons told employees yesterday that he was temporarily assuming the additional duties of head of the firm's large retail operations. **********The announcement by Mr. Simmons, the former head of the retail division at Shearson Lehman Brothers, came after he dismissed Richard Sichenzio, who had been president of retail for Prudential Securities since 1988. **********The dismissal was the first significant corporate shake-up within the firm since Mr. Simmons succeeded George L. Ball, who had been chairman and chief executive for more than nine years. Mr. Simmons was the former head of the retail division at Shearson Lehman Brothers. **********Executives at the firm said the decision to dismiss Mr. Sichenzio, who was popular with brokers, had been made by Mr. Simmons, 51 years old, because he wanted to put his own imprint on the firm. **********"He wants to get a hands-on feel," one executive with the firm said of Mr. Simmons's decision. **********Some on Wall Street speculated that the dismissal of Mr. Sichenzio, 50, had been pushed by Robert Winters, the new chairman of the firm who is also chairman of its parent, the Prudential Insurance Company of America. But executives with Prudential Securities said the move had been made on Mr. Simmons's initiative. **********"This was a pure Simmons decision," one executive said. "This was not a Winters decision." The executive added that the parent company had supported Mr. Simmons in his move. **********These executives said that in addition to wanting to get closer to the operations of the firm, Mr. Simmons, felt that he and Mr. Sichenzio's working styles were too different to mesh. Mr. Sichenzio did not return a telephone call seeking comment. **********Some Wall Street executives outside the firm speculated yesterday that the firm might well have chosen someone to succeed Mr. Sichenzio while they complete job negotiations with someone else. But executives with the firm denied that, saying that Mr. Simmons will use his time running the operations as an opportunity to see if there are any executives at Prudential Securities who should run retail. **********As a result of the change, Mr. Simmons will be the head of the retail division as well as the head of the entire firm for as much as eight weeks, executives with the firm said. All of the executives who reported to Mr. Sichenzio will now report directly to Mr. Simmons. **********The move comes at a particularly odd time. Mr. Sichenzio's second in command, Joseph Haick, is on a medical leave that is expected to last as long as another 10 weeks, executives with the firm said. **********That means that Mr. Simmons will have to handle the job without the entire traditional support team in place, while at the same time overseeing as chief executive all of the non-retail operations, including capital markets and investment banking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.main_headline: Finlandia Drops the Puns To Take On a New Identity
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Finlandia Drops the Puns To Take On a New Identity
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/06/busin.body_text: **********A VIVID new advertising campaign for Finlandia vodka shifts the focus of the pitch for the "super premium" brand from Finland to strong imagery from weak puns. **********In an advance look at the campaign, the signature style of Finlandia's new agency, Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, which won the $10 million account in September from Young & Rubicam, is evident. **********The print advertisements for the third-largest imported vodka, being displayed in July issues of many magazines, employ dramatic photographs and witty language. Those are key characteristics of the work done by the San Francisco-based agency for clients like Royal Viking Cruise Lines, the National Basketball Association and The San Francisco Examiner. **********Finlandia's new campaign is the latest change in ad plans in the fiercely competitive $450 million market for imported vodkas, one of the few types of liquor still enjoying sales growth. **********Last month, Stolichnaya, the Russian brand that outsells Finlandia but lags well behind the leader, Absolut from Sweden, introduced a radically revamped campaign from Calet, Hirsch & Spector based on puns like "Stolar system." And later this month, Wyborowa, the Polish vodka that Joseph E. Seagram & Sons hopes to build into a best-selling brand, will introduce a revised campaign from DDB Needham Worldwide with the theme "If you can't say it, you can't have it." (It's pronounced Vee-ba-rova). **********Finlandia's previous campaign "wasn't provocative enough," said Chester Brandes, president of Finnish National Distillers (ALKO) Inc., in an interview yesterday. His company markets Finlandia in the United States. "In this category, you need some really terrific advertising to get people interested," he added. The previous campaign, with the theme line "The final word in vodka," used pun-filled presentations like the headline "The Finnish line" next to a line of Finlandia bottles. **********Research showed that consumers' reaction to the "Finnish" references was to say, " 'Drink up, it's closing time,' " joked Andy Berlin, principal and managing director of Goodby, Berlin, who joined Mr. Brandes for the interview. Still, linking the brand and its country of origin is a smart strategy, Mr. Berlin said, because once consumers learn more about Finland, "they like it. They say, 'Way up north, cold, pure . . . That's a good place for a vodka to come from.' " **********So the new campaign dubs Finlandia "vodka from the top of the world." The first three advertisements, photographed in Finland, have striking shots of frosted landscapes and ice-blue skies. Readers of publications including GQ, Interview, The New York Times Magazine and Sports Illustrated will see a lone swimmer diving into a pool, a signpost at the Arctic Circle pointing to 32 cities around the world and a reindeer watching an ice fisherman. **********The text of the ads is subtly humorous: The pool ad describes saunas, which Finns build "on the shores of their lakes, the idea being that nothing soothes the soul better than a period of total warmth followed by a moment of pristine, crystal-clear coolness. If you reverse this, you get the formula for Finlandia, which, as it happens, the Finns also invented."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.main_headline: Chrysler Offers Certificates Backed by Loans on Vehicles
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Chrysler Offers Certificates Backed by Loans on Vehicles
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation is offering $1.48 billion in certificates backed by automobile and light-truck loans through its U.S. Auto Receivables Trust 1991-A. **********Underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation said the certificates, which have an average life of 1.75 years and a legal maturity of Jan. 16, 1996, carry an 8.15 percent coupon and are being offered to investors at a price of 99 21/32 to yield 8.30 percent, or about 120 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The certificates are rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********The corporate debt of Chrysler, like General Motors and the Ford Motor Company, has been under review, according to Standard & Poor's. The rating agency said the problems affecting the nation's Big Three auto makers are deeper than it had assumed six months ago when it lowered ratings of Ford and Chrysler. None of Chrysler's asset-backed transactions are under review.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.main_headline: Boeing Sees Rising Sales To Airlines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.print_headline: Boeing Sees Rising Sales To Airlines
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/26/busin.body_text: **********Even as some carriers are parking airplanes because of weak business, the Boeing Company forecast yesterday that airlines will sharply increase their purchases in the next 15 years. **********The Seattle-based company, which has orders for 1,838 planes, predicted that airlines would buy 9,000 new airplanes worth $617 billion from the world's leading airplane builders between now and 2005. **********Boeing said this would mean that based on inflation the world's airlines would take delivery of an average of $41 billion worth of airplanes in each of the next 15 years, compared with an average of $16 billion each year during the last two decades. The company said that because of past trends, it expected traffic to double worldwide over 15 years. Figures Under Scrutiny **********Some analysts questioned Boeing's optimism, noting that even short-term predictions have been difficult because of unstable fuel prices and huge drops in traffic because of fears of terrorism. They noted that strong carriers like American, United and Delta had shown unexpectedly heavy losses in the fourth quarter because of the big increase in the cost of fuel and a downturn in traffic. **********"They're a little too optimistic with respect to the number of aircraft to be delivered and the financing that would be available," said Peter L. Aseritis, an aerospace analyst for the First Boston Corporation. **********He said that some airlines had taken planes out of service to cope with the lower traffic and that British Airways planned to park the new planes that Boeing would deliver. **********But John Hayhurst, Boeing's vice president of marketing, said traffic had dropped severely in 1973 and in the early 1980's but had come back strong, averaging growth of 7.2 percent a year since 1982. **********"Whenever the market has experienced a short-term disruption, it has always bounced back," he said. **********While traffic growth will be slower this year and part of next year, he predicted, it will rise to a rate of about 4 percent toward the end of 1992 and then average about 5.2 percent a year thereafter. **********Boeing said 70 percent of the new aircraft to be delivered would be for expansion, while only 30 percent would go to replacing aging jets. **********To dramatize the hazards of long-term forecasting, Mr. Aseritis of First Boston recalled that Boeing had predicted that about 307 airplanes would be retired in 1990 but that only about 70 were.  Delays Being Allowed **********Boeing has agreed to allow a few airlines to delay delivery of their new aircraft. Mr. Hayhurst said that if the Persian Gulf war continued, more airlines might ask Boeing to put off delivery. **********He said congestion at airports would be solved partly by using larger airplanes. He added that the average number of seats on airplanes would go from 188 to 233 in 15 years. **********Boeing has had the highest market share for commercial airplanes since World War II, capturing 56 percent of the market on average over that time, with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation accounting for 21 percent and Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European aerospace consortium, for 15 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.main_headline: Disarray in Moscow Vilnius Crackdown Raises Questions On Who Leads Nation and to Where
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.print_headline: SOVIET CRACKDOWN: THE KREMLIN; Disarray in Moscow Vilnius Crackdown Raises Questions On Who Leads Nation and to Where
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/15/world.body_text: **********The violent attack in Lithuania has only intensified the question of whether the crisis in the Soviet nation is beyond the control of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********Soviet Army tanks and troops moved against Lithuanian independence demonstrators Monday morning with a brutality recalling brutal episodes of Bolshevik autocracy. They left 14 dead, as well as the clear and frightening implication that, at a critical moment in Soviet history, Mr. Gorbachev, like his predecessors, ultimately chose to sacrifice notions of change and popular free choice to satisfy cravings for a sense of order that continue to be expressed in corridors of the Kremlin, and in much of the exhausted empire that lies beyond. **********Today, Mr. Gorbachev said he learned of the deadly assault after the fact and he contended the Lithuanians themselves were to blame in bringing down the army on their heads. His ministers attempted to spare him personal blame, contending that there was no direct order from the Kremlin for the attack. **********They talked as if the central Government's army had somehow come under control of a hurriedly cobbled Communist front group in Lithuania that operated with neither the knowledge nor blessing of Mr. Gorbachev's office. Question of Responsibility **********Such an explanation only further sapped Mr. Gorbachev's faded prestige. For by any logic, he had to be either responsible or irresponsible in the Vilnius tragedy. Either he had opted to demonstrate the Kremlin still has fist enough to retain the old Czarist empire, or he had let the critical issue of domestic sovereignty and peace slip from his hands into the clutches of a still vague coterie of local military officials and loyalists of the Communist patronage machine in Lithuania. **********Either way, Mr. Gorbachev's image as the herald of national change was badly tattered. The powers of persuasion that he had demonstrated as the one-time optimist of perestroika were shown to have evaporated as his government turned more to force. **********In the case of the Vilnius attack, Mr. Gorbachev, who had been unavailable to the alarmed Lithuanian leadership at the height of the confrontation, waited more than 36 hours after the event to comment. And when he did, he spoke as if he had been on the sidelines, observing violence he contended was unavoidable because of the Lithuanians' refusal to abandon their independence claim. **********The effect could not be reassuring to Mr. Gorbachev's supporters in the world, including President Bush, who watched for evidence that he is both on top of events in his nation and keeping some distance from the more hard-line elements within the army and party, and other institutions of the Soviet system that he once vowed to transform through democracy. **********The Gorbachev Government's action in Vilnius comes at time when he is trying to deal with two contrary forces in the nation. One is the increasing need to project a sense that someone is ultimately in charge amid the daily morass of political and economic uncertainties. The other is the insistence from the 15 Soviet republics that they must have far more self-rule if the union is to have a chance of healthy survival and popular support. **********Between these pressures, Mr. Gorbachev, even in days when his prestige was higher, has always backed the concept of the current centralized union and insisted the constitutionally guaranteed independence for the constituent parts was an unthinkable option, even for the Baltic republics that were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. **********The action in Vilnius, in accord with this position, stood as a demonstration, frightening to the other Baltic lands and separatist republics elsewhere in the country, that eventually the army will still be used to defend the Kremlin's political will. Only a Partial Coup **********But for Mr. Gorbachev, the political mess has only been compounded by the use of tanks. On the pragmatic level, the Soviet military did not fully carry out a coup in Lithuania, for it left the elected Parliament still sitting in Vilnius and apparently more popular than ever. If the present confusion of authority continues there, the Kremlin may feel further threatened by a growing popular suspicion that it has grown so inept that it can no longer even impose martial law. **********The Soviet leader also suffered politically by severely embarrassing the more independent and influential members of his new Federation Council, an advisory committee of the 15 republic leaders that Mr. Gorbachev crafted last month in an attempt to regain some credibility among the sovereignty-hungry republics. He had invited them to come forward as political mediators during a smiling Kremlin meeting even as the Soviet military was preparing for its night raid in Vilnius. **********This was the worst possible beginning for his promised new era of more open and conciliatory relations with the republics. With military force now an established option in his political dealings, the deaths in Vilnius mark a new, far tougher time in Mr. Gorbachev's once-promising reign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/busin.main_headline: NCR to Buy Data Company for $520 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/busin.print_headline: NCR to Buy Data Company for $520 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/busin.body_text: **********The NCR Corporation, which was bought recently by A.T.& T., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a California computer company that specializes in parallel processing, an arcane computer skill that is especially useful in manipulating huge amounts of data. NCR is exchanging $520 million worth of A.T.& T. stock for the company, the Teradata Corporation. **********Teradata made its name in managing data, and its largest customer is the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which last year spent nearly $100 million on its services. It is one of the largest and fastest-growing companies in the field. **********A.T.& T. now uses Teradata systems to keep track of long-distance customers' addresses, telephone numbers and billing charges, as well as for market research. Teradata also handles some of A.T.&T.'s financial chores, as well as "network provisioning," which governs how the telephone network is repaired and maintained. **********Based in El Segundo, Calif., Teradata designs computer systems that use parallel processing to divide up big tasks into many smaller ones so they can be solved simultaneously, and therefore more quickly. For an analogy, say someone is asked to look through a 52-card deck and find a royal flush. Thirteen people with four cards each can do it in less time. **********But breaking up a problem into these smaller tasks is difficult, so the parallel-processing market has remained tiny compared with the multibillion-dollar market for huge mainframes made by companies like I.B.M. Most of Teradata's customers come from the 200 largest corporations in the country. For example, American Airlines, the nation's largest airline, uses a Teradata system to administer its frequent-flier program. **********Teradata's systems, like the company's top-of-the-line DBC 1012, can cost up to $20 million. Like the computer system, the company's name comes from the exponential term meaning 10 to the 12th power, or one trillion. A terabyte, meaning a trillion bytes of data, is equivalent to three million copies of "The Great Gatsby."  Analysts Not Surprized **********Analysts did not find the deal surprising. "Ever since A.T.& T. considered buying NCR, it was only a matter of time before it bought Teradata," said Wayne T. Kernochan, a senior analyst at the Yankee Group, a computer and telecommunications industry research firm in Boston. "NCR and A.T.& T. had to steal a march on the high end, to make some technical leap, like parallel processing." **********But Mr. Kernochan speculated that A.T.& T. could someday apply parallel processing to telephone switching systems, like the huge modernization program involving Signaling System No. 7, which could make "picturephones" and other complicated digital telecommunications possible. "If the Teradata deal works out, boy is it worth it," he said. **********A one-time restructuring charge and disappointing sales in the September quarter of the fiscal year ended June 30 forced Teradata to consolidate some of its operations and lay off 200 workers, or 12 percent of its work force. Teradata improved in the subsequent three quarters, although not enough to post a profit. Loss of $2.4 Million **********In the year ended June 30, Teradata lost $2.4 million on annual revenue of $257.8 million. It has about 1,600 employees worldwide, compared with the 54,000 employees of NCR, based in Dayton, Ohio, which is the nation's fifth-largest computer company. **********In March 1990, NCR bought about 1.4 million newly issued Teradata shares, or about 9.4 percent of outstanding shares, for about $26.27 a share. **********Teradata is scheduled to be merged next year into NCR, subject to approval by Teradata holders. **********Under the agreement announced yesterday, A.T.&T. would exchange $30.25 worth of A.T.& T. common stock for each Teradata share. Teradata's share price jumped $5.125 yesterday, to $28.875. With 2.7 million shares traded, it was the second-most-active over-the-counter stock. On the New York Stock Exchange, A.T.& T. slipped 12.5 cents, to $36.25.  The Ratio of Exchange **********The ratio of exchange would be based on the average closing price of A.T.& T. common stock during the 20 consecutive trading days that end five trading days before Teradata's shareholders meet to vote on the deal. That meeting has not been set, but it may be scheduled for late January. **********In a statement, Gilbert P. Williamson, NCR's chairman, said the Teradata acquisition was a logical extension of NCR's earlier purchase and joint-venture agreement because Teradata would now have access to more money for marketing and distribution, as well as general-purpose computing and communications technologies. **********A.T.& T. bought NCR in a $7.5 billion deal earlier this year to take advantage of the growing symbiosis between computers and telephones.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/18/world.main_headline: Wide-Ranging Afghan Talks Urged by Kabul Government
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/18/world.print_headline: Wide-Ranging Afghan Talks Urged by Kabul Government
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/18/world.body_text: **********With a cutoff of its Soviet weapons supply only weeks away, the Government called today for wide-ranging peace talks to bring about a political solution to the 12-year civil war. **********The appeal came in response to a joint statement issued Saturday in Moscow after talks between Soviet officials and a delegation from the American-backed Afghan rebels. **********The Soviet officials and the Muslim guerrillas called for an undefined "Islamic interim government" in Afghanistan and supported a United Nations peace plan in which an interim administration would oversee elections. **********In a statement, the Afghan Foreign Ministry said that "a comprehensive solution" to the civil war could only be achieved "through an intra-Afghan dialogue." **********But a ministry spokesman, Abdul Wahid Qayoumi, said "the war will go on" if an Islamic interim government excludes President Najibullah and his Homeland Party. Rebel leaders are seeking the removal from power of President Najibullah, who was installed by Moscow, and the cancellation of all Soviet treaties with his Government. **********Washington and Moscow agreed in September to halt all weapons shipments to the two sides in the Afghan war by Jan. 1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.main_headline: Ford Maintains Dividend, But May Cut Future Payouts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.print_headline: Ford Maintains Dividend, But May Cut Future Payouts
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/11/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company did not cut its dividend this time, but a top company official said it might do so in the future. Amid predictions that it might trim its quarterly payout, the company today declared the regular dividend of 75 cents a share for the first quarter of 1991. **********Allan D. Gilmour, Ford's executive vice president in charge of automotive operations, was quoted by the Reuters news agency as saying the nation's No. 2 auto maker might consider lowering the dividend "if the recession is a lot worse than normal." Speaking to reporters at the North American Auto Show in Detroit, Mr. Gilmour said it was "too early to predict what's going to happen to the economy."  Bonuses Are Canceled **********Although Ford will maintain its dividend, "it doesn't appear likely at this point" that the company will make profit-sharing payouts to its hourly employees for 1990, Mr. Gilmour said. **********He also said Ford would not pay executive bonuses for 1990. "We didn't make enough to pay bonuses," he added. **********Analysts have suggested that the Big Three auto makers face increasing pressure to cut dividends because of deteriorating sales and dwindling profits. **********But "each company hopes that one of its competitors will cut the dividend first and receive the initial bad publicity," said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter Securities in San Francisco. Debt Ratings at Risk **********Mr. Glantz added that unless Ford, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation pare their dividends this year, "each faces having its credit rating lowered, which would add hundreds of millions of dollars to their borrowing costs." **********The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced on Wednesday that it had placed the Big Three United States car companies on its credit watch list, raising the possibility that the debt ratings of some or all of them might be downgraded. **********Chrysler's senior debt is now rated at BBB-, one notch above S.& P.'s speculative category. The senior debt issues of Ford and G.M. are rated at AA-, well above the threshold for investment grade. **********Some analysts said the decision today by Ford's board to maintain the 75-cent dividend simply delayed the inevitable, given the uncertain economy and the unhealthy state of the American vehicle market.  Big Losses Predicted **********Ford is expected to post an operating loss of as much as $500 million for the fourth quarter. **********Analysts expect G.M., the No. 1 auto company, to announce an operating loss of $1.4 billion for last year's fourth quarter, which would be the largest quarterly operating loss in the company's history. **********Chrysler, the No. 3 auto maker, is also expected report a loss on operations in the fourth quarter of 1990, Mr. Glantz said. He predicted Chrysler would post a loss of $34 million on its operations during the period. **********The auto makers have been hurt by the high costs of paying rebates to attract customers. Ford spent a record $3 billion on buyer incentives and another $1 billion on fleet and leasing incentives in 1990, Mr. Gilmour said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/world.main_headline: Near Border, Saudis Abandon Town to the Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: SAUDI ARABIA; Near Border, Saudis Abandon Town to the Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/world.body_text: **********Only two weeks ago, the schools here were full and the streets were filled. But deliveries of milk, frozen food and newspapers stopped days ago, and today Hafr al Baten is nearly deserted. **********The reason is location. Situated next to King Khaled Military City -- one of Saudi Arabia's largest military bases -- and about 50 miles from the Iraqi and Kuwaiti borders, this town of 30,000 Bedouin and other residents is the last major population center on the convoy route north. As a result, the town, where Baghdad radio can readily be heard on a car radio, is now host only to a few journalists and some soldiers of the international forces opposing Iraq. **********"Business is suffering," said Hussein Eisa Ibrahim, a Sudanese desk clerk at the Al Fao Hotel, the only two-star hostel in town. Normally, Mr. Ibrahim said, the hotel would be full at this time. But fewer than half of his rooms are occupied now. **********Many of the military people not staying at the Al Fao are discreetly billeted on the playing field of a vast sports stadium, at the local youth hostel and at other places out of sight behind the walls of traditional compounds. Street after street of residential housing stands empty; none of the usual collection of Nissan trucks and Toyota Landcruisers are parked in front of them.  The Streets Are Muddy **********A "No to Drugs" sign still greets visitors to the city. But beyond the street lights and signs, the atmosphere in town is eerie. A steady drizzle of cold rain has turned the normally dusty streets into instant mud puddles. While the city has dozens of mosques, only one muezzin could be heard calling the faithful to prayer. **********The only women in sight were American military policewomen at the entrance to the city, the "T.C.P." or "Traffic Control Point" for convoy traffic. At the intersection just in front of the town, military convoys streamed through in an unending modern caravan. **********"Friday used to be a big day for me," said a Jordanian at what was once a thriving gas station. "Now, no one comes for gas." **********But repair shops have been doing well. Nearly all were filled to capacity with the coalition's disabled military vehicles. **********Despite the absence of residents, security is tight in town. A group of aging former military men who are paid a modest stipend for what amounts to guard duty are posted outside every major bank and institution and most large shops. Clutching their World War II-vintage rifles, they suspiciously eyed the few passers-by in civilian clothes. **********Owners and residents left so quickly that many failed to put masking tape across glass doors and windows to protect their property from flying debris. Many were said to have taken advantage of the two-week school vacation to flee to Mecca and Medina, Islam's two holy cities, which are out of Scud missile range and presumably targets that President Saddam Hussein would not attack even if he could.  Many Flee to Desert **********Others have not gone as far. The Dahna desert, about an hour outside town, is speckled with the Bedouin-style tents of campers from Hafr al Baten. Few are expected to return here until the war is over. And no one seems willing to predict when that will be. **********This town is beyond the range of electronic jammers operated by the Saudi Government to prevent broadcasts from occupied Kuwait and Iraq from reaching Saudi ears. Here, the nonstop fulminations of Iraqi broadcasters come through loud and clear. "Saddam Hussein," one singer rhapsodizes in Arabic song and verse, "you are the smile on the lips of the young and the old. You are the moon over Mesopotamia." **********The police who patrol the empty streets do not listen to the voice of the "aggressor," as Iraq is called. And despite the absence of any immediate threat here, any suspicious activity is monitored. When two journalists snapped a picture of a deserted street, the police promptly pulled alongside their car and admonished them about it. Identification forms were duly checked. And then the police, unwilling to abandon Saudi hospitality, invited the guests to dinner.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/13/busin.main_headline: Producer Price Report Is Encouraging on Inflation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/13/busin.print_headline: Producer Price Report Is Encouraging on Inflation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/13/busin.body_text: **********In a heartening report on inflation, prices at the producer level rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August, a modest increase caused mainly by higher oil prices that have since subsided, Labor Department figures showed today. **********The report, which was somewhat better than expected, touched off a rally in the market for fixed-income securities as investors and traders viewed it as increasing the chances of a new and prompt easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve. **********"The economy would benefit from additional monetary stimulation, and there's very little chance of stirring up inflation by doing so," asserted Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. The trade group's members closely follow the Producer Price Index since it reflects transactions with their suppliers. Expectations of the Fed **********The Federal Reserve generally seeks to avoid appearing to respond to any particular piece of economic news but analysts said today that the next, long-anticipated round of rate cuts could come at any time. On Friday morning the Government is to publish its comprehensive report on retail sales during August and on inflation at the consumer level. Both are expected to reflect sluggish economic conditions. **********"This prepares the way some more for the Fed to ease," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist for Fuji Securities in Chicago. Comparing a cut in short-term rates to an apple fully ripened on a tree, he said, "Today, tomorrow, we know it's going to fall." **********The most recent Fed easing came in early August on the heels of weak employment data. **********The two-tenths of 1 percent rise in the index for finished goods followed modest declines for June and July, but analysts noted that prices would have been unchanged if energy prices are excluded. They added that political uncertainty in the Soviet Union, the world's biggest oil producer, was a chief factor for a 4.6 percent jump in gasoline, which had dropped 5.5 percent in July. Oil Prices Letting Up **********Recently, oil prices have eased and economists said they did not expect overall energy prices -- up 1.8 percent last month -- to prove an obstacle to further reductions in inflation. **********The so-called core rate of inflation, which eliminates food as well as energy, also rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August. This was the same pace as in July and in May, with June unchanged. The Labor Department revised downward today the pace of inflation it reported earlier for April and May. **********Of further encouragement to analysts was the fact that the producer price indexes for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production were also held in check. Intermediate goods rose four-tenths of 1 percent over all, but just one-tenth without energy; crude goods were unchanged over all, but 1.1 percent lower without energy. **********A dress or suit of clothes would be an example of a finished good, an item that will not undergo further processing and is ready for sale to the final user, either an individual consumer or a business. In this case, a bolt of cloth would be the intermediate good and the raw cotton or wool the crude good. 'Inflation Is Under Control' **********"These figures conclusively demonstrate that inflation is under control," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, noting that core inflation at the producer level has remained at about 2.5 percent since February. **********The 1.8 percent jump in finished energy prices last month, which included a decline in residential natural gas, was significantly offset by a four-tenths of 1 percent decline in consumer foods. Beef and veal fell 4.7 percent, and prices also fell for fish, fresh and processed fruits and vegetables, soft drinks and pork. **********But passenger cars and tobacco prices both advanced 1.1 percent as did women's apparel, household appliances, prescription drugs, glassware and textbooks. Automobile prices fell four-tenths of 1 percent before seasonal adjustment. Prices for Manufacturers **********Among intermediate goods, materials for nondurable manufacturing, like paint and chemicals, rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the first increase for this category since November, the report showed. Materials for durable manufacturing, like copper and brass mill shapes, fell seven-tenths of 1 percent following a one-tenth of 1 percent decline in July. **********Finished capital equipment rose one-tenth of 1 percent for the second straight month, as increases for cars, civilian aircraft, agricultural machinery and construction machiner more than offset lower prices for computers, oilfield machinery and trucks. **********For the first eight months of the year, prices of finished goods have fallen at an annual rate of 1.1 percent, the report also showed. Since August 1990 there has been a 2 percent advance.
