https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/04/busin.snippet: JOANN HARRISON spent most of the 1980's building her own software company. As an entrepreneur, she sought the sense of personal achievement that had eluded her during her years at other computer companies. But after eight years, she realized that ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/04/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
The Sun Sets on the Silent Generation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/04/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
The Sun Sets on the Silent Generation
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/04/busin.body_text: **********JOANN HARRISON spent most of the 1980's building her own software company. As an entrepreneur, she sought the sense of personal achievement that had eluded her during her years at other computer companies. But after eight years, she realized that 60- and 70-hour work weeks brought no more satisfaction than the corporate rat race. She liquidated her business and now, at 45, works occasionally as a consultant. **********"My sense of joy," she says, "comes from being able to look at my business and say, 'That's not what I had in mind' and walk away from it." After two unsuccessful marriages and a failed love affair, she now devotes more time to personal relationships and to a longstanding passion, opera. **********It is a path that would have been unthinkable to her father, one of men profiled by William H. Whyte in his groundbreaking 1956 book, "The Organization Man." But it is one that we found trod, over and over again, as we tracked down the adult sons and daughters of many of Mr. Whyte's subjects and other children of the men who bought into corporate America in the 50's and 60's. **********Obviously, the corporate landscape has changed since those "Ozzie and Harriet" days -- and quite a few of the men profiled by Mr. Whyte retired saying that they felt troubled by the antagonism and anxiety stalking corporate offices in the wake of the mergers and downsizings of the 80's. Quite a few were fired during corporate layoffs, and their feelings of betrayal are even greater. **********But how their grown children react is critical for American business because they are poised to take leadership roles and chart the direction for the next generation. **********The 80's, with its mergers, buyouts and restructurings, brought the end of corporate loyalty. But devotion to a profession -- as opposed to a company -- remained. In the 90's, however, even that bond grows more tenuous every day. Just when American businesses must become more competitive or face extinction, an entire generation of Americans is psychologically withdrawing from its commitment to work. **********In the mid-80's, when we began a follow-up study to "The Organization Man," this phenomenon hardly existed. With the help of Mr. Whyte and a small team of researchers, we interviewed more than 175 men from his original study and 125 of their sons and daughters and other "organization offspring." **********In the ensuing years, we watched as these sons and daughters transformed themselves, in rapidly increasing numbers, from people who lived to work into people who work to live. This shift took even them by surprise. **********"I've felt my values changing," said a bank executive, Dale Radcliff, who, in his late 30's, was on the brink of starting a family. "I don't know what to make of it." **********Since the 60's, these 19 million organization offspring have been in the forefront of an individualism that ran the gamut from earnest self-development to sheer selfishness. Celebrated as sensitive souls or castigated as yuppies, they have followed self-fulfillment with abandon. Many took those values into the workplace, demanding that their jobs fulfill their needs for self-expression. Many made work the center of their lives. But unlike their fathers, they refused to give loyalty to any one organization. **********Now as their fathers retire, they are poised to assume responsibility in virtually every kind of public and private enterprise. Well-educated and ferociously competitive, they survived the Darwinian struggle for achievement inevitably imposed on every large generation -- and theirs is the largest in American history. **********But huge numbers of them are turning their attention to other matters, mainly to their families. As the torch is being passed to them, they appear to be handing it back. **********AS Nancy Caton, a foreign exchange trader, put it: "I feel I'm ready to make some sort of commitment to something, and I don't really want to make it to a corporate entity to which I feel no particular loyalty." **********But it is not that they do not want to work. They want to work differently. They want a new balance in their compact with the organization and they will walk if they don't get it. **********In the mid-80's, Scott Myers's work at Memorex left him little time to spend with his two infants. He was frustrated but his work provided a satisfying challenge. When Unisys acquired Memorex, however, his project was ended and he left the company. A gifted software developer and son of one of the Whyte organization men, he and a partner now run a business out of their homes. **********"Some people are out to make lots of money, but not me," he said. "I am in it for the challenge. I have found something I like, plus this new job has allowed me to be with my wife and our new daughter and it has been great." **********Why has the corporate world become so irrelevant to people like Scott Myers? For many, the short answer is family. **********In 1990, there were 4.2 million births, a level not seen since the peak years of the baby boom. Of the 3.7 million babies born in 1988, the most recent year for which detailed figures are available, 35 percent were born to women between the ages of 30 and 44 -- a quarter of a million of whom were managers or professionals. This is to say nothing of managerial-professional fathers, for whom figures are not available. **********The same managers who used to seek raises and promotions now demand parental leave, flex-time and home-based work. **********BUT the roots of the psychological withdrawal reach into the childhoods of the organizational offspring. The affluence in the suburban enclaves settled by the organization man and his wife enabled their children to focus on emotional gratification. **********The organization man and his wife, however, inadvertently launched their children on their long, often lonely, search for self-fulfillment -- a search that ended in disillusionment for many. As a result, many are seeking to re-establish old values through new families, but doing so with a much-chastened sense of their own self-sufficiency and a determination not to put career ahead of family as their fathers did. **********This waning of interest in work by our most talented and best-educated workers is likely to be the most pressing crisis facing American businesses in the coming decade. **********Unsympathetic employers could presumably try to screen them out, but there are simply too many of them: Ten million of the roughly 19 million organization offspring are managers or professionals between the ages of 35 and 45. **********Moreover, such a course would mean lowering the educational level of the organization relative to competing organizations and spurning the personality type -- autonomous and anti-hierarchical -- best suited to performing the kind of intellectual-based "knowledge work" that is crucial to global competitiveness. **********Leadership, it is often said, can rectify the mistakes of arid managerialism and restore loyalty and commitment. For companies, however, success in the 90's will lie not in finding models for leadership, but in understanding who is to be led. **********These are people whose former appetite for work, far from being selfless in the manner of the organization man, was motivated by the desire for self-expression. Less competitive and more cooperative, they will be pouring more psychic energy into family and community. **********To tap some of that, smart organizations -- and the list ranges from big companies like Levi-Strauss and Corning to young, small companies like On Technology and Next Inc. -- will have to provide something that money, inspirational corporate philosophies, manipulative human relations programs, even flex-time, cannot buy. They will have to provide a sense of shared purpose among individuals whose devotion to self-expression has led them to see that their fierce commitment to work was too self-centered.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/busin.snippet: AFTER sitting nearly half vacant for the last three years, a 320,000 square-foot-office building at 16 East 34th Street is being remodeled and brought back on the market at reduced rents, providing another lift to one of Manhattan's major commerci...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/busin.main_headline:
Real Estate;
A Manhattan Building Gets A Face Lift
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/busin.print_headline:
Real Estate;
A Manhattan Building Gets A Face Lift
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/18/busin.body_text: **********AFTER sitting nearly half vacant for the last three years, a 320,000 square-foot-office building at 16 East 34th Street is being remodeled and brought back on the market at reduced rents, providing another lift to one of Manhattan's major commercial centers. **********The 21-story Art Deco structure is half a block from the Empire State Building, a commercial stalwart, and directly across 34th Street from the empty former B. Altman department store, part of which is to be turned into a 650,000 square-foot-design center. A division of the New York Public Library will fill the remaining 200,000 square feet. **********The site is not far from the former Ohrbach's department store, just west of Fifth Avenue, which has been fully rented since its renovation and conversion into an office building in 1989. Three tenants have leased all 377,000 square feet of office space there. **********Now 16 East 34th Street, erected in the late 1920's, has an assured future. The building was acquired in the fall by S. L. Green Real Estate Inc. of Manhattan and a group of Hong Kong investors who plan to spend $2 million to $3 million over the next 10 months to renovate it. **********The work, following plans by JCS Design Associates of Manhattan, includes refurbishing the 1,600-square- foot lobby and elevator cabs, as well as replacing the windows. And to make the building more visible, the facade will be embellished by extending the ornamental bronze work that now frames the entrance to the second floor. **********Bathrooms will also be remodeled, and new air-conditioning and electrical systems will be installed on the vacant floors, which have from 13,900 to 17,000 square feet. That work is to cost $35 a square foot, Stephen L. Green, chairman of S. L. Green, the managing partner in the joint venture, said. **********Asking rents for the available space, depending on the floor, are $21 to $23 a square foot, he said. Two years ago, he noted, rents per square foot in the unrenovated building were in the high $20's. **********Throughout the Grand Central District -- from 32d to 47th Street and from Fifth Avenue to the East River -- the average asking rent for older, prewar secondary buildings, which includes 16 East 34th Street, is $23.46 a square foot. Concessions like six to 12 months' free rent are still common there, as in the rest of Manhattan's sluggish office market. The vacancy rate in such buildings is 14.4 percent, up from 13.8 percent a year earlier, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage firm. **********"The driving force in the market today is price," said Noel Berk, a Cushman & Wakefield broker. "And tenants nearing the end of 15-year leases are moving around to make good deals." **********Mr. Green said he was confident that the lower rents for newly renovated space being offered at 16 East 34th Street would draw some of those shoppers. A lease for a full 16,000- square-foot-office floor is to be signed at the end of this month. One for the building's 10,000-square-foot-street-level storefront is to close in January. **********Mr. Green and his partners hope to continue to draw garment industry tenants needing showroom space, as well as law and accounting firms and nonprofit organizations. Among the current tenants are Playtex undergarments and Monet costume jewelry. **********The partners are able to offer lower rents because of the favorable deal they struck with the Bank of New York to buy and renovate the building. The previous owner, 1634 Associates, a partnership between Joseph Neumann, the general partner, and some limited partners including Beriss Ford Properties, a major British real estate company, said it was unable to continue. The bank held a loan of more than $40 million on the building, which it subsequently wrote down to $19 million. **********The building, once fully occupied, began to lose tenants as uncertanity over its ownership persisted. The lingering market slump also took its toll. After the building's problems became apparent, the lender and the previous owner agreed in the summer to sell it at a bankruptcy auction, but the opening bid of $22 million was not matched, and the bank took it over. **********The building was then sold for $24 million to the current owners, who financed one-third of the purchase price with their own equity, Mr. Green said. As part of the deal, the bank provided favorable acquisition and renovation loans. **********The transaction, commercial brokers say, is an example of the situation in today's market. Joseph McCluskey, a vice president at the Helmsley-Spear brokerage, said many buildings now on the market were purchased at high prices with big loans that cannot be carried at the lower rents now prevailing. **********Mr. McCluskey and other brokers said that the number of such buildings would grow over the next two years as they worked their way through the bankruptcy and foreclosure process. They also warned that the lower rents offered at the marked-down buildings would put pressure on healthy properties to do the same, making a tough market even tougher.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/busin.main_headline: Ex-Officer of Chrysler Gets Dillon, Read Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Ex-Officer of Chrysler Gets Dillon, Read Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/02/busin.body_text: **********After a career in the automobile industry and a fling of participation in a major buyout, Gerald Greenwald is hanging out his shingle on Wall Street. **********Mr. Greenwald, the former vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, who had once been considered a likely successor to Lee A. Iaccoca as the company's chairman, joined Dillon, Read & Company yesterday as a managing director. **********In his new job, Mr. Greenwald, who is 55 years old, will be primarily responsible for overseeing a buyout fund at Dillon, Read. He will also be involved in the firm's efforts to provide financial assistance and advice to troubled companies. **********Mr. Greenwald's closest dealings with the buyout world came last year, when he agreed to serve as chief executive of a company organized by United Airlines' unions that was attempting to buy out the UAL Corporation. That bid eventually failed. **********In an interview yesterday, Mr. Greenwald expressed delight at his new career move. "I don't feel like I'm 55 today," he said. "I feel like I'm a young man just starting out." **********Mr. Greenwald said yesterday that after the UAL bid failed, he considered a number of career opportunities, ranging from running companies to running for office. **********But, he said he thought that working on Wall Street would provide him the greatest opportunity to use his wide-ranging background. "I concluded that this was something that I could apply some of my experiences to," he said. **********Regarding his responsibility for reorganizations, Mr. Greenwald said, "What I would hope to bring is an operational skill that would permit me and others to provide a special capability to not only assist companies that are having financial problems but to provide some operational ideas to get out from under." **********Mr. Greenwald said that there was little bureacracy at Dillon and that if he did report to anyone at the firm he believed it would be John P. Birkelund, the chairman and chief executive. "There really isn't the kind of formalized hierarchical structure at Dillon" that prevails in the automobile industry, Mr. Greenwald said. **********Mr. Greenwald worked in several positions at Chrysler before becoming a vice chairman and a member of the office of the chairman in 1988. His departure from Chrysler last year led to a juggling of senior management to strengthen the line of possible successors to Mr. Iaccoca. **********Mr. Greenwald joined Chrysler from the Ford Motor Company, where he worked for 22 years beginning in 1957. His positions were varied, including president of Ford's operations in Venezuela and director of European operations. **********Mr. Greenwald graduated from Princeton University in 1957, and received a master's degree in economics from Wayne State University in 1962.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.main_headline: Your Money; Important Choice Upon Retirement
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.print_headline: Your Money; Important Choice Upon Retirement
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/16/busin.body_text: **********With the country in recession, increasing numbers of employees are being offered early retirement. Those who accept, like all retirees, face a crucial decision: how to take their pensions. The choice they make can play a big role in determining their financial security and that of their families. **********The most popular choice for married people is a 50 percent joint and survivor annuity. It reduces the retiree's pension payments, but if the retiree dies a surviving spouse will continue to receive payments equal to 50 percent of the benefits. **********Under Federal law a retiree can elect to receive the full pension, known as a straight life annuity, which would leave a surviving spouse with nothing, only if the spouse signs a waiver of consent. Experts sometimes recommend doing just that. **********Joel S. Isaacson, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company, said that often when the pension cannot be taken in a lump sum it may be better to take the life annuity and use the after-tax difference in those monthly benefits, compared with the joint and survivor annuity, to buy life insurance. **********Insurance provides greater flexibility in naming beneficiaries or cashing in the policy, and depending on the insurance chosen and the health of the retiree, it may be financially advantageous to take the life annuity and buy insurance. Also, insurance payments are not subject to income tax. **********Experts emphasize, however, that decisions must be made on a case-by-case basis. **********"A spouse should not waive the right lightly, and should even consider legal counsel," Mr. Isaacson said. "It should be planned out in advance. Once the decision is made, it's irrevocable." Also, he said, the decision should not be made until the insurance is in place. "I have one client who is holding up on receiving his pension until he is sure he has the insurance." **********Mr. Isaacson encourages clients in their 50's, which he called the peak cash-flow years, to buy insurance for this reason. "It is something of a forced savings program," he said. "The house is paid for; the kids are grown. They can get insurance then and pay up by 65. Then they can take the higher annuity and have the insurance to protect the spouse. If they wait until retirement, often the insurance rates are higher, and there is a greater possibility that someone is uninsurable." **********Donald R. Levy, who retired in 1985 as vice president of human resources at the U.S. Tobacco Company and is now a consultant at Maxwell Macmillan, formerly Prentice Hall Information Services, bought insurance and chose a life annuity. His first wife, who had cancer, died two years after he retired, and he was then able to name his children as beneficiaries of the insurance. **********"If I had taken the joint and survivor annuity, I would have a lower pension today and no insurance for others in the family," Mr. Levy said. "I was able to finance this whole thing with the saving on my pension." **********Mr. Levy said that "the big thing was being able to pass the physical" examination required for insurance. Rates on policies are actuarily determined, he noted, as is the reduction in the pension to provide the survivor annuity. The difference is that "the pension plan takes all comers, sick and well," he said. The uninsurable or high-risk person who would have to pay higher insurance premiums might well do better with the survivor annuity. **********To decide which option to take, a retiree needs to look at the numbers for his or her particular pension plan and see whether the extra money from the life annuity, after taxes, can buy enough insurance to replace the survivor annuity. **********Mr. Isaacson cited this example: A retiree could get a life annuity of $2,400 a month. The payment would be cut to $2,000 if he chose the 50 percent joint and survivor annuity, and if he died, his wife's monthly payment would be $1,000. After taxes that might be $9,000 a year, Mr. Isaacson said, calculating that $150,000 of insurance invested in tax-exempt securities yielding 6 percent would provide a replacement income. Less insurance could be bought if an actuarial assumption were made on the basis of life expectancy, he said, adding that $103,000 would be sufficient for 20 years or $115,000 for 25. **********One consideration, he said, is that pensions are insured by the Pension Board Guaranty Corporation, whereas some people are concerned about the soundness of certain insurers. **********"You want to be with a good carrier that has a good track record," Mr. Isaacson said. "And look at more than one set of projections. Many were sold policies with very optimistic dividend projections." Generally whole life or universal life is the appropriate choice, he said, but sometimes coverage may be supplemented with term insurance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.main_headline: Many Communists Desert Party For Its Complicity in Failed Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.print_headline: AFTER THE COUP; Many Communists Desert Party For Its Complicity in Failed Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/24/world.body_text: **********The Communist Party, for decades the bulwark of the Soviet state, was put to a humiliating rout today, as party bosses and organizations across the country either defected or were locked out of their offices in mass retribution for the party's complicity in the coup attempt this week. **********In Moscow today, Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian federated republic, ordered a halt to the publication of Pravda and other party newspapers, sealed the headquarters of the Central Committee and suspended the activities of the Russian republic's party branch while an investigation takes place into party support for the coup. **********The city of Moscow had already moved to close its party committee on Thursday, and today district party offices were locked and empty. In some cases, their signs had been stripped off. The city party chief, Yuri Prokofiev, was detained and taken to the prosecutor's office for questioning. **********The Russian Information Agency tonight reported that a group of Muscovites who had ringed the Central Committee building stopped an attempt to carry documents out of the building. The documents, the agency of the Russian Government said, concerned the Communist Party's foreign business dealings, in particular the sale of a party-owned Black Sea resort.  Deathwatch for the Party? **********Covered in disgrace and on the run, the Soviet Communist Party is on the verge of extinction, Aleksandr Rutskoy, Vice President of the Russian republic and a Communist who had tried to reform the party from within, said in an interview with the alternative newspaper Kuranti. **********"It can no longer call itself the people's party," he said. "Its place is where the Communist parties of Eastern Europe ended up." **********As the party apparatus seemed to near collapse, people in Moscow and other cities took to the streets to remove once-sacred symbols of Communism. **********In the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, thousands cheered at the toppling of a statue of Lenin. In Moscow, crowds that had watched as a monument to Feliks Dzerzhinsky was removed from the square in front of K.G.B. headquarters on Thursday moved on today to dismantle a statue of Yakov M. Sverdlov, a Bolshevik leader, across the square from the Bolshoi Theater. **********The flight of the Communists happened so fast that party members were caught off guard. Answering the telephone at the Central Committee headquarters on Staraya Ploshchad, someone said, "No one is here." **********In the city of Kaliningrad, 60 miles from the capital, the city party secretary put down the telephone and then turned to a visitor to say that the phone call had been from Moscow, telling him to pack and leave. **********In Vilnius, party leaders fled their headquarters in four Soviet Army personnel carriers, followed minutes later by Lithuanian national guardsmen, armed with an arrest warrant, who found coffee still warm in the cups.  Revenge Is Acted Out **********In some regions, the reaction to the coup provided cover for actions, in some cases vendettas, by democratic forces caught in longstanding struggles against the Kremlin. **********In Latvia, Parliament voted an outright ban on the Communist Party and ordered criminal proceedings against its leaders. In the southern republic of Moldavia, the nationalist government arrested Communist leaders in Gagauz, a territory trying to break away, as "adherents of dictatorship" because they had sent a telegram of greetings to the coup leaders. **********The Lithuanian police last night seized the headquarters of the Communist Party in Vilnius and regained control of all major public buildings occupied by Soviet troops in the violence in January that left 13 people dead. **********In the Russian republic, under Mr. Yeltsin's order, party cells, which had been used as the leash to exert central control over once-powerful state agencies, dissolved at the K.G.B., at the official press agency Tass and at the national radio station Mayak. There, the acting party secretary resigned from the party altogether, and according to a report from the independent news agency Interfax, no one came forward to take his place.  Anger's Wide Geography **********From the once-loyal republic of Kirghizia in Central Asia to the breakaway republics on the Baltic coast the party was accused of "cowardly and unscrupulous" behavior during the coup. **********The party leader in Uzbekistan announced that he was leaving the Politburo, while Vladimir Zyukin, the head of Komsomol, the Communist youth organization, said he had withdrawn from the Central Committee "in connection with the full disassociation of the Komsomol from the line taken by the Communist Party leadership, its criminal position and its betrayal of all honest Communists." **********Except from Communists themselves, there were no protests against some of the peremptory moves taken against the party. Nor did those party leaders who quit their positions on leading councils explain why they had not, as individuals, spoken out against the coup. **********To some observers, the lack of debate in the three days of the coup was a troublesome sign that all criticism of the prevailing political line would be considered suspect. **********At a news conference today, a deputy editor of Pravda accused Mr. Yeltsin of using "the same unconstitutional methods as the so-called state emergency committee." The editor, Gennadi Seleznev, said there was no legal basis for the suspension of Pravda, a daily newspaper of three million circulation that has been the authoritative voice of the Soviet leadership since the days of Lenin. **********Speaking before the Russian Parliament today, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is not only the Soviet President but also General Secretary of the Communist Party, warned against "anti-Communist hysteria." **********"We should separate out those who participated in the first stage, and who afterward supported" the coup, he said. "But by all means, we should prevent this from turning against the rank-and-file citizen, the workers, peasants and intelligentsia of the party." **********"No one has the right to set the task of banishing socialism from our country," he said. "This is just another utopia, and notorious witch hunting."  'Handful of Adventurers' **********In a statement tonight, the ruling council of the Communist Party Control Commission expelled the coup leaders from the party and condemned their "unlawful actions." But the commission protested against "attempts to hold the entire party responsible for criminal actions of a handful of adventurers." **********But with hard-liners paralyzed by the failure of the coup, the leaders of forces supporting fundamental change in the Soviet Union struck hard and fast to take advantage of the Communists' weakened position. Although the party itself remained silent during its coup, all eight leaders of the coup committee were members of the Central Committee, and the party-controlled press, radio and television fell into line without a pause. **********On the streets and from speakers' tribunes, people said over and over again that now was the time to break the party's back, in case it managed later to regroup and reassert control. **********The aborted coup was only the latest offense to be laid at the party's door by such speakers. The outburst of revulsion against Communists drew from a longer history of undeserved privileges, abuses of power and going further back, to terror conducted under its name. **********In recent times, the Communist Party has suffered repeated blows to its once all-powerful status. In 1990, it was stripped of its monopoly as the Soviet Union's only legal party, and in local and republic elections, it has repeatedly lost to nationalist and democratic insurgent forces. **********This summer, Mr. Yeltsin, elected over fierce Communist Party opposition, moved to ban party cells in factories and offices, cutting a vital link that tied the economy to the party apparatus. That attempt was challenged as illegal by the party, and until now, has been enforced only sporadically.  Yeltsin Bans Many Papers **********After his victory over the coup, Mr. Yeltsin has taken his ban further -- ordering the party out of armed forces serving on the Russian republic's territory, and now, moving to take control over the party-owned press. **********Besides suspending the publication of Pravda, Sovetskaya Rossiya, Glasnost, Rabochaya Tribuna, Moskovskaya Pravda and Leninskoye Znamya -- all official papers that during the coup, were allowed to publish -- Mr. Yeltsin placed publishing houses and printing plants within Russia under the control of the republic's Ministry of the Press and Mass Media. **********On its front page today, Pravda criticized its own "lack of objectivity" in reporting on the coup. The paper also changed its logo today, from the "Organ of the Central Committee of the Communist party," to the "General Political Newspaper" of the party.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/busin.body_text: **********Two years after it emerged from history's largest leveraged buyout, RJR Nabisco has made significant progress toward becoming, as one analyst put it, "just another operating company." **********The latest evidence came yesterday when RJR, still burdened by heavy debt, said it slashed its fourth-quarter loss to $13 million, from $144 million a year earlier. **********Quarterly sales advanced 4.2 percent, to $3.69 billion, from $3.54 a year ago. Food revenue, mainly from cookie and cracker sales, declined slightly, to $1.625 billion, from $1.63 billion a year earlier, because of the sale of certain candy bar businesses at RJR Nabisco's Lifesavers unit. **********The business unit contribution, meaning the operating profit before special charges and debt payments, rose for both cigarettes and food. Earnings from brands like Camel and Doral rose 18.1 percent, to $691 million, from $585 million a year ago. Food profit rose 8.2 percent in the quarter, to $265 million from $245 million. **********The shares of the company, trading on a when-issued basis and linked to its recapitalization plan, rose $1 yesterday, to $6.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. When the plan is completed in March, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, will be partly public. Out of more than a billion common shares fully diluted, more than 17 percent will be publicly owned. **********RJR Nabisco was taken private in early 1989 in a $25 billion leveraged buyout by the investment firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. **********Some analysts are sniping at RJR Nabisco as if it were already just another publicly traded company. Joseph C. Frazzano, who follows RJR Nabisco for Oppenheimer & Company, said that despite the strong operating numbers, the RJR Nabisco securities were overpriced compared with others in the food and tobacco business. **********"Compared to Philip Morris, and you have to compare them to Philip Morris," Mr. Frazzano said, "they really ought to trade in the $3 to $5 range." **********The quarterly results represent "a turning point for the company," said Edward P. Mally, a high-yield bond analyst who follows RJR Nabisco for Salomon Brothers. "They are now in phase two of the buyout, meaning they are well on their way to becoming just another operating company. Phase one was debt paydown, asset sales and recapitalization." **********Mr. Mally expects RJR Nabisco to increase capital spending this year to about $570 million, after slashing spending 18 percent last year to $426 million. **********He expects the pace of asset sales to slow or stop. "They've pretty much sold off everything they had to sell," he said. "They may have more they want to sell, but there's really no pressure to do so." He said that RJR Nabisco had wanted to sell the Milk Bone dog business, for example, but that the bids were too low. **********Free cash flow, a closely watched indicator of RJR Nabisco's financial health, totaled $622 million in the fourth quarter and about $2.7 billion for the year. 'Awfully Big Numbers' **********Mr. Mally said those figures were somewhat overstated, partly because there was no agreed definition of free cash flow. Mr. Mally estimated free cash flow in the quarter totaled $493 million and full-year cash flow totaled $2.1 billion. "They're still awfully big numbers however you slice it," he said. **********Mr. Mally defines free cash flow as earnings before interest, depreciation, amortization and subtracting preferred dividends, capital expenditures and other expenses. "It's the dough you need to pay off what you owe," he said. **********Full-year losses totaled $429 million, down from the 1989 loss of $1.15 billion. Annual sales totaled $13.88 billion, up 8.8 percent from $12.76 billion in 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/31/busin.body_text: **********Lehman Brothers, New York, a financial services unit of the American Express Company, has started a review of its $2 million advertising account. The search has been narrowed to less than half a dozen agencies, said Steven Faigen, a company spokesman, who added that a decision was expected in September. **********The account was put into review on July 1, after the brokerage ended a trial relationship with Lord, Dentsu & Partners, New York. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/01/busin.main_headline: Making a Difference; A Backer for a Renegade
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/01/busin.print_headline: Making a Difference; A Backer for a Renegade
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/01/busin.body_text: **********R. ANDREW HELLER, who was regarded as far out when he worked for I.B.M., received a $40.2 million vote of confidence last week from Fujitsu. **********The Japanese company made the investment in return for a 44 percent stake in Mr. Heller's new venture, Hal Computer Systems, based in Campbell, Calif. The deal also calls for a technology exchange between Fujitsu and Hal, which plans a complete line of new computers, from work stations to mainframes. **********"Hal's skills in the design of hardware and software systems and Fujitsu's complementary capabilities in semiconductor technology will enable Hal to create world-class products," Mr. Heller said. **********The announcement met with some skepticism from industry analysts, who questioned whether there is a place for a new computer company. Many pointed to the example of Next Inc., formed by Steven P. Jobs, a founder of Apple Computer, which is still struggling to find a niche after five years. **********Mr. Heller, who is 44, scored his biggest success as vice president and general manager of I.B.M.'s advanced engineering systems' independent business unit, which developed the RISC System 6000 line of computers. **********But Mr. Heller, who is partial to cowboy boots, was regarded as a renegade within I.B.M.'s pin-striped culture. He was stripped of his management position and ultimately left the company in March 1989 to become a consulting partner with a Silicon Valley venture capital firm. **********Hal's computer will use a RISC design called Sparc, which was created by Sun Microsystems Inc. But Mr. Heller plans to achieve a significant jump in performance by designing his own implementation of Sparc, which will be produced by Fujitsu. **********The name Hal refers to the computer in the science-fiction film "2001: A Space Odyssey," which in turn was named by picking the letters that come before I, B and M in the alphabet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/01/world.main_headline: As Winter Nears, Quake Survivors Need Shelter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/01/world.print_headline: As Winter Nears, Quake Survivors Need Shelter
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/01/world.body_text: **********More than a month after their homes were destroyed by a devastating earthquake, thousands of ill-clad and frightened villagers in the Himalayan foothills still huddle with their cattle for warmth under tents as rain -- snow in the higher mountains -- signals the onset of winter. **********The survivors have lived in the open since Oct. 20, when an earthquake rumbled across a 70-mile belt in the foothills of the western Himalayas, destroying bridges, roads and villages. **********More than 700 people were killed, officials at Uttarkashi, a major town in the region, have said. Relief workers said the number was at least 1,500. **********District Magistrate Sunil Aggarwal said that the crucial factors in the next weeks would be the construction of snow-proof shelters and the providing of relief material, including food, blankets and medicines, to distant villages. **********Villagers are still without power and people in the worst-hit areas remain in tents, unable to fend off the cold, reports from the region indicated. **********In the village of Netala, clusters of tents have sprung up as the entire population, about 1,000 people, have deserted their damaged homes. **********District officials have appealed for tin sheets to replace the tents before winter envelops the region. **********"Right now we need houses and proper shelter," said Maheshwari Bhatt, the pradhan, or chief, of Netala. "The tents will not keep out the cold and the snow." **********Mrs. Bhatt said that the quake had killed 51 people in the hamlet, including 9 of her relatives. She added that the disaster had kept the villagers from sowing the wheat crop in time. Many buffalos and other cattle were killed, depriving the villagers of draft animals. Tractors are not used at these heights and many fields have been ruined by the collapse of walls that keep the terraced fields in place. **********The crumbled homes often also represent the collapse of years of toil. **********"Women sold their jewelry to help build the houses, and now entire families are paupers," said Raghubir Singh, a trader at Netala. **********For two weeks after the quake, Netala and hundreds of villages beyond it were cut off from the south because the only major bridge connecting the regions collapsed. Indian Army engineers built a temporary iron bridge. **********Mr. Aggarwal, the district magistrate, said that compensation for death and injuries was being distributed, with the next-of-kin of each of the dead receiving the equivalent of $800 dollars, up to a maximum per family of $2,400. Cash grants for rebuilding are also being distributed. **********Some engineers say cooperation is needed to develop safe structures. **********"The reason why so many died was not because of the magnitude of the earthquake but because the buildings were badly designed and badly built," said A. S. Rawat, an electrical engineer. "Light, flexible structures, such as tin and wood, are among the best in earthquake-prone areas." **********Mr. Rawat said that deforestation had led to a shortage of wood for construction, so that instead of the traditional homes of wood and earth, villagers took to using stone and plaster. **********Many villagers, envious of richer families who could afford homes of brick and mortar, plastered cement over rock walls to give visitors the impression that they too lived in "proper houses," Mr. Rawat said. But the buildings proved to be deathtraps.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/busin.body_text: **********The Eastman Kodak Company said on Tuesday that it had sold its Ultralife 9-volt lithium battery business for an undisclosed sum to investors operating under the name Ultralife Batteries Inc.
