https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/02/busin.main_headline: F.D.I.C. Is Dealt a Setback In Judge's Ruling on Mcorp
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/02/busin.print_headline: F.D.I.C. Is Dealt a Setback In Judge's Ruling on Mcorp
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/02/busin.body_text: **********The top agency regulating the nation's banks was dealt a potentially costly blow today when a Federal judge in Dallas ruled that the agency violated banking laws two years ago by seizing a dozen banks owned by Mcorp. **********When the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took that step, in March 1989, it was part of a broader action that put 20 of Mcorp's 25 subsidiary banks under Government control, and led to the bankruptcy of what had been the second-largest banking organization in Texas. **********In his opinion today, Judge Robert W. Porter defied a doctrine endorsed by the Federal Reserve Board, supported by President Bush and approved by Congress in August 1989, under which solvent banks operated by a bank holding company must cover losses of insolvent bank units in the company. **********Judge Porter ruled that no law to that effect was on the books when the Mcorp action was taken. **********The setback for the F.D.I.C. and its chairman, L. William Seidman, came two days after a Congressional task force gave a harsh assessment of the agency's sale of the 20 Mcorp banks, as well as 40 banks taken in 1988 from the First Republicbank Corporation. **********The Congressional report said the agency had overlooked a less costly bid for the Mcorp banks when it picked the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, as the acquirer over an offer from a group led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. That issue was not addressed by the judge. **********A spokesman for the F.D.I.C. in Washington, David Barr, said officials had not seen the judge's ruling and could not comment. **********Judge Porter blocked the agency from filing an appeal until after lawyers representing Mcorp and the F.D.I.C. prepare arguments on the amount the F.D.I.C. must pay in damages to the company. **********That is a vital concern for Mcorp's creditors and stockholders. Mcorp, which once hoped to carry on with the five banks it retained, has been in a slow state of liquidation for more than a year. It has $330 million in cash and Government securities, and owns three banks. **********Two of the five banks were sold last year; a sale is pending for a third, and negotiations are under way with potential buyers of the other two. Mcorp is seeking $250 million in actual damages from the F.D.I.C., plus $1 billion for various liabilities, like office lease payments it was unable to pay after the 20 banks were seized. **********Peter Bartholow, Mcorp's president and chief executive, said a recovery of $250 million in actual damages would give Mcorp enough money to repay creditors and "recover something for our stockholders." Mcorp's largest creditor was Shearson Lehman Brothers, which held $140 million in Mcorp debt. **********For its part, the F.D.I.C. is seeking more than $250 million from Mcorp through the holding company's bankruptcy proceedings in a Houston court.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/25/busin.main_headline: Canada Seeks Licenses For Pocket Telephones
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/25/busin.print_headline: Canada Seeks Licenses For Pocket Telephones
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/25/busin.body_text: **********In a move that upstages efforts in the United States, the Canadian Government said yesterday that it would begin taking applications for licenses for new wireless pocket telephone services. **********The move paves the way for the development of advanced services that are still the subject of lengthy policy debate in the United States. Analysts said the move was likely to increase the pressure on American policy makers as to what kinds of services they wanted to authorize. **********The Federal Communications Commission is collecting information from different experimental systems, but it has yet to determine what kind of service is needed or what frequencies on the radio spectrum should be made available. Four National Franchises **********The Canadian Communications Department said it would allocate a small swath of frequencies near those now used by ordinary cellular telephones. The agency said it was hoping to award four national franchises that would compete with one another. **********The new services would be somewhat more limited than today's cellular telephones, but they would also be more convenient, and in some ways, more flexible. With a range of about 600 yards, the phones would be used in designated "phone zones" in high-traffic locations. The zones would have clusters of antennas that would relay the signals to local telephone companies, which in turn would send the calls anywhere in the world. **********Much of a city's downtown business district, for example, would be one zone, as would a shopping mall or other high-traffic area. **********"It's like having a coin-operated telephone right in your pocket," said Parke Davis, the department's director of industry structure and services. Because the new phones would need very little power, Government officials said they expected them to cost as little as $150. **********In addition, the Government said it planned to allow private networks, not needing special licenses, that would allow people to use wireless telephones within a single building or as an improvement on cordless phones now used in homes. Such private networks could be used within an office to allow workers to communicate, or on college campuses or within nursing homes. **********But still unanswered is which of two rival technical standards Canada will adopt for the service. **********One group -- led by Rogers Cantel Inc. of Montreal, Motorola Inc., the cellular unit of Bell Canada, and Northern Telecom Inc. -- are pushing for what they call Cordless Telephone 2-Plus. But L. M. Ericsson, the big Swedish communications concern, is pressing for what it calls Cordless Telephone 3. **********Canadian officials said the systems would seem similar to consumers, but have different technical advantages and disadvantages. Service Seen by 1993 **********The officials said they were hoping to begin issuing licenses as early as July, and industry executives said they hoped to offer the first services as early as January l993. **********"This is where it gets real," said David Annan, the general manager of the personal communications division at Rogers Cantel, which holds a national franchise for cellular service. "This means that we and other people are now going to get very serious about arranging networking technologies, suppliers, products and financing." **********Herschel Shosteck, an independent cellular industry analyst in Silver Spring, Md., said the move would certainly place new pressures on the F.C.C. to decide how it wanted to authorize new wireless technologies. **********The commission has approved licenses for more than 80 experimental "personal communications networks," but the systems vary greatly, and the agency has yet to make even basic decisions about the services it wants to promote. **********Mr. Shosteck said the biggest question was simply deciding what the new services were supposed to do, and added that it remained unclear what consumers actually wanted or needed. **********"We see no market for P.C.N. as a second public network to compete with cellular," Mr. Shosteck said, adding that advanced cordless telephones in Britain had been a flop with consumers. But he said there were some "very interesting markets" for wireless office telephone systems and wireless corporate switchboards.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/busin.main_headline: The S.E.C. And the Death Of Disclosure
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH; The S.E.C. And the Death Of Disclosure
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Disclosure has been the foundation of American securities laws ever since the Securities and Exchange Commission was created, in the aftermath of the 1929 crash. **********But while the people at the S.E.C. still talk a good game when it comes to disclosure, the fact is that the rules requiring it are being sacrificed at the altar of internationalization. It is getting easier for foreign companies to get American money without bothering to comply with America's accounting standards, which are generally more strict, and require more information, than their overseas counterparts. **********There have always been ways for companies to raise capital in this country without complying with disclosure requirements, but they were relatively unimportant until the S.E.C. stepped in. Now, institutional investors can buy privately placed securities and trade them freely with other institutions. Often, there is minimal financial disclosure. **********The S.E.C.'s latest move is to assure that Americans who own foreign shares that are not registered here will get equal treatment in certain corporate transactions, like takeovers. That sometimes was prevented by the rules, and changing them sounds fair. To some extent, the old rule discouraged American ownership of such stocks, so changing it will encourage such purchases. **********In the long run, that development may prove much more important to the health of the American markets than the surprising jump in employment reported last week. Stock traders took their cue from the drop in bond prices, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 51.36 points, to 2,976.74. **********S.E.C. chairman Richard Breeden professes a deep belief in the disclosure rules, and vows that he will not allow large foreign companies to be traded publicly in this country without disclosure. He correctly points out that when international companies use different accounting rules, it can be impossible to compare them. **********Consider, for example, companies run by press barons. Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation tapped the American capital markets before the S.E.C. made it easy, and investors can see just how little net worth it has under American accounting rules. But Robert Maxwell's Mirror Group Newspapers raised $84 million from American investors last month, and made no comparable disclosure. What little the company did disclose -- to institutional investors only -- showed that, under the American rules, it probably had no net worth. **********The double standard shown by that situation can be expected to grow, as more and more companies become comfortable with private placements and as institutional investors grow accustomed to trading them. Eventually, those companies that comply with the rules will begin to feel more and more like fools, and will demand equal treatment. And the American standards of financial disclosure could wither away. **********If Mr. Breeden is not careful, that may end up being the legacy of his term as S.E.C. chairman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/world.main_headline: Nairobi Street Children Play Games of Despair
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/world.print_headline: Nairobi Street Children Play Games of Despair
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/02/world.body_text: **********As night fell, a group of girl prostitutes emerged from the squalid plastic and paper hutches they call home and ambled toward the luxury tourist hotel a few steps away. **********For this group of 6- to 16-year-olds in dirt-speckled clothes, business, the search for a $5 trick or a 20-cent handout, was about to begin. A few blocks away, a gang of homeless boys had started hustling, sidling up to European visitors, hands outstretched, asking for money. **********The number of street children abandoned by their parents and living by their wits has increased in Nairobi and other major sub-Saharan cities in recent years, a product of the breakdown of the extended families and village culture that were pillars of African life. By some estimates, 50,000 children roam this city's streets, often because their parents cannot afford the fees at Government schools. **********The streets of Nairobi are now divided into turfs, with gangs of girls run by what in Western terms would be considered pimps, and gangs of boys ruled by an older boy who enforces discipline. **********One gang of boys, led by Benson Matende Chero, claims the sidewalk outside a seedy pick-up joint, the New Florida Nightclub. Friday nights, with their array of diplomats, businessmen and adventurous tourists, are especially lucrative for Benson's beggars. The nightclub has the attraction of being a few blocks from Benson's headquarters, a stretch of litter-strewn grass hidden by trees in a city park. **********The gangs, generally not armed, are more juvenile support and self-protection groups than street gangs in the Western sense. **********Somewhat respectful of each other, the gangs do not resort to the kind of warfare common among Western street gangs. There are fights over turf, but not many. Too much time is spent on sheer survival: collecting money, scavenging food, fetching cooking water or washing clothes at a burst water main in a city park. **********The members decide on a method of survival -- begging and prostitution as is the case with the girls in the alley, or parking cars for a fee, or collecting trash. Then, with the leader in charge, they divide the daily proceeds among themselves. **********One of the denizens of the hutches in the alley, Elizabeth Wanjiru, 12, a tattered blue skirt and tee-shirt hanging from her spare frame, said she had been on the streets for a year. She came to Nairobi with her mother from their rural village to stay with her grandmother, she said, in a husky voice, the result of malnourishment. **********Her mother, who could no longer afford the fees for the school "building fund" -- an ostensibly voluntary but in practice mandatory contribution necessary to enroll at a Kenyan Government primary school -- went back to the countryside, abandoning her in Nairobi. The grandmother then chased her away. **********Neither the mother nor the grandmother could afford the $25 annual school cost. The Kenyan minimum wage amounts to about $480 a year, but many families have seven or eight children. **********Elizabeth said she could earn 100 Kenyan shillings by sleeping with a man, or about $5. She would give 20 shillings to one of the pimps, she said. She liked the pimps -- speaking in Swahili, she used a friendly term for "man," alluding to the protection that the four pimps offered -- because they did not force her to have sex with them. **********The most seasoned of the gang's prostitutes, Mercy Wanjiru, who is not related to Elizabeth, said she was 16. With a winning smile that flashed perfectly white teeth, Mercy looked more like 13 or 14. **********"Except for the disease, it's not a bad life," she said.  And Now, V.D. **********Mercy said she was upset because her genital sores had become so painful that she could no longer work. She was unafraid of AIDS, she said, because she slept only with African men, whom she considered safer than white men. She usually stayed near the 20th Century Cinema, the plushest movie house in Nairobi, waiting for a client to drive by. She would earn as much as 200 shillings a client. **********But her venereal disease now meant that she could only attract the clients and pass them on to other girls in the gang, who were less experienced and yielded only 100 shillings. Thus, she said, the men at the head of the gang were becoming abusive, even hitting her. **********A few streets from the alley of the girls, Benson runs a gang of 32 homeless boys who have found a home in the city park across the road from a new slick black marble monument venerating Kenya's President, Daniel arap Moi. Benson showed a visitor his bed, a battered steel packing case swathed in an outer layer of plastic sheeting and hidden among litter in the center of the tree-studded park. **********One of 11 children, he said he never knew his mother. He left his rural village eight years ago, driven away by the violence that surrounded a second marriage of his father, a bus driver. He said begging was the best means of survival for his gang because it left it less vulnerable to the law than other street activities.  Parking Boys and Beggars **********Selling parking spaces or offering to watch parked cars, a common way for Nairobi's vagrants to raise money, left his gang members too vulnerable to the petty crimes of other parking boys. For example, a gang member could be charged for stealing a car mirror when in fact he had not done it. Collecting garbage also left one open to charges of theft, he said. **********With begging, he had developed routines. His favorite targets were white tourists -- "millionaires," he said in one of his few words of English -- many of whom do not understand the value of Kenyan money. **********So far, social workers say, the peddling of drugs, a mainstay of Western street gangs, has not permeated juvenile street life in Nairobi. But sniffing glue, a substance used by sidewalk shoe repairers, is a popular high among the children. Glue costing the equivalent of 50 cents a hit increased his motivation, Benson said. **********"You can even dare to rob." Benson said he had been arrested so many times that he could not keep track. But one charge stuck: he spent 10 months in a juvenile center for "snatching," he said, followed by 18 months in Government schools of detention before "escaping."  Social Workers Wonder **********The problem of street children leaves social workers struggling for answers. "There's a big increase in street kids, especially in the number of girls," said Jones Muchendu, a social worker with the Undugu Society, a private Kenyan group that helps street children. **********"It's because of the economy," he said. "Most people in the slums are unemployed, most parents are single parents. Life in the city is very expensive. Everything depends on cash, even water. Now the girls are even sent to the streets by the parents to look for money and they become prostitutes." **********The Undugu Society says that Nairobi, a metropolitan area some estimate at two million people, has several thousand "hard core" children with no parental supervision and 50,000 other children who roam the streets because their single parents cannot afford the fees at Government schools. **********Nearly 25 percent of Kenya's population, now about 24 million, live in cities, compared with less than 10 percent at independence in 1964, according to the World Bank. Similar increases have occurred in all the major cities from Lagos in Nigeria to Lusaka in Zambia. **********The United Nations estimates that 40 percent to 75 percent of squatter families in Nairobi are headed by single women, a phenomenon that it described as "symptomatic of the breakdown of the traditional family structures and the increasingly ambivalent role of the male in the household." **********For the child vagrants of Nairobi, the Christmas and New Year holidays present a period of danger. The city authorities, intent on an upbeat image for tourists, stepped up the number of police squads. Arrest and detention in an overcrowded, often brutal juvenile center are about the only remedies that the economically stretched Kenyan Government offers to the problem of the street children.  Government Is Embarrassed **********The harsh attitude of the Kenyan authorities is a combination of callousness and economic limitations. The children are considered an embarrassment and a blight on Nairobi, the Government's public showcase. And many of the social services now considered a basic right in developed countries have long been considered the duty of the family in Africa. **********To counter these punitive attitudes, Undugu Society, founded in the mid-1970's under the auspices of a Dutch missionary, has a network of social workers, four schools with a Government-approved curriculum and a reception center. Now run by a Kenyan staff, the society has reunited some street children with their rural families. **********But even some of the charitable endeavors of the Undugu Society -- the name comes from the Swahili word for "solidarity" -- have been ripped up by the authorities. In April this year, because of the overwhelming numbers of homeless children, the society added to its services a temporary school and shelter, in a squatter settlement, walking distance from downtown. **********By giving poles and plastic and mud for the walls, the society persuaded the boys to build the school themselves. There, Benson learned some trade skills. The boys slept at the shelter at night. During one of its zealous slum clearance campaigns, the city council bulldozed the shelter, scattering the boys back to the parks and alleys.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/busin.body_text: **********The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it had put another of its financial problems behind it by settling a tax dispute with the Internal Revenue Service. **********McDonnell Douglas said it had already paid the Government the additional $150 million called for in the settlement. Because the company had set up financial reserves in excess of that amount to cover any settlement, McDonnell Douglas executives said they expected to record a one-time gain to earnings of about $50 million in the fourth quarter. **********As part of the settlement, the I.R.S. returned to McDonnell Douglas the stock of the McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Company, a wholly owned subsidiary that the Government had held title to pending a resolution. **********The agreement comes as McDonnell Douglas, the nation's largest military contractor and its second-largest maker of commercial jetliners, is rebounding from a financial crisis that early this year threatened the company's viability. McDonnell Douglas, which is based in St. Louis, has restored its commercial aircraft business to profitability and substantially reduced its debt. **********The company remains intent on cost-cutting, however, and yesterday said it expected to cut between 1,800 and 3,800 jobs out of a work force of 41,000 at its Douglas Aircraft subsidiary in the next 18 months. **********A spokesman said the cuts would come from a combination of layoffs and attrition, and would affect both the commercial aircraft production lines and Douglas's one big military program, the C-17 transport plane. Most of the job cuts are expected to come from Douglas's main plant in Long Beach, Calif. The company previously warned that declining orders for jetliners would lead to further layoffs. **********McDonnell Douglas share price closed yesterday at $69.875, unchanged, on the Big Board. **********The settlement ends a dispute over the company's taxes from 1977 to 1985. The dispute centered on the timing of the completion of the company's Government contracts, an issue that has led to similar tax problems for other aerospace companies. **********McDonnell Douglas said it still must pay the Government more than $500 million in deferred taxes and interest by the end of 1994 to cover the years 1986 through 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.main_headline: Administration Foresees a Deficit In Bank Insurance Fund by 1992
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.print_headline: Administration Foresees a Deficit In Bank Insurance Fund by 1992
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.body_text: **********Raising the specter of another huge taxpayer bailout, the White House has estimated that the program that insures bank deposits will show a deficit sometime next year, Government officials said today. And after that, they said, the hole will only grow deeper. **********The projection by the Office of Management and Budget, made in the budget request the White House will send to Congress on Feb. 4, is the first official estimate to become public that suggests that the bank insurance fund could be insolvent as early as 1992. The White House projection is that by the end of next year, the fund will have a deficit of $4 billion and that by 1995 the shortfall will be $23 billion. **********A taxpayer rescue could be averted through increased industry contributions, but the insurance fund's troubles would still be felt by bank depositors and other customers through increased fees and lower rates paid on deposits. **********The fund has posted three consecutive years of losses, and is now at its lowest ratio of insurance to deposits since its creation in 1934. Because of the growing number of failures of large banks, the fund is expected to show record losses for both last year and this year, totaling $9 billion. That would leave it with about $4 billion by the end of this year. Fears of Another Bailout **********Administration officials have struggled in recent months to distinguish the plight of the fund and the commercial banking industry from that of the nation's savings and loans. The bailout of that industry could cost taxpayers as much as $500 billion over 40 years. But the latest estimates on the bank fund and the failure of the banking industry to agree on a solution provide the strongest indication so far that a bailout to protect bank deposits may also be needed. **********"The Treasury is looking at a budget that has a black hole and saying our first job is to fill that black hole," a bank lobbyist said. "If the economy and the real estate markets do not turn around soon, then it is clear we will not be able to make up the difference." **********Industry representatives have been meeting with regulators and Treasury officials this week to try to find a way to rebuild the insurance fund through industry contributions in a way that would not cripple banks, many of which have been posting anemic profits. **********"They are still far from any agreement," said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. He added that within the next month, the F.D.I.C. would probably be considering another increase in the premiums that banks pay to the insurance fund.   Rising Premiums **********On Jan. 1, the premium paid by banks to the fund rose to 19.5 cents for every $100 in deposits, from 12 cents. Lobbyists are predicting that it could soon be increased again, to at least 23 cents. For the first nine months of 1990, the industry earned about 60 cents for each $100 in deposits. **********The White House estimate is based on the expectation that the premium will increase to 23 cents, an 18 percent jump over the current payments and a 92 percent rise over the 12 cents paid last year. Its projections for losses are based upon an economic model that compares the capital and quality of assets of banks with the trends shown by similar institutions that failed. **********A similar method has been used by the Congressional Budget Office, which will present its latest forecasts on the health of the insurance fund at a Congressional hearing on Tuesday. The budget office projection is also expected to show a deficit, even assuming an increase in industry contributions. **********Mr. Seidman said the F.D.I.C. was in the process of calculating how it would fare in 1992, and he questioned the reliability of long-range forecasts. Within the last year, the F.D.I.C. has been forced several times to increase its estimates of the amount it expected to lose. **********The Administration is preparing to release its proposals for overhauling the banking industry next week, shortly after the President's State of the Union address on Tuesday.   Activities Are Restricted **********The proposals will call for the elimination of barriers that have prevented the merger of commercial and investment banks, have sharply limited interstate banking and have prohibited industrial enterprises from owning commercial banks. The Administration will also recommend a significant reorganization of the regulatory structure that oversees banks and savings associations. **********But officials said today that the package might not include specific details on reorganizing the bank insurance fund because bank trade groups in Washington had been unable to agree among themselves on how to proceed. **********A senior official at the Treasury Department said that despite the disagreements, the Administration would support some significant principles in next week's report. **********"We think our plan ought to take care of the future and rely on the industry," said the official, who insisted on anonymity. "But it ought not break the backs of the banks." **********"It ought to have the industry's leadership behind it, but that is complicated to achieve," the official continued. "To bring together an industry as diverse as banking is a very, very tough job."  Sizing Up the Contributions **********The official said the Treasury Department did not know how much the industry would be able to contribute without damaging some banks and leading to sizable failures. **********One proposal under discussion is for banks that are more secure to set up a fund to invest in weaker institutions. But officials and industry representatives said there were substantial disagreements over the size of such a fund and its structure. Of particular concern to some banks, especially the smaller ones, is whether the fund would be used only to prop up the larger institutions. **********Another proposal being discussed is the issuing of zero-coupon bonds backed by bank assets to raise $25 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/22/busin.main_headline: 3 Marketers Are Packaging Film Tie-Ins, Kiddie-Style
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 3 Marketers Are Packaging Film Tie-Ins, Kiddie-Style
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/22/busin.body_text: **********SOME of the nation's largest consumer-prodct companies are choosing sides in the battle that begins today between two animated Christmas-season films, "An American Tail: Fievel Goes West" and "Beauty and the Beast." **********Hoping that the appeal of the films' cartoon characters will animate sales of their products, marketing giants like Colgate-Palmolive, Nabisco Brands and Pizza Hut are spending tens of millions of dollars on elaborate promotional and advertising programs tied to the movies. **********Universal Pictures is opening "An American Tail: Fievel Goes West" in about 1,400 theaters nationwide. And Walt Disney is opening "Beauty and the Beast" in 900 or so additional theaters after a successful limited release last week in Los Angeles and New York. **********The programs underscore the intensifying concern among marketers that as consumer interest wanes in traditional mass media like network television, they must devise new ways to deliver their messages. As a result, in the last decade these programs, called movie tie-ins, have become popular marketing tools; today's releases are unleashing perhaps the most extensive, and expensive, series of tie-ins yet. **********"The results, we find, are very effective," Jeff Myers, Nabisco's senior director of integrated marketing programs, said in a telephone interview from his office in Parsippany, N.J. Nabisco's program ties in with the nonprofit Reading Is Fundamental Inc. organization, which is using Fievel, the mouse that stars in "An American Tail," in a Reading Buddies project intended to encourage children to read. **********"We're optimistic that Fievel will become larger than mouse," Mr. Myers said. Nabisco will mail consumers Reading Buddies kits, featuring Fievel, in exchange for proofs of purchase from cookie and cracker packages. **********Nabisco's program typifies the predominant link between marketer and film studio in most movie tie-ins: a desire to reach children and families. **********"We look for all-family, wholesome entertainment," Michael L. Hoye, executive vice president of Colgate U.S., said in an interview in his office in midtown Manhattan. His colleague, Chester Gittleman, associate director of promotion management, said that the company's movie tie-in standards were as stringent as for the content of television programs in which Colgate ran commercials. **********The primary reason Colgate chose to tie in with "Beauty and the Beast" was the Disney imprimatur, Mr. Hoye said. In a videotape produced for Colgate's sales force, which was shown to retailers, he called Colgate's movie tie-in "merchandising with that Disney magic that's sure to ring up holiday sales." **********The tie-in, Colgate's first with the theatrical release of a film, offers consumers a "Beauty and the Beast" storybook in exchange for mailing in proofs of purchase from packages of Colgate-brand toothpaste, toothbrushes and mouth rinse. It is being promoted in a television spot, created by Young & Rubicam New York, for which Colgate bought around $3 million worth of air time; in 50 million coupon inserts that appeared in Sunday newspapers on Nov. 10, and in aisle displays in some 25,000 stores across the country. **********Sometimes, of course, when all the magic in Hollywood cannot sell a film, marketers find that the tie-in plans they made, usually a year or more in advance of a film's release, hogtie them to a box-office disappointment or out-and-out bomb. **********"If a picture is a dog, it doesn't matter how much hype you have on it," said Philip Garfinkle, senior vice president of Entertainment Data Inc., a Beverly Hills, Calif., firm that tracks movies' box-office performance. **********Yet that does not necessarily spell doom for a dud film's tie-ins. Bob Perkins, senior vice president of marketing for Pizza Hut in Wichita, Kan., recalled the company's tie-ins with "The Rocketeer," a Disney summer release that never ignited among filmgoers. **********"'The Rocketeer' was not the biggest movie of the summer," he said diplomatically, "but it worked out great for us." So Pizza Hut is returning to tie-ins by featuring characters from "An American Tail" on boxes of its Pizza Pack children's meal and on soft-drink cups.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/busin.main_headline: A Financing Drive Begun By Sematech
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; A Financing Drive Begun By Sematech
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/20/busin.body_text: **********Sematech, the controversial American semiconductor industry consortium, today formally opened what could be a difficult battle to continue to receive Government funding for five more years. Its initial charter expires at the end of this fiscal year. **********The consortium, based in Austin, Tex., outlined a proposed strategy for the next five years that will mainly carry on the work it started in its first five, with two significant changes. **********One change is that the consortium will put less emphasis on producing chips from start to finish at its factory in Austin, and will instead use the factory mainly to test individual pieces of manufacturing equipment. The other is a new thrust toward developing software to automate semiconductor factories.  A Pioneering Example **********Sematech is a pioneering example of a cooperation among American companies aimed at improving the competitiveness of the United States industry that makes the microelectronic circuits used in everything from computers to videocassette recorders and missiles. **********Opinions on Sematech's track record so far range from highly effective to completely useless. Certainly, Sematech appears to have helped some American companies improve their products, but the American industry as a whole still trails the Japanese in certain key markets, like memory chips. **********Sematech could face a battle both in Congress and within the Bush Administration to continue receiving the $100 million a year in Defense Department funding that accounts for about half of its budget. The other half comes from 13 member companies, which include large semiconductor companies and some computer companies that also make chips, like I.B.M. and the Digital Equipment Corporation. **********The Bush Administration has expressed an aversion to having the Government finance particular industries, although it has opened the door to "precompetitive generic" technology development that could be of use to many industries. There is also pressure on the Defense Department to restrict its dwindling budget to areas directly connected to the military. **********Sematech's new thrust into computer-aided manufacturing seems to be in part intended to make the consortium more acceptable, down to borrowing the Administration's buzzwords. Sematech refers to its new effort as "precompetitive generic R&D to apply software solutions to U.S. manufacturing problems." The planning document also highlights how important semiconductors are to high-tech weapons. **********William J. Spencer, president and chief executive of Sematech, said in an interview that he is optimistic the consortium will continue to receive Government funding. **********He said the Defense Department budget for fiscal 1993, which begins in October, includes funding for Sematech at some unknown level. The budget figures have not yet been released. **********But Dr. Spencer said Sematech members will continue with the project even in the absence of Government funding, although progress would be slower. **********In its plan for the next five years the consortium said it would continue to focus on improving the quality and technical capability of the numerous small American companies that make tools used in computer chip manufacturing and to shrink the sizes of circuits. **********New technical goals will be to reduce circuit features to .25 microns by the end of 1994 and .18 microns by the end of 1996, compared with .35 microns that Sematech is now starting to achieve. **********Dr. Spencer said the new software effort will give companies the ability to predict the effect of changes in their manufacturing processes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/busin.main_headline: S.E.C. Case Says Scheme May Have Defrauded 40,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/busin.print_headline: S.E.C. Case Says Scheme May Have Defrauded 40,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/17/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had uncovered an investment scheme that may have defrauded 40,000 people, mostly from lower-income families and minorities, of tens of millions of dollars. **********In court papers unsealed today, the commission said International Loan Network Inc. promised its investors that they would be able quickly to make five times their investments in cash or 10 times their investments in property value. The papers were unsealed a day after a Federal district judge in Washington froze the assets of both the company and its two senior executives. **********S.E.C. officials said the solicitations were made at pep-rally-like seminars held by the company's founder, Melvin J. Ford, a former encyclopedia salesman from North Carolina who has been under investigation in at least seven states. No Response to Messages **********Mr. Ford did not respond to a message left at his office today seeking comment, and S.E.C. officials said that neither he nor the company had listed who they were retaining as their lawyers. **********At the investor meetings, Mr. Ford would give out checks as large as $50,000 and provide testimonials from people who claimed to have received large returns on their investments. The meetings are said to have drawn thousands of potential and actual investors, who contributed between $100 and $25,000. **********The Rev. Jesse Jackson was a keynote speaker at one such daylong meeting earlier this year in Washington. Mr. Jackson has not been accused of wrongdoing. **********"When Ford speaks, the audience reportedly becomes very excited as he describes the tremendous wealth that participants can accumulate if they invest in I.L.N.," Daniel H. Rubenstein, an S.E.C. lawyer, said in a court declaration. "At one meeting, Ford stated that I.L.N. distributed over $60 million during the past two years." **********Barry Goldsmith, another lawyer at the S.E.C., said the contributions were used as part of a pyramid, or Ponzi, scheme, to pay back those who invested earlier. Investors received bonus payments for recruiting new investors, he added. Recent Transfers of Cash **********On Wednesday a Federal district judge in Washington issued orders under seal to freeze the assets of the company, Mr. Ford and a vice president of the company, Odell Mundey. S.E.C. lawyers said they were prompted by recent transfers of more than $2 million from the company's bank accounts, including $300,000 to a bank account in the Bahamas in the name of Worldwide Properties Inc. **********The court orders were served on Mr. Ford Wednesday afternoon at a hotel near La Guardia Airport in New York, where he was completing a 31-city tour to attract new investors. **********International Loan Network is based in Lanham, Md. Since the company was founded in October 1988, it is said to have got at least $40 million from at least 40,000 investors. **********In one investment program, the company promised that persons who invested $25,000 would receive either stock in real estate valued at $250,000 or income of $50,000 a year for life.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/busin.main_headline: Stenrich to Develop Campaign for WNET
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Stenrich to Develop Campaign for WNET
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/04/busin.body_text: **********WNET, Channel 13, the New York public television station, has recruited Stenrich Group Inc., a direct- marketing firm from Virginia, to develop an advertising campaign to attract and retain members. **********The station previously used a variety of agencies for its advertising needs. After an informal review, it decided to integrate those responsibilities and assign them to Stenrich, an agency it had not used before, said Jennifer Friedberg, the station's director of membership. **********The $50 million agency, which is based in Glen Allen, Va., is already working on a direct-mail campaign, Ms. Friedberg said. **********"I really thought they were best suited to our business," Ms. Friedberg said. "They are a small boutique with copy strength. The president had experience with PBS. Personally, my experience with players at Stenrich was excellent."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/29/busin.body_text: **********Daimler-Benz A.G., maker of Mercedes automobiles, said today that it was buying a 10 percent stake in Metallgesellschaft A.G. in what analysts viewed as a step into the car-recycling business. **********At current market prices, the stake is worth about $233 million. It was sold by Dresdner Bank, which still holds a 13.3 percent interest. **********Analysts said the purchase would help Daimler increase its efforts to recycle old cars and strengthen its links with Metallgesellschaft's car-parts subsidiary. **********Car makers began looking at recycling the growing numbers of scrapped cars after Bonn's Environment Minister, Klaus Topfer, asked them to devise a plan for recycling. **********Daimler's rival in luxury cars, Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G., maker of the BMW, opened a pilot recycling plant last year.
