https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Ex-Drexel Executive Heads Blair Brokerage
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/busin.body_text: **********Richard A. Maio has taken a job heading a much smaller operation than he used to. But then his old company, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., is no longer in business. **********Mr. Maio, 50, has been named president and chief operating officer of D. H. Blair Brokerage, a new position at D. H. Blair & Company, a relatively small investment firm that specializes in bringing small companies public. **********At Drexel, Mr. Maio was a senior vice president and national sales manager of the retail sales division. "Those were the most productive and happiest eight years of my life," Mr. Maio said yesterday, contemplating the heady 1980's. "It was a wonderful place." **********Drexel, the former powerhouse that popularized "junk bonds" under Michael R. Milken, collapsed last year and sought protection from creditors in bankruptcy proceedings. **********D. H. Blair is based at 44 Wall Street and specializes in what Mr. Maio called "public venture capital" -- selling stock in promising companies that might or might not succeed. **********"Their desire now is to capitalize on that niche but yet bring the firm into the present market and update its product line to become a mainstream house," Mr. Maio said. That would mean more research and recommendations of listed stocks, more involvement in the fixed-income markets, certificates of deposit, bonds, mutual funds and so forth, he said. **********Mr. Maio will report to the president and chief operating officer of D. H. Blair & Company, Kenton E. Wood, who will also hold the new title of chairman and chief executive of D. H. Blair Brokerage. J. Morton Davis is chairman and chief executive of D. H. Blair & Company. **********Before he joined Drexel, Mr. Maio spent 19 years at E. F. Hutton, now part of the American Express Company. During that time, he rose from broker to branch manager to national product manager. He developed and marketed several Hutton products, including certificates of deposit, zero-coupon bonds and bankers' acceptances. **********Mr. Maio attended Villanova University and is a graduate of the University of Miami. Earlier, he spent four years at La Salle Military Academy, where his roommate for a time was John H. Sununu, now the President's chief of staff. **********As for his role at D. H. Blair, he said, "You never want to expand something at the expense of something else." The public-offering niche, he added, "gives us a nice foothold and a nice springboard."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/world.main_headline: Ex-Beirut Hostage Is in Care of U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/world.print_headline: Ex-Beirut Hostage Is in Care of U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/23/world.body_text: **********Jesse Turner, pale and slightly unsteady on his feet after nearly five years in captivity in Lebanon, was turned over to American officials in Damascus today. **********"I am happy to be out, finally," he said in a soft voice. "I am looking forward to seeing my family and friends." **********The 44-year-old Mr. Turner, who was held by a pro-Iranian group called Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, was an assistant professor of computer science and mathematics at Beirut University College when he was kidnapped by men posing as Lebanese police officers on Jan. 24, 1987. **********Mr. Turner appeared exhausted and pale. When he was leaving his brief news conference he stumbled and nearly fell before being assisted to a waiting car. Few Public Comments **********American officials who met with Mr. Turner described him as "lucid" and "chatty." But the released hostage made few public comments, they said, because of his fear that he might jeopardize the release of the remaining hostages. **********There are now eight Westerners believed held hostage in Lebanon, including four Americans, two Germans, an Italian and a Briton. **********When Mr. Turner was asked if he had knowledge of other hostages in Lebanon he looked toward the American Ambassador, Christopher Ross, for guidance, whispered a comment to the diplomat, and then declined to answer. Information on Captive **********Mr. Turner was held at least part of the time with another American, Alann Steen. Asked whether he had any information to pass on from Mr. Steen, Mr. Turner said: "Not at this moment, no. I want to speak to his wife first." **********Mr. Turner also refused to comment on whether he carried a statement or a message from his kidnappers. **********Mr. Turner, who had a bushy moustache, neatly cropped hair and wore a double-breasted beige jacket, was turned over to Syrian security forces in the early morning hours Tuesday in Lebanon. He was driven to the Syrian Foreign Ministry in Damascus, where he was greeted by Ambassador Ross and Nasser Qaddur, the Syrian Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, about 9 A.M. **********Two hours later, he boarded a C-141 transport plane to an American military hospital in Wiesbaden, Germany. He will be joined there by his Lebanese wife, Badr, and a 4-year-old daughter, Joanne, who was born five months after his abduction. Mr. Turner will also undergo psychological and medical tests and be debriefed by State Department officials. Confusion on Release **********United Nations officials and Western diplomats are hopeful that further releases will soon follow as Iran, Lebanese groups and Israel continue to exchange information through United Nations. **********The United Nations announced the impending release of a Western hostage on Sunday, the first time the organization has forecast such an event. **********The Lebanese group that held Mr. Turner said he would be released early Monday, but several hours elapsed before Mr. Turner was actually turned over to the Syrian authorities and brought to Damascus, creating some confusion among diplomats and Syrians who were following the event. **********The delay may have been due to fighting along the transit route, Western diplomats said. Members of the Party of God, the largest Iranian-backed Shiite Muslim faction in Lebanon, battled a local Lebanese clan in the town of Baalbek in the Bekaa until close to midnight. Clashes Cause Delay **********Mr. Turner was apparently taken out of the town, which serves as the Party of God's headquarters and is where many of the remaining Westerners are believed to be held, only after Syrian troops moved in to impose a cease-fire, Western diplomats said. **********Baalbek is the main town in the Bekaa, which is under Syrian military control. But Syrian troops are not allowed to enter the barracks and training centers belonging to the Party of God, which is believed to be the umbrella organization for all of the groups holding Western hostages. Its operations in Baalbek are supported by a force of several thousand Iranian Revolutionary Guards. **********Mr. Qaddur said Syria would "continue to exert all its efforts" to get the remaining Western hostages out of Lebanon. **********United Nations officials, seeming buoyed by the resumption of prisoner exchanges in Lebanon, say they expect to announce new releases soon. **********Those officials said Mr. Turner's release was the outcome of an "intensive stage" of negotiations between Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar's special envoy, Giandomenico Picco, and a hostage negotiator identified as Abu Abdullah, described as the "special envoy of the organization that holds the hostages."  Pact on Freeing Captives **********The Israelis hold about 300 Arab prisoners, including Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, a Party of God leader who was kidnapped from his home in southern Lebanon by Israeli commandos on July 28, 1989. **********Israel released 15 Arabs on Monday after receiving hard information about the fate of one of its missing servicemen, Pvt. Yossi Fink, who was confirmed dead. **********Israel is demanding concrete information on four remaining missing servicemen. **********The Lebanese kidnappers said the decision to free Mr. Turner constituted an "obligation and readiness to complete the comprehensive agreement being arranged to free all prisoners and the hostages." **********Israel freed 51 Arabs and turned over the bodies of 9 guerrillas after Lebanese kidnappers freed a British hostage, John McCarthy, and an American, Edward Austin Tracy, in August and provided information on the fate of one of Israel's missing servicemen.                    --------------------       Turner Arrives in Germany **********WIESBADEN, Germany, Oct. 22 (Special to The New York Times) -- An unsteady Jesse Turner was helped from a United States army helicopter by two crewmen this afternoon, but managed a broad smile at the sight of several hundred Americans at a United States military hospital here welcoming him with shouts and tiny American flags. **********Mr. Turner smiled and waved repeatedly. When a reporter shouted a question about what he would do tonight, he smiled and shrugged his shoulders, then entered the hospital without making a statement. **********A military spokesman, Comdr. John Woodhouse, said physicians who gave Mr. Turner a preliminary checkup aboard the C-141 military transport plane that brought him to the big American Rhine-Main air base near here from Damascus, Syria, said he "appears to be in generally good health." **********The spokesman said he had no information about his psychological state. **********The Wiesbaden hospital has become a kind of official recepion center for Americans released from captivity in the Middle East, since the 52 American hostages held in Teheran arrived here in 1980 after 444 days of captivity. But by 1993, the sprawling medical center will be shut down under plans to cut the American military presence in Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/11/busin.main_headline: OPEC Cuts: How Much and Whose?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/11/busin.print_headline: OPEC Cuts: How Much and Whose?
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/11/busin.body_text: **********When OPEC ministers gather on Monday in Geneva for their first meeting since the end of the Persian Gulf war, they are expected to try to rein in overproduction, seeking to prevent a collapse of crude oil prices. **********Oil analysts say the ministers will probably reaffirm the organization's prewar target price of $21 a barrel. That is about $3.50 above current levels for crude oil from the gulf. But oil experts say the meeting could grow tense when the ministers debate how much production should be cut, and by whom, to re-establish the $21 price. **********"There is a tremendous desire among all OPEC countries to prevent an oil-price collapse," said Mehdi Varzi, a London-based oil analyst with Kleinwort Benson Securities Ltd. "They all recognize they have to cut output collectively for the second quarter. But how they do it? That's where the problems arise." Crippled Export Capacity **********Since the oil-production and export capacities of Kuwait and Iraq are crippled, many analysts say it should not be difficult for the 11 other OPEC members to carve up their production into a new system of quotas, but in the highly charged postwar atmosphere that may not be so easy. **********With Saudi Arabia accounting for about 8.3 million of the nearly 23 million barrels a day that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pumped last month, other OPEC members are expected to put pressure on the Saudis to absorb the bulk of any cuts. But the Saudis say they will fend off such pressure. After incurring some $50 billion in expenses in fighting Baghdad, as well as huge investments to increase output to offset the embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, Saudi Arabia does not want to be the only country to cut production. **********Oil analysts say the Saudis do not want prices to rise quickly, since a price jump could be seen as a slap in the face to the United States and other Western nations that joined Riyadh in fighting Iraq. What is more, the Saudis recognize that a jump in prices could undermine a recovery of the slumping American economy.  Agreement on Price **********"What they will quickly agree on is the price will go to $21," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, based in New York. "The question is whether the price will go up right away." **********Some analysts suggest that Washington would not be disappointed if OPEC moved to re-establish a price of $21 a barrel, which is usually about $2 a barrel below the price of West Texas intermediate, the benchmark American grade of crude oil. In February, OPEC's average price was $17.55 a barrel. **********"Twenty-one dollars is realistic for everyone, even the U.S.," said Pierre Terzian, editor of Petrostrategies, a Paris-based oil journal. He said that level would just reaffirm the July price target, to which Washington did not object. He added that because the dollar has plunged against the Japanese yen and most European currencies, oil, which is priced in dollars, is far cheaper for Japan and Western Europe than it was five years ago.  A Glut in the Offing **********Oil experts say that if OPEC continues to produce oil at the February rate of 23 million barrels a day, a glut could develop quickly. Prices would plunge as a result, because daily demand for OPEC oil is expected to be between 21 million and 21.5 million barrels in the second quarter. **********Demand for oil historically falls by more than two million barrels a day from the first quarter to the second as spring weather comes to the Northern Hemisphere. Also weighing on the market is some 120 million barrels of oil stored in tankers at sea, far more than the 45 million barrels usually stored that way. **********In Geneva on Sunday, the Oil Minister of Indonesa, Ginanjar Kartasasmita, said: "OPEC will take all the necessary steps to stabilize the market. If a cut is necessary, then we will do it." **********Saudi Arabia's former oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said that if nothing was done to control the glut, oil prices could drop to $12 a barrel. He said Friday that there was a 50 percent chance that OPEC would agree on new production ceilings at the Geneva meeting. **********Sheik Yamani said one possibility that could drive down prices was a resumption of Iraqi exports by June. Some experts said the country's northern oilfields were only partially damaged by allied bombing. But many analysts said it would take much longer for Iraqi oil to enter export markets, because of the continuing embargo against Iraq and the destruction of that country's electric power stations. **********OPEC's Market Monitoring Committee, which is not empowered to decide on production quotas, meets on Monday to review the supply and demand situation. Oil analysts say there is a good chance the ministers will turn the committee's talks into a full-scale emergency meeting to decide on quota levels. **********Last July, OPEC set a production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day, but those quotas were suspended in September, when the 4 million barrels a day produced by Iraq and Kuwait were embargoed after the invasion of Kuwait. **********Many oil analysts predict that OPEC will agree to set a production ceiling of 21 million or 21.5 million barrels a day. "If they cut to 21 million barrels, it won't take long to establish the $21-a-barrel price," said Mr. Varzi of Kleinwort Benson. "If they cut to 21.5 million barrels, it will take longer." **********In recent days, OPEC ministers have maneuvered to put pressure on Saudi Arabia, the world's largest exporter, to cut production. In a comment that many construed as a suggestion that Saudi Arabia had become a vassal of Washington, Algeria's Oil Minister, Sadek Boussena, who is also the president of OPEC, said the gulf countries had to "show their capability of pursuing an independent oil policy, despite the new balance of forces in the region." **********Some of OPEC's price hawks fear that Saudi Arabia wants to keep its and OPEC's production high to please Washington, since this would help hold down prices. But Saudi officials deny they are doing Washington's bidding, noting that they have long opposed high prices. **********Saudi production is some 3 million barrels a day higher than the 5.3 million barrels a day the country produced before Iraq invaded Kuwait. **********The key to the meeting, many analysts say, is whether the Saudis can persuade other members to cut production as well. **********Analysts expect the Saudis to balk at accepting a quota of less than seven million barrels a day. Indeed, OPEC officials say Kuwait is negotiating with Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates so they could produce part of Kuwait's 1.5 million-barrel-a-day quota. This would help pay for Kuwait's reconstruction. Kuwait would, in theory, repay this production when its oilfields are up and running.                    --------------------       New Kuwait Oil Output **********KUWAIT CITY, March 10 (AP) -- Kuwait hopes to start producing 50,000 barrels of oil a day in the next two months to run its power stations, an executive with the Kuwait Oil Company said today. **********Officials have estimated that between 80 and 85 percent of Kuwait's oil production capacity was damaged by fires set by fleeing Iraqi troops, but the executive, Ahmad Murad, said some wells were unscathed. **********"We have identified about 30 to 40 wells which are not on fire, but they could have been affected," he said at a news conference. "There are a number of wells that are not even damaged. In fact, I saw 7 by my own eyesight." **********Mr. Murad said tentative plans call for American firefighters to start tackling the blazes on Friday after equipment is brought from the United States. He said that once Kuwait starts producing crude for the power stations, the next goal will be to start producing another 50,000 barrels a day to refine into gasoline for the local market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/busin.main_headline: I.B.M. Model to Be Sold by Mitsubishi
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/busin.print_headline: I.B.M. Model to Be Sold by Mitsubishi
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/27/busin.body_text: **********I.B.M. has agreed to allow the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation of Japan to sell an I.B.M. mainframe, the first time I.B.M. has allowed another computer company to resell one of its most powerful machines. **********The agreement, announced this week in Japan, could help the International Business Machines Corporation achieve greater sales in the large and highly competitive Japanese market, in which I.B.M. has recently been having problems. **********The accord is also a reflection of the broad consolidation going on in the world computer industry, particularly among manufacturers of mainframes, the large machines used for central data processing.   Hardware and Software **********Mitsubishi Electric will resell under its own name the I.B.M. 9121 processor, which is at the low end of I.B.M.'s 390 mainframe line, and the MVS/ESA operating system, the software for controlling the computer. In Japan, Mitsubishi said it hoped to sell 900 machines in the next three years, at roughly $1 million to $5 million each, according to the Reuters news agency. **********I.B.M. has sold machines and disk drives to other manufacturers for resale under their own names before. In Japan, for instance, the Ricoh Company resells the I.B.M. AS/400 mini-computer. But the company has never before allowed resale of a product "this far up the product line," said Mac Jeffery, a spokesman at I.B.M. headquarters in Armonk, N.Y. **********Mr. Jeffery said I.B.M. was seeking to broaden the sale of technology to other companies. In December, it appointed an executive specifically to bolster such sales. **********The mainframe business is undergoing a consolidation, in part because the growth of mainframe sales has slowed, as smaller machines have become more popular. Many companies have given up their own manufacturing and begun to sell machines made by others. **********Mitsubishi, which has been selling its own I.B.M.-compatible machines, is the fifth-largest computer vendor in Japan and might be realizing that it cannot make all of its own machines, analysts said. **********IBM Japan Ltd., the computer giant's Japanese subsidiary, had a 19 percent decline in profits last year, to 82.82 billion yen, or about $600 million. Its revenues climbed 1 percent, to 1.326 trillion yen, or about $9.6 billion. Recently, the company took other steps to lift its sales in Japan, including trying to recruit Japanese companies to make I.B.M.'s personal computer design a standard. **********Daniel Mandresh, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, said the agreement was "an interesting first," but added that the deal would have been more important had it involved one of I.B.M.'s largest mainframes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Affiliated's Profit Slips
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/08/busin.body_text: **********Affiliated Publications Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter earnings plunged 54 percent, largely because of declining advertising volume at its flagship newspaper, The Boston Globe. Affiliated had net income of $6.3 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with $13.5 million, or 19 cents a share, in the 1989 period. Revenues totaled $139.8 million, a 6 percent drop.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/15/world.body_text: **********The Kenyan Government arrested five members of opposition groups who were calling for more political freedom. The arrests early today appeared to be tied to a rally that the opposition has organized for Saturday but which President Daniel arap Moi has condemned as illegal. **********A lawyer for the opposition, Kathurina M'inoti, said that the opposition leaders, all of whom have been calling for a multi-party political system, were arrested at their homes. **********The most prominent among those arrested was Oginga Odinga, a former vice president, who is in his early 80's. Mr. Odinga tried to form an opposition party earlier this year but was prevented from doing so by Mr. Moi. **********Gitobu Imanyara, the editor of The Nairobi Law Monthly, who has been detained three times by the Government, was also arrested. The other three were: Luk Obok, an associate of Mr. Odinga's, George Nthenge and James Orengo, members of the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy, which had organized the Saturday rally.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/world.main_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Congress; Legislators See Limited Value in Their Private War Briefings
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF: Congress; Legislators See Limited Value in Their Private War Briefings
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/10/world.body_text: **********They gather two or three times a week in guarded rooms to hear the latest Pentagon account of how the war against Iraq is going. But members of Congress generally think they do not know much more about the war than careful newspaper readers or television viewers do. **********At those closed-door briefings they get more details than reporters do at news briefings. They get a chance to ask their own questions. But as Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, put it, "I don't know that we've learned a lot more than we would have by watching the Pentagon briefings on the news." **********Still, she is not dissatisfied, saying that the briefings gave her insights into the "general thrust" of the war that she might have missed without them. Representative Ray Thornton, Democrat of Arkansas, said the value of briefings to him was that from the start, their tone "kept us from being swept up in the euphoria." **********But Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, who called the briefings of only "marginal use," said their tone had changed. "There was this clear euphoria the first couple of days, the exotic picture of missiles that would do everything but stop at a red light," he said. "Now, a much more somber, serious tone." **********For some lawmakers, the value of the briefings may not lie only in a greater understanding of the war, but in the material that they can use in a press release. Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, complained, "An awful lot of the questions seemed to be asked to get an answer like, 'Yessirree, that weapons system produced in your district is doing fine.' " CNN's Influence **********For other lawmakers, the value seems so limited that they have stopped going. Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York, said, "At the last one I went to, they told us to keep everything to ourselves, and that night I saw the same thing on CNN." **********The Cable News Network's immediacy hangs heavily over the afternoon meetings, in the House Armed Services Committee room in the Rayburn building and in a fourth-floor room on the Senate side of the Capitol. **********Mr. Obey said that last week, when one Representative asked about a downed transport plane and was told the information was classified, several members shouted that they had just seen the news reported on CNN. **********Representative William M. Thomas, Republican of California, said the differences between what was provided to the press and that given to Congress were not of critical importance, even though lawmakers get to see more photographs than reporters do. "It doesn't help you make decisions," he said. "It's just more." **********Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, acknowledged that he sometimes did not get all the information he sought from the briefings. But, he said, "Understand, sometimes they just don't have it." **********Senator Kassebaum praised the briefers for their conservative approach, avoiding the risky body counts that had characterized official statements on the war in Vietnam. Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, said too many of his colleagues were frustrated when they asked questions that had no clear answer, like "When is this going to end?" or "How much is it going to cost." **********Like reporters, the lawmakers find they get different levels of information from different briefers and think they get the best from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. **********Representative Jan Meyers, Republican of Kansas, said the two men appeared more at ease than lesser officers because they did not have to worry that higher-ups might think they told too much.   Some Outspoken Critics **********The briefings have some outspoken critics, like Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, who calls them "a waste of time." **********Still, attendence at the briefings remains heavy. There appears to be a widespread sense of satisfaction that the Bush Administration is showing Congress some welcome respect by holding the frequent briefings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/world.main_headline: U.S. Is Said to Weigh Shift In Lease on Philippine Base
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/world.print_headline: U.S. Is Said to Weigh Shift In Lease on Philippine Base
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/14/world.body_text: **********The United States would consider modifications of a lease agreement for the Subic Bay Naval Station in the central Philippines to prevent an immediate shutdown of the huge American installation, Western diplomats said today. **********The diplomats said the Bush Administration, in what appears to be a major shift in its bargaining position, is willing to consider a three-year phased withdrawal from Subic instead of the 10-year base treaty that is now under debate -- and facing rejection -- in the Philippine Senate. **********"It's fair to say that we would consider any proposal presented by the Filipinos short of an out-and-out rejection of the treaty," an American diplomat said today. "Subic is a very valuable facility to the United States." **********The largest American military base in Southeast Asia, Subic Bay is a major repair and supply installation for the United States Seventh Fleet and is home to more than 7,000 American troops and civilian workers. **********While its strategic importance has been questioned because of the end of the cold war, American officials say Subic remains a critical, and in many ways irreplaceable, component of military planning in the Pacific.  Earlier Stand by Bush **********They say Subic's functions could be duplicated elsewhere in the region, but at a cost of several billion dollars. "And you can't replicate those functions in any one place," a diplomat said. **********Earlier this week, President Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney suggested that the United States would abandon Subic before agreeing to any modification of the treaty. "We've made our best offer," the President said in Washington. **********Most of the 23 members of the Philippine Senate, which must ratify treaties, have already announced their opposition to the decade-long base agreement negotiated this summer. Under the pact, the United States would pay $203 million a year in rent for the base. **********Several senators oppose the treaty on the ground of national sovereignty, saying it is time to end nearly a century of American military presence on Philippine soil. Others oppose the specific terms of the agreement, especially what they regard as an insultingly low amount of money offered. **********The vote on the new base agreement is expected on or before Monday, when the treaty expires. As the Philippine Senate moves closer to a final decision, members are being confronted with a series of alternatives designed to make it possible for American troops to remain, at least for the time being. **********One set of proposals would put off the United States withdrawal for three years, a period in which American negotiators could seek a new, long-range treaty. **********Another proposal, sponsored by President Corazon C. Aquino, would put the base issue to voters in a referendum in which they might overrule the expected Senate rejection. Opinion polls suggest that Filipinos overwhelmingly support an American presence at Subic, since the base contributes hundreds of millions of dollars a year to a fragile economy. **********Western diplomats say the United States would be willing to discuss these alternative proposals with Manila. **********The diplomats here said today that they were closely watching the actions of leaders of the coup-prone Philippine military, who have called for ratification of the 10-year treaty. **********The Philippine military is dependent on weapons and other assistance from the United States, and Philippine reporters and politicians have wondered aloud in recent days whether the country's civilian Government might be under a coup threat if the treaty was rejected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/world.main_headline: Jordan Closes Border to New Refugee Wave
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF; Jordan Closes Border to New Refugee Wave
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/10/world.body_text: **********Jordan closed its land border with Iraq today, saying it could not cope with another flood of refugees from the Persian Gulf crisis. **********Prime Minister Mudar Badran said the border would stay closed until arrangements are made to repatriate refugees. **********Crown Prince Hassan said on Monday that Jordan could not financially handle another huge influx. More than 800,000 refugees surged into Jordan and were sheltered in refugee camps just after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The Crown Prince predicted that 2 million refugees would flee Iraq and Kuwait if war broke out. **********Mr. Badran maintained Saudi Arabia refused to let Royal Jordanian charters carrying evacuees from Iraq and Kuwait fly through its airspace, and that Egypt might enforce a similar ban as of Saturday. There was no comment available from the Saudi or Egyptian Governments. **********Mr. Badran told Parliament the developments meant that hundreds of thousands of people believed ready to flee Iraq and Kuwait would be stranded in Jordan. **********Mr. Badran said Iraq was informed beforehand of Jordan's decision to close the border.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/busin.main_headline: Military Gives Big Role To Civilian Technicians
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/busin.print_headline: Military Gives Big Role To Civilian Technicians
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/30/busin.body_text: **********As they wage war on Iraq, the United States and its allies are relying heavily on civilian employees sent to the Persian Gulf by military contractors to provide technical expertise in maintaining the world's most advanced weapons, industry executives and military officials said. **********Industry executives estimate that there are about 1,000 contractor employees at air bases, on aircraft carriers and at other military installations in the region. Companies declined to specify how many employees they have in the gulf, citing security concerns, but the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the Raytheon Company, the Lockheed Corporation and almost every other major contractor confirmed having at least some workers on the scene. **********The employees are the 1990's high-technology version of civilian personnel who have long flocked to jobs in war zones. If the need in Vietnam was for engineers and laborers to build airfields and ports, the need in Saudi Arabia is for technicians to maintain sophisticated radar, navigation, guidance and communications systems and the other hardware and software that make modern planes, missiles, bombs and sensors work as advertised. More Complex Systems **********Arms makers have dispatched technical representatives to wars where their weapons were deployed at least since the Vietnam War. But the complexity of the new weapons of the gulf war, like the Patriot and Tomahawk missiles, and the fact that many advanced weapons have never been used in combat, has increased the need for industry support. **********The primary role of the personnel is to assist military technicians in diagnosing and solving problems with weapons systems and in assessing and repairing battle damage. In some cases, companies are under contract to provide support services directly to Saudi Arabia's military as well as to American forces. **********Several companies said their employees had had extremely heavy workloads as the United States and allied forces continued their constant air attacks on Iraq. **********"You can be sure they're pretty busy," said Michael Burch, a spokesman for McDonnell Douglas. Mr. Burch said the company's personnel were generally present wherever there were McDonnell Douglas weapons systems, like the Air Force's F-15 fighters and the Navy's ship-based Tomahawk missiles.  New and Untested **********Industry executives said the military relies heavily on contractor personnel when a weapons system is relatively new and untested in combat, as is the case with many weapons systems in the gulf. In those cases, military technicians may have limited experience in dealing with any problems that may arise with increasingly complex electronics systems. Raytheon, for example, is known to have sent technical representatives to aid military personnel in installing and maintaining the Patriot anti-missile system both in Saudi Arabia and in Israel. **********Lockheed said it had a number of employees stationed in Saudi Arabia with the F-117A Stealth fighters made by the company. E-Systems Inc., a Dallas-based military contractor, is believed to have employees in the gulf supporting missions flown by the TR-1 and RC-135 reconnaissance planes, analysts say. The Hughes Aircraft Company, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, has "a few dozen people over there," said Richard Dore, a spokesman. Hughes makes missiles, radar systems, night-vision and targeting equipment and other gear. **********"In these types of situations, if something does develop, the Defense Department and the people in the field understandably want immediate assistance," Mr. Dore said. "The Government has a lot of good people of its own there, but it helps to have someone from the team that built it." Request From the Navy **********Richard Vance, the director of field operations for the Grumman Corporation's aircraft division, said the Navy had for some years been trying to reduce its dependence on contractor employees on aircraft carriers by building technical and trouble-shooting expertise among its own seamen. But he said the Navy requested more help last year after Iraq invaded Kuwait and the American military buildup in the gulf began. **********"There's a desire to have as much expertise there as possible," Mr. Vance said. Grumman makes the carrier-based F-14 fighter and A-6 bomber, among other weapons. **********While the employees are not armed and remain well behind the front lines, industry executives said they were at risk like anyone else attached to a military installation during a war. **********"Are we concerned? You bet," Mr. Vance said. Advance Agreements **********Most contractors agree to provide support services as part of their contract to build a weapon. The companies recruit technical representatives from among their own employees and from among former military personnel, and most agree in advance to go to a war zone if needed. **********Industry executives declined to discuss the pay scale. Mr. Dore said that in a war, Hughes employees on the scene received their regular pay, plus an amount equivalent to whatever differential the military pays soldiers for combat duty. The differential ranges from 10 percent to 40 percent of base salary, depending on how close the employee is to the front lines. **********Contractor representatives are in regular communication with engineers and technicians at company plants in the United States. "If the F-15E is experiencing problems that are not normal, the tech rep gets in touch with the factory, anytime day or night," said Mr. Burch of McDonnell Douglas. **********Industry executives said that the Pentagon had been pushing in recent years to reduce the amount and complexity of the maintenance needed for its weapons. As a result, contractors expect the role of their employees in future conflicts to decline. **********"In ordering new airplanes, the Pentagon has given manufacturers high goals to meet in terms of reliability and maintainability," said James Ragsdale, a spokesman for Lockheed's aircraft division.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/13/world.main_headline: Excerpts From the Demands: Free 'All Detainees Throughout the World'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/13/world.print_headline: THE HOSTAGE DRAMA; Excerpts From the Demands: Free 'All Detainees Throughout the World'
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/13/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from a statement by Islamic Holy War, the pro-Iranian Lebanese group that released a British hostage, John McCarthy, last week. The statement, addressed to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations, was delivered to him on Sunday and released in translation by the United Nations today. **********Why has the United Nations been given an effective and important role to play in solving the crisis that arose in the gulf while it has been prevented from playing any role in helping to find a just solution to the question of the Muslim people in Palestine in spite of the fact that more than 50 years have passed since the Israeli enemy usurped the land of Palestine? **********Why were the United Nations resolutions implemented immediately after their adoption during the gulf crisis while none of the resolutions adopted in regard to the just Palestinian cause have yet been put into effect decades after their adoption? **********What has the United Nations done to protect the human rights of Muslim and other oppressed peoples and to prevent the barbaric massacres that are being committed against them throughout the world? **********Where is the right to self-determination in the case of the Islamic and oppressed peoples in Palestine, Kashmir and Afghanistan? Do the United Nations conventions not make provision for the right of peoples to self-determination without tutelage or external colonialist interference, and do they not regard the struggle for self-determination by various means, including force, as a legitimate and justifiable act that is in no way related to terrorism? **********When oppressed peoples and societies demand freedom, independence, justice, a decent life and deliverance from those who wreak havoc with their countries, their resources, their beliefs and the future of their children, can they be regarded as terrorist peoples and societies?                    . . . **********In this connection, we appeal to you, in your capacity as Secretary General of the United Nations, and to the world as a whole, to adopt Islam as an ideology, a code of law and a system and to follow the teachings of the Great Imam Khomeini, who expounded the principles and conventions on which peoples, movements and regimes must base their endeavours to achieve progress, to solve the problems with which they are burdened and to achieve happiness and well-being.                    . . . **********The slogan of the need to combat international terrorism, which has been raised by America and its supporters, is a spurious slogan designed to leave them with drawn swords in their hands, which they can use whenever they feel that their interests are being threatened by the actions of rebellious oppressed peoples on the pretext of an end to the terrorist threat to international peace and security. However, the uprising of peoples seeking to achieve self-determination, recover their stolen freedom and independence, sever their links of dependence on the imperious states and insure that the principles of justice are put into practice is not terrrorism; it is a legitimate right. If the slogan of the need to combat international terrorism is an attempt to divert us from our course of holy war in the face of international arrogance, we will continue along the difficult path that we have chosen for ourselves without giving an inch. If its purpose is to maintain the state of open warfare between us and them, we are fully prepared to pursue this confrontation until we achieve one of the two divine rewards: victory or martyrdom. If struggle, holy war and resistance against the superpowers is terrorism, we and the oppressed peoples throughout the world are proud to be terrorists combating injustice and striking terror into the hearts of the enemies of God and mankind as long as they interfere in the internal affairs of oppressed nations and peoples anywhere in the world. We are part of the worldwide Islamic movement; the causes of the Muslims are our causes, and we share their sufferings and jubilations. By the grace of Almighty God, we shall always remain in the vanguard of the defenders of the causes of Islam and the Muslims and, in the cause of God, we do not fear the reproaches of anyone. The question of detainees and prisoners in the world today is one of the consequences of the confrontation between us and the forces of international arrogance led by America, the mother of iniquity throughout the world, and its offspring Israel.                    . . . **********Consequently, the question of the detainees was a reaction on the part of the Muslim freedom-fighters to all those practices and an endeavor to secure the release of our incarcerated fighters. This reaction will continue as long as they remain incarcerated. Release All Detainees **********In view of our belief in the need for action to secure the release of our freedom-fighters from prisons in occupied Palestine and Europe and also to solve the question of the detainees whom we are holding and the problem of their families, we call upon you to make a personal endeavor, within the framework of a comprehensive solution, to secure the release of all detainees throughout the world. In such an eventuality, we would be perfectly willing to complete the process that we began today and to release the persons whom we are detaining within 24 hours.                    . . . **********We are awaiting a practical response from you that will lead to the desired fruitful solution. We are waiting and praying that our incarcerated fellow freedom-fighters will obtain freedom with honor and that the peoples of the world will obtain the security and justice which we believe will inevitably prevail through Islam at the hands of the expected Mahdi, who will arise among the descendants of Mohammed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/25/world.main_headline: Dispute Over Settlements and Loan Deal Is Symptom of a Deeper U.S.-Israel Strain
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/25/world.print_headline: FAILING TO COMMUNICATE; Dispute Over Settlements and Loan Deal Is Symptom of a Deeper U.S.-Israel Strain
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/25/world.body_text: **********The dispute between the Bush Administration and Israel over loan guarantees and restrictions on Israeli settlements underscores the stunning lack of communication between two Governments on some of the most sensitive issues between them. **********"This whole crisis is symptomatic of our relationship," said an Administration Middle East expert. "We have this ritualized relationship, with all of the structures of closeness, but people don't really talk to each other or hear each other, because there is no real private honesty. Everyone is afraid to be honest, because they are aware that there are some real underlying differences over the question of the occupied territories." **********Interviews in recent days with many American and Israeli officials and others involved in the dispute suggest that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir badly miscalculated when he brushed aside a Bush Administration request in early September to put off a request for $10 billion in loan guarantees or face a confrontation over Jewish settlements in the occupied territories. Bush-Shamir Misunderstanding **********It is now evident that Israel's supporters in Congress have decided not to fight the Administration and will postpone dealing with the loan guarantee issue until after a Middle East peace conference begins. **********The lack of communication between Mr. Shamir and President Bush goes back to the very first meeting between the two men in the Oval Office in April 1989, when Mr. Bush expressed his displeasure over Israeli settlement-building practices and Mr. Shamir responded, "It won't be a problem." **********Mr. Shamir meant that if the Israelis really have an Arab partner for peace talks, settlements will not be an obstacle to peace. What Mr. Bush thought he heard, though, was a commitment from Mr. Shamir to slow down or stop settlement-building, and when just the opposite happened as soon as Mr. Shamir returned to Israel, the seeds of Mr. Bush's personal wrath with Mr. Shamir were firmly planted.  Loan Guarantees Delayed **********Mr. Bush's focus on Israeli settlements grows out of a longstanding American belief that an accord between Israel and the Arabs will only come about in a trade of land for peace, and if Israel builds housing all over the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, no trade will be possible. **********The tension between Mr. Shamir and Mr. Bush dating back to that first meeting hung over their relationship. In early 1990, Israel appealed to the Bush Administration for $400 million in housing loan guarantees to help resettle Soviet immigrants who were flooding in. **********The guarantees sailed through Congress, but they did not become available for almost nine months while Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d negotiated with the Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, an unusual letter in which Israel for the first time promised not to use the money to settle Soviet Jews "beyond the green line" dividing Israel proper from the territories occupied in the 1967 War. The expectation in Washington was that as a result of that letter there would be no increase in Israeli settlement activity of any kind, whereas the view in Jerusalem was that Israel had agreed not to spend the $400 million in the territories, but that it could spend its own money. **********Mr. Levy also agreed to provide Mr. Baker with certain financial data to assure the Americans that their money was not going into the West Bank. Baker and Levy Letter **********The Levy letter was signed on Oct. 2, 1990, and the $400 million in guarantees was granted. After the new year, though, it became apparent to the Israelis that the number of Soviet Jews that could descend on them could reach a million, far more than anticipated, and therefore their housing and absorption requirements would be much greater. **********In between all of that the Persian Gulf War intruded and Israel sought a special aid infusion from the Bush Administration -- over and above the annual $3 billion it receives for economic and military assistance -- to compensate for losses it incurred from Iraqi Scud missile attacks and increased defense spending. **********The Bush Administration, beholden to Israel for not retaliating against Iraq, agreed after a period of bargaining to a one-time grant of $650 million in cash -- on the condition that Israel not ask for any more extra aid of any kind until after Labor Day, when the Administration hoped it would be too late to get the request through Congress this fiscal year. **********Between March and Labor Day, the President was privately seething over what he believed was Israeli non-compliance with the Levy letter of October and the fact that every time Mr. Baker came to Israel on his peace missions a new settlement was erected. Despite the Levy letter, Israeli settlements in the occupied territories were increasing instead of decreasing and the financial data Israel promised was not forthcoming. At a news conference on July 1, Mr. Bush said he did not think there "ought to be a quid pro quo" between a halt on settlements freeze and loan guarantees, but he implored the Israelis to live up to the Levy letter. Lobbying Campaign in U.S. **********But Mr. Baker was obsessed with putting a peace conference together, and while he regularly spoke to the Israelis about problems he had with settlements, he acceded to their demand that a halt on settlement not be made a precondition for the peace conference, and sold that to the Arabs. **********The Israeli Government began talking about the need for $10 billion in housing loan guarantees and the Israeli lobby, the American Israel-Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, and every other major American Jewish group began organizing a lobbying campaign that would culminate after Labor Day to insure that the Israelis got the money through Congress. **********The Israeli Government was aware of how President Bush was feeling, because Israel's Ambassador to Washington, Zalman Shoval, was hearing it from his sources. But Mr. Shamir apparently did not take his warnings seriously. On June 22, Mr. Shoval, in an unsual move, went public. Asked in an interview with Israel Radio whether the $10 billion in loan guarantees was assured, he answered: "Very probably there will be a difficulty. The Government of Israel with all the data in its hands may have to decide whether the issue of settlement is a priority or that the issue of aid is a priority. Sometimes there are moments and there are issues where governments have to take decisions." **********For his candor, Mr. Shoval was berated by his superiors. Mr. Shamir apparently thought the Administration was simply using the loan issue as leverage to get him to say yes to Mr. Baker's peace conference. **********But he had received other warnings. On July 25, Vice President Dan Quayle personally warned the Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, when he visited Washington that linkage was a possibility if Israel did not curb settlements. **********In early August, though, Mr. Shamir finally told Mr. Baker that Israel would come to his peace conference and Israeli officials said at the time that they assumed that the Shamir "yes" to the conference meant that the housing guarantees were assured. **********While Baker aides say they never told the Israelis that, Mr. Baker, still focused on his peace conference, also did not explicitly tell Mr. Shamir that the Administration intended to hold up the guarantees until it got even more restrictions on Israeli settlements. **********A few days later, after Mr. Baker returned from the Middle East, senior Administration Middle East experts began focusing on the gauarantees. It became clear to them then that President Bush had no intention of granting the guarantees without restrictions that would finally either freeze or severely curtail Israeli building. Mr. Bush is said to have literally laughed at the notion that the sort of understandings Mr. Levy agreed to for the $400 million guarantee would be satisfactory for the $10 billion. **********Meanwhile, Aipac and other Jewish organizations were putting the finishing touches on their lobbying campaigns for the guarantees. **********Over the Labor Day weekend, Secretary Baker telephoned Mr. Shamir twice and asked him to delay the loan request for four months. But Mr. Shamir said he could not do that. He had just concluded an exhausting domestic budget battle in which he agreed to increase the defense budget by cutting the housing budget and the only way he could limit the damage to his housing budget was by assuming that the loan guarantees would come this fiscal year. It was already written into the Israeli budget. **********The guarantees would enable Israel to borrow $10 billion from banks over the next five years at reduced interest rates, since the United States would be giving its assurance that it would meet any principal or interest payments that Israel could not make. Israeli officials, noting that Israel's credit rating is fairly good, say there would be no need for Washington to pay any money. **********When Mr. Baker got no satisfaction from Mr. Shamir, the Administration turned to Congress to delay the issue for 120 days, which it now appears ready to do. **********In four months, the Administration will again try to link Israeli housing guarantees with some sort of suspension of Israeli settlements. But the Administration apparently hopes that by then the Arab-Israeli peace conference will be well underway and they can use their leverage over Israel on that issue to help forge the first interim deal in that conference: Israel suspends settlements in return for the Arab countries' suspending their boycott of Israel and the Palestinians' suspending their uprising.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/world.main_headline: A Daring Magazine and Its Awkward Questions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/world.print_headline: MEXICO CITY JOURNAL; A Daring Magazine and Its Awkward Questions
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/21/world.body_text: **********If the editors of Mexico's newest monthly magazine had merely wanted to print their own views about Mexican politics and society, no one might have cared. What has stirred critics of the new magazine, Este Pais, is a much more delicate editorial goal: to publish what the Mexican people think about themselves. **********Started by a group of intellectuals and public servants that spans the spectrum of Mexican politics, the new publication has been designed to include extensive monthly opinion polls and analysis of national attitudes, exploring public feelings on everything from politics to corruption to religious behavior. **********But in a society where such surveys are carefully managed and seldom published, that proposition has surrounded the magazine with controversy, even before the publication of its first issue, which is scheduled to come out next month. **********Government officials portray the magazine as an opposition tool, opposition parties are wary of its electoral implications, and, in general, the idea of putting cherished political myths to a statistical test appears to have challenged the comfortable ambiguity that pervades much of Mexican scholarship and political life.  A Tradition Is Lacking **********"If you think about political science in the United States, you think about polls, statistics, that kind of thing," said Federico Reyes Heroles, a 36-year-old political scientist and novelist who is to edit the new publication. "But in Mexico, political science means philosophy. We don't have a tradition of fact in Mexico, even in economics." **********Although scientific soundings of national opinion are routinely commissioned by Mexican political parties and the Government itself, they have seldom formed an important part of public debate. Moreover, rarely if ever have they presented a full-scale portrait of values and social attitudes in a country where national stereotypes have long substituted for direct investigations of public thinking. **********Among other findings presented in its first few issues, editors say, the new magazine will scrutinize traditional conceptions about Mexican nationalism, citing recent polling data that show just 56 percent of Mexicans to be "very proud" of their nationality, down nearly 10 percent from survey results a decade ago, and fully 20 percent below the corresponding figure for the United States. **********Similarly, according to figures compiled by the magazine, the number of Mexicans who are ready to fight for their country in case of war has fallen from 90 percent in 1981 to less than 75 percent last year. **********Other issues will deal with delicate social and political questions, ranging from confidence in public institutions to family relations to moral issues. For example, Mexican respondents in recent polls expressed a lower level of trust in their family members than did American or Canadian respondents. And the number of Mexicans who described themselves as "very religious" was just over 40 percent -- less than the corresponding figure for American respondents.  Some Are Uneasy **********The striking unpredictability of those figures -- and the prospect of having such data published and analyzed systematically in the pages of Este Pais -- has prompted conspicuous unease from many politicians and business people with a stake in the traditional order of Mexican society. **********Citing the opposition ties of Mr. Reyes, who gave up his membership in the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party to form the magazine late last year, many party and Government officials have hurried to denounce the journal as an anti-Government project. **********"It seems clear at this point that this is going to be strictly an opposition magazine," a Government official said. **********But ownership of the magazine has been structured around a diverse group of 200 principal shareholders, each of whom is permitted only one vote in decisions on magazine policy, regardless of financial investment. And Mr. Reyes and his colleagues have taken care to insure that the group spans the broadest range of Mexican politicians and intellectuals, ranging from opposition economists to sitting Governors from the ruling party. **********The magazine's founders' list also includes an eclectic, nonvoting group of foreign associates that includes many of the most distinguished American academic experts on Mexican government and society. **********"This is something that could help reduce cynicism about Mexican politics," said Susan Kaufman Purcell, a foreign associate of the magazine who is vice president of the Americas Society, a prominent New York-based group dedicated to the study of Latin American affairs. **********"The problem at this point is that the Mexican people don't trust declarations and statements and rhetoric. So to the extent that you can start basing things on more scientific kinds of studies, the people may have more confidence." **********As now envisioned, the magazine will conduct many of its own polls, overseen by Miguel Basanez, a well-known Mexican political scientist who is president of the magazine's board of directors. But its editors say they also plan to use polls conducted by academic institutions, foreign experts, multilateral institutions and other investigators, making full disclosure of the samples and methods used in each to provide the clearest possible portrait of Mexican thinking. **********Dr. Purcell and others caution that the test of Este Pais's success will lie in the magazine's ability to maintain a political balance in the kinds of questions it seeks to explore, as well as the scientific accuracy of the results. But that concern is viewed more as a challenge than a limitation by the editors of the magazine, who say they have planned from the start to let the political chips fall where they may. **********"Everyone is very anxious about what we are going to find," Mr. Reyes said. "But that is exactly the point -- nobody really knows."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.main_headline: Selloff Hits Compaq on Profit News
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.print_headline: Selloff Hits Compaq on Profit News
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.body_text: **********Shares of the Compaq Computer Corporation lost more than a quarter of their value today after the company said it expected earnings to plummet at least 79 percent this quarter, mainly because of a sharp downturn in orders from some big retailers. **********Joseph R. Canion, president and chief executive, said the earnings setback was caused by short-term problems as retailers with too much inventory trimmed orders, and he called the selloff an overreaction. But some analysts said Compaq's history of rapid growth since offering its first personal computers in 1982 might be over. **********Investors raced to sell the company's shares, causing the New York Stock Exchange to delay trading for 45 minutes after the 9:30 opening. By the final bell, Compaq's market value had tumbled by $1.2 billion, or 27 percent. **********The stock began the day down $10, and by the close it had fallen $13.25, to $36. With more than 11 million shares changing hands, it was by far the Big Board's most active issue. The shares traded at $61.875 three weeks ago, before first-quarter earnings were announced. **********Compaq's forecast sent the stock market into a tailspin, with the Dow industrials falling 21.47, to 2,865.38, but over-the-counter stocks falling far more.  [ Page D10. ] **********Shares of other bellwether technology companies, including International Business Machines and Apple Computer, also declined. I.B.M. fell $3.25, to $102.75, and Apple was down $3, to $50.50. **********Compaq said its second-quarter profits would be less than 25 cents a share, compared with $1.18 in the period last year. Revenues were likely to drop more than 15 percent below the $862 million posted in the period a year ago.  Second Big Drop **********It was the second big dent in Compaq's market value in three weeks. On April 25 it reported lower-than-anticipated growth in sales and earnings for the first quarter and gave its first warning of the current quarter's woes. Its stock fell 15 percent then. **********This quarter's troubles represent "the first real disappointment from Compaq," said Mark D. Stahlman, technology analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., in New York. Growth in worldwide sales of business personal computers has slowed to less than 10 percent a year, he said, and investors considered Compaq ill prepared to compete in other, faster-growing niches in the computer industry. **********Mr. Stahlman said he had reduced his forecast for Compaq profits this year to $2.10 a share from $4.90 after the announcement. **********Jim Poyner, who follows Compaq for William K. Woodruff & Company, a Dallas brokerage, said Compaq erred by not using specialty retailers or hiring its own sales force as alternatives to the retail dealers now in retreat.  Seeking New Markets **********"The distribution strategy should have changed more than a year ago," he said. "This is what happens when you put all of your eggs in that one basket." **********The Houston-based company is trying to challenge Sun Microsystems, Digital Equipment, I.B.M. and others in work stations and minicomputers as it moves beyond the personal-computer market, where lower-price rivals like Dell Computer and AST Research have gained ground this year in notebook models. **********Compaq disclosed the news on its second-quarter earnings on the eve of its annual shareholders meeting, scheduled on Thursday in Houston. Mr. Canion said in an interview today that Compaq learned some of its major dealers had trimmed orders in the last few days because recent mergers among them left them with too much inventory. Also, the strong dollar is reducing profits from European sales and unit sales remain flat to lower in the United States, he said. **********Three of the nation's 10 biggest computer dealers were acquired earlier this year by other major dealers amid a shakeout in computer retailing. Inacomp merged with Balcom, Compucom bought the Computer Factory and Computerland, the largest, acquired Nynex's retail stores. **********Mr. Canion said sales by major dealers of Compaq products appeared to be unaffected by the consolidations, and that the company's market share probably increased since it announced price cuts last month. But the slowdown in dealer orders from Compaq could last through most of the summer, he said.  Oversupply in Stores **********Computerland, for instance, found a 12-week supply of Compaq machines in Nynex stores, and plans to pare those inventories to no more than eight weeks before stepping up orders, he said. **********"This will be with us a few months, but it is not a long-term factor," he said. "You might say some channels were less efficient than others in managing their inventory. Once that inventory bubble is passed, it will have a positive impact on our overall distribution." **********But some analysts said Compaq, which earned $114.3 million, or $1.26 a share, in the first quarter, would struggle for profits in the months ahead. Price cuts from rivals are anticipated soon, and Compaq, burdened by high costs, could be unwilling to chop prices again after cutting them by as much as 34 percent on some models last month. **********Mr. Canion conceded that the April price cuts had squeezed profits, but insisted that the decline was temporary and "will be offset over a period of time by increased volume."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/world.print_headline: Greenpeace Count Puts Dead From War in Gulf at 200,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/30/world.body_text: **********The environmental group Greenpeace reported today that as many as 200,000 people may have died as a result of the war with Iraq and that 5 million to 6 million people were displaced. **********The Greenpeace report, based on interviews with international relief workers, reporters, officials and news reports, estimates that 100,000 to 120,000 Iraqi troops died; 5,000 to 15,000 Iraqi civilians died in bombing; 2,000 to 5,000 Kuwaitis died; 20,000 Iraqis died in the Kurdish and Shiite rebellions; 15,000 to 30,000 Kurds and other refugees have died; 4,000 to 16,000 Iraqis have died of starvation; and 343 allied troops died.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/16/busin.body_text: **********Talks between British and United States aviation officials broke off today, leaving unsettled whether American Airlines and United Airlines would be able to fly into London on routes purchased from T.W.A. and Pan Am. **********A Transportation Department official said the talks had made some progress but several problems remained unresolved. The discussions are tentatively scheduled to resume on Jan. 28, he said. He provided no further details. **********The biggest stumbling block involves whether the United States carriers may continue to fly into Heathrow Airport outside London after purchasing the routes from the bankrupt Pan American World Airways and the hard-pressed Trans World Airlines. The two airlines are selling these and other routes for hundreds of millions of dollars. **********The British have insisted that only the carriers that currently have the authority to operate at Heathrow may do so and that if the routes are sold, their new owners must fly to Gatwick Airport, which is farther from downtown London and offers fewer connecting flights. **********The British negotiators are said to be holding out for expanded access to cities in the United States, perhaps including the right to carry United States passengers between two domestic cities, in exchange for the concessions sought by the American carriers.
