https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/07/world.body_text: **********The Foreign Ministers of the European Community decided today to go ahead with their peace conference for Yugoslavia on Saturday in The Hague, despite the continuing ferocious fighting between Serbs and Croats. **********Hans van den Broek, the Dutch Foreign Minister, who holds the presidency of the community's decision-making body for the last half of 1991, said that he and his European colleagues felt it was important to establish the framework for peace even though the signs in Yugoslavia pointed to war. **********"Perhaps all the participants don't know it yet, but there is no choice for peace except this conference," Mr. van den Broek said. Panel of International Judges **********The Dutch official said all the presidents of the six Yugoslav republics would attend Saturday's session, as well as the President of the federal Yugoslav Government. Mr. van den Broek's spokesman, Dig Ishta, said that there would be no representative of the Serbian irregulars operating in Croatia at the conference, and that that absence would be one of the first points of contention. **********Mr. van den Broek has spent much of the last two months promoting peace in Yugoslavia. Several times he and his envoys have brokered cease-fires in Croatia, only to have gunfire begin hours after the documents were signed. **********The peace conference, involving a panel of international judges to arbitrate the disputes in Yugoslavia, will take place in the Peace Palace in The Hague. The ornate building, funded by Andrew Carnegie, was opened in 1913 to house an international arbitration panel of judges. The next year, World War I broke out. **********The arbitration process envisioned by the European Community would include three judges from the community and two from Yugoslavia to arbitrate the issues that are causing Yugoslavs to kill one another.  Community Applies Pressure **********On Saturday it is expected that the participants will make speeches for two hours, have a closed session of an hour to discuss who will be permitted to observe from Yugoslavia's many unrepresented minorities, have lunch and a news conference, and then return to their various capitals. It could be a week or more before the next stage in the putative peace process begins. **********At today's meeting of foreign ministers here there were indications from a number of delegations that the European Community was applying considerable economic pressure to the contending parties to get them to the conference table. **********Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany has already threatened to recognize the independence of Croatia and Slovenia unless Serbia makes moves toward peace. Mr. Genscher told the other foreign ministers today that Germany would not be alone in such recognition if it came to that. **********The other threat that the community could make to Serbia is economic sanctions. Yugoslavia's economy depends almost exclusively on Western Europe, and has already been severely damaged this summer by the absence of European tourists from Croatian resorts. YUGOSLAVIA TO SEND DELEGATION **********ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 6 (Special to The New York Times) -- As fighting continued across Croatia, Yugoslavia's eight-member collective presidency convened today in Belgrade and voted to send a delegation to the peace conference in The Hague. **********After several hours of talks this morning, the chairman of the presidency, Stipe Mesic, a Croatian, returned to Zagreb saying that he was "not particularly optimistic," but that he thought the European conference might at least "prevent a resolution being imposed on Croatia by force." **********While the presidency met, there were reports of continued fierce fighting across Croatia. Sixteen deaths were reported, including six in Osijek, an eastern Croatian city that has come under intense artillery attack in the last 24 hours, after a cease-fire was shattered within an hour of its signing on Thursday by local commanders in the presence of a European envoy. **********The Zagreb radio reported that Croatian militiamen skirmished with Serbian rebels and army units at Nova Gradiska, in southern Croatia, to wrest the main highway linking Zagreb and Belgrade from their control. **********By this evening, the road was reportedly open, though it was doubtful much traffic would pass, given heavy sniper fire from woods skirting the road.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/03/busin.body_text: **********Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts have fallen for the fifth consecutive week. But the decline was less for the period that ended yesterday than in the previous two weeks. **********New York banks, which have led most of the country in cutting the yields on certificates of deposit, are now cutting them by less, falling in stride with other markets. **********Some analysts say that C.D. yields, which had been falling faster on indications that the economy was still slowing, have begun to fall by less because of mixed economic signals. The analysts say the mixed signals are preventing the Federal Reserve from easing short-term interest rates further.  3-Month Bill Down **********At the Treasury Department's weekly auction of short-term bills, which was held on Monday, average discount rates slipped after rising in the previous week. The results of the bill auctions often indicate the rates that many banks will eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit. **********The three-month bill fell 6 basis points, to 5.8 percent, while the six-month bill fell 5 basis points, to 5.79 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The rates are at their lowest levels since early 1988. **********In its weekly survey of New York-area banks, The Bank Rate Monitor noted anew that the larger cuts in yields continued to come from the savings institutions, with the spread between savings institutions and commercial banks narrowing each week. **********The largest yield changes for the the New York area this week was at the Chemical Bank, which cut 32 basis points from its money market account, to 5.39 percent. First Nationwide, which had cut its money market account in the previous week, last week cut its three-month certificate by 25 basis points, to 6.25 percent, and its six-month certificate by 20 basis points, to 6.55 percent. **********Commercial banks this week lowered money market accounts by 5 basis points, to 5.57 percent, and lowered three-month certificates by 3 basis points, to 6.01 percent. The six-month certificate was cut 2 basis points, to 6.17 percent. **********At savings institutions, the average yield for a money market account was cut by only 3 basis points, to 5.8 percent, while a three-month C.D. was cut by 8 basis points, to 6.4 percent, and the six-month C.D. by 5 basis points, to 6.61 percent, **********Yields at 20 large banks outside the New York area and around the country show the average money market account yield down 2 basis points, to 5.46 percent, with the average yield for a six-month certificate unchanged at 6.15 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/busin.body_text: **********Last Jan. 24, as F-15 fighters and Tomahawk missiles made by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation were screaming through the skies above Iraq, the aerospace company's chief executive, John F. McDonnell, made a shocking request of the Pentagon. **********McDonnell Douglas, Mr. McDonnell wrote in a letter to Undersecretary of Defense Donald J. Yockey, was suffering through a cash crunch caused by a mounting debt load, weapons-contract cancellations and problems in its commercial aircraft division. Shut off from further bank financing and worried about the company's ability to handle any unexpected problems, Mr. McDonnell asked the Pentagon to give McDonnell Douglas an advance on its weapons-contract payments. A billion dollars would be sufficient, he wrote. **********The notion of the nation's largest military contractor seeking a financial lifeline from the Government in the midst of a war jolted Pentagon officials, who kept the request a secret at the company's behest until it was uncovered by Congressional investigators in July. The request was never granted and was ultimately withdrawn by McDonnell Douglas last spring, when its cash crunch eased. But the episode added fuel to longstanding rumors questioning the viability of the company, the No. 2 builder of commercial jetliners, behind the Boeing Company, and the third-largest supplier to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.  Back From the Bottom **********Yet from that nadir just eight months ago, McDonnell Douglas has rebounded sharply, with a cost-cutting program imposed last year by Mr. McDonnell helping it to post stronger earnings and pare its swollen debt load substantially. While its troubles are by no means completely behind it, McDonnell Douglas is recovering from a period of intense upheaval, confident not only of surviving the shriveling of the weapons business, but also of emerging as a more potent competitor in jetliners to Boeing and the European Airbus consortium. **********Increasing sales of commercial aircraft may well offset the military slide. The company forecasts that its commercial sales, which accounted for 34 percent of its 1990 revenue of $16.2 billion, will grow to 53 percent of sales by 1995. In a sign of its confidence, McDonnell Douglas is moving ahead with plans for a new jetliner, the MD-12X, to be built with a foreign partner in a direct challenge to Boeing's successful 747-400 long-range wide-body. **********"I think they've really turned the corner," said Jerry Cantwell, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company. **********But not everyone is upbeat about the company's prospects. Short sellers, who bet on declines in the prices of particular stocks, own the equivalent of 13.3 percent of McDonnell Douglas's outstanding shares. They and others point to a long list of questions about McDonnell Douglas's future. **********The St. Louis-based company faces the end of some of its biggest weapons programs, including the Air Force's F-15 fighter and the Army's Apache helicopter, and it lost out this spring on competitions to build their replacements. It remains exposed to potentially crippling losses from contract disputes with the Pentagon over several troubled programs, including the Navy's A-12 bomber, a joint venture of McDonnell Douglas and the General Dynamics Corporation that was canceled in January by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Air Force and Pentagon auditors have calculated that McDonnell Douglas also faces losses ranging from a few hundred million dollars to more than $2 billion on the development of the new C-17 military transport plane. The company insists that it expects no significant loss and that it will ultimately earn billions of dollars if the Air Force goes ahead with plans to buy 120 of the planes. **********And now, with the company's future resting more than ever on the commercial aircraft business, the airline industry is cutting back on airplane orders as the weaker carriers grapple with financial woes and some of the stronger ones retrench. **********"The worst is behind us," said Mr. McDonnell, the 53-year-old son of the company's founder, James S. McDonnell Jr., who died in 1980. "But we have a long way to go before we're at a level I think we can be proud of." **********In some areas, McDonnell Douglas has already come a long way. It has slashed its costs, in large part by laying of nearly 20,000 employees, or 15 percent of its work force, over the last 15 months. It has kept profit margins high in its remaining Pentagon business in St. Louis, and has won some vital new business, including a contract to build an upgraded version of the Navy's F/A-18 fighter.  A Rehabilitated Douglas **********Perhaps most important, it has finally shored up its Douglas Aircraft division in Long Beach, Calif., the home of the company's commercial aircraft business, after decades of abysmal performance. Although its margins remain slim, the division turned profitable in the fourth quarter of last year when it began delivering its new MD-11 wide-body jetliner, ending years of heavy investments in its development. After a decade in production, the midrange narrow-body MD-80 aircraft has at last become consistently profitable. Douglas also got a lift when the one military program it manages, the C-17, flew for the first time earlier this month, albeit more than a year behind schedule. (The C-17 is part of Douglas rather than McDonnell because it is a transport, not a combat, aircraft. **********Overall, said Robert H. Hood Jr., the president of Douglas, the division should post higher operating profits this year than in any year since the McDonnell Aircraft Company of St. Louis merged with Douglas Aircraft of Long Beach, Calif., in 1967. Mr. Cantwell of Wertheim Schroder projected 1991 profits for Douglas at $120 million, compared with a $177 million loss last year. **********With Douglas finally profitable, the parent company has had enough money to begin paying off debt, much of it taken on to finance the MD-11 development program. The debt, which peaked at $3.3 billion in the first quarter, was reduced to $2.9 billion as of June 30, and analysts think it could shrink to as little as $2.5 billion by year-end, significantly easing the pressure on the balance sheet. **********The turnaround comes after nearly three years of tumult, some of it induced by the rapid shrinkage of the weapons business and some by Mr.  McDonnell's decision after taking over in 1988 that shock therapy was in order, especially at Douglas. **********Douglas Aircraft had been unable to keep up with Boeing as far back as the dawn of the jet age in the 1950's, and the merger with McDonnell did little to change things. Despite a generally healthy backlog of orders, Douglas did not turn an annual operating profit after 1974, primarily because its engineers and workers could not build aircraft quickly enough. **********Mr. McDonnell, a self-effacing engineer who joined the company in 1962, determined quickly that, given the coming decline in weapons orders, the company would no longer be able to count on the steady profitability of its combat-aircraft division in St. Louis to make up for the chronic weakness of Douglas in California.  A Radical Departure **********"It was time to bite the bullet and systematically change the way business was done" at Douglas, Mr. McDonnell said in an interview during a trip to California last week. **********His solution, announced early in 1989, was a radically new management approach, built around a philosophy called the Total Quality Management System, or TQMS. One of the approach's primary tenets is to push responsibility and authority down the organizational chart as far as possible. At Douglas, it was often pushed down to the production line, where, under TQMS, workers, supervisors and engineers were supposed to work together in teams to solve problems and increase efficiency. **********At first, the approach did little except alienate and confuse production workers and managers alike, with some joking that TQMS stood for "Time to Quit and Move to Seattle," the home of Boeing. In fact, many of the improvements in Douglas's performance seem to stem primarily from more disciplined and aggressive management rather than from teamwork. For example, instead of allowing the three shifts of workers on the MD-80 production line to use three different techniques for applying the metal skin to the plane's nose cone, as it always had, the company studied which technique was most efficient and then directed all three shifts to use that technique. **********Still, the TQMS approach clearly helped, especially on the MD-80 line. It now takes the company 19 weeks to build an MD-80, down from 30 weeks at the beginning of 1990. Although it is difficult to measure because the programs are still in their early phases, company executives say they are convinced TQMS has helped on the MD-11 and C-17 programs as well. **********"It played a key part in getting us where we are," Mr. Hood said. **********But TQMS may not have helped profitability as much as the huge number of layoffs Mr. McDonnell ordered last year to cut the entire corporation's costs by more than $700 million a year. At Douglas, thousands of middle managers, as well as some production workers, lost their jobs. **********The company will need its lower cost structure to weather the downturn in commercial aircraft demand. The airline industry has been growing weaker, with troubled carriers like Eastern disappearing and strong companies like American Airlines ordering fewer new planes and in some cases canceling orders. **********For Douglas, the effects have been most apparent in a falloff in orders for its twin-jet MD-80, used mostly on medium-length domestic routes. Through the first six months of the year, total orders for the MD-80 and a planned upgrade called the MD-90 had declined by 90, to 309 firm orders and 409 tentative "option" orders. For the same period, there were no net new orders for the longer-range, wide-body MD-11, whose backlog stood at 160 firm orders and 197 options as of June 30. **********Douglas now faces the possibility that it will not have enough orders to run the MD-80 and MD-11 production lines profitably after next year, analysts said. The weak market will also make it harder for the company to reach the 301 MD-11 deliveries it needs to recoup its $3 billion investment in that program. **********"The cost-cutting moves McDonnell Douglas has made appear to be paying off, but the problem is that the market for their products has weakened over the same time period," said Steve Binder, an analyst at Bear Stearns & Company. **********McDonnell Douglas executives acknowledge that the MD80/90 production line will have to be slowed because of the weakened order book, but they say they are optimistic about the outlook for the larger MD-11. American Airlines, they said, has expressed some interest in modernizing its fleet of Douglas DC-10's instead of buying new planes, which probably would have come from Boeing and Airbus. American, meanwhile, has indicated that it may still go ahead with plans to buy more MD-11's for many of its new overseas routes. A Test of Demand **********"It's a cyclical business," Mr. McDonnell said. "As sure as it's going down, the business is going to come back again in a few years. And right now, we have a luxury we haven't had at this point in the cycle in the past, which is a big backlog." **********It is still unclear whether enough airlines will have sufficient confidence in the future -- and in McDonnell Douglas -- to start ordering the proposed MD-12X, a larger variant of the MD-11. The company's board, at its meeting next month, is expected to authorize the company to begin soliciting orders for the new plane, a key test of demand. **********But the program will hinge on more than orders. In a sharp break with its past, McDonnell Douglas is seeking to cut much of the multibillion-dollar risk of developing the new plane by signing a deal with one or more partners who would take ownership positions in the project. At least one of the partners is likely to be Asian -- the current speculation centers on Mitsui of Japan -- because of McDonnell Douglas's criteria that any partner provide access to a low-wage work force and to a fast-growing market like the Pacific Rim. **********Some analysts question whether the company will be able to afford the several billion dollars it will take to develop the MD-12X, especially if MD-80 and MD-11 orders do not rebound quickly. Mr. McDonnell said that with a strong partner and an efficient new assembly plant in the United States -- the company has ruled out building the plane in Long Beach and is evaluating a half-dozen other cities -- McDonnell Douglas will have the resources it needs. **********"We're not going to launch it until we can do it in a way we are satisfied will not bet the company," Mr. McDonnell said. **********Boeing uses Japanese companies as major suppliers, but neither Boeing nor McDonnell Douglas has ever taken on equity partners for an airplane. Mr. McDonnell said any deal will also be complicated by the company's desire to structure it in a way that will minimize the chances its new partner might someday become an unwelcome low-cost competitor, a fear that has plagued relations between American aerospace companies and their counterparts in Japan and South Korea for the last several years. **********"The U.S. is not going to stay a leader in aerospace by becoming Fortress America. We're going to stay a leader by sharing today's technology while developing tomorrow's," Mr. McDonnell said. **********For now, however, Mr. McDonnell said he is convinced the company can do what it must to continue growing and becoming more profitable. **********"We've all been through the fire," he said. "We've all been hardened in the forge these last couple of years." A PENTAGON BAILOUT? **********Has McDonnell Douglas been the beneficiary of an unacknowledged bail out effort by the Pentagon? The company and the Pentagon say no, but two Congressional committees are not sure. They are looking into decisions by the Government that they say greatly aided the company. **********In February, for example, just a few weeks after canceling the Navy's A-12 bomber, the Pentagon said it would not immediately force McDonnell Douglas and its partner on the program, General Dynamics, to repay more than $650 million each the Government claims it is owed from work paid for but never completed. The Pentagon, which could have demanded immediate payment, did not give up its claim on the money, but said it would settle the matter in court. The case is not expected to be resolved for years. **********Investigators for a subcommittee of the House Government Operations Committee are studying whether the Pentagon funneled additional money to the company on the Air Force's C-17 program. Pentagon officials have denied making any unauthorized payments and McDonnell Douglas has denied receiving any. **********But critics remain unconvinced. The House Oversight and Investigations Committee has planned a hearing for Thursday. The Operations subcommittee will hold hearings later in October. BIDING TIME FOR BAD NEWS **********The earnings of McDonnell Douglas have improved, its debt is down and its stock price is up sharply. But that has not deterred the short sellers, who have made a huge bet that there is bad news lurking in the company's future that will drive its share price back down again. The stock closed Friday at $61.875. Between August 15 and September 15 alone, short interest in the stock rose 16 percent, to 5.1 million shares, or 13.3 percent of the 38.4 million shares outstanding. **********Analysts and journalists who follow McDonnell Douglas receive frequent, unsolicited calls from short sellers eager to pass on the latest unsubstantiated rumors: that American Airlines plans to cancel its MD-11 orders next month or that yet another Pentagon audit has found the company at risk of a $2 billion cost overrun. **********Fred Wadler of Gilford Securities in Chicago, which is holding its short position in the company at a loss, said he remains convinced that McDonnell Douglas faces serious problems. "They've got problems coming up in the C-17, and there's going to be a drain on the commercial side," he said. Those analysts who are becoming bullish on the stock, he said, "are calling it too early." **********But John McDonnell, the company's chief executive, said it is the shorts who are in for the rude surprise. "We think they are wrong," he said, "and that eventually our performance will prove it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/busin.main_headline: Report of Cutbacks Is Denied by P.& G.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Report of Cutbacks Is Denied by P.& G.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/28/busin.body_text: **********The Procter & Gamble Company said it was seeking to control costs to weather the recession but denied a report that said the company was cutting development and marketing budgets because of sluggish sales. The Wall Street Journal, in a report attributed to unidentified sources, said today that P.& G.'s chief executive, Edwin L. Artzt, had been telling managers to concentrate on their most important projects and to discard the rest. **********A P.& G. spokeswoman, Sydney McHugh, said that while the company was "tightening its belt" because of the recession, research and marketing spending would grow by more than 10 percent this year. She declined to disclose dollar figures. P.& G., the nation's largest maker of consumer products, spends heavily on development and has often led competitors in innovations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.main_headline: An Appraisal Of Top-Level Job Seekers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.print_headline: CAREERS; An Appraisal Of Top-Level Job Seekers
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.body_text: **********CANNY, BOWEN INC., a management recruiting firm based in New York, decided to survey high-level executives who had sent in their resumes. It took the step after receiving about a thousand resumes a week since the late fall. **********The firm, which specializes in recruiting top executives, said the deluge was about three times the rate received a year earlier. **********From its pool of unsolicited resumes, Canny, Bowen mailed questionnaires to a sample of 160 executives and received 100 replies. About 80 percent of the executives signed the questionnaires, though they were told they could remain anonymous, **********For years management recruiters insisted that they had seldom filled jobs from among the ranks of unemployed executives or those who were about to lose their jobs. Now, with so much talent out of work, recruiters look upon unsolicited resumes more kindly. **********Sometimes the names of those who submit unsolicited resumes are put into data banks, and the executives are occasionally offered as candidates to client companies. **********Unfortunately, said David R. Peasback, Canny, Bowen's president, few of the job seekers who had sent unsolicited resumes could expect help from his firm. **********The executives who responded to the survey had been working an average of 22 years since college or graduate school, indicating that they were in their mid-40's. Compensaton ranged from $150,000 to $350,000 a year. **********About 30 percent said they had lost their jobs because of downsizing, 19 percent said they had disagreed with corporate strategy and 17 percent reported they were disgruntled because a new superior had been appointed over them. An additional 15 percent said their companies had been acquired, and 15 percent cited dissatisfaction over a change in responsibilities. **********Mr. Peasback was surprised that few had said their compensation was unsatisfactory and that even fewer had objections to relocating. **********Most of the job-seeking executives reported relatively generous severance packages: 31 percent reported severance of six or more months, while 44 percent indicated they had received or would receive a full year's pay or more. **********At many companies severance typically runs about two weeks for each year on the payroll, but employment contracts, which some executives have, often include generous severance payments even for a short stint with a company. **********"I don't think many respondents had employment contracts," Mr. Peasback said. **********Despite the state of the economy, 41 percent of the job hunters said they had turned down offers, but about a third acknowledged that they had been rejected for what they had considered attractive openings. **********The executives were asked what they would have changed in their careers. Some regretted that they had not done more networking -- building lists of acquaintances who could help them find a new job. Others wished they had earned an advanced degree. **********Mr. Peasback was surprised that only a few of the executives had done much planning for career changes. **********One respondent said: "I should have chosen my job based on people and the chemistry between them. I made the mistake of taking a position based upon analysis of the company's potential -- not people and management." **********"Politics within a company," Mr. Peasback said, "can be deadly to an executive's career and always will be."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/busin.main_headline: A Marketing Expert To Run Laura Ashley
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A Marketing Expert To Run Laura Ashley
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/19/busin.body_text: **********What does a former automobile and electronics salesman know about selling flowered frocks and perfumed potpourri? **********"I know what a consumer is," says Jim Maxmin, 48 years old and the new chief executive of Laura Ashley Holdings, the beleaguered purveyor of genteel household furnishings, toiletries and clothing that evoke the style of an English country manor house. **********Mr. Maxmin, an expatriate American who has lived in Britain since 1964, learned the marketing business selling soap door to door in London's East End. "That's tough -- every sale was a hard one," he recalled. **********Reviving Laura Ashley could be equally tough. The company posted pretax losses of $11 million for its 1990 fiscal year ended Jan. 26, compared with a loss of $7.2 million the previous year. And it has laid off a fifth of its work force and closed seven factories in Britain and Ireland. The company blamed poor exchange rates, the recession and high inflation, but retailing analysts said it needed to update its image. **********"Young women under 35 who have been working out and sweating buckets to slip into cat suits are not about to start wearing granny-length dresses in floral prints," said Alan G. Millstein, publisher of Fashion Network Report, a fashion and retail trade newsletter. **********Mr. Maxmin disagreed, saying most Laura Ashley customers have remained loyal and introduced their daughters to the company. "That's the essence of niche marketing," he said. "You're not trying to reach everyone." **********Nonetheless, Mr. Maxmin said his task was to protect the brand name and image while making sure consumers understand that every item in the Laura Ashley collection "doesn't have flowers on it." **********He acknowledged that the company had had difficulty in its transition from a family-run business to a specialty retail chain of more than 500 company-owned stores and 200 franchised stores manned by more than 7,000 employees in 24 countries. Most of the stock is held by the family. A Japanese supermarket operator, the Jusco Company, holds a 15 percent stake. **********Mr. Maxmin's strategy involves expanding business in Asia and Europe, increasing advertising and enhancing or adding products to attract new customers. **********Mr. Maxmin started in retailing with Unilever and in 1973 joined Volvo Concessionaires U.K., rising through the ranks to become chief executive of the British subsidiary and later joint chairman. A decade later he joined Thorn-EMI P.L.C. as chief executive of television rentals. He was named president of Thorn in 1988 and led its $600 million acquisition of Rent-A-Center Inc., an American consumer electronics rental company. **********Mr. Maxmin has a home in London but spends half his time in Boston. His wife, Shoshana Zuboff, teaches at Harvard Business School. He has four children, ages 8 to 20, from his first marriage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/08/busin.main_headline:
Your Own Account;
Estimated Taxes Get More Exacting
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/08/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;
Estimated Taxes Get More Exacting
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/08/busin.body_text: **********The compromise that Congress and President Bush recently hammered out to pay for a 20-week extension of benefits for the unemployed will result in cumbersome calculations -- and earlier payment of taxes -- for hundreds of thousands of people who pay estimated quarterly taxes each year. If you are one of them, you should start thinking now about how you will comply. **********Precisely half of the estimated $5.2 billion needed to pay for the benefits will come from changing the rules for paying estimated taxes beginning in 1992. The changes will remain on the books through 1996. **********For those five years, many taxpayers with incomes over $75,000 will be forced to calculate their income on a quarterly basis and "pay as they go" rather than submit the same tax they paid the previous year, an option that is referred to as a "safe harbor" under current rules. The change will mean more paperwork -- and higher accountants' bills -- for many of those affected. And in some cases, it will result in an overpayment of taxes for which a refund may not be available for nearly a year. **********Estimated quarterly taxes are paid by those who do not have money withheld at their job or who do not have enough withheld because they have additional earnings from outside work or investment income. These people must make estimated tax payments on April 15, June 15, Sept. 15 and Jan. 15. **********For simplicity's sake, many pay the same amount they paid the year before, split into four chunks. At the end of the year, a full return is filed and any taxes owed are paid. This "safe harbor" approach is particularly advantageous to people with rapidly rising or erratic incomes, to active investors and to people who receive their income from partnerships, like lawyers and accountants, and often don't know until year end just what their compensation will be. **********Under the new rules, though, taxpayers who meet three conditions will not be eligible for the safe harbor treatment. To be affected, a taxpayer must have adjusted gross income of more than $75,000 and the amount must exceed the previous year's income by at least $40,000. The taxpayer must also have paid estimated taxes in at least one of the three prior years. Those affected will have to calculate their taxes quarterly and pay at least 90 percent of taxes due for that portion of the year. Otherwise, they will be subject to stiff penalties and interest. **********The problem is that overpayments may result for those who earn a great deal early in the year and little or nothing later on. If that happens, a refund cannot be claimed until a final return is filed. **********The income thresholds for the new rules are established for taxpayers who are married, filing jointly. It is not clear whether they are the same for individuals. Henry Holmes, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, said there were no separate income levels for individuals in the legislation. "The I.R.S. will have to go back and look at committee reports to see if the same levels are applicable," he said. **********The I.R.S. says that about 12.5 million of the 114.5 million individual taxpayers file estimated taxes. Although the agency predicts that only 500,000 will be forced to accelerate payments, most of the other 12 million will have to become familiar with the new rules to make certain they don't apply. **********There are a couple of exceptions to the rules. Taxpayers will be allowed to use the old "safe harbor" for the first-quarter payment on April 15 each year. But then they must "catch up" with the next payment, making certain that they have paid 90 percent of taxes due at midyear. **********Taxpayers who did not file estimated taxes for three years, and were not required to, will escape the reach of the new rules. And there is an exception for proceeds from the sale of a principal residence. **********But the rules will leave plenty of taxpayers with far more complicated tax preparation tasks. "There's no question that they've made it much harder for people," said Larry Elkin, manager in charge of personal financial planning for Arthur Andersen & Company in New York. **********Consider what might happen to an active investor who has a $100,000 capital gain in May. That investor will have to pay $28,000 in taxes on that amount on June 15 because the capital gains rate is 28 percent. **********But suppose the investor has a $100,000 capital loss in October. While that erases the earlier tax liability, the taxpayer cannot immediately ask for a refund. "There is no provision for getting this money back until you file your tax return the following year," said Laurence I. Foster, a tax partner at KPMG Peat Marwick in New York. **********The new rules will also eliminate what accountants like to call a "planning opportunity" for taxpayers who plan to sell appreciated property. Under the old rules, accountants advised clients to sell appreciated property in January so they could bank the capital gain until taxes were due a year from April. "You could have had a 15-month deferral on taxes due," said Vincent D. Vaccaro, partner at Coopers & Lybrand in New York. "That deferral will be eliminated under the new rules." **********The same is true for bonuses and other incentive compensation customarily paid in January. Companies are required to withhold only 20 percent of such payments, Mr. Vaccaro said. But under the new rules, you may be liable for additional estimated taxes if your bonus or other incentive compensation sharply increases your income.AVOIDING THE HARSHER RULE **********Accountants are already beginning to look for "planning opportunities" in the new estimated tax rules. For example, Laurence I. Foster, partner at KPMG Peat Marwick, suggests that some people may profit by doing "quarterly planning," or moving sales of appreciated property from one quarter to the next. **********Lorin D. Luchs, partner at BDO Seidman's national tax office, says he will advise clients who can do so to pay their tax through withholding rather than make estimated payments so they can preserve the opportunity to use the old rule on an important occasion, if need be. **********The old rule can still be used by those who did not file estimated taxes during the previous three years, among other exceptions. **********"If you pay everything through withholding, then you're not tainted by the payment of estimated taxes," Mr. Luchs said. **********Thus, if a taxpayer wanted to sell a piece of appreciated property and delay paying tax on the gain, he or she could use the old "safe harbor" rule for one year, paying estimated taxes that equaled the total tax from the previous year. **********For the same reason, Vincent D. Vaccaro of Coopers & Lybrand says he will look at the withholding for clients who receive large lump sums like bonuses early in the year. There may be an advantage to withholding more than the required 20 percent from these lump sums so that the client will not be required to make an estimated payment later in the year, similarly "tainting" that year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Genentech Enters Research Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/24/busin.body_text: **********Genentech Inc. and Incyte Pharmaceuticals have signed an agreement to develop a drug to treat septic shock, an often fatal condition arising from bacterial infections. Genentech will pay $14 million to Incyte, a privately held company based in Palo Alto, Calif., to cover research and development expenses and an equity investment. Genentech will have the rights to market the drug everywhere except in the Far East. **********The drug, known as bactericidal/ permeability increasing protein, or BPI, is a human protein that may be able to inactivate the toxins released by bacteria. Genentech and Incyte had been separately working on BPI.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Consumer Trends Bothering P.&G.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Consumer Trends Bothering P.&G.
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/17/busin.body_text: **********WHEN the Procter & Gamble Company bought Max Factor and other cosmetics lines from Revlon Inc. for $1.14 billion last week, it won general praise on Wall Street. Now comes the hard part. **********Later this month, Procter & Gamble will report how severely the recession has punished the 97 percent of its business that is not cosmetics. **********In recent months, securities analysts have been steadily whittling their forecasts for P.&G.'s third-quarter earnings, from about $1.29 a share to about $1.20 or less. That compares with $1.14 a share in the 1990 quarter. Modest or flat unit sales growth in the United States, where P.&G. does more than 60 percent of its business, is to blame for the weak expectations, analysts say. **********Despite the soft short-term outlook, many analysts think Procter & Gamble has strong growth possibilities, especially in its stock price. Yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, P.&G. gained $1.875 a share to close at $89.375, almost 18 times estimated 1991 earnings. Jay H. Freedman, a consumer-products analyst at Kidder, Peabody, thinks that the share price could reach $110 in the next year and a half. **********Getting there may be a bumpy road, however. Although many consumer-products companies are perceived by investors as safe harbors in a recession, they are nonetheless harmed when increasing numbers of consumers lose their jobs, or even when those still employed begin to cut back spending. Analysts say that an internal P.&G. survey found that 18 out of 24 markets that the company serves -- including detergents and toothpaste -- are showing soft or declining unit sales. **********Added to that is the fact that population growth in the United States has been only 1 percent or so a year. So, the supply of consumers with money in their pockets is growing slowly even without a recession. In addition, supermarkets and mass merchandisers have built too many stores, adding to the pressure to stock less. **********Procter & Gamble is especially vulnerable when people curtail spending because the typical American home offers a cavalcade of the Cincinnati giant's products. Wake up in the morning and you can wash with Ivory soap, shampoo with Pert Plus and brush your teeth with Crest. Don't forget the Secret deodorant. Still groggy? Have some Folgers coffee. Before you leave the house, be sure to load the dishwasher with Cascade detergent and the washing machine with Tide laundry detergent. **********But even such a roster of strong brands cannot entirely offset some apparent trends in the marketplace. Analysts say that retailers, despite already lean inventories, are continuing to cut back, a development affecting many packaged-goods companies. Bonita Austin, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder, said the Colgate-Palmolive Company reported that some of its supermarket accounts were maintaining inventories of 1.5 weeks on some products, compared with 3 weeks, only a few months ago. "Even three weeks isn't a whole lot," Ms. Austin said. **********Inventories may be thinning because money-conscious consumers are stocking up less, buying one bottle of shampoo instead of two, for instance. **********Moreover, there is scattered evidence that consumers, either newly jobless or simply cautious, are increasingly "trading down" to cheaper generic or store brands for detergents, toilet paper, toothpaste and other consumer goods. The strength of the trend isn't clear yet, however. Ms. Austin notes that Helene Curtis Industries is reporting booming sales of its budget Suave shampoo, but is also seeing strong sales of its higher-priced Salon Selective. **********The hazards of recession have focused Procter & Gamble's attention on acquiring health and beauty lines. In recent years, it bought such brand products as Nyquil cold remedy, Oil of Olay moisturizing cream and Cover Girl cosmetics, and last week, it made the Max Factor deal. **********Health and beauty products have above-average growth possibilities in unit sales, perhaps 3 percent to 5 percent annually, because the population is aging and older consumers are more likely to buy products like P.&G.'s Pepto-Bismol. A growth rate of 2 percent or so is expected for P.&G.'s more basic products, like laundry detergent. **********Profits, too, can be above average in health and beauty products, another attraction for P.&G. Alice Beebe Longley, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said a successful fragrance could have a profit margin as high as 40 percent, compared with 10 percent or 11 percent for detergents. **********Not all analysts, of course, are excited about Procter & Gamble's Max Factor deal, which at least doubled, to about $1.6 billion, the company's revenues from cosmetics and fragrance lines. Mary Ann Winter, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman, noted that those revenues would still be only a small part of Procter & Gamble's total, which was $24 billion in the 1990 fiscal year. **********Ms. Winter, who has been neutral on P.&G. since the start of the recession and the onset of the Persian Gulf crisis, said: "I'm not excited about the deal. I'm not against the deal. I'd like to see how the company as a whole performs in the next few months."
