https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/busin.main_headline: Bonds Post Modest Rise in Light Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Bonds Post Modest Rise in Light Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/27/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices rose modestly yesterday on the strength of slight buying by mutual funds and other investors who had cash but were not willing to keep it invested in low-yielding short-term securities. **********By late in the day, the 8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2021 were offered at 105 7/8, up by an eighth of a point on the day, to yield 7.50 percent, compared with 7.51 percent late on Tuesday. Shorter-term issues were little changed, with two-year notes closing with a yield of 4.83 percent and five-year notes at 6 percent. **********Trading was light, as securities dealers and other speculators, their ranks thinned by the holidays, stayed on the sidelines. Stocks Still Gaining **********But while the bond market was little changed, the stock market continued to rise sharply. To some analysts, the recent behavior of the two markets suggested sharply different views of the future. The bond market has rallied, with 30-year Treasury bond yields falling from 8 percent in early November, amid predictions that inflation will remain subdued while the economy and credit demands stay weak. **********Stock prices, meanwhile, are moving to new highs, in anticipation of a stronger economy because of recent cuts in interest rates and some package of increased spending or tax cuts to be enacted by Congress next year. **********"The stock market is strong, looking ahead to developments of next year, while the bond market right now is not too cerebral, and isn't looking much beyond next week," said Len Santow, an economist and co-author of the Griggs & Santow Report, one of the oldest newsletters on Wall Street covering the bond markets and the economy. **********Mr. Santow said that fiscal and monetary policy "are going to get mroe stimulative," and that by the second half of next year, "the economy will be considerably stronger." By 1993 or 1994, he said, rising inflation may cause bond investors, with the benefit of 20-20 hindsight, to decide that economic policy makers provided more stimulus than was needed. **********Alan C. Lerner, managing director at the Bankers Trust Company, noted in a recent issue of Prospects for Credit Markets, a bank publication, that recent Fed moves to reduce short-term interest rates reflected a desire "to get the economy rolling before the politicians act." **********But he added that the Fed's moves would take time to bear fruit and that "it seems almost inevitable that Congress and the Administration will be competing in 1992 to stimulate the economy." **********In addition to the danger of a revived economy, Mr. Santow said bond investors and traders might be overlooking the potential for a heavier supply of new Treasury securities if Congress and the President agreed on tax cuts or new spending programs. **********While there were no new corporate bond offerings yesterday, investment bankers expect a flurry of new issues in early January, as corporate treasurers try to take advantage of low rates. Based on past episodes of herd behavior by large corporations, new bond sales could exceed $10 billion in a week, or more than four times the monthly average of new investment-grade corporate issues this year. **********According to Salomon Brothers Inc., the average monthly volume this year was about $9.09 billion for new investment-grade issues and $1.37 billion of below investment-grade issues, including those that could be converted into common stock. **********Graphs: "Freddie Mac Yields" shows average weekly yhields on Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation 30-year and 15-year participation certificates, in percent, from Sept.-Dec., 1991. (Source: Federal Home Loan Mortgate Corp.); "Tax-Exempt Yields" shows average weekly yields for 20 general obligation bonds and 25 revenue bonds, in percent from Sept.-Dec., 1991. (Source: The Bond Buyer)

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/15/world.body_text: **********A postscript to the cold war is being written here: a missile factory has been converted to make refrigerators. **********Just as important, the refrigerators are rolling off assembly lines not in the company's old location in the mountains of south-central China but in a new industrial zone here in the provincial capital. As the people here say, the tiger has come out of the mountains. **********The tiger is China's so-called Third Line of industry, built mostly in the 1960's. Fearing attack by the United States or the Soviet Union, Mao Zedong ordered 2,000 companies representing a large share of China's industrial and military capacity removed from vulnerable coastal areas to remote hillside towns in the country's interior. Mao thought that the Communists could rely on that Third Line of industry even if an enemy attacked the coast. **********It was an extraordinary scheme, the most daring and perhaps the most ill-considered industrial relocation plan that any country had ever attempted. From the mid-1960's to the mid-1970's, nearly half of China's budget went to Third Line construction, but the new factories tended to be inefficient because of poor infrastructure and supply lines. Moving Back to Cities **********In this post-Mao, post-cold-war era, the Third Line companies are now moving back to the cities, and in many cases retooling to make consumer goods instead of weapons. Across the nation, enterprises that once produced tanks and missiles and other military products are now making 650 kinds of civilian goods. Here in Guiyang, the capital of Guizhou province, two new industrial zones are filling up with Third Line factories making everything from transistors to automobile headlights. **********"Intellectuals are very happy with the move, after being in the mountains for two decades," said Wang Quan, director of the Guiyang office of the Zhenhua Electronics Industry Corporation, one such enterprise. "Life is better here, there is entertainment and culture, and there's better education for the kids." **********Of the 700,000 industrial workers in Guizhou Province who work in Third Line enterprises, about a third have already moved to the cities or are in the process of doing so, according to Hu Lun, chief economist of the Guizhou Province Planning Commission. Efficiency and Location **********"We plan to move all our workers to Guiyang," said Mr. Wang, of Zhenhua, which has 30,000 employees at 21 factories scattered across Guizhou. "But that will depend on economics and on how efficient the factories are here." **********One of the factories that already has moved and started operations in Guiyang is the Jianxin Machine Factory, a unit of Zhenhua that makes stone cutters, drill presses and other industrial equipment. In the past it exported some goods to Eastern Europe and now the managers are hoping that the improved location will improve exports to the West. **********"It's much more convenient here," said Feng Yisong, a senior engineer of the factory. "Transportation is much easier, and it's far simpler to make contacts and get a hold of people. So our efficiency is much better now." **********The factory shop -- emblazoned with huge red characters across the wall declaring: "Socialism is Good. The Communist Party is Good" -- is spacious and is taking advantage of a tax break to install some brand-new equipment in addition to assembly lines brought in from its old location near the town of Duyun. Creating a Society **********The director of the nearby New Cloud Equipment Factory, Long Hanmin, said that though there is a hefty cost to moving the plant and all of its employees to Guiyang, the move will soon pay for itself in improved efficiency and reduced transportation costs. **********"We used to be a company town and had to create our own society," said Mr. Long. "We had to provide schools, restaurants, a movie theater and a hospital. In Guiyang, we don't have to do any of that." **********Mr. Long's factory used to make electronic components for the army, but it shifted a half-dozen years ago to manufacturing similar civilian products, like transistors and capacitors. These days, the transition from military production to civilian production is well underway, not just in Guizhou but throughout China. **********For Guizhou Province, one of the poorest in China, that switch -- coupled with the emergence from the mountains of the Third Line "tiger" -- also offers an important opportunity to lure foreign investment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.main_headline: Now, When You're Out You're In
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.print_headline: Now, When You're Out You're In
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/21/busin.body_text: **********A few years ago, it was just about impossible for a fashion newcomer like Byron Lars to get a foot -- let alone a dress -- inside a major store. Lars? Who had ever heard of him? But last winter the 26-year-old designer packed up the eight samples that were his entire spring line, marched into Henri Bendel and walked away with an order for 80 pieces. **********Now his second collection, for fall, is in 10 stores around the country, including Bloomingdale's in New York, which put his witty clothes in its Lexington Avenue windows in July. **********Mr. Lars is one of the recent brood of fledgling designers to benefit from retailers' new receptiveness toward unproven talent. In the last year or so, major stores long dominated by names like Klein and Armani have been giving valuable floor space to designers like Gemma Kahng, Gordon Henderson, Todd Oldham and Zang Toi. **********Before the buyout wave and the recession hit the retailing industry, unknowns like them had trouble getting store buyers to take their calls. Now the stores are banking on such young designers to bring in the customers without driving up their costs . **********The stores are finding that the eager new designers can often save them the expense of accommodating the major names. Prominent designers can impose minimum orders of $100,000 or $200,000, and not only demand their own in-store boutiques but even dictate the size and decor. Giorgio Armani expects his departments to look like his stark, ultra-modern Milan boutique; Calvin Klein wants soothing beige and brown furniture. The store is expected to foot the bill, and how can a store say no to any of the world's top designers? **********Young designers set no minimums, said Joan Kaner, senior vice president and fashion director of Neiman Marcus. "They're thrilled to sell you one piece, just so they can be in a big store," she said. "You can pick just what will work for your store and expand later based on performance, delivery and quality." **********Ellin Saltzman, senior vice president and corporate fashion director of R. H. Macy & Company, said that to distinguish themselves, stores were looking for fresh young names. "The stores got so much alike with all the same designers," she said. "They now realize that the safe route of the tried and true is not necessarily the only way. So they're looking for a gimmick, some way to be different. It's a new attitude." Returning the Calls **********New designers appreciate the change. "When we started two years ago," Gemma Kahng said, "we couldn't get anybody to come see us. We called and called and called, and they didn't even return our calls. Then we got some press, and the stores started calling us." Her colorful clothes with oversize jeweled buttons are now in many major department and specialty stores, and she expects her wholesale volume to reach $2 million this year. **********Traditionally, newcomers have relied on specialty stores willing to take a chance with a small order of five or six styles, which got the designers started but allowed them little room for growth. Then, two years ago, Lynn Manulis of New York's venerable Martha Park Avenue boutique opened a shop totally devoted to a new generation of designers. Called Martha International, it offered clothes by Christian Francis Roth, Carmelo Pomodoro, Charlotte Neuville and Randolph Duke. Soon, department stores decided they were missing out on a good bet. **********A store can put a few styles from each of several young designers together in one department and see what sells. Macy's Northeast put a New Signatures department in the Herald Square store in New York last year as an experiment; it was successful enough to be expanded to Macy's San Francisco and the company's Bullocks stores. A Growing Trend **********Henri Bendel, which was once well known for discovering new talent, has made its new store on Fifth Avenue a showcase for young designers. **********Nordstrom, the Seattle-based retailer with more than 60 branches, has a department called Savvy where newcomers can get a tryout. Byron Lars is there this fall, along with Gemma Kahng, C. D. Greene, Anna Sui and Randolph Duke. "I look for items, not names," said the Nordstrom buyer, Carrie Fahey, who was one of the first to give Randolph Duke a break. **********Mr. Duke, in business three years, said Nordstrom had saved his operation. "When you first start, it's good to have the anchor of one department store," he said. "Our anchor was Nordstrom. There was one season where we would have gone under if we didn't have paper from Nordstrom. " **********At Bloomingdale's, Byron Lars received the most lavish promotion of any new designer since Isaac Mizrahi. Although Mr. Mizrahi beat the odds by attracting major retailers to his first show three years ago, he had the advantage of the contacts with store executives that he developed as an assistant designer for Perry Ellis and Calvin Klein. Mr. Lars, a native of San Francisco with limited experience as a freelance designer, was an unknown quantity. **********"We don't normally do windows and ads for a new talent," said Kalman Ruttenstein, Bloomingdale's vice president for fashion direction. "This is the first time since Isaac Mizrahi that we pulled out all the stops for a new designer. But we think our customers will respond to Byron. His clothes have a street humor, but they're also very sophisticated and cut beautifully." **********What sets the designs by Byron Lars apart is his way of adding an ironic twist to the classics. He uses striped cotton for a shirtdress, adding a man's necktie but also a seductively draped skirt, and he cuts rustic buffalo plaid into feminine full-skirted shapes for coats. The dresses retail for $325; the coats for $750. **********Gambling on new designers is not without its risks. Customers are often reluctant to spend $800 on a jacket by someone they have never heard of. Because it can cost more for a small manufacturer to produce a garment than for a big company that makes thousands of each style, a young designer's clothes can end up priced as high as a well-known designer's. **********A store has to be patient, said Mara Urshel, a senior vice president and general merchandise manager of Saks Fifth Avenue. "You know up front that the merchandise will not walk out of the store the first day," she said. **********Mr. Ruttenstein of Bloomingdale's agrees. "You can't just buy the clothes and let them sit there," he said. "You have to promote them, and let the customer know about them. And you have to be prepared to give them a few years before you can make money with them." **********Another risk for stores is that untried talent is often undercapitalized. "You may place an order, and it's never sent to you," said Ms. Kaner of Neiman Marcus." A Sudden Demise **********That has happened to stores that ordered fall merchandise from Michael Leva, who suddenly closed his four-year-old business in July. Faced with a doubling of orders, he could not raise enough capital to buy the fabrics and pay the contractors. **********Mr. Lars hopes to avoid that danger. He sought professional advice from Mary Ann Wheaton, who is in the business of helping to introduce new lines. She determined that he could afford to ship to just 10 stores for fall. "The hard part for a designer to understand," Ms. Wheaton said, "is that there's a big danger in being immediately successful and growing too quickly." **********But by and large, the new designers are thoroughly professional. Andrew Basile, the fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman, said today's young designers were more aware of the need for well-made, high-quality clothing as well as fresh ideas. "They know they must present a clean, clear point of view that marries value and quality with creativity and ingenuity," he said. "This has all happened in the last two years. It's all come together in one moment."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/25/world.main_headline: Grief and Bitterness Smolder In the Embers of a Fatal Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/25/world.print_headline: Grief and Bitterness Smolder In the Embers of a Fatal Fire
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/25/world.body_text: **********Ruben Valladarez is nearly over the worst of his nightmares, the dreams in which terrified faces of old friends stare through him into the flames consuming the Happy Land Social Club -- dreams from which he wakes crying. **********He has other reminders of the fire that killed 87 people: the light brown scars that wrap around his calves and the thick black ones that crawl over his ribs and thighs like scabs, the scars that paralyze his hands, the scars that run across his face and finally fall like a heavy tear at one end. **********All of that Mr. Valladarez can understand. **********What he cannot fathom is the court case against Julio Gonzalez, the man accused as the arsonist, which has dragged on for a year without so much as a date for trial; the welfare case workers who he says balked at helping his family while he recovered from his burns, and the terrible dispatch with which he saw people stop caring about the fire's victims. **********"Everyone promised help: $40,000 here, $50,000 there," said Mr. Valladarez, a 28-year-old illegal immigrant who used to earn $150 and free beer for three long nights of work as the club's disk jockey. "It was all a lie." **********For the relatives of those who died, the anniversary of the fire today will be a day of prayer in the Tremont section of the Bronx, where a Mass is to be celebrated two blocks from the club, in villages along the northern coast of Honduras, and at cemeteries scattered elsewhere in the Americas. And it will be a day of bitterness as well as pain. Guilt, Loneliness, Poverty **********At a year's distance, the suffering seems to have only begun with the deaths. Like Mr. Valladarez, six other people escaped the burning club only to find their lives a shambles. For them, as for hundreds of people who loved and depended on those who died, the months have been filled with anguish, guilt, loneliness and poverty. **********The fire would have stunned New York simply with its tally of innocent death. But for 16 months and without much difficulty, the Happy Land's proprietors ignored officials who had cited the place as a fire hazard and ordered it vacated. Around the city, scores of other illegal clubs -- many of them, like the Happy Land, sanctuaries from the hardships of immigrant life -- were found to have been doing the same. **********Among the fire's survivors and the relatives of its victims, the outrage has lasted months and perhaps grown. They complain of the inevitable bureaucratic failings: aid checks not received, funeral expenses not remunerated. But this hardly explains their sense of abandonment. That accounting also involves the sudden loss of promising lives, the battering of their dreams, the expectations of support that were inflated by an outpouring of concern and then quickly disappointed. **********What many had initially taken to be a net of help they now describe as a web of cold regulations and promises that cancel out. Their unwanted celebrity -- perversely lavish even by the standards of New York victims -- has quickly given way to anonymity. The same families that once marveled at their adoptive country's generosity and promises of justice now see prejudice and cruel tricks. **********"Since all of the people in there were Hispanics, everyone washes their hands quickly," said Roberto Michell Suazo, a shy 36-year-old who found a way out the club but lost his job, many of his belongings and most of his hopes to the demons that followed him. **********Like Mr. Michell, 59 of the dead were from Honduras, a country where poverty kills every day without drawing much of the world's attention. But there was another common denominator: The Happy Land built its following among Latin soccer players, vigorous young immigrants who stood out from compatriots just by the determination it took them to find homes and jobs in places like the Bronx. Fights Over Painful Remnants **********As suddenly as it choked the dance floor of the club's two-story space at 1959 Southern Boulevard, near East Tremont Avenue, the fire seemed to bare lives that had not had a chance to sort themselves out. **********Social workers still confronting the fire's emotional toll no longer speak of 87 victims, but of hundreds. There are the scores of orphaned children, the 20-odd widows and widowers and the uncounted men and women linked to the victims by everything but marriage. Perhaps a dozen new babies bear the names of loved ones who died. **********In their grief, some families have drawn closer together. Yet there has also been another pattern, in which death has stolen the distance that separated estranged parents from one another and new families in the United States from old families abroad. With nothing else between them, the sides have fought over painful remnants: keepsakes, children, the uncertain promise of huge civil lawsuits. **********The dislocation has been replicated on a broader scale. Last spring, the disaster seemed to bring together the city's scattered and largely poor Honduran community. In the months since, groups that sought unity have seemed to lose momentum, and many victims' relatives have begun keeping to themselves. For the jumble of families from other parts of the hemisphere (only nine victims were listed as Americans), social workers say the sense of isolation has been even worse. Coming Together in Court **********Nowadays, the families' most regular communion takes place on the sixth floor of the Bronx County Courthouse, where they come with a sense of duty they often find hard to explain. **********Stepping patiently through metal detectors, they take seats in a vast paneled room and chat in Spanish until Mr. Gonzalez, the arson suspect, appears. **********Before a hearing earlier this month, the talk went like this: **********"I had never thought death was so bad," said Maria Colon, a woman from Ecuador who was thinking of her Puerto Rican husband. **********"I thought it was just one more step," Dilcia Pineda said, thinking of the Honduran man with whom she had lived. **********One row ahead, Lourdes Robledo was saying, "I haven't missed one of these hearings -- except when my husband was buried." **********And Lydia Rodriguez, a sister of the man who ran the Happy Land and died there, wondered aloud: "When? When is this going to be resolved? When?" The Fire Injuries of Body And of Spirit **********As survivors recall it, March 24 had been another busy Saturday night at the Happy Land. At 3 A.M., people were still arriving. Nearly everyone was upstairs, crowding the dance floor and the fake-wood bar that sold beers for $2. **********Downstairs, Elena Colon was waiting for her husband, Elias, who ran the club. She remembers Julio Gonzalez having a couple of drinks and talking calmly to a boy who later died. **********It was not much later, the police say, that Mr. Gonzalez was ejected by a bouncer after arguing with Lydia Feliciano, the club's ticket-taker and the woman who had just broken up with him after eight years together. **********Mrs. Colon said she saw no argument. But in a videotaped statement that they have described as a confession, the police say Mr. Gonzalez told of grabbing a plastic jug outside the club and filling it with $1 worth of gasoline at a nearby Amoco station. Dousing the Happy Land's door, he lighted a match, they say. Then, Mr. Gonzalez told them, he went home to sleep. **********Ms. Feliciano, Mrs. Colon and three young men who had been downstairs all escaped through a poorly marked emergency door down from the flaming main entrance. **********Ruben Valladarez, warned by a friend who also found the emergency door, shut off the music and alerted the crowd through his microphone. Then he turned to friends gathered around him by a front staircase. "Whoever wants to live should follow me," he recalls telling them before bounding down into the fire. **********None of them did. As smoke poured upstairs, they were quickly asphyxiated. Firefighters later told of men with their arms still around women, as if to protect them. The Aftermath Shining Promises Quickly Tarnish **********Many of the victims' relatives and friends seem to remember the fire's aftermath almost as a dream. City officials, social workers and reporters were everywhere. Telephones rang incessantly. Honduras declared three days of national mourning. **********Then came the lawyers. They called, knocked on doors and traveled thousands of miles in search of grieving relatives looking to sue. In Francia, Honduras, a farming hamlet eight bumpy hours from the nearest international airport, "there were American lawyers, Puerto Rican lawyers -- all kinds," said Maria Arriola, who returned home there to bury her daughter, Alba, her brother, Querry Romero, and four other relatives. "It was like a world event." **********Amid the onslaught came government and private agencies offering aid that many families never expected. **********Inside the school gymnasium where families went to identify snapshots of the dead, city social workers gave many of them hundreds of dollars for rent, food and other expenses. The State Crime Victims Board paid funeral expenses of up to $2,500. The American Red Cross gave money, too, and 48 coffins were flown to Honduras for burial. 'That's Where Things Failed' **********Rosa Guevara, a native of El Salvador who lost her brother, Victor Hugo Benavides, still talks of the limousine ride to his funeral. "If things like this happen in one's own countries, you have to bury your own," she said. **********By summer's end, 87 relatives of the dead and Mr. Valladarez's wife had received $1,600 each from private donations. But for each loved one who cashed a check, social workers say, several others were left empty-handed. **********Some city agencies declined to provide aid they believed would be given by other city agencies. Some relatives, because they lacked legal residency, feared contacting the government, while others, accustomed to self-sufficiency, did not know how. **********"The initial response was fabulous, but it was crisis-oriented and somewhat chaotic," said Antonio Fernandez, who worked with the South Bronx vicariate to help many families. "There was no planning for what happened after the crisis, and that's where things failed." **********As the initial aid took many of the relatives by surprise, so have some of them seemed to grow obsessed by the promises they say went unfulfilled. **********Some recall the Permanent Honduran Committee, which vowed to raise $1 million for the victims' families, but faded away after a single event that barely covered its costs. Others remember the Honduran community center for which President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras and John Cardinal O'Connor donated $52,000, only to see the project set aside when they could not persuade the city to donate a site. **********And then there are the stories of women like Lourdes Robledo, who because of a bureaucratic foul-up is being made to pay back $900 she was given after her husband's death, and Rosa Perez, who cannot become a legal resident because her residency papers are in Honduras and she is in the Bronx, destitute after the death of her son's father. **********Though some of the relatives speak with resignation carried from countries where sudden death is too familiar, their bitterness also betrays quick assimilation. 'He Would Be Dead' **********"When you live in a country like this -- where you work and you pay taxes and when you hurt your leg on a broken sidewalk you can sue someone -- it's different," said Rosiviltt Garbutt, who lost a son. "Of course it's different." **********But ideals of American justice have eroded with delay after delay in the courts. The trial of Mr. Gonzalez, a 37-year-old Cuban refugee, is expected to begin sometime between May and July, after yet another round of psychological evaluations. Although the club's landlords were cleared of criminal liability last year for the deaths, they still face misdemeanor charges. And the civil suits may drag on for years. **********"In our country, this man would no longer be in jail," said Francisco Gamoneda, a Honduran who lost two sons to the fire. "He would be dead." **********From his cell in the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men, Mr. Gonzalez seems to prolong an agony of many forms. **********At the Gamonedas's small house in the Belmont section of the Bronx, for instance, 9 children, 12 grandchildren and various other relatives come and go. Still, Leticia Gamoneda says she cannot find a way out from the shadow of her two missing sons, Marco Tulio and Lenin Ernesto. **********"You could have 20 children," she said, "but if you lose one or two or three, you'll miss them always." **********Dilcia Pineda's apartment in the Fordham section is a quiet, almost serene place where the image of Marvin Doubleday lingers in a blown-up snapshot on the wall and in the face of an infant who carries his name. **********"Each time I look at the baby," she said, "I remember how much he wanted a son." Ms. Pineda discovered she was pregnant after feeling sick when she went to identify the body of Mr. Doubleday, with whom she had lived. Since that day, she has felt little comfort from others. "This is a country that forgets pretty easily," she said. The Only Memorial **********Compared to some, Ruben Valladarez has been lucky in the help he received. What sympathy may not have been prompted by the burns over more than 40 percent of his body, his courage has seemed to elicit. And he is grateful for all of it, as he is for his hands, which he feared might be amputated, and the ability to walk. But he is bitter about America: about its system of justice, its bureaucracy and the promises it seemed to make to him in Honduras that he believes have not been kept. **********Though his wife was born in the United States, Mr. Valladarez said, welfare workers offered him only $40 a month to supplement her income as a word processor while he recovered. A spokesman for the Human Resources Administration, Earl Weber, said that the case was being investigated and that he could provide no details. **********Israel Bulnes arrived at similar thoughts as he drove around the Bronx listening to a tape of old Spanish songs that his son, Israel Antonio, made for him and talked about how much he misses the boy. **********"Before people come, back in Honduras, they think poverty doesn't exist here," he said. "When you go there and tell them that life is very hard here, that you live in cold buildings with rats and cockroaches, they don't believe you." **********Parking on Southern Boulevard, he added, "Somebody should send them a picture of that." **********Across the street, behind two barren trees ringed by burnt candles and empty pints of cheap vodka, was the boarded-up storefront from which he had watched Israel Antonio's body emerge in a thick plastic bag. **********There were plans to build a monument, but so far only relatives like Mr. Bulnes have contributed, and their money pales at estimates of the cost. So until an all-weather sign was affixed to the building for a modest commemoration yesterday, the only memorial consisted of some weathered wreaths, some artificial flowers and a plastic sheet with 87 names and the legend "Descansen en Paz," Rest in Peace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/busin.main_headline: House Panel in Compromise on Bank Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/busin.print_headline: House Panel in Compromise on Bank Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/02/busin.body_text: **********House Democrats reached a compromise today that increased the chances of banking legislation being passed in the next few months. **********Democrats on the House Banking Committee had threatened to join Republicans in opposing a narrowly tailored bill that fell short of the Bush Administration's recommendations to overhaul the banking system. **********The bill was proposed by the chairman of the committee, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, and by Representative Frank Annunzio, an Illinois Democrat, the chairman of the Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Financial Institutions Supervision, Regulation and Insurance. **********The legislation is scheduled to be considered by the subcommittee on Tuesday. It would expand the borrowing authority of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation by $20 billion. The bank insurance fund has been rapidly deteriorating, and according to the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, is already nearly insolvent. **********The Treasury Department has proposed allowing commercial banks and investment banks to merge, as well as the ownership of banks by industrial enterprises. It has also sought to eliminate the barriers to interstate banking. **********Democrats on the subcommittee had threatened to join the Republicans in opposing the Gonzalez-Annunzio bill because they said now was the best time politically to change the structure of the banking system. **********Today, the Democrats emerged from a caucus with a fragile alliance after reaching a compromise on the procedure for drafting the legislation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/world.main_headline: Soviet Muslims Riot, Seeking Trips to Mecca
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/world.print_headline: Soviet Muslims Riot, Seeking Trips to Mecca
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/14/world.body_text: **********Soviet Muslims angry at the high cost and limited number of pilgrimages to Mecca rioted today and tried to occupy the government headquarters in the capital of the autonomous republic of Dagestan, the ass news agency reported. **********Tass said the authorities had used tear gas and fired warning shots in the air to hold off the demonstrators, some of whom reportedly returned the fire. There were no serious injuries, according to Tass. **********The Soviet agency said that protesters in the capital, the Caspian Sea city of Makhachkala, had been meeting angrily for more than 10 days. They demanded that the Government reimburse pilgrims for the high cost of the journey to the holy places of Mecca, in Saudi Arabia, and allow anybody who wanted to go to go. **********The Soviet Union has no diplomatic relations with Saudi Arabia. But Tass said the Soviet authorities had agreed with "Arab countries" to set the price at roughly $10,000, and to provide spaces for 4,000 pilgrims from all over the Soviet Union. **********More than 10,000 people from Dagestan had applied for the 1,200 places available to them, Tass said. **********Dagestan, part of the Russian Federation, had no money available to satisfy the demands of the protesters, Tass said, but talks were continuing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Rolls Withdraws Worker Warning
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/24/busin.body_text: **********Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the British airplane engine maker, agreed to withdraw letters it sent to its 34,000 employees threatening them with the loss of their jobs if they did not accept a pay freeze. Rolls-Royce said it had also agreed to hold talks with the unions about pay and job losses. The move followed talks between the company and union leaders, in which the union warned Rolls-Royce that its workers could take legal action for breach of contract. **********In the letters, the company had given notice that contracts of employment would be terminated and replaced with new ones eliminating automatic pay increases. Despite the withdrawal of the letters, a Rolls-Royce spokesman said, "it is still our intention to achieve a pay freeze, because it is an important element in our cost-cutting exercise."

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Airline Accord On Reservations
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/03/busin.body_text: **********The European Commission cleared a venture between two travel computer reservation systems, Sabre of American Airlines and Amadeus of Lufthansa, Air France and Iberia. Through the agreement, Sabre will get access to markets within the 12-nation community and Amadeus will benefit from new technologies, said a spokesman for the commission, the executive body of the European Community. Travel agents will now be able to get both systems on one computer screen, making it easier to see all available flights. **********The agreement will reduce competition between Sabre and Amadeus, but the commission said it would also open Amadeus's home markets of France, Germany and Spain to more competition from other reservation systems. The commission was concerned that the link-up could have distorted competition in the home markets, but has accepted assurances from the companies involved that they will not discriminate against other systems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.main_headline: 2 American Warships Denied Docking Rights by Sri Lanka
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.print_headline: WAR IN THE GULF; 2 American Warships Denied Docking Rights by Sri Lanka
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/world.body_text: **********Two American warships apparently en route to the Persian Gulf were denied berthing rights in Sri Lanka and one docked in the Indian port of Bombay, shipping officials said today. **********The Ford, a guided missile frigate, and another American warship that was not identifed arrived at Colombo's port on Jan. 20 but were turned away, the officials in Colombo said. **********The Ford later docked in Bombay, the officials said, adding that they understood that the ships were en route to the Persian Gulf war zone. **********India's Government has been criticized by Indian politicians, the press and Iraq for permitting American military transport planes to refuel in Bombay on their way to the Persian Gulf. India and Sri Lanka have remained neutral in the gulf war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/05/busin.body_text: **********Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene today scheduled oral arguments for April 18-l9 on whether the regional Bell telephone companies should be allowed to own information services. **********Under the consent decree that broke up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984, the Bell companies are prohibited from owning information services, like as on-line data bases, as well as from manufacturing equipment or entering the long-distance business. **********Judge Greene has refused to lift the restrictions, but the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ordered him to reconsider the issue of information services. **********In scheduling the arguments, the judge sought comments from supporters and opponents to address 10 questions. Because many different interest groups are on each side of the issue, Judge Greene asked them to agree among themselves on one lawyer to make each argument. If the groups did not agree on the lawyers, Judge Greene said he would have named them. **********Among other things, Judge Greene sought comments on whether he should consider evidence accumulated against A.T.& T. before the breakup, what opportunities the Bell companies have to subsidize new businesses with profits from their regulated telephone services, and whether cellular radio and other technologies could provide competition in information services. **********A final ruling is expected within several months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/world.main_headline: Ethiopian Guerrillas Mount an Offensive As Peace Talks Near
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/world.print_headline: Ethiopian Guerrillas Mount an Offensive As Peace Talks Near
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/20/world.body_text: **********Ethiopian guerrillas have overwhelmed army units in a number of strategic towns and are now threatening to seize control of all roads linking the capital with the last port the Government still controls, military officials said today. **********The weekend offensive put the Government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam in a deteriorating military situation as it prepares to meet next week with the three rebel groups in a peace conference sponsored by the United States in London. **********A Western diplomat said the guerrillas "appeared to be posturing to get into position for the talks," but noted that they now had the ability to paralyze the capital by blocking its fuel supply, which has been imported through the Red Sea port of Assab and then trucked overland. **********"This should convince the hard-liners in the party Politburo who oppose concessions and favor a military victory that a military solution to the conflict is impossible," the diplomat said of the governing Ethiopian Workers Party, which is headed by Colonel Mengistu. **********The Government currently controls most of the major cities and just over half the nation's territory. **********The Ethiopian civil war has raged on and off for more than 30 years, beginning with a separatist rebellion in northern Eritrea Province. The war now involves three loosely allied, ethnically based rebel armies pitted against the Government. **********The rebel gains are the latest in a three-month offensive in which the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, the largest guerrilla army, has driven to within 65 miles of Addis Ababa. **********Backed by mortars and artillery, the rebels moved on the provincial capital of Dese and the nearby highway towns of Kembolchza and Bati late Saturday, effectively taking control of the entire north-central province of Wollo and blocking the highway that leads to the rebel heartland in Eritrea and Tigre provinces. **********Residents in Dese described heavy street fighting between guerrillas and army troops. They also reported government aerial bombardments on the outlying lowland plains. **********"I can see from my window that people are engaged in hand-to-hand fighting," Amina Abdella, a housewife, said in a telephone interview Saturday night. "Bodies are falling one after another, though I cannot tell whether they are rebels, soldiers or civilians." **********There were no official reports on casualties.  Telephone Lines Are Cut **********After the rebels secured Dese this morning, telephone lines were cut. The Government prohibited travel to the combat zones. **********Simultaneously with the northern attacks, guerrillas attacked the town of Ambo, 65 miles west of the capital. The rebels had driven the army out of Ambo last month, only to withdraw shortly afterward under threat of a Government counterattack. The rebels claimed control of Ambo on their radio station, but fighting was still reported in the area today. **********The capture of Ambo and Dese appeared to signal the collapse of the Ethiopian Third Army, probably the best Government military unit stationed outside the capital. Should the rebels follow up their victories with an expected attack on the highway town of Mille, east of Dese, they will control all the routes north from Addis Ababa and will have severed overland links between the capital and Assab, the last Government-held port. **********Sesseha Tessema, a rebel envoy based in Washington, said in a telephone interview that the rebels launched their offensive in response to an air force bombing of the guerrilla-held village of Shiraro, about 45 miles southwest of Asmara, the Eritrean capital. Mr. Tessema said 20 people were killed and more than 100 wounded in the air raid, which he said took place on Thursday. He also said the attacks were staged because the army was mobilizing to break through rebel positions outside Addis Ababa and Dese. **********"This is not an offensive," he said. "It is a counteroffensive." He denied that the latest military activity betrayed a promise the rebels had made to American officials that they would not mount a major operation in the days preceding the conference. **********"We are still going to the peace talks," he said, adding that the rebels had no intention of blocking food or other nonmilitary supplies from entering the capital. **********But Government officials responded to the new attacks with skepticism that the rebels would attend the London conference. They noted that the rebel faction based in Eritrea, on the Red Sea coast, had already postponed the talks, which were originally scheduled for Monday, until next week. **********The Eritrean rebels seek independence for their region, but the rebel group based in neighboring Tigre province merely wants a different government in Addis Ababa, and says it is willing to enter an interim coalition. But Addis Ababa insists that it will consider a coalition only if Ethiopia remains a unified nation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.main_headline: Silicon Graphics to Offer A Cheaper Work Station
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.print_headline: Silicon Graphics to Offer A Cheaper Work Station
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/22/busin.body_text: **********The liquid-metal creature that easily changes shapes in "Terminator 2" is a creation of sophisticated computers made by Silicon Graphics Inc. that cost tens of thousands of dollars. **********On Monday, in an effort to broaden the market for such graphics beyond Hollywood's special-effects experts, Silicon Graphics will introduce a computer with similar capabilities but costing only $8,000. The new machine is another example of how once-costly technologies are rapidly becoming inexpensive enough to incorporate into personal computers. **********"Nothing in 'Terminator 2' is beyond the capability of this machine," said Carol Peters, director of advanced products for Silicon Graphics' entry systems division. **********The new machine, named Iris Indigo, also represents an effort by Silicon Graphics to break out of its graphics niche and to compete more directly with Sun Microsystems, Hewlett-Packard, Next and other companies selling general-purpose desktop computers known as work stations. **********"It's a very different position for Silicon Graphics as a company," said Michael Ramsay, vice president and general mangaer of the entry systems division. **********The new computers have special chips that allow images that look three-dimensional to be created and rotated on the screens so as to be viewed from different angles. Such computers have been used by product designers who want to see how a car might look before it is built and by scientists who want to visualize complex data like the flow of heat in a thunderstorm, as well as by special-effects artists. **********The $8,000 version of Iris Indigo includes a 16-inch color monitor but no disk drive. It will be capable of playing compact-disk-quality sound and recording voices with a microphone. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., said programs like spreadsheets and desktop publishing would be available. **********Silicon Graphics said its machine, based on an R3000 microprocessor designed by MIPS Computer Systems, can execute 30 million instructions a second and is the fastest such machine available for less than $10,000. **********But such speed records are usually eclipsed within months in the competitive work station business. Sun is expected to introduce a new work station this week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/world.main_headline: Turkish Premier Quits After Party's Defeat
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/world.print_headline: Turkish Premier Quits After Party's Defeat
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz handed his resignation to President Turgut Ozal today after their center-right Motherland Party was beaten in general elections on Sunday. **********Mr. Yilmaz told reporters that Mr. Ozal had asked him to continue as head of a caretaker Government until a new Cabinet could be formed by Suleyman Demirel, whose center-right True Path Party won a narrow electoral victory. **********Mr. Demirel, a veteran of Turkish politics, has been Prime Minister six times and has been removed from office by the military twice. **********Mr. Ozal, who was not up for re-election, has five years of his seven-year term remaining and says he will not resign. **********With more than 23 million of the nearly 30 million votes counted, Mr. Demirel's party received 27.3 percent, trailed by the governing Motherland Party with 24.0 percent and Erdal Inonu's Social Democrat Populist Party with 20.8 percent. **********Computer projections suggested the True Path Party would take 182 seats, Motherland 111 and the Social Democratic Populists 88 in the 450-member Parliament. The projections also indicated 62 seats for the Islamic Welfare Party, led by Necmettin Erbakan, and 7 seats for the Democratic Left Party, led by Bulent Ecevit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/world.main_headline: 17 Are Killed and Dozens Injured in Guatemalan Earthquake
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/world.print_headline: 17 Are Killed and Dozens Injured in Guatemalan Earthquake
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/19/world.body_text: **********Two earthquakes rocked Guatemala today, killing at least 17 people and injuring dozens when their houses collapsed on them. Landslides blocked the Pan American Highway. **********The first, measuring 5.8 on the Richter scale, shook much of the country shortly after 4 A.M. and lasted about 10 seconds. **********A second, less powerful quake, measuring 4.0 on the Richter scale, struck in the early evening. **********The United States Geological Survey in Golden, Colo., said the initial quake was centered about 25 miles southwest of Guatemala City. Local officials reported more than 12 strong aftershocks. **********Reports of severe damage and deaths came from Pochuta, about 80 miles southwest of the capital in the department of Chimaltenango. **********At least 13 people died in Pochuta and more than 60 were injured, the Guatemalan National Emergency Commission reported. **********Eddy Sanchez, a spokesman for the Guatemalan seismology institute, said many small villages around Pochuta were also badly damaged. **********In a telephone interview, Emilia de los Santos, a resident of Pochuta, said about half the homes, made of adobe, were destroyed. **********Military patrols with helicopters and planes searched the area. **********About 30 seriously injured people were evacuated by helicopter from Pochuta to the neighboring town of Patulul, which has a better hospital, Mrs. de los Santos said. **********James Dickmayer, an official of the United States Embassy, said that two United States helicopters were assisting in the rescue. **********The second quake was centered about 30 miles west of the capital in the department of Chimaltenango, Mr. Sanchez said. **********Four other deaths were reported in the village of San Lucas Toliman, in the state of Solola, about 75 miles west of Guatemala City on the shores of Lake Atitlan, the National Emergency Commission reported. A section of the Pan American Highway between Solola and Chimaltenango was blocked by landslides, the commission said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.main_headline: Patents; Structures Developed For Compact Use
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.print_headline: Patents; Structures Developed For Compact Use
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/26/busin.body_text: **********Using a new approach to folding, a former art student who turned to mechanical engineering has invented a family of structures that can collapse into compact bundles in seconds. **********The invention could make it easier to design pup tents that pop out more quickly, trunks and suitcases that fold up for easy storage and even the trusses of a space-station platform that must be packed tightly for launching into orbit. **********The structures were invented by Charles Hoberman of New York City, who said the folding methods could be applied to both soft materials like nylon or rigid materials like wood and metal, if the folding segments were linked by hinges. **********Mr. Hoberman said that the structures could be built in many three-dimensional shapes but that they all originated from a single sheet of material. The sheet is divided into several tapered regions, each of which is pleated along both horizontal and vertical lines. The pleats cause the material to fold and unfold into particular patterns, much like a road map has a tendency to fold along particular lines. A prototype for a pup tent, for example, blossoms from a compact block when two cables are pulled. **********He received patent 4,981,732.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.snippet: Legislation sometimes creates results different from its sponsors' intention. Nowhere has this been more true than in retirement savings, where legislative initiatives have undermined traditional sources of retirement income, contributing to a gro...
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.main_headline:
FORUM;
Retirement Plans That Could Fall Short
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.print_headline:
FORUM;
Retirement Plans That Could Fall Short
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/26/busin.body_text: **********Legislation sometimes creates results different from its sponsors' intention. Nowhere has this been more true than in retirement savings, where legislative initiatives have undermined traditional sources of retirement income, contributing to a growing national crisis. **********The United States Senate now wants to reinstate tax deductions for all individual retirement accounts. But the measure allows nonpenalized withdrawals for such activities as financing a college education, buying a new home or paying for nonreimbursed medical expenses. Such needs deserve support, but they undermine an I.R.A.'s value for retirement savings. **********Many Americans' main source of retirement income is Social Security, but Congress has cut the system's effectiveness. The Social Security Administration warns that it will have a negative cash flow by the year 2015, as baby boomers age. **********Traditional "defined benefit" pension plans, which obligate employers to pay specified benefits to retirees, have been burdened with expensive new compliance requirements, a cut in allowable tax-deductible contributions and benefit cutbacks for executives. In their place, the 401(k) plan has become the preferred corporate retirement plan. But 401(k) plans -- with liberal fund withdrawals, limited employee and employer contributions and conservative investments -- may not produce enough money for a comfortable retirement. **********A couple needs about 70 percent of pre-retirement income each year after retirement to maintain their standard of living. Add a modest 4 percent inflation rate and a decade after retirement they will need more than they earned when working to maintain their standard of living. **********This all means that Americans will be forced to rely more and more on their own savings for retirement. Yet only about one-third of Americans in the key retirement savings years -- 35 to 44 -- are saving for retirement. **********Our government has not adequately addressed our nation's long-term retirement policy. Congress should reject current early-withdrawal provisions and instead restore for all Americans the tax-deductible I.R.A.'s that earmark savings for long-term security. It should also adopt a hands-off policy toward the Social Security trust fund. These should be the first steps toward a badly needed national retirement policy. **********The inexorable fact about retirement planning is that there is no second chance. The Government must act to insure that the American dream of a secure retirement does not become the nation's nightmare.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/16/busin.body_text: **********Greyhound Lines Inc. said today that a bankruptcy judge had reduced by 75 percent the Government's claim against the company for back wages for 6,300 striking bus drivers. **********A lawyer for the nation's last intercity bus carrier predicted that the ruling in Federal bankruptcy court in Texas on Tuesday could result in a out-of-court settlement of Government charges against the company. Greyhound filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors last year. **********"They are reconsidering their views and are considering a settlement," said George W. Hanthorn, a lawyer at Greyhound's Dallas headquarters. "We would be most interested in receiving it." **********Government lawyers trying to prove that Greyhound illegally forced the bitter strike with its drivers 14 months ago met privately today after learning of the judge's ruling. **********The National Labor Relations Board had argued that the striking bus drivers deserved more than $120 million in back pay because the company had declared an impasse in contract negotiations that forced the union to strike. **********But Judge Richard Schmidt in Corpus Christi, Tex., reduced the claim to $31.5 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/world.main_headline: U.S. Expanding Refugee Center As More Haitians Flee Homeland
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/world.print_headline: U.S. Expanding Refugee Center As More Haitians Flee Homeland
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/03/world.body_text: **********With more than 6,300 Haitian refugees in American custody, the United States Navy is expanding its emergency center at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to accommodate as many as 10,000 new arrivals, a military official said today. **********The Navy base at Guantanamo was ordered last week to erect temporary shelters for 2,500 people after a Federal judge in Miami issued a temporary order on Nov. 19 stopping the forced repatriation of refugees to Haiti. The original plans for the tent camp's capacity have proved inadequate as more than 4,000 Haitians have been brought to Guantanamo by the Coast Guard over the last week. Guantanamo Bay is across the Windward Passage from Haiti. **********[ The Bush Administration argued for the lifting of the restraining order against forcible return in an evening hearing in Miami, The Associated Press reported. In a rare appearance before a district court the Solicitor General of the United States, Kenneth Starr, told Judge C. Clyde Atkins that Haitians stopped at sea while trying to flee to the United States have no rights under American laws. **********[ An attorney for a refugee group, Ira Kurzban, said Haitians were being denied a fair chance to seek political asylum because immigration agents interviewing them knew little about the political situation in Haiti. The judge reserved decision. ] Deterrent Factor **********The Administration has also argued that forced returns deter other Haitians from attempting a dangerous trip by boat. The Administration considers the large majority of the Haitians economic refugees and not victims of political persecution, a status that would make them eligible for political asylum. Administration officials also say there is no evidence of retribution against Haitians who are brought back. **********But critics of Administration policy say the Haitians should receive more lenient treatment because they are leaving at a time of dangerous political turmoil and mounting deprivation in their country after the Sept. 30 military overthrow of the President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. **********Since the end of October, Coast Guard cutters in the Caribbean have picked up 6,372 Haitians, nearly all of them on dangerously overcrowded boats. Over the weekend, 458 more were rescued from six sailboats, the Coast Guard said today.                    --------------------       Election May Be Postponed **********PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The interim Prime Minister said today that he would put off the election scheduled for Jan. 5 to pick a successor to the overthrown President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, if negotiations with him were resumed. **********In an interview, Prime Minister Jean-Jacques Honorat said he preferred a negotiated settlement to holding elections. **********The Organization of American States sponsored talks between Haitian legislators and Father Aristide in Cartagena, Colombia, on Nov. 23-24. The talks ended in a standoff.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.main_headline: U.S. Issues Up in Slow Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; U.S. Issues Up in Slow Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/09/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in very slow trading yesterday and short-term bill rates were at the lowest levels since 1987, as dealers began to mark time in advance of inflation reports scheduled later in the week. **********Even though the economy is mired in recession, inflation remains stubbornly high. Most market participants say it is unlikely that the Federal Reserve Board will push down short-term interest rates further until there is evidence that price pressures are easing. **********Nevertheless, anticipation that the Fed may be on the verge of easing policy was again seen in the weekly auction for short-term Treasury bills, when rates fell to their lowest levels in more than three years. **********In addition, the Fed did nothing to push up the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market yesterday. For the second straight session, Federal funds traded below the 6 percent level that is widely considered to be the central bank's target. **********After opening at just under 6 percent, the funds rate yesterday traded down to 5 1/2 percent. At the time the Fed normally conducts open market operations, funds were offered at 5 13/16 percent. **********"There has been no definitive signal from the Fed, but the fact that funds traded below 6 percent for the second straight day is piquing our interest," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. **********James Fralick, a principal and senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said the Fed might be allowing the funds rate to drift down a bit in preparation for a cut in its discount rate, which is also at 6 percent. **********"I don't think they have pulled the trigger yet, but they are friendly," he said. "I still think they will wait to see the inflation numbers before they actually move." **********Producer price and consumer price figures for March are to be released by the Government on Thursday and Friday, respectively. **********Given the spate of recent reports about policy disputes among Fed governors, some analysts and traders said that even better inflation figures would not cause the Fed to ease policy. **********"Unless they get a fabulous inflation number, I don't think they will do anything until after the next employment number," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence Morgan Grenfell. **********At the Treasury bill auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.60 percent, down sharply from the 5.80 percent average rate at last week's sale. It is the lowest rate on a new three-month bill since the auction of Nov. 30, 1987, when the rate was 5.49 percent. **********Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.68 percent, compared with an average rate of 5.79 percent at last week's auction. It is the lowest six-month bill rate since the auction of July 13, 1987, when six-month bills were auctioned at an average rate of 5.54 percent. **********In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at 96 7/8, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.15 percent, down from 8.17 percent late Friday. **********Among Treasury note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 18/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 7.96 percent. And the 7 1/8 percent two-year notes were unchanged, at a price of 100 14/32, to yield 6.88 percent. **********A number of corporations priced new debt securities in the investment-grade corporate bond market. **********Among the issuers was Pep Boys Inc., which offered $125 million worth of new five-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan Stanley. The 8 7/8 percent notes were priced at $99.782, to yield 8.93 percent, 1.30 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 3/4 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing. **********The securities are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB-minus by Standard & Poor's. **********Traders in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said prices of most issues were unchanged to up 1/8 point on thin volume. **********In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point, market participants said. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:  (000 omitted in dollar figures)               3-Mo. https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/busin.main_headline: Iacocca Urges U.S. Limits on Japanese Car Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/busin.print_headline: Iacocca Urges U.S. Limits on Japanese Car Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/16/busin.body_text: **********Lee A. Iacocca said today that the Big Three auto makers should consider promoting Federal legislation to limit the Japanese car industry to a fixed percentage of the American market. **********Speaking at the dedication of the Chrysler Corporation's $1 billion technology center outside Detroit, Mr. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said: "We've never favored a complete restriction, but we'll have to decide our collective position. We have to deal with our own self-interests. At some point, you have to decide what you stand for." **********The nation is "out of the electronics business, the VCR business, and soon we could be out of the car business," he added.  Others Not Consulted **********Mr. Iacocca said he had not discussed the idea with executives of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation or the Bush Administration. A G.M. spokesman said he was not aware of any such proposal under consideration by the company, and a Ford official did not provide an immediate response to a telephone call seeking comment. **********The Chrysler chairman's remarks seemed to be motivated by a growing sense of desperation that Japanese competition and a weak economy were mortally wounding the nation's largest manufacturing industry. **********But the 67-year-old Mr. Iacocca, who will retire at the end of next year, dismissed questions about Chrysler's viability over the coming 10 months, saying the company thought its new products, including a four-door Jeep that goes into production in early 1992, would increase cash-flow substantially. **********"We're in good shape, and have plenty of backstops," he said. "We still have a $1.75 billion revolving credit line that we've paid fees on for 10 years that we haven't touched." **********A limit of market share, like the 16 percent cap imposed last summer by the European Community through 1999, would cover all cars and trucks sold by Japanese manufacturers, including those assembled at American factories, or transplants, like the Honda Motor Company's plant in Marysville, Ohio. Japanese producers now sell about 31 percent of the cars sold in the United States. **********It was not immediately clear today how Mr. Iacocca's proposal would treat Japanese components, which are found in most domestic models, or vehicles built in joint-venture plants but sold by domestic manufacturers. General Motors's Geo Prizm car, for example, is built in Fremont, Calif., but has an engine made by the Toyota Motor Corporation. **********The European laws on market share do not cover Japanese vehicles built in North America, like the Honda station wagon now sold in several European countries. **********A ceiling on the number of vehicles that could be sold by Japanese auto makers is the most extreme proposal so far to help ailing American car makers, whose cumulative losses in the last year have totaled about $6 billion. Despite voluntary export restraints by the Japanese starting in 1981, the industry has steadily lost ground against Japanese auto makers. **********In recent years, the number of Japanese imports has fallen as the number of vehicles produced by their transplants has increased. Indeed, most Japanese producers are importing substantially fewer vehicles than are permitted under the voluntary restraint agreement. **********Democratic legislators have recently been exploring the possibility of following the European model to cap overall sales of Japanese cars. No one has offered a bill yet, but prospects for passage would be uncertain, given the Japanese industry's efforts to build an American infrastructure of plants, workers, research labs and lobbyists.  Most Damage to Chrysler **********Chrysler, as the smallest of the Big Three, has experienced the most serious financial damage. Its debt securities have been downgraded to junk-bond status, and it was recently forced to raise equity capital when its stock price was at a 10-year low. **********In recent weeks, the car maker's rhetoric against the country's trade imbalance with Japan has grown sharper. Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler president, criticized American trade policy, comparing United States consumption of Japanese-made products to the behavior of an alcoholic. **********Separately, Mr. Iacocca acknowledged that Chrysler was close to agreement with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation for the sale to Mitsubishi of Chrysler's 50 percent stake in the companies' Diamond-Star assembly plant venture in Bloomington, Ill.

https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/busin.main_headline: U.S. Will Trim Sale of Reserve Oil by Half
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/busin.print_headline: U.S. Will Trim Sale of Reserve Oil by Half
https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/31/busin.body_text: **********The Energy Department, facing a very weak market for the high-sulfur crude it had planned to sell from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, said yesterday that it would cut the total sale by nearly 50 percent. **********The department said it would sell only 3 million barrels of the high-sulfur, or "sour," crude instead of the 22.5 million barrels originally planned, because the prices bid were too low. But it said it would increase the sale of "sweet," or low-sulfur, crude to 14.35 million barrels, from 11.25 million barrels. As a result, the sale will comprise a total of 17.35 million barrels, rather than the 33.75 first planned. **********The intended sale from the 586-million-barrel reserve was first announced two weeks ago, when the air attack on Iraq began, as a way to avert panic in the oil market. But the price of oil unexpectedly plunged when traders concluded that the attack was a success and that Saudi exports were not threatened. Statement by Watkins **********In a statement yesterday, James D. Watkins, the Energy Secretary, said, "We clearly must remain sensitive to the market by making available the crude oil the industry is saying it really needs, and not allowing bargain hunters to take advantage of the taxpayers." **********He added that the department would also fulfill the commitment it made to the International Energy Agency, the Paris-based organization of 21 oil-importing nations, whose members had collectively agreed to release 2.5 million barrels a day. Half of that was to come from American reserves, although the department had said it would be flexible. **********The largest contract, for 7.52 million barrels, was awarded to Phibro Energy Inc., a trading company and refiner based in Greenwich, Conn. Bids were submitted by 26 companies, 13 of which won contracts. **********The 17.35 million barrels were auctioned at prices ranging from $25.67 to $28.52 a barrel.  Oil Drops 88 Cents **********The news of the amended sale plan, which was first disclosed in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, did not upset the oil market yesterday, with oil for delivery in March closing on the New York Mercantile Exchange at $20.97 a barrel, down 88 cents. **********That oil, however, is sweet crude. The announcement did push up the price of sour crude relative to sweet, according to industry experts. Sour crude is traded among refiners, producers and trading houses, generally at bids expressed in relation to sweet crude rather than at an absolute price. And the announcement prompted the discount for sour crude to shrink, with the price difference per barrel dropping to $3.30 late yesterday from about $3.70 on Tuesday. The reason was that supplies of sour crude will now be smaller than the market had anticipated. **********Market participants said the price of sour crude actually started to close in on the price of sweet crude in trading late Tuesday afternoon. Several participants said they were angry with the Energy Department because it appeared to them that the information had leaked out and that some companies had been able to take advantage of it.  Department Denies Leak **********The department denied there had been a leak. And at least one trader, while saying he had suspicions of such an advantage, said it was possible that an astute trader could have made the same trades based on conclusions drawn from publicly available information. **********Philip K. Verleger Jr., a commodities economist and visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, who follows the oil market closely, said the price move started Tuesday afternoon when Phibro, the company that received the largest contract, "started buying up a lot of sour crude." He said the trading suggested that Phibro had "advance notice" of the change in the oil auction, and that what he believed was an information leak "tarnished what is otherwise the greatest success in energy management in 18 years." **********There is no law against insider trading in commodities, as there is in stocks. **********A Washington lawyer who specializes in energy matters, Peter H. Rodgers, said that trading companies he works with had complained to him yesterday morning, after the change in the auction was made public, that Phibro's purchases, beginning at about 4:30 P.M. on Tuesday, appeared to them to indicate the company had early knowledge.  A 2 P.M. Decision **********Robert F. Baker, a spokesman for Phibro's parent company, Salomon Brothers, would not confirm trading by Phibro, but said any suggestion Phibro had advance information was "utter nonsense." **********At the Energy Department, M. J. Jameson, the chief spokeswoman, said that the decision was made at about 2 P.M. on Tuesday, in consultation with the White House, and that the first time the information was divulged outside the Government was to a Wall Street Journal reporter at 6:30 P.M. **********But a trader at one international oil trading company, who spoke on condition that neither he nor his company be identified, also said Phibro started buying at about 4:30, and he felt there may have been a Government leak. "I trade off information all the time," he said. But, he added that his information usually came from private sources, "and this is a Government body." **********One energy trader at a different international company also said there may have been a leak, although he added that a perceptive reading of publicly available information, including Energy Department data showing that sweet crude was in much higher demand than sour, might have led an astute trader to expect the Government to cut back on its sale of sour crude and to anticipate a rise in its price.
